____________ Burra Meat Stores

90, 1, 12 January 1960, page 1 [Page numbering after 4 is incoherent.]

Weather

Many places in SA recorded a dry year for 1959, but in Burra the recording was 9.3 inches, well above the record low of 7.17 inches in 1914.

Burra School Headmaster Mr M.W. Scriven is seeking board for students in 1960. So far he has enquiries for several first year boys, but others may come in.

Craig Evans of St Dye St Burra North was the district winner in the 13-18 month section of the H.J. Heinz Co. National Baby Contest. District winners got a £5 prize.

Burra Rural Youth

27 members attended the Zone Christmas Social at Jamestown on 14 December. Three attended the Clare Social on 22 December. 28 members visited Burra and Heathmont Hospitals with boxed biscuits for patients and to sing Christmas carols. Supper was provided at Heathmont by Matron and Mr Barnes. Proceeds of their Christmas dance will buy a Nativity Scene for Market Square.

Burra Rifle Club entertained the Yunta Rifle Club members at their first shoot for 1960. Due to Yunta’s limited representation it was decided to have a four man team. Burra won 370 to 318.

The top scorer was Gordon Webster with 93 off the gun.

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club begins competitive shooting for 1960 tonight. In the last practice match the best scorers were J. Brown, W. Barker & M. Mitchell.

Christmas Eve in Burra

Christmas music etc. was relayed around the street through four speakers. Father Christmas arrived at about 9.10 p.m. and distributed ice creams, bags of sweets and trumpets. Business houses reported successful Christmas trading generally.

Burra Rural Youth Christmas Eve Dance netted £20-3-0.

Accident. Fred Atkins broke a bone in his shoulder last week when he fell while working in the ceiling of the Kooringa Methodist Sunday School. He was knocking out the old plaster ceiling in preparation for a new one and fell 20 feet to the floor. He also sustained a slight concussion, abrasions and bruising.

Hanson Road. In the paper of 13 January 1945 it was suggested that there be a new Burra-Hanson Road to meet the Kapunda Road two miles south of Black Springs. It was suggested that it run along the eastern side of the railway line instead of going past G. Finch’s residence. On reaching Hanson it would continue past the water tanks on the Whyalla Pipeline and then along the western side of Porter Lagoon to meet the Kapunda Road. Now fifteen years later the Burra-Hanson section is nearing completion.

Burra Hospital. Four volunteers planted a couch lawn in front of the hospital last Saturday afternoon. A sprinkler system had been previously installed to water it. The workers were E.T. Baulderstone, C.H. Cummins, M. Breen and Dr L.G. Miller.

The Booborowie CWA Christmas Party is reported in 3⁄4 column.

Burra High School staff changes:

Mr J.C. Morrison goes to Wudinna Area School as headmaster.

Mr G. Ireland is leaving.

Mr K.G. Hicks comes from Findon High School.

Miss A.T. Dadleff comes from Adelaide Teachers College

Miss F.A. Schwartz comes one day a week from Gawler Adult Education Centre.

90, 1, 12 January 1960, page 2

Advt. Royal Exchange Hotel is under new management: M.C. & M.M. McDonald, late of Reilly’s Hotel, Penola.

Advt. Rev. R. Jenner will be inducted into the Burra Methodist Circuit on Wednesday 20 January. Rev. Wilms, Chairman of the District will officiate.

Advt. Mrs R.W. Fullgrabe proposes to open ballet classes in Burra soon.

Advt. Gigantic Australia Day Picnic at Porter Lagoon 1 February 1960. Speed Boats & Skiing.

J.W. Riggs Hon. Sec. Lake Carnival Committee.

Advt. Official Opening of the Burra Swimming Pool Saturday 30 January by G. Stanley Hawker at 3 p.m.

Grand Swimming Carnival.

90, 1, 12 January 1960, page 3

Advt. Booborowie Pictures

Advt. Burra Pictures, Wednesday 13 January

Terry Thomas in Carlton Browne of the F.O.

Arthur Kennedy in Home is the Hero

Saturday 16 January

John Wayne & Sophia Loren in Legend of the Lost

Louis Armstrong in Satchmo the Great

Wednesday 20 January

Alan Ladd & Rossana Podesta in The Gun Runner

Guy Madison & Joan Weldon in The Command

Mt Bryan School Christmas Tree was well attended by parents, relatives and friends. The students provided a concert, including solo performances and carols from the school choir. Prizes were distributed by E. Willis, Chairman of the School Committee.

Mr Schiller gave an address, as did Mr R. Dewhirst.

[Prize winners are listed.]

Father Christmas followed and then supper and to conclude Ashley Woodgate’s Band played for dancing.

90, 1, 12 January 1960, page 4

Bowls

Clare Red 137 defeated Burra Gold 56

Burra Green 90 defeated Auburn 87

Hallett White 91 defeated Burra Blue 83

90, 1, 12 January 1960, page 5

Burra High School Annual Banquet was organised as usual by the Parents & Friends’ Association and was held at the Burra Town Hall on Wednesday afternoon. Approximately 100 students and 60 guests attended including the Mayor & Mayoress Mr & Mrs E.T. Baulderstone, Chairman of the DC Mr A.D. Radford & Mrs Radford and the Chairman of the High School Council Mr H.J.B. Jennison & Mrs Jennison.

Burra High School break-up assembly was held on 17 December. Mr Morrison was presented with a picnic hamper case and Mr Ireland was given a cigarette case and lighter.

90, 1, 12 January 1960, page 7

Adult Classes in Woodwork and Dressmaking will be conducted at the High School from Tuesday 9 February by Mr H. Hicks and Miss F.A. Schwarz respectively. If numbers warrant there may also be an afternoon class for Dressmaking.

90, 1, 12 January 1960, page 8 [This page only wrongly dated 9 January.]

Cricket

Koonoona 1 for 167 v. Farrell Flat

Buffs 30 in their 1st innings v. Burra 77

Burra Town Council, 21 December 1959

The Mayor reported that Burra High School members had painted Johnny Green bright colours with the permission of the landowner.

Council will pay £1 towards the water rates of the Aberdeen Croquet Club. (The Council owns the land.)

Council is to procure an Australian Flag to fly on Australia Day.

The warning bell at the Bon Accord crossing is unsatisfactory. The Railways are to be asked to fit a reliable warning device.

The Council confirmed the Mayor’s action in allowing the Town Clerk to build an additional room at the residence.

90, 2, 19 January 1960, page 1

The Burra & District Swimming Pool will be officially opened on 30 January by Mr G. Stanley Hawker at 3 p.m. Although the pool has been in use for twelve months the committee had many jobs to do to complete the surrounds and this has delayed the official opening. A Grand Swimming Carnival will mark the event.

Burra Rifle Club. In the last match the best off the rifle were H.H. Byles, W. Barker and W. Hempel, while with handicap the best were R. Oakley, W. Barker and J. Brown.

Mrs J. Voumard of Largs, a former resident more than 20 years ago, visited Burra and lists the improvements she noticed:

The wonderful swimming pool

The almost completed post office

Improvements to a number of shops

Improvements at the bowling green

More bituminised streets

Improvements to the oval, lawn tennis courts and the new rifle range

The Town Hall supper room and kitchen

More trees and some lovely gardens

BUT she also noted the ‘dirty, untidy, and “hard to walk on” footpaths and weed infested watertables’ which spoil the solid impression.

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club. The leading scorers in the 1st stage of the trophy shoot were Mrs W. Barker, R. Robinson & J. Taylor.

Cricket

Booborowie 9 for 283 declared defeated Hallett 133

Spalding 200 defeated Leighton 167

Mt Bryan 264 defeated North Booborowie 152.

The CWA has made a donation of £150 to the Burra Hospital.

Arrivals in Burra

Mr Fullgrabe the new Town Clerk with his wife and five children.

Mrs Fullgrabe will teach ballet if numbers warrant it.

Rev. R.S. Jenner, Mrs Jenner and six children will arrive about 20 January.

New Teachers at Burra High School: Mr Hicks (Woodwork) and Miss Dadlleff from Adelaide Teachers College.

Mr A.L. Wright is the new manager at Elders and he, his wife and three children have arrived from Pinnaroo.

Departures from Burra

Rev. D.G. Haydon & Mrs Haydon with children Barry & Janet left for Broken Hill early this month after a stay of 43⁄4 years. Rev. Haydon has been particularly active in youth work and during his term the Redruth and Kooringa circuits were amalgamated to form the Burra Circuit. He was President of the Burra Cricket Association for two years and led the Kooringa tennis team to victory last season. Mrs Haydon was President of the Redruth Methodist Ladies’ Guild and a member of the Church’s House Committee.

The Morrisons are leaving Burra after Colin Morrison had been teaching in the Burra District for 20 years and at BHS for the last three. Mr J. Colin Morrison has been appointed headmaster at Wudinna Area School. His BA degree was formally conferred at a ceremony in Adelaide last December. He is presently the Secretary of the Burra RSL and was a fighter pilot and instructor in WWII, being awarded the AFC. He played cricket and tennis in Burra. Mrs Morrison was formerly Miss McWaters of Burra and has played tennis and badminton here. She was a member of the Kooringa Methodist Guild. They and there children Heather, Dean and Jane will leave soon for Wudinna.

Mr Grenville Ireland has been Woodwork teacher at Burra for three years, but has now resigned to take on business life in Adelaide. He was a member of the Lawn Tennis Club and a keen shooter. Mr & Mrs Ireland have moved to East Glenelg.

Mr & Mrs F.H. Binks-Williams with children Judy and John moved last week to Seacombe Heights. Mr Binks-Williams was manager of Elder, Smith & Co. at Burra for the last ten years, but has now been moved to the Adelaide Office.

Weather. Thunderstorms in the past week have filled many dams to the east. Some graziers had been carting water for months. The past week has seen temperatures well over the century with no relief at night, but a cool change arrived on Saturday night and rain began to fall at about 9 a.m. Sunday. Burra scored 41 points to make 57 for the month. Some places to the east recorded up to 50 points on Sunday and with earlier thunderstorms some have totalled 150 points for the week.

90, 2, 19 January 1960, page 2

Notice. Burra Burra DC calls a meeting of ratepayers at Burra Town Hall Supper Room for 21 January to consider fire-fighting trucks and equipment.

They will live at Mt Bryan East. [Details in c. 1⁄3 column.]

Burra Burra DC, 4 January

Tenders are called for the installation of a fire siren at the Council Chambers in Burra.

Contribution to Burra Hospital for 1960 will be £1,380 and to Clare Hospital £30.

90, 3, 26 January 1960, page 1

The Education Department’s Learn to Swim Campaign

204 swimming certificates were gained, ranging from Beginners to Seniors. 112 children gained these between them. [Those who gained certificates are listed.]

Burra Rifle Club. At the last shoot best off the rifle were H.H. Byles, R. Francis and G. Webster. With handicap the best were R. Francis, K. Phillips & R. Kellock.

Q. Feletti of NSW writes to express his shock at seeing trees were being cut down in Kangaroo Street and at Burra North. Given recent heat surely the opposite should be happening.

Tennis

A Grade Aberdeen 12 defeated Hallett Country 8

B Grade Aberdeen 15 defeated Ironmine 5

Burra Town Council, 10 January

Mr Tiver advised to remove old buildings from a block following a request by Mrs E.R. Kotz.

Burra Hospital contribution for 1960 has been set at £410.

Moved Crs Cummins & Lehmann that the name E.R. Davey be removed from the honour roll of Town Clerks. Carried.

[The honour board of Mayors and Town Clerks was still in the Town Hall in 2014 and Mr Davey’s name was still there. The name of J. Fogg who was appointed Town Clerk in January 1879 and was compelled to resign in April 1879 is however, missing. From the reports in the paper he seems to have been extremely neglectful of his work and also to have misappropriated a cheque for £12. A later report says all but £2 had been recovered. He was not pursued in the courts because, the paper says, he was not worth 12/-. He promised to repay the losses when able.

See also comment at 90, 14, 19 April 1960, page 1.]

18 January

A recommendation was accepted that £500 be spent on seating for the back portion of the Town Hall.

90, 4, 2 February 1960, page 1

Rev. R.S. Jenner was inducted as Methodist Minister for the Burra Circuit on 20 January. He comes from Minlaton to replace Rev. D.G. Haydon who has gone to Broken Hill. Rev. Wilmes [Wilms previously] officiated and Rev. Hayward of Crystal Brook gave the address.

The Morrison Family was given a farewell after the service at Kooringa Methodist Church on Sunday night. Many people spoke for organisations in the town and a presentation was made.

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club

Best results with handicap from the last shoot were obtained by R. Angel, J. Brown & J. Taylor.

probably 7: 2 credits)

Adelaide Wool Sales, 26-28 January

S.J. Woollacott topped local district sales with 751⁄4d. [Other local district prices are printed.]

90, 4, 2 February 1960, pages 1 & 6

Burra Swimming Pool Opened A large crowd attended in perfect weather to see Mr G. Stanley Hawker open the Burra Swimming pool free of debt. At about 3 p.m. the President of the Committee welcomed all present and thanked all those who had donated cash, materials and labour and announced that the pool could be opened free of debt, due to the recent arrival of a Government subsidy cheque. There were still things they needed – a filtration plant could be added later. Mr Topsfield was glad to see the presence of Mr & Mrs R.G. Jeffery (now of Clare), who had been holidaying at Port Broughton. Mr Jeffery had done a wonderful job as Secretary etc. towards Burra obtaining such a fine asset. Mr & Mrs Shaw were present too. Mr Shaw had been the architect for the pool. Mr Hawker was then asked to open the pool. Mr Roy Jeffery moved a vote of thanks to Mr Hawker, whom he said had always been ready to assist as MP for the district.

[The editor said that when Mr H. Quirke took over as MP for the district he too had given what assistance he could.]

Mayor Baulderstone also spoke of the wonderful way the pool transformed this section of the creek bank and beautified the whole area. He listed some who had given much assistance like H.C. Cummins and Keith Spackman.

Mrs Hawker presented the Learn to Swim Campaign Certificates.

The official party had afternoon tea in the Town Hall. The committee presented Mr Shaw with a silver tray for his services.

[The results of the carnival that followed are then printed.]

90, 4, 2 February 1960, page 2

Advt. Burra Pictures, 6 February

Cary Grant, Frank Sinatra & Sophia Loren in The Pride and the Passion

Man in the Shadow

90, 4, 2 February 1960, page 3

Ashley Sutton, Son of Mr & Mrs R. Sutton of Booborowie, has topped the state in the Junior Postal Officers Exam.

Cricket. Mokota Association

Mt Bryan 172 defeated Spalding 118

Hallett 274 defeated North Booborowie 143.

90, 4, 2 February 1960, page 6

Mr Neville Wright (21) of Adelaide was found on Sunday afternoon by searchers on Pine Valley Station after being lost for more than 24 hours. Wright and two companions were camping on a dam c 15 miles southeast of Canegrass Homestead. On Saturday he became separated from the others when he chased a wild goat. He was tracked for ten miles by Messrs A.D. Radford and Bill and Gill Moxham. Constable Clift of Burra Police went out, but Wright had been found by his arrival.

90, 4, 2 February 1960, page 7

Cricket. Burra association

Buffs 171 defeated Farrell Flat 71 & 95

Koonoona 86 & 3 for 208 defeated Burra 33 & 71

Tennis

B Grade Ironmine 10-91 defeated Aberdeen 10-80

90, 4, 2 February 1960, page 8

Summary of Notable Events in Burra 1959

Burra & District Swimming Pool in use.

Vice-Regal visit.

Formation of Burra Redlegs football team.

Small Bore Rifle Club established.

Centenary of the Foresters’ Lodge – State Annual Meeting held in Burra.

Mid North Local Government Meeting held in Burra.

Opening of a private hospital for the aged. [Heathmont]

TV sets installed in Burra.

$15,000 canvas for St Mary’s Church of England.

Death of the great townsman and nonagenarian Mrs E.P. Sara.

[Emma Price Sara nee Tiver d. 31 August aged 94.]

ETSA Electricity for Hilltown and Mt Bryan.

The Billiard Room was demolished.

The new post office was under construction.

New Roadhouse.

New dressing sheds at the War Memorial Oval.

90, 5, 9 February 1960, page 1

The Burra Races will have £183 worth of trophies and £480 in stake money for its seven-race meeting on 23 March.

Burra Rifle Club

In the match against Eudunda on Saturday the shooting was difficult due to strong winds.

In the marksman’s competition Burra 566 defeated Eudunda 560, but Eudunda won the handicap section.

Methodist Youth Fellowship Annual Meeting was held on 2 February. Rev. R. Jenner chaired the meeting.

Elected: President, Terry Welsh; Vice-President, Kath Webster; Secretary, Valmai Williams & Assistant Secretary, Trevor Forby. They will meet alternate Monday nights.

The Country Tennis Carnival held recently in Adelaide was won by Mr Don Lloyd of Ironmine, who came away with the H.G. Hastings Trophy for outstanding sportsmanship and ability. Other members of the Burra Association Team were D. Bruce, G. Sladden and F. Sullivan.

Tennis

A Grade Aberdeen 17 defeated Booborowie 3

B Grade Booborowie 13-93 defeated Aberdeen 7-82

Mr & Mrs Lewis Gare have retired to ‘Three Trees’ near Burra, the old home of Mr & Mrs John Thomas, who were Mr Gare’s great grandparents and who came to Burra in 1849 from Cornwall to work in the Burra Mines.

Mr & Mrs Levi Hughes who married in December are living in Mr & Mrs Jones’ home. They went to live at Canowie some time ago. [Presumably the ‘they’ refers to Mr & Mrs Jones, since the marriage report for Mr & Mrs Hughes says they intended to live at Mt Bryan East.]

Burra Rural Youth had a demonstration of resuscitation at Burra Swimming Pool by four members of the Saddleworth-Manoora branch of St John’s Ambulance at their first meeting for 1960.

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club. Best shots last week were R. Angel, G. Webster & W. Barker.

Cricket. Mokota Association

Spalding 126 v. South Booborowie 2 for 50

Mt Bryan 8 for 192 v. Hallett

Leighton 133 v. North Booborowie 1 for 57

Porter Lagoon Picnic Day saw about 100 cars there in the afternoon. It was windy and the rough conditions meant that the boat races had to be abandoned. The only boats on the water were those of Lance Fiebig and the Dunn Bros. of Black Springs. Some water skiing events were also abandoned, but R. Taylor and P. Williams staged a contest and Gerald Day, impersonating a ballroom dancer, successfully went over the ski jump.

A Dart Competition was won by Miss J. Fiebig from Mrs P. Calda 98 to 91.

Mr K. Calda won the shot putt.

The children kept the boat-owners busy after they offered free rides around the lake.

Photo of Signalman E.G. Bagg of Paradise Street, apparently on military manoeuvres near Victor Harbor. He is attending the University of Adelaide doing a BA and is already a primary school teacher.

90, 5, 9 February 1960, page 2

Advt. Burra Pictures, Saturday 13 February

Sweet Smell of Success

Night in Havana

Wednesday 17 February

James Garner & Etchika Charlau in Darby’s Rangers

Plus The Amazon

Advt. Tenders are called for renovations to the premises of Burra Dry Cleaners.

Birth. To Brian & Kath Hall (nee Pens) at Burra Hospital, a son, Stephen Thomas.

90, 5, 9 February 1960, page 4

Ron Dewhirst writes with some comments and suggestions about local football:

Years ago we had the formation of Junior Football and over recent years it seems that an ‘in between’ grade is required, but owing to lack of numbers this won’t work. It could be overcome by having a ‘B’ Grade, which would have no age limits, which appears to be the stumbling block for the present Colts (changed from Juniors).

From the spectator point of view the present six A Grade teams can hardly be considered a great success. My suggestion is four A Grade and 4 B Grade teams. Burra, Hallett, Spalding and Booborowie could field A Grade teams. It seems that Leighton can only function with the assistance of players from other areas and has never had the numbers for a Junior team.

The season would comprise five rounds and two Association matches.

Booborowie would call its B Grade team Leighton – the surplus from Booborowie.

Hallett would call its B Grade team Mt Bryan with the surplus from Hallett’s Redlegs.

Burra would call its B Grade team Redlegs with the surplus from Burra A.

Leighton Oval could be shared with Booborowie Oval.

[He continues of in some detail of where games would be played, the timing of both grades’ matches and some rules about the exclusion of A Grade players from B Grade for finals etc.]

90, 5, 9 February 1960, page 5

Burra Town Council, 2 February

The Town Clerk reported on progress with the books of the Corporation.

Treasury wrote from Adelaide about the Local Public Works Scheme and payments made to Council under that scheme.

The scheme had its origins in the 1930s when, in order to relieve unemployment, the Commonwealth and State Governments invited local Government to submit proposals for work to be financed from loans and undertook to pay to those local authorities two-thirds of such amounts as were required to amortise such loans over a ten year period.

Burra Council submitted a proposal to improve Victoria Park at a cost of £400, but due to the outbreak of war no start was made.

After the war the matter was revived in 1946 and after some consideration about changing the proposal to the swimming pool, Treasury was advised by a letter dated 24 July 1946 from the Town Clerk that the Corporation would continue with the original proposal to beautify Victoria Park. The Commonwealth Government’s approval was obtained and Council was advised that it could proceed, by a letter dated 16 October 1947.

In July 1948 the Council sought to amend the proposals to cover a project costing £1,200 – still in relation to the Recreation Ground [Victoria Park]. It was advised that it could do so if it wished, but the two other Governments’ contributions would remain as much as would amortise £400 of the amount borrowed.

In November 1950 a letter from Council advised that work had been completed, along with an accompanying financial statement signed by the then Mayor, the President of the Burra & District War Memorial Committee and the Town Clerk. Receipts totalling £800 were forwarded for the contractor F.L. Hogan of Booborowie.

As a consequence half-yearly payments of £15-16-5, being 2⁄3 of the amount needed to amortise a loan of £400 at 33⁄8% p.a. commenced on 17 May 1951 and have continued to be paid each half year since. (Schedule enclosed.)

An agreement was received from the Fire brigade Board for signature concerning the tenancy and tenders for additions and alterations to the Fire Station.

The SA Government Tourist Bureau forwarded £385 for the swimming pool.

90, 5, 9 February 1960, page 6

Marriage. Hallett Methodist Church, 23 January

Yvonne Ann Jones, only daughter of Mr & Mrs W.T Jones of Hallett, married

Bernard Ross Smith, elder son of Mr & Mrs F.K. Smith of Minlaton.

They will live at the school house at North Booborowie. [Details in 1⁄2 column.]

90, 5, 9 February 1960, page 10

Bowls

Mid North Association

Burra Gold 91 defeated Auburn 86

Burra Green 95 defeated Clare Red 90

North Eastern Association

Hallett White 102 defeated Burra 91

90, 6, 16 February 1960, page 1

The New School Year

St Joseph’s Convent School has an enrolment of 36; down one on 1959. [New pupils are listed.]

Burra Primary School starts the year with 228 compared with 256 in 1958 [and 249 in 1959 according to another paragraph]. [New enrolments are listed.]

The staff is the same as last year:

Miss Coventry Grade I 33

Mrs Pens Grade II 25

Mrs Perry Grade III 30

Mrs Jeffery Grade IV 39

Mrs Sladden Grade V 36

Mr Kowald Grade VI 35

Mr Kies Grade VII 30

Burra High School has a record 122 this year; up from 116 in 1959.

First Year 49

Second Year 40

Intermediate 25

Leaving 8

Prefects and House captains were elected on Thursday and Friday.

The Head Boy Prefect is Don Topsfield

The Head Girl Prefect is Trenna Eberhard

[Other prefects and House Officers are listed.]

This year two new houses, Jennison and Riggs have been added to Draysey and Steele.

In the 1959 PEB Examinations three students gained Leaving Certificates with 89% subject passes.

Twenty-two students gained Intermediate Certificates with a 77% subject pass rate and there were nine credits.

The Bank of Australasia merged with the Union Bank in 1951 to form the Australia & New & New Zealand Bank Ltd. The Bank of Australasia opened in Burra on 14 February 1860. To mark the centenary 25 guests were entertained at the Burra Hotel on Friday 12 February. The State Manager and his wife, Mr & Mrs E.K. Spence, attended.

Adult Education Classes in Woodwork and Dressmaking are underway – there were insufficient enrolments for a day class in Dressmaking.

Tennis

A Grade Aberdeen 12 defeated Ironmine 8

B Grade Spalding 16 defeated Aberdeen 4

Cricket. Mokota Association

South Booborowie 12 defeated Spalding 126

North Booborowie 4 for 221 (including B. Smith 100 retired) defeated Leighton 143

Mt Bryan 218 drew with Hallett 6 for 114.

Weather

Good rain with up to 180 points fell over the inside country, but to the east falls were patchy.

Farrell Flat recorded 180 points, Booborowie 131, Hallett 19, Morgan 145 and Burra 99.

To the east the Burra to Morgan area reported about 100 points (1 inch), Redcliffe 78, Kia-Ora 47, Balah 40, Woolgangi 30, Thistlebeds 29, Faraway Hill 20 and Pine Valley 15.

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club. Best scorers with handicap for the last meeting were A. Day, W. Hempel & J. Brown.

Mt Bryan CWA held its International Day meeting. Mrs Gryst of Burra spoke entertainingly of a tour through France.

90, 6, 16 February 1960, page 10

Bowls

90, 7, 23 February 1960, page 1

Football. North Eastern Association AGMs

Burra & Rovers. Mr E. Orchard resigned as Secretary after three years. Elected: Patron, Reg. Warnes; President, W. Brown and Secretary-Treasurer, Trevor Forby.

[Reports are printed of AGMs for Hallett, Booborowie and Leighton Football Clubs.]

Burra Showgrounds – New Wool Pavilion

The Wool Pavilion Committee has commenced work on erecting the new pavilion. The building will be 30 feet x 30 feet with a roof light facing south to provide even lighting. Mr R. Fuss and helpers have cemented the bases for the columns of the building. The frame has been ordered and is due at the end of this week. Further donations are solicited.

Town Hall Chairs

When Wednesday night films came into operations it was decided to take the profits from them to buy folding chairs for the hall. It has taken quite a while to accumulate the funds. After various Councillors investigated possible chairs, which have to be comfortable, light and stackable, a type was selected. It has been found that Matthew’s Emporium in Burra can supply them for £6-5-0 less 4%, delivered, while the best city price the Town Clerk could arrange was £6-12-6 less 21⁄2% plus delivery charges. As a result the Council voted to buy 104 ‘Royal’ chairs from Matthew’s Emporium. They will complete the rows at the back of the hall.

Cricket. Mokota Association

Hallett 29 v. Spalding 5 for 117

Leighton 77 v. Mt Bryan 3 for 76

South Booborowie 188 v. North Booborowie

Accident. A car taking M & Mrs Bruce L. Bayes from Henley Beach to Broken Hill for holidays overturned about four miles north of Burra on the Mt Bryan Road at about 7.30 p.m. on 19 February. Both were taken to Burra Hospital.

Kevin Cousins was chosen as Norwood’s best half forward for 1959.

Mr John Lovegrove has been farewelled before leaving Burra to reside in the city. There was a dinner at the Commercial Hotel. The ladies had arranged a similar function for Mrs Lovegrove at the Kooringa Hotel, but she was unfortunately unable to attend.

Mr F. Sims, manager of the National Bank in Burra for 31⁄2 years, is being transferred to Auburn. As Treasurer of the Burra Bowling Club he will be missed and Mrs Sims is Past President of Burra Bowls Associates. Mr J. Dalwood comes from Renmark as the new manager.

Mr Don Stubing has been at Elder’s Burra Branch for almost four years and has now been appointed to Elder’s Adelaide Stock Depot. He is replaced by Mr Jim McRae from the Cummins Branch.

Miss Valerie Terry is leaving next Monday to work in Adelaide. She has been prominent in the Kooringa Methodist Church and has worked for Messrs M.W. & D.M. Bednall for six years.

John Bray of Penola replaced Mr Roger Jenkins in Goldsbrough Mort’s and Roger went to Hawker. Now Roger has been returned to Burra to replace Mr Stan Freeman, who has resigned from the company.

Kevin Ayliffe, formerly of Goldsbrough’s in Burra, has mow been moved to Mt Pleasant.

Sergeant Walker was transferred to Adelaide on 5 February, leaving Constable Martin Slift in charge at Burra, but now he has been moved to Brinkworth.

Sergeant F.G. McGrath will come from Karoonda early in March and Constable A.B. Conrot will come from Whyalla later. Constable C.C. Allen has been moved from Hallett to Gumeracha.

90, 7, 23 February 1960, page 2

Advt. Burra Pictures, next Saturday

Stampeded

Goodbye My Lady

2 March

Let’s Be Happy

My Wife’s Family

90, 7, 23 February 1960, pages 3, 4, 5 & 6

Souvenir Supplement to the ‘Burra Record’

Official opening of the Burra & District Swimming Pool

30 January 1960 at 3 p.m. by Mr G. Stanley Hawker. [Photos of the pool, Mr Hawker & Mr Roy G. Jeffery.]

The cost of the pool was met by numerous donations of cash, Government subsidy, donated materials and much voluntary labour. Despite competing with other appeals that raised something like £5,000 during the same period – the Town Hall Supper Room, The Murray Flood Appeal and the War Memorial Oval.

In 1956 it was drawn to the attention of the Burra Progress Association that only 14% of Burra children could swim. They decided it was time to make that 100%. Several previous attempts had failed to raise the money for a pool, but they were undeterred.

Approximately 170 people attended a public meeting on 2 March 1956 in Burra Town Hall. The Mayor Mr E.T. Baulderstone listed the pros and cons and said any committee elected to carry out the project would need to convince Council that it would not become a liability.

Mr H.J. Topsfield outlined the proposed scheme. Members of the Progress Association had concluded it was too big a project for them and needed district support. Mr C.A. Brooks as Acting Supervisor of Physical Education spoke strongly in favour and so did Messrs H.C. Cummins, I. Trigwell, R.G. Jeffery and H.J.B. Jennison.

A motion to proceed was passed unanimously and a committee was formed. It met first on 3 March 1956. H.J. Topsfield was Chairman and Mr B.E. Gryst of the Savings Bank in Burra was elected Treasurer with R.G. Jeffery, Headmaster of Burra High School as Secretary. Mr D. Bednall [solicitor] undertook to draft a constitution and rules. Discussion and public consultation moved on to site selection. Visits were made to Mt Barker & Nuriootpa pools. Both those pools were self-supporting.

On 22 March 1956 it was decided that the pool would be 100 feet x 30 feet with a depth ranging from 3 feet to 9 feet. On 17 April 1956 a subscription list was opened to try to raise £1,000.

A deputation waited on the Council to see whether the Council would apply for a £1,500 Government subsidy and if they would appropriate a site for the pool. By 15 May 1956 £246-13-6 had been raised and the Government advised that it would grant a subsidy of £1,500. By 9 June 1956 £400 had been raised. The army advised that the Drill Hall site would not become available and the present site was then selected.

By early August the fund stood close to £500.

The River Murray floods that year then occurred and this no doubt slowed subscriptions. Excavation work began on 14 August 1956, but before it could be completed the equipment was needed for emergency work along the flooded river.

By 28 August the fund had reached £572, but meanwhile the Flood Appeal had reached £1,089.

The architect Keith Shaw talked with the Committee and the builders Messrs C. Parker, Bill Robinson, Len Taylor and Bert Cornelius.

By the end of 1956 £800 had been raised for the pool.

In the first three months of 1957 considerable preparatory ground work was done. The annual meeting in March 1957 saw the fund at £817 and the principal officers were re-elected.

[Photos:

The old Mine Pool.

The site before work started.

Excavation work.

Further preliminary work – boarding up for the concrete.

Mixing concrete: P. Murphy, D. O’Brien & W. Corner.

Wheelbarrowing concrete [M.T. Kellock, L.A. Beinke, J.B. Topsfield & G. Kellock.]

On 2 June 1957 sixty-five men at a working bee gave 312 man-hours of work worth £120. The first section of the floor was laid. The second section followed a fortnight later, having been delayed by rain. The final section was laid on 7 July.

In August 1957 the fund reached £1,007. A further application for a Government grant of £1,500 was made. The walls were poured by the end of November and the setting up of the concrete surrounds began. In February 1958 the walls and floor were sealed. The pool was slowly filled beginning on 7 February 1958. The pool was next fenced. Rural Youth contributed 146 hours of labour in June 1958. A toddlers’ pool was planned. Retaining wall and work on planting the slopes etc. followed. In November 1958 £500 was urgently needed for dressing sheds, kiosk etc. which were estimated to cost £900 to £1,000. This meant £500 had to be raised to qualify for a £500 subsidy. Quite quickly a variety of means raised about £270 and foundations were poured and bricks obtained.

[The wading pool was completed on 10 August 1959] On 7 December a working bee painted the wading pool and donations reached over £500. At the end of the school year in 1958 Mr R.G. Jeffery was transferred to Cleve.

[Although there were no changing rooms at this time] the pool was available for the Education Department’s Learn to Swim Campaign from 5 to 16 January 1959. 154 children enrolled and 100 gained certificates. The instructors were Messrs Tom Bowden & Grenville Ireland. Check the timeline in 1958-59. In this report it gets rather jumbled. THIS CAN ONLY BE DONE WHEN 1959 HAS BEEN NOTED.

On 22 January 1959 it was decided to appoint a caretaker and to postpone the official opening till the following season when the pool would really be completed.

Lighting for evening sessions was discussed with Electricity Trust Officers and Mr Bert Beinke was enlisted to install it. The committee was then led by H.J. Topsfield as President and E. Orchard as Secretary.

A working bee called for 24 November 1959 was disappointing and the pool could not be re-opened as early as had been hoped. On 30 November 1959 it was re-opened after an energetic band had worked painting the outside of the dressing sheds and doing other necessary jobs. The remaining major job is the installation of electric light and refrigeration to satisfy the demand for cold drinks.

In February 1959 the first Swimming Carnival was held in the new pool. It was won by Draysey House.

In January 1960 the Education Department’s Learn to Swim Campaign saw 112 school children gain 204 certificates. Instructors were Mr L. Pemberton & Miss Judy Kellock.

Prior to the opening floodlights were erected for night swimming and they did an excellent job, though one more on the eastern side will be required when finance permits.

Photographs:

Page 5

Preparing reinforcements for pool walls: E. Orchard, 2nd from left and H. Topsfield in the background.

Same day Messrs W. Nankivell, H.J. Topsfield and K. Spackman.

C.H. Cummins & R.G. Jeffery study the plans.

C. Parker working on early stages of the dressing rooms.

The completed pool with dressing room walls topped, almost ready for the roofing.

The western side retaining wall.

Page 6

H.J. Topsfield at the official opening.

Official Party: H.J. Topsfield, R.G. Jeffery, DC Chairman A.D. Radford, P.H. Quirke MP.

Mr Fullgrabe (Town Clerk), Mr E. Orchard (Secretary), Mrs Hawker and in the background Cr J.A. Fisher (Supervisor).

Mayor E.T. Baulderstone moves the second vote of thanks at the opening.

Elaine Broderick – one of those who received a certificate.

A group of boys at the pool on opening day.

90, 8, 1 March 1960, page 1

Burra District LCL Meeting at Booborowie

The half-yearly meeting of delegates from Burra LCL was held at Booborowie on the 19 February with a large attendance from across the region. Mr G.S. Hawker presided. There was a brilliant address from Senator Clive Hannaford on his visit to America as one of Australia’s delegates to the United Nations.

President G.S. Hawker reported on a quiet political year. He thought there was too much emphasis on the stabilising effect of secondary industry when three-quarters of export credits came from primary production, especially wool. Better methods of production and good primary prices for most years since the war have put primary industries on a sounder basis than prior to the 1930s. These factors have softened the impact of the drought and lower prices. Secondary industries contribute very little to export income and with rising costs the prospect of their doing so seems remote. But, their expansion is having an adverse effect on primary industries.

Farrell Flat Tennis Club Ball on 19 February had takings of £34-11-0 and a nett profit of £14.

90, 8, 1 March 1960, pages 1 & 5

Burra High School

The Swimming Carnival was held on Friday afternoon. Draysey House won the shield narrowly from Jennison. Outstanding performers were:

Judith Willmott, winning 8 events and 24 points in the Junior Girls.

George Kelly who won 15 points in the Junior Boys.

Lorraine Irlam was second best for Draysey with 18 points.

Anthony Tame for Riggs won 17 points.

Janet Scriven for Steele won 16 points.

At the conclusion of the event the Headmaster Mr M.W. Scriven announced there would be a special Swimming Cup to be held from year to year by the house winning the carnival and to be known as the Roy Jeffery Cup, as a tribute to the former headmaster whose efforts had done so much to provide the Burra Swimming Pool.

[Results are printed.]

Mrs Mary Bevan is 93 today.

[As May Mannix on 27 January 1896 she had married Foon Tie in Kooringa. After his death on 9 February 1900, following an accident, she married Robert Bevan 28 April 1900 at the residence of Mr Chin in Kooringa. She died 8 March 1964 in Adelaide, residence Myrtlebank aged 97. Robert Bevan died in 1920 aged 87.]

90, 8, 1 March 1960, page 8

Burra Town Council, 15 February

W.A. Field was granted permission to rip up the area and plant trees in Paradise Street.

Burra Burra DC, 15 February

The SA Fire Brigade was given permission to install a fire siren.

90, 9, 8 March 1960, page 1

Burra Town Council recently approved a plan for the beautification of the creek area near the swimming pool. A committee of Messrs Baulderstone, W. Lloyd, Cummins and Fullgrabe were elected to investigate and report to Council.

The plan was accepted and work will begin in the winter months. The plan covers both sides of the creek from the new footbridge to the Jubilee Fountain. [A very rough plan of the area is printed.]

Between the bridge and the dressing sheds the area is to be planted with lawn and shrubs – to be sustained with waste water from the pool. Next to the toddlers’ pool will be an area 100 feet wide to be a children’s playground enclosed by a cyclone fence. Between the playground and the present caravan park sheds the area will be developed as a car park.

On the eastern side of the pool and playground a strip will be planted with lawns and shrubs beneath the large gums with barbecues to be built.

Near the old fountain a natural vehicle entrance presents itself, giving access to the car park, pool and barbecue area.

Only two or three old and dangerous pines would have to be removed and some other trimming would be required. A new block of conveniences is to be erected near the present caravan park entrance. The old type of conveniences presently in use would be removed. The whole area from the car park to the fountain would be ideal for a caravan park. The eastern bank of the creek is to be planted with trees and shrubs; perhaps on school arbor days.

Wool Pavilion Donations. The total cash so far has been £249-12-0, but there have been fleeces and a bag of wool as well.

Miss Valerie Terry was farewelled in the Kooringa Methodist Sunday School Hall on Friday 26 February. Entertainment took the form of games, items and competitions and was organised by the MYF. Mrs M. Satchell sang, Mr J. Carpenter gave a guitar performance, Mrs J. Carpenter sang, Miss V. Williams performed a piano solo and Miss K. Webster a piano accordion solo.

Tennis

A Grade Aberdeen 11 defeated Spalding 9

B Grade Aberdeen 16 defeated Leighton 5 [sic: but this is an unusual total of sets played.]

The Leighton Ladies’ Committee held its annual meeting in Leighton Hall on 24 February. Mrs F. Carmody gave the annual report, which mentioned a Saturday night dance, Mid-winter Ball, afternoon teas at football matches and a fete. The fete raised £46-2-0, which was given to the Burra Hospital Fundraising Committee. £148 had been given to the Leighton Hall Committee to renovate the kitchen and supper room. All meetings had been poorly attended, but people turned up for the events. Thanks were tendered to the ladies of the Ironmine Methodist Ladies’ Guild for help at the fete and in making new supper room curtains. Financially they were in credit £120-14-6. No member could accept nomination as President, so a motion was passed calling for a special meeting on 5 April and resolving that if no nominees come forward the committee would be disbanded.

Burra RSL held its AGM on Saturday 20 February. Only 26 members attended. Elected: President, G.J. Kelly; Vice-Presidents, T. Rogers & E.C. Pietsch; Secretary, R.W. Fullgrabe and Treasurer, Ron Wuttke.

President E.C. Pietsch reported on a successful year with a farewell visit by the Governor Sir Robert George, a successful Annual Smoke Social and Ball and two lectures. The Anzac day Service was conducted by the Ministers’ Fraternal and the Port Pirie Pipers’ Band led the march. The Christmas Party was combined with the Air Force Association. Successful Badge Days were held for Legacy, Poppy Day and Anzac Day Appeals. Two Legacy wards have been maintained and £81-4-0 collected in a weekend bottle drive for this cause – a similar drive was conducted last weekend. The front of the clubrooms has been painted without charge for labour by Messrs J. Kelly, E.C. Jones and R. Day. Farewells were tendered to T. Brazil and Colin Morrison, who had been an able Secretary in the past year. Bob Ford died during the year and was provided with a funeral escort. The Ladies’ Auxiliary was thanked for their valued help.

Mr & Mrs M.B. Davey, formerly of Burra and now of Chamroc Ave. Prospect, celebrate their Golden Wedding tomorrow, having been married at Pine Point Methodist Church 9 March 1910. They have three children: Lyell of Mallala, Win. Mrs S. Pearce of Burra and Mervyn (RAAF deceased).

Burra Rifle Club. In the 14th stage of the Carpenter Trophy the best results were by R. Oakley, K. Phillips and R. Francis.

Burra Rural Youth decided to hold a Debutante Ball on 29 July with the Dee Jay Juniors to provide the music. Sir Thomas Playford will be asked to receive the debutantes. On 25 February Shell Pictures were shown at Burra Town Hall. It has been decided that the proceeds from the Easter Dance at the Burra RSL Hall will aid the Wool Pavilion.

Booborowie School

Mr Gower and family have been welcomed. He arrived on 1 March to take over the duties as headmaster at Booborowie Primary School.

90, 10, 15 March 1960, page 1

Burra Town Council will take immediate action to recover all outstanding rates. At present £846 is owed.

Mothers & Babies Health Association

At last, after three years the Association can be said to be established in Burra. The first clinic served 12 mothers and now the monthly total is nearly 50. This increase means more expense and the branch is organising a second-hand clothes sale to be held at Semaphore in May.

Burra Rifle Club. The 4th stage of the Carpenter Trophy had been postponed from 21 November 1959 and was fired last weekend. Best on handicap were: K. Spackman, K. Williams & K. Phillips.

The Burra Wool Pavilion is progressing, but the appeal for funds continues. The building itself and roofing have been completed and the next stage is the pouring of the concrete floor, which has been arranged for Saturday 19 March. Volunteers would be greatly appreciated.

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club. Best score for the last shoot on handicap were K. Lane, N. Todd, A. Day and B. Aworth.

Cricket. Mokota Association Semi-Finals

Mt Bryan 162 v. Booborowie 5 for 146

Spalding 199 v. North Booborowie 164

Booborowie Tennis Club has almost completed erecting new backstops and is appealing for funds to match the £200 cost.

Burra race Meeting will be held on 23 March. A record 135 nominations have been received (previous best was 117 in 1950.) It is anticipated that at least one race will have to be divided to make an eight race program. The track has been watered and is well covered with green.

Notice. For sale by Tender. Hallett Institute 110 volt Lighting Plant. A 5 h.p. Lister Engine coupled to a Lister 110 volts generator of 600 r.p.m. with switchboard. Also one 110 volt set of Exide 2 volt glass cell batteries in good order.

Burra Town Council, 7 March

No tenders were received for the old swing bridge. Its disposal was left in the hands of the Mayor.

A building permit was granted for the Burra Show Society’s Wool Pavilion. Its estimated cost was £1,000.

Approved with some opposition from Crs Lehmann and Lloyd.

90, 10, 15 March 1960, page 5

Cricket. Burra Association

Burra 8 for 207 defeated Buffs 9 for 104 & 74

Koonoona 6 for 203 defeated Farrell Flat 97 & [2nd innings score not to hand]

Mr Jim McRae comes to Elder’s at Burra from 18 months in Cummins. In Burra he will play for Burra Football Club. We understand Mrs McRae is an accomplished pianist.

C.W. (Nip) Kelly, formerly of Burra, won the Whyalla Gift recently, but lost the Pt Pirie Gift by a few inches.

Bowls

Mid North Bowling Association Champion of Champions Tournament was held at Burra last Saturday.

The honours went to Jack Goodenough of Clare.

Clare green won the Rinks Competition.

North Eastern Association Champion of Champions Tournament was held at Spalding on Saturday.

The title went to Bill Phin of Hallett, but in the Rinks Competition the Burra team of George Terry (Skipper), K. Parker, S. Pearce and Max Jacka were victorious.

90, 10, 15 March 1960, page 6

Burra Institute

President F. Atkin presented his annual report. Membership was steady. About 250 new books were added to the library. Cataloguing has been a long job, but is now nearing completion. Circulation of books and magazines has been about 7,500 for the year. The library holds c. 6,823 books. Membership at 31 December was 126 adults, 35 scholarship, 18 juveniles and 1 life member for a total of 180.

The New Year began in credit £12-1-4 and ended in credit £23-2-11.

Thanks to the Town and District Councils who each gave a grant of £5.

The Government subsidy of £50 is vital for the continuation of the Library. £63 was spent on books, freight, insurance, repairs and sundries. £120 for the Librarian’s salary and £40 on magazine subscriptions. Subscriptions bring in £135, so the need for grants, subsidies and money raising efforts is obvious.

Tennis

A Grade Aberdeen 10 defeated Hallett Town 10 by 14 games

B Grade Spalding Blue 13 defeated Aberdeen 7

90, 10, 15 March 1960, page 8

Obituary. Rev. David George Longbottom of Burra was born at Jamestown in 1904 [30 November] and died on 22 February after a short illness. He was a member of the Ironmine Church before joining the Methodist ministry 34 years ago. He began as a home missionary at Darke Peake Home Mission Station. He studied at Wesley College and obtained highest results in the Commonwealth in Hebrew and Greek. He was a humble and conscientious person, possessed of quiet persuasiveness and he won the confidence and support and affection of young people. He loved astronomy and only recently vacated the chair as Master of Epworth Masonic Lodge. He is survived by his widow and daughter Joan. [The death is registered as 27 February at Prospect, residence Manningham. He is apparently ‘of Burra’ because his parents had a property at Braefoot when he was young.]

90, 11, 22 March 1960, page 1

Burra racing Club will conduct an eight race program tomorrow.

[Full details of races, horses and weights are printed.]

Obituary. V.T.L. Hughes of Mt Bryan East died suddenly on 8 March aged 69, while attending to stock.

Mrs Colin Hughes and her little girl were the only ones at home at the time. Mr Hughes came to Mt Bryan East about 1907 to work for Messrs Thomas & Gare at Glen View and after a number of years he purchased a small holding and went share farming. Owing to low wheat prices he sold his farming plant and took casual work as his holding was far too small to make a living on. He has erected many miles of fencing in the district and up to a few weeks of his death was still engaged in that laborious work. He was a loyal member of the Mt Bryan East Methodist Church and was a regular worshipper until the church closed a few years ago. He was a life member of the Mt Bryan East Agricultural Bureau. He was buried at Hallett Cemetery. Mrs Hughes predeceased her husband in July 1950. Six children survive: May Mrs Williams of Wallaroo, Aileen Mrs Modra of Gawler District, Albert of Adelaide, Jean Mrs Don Kessel of Kadina and Colin and Levi both of Mt Bryan East.

[Victor Thomas Levi Hughes born 1 June 1890 at Wonna: died 8 March 1960 Mt Bryan East.]

Burra Wool Pavilion. About 20 men turned up for the working bee. The carpenter had set up the screeds and all was ready. Brian Riggs and his gang of workers set to the task with three mixers and poured 100 yards of 4 inch concrete in fewer than three hours. Plasterer ‘Jimmie’ James lay the topping.

[Volunteers are listed; including R. Fuss.]

Bt Bryan’s St Patrick’s Ball on 18 March was a great success. Dancers came from Adelaide, Robertstown, Clare, Riverton and Saddleworth as well as from the local area.

Obituary. Mr Lyal Webber, who spent most of his life at Mt Bryan East, died in Adelaide Hospital 21 February 1960 aged 67. He was buried at Centennial Park Cemetery, Adelaide.

[Lyell Willcox Webber born 22 April 1892 Hindmarsh: died 21 February 1960 at Woodville, residence Alberton.]

The Smelts Road Bridge between the Aberdeen Tennis Courts and the school has now been closed to traffic heavier than three tons due to its dangerous condition.

Obituary. Leonard Melrose Schmidt collapsed at Brady Creek tennis courts while playing on Saturday 12 March and died aged 37. He is survived by his wife and three young children.

[Born 10 October 1922 Robertstown: died 12 March 1960 Emu Downs.]

Burra Rifle Club last Saturday the best marksmen were H. Byles, R. Shipard and R. Bernhardt and on handicap were H. Byles, R. Shipard and R. Bernhardt.

90, 11, 22 March 1960, page 5

Kooringa Methodist Sunday School has been repainted after more than 40 years. A re-opening service is to be held on 27 March at 3 p.m. The Kooringa Methodist Guild provided funds for most of the paint. A frolic is being organised for 8 April to pay for the balance of the paint.

Cricket. Mokota Association

Mt Bryan 162 v. South Booborowie 5 for 166

The Grand Final will commence at 1 p.m. next Saturday at Spalding between South Booborowie and Spalding.

90, 11, 22 March 1960, page 6

Burra Show Society AGM 8 March.

Election of Officers: Patron, A.B. Riggs; President, Rex. C. Warne re-elected; Vice-Presidents, C.F. Pearce & B.A. Riggs.

Mr R. Fuss was made an honorary life member in recognition of his untiring support and help with the show improvements.

Burra Rural Youth was acknowledged for helping improve buildings and to run Gala Night Dance and assisting with finance.

President’s Report

Despite the drought the annual show on 10 October 1959 was an outstanding success. The show was officially opened by Sir Philip McBride KCMG.

The weather was glorious and over 2,000 people attended.

Entries were just short of a record.

The main ring events were good and horses numerous.

A Sanction Dog Show attracted much interest and it was pleasing to see the sheep pavilion comfortably full.

The Rural Youth Sheep Judging Competition was a popular innovation.

Wool entries were well supported, causing congestion in the Agricultural Pavilion.

This prompted the decision to find new accommodation for wool and a new building is being erected for this purpose. Mr R. Fuss has come forward to help the society erect this building and for this we are most grateful.

The Rural Youth have also been most helpful this year with financial aid and looking after Gala Night arrangements.

Membership remains over 300, a gratifying level and our financial position is sound.

With regret I note the passing of Mr A.T. McWaters, one of our staunchest committeemen, who gave untiring energy to the society.

We thank our secretary Mr T.G. Perry and Miss Hopkins for their assistance and to all those who served on committees or helped in other ways.

Tennis. Burra Tennis Association Semi-Finals

A Grade 1st Semi-Final Hallett Town 12 defeated Aberdeen 8

2nd Semi-Final Kooringa 13 defeated Spalding 7

B Grade Spalding 10 defeated Booborowie 10 by 11 games

Spalding 15 defeated Mt Bryan 5 [The Spalding teams are not distinguished in the report.]

Burra Primary School Welfare Club held its annual meeting 1 March.

Elected: President, Mrs J. Phillips; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames D. Field & H. Topsfield; Secretary, Mrs M. Mitchell; Assistant Secretary, Mrs M. Broderick and Treasurer Mrs J. Bogisch.

Last year the assistance to the school included the long awaited bicycle racks freework for Grades I & II, sports equipment, desk bags for the Grade VI room, a new pillow and rug for the sick room and ice creams and drinks for the Christmas Party.

90, 11, 22 March 1960, page 8

Marriage. St Joseph’s Church, Burra 20 February

Anne Verna Bampton, youngest daughter of Mr & Mrs P.S. Bampton of Burra, married

Guenter Zieke, eldest son of Mrs L. Zieke and the late Mr Zieke of Berlin. The couple will live in Adelaide.

[Details in 1⁄2 column and photo 90, 12, 29 March 1960, page 3.]

90, 12, 29 March 1960, page 1

The Burra Racing Club’s meeting on Wednesday last was conducted in perfect weather and proved to be the best in the history of the club. Starting stalls were used for the first time in Burra and proved most successful.

Quinella betting was introduced and proved quite popular as £465 was invested and in the tote investments were £997, an increase of £750 on the previous meeting. Bookmakers’ holdings of £39,000 were up £20,000 on 1959, showing that better types of horses brought a greater following of punters.

[The races are reviewed and the results printed.]

Sergeant H .McCallum, recently in charge of the Burra Police, was a member of the winning rink in the Championship of the Australian Police Bowling Carnival at Millswood on Wednesday.

Burra High School Prefects were inducted on Monday afternoon 21 March.

Adelaide Wool Sales, 15-17 March closed on a strong tone. L.L. & A.J. Martin of Burra topped the district with 71d per pound. [Other local district prices are printed.]

Roland Robinson of Sydney, poet and author, will visit Burra on Thursday 7 April. He was part of the recent Adelaide Festival of Arts and will address High School students in the afternoon and the public at the Town Hall at 8 p.m.

Accident. Mr Bert Wardle was bulldozing rubbish down the slope of the town dump on Saturday morning when the ground gave way beneath his crawler. The tail of the dozer sank some eight feet with the front still on top. Bert scrambled out and the nearly lost dozer was retrieved on Sunday morning. His son Ray showed real courage in climbing down to work the controls as the tow cable took the strain.

Aberdeen Tennis Club’s Variety Concert at the Town Hall on 25 March drew a capacity crowd and takings were £92.

Program:

Cricket. Mokota Association Grand Final

90, 12, 29 March 1960, page 4

Peter Murphy who has been at Dalgety’s in Burra for four years will go to Kimba on 4 April to be replaced by Mr J. Merkel from Bordertown.

Peter was educated at St Joseph’s and Burra High School before joining the staff of Richardson, Kempe, Hogarth & Edwards in 1953. He has been a member of the Aberdeen Tennis Club, Burra North Badminton, Burra Cricket Club and Burra Football Club as well as Burra Rural Youth.

Accident. Jack Skinner, Overseer for the Robertstown District Council was bulldozing out two fifteen foot mallee trees on 21 March when a dead limb broke off and crashed on his head. He was taken to Eudunda for treatment and then to the RAH with a probably fractured skull.

[See obituary 89, 15, 26 April 1960, page 1.]

Mr G.S. Hawker of Mt Bryan and Mr E.J. Ashby of Hallett will be judges at this year’s Sydney Sheep Show.

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club. Best shots on Tuesday on handicap were M. Thomas, R. Francis, J. Taylor and W. Barker.

Night Basketball. The season ended on 23 March with a tournament. In the final Burra 11 defeated Jamestown 7.

Mr Terry Welsh of the ANZ Bank in Burra has been transferred to the Grenfell Street Branch after almost two years here. He was Captain of the Kooringa tennis team, a Burra footballer, a member of the Kooringa Methodist Choir, a Badminton Club member, leader of the Methodist Youth Fellowship and Treasurer of the Burra Rural Youth. He leaves on 12 April to be replaced by Mr John Paynter.

Burra Town Council, 21 March

His Worship the Mayor reported attending the Air Force Association Dinner.

After inspection of the Smelts Road Bridge with the Highways Engineer Mr Wilkins, it was decided that a weight limit of 3 tons be imposed on it.

Burra Football Club was granted the use of the Burra Oval for 1960 season for 1/- and to pay for light and water for the season.

It was resolved that the footbridge be fitted with cyclone fencing. [Presumably the footbridge that replaced the swing bridge opposite the Town Hall.]

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club completed the shoot for the season’s trophy last Tuesday night. On the night the best on handicap were M. Thomas, Mrs C. Taylor & R. Cullen.

Burra Lawn Tennis Tournament, 27 March.

68 players took part. President John Hammer welcomed all and presented prizes. Winners were Mr L. Hopgood and Mrs J. McBride.

90, 12 (2), 5 April 1960, page 8

Cricket. Burra Association Grand Final

Koonoona 226 defeated Buffs 76 & 55 by an innings and 95 runs.

90, 13, 12 April 1960, page 1

Accident/Obituary. Brian Kenneth Baulderstone, a 19-year-old apprentice carpenter of Firle, was killed near Hanson on Saturday night when the car he was driving overturned. The car was a Holden sedan and his mother Mrs Nellie Margaret Thompson was a passenger. They had intended to stay at Burra overnight before proceeding to Terowie the next day. The noise of the crash was heard by Messrs Barry Eberhard, Kevin Lane and John Bray who were in the area. When they arrived the car was back on its wheels, but the occupants had been thrown out. The ambulance and Burra Police were summoned and Mrs Thompson was admitted to Burra Hospital with shock and severe bruising. The driver was dead when examined by Dr R.B. Pitcher. Brian and his mother were to have attended the Prize Shoot at Terowie on Sunday. Other members of the East Marden Club did not learn of the fatality until they arrived at Terowie the next day. Although the shoot continued the East Marden members withdrew.

The Methodist Quarterly Meeting was held at Redruth on Thursday 7 April. A resolution was carried that a letter be sent to the Burra Council protesting against permission for the use of the Aberdeen Tennis Courts for organised Sunday sport.

The Burra Wool Pavilion

The cement floor has been laid and finished by Mr ‘Jimmy’ James. Mr R. Fuss has since carried on fitting iron on walls and gable ends and installed most of the glass in the roof light. He is now working on the interior fittings and preparing the doors.

Rovers & Comrades Basketball Clubs held their AGM in the Kooringa Sunday School Hall on 30 March and elected:

90, 14, 19 April 1960, page 1

The Morgan-Whyalla Pipeline will be duplicated, with work starting this year. The proposals for the year ending 31 December are for new pumps for numbers 1, 2, 3 & 4 pumping stations between Morgan and Robertstown and for booster stations at Spalding, Georgetown, Baroota and Lincoln Gap. The 1961 works include a major pumping station and a 33-inch concrete-lined steel main to Bald Hill, two miles northwest of Burra and a summit storage of 2 million gallons. The pumping station at Hanson is planned to lift 12,000 gallons per minute to the Burra tanks and three of a probable four pumping units are listed for early installation.

The Burra to Jamestown section will start in 1962 and will continue through 1963. Jamestown to Wirrabara commences in 1964 and Wirrabara to Baroota in 1965. Later the rising main from Morgan to Hanson will be duplicated as will also the main from Baroota to Whyalla. The total cost will be £12,237,000 and the work will not be completed till 1985.

The Bald Hill storage tanks will be located where the Hundreds of Ayers, Hanson and Kooringa join west of Burra. From the Burra Tanks the main will pass through the Hundred of Ayers to Booborowie, passing just north of the town and assuring it of reticulated water. It will then trend northwest through Ayers and almost due north through the Hundred of Reynolds, then northwest to appoint almost due south of Jamestown, where ultimately there will be four 2 million gallon tanks. Then it will go northwest in an almost direct line to Caltowie and on to Wirrabara, through Germein Gorge to meet the existing main. Burra should receive Murray water in 1962.

These details from P.H. Quirke MP.

Kooringa Methodist Ladies’ Guild held its AGM early in March.

Burra Town Council, 4 April

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club was given permission to erect a club shed on oval property through the southern wall and to plant trees and shrubs and improve the area.

A hole in the netting of Gully’s Wharf Bridge [i.e. the Burra North Swing Bridge] is to be repaired.

A previous motion had been passed to have the name of E.R. Davey removed from the Town Clerk’s Honour Roll.

Crs Fisher and Cornelius moved to have all names removed, as those concerned had been paid servants. Carried.

[Given that the roll is still there in the Town Hall in 2014, this resolution does not appear to have been put into effect. See also comment at 90, 3, 26 January 1960, page 1.]

Resolved that a carpet runner be obtained for the dress circle stairways and from the doorway to the stage in the main hall. Quotes were of £59 and £35. Also that winding gear be obtained for masking the screen for pictures. Quote £48. Carried.

Polio Injections. Persons who received their second injection over seven months ago are now due for their third. Please bring the original white card. The unit will be in Burra Thursday 12 May. All three injections are needed to stop this crippling disease.

Burra Golf Club held its AGM recently. Mr Lindsay Thomas was elected a life member.

Elected: President, Dr L.G. Miller; Vice-Presidents, Messrs M.V. Scriven & J. Murray; Secretary, T.M. Richardson and Treasurer, R.B. Jennison.

Early last season the committee decided to invite the associates to nominate two delegates to attend committee meetings so that associates’ interests could be represented on club matters concerning them. This has proved most successful. The club began the season in credit £271-8-11 and spent £287-3-7 on extensions to the clubhouse and other capital items and £145-6-11 for course improvements and weekly labour. It finished the year in credit £70-0-10. The new season will start on 30 April.

Redruth Methodist Ladies Guild

Annual Report by the Secretary Mrs Jennison is printed in c. 11⁄3 columns.

During the year the Guild raised £397-3-2. Average attendance had been 31.

Burra Rifle Club. The final stage of the Championship was shot on Saturday 9 April

The Off the Rifle Champion was C. Edwards with 352, just ahead of G. Webster on 351.

In the Handicap Section Ed Hopkins was the winner with 348, with A.G. Heinrich on second place with 346.

90, 14, 19 April 1960, page 6

Obituary. Leonard Melrose Schmidt, second son of Hedwig Wilhelmina Schmidt (nee Bruhn) and her late husband Johannes F.C. Schmidt, was born at Robertstown 10 October 1942. He lived in the Emu Downs district all his life and followed farming pursuits. He was a constant member of the Emu Downs Lutheran Church, which he served as a lay reader for 18 years. In November 1950 he married Elizabeth Joyce Werner. The deceased enjoyed average good health and his death was unexpected. On Saturday 12 March he was standing on the local tennis court, apparently enjoying good health and in good spirits, when he suffered a coronary occlusion, collapsed and died in a moment aged 37 years and 5 months. He leaves his wife Betty and three young children: Christine, Jeffery and Wayne. He is also survived by his mother, one brother and three sisters and their families.

90, 14, 19 April 1960, page 8

Marriage. Kooringa Methodist Church, 26 March

Kaye Lehmann, only daughter of Mr & Mrs M.W. Lehmann of Burra, married

Kevin Campbell, second son of Mr & Mrs R.C. Campbell of Burra. The couple will reside at Bordertown.

[Details in 1⁄2 column and photo on page 1.]

89, 15, 26 April 1960, page 1 [Note inconsistent change of volume number.]

The Bishop of Pt Pirie, Rev Dr Bryan Gallagher will visit Burra next weekend. He will probably attend the St Joseph’s School Physical Culture Display and Sports Day on Saturday afternoon and on Sunday will administer confirmation at St Joseph’s Church.

Burra Ambulance Service

Following the withdrawal of the privately owned ambulance, which has operated in the district for some time, a meeting has been called to discuss the possibility of buying a District Ambulance. The withdrawal of the ambulance without notice came as a shock to the town’s doctors. The Mayor was notified on Monday night, but before he could notify those affected, Dr Pitcher called for an ambulance to transfer a patient to Adelaide. The doctors then discovered there was no ambulance in the town and the Clare ambulance had to be used. A meeting will be held on 29 April. An ambulance committee had been formed, but when the offer of a private ambulance was made its work was halted.

Obituary. John Reginald Skinner, the Overseer of the Robertstown DC, died in the RAH on 18 April as a result of injuries sustained about five weeks earlier at Robertstown when a tree limb crashed onto his head. He is survived by a wife and a son. [Born 8 March 1919, Adelaide.]

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club fired a blind shoot over 25 and 50 yards. Norm Todd won on the day.

89, 15, 26 April 1960, pages 1 & 4

Anzac March & Service in Burra

On Sunday afternoon about 50 ex-servicemen attended the service of commemoration conducted by the Ministers’ Fraternal before the War Memorial in Market Square. The march was led by the Pt Pirie Pipers’ Band and members of the RSL, Air Force, Ex-Servicemen’s and Fathers’ Associations. Wreaths were laid by G.J. Kelly (RSL), T.G. Perry (Air Force Association), P. Williams (Demobilised Soldiers), W. Carpenter (Fathers’ Association), The Mayor and Mr E. Finch for the District Council. Rev. R.S. Jenner gave the address.

[The address is printed in 2 columns.]

89, 15, 26 April 1960, page 6

Burra Post Office Photos

The old Post Office from the Swimming Pool

The new Post Office in Market Square receiving finishing touches before being officially opened on 9 May 1960.

Telephone Facilities in Burra were disrupted on the Thursday before Easter when Council employees washed out water tables while unaware that the PMG cable pits were open. Water entered the pit in front of Elders and ran through the conduit to the pit in front of the District Council Offices. About 150 telephones were placed out of service until the pits could be pumped out and approximately 1,200 joins were made. Communications were restored by Friday morning.

Tennis Tournament Late Results

Men’s Championship to R. Hopgood

Mixed Doubles Championship to R. Hopgood & Mrs Ross.

89, 15, 26 April 1960, page 8

The Rural Youth Dance on Easter Saturday night attracted about 150 dancers and raised £27 for the Show Society’s Wool Pavilion.

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club. The pairs match was won by K. Spackman and R. Angel.

89, 16, 3 May 1960, page 1

Burra Ambulance

A meeting of district organisation representatives on Friday night decided on a target of £2,000 to purchase a new ambulance. St John’s Council representatives assured the meeting of a subsidy up to £500. A committee was formed.

The Morgan-Whyalla Pipeline. Section numbers along the proposed route of the duplication of the pipeline are printed.

Hallett Football Club. New clubrooms have been built at Hallett.

Weather. Patchy rain has delivered some good falls to eastern stations, but others have missed out: Hogback reported 72 points, Woolgangi 69, Koomooloo 58, Old Koomooloo 5, Sturtvale 4. Burra recorded 109 for the week.

The CWA will hold an Exhibition of Antiques, Pictures and Art at the Burra Town Hall on 27 May. The aim is to raise money for new CWA Rooms in Burra, to be known as the Mary Warnes CWA Rooms. In 1926 the late Mrs T.R. Bowman came to Burra to speak about what was then known as the Country Women’s Service Association and soon afterwards a branch of this was opened in Burra with the Late Mrs I.J. Warnes as its first President. Two years later the name was changed to the Country Women’s Association. Lady Swift, the daughter of the late Mrs John Tennant, an original member, has consented to open the exhibition.

89, 16, 3 May 1960, page 3

Tab Hunter & Van Hefflin in Gunman’s Walk

Molly Bee & Allan Reed in Going Steady

Saturday 7 April

Plus Montparnasse

Berwick on Tweed

89, 16, 3 May 1960, page 4

Burra Rural Youth visited Burra Cold Stores to see the manufacture of cordials as a prelude to their meeting on 11 April.

Burra Rifle Club fired the 18th stage of the Carpenter Trophy and best marksmen were H. Byles and G. Webster, but the handicap honours went to K. Williams.

89, 16, 3 May 1960, page 5

Afternoon tea was served in the Convent Schoolroom. The program comprised a display of physical culture and team sports.

89, 16, 3 May 1960, page 7

Hallett Football Club new clubrooms will be opened on Saturday 7 May by Mr W.B. Ashby.

89, 16, 3 May 1960, page 8

Telephone Calls

The Director of Posts and Telegraphs has announced that from 1 May the local telephone area has been greatly enlarged. Previously the local call area for Burra extended for a circle within a radius a little greater than halfway to Mt Bryan or Hanson. Now it will extend to Clare and Watervale in the west, to beyond Robertstown in the southeast and beyond Booborowie, Willalo and Hallett in the north. [A map of the area is printed.]

The local call cost will be 4d. Trunk call charges will also change. Eleven different rates will become eight and the minimum charge will be 1/4.

89, 17, 10 May 1960, page 1

Table Tennis. North Eastern Association

Willalo 22-39 defeated Hanson 3-13

Inter-High School Sports planned for last Friday at Riverton have been postponed to tomorrow due to heavy rain.

Weather. Rain in the past week has seen good registrations in the district. Burra has recorded 330 points.

Polio. The mobile vaccination unit will be in Burra next Thursday.

Fire Siren. The new fire siren has been installed at the Town Hall and this replaces the siren at the Fire Station. The normal 7 a.m. and 7 p.m. sirens and soundings for town fires will be a continual note. A bushfire will be announced with a wailing note.

Advt. Sara’s Stock Clearance of Preserved Fruit.

89, 17, 10 May 1960, pages 1 & 10

A Burra Ratepayers’ Meeting was held in the Town Hall last Tuesday night. Thirty-one people attended to hear the report of the Mayor Mr E.T. Baulderstone. [They are listed.]

Mr Baulderstone expressed his disgust at the attempt by some to arrange the amalgamation of the Town and District Councils. He said he would oppose this because he did not wish to see the townspeople give away what their ancestors had fought for. The Town Council gets much abuse about its roads, but Burra is scattered along miles of road, many of them with low rated properties. The roads are not any worse than in other towns of comparable size, though some footpaths are not as good as they should be. The town also has quite a number of bridges to maintain and many of them are old.

They had received quite a lot of criticism regarding the main [foot] bridge, which is now almost completed. They had made mistakes there, but they had been rectified.

The Council has been criticised for removing street trees in some places, but they had planted many in the past five or six years. Many old trees were unsuitable or were planted in the watertables. I am confident that for every tree removed twenty or thirty have been planted.

Jubilee Avenue. The row of trees planted along the creek side of the Burra North Road provides a golden opportunity for beautifying the town and providing a good caravan park area.

The War Memorial Oval is mainly controlled by its committee and they have achieved quite a lot with little public support. A turf oval would be something to be proud of and I think should be more the responsibility of the Football Club.

The first public meeting in 1956 called for a swimming pool and by 1959 the Education Department was using the pool for its ‘Learn to Swim Campaign’. I congratulate those few who went ahead with action and not just words.

When the Council decided to raise a loan to buy the Mine area we didn’t receive any objections. It will cost the ratepayers little, with grazing rights offsetting much of the cost. The area can also be controlled for rubbish dumping and road metal is available there where previously the Council had to pay a royalty for it. In addition old mining relics can be preserved and the area developed as a tourist attraction.

With ETSA having taken over the electricity supply, there are more and brighter street lights.

Naming the streets is another idea and with gradual placement of the signs it would cost little.

The cemetery is proving a problem. It covers a large area and finance is very limited.

Burra is getting a fair share of new buildings and the main street compares most favourably.

The Fire Station has been leased to the Fire Brigade Board for £10 p.a. for ten years with the right of renewal and the Board is now responsible for repairs and improvements, such as those being carried out at present.

The Town Hall had been allowed to get into a bad state of repair. Until about ten years ago the hall was costing the taxpayers money. It was then decided to operate the pictures for the benefit of the hall. Money was borrowed to set this up and now the income has allowed the hall to prosper. £6,000 has been borrowed for the new supper room, but it is all being paid for by the pictures.

Most of the health budget goes on scavenging. In recent years this seems to have slipped somewhat. I would like to see a regular fortnightly collection. This would mean each ratepayer paying £1 p.a. for the service.

Septic tank systems will have to be mandatory within a few years.

There is now an urgent need to do something about getting a town ambulance.

Last year at the end of June the overdraft of £2,567 was too large. This year we anticipate ending the financial year with a reduction of at least £1,000 in this.

Answers to questions revealed:

The Town Hall pictures account was in credit

The pictures had paid off the Town Hall mortgage

There is currently no special rate for garbage collection

There is only a partial list of old relics in the town

The question of amalgamation of councils has not come from the District Council

[A question re the cost of the new bridge is garbeled in the paper.]

89, 17, 10 May 1960, page 3

Advt. Burra Pictures, 11 May

Terry Thomas in Too Many Crooks

William Sylvester in Dublin Nightmare

14 May

Don’t Go Near the Water

Frontier Rangers

89, 17, 10 May 1960, page 4

Burra Town Council, 2 May

Tenders were received from E.J. Lehmann and Hirschausen Bros for the fortnightly collection of garbage.

Consideration was held over until figures are available for scavenging by Council employees.

The Health Officer reported on Paxton Square. All but 3 or 4 homes were inspected. All were structurally sound, but the single complaint was the lack of bathing or washing facilities. Sanitary conditions were in accordance with the tenants themselves.

The owner of a cottage in Hill Street is to be served notice concerning white ant damage and leaking ceilings.

After efforts to recover same it was decided to write off £32-15-0 in outstanding cemetery fees.

Owners of the Burra Hotel were granted permission to remove trees in front of the building and to replant with candle pines.

The hire of the Town Hall was granted for badminton on Monday and Thursday nights.

89, 17, 10 May 1960, page 5

William Charlick Ltd, supplier of animal and poultry food has arranged with Goldsbrough Mort & Co. to establish a sales and distribution depot in Burra. The company has been in business in SA since 1880.

89, 17, 10 May 1960, page 6

Burra Primary School Committee AGM

Mr M.G. Stockman was elected Chairman with Mr D.H. Field as Secretary-Treasurer.

Report for 1959

The staffing position was satisfactory with seven teachers for seven grades.

The highlight of the year was the visit of the Governor Sir Robert George and Lady George.

A sports day was held on the oval in lieu of a picnic.

Visiting Day was held in conjunction with the High School.

Negotiations are under way to acquire the land between the school and the Drill Hall to allow an extension of the playing area and these should be concluded shortly.

We missed out on Arbor Day due to the dry conditions.

The lunch room has been nicely furnished and the free milk system is working well.

There is still a move afoot to have an extension library in the main building, a new classroom in the yard and a new block of lavatories for Primary School use on the east side.

The latest advice from the Department is that the main school roof is to be renovated to do away with the roofing well and the box guttering – rendering many pigeons homeless and helping to keep drinking water clean.
