Burra Rifle Club. 18th stage of the Carpenter Trophy. G. Webster was best off the rifle and with handicap the best were W. Hempel, R. Bernhardt and G. Webster.

89, 18, 17 May 1960, page 1

Burra Post Office

Mr C.R. Kelly MHR cut the ribbon on Monday night 9 May to officially declare open the new Burra Post Office. Local Postmaster Mr O. Tattersall introduced Mr Sullivan, Director of Posts and Telegraphs, who welcomed all to the ceremony. The building was erected by Taras & Co., Builders. The CWA ladies provided refreshments in the RSL Hall. His worship the Mayor Mr E.T. Baulderstone congratulated the PMG on the erection of such a suitable and up-to-date post office in Burra in an ideal situation. Mr Quirke said he would like to see an extension of the shelter in front of the building to cover people using the private boxes. In his speech Mr Kelly referred to the history of the town and the Burra Mine and also to the history of its post office. A post office was established at the Mines in 1847 and the first postmaster was Mr H.M. Buswarra [sic: for H.M. Boswarva]. The town comprised five settlements: Kooringa, Redruth, Aberdeen, Copperhouse and Hampden [sic: for Hampton]. Kooringa was the largest and a post office was established there in 1849 under postmaster Thomas Grant. In 1858 a peppercorn lease was granted by the mining company to the PMG’s Department. The old stone post office is thought to have been built in 1860. In 1942 [sic: actually on 1 December 1939] the name was changed to Burra to save confusion, since the railway station and District Council were already known by that name. Telegraph facilities were provided at Kooringa in 1860 and a telephone exchange, with two subscribers, was established in 1911 – Elder, Smith & Co. Ltd and Bagot, Shakes & Lewis. A telephone trunk line to Adelaide was provided on 1 April 1920. Today there are more than 300 subscribers connected to the Burra Exchange and two rural automatic exchanges at Gum Creek and Hanson are controlled from Burra. From 1 May last the local call service area of Burra has been greatly extended. In the past year the Burra Post Office handled:

Postal articles 591,655

Telegrams 5,614

Trunk calls 125,281

Local calls 145,431

The new building has an area of 16,000 square feet and cost £17,500.

The old building will accommodate telecommunications equipment and the telephone exchange. At present there are 32 people on the staff of the PMG at Burra and the present postmaster Mr O.A. Tattersall has held the position since 1950. [Photo of Mr Kelly cutting the ribbon.]

Weather

It has been a week of fairly consistent rain, with strong gusty winds and hail and in some places snow. Some shorn sheep and young lambs have succumbed to the conditions. Mushrooms are plentiful. So far in May Burra has received 539 points making 945 for the year to date.

89, 18, 17 May 1960, pages 1 & 10

River Murray Water

The Government Public Works Committee took evidence at Burra Town Hall on Friday concerning the supply of water to Burra and districts further north, from the duplication of the Morgan-Whyalla Pipeline. Representatives of Burra Town and District Councils gave evidence. Mr Shannon MP chaired the meeting and outlines the project to supply water to Whyalla BHP Steel Works.

Part of the planning provided for large storages, the first of which is at Burra, from Hanson, planned for 1961. Mr E.T. Baulderstone said that although Burra had a good water supply its quality was not suitable for hot water systems – especially at such places as the hospital. Mr Shannon said that whether the supply would be all Murray water or a mixture of Murray and local water would be purely an economic decision; a shandy could be dearer than straight River Murray water. If a shandy were chosen the ratio would be fixed. Cr Ashby (Hallett DC) said Hallett, Whyte Yarcowie and Terowie had no permanent water supply. Their elevation could prove troublesome and expensive. He felt that a special rate to cover supply costs would probably be acceptable – though ratepayers had not yet been asked this. The cost of carted water at Terowie was presently 25/- per 1,000 gallons. Mr Shannon said landowners along the area within one mile either side of the pipeline would be rated whether they used the water or not. Mr Shannon also thought that landowners a couple of miles away would not be denied access if they laid their own pipes. Burra will definitely be supplied.

89, 18, 17 May 1960, page 2 [Misnumbered 6]

89, 19, 24 May 1960, page 1

Burra Ambulance Committee has decided too purchase a Volkswagen Ambulance and to launch an appeal for £2,000 on Tuesday and also to call a meeting to form First Aid Classes. A representative of an Adelaide firm brought a Volkswagen Ambulance to Burra for inspection. Both Doctors L.G. Miller and R.B. Pitcher said that such a vehicle would ably serve the district. The ambulance would not cost as much as £2,000, but funds would also be needed for a building to house it.

Burra Cemetery. Burial fees will rise from 1 July to £10, with a surcharge for weekends and public holiday burials.

The Minister of Highways is to be asked to erect school safety signs at the crossing near the old post office.

Table Tennis

Burra Methodists 19-35 defeated Hanson 6-13

Spalding Blue 20-38 defeated Mt Bryan 5-14

Willalo 16-27 defeated Spalding 9-19

David Dawkins of the National Bank has been transferred to Pirie Street Branch in Adelaide and will be replaced by Mr Alan Mitchell from 7 June.

Miss Moira Byrnes has begun nursing at the RAH from this week.

Burra Rural Youth had 25 members at its 9 May meeting. John Markel was a new member, having transferred from Bordertown.

Rural Youth Upper Zone Conference at Spalding Institute on 12 May was chaired by Burra Club President Rex Stockman.

Mr R.H. (Dick) Smith of Elder, Smith & Co. will retire on 30 June after 50 years’ service with the company. He was born at Bordertown, where he began working for Elder’s. He has been stationed there four times and also at Pt Augusta, Crystal Brook and has managed branches at Wilmington, Bordertown, Orroroo and Burra before being promoted to the Stock Department in Adelaide in 1949.

Mrs George Parker will be 91 next Friday 27 May. She is staying with her daughter Mrs W.H. Collins at Booborowie.

89, 20, 31 May 1960, page 1

CWA Antique & Art Exhibition

To launch the building fund for their new rooms a committee convened by Mrs A. Tennant with Mrs M. Ashton as Secretary staged a magnificent exhibition of curios, pictures and things of historical interest in Burra Town Hall on Friday 27 May. The event was opened by Lady Swift who is the daughter of Burra CWA’s foundation Vice-President, the late Mrs John Tennant. The funds raised will be spent on a CWA building to be erected on land given by the Warnes Family in memory of the late Mary Jane Warnes, Burra Branch foundation President. Mrs H. Jennison moved the vote of thanks. The SA National Gallery provided 14 pictures, the Advertiser gave screens, Myers donated carpets and John Martin provided ropes and stanchions.

Burra mining days were represented by relics of mining and by pictures by Gill and Goodhart, arranged by Mrs A. Tennant assisted by Mr L. Bence.

The antique display included period furniture, china, glass, silverware and jewellery. A wedding table setting was arranged by Mrs Rex Warnes and Mrs R.B. Pitcher. Mrs H.L. Riggs and Mrs J. Hill arranged a Victorian drawing room on the stage. An early Victorian table was arranged by Mrs G.S. Hawker and Mrs J.R. Barker. Mrs L.G. Miller was responsible for a children’s party setting. Mrs L. Bence, Mrs A. Bence and Mrs C. O’Connor organised an oriental display. Mr R. Fuss provided articles relevant to Burra’s mining days including a beer pump and a collection of malachite. [Considerably more detail is printed.]

[The exhibition raised a little over £180.]

Table Tennis. North Eastern Association

Spalding Blue 19-31 defeated Hanson 6-12

Spalding White 17-32 defeated Mt Bryan 8-19

Willalo 17-33 defeated Burra Methodists 8-18

Burra Ambulance Appeal was launched by the Mayor this week. The ambulance will cover all the areas in our district and will connect with areas served by the Peterborough, Jamestown, Clare, Kapunda and Eudunda ambulance.

Weather. May has been the wettest on record with 651 points. The previous wettest May was in 1893 when 638 points fell. The wettest month ever was April 1889 with 830 points. May 1960 now takes second place.

89, 21, 7 June 1960, page 1

Burra Ambulance

32 people have joined the First Aid Course.

Donations for the ambulance are tax deductible.

Donations so far have been slow in the last week with £56 received. The total so far is just over £200.

Burra Rifle Club. Last Saturday best off the rifle were J. Brown, R. Francis and H. Byles and with handicap J. Brown, R. Kellock and N. Todd.

Mt Bryan East’s Drought broke on 27 April and since then it has had the best opening rains for many years. Dusthole Creek has again become a miniature river. Gales in the last two weeks uprooted trees and damaged some windmills. Mushrooms are plentiful.

89, 22, 14 June 1960, page 1

The Burra Ambulance Fund has reached £340.

Burra Town Council will supply and plant decorative street trees of adjacent ratepayers are prepared to tend to them in their early stages of growth.

St Mary’s Church

On the first anniversary of her death a memorial window will be dedicated to Mrs Mary Jane Warnes. It has been given by her sons Rex, Jim and Tom Warnes and will be dedicated by Rev. L.R. Lenthall, who was the Rector of St Mary’s 1953-58, at a service on Sunday 19 June at 3 p.m.

89, 22, 14 June 1960, page 4

Burra Town Council, 6 June

Dr L.G. Miller has been inspecting places where kitchen, bath and laundry waste water has been directed into watertables or other Council property and has been devising alternative arrangements. It was decided to give such persons three months notice to correct such faults.

A decision of street signs was held over for two months, pending a patent decision on a type of ‘Scotch Light’ sign.

Grave fees had been fixed at £10. Now children’s graves were fixed at £5 and those of stillborn babies at 30/-.

A wall had blown down recently at the rear of the Clerk’s residence. It was decided to replace it with 3 foot iron.

Dr R.B. Pitcher had been elected as Councillor for West Ward in place of Cr Cummins.

The Clerk is taking drastic action to bring in outstanding rates.

Council decided to accept the offer of the District Council’s Depot area in Kingston Street for £100 plus transfer costs.

Cr Lloyd reported that the footbridge at Gully’s Wharf was considered unsafe. The uprights had rotted away in the concrete foundations and the whole structure had dropped.

Cr Fisher suggested that the Queen Street [footbridge on the western side] was now excellent and at no great cost to Council and he would like to see similar repairs at Gully’s Wharf.

The Overseer was ordered to make the bridge temporarily safe.

[Photo of the recently opened footbridge in Queen Street.]

It was moved that the old Town Council Depot be offered to the Burra Bowling Club at £100 plus transfer costs, subject to the successful transfer of the District Council land for their depot.

89, 22, 14 June 1960, page 5

Obituary. An extended obituary is printed for Patrick Murtin Bunfield [sic] of Spalding who died 7 May 1960.

[Patrick Martin Bunfield born 1876, but birth not traced on SA Births CD. Appears in BISA as 1876-1960.]

Obituary. From Perth Elder’s Weekly 12 May 1960.

Mr Frederick William Pohlner of Bencubbin district of Western Australia died on 30 April aged 66 following a short illness. He was born at Hallett SA and was one of a family of ten children. He joined the AIF in 1914 and later transferred to the Australian Flying Corps. After the war he returned to farming with his father near Peterborough and later took land of his own at Copley in 1922, selling it in 1926 to come to WA. He was a keen sportsman and played golf and was greatly interested in the affairs of the local football and cricket clubs. He is survived by a widow and a daughter.

[Born William Fredrich Godfrey Pohlner 29 March 1894 Hallett.]

89, 22, 14 June 1960, pages 6 & 7

Football. Central Districts Carnival – Round 1

1st Eighteen North Eastern 22.17 defeated Mid North 4.11

2nd Eighteen North Eastern 11.15 defeated Mid North 9.7

In the Final on Monday

1st Eighteen North Eastern 27.18 defeated Adelaide Plains 9.14

89, 22, 14 June 1960, page 8

Booborowie RSL Ball on 3 June was an outstanding success. Excellent music was provided by the D-J Orchestra and Mr Howard of Clare conducted a demonstration of ballroom dancing with three juniors and one teenage couple.

89, 23, 21 June 1960, page 1

Hallett Hall Supper Rooms

Through the generous gift of Mrs A.G. Owen-Smyth new supper rooms at Hallett Institute were opened on 11 June. The large supper room is fully furnished with tubular steel tables and chairs and the kitchen is compact and fitted with modern facilities. There is a large cream brick fireplace in the supper room above which is a bronze plaque indicating that the room was built as a tribute to Sir John Melrose of Ulooloo in recognition of his practical support over many years. The design of the new rooms is by Glover and Pointer, architects and construction was by E.J. Affolter & Son. Mrs Owen-Smyth declared the building open.

[Two photos: Mrs Owen-Smyth opening the door and an interior shot.]

[Mrs A.G. Owen-Smyth was a daughter of Sir John Melrose.]

Mr E. Finch of Burra completes 391⁄2 years as a Burra Burrs District Councillor at the end of this month. On 4 July he takes his seat as Burra Town Councillor for North Ward.

Burra Ambulance Fund has now reached £631,

Burra Show Society’s New Wool Pavilion has now been completed. The project began in February and a committee set about raising donations for the building proposed by Mr R. Fuss; a structure 30 feet x 30 feet with a steel frame and with a south facing roof light. The final cost was £1,007-13-3. The Hon. The Minister of Agriculture has approved a subsidy of £250. The building has a cement floor and all fittings are painted. It is a credit to Mr Fuss and the band of helpers who assisted.

89, 23, 21 June 1960, page 2

Advt. Burra Pictures, 22 June

Glen Ford & Jack Lemmon in Cowboy

Lee J. Cobb &Patricia Medina in Miami Exposé

25 June

Howard Keel in Floods of Fever

Adrienne Corri in The Big Chance

89, 23, 21 June 1960, page 4

Football. North Eastern Association

A Grade Booborowie 15.5 defeated Spalding 10.18

Burra 18.11 defeated Hallett 8.12

Leighton 12.19 defeated Redlegs 5.6

Mt Bryan has had five streetlights installed; three in the main street and two at corners across the railway line.

89, 23, 21 June 1960, page 6

Golf. Ossie Tattersall scored a hole in one on the 6th hole on Saturday. He did the same thing there three years ago.

Obituary. Mr Johannes Alwin Heinrich died at Tanunda on 31 May. He was born at Baldina 17 April 1884, the eldest son of Gottlieb Wilhelm Heinrich and Anna Emilie nee Hetzel. He was baptised at Baldina 18 May 1884 and confirmed at Immanuel College at Point Pass in 1897. He had lived in the Apoinga District from about 1909, only moving to Tanunda three weeks before his death. On 14 September 1911 he married Mathilde Maria Heinrich who died 18 April 1943 and on 30 September 1949 he married Mrs Hilda Maria Eckernann. He took a keen interest in church and civic affairs and was church treasurer for 44 years and a frequent delegate to synods. He is survived by a wife, son, and grandson, two stepsons, three brothers and four sisters.

89, 23, 21 June 1960, page 8

Burra Burra DC, May

The tender of A.J. Bowley & Son for the supply and erection of a shed was accepted.

Election results:

Farrell Flat Ward J.H.J. Stevens

Kooringa Ward G.R. Finch

Leighton Ward J.F .Hogan

Mongolata Ward A.D. Radford

It was resolved that the [broken] flagpole be reinstated outside the Council Chamber.

E & WS Department is to be advised that preparations are in hand to seal the main street and requesting water pipes be installed before the final seal.

The question of a donation to the Ambulance Fund was deferred.

Appreciation was expressed for Cr E. Finch’s 391⁄2 years of service to the Council and he was wished every success as a Burra Town Councillor.

89, 24, 28 June 1960, page 1

The Burra Ambulance is now ready and will be handed over next Friday in Market Square. The official presentation by the St John Council for SA will take place at 3.30 p.m. The fund has now reached £1,356-19-0 and the committee is anxious that the total of £2,000 should be reached quickly so that the matter can be finalised by the end of the month.

Burra Methodists 13-24 defeated Hanson 12-23

Mt Bryan 16-25 defeated Spalding Blue 11-20

Willalo 14-25 defeated Spalding White 11-21

Hallett Football Club. Photo of the new club and change rooms built at a cost of £2,100.

Mr & Mrs Hugh Wilson of Burra celebrated their Golden Wedding yesterday.

Weather. Burra experienced severe frosts last Friday, Saturday and Sunday. To the end of May 1,061 points of rain had been recorded. Snow fell on 15 May.

John William Everett, only son of Mr & Mrs Everett of Eastwood, Sydney. The couple will live in Kogarah, Sydney.

89, 24, 28 June 1960, page 8

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club held its AGM 18 June.

R.G. Bernhardt, W. Hempel and M. Mitchell were made life members in recognition of their role in setting up the club. The club had a credit balance of £40. The Captain M.E. Mitchell presented the 1st Annual Report.

Weekly shoots began in October 1959.

Thanks go to Mr W. Hempel for acting as guarantor for the fee of lighting installation and to Mr Eric Angel for the loan of finance to procure ammunition to commence the weekly shoots and to the Burra Rifle Club for their financial assistance.

Elected: Captain, R. Angel; Secretary, M. Thomas and Treasurer, K. Spackman.

89, 25, 5 July 1960, page 1

Burra & District Ambulance

The new ambulance was handed over at an official ceremony in Market Square on Friday 1 July. The committee secretary Mr R.W. Fullgrabe introduced the Mayor who welcomed Dr H.H. Hurst, Commissioner of the St John Ambulance Brigade and other officials. Mr K.G. Shapter, Manager of the Order of St John for SA presented a cheque for £500 towards the cost of the vehicle. Further donations are listed to bring the present total to £1,575.

Weather. There were good falls of rain over the weekend. Burra registered 90 points and to the east some heavy falls were recorded. Braemar had 150 points, Woolgangi 110, Oakbank 114, Balah 121, Redcliffe 92, Thistlebeds 105, Glenora 103, Parcoola 150, Gluepot 130 and Koomooloo 94.

Norman J. Wilson, formerly of Burra, has been elected Councillor for Glynde Ward in the Payneham Council by 374 votes to his opponent’s 178.

Burra Town Council. Burra will have regular garbage collection from 1 July when a fortnightly service will begin. [Details are provided in a notice on page 2.]

Mr Phil Bampton, local postal officer, was knocked off his bike this week when it collided with a stray dog. He suffered lacerations requiring treatment at the hospital.

ETSA has advised the Town Council that it cannot provide Burra with cheaper power and it will remain in Zone 5. Council had asked that it be reallocated to Zone 4.

89, 25, 5 July 1960, pages 1 & 8

First Aid Class: three photographs.

9 July

89, 25, 5 July 1960, page 5

Burra CWA held its AGM 17 June. Elected: President Mrs H. Jennison; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames H. Riggs & M. Finch; Secretary, Mrs S. Scroop and Treasurer, Miss E. Tiver.

D.E. Pietsch the retiring President reported on an active and successful year.

During the year a committee was formed to build premises for the CWA in Burra. A block of land was acquired, which has since been donated to the CWA by the family of the late Mrs I.J. Warnes as a memorial to her work for the Burra CWA. A fine financial result rewarded the effort of staging the Antique Show.

The Secretary Mrs Florence Scroop reported the branch had 72 financial members with an average attendance of 20.

[Details of the year’s activities are reported.]

Two deaths are reported for the year: Mrs Clode and Mrs I.J. Warnes, late President and foundress of the CWA in SA.

[Born Ada Jane Burton 19 June 1897 Mt Bryan: died 25 February 1960 Burra North. Married Arthur Lawrence Clode 1925.]

89, 25, 5 July 1960, page 6

The Church of England Girls’ Friendly Society held a Chinese Barn Dance in the Oddfellows’ Hall on Friday 1 July to aid the World Refugee Year Appeal. Gross takings amounted to £21.

89, 25, 5 July 1960, page 7

Obituary. Eva Maud Spackman died Sunday 26 June at Burra. She was the widow of the late Edward Spackman and mother of Clarrie and Daphne Mrs Weeks, and grandmother of Jill.

[Born Eva Rebecca Maud Holmes 23 May 1883 Burra: died 26 June 1960 Booborowie, residence Burra. Married Edward Spackman 1905.]

89, 25, 5 July 1960, page 8

Burra Town Council, 28 June

Mr E. Finch & Dr R.B. Pitcher were welcomed as new Councillors from 1 July.

Mr R.J. Jeffery presented a case for the purchase of the laneway at the rear of his premises.

Mr Pollnitz of the Tourist Bureau will visit Burra on 9 July to inspect the Mine area with a view to Council receiving a subsidy for work to promote tourism.

Outstanding rates have been reduced to £49.

ETSA will install new lights near the new footbridge.

Crs Cummins and Lehmann moved that the decision to offer the old Town Depot to the Bowling Club for £100 be rescinded. They argued that the cost of effecting the transfer of plant, tools etc. Would be £50 to £60 and this too should be recovered. Carried, with the offer price to be determined after the move.

The footbridge in Chapel Street is to be repaired with new decking.

89, 26, 12 July 1960, page 1

Weather. Further showers this week have brought Burra’s total rainfall for the year to date to 1297 points.

Burra Burra DC. Photo of Chairman A.D .Radford presenting Cr E. Finch with a silver tray in recognition of nearly 40 years of faithful service. 4 July.

Local History

Last April Frank Bitmead of the Adult Education Department of the University of Adelaide visited Burra and was struck with the atmosphere of the town. He has now suggested a one day conference to be held in Burra in October. He is willing to bring speakers, exhibits etc. from Adelaide and to arrange a full program if 30 people are willing to attend and pay a fee of about £1 each. The Town Council endorses the idea. The suggestion is for 1 October or 15 October from 10 a.m. to 5 p.m. Please indicate your interest to the High School Headmaster Mr M.W. Scriven as soon as possible.

89, 26, 12 July 1960, pages 1 & 4

Burra Town Council, 4 July

Advertisement to be placed in the paper advising that fortnightly rubbish collection will commence on Monday 18 July. [An advertisement on page 2 of this issue carried the necessary information.]

It was resolved that the Mayor’s allowance for the year be £100. (Unchanged.)

The contribution of the Council to the Burra Hospital will be £410; the same as the previous year.

Council resolved to enforce the by-law concerning dogs and to employ a dog-catcher if the nuisance does not abate.

It was resolved that the previous assessment be adopted for the current year with the necessary adjustments.

Councillors will inspect the Mine site and select a suitable place for a new town dump.

89, 26, 12 July 1960, page 2

Advt. Burra Football Club Picnic at Redbanks on 17 July.

A football match will be played between Aberdeen and Kooringa.

Advt. Tenders are called for Land Sale or Leasing of 4591⁄2 acres freehold, comprising sections 177 & 2253 and a closed road in Hundred of Kooringa, 3 miles from Burra, disposed as three paddocks with a four room weatherboard house. K.R. Crewes, Burra.

Advt. There was a full page advertisement announcing a two in one sale.

The first sale in the showroom starts Friday 15 July.

The second sale starts on Tuesday 19 July and ends 23 July

This is in the premises at present occupied by Fred Pearce & Sons.

We have purchased the complete drapery and Men’s wear Stock of Sara & Co. of Burra North.

Free transport for both sales between the Royal Exchange Hotel corner and our store by Lehmann’s Bus – 8.45 a.m. and 1.15 p.m.

[Note that this event marked the end of trading by Sara’s. It is not otherwise reported.

The ‘We’ in the advertisement was Bence’s Ltd.]]

89, 26, 12 July 1960, page 10

Burra Women’s Branch of the LCL held its AGM on 1 July in the Town Hall. An address was given by Mrs K.C. Wilson OBE. Elected: President, Mrs R.B. Pitcher; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames A.L. Kellock, G.S. Hawker & J. Stevens; Secretary, Mrs J.W. Riggs and Treasurer, Miss E. Tiver.

89, 27, 19 July 1960, page 1

Golf. Burra won the A Grade Pennant at Saddleworth last Saturday for the Mid North Association. The B Grade team tied with Clare for 2nd behind Blyth.

Local History

So far only five persons have handed in their names as likely to attend a proposed conference in October on ‘Early Burra and Its History’. Please notify the Headmaster of the High School Mr M.W. Scriven by next Saturday 23 July. Thirty people are needed to make the conference worthwhile or it will be abandoned.

Burra Ambulance Fund donations are almost at £1,700.

Arbor Day at Burra Schools was held on Friday 1 July. Trees were planted in the school grounds.

[Three photos of the occasion.]

89, 27, 19 July 1960, page 2

Notice. Burra Burra District Council – Declaration of the Rate

General Rate 11⁄2d in the pound.

A differential rate of 1/- in the pound has been declared for the townships of Booborowie, Mt Bryan, Hanson and Farrell Flat. Minimum rate payment of 5/-.

At the picnic match at Redbanks last Sunday Aberdeen, led by Kevin Lane defeated Kooringa, led by Ian Allen, by a margin of 12 points. About 250 watched the game.

89, 27, 19 July 1960, page 5

Mt Bryan CWA concluded its 14th year with an AGM which elected: President, Mrs D. Thomas; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames Jefferies, Crew and O’Connor; Secretary, Mrs K. Schiller and Treasurer, Mrs C.H. Griffen.

[The President’s report runs to 3⁄4 column.]

89, 27, 19 July 1960, page 6

Bence’s Sale drew a record crowd. 155 cars at one time lined the main street. Only a portion of the crowd could be admitted at one time. Mr Len Bence reports a terrific volume of business, but says there will be plenty of bargains for the rest of the week. [Further half-page advertisement on page 7.]

The Badminton Season opened on Saturday 16 July. Burra North played Kadina in the Kooringa Methodist Hall. The result was an unexpected draw 8 sets 220 games each.

Ironmine Methodist Sunday School celebrated its 37th birthday on 15 July with a successful party.

89, 27, 19 July 1960, page 7

Weather-Season

Rainfall to date for 1960 is 1349 points. Most of the district has received about ten inches for the year and soils were getting very wet, but recent fine days and frosty nights have permitted some drying out to allow seeding operations. Crops have germinated well enough, though some areas are waterlogged and some early sown crops are infested with weeds. Pastures are generally looking well.

Obituary. Gertrude Blanche Goss was born in Burra on 4 May 1872, the eldest of six children of the late Mr & Mrs Isaac Goss. Her father was a carpenter and builder, who in the early days of Broken Hill Mines took his family there. Miss Goss was an organist at one of the Methodist Churches there and it was there she met and married the late Edgar Tiver of Burra in 1895. After marriage they settled at Oodla Wirra where Mr Tiver was a signaller for the SAR. Mrs Tiver was organist there at the little wood and iron Methodist Church, with her own little organ, which was carried into the church for the service and is still in her home at Hallett. Mr Tiver was the Sunday school superintendent and local preacher. In 1904 Mr & Mrs Tiver and their three eldest children moves to the Hallett District where she lived until last year when in February she moved to Adelaide in the face of advanced age and failing health. She died there peacefully on 10 June, leaving seven children, twenty-one grandchildren and twenty-five great grandchildren. Her husband had died 22 years earlier.

[Gertrude Blanche Goss born 4 May 1872 North Adelaide: died 10 June 1960 Kent Town, residence Hallett.]

89, 27, 19 July 1960, page 8

Burra Red Cross held its AGM on 12 July. Twenty members attended. Elected: President, Mrs H.J. Topsfield; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames R. Pitcher & E. Rooke; Secretary, Mrs N.P. Sieber and Treasurer, Mrs J.N. McBride.

Basketball. North Eastern Association

A Grade Hallett 27 defeated Spalding 13

Burra Comrades 39 defeated Mt Bryan 0

B Grade Spalding 15 defeated Hallett 9

Shell Company of Australia has installed a large underground tank at Booborowie, completing true bulk facilities for diesoline with their agents Dinham Bros.

89, 28, 26 July 1960, page 1

P.H. Quirke MP writes to advise that a greatly increased demand for water at Whyalla by BHP has occasioned a change of plans in the proposed duplication of the Morgan-Whyalla Pipeline. As a result preparatory work has temporarily been halted. An official statement will be issued shortly and nothing has yet been decided about any change in the role of the pipeline. Although people who expect to receive supply are naturally concerned Mr Quirke suggests that they wait for the official statement before taking any action.

The Wheat & Woolgrowers’ Association will hold a meeting at Booborowie on Monday 1 August to choose delegates for Mid North and Central Conferences and to discuss the pipeline situation.

Burra Rifle Club. Presentation Night and Annual Social. Trophy Winners:

89, 28, 26 July 1960, page 4

Football. North Eastern Association

A Grade Booborowie 10.10 defeated Burra 12.2

Hallett 17.13 defeated Leighton 5.8

Spalding 21.21 defeated Redlegs 4.4

89, 28, 26 July 1960, page 5

Obituary. Mrs E. Opperman was born on 24 December 1884 at Burra, a daughter of the late Mr & Mrs William Hardy. Both Mr & Mrs Opperman spent their entire lives in Burra. Mrs Opperman was an active member of the Red Cross and one of many who assisted greatly in the war years. She was a regular attendant at St Mary’s Church until stricken with a long illness. She is survived by Murray of Booleroo Centre, Ann Mrs Andrews of Adelaide, Lila Mrs Leedham of Burra and Rex of Burra. There are six grandchildren and four great grandchildren.

[Born Esther Hardy 24 December 1883 Kooringa: died 24 June 1960 Woodville, residence Burra. Married Albert Ernest Charlie Oppermann in 1904. The name was changed sometime to Opperman sometime after the birth of the last child in 1915.]

89, 28, 26 July 1960, page 6

Advt. Burra Pictures, 27 July

Robert Ryan, Virginia Mayo & Jeffrey Hunter in Proud Ones

Bill Williams, Lyn Thomas & Robert Ellis in Spacemaster X7

30 July

Juliette Greco in Whirlpool

Ronald Shine in Dry Rot

89, 28, 26 July 1960, page 7

Leighton Basketball & Football Ball drew a really large crowd on Friday 22 July. The Melodians’ Band supplied the music.

Obituary. Norman Horton Ford, eldest son of the late Mr & Mrs Francis H. Ford’s family of nine children, was born at Burra 19 October 1892. The family moved to Diprose Creek near Burra, which was the family home for many years and the home of Mr Norman Ford and his family for thirty years. Mr Ford enlisted for service in the Great War and served nearly three years overseas. He died at the Queen Elizabeth Hospital 6 June 1960. He leaves a widow and seven children (one deceased) [sic] and five grandchildren.

[Actually born 1891. There were eight children. One daughter died in 1948. The meaning of the last sentence therefore is unclear.]

89, 28, 26 July 1960, page 8

Burra North Red Cross had only eleven members at its recent AGM. Elected: President, Mrs Jennison; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames V. Cox & T. Wall; Secretary, Mrs E. Heinrich and Treasurer, Mrs S. Scroop.

Although the membership is 54 only about 25 are active and the average attendance at meetings is 15. During the year three members died: Mrs Gare (Patroness), Mrs Sara and Mrs Clode.

[Clara Ethel Gare died 24 August 1959 aged 85, Emma Price Sara died 31 August 1959 aged 94 and Ada Jane Clode died 25 February 1960 aged 63.]

£52-4-0 was sent to Headquarters for the March Appeal. We thank the Aberdeen Croquet Club for the use of the hall and facilities.

89, 29, 2 August 1960, page 1

Burra Rural Youth Debutante Ball drew a large crowd to the Burra Town Hall on Friday night despite an inch of rain and drenched roads. Twelve debutantes were presented to Sir Philip and Lady McBride. Door takings were £170. There was a pre-ball dinner at the Burra Hotel at which the debutantes presented gifts to the ladies who trained then. The Rural Youth Ball Committee, Executive and Advisory Members entertained the guests of honour at a pre-ball party at the Town Hall. [Details occupy c. 11⁄2 columns.]

The debutantes were:

Judith Byrne with John Irlam

Valda Edwards with Arthur Simpson

Kay Heinrich with Peter Sandercock

Beth Hempel with Richard Price

Lynette Kotz with John Kelly

Valda Michell with Ross Wood

Anne Opie with Gordon Neill

Janice Schwartz with Graham Woolford

Lorraine Schwartz with Roger Jones

Jill Stolte with Murray Stolte

Pamela Sutton with Alan Day

Margaret Willmott with Peter Murphy

Weather. Burra rainfall has now reached 15 inches for the year.

Burra Ambulance Fund has reached £1,735.

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club. Presentation Night was held in the RSL Hall last Saturday. Mrs Tom Ryan on the piano, Mr J. Brown on drums (relieved by Mr Dean Bernhardt) provided the music for dancing.

Mr R.G. Bernhardt made the presentations. Trophies were won by Mr & Mrs W. Barker, Mr & Mrs John Taylor, Alan Day, Robin Eberhard, Jim Brown and Gordon Webster.

P.H. Quirk MP writes following the Premier’s announcement about the duplication of the Morgan-Whyalla Pipeline. It is likely the new pipeline will follow the route of the original. The first route proposed would increase the cost of the large main by £3,000,000 and incur additional pumping costs of £75,000 p.a. Plans are being drawn up which will provide water to Burra and over the first proposed route to Booborowie. Pipelines like the one for Burra and Booborowie are built with extension in mind. Residents further north should waste no time in preparing a petition for water so that the pipeline is built to sufficient capacity to take future loading.

89, 29, 2 August 1960, page 4

Football. North Eastern Association

A Grade Hallett 14.14 defeated Burra 9.14

Booborowie 21.13 defeated Spalding 10.12

Leighton 17.4 defeated Redlegs 3.11

89, 30, 9 August 1960, page 1

‘Regular Sufferer’ writes urging Sir Thomas Playford to try the Burra-Hallett Road after his remarks on the laying of bitumen from Jamestown to Peterborough. The writer’s description is of a road full of potholes, corrugations and ‘dips’ caused by storms.

Rural Youth Debutante Ball. Photos of the debutantes and the Official Party.

The Booborowie Church of England Ball was a success on Friday night when nett proceeds were £86.

The Rabbit Population is at its lowest for many years.

Burra Rural Youth is celebrating its 7th birthday.

89, 30, 9 August 1960, page 2

Notice. Burra Burra DC

A Naturalization Ceremony will be held at Farrell Flat Institute on Monday 15 August for Adolf Karl Fritz Heitmann. Supper will follow arranged by the Farrell Flat CWA.

Football. North Eastern Association

A Grade Hallett 16.9 defeated Booborowie 13.16

Burra 15.11 defeated Redlegs 4.6

Spalding 21.20 defeated Leighton 3.4

89, 30, 9 August 1960, page 6

Harold Raymond and His Gloombusters recently visited Burra and Spalding in severely wintry conditions, nevertheless it was successful. Gross receipts at Burra amounted to £81-10-0, at Clare £66-17-11 and at Spalding £58-3-0. Nett proceeds will aid Townsend House, Brighton, Home and School for blind and deaf children.

Golf. The C Grade Club Championship has been won by Ern Zanker.

Advt. Burra Pictures, 10 August

Humphrey Bogart in Desperate Hours

Tony Perkins in Lonely Man

13 August

Gunfight at O.K. Corral

Plus Short Features

89, 30, 9 August 1960, page 8

Obituary. Mr & Mrs Rex Pickering had paused for a picnic during a Sunday drive when Mr Pickering suddenly collapsed. He was aged 42 and came to Burra when aged 17. He was instrumental in the opening of the local branch of Oates Ltd, with which firm he has been connected for 25 years. At his death he was a Director of the firm as well as the Branch Manager.

[Rex John Pickering born 14 June 1918 at Semaphore: died 7 August 1960 at Mongolata, residence Burra North.]

89, 31, 16 August 1960, page 1

Burra RSL Ball was held at the Burra Town Hall on 12 August, preceded by a pre-ball party at the RSL Hall hosted by Vice-President Mr E.C. Pietsch and Mrs Pietsch due to the ill health of President Mr G.J. Kelly and Mrs Kelly. Bad weather and appalling road conditions deterred some from attending.

Booborowie Church of England revived their annual ball after a five year lapse and it proved a great success on Friday 5 August. Nett proceeds were £86-12-6. [Three photographs.]

SAR has advised that it considers the present warning device at the Bon Accord railway crossing to be quite adequate.

Bence’s 3rd Annual Mannequin Parade will be held in Burra Town Hall next Thursday.

Farrell Flat Golf

A meeting was held on 1 August to consider re-opening the Farrell Flat Golf Course. A committee was formed to implement the decision to do so.

Burra Town Council has received advice from the Executors of the estate of the late Clare Ethel Gare of a legacy of £399-15-0 for improvements to the Burra Town Hall.

Theft. A safe containing c. £25 in cash and various papers was stolen from the Burra Motor Co. on Thursday night. The safe was recovered by police at Hanson on Sunday. Papers from the safe were found scattered over a wide area and the safe drawer was about two miles from Hanson on the Farrell Flat Road. The opened safe was found about a mile this side of Hanson on a side road. The rear door of Aldam’s garage was also forced, but the burglars found nothing worth taking.

Weather. Burra had a week of wind, hail and snow with falls recorded each day to a total of 134 points. Thursday was bitterly cold with a heavy fall of hail followed by a light fall of snow in Burra, but heavier falls between Mt Bryan and Hallett, especially on the hills. The afternoon temperature in Burra was 36°F. The Burra Creek ran strongly for the fourth time this season and flowed over the Pig and Whistle crossing for the first time in a number of years. [Photos of the Pig and Whistle crossing and the St Just Street Ford.]

Many district roads are impassable and the Burra-Hallett and the Hanson-Farrell Flat roads are damaged with washaways and potholes. The main road at Cobb & Co.’s Corner was submerged on Saturday morning and the Clare Farrell Flat road was also under water for some distance.

89, 31, 16 August 1960, page 2

Advt. Goldsbrough Mort & Co. Ltd has instructions from the Public Trustee in the Estate of the late N.H. Ford to auction 1451⁄2 acres of freehold at Diprose Creek on 30 August – being a portion of section 1 in the Hundred of Kooringa with a stone house of five rooms etc.

89, 31, 16 August 1960, page 3

Basketball

A Grade Rovers 30 defeated Hallett 21

Comrades defeated Spalding

Obituary. A Return Thanks Notice appears to refer to the death of the wife of C.B. Longford.

[Born Martha Emilie Beinke 20 December 1892, Walloway: died as Martha Amelia Longford 4 July 1960, Hallett. Married Charles Benjamin Longford in 1921.]

Weather. There are still patches of snow on Mt Bryan six days after the fall.

89, 31, 16 August 1960, page 8

Burra Burra DC, 1 August

A letter was received from the Town Council accepting the offer of the old depot property.

The Highways and Local Government Department advises that the Grant in Aid for 1960-61 is £378. (To be divided equally between three towns.)

Also advising that FRA Grants 1960-61 will be £3,900 with Council contribution to be £600.

The Main Road Grants will be £9,100 with a Council contribution of £500.

The Hospital Contributions for the year are to be Clare £36 and Burra £1,380.

89, 32, 23 August 1960, page 1

Golf. Burra’s Annual Open Day was held last Sunday. There was a record field of 96. The Open Championship was won by Horrie McKeough of Marrabel. The B Grade winner was Murray Odgers.

[More detailed results were printed on page 6.]

RSL Ball. Photo of the Belle of the Ball Miss Judith McDonald of Hallett and partner Barry Eberhard.

Photo of the judges.]

Bence’s 3rd Annual Mannequin Parade on Thursday 19 August in Burra Town Hall proved to be very popular. Proceeds will aid Burra and Burra North Red Cross.

Mr A.K.F. Heitmann’s naturalisation ceremony at Farrell Flat on 15 August was attended by about 200 people.

P.H. Quirke MP writes to ‘Regular Sufferer’ saying he is hopeful that this year some money will be available to improve the road north from Burra.

Wayne Dodds has been appointed as Officer in Charge of the Livestock Section of Oates Ltd at Burra.

Hallett 18.14 defeated Spalding 14.10

Burra 22.15 defeated Leighton 4.5

With the completion of the minor rounds, Barry Eberhard has won the goal kicking trophy for the second year in succession.

Best marksmen were H. Byles, R. Francis and W. Barker. The same three names were in the same order for the handicap contest.

Marcia Fay Terry, elder daughter of Mr & Mrs J. Terry of Burra, married

[Details in 2⁄3 column and photo.]

Burra Benevolent Society held its AGM recently. Officers were re-elected: President, Rev. T.G. Drought; Secretary, Mrs H.J.B. Jennison and Treasurer, Mr F. Atkin.

89, 33, 30 August 1960, page 1

Burra Hospital

The annual report showed the Board managed to balance its budget for 1959-60 despite two pay rises, increasing commodity costs and a drop of 750 occupied bed days, when it was read at the meeting in Burra Town Hall on Monday 23 August.

Ratepayers contributed on the following basis:

Burra Town Council £410

Burra Burra District Council £1,380

Hallett District Council £340

Robertstown District Council £190

Chairman A.D. Radford said the fall in patient numbers meant a fall in revenue of £2,250. Salaries and wages account for more than 50% of expenses. The scatter of hospital buildings means more domestic staff are required. Fees were raised in March, which will benefit the coming year. Fluorescent lighting was installed in the Men’s and Women’s Wards, which considerably brightened up the wards and recently the hospital and Sisters’ quarters were treated for termite extermination at a cost of £150.

Lawns have been sown in front of the Wing and the Nurses and Sisters’ Home and about 30 trees planted.

[Presumably ‘Wing’ refers to the Maternity Wing.]

The Women’s Organisations have again been active and have handed over £550. This assisted in renovations to the Sisters’ Quarters at a cost of £1,200 – for which Government subsidy has been promised.

The Hospital Auxiliary has also rendered valuable service, especially in repairing bed linen etc.

Since the close of the financial year the hospital has received a bequest of £399-15-0 from the estate of [the late Mrs Clare Ethel Gare]. This will be devoted to capital improvements and so attract a two for one subsidy.

Bence’s Mannequin Parade. Seven small photographs.

Burra Footballers Variety Concert on Friday 26 August produced takings of £90. [Mr Orchard recited Max Fatchen’s poem The Burra-Hallett Road. The items are detailed in a report of just over 1 column.]

89, 33, 30 August 1960, pages 1 & 8

Golf. The B Grade Championship has been won by Laurie Anderson.

89, 33, 30 August 1960, page 2

Advt. Burra Pictures, 31 August

Robert Mitchum & Robert Wagner in The Hunters

Jefi Morrow & Colleen Gray in Copper Sky

3 September

89, 33, 30 August 1960, page 3

Booborowie Catholic Ladies Guild Ball on Friday 19 August was very well attended and a nett profit of £31 was made for St Dymphna’s Church.

Burra Ambulance Fund donations have reached £1,768-1-6.

Football. North Eastern Association First Semi-Final

A Grade Hallett 12.9 defeated Spalding 9.10

P.H .Quirke MP writes regarding plans to extend electricity supplies over the northern part of his electorate by the single wire earth return system. (SWER)

A 33,000 V line from Jamestown to Whyte Yarcowie and Terowie is needed to serve the area north and south of such a line. Country to the east of the Hundred of Anne is receiving supply from SWER lines radiating from the Burra system.

The Hundred on Mannanarie and part of the Hundred of Belalie north of Jamestown will be supplied from Caltowie – operations are expected to begin in March 1965. Yongala could be supplied from this source.

The Hundred of Belalie south of Jamestown should get a service scheduled in October 1964 together with part of the Hundred of Reynolds.

Spalding stages 1 & 2 are due for commencement in 1963 with stage 3 to follow.

The Hundred of Ayers has three areas. The Burra-Hallett scheme supplies the east and south areas and is due for completion this year.

Booborowie will serve two groups north and south of the town, scheduled for 1963 and 1964 respectively. ETSA is currently investigating how best to provide the Hundreds of Whyte, Anne and Terowie and an answer is expected in about three months.

89, 34, 6 September 1960, page 4

Football. North Eastern Association Second Semi-Final

Booborowie 11.18 defeated Burra 9.11

Best and Fairest Player 1960 and winner of the Mail Medal is Don Lloyd, Captain of the Leighton Football Team.

High Schools

The Education Department has acquired land at Clare for anew High School on 20 acres.

Burra High School has 120 students with an estimate of 130 next year.

An area of land for a new High School has been referred to the Public Buildings Department for investigation. It would then be referred to the Land Board and then Cabinet for purchase approval, after which consideration would be given to the provision of a new school.

Burra Rifle Club held a shoot in wet and windy conditions on Saturday. Best marksmen were Gordon Webster, J. Brown and R. Francis. On handicap the leaders were J. Brown, G. Webster and W. Hempel.

Burra Bowling Club held its AGM and elected: Patron, E. Finch; President, S. Woollacott; Vice-Presidents, D. Jacka & H .Foote; Secretary, J.B. Topsfield and Assistant Secretary, M. Scriven.

89, 34, 6 September 1960, page 5

Aberdeen Tennis Club held its AGM 1 September. It was resolved to enter A & B teams for the next season.

Elected: Patron, F.H. Reed; President, Lloyd Turner; Secretary, S. Scroop and Treasurer, Mrs S. Scroop.

No. 1 court will be re-topped this year.

Kooringa Tennis Club held its AGM 31 August and elected a new secretary, Miss Raelene Edwards. Other officers were re-elected.

Tennis. AGMs are reported for tennis clubs at Booborowie, Hallett, Leighton, Mt Bryan, Spalding and Willalo.

89, 34, 6 September 1960, page 6

Burra Town Council, August

The Mayor reported visiting the Mine Area, the Caravan Park and the Swimming Pool with Mr Pollnitz of the Government Tourist Bureau with Councillors Cornelius and Finch and the Town Clerk. Mr Pollnitz suggested asking the RAA to send an officer to devise a long term plan for the Caravan Park. Mine access roads need grading and shafts need to be made safe.

It was resolved that Johnny Green be moved and consideration be given to relocation at a suitable site in the Mine Area.

A general rate of 47d in the pound was declared with a differential rate of 35d in the pound for assessments 89, 326, 568 and 577.

In the event of school crossing lights being approved the Council will support this to £50.

The Corporation will pay £50 rent for the Town Hall this year.

A price will be obtained for cyclone mesh and posts to make shafts at the Mine safer. Up to £200 was approved for a ramp at the Mine entrance and road grading by the Burra Burra DC.

89, 34, 6 September 1960, page 8

Basketball. North Eastern Association First Semi-Final

Hallett 9 defeated Spalding 8

Rovers 26 defeated Comrades 24

89, 35, 13 September 1960, page 1

Burra Burra DC is seeking details from all landowners about horehound infestation. Over the past two years adjoining councils have attempted to reduce the incidence of horehound seed on roadsides and it is intended to carry this work on throughout the Burra Burra DC area. Later eradication will be extended to the whole area.

Burra CWA Street Stall raised £43 on Friday 2 September.

Burra Rifle Club. At the Dean Range last weekend Port Adelaide 593 defeated Burra 575.

‘Burra-ite’ writes wondering why the fact that there is a bitumen road now between Adelaide and Burra is not better publicised. In the past few months many people, including some members of Government Departments have come to Burra via Black Springs, apparently unaware that the sealed road exists. Signage is also a problem. At the southern entrance to the town the sign to Adelaide still points to Black Springs and on the new road near Brown’s the sign points to Broken Hill via Burra North so that traffic bypasses Burra.

Football. The runner-up in the Mail Medal was P. Sullivan of Booborowie who consequently gets the Record Trophy for 1960.

Marriage. Kooringa Methodist Church, Saturday 3 September

Deidre Snell of Booborowie married Robert Ashby. [Photo.]

Weather. Last week general rains of 3⁄4 inch to 1 inch fell across the eastern pastoral region and further rain is falling today.

89, 35, 13 September 1960, page 8

Burra Bowls Associates AGM elected: President, Mrs S.A. Pearce; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames E. Pietsch & H. Pearse; Secretary, Mrs C. Haythorpe; Assistant Secretary, Mrs L. Phillips and Treasurer, Mrs R. Sandercock.

The Croquet Club donated £5-10-8 to the Associates.

89, 36, 20 September 1960, page 1

Accident. Cheryl Anne Paynter fell from a moving car between Hanson and Burra on Sunday. Cheryl was 10 yesterday and spent her birthday in Burra Hospital with a fractured skull and abrasions. She was a passenger in a car driven by Theodore Paynter of Oaklands. It is thought the door flew open when the car hit a bump. Her condition yesterday was satisfactory.

Burra Rural Youth & St Joseph’s Church will give a farewell on 27 September in the RSL Hall to Pauline Williams and the J. O’Sullivan Family. Pauline has worked at the Burra Record for six years and will leave to take up nursing at Mr Gambier early in October. Mr & Mrs J. O’Sullivan will leave the district to take up land in WA.

Miss SA will, it is hoped, attend the Hallett Buffalo Lodge Ball on 11 November.

The River Murray is expected to peak in mid-October. The low sections of the Kingston Ferry approach and at Barmera are being banked to hold back at least a foot of water.

Mrs A. Carpenter will be 93 on 8 November. Photographed with Marlene Carpenter (19) and fiancé Mr Keith Graetz, who held an engagement party at Burra Hotel 3 September.

[Mrs Augusta Carpenter nee Hirschausen was actually 92 on 8 November 1960. She was born at Millerton (Burra) in 1868 and died 18 April 1962 aged 93.]

89, 36, 20 September 1960, pages 1 & 4

Football. North Eastern Association Grand Final

Rain made the ground a little heavy and slippery in patches and a strong wind favoured the northeast pocket. About 700 spectators saw the opening bounce at Spalding Oval.

Burra 7.4 defeated Booborowie 2.1

Mr Geoff Bannon, manager of the Bank of Adelaide at Booborowie, has been transferred to Blyth after two years, effective from 19 October. He will be replaced by Mr R.W. Gaskmier.

89, 36, 20 September 1960, pages 7 & 10

Burra Burra DC, September

It was resolved to apply for a loan of £2,500 repayable over ten years to allow the sealing of 3rd and 6th Streets in Booborowie.

89, 37, 27 September 1960, page 1

Burra Racing Club. The Cup meeting will be held on 5 October. The cup is valued at 300 guineas. Mr R.M. (Dick) Reed has been made a life member.

Burra Golf Club. The closing day for the season last Saturday was spoilt by rain and wind and only eleven members attended and most of those stayed in the clubhouse. President Dr L. Miller presented the Championship Trophy to Ern Zanker.

Weather. Boisterous conditions at the weekend brought 67 points to bring the September total to 312 and the year’s total to 2012 points.

The Kooringa Methodist Sunday School will celebrate its centenary on 2 October.

Hallett Red Cross Annual Flower Show on 23 September drew excellent entries and netted £90.

Burra & District Ambulance Association has a relatively meagre membership of 381. Donations have now reached £1,779-1-6.

89, 37, 27 September 1960, page 2

Advt. Dalgety & Co. Ltd have instructions from the Administrators of the Estate of the late G.B. Morgan to sell land of 96 acres 21 perches with two houses.

Land in the Hundred of Kooringa; closed road of 3 roods 23 perches and part Section 1 of 6 acres 19 perches and allotment M of 4 acres 19 perches.

2a. Land in Hundred of Kooringa; part Block 3 of Section 1 & other land containing 43 acres.

2b. Land in Hundred of Kooringa; part Block 2 of Section 1 & other land containing 21 acres and 1 rood.

3a. Land in Hundred of Kooringa being allotment 202 of 3 roods 14 perches; allotment 203 of 1 acre 1 rood 27 perches; allotment 205 of 3 roods 18 perches; part allotment 204 of 3 roods 16 perches.

3b. Land in the Township of Burra of a closed road of 2 roods 32 perches.

  1. Land in Hundred of Kooringa being a portion of Section 1 of 15 acres 3 roods 32 perches.

  2. Land in Hundred of Kooringa being allotments 4 & 48 laid out as Millerton.

  3. Land in Hundred of Kooringa in the Township of Burra being a portion of Section 104 of 20 perches.

  4. Land in Hundred of Kooringa being apportion of allotment 125 of Part Section 1 with a cottage thereon.

89, 37, 27 September 1960, page 8

Burra Town Council, September

It was recommended that the Gare Legacy of £399-15-0 be spent on beautification of the stage of the Town Hall.

Recommended that a further 100 seats be purchased at a cost of £624 – similar to those recently obtained.

89, 38, 4 October 1960, page 1

Mrs Geo. Hanlin of ‘Ingleside’ Willalo will be 90 on 8 October. Miss Alice Collins of Lucerne Downs North Booborowie is a sister and Mr Arthur Collins of Adelaide is a brother. She is a daughter of the late Mr Henry Collins of Lucerndale, one of Mt Bryan’s early pioneers.

Pauline Williams and the O’Sullivan Family were farewelled on Thursday at an evening arranged by Burra Rural Youth and the Catholic Church Committee. Presentations were made and dancing was enjoyed to music by Ashley Woodgate and Barry Allen.

The Planned Local History Conference has been cancelled due to the illness of the main speaker. Mr Bitmead said it was not possible to find a replacement at short notice. The conference could now take place in the first half of 1961.

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club will begin its first Trophy Shoot tonight. Last week’s best scorers were W. Barker, R. Kellock and J. Brown.

Burra Races will be held tomorrow. [Entrants are listed.]

Redbanks Sports Day on 5 November will feature a number of Go Karts – the latest speed craze to hit SA.

A licence has been granted for a publican’s booth and some youngsters have started making ‘guys’ to be judged prior to the fireworks at night. The bird for the rooster chase is being well fed and kept up with good exercise work each week.

J. Carpenter, Honorary State Secretary of the Totally and Permanently Disabled Soldiers Association, appeals for support for their Badge Day in Burra on 7 October.

Burra Bowling Green has been prepared for next Saturday week’s opening. Lal Kellaway has concreted the area in front of the Clubhouse and the entrance path has been paved and the western bank remodelled.

89, 38, 4 October 1960, page 2

Advt. Elder, Smith & Co. Ltd have instructions from Mrs J.R. Phillips (who is leaving the district) to conduct a sale of 602 acres of freehold land at Hanson in the RSL Hall At Burra on 25 October. The land comprises Section 69 in the Hundred of Hanson and lies 8 miles southwest of Burra and 3 miles west of Hanson.

Advt. Elder, Smith & Co. Ltd & Goldsbrough Mort & Co. Ltd have instructions from J. & A.L. Kellock for the sale of ‘Wyoming’, 15,332 acres of Crown Perpetual Lease at the RSL Hall in Burra on 25 October.

Comprising Block 80 County of Burra of 14,370 acres

Sections 26, 27 & 86SE Hundred of Tomkinson of 962 acres 2 roods, of seven sheep-proof paddocks, 8 dams, 4 room G.I. cottage and shearing shed etc. [89, 40, 18 October 1960, page 2 adds that the property has been in the Kellock Family for 60 years.]

Advt. Elder, Smith & Co. Ltd have instructions from L.H. Thomas & Co. to sell ‘Springbank’ comprising 708 acres freehold located 31⁄2 miles southeast of Burra at Burra RSL Hall on 14 October.

The property comprises Sections 172, 173, 174 & 184 in the Hundred of Kooringa, with a solid stone house of four rooms and enclosed verandah with 32v lighting plant, telephone etc.

Advt. Elder, Smith & Co. Ltd has instructions from Mr Reg. Warnes to offer for sale 130 acres freehold at the RSL Hall at Burra on 14 October. The land comprises Block 6 Hundred of Kooringa of 130 acres 2 roods in close proximity to the Burra Township.

89, 38, 4 October 1960, page 3

Notice. A naturalisation ceremony will be held at Burra Town Hall on Monday 17 October at 8 p.m. for Mr & Mrs H. Gizi.

A Red Cross Mannequin Parade was held at Spalding on 23 September. As well as the parade Mrs Longmire and Miss C. Handcock played a piano duet and Mrs Satchell sang a bracket of numbers. Takings were c. £30.

89, 38, 4 October 1960, page 8

Burra North Red Cross Children’s Frolic

[Prize list is printed.]

89, 39, 11 October 1960, page 1

[Note: the sequence of pages in the bound hard copy was strangely disordered. The page numbering in these notes follows that of the microfilm version.]

Notice. The land sales due to be held in the RSL Hall on 14 October have been transferred to Burra Town Hall Supper Room.

Burra Races last Wednesday had to contend with wind and patchy rain, but nevertheless had a crowd of c. 1,500. Twenty-two bookmakers attended. The club expects to make a small profit. [Results are printed.]

The Burra Cup was won by Tod Star ridden by Raven.

There were two minor accidents. In the First Maiden Woolyarn fell, but the jockey, Nadels, escaped injury and in the Improvers the jockey J. Letts had his leg jammed against the barrier stalls by Canunda and had to withdraw, being replaced by A. Alma.

89, 39, 11 October 1960, pages 1 & 4

The Burra Show was held on Saturday last. The day began with windy conditions, but improved. Gate Takings were up and entries were on a par with previous records. The wool show was the most outstanding ever. Official guests included the Hon. D.N. Brookman & Mrs Brookman, Sir Lyell & Lady McEwin and Mr & Mrs P.H. Quirke.

The new Wool Pavilion displayed 116 fleeces.

Mr Brookman opened the show. [His speech is reported.]

Mr Brookman also cut a large ribbon to open the new Wool Pavilion and was presented with a key donated by Mr R. Fuss, to serve as a memento of the occasion.

The Burra Rural Youth Club greatly aided the show; firstly by providing and arranging a display of rural products in the lower pavilion and secondly by providing stewards for most sections of the show.

The club also arranged the Sheep Judging Competition and at night ran a successful dance in the Main Hall, which added £38 to the Society’s funds. During the year the club raises funds for the Show Society and assists in the maintenance of buildings etc.

[Results are printed on pages 1 & 4.

Personal interest. R. Fuss donated the trophy for the greatest number of staged exhibits in the Flower Section. He is also listed as one of the winners in the Flower Section – details of which are not printed.]

89, 39, 11 October 1960, page 2

Advt. Dalgety’s & Co. Ltd will offer 20,000 sheep and lambs in their off shears sale on 26 October. (Elder’s Yards.)

Advt. Elder, Smith & Co. Ltd. Land Sales RSL Hall Burra, 25 October.

For H.L. Riggs: allotments 254 & 255 laid out as Burra and Part Block 1 containing in all 52 acres 10 perches.

[The eastern end of Jaffney Street Kooringa and land to the east.]

For V.A.W. Riggs: Blocks 29 & 32, portion of Section 1Hundred of Kooringa containing 59 acres 3 roods 10 perches, with town water supply and in close proximity to the township.

89, 39, 11 October 1960, page 10 [Misnumbered 8]

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club. First Stage of Group 1 Trophy Shoot.

89, 40, 18 October 1960, page 1

[Note: the sequence of pages in the bound hard copy was strangely disordered. The page numbering in these notes follows that of the microfilm version.]

Bowling Season Opens. About 100 people including some 60 bowlers attended the opening of the new season by Mr J.M. Gebhardt near the Marston Memorial Entrance. The opening marks the 40th anniversary of the Burra Bowling Club and it was thus appropriate that the son of the Club’s first President (Mr Albert Gebhardt) should have accepted the invitation to open the new season.

The Associate’s President Mrs Syd Pearce rolled the first kitty and Club Patron Mr Eddie Finch delivered the first bowl and Mrs Baulderstone raised the Club Pennant.

Burra Mayor E.T. Baulderstone announces an appeal to raise £200 for the purchase and installation of traffic lights to protect the children’s crossing between the Town Hall and the new footbridge.

J. Carpenter on behalf of the TPI Association thanks Burra for raising £96-12-3 from their badge day, plus £2-2-0 from H.B. Riggs.

Burra Amateur Swimming Club

Burra can be proud of its swimming pool, officially opened last January; four years after a small band of enthusiasts were told it was impossible. However, the apathy displayed towards the AGM called for last Thursday suggests it may not take the next step to form a swimming club to promote swimming and diving, conduct carnivals and assist with the running of the pool so that it does not become the liability the Mayor was so anxious to avoid on the night of the public meeting of 2 March 1956. The public is urged to attend the meeting now called for Monday 31 October to form a Swimming Club in Burra.

The Annual Catholic Fete was a most successful function with the financial results expected to eclipse previous years.

The Saddleworth Show last weekend was successful with some 2,200 attending.

Burra Rifle Club on Saturday fired the postponed match versus Eudunda. Burra won the both the marksman’s contest and the handicap section.

Off the Rifle With Handicap

Burra 579 635

Eudunda 537 615

Morgan Races will be held tomorrow.

Basketball. Burra Rovers and Burra Comrades Clubs have set about raising £200 for the completion of electrically lit courts before the next season opens.

89, 40, 18 October 1960, page 3

Advt. Dalgety & Co. have orders from Mr J.O. Pearce to sell his property 5 miles west of Whyte Yarcowie.

[Details in 3⁄4 column.]

[Details in 11⁄4 columns.]

Advt. Sports, Barbecue and Fireworks at Redbanks Picnic Ground 5 November.

89, 40, 18 October 1960, page 4 [Misnumbered 9]

Burra & District War Memorial Committee held its AGM on 26 September.

D. Halliday gave the President’s Report.

Last year in conjunction with the Burra Football Club the Committee decided to build new dressing rooms with better amenities. The first stage has been completed. This year the second stage was completed. The first step was the erection of the verandah by F.M .Pearce & Sons and Don Halliday at a cost of c. £88. The Football Club financed the concrete floors, repairs to walls and the installation of an 80 gallon hot water unit, showers and seating. Work was carried out by Messrs James, Parker, Halliday and Hirschausen to the extent of £219. During the year frames were made and fitted as protection for the lower windows. E. Finch donated the required bird netting and R. Fuss carried out the work gratis. Water pressure improved when E & WS laid a new main from Paxton Street [sic: for Terrace] to the corner of the oval. A one inch polythene water pipe was laid across the oval to connect with this, so making provision for the watering of the oval. Mr E. Baulderstone experimented with watering and showed that two or more sprinklers can now be used successfully. A new scoreboard was erected.

[Of which details are given.]

Elected were: President, D.A. Halliday; Senior Vice-President, P.J. Byrnes [sic: for Byrne]; Secretary, H.E. Kowald and Treasurer, M.W. Scriven.

[Financial statement printed.]

89, 40, 18 October 1960, page 5 [Misnumbered 9]

Redbanks Sports Day

[This report offered the first indication that the event was organised by the Small Bore Rifle Club.]

Have you ever been to Redbanks Picnic Grounds c. 10 miles east of Burra?

The Baldina Creek runs past the grounds on the south side.

The grounds are ideal for sports and barbecues.

Kookaburras are numerous and the clear running water adds to the beauty of the scene.

In the first season of the Small bore Club the purchase of the Old Drill Hall by the PMG Department forced them to remove all club gear and erect a suitable clubhouse on the range itself. The club had and still has no funds and this activity was only possible through several persons being prepared to act as guarantors at the bank.

The [range] area has been beautified by working bees.

It is with a view to raising some money that this sports day etc. has been organised for 5 November.

Among the attractions it has been arranged for several go-karts to be present and for demonstrations of powered model aircraft. There will be a publican’s booth and an ice cream and cool drinks stall. Fireworks will be on sale for those wishing to join in the evening.

89, 40, 18 October 1960, page 12 [Misnumbered 8]

F.M. Jefferies writes a sarcastic letter thanking the driver who forgeot to take the turn at the south end of Mt Bryan Main Street last week and thereby saved him the trouble of grubbing out three large bushes in his hedge.

89, 41, 25 October 1960, page 1

[Note: the sequence of pages in the bound hard copy was strangely disordered. The page numbering in these notes follows that of the microfilm version.]

Burra Show

At the opening of the 86th Burra Show on 8 October the Hon. D.N. Brookman Minister for Agriculture also opened the new Wool Pavilion.

[The 1960Show was actually the 68th Show not the 86th. The mistake arises from not deducting the years in which no show was held.]

There is no doubt the Show received a boost from the excellent wool and sheep sections. The ability to house wool exhibits in the one pavilion helped the presentation of the other sections.

The Show Committee wish to extend their thanks to all who contributed to the success of the venture. Many weeks of patient work on the part of Mr Fuss and members who helped him, together with the capable urging of Mr Herb. Riggs and his committee were well rewarded.

Local stores in the town contributed with the display of wool and wool products in their windows.

[Photos:

Opening of the Wool Pavilion.

Messrs D.N. Brookman, Rex Warnes & P.H. Quirke at the fleece display.

Champion Fleece of the show.

Burra Rural Youth Display in the Produce Pavilion.]

A Deputation led by Mr P.H. Quirke MP with members of the Hallett and Burra Burra District Councils waited on the Minister for Roads on 14 October re the highway north of Burra, which has been considerably damaged by winter conditions. The Minister is considering the matter, but has already made a grant for the Burra Burra DC to construct two cement spoon drains and two culverts on the worst creeks between Mt Bryan and Burra.

Burra Rural Youth

Gerald Wood won the Sheep Judging Contest at the Burra Show and Rex Stockman was second.

The Burra Rural Youth Dance raised £38 for the Show Society.

A visit to Roseworthy College was arranged for 20 members on 15 October, travelling by bus.

22,650

Burra Town Council, 3 October

It was resolved to launch an appeal for £200 for flashing lights at the school crossing adjacent to the Town Hall.

It was decided not to lease land at the rear of the old mill and Fairchild Park to D.M. Carpenter.

Marriage. Kadina Methodist Church recently

Maxine Ruth Brown, eldest daughter of Mr & Mrs Allan Brown of Kadina, married

Francis Alexander Fillmore (Joe), elder son of Mr & the late Mrs F.A. Fillmore of Burra.

His brother ‘Tony’ was best man. The couple will live at Amberley Queensland where the bridegroom has an RAAF posting.

89, 42, 1 November 1960, page 1

Lawn Tennis. The season opened on Saturday.

President John Hammer declared it open. Mr Lindsay Thomas has been declared a life member.

The Catholic Ball at the Burra Town Hall on Friday last did not draw a particularly large crowd, but was quite successful with door takings of £82. Daphne Wenham’s four-piece band supplied the music and Mr Eugene Madigan was MC.

Cricket. Mokota Association

North Booborowie 172 defeated Leighton 61 & 75.

Land Auctions

‘Wyoming’ was passed in at 33/6 per acre, but subsequently sold for an undisclosed figure.

J.R. Phillips’ Hanson property of 602 acres freehold was passed in at £25-10-0 per acre.

H.L. Riggs’ Burra property of 52 acres was passed in at £16-10-0 per acre.

V.A.W. Riggs’ Burra property of 59 acres 3 roods was passed in at £20 per acre.

All were privately sold later at undisclosed prices.

The Burra Masonic Lodge installed Bro. T.R. Norman as Worshipful Master. During the ceremony the ladies were entertained in the RSL Hall by Mesdames Jim Riggs and Darrel Field. A ball in the Town Hall followed. The Hall was decorated by Mrs Herb Riggs and Mr Tom Perry.

Mt Bryan School Welfare Club catered for the supper.

Basketball. North Eastern Association Premiers.

[Photo of the Burra Comrades Team.]

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club. Last weeks best scorers were M. Thomas, A. Angel and R. Gilbert.

Burra Golf Associates held their AGM and elected: Patroness, Mrs A.L. Collins; President, Mrs Jim Riggs; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames D. Field & H. Topsfield and Secretary-Treasurer, Miss E. Tiver.

The Secretary reported on a successful year with entries on open day up on previous years, improvements to the clubhouse facilities. Portagas was installed.

89, 42, 1 November 1960, page 6

Advt. Burra Pictures, 2 November

Susan Hayward & Kirk Douglas in Their Secret Affair

Plus Animal World

5 November

Debbie Reynolds, Tony Randall & Paul Douglas in The Mating Game

John Cassavettes, Sydney Poitier & Kathleen Maguire in A Man is Ten Feet Tall

89, 43, 8 November 1960, page 1

Burra Amateur Swimming Club was formed at a meeting of about 30 people on 31 October. It was decided to disband the Burra & District Swimming Pool Committee and form the Burra & District Amateur Swimming Club. H.J. Topsfield was elected first President. The Swimming Pool Committee had a credit balance of £355.

Also elected were: Patron, G. Stanley Hawker; Vice-President, A.L. Beinke; Secretary, Allan Ireland and Treasurer, K. Hicks.

The Club will apply for affiliation with the SA Amateur Swimming Association.

A minute of appreciation was recorded for the untiring efforts of the Secretary and Treasurer of the Swimming Pool Committee Mr Ted Orchard.

The report of the Swimming Pool Committee said:

The pool was officially opened by Mr G. Stanley Hawker 31 January 1960.

Voluntary hours given to the completion of the pool were 1,154.

The formation of a swimming club affiliated with the Amateur Swimming Association would allow swimmers’ times to be recognised and would stimulate competitive swimming.

Special tribute must be paid to Mr R.G. Jeffery for his untiring effort in the initial stages of the construction of the pool and to Mr Ted Orchard for his efficiency as Secretary-Treasurer.

Snakes are quite prevalent at present.

Tennis. Burra Association.

A Grade Aberdeen 13-109 defeated Kooringa 7-85

Spalding 13 defeated Mt Bryan 7

B Grade Spalding Red 14 defeated Mt Bryan 6

Spalding Blue 17 defeated Ironmine 3

Photo: R.G. Bernhardt presents trophies to representatives of the Burra Rovers Basketball Team: M. Scriven, D. Broderick and P. Partridge.

Kooringa Methodist Fete was held on Friday in the RSL Hall and raised about £200. It was opened at 2.30 p.m. by Mrs R. Jenner. [Stall details are printed.]

[Born Emma Blanche Lawrence 14 January 1864, Adelaide: died 21 August 1960, Burra, Residence Prospect. Married William Tavender in 1886, though the Marriages CD has wrongly transcribed the name as Lavender.]

89, 43, 8 November 1960, page 8

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club. In the first stage of the Championship best scorers were W. Barker, P. Hann & A. Day.

89, 44, 15 November 1960, page 1

Weather. Last Friday and Saturday saw heavy showers bringing 157 points at Burra to bring the yearly total to 2,208 points.

Booborowie has recorded 2218 points, Hallett 2026, Mt Bryan 2012 and Farrell Flat 2344.

Falls to the east in the week ranged from 39 at Oakvale to 89 at Farella, with many falls in the 70s.

Camera Club. A preliminary meeting has been called to discuss the possibility of forming a camera club at Burra. The meeting will be at the home of Mr F.G. McGrath at Burra North 24 November.

Accident. At cricket at Burra Oval on Saturday Jim Richards of Burra and R. Keany of Koonoona collided while attempting to take a catch. After examination by Dr L.G. Miller Jim was transferred to the RAH suffering from a broken nose, and a fractured cheek and jawbone.

89, 44, 15 November 1960, pages 1 & 6

Bowls. Most greens were washed out on Saturday

Burra Blue 101 defeated Spalding 78 at Spalding.

Helen Hogan married Ken Bruce. [Photo.]

[Born Mabel Jane Bagg 16 May 1880 Hundred of Baldina: died 3 October 1960 Burra. Married Richard Bruce 1917.]

Advt. Oates Ltd has instructions from Mrs Jeanne Pickering of The Crescent, Burra North, to conduct a household clearing sale on Friday 25 November.

89, 44, 15 November 1960, page 3

Burra Rifle Club. In wet and blustery conditions ten shooters turned out and the best scorers off the rifle were J. Brown, W. Barker and H. Byles. With handicap it was J. Brown, K. Williams and W. Barker.

89, 44, 15 November 1960, page 4

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club

The Redbanks Show cleared £75 for the club. The windy conditions raised so much dust, despite the application of hundreds of gallons of water that the go-kart demonstration had to be called off with only one kart making a few laps. [The sports results are printed.]

On Tuesday’s shoot the best scorers over 75 yards were M. Thomas, J. Brown and R. Kellock.

On Sunday a team’s shoot at Morgan with Renmark, Riverton and Morgan was fired over 25, 50, 75 and 100 yards. Aggregate results: Morgan 2142

Riverton 2076

Burra 2043

Renmark 1560

Burra Club is preparing for the official opening of the range by Mr E.T. Baulderstone on 3 December.

Burra Association

Koonoona 147 defeated Buffs 101

89, 46, 22 November 1960, page 1 [There was no issue numbered 45.]

Leighton School Welfare Club raised c. £21 from a Children’s Frolic on 11 November. [Prize winners are listed.]

Burra Ambulance has now covered 2,500 business miles, carrying mainly non-members.

Weather. Burra had more rain this week, totalling 32 points to bring the annual total to 2241.

Some falls of about 50 points are reported from the east.

The Bridge near the Bowling Green across the Burra Creek has been closed until repairs can be effected.

Football. North Eastern Association Premiers. Photo of the Burra Team on the Town Hall Steps.

89, 46, 22 November 1960, page 4

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club.

At the practice shoot on Tuesday the best scores were from W. Barker, J. Brown and W. Corner.

Work on the 100 yard mound continues. This will complete the major construction work on the range.

89, 46, 22 November 1960, page 8

Booborowie CWA held its International Day on 10 November. Mrs W. Brown of Burra played an overture and Mrs Satchell of Burra performed a bracket of Scottish Songs before Mrs Crawley of Watervale gave an address on Scotland.

89, 47, 29 November 1960, page 1

Redruth Methodist Ladies Guild organised a Fete, Public Tea and Concert on Saturday and raised £240.

Tennis. Burra Association

A Grade Aberdeen 12 defeated Willalo 8

Burra Town Council has made a further application to the Highways Department for a grant to complete the Smelts Road Bridge. The bridge, which has been open to traffic for some weeks, at present carries an overpayment on work already carried out of £600.

Hallett CWA Held its International Day meeting on 22 November. Miss Parker spoke on Scotland.

Football. Photo of Burra footballers practising for their concert tonight.

Burra Forresters’ Lodge (Court Unity) held a meeting on Friday in the Masonic Hall and discussed the disposal of surplus funds without reaching any conclusion.

A Camera Club was founded at a meeting called by Sergeant McGrath of Burra North. Elected: President, Rev. Jenner; Vice-Presidents, F. McGrath & R. Sandercock; Secretary, D. Sleader.

Burra Show Society. Mr R. Fuss is presently completing improvements to the Agricultural Pavilion at the Showgrounds. Additional skylights are to be placed in the Wool Pavilion.

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club

Mrs Barbara Pain of Adelaide has accepted an invitation to attend the official opening of the range. She has recently won the State Championship at Pt Pirie and will bring a number of experienced shooters with her.

Mr R. Fuss has recently offered to make two complete sets of target frames. They will be in operation for tonight’s shoot over double 25 yards.

Best at Last Tuesday’s shoot were W. Corner, R. Gilbert and R. Kellock.

Burra Pictures. Wednesday night audiences have been poor for some time. After a meeting on Tuesday night it was decided to continue Wednesday screenings until next March when the position would be reviewed.

89, 47, 29 November 1960, page 2

Obituary. A Notice to Creditors and Beneficiaries reveals the death of Archibald William Kellock of Burra, who died at Burra on 28 August 1960. [Born 20 March 1915, Kooringa.]

89, 47, 29 November 1960, page 3

Burra Rifle Club. Best marksmen on Saturday were R. Bernhardt, Cec. Edwards & H. Byles and with handicap were R. Bernhardt, C.W. Edwards and R. Oakley.

89, 47, 29 November 1960, page 5

Burra Town Council, November

Burra Burra DC has agreed to carry out work in the Burra Mine area.

The Clerk will write to the Commissioner of Police about the disadvantages from the Head Station being at Burra North.

The deputation to the Minister of Roads had achieved little.
