89, 47, 29 November 1960, page 8

Burra Burra DC, November

The Clerk is empowered to complete the installation of water on the Hanson Parklands.

Market Square

Mr Saunders of the Highways Department commenced a traffic survey of Market Square as had been sought by the Town Council for some time.

89, 48, 6 December 1960, page 1

Burra Christmas Shopping

A meeting of local traders on Thursday decided to trade from 7 to 9 p.m. on Friday 23 December and to leave Saturday morning hours to individual choice. It is believed that most Burra shops will trade on Saturday 24 December and will close on Tuesday 27 December; i.e. will be closed Monday, Tuesday and Wednesday and re-open on 29 December. Traders will fund Father Christmas’s arrival on 23 December.

Barry Nourse, son of Mr & Mrs C. Nourse of Burra, has been awarded first prize as best apprentice for 1960 in fitting and turning. He also took this honour in 1959. He is serving his apprenticeship with Max Bryant Engineers of Clare.

Booborowie Recreation Committee has approved South Booborowie Cricket Club placing a cricket pitch in the centre of the main oval and that a bore with an electric pump be sunk near the Hall to provide water for toilet use. This had previously depended on a 1,000 gallon tank, which sometimes proved inadequate.

Music Exam Results are printed.

Explosives

A quantity of explosives that had been stored for about 20 years in Burra was determined to be dangerous and has been destroyed under the supervision of the Chief Inspector of the department of Chemistry in Adelaide. Approximately 31⁄2 pounds of gelignite and one pound of blasting powder with fuses and detonators was involved. Sergeant McGrath warned people that stored explosives can become highly dangerous and people should only obtain what they need and not store it at all.

Cricket. Mokota Association.

Mt Bryan 174 v. North Booborowie 0 for 46

Leighton 8 for 152 v. Spalding

Hallett 22 v. Booborowie 8 for 191

Burra High School speech night will be in Burra Town Hall 13 December. Last year’s Fulbright Scholar for SA Mr K.L. Berndt will be guest speaker and Mrs Berndt will present the prizes, certificates and trophies. Arrangements for a school bus next year from Hanson via Hams’ Corner and Shafton are in their final stages.

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club

The official opening of the Small Bore Range was held on Saturday despite adverse weather conditions. The SA and Australian Champions attended and the first possible for this range was fired by C. Lewis of Ramco over 25 yards. About 70 people attended. Captain of the Burra Club Mr R. Angel welcomed visitors. Mr E.T. Baulderstone performed the official opening. Afternoon tea followed.

Of the seven trophies being competed for on the day the SA Champion Mrs Barbara Pain won four, the Australian Champion Mr John Murphy won two and C. Lewis of the Morgan Club won one.

But as any one shooter could only claim one range trophy Mrs Pain had to concede the 75 yard trophy to V. Pfitzner of Pt Augusta West Club and she kept only the grand aggregate trophy and presented the 100 yard trophy to Mike Thomas, while the best Burra Club score in Night Aggregate went to J. Brown.

Mr Murphy retained only the afternoon aggregate trophy and gave the 50 yard trophy to Milton Mitchell. Mr C. Lewis, who was best over 25 yards, presented his trophy to the highest Burra scorer in R. Angel.

Tuesday night’s best scorers were W. Corner, A. Angel and M .Mitchell.

89, 48, 6 December 1960, page 2

Obituary. Theodor Pryde died on 27 November at Strathalbyn Hospital aged 56. He was formerly of Goolwa and Booborowie, the son of C. and the late G. Pryde of Booborowie and brother to Lila (Mrs E.J. Affolter) and Myra (Mrs A.J. Cousins).

[George Hector Pryde was born 20 April 1904 at Copperhouse, the son of George and Caroline Pryde. He died 27 November 1960 at Strathalbyn, residence Goolwa. The error in the name was corrected in 89, 49, 13 December 1960, page 11]

89, 48, 6 December 1960, page 3

Booborowie Methodist Strawberry Fete was recently held in the Booborowie Memorial Hall and raised £231.

[Stall details are printed.]

89, 48, 6 December 1960, page 4

RAA’s Mr Vowles will be in Burra from today till Thursday to map out a suitable plan for the improvement of the Burra Caravan Park to bring it into line with other parks recommended by the Tourist Bureau.

89, 48, 6 December 1960, page 8

Burra CWA held its 34th birthday celebrations and its International Day on 15 November in the Burra town Hall with President Mrs Jennison presiding. It was resolved that the annual donation to the Burra Hospital would only be £75 in view of the branch’s building program. Mrs L.H. Thomas and Mrs Satchell played and sang appropriate items before Mrs Thorpe of Farrell Flat gave a talk on Scotland.

89, 49, 13 December 1960, page 1

[Note: the sequence of pages in the bound hard copy was strangely disordered. The page numbering in these notes follows that of the microfilm version.]

Burra Hospital

The Combined Committee of Women’s Organisations held its half-yearly meeting on 28 November. President Mrs A. Tennant presided.

Delegates discussed the long term program of hospital improvements proposed by the Hospital Board. Among them were:

Painting the interior of the Mid wing

Innerspring mattresses throughout

Additional rainwater storage

Sealing areas in front and at the rear of the hospital

Certain repairs to the Hospital and to the Nurses’ Home

Donations raised in the past twelve months:

Burra CWA £75

Burra Red Cross £45

Burra North Red Cross £75

Mt Bryan CWA £59-5-0

Booborowie CWA £60

Hanson CWA £20

Farrell Flat CWA £10

Burra Town Council, 4 December

Mr Baulderstone reported on Councillors in the town receiving abuse and those in business losing trade. People had refused to deal with Councillors’ businesses because the footbridge by the bowling green had been closed for repairs. This was unfair on people who do a voluntary job to the best of their ability and who suffer through ratepayers who take no apparent interest in town affairs other than when something doesn’t suit them and who would not offer themselves for election to the same position.

89, 49, 13 December 1960, page 2

Advt. Burra Town Council calls tenders for the ceiling of the stage of the Burra Town Hall.

The work to be completed by 31 January 1961. R.W. Fullgrabe, Town Clerk.

89, 49, 13 December 1960, page 3

St Joseph’s Convent School, Burra, staged a Concert in Burra Town Hall on Thursday 8 December. It raised £50 for school funds. [The program is printed.]

89, 49, 13 December 1960, page 4

Burra Town Council, 5 December

The condition of certain houses in Paxton Square was discussed and a conference with the trustees is to be arranged if possible.

The Mayor attended a farewell for Mr L.H. Thomas on 4 December.

Five street signs are to be obtained for each ward as a trial.

Aberdeen Croquet Club sought its usual subsidy on its water rate. Council found it was responsible for the annual rate only.

The cost of curtains for the Town Hall stage is to be obtained.

Photo: Miss Kaye McKenzie, Miss SA, presenting the sash as Belle of the Spastic Ball at Hallett to Miss Jeanette Prior with runner-up Miss Judith McDonald.

89, 49, 13 December 1960, page 7

Burra Burra DC, December

89, 50, 20 December 1960, page 1

Burra High School Speech Night, Burra Town Hall.

About 500 people attended on Thursday night when Chairman of the High School Council Mr H.J.B. Jennison presided. The guest speaker was Mr K.L. Berndt who gave an address on Changes in Our Time.

He stressed that schools needed to aim more at developing their pupils’ ability to think and assess, rather than at the mere absorption of knowledge. Mrs Berndt presented prizes and awards.

[Items are listed and prize winners are printed.]

Farewells for staff:

Mr Scriven

Miss Crouch

Miss Judith Field

Mr & Mrs Jim Battye & Family are leaving Burra. Mr Battye has resigned from his position as branch manager of Goldsbrough Mort & Co. and intends accepting a position as Country Representative for Legal & General Assurance Pty Ltd. No replacement as branch manager has yet been made.

89, 50, 20 December 1960, page 8

The Education Department advises tenders are being called for a school bus service from Hanson to Burra High School for 1961, to be advertised in the Advertiser and the Record 10 January 1961.

Burra High School

The annual banquet arranged by the Parents & Friends’ Association was held in the Town Hall on Wednesday afternoon last. More than 150 sat down at the tables with Mrs F.D. Arnold presiding. Official guests included Mr C.R. Kelly MHR, the Mayor and Mayoress of Burra and Chairman of the High School Council Mr H.J.B. Jennison and Mrs Jennison. Mr Kelly gave an address.

Characteristics of the paper for 1960

In general there is a satisfactory coverage of local news, though the paper is beginning to carry material directly relevant to nearby towns as well. Hallett in particular gets a considerable coverage, with District Council reports for example. Some articles fail initially to make clear which town is being reported.

There is some evidence of careless editing with jumbled print not always being corrected in time or even referred to in the next issue so that it might be clarified.

Almost all the news except sport appears on page one. Photographs put in an occasional appearance, but as yet remain a week at least after the event.

Sports as always get a great deal of space. District Council reports are extensive, but not always very informative. A long list of letters received conveys no real information. Even an explanation that the letter concerned a particular road or building etc. is useless if it fails to say what the concern was.

Note that this summary has generally ignored events reported from other towns in the district.

Page 1

Entirely devoted to news and photos of local event or people are not uncommon, though somewhat delayed.

Page 2

Advertisements for sales, entertainment, public notices and the like.

Page 3

Often a continuation of page 2 content with some large advertisements.

Pages 4-8

Dominated by advertisements of considerable size. Most are two columns wide by 3 inches (7.5 cm) in depth or larger. News here is dominated by sports results. District Councils are also reported at length here. CWA news is significant and the activities of the schools get good coverage. News of any sort rarely exceeds 11⁄2 of the 6 columns. One page usually carried a ‘Cash Column’. This was essentially very brief advertisements of items for sale.

90, 1, 10 Dec. 1961, page 1 [Sic: in error for 10 Jan.]

Burra-Peterborough Road. Following a deputation to the Minister of Roads Hon. N.L. Jude MLC on 14 October, advice has been received that a £12,000 grant has been made to maintain and repair this road. A further £20,000 for construction work is expected in 1961-62.

The £12,000 is divided between Councils: Burra Burra £2,000

Hallett £5,000

Peterborough £1,500

£8,500

The remaining £3,500 is available for the improvement of watercourses by the construction of culverts and spoon drains.

Booborowie CWA held its Christmas Party in the supper room at Booborowie Hall and about 40 members and visitors attended. [Reported in c. 1⁄2 column.]

Burra School. The central roof of the 1877 building is being modernised. The big longitudinal valley is being replaced by a more effective and less troublesome gently pitching crown. The contractor is Mr F. Randell of Magill.

Farrell Flat CWA held a Christmas Party which is reported in c. 1⁄2 column.

Mr Jim Battye has resigned as Manager of Goldsbrough, Mort & Co. in Burra and Mr Ted Orchard has been appointed in his place. Mr A. Hale of Balaklava Branch will take Mr Orchard’s old position.

Burra High School. The new headmaster id Mr R.V. Mueller from Murray Bridge. Mr M.W. Scriven goes to Mt Barker.

Burra Primary School Headmaster Mr A.A. Kies goes to Walkerville to be replaced by Mr K. Horsnell from Murray Bridge.

Mt Bryan Christmas Tree of 15 December in the Mt Bryan Hall is reported in 1⁄2 column.

90, 1, 10 Dec. 1961, pages 1 & 6 [Sic: in error for 10 Jan.]

Burra High School Headmaster’s Report for 1960 (The 48th Report)

Enrolment in 1960 was 122; up 6 on 1959’s record. Only 4 left during the year. There were 8 in the Leaving Class.

[He then goes on at some length to thank his staff, the High school Council, the Parents & Friends Association, the Ministers of Religion, bus drivers and students.]

The school has striven, beyond the resources of time and staff, to provide for the less academically capable by providing subjects outside of the matriculation route: Shorthand, Typewriting, Home Science, Needlework, Drawing and Woodwork. Public Examination results last year were very good. In Leaving the three students won certificates with 90% passes in subjects taken. In Intermediate there were 14 certificates and three others with six subjects each out of the 22 entrants. All told our students got 9 credits and a 77% subject pass rate.

Sports continue to feature with weekly house matches, a Swimming Carnival in February and an Annual Sports Day in April. Burra was doing well with the handicap system in the Mid Northern High School Sports at Riverton in May. At lunch we were coming second, but rain turned the oval into an impossible morass and hopes were thwarted. Virtual flood conditions washed out the series of football and basketball matches with Clare and Balaklava.

In July the Leaving Class went to Adelaide to see Richard III and in August the Senior School and some Second Year students went to Clare to see The Merchant of Venice. The Annual Ball in September was a highlight with record takings of £149. An Arbor Day in July replaced Visiting Day and most of the trees and shrubs planted are doing well. A new classroom unit was added in the year and awaits the painters, so it should be ready for use in 1961. Acquisitions in the year have included a new refrigerator in the Home Sciences room, new floor coverings in the Library, a new motor mower, remodelling of the Library and £100 worth of books.

Adult education classes in Dressmaking and Woodwork continued.

Two items of unfinished business are the site for the new school and the issue of a Hanson bus.

[Tenders for the bus are called on page 1 of this paper.]

At the end of 1960 Miss Shirley Crouch (Home Science) goes to Adelaide and Mr Kowald to Angaston.

90, 1, 10 Dec. 1961, page 2 [Sic: in error for 10 Jan.]

[There are two detailed advertisements.]

90, 2, 17 Jan. 1961, page 1

Burra Town Hall. A.L. Clode & Son have the contract for the new ceiling at the back of the Town Hall stage.

Burra Rifle Club. Possibles were fired by W. Barker, K. Spackman & R. Francis.

R.S. Norris writes commenting on an article in the Advertiser reporting comments by Mr H. Toepfer of the importing firm of Alfred Toepfer of Hamburg, who was amazed to find SA still handling virtually all its oats and barley in bags and calling for bulk handling both for efficiency and to control pests. The need to change to bulk handling, he says, is clear.

W.V. Ford writes on returning to the town after an absence of 38 years and being dismayed to find that Aberdeen no longer exists. He was sorry to see such a small attendance at Redruth Methodist Church. He believed the mine area was a tourist asset going to waste. He was glad to renew acquaintance with Jock Bernhardt, Stan Woollacott, Hedley Pearce, Cliff Turner and Sid. Scroop. Rev. E.M. Ingamells asked to be remembered to friends.

J.R. O’Sullivan, Director of Posts and Telegraphs writes in response to a letter by R. Fuss in the paper of 13 December 1960, in which Mr Fuss thanks the Fire Brigade and others who helped extinguish the fire on his property, ‘But no thanks to the Telephone Exchange.’ Mr Fuss has refused to supply any details which would assist the department investigations into the implied failure. There is no record of a fire call from the service of Mr Fuss. A query was received from Burra 233 at 12.10 p.m. on Saturday 10 December asking whether the exchange had heard about the fire over the hill and the caller was connected with the Fire Officer at Burra 183 and the officer then activated the fire siren. The postmaster also received a letter from another subscriber explaining that a call in connection with the fire from the extension telephone of his service was not effective as he had not switched the extension switch at his house to the correct position. The postmaster has no further knowledge of the case, but should Mr Fuss care to furnish any information of the alleged failure by staff I would be pleased to have further investigations made. In the absence of such I can only assure Mr Fuss acted under a misapprehension which unfortunately has brought unwarranted discredit on the exchange staff.

90, 3, 24 Jan. 1961, page 1

The 1960 Season. This harvest has seen the best grain intake for years and direct trucking has helped storage problems. Burra took in:

Premium Grade Wheat 490

Soft Wheat 14,638

Hard Wheat 8,726

Estimated Total 27,500 [bags]

The compound at Burra Station is full.

Last season saw only 5,542 bags of wheat and the 1958-59 season 18,000.

Barley this season:

Malting Barley 1095 bags

3rd Grade 2063 bags

4th Grade 3882 bags

Total 7040 bags (To Saturday – with perhaps 1000 to come.)

Hanson area has had to use direct trucking to handle 50,000 bags carted in the area with 20,000 estimated to come.

Last season’s intake was 12,500 bags and the 1958-59 intake was 33,000 bags.

This year Hanson depot handled 23,000 bags of barley compared with 6,000 last season and 12,500 in 1958-59.

Manoora has handled a record 26,000 bags of barley compared with 18,000 in 1958-59.

Of the 30,000 bags of wheat 4,392 are of inferior quality due to star thistle.

Mt Bryan barley carting has finished with 9,000 bags and wheat to date is 28,000 bags and the estimated 4,000 to come will fill the stack to capacity.

Hallett has so far received 50,000 bags with a considerable amount to come.

Burra Swimming Pool. In the Learn to Swim Campaign under Mr K. Hicks and Miss Judith Field from 9-20 January, 154 enrolled, of whom 70 were non-swimmers. All but 5 gained beginners’ certificates, 54 gained progress certificates and 30 got junior certificates. 17 gained senior certificates.

‘Waterless Willie’ complains of Burra’s low water pressure.

Hanson School Bus. A bus will be operated by the Education Department this year from Hanson for High School students travelling via Harris Corner and Shafton. Students from Farrell’s Flat and Leighton will use existing Primary School services to meet the new bus.

Mt Bryan Road. Work has commenced on improving waterways.

Booborowie Streets in the shopping area (South Terrace, 3rd, 5th and 6th Streets) have been sealed.

Cricket

Koonoona 113 defeated Burra 82.

Burra 81 defeated Farrell Flat 64.

Burra Small Bore Club. Over 25 yards Keith Spackman was 1st with Bill Barker best off the rifle.

Burra Rifle Club fired the 9th stage of the E.S. Williams Trophy over 600 & 700 yards. Best were G. Kakoschke, M. Stolte & R. Francis.

Burra Town Council, 9 January

A.L. Clode’s tender for the ceiling of the Town Hall stage was accepted.

The quote from Matthew’s Emporium of £178-16-2 was accepted for the supply and fitting of the Town Hall stage curtains.

The Finance Committee recommended the Council ascertain whether the District Council has vacated their old depot and if so that the Town Council offer their own depot to the Burra Bowling Club for £100 and transfer costs, when the sale of the District Council depot has been completed.

90, 3, 24 Jan. 1961, page 6

The Record points out a missing line in the J.R. O’Sullivan letter of last week and then publishes the same error instead of adding the missing line.

Burra Library is threatened with closure if subscribers do not attend the AGM. Rules do not permit it to operate without a committee of at least ten.

90, 4, 31 Jan. 1961, page 7

Obituary. Mrs M.A. Jefferies late of Burra died 27 January at her residence in Colonel Light Gardens aged 92 [93]. She came to Burra in 1870 with her parents and spent all her girlhood in the town. She went first to Mr Kat’s School and later to the Public School. Her father, the late Mr Simpson, we believe drove the first train from Burra to Hallett when the line ended there. When refreshment rooms were opened at Burra Mr & Mrs Simpson had charge of them. Later they took the refreshment rooms at Hamley Bridge and it was there she met and married Albert Jefferies, who was in the SAR. After the marriage they moved to Wallaroo for five years and then to Adelaide. Mr Jefferies then left the railways and they ran a shop at Reynella. In 1912 they purchased a farm at Mt Bryan and were there until Mr Jefferies died. Mrs Jefferies then moved to Burra with her daughter Joyce and in 1956 to Adelaide where her three daughters reside. She is survived by her three daughters and one son as well as ten grandchildren and sixteen great-grandchildren. Mr Frank Jefferies still lives on the farm.

[Born Mary Ann Simpson (known as Mollie) 10 August 1868: died 27 January 1961 Reade Park.]

90, 4, 31 Jan. 1961, page 8

Marriage. Knoxville Congregational Church, 14 January

Moira Smith, only daughter of Mr & Mrs George Smith of Toorak Gardens and late of Edinburgh, married

Neil McDonald, only son of Mr & Mrs Frank McDonald of Hallett.

90, 5, 7 Feb. 1961, page 1

Mr E.T. Baulderstone has called a public meeting for 20 February in response to the Secretary of the Industries development Special Committee who seeks ideas for the establishment of local industry.

Burra High School. Photographs are printed of the High School Prefects and of the Cricket and Tennis teams for 1960. [This is correct; not the 1961 Prefects.]

Burra Rifle Club fired the 1st Stage of the Championship over double 700 yards. Bill Barker took both the marksman’s and handicap honours. Possibles were scored by W. Burton & R. Francis.

Burra Small Bore Club. On Tuesday K. Spackman was best on handicap and Jim Brown in the marksman’s contest.

Weather. There has been no significant rain for three months.

Bon Accord Bridge. The Highways Department has advised that the bridge is unsafe for loads in excess of three tons. The bridge will be surveyed and plans drawn up for a new one.

Fire. A fire at the Burra Hotel in the Saloon bar on Friday night did about £300-£400 damage. It was noticed by joint proprietor Mr D. Sleader at about10.50 p.m. and his partner Mr K. Flaherty rang the alarm at the Fire Station and returned with a fire extinguisher. Firemen Spackman, Williams and Barry followed with another. Mr Sleader had largely extinguished the fire when they arrived and finished the job. The cause has not been identified.

90, 5, 7 Feb. 1961, page 2

Advt. Elder, smith & Co. will sell on account of R. McWaters, a stone house of five rooms etc. on allotment 13 at Burra North containing 1 acre 15 perches.

Advt. Goldsbrough, Mort & Co. have instructions from Mr G. & Mrs D. Gask to conduct a clearing sale at ‘Gilrose’ Gum Creek on Tuesday 28 February; the property having been sold.

Notice. An attempt will be made to re-form the Aberdeen Football Club at a meeting in the Oddfellows’ Hall Thursday 9 February at 8 p.m.

90, 5, 7 Feb. 1961, page 4

Burra Institute held its AGM on 31 January after a postponement due to lack of numbers. A committee was elected. President W. Carpenter presented the annual report. The grant for 1960 was £64-15-4 and subscriptions were £138-7-7. This is down due to removals from the town and the impact of television. Expenses amounted to £179-19-11, leaving a credit balance of £39-3-4. There were 6.963 books in the library. Present membership is 106 adults and 20 juveniles. The scholarships for students have been discontinued because the schools now have good libraries. The librarian Mrs Steer continues to give excellent service.

90, 6, 14 Feb. 1961, page 1

Burra High School opened on Tuesday with an enrolment of 125; the highest ever. There are 70 boys and 55 girls. Leaving 9, Intermediate 30, 2nd Year 39 and 1st year 47. New Staff:

Mr R.V. Mueller from Murray Bridge

Mr R.D. Hillman from Henley

Mr B.I. McElroy from Teachers’ College

Miss N.I. Lawes from Pt Pirie

Mrs J.E. Bogisch from Burra

Miss E. McCabe from Gawler AEC one day a week.

Burra Primary School. Mr A. Kies Headmaster has been transferred to Walkerville and has been replaced by Mr K. Horsnell, formerly Deputy Headmaster at Murray Bridge. Mr H. Kowald, acting Chief Assistant has been appointed Chief Assistant at Angaston. Mr Sullivan comes from McLaren Vale and was formerly with the Queensland Education Department. There is new flooring in two rooms and a new roof. Enrolments at 250 are up 22. Grade 1 49, Grade II 32, Grade III 25, Grade IV 31, Grade V 43, Grade VI 38 and Grade VII 32.

[New admissions to Grade I are named.]

St Joseph’s Convent School has 35 students. Numbers and staff are unchanged.

[The 7 new students are listed.]

Booborowie School. Miss Pat Oxley has been transferred to Dover Gardens infant School. Miss Rachel Woolford comes from Wirrabara. The enrolment of 66 is the highest for 25 years. [12 new enrolments are listed.]

Weather. Thunderstorms delivered 37 points at Burra on Wednesday to 9 a.m. and 8 points later in the day.

Miss Raylene Edwards is being sponsored by Mrs R.B. Pitcher and Mr L.P. Bence as Burra’s entrant in the Sky Queen Contest in aid of the Adelaide Children’s Hospital Building Fund.

Marriage. St Andrew’s Anglican Church Mt Bryan, 10 December 1960

Mary Edwards married Arthur Talent.

This was the first wedding at this church since Mary’s parents were married there 27 October 1934.

Burra Rifle Club fired the 10th stage of the Williams Trophy. Best were A.G. Heinrich, R. Oakley & E. Hopkins. Tom Heinrich was best off the rifle as well as on handicap.

90, 6, 14 Feb. 1961, page 5

Burra Small Bore Club fired a night 100 yards range for the first time on Tuesday. Bill Corner took the marksman’s and the handicap sections.

Bowls. North Eastern Association

Mid North Association

Clare Green 110 defeated Burra Gold 78

90, 7, 21 Feb. 1961, page 1

Grain Silos. Tenders have been called for the erection of a 300,000 bushel silo at Farrell Flat. A meeting of about 200 local wheat growers at Hanson on Wednesday failed to convince the Chairman of the Bulk Handling Board that Hanson was a more central point. It is understood that growers in the Gum Creek-Farrell Flat area would fill the silo before growers further north and east would start reaping, as they are normally 2-3 weeks later.

After Farrell Flat, the next silo planned is at Pt Pirie with 16 cells. It is expected erection of a complete coverage of silos throughout the state will take at least four years.

Burra Rifle Club travelled to Dean Range on Sunday for the Country Teams Championship. Conditions were hard and Burra did poorly in the teams’ event. On the Saturday at the Prize Meeting Herb Byles shot well to take 6th place in the grand aggregate and Bill Barker also did well.

Stud Breeders v. Stock Agents Sports, 10 February

Photos of the Bowls Teams are printed. Stud Breeders won the bowls by 14 points and the cricket by 4 wickets and 10 runs.

Clem Sampson writes from Esperance WA with best wishes to old Burra friends.

Fire. A small fire at Dalgety’s Office on Friday night was quickly extinguished by the Fire Brigade at about 10.50 p.m. Little damage was done. A cigarette butt in a box of sawdust is believed to have started the fire.

Burra Football Club held its AGM. Past President Mr W. Brown reported a successful season. They won the ‘A’ Grade Premiership. Members of the newly formed Aberdeen Football Club attended to put their case for having two clubs in the town. Elected: Patron, Mr Reg. Warnes; President, Mr J. Merkel; Vice president Mr Bert Beinke and Secretary-Treasurer, Mr T. Forby.

Burra High School Parents & Friends Assoc. met 16 February and welcomed new teachers and headmaster Mr R. Mueller. The Headmaster said the Department had a lot of trouble staffing high schools and the number had increased from 30 to 49 in the past five years. Burra was at present a Junior Teacher short. He outlined the organisation of the school for the year.

90, 7, 21 Feb. 1961, page 2

The land comprising Pt Lot 32 Township of Mt Bryan.

The land adjoining Section 619 Hd Ayers, being 4 acres, together with the pound and Council Chamber.

The structure of the pound enclosure only.

The land adjoining Section 619 less the pound structure only.

90, 7, 21 Feb. 1961, page 3

Obituary. Return Thanks Notice reveals the death of Ern Threadgold of Burra North.

[Ernest Albert Threadgold died 30 December 1960 Whyalla, residence Burra North. Age at death of 74 suggests a birth in 1886. Age at marriage suggests a birth in 1883. SA Births CD does not record an Ernest Albert Threadgold.]

Tennis

‘A’ Grade Aberdeen 11 sets defeated Ironmine 9 sets

‘B’ Grade Aberdeen 12 sets defeated Ironmine 8 sets

Football. The North Eastern Football League met at Booborowie on 20 February and decided not to admit Aberdeen to the League. Mr Jenner was re-elected President and Mr Ted Orchard is Secretary & Treasurer for 1961.

Burra Town Council, 6 February

Building Application on Lot J Chapel Street on account of T. Ryan was approved.

Mr R.B. Lewis wrote concerning the proposed conference with Council concerning Paxton Square. A letter will be sent to him saying Council wished to discuss health issues relating to the square.

The Highways Department is to be asked how long before action can be expected on a new Bon Accord Bridge.

Local Board of Health

Notice has been served on the owner of the old bakery at Burra North.

90, 8, 28 Feb. 1961, page 1

Public Meeting on Decentralization

Thirty-four people attended the public meeting at the Burra Town Hall on 20 February. The meeting was to pass on suggestions about industry for the town. With population dwindling what could be done in Burra was the question. The Mayor’s own suggestion was the concrete trade – posts and bricks, many of which are used in the district and further north. Another suggestion was crushed metal and another the development of mineral resources within the ‘Eastern’ country. Other suggestions touched on meat works and a cannery, Mongolata goldfield, clay, pottery and bricks and small scale machinery. Questions of cheaper electricity and water were raised and the question was asked about how much and whether the Government would pay for decentralization.

Burra High School. A successful Swimming Carnival was held on 24 February.

[Results are printed.]

Commonwealth Scholarships have been won by Misses Trenna Eberhard & Merle Wickes. The scholarships give free tuition in any University course plus a living allowance of up to £338 p.a. while studying the course. They are based on marks in the student’s best five subjects.

Burra Small Bore Club. 75 Yards Championship on Tuesday night was won by Jim Brown from Gordon Webster & Norma Barker, who won in the handicap section.

‘Regular Sufferer’ writes complaining of power outages since ETSA took over. The Editor says ETSA has informed them that recent failures have been due to lightning strikes on a new sub-station.

Ron Dewhirst writes a long letter running about 11⁄4 columns suggesting that following the north Eastern Football League’s decision not to admit Aberdeen to the ‘A’ Grade and to continue with a League of four teams, the best solution would be for a ‘B’ Grade competition or a Colts competition. Two ‘A’ Grade teams is more than one town could maintain. When he first came to the district Booborowie had three and then for several years it had two and so did Burra and Spalding, but population has fallen with young people going to the city and all three towns have difficulty fielding one strong team. A strong competition could not have been sustained with two teams in one town. He does not believe four teams too few for a league and most country leagues have only four teams. He feels ‘B’ Grade would be a better solution than Colts teams. With a Colt age limit of 18 a lad reaching 18 is deprived of a game if he is not quite good enough for the ‘A’ team. A ‘B’ team would solve this problem (or a Colts team without age limit). The possibility of interchange between ‘A’ & ‘B’ teams would also make ‘A’ team players look to their laurels.

90, 8, 28 Feb. 1961, page 2

Notice. ETSA advises that the need to renew insulators at the Burra Sub-station will see power cut to the area from Burra to Ulooloo inclusive from 7 a.m. to 10 a.m. on Sunday 5 March.

90, 8, 28 Feb. 1961, page 8

Booborowie Football Club held its AGM and elected: President, Mr F. Willis and Secretary, Mr J. McMahon. Finances are healthy with a credit of £140. The Captain Coach is Peter Sullivan. A meeting to decide on the formation of a Colts team is to be held 3 March.

90, 9, 7 Mar. 1961, page 1

Booborowie School. The Annual Parents’ Meeting is reported in 1⁄3 column.

Burra High School. Inspector Mr J.O. Glastonbury visited the school last week and Miss Clarke, a Craft Inspector, was present for a day also. Mr Kim Horsnell has been appointed as a Junior Teacher.

Cricket

Koonoona 183 defeated Burra 99 & 6 for 43.

G. & D. Gask’s ‘Gilrose’ clearing sale is reported in c. 1⁄2 column.

Burra Small Bore Club shoot over s5 and 75 yards saw Jim Brown best off the rifle and Gordon Webster best with handicap.

90, 9, 7 Mar. 1961, pages 1 & 8

Burra RSL held its AGM. President Mr G.K. Kelly asked members to take a more active role in the club. Elected: President, H. Cornelius; Vice-Presidents, T. Rogers & C.L. Phillips; Secretary, R.W. Nankivell & Treasurer, B. Kotz.

The year was uneventful. Anzac Day Service was conducted by the Ministers’ Fraternal and preceded by a march led by the Pt Pirie Pipers’ Band. There was a good muster of ex-servicemen. Remembrance Day was also observed at the Memorial with a large attendance of school children. The poor weather reduced attendance at the annual ball, but it was a social success. Thanks are paid to the Ladies’ Auxiliary. The annual dinner also had a small attendance. The Christmas Party was a combined function with the Air Force Association. Several successful badge days were held and the branch continues to support two Legacy wards. Thanks are extended to the various officers who gave their time and effort during the year.

90, 9, 7 Mar. 1961, page 3

Burra Rifle Club fired the 2nd Stage of the Championship, which was won by Keith Spackman with top marksman’s points to Tom Heinrich.

90, 9, 7 Mar. 1961, page 6

Bowls. Wednesday’s night games saw Burra 139 defeat Hallett 90.

Mid North Association: Burra Green 100 defeated Burra Gold 80

North Eastern Association: Burra Blue 101 defeated Hallett Red 100.

90, 10, 14 Mar. 1961, page 1

Burra Open Swimming Carnival was not as successful as hoped because the Peterborough competitors did not arrive and this prevented the night program as planned. The rest of the events went of satisfactorily. The weather was a little cool. Peterborough had over 40 entries from 20 competitors, but could not arrange transport. Overall the club showed a small profit on the day.

Country Championship 800 yards Freestyle I. Wingate (Renmark)

Sub Junior Women’s 662⁄3 yards Freestyle C. Semmler (Barossa Valley)

Women’s 100 yards Freestyle L. Irlam (Burra)

Sub Junior Men’s 662⁄3 yards Freestyle R. Hammatt (Spalding)

Junior Diving M. Sieber (Burra)

Junior Men’s 100 yards Freestyle R. Warnest (Jamestown)

Men’s 100 yards Freestyle I. Wingate (Renmark)

[Other positions and times are printed.]

Burra Rifle Club. Triangular shoot at Peterborough. Results: Pt Pirie 1045, Burra 977 and Peterborough 955.

Accident. Mrs O’Connell, a former resident of Burra, is in Burra hospital and making progress. She fell and broke her leg taking a short cut through the Burra Creek to visit friends and was not able to attract attention for four hours.

90, 10, 14 Mar. 1961, page 3

Ray McAuley writes a letter intimating that he will be a candidate for LCL endorsement for the Northern Legislative Council District at the next state election. The Present Members are Sir Lyell McEwin and Mr Harry Edmonds. Sir Lyell has said he will stand again, but Mr Edmonds is retiring.

90, 10, 14 Mar. 1961, page 8

Burra Small Bore Club. In a 50 & 75 yards shoot W. Barker was best off the rifle and A. Angel best with handicap.

Cricket. Burra Cricket Association Final

Koonoona 1 for 248 including D. Bednall 131 n.o. [The game will be played out.]

90, 10, 14 Mar. 1961, page 9

Fire. A tractor is believed to have started a fire that burnt 1,000 acres of grass on Koonoona on Tuesday at about 1.30 p.m. Units attended from Robertstown, Manoora, Eudunda, Burra & Saddleworth, but in the rough terrain it could not be completely extinguished, though it was controlled by 7 p.m. No stock losses were reported and only slight fencing damage.

Burra Burra Show Inc. held its AGM. President Rex C. Warnes reported a very successful 1960 show in perfect weather, with gate takings of £217 and £38 from the dance run by the Rural Youth Club. Entries were good and the show was opened by the Minister of Agriculture Hon. D.N. Brookman. He also opened the new Wool Pavilion, which housed a record entry of 117 fleeces. Membership remains at about 300, but the financial position is not quite as good as in previous years. ‘Much maintenance work is being done and we are indebted to Mr R. Fuss for the time he gives this society. He is not only saving us money, but is improving our assets as well.’

[Mr R. Fuss was present at the meeting.]

The year left the overdraft at £280-9-7, slightly up on last year.

Elected: Patron, A.B. Riggs; President, Rex C. Warnes and Vice-Presidents, C.F. Pearce & B.A. Riggs.

90, 10, 14 Mar. 1961, page 10

Accident/Obituary. Lloyd Cecil Pfitzner was found unconscious near a stationary engine attached to a corn crusher on his Robertstown property on Wednesday [8 March]. He had a fractured skull and died soon after admission to the Eudunda Hospital. He may have been caught or struck by a belt. He was aged 30 and was single.

Burra Town Council, 6 March

CWA plans for clubrooms in Chapel Street were approved.

Permission for the Aberdeen Tennis Club to use the courts at Aberdeen on Easter Sunday was denied (under the conditions of the lease).

Burra Bowling Club forwarded a cheque for £100 as payment on the old Council Depot.

R.H. Rishbeth offer a trowel used to lay the Town Hall foundation stone in 1874. Council accepted the offer with thanks.

Local Board of Health

Dr L.G. Miller reported on the inspection of the property owned by Mr Lyle Pearce with the possibility of its becoming a boarding house by Mr F. Dainty. Dainty’s Roadhouse was also inspected.

Mrs Gosse is to be written to and asked to reply to previous correspondence concerning Paxton Square.

Burra Primary School Welfare Club held its AGM on 7 March. Elected: President, Mrs D. Field; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames H. Topsfield & M. Mitchell; Secretary, Mrs D. Bannister; Assistant Secretary, Mrs M. Mitcher [sic: perhaps Mitchell] & Treasurer, Mrs Benger.

90, 10, 14 Mar. 1961, page 12

Burra Burra DC, 6 March

Tenders of F.J. Lomman & P.T. Cousins & Co. were accepted for the Booborowie Council Block.

[Accepting two tenders suggests one was for the pound equipment & material and the other for the land.]

Permission to erect a gate on Booborowie Park Lands was granted.

Education Week. A public meeting in the School Hall on 8 March resulted in the following tentative plans for the week.

Thursday 27 April Primary School official opening of Education week

High School at combined sports at Kapunda

Friday 28 April Official opening of Education Week in the Burra Town Hall

Primary School Pioneers’ Day

Sunday 30 April Combined Church Service in Kooringa Methodist Church

Monday 1 May Primary School Sports Afternoon

Tuesday 2 May Primary and High Schools Visiting Day

Wednesday 3 May Sgt McGrath will arrange a film and slide evening.

Primary School will adopt a school for the day.

There will also be some shop window displays for the week.

Weather. Burra recorded 36 points for the week, Woolgangi 45 and Old Koomooloo 53.

Myxomatosis is active at present and rabbit numbers are down.

Fire. A grass fire on the property of Mr Wilf Nankivell on Thursday night killed a number of fruit and ornamental trees. The cause is unknown.

Burra CWA has planted 150 trees in the year.

90, 11, 21 Mar. 1961, page 5

Burra Rifle Club fired the 11th stage of the annual trophy over double 800 yards. There were four possible scored by W. Hempel, E. Hopkins, W. Barker and G. Webster. Best off the rifle was Bill Hempel and best with handicap were W. Hempel, W. Barker and H. Byles.

90, 11, 21 Mar. 1961, page 6

90, 11, 21 Mar. 1961, page 7

John James Thompson writes a letter because he is seeking LCL endorsement for the Northern District in the Legislative Council at the next election.

90, 12, 28 Mar. 1961, page 1

Burra Racing Club held a successful meeting at the local course last Wednesday. The running track was in excellent condition. The meeting was unfortunate in having a fall or stumble in the first race when Yvette broke a leg. The rider R. Wittwer escaped serious injury. The CWA ladies provided lunch. The main race was the Maylands Handicap of £100 and £16-5-0 trophy. It was won by the favourite Burbyng owned by J.A.M. Mitchell & H. Stratman and ridded by May. [Other results are printed.]

Burra Burra Hospital Inc. decided at its August AGM that anyone wishing to become a life member could do so by donating £10. The Board has now decided to use the donations so received to go towards the installation of an air conditioning unit in the nursery of the Midwifery Wing of the hospital, which will cost c. £250.

Burra Small Bore Club. 100 yards Championship. This stage was won by Gordon Webster both off the rifle and with handicap. Bill Barker was second off the rifle and won the Championship over the four stages on aggregate points.

M & BHA needs attendance to improve at its general meetings. Unless these improve and especially unless attendance improves at the AGM the local branch will have to close despite record high attendances at the Baby Clinic.

Burra Basketball Club

At the AGMs of the two clubs it was found that reduced interest from older girls meant the town could field only one ‘A’ Grade team and two ‘B’ Grade teams in the North Eastern Association. It has been decided to amalgamate Burra Rovers and Burra Comrades to form one club.

Elected: President, Mrs Dawn Broderick; Secretary & Treasurer, Miss Lorraine Baulderstone and Coach, Mrs L. Hirschausen.

Burra High School. The Prefects for 1961 were inducted on 21 March. Head Prefects are Ellen Kemp & Robert Brooks. Others are: Suzanne Harris, Raelene Hirschausen, Janet Sladden, Elaine White, Errol Hood, Ian McGrath, Robert Parker, William Standing and John Fullgrabe who replaced Kim Horsnell when he was appointed a Junior Teacher.

90, 12, 28 Mar. 1961, pages 1 & 6

Koonoona 363 v. Burra 188 and being forced to follow on was then 2 for 69.

90, 12, 28 Mar. 1961, page 2

Advt. Dalgety’s & Elder, Smith’s will conduct a land sale at Mt Bryan Institute 18 April on instructions from F.H. Treweeke and trustees in the estate of E.M. Murray.

Lot 1. Sections 554, 555, 560, Pt section 561, Pt section 562, Hd Ayers of 701 acres

Sections 552 & 553 Hd Ayers of 379 acres, 300 acres of which is arable.

Lot 2. Sections 114 & 2539 Hd Ayers of 799 acres (200 arable) 6 miles northwest of Mt Bryan.

90, 12, 28 Mar. 1961, page 4

Mid North Football Association held its AGM. The Association had a credit balance of £500. W.E. Blatchford presented the President’s report on an interesting year. Clare had two ‘A’ Grade teams and while Saddleworth did well, Riverton just managed to come out premiers. Roy Noack of Saddleworth won the Mail Medal. Rex Smith of Sevenhill won the Jennet Trophy for best and fairest in the ‘B’ Grade for the 5th consecutive year. The Colts’ first year was also successful and Riverton were premiers and won the Blatchford Cup. Elected: Patron, W. Knappstein (Clare); President, W.E. Blatchford was re-elected; Senior Vice-President, V. Jenner (Mintaro) and Secretary, N. Burfield (Auburn). There will be 14 teams this year in two divisions. Number 1 Division will comprise two Clare teams and one each from Riverton, Saddleworth, Auburn, Manoora Robertstown and Aberdeen (a new team for the Mid North). Number 2 Division will comprise Seven Hill, Mintaro, Marrabel, Farrell Flat, Tarlee and Watervale (a new team). Division 1 competes for the A Grade Shield and Division 2 competes for the Clayton-Dunn Shield.

Aberdeen Football Club was admitted to the Mid North Football Association last Friday night. Aberdeen colours are blue jumper with white sash, white shorts, blue socks with white tops. The election of club officers is to be decided at a meeting this week. The home ground and training ground is to be the Racecourse Oval.

90, 12, 28 Mar. 1961, page 5

Tennis. ‘A’ Grade: Hallett 10-82 defeated Aberdeen 10-77.

90, 12, 28 Mar. 1961, page 8

Gordon James Gilfillan has also submitted a résumé because he seeks LCL endorsement for the Northern Division of the Legislative Council in the LCL plebiscite.

90, 13, 4 Apr. 1961, page 1

Booborowie Hall Recreation Committee has undertaken a cropping project in the Booborowie Parklands for improvements to the hall and the recreation ground. When the project began in 1959 the first season was very dry and only 21 bags were obtained and this was kept as seed. The 1960 season was more successful and the committee was able to sell 89 bags of grade 3 and 186 bags of grade 4 as well as keeping 21 bags for seed.

[Details of who did what are printed.] A larger area will be sown this year than the 27 acres sown last year.

[Details of working bees are given.]

As a result of the committee’s work so far a tank has been erected alongside the windmill and pipes laid to both toilets, paths have been laid and grass cleared. At the end of the football season it is intended to grade the oval and install a cricket pitch to centralise sporting facilities.

Obituary. Mr Michael Breen, formerly the Secretary/Manager of the Burra Hospital and Secretary of the Burra Racing Club, has died in Auckland New Zealand. He resigned from these positions in the latter part of 1960 to return to Norfolk Island. He had just arrived ‘home’ and was settling in when death occurred. Earlier he had been Secretary of the Woomera Town Board for 8 years, retiring in 1958 from a position like that of a town mayor, town clerk, editor of the local paper Gibber-Gabber, supervisor of civic amenities, registrar of burials and curator of the cemetery. He held a BEc, BA and Dip. Public Administration from Sydney University. Mr H. Foote said Mr Breen loved his pet galah and paid a large sum of money to get it to New Zealand, but on arrival was advised that because of some technicality it could not land and he had to leave it with the coxswain of the boat.

Mr W. Butler of Burra is 85 on Saturday.

Burra Camera Club saw movies by Mr Sandercock on 27 March, including some with sound, of the Queen’s visit to Adelaide and scenes of Burra. Messrs McGrath & Jenner showed examples of black and white enlarging.

A Burra Traders’ Association was formed at a recent meeting. An attempt will be made to get 100% membership.

90, 13, 4 Apr. 1961, page 8

Ron Dewhirst writes about the new Mid North Football Association arrangements. He is sorry to see so many Burra players from last year’s premiership side deserting their team instead of defending their team’s honour this year. He maintains that Burra cannot field two ‘A’ Grade teams. Each team needs at least 25 players to account for injuries, sickness etc. Burra has won about three premierships in 25 years – hardly an indication it can field two ‘A’ Grade teams of the strength to repeat last year’s performance. At any rate the new team has yet to be cleared by NEFA and as we were not recognised by the SA League last year they cannot rule over our own league. If clearances are not granted (and he thinks they should not be) they would have to appeal to the National Council – a time consuming thing. The players should reconsider and stick to their former team.

90, 14, 11 Apr. 1961, page 1

Burra High School Sports Day was held on Friday. [Results are printed.]

Senior Boys’ Cup K. Neill

Senior Girls’ Cup L. Brooks

Junior Boys’ Cup I. Mickel

Junior Girls’ Cup H. Angel

Mr & Mrs George Goodridge of Mt Bryan celebrated their Golden Wedding on 1 April with a gathering at Mt Bryan Hall in the CWA Room. About 120 people sat down to tea in the supper room. Mrs Goodridge had completed 53 years of faithful service to the Methodist Sunday School, first at the Old Church and later at the new one. [A photograph of the couple is printed.]

Weather. Burra recorded 36 points in the past week.

Cricket. Burra Association Final. Burra went on in its second innings to make 192, giving it a lead over two innings of just 14 on Koonoona’s first innings of 365. In their second innings Koonoona lost 3 for 22 and won by 7 wickets.

E.T. Baulderstone writes concerning the Burra War Memorial Oval, pointing out that neither the football nor the cricket nor any other club has any ownership of the facilities; the oval is the property of the ratepayers of Burra. An improvement committee is appointed annually and in ten years has done a magnificent job in providing facilities with very little support from sporting bodies etc. The next project is to improve the grassing of the oval and watering of the playing field.

He writes that the town cannot maintain more than one oval and he clearly regrets the tendency of some to drift away from the oval to play their sport elsewhere. He calls for unity behind using the Burra Oval.

90, 14, 11 Apr. 1961, page 5

Burra Small Bore Club. The 50-75 yard shoot went to Norman Barker on handicap.

90, 14, 11 Apr. 1961, page 6

Bowls. Lower North Champion of Champion Rinks. Burra reached the final four with a team comprising L. Kellaway, J. Lloyd, L. Phillips and J. Topsfield, before going down to Balaklava in the semi-final.

Tennis

‘A’ Grade Semi-final Spalding 11-109 defeated Hallett Red 9-96

90, 14, 11 Apr. 1961, Supplement [Single-sided 4 columns, approximately A4 size.]

Tennis. First Semi-final ‘A’ Grade: Aberdeen 14-101 defeated Mt Bryan 6-68.

A CWA Garden Party will be held at ‘Princess Royal’ Admission 4/-. [An advertisement on page 2 says 21 April.]

90, 15, 18 Apr. 1961, page 1

Burra Rifle Club fired a match over double 900 yards. Herb Byles fired the only possible for the day and was first in the marksman’s contest. The handicap positions went to R. Gilbert, J. Brown and H. Byles.

Burra Public Toilets. For some time the toilets in use at the rear of premises on the west side of Market Square have been the subject of discussion by the Local Board of Health. These toilets may be condemned and if shopkeepers agree to contribute to cost and maintenance, a new block of up-to-date toilets will be erected.

Burra Primary School. Students from Grade VII in charge of Mr Horsnell attended the Burra Town Council meeting on 18 April.

Burra CWA. A tender for the new Rest Rooms [in Chapel Street] has been accepted and work has begun.

Burra Town Council has adopted plans drawn up by the RAA for a new Caravan Park.

Tennis. ‘A’ Grade Preliminary Final: Aberdeen 11-95 defeated Hallett 9-89.

Hanson Tennis Club members have erected a new shed by their courts during the past season.

90, 15, 18 Apr. 1961, page 2

Burra Burra District Council Elections: Members retiring through the effluxion of time.

Hanson Ward S.T. Miller

Baldina Ward M.T. Kellock

Mt Bryan Ward G.H. Cockrum

Booborowie Ward H.B. Quinn

Nominations are called by 12 May with elections on 1 July if required.

90, 15, 18 Apr. 1961, pages 4 & 8

Burra Primary School Parents & Friends Association held its AGM 28 March.

Retiring President M.G. Stockman reported on the past year.

Headmaster Mr Kies was transferred to Adelaide and was replaced by Mr K. Horsnell. Mr H. Kowald was transferred to Angaston, to be succeeded by Mr Sullivan.

Sports Day was held at the Memorial Oval instead of a picnic.

Many people came to Visiting Day, which was held in conjunction with the High School.

The Town Council supplied trees for Arbor Day.

The school roof has at last been renovated and the well roof and box gutters have been done away with, which should improve the quality of the drinking water too.

A school bus has been instituted to carry students from Hanson and Leighton areas.

The school broadcast system has been redesigned and a new speaker added to help in PT exercises and marching; an expensive, but necessary change.

The Department has acquired the land between the Drill Hall and the school. Plans are in hand to extend the asphalted area of the yard.

A move is also planned for a new library and toilet block for primary school children on the east side of the school.

Mr Kies, Mr Kowald and Mrs Phillips were farewelled at the end of the year.

The Secretary reported a membership of 53 and an average attendance of 25. Various items of equipment were purchased for the school as requested by the Headmaster.

[A number of fund raising events are listed.]

Mrs Phillips, the Secretary, moved to Adelaide with her family at the end of the year.

The Christmas break-up was held in individual class parties with ice cream and drinks supplied by the Welfare Club.

90, 15, 18 Apr. 1961, page 5

North Eastern Tennis Association held its AGM in the RSL Hall 6 April. Six teams are to compete this year: Spalding Blue and white, Willalo, Hanson, St Mary’s Burra and Burra Methodist.

90, 15, 18 Apr. 1961, page 6

Bowls

Saddleworth forfeited to Burra Green

Burra Gold defeated Clare.

90, 15, 18 Apr. 1961, page 7

Tennis

B Grade Preliminary Final:

Spalding Red 11-88 defeated Leighton Gold 9-85

The Mokota Tennis Association Final was won by Spalding when they defeated North Booborowie.

90, 16, 25 Apr. 1961, page 1

Burra High School Parents & Friends’ Association was addressed by Inspector Glastonbury on Tuesday 18 April. He said parents could do much towards their child’s education. Plans to improve the playing area would be discussed. 120 chairs for the hall, which had been applied for earlier in the year, had been approved.

Students will go to Kapunda for the Mid-Northern High Schools’ Sports on Thursday 27 April. On Saturday assistance by parents made it possible for Intermediate students to go to Adelaide to see a performance of Julius Caesar. Plans for Education Week have now been finalised.

Burra Golf Season will begin on 29 April.

Redruth Ladies’ Guild reports on a successful year. Secretary Mrs R. Jennison reported that they had 43 members with an average attendance of 30. [Details of the year’s activities are given in 11⁄3 columns.]

90, 16, 25 Apr. 1961, page 2

Advt. Goldsbroughs announce a clearing sale of household furniture at Burra North on 28 April on instructions from the executors in the estate of the late Winifred Bird Nourse.

90, 16, 25 Apr. 1961, page 3

Notice. Burra-Redruth Methodist Church Anniversary will be held 7 May. The preacher will be Rev. Ian Anderson. The Public Tea will be on Monday8 May at 6 p.m. and will be followed by the Religious Sound Film Angel in Ebony.

Weather. Rainfall in Burra for the week was 56 points.

Tennis. Preliminary Final ‘A’ Grade: Aberdeen 11-95 defeated Hallett Red 9-89.

90, 16, 25 Apr. 1961, page 4

Burra Burra District Council

The Department of Lands will be asked for advice concerning the sale of Hanson Streets.

90, 16, 25 Apr. 1961, pages 6 & 7

Anzac Memorial Service. The Burra commemoration was marred by wet and wintry conditions. About 250 attended, but owing to the rain at the commencement, the actual service was transferred to the RSL Hall in place of the Rotunda. After the address by the Rev. T. Drought about 45 ex-servicemen led by the Pt Pirie Pipe Band marched to the Commercial St Bridge and returned to the Memorial where the formal laying of wreaths took place:

Mayor E.T. Baulderstone for the Burra Town Council and Citizens

A.D. Radford for the Burra Burra District Council

L. Fiebig for the Demobilised Soldiers Association

W. Carpenter for the Fathers’ Association

H.R. Cornelius for the Burra Sub-Branch of the RSL

T. Rogers for the Air Force Association.

After the service members of the band were entertained by the RSL members at afternoon tea.

Rev. Drought’s address is printed.

90, 16, 25 Apr. 1961, Supplement [Two-sided 4 columns approximately A4]

Burra Rifle Club. Two possibles were scored by R. Francis and one each by H. Byles, R. Bernhardt, W. Barker and W. Hempel. Best marksman was R. Francis and with handicap R. Francis, R. Bernhardt and M. Stolte.

Bowls. The Premiership Mid North Pennant was won by Spalding.

Tennis. Rain spoilt the Grand Final of the Burra Association, but by the time rain forced play to be abandoned Spalding had won enough sets to win the premiership. Spalding 11-81 defeated Burra 5-67.

90, 17, 2 May 1961, page 1

Tennis. Burra association Grand Final: Spalding 11-81 defeated Aberdeen 5-67.

[Photographs of both teams are printed.]

‘Ratepayer’ writes complaining about the shocking state of the Burra Cemetery and calling for it to be cleaned up and if the Council can’t afford to do so, then some working bees are called for.

Burra Rural Youth have offered to hold dances etc. to aid the CWA Building Fund. The walls of the new CWA Rest Room are rising.

Mid North High Schools Sports were held at Kapunda on Thursday 27 April. Scores in the handicap competition: Kapunda 261, Burra 222, Riverton 2111⁄2, Balaklava 186 and Clare 145. In the open section Clare was first, ahead of Riverton. [Selected local results are printed.]

90, 17, 2 May 1961, page 2

Advt. Under instructions from the Executor for the estate of F.S. Tralaggan, deceased, Elders will auction on 12 May in the Burra RSL Hall four stone lock-up shops (three of which are subject to monthly tenancies and the other to a lease expiring on 4 May 1962) on land with a frontage of 72 ft 7 inches to Market Square and a depth of 66 ft, lying between the new Post Office and the District Council Chambers. There is rear access from Howard Street.

Also the house on the corner of Truro and Fare [sic: for Fore] Streets Burra North – a stone house of five rooms etc.

Proceeds will aid Townsend House Brighton. Seats 5/-, Children 2/6.

90, 18, 9 May 1961, page 1

Burra Hospital is seeking land it can plant with crops to raise money for needed improvements. The electrical wiring in the hospital is out of date and condemned by ETSA. A completely new switchboard is also needed. An air-conditioning plant for the Nursery in the Midwifery Block is also a project on hand. It is also proposed to plant a garden at the entrance to the Nurses’ Home.

Burra Town Council. Cr W.H. Lloyd has advised that he will not seek re-election due to health reasons.

Table Tennis. 26 April

Willalo 21 defeated St Mary’s 4

Hanson forfeited to Spalding White

Burra Methodists 14 defeated Spalding Blue 11

2 May

Willalo 18 defeated Hanson 7

St Mary’s 13 defeated Burra Methodists 12

Spalding Blue 20 defeated Spalding White 5

Education Week in Burra

Friday 28 April. Mr J. Sladden was MC to a series of items in Burra Town Hall by students from Burra Primary, Burra High and St Joseph’s Convent School. The Mayor E.T. Baulderstone introduced Mr R. King, who spoke on What are we doing for our youth?

Sunday 30 April there was a combined service at Kooringa Methodist Church where Rev. R. Jenner traced the history of education.

The schools’ visiting day was a success with many visiting parents.

The Camera and Rural Youth Clubs put on a very successful film evening in the school hall.

Notice. Burra Electric Supply Co. (In Voluntary Liquidation)

A meeting of shareholders will be held at the office of the Liquidator, Douglas J. Wilson 24-26 Eagle Chambers 7 Pirie St Adelaide 2 June 1961 when an account will be laid before them of how the winding up has been conducted and the property of the Company disposed of.

Obituary. Robert (Bob) Finch died suddenly 20 April at his residence in Hindmarsh aged 64. He was the son of William E.J. Finch and brother to Will (deceased), Ethel, Albert (deceased), Lizzie, Lily, Dora and Jack.

[Robert Leonard Finch born 20 April 1896 Kooringa.]

Burra Hospital has received the offer of 8 acres to crop near the Burra Cemetery. The Board is now calling for help in the cultivation and sowing of the crop.

Burra Town Council, May meeting

The Badminton Club was granted the use of the Town Hall.

The Education Department was granted a 20 year lease on both lots in block 13A with the proviso that entrance be allowed to the slag paddock along the western fence. [This is the area in front of the original school building including the pre-school area now.]

90, 20, 23 May 1961, page 1

Burra Hospital Cropping Project has received offers totalling 70 acres and some offers of labour, but more offers of labour, seed and super are still needed. Chief Secretary, Sit Lyell McEwin has granted a subsidy on the new 50,000 gallon cement tank, which will be commenced shortly. The tender has gone to Concrete Tanks Ltd with A.L. Clode & Son to do the roofing and guttering. It is hoped to have it ready for this winter’s rains.

Donors of land: John McBride (17 acres), Koonoona Proprietors (16-20 acres), Burt Broad (8 acres), Jack Terry (21⁄2 acres) and Peter Drew (22 Acres).

Mr & Mrs F.A. Smallacombe were farewelled at Booborowie on 17 May. They are moving to Spalding.

Tennis. Final of Burra Association ‘B’ Grade:

Spalding Blue defeated Spalding Red. [Photographs of both teams are printed.]

Burra Burra DC, 22 April.

A deputation was received from Mt Bryan Emergency Fire Service with a proposal to the Council for supplying a Fire Fighting Pump and Truck to the Mt Bryan Fire Service. Council then decided to apply for a subsidy of £600 on the purchase of a truck and for the allotment of a suitable truck.

Detective Sgt D.A. O’Malley of Pt Pirie, whose district covers this area, has been transferred to Elizabeth. He will be replaced at Pt Pirie by Detective Sgt R. McCallum from Glenelg.

Adelaide Wool Sales. Top district price was 721⁄2d for Old Koomooloo Ltd, while J.N. McBride of Kia-Ora received 72d. [Other local district prices are printed.] [Top price corrected 90, 21, 30 May 1961, page 1 to 73d for A. & G. Tennant’s wool from Redcliffe.]

90, 20, 23 May 1961, page 3

Burra Rifle Club fired the 15th stage of the Annual Trophy. R. Kellock topped the marksman’s contest and best on handicap were R. Oakley, R. Kellock and J. Brown.

90, 20, 23 May 1961, page 4

Mr W.F. Johns, formerly a Burra grazier at ‘Studholme’, has designed a special motor cycle for terrain and cross-country areas and for slow tedious mustering duties. Produced by the Nippon Gakki Co. Ltd of Japan, they were introduced to SA stock firms last week and were demonstrated in Adelaide. Mr Johns said the idea came to him when attending to sheep on ‘Studholme’ on unsuitable machines. He had a knowledge of military vehicles, gained during the war. Nippon Gakki were prepared to build machines for testing before getting larger orders. The result is the Liberty Yamaha Ranch Model with high clearance mudguards, upswept exhaust pipes to avoid rocks etc. duplex reinforced frame and heavy duty suspension front and rear in telescopic assembly and five gears, allowing extensive use at low speeds. Dalgety’s are the distributors.

90, 22, 6 June 1961, page 1

Weather. 25 of the past 80 years were drier than 1961 and 1957 was the driest. The present dry spell is causing concern. Rainfall to date is 431 points for January to May. In 1957 only 169 points fell with then 149 in June.

Basketball. North Eastern Association

‘A’ Grade Burra 39 defeated Booborowie 17

Spalding 21 drew with Hallett 21.

Burra Hospital. The cropping project is going well, but offers of labour, seed and super are still needed. The floor of the hospital’s 50,000 gallon tank has been poured and the walls will be poured today.

Mr R.G. Bernhardt was elected unopposed. He has previously been a Councillor for 1950-51 & 1951-52.

90, 22, 6 June 1961, page 5

Advt. Full page advertisement for Jennison’s Tyre Service.

90, 23, 13 June 1961, page 1

Burra Town Council received a deputation on Monday night last week of representatives of the Burra Primary School, concerned about the dangers of crossing the main road. The Mayor said the Council was sympathetic, but in the end the whole thing would depend on the Commissioner of Highways. The deputation said their purpose was to get, if possible, a pedestrian crossing connecting the new bridge across the Burra Creek and the Town Hall. The Welfare Club had sought action some time ago. The Highways Department had inspected the area and given the distance of the crossing from the school, they could only suggest flashing lights.

It had been understood that monitors would be required, but this is not necessary on advice from the Minister of Roads, Mr Jude. It was decided to go ahead and the Welfare Club had £200 in hand, but the Minister of Education advised that the sum could not be used for this purpose and so a move to press for a pedestrian crossing was considered.

Mr Stockman pointed out that a crossing could be used by other than school children and in the summer period by people going to and from the swimming pool.

It was pointed out that a pedestrian crossing would compel motorists to stop if any pedestrian was using the crossing, whereas flashing lights would merely warn motorists of the possibility of children crossing and slow them down to 15 m.p.h., but as the school was half a mile away motorists could not be compelled to observe the 15 m.p.h. speed limit. It could be enforced past the playground, but that would not help much. A pedestrian crossing could be set up by the Council with the permission of the Commissioner of Highways and it needed a prohibition of parking for 30 ft either side.

After discussion the Council decided to apply for a pedestrian crossing.

Obituary. A memorial service was held at Willalo Methodist Church on Sunday 4 June for the late Mr & Mrs Joseph Thomas of ‘Glenburnie’ Willalo.

[The commonness of this name makes identification uncertain. Mrs Joseph Thomas nee Marion Henderson Bryce died 4 April 1961 at Adelaide, residence Manningham and her husband may have been the Joseph Thomas who died 27 November 1957 at Northfield, residence Balaklava.]

Adelaide Wool Sales. The highest price in the district was 76d by D.G. & S.M. Radford of Canegrass.

[Other local district prices are printed.]

National Heart Campaign ‘Operation Heartbeat’

Only 12 attended a public meeting in Burra called by the Mayor E.T. Baulderstone about the above campaign. It was decided that sufficient collectors could be arranged from the CWA, Burra North Red Cross, Burra Football Club, Rural Youth and the RSL to carry out a door knock collection in the town.

Football. Booborowie Football Club has decided to form a ‘B’ grade team and was in favour of a ‘B’ Grade team to replace the Colts competition, but realised this move would have to come from the Association.

Burra Town Hall Picture Committee has recommended that now that the loan for the purchase of the projector etc. at the Town Hall has been paid off, the income could be used for any local club or body using the Town Council property and desirous of improving their grounds or buildings. Bodies concerned would apply to the committee for a date on a Wednesday night and profits from that night’s showing would go to the body making the application. The Town Council has accepted the recommendation.

90, 23, 13 June 1961, page 2

Birth. To Bernard & Yvonne Smith nee Jones, at Burra Hospital, a son, Graeme Ross.

90, 24, 20 June 1961, page 1

Weather. Burra rainfall for June is now 1 inch.

Burra Hospital. A further 1⁄3-column article of news about the cropping project. The Rural Youth Club has taken over the 10 acres of land near the cemetery and is doing the necessary preparation.

90, 24, 20 June 1961, page 6

Obituary. Herman Rudolph Weickert of Kapunda and formerly of bethel and Bandmaster at Riverton, having been appointed 25 July 1947. He was 69. [Hermann Rudolph Weichert born 9 September 1891 Bethel: died 13 June 1961 near Adelaide, residence Kapunda.]

90, 25, 27 June 1961, page 1

Burra Ratepayers’ Meeting. Thirty attended. The Mayor E.T. Baulderstone revealed a reduction in the Council’s overdraft from £1,200 to £300 in the last 12 months. Record grant money had been received. Owing to the large number of creeks in the town bridges were costly to maintain and through grant money it had been possible to reconstruct the Smelts Road Bridge and also that on the Eastern Road near Mr H. White’s. The cemetery came in for much criticism, but care of graves was the responsibility of the people and for the paths, of the Council.

There were many parks in the town and a good beautification scheme could be submitted. The Caravan Park is now obsolete as far as parks of today are concerned. A plan for a new park has been adopted and it is hoped a pound for pound subsidy can be obtained for the coming year. It had been hoped to open the mine area as a tourist spot in March or April this year, but this had not been possible. A public meeting was called, but with only five or six people attending, it was not known whether people in the town were in favour.

Street lighting appears to be OK. The War Memorial Committee continues to work at the oval and a new basketball court is being erected. The Small Bore Club has improved the area on the south of the wall and thanks go to them for the effort.

The Mayor was proud of the financial care, which had reduced the overdraft from £1,200 to £300 this year.

Burra Hospital. The cropping project is up-dated in c. 1⁄2 column.

The urgent needs at the hospital have been listed as:

Air-conditioning in the Midwifery Wing Nursery

A new buzzer system

A wheel chair

An infra-red lamp

Personal scales for Midwifery

Heart Campaign Appeal donations from Burra and District are reported to be nearing £300. In an associated Schools’ Essay Competition, Ian McGrath obtained the 4th year prize of £2 and also the second State Prize of £5. Suzanne Harris got £2 for her effort in the 3rd year class, Peter Benger won £1 in 2nd Year and Ian Mickel £1 for 1st year. Ian McGrath has been accepted as a Junior Recruit in the RAN and will report on 10 July to commence training on HMAS Leuin [sic: elsewhere Leeuwin] a sick berth attendant for a two month period of training.

St Mary’s will celebrate a ‘Back to St Mary’s Day’ on 2 July; it being the Feast of the Visitation of the Blessed Virgin Mary. It will be a special day of thanksgiving for the recent restoration of the interior and exterior of the church. Present for the occasion will be Rev. R.S.T. Pettet (Rector 1948-53), F.J. Hopton whose father was Rector 1918-21, K.T. Jenkins of St Peter’s College and Rev. R.S. Jenner of Burra Methodist Church. Program:

11 a.m. Holy Eucharist

1 p.m. Lunch at the RSL Rooms

3 p.m. Thanksgiving Service

4.30 p.m. Afternoon Tea in the RSL Rooms

250 have accepted invitations and a large gathering is assured.

At the morning service there will be the dedication of:

A new side chapel.

The High Altar given by Mrs O.A. Tattersall in memory of her parents.

Altar candlesticks given by Mr & Mrs H.J. Wilson & family in memory of their son and brother Roderick Richard Wilson SBA who was lost with HMAS Sydney in 1941.

A flower pedestal given by Mr & Mrs H.L. Riggs.

And other sanctuary furnishings.

The cross and candlesticks are being made of copper to preserve the link with Burra’s past and pieces of malachite will be inserted into the cross; taken from the old mine and donated by Mr E. Finch, Mrs L. & Mr S. Kellaway and Mr H.J. Wilson.

90, 25, 27 June 1961, page 2

Burra Town Council Election

North Ward. 52% of electors voted.

R.J. Jeffery 72

Hallett RSL Ball is reported. Miss Beth Hempel of Burra and partner Mr Richard Price of Booborowie were judged the Belle and Beau.

Burra Hospital. The cropping project now has 871⁄2 acres sown.

Burra Town Clerk Mr R. Fullgrabe reports that all rates and all arrears have been paid.

Basketball

Hallett 39 defeated Booborowie 15

Burra 39 defeated Mr Bryan 15 [This coincidence of scores is highly suspicious.]

‘B’ Grade Booborowie 18 defeated Burra Blue 14

Burra CWA’s new Rest Rooms were opened on Friday by Mrs C.E. Dolling. The building was erected as a memorial to the late Mrs Mary Warnes, the founder of the CWA in SA and a plaque bearing this inscription was unveiled by Mr Rex Warnes. [A more detailed report is held over pending the arrival of the photo blocks.]

The Heart Campaign Appeal in Burra & the District raised £327-19-8.

St Mary’s. The back-to-St Mary’s Day at Burra was believed to have attracted the largest congregation ever, with approximately 400 at the dedication service. The dedications (as listed last week) were performed by Rev. R.S.T. Pettet, who was also the celebrant. Mrs Herb Riggs was convenor of the Guild group who had the tremendous task of serving a buffet luncheon in the RSL Hall and also afternoon tea. At the 3 p.m. Thanksgiving Evensong Rev. K.T. Jenkins, Chaplain of St Peter’s College, was the preacher and Rev. R.S. Jenner of Burra read the lessons. The organist was Rev. John Hopton whose father was a former Rector at St Mary’s some 40 years ago. St Joseph’s Church committee sent greetings and best wishes that were much appreciated.
