90, 26, 4 July 1961, page 4

Mt Bryan CWA held its AGM and elected President, Mrs D. Thomas; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames Crew & Jefferies; Secretary Mrs Osterhage & Treasurer, Mrs Griffen. [The whole report extends for c. 1 column.]

Kooringa Methodist Youth Fellowship held a chop picnic at Redbanks on Monday 26 June.

90, 26, 4 July 1961, page 5

Burra Ratepayers’ Meeting (Continued from last week.)

The Town Hall has not deteriorated and in the past twelve months 100 chairs have been purchased and the main aisle and stairways have been carpeted. Through a legacy it was possible to completely redecorate the stage. Overall the pictures have held their own despite television and they are still doing a wonderful job towards the finances.

On the health front the collection of refuse is more satisfactory than in the past.

The ambulance service is running smoothly.

The Mayor expressed his concern of the way that he and other Councillors in business have been penalised for doing ‘something for nothing’ in the Council. He had been in business in Burra for 30 years and in Council for 15. He expressed bitterness at the attitude of the people concerned, but whatever he did in Council would not affect him in the future as he was retiring from his Market Square business on 30 June. He expressed concern at the lack of interest in Council elections. On numerous occasions ratepayers had not even arranged to see that their ward was represented. He expressed his thanks to the retiring Councillors.

[There were apparently many questions posed and answered, but not reported in the paper.]

Mr H.J.B. Jennison moved the vote of thanks to the Mayor, Mayoress and Councillors and said it was a thankless job.

90, 26, 4 July 1961, page 7

Football. North Eastern

Hallett 25.22 defeated Burra 8.7

Booborowie 17.15 defeated Spalding 10.12

‘B’ Grade

Spalding 15.16 defeated Booborowie 0.2

Spalding Colts 12.17 defeated Booborowie Colts 0.0

Mid North

Manoora 6.9 defeated Robertstown 4.12

Saddleworth 15.6 defeated Clare South 11.17

Clare North 13.14 defeated Riverton 5.5

Aberdeen 34.17 defeated Auburn 8.5. (For Aberdeen Kevin Lane kicked 16 goals.)

90, 27, 11 July 1961, page 1

Burra CWA had a proud day on Friday 30 June when its new Rest Rooms were opened in memory of the late Mary Warnes. Before this the branch has never owned their own rooms. A large crowd gathered in Chapel Street for the opening and 15 of the 16 branches in the Warnes Group were represented. Seven other branches were also represented. Seven foundation members of Burra branch were present: Mesdames

H. Wardle G. Leaney A.T. McWaters

E. Jettner A.L. Kellock __ Hogan Sen.

A. Marchant

The Mayor and Mayoress of Burra and the Architect Mr H.M. Jackman & Mrs Jackman were among the official guests. Burra President Mrs H.J.B. Jennison welcomed the guests and said the rooms had been erected as a memorial to Mary Warnes as founder of the CWA in SA. The Burra Branch had never had a home of its own, though it had had many ‘homes’ including the Town Hall where they had been very happy. At the last AGM it was decided it was time to build a home of their own. The site chosen was judged ideal, close to the shopping area. Negotiations commenced with Mr L. Gordon and at that stage the Warnes Family presented the branch with the necessary finance to make the purchase. Considerable funds were on hand and a building committee was formed. When a likely looking plan had been developed Mrs A. Tennant arranged with Mr Jackman to draw up the plans at no cost to the branch. The tender of A.L. Clode and Son was accepted for the construction and portions of it were sub-let. The building was due for completion by 20 June and the opening was hurried a little because Mrs Dolling and Mrs Tennant were going away in early July. Furnishings etc. were not quite completed. Mrs Dolling was called on to perform the opening and in doing so recalled the youthful experiences of Mrs Warnes, who had learned the meaning of loneliness and formed a desire to form the CWA in SA, having read of its work interstate. Now 80 Rest Rooms are owned by the CWA and many more are rented throughout the state. Mr Rex Warnes said it was a proud moment for him as he unveiled the plaque in memory of his mother. An inspection of the interior was followed by afternoon tea.

[Five photographs are printed:

Mrs Mary Warnes.

The group at the unveiling of the plaque.

Mr Jackman & Mr A.L. Clode at the plaque.

An outside view of the building and the crowd.

The foundations members present. [This one is on page 8.]

Mr G.C. (George) McWaters of Cunderdin WA is 90 on 16 July. He is an old Burraite who still enjoys good health. [George Cranford McWaters born 16 July 1871 Leighton: died 15 March 1963.]

Burra & District Ambulance covered 6,400 miles in the past year. 65 patients were conveyed to hospital of which 16 went to Adelaide. Membership was 379 in 1960, but so far only 213 in 1961. Present credit balance is £600. The annual meeting last week attracted only 7 members!

Weather. Burra received 117 points in the past week, but rain did not extend far to the east. 65 points fell at Mongolata, but only 20 at Glenora.

Hogget Competitions

At Mt Bryan on 4 July the winner was T.P. Griffen & Co.

The Hanson winner was C.A. McDonald.

At Hallett on 5 July the winner Was W.G. Miller & Sons.

The North Eastern Zone Final will be held at Booborowie 12 July.

Obituary. ‘Lel’ Kellaway died suddenly on 5 July. In the past year he has been the Burra Bowling Club greensman. He was always very interested in sports and in his youth was a renowned cricketer, excelling in bowling. He was one of the best ‘draw bowlers’ Burra Club has seen and was a top bowler and skipper for many years. [Leslie Kellaway born 18 March 1893 Kooringa: died 5 July 1961 Burra.]

90, 28, 18 July 1961, page 1

M & BHA held its AGM in the Town Hall supper room. 28 attended and elected: President, Mrs B. Bevan; Secretary, Mrs R. Thamm and Treasurer, Mrs C. Spackman.

Burra Small Bore Club has arranged for 5AD’s Western Party & Variety Show to be conducted from the Burra Town Hall on 28 July, compered by Robert Fricker. Proceeds of the concert will fund improvements to the range at Burra.

Burra High School held its Arbor Day on 14 July. Ten trees were planted.

The North Eastern Hogget Competition was decided at Windy Brae, the property of J.T. & M.E. Drew of Booborowie on Wednesday 12 July. The weather was ideal. There were 8 pens, each of 25 hoggets. First place went to W.G. Miller & Sons of Hallett. Second place went to A.D. & C.A. McDonald of Leighton.

[Details of the whys and wherefores are printed.]

Burra Red Cross held its AGM 11 July and elected: President, Mrs H. Topsfield; Secretary, Mrs N. Sieber & Treasurer, Mrs J. McBride.

Burra Rifle Club visited Clare on Sunday, where, despite the two top scores coming from G. Webster and Jim Brown of Burra, Clare managed to win 557 to 528.

90, 28, 18 July 1961, page 5

Golf. Russell Pitcher hit a hole in one at the sixth.

A meeting is to be called shortly to consider the re-forming of the Hallett Golf Club, which was disbanded during the war. It is considered the 9-hole course can be restored without much work.

90, 28, 18 July 1961, Supplement [Single sided 4 columns on page of approximately A4 size.]

Hallett CWA held its AGM and drew 40 members. Elected: President, Mrs J. Murray; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames E. Ashby & M. Rayner; Secretary, Mrs J. Reed; Assistant Secretary, Mrs K. Miller and Treasurer, Mrs J. Honan.

Burra Rural Youth. Miss Ruth Neal, a representative of UK Young Farmers, is at present a guest of the Burra Rural Youth Club for two weeks.

90, 29, 25 July 1961, page 1

Hallett CWA Ball is reported. It was a great success with some 450 in attendance. Sixteen debutantes were presented along with five presentees to the President of the CWA Mrs R.L. Hall. Door takings were £136.

[A photograph of the young ladies is printed.]

Weather. Good general rains brought falls from 0.5 to 1 inch generally. In the east there was little run-off, but most places are reasonably well situated for water at present.

The DLP Meeting at Burra in the RSL Hall on 19 July is reported. Speakers were Mr J. Schlitz, Country Organiser for the NSW Branch and Mr B.J. Nash.

Mr Schlitz spoke of the growth of Communism and its influence on the ALP and the Trade Unions.

Mr Nash also spoke of the way Communist Russia was able to dominate and control Eastern Europe and he feared the same fate for Australia with respect to Communist China. Supporting the LCL with preferences was the lesser of two evils he said.

Burra LCL Women’s Branch held its AGM on 7 July in the Institute Supper Room. Elected were: President, Mrs R.B. Pitcher; Vice-Presidents, Mrs G.S. Hawker, Mrs A.L. Kellock & Mrs J. Stevens; Secretary, Mrs J.W. Riggs and Treasurer, Miss E. Tiver. The Premier Sir Thomas Playford, Lady Playford and the Hon. W.W. Robinson were welcomed. Sir Thomas addressed the meeting, stressing SA’s progress since WWII and continuing advances in the South East and at Whyalla.

Three youths were prosecuted for the use of a spotlight from a motor vehicle on a road for the purposes of shooting.

90, 29, 25 July 1961, page 8

Burra Rural Youth held a Teenage Ball in Burra Town Hall on Friday and door takings were c. £86. Music was by the ‘Tremours’ from Adelaide.

90, 30, 1 Aug. 1961, page 1

Pascoe’s Barber Shop has closed after 73 years. In 1888 the late R.D. Pascoe began business in the shop now occupied by Messrs R.A. Bevan & Son and later moved to a portion of that now occupied by Bence’s Ltd. In 1910 the premises now housing the Burra Radio & Electrical Service were taken over and one portion used as a barber shop and the other as a newsagency. It was at this time that Mr J. (Joe) Pascoe commenced his trade with his father and brother, the late Mr Claude Pascoe. Another brother, Frank, ran the newsagency and the late Mr O. (Twist) Ockenden was in charge of a branch of the saloon at Aberdeen. In 1946 following the death of Mr R.D. Pascoe ‘Joe’ carried on the business on his own until five or six weeks ago when ill health caused him to retire and close the hairdressing section of the business. One interesting feature, which has gradually faded over the years, was the pigeonholes of shaving mugs and brushes. Years ago the business formed a Shavers’ Club with a membership fee of one shilling a week. Each member had his own mug and brush in one of the pigeonholes and for the one shilling fee he would be shaved as often as he presented himself during the week. At one stage there were 184 mugs and brushes. Going back a year or two ‘Joe’ said haircuts were 6d and shaves 3d and with three chairs in operation it would have been a quiet Friday to have fewer than 40 shaves to do. Joe still has the razor he used when he first commenced work and though considerably worn down, it could still be used today. All this has changed with the advent of the safety razor and later the electric razor. Another well known feature was the collection of sheep photos, which covered the entire four walls. The collection dates back to 1910 when the late Mr L. Gebhardt of Mokota brought in the first photo to hang in the shop. Other stud breeders followed suit and after a time it amounted to a very fine collection indeed.

Hallett Red Cross held its AGM and elected: President, Mrs R. Honan and Vice-Presidents, Mrs Owen-Smyth, Mrs J. Murray and Mrs R. Nutt.

Mrs R. Holmes was given a farewell at Leighton recently. She now lives in Spalding.

Mr & Mrs Merv. Lehmann were given a farewell at the RSL Rooms last Thursday. They are to reside at Balhannah.

Burra Small Bore Club. The Western & Variety Show compered by 5AD’s Robert Fricker in the Burra Town Hall on Friday night resulted in a profit of £72 to be spent on improvements to the range area.

Burra Rifle Club held its presentation night and annual dance in the RSL Rooms on 22 July. Life membership was conferred on Messrs R. Fuss, W. Hempel, R.G. Bernhardt & M.E. Mitchell.

90, 31, 8 Aug. 1961, page 1

St Joseph’s Convent Fete was held in the RSL Hall on Friday. £211 was raised.

Mr Syd. Pearce of Burra will be 90 on Thursday 10 August.

Theft. Thieves broke into the strong room at Dinham Bros. store in Booborowie during the night of 31July/1 August and escaped with £190 in cash and goods. Oxy-acetylene equipment was used to gain entry.

Burra High School. The Intermediate Class recently travelled to Clare to see a performance of Shakespeare’s Julius Caesar. Mr L. Bence has donated £15 to the school and enabled it to purchase a selection of ten pictures. Mr E. Zanker has presented an excellent painting of his to the headmaster.

Ironmine Methodist Sunday School celebrated the 38th birthday of the Sunday School Hall on 22 July.

Leighton Hall Committee has called tenders for the installation of wiring etc. in preparation for the arrival of ETSA power, which is about to be connected.

Kooringa Methodist Church. A photo is printed of the Junior Christian Endeavour Class.

90, 31, 8 Aug. 1961, page 2

Advt. Goldsbrough, Mort & Co. have instructions from the proprietor of Burra North Motors of Morehead Street Burra North to auction on 25 August the Garage, Plant Machinery and Spare Parts.

90, 31, 8 Aug. 1961, page 7

Mid Northern District Methodist Synod sent a letter of congratulations to Mr E.W. Dunhill of Burra, who celebrates 70 years of active service as a local preacher of the Methodist Church. He continues to preach with amazing vigour and earnestness and his remarkable memory allows him to preach without notes and to keep exactly to time.

90, 31, 8 Aug. 1961, page 8

Table Tennis. 25 July

Willalo 20-39 defeated Spalding White 5-11

Hanson 13-28 defeated Burra Methodists 12-23

1 August

Spalding Blue 13-29 defeated Hanson 12-28

Spalding White 15-31 defeated St Mary’s 10-24

Willalo 18-35 defeated Burra Methodists 7-16

90, 32, 15 Aug. 1961, page 1

Burra Bowling Club held its AGM and elected: Patron, G. Dollman; President, S.J. Woollacott; Vice-Presidents, D. Jacka & J. Topsfield; Secretary, O.A. Tattersall and Treasurer, B. Riggs.

The club had a minute’s silence for the deaths in the past year of L. Kellaway, W. Pattrick and M. Breen. It was resolved that there be three teams this year: two in the Mid North Association and one in the North Eastern Association.

Burra War Memorial Committee. The picture night at the Town Hall last Wednesday raised c. £20.

The Northern Areas Small Bore Association was formed at a meeting on Friday at Burra. Delegates came from Riverton, Clare, Morgan, Peterborough, Terowie and Burra. R. Kellock was elected President and W. Barker the Secretary.

Burra Town Council, having adopted the E & WS assessment values for the town, received 18 appeals against those valuations. Ten were unsuccessful and eight were reduced. Council declared a rate of 4/- in the pound – a reduction of 3d from last year.

1960-61 assessment £33,625 and a rate income of £7,182.

1960-62 assessment £37,670 and a rate income of £7,565-2-0.

Booborowie CWA held its AGM. Twenty-four members attended at the home of Mrs F. Sullivan on 10 August. Financial report shows a credit of £142 and it was decided to donate £15 to Red Cross.

90, 32, 15 Aug. 1961, page 3

Advt. For Sale. A stone home of five rooms etc. in Thames St. Apply to Dalgety’s or to J.T. Pascoe.

19 August

Rally Round the Flag Boys

Flaming Frontier

90, 33, 22 Aug. 1961, page 1

Weather. 175 points of rain fell for the week and were a wonderful boost for crops and pastures. The 110 points overnight on Saturday/Sunday tested gutters and drains. Some light snow was reported from several places on Sunday. The rain did not extend to the east.

Burra High School. Burra went to Riverton and Clare for lightning sports carnivals last Wednesday, which were played in continuous rain.

Football. In the North Eastern Association the leading goal-kicker for the season was J. Brooks of Hallett with 41. The best for Burra was B. Eberhard with 28 – ranking 6th overall.

Table Tennis. Semi-Finals

Burra Methodists 8-35 defeated St Mary’s 7-17.

Burra Catholic Ball was held in the Town Hall on Friday night. The crowd was smaller than usual, but the profit is still expected to be about £50.

The Burra Open Golf Tournament was marred by rain, hail, a bitterly cold wind and the threat of snow on Saturday. Despite this 96 players paid the fee and entered the event, though not all ventured beyond the Club House. The Treasurer was probably the happiest person on the day, with £70 to bank and some rain insurance money to come.

‘A’ Grade Championship H. McKeough

‘B’ Grade Championship J. Murray

‘A’ Grade Handicap 27 Holes B. Prior

‘B’ Grade Handicap 27 Holes A.J. Hunter

‘A’ Grade Morning Handicap 18 Holes B. Prior

‘B’ Grade Morning Handicap 18 Holes P. Ellis

‘A’ Grade Afternoon Handicap 9 Holes R. Barnes

‘B’ Grade Afternoon Handicap 9 Holes A. Wright

Veterans’ A.J. Hunter

Diggers’ J. Sladden

Teams Event A. Hancock, G. Pengilly & E. Norton

On Wednesday six Associates went to Jamestown for their Open Day and Mrs J. Minchin got a trophy for the afternoon round and Miss E. Tiver won the 9-hole competition.

90, 33, 22 Aug. 1961, page 8

Basketball. Mid North Association. Semi-Final

‘B’ Manoora 36 defeated Tarlee 20

Preliminary Finals

Robertstown Gold 41 defeated Riverton Black 31

90, 34, 29 Aug. 1961, page 1

Booborowie Robbery. A possible clue to the robbery of Dinham Bros. at Booborowie is the finding of oxy-acetylene cutting equipment and a cash box near Porter’s Lagoon. The oxy equipment was stolen from the SA Harbour’s Board at Pt Adelaide about a month ago. Investigation continues.

Basketball Court. A meeting at the Burra Town Hall on Thursday night considered floodlighting for the basketball court and the Memorial Oval. It is believed the cost would be about £150-£200. As most players were juniors it was thought it would be unfair to expect them to raise the funds and therefore the help of outside bodies and persons would be appreciated. One generous sponsor has offered £150 on loan for 12 months, interest free to enable the work to be completed as soon as possible. A committee has been established.

Burra Golf Club. Stan Longford retained his ‘A’ Grade Championship on Sunday when he defeated Jim Minchin. Four members went to Eudunda for their open day. Roly Barnes won the ‘A’ Grade 27-hole Handicap. Ray Jennison won the 18-hole Stableford. The Burra Team of R. Barnes, R. Jennison & Clutterbuck won the teams’ event.

Football. The Burra Record Trophy for 1961 goes to John Dewhirst of Booborowie. He also won it in 1959. He came second to Keith Warrior of Hallett for the Mail Medal for 1961. [The Mail Medal voting is printed.]

Burra RSL entertained members of the Burra Bowling Club last Thursday.

Basketball. First and Second Semi-Finals

‘A’ Grade Hallett 41 defeated Burra 40

Spalding 26 defeated Booborowie 21

‘B’ Grade Burra Blue 24 defeated Burra Grey 13

Terowie 23 defeated Spalding 9

SA Country Racing Clubs Assoc. was formed at a meeting in Adelaide on 11 August. The object is to promote and improve country racing in SA.

President, Gerald Gask, President of Northern Racing Clubs’ Association & Chairman of Burra Racing Club.

Vice-President, Mr Ray Hall of the Upper Northern District Racing Assoc. & Chairman of Iron Knob Racing Club.

Secretary/Treasurer, Mr Alan Durward, Secretary of the Southern Racing Clubs’ Assoc. & Secretary of Strathalbyn Racing Club.

6 September

91, 35, 5 Sep. 1961, page 1

Weather. In the past week good general rains have delivered up to an inch, most of it from Thursday onwards. Most dams are now full. For the week some registrations to hand: Old Koomooloo 81 points, Koomooloo 92, Woolgangi 76, Balah 107, Grassville 141, Mongolata 120 and Burra 123.

A Charleston Competition at Booborowie on Friday night was judged by Mr & Mrs Ken Murphy of Burra and Mr & Mrs Glen Williams of Hallett. It was won by Mr Dick Price and Mrs Benton, both of Booborowie.

Mr & Mrs Ross Day were given a farewell at the RSL Clubroom on Friday when 27 members and 13 ladies attended. A games evening was followed by supper. RSL President Mr H. Cornelius said Ross had been an active member of the House Committee over many years.

Mr & Mrs Walter Smith’s family had a reunion at their Glenunga home on 3 September. The family was formerly of Burra. Visitors included:

Mr & Mrs Gordon Smith (Riverton) and daughters Dawn & Kay (Mrs Lambert of Auburn).

Mr & Mrs Dick Crang & sons Bill & Richard (recently relocated from Alice Springs to Adelaide).

Mrs Muriel Humphris & children John & Ann, from Arthur River WA. (Husband Zac Humphris was unable to accompany them.)

Mr & Mrs Ron Smith (from Hamilton Victoria) and daughters Pam & Sue.

Burra Camera Club. Competition photo printed. A country scene slide by M.K. Bell: placed 5th.

Hallett CWA. 5th birthday celebrations on 22 August are reported.

Basketball. Mid North Assoc. Finals

‘A’ Grade Robertstown Gold 52 defeated Saddleworth 31

‘B’ Grade Saddleworth Blue 43 defeated Manoora 30

North Eastern Assoc. Finals

‘A’ Grade Burra 31 defeated Spalding 12

‘B’ Grade Spalding defeated Burra Blue

Burra Bowling Club. The six new rinks were top dressed by a working bee on Saturday. This gives the club 13 rinks.

91, 35, 5 Sep. 1961, pages 1 & 5

Burra Hospital Annual Meeting 28 August

R.K .Pearse presented a comprehensive report.

Financially for the year the average daily cost per in-patient £4-1-0 (£4-5-7 in 1959-60) and for out-patients was 17/-. Prompt payment of accounts attracts a rebate of 5/- per day and this has proved attractive. No payment of accounts is the Board’s greatest difficulty and the Board urges all to join a Hospital Benefits Scheme.

During the year there were 428 patients, which averaged 11.9 compared with 11 in 1959-60. There were 692 out-patients and 67 births. The hospital greatly benefits from support of the community and a list of donations received is attached. This year we are particularly grateful for a bequest from the estate of the late Clare Ethel Gare of £399-15-0. The cropping program reached 90 acres despite a late start and we are grateful to all concerned. We hope to double or treble this next year. [Mr Pearse then lists a host of minor repairs and improvements.]

The use of the town’s hard water has a very detrimental effect on the hot water system and the boiler had to be replaced. The Board decided to install a 50,000 gallon tank to catch all rain water, increasing the capacity to 130,000 gallons and this has been completed and will enable the usage of rain water only in the hot water system, which weekly uses 2,500 gallons. Major improvements planned are air-conditioning in the Nursery, a new switchboard and rewiring of the hospital. (Already commenced.) Also, modernisation of the laundry, a toilet in the domestic quarters, a buzzer system and improvements to the grounds.

Staffing has improved and Matron L. Fyfe has proved very efficient and co-operative and we are lucky to have someone of her conscientiousness and ability. The Board expresses its appreciation of all nurses and domestic staff. Last December Mr M .Breen BA BEc Dip PA, who had been our secretary/manager for 18 months and who was responsible for putting our books in order, resigned to retire to Norfolk Island and it was with deep regret that we learned of his death only two months later. Mr Harold Foote was appointed secretary/manager and has the full confidence of the Board.

The Ladies’ Auxiliary continues to give valuable assistance and the hospital is indebted to them. The Burra & District Fund Raising Committee has been active and handed over cheques to the value of £459. We are also thankful for the Burra Record for making available space for publicity for the hospital.

91, 35, 5 Sep. 1961, page 2

Advt. Elders will conduct a clearing sale for M.T. & I.J. Pettet at Mt Bryan 26 September. Their property has been sold.

CHECK PAGINATION OF THIS ISSUE: HARD COPY HAS PAGE 9 AFTER PAGE 6 THE REVERSE OF PAGE 9 HAS NO NUMBER AND THERE ARE NO PAGES 7 & 8

91, 36, 12 Sep. 1961, page 1

Burra Racing Club held its AGM and discussed the need for more members when only two members other than the committee attended. Elected: Patron, Andrew Tennant; President, Mr G. Gask. [Photo printed.]

Many district residents have been circularised and issued with membership tickets and the committee hopes for greater district support. The President said he was concerned about the deficit of £205, but hoped with fewer expenses this year the situation would improve. The smaller clubs generally were finding it hard to carry on and Burra is unfortunate in being too far away to draw horses from either the northern areas or from the Upper Murray. The situation for Burra is not the best. It is hoped to have the Northern Racing Association’s mobile starting gates at the March meeting. There are 96 nominations for the September meeting.

Table Tennis. North Eastern Association Grand Final

Willalo 19-36 defeated Burra Methodists 6-16

In the inter-association game Stanley Assoc. 16 sets defeated North Eastern Assoc. 14 sets.

Burra Hospital crops are looking good and the 50,000 gallon tank is now two-thirds full and all the hospital tanks are interconnected. A subsidy has been granted for air-conditioning in the Nursery.

Booborowie Basketball Club held a Roaring Twenties Ball on 1 September, which was a success with door takings of £75. [A photo of club members who provided a floor show is printed.]

Burra Camera Club Landscape Photo Competition. R. Sandercock’s 3rd placed photo is printed.

F.L. Kerr, Director of Emergency Fire Services in SA was guest speaker at the AGM of the Burra District Emergency Fire Service on 30 August in the RSL Rooms. Attendance of local residents was very poor; only five attended. Mr Kerr explained details of the new Bush Fires Act and congratulated the Burra Burra DC on buying a fire-fighting truck to be placed in the hands of the Mt Bryan Fire Fighting Organisation. The good season will provide fuel for the coming fire season.

Burra Town Council

An invitation was received from the Trustees of the Redruth Methodist Church for Councillors to attend the unveiling of the C.E. Gare Plaque at Burra North on 17 September.

Permission was given for the Small Bore Club to hold a shoot on Sunday 1 October.

It was resolved that the Burra Basketball Club be responsible for power used to light the court.

A letter of appreciation is to be sent to Dr R. Rischbieth of Church Terrace for his sending the trowel used to lay the foundation stone of the Town Hall.

91, 38, 26 Sep. 1961, page 1

Football. Photo of Booborowie Football Club Premiership Team 1961.

Photo of John Dewhirst (Booborowie) winner of the Burra Record Trophy 1959 & 1961.

Burra Rifle Club. A double 500 yard match was shot at Clare.

Mr John Hammer, ANZ Bank accountant at Burra for four years, has been transferred to Mt Barker. He has been in the district for 12 years, having transferred here in 1942 and joining the Air Force a year later. He returned in 1946. After five years in Adelaide he returned in 1957. He has been active in town affairs and sport. He is the President of the Lawn Tennis Club and Secretary/Treasurer of the Air Force Association and a member of the Golf Club. His replacement will be Mr Don Zanker, presently officer in charge of the Savings Bank Department Adelaide Branch.

Burra Small Bore Club made £38 from the film show on Wednesday night.

Mrs R.S. Jenner of Burra recently won first prize in the state in an essay competition on Bible Reading. Two other members of the family, Rosemary & Dennis were awarded consolation prizes.

Kooringa Methodist Ladies’ Guild held its 36th Birthday Social and Apron Display to aid the Kooringa Methodist Fete. It raised £20-12-6.

Burra Racing Club had a very successful race meeting in perfect weather and on an excellent rack last Wednesday. Gate takings were £50. [Race results are printed.]

Tennis. This season there will be 16 teams (both ‘A’ & ‘B’ Grade) in the Burra Association. Elected were: President, J. Field; Vice-Presidents, D. White and D. Jones and Secretary, P. Gill.

J. Collins & Sons of Collinsville Mt Bryan obtained a Poll Merino Ram sold at auction at the Royal Adelaide show with a price of 1,450 guineas. [Photo printed.]

91, 39, 3 Oct. 1961, page 1

Burra North Children’s Playground is to be aided by the pictures this week. The first meeting of the Children’s Playground Committee was held 11 October 1923, permission having been given by the Town Council for the use of Lowe’s Park as a playground. Mr James Reed was Patron and Mr L.H. Foote President with W.J.C. Ewins and M.A. Radford as Vice-Presidents. Max Morton was Secretary. Practically all the buildings and pieces of equipment were donated by citizens. The committee is desirous of improving the facilities. The present Committee is President, F.H. Reed with Messrs S. Scroop, S.J. Woollacott, L. Hirschausen, L. White, A.B. Riggs, W. Carpenter and Mesdames S. Scroop, H. Jennison and W.H. Lloyd.

Adelaide Wool Sales. Best district price of 72d was by G.G. Lines & Sons of Mt Bryan. [Other local district prices are printed.]

Kevin Lane, Captain-Coach of Aberdeen Football Club and winner of the Mail Medal for the Mid-North Association 1961 kicked 87 goals in 16 matches. Photograph.

Burra Football Club Presentation Night photo: President of North-Eastern League Mr T.J. Jenner presents a trophy to Barry Ryan.

J. Carpenter, Hon. Sec. of the TPI Assoc. writes announcing a badge day in Burra on Friday & Saturday 6 & 7 October 1961 and seeking public support.

Burra Rural Youth held a Car trial on 25 Sept

91, 39, 3 Oct. 1961, page 7

Sir Walter Duncan will retire as Director on the Head Office Board of Goldsbrough, Mort & Co. Ltd on 30 September. He will also retire as Chairman of the Adelaide Board, but continue as a director. He has been Chairman of the Adelaide Board since its inception in 1924. He was also Chairman of Bagot, Shakes & Lewis Ltd, which was absorbed by Goldsbrough, Mort & Co. in that year. He served as a Director of Bagot, Shakes & Lewis for 11 years. Sir Keith Angas will succeed Sir Walter as Chairman of the Adelaide Board.

91, 39, 3 Oct. 1961, page 8

Aberdeen Football Club held its annual dinner in the Oddfellows’ Hall on Friday 22 September.

Most Consistent Forward P. Ryan

Most Consistent Backman R. Partridge

Most Goals Kicked (87) K. Lane

Best Junior D. Stockman

Most Improved Junior D. Irlam

Most Improved Player J. Ward

Best Ruckman K. Walker

Most Attentive to Training R. Taylor

91, 39, 3 Oct. 1961, Supplement [7 columns – single sided.]

BOTTOM HALF OF PAGE MISSING

91, 40, 10 Oct. 1961, pages 1 & 5

Burra Show 1961

The very successful show for 1961 was opened by Mr R.C. Gosse, President of the Royal Agricultural Society. Despite entries being down in some sections, the total of 2681was a record. The tractor driving competition, tried for the first time, created much interest.

The weather was a little warm, but nearly perfect.

Sideshows were disappointingly few this year because there were eight shows on the same day. The tiny tots, as a result, were not really catered for, except for pony coach rides.

There were some excellent displays in the Industrial Stands, though overall fewer than last year.

The ring events as usual kept the interest till late afternoon.

Gate takings amounted to £241.

[Personal interest: At the opening there was an apology from Mr R. Fuss, a member of the Committee.]

Mr Rex Warnes, as President of the Burra Show, asked Mr Gosse to open it. Mr Gosse commented on hoe important Burra had been in the past with copper, but now it was rather the gold of the Golden Fleece. The district has become renowned as the cradle of the SA Merino Industry. He regretted that all too few of the district’s fleeces were entered in the Royal Adelaide Show and hoped for better in the future.

The Tractor Driving Contest was the first to be held at a country show in SA. The winner was R. Gillett with 99 points, followed by Les Warnes with 97 – in the fastest time of 3 minutes 14 seconds.

In photography the best black and white entry was by Rev. R.S. Jenner and the best colour transparency by K. Horsnell.

In poultry the Grand Champions Bird of the show was exhibited by R.D. Hall.

Champion Budgerigar was by M. George.

There was a good display of Jerseys in the cattle section.

Champion Cow: M.C. Garrard. Champion Bull: D.C. Rowley.

In Cooking the aggregate points prize went to Mrs F.C. Stolte.

In Flowers the Champion Pansy was entered by C.R.E. Simon.

[Rest of results next issue. Prizes were not individually listed.]

91, 40, 10 Oct. 1961, page 3

Advt. Burra Pictures, 14 October

Clifton Webb & Jane Wyman in Holiday for Lovers

Bill Williams & Nora Hayden in Alaska Passage

91, 40, 10 Oct. 1961, page 6

Burra Rural Youth Ball was held recently in the Burra Town Hall and was successful with door takings of c. £87. Miniature Debs were presented to Mr & Mrs John Dutton of Kapunda. [Debs are pictured.] They were:

Nola Simpson with Russell Williams

Marlene Hentschke with Mark Moreland

Delray Miller with David Pitcher

Cynthia Oates with Dean Bogisch

Rosemary corner with Garry James

Sandra Dainty with Neville McDonald

Jillian Eberhard with Tony Ryan

Jill Hobba with Grant Broad

Lynette Kelly with Ian James

Cheryl Ireland with Neil Barry

Proceeds aid the CWA Building Fund.

91, 40, 10 Oct. 1961, page 8

Hallett Flower Show: Children’s Section Prize Winners are listed.

91, 41, 17 Oct. 1961, page 1

Burra Lawn Tennis Club held its AGM and elected President, R. Osborne; Vice-President, I. Allen; Secretary, D. Lubcke and Treasurer, R. Riedel.

With costs of c. £200 p.a. to maintain the courts it is necessary to have considerable support from players. To try to increase membership numbers, the fees have been reduced to 30/- adults plus 2/- ball fees and for juniors at school 10/- plus 1/- ball fees. Opening day will be 29 October.

Booborowie School Welfare Club staged a very successful Fancy Dress frolic in the Memorial Hall on Friday night. Proceeds were over £50. [Prize winners are listed.]

J. Carpenter writes as Secretary of the Totally & Permanently Disabled Soldiers’ Association, thanking Burra & District for the £78-6-4 recently raised at badge days on 6 & 7 October.

91, 41, 17 Oct. 1961, pages 1 & 5

Burra Burra Show Inc. can report a successful Gala Night organised by the Rural Youth with nett proceeds of £41-15-0. [A note regarding R. Fuss being unable to set up the cut flowers and a hope that he is progressing favourably, reveals he must have been ill.]

The Prize List is continued.

Best exhibit in Floral Art was by R.V. Mueller.

M.R.E. Simon gained the highest aggregate points in Grain & Fodder.

In the Goat section the Champion Doe, Reserve Champion Doe and Junior Champion Doe all went to Mrs T.E. Gericke.

Aggregate points in Needlework: Mrs R.J. Jarmyn.

An extensive list of Horses in action is printed.

J.E. Zanker had the best collection of vegetables.

The school work display was again interesting.

S.H. & W.N. Wood of Kybunga exhibited the Grand Champion Ram, the Reserve Grand Champion and the Grand Champion Ewe. The Grand Champion Ewe was entered by R.V. & N.S. Rzeszkowski of Arabar Mount Templeton.

Best Fleece was entered by K.R. Phillips and a list of awards in various classes is also printed.

91, 41, 17 Oct. 1961, page 4

Burra Rifle Club. Burra & Clare shooters joined forces to form a team to shoot in the first stage of the Union Teams’ Matches against Hamley Bridge.

Burra-Clare 573 plus handicap 53 = 626

Hamley Bridge 553 plus handicap 53 = 606

91, 41, 17 Oct. 1961, page 6

The Anthropological Society of SA visited Burra on the holiday weekend with Society President Mr N.B. Tindale of the SA Museum. They visited the miners’ dugouts, the old mine, had a buffet lunch the next day at Baldina and on Monday with the permission of Mr Ted Rooke visited the Aboriginal rock carvings on his property. These had been photographed and tabulated some thirty-five years ago by Professor Wood-Jones & Dr (later Professor) T.D. Campbell. They also visited camp sites in Baldina Creek where Aboriginal stone implements were located.

Burra Small Bore Club. 50-75 yards ranges: W. Corner was best in the marksman’s section and Gordon Webster best with handicap.

91, 42, 24 Oct. 1961, page 1

Booborowie Basketball was played under lights on 18 October for the first time. A five team lightning carnival was held to celebrate the occasion and Gulnare was the winning team.

Burra Bridges in trouble: The Chapel Street Bridge has a 3 ton load limit and the Kangaroo Street Bridge is closed to all traffic.

Burra Bowling Season has opened. President Stan Woollacott welcomed members and visitors. The Mayor and Mayoress opened the season. The ladies’ bowling season was opened last Wednesday when President Mrs D.H. Field welcomed all present and Miss Ruediger from Robertstown Club opened the season.

Burra High School. The Leaving class is going to Adelaide to see a performance of Hamlet.

91, 42, 24 Oct. 1961, page 8

Burra Town Council, 2 October

One minute’s silence was observed for the death of Cr E. Finch.

Approval was given for the erection of a toilet block at RAOB Burra North [The old Scout Hall.]

The Cricket Association is to be advised that the Memorial Oval is not available this season due to the War Memorial Committee turfing the oval.

A letter from the Director of the Royal Agricultural & Horticultural Society re the Jinker for the Burra Mine.

[There is no indication of the details of this correspondence.]

Local Board of Health

Mrs E.J. Thomas writes re the condition of 33 Paxton Square. [No details of the letter are given here, but there is a Medical Officer’s report.]

Dr Miller reports on the premises occupied by Mrs Thomas and suggests a letter be sent to the trustees regarding the sanitary condition of the house.

Re Mr Luke Day’s house – a box gutter is in need of repair and the back yard is littered and though not in an unsanitary condition, it could be a fire hazard. The pit type toilet needs resiting.

Resolved that letters be sent:

To Mrs Thomas re the condition of her place.

To the landlord to attend to the matter within 28 days.

To Mr L. Day to renew the pit lavatory and repair the box gutter.

91, 43, 31 Oct. 1961, page 1

The Burra Mine Area is to be opened as a tourist resort for Burra by the Director of the SA Government Tourist Bureau Mr P.F. Pollnitz on Friday 17 November. The Town Council through the Mayor Mr Baulderstone has been working on the idea of ‘selling’ the mine as a tourist area for some time. A road has been graded around the area so one can drive around and through the area in safety and reasonable comfort. This provides some excellent views of the mine, the town and the surrounding countryside. The old open cut and mine buildings etc. provide many opportunities for the photographer. [Photo of the open cut.]

Burra Swimming Pool Committee is seeking the services of a suitable caretaker, without whom the pool cannot be opened to the public.

Garfield Sobers will visit Burra and conduct a cricket school at the Burra Racecourse Oval on Monday 13 November from 10.30 a.m. to 12.30 p.m. It is open to all boys over 10. Mr Vic. Richardson will be a member of the party. All are welcome to come and observe.

Burra Basketball will be played under lights for the first time next Thursday night.

Burra Small Bore Club. The 50 yards Championship was won by Ross Gilbert. A. Angel won the handicap section using 82.5% of her handicap to Ross’s 83.8%. On Thursday Burra Golf Club visited the range for a double 50 yards shoot.

An Amateur Hour at the Redruth Memorial Hall on Friday raised c. £90.

Norman B. Tindale of the SA Museum and Chairman of the Anthropological Sociaety of SA writes to thank everyone for the hospitality the Society recently enjoyed at Burra.

Mr John Bailey has won LCL endorsement for the Seat of Burra in the House of Assembly at next year’s elections. He is a well-known farmer of the Jamestown District.

Burra Swimming Pool. Mr W. Broad has been appointed caretaker at the pool, which was opened to the public on Saturday. Several instances of misconduct by youths have been reported and the committee will enforce the local rules.

Violet Hawkes married Dudley Lehmann. The couple will live at Robertstown.

91, 44, 7 Nov. 1961, page 2

Obituary. Return Thanks Notice says that Mr & Mrs A. Herewane [though Herrawane in the paper] have had a sad bereavement. [Could this possibly be the death of Violetta Cassandra May Herawane aged 5, daughter of Mr & Mrs Alexander Herawane of Spalding? Unfortunately SA Deaths CD gives an appropriate day and month, but the wrong year: 26 October 1962! The surname is uncommon and no other death suggests itself unless this refers to a relative with a different surname.]

91, 44, 7 Nov. 1961, page 7

St Joseph’s School Picnic was held on Sunday 29 October at Redbanks. Sports were held in the afternoon.

91, 45, 14 Nov. 1961, page 1

Burra Basketball Club held a Fancy Dress Frolic in the Burra Town Hall on Friday night and raised a further £40 towards the cost of lighting the courts. [Prize winners are listed.]

The Royal Agricultural & Horticultural Society has agreed to return the old jinker for preservation on the mine property. It was specially made in England to transport Morphett’s huge boiler and engine to the Burra Mine from Port Adelaide. Forty bullocks were used under the direction of six bullock drivers. [Photo of the jinker.]

Adelaide Wool Sales. Top price for the district went to Willogoleche Ltd of Hallett at 691⁄2d.

Goldsbrough, Mort & Co.’s stud ewe sale recently saw an almost total clearance. [Prices are given.]

[Photo of G.A. Lucas, P.T. Cousins, John Sullivan & D.R. Gare.]

The Advertiser Cricket School at Burra yesterday attracted c. 400 including 250 schoolboys from the district. The party comprised Garry Sobers, Gil Langley, Vic Richardson & Allan Lyons. They were introduced by Mr C. Furst of the Mokota Cricket Association. After coaching, the boys were tested on what they had learned and Ron Warrior (13) an Aboriginal boy from Hallett was the winner and received a new bat autographed by Sobers and another one for his school.

The Fire Siren used to be tested at 7 a.m. & 7 p.m. but you may have noticed it is now tested only once a day. This is because the telephone exchange now charges for these testing calls to the local exchange.

The Road Traffic Board will investigate a pedestrian crossing near the Burra Town Hall.

Burra Town Council has applied to the Attorney General’s Department for permission to level the disused part of the Cemetery. The majority of graves in this area were used about 100 years ago.

91, 45, 14 Nov. 1961, page 2

Advt. Elders Off-Shears Sale will combine the Burra, Farrell Flat and Hill River Station Markets and offer 14,000 sheep on 17 November.

Burra Hospital seventy mile car trial was successful recently, though delayed half an hour for those attending the fire call at 6.50 p.m. Winners were ‘Slap-em-back’ Sandercock and navigator ‘Gear-shift’ Gallis.

Burra Town Council has been advised by the Highways Department that it is likely to receive a grant of £300 for rebuilding the Kangaroo Street Bridge, which has been closed for some weeks. The total cost is estimated at about £500.

91, 45, 14 Nov. 1961, page 8

Burra High School. The Education Department building program for 1962 includes funding a new science laboratory for Burra High School.

Armistice Day was observed on the Primary School Grounds. Mr L. Phillips Vice-President of Burra RSL read the message.

91, 46, 21 Nov. 1961, page 1

Burra Mine Area opened as a Tourist Resort

On Friday a large gathering of local and district residents attended the opening of the Burra Mine area as a Tourist Resort by Mr P.F. Pollnitz, Director of the SA Government Tourist Bureau. It took place at the gate on the eastern side of the mine area. Also present were the Town Mayor & Mrs Baulderstone and Mr P.H. Quirke MP with Mrs Quirke. The Burra Town Clerk Mr R.W. Fullgrabe introduced the Mayor who welcomed guests. The Mayor said the Council had brochures printed giving a brief history of the Mine and its workings, to give visitors an idea of what they were inspecting. In 1845 the Burra Mine had prevented SA from going bankrupt and the importance of this fact makes it essential that every effort be made to preserve these old workings. Ex-Councillor H.C. Cummins had first suggested ‘selling’ the mine to visitors as a tourist resort, but up to that time not much thought had been given to the idea and the Mine had mainly been used as a rubbish dump site. Mr Baulderstone said he soon fell in with the idea, as he realised what a wonderful venture it could prove. Later he had the opportunity of showing Mr Polnitz over the site and from his enthusiasm had been much heartened. The response to a public meeting to discuss the matter was disheartening, but he and his Councillors had battled on and though they had aimed to open it in March, it had not been ready until now. He thanked former Burra High School Headmaster Mr Murray scrivener for writing the history used in the brochure. He also thanked Mr P.H. Quirke for tracing facts used in it, Mr McGrath for his reproduction of photos and Mr S. Sleader for lending the same. The Burra Record was thanked for printing it. There was still much to be done.

Through the efforts of Mr Rex Warnes the Royal Agricultural and Horticultural Society has agreed to return the Old Jinker to be preserved on the Mine Property and this would be part of the Museum collection.

Mr Pollnitz then opened the site. He said other countries went to much more trouble to ‘sell’ their historical attractions and we should also. Burra needed to encourage people to stay in the town to see the attractions. He would encourage the formation of a museum as mentioned by the Mayor.

Mr Quirke moved a vote of thanks and spoke of the amount of information and other material available for such a museum project. [Photo of the Mine in working condition: probably taken in 1869 just before conversion to open cut operation.]

Burra Swimming Pool. The session by Mr Ern Reddaway was well attended. He lectured on training and swimming styles and later on individual coaching.

Obituary. The body of Mr Bert Schultz, late of Eudunda, was recovered by the Police Aqua Lung Squad from the River Murray near Bryant’s Creek on Sunday morning. [In 1978 this creek near Morgan was renamed Bryan Creek.]

[Bertram Albert Schultz born 30 November 1905 Kapunda: died 19 November 1961 Morgan, residence Somerton.]

Burra Camera Club. Mr John Mack of Adelaide visited the club on 24 October and showed coloured movies of his trip around the world. There are plans for a photographic exhibition involving six clubs in the Mid North to be held in Clare Town Hall 13 April 1962.

Remembrance Day was commemorated in Market Square with wreaths laid by Mr H. Cornelius (President Burra RSL), W. Young (for the Air Force Association), Mayor E.T. Baulderstone for the Town, M.T. Kellock for the Burra Burra District Council and Mr Dan O’Brien for the Pensioners’ League.

Weather. In the latter part of last week general rains of one to more than three inches were recorded. Examples of totals: Sturt Vale 152 points, Quondong 107, Mt Bryan East up to 360, Hogback 338, Woolgangi 292, Koomooloo 186 and Burra 240. Page 3 adds the information that Dust Hole Creek carried its biggest flood in years.

Some Notes by ‘12th Man’ reveal that the Burra Footballers entered the Mokota Association late and had neither a home ground nor any money. They soon acquired a debt of £70, but hope to pay it off within two weeks.

91, 47, 28 Nov. 1961, page 1

Redruth Methodist Ladies’ Guild held its Annual Fete and Concert in the Redruth Memorial Hall on Saturday. It was very successful and raised over £200. Mrs L.H. Thomas opened the fete.

Burra Mine Tourist Resort

Two photos are printed of Mr P.F. Pollnitz opening the site:

Mr Fullgrabe, Mr Baulderstone, Mr Pollnitz & Mr Quirke.

Mr & Mrs Pollnitz and Mr & Mrs Baulderstone with the brochure.

A poem by Douglas Marshall The 40 Bullock Team for the book Southern Festival is also published.

Joan Hanlin of Clare writes wondering if there is anyone who was born in Burra earlier than her mother who was 96 in July. Her father was Captain Roach. [Elizabeth Tuck, the wife of Alfred Robert Tuck, was born 18 July 1865 at Burra Mine to James and Mary Roach (nee Dunstan) and she died 9 September 1962 at North Adelaide.]

Weather. Burra had a further 50 points of rain in the past week.

A Record Merino Ram Price of 9,000 guineas was achieved at the Perth Ram Sales. The Record quotes a London paper as saying: ‘In Australia it is possible to pay more for one sheep than for a Rolls Royce.’

[It is typical of the reporting style of the paper at this stage that the article doesn’t say who sold the ram, though the headline presumably reveals it: ‘Such is Fame … Collinsville – Rolls Royce’.

St Edmund’s Booborowie. The Guild’s Christmas Party is reported in 1⁄4 column.

The University of Adelaide is installing a seismograph at Hallett in a vault being blasted on the property of Mr Don Tiver.

Accident/Obituary. Paraskiras Skafidis (26) a motor cyclist of Peterborough was fatally injured on the Adelaide-Broken Hill Road about a mile north of Hallett on Monday last week. In a cloud of dust he had a collision with a car coming the other way. His condition deteriorated in the ambulance en route to Adelaide and he died in the Riverton Hospital. [Paraskevas Skafidas aged 27 died 20 November 1961 Riverton, residence Peterborough.]

91, 48, 5 Dec. 1961, page 1

Burra RSL held its Annual Reunion Dinner, which was smaller this year, but still quite successful. It was held in the local club rooms and was prepared by the Women’s Auxiliary. [Details are given in c. 11⁄2 columns.]

A District Swimming Association was formed on 1 December between Burra, Clare and Spalding Swimming Clubs. A shield will be contested between the three clubs over an aggregate of three carnivals, of which the first will be held in Burra on 6 December.

Adelaide Wool Sales. The top district price of 703⁄4d was achieved by Mackerode Ltd.

[Other local district prices are printed.]

Basketball. A photo taken at the opening of night basketball in Burra shows Mayor Baulderstone and the President of the Burra Basketball Club Mrs Dawn Broderick.

Notice. Commonwealth of Australia Electoral Division of Wakefield

A poll will be contested on 9 December 1961. The Candidates will be:

Charles Robert Kelly of Tarlee MHR

John William McMahon of Leighton, farmer

Collin James Wood of Elizabeth East, organizer

[Voting places in Burra were the RSL Hall and the Court House. There were also polling places at Leighton Hall, Hanson Institute, Mt Bryan Hall and the Booborowie School.]

91, 48, 5 Dec. 1961, page 3

Burra CWA celebrated its 35th birthday and International Day on 17 November. Mr A.L. Clode on behalf of himself and his family presented a beautiful President’s Chair [or perhaps a table – depending on which sentence you are reading in the report!] in memory of his wife who was a member for many years. It was decided to donate £75 to the Annual Hospital Fund Appeal. The guest speaker was Mrs R. Murray of Stockport, Divisional President of the Lower North Division, who spoke on Famous Australians.

Burra Blue 103 defeated Spalding 98

Saddleworth Gold 99 defeated Burra Gold 91

91, 48, 5 Dec. 1961, page 5

Hallett CWA celebrated International Day on 28 November when the guest speaker was Mrs Owen-Smyth.

Llewellyn Herbert Piggott of Porter’s Lagoon had a party on 19 November to celebrate his 90th birthday. He was born at Watervale in 1871 to Richard and Eliza Piggott. His parents settled at Clarendon in 1853 and about 1869 moved to Watervale where Richard Piggott was employed on property associated with the names of Duncan and Hughes. Some of his children attended Stanley Grammar School established by Mr Coles. In 1875 the family moved by wagon to Morchard where virgin land was taken up. Here Herbert began farming with his father and continued when he and his parents moved to Booleroo Centre about 1892. His father died in 1895 and in 1904 Herbert married Annie, eldest daughter of Richard and Christina Dunstan of Booleroo Centre. He and other farmers of the area carted their wheat through picturesque Telowie Gorge to Port Germein – some 29 miles. In 1911 he and his family moved to Porter’s Lagoon where he has resided ever since. His two brothers and three sisters all lived to be over 80, but are now deceased: Robert (Wistow), Sidney (Lameroo), Mrs Sanders (Booleroo Centre), Mrs Nancarrow (Glenelg) and Mrs Sargent (Crystal Brook). Of his seven children, five survive: Bert (Porter’s Lagoon), Tom (Clare), Myra Mrs Ross Reed (St Georges), Elvy Mrs Glen Krummel (Eudunda) and Lily Mrs Henshaw (Ormond, Melbourne). Mabel and Jean are deceased. Some 70 people attended the celebrations and Mrs Piggott responded capably on behalf of her husband. [He died 15 June 1964 Riverton, residence Farrell Flat and his wife died 28 April 1972 at Clare aged 92.]

91, 48, 5 Dec. 1961, page 8

Cricket. Burra Association

Koonoona 257 v. Farrell Flat 66 & 9 for 140 when forced to follow on.

Mokota Association

91, 49, 12 Dec. 1961, page 1

Burra Town Council, 4 December

Sgt F. McGrath discussed parking problems in Burra. He was particularly concerned with the area of the Burra Town Hall to the Telephone Exchange when functions were held. Here cars are parked on the western side and ranked on the eastern side, which seriously narrows the road, which is only 43 ft wide and as the main road to Broken Hill it carries heavy transports. Parking too close to corners is another problem and he recommends painting lines on the areas 15 ft from the building alignment where parking is prohibited. Traffic islands in Market Square as proposed by the Highways Department would be a good idea.

Burra Small Bore Club. The 25 yards Championship was won by Gordon Webster. K. Spackman won the handicap section.

Cricket. Three Burra High school students have been chosen to take part in SA Cricket Association’s Schoolboys’ Carnival in Adelaide from 3 to 24 January. They are: Robert Brandt, Keith McWaters and Robert Todd.

Booborowie Methodist Ladies’ Guild’s annual fete took the form of a Nursery Rhyme Fair recently and takings amounted to £231. [Details in just over 1 column.]

Notice. Ron Wickes [Chemist] announces that his business in Burra will be closing from 24 December 1961 after operating for 11 years,

91, 50, 19 Dec. 1961, page 1

Burra High School held its speech night on Thursday at the Burra Town Hall, which was packed with c. 500 people for the occasion. Chairman of the High School Council H.J.B. Jennison presided. Mr E.A. Haese was guest speaker. Mr Haese was a former headmaster at Burra and later served at Peterborough, Nuriootpa, Mt Barker and Murray Bridge from which he retired. He has just returned from a six month tour overseas. After his address prizes were distributed. Various items by students were interspersed throughout the evening and a new summer uniform for the girls was displayed.

In 1960 Intermediate Certificates had been gained by the following (numbers indicate the number of subjects passed):

Jillian Arnold 7 David Baynes 7 John Fullgrabe 7

Antoinette Harris 6 Errol Hood 7 Joyleen Jenner 9

Ellen Kemp 6 Ian McGrath 7 Terrance Opie 5

Robert Parker 8 Janet Scriven 6 Peter Wurfel 7

Peter Collins 5 Trenna Eberhard 6 Maurice Perry 7

Donald Topsfield 6 Merle Wickes 6 Gloria Willis 4

St Joseph’s Convent music students’ results at Music Examinations 1961 are printed.

Swimming Carnival. Gate takings at Burra’s first swimming carnival in the planned series amounted to only £12 on Saturday night when rain marred the event. Burra won the first pennant with 60 points from Clare 28 and Spalding 20. [Results are printed.]

Mrs B.T. Preiss is 91 today.

91, 50, 19 Dec. 1961, page 7

Mr & Mrs C.W. Dare of ‘Pinehurst’ Mt Bryan East have retired to live in Burra.

The Kangaroo Street Bridge has been re-decked and is open to traffic.

Characteristics of the paper in 1961

In a number of ways it is disappointing. Coverage extends to Spalding and Riverton, so there is less on Burra, but that is not the principal concern. Articles frequently fail to identify which town they are about, at least not until you are well into them. An example is an article headed ‘Swimming Pool Competition Completed,’ which does not indicate it is about Riverton until almost half a column into the report. Another example informs us that Mrs King has been appointed a Senior Assistant without telling the reader at which school.

Typographical errors with jumbled lines, incorrect spacing or omitted words or lines are all too common.

Most of the news (other than sport) is on page one and photographs are a welcome, if occasional, addition. Some news extends to other pages, but sport dominates there, though even the sport is not consistently reported.

The CWA gets particularly good coverage and as usual football is extensively reported. Coverage of other sports is not very consistent; no doubt reflecting the inconsistency of the clubs’ publicity officers. District Council meetings are generally well covered, but little of the information is of interest at this distance in time.

A sitting Councillor died without comment in the paper.

A welcome feature was the inclusion of some local photographs, though they were a week or two after the event by the time the plates got back for printing.

Note that this summary has generally ignored events reported from Riverton, Spalding or Saddleworth.

Page 1

Entirely devoted to news and photos of local event or people are not uncommon, though somewhat delayed.

Page 2

Advertisements for sales, entertainment, public notices and the like.

Page 3

Often a continuation of page 2 content with some large advertisements.

Pages 4-8

Dominated by advertisements of considerable size. Most are two columns wide by 3 inches (7.5 cm) in depth or larger. News here is dominated by sports results. ‘The Christian Message’ is a regular column of fluctuating size. CWA news is significant and the activities of the schools get good coverage. News of any sort rarely exceeds 11⁄2 of the 6 columns.

92, 1, 9 Jan. 1962, page 1

Council Amalgamation. 300 ratepayers have petitioned for the amalgamation of the Burra Burra District Council and the Burra town Council. The Town Council resolved to approach the District Council for a meeting to discuss the question on 31 January.

Burra Caravan Site. The Council resolved to proclaim it a camping area only.

Mr R.W. Fullgrabe has won the position of District Clerk at Robe and has resigned as Town Clerk at Burra.

Burra Primary School. The girls’ uniform will feature a grey tunic, white blouse, dark grey jumper with blue stripe, brown shoes and white socks.

Christmas in Burra. Burra businesses were quiet on the afternoon of Friday 22 December, but the town was busy between 7 and 9 p.m. and the Merry-Go-Round proprietor reported the same. He did not continue operating after lunch on Saturday. Father Christmas arrived on schedule and distributed sweets, ice cream and whistle in an orderly fashion. Burra Rural Youth organised a Christmas Eve Dance with Darrell Field’s Band. Over £23 was raised for the Burra Hospital.

Booborowie New Year’s Eve Ball at the Booborowie Hall had door takings of £67.

Burra RSL held its AGM at the end of December and Mr H. Cornelius was re-elected as President with C.L. Phillips and T. Rogers as Vice-Presidents. Ben Kotz is Secretary and Bill Nankivell is Treasurer.

[Correction 92, 2, 16 Jan. 1962, page 1: Secretary, R.W. Nankivell & Treasurer, B. Kotz.]

It was resolved to demolish the Caravan Park toilets.

Swimming Carnival. With heavy disqualifications of Burra swimmers at the Clare carnival on Saturday, the Clare Club has taken the lead in the aggregate.

Weather. On Monday a thunderstorm delivered 76 points locally. Falls were very patchy with none to the east, but Booborowie recorded 8 points, Farrell Flat 11, the Hanson area between 100 & 200 and Robertstown 294.

Burra Primary School presentation of prizes and certificates was done at the break-up before Christmas. Headmaster Mr K. Hornell welcomed the Chairman and Secretary of the School Committee (Messrs M.G. Stockman & D.H. Field) and the President and Secretary of the Welfare Club (Mesdames D.H. Field & D. Bannister) and the High School Principal Mr R. Mueller. The Dux of the School was Markku Sipari and the top girl was Marilyn Kotz. Presentations were made to departing teachers:

Miss Coventry goes to Pt Elliott

Mr Sullivan is going to Brisbane University to complete his degree.

92, 2, 16 Jan. 1962, page 1

Burra Swimming Pool. 130 took part in the Education Department’s Learn to Swim Campaign. A local swimming carnival on Friday night was quite popular, with gate takings of £9-15-0. [Results are printed.]

Sister L. Leadham is acting Matron while Matron L.M. Fyfe is on holidays.

Bowls. In the Massey Ferguson Regional Bowls Tournament at Spalding on 9 January Burra came second to Gulnare.

Murray Cod. Messrs Kevin Flaherty and Albert Hempel landed a 60 lb Murray Cod at Cadell last Wednesday, The previous biggest cod known to have been landed by a Burraite was one of 54 lb by Bob Cummins, who took the title from Johnny Hill with a 46 lb fish. [There is a photograph, presumably with one of the above men, but not so named, with the fish.]

It was resolved to meet the Burra Town Council on 31 January to discuss the recent petition concerning the amalgamation of the two Councils.

Local Board of Health

The resolution to demolish the toilets at the Caravan Park was rescinded.

92, 2, 16 Jan. 1962, page 5

Burra High School. 49th Headmaster’s Report

[Three photos are printed of Staff, Prefects and House Leaders and Magazine Editors.]

Mr Mueller reported an enrolment of 125 (75 boys and 55 girls, a few more than in 1960. This number is unlikely to grow in the future with now 72 in Grade VI and 76 in Grade V, but 64 in Grade IV and 62 in Grade II.

In 1961 there was a big turnover in staff with 9 changes, including part-time staff:

New were: Miss N. Lawes (S.M.), Mr R. Hillman, Mr B. McElroy, Mrs J. Bogisch (0.6), Miss E. McCabe (0.2), Mr K. Horsnell & Mr R.V. Mueller. Mr J. Sladden & Mr K. Hicks were the only staff to carry on from 1960.

Religious Instruction has functioned smoothly throughout the year.

About 70 people attended the prefects’ induction in March.

The most urgent need for the school is improved playing grounds and the High School Council has been most supportive in plans to implement this.

The Department has offered £10 annually towards the use of the Town Oval. In the year two fresh water tanks were installed and a new clothesline was erected. 154 steel chairs were obtained for the assembly hall. A new Banda duplicating machine has been procured and linoleum was laid in the Needlework Room. Anew lathe was obtained for the Woodwork Centre. Most desks have been planed and varnished (and various other minor matters attended to.)

Six students gained Leaving Certificates and Trenna Eberhard & Merle Wickes won Commonwealth Scholarships.

11 students gained Intermediate Certificates.

92, 2, 16 Jan. 1962, page 6

Burra Association 27 sets defeated Cavandale Association 13 sets, at the Aberdeen Courts.

92, 2, 16 Jan. 1962, page 8

Burra Camera Club – Photo – At the Seaside by Mrs R. Sandercock.

Burra Town Council, 2 January

A petition forwarded by S.J. Woollacott asked the Council to move without delay to seek an amalgamation with the Burra Burra DC. A move to have a combined meeting with the District Council on the matter was carried on the casting vote of the Mayor.

It was resolved that the Caravan Park become a camping site only.

The resignation of the Town Clerk was accepted with regret.

92, 3, 23 Jan. 1962, page 1

Learn to Swim Campaign

Fifty children learnt to swim and 135 gained certificates. The instructors were Mr K. Hicks, assisted by Mr P. Tattersall. There were 50 Beginners’ Certificates, 44 Progress, 24 Junior and 17 Senior Certificates. Bad weather forced cancellation of the carnival planned for the Burra Pool last Friday.

Geraldton Subterranean Clover has been a big success in many areas of Spalding, Jamestown and Burra Districts. It has outclassed Dwalganup. Its low growth is a drawback in weedy paddocks. It thrives in areas with 16-19 inches of rain and is more lime tolerant than Dwalganup.

Obituary. Mary Ann Inid (Dolly) Goodridge died 6 January at Burra Hospital aged 82. She was the wife of T.E.G. Goodridge of Mt Bryan. [Born Mary Ann Ind Edwards 23 March 1881 Mt Bryan: death registered as Mary Ann Ind Goodridge died Burra, residence Mt Bryan aged 80.]

Obituary. Edith Maud Thomas died 17 January at Burra Hospital. She was the wife of the late William Stephen Thomas (who died 1919) of Mt Bryan East. She was the mother of Leslie, Perce and Eva (Mrs Wilks).

[Born Edith Maud Howe 2 May 1880 Gawler South: died 17 January 1962 Burra, residence Cumberland Park.]

92, 3, 23 Jan. 1962, page 4

Burra RSL. Annual Report of President H. Cornelius

Members have not given the club the support needed for it to continue. A few willing members who are overworked are making all the effort. Weather forced the Anzac Service to be held in the clubrooms and it was again conducted by the Ministers Fraternal. Fortunately conditions afterwards improved and allowed the march to take place. Remembrance Day proved very popular and greater interest was shown by the public. The RSL Ball in the Town Hall was very enjoyable and owed much to the Ladies’ Auxiliary. Between 60 & 70 diggers attended the annual dinner. A Christmas party was held for members’ children. We are still maintaining two Legacy Wards at £25 each.

Marriage. Kent Town Methodist Church, 13 January

Margaret Ruth Jefferies, daughter of Mr & Mrs F.M. Jefferies of ‘Almonda’ Mt Bryan, married

John Lange, son of Mr & Mrs Keith Lange of Felixstow.

92, 3, 23 Jan. 1962, page 5

Burra Small Bore Club fired the 5th stage of Group 2 Trophy over double 75 yards. Gordon Webster was best off the rifle and on handicap.

Obituary. Mrs George Parker was born at Stony Gap in 1869, the eldest daughter of the late Mr & Mrs Joseph Flower. She was educated at Stony Gap and in 1893 married Mr George Parker. After three years of marriage they moved to Copperhouse where they spent 23 years share-farming, shearing and contracting. There was a family of six: four daughters and two sons, of whom five survive. The youngest son, Joe, died as a result of an accident in 1925. In 1916 Mr Parker bought a property at Booborowie and the family moved there until his death in 1946. Mrs Parker then came to live in Queen Street in Burra where she lived alone until in the last five or six years of failing health she was forced to share her home life with daughter, Mrs H. Cornelius of Burra and Mrs Herb Collins of Booborowie. She died at Burra Hospital on 8 January after an illness of nine weeks. She leaves four daughters and one son: Vida Mrs Jack Pens (Burra), Mill Mrs Herbert Cornelius (Booborowie) [sic], Cecil (Queensland), Cass Mrs Oliver Earle (Swan Hill) and Lill Mrs H. Cornelius (Burra).

[Mill (Mildred) was really Mrs William Herbert Collins]

[Born Rebecca Flower 27 May 1869 at Stony Gap.]

Burra High School. Certificates presented on Speech Night are listed.

Intermediate Certificates to:

Julian Arnold David Baynes John Fullgrabe

Bowls

Burra Green 99 defeated Auburn 95

Burra Gold 97 defeated Clare Red 90

Hallett Red 92 defeated Burra Blue 90

92, 4, 30 Jan. 1962, page 1

Burra Hospital Cropping Scheme. The result of 194 bags was below target, but useful and a satisfactory result considering the unfavourable season. Land is required now for the 1962 season.

Morgan-Whyalla Pipeline. The SA Government is considering laying a 12 mile portion of the pipeline on the bed of Spencer Gulf. If feasible this would cut the length by 56 miles of the 223 miles. The suggestion would be to run from Pt Germein to Point Lowly at a maximum depth of 75 ft. Three-quarters of this length is exposed at low tide. The new pipe will be of 42 inches diameter for more than half its length and is expected to have a capacity of five times that of the original pipeline opened in 1944 at a cost of £2,750,000. A work camp has been established at Spalding for the Hanson to Bundaleer section, on which work will start this month. Duplication will take several years.

The Heliothis Grub poses a threat to lucerne seed crops in the next few weeks. The moth has become more prevalent lately after a long period of little change. Recommended control is 2 ounces of actual DDT (8 oz of 25 p.m. DDT) to the acre. One spray gives one week’s protection at this time of the year.

Weather. Hail storms. A wild storm struck Mt Bryan about 4 p.m. on Friday in a confined strip. Golf ball sized hail and 136 points of rain fell in 40 minutes accompanied by high winds which wrecked two sections of the wheat stack shed and hurled them through telephone lines and wrapped them around one of the large steel poles which was then levelled with ground, but which saved the hotel from being damaged by the flying debris. Some of the 8 inch by 8 inch uprights were snapped off like carrots and twisted iron and broken timber littered the highway. Telephone services to the north were cut. A large tree near the station fell and cut railway control lines. Hail broke windows and skylights and tore gardens to shreds. Colin Lloyd, who was working at Mt Bryan, brought in some of the hail which would barely fit into the neck of a two pint thermos flask. The creek north of the town came down and stranded a number of travellers. At the top end of the creek Mr H. Griffen’s property received 3 inches with damage to fences etc. Burra had a less severe hail storm at about 3 a.m. on Saturday.

92, 4, 30 Jan. 1962, page 3

Advt. Wirth’s Circus is arriving by Special Trains on Thursday 1 February for one night only.

Prices 6/-, 8/-, 10/6, 12/6, 14/- and 16/6. Zoo is open 3 p.m. to 5 p.m.

92, 4, 30 Jan. 1962, page 4

Burra Small Bore Club fired a double 25 yard shoot. G. Webster was best off the rifle and with handicap.

92, 4, 30 Jan. 1962, page 6

Obituary. Richard (Dick) Crang died in an Adelaide Hospital 24 January. He spent five years in Burra at Elder, Smith & Co. He joined Elders in 1932 at Wentworth NSW where he was born 49 years ago. He came to Burra in 1935 and enlisted from here in June 1940 in the 2/7 Field Regiment AIF. After the war he opened Elder’s Kingscote Branch and from 1947 to 1951 was manager at Pt Augusta. He then spent five years as a Branch Inspector before opening Elder’s Alice Springs Branch in 1956. Ill health forced a transfer to Adelaide twelve months ago. He is survived by a widow and two sons, Bill and Richard.

[Born 24 June 1912 Wentworth NSW.]

Advt. Burra Pictures, 3 February

James Stewart & Lee Remick in Anatomy of a Murder

Plus Wrestling Knight

7 February

Jeff Chandler & Jack Palance in 10Seconds to Hell

Patricia Driscoll & Robert Arden in The Man in the Shadow

92, 4, 30 Jan. 1962, page 7

Burra Institute Library again failed to get a quorum on 23 January when only eight of the one hundred members attended the annual meeting. Another attempt to hold the AGM will be made on 6 February.

92, 4, 30 Jan. 1962, page 8

Burra Town Council, Special Meeting 22 January

Approval was given for the Small Bore Club to hold a Prize Shoot on Sunday 1 April.

Council advises the Aberdeen Tennis Club that it is in favour of giving permission to hold a tennis tournament on Sundays, but is seeking legal opinion regarding the agreement.

The Club sought a new pit toilet and children’s convenience adjacent to the ladies’ toilet – advised that this is the responsibility of the Playground Committee.

Mr W.A. Holness of Paruna was appointed Town Clerk.

A minute of appreciation was recorded for the work of the outgoing Town Clerk, Mr Fullgrabe.

92, 5, 6 Feb. 1962, page 1

Council Amalgamation was discussed at a meeting between the Burra Town and District Councils on 31 January following a petition from 300 ratepayers. It was resolved that the Councils separately discuss the issues and there be another joint meeting 21 February. Mr Baulderstone said the issue arose from a petition of ratepayers, but he personally felt from 15 successive years’ experience that the Town Council was too small. The Council had reached its limit in rate revenue and the population had declined. Rate revenue is three times that of thirty years ago, but administration [costs] are five time that of thirty years ago. Money on administration could be saved by amalgamation. He could not see why the two Councils could not work together. The District Council than asked a series of questions:

What is the rate revenue?

What percentage of the ratepayers is represented by the 300 petitioners?

How many miles of road are there in the Town Council area?

How is the income spent?

Does the Council work on Ward Accounts?

Is money raised in a ward spent in the ward?

What is the percentage of administrative costs against rate revenue?

Town Council members felt they needed to discuss matters further in their own chamber.

DC Chairman A.D. Radford felt amalgamation would be a step in the right direction, though the opinion of Councillors in both Councils was divided. If amalgamation was desired there would be many problems to overcome and a series of meetings would be needed.

Mr Robert Simpson has opened a garage in Mt Bryan.

Adelaide Wool Sales. S.J. Woollacott topped local prices at 703⁄4d. [Other local district prices are printed.]

Obituary. Mrs Bert Bishop nee Miss Teresa Burton who has lived at Mt Bryan all her life died recently.

[Born Olive Teresa Burton 21 November 1887 Kooringa, wife of Walter Bertram Bishop: died 28 January 1962, Mt Bryan.]

92, 5, 6 Feb. 1962, page 2

Advt. Elders, Dalgety and Bullock & Wilkinson Ltd will auction 2,794 acres of freehold being a portion of Koonoona at the RSL Hall Burra on 23 February for the Executors of the Will of the late Kenneth L. Duffield.

Lot 1. 93 acres 3 roods 24 perches Pt Sections 201 & 202 & closed road Hd Apoinga disposed as 1 paddock.

Lot 2. 749 acres 2 roods 15 perches Block G Koonoona Estate of 399 acres 3 roods 15 perches with a stone building of 6 rooms etc. and Block H of 249 acres 3 roods.

Lot 3. 1,272 acres 32 perches Sections 184, 194, 190, 191, 189, 188, 187, 186, 429 & closed roads Hd Apoinga disposed as 2 paddocks.

Lot 4. 680 acres Sections 241, 242, 30, 250 & 251 Hd Apoinga disposed as 1 paddock.

Advt. Elders will auction for Mr A.L. Thomas of Terowie that portion of the original Hogback Station known as White Dam in the RSL Hall Burra 23 February. 6,289 acres perpetual lease. 25 miles east of Hallett.

[Details of sections are given.]

92, 5, 6 Feb. 1962, page 5

Weather. In the hail storm at Mt Bryan recently Miss Jill Stolte was badly bruised by the hail before she could reach shelter. At the time she was bringing in the cows for milking.

Mr F. Jefferies lost the roof from one shed and two strips from the roof of his big hay shed along with the two big sliding doors.

The hail cut standing oats crops to pieces. A new tank on the railway platform was blown down to the cattle yards at the north end of the town and en route badly bent a windmill tower.

Burra Swimming Carnival of 26 January is reported.

92, 5, 6 Feb. 1962, Supplement [Two sides of six columns.]

Trevor Forby of the Savings Bank staff at Burra was farewelled on Friday evening at a social and dance in the RSL Hall. He is moving to Adelaide and his replacement is Mr A.R. Webber from Prospect. He has been active in the Football and cricket Clubs. A presentation of a wallet of notes was made.

Advt. Goldsbrough, Mort & Co. have for sale a house in Lancelot Terrace off Kangaroo Street for Mr H.J. Wilson. A six roomed stone cottage etc.

Advt. Elder, Smith & Co. will auction in Burra RSL Hall 9 March, 198 square miles of Pastoral Lease located 30 miles northeast of Morgan.

[This is ‘Gluepot’.]

85, 6, 13 Feb. 1962, page 1 [Note volume number reverts to 85 from 92.]

Burra High School enrolments were 144 compared with 125 last year. There were 76 boys and 68 girls.

Leaving 11, Intermediate 39, 2nd Year 38 and 1st Year 56. Newcomers are named as are prefects and house leaders. Mr J. Murphy just arrived from England with his family, commenced duty on Tuesday.

Burra Primary School opened with 244 on the roll. Mr Sullivan, Mrs Sladden and Miss Coventry were replaced by Mr King, Miss Langsford & Miss Reed. The erection of the sick bay has been completed. 31 infants were enrolled on Tuesday and are listed.

St Joseph’s Convent School reports 5 new enrolments and no staff changes.

Hallett School opened with 63 children, about the same as in recent years. New students are listed.

Mt Bryan School began with 47 students, the same as last year and with the same staff. New students are listed.

Booborowie School started with 59 students; 7 less than in 1961. New students are listed.

Hallett Wheat Growers are seeking the construction of silos there.

Burra Swimmers won the North Eastern Swimming Association’s ‘Eric Tilbrook’ Shield with 164 points from Clare with 155 and Spalding with 125. [Results are printed.]

Burra’s Open carnival planned for Saturday has attracted nearly 500 entries.
