85, 7, 20 Feb. 1962, page 1

Burra Open Swimming Carnival last Saturday was held in perfect weather. Takings were £71 of which c. £40 should be profit. [Results are printed.]

Burra Swimming Club. Photo of the team which won the shield.

Burra Playground Committee has decided to improve the facility by installing a swinging boat. Swings will be repaired and the seesaws, which are beyond repair, will be removed. Council will be asked to co-operate in the erection of a new ladies and children’s toilet.

85, 7, 20 Feb. 1962, pages 1 & 4

Burra Town Council met on 12 February to discuss the amalgamation with the District Council. Most Councillors felt that the loss of town status and of the leadership of a Mayor and Mayoress would be an important deciding factor. The expression of the ratepayers who signed the petition, giving reasons for the amalgamation would be sought. It was felt much more discussion between the two Councils would be needed before the actual facts for and against any amalgamation could be laid before the ratepayers. The Mayor protested against the long delay in repairing the footpath in front of his home; it having been ripped up by a Government Department and now has been sealed at his own expense. He also objected to pine trees cut down and dumped along Mr Brian Riggs’ fence that should have been removed months ago. The Town Council resolved to meet fortnightly instead of monthly, on the first and third Mondays of the month.

The Aberdeen Tennis Club is to be allowed to run a tournament on Easter Sunday subject to the Clerk establishing the legality of the agreement.

Burra Small Bore Club is to be permitted to change the date of the Sunday shoot from 1 to 8 April.

85, 7, 20 Feb. 1962, page 5

Burra Football Club held its AGM last Friday in the Town Hall Supper Room. President John Merkel welcomed 30 members. Life Certificates were presented to Messrs L.A. (Bert) Beinke, K.J. Murphy and D. Edwards. Elected were: Patron, Reg. Warnes; President, John Merkel; Vice-President, L.A. Beinke and Secretary & Treasurer, D. Zanker. It was decided Burra could form a ‘B’ team or a Colts team, but no final decision was to be made before the Association meeting.

85, 8, 27 Feb. 1962, page 1

Koonoona Estate Sale, Burra RSL Hall 23 February.

Lot 1. 92 acres 3 roods 24 perches was bought by C.V. Kotz of Emu Downs for £41 per acre.

Lot 2. 749 acres 2 roods15 perches was bought by E.H. & J.O. Friebe & O.H. Broad at £18 per acre.

Lot 3. 1272 acres 32 perches was passed in at £16 per acre.

Lot 4. 680 acres was bought by Broad Bros of Booborowie. [Price unclear – perhaps £11-15-0 per acre.]

Portion of Hogback Sale, RSL Hall 23 February, of 6289 acres of perpetual lease was passed in at £1-10-0 per acre and sold after private negotiation to Messrs G.R. Thomas & Sons for an undisclosed figure.

An Intermediate Christian Endeavour Society has been formed at Kooringa Methodist Church and first met last Sunday with twelve teenagers attending. Peter Benger has been elected Secretary and Joyleen Jenner is the Treasurer.

The Premier Sir Thomas Playford addressed electors in the Burra Town Hall on Thursday night, together with Mr John Bailey the LCL Candidate for Burra and Mr G.J. Gilfillan LCL Candidate for the Northern Division in the Legislative Council.

Burra Swimming Club. Photo of Captain Mr Alan Wilkinson receiving the Inter-Club Shield recently.

A Bowls Tournament held on Wednesday night raised £80 for the Burra Hospital. Light rain fell at times, but nevertheless 64 players took part using 8 rinks. The winning team was W. Corner, K. Williams, A. Wright and N. Sieber.

Matron Fyfe has returned to duty at Burra Hospital after her holiday in Tasmania. Sister W.A. Crossing, who was Acting Matron, has returned to her home at Topar Station via Broken Hill.

Porter’s Lagoon Boating Carnival by the Outboard Motorboat Club of SA was quite successful with gate takings of £75. (It was run in conjunction with the Demobilised Soldiers’ Assoc.) Mr Lance Fiebig of Burra won two events. As well as races there were boat rides and water skiing. (Results are not to hand.)

A stone house of four rooms with two 1,000 gallon tanks with a frontage of 71 ft 11 inches to Queen Street and 195 ft 4 inches to Stock Street to Kangaroo St. 1 rood 11 perches. Check: this doesn’t make sense.

Mr John Merkel of Dalgety’s Burra office for the past three years has been transferred to Adelaide, to be replaced by Mr Peter Murphy. He has been President of the Burra Football Club. He will leave in about a month’s time.

85, 8, 27 Feb. 1962, page 8

Burra High School. The Parents & Friends’ Association had about 80 persons at their first meeting for the year. The present credit balance was £360. This is a good start towards financing two tennis courts, two half-cricket pitches and a sprinkler system to water a grassed area for football, softball and athletics. The Education Department has granted £135 for the initial ground formation of the ‘Flat’.

85, 10 (2), 13 Mar. 1962, page 6 [This number first used in 1954.]

Burra Town Council

The minute of 16 August 1948 forbidding the playing of sport on Sundays on courts leased to tennis clubs was repealed. The clause ‘K’ of the agreement is to be amended to allow play between 1 p.m. and 6 p.m. and the amended is to be presented at the next ratepayers’ meeting.

The Housing Trust is to be advised that the Council was disturbed at not receiving a building application before building started and in future application must be made before worked commenced.

Cricket. Mokota Association

Burra Footballers 102 v. Spalding 1 for 20

Mt Bryan 240 v. Hallett

Booborowie 6 for 312 v. North Booborowie

85, 10 (2), 13 Mar. 1962, page 8 [This number first used in 1954.]

Bowls

Saddleworth Gold 108 defeated Burra Gold 72

Clare White 106 defeated Burra Green 67

Burra Small Bore Club. Best scorer was R. Angel.

85, 11 (2), 20 Mar. 1962, page 1 [This number first used in 1954.]

State Elections: declaration of the poll at Burra Town Hall last Wednesday.

P.H. Quirke (Ind.) 3218

J.P. Bailey (Lib.) 2481

At the election Labor has won 19 seats and Liberals 18, with 2 Independents. Mr Quirke has agreed to continue to support Sir Thomas Playford. The final decision will rest with Mr T.C. Stott. Sir Thomas Playford has resolved to test the matter on the floor of the House of Assembly.

Council Amalgamation. The meeting on 12 March resolved nothing and it was suggested that the Council refer back to the ratepayers.

The M & BHA has had an average attendance of 43 at clinics held in the last six months.

Tennis. Burra Association ‘A’ Grade: Aberdeen 14 sets defeated Spalding 6 sets.

‘Red Cross Calling’ in Burra has raised £132-10-0, with some yet to come in.

Attempted Robbery. An attempt was made on the night of 14 March to blow the lock on the strong room at Bence’s Ltd in Burra. The door became jammed. Entrance was obtained to the building via a skylight and then via a manhole in the office ceiling. The robbery was unsuccessful, though considerable damage was done. Frocks and materials were burned or scorched when used to deaden the noise.

85, 11 (2), 20 Mar. 1962, page 7 [This number first used in 1954.]

Redruth Methodist Guild reports on the year. (R. Jennison, Secretary.)

Membership was 43 and average attendance was 23. In all £315 was raised for the circuit.

[Details of the year’s activities are given in 13⁄4 columns.]

85, 11 (2), 20 Mar. 1962, page 8 [This number first used in 1954.]

North Eastern Football League held its AGM at Booborowie 12 March.

There will be ‘A’ and ‘B’ teams from Booborowie, Burra, Hallett and Spalding

The President Mr J.T. Jenner reported on 1961.

There were four teams in ‘A’ Grade and 3 Colts. (Hallett was unable to field a Colts team.)

Aberdeen Club was re-formed and applied to join, but was refused and had a successful year as part of the Mid-North Association. Leighton Club, after being part of the North Eastern Association in 1960, went into recess in 1961, having lost players to Aberdeen.

[He then went on to report on inter-association matters and finals.]

Congratulations to Keith Warrior for his 1961 Mail Medal – his 5th over several years and to John Dewhirst for the Burra Record Trophy and to John Brooks as leading goal-kicker for the season.

He reported that the association was in a sound financial position.

85, 12 (2), 27 Mar. 1962, page 1 [This number first used in 1954.]

Burra Racing Club conducted an excellent meeting on Wednesday. Weather was good if a little windy. There was some difficulty in getting horses into the mobile starting stalls, used for the first time at Burra and the Maiden Handicap was delayed for 26 minutes. The delay was entirely due to the lack of experience of the horses. The track and surrounds were in excellent condition. Gate takings were £209. (£30 down on the previous March meeting and c. £100 down on September.) [A photo of the Club President Mr G. Gask is printed and so are the results.]

Burra Swimming Pool will close for the season on 31 March.

Adelaide Wool Sales. Local district prices are printed.

St Patrick’s Sports Meeting at Booborowie was held on Saturday.

Gate £44-8-0, Afternoon Tea £16, High Tea £62 and Ball £29-10-0. [Results are printed.]

The couple will live in Burra. [Photo printed.]

85, 12 (2), 27 Mar. 1962, page 2 [This number first used in 1954.]

[Railway Terrace, New Aberdeen.]

Advt. Travel Talk with coloured slides by Mr Horace Oates in Burra RSL Hall Tuesday 3 April:

They of the Inland.

Advt. Paint Work & General Repairs at reasonable prices. H.W. Rost, Burra. CHECK PAGE NUMBER

85, 12 (2), 27 Mar. 1962, page 3 [This number first used in 1954.]

Weather. Rain today in Burra has produced 128 points so far. Thunderstorms yesterday delivered good falls to parts of the district: Booborowie 114 points, Baldina 170, Old Koomooloo 74 and World’s End 162.

Mt Bryan reports 220 points from midnight to 9.45 a.m. today with Dust Hole Creek carrying fairly heavy flood waters.

Tennis. Semi-Finals

‘A’ Grade Hallett Red 15-104 defeated Spalding 5-70

Aberdeen 10-100 defeated Mt Bryan 10-80

‘B’ Grade Spalding Blue defeated Leighton Black

Spalding Red 16 sets defeated Kooringa 4 sets

Fire. A fire on Monday, which began in a paddock of Miss E. Bailey’s, burned a narrow strip for one and a half miles in a northeast direction and spread quickly through Clem Bailey’s property and thence to Mr M. de N. Lucas’s where volunteer fire fighters saved a house near Gum Creek School, but a new hay shed full of baled hay was destroyed.

Dermot Walsh & Hazel Court in Woman 0f Mystery

85, 12 (2), 27 Mar. 1962, page 4 [This number first used in 1954.]

John Merkel was farewelled by the Football & Cricket Clubs in the Air Force Clubrooms on Friday night. He is the immediate past President of the Burra Football and Cricket Clubs and is being transferred from Dalgety’s Burra office to Adelaide. He is a foundation member of the Burra Footballers Cricket Club. A presentation was made.

Burra High School. The Parents & Friends’ Association held its AGM and elected for 1962 President, Mrs M .Kellock; Vice-Presidents, Mrs E. Baulderstone & Mrs R. Mueller; Secretary, Mrs A. Benger; Assistant Secretary, Mrs R. Sandercock and Treasurer, Mrs C. Neill.

85, 13 (2), 3 Apr. 1962, page 1 [This number first used in 1954.]

Tennis. Burra Association Final

‘A’ Grade Aberdeen drew with Spalding 10-85 each. The final is to be replayed on Saturday next.

Mid North Photographic & Art Exhibition at Mr Garth Mitchell’s Studio in Adelaide.

Six camera clubs participated with 455 colour transparencies, 133 black and white prints and 57 awards of merit were given. The best of this work will be shown in the Clare Town Hall on Friday 13 April. The best black and white print was by L.W. Richardson of Saddleworth. The best colour transparency was that of Me E. Williams of Clare. [Winners of merit awards are listed.]

Attempted Robbery. Following the attempt to blow the strong room at Bence’s Ltd on 14 March, two men were charged in Burra Police Court on Friday and pleaded guilty to breaking and entering with intent. They were Charles Francis Cefie and Maxwell George Christie. They were remanded in custody for sentencing at the Supreme Court in Adelaide.

85, 13 (2), 3 Apr. 1962, pages 1 & 3 [This number first used in 1954.]

SA Co-operative Bulk Handling Ltd will hold a meeting of growers from Burra, Mt Bryan, Hallett and surrounding areas at the Mt Bryan Hall on 9 April at 7.30 p.m. to discuss bulk handling requirements. An inspection of sites will take place at Hallett at 1.30 p.m., Mt Bryan at 4.30 p.m. and at Burra on Tuesday morning. The first requirement is to convince directors that facilities are needed before settling down to argue where and how many.

85, 13 (2), 3 Apr. 1962, pages 1 & 8 [This number first used in 1954.]

Burra High School held its Sports Day on Friday. [Results are printed.]

Jennison House won the shield. Cups were won by:

Senior Boys’ Cup M. Sieber

Senior Girls’ Cup H. Hentschke

Junior Boys’ Cup J. Edwards

Junior Girls’ Cup H. Angel

Burra Burra Show Inc. Mr Rex. Warnes was re-elected President at the Annual Meeting.

Tribute was paid to Mr R. Fuss, Life Member of the Society, for his efforts in making additions and repairs and maintenance.

Mr Warnes reported a successful show on 7 October 1961 in perfect weather. Gate takings were £241 and there was £41-15-0 from a ball run by the Rural Youth Club. Entries numbered 2681, a record. The tractor driving contest, held for the first time at a country show, proved successful. Membership is steady, but the financial position is not quite as good as previously.

‘Once again Mr Robert Fuss has been a tower of strength to us with his work. He saves us a considerable amount of money and is forever willing to keep things in order. Through his efforts I can report the additions of a Casualty Room and a President’s Room. Both proved an acquisition at the Show. Mr Fuss was also instrumental in bringing the staging positions in the main pavilion up to date. This caused a much better display of exhibits. He also did numerous other jobs to benefit the Society, including the watering of trees which were presented by Mrs Stanley Hawker in front of the main buildings. We are proud to have Mr Fuss as a Life Member.’

I regret to record the death of Mr Edwin Finch and Mr John Kellock who both did much solid work for the society.

Elected: Patron, G.S. Hawker; President, Rex C. Warnes; Vice-Presidents, Messrs B.A. Riggs & C.F. Pearce.

[R. Fuss was on the Produce Committee.]

85, 13 (2), 3 Apr. 1962, page 2 [This number first used in 1954.]

North Eastern Combined Schools’ Sports was held at Spalding on Friday. St Joseph’s Convent School of Spalding was the host school for the day and other schools were Spalding, North Booborowie, Booborowie, Willalo, Hilltown and Leighton. [Results are printed.]

Burra Town Council resolved at its last meeting to advise the organiser of the petition on amalgamation of Councils that after investigation the Councillors have decided that little or no benefit would arise from amalgamation.

Willalo Tennis Tournament, 3 & 4 March

Championship Singles won by R. Scheid of Jamestown from Miss Rosemary Reed of Burra.

Burra High School is celebrating its Golden Jubilee this year. The Headmaster Mr R.V. Mueller recounts some of its highlights. [In the summaries that follow references to sports achievements and prizes awarded have been omitted. They have generally appeared when they occurred.]

1913

The school officially opened 20 January 1913 with J.W. Statton as Assistant in charge and with 30 pupils. Pictures chosen by Mr V. Pavia arrived and the library began with 42 books. A basketball was purchased. Inspector T. Cole recommended a table be obtained for the teacher. Late in the year a cupboard was supplied.

1914

Dorothy Pederson, Isobel Rosewall and Ella Harris applied to be Junior Teachers. Senior Cadets were taken in the Drill Hall by a Military Officer. A medal presented by Mr Crewes was won by Fred Scholz and Frank Riggs won a scholarship to Roseworthy Agricultural College. A seaside picnic was held at Semaphore. On 5 October it was recorded that due to the bad season many children left to help at home.

1915

Mr Statton enlisted and was replaced by the head teacher John T. Johnson, with Frank Thomas Assistant in Charge. A note records: ‘As a Junior Commercial Class has been formed, a typewriter is needed, but we have had no success in obtaining one.’

Cliff Flower topped the Primary division with 92%. He later died whilst Headmaster of Mt Gambier High School and his memory was much revered by Inspector A.O. McPherson. On 5 August there was a short address on the Anniversary of the Declaration of War. H. Collins won the Scholarship to Roseworthy and Fred Scholz entered the Junior Commercial Exam. The year ended with an enrolment of 14 – many having left due to hardship.

1916

The Head Teacher Mr J. Mundy with John Biddle Assistant in Charge. Enrolment was 29. There was a measles epidemic in the year. Clifford Flower passed six subjects with one credit in the Junior Class and Josephine West topped the Primary Class. (To be continued.)

Mr Hughie Parker of Spalding is 91 on 17 April.

85, 14 (2), 10 Apr. 1962, page 2 [This number first used in 1954.]

Advt. Elder, Smith & Co. under instructions from Elder’s Trustee & Executor Co. Ltd in the Estate of the late W.H. Sandland offer the property of ‘Heathmont’ for sale by tender, comprising nine rooms including a large lounge, dining room, study, kitchen etc.

Permission was granted for a new Housing Trust house.

Council will seek some contribution towards cleaning up the cemetery.

The clerk will clarify requirements before removing headstones from the old cemetery.

85, 15 (2), 17 Apr. 1962, page 1 [This number first used in 1954.]

Junior Red Cross has sent £21 to Headquarters after selling more than 500 pasties at 9d each on 5 April.

Poliomyelitis Immunization on 27 April. 212 registrations have been made for injections at Burra Hospital.

A Burra Basketball & Football Ladies’ Auxiliary was formed on 3April: Patron, Mr W. Brown; President, Mrs D. Broderick; Vice-President, Mrs W. Corner and Secretary-Treasurer, Mrs D. Zanker.

Burra Postmaster Mr O.A. Tattersall suffered a heart attack while playing bowls at Mildura earlier this month and after time in hospital is recuperating at home. Mr R.P. Riedel is acting postmaster.

Burra Golf Club held its AGM and elected: President, Ray Jennison; Vice-Presidents, John Murray & Trevor Richardson; Secretary, Hugh Clutterbuck, Assistant Secretary, Ron Wuttke; Treasurer, Bob Riedel, Captain, Stan Longford and Vice-Captain, Jack Bogisch. President Ray Jennison reported a successful year. In the Pennant Competition Burra won both A and B grades. The bank balance was healthy even after buying a mower for £120 during the year. Opening day will be 28 April.

Burra Camera Club. The club held a combined competition with Spalding and Yacka Clubs on ‘Coastal Scenes’. For Burra Rev. Jenner was 1st and 2nd. The Championship slide was taken by Mr Stewart Meyer of Spalding.

Burra 124 & 2 for 96 defeated Koonoona 112 & 95.

85, 15 (2), 17 Apr. 1962, page 5 [This number first used in 1954.]

Burra Institute. AGM elected President, P.J. Byrne; Vice-President, R.W. Nankivell and Secretary, J. Carpenter.

About 180 books were added in the year. Subsidy for the year was £65-19-7, without which the library could not continue. Subscribers are 89, having lost a few due to television. Mrs Steer continues as librarian to do an enthusiastic job and thanks to Mrs K. Broad for repairing over 100 books. The credit balance at 31 December was £3-1-0.

Burra High School. The Jubilee History continued by R.V. Mueller

1917

The year opened with 23 students and a new football and basketball were ordered. Seven students attended a Boy Scout Rally in Adelaide and the school celebrated Violet Day on 6 July. On 21 August snow fell between 8 and 11 a.m. Hazel Edwards got 5 subjects in the Junior Commercial Class. Josephine West topped Junior Public and Grace Lloyd topped the Primary Class.

1918

The Head Teacher was R. Hitchcox with J. Biddle Assistant in Charge & Lois Jones Assistant.

There were 20 in 1st year, 7 in Commercial, 2 in Junior Public and 2 in Senior Commercial. Commercial Classes were formed to encourage parents to keep children at school. Application was made to the Education Department for the formation of a High School Council, but this was refused. On 12 November three earth tremors were felt.

1919

J. Biddle was Assistant in Charge. The school was closed for some time due to the influenza epidemic. On 14 March the school took part in the opening of RSL Club Rooms. On 2 April there was a Welcome Home to Nurses and Soldiers. The Hon. John Lewis presented the school with gymnasium apparatus. On 19 July Peace Celebrations were held and Peace Medals distributed. The school assembled to see Prime Minister Hughes pass through the Burra Railway Station on the way home from the Peace Conference and they were given a half-holiday.

1920

School opened on 19 January with 26 on the roll, but only 19 presented. Later in the year the possibility of school closure was raised. Mr James Reed presented a Model Ship to the school, the sale of which had raised a large sum for patriotic funds. @3 March Sir Ross Smith and party arrived and a half-holiday was declared. On 3 July the school closed for a fortnight in honour of the visit to SA of the Prince of Wales.

(To be continued.)

85, 15 (2), 17 Apr. 1962, page 6 [This number first used in 1954.]

Bowls. On a visit to Eudunda the home team defeated Burra by 10 points in a seven rink contest.

At Riverton the Burra rink won 2 games and lost 2.

85, 15 (2), 17 Apr. 1962, page 7 [This number first used in 1954.]

Aberdeen Football Club was re-formed last year after being in recess for a number of years. An application to join the North Eastern League was rejected, but the club was accepted into the Mid North Association. The club compared favourably with other teams in that Association. Aberdeen’s Captain-Coach, Kevin Lane, was elected Captain of the Association team. The team got as far as the preliminary final, which was very satisfactory for a first year team. The club now has a very substantial club house erected and a hot shower room is nearing completion and should be ready for the first home match on 5 May. The Captain topped the Association goal-kicking list and won the Mail Medal. This year Kevin Lane is again Captain-Coach with Don Lloyd as Vice-Captain. Darrel Kakoschke is Captain of the Colts. A scratch match against Farrell Flat was played last Sunday at Farrell Flat.

85, 15 (2), 17 Apr. 1962, page 8 [This number first used in 1954.]

Cricket. Mokota Association Grand Final.

Booborowie 256 & 1 for 22 v. Spalding 298. Game to be played out.

85, 16 (2), 24 Apr. 1962, page 1 [This number first used in 1954.]

Booborowie Tennis Club. Fund raising for improvements has produced over £350 and concluded with a ball to wind up a Queen Competition. Miss Kathleen Benton whose sponsors raised £172 was crowned Queen by Miss Port Adelaide (Miss Rosemary Searle). [Two photos are printed.]

The long wooden bench that stood for many years under Sara’s verandah at Burra North has vanished. If it was a prank, local elderly folk, who appreciated the chance for a ‘breather’ on it, are not amused.

Burra Town Council has resolved that on or before 31 December 1963 all buildings in the town area must be equipped with a septic tank.

A Ratepayers’ Meeting has been called for 1 May to consider the alteration to clause K in the lease agreement with the Aberdeen Tennis Club, the granting of a lease to the Burra & District Swimming Club and to receive the Mayor’s Report on the Council for 1961-62.

Northern Agricultural Show Societies’ Association (14 Societies) held its AGM for 1962. Mr A.B. Riggs was elected President. The Burra Show will be held on 6 October. Check, This should be B.A. Riggs

Burra High School. The Jubilee History continued by R.V. Mueller.

1921

Twenty-five students started the year. On 6 April the school closed for the laying of the foundation stone of the Fallen Soldiers’ Memorial by Governor Sir Archibald Weigall. On 29 May heavy rain flooded the streets and Lady Hackett visited to speak to the girls about Girl Guides. Inspector W. Adey cited average attendances and said Burra would be considered when the new Higher Primary Schools were being established. Burra average attendance:

1913 25.3 1914 23 1915 24.2

1916 27.3 1917 23.8 1918 33.8

1919 13.1 120 23.1 1921 20

1922

John Biddle was Assistant in Charge with Edna Grosvenor newly appointed and enrolment was 44. An Old Scholars Assoc. was inaugurated. On 21 September all classes went to the top of the hill to observe the solar eclipse.

1923

Lancelot Carthew was Assistant in Charge with Miss O.G. Mawley & R. Davis. Enrolment was 36. On 24 March Miss Mawley transferred to Adelaide when attendance fell to 29. On very hot days the boys were taken to the Mine Pool during the last lesson and the girls were dismissed. Heavy rain made the road to Clare impassable for sports on 19 July and it wasn’t much better on 22 September when teams arrived at Clare at 10.30 and had to leave early on their return.

1924

Enrolment was 35. Domestic Arts was introduced with Miss Forss (part-time).

(To be continued.)

85, 16 (2), 24 Apr. 1962, page 4 [This number first used in 1954.]

Burra Small Bore Club

3 April. Double 25 yards: Mike Thomas won the handicap and W. Barker was best off the rifle.

10 April. Double 75 yards: Ron Kellock won on handicap and off the rifle.

17 April. Double 50 yards: Mike Thomas won on handicap and off the rifle.

This season W. Barker took the championship Trophy over four shoots, the Marksman’s (aggregate) and also the Handicap Trophy. Norma Barker won the main trophies in the Ladies’ Section.

85, 16 (2), 24 Apr. 1962, page 5 [This number first used in 1954.]

Burra Primary School Committee held its Annual Meeting. Elected: Chairman, M.G .Stockman and Secretary-Treasurer, D. Bannister.

Staff changes since Christmas:

Mrs Sladden, Miss Coventry and Mrs Sullivan have left, and Miss Reed, Miss Longford and Mr King have come.

There are seven teachers for seven classes.

Report for the past year:

Education Week passed off very well. A sports day on the oval again replaced the annual picnic. Visiting Day was held in conjunction with the High School and Arbor Day was held in winter. The land between the Drill Hall and the School has at last been transferred to the Education Department and can now be developed as a playing area. A sick bay has been built in the central part of the school and furnished by the Welfare Club. All rooms now have efficient lighting for dull days. Nothing has yet eventuated from a deputation and discussions regarding a crossing near the Town Hall. At present two white lines make a crossing. The school’s new roof was a godsend during this summer’s storms. We are pushing for a Primary School toilet block on the east side of the school. In the year sporting equipment has been purchased and a Christmas party was held in each class. A school uniform has been selected with colours of grey and blue.

85, 16 (2), 24 Apr. 1962, page 7 [This number first used in 1954.]

Marriage. Kooringa Methodist Church 7 April

Margaret Beryl Kellock, only daughter of Mr & Mrs M.T. Kellock of Burra, married

John Gilmore Lobban, elder son of Mr & Mrs J.D. Lobban of Naracoorte.

Obituary. Mrs A. Carpenter died in Adelaide at the home of her daughter Mrs R. Garrard aged 94. [Photo.]

[Born Augusta Hirschausen 8 November 1868 Millerton (Burra): died 18 April 1962 Albert Park, residence Burra North. She was the wife of the late William Carpenter 1860-1914.]

Burra High School. The Jubilee History continued by R.V .Mueller.

1925

Miss Olive Drever joined the staff as 0.2 time Domestic Arts Teacher. Enrolment was a record 42 with 21 new students and 6 probationary. The school was conducted in three rooms on the western side of the Primary School Building. 17 March was speech afternoon. The Director of Education and the Superintendent of High Schools visited and decided the Physics room should be remodelled and the yard gravelled. On 27 June a bus and six cars took students to Kapunda for sports.

1926

There was a complete change of staff with the arrival of Mr E.A. Haese as Headmaster with Miss Dorothy Robinson and Elsie Tiver (Part Time Domestic Arts). Enrolment was 40. School caps came from James Marshall & Co. at 2/11 each. On 28 September the Old Scholars held a reunion in the Parish Hall.

(To be continued.)

The Anzac Service at Burra on Sunday saw a smaller attendance this year. Before the service the Pt Pirie Piper’s Band played at the Burra Hospital between 12 and 1 p.m. At the service at the Memorial 86 ex-service personnel were on parade led by Burra RSL President H. Cornelius. Rev. R.S. Jenner gave the address, which is printed in just less than 2 columns. The march went from the RSL Building up Commercial Street to Kangaroo Street and returned to the Memorial. W. Kotz & M. Burt were pallbearers. Wreaths were placed by H. Cornelius (for the RSL), T.R. Rogers (for the Air Force Assoc.), Mr Arnold Heinrich (for Demobilised Soldiers), W. Carpenter (for the Fathers’ Assoc.), Mayor E.T. Baulderstone (for the Town Council) and Chairman A.D. Radford (for the District Council). Flag attendants were H.L. Riggs and J. Lockett. There was an evening service at St Mary’s conducted by Rev. T. Drought and a collection for Legacy. He also conducted an Anzac Service at Booborowie Hall on Sunday at 3 p.m. with a lesson read by local RSL President Barry Dinham.

85, 17 (2), 1 May 1962, page 2 [This number first used in 1954.]

Polio Injections were received by 204 of the 213 who had registered for them.

Warnes Group CWA Conference was held at Manoora with Mrs Hall, State President. It is reported in c. 21⁄4 columns. Mrs Badman of Yacka was elected the new Group President with Mrs Page of Yacka as Secretary.

85, 18 (2), 8 May 1962, page 1 [This number first used in 1954.]

New Clothing Factory. ‘Benoco’ Manufacturing Company has established its operations at the old Power House and has begun a trial run yesterday. A sample range of children’s clothing commenced circulation in the city and country towns recently.

Burra High School. The Jubilee History continued by R.V. Mueller.

1927

The staff was unchanged from 1926. Enrolments were 37. On 4 February Premier Hon. L. Hill and the Minister of Education visited. The building was severely commented upon and renovations and alterations worth £800 were promised. [The building was condemned as being too dark and poorly ventilated. The £800 was to enlarge windows and install new floors.] The May vacation was extended one week at the request of the Duke of York. On 21 September the Governor General Lord Stonehaven and Lady Stonehaven visited the school.

1928

Ruth Batchelor joined the staff and Elsie Tiver was transferred. Mabel Nield replaced her as part-time Domestic Arts Teacher. When enrolments increased to 60 an additional teacher, Miss Batchelor was appointed. High School Council funds provided many teaching aids. On 9 July the Aurora Australis was visible from 7 to 8.30 p.m. For four months the school routine was upset by the alterations to improve lighting and ventilation. Dr Steele was a driving force behind many of the changes.

(To be continued.)

85, 18 (2), 8 May 1962, pages 1 & 8 [This number first used in 1954.]

Burra Ratepayers’ Meeting

Mr Baulderstone welcomed an unusually large attendance of 55. After he had introduced the items of business, he accepted the motion of Mr H.C. Cummins that competitive tennis be permissible (upon written application to the Corporation) between 1 p.m. and 6 p.m. on Sundays. Mr H. Jennison spoke against it – being opposed in principle. Mr F. Reed spoke in support – mainly citing the financial benefits to the club and through that to the town. Mr Cummins also spoke in support and it was passed 28 to 18.

The Burra Amateur Swimming Club had been running the pool without a lease and the Mayor felt a lease desirable and so Council had one drawn up to run from 1962 to 1972. Mr H. Cornelius moved the lease be granted. This was seconded by T.G. Perry and carried.

A lease for the Burra North Playground was also carried.

Mr Baulderstone appealed for questions to be asked about the amalgamation of the Councils, rather than as street gossip. He also challenged the view heard in the street that the town was going backwards. He did not agree. In the last few years there had been significant improvements at the racecourse, the showgrounds, playground, basketball courts, oval, small bore range, the Post office, the swimming pool and the hospital. Some progress in the past year had been stifled through lack of money. Council had sought £1,200 for the school road, but had got only £700. Numerous bridges needed repair or renewal and again the Kangaroo Street Bridge needed £500, but the grant was for £300, leaving the Council to meet the gap, as it had to for the school road. The cemetery is old and hard to maintain and permission is being sought to remove headstones. Tree planting had been encouraged and it is unfortunate that some of the CWA Avenue on the approach to the town had to be removed by the Highways Department to re-form the road. Burra was a beautiful town, but lends itself to further beautification, especially along the creek and around the pool area. He had plans in mind to achieve this together with a Caravan Park area. Street lighting is now quite satisfactory. The attendance at pictures had declined, but it was still a paying proposition. The £6,000 borrowed to renovate the Town Hall was covered by a special rate of 4d, but interest and repayments come from the pictures and the rate is merely security. A bequest from the late Mrs Gare enabled the Town Hall stage to be modified and renovated. The erratic dumping of rubbish at the mine is causing trouble and needs the Council’s attention in the coming year.

(To be continued.)

85, 18 (2), 8 May 1962, page 2 [This number first used in 1954.]

Advt. Burra Pictures, 12 May

Elizabeth Taylor & Montgomery Clift in Suddenly Last Summer

John Gregson & Sybil Thorndike in Hand in Hand

85, 18 (2), 8 May 1962, page 7 [This number first used in 1954.]

Weather. Burra recorded no rain in April for the first time in 82 years of records.

Mr R.E. Geve, Manager of Koo-Owie Stud found a ‘Radiosonde’ (a weather balloon) on the property. It had been released from a weather station in Melbourne.

Aberdeen Football & Tennis Clubs held a successful Gala Afternoon on 14 April, which raised £50 to be split equally. [Results of the sporting events and other contests are printed.]

Burra Bowling Club. Trophy Winners 1962:

Singles Champion K. Williams

Pairs Champions H. Foote & M. Jacka

Handicap Singles K. Murphy

Consistency K. Williams

Night Pairs K. Horsnell & P. Pritchard

Mixed Pairs O. Holmes & I. Phillips

85, 18 (2), 8 May 1962, page 8 [This number first used in 1954.]

Burra Camera Club, 30 April

Visit by Mr Bob Riedel who showed a selection of slides taken on a recent overseas trip.

85, 18 (3), 15 May 1962, page 1 [This number first used in 1954.]

Burra Town Council. Elections.

Following a petition from 71 ratepayers Mr E.T. Baulderstone has consented to stand again for Mayor.

Other nominations:

North Ward Mr M.E. Mitchell elected unopposed

West Ward Dr R.B. Pitcher elected unopposed

East Ward Mr H.R. Cornelius

Mr I.T. Allen

An election for East Ward will be held 7 July.

Burra Burra District Council. Nominations.

Kooringa Ward G.R. Finch elected unopposed

Leighton Ward R.J. White elected unopposed

Mongolata Ward A.D. Radford elected unopposed

There were no nominations for Farrell Flat Ward

A Supplementary Election is called for Farrell Flat Ward with nominations by 25 May and an election on 7 July if required.

Burra Town Council has declared a prohibited parking area on the east side of Market Street from the camping area gates south to the public conveniences. Loading or unloading is permitted.

A.S. Barrett writes condemning the recent approval given for competitive tennis on Sundays.

Mid Northern High School Sports were held at the Burra Race Course on Thursday 10 May. Head Prefects read the names of old scholars who had made the supreme sacrifice in wars. Mr H.J.B. Jennison as Chairman of the Burra High School Council opened the sports and Inspector A.O. McPherson presented the shields. The Parents & Friends Association fed the multitude of over 300 adults and 700 students. Shield results:

In the Open Contest In the Handicap Contest

Balaklava 124 197

Burra 115 255

Clare 141 141

Kapunda 73 259

Riverton 130 219

[Results of events next issue.]

Burra Hospital is modernising its laundry and installing expensive machines to wash, spin dry and dry. The Hospital has secured the machines from Melbourne. The Board is seeking assistance from landowners in the district to help in their cropping program.

85, 18 (3), 15 May 1962, pages 1 & 7 [This number first used in 1954.]

Burra Ratepayers’ Meeting: Report continued from last week.

The Mayor said he felt bitter that after the 1961 ratepayers’ meeting rumours circulated that about £1,000 repaid to the Council by the Police Department had not been accounted for and ratepayers had been misled. This money (£961-5-4) was received on 29 June 1960 and the amount of £493-13-7 due to the Pictures account and £467-12-1 to the general account and this appeared in the 1960-61 balance. Neither he nor his Council had anything to hide and as Chairman of the Finance Committee for ten years he could answer any question put forward.

[Check this statement because if, as it seems to imply, the sum received was divided between the two accounts, it doesn’t quite add up.]

On Council amalgamation he reported two meetings with the District Council, but after discussion neither he nor his Council could see any major gains in rates or administration and therefore had decided against it. He thanked Councillors and others including Mrs Baulderstone.

Mr S.J. Woollacott expressed dissatisfaction on the views about the amalgamation, stating he had spent many hours gathering the petition.

Cr Cornelius said he had originally been in favour, but after consultation could see no gains and changed his mind. Mr Baulderstone said it had been ‘harped’ on for some years and although he had been in favour, he would not support it at this time.

Mr Woollacott also felt that more should be spent on premises owned by him considering the rates he paid.

[Check. Presumably he meant of services like roads and footpaths adjacent to his properties.]

Mr Jennison commented on the unsightly sandbags used for the traffic island in Market Square.

The Mayor said it was hoped the Highways Department would do something towards implementing a plan that had been approved.

A.J. Bruce commented on the unfit state of the ladies’ conveniences near the Fire Station. The Mayor agreed, but blamed the travelling public. Mrs S. Scroop supported this view.

Mr J.G. Carpenter wanted the eradication of noxious weeds enforced.

Mr R. Jennison thought the Aberdeen Playground was in a sad state and Mr W.H. Lloyd (Committeeman) said the swings were in a sorry state, but some new equipment had been added. There were also questions on cemetery upkeep.

Mr D.T. Jacka, in commenting on town progress, said 24 new homes had been built in Burra since the war.

Mr R.M. Reed asked about the whereabouts of funds donated for school crossing lights that had not eventuated. The Mayor blamed the previous Town Clerk for inaction here [and for lack of action on cleaning water-tables.]

Dr Pitcher supported the Mayor, saying they had been led to believe there were complications involved, but recent discussions with the Highways Department suggested there would not be difficulties and the matter was being taken up again. Mr Woollacott queried the competence of the Council in blaming the former Town Clerk for inadequacies and Mr Baulderstone said he would not stand again and so give the town a chance to install a capable Council.

Mr Jennison proposed a vote of thanks to the Mayor and hoped Mr Baulderstone would reconsider his decision regarding a further term as Mayor.

85, 18 (3), 15 May 1962, page 3 [This number first used in 1954.]

85, 19 (2), 22 May 1962, page 1 [This number first used in 1954.]

SA Co-op Bulk Handling has advised that it intends to construct 2-cell 100 bushel [!!] concrete silos at Hallett and Burra in 1963, finances permitting.

Burra Small Bore Club. In a double 50 yards self handicap event shooting to a limit of 200, R. Angel came first.

Booborowie Pictures were shown regularly, but with falling attendances they first became irregular and then ceased. Now the Hall Committee has decided to begin pictures again and to show the films themselves. It cannot continue unless it pays, so locals are encouraged to give their support. Good films have been booked fortnightly for the next six months.

Jennison’s Tyre Service is 40 years old today. Mr H.J.B. Jennison opened the business on 22 May 1922 as a tyre retailer and repairer. Years ago tyres had to be ordered from overseas with waiting periods of six months. Now the stock held can supply most needs for cars, tractors and farm machinery. The business has expanded to include repairs and a Lubritorium. A big change has been to get the public to buy Australian tyres and another was the change from solid to pneumatic tyres on tractors. Methods of retreading tyres had also changed in that period.

Adelaide Wool Sales. Top district price of 793⁄4d came from J.N. McBride of Kia-Ora.

85, 19 (2), 22 May 1962, page 2 [This number first used in 1954.]

85, 19 (2), 22 May 1962, page 6 [This number first used in 1954.]

R.E. Dewhirst writes regarding Colts Football.

With NEFL changing to a ‘B’ Grade competition a group at Booborowie has decided to re-form Booborowie Colts. Spalding and Hallett seem able to form a Colts team, but Burra (because Aberdeen already has a Colts team in the Mid North League) may not be able to do so – though it may yet prove possible.

85, 19 (2), 22 May 1962, page 8 [This number first used in 1954.]

Inter-High School Sports: results are printed.

85, 20, 29 May 1962, page 1

Weather. Good general falls of 1 to 2 inches have ensured a good opening to the season. Burra recorded 256 points. Mt Bryan East had 120 points last week and 120 more at the weekend. Dust Hole Creek carried a small flood on Tuesday.

Electricity. ETSA will extend power to Mt Bryan East and also east of Hallett.

Burra High School. The Jubilee History continued by R.V. Mueller.

1929

E.A. Haese was Headmaster with Ruth Bachelor, Elizabeth Jones and Stella Parker. The enrolment was 54. The school was still being painted when the year began. A professor deplored the waste of money in educating many in our schools and Dr Steele attacked him, saying that knowledge was power and while it might be dangerous to educate the masses, it was right to give the boys and girls every chance and this was a duty parents owed the child and the nation.

1930

The staff was unchanged and the enrolment was 49. The Headmaster returned to find drawers forced, lockers broken and 11/7 missing. On 3 September Brown’s bus, Fuss’s lorry and seven cars took students to Clare for the Mid North High Schools’ Sports. Between Hanson and Farrell Flat Fuss’s lorry was bogged for two hours.

(To be continued.)

Burra Hospital. The washing machine, Hydro Dryer and gas-heated tumble dryer have been installed. The cropping and wool drive for 1962 is under way.

85, 22, 5 June 1962, page 1 [CHECK THE ABSENCE OF NUMBER 21]

Burra High School. A Jubilee Committee has been formed at the school to arrange the celebrations. The Jubilee Project is the improvement of the playing area. An expenditure of £1,200 is anticipated. The project includes laying two tennis courts with cyclone wire enclosure (to be used for basketball in winter), and also two half cricket pitches and a sprinkler system to water a grassed area for football, softball and athletics.

The Jubilee History continued by R.V. Mueller.

1931

The staff was E.A. Haese Headmaster, Beryl Dunstan, Olive Prior, Mabel Dunstan & H. Robinson. On 7 March in a cricket match against Clare Alan Phillips, a left handed bowler took four wickets from four successive balls. The Government was considering closing country high schools and on 21 July a deputation from Burra High School Council waited on the Minister of Education at Parliament House.

1932

There were no staff changes. Enrolment was 57. On 13 February a working bee was organised for improving the Mine Pool. A path was cut to the edge of the pool and dressing sheds and a safety fence were later erected. A cricket pitch was prepared for the girls. On 26 April Lyall Turner broke his arm when he fell from his horse while riding to school.

(To be continued.)

Willalo Hall. A recent meeting of the committee decided to install a lighting plant and to renovate and paint the exterior. A social afternoon, which was held on 25 May to raise funds, resulted in £52.

Weather. This week there were further general falls in which Burra recorded 118 points.

There was a heavy downpour on Saturday at 11 p.m. just as patrons left the pictures and rain reduced attendance at the RSL Ball on Friday night too.

Polio Vaccinations were given to 256 persons at the Burra Hospital on Friday. (58 attended for their 1st, 155 for their 2nd and 43 for their 3rd.)

Football Carnival at Hoyleton on Monday. North Eastern won the 4th successive carnival:

North Eastern 14.16 defeated North West 8.7

85, 22, 5 June 1962, page 7

RSL Ball is reported from last Friday night. In wet and windy conditions attendance was reduced. Door takings were £72, which was about £50 below 1961.

85, 23, 12 June 1962, page 1

Burra-Hallett Road. Following a question in Parliament from Mr Quirke, he was advised that it was intended to seal the road for 6 miles north from Cobb & Co.’s Corner and sub-base construction will be continue with the expectation that this will be completed to Hallett in the 1962-63 financial year.

Burra Hospital. The cropping plan: donation of funds and lands are acknowledged.

Housing Trust of SA says no rental homes have been constructed in Burra because no applications have been received from anyone requiring such a home.

Booborowie Pictures resumed on Saturday with a satisfactory attendance.

A Mouse Plague is presently afflicting Booborowie. [An article on control methods is printed.]

85, 23, 12 June 1962, page 2

Advt. Goldsbrough, Mort & Co. have for private sale or lease the double fronted shop at Burra North on the corner of Young and Morehead Streets, under instruction from the Misses Bentley. Allotment 47 with a frontage of 136 ft to Morehead and a depth of 100 ft to Anne & Young Streets.

Notice. Nankivell Bros is closing business. All persons having articles for repair etc. please pick them up by next Friday.

Basketball. North Eastern

‘A’ Grade Burra Grey 29 defeated Booborowie 22

Burra Blue 30 defeated Hallett 14

‘B’ Grade Booborowie 24 defeated Burra Blue 4

Burra Town Council

Burra Badminton Club was granted hire of the hall at 6/- with the club to remove and replace seats and make good any breakages, but the club will not take preference over any person or body desirous of hiring the hall on that night.

A letter is to be written to ETSA protesting over their use of the parklands at Burra North as a depot for poles, water carts etc.

Donors for school crossing lights will be reimbursed, as the Council will not be installing lights.

The SA Symphony Orchestra will be invited to play in the Burra Town Hall.

P.H. Quirke supplied information about plans for the district schools.

Booborowie: Funds have been approved for paving and fencing.

Black Springs: A scheme for connecting the new toilets to a septic system is in hand. The Department of Mines is to provide a suitable windmill and overhead tank.

Burra: A detailed plan and estimates for a site-works scheme including paving, drainage and retaining wall is being prepared for the approval of funds.

85, 24, 19 June 1962, page 1

Burra Burra DC has appointed Messrs P.G. Rehn & Associates as Weed Inspectors for the district in an effort to strengthen weed control and elimination.

Burra Primary School will host a conference on Friday 22 June for 35 teachers from as far north as Yunta and Olary and south to Manoora as well as from the Pt Pirie District. It will be directed by Mid-North Inspector Mr A.E. Wood. Assistant Superintendent of Rural Schools Mr K. Polkinghorne will open it. Tow Inspectors from Kenya will also attend.

Burra Racing Club. After eleven years as President of the Club, Mr Gerald Gask will resign after the race meeting on 25 June. He is resigning this and other industry positions to be eligible for election to the Adelaide Racing Club Committee.

Shoe Repairer needed in Burra. Burra Traders feel it is necessary that an attempt be made to have a shoe repairer in Burra following the closure of the Shoe Repair Shop. Mr P.J. Byrne of Byrne’s Shoe Store has been approached to try to locate a suitable man and the RSL is also being contacted. It is understood a rental house could be made available to a person prepared to act in this capacity.

Hallett Golf Club was opened by President Mr C. Lucas on 5 May. It is a 9 hole par 68 course and is playing particularly well. There is a membership of 40 odd.

Burra High School. A list of first enrolments is printed. (1913)

[Personal interest: the list includes Aubrey O. Fuss and Eric Russell Fuss.]

The Jubilee History continued by R.V. Mueller.

1933

Staff was E.A. Haese Headmaster, Beryl Dunstan, Olive Prior and Mabel Dunstan.

B. Dunstan was transferred early in the year to be replaced by Marie Coghlan. The enrolment was 52.

The school owned two typewriters. On 7 June J. Gibbs addressed the school on the dried fruits industry. On 6 September the school went to Balaklava for the combined sports using Hill’s bus, Thomas’s buckboard, Fuss’s lorry and Hutchinson’s and the Headmaster’s cars. A mass meeting of parents was held to hear the report from a delegation to the Minister of Education concerning fees for High School students. The school was divided into two ‘Houses’ for the first time.

1934

The staff was E.A. Haese, Doris Parry, Olive Prior and Beryl Waterhouse. On 15 March it is noted there had been no homework for the previous two weeks because of the excessively hot weather. Mr Haese was transferred to Peterborough and Mr T. Charlesworth was appointed from the start of second term. On 13 July the Minister of Education Hon. S.W. Jefferies, accompanied by the district MP visited the school. This was the first year that an end of year banquet was mentioned.

(To be continued.)

85, 24, 19 June 1962, page 2

Notice. Burra Town Council

From today the rubbish dump adjacent to the open cut mine is closed and a new area opened west of the closed dump.

Notice. Burra Rifle Club AGM is called in the Air Force Association Rooms for 30 June. R. Francis, Secretary.

85, 24, 19 June 1962, page 6

Football

‘A’ Grade Robertstown 13.15 defeated Saddleworth 8.12

Riverton 6.14 defeated Marrabel 4.9

Clare North 11.22 defeated Auburn 6.17

Clare South 41.22 defeated Farrell Flat 2.4

Colts Clare North 7.7 defeated Auburn 1.3

Clare South 3.6 defeated Farrell Flat 2.5

Robertstown 3.4 defeated Saddleworth 3.2

Annual Catholic Ball at the Burra Town Hall on Friday drew a fair crowd. The sumptuous supper followed a somewhat unenjoyable period on the dance floor. The general view was that the band lost all sense of time and beat and was merely loud and blaring. While the band had supper Miss Shirley Ryan on the piano and a drummer provided a more satisfactory accompaniment for several dances. Door takings were about £63.

85, 24, 19 June 1962, page 7

Burra Footballers Cricket Club held a dinner at the Commercial Hotel on 9 June. Thanks were extended to Mr Bert Beinke (Patron) who stood the cost (c. £80) of materials until the members could raise funds to reimburse him. The club eventually ended the season in credit £17. Trophies were presented:

Best Batting Average Barry Eberhard

Best Bowling Average Roley Barnes

Best Fielding John Merkel

Most Catches Keith Treleaven

Best All-Rounder John Merkel

85, 25, 26 June 1962, page 1

An Amateur Hour organised by Mesdames S. Pearce & J. Carpenter was held on Friday night at the Kooringa Sunday School Hall and raised £60 towards the Annual Kooringa Methodist Fete. [Reported in c. 1 column.]

Adelaide Wool Sales. [Local district prices are reported.]

The PMG advises that an additional telephone circuit will be available between Burra and Gum Creek from 2 July.

ETSA calls tenders for the extension of electricity to more farms in the Burra-Hallett area.

Burra Red Cross. At a meeting on 12 June Mrs F.J. McWaters was presented with a long service medal for more than 20 years’ work.

Russell Tiver (19) who was among six finalists from 670 entrants has won a Flying Scholarship. He is the youngest son of Mr & Mrs M.H. Tiver of Abberton Park. The £300 scholarship enables Russell to qualify for a private licence. His brother Harold has been flying his own plane for a number of years.

Burra Rural Youth held its AGM 4 June and elected President, John Secomb; Vice-President, Rodger Humphrys; Secretary, Faye Tiver and Treasurer, Graham Kellock. [The club’s activities for the past year are reported in c. 3⁄4 column.]

85, 25, 26 June 1962, page 3

85, 25, 26 June 1962, page 7

Booborowie Oval’s new afternoon tea shed was used for the first time on Saturday.

Football. North Eastern Association

‘A’ Grade Hallett 11.7 defeated Spalding 10.7

‘B’ Grade Spalding 16.9 defeated Hallett 4.3

85, 25, 26 June 1962, page 8

Burra CWA held its AGM and Secretary Mrs F. Scroop reported a good year.

Membership was 80 and average attendance was 24.

In 1961 the new CWA rooms were opened and dedicated to a much loved pioneer of the CWA, Mrs Mary Warnes. They were opened 30 June by Mrs Dolling OBE and the memorial plaque was unveiled by Mr Rex Warnes, the eldest son of the late Mrs Warnes. The CWA again catered for the race luncheon in September. At the International Day Mr A.L. Clode presented on behalf of himself and family a very lovely polished table in memory of his late wife, who had been an active and good CWA worker. Also the rooms received their new toilet floor covering and a large green and yellow blind for the western window. Mrs Ralph Murray was the guest speaker. CWA also catered for the race meeting on 21 March. The branch catered for several weddings as well in the year. Thanks are also due to the Trustees of the late Mrs Warnes for donating the land on which the branch is built and to Mr Jackman for drawing up the plans.

85, 26 (2), 3 July 1962, page 1 [This number first used in 1955.]

A Trade Mission from the UAR [Egypt] visited Burra and inspected several stud sheep properties. They were impressed both by the sheep industry and the hospitality.

Adelaide Wool Sales. Photo of M.A. Radford, R.H. Toms (of Goldsbrough’s) & Mt David Radford at the sales.

[Check who was included in this scene.]

Burra Mine. L.W. Parkin, Director of Mines advises that a preliminary exploration at the Burra Mine has been made by officers of the Department of Mines. A full exploration will depend upon the geological appraisal, which is in progress and will occupy at least another six months.

Ian or Ivan McGrath [depending on which line you are reading] of Burra North, recently won a trophy as the most proficient cadet of HMAS Leeuwin’s junior naval cadets. Aged 16, he is the son of Mr & Mrs F.G. McGrath who made the trip to Perth for the passing out parade when 147 cadets graduated.

Golf. Burra Associates Open Day

‘A’ Grade Championship Mrs E.J. Jeffery (Burra)

‘B’ Grade Championship Mrs F. Reed (Burra)

‘C’ Grade Championship Mrs J. Oates (Burra)

‘A’ Grade 18 Hole Handicap Miss E. Tiver (Burra)

‘B’ Grade 18 Hole Handicap Mrs F. Reed (Burra)

‘C’ Grade 18 Hole Handicap Mrs J. Oates (Burra)

‘A’ Grade 9 Hole Handicap Mrs E.J. Jeffery (Burra)

‘B’ Grade 9 Hole Handicap Mrs K. O’Dea (Jamestown)

‘C’ Grade 9 Hole Handicap Mrs Rumbelow (Crystal Brook)

Veterans Mrs E.S. Chapman (Clare)

Teams’ Event Burra No. 1 (Mrs E.J. Jeffery, Mrs J. Minchin & Miss E. Tiver)

Burra Town Council took delivery of a new 2⁄3 ton Bedford tip truck on Friday.

Mt Bryan CWA held its AGM 20 June and elected President, Mrs D. Thomas; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames Crew & R. Dare; Secretary, Mrs Osterhage and Treasurer, Mrs Griffen. Tribute was paid to the work of Mr & Mrs F. Jefferies over the years.

85, 26 (2), 3 July 1962, page 8 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra High School. The Jubilee History continued by R.V. Mueller.

1935

Staff were Thomas Charlesworth Headmaster, Lyall Braddock, Doris Parry & Beryl Waterhouse. The enrolment was 49. On 29 May the Governor of SA Sir Winston Dugan & Lady Dugan paid a visit.

1936

The staff were T. Charlesworth Headmaster, L.A. Braddock, Miss C.R. Isom, Miss J. Jackson and Thomas Kissel (Junior Teacher). The enrolment was 55. On 3 September the school held a Centenary Banquet. [Celebrating the Centenary of SA.]

(To be continued.)

CWA. Held its annual meeting and elected: President, Mrs H. Riggs; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames H. Jennison & S. Scroop; Secretary, Mrs A. Ford; Assistant Secretary & Reporter, Mrs A. Benger and Treasurer, Miss E. Tiver.

85, 27 (2), 10 July 1962, page 1 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra Town Council. Election for East Ward.

H.R. Cornelius 50

Ian T. Allen 22

Revs T.G. Drought & Richard S. Jenner write calling on the Town Council to call a public meeting for the purpose of holding a Home and Family Week in Burra, as had been done elsewhere in SA. The idea would be to promote Education in Marriage, Parenthood and Family Relationships.

It would require

The availability of the Town Hall or other suitable premises.

The co-operation of the churches.

The recognition that much voluntary work would be involved.

The Governor & Lady Bastyan will visit Burra on 9 November.

A Burra-Adelaide Road Race is expected to be run by the Goodwood Cycling Club in August.

Burra Town Council has protested against the increase in its contribution to the Burra Hospital. It is not happy with having to charge ratepayers more to cover this increase.

The Education Department advised that construction of a new 32 ft x 24 ft Science Laboratory costing an estimated £5,500 will be commenced next month. Also that improvements to the playing area costing £1,200 should move smartly along. The school yard was resurfaced with bitumen last week.

85, 27 (2), 10 July 1962, page 3 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra Burra DC has appointed A.D. Radford as Chairman for 1962-63.

85, 27 (2), 10 July 1962, page 7 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra High School. The Jubilee History continued by R.V. Mueller.

1937

W.E. Richards was Headmaster with L.A. Braddock, C.R. Isom, H. Simonds and Albert Swanson (Junior Teacher). A Parents & Friends Association was established for the first time – 30 attended. School uniforms were introduced. There was a special assembly on 11 May to celebrate the Coronation of King George VI. Mr Davidson relieved for two months during Miss Isom’s illness. Burra hosted the Mid North Sports (which had to be postponed due to rain) and Burra won for only the second time. (The previous win had been in 1929.)

1938

W.E. Richards was Headmaster with Lloyd Draysey, Marjorie Koehne, Marjory Edington and Beresford Pitman. Enrolment was 68. On 1 October a wireless and amplifier were presented to the school when the Minister of Education Hon. S. Jefferies and the Director of Education W.J. Adey attended.

[The money for the purchase had come from a combination of Departmental, School Council and Seaside Committee funds.]

(To be continued.)

85, 27 (2), 10 July 1962, page 8 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra Town Council. Kooringa Tennis Club lease renewed.

85, 27 (2), 10 July 1962, page 9 [This number first used in 1955.]

Advt. Full Page advertisement of Bence’s Ltd Winter Clearance.

85, 27 (2), 10 July 1962, page 10 [This number first used in 1955.]

Basketball. North Eastern Association

‘A’ Grade Burra Grey 28 defeated Burra Blue 27

Booborowie 31 defeated Mt Bryan 100 [sic: perhaps 10?]

‘B’ Grade Burra Grey 18 defeated Booborowie 14

Hallett 20 defeated Burra Blue 18

85, 28 (2), 17 July 1962, page 1 [This number first used in 1955.]

North Eastern Hogget Competition. The final was held at Burra Showgrounds on Wednesday. There were ten finalists. The best were judged to be by S. & L.J. Wood from L.J. & H. Staker (Whyte Yarcowie).

In the single entry category the Champion Ewe Hogget was exhibited by L.J. & H. Staker. The first two place getters were sheep of Bungaree blood.

Burra High School. The Jubilee History continued by R.V. Mueller.

1939

The staff were W.E. Richards Headmaster, Marjorie E. Koehne, Lloyd Draysey, Clive Taylor and Hilda Simmonds. Enrolment was 65. The Premier Hon. T. Playford visited with W.T. Martin the Superintendent of Primary Schools and A.D. McDonald MP. The visitors were impressed by the buildings, but concerned about the rugged playgrounds, which had not improved much in 70 years. The Premier attended to open the Assembly Room.

Burra Bowling Club held its AGM and elected: Patron, Guy H. Dollman; President, D.T. Jacka; Vice-Presidents, J.B. Topsfield & C.L. Phillips and Assistant Secretary & Treasurer, B.A. Riggs.

Mrs Alice Rost’s Naturalization Ceremony is reported in 11⁄3 columns – most of the report comprises the speeches of the two MPs present: C.R. Kelly & Mr Quirke. The CWA ladies provided supper.

85, 28 (2), 17 July 1962, page 8 [This number first used in 1955.]

Obituary. Albert George Dixon of the SAR (Two Wells) died on duty aged 62. He was the third son of the late Mr & Mrs William Dixon of Hanson and brother to Gladys Mrs Fraser (Prospect), Jack (Hanson), Oliver (Melbourne) and Tom (deceased in WWI). Mr Dixon joined the SAR at Burra in 1916. He is survived by a wife, Lorna and children: Bob (Adelaide), Dorothy (Tasmania), Ruth (NSW) and Claire (Adelaide).

[Born 19 March 1900, Hanson: died 1 July 1962, Two Wells.]

85, 29 (2), 24 July 1962, page 1 [This number first used in 1955.]

The Governor will visit Burra on 9 November and will also be present at the Civic Ball to be held that night in the Town Hall.

Burra Town Council ended the financial year £39 in credit after closing the 1960-61 year £189 in debit.

M & BHA held its AGM recently in the Burra Town Hall. Dr Geoffrey de Crespigny was the guest speaker. Overall attendance this year was 441 for 11 visits or an average of 40 per month. Elected: President, Mrs Ray Jennison; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames B. Bevan & D. Holmes; Secretary, Mrs T. Thamm & Treasurer, Mrs D. Barry.

Burra High School. The Jubilee History continued by R.V .Mueller.

1940

The staff comprised W. Richards Headmaster, Lloyd Draysey, Marjorie Koehne, Hilda Simmonds and Junior Teachers John Womersley and Patricia Aughey. During the year Mr Richards was appointed Education Officer in charge of RAAF in SA with commissioned rank and Mr Draysey became acting headmaster.

1941

The school journals are missing for the period 1941-55.

Staff comprised Lloyd Draysey acting headmaster, Marjorie Koehne, Joyce Brooks, Linda Linke and Junior Teachers Max Allen and Bethel Smit. The enrolment was 63. Mr A.B. Riggs presented the school with a wall clock. School students raised £26 for the School’s Patriotic Fund.

(to be continued.)

85, 29 (2), 24 July 1962, page 2 [This number first used in 1955.]

Advt. Goldsbrough, Mort & Co. will auction on 3 August, for Mr Robert H. Garrard his solid 5-roomed stone dwelling with passage, cellar and 1,000 gallon tank on a block with frontage 247 ft to Penclawdd Street x 218 ft to Morriston Street Burra North comprising 3 roods 7 perches. Pt lot 43 of Pt section 2067.

Advt. Goldsbrough, Mort & Co. will auction for Messrs E.L. & L.M. Heinrich their 7-roomed double fronted stone dwelling with two kitchens, two bathrooms etc. Readily convertible into two flats. Large u.g. room with 12,000 gallon u.g. tank and 600 gallon o.h. tank and outbuildings etc. 90 ft frontage to Morehead Street and depth 330 ft on Anne and Grainger Streets. Allotments 62, 63, 64, 65 & 66 Burra North.

[Formerly Rabbich’s butcher shop and house.]

Notice. V.J. Dower wishes to advise he has disposed of his plumbing business and shop in Market Square to Mr C. Griffiths and thanks people of the town and district for their past patronage.

85, 29 (2), 24 July 1962, page 3 [This number first used in 1955.]

Obituary. Hedley Charles Jones died suddenly at Burra Hospital on Tuesday 24 July aged 44. He was the husband of Ellen Jones.

[Probably born 31 August 1917 Mannanarie, but someone of the same name was born 10 September 1917 at Exeter.]

85, 29 (2), 24 July 1962, page 6 [This number first used in 1955.]

Mt Bryan CWA held its AGM and a summary of the year’s activities is given in 1 column.

Burra Town Council, 16 July

The Mayor’s allowance was set at £100 for the year.

85, 29 (2), 24 July 1962, page 8 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra Burrs DC. The Chairman’s allowance was set at £150 for the year and Cr A.D. Radford was elected Chairman 1962-63.

85, 30 (2), 31 July 1962, page 1 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra Rural Youth Ball was held on Friday 20 July in the Town Hall. Six debutantes were presented to Mr C.R. Kelly MHR and Mrs Kelly:

Miss Raelene Hood with Mr Peter Henderson

Miss Elaine Phillips with Mr Dean Pearce

Miss Elaine White with Mr Roger Humphrys

Miss Raelene Nankivell with Mr Dean Billing

Miss Marie Nourse with Mr Peter Bryant

Miss Barbara Irlam with Mr David Stockman

[Photo of the debutantes and a photo of the official party.]

Burra & District Ambulance Association has increased benefits to members. Subscription £1 or 10/- for pensioners. The £1 covers a man, his wife and children to age 16, and gives free transport to the local hospital from anywhere in the district. The fee to Adelaide is £1 plus 2/- per mile. This is now reduced from 662⁄3% to 50% for members.

Weather. Soaking rain fell throughout the area for the whole week. Burra recorded 118 points. To the east light falls of up to 20 points were recorded.

St Joseph’s School Welfare Club benefited by c. £28 from a talk illustrated with coloured slides of Mr Eric Tilbrook’s round the world trip, shown in Burra Town Hall on Friday night.

Burra High School. A tender has been accepted for improvements to the sports area. Hirschausen Bros will lay two tennis courts and two half cricket pitches with chain mesh surrounds. Plans for Jubilee Celebrations are in hand. Arbor Day was held on Friday with speeches by Messrs E.T. Baulderstone & K. Hicks and trees were planted. The furniture for the new laboratory has arrived – all that is needed is the building.

85, 30 (2), 31 July 1962, page 2 [This number first used in 1955.]

Advt. Goldsbrough, Mort & Co. will conduct a sale on 17 August of 780 acres of freehold land in the RSL Hall Burra for Messrs S. & S.A. Pearce.

Lot 1. ‘Leighton’ Sections 399, 404, 446 Hd Ayers. Section 580 Hd Hanson, disposed as 5 paddocks totalling 489 acres 3 roods 30 perches. Includes a five-roomed stone house etc.

Lot 2. ‘Springbank’ Section 178 Hd Kooringa of 273 acres disposed as 3 paddocks with a four-roomed stone cottage, etc.

Lot 3. Allotment 115 Burra, frontage 215 ft 10 inches to Kingston St with stone house of four main rooms etc.

Lot 4. Allotment Pt 33 & Pt 114 Burra with frontage 142 ft 7 inches to Queen St with four bedroomed home etc.

Lot 5. Vacant land adjoining lot 4: Allotments Pt 34 & Pt 116 Burra with frontage 220 links to Queen Street.

Lot 6. Vacant land: allotments 9. 10, 117-120, 121, 124, 130 & 131 and a closed road, Burra comprising 6 acres 1 rood 30 perches, lying west of Chapel Street between Allen Street and South Terrace.

85, 30 (2), 31 July 1962, page 3 [This number first used in 1955.]

Notice. A pre-school Kindergarten will open Monday 6 August in the Kooringa Methodist Sunday School.

7/6 a week. 9 a.m. to noon Monday to Friday.

85, 30 (2), 31 July 1962, page 5 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra Bowling Club. President S.J. Woollacott’s report.

The year has been a social and financial success. There were 71 members last year and 69 this year. The Blue Team won the pennant in the North Eastern Association, but in the Mid North Association both teams finished near the bottom. The Easter Tournament was a great success.

[He continues after discussing the club games and tournaments.]

Three things now need our attention:

The present toilet facilities are an embarrassment and a completely new block is required.

The clubroom requires lining.

Some feel that external lighting is required.

The toilets would cost £400 to £500 and one Night Tournament would cover the £20 interest charge.

The death during the year of their oldest member Mr E. Finch was greatly regretted. He had been a foundation member and a past patron.

[The report concludes with thanks to committee members and a number of individuals.]

Winners of the Club Trophies:

Championship K. Williams

Handicap Singles K. Murphy

Championship Pairs H. Foote & M. Jacka

Consistency K. Williams

Night Pairs K. Horsnell & P. Pritchard

Mixed Pairs O. Holmes & Mrs K. Phillips

85, 30 (2), 31 July 1962, page 7 (numbered 5) [This number first used in 1955.]

Obituary. A minute’s silence at Burra CWA meeting reveals the death of Mrs A.L. Kellock.

[Born Adelaide May Riggs 19 April 1886 Mullaby Station: died May Adelaide Kellock 19 July 1962 Burra: the wife of Arthur Lillie Kellock.]

Burra High School. The Jubilee History continued by R.V. Mueller.

1942

The staff comprised Leonard J. Easson acting headmaster, Marjorie Koehne, Joyce Brooks and Alan Hickinbotham. The enrolment was 63. Air raid trenches were dug early in the year and exercises held.

[To be continued.]

85, 31 (2), 7 Aug. 1962, page 1 [This number first used in 1955.]

St Joseph’s Fete in the Burra RSL Hall on Friday drew a larger than usual crowd and took c. £170. Mrs E.T. Baulderstone opened the event. [Details in 3⁄4 column.]

Burra Swimming Club held a successful concert in the Town Hall on Friday and raised £42.

Booborowie Amateur Hour raised £178 for the new football pavilion.

Burra Small Bore Club needs more members in attendance. Only four attended on Saturday for the 25 yards shoot when A.G. Heinrich was the best shot.

St Johns-Aberdeen Football Club Ball was held recently.

There is a photo of the Mayor & Mayoress congratulating the winners of the Waltzing Competition, Mr & Mrs Ron Kelly of Burra North, with Mr R.G. Bernhardt, one of the judges.

Mr & Mrs F. Jefferies were farewelled at the Mt Bryan Memorial Hall recently when locals filled the place to capacity. Mr T. Quinn chaired the meeting. Mr & Mrs Jefferies had been strong supporters of the community for 40 to 50 years. Mrs Jefferies had been President of the Mt Bryan CWA and of the [Warnes] Group. Both Mr & Mrs Jefferies had supported the Hall. Mr Jefferies had been a member of the Agricultural Bureau for 40 years and had served two terms as President, four as Vice-President, 12 years as Secretary and 10 years as a committeeman. A presentation of an envelope containing notes and silver was made. There were several items, including Rev. Bell playing the bones to the accompaniment of the piano. Dancing and supper completed the evening.

Ironmine Methodist Sunday School celebrated the 39th anniversary of the Sunday School Memorial Hall on 21 July.

Burra Primary School held its Arbor Day on 27 July. Seven trees were planted after speeches by the Headmaster and Mr Stockman, Chairman of the School Committee.

85, 31 (2), 7 Aug. 1962, page 2 [This number first used in 1955.]

Advt. Goldsbrough, Mort & Co. will auction household furniture, crockery etc. for Mr R.A. Bevan, who has sold his business.

85, 31 (2), 7 Aug. 1962, page 6 [This number first used in 1955.]

Rev. A. Bell conducted a farewell service for Mr & Mrs F. Jefferies on Sunday at Mt Bryan Methodist Church.

Advt. Burra Pictures, 8 August

Dirk Bogarde & John Mills in Singer Not the Song

William Lucas & Andrew Faulds in The Professionals

11 August

Kirk Douglas & Kim Novak in Strangers When We Meet

Charles Coburn & Nigel Patrick in How to Murder a Rich Uncle

15 August

Rod Taylor & Alan Young in The Time Machine

Johnny Weissmuller & Maureen O’Sullivan in Tarzan’s New York Adventure

85, 32 (2), 14 Aug. 1962, page 1 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra Burra DC Weed Control Program is getting under way. The main aspects of the program following the appointment of Mr Ian Fry of P.G. Rehn & Associates as Weeds Officer are:

Control of roadside weeds

Control of weeds on Council property and on Crown Lands

Control of weeds on private property

Mr Fry is concerned to remove reservoirs of seed wherever they lie. The first step is a circular that has been sent out to ratepayers asking them to list weeds on their property and what steps are normally taken to control them. Mr Fry has begun a survey of the district.

Table Tennis. Semi-Final

On Tuesday at Spalding: Burra Blue defeated Spalding Blue by one game.

Burra Small Bore Club. D. Field topped the 75 yards competition.

Weather. The recent storm that caused widespread damage across SA disrupted telephone service between Burra and Booborowie. Gust up to 60 m.p.h. swept a 600 yard wide strip of forest in the Leighton area. Large gums were hurled across the telephone lines.

Mr & Mrs R. Jennison will leave for Sydney on 25 August to take a trip to Fiji, which was the prize won by Jennison’s Tyre Service as part of a Car Sales Competition run over 10 weeks by the Ford Motor Co. of Australia Ltd.

85, 32 (2), 14 Aug. 1962, page 2 [This number first used in 1955.]

Obituary. A Return Thanks Notice reveals the death of the husband of Mrs Leaney and father of Eric and Beryl.

[Gilbert Edwin Leaney, born 12 October 1884 near Waterloo: died 12 July 1962 Burra, residence Burra North.]

Carry on Regardless

Notice. R.A. Bevan & Son thank all for their patronage over 16 years in business and hope it will continue with their successors Messrs D. Sleader & K. Flaherty, late of the Burra Hotel.

85, 32 (2), 14 Aug. 1962, page 3 [This number first used in 1955.]

Basketball. North Eastern

‘A’ Grade Booborowie defeated Spalding by 9 goals

Mt Bryan 15 defeated Burra Blue 14

Hallett 30 defeated Burra Grey 25

Terowie 35 defeated Burra Blue 8 Check to see if grade is stated for these last three teams.

An Aborigine who escaped recently from a Mental Institution was sighted at about 5.30 p.m. yesterday at Mt Bryan East. He is understood to be making for Pt Pirie.

The RAA endorses the opinion that stop-lights and flashing turning lights should be legal [in place of hand signals.] Victoria is revising its traffic code to do away with the ‘stop’ hand signal. SA law has provided for the use of turn light and brake light signals for some years.

85, 32 (2), 14 Aug.1962, page 4 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra Town Council, 6 August

A general rate of 46d in the pound and a special rate of 4d in the pound were adopted.

The Royal Agricultural & Horticultural Society of SA wrote to the Council. It was resolved that a letter be sent to them saying Council had made arrangements for the removal of the jinker.

Mr R.M. Reed is to be informed that Anne Street has not been sold and Council can see no inconvenience caused by the fences mentioned in his letter and he will be asked to state any complaint he may have.

It was resolved to hold a Civic Ball on 9 November in honour of the Governor’s visit.

The SA Tourist Bureau is to be advised that Council is proceeding with the first section of its original plan for a Caravan Park at a cost of £1,500 and it will be asked what subsidy would be available on that amount in this financial year.

The Highways & Local Government Department is to be asked for a grant to complete the traffic islands in Market Square.

Tothill’s Creek residents plan a ‘Back to School’ celebration on either 27 October or 3 November.

85, 32 (2), 14 Aug. 1962, page 6 [This number first used in 1955.]

Mr Wood of Whyte Yarcowie has his photo printed following his recent success in the Hogget Competition.

85, 32 (2), 14 Aug. 1962, page 7 [This number first used in 1955.]

The Education Department through Baden Pattinson (Minister for Education) explains the delays in purchasing land for Robertstown School.

85, 32 (2), 14 Aug. 1962, page 8 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra High School. The Jubilee History continued by R.V. Mueller.

1945

The staff comprised H.O. Pederick Headmaster, G.W. Owen, M.C. Spark, E. Maddern & K. Parkinson (Junior Teacher). The enrolment was 47. During the year K. Butler replaced M.C. Spark and G.W. Owen, who were transferred. In April plans were prepared for building a new residence for the High School Headmaster.

1946

The staff were Hubert O. Pederick Acting Headmaster, Ivor Burdon, Kath Butler, Joan Tapley & Colin Laubsch (Junior Teacher). Enrolment was 72 – an increase due to a new Hallett bus run. The Parents & Friends Association held its first Annual Ball in the Town Hall to raise funds for the school. Profits were £15. Dr Steele, who was the first President of the High School Council and who had held office for 26 years, left the district. One of the school houses was called ‘Steele House’. The other was named Draysey House in honour of a previous Acting Headmaster who gave his life during air operations in WWII.

85, 32 (2), 14 Aug. 1962, page 9 [This number first used in 1955.]

Advt. Full page SAGASCO Advertisement. Burra Motor Co. local agents for SAGASCO bottled gas.

Burra Golf Club held its Open Day, which drew 111 entries and 97 of them took part on the day despite cold, blustery conditions. Winners:

36 Hole ‘A’ Grade Championship Don Bachli (Former British Amateur Open Champion)
