Burra ‘A’ 24 defeated Riverton ‘E’ 20

Riverton 27 defeated Burra 8

Riverton ‘C’ 30 defeated Burra ‘B’ 17

Riverton ‘D’ 51 defeated Burra ‘D’ 1

Burra Small Bore Club scheduled a 25 yards shoot that was cancelled due to wet weather. Two members completed the shoot and Ross Gilbert did very well to score 98 & 97.

Burra Hospital. 85th Annual Report and AGM.

Chairman of the Board of Management R.K. Pearse reported finances in a sound condition with the overdraft reduced. The daily average number of patients fell from 11.9 in 1960-61 to 10.1 in 1961-62. Outpatient numbers fell to 430 and births to 63. Mr Pearse said he would like to see plans for building new private rooms in the near future. Brochures of the balance sheet had been printed and were available from the Secretary-Manager.

Lobethal Harmony Choir gave a performance at the Mt Bryan Hall during a visit on 11 & 12 August. Mt Bryan Methodist Ladies’ Guild hosted the visit and the choir also sang at the Sunday afternoon service.

85, 33 (2), 21 Aug. 1962, page 2 [This number first used in 1955.]

Advt. Burra Pictures, 25 August

Sidney James & Kenneth Connor in Carry On Regardless

John Cairney & Harry H. Corbett in Marriage of Convenience

85, 33 (2), 21 Aug. 1962, page 3 [This number first used in 1955.]

The Old Jinker is back. The old jinker, made in Burra by William Cullen for the Burra Mine and used to haul the first boiler to the Mine, has now been returned. It was transported from Adelaide by rail and was towed to the Mine area yesterday by Burra Town Council employees.

85, 33 (2), 21 Aug. 1962, page 4 [This number first used in 1955.]

The Mid Northern Methodist Synod held at Burra North Methodist Church from 31 July is reported in c. 13⁄4 columns.

The Hanson Trust has offered to make available their two properties for use as a District Youth Centre. It is estimated an expenditure of about £2,000 over several years would be needed to convert it to a camp of this nature – including a toilet block.

‘Members expressed their view that both the Crystal Brook town camp and the Hanson camp would be complimentary [sic] to each other.’

85, 33 (2), 21 Aug. 1962, page 5 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra High School. The Jubilee History continued by R.V. Mueller.

1947

The staff were H. Pederick Headmaster, Ivor Burdon, Keith Morley, Alma Hill, Gladys Kay, Margaret Burge and Graham Nerlick (Junior Teacher). The enrolment was 71.

The Parents & Friends Association assisted financially in purchasing a Gestetner duplicating machine.

1948

The staff comprised H. Pederick Headmaster, Ivor Burdon, John Deer, Alma Hill, Ronald Walker, Gladys Kay and Margaret Burge. A deceased Burra resident bequeathed the school £100.

85, 34 (2), 28 Aug. 1962, page 1 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra High School Jubilee Celebrations

Many old scholars will be returning for the planned events. Celebrations begin at 12.55 p.m. on Thursday with a Back to School event. Guides for old scholars will be H.J.B. Jennison, T. Perry, D. Field, M. Stockman, Mesdames M. Kellock, A. Benger & C. Neill. A back to school class will be conducted by former headmaster Mr L. Carthew. The Mayor will welcome visitors at the new tennis courts and Mr A.K. Statton, Superintendent of High Schools will address the assembly and unveil a plaque to open the area for future use. Visits will be made to various areas of the school. Speakers at the Birthday Celebrations will include Mr J.P. Biddle (Headmaster 1916-22), A.B. Riggs (Past President of the High School Council), K. Horsnell (Headmaster of the Primary School) and Mr J.W. Statton (First Headmaster). Old scholars will present a concert in the evening at which speakers will include Dr D.M. Steele, H.J.B. Jennison and Brian Riggs (deputising for his father). On Friday sporting contests between old and present scholars have been arranged. The Golden Jubilee Ball will be held in the evening.

[Photo of Chairman of the Jubilee Committee Mr H.J.B. Jennison is printed.]

Miss Marie Nourse of Burra was selected as Best Debutante for 1962 at Jamestown’s Annual Hibernian Ball on Tuesday night. She was partnered by Mr Peter Bryant of Clare.

Obituary. Mr James Lomman, formerly of Booborowie, died in his sleep on Monday 20 August at his old home ‘Whitefield’, now occupied by his son, George.

[Frederick James Lomman, born 15 May 1892 Kooringa: died 21 August 1962 Mt Bryan East, residence Booborowie.]

The Burra-Mt Bryan Road will be prepared for sealing this spring and it is expected the bitumen should be in place by Christmas.

Mid North High Schools (Balaklava, Clare, Riverton & Burra) held a lightning sports carnival.

85, 34 (2), 28 Aug. 1962, page 2 [This number first used in 1955.]

Advt. Bennett & Fisher Ltd offer for sale by tender, on instructions from R.G. Mayfield:

Lot 1. Section 844 Hd Ayers of 2561⁄2 acres with house of five large rooms etc.

Lot 2. Section 835 Hd Ayers of 365 acres disposed as eight paddocks.

Advt. Elder, Smith & Co. on instructions from Dr David Steele Sen. and Trustees of the ‘Koo-owie Trust, will auction ‘Koo-owie’ of 2,169 acres freehold, 121⁄2 miles south of Burra, on 5 October at Burra RSL Hall. Disposed as 34 paddocks with a substantial nine-roomed stone house etc.

85, 34 (2), 28 Aug. 1962, page 3 [This number first used in 1955.]

Obituary. Edmund Theodore Rooke died 27 August suddenly at his residence [Kooringa] aged 61. He was the husband of Jessie May Rooke. [Born 7 October 1900 Baldina.]

85, 34 (2), 28 Aug. 1962, page 4 [This number first used in 1955.]

Obituary. Well known Farrell Flat grazier Mr Douglas McCloud Short died at Burra 23 July. He was born at Deniliquin NSW in 1890 and came to SA with his parents as a young boy and attended Morphett Vale School. His father has taken up farming at Penfield and later on property now the Parafield Aerodrome. As a young man he carted hay by horse wagon to chaff mills at Enfield and Port Adelaide. He was a keen footballer; winning medals at Salisbury. In 1915 he married Dulcie Neal of Salisbury and in the 1920s they came to Farrell Flat where he was a farmer and later a sheep dealer. He is survived by his wife, two sons and three daughters: Jack & Ken (Farrell Flat), Melva Mrs Berryman (Adelaide), Nancy Mrs L. Simpson (Farrell Flat) and Joan Mrs K. Cooper (Farrell Flat).

85, 34 (2), 28 Aug. 1962, page 5 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra Jubilee Benevolent Society held its AGM. Though there had been only one meeting for the year, the society has not been inactive. We secured a wheelchair and now have two located in the Burra Hospital and available to anyone in the district who may need them (free). Several families in need have been helped with wood and groceries. Some clothes and shoes have also been distributed. Former officers were re-elected: President, Rev. T. Drought; Secretary, Mrs H. Jennison and Treasurer, Mrs F. Atkin.

85, 34 (2), 28 Aug. 1962, page 6 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra High School. The Jubilee History continued by R.V. Mueller.

1949

The staff was as for 1948 except that Rae T. Blesing replaced Alma Hill. The enrolment was 66.

The Minister for Education Mr R. Rudall and the Director of Education Mr E. Mander-Jones visited the school and discussed the schoolyard, the building of new laboratories, painting of the school and the erection of new classrooms, but the Minister did not promise much. On 29 April the students visited Adelaide by train (three of them for the first time). Two new classrooms were opened by Mr [illegible] Walker, Inspector of Technical Schools.

1950

The staff were H.O. Pederick Headmaster, Ivor Burdon, John G. Deer, Rae F. Blesing, Ronald E. Walker and Nancy Hannaford. Enrolments were 62. Painters moved in to repaint the school in May. New septic tank lavatories were installed. A polio epidemic discouraged any indoor functions. The Parents & Friends Assoc. presented an Encyclopaedia Britannica worth £93.

1951

The staff was the same as for 1950 except that Margaret Miller replaced Nancy Hannaford. Enrolment was 65. Two houses were bought for staff members by the Education Department. Buses were complained about – one was very cold in winter and hot and dusty in summer. The other was so small it had to make two journeys morning and night.

1952

Staff were H.O. Pederick Headmaster, Ivor Burdon, John Deer, Clare Milazzo, Ronald Walker and Helen Inglis. Enrolment was 66. The underground tank became polluted with dead rats and pigeon manure. ‘It is believed that when the tanks were emptied recently six dead rats were removed and approximately 61 buckets of pigeon manure.’

Trees were planted in honour of old scholars who had made the supreme sacrifice. Mr S. Woollacott presented the honour roll.

85, 34 (2), 28 Aug. 1962, page 8 [This number first used in 1955.]

Infestation of Pasture Loopers need not worry most farmers. They had a predilection for capeweed and only in very high numbers did they bother lucerne etc. (The treatment where necessary was 32 fl oz of 25 pm DDT per acre.)

85, 35 (2), 4 Sep. 1962, page 1 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra High School. Jubilee Celebrations

On Thursday there was an inspection of present classes at work, a ‘back to school’ class and the opening of the new sports area, followed by a concert at night in the Town Hall.

The Headmaster Mr R. Mueller greeted visitors and organised them into seven groups to visit the school. [Guides as per list last week.] The back-yo-school class assembled at the rear of the school and marched with the aid of drummer Norrie Baynes to the tennis courts where the teacher was Mr L. Carthew. [The ‘pupils are listed.]

Five of those attending were from the 1913 class. Others attending were Mr Joe Statton (the first headmaster), Mr Biddle, Mr Haese and Mr Murray Scriven; all former headmasters. Mr L.W. Gare, one of the 1913 class, moved a vote of thanks. From here there was a move to the new sports area and despite a bleak day with gusty winds and a shower or two, the crowd persisted. [Official guests are listed.] The Mayor Mr Baulderstone welcomed visitors and Mr Mueller also welcomed them to the school. He particularly welcomed Mr Statton (Superintendent of High Schools). Mr Jennison, in his speech as Chairman of the High School Council, said 100 old scholars had enlisted in WWII and eleven had died in that conflict. The Parents & Friends, Association had raised £1,434-10-0 in the last five years, and today’s project, though not yet completed, would cost £1,200, split equally between the Parents & Friends’ Association and the Department. It was only a week or two ago that the signal to proceed had come through and much was due to the efforts of Messrs Hirschausen Bros and D.A. Halliday that so much of it had already been accomplished. Mr A.K. Statton then opened the new sports area.

Football

Keith Warrior of Hallett won the Burra Record Trophy for football in 1962. Keith was the runner-up in the 1962 Mail Medal for the North Eastern League.

In the Mid North League Kevin Lane of Aberdeen was runner-up for the Mail Medal, which went to D. Maynard of Clare South.

Burra & District Amateur Swimming Club elected at its AGM: Patron, G. Stanley Hawker; President, E. Orchard; Vice-President, H.J. Topsfield; Secretary, D. Clarkson and Treasurer, S. Britton.

The balance sheet showed a credit of £242-5-2.

Koomooloo Station Ewes. A photograph at the Burra Market 24 august is printed.

R.H. (Dick) Smith who managed Elder, Smith & Co. at Burra from 1938-49 has been appointed consultant on farming and station properties to Elder’s Trustee & Executor Co. Ltd. He retired from Elder, Smith & Co. in 1960.

Elder, Smith & Co.’s Ewe Lamb Sale is reported.

Mr & Mrs Roy W. Humphrys celebrate their Golden Wedding today 11 September.

Mt Bryan Agricultural Bureau marked 30 years of service by P. Griffen and 40 years of service by F. Jefferies by presenting each with badges for meritorious service and extending Life Membership to both.

Burra Town Council will experiment with weed destruction by spraying water tables to compare costs with contractors.

85, 36 (2), 11 Sep. 1962, pages 1 & 4 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra High school Jubilee Celebrations

During the party Mr Jennison hoped Mrs Draysey would enjoy her brief return to Burra and a variety of other people spoke. Former Headmaster Mr Biddle said that 46 years ago there had been one teacher and one room, making it difficult to keep all classes going smoothly. Transport difficulties made it hard to increase roll numbers, though a few like Cliff Flower and Fred Schultz came in on horseback. Others who spoke included Barbara Hogan (Head Prefect), Hedley Pearce, Murray Scriven and Mr A. Bartholomaeus, who was number 1on the High School roll. Mrs M. Kellock moved a vote of thanks on behalf of the Parents & Friends Association. The Burra Town Hall was filled to capacity on Thursday night for the concert [for which items are listed.]

On Friday morning there was a basketball match in which Old Scholars 18 defeated Present Scholars 17. [Best players are cited.] In the afternoon the football game resulted in a victory for Old Scholars 11.14 to Present Scholars 7.6. [Teams are listed.]

On Friday night the Town Hall was again filled to capacity for the annual ball. Door takings exceeded £160.

Two Photographs are printed.

Past Headmasters: J.P. Biddle (1916-22), E.A. Haese (1926-34), J.W. Statton (1913-15) and L. Carthew (1923-35)

Members from the first class in 1913: L.W. Gare, Mrs H.J.B. Jennison (nee Reta Thomas), Mrs W. Young (nee Amy Morrison), A.R. Bartholomaeus and F.H. Reed.

85, 36 (2), 11 Sep. 1962, page 2 [This number first used in 1955.]

Adelaide Wool Sales. The best district price was 70d for W. Ashby & Sons Ltd ‘Ashrose’, Hallett.

[Other local district prices are listed on page 5.]

85, 37 (2), 18 Sep. 1962, page 4 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra & District Amateur Swimming Club held its AGM.

Mr E. Orchard said the club was formed in lieu of the Burra & District Swimming Pool Committee at the start of the 1960-61 season and affiliated with the SA Amateur Swimming Association for the 1961-62 season. The last season was the club’s first serious season of competitive swimming and it was very satisfying to run out winners of the Eric Tilbrook shield in the triangular competition with Clare and Spalding. This led to the formation recently of the Mid North Amateur Swimming Association of which Burra, Clare and Spalding are the foundation members. In the past year a lease was obtained from the Burra Town Council and includes 60 ft beyond the present northern boundary to allow room for a barbecue and other entertainment facilities. Over £200 was spent for cabinets for the PA system, stop watches and a filing cabinet. In addition to inter-club competition, the two main functions are the Learn to Swim Campaign in the school holidays and the annual open carnival. Recently the ladies have formed an auxiliary and so far they have added over £40 to funds. Funds are needed to install a filtration and chlorination plant at an estimated cost of about £4,500 – fortunately subsidised pound for pound by the SA Government Tourist Bureau.

Fortunately we have a plentiful supply of cheap clear water, which needs to be changed more frequently in the hot weather, but this will push up costs as we exceed our water allowance and the filtration plant is needed, especially if Burra’s water supply should change to Murray water. Thanks are due to Mr Bill Broad as caretaker, following the resignation of Dave Tanswell. Mr Allan Ireland has had to resign as Secretary on being transferred to Jamestown.

[The balance sheet is printed.]

85, 37 (2), 18 Sep. 1962, page 6 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra Small Bore Club. Double 75 yards shoot. W. Hempel was best on handicap, with Ross Gilbert best off the rifle.

Football. North Eastern Association Finals

‘A’ Grade Booborowie 13.16 defeated Hallett 6.11

‘B’ Grade Spalding 9.15 defeated Booborowie 6.6

Colts Spalding 6.12 defeated Hallett 3.5

Game to be replayed

Colts Robertstown defeated Riverton

85, 38 (2), 25 Sep. 1962, page 1 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra High School. Photo of Mr H.J.B. Jennison and the official party at the opening of the Burra High School Jubilee Sports Area.

Burra Show on 6 October will be greatly indebted to the work of voluntary helpers. The ring grass will be mown and the grass elsewhere cut where necessary. Pavilions are in order. Mr Fuss has the cleaning and organisation well in hand and Mr & Mrs Scroop have fitted curtains to the tables, making a pleasing setting. Burra Rural Youth has repainted the kitchen and copper room and installed a cement floor in the casualty room.

Max Rayner of Messrs L.B. Rayner & Son of ‘The Bluff’ Hallett is pictured with the Collinsville Merino stud ram he purchased for a new world record price of 12,500 guineas at the Annual Ram Sales. The ram aged 2 years and 4 months was born and reared by Messrs John Collins & Sons of Collinsville Mt Bryan.

The British & Foreign Bible Society Deputation Mr Williams addressed the annual meeting of the society at the Kooringa Methodist Church Hall on Sunday night and showed a film on the society’s work in the Congo. Mr H. Jennison resigned as President after having been either Secretary or President for over 30 years. Elected were: President, Rev. T.G. Drought and Secretary, B. Thamm.

Burra Burra DC will use a grant of £650 to spray horehound on the stock route between Burra and Robertstown soon. Boxthorn will be attacked as well and it is hoped to get as far as Redbanks with the bulldozer this year.

Burra Mine. In answer to a question from Mr Quirke MP, Sir Thomas Playford said that because mineral rights had been alienated from the Crown in the area it was impossible to get organisations with sufficient capital to take on exploration due to uncertainty of tenure. Amendments currently before the House of Assembly should facilitate investigations at Burra and similar places in some of the older mining areas of SA.

85, 38 (2), 25 Sep. 1962, page 3 [This number first used in 1955.]

Advt. Burra Pictures, 29 September

Albert Finney & Shirley Anne Field in Saturday Night and Sunday Morning

Donald Sinden & Peggy Cummins in Your Money or Your Wife

3 October

Victor Mature & Yvonne de Carlo in Timbuktu

Marie Windsor & Vince Edwards in Island Women

85, 38 (2), 25 Sep. 1962, page 5 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra Town Council

Council is to inspect the section of Thames St required by H. Quissner [sic: Queissner?]

In reply to Mr R.M. Reed the Clerk will write to Mr Reed saying they consider Mr Jeffery has acted in good faith on the word of the previous Town Clerk and they consider that Mr Reed has access to the back of his property by way of Jessie Street and they would require further explanation from him of why Anne Street needs to be open.

The estate of E.T. Rooke was given permission to demolish an old house.

The Clerk will write to the Highways and Local Government Department giving the Council’s views that, with the advent of Grain Silos at Burra, it would be better for the [Bon Accord] bridge to be reconstructed, rather than open Young Street as the main road.

The Clerk will write to the Attorney General about the old portion of the cemetery, asking how old graves must be and what procedure must be followed when reclaiming.

M.E. & E.M. Mitchell will be permitted to open a new pit in the Council’s Mine area and pay 1/- per yard royalty on all rubble excavated.

85, 38 (2), 25 Sep. 1962, page 6 [This number first used in 1955.]

‘A’ Grade Clare North 10.12 defeated Riverton 6.11.

‘A’ Grade M. Brooks 21 from K. Warrior 20.

‘B’ Grade R. Stalhut of Spalding

Burra Small Bore Club fired a double 25 yards shoot, which was won by R. Gilbert.

85, 38 (2), 25 Sep. 1962, page 8 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra High School. The Jubilee History continued by R.V. Mueller.

1953

Staff were H.O. Pederick Headmaster, Ivor Burdon, John Deer, Joan Hallewell, Ronald Walker and Helen Inglis. Enrolment was 64. On 5 May a new bus arrived to convey students from Hallett and intermediate areas. A lengthy article in the Record called for better co-operation between the Primary and High Schools in organising similar functions and generally for more congenial relations.

1954

Staff: Roy G. Jeffery was Headmaster with Ivor Burdon, John G. Deer, Richard Pillar, Gwendoline Jeffery and Helen Inglis. SA Governor Sir Robert & Lady George visited during the year.

1955

The staff was unchanged except that Mrs H. Kowald replaced Miss Miller [who is not mentioned as being there in 1954.] The enrolment was 70. On 29 August there was a trip to Adelaide with visits to Motteram’s Biscuit Factory, British Tube Mills, Port Adelaide, Outer Harbour and GMH.

(To be continued.)

85, 39 (3), 2 Oct. 1962, page 1 [This number first used in 1955.]

Sagasco’s Cooking Demonstration at the Burra RSL Hall on Friday drew a large crowd. There was also a fine display of gas stoves, coppers and fridges etc.

Burra Basketball & Football Clubs held a concert at the Burra Town Hall on 21September and drew a capacity crowd. Door takings were a little over £75.

Adelaide Wool Sales. Photo of Bill & Eric Ashby of Hallett with Goldsbrough’s Wool Supervisor, Mr Doug Richmond.

85, 39 (3), 2 Oct. 1962, page 2 [This number first used in 1955.]

Advt. Burra Cold Stores announce that from 23 October they will be delivering Golden North Tetra Pack Pasteurised Milk to all parts of Burra.

Notice. Burra Town Council

A supplementary election is called for West Ward following the resignation of Cr. E.J. Lehmann.

Nominations are called by 12 October with poll on 2 November if required.

Hallett & District Schools’ Athletic Association’s Annual Sports Meeting was held at the Hallett Oval on Friday in rather cold and blustery conditions. Six schools competed: Hallett, Terowie, Whyte Yarcowie, Mt Bryan, Canowie Belt and Willalo. Hallett scored best in aggregate. [Results are printed.]

85, 39 (3), 2 Oct. 1962, page 5 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra High School. The Jubilee History continued by R.V. Mueller.

1956

The staff was as in 1955 and the enrolment was 70. The leaving Geography class visited Port Pirie and the South Flinders Ranges and a visit to Adelaide included the Abattoirs, West Beach Aerodrome and Mt Bold Reservoir.

1957

Staff: R. Jeffery was Headmaster with J.C. Morrison, G. Ireland, T. Bawden, G. Jeffery and R. Kowald. The enrolment was 79. In April the school went to Adelaide for the SA Exhibition.

1958

The staff was the same as in 1957 and the enrolment was 90. On the 5 March students went to Adelaide to see the Queen Mother. Two new rooms were added to the school.

(To be continued.)

Burra Football Club held a banquet in the RSL Hall attended to by about 50 people. Mr Tony Fillmore welcomed everyone and expressed his thanks to Mr Ron Dewhirst for re-forming the Colts in the North Eastern League. He went on to thank parents and trophy donors and those supplying transport. Trophies:

Fairest & Best Darrell Field

Most Consistent Andrew Phillips

Best Forward Graham Benger

Best Backman Leon Hawke

Most Effective Brian Kakoschke

Best Attendance at Practice Raymond Swinson

‘A scratch match between members of the Burra Colts played at the Memorial Oval on Saturday afternoon resulted in a draw, owing to poor umpiring and one member changing sides every time the opposition gained the lead.’

J. Carpenter Hon. Secretary writes re TPI Badge Day.

Cricket. Mokota Association

At a recent meeting Mr C. Furst was again elected President with Mr Ken Deer as Association Secretary.

At a meeting of the Burra Cricket Club and the Koonoona Cricket Club on 29 September it was decided to merge the two clubs and enter the Mokota Association. The team is to be known as Koonaburra. President is Mr Ron Pearse and Secretary Mr A. Fillmore. The Mokota Association this year comprises Spalding, Booborowie, Hallett, Mt Bryan, North Booborowie, Burra Footballers, Koonaburra and Leighton.

85, 40 (2), 9 Oct. 1962, page 1 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra Town Council, 1 October

Council decided to enforce its by-laws regarding dogs to reduce the stray dog problem.

A letter is to be sent to Mr G. Nourse about the straying of his Alsatian dog.

Adelaide Wool Sales. The top local price was 73d received by S.T. Miller & Sons of Gum Creek.

[Other local district prices are printed.]

85, 40 (2), 9 Oct. 1962, pages 1, 3 & 5 [This number first used in 1955.]

The Burra Show was held last Saturday when rain, hail and wind lowered the attendance, but entries were a record at 2,500. Brigadier J.G. McKinna, the SA Commissioner of Police, was unable to open the show as had been planned, due to a foot injury. The task fell to Mr Brian Riggs, President of the Northern Agricultural Show Societies’ Association. Gate takings were down between £80 and £100, at £141. Considering the weather the patronage was pleasing. Voluntary workers had greatly improved facilities and the lining and painting of the President’s Room, Secretary’s Office and the Flower Pavilion are noted. The list of prize winners is continued on pages 3 and 5.

85, 40 (2), 9 Oct. 1962, page 4 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra Small Bore Club. A double 25 yards contest was won by Ron Kellock.

85, 40 (2), 9 Oct. 1962, page 8 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra Town Council, 1 October

Amendment to Model By-Law XIII was adopted: see Government Gazette 3 September 1962 page 655.

Cr E.J. Lehmann’s resignation was accepted.

A portion of Thames Street 46 ft x 11 ft was let to H. Quissner [sic] for 1/- per annum.

Approval was given for the purchase of a set of steps for the Town Hall stage and carpet for the front portion of the stage.

ETSA is to be applied to for an all-night light adjacent to the hospital.

85, 41 (2), 16 Oct. 1962, page 1 [This number first used in 1955.]

Bowls. Mr H. Binks-Williams opened the Burra Bowling Club’s 1962-63 season. The rinks were well grassed, but the heavy rain on Friday had prevented a final cut and rolling, resulting in a slow, but true green. 56 players enjoyed a game.

The Burra Show Dance was organised by Burra Rural Youth and door takings amounted to £45.

The Market Square Traffic Island was completed in the past week. The area inside the island’s concrete rim will be ripped up and filled with loam for planting lawn and low shrubs. There will be a parking area made in front of the RSL Building.

St John Ambulance Brigade gave a First Aid Demonstration in Burra Town Hall on Thursday night before about 60 people. The Mayor welcomed the unit and the audience. He also made an appeal for more cadets and senior members. Mouth to mouth artificial respiration was demonstrated on a manikin.

Koo-owie (2,169 acres) situated 12 miles south of Burra was sold on Friday 5 October for Dr Steele and the Trustees of the Koo-owie Trust. It was passed in at £24 per acre, but later sold for an undisclosed sum to the highest bidder, Barton Hill Proprietors.

A Fancy Dress Frolic for Booborowie Basketball Club on 5 October is reported.

Burra War Memorial Committee had to postpone its AGM on 24 September for want of a quorum. Another attempt will be made on 22 October and without more interest being shown this project could ‘go under’. In the past year the oval has been sown to grass and good coverage achieved for a large area. The Football Club has installed lights for night play. The courts have been resurfaced and wire mesh surrounds installed and a shelter shed erected. The division was has been removed.

Burra Women’s LCL met for the first time this year on 6 October. The death of former Vice-President and supporter Mrs A.L. Kellock was noted. Mr Jim Riggs was elected Vice-President. An open meeting at Burra Town Hall on 29 October will be addressed by Mrs Anne Neill who has operated as an undercover agent in the Australian Communist Party.

Mr Bill Voumard of Burra will be 87 on 19 October. He still rides his bike about the town.

85, 41 (2), 16 Oct. 1962, page 3 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra Town Council. Supplementary Election for West Ward. Nominations:

Colin Harry Cummins

Herbert Gerald Wardle

An election will be held on 3 November with polling in the Council Chamber at the Burra Town Hall.

85, 41 (2), 16 Oct. 1962, page 4 [This number first used in 1955.]

Booborowie Football Club held a barbecue lunch on Saturday 14 October. It was reported at it that due to staunch supporters and hard-working ladies, it had a new afternoon tea shed almost paid for and the dressing shed and showers had been greatly improved. There is also an excellent scoreboard. A presentation was made to Secretary Ray Gasmier who is leaving Booborowie to take over the bank at Kimba.

85, 41 (2), 16 Oct. 1962, page 5 [This number first used in 1955.]

Cricket. Mokota Association

Koonaburra 90 v. Leighton 3 for 12

North Booborowie 34 v. Burra Footballers 3 for 111

Mt Bryan 8 for 244 v. Hallett

85, 42 (2), 23 Oct. 1962, page 1 [This number first used in 1955.]

Mt Bryan Methodist Church held its Anniversary last Sunday. The preacher was Rev. V. Goldney who returned to the area after 38 years. Miss C. Reed was organist and the combined Burra-Redruth Choir was in attendance. David Clarkson was soloist.

ETSA has almost completed erecting new power lines to Mt Bryan East and power should be available by the end of November.

Weather. On Friday good general rains delivered an inch or more and a few more points fell on Saturday and Monday. Weekend falls at Burra totalled 96 points, Mt Bryan 144, Booborowie 126 and Hanson 124.

Mr H.W. (Bill) Symonds last week took over as Manager of the Bank of Adelaide at Booborowie from Mr R.F. Gasmier who moves to Kimba after two years. Mr Symonds previously played football and cricket at Angaston. He was born at Gumeracha, but has most recently been at head Office and on suburban staffs. [Photo.]

Horehound has been sprayed with poison on the 60 acre section of the Burra Stock Route.

85, 42 (2), 23 Oct. 1962, page 4 [This number first used in 1955.]

Hallett 5 for 266 defeated Mt Bryan 8 for 244 declared.

This is confirmed by a Return Thanks Notice Burra Record 85, 43 (2), 30 Oct. 1962, page 3. She was the wife of Patrick Joseph McIntyre and was married at Burra. 85, 43 (2), 30 Oct. 1962, page 5 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra High School. The Jubilee History continued by R.V. Mueller.

1959

The staff comprised M.W. Scriven Headmaster, J.D. Sladden, C. Morrison, G. Ireland, L. Pemberton, S. Crouch, R. Kowald and P. Kowald (Junior Teacher). Enrolment was 115. Sir Robert & Lady George visited the school on 29 June.

1960

Staff changes: C. Morrison & G. Ireland were transferred and A. Dadleff & J. Field (Junior Teacher) joined the staff. Enrolment was 119. A new rotary power mower and refrigerator were purchased and linoleum laid in the library. Mr Beinke rewired the school, installing power, heater and clock points.

(To be concluded.)

85, 43 (2), 30 Oct. 1962, page 6 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra Primary School and St Joseph’s School held a Sports Day on 26 October. [Results are printed.]

85, 43 (2), 30 Oct. 1962, page 7 [This number first used in 1955.]

Tennis. Burra Association

‘A’ Grade Spalding 13-99 defeated Booborowie 7-71

‘B’ Grade Spalding Blue 16-107 defeated Booborowie 4-66

85, 43 (2), 30 Oct. 1962, page 8 [This number first used in 1955.]

Obituary. Mrs Joe McIntyre formerly of Booborowie died at Port Pirie on 11 September. She came to Booborowie in 1912 with her mother, two sisters and a brother, as one of the original settlers on the North Booborowie Estate when it was allotted for closer settlement and apart from a brief period lived in Booborowie for the rest of her life. She married Mr Joe McIntyre and they moved to Yarcowie, but on her mother’s death Mr & Mrs McIntyre moved back to Booborowie and carried on the farm for a number of years. She was known in Booborowie and district as Lil Jones and was a gifted pianist and vocalist, giving her time at many charitable functions during WWI and was organist for a number of years at the Catholic Church. With failing health she went to live with her son and daughter in Port Pirie about twelve months ago. She is survived by a son, Jock and daughter, Margaret as well as by two sisters and five grandchildren.

[Born Mary Lillian Jones 28 October 1886 Gladstone: died 11 September 1962 Solomontown.]

85, 44 (2), 6 Nov. 1962, page 1 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra Women’s LCL Branch. The address on Communism by Mrs Ann Neill is reported in c. 12⁄3 columns.

St John’s Building Appeal reaches £159-6-6.

Burra High School. A new £4,000 bus has been put on the Hallett run. The Jubilee Sports Area project has been completed except for a few minor improvements. It has been decided to make investigations about the resurfacing and extension of courts at the front of the school, making two basketball courts possible.

85, 44 (2), 6 Nov. 1962, pages 1 & 7 [This number first used in 1955.]

Kooringa Methodist Fete was held in the RSL Hall on Friday and was opened by Mrs John Drew. It drew perhaps one of the largest crowds ever and takings totalled £304.

85, 44 (2), 6 Nov. 1962, page 7 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra Small Bore Club Double 100 yards Championship. Best scorer was R. Kellock.

85, 45 (2), 13 Nov. 1962, page 1 [This number first used in 1955.]

The Vice-Regal Visit of Sir Edric & Lady Bastyan went smoothly last Friday. The hospital and school were visited and there was a Civic Ball in the evening. In the afternoon Sir Edric visited the Mine while Lady Bastyan was entertained by the CWA. Prior to the Ball, Sir Edric paid a visit to the RSL. The Town Council entertained the visitors at the Kooringa Hotel for luncheon. At the hospital the Governor met staff, the Board of Management and patients. In the latter group were: Miss A. Simmons (who with her family owned land near Ulooloo gold fields), Mrs Ellery (who with her husband was a drover in Queensland), Mrs R. Steele, Mrs G. Dollman Jnr, Mrs R. Cullen, Miss S. Murphy (late of England), Mr L. Hirschausen, Mr Leo Wilson, Mr G.E. Phillips, Mr S. Sanderson (retired farmer of Gum Creek), Mr George Goodridge (of Mt Bryan), Mr B.H.K. Dunstan (grazier of Mt Bryan East, whose father was first postmaster at Mt Bryan) and Mr Gordon Fenton (Boer War veteran, fought in WWI and tried to enlist for WWII. He rode in the Coronation Procession of Edward VI [sic: for VII] in 1903).

At the school the visitors saw classes at work, with the Governor visiting grades VII, VI, & V, while Lady Bastyan visited grades I to IV. After that the school assembled in the Primary Yard together with the High School, where they were addressed by the Governor. [His address is printed on page 5.]

From the school Lady Bastyan went to the CWA Room where she was net by the Mayoress Mrs Baulderstone. Representatives of ladies’ organisations in the district attended. The Governor meanwhile inspected the old Burra Mine area and afternoon tea followed at the Mayor’s Parlour. The Governor’s visit to the RSL was brief, but he had the chance to meet representatives of the Burra, Farrell Flat, Booborowie and Hallett sub-branches.

Door takings at the Civic Ball amounted to £100.

The Koo-owie Clearing Sale is reported.

Remembrance Day was observed at the schools, where Mr B.A. Riggs represented the RSL and addressed the assembly and recited the ode. There was an impressive ceremony at the War Memorial on Sunday when wreaths were laid by H. Cornelius for the RSL, T. Rogers for the AFA & RAN, the Mayor for the Town Council, Cr M. Kellock for the DC and V. Preiss for the Pensioners’ League.

Elder, Smith & Co. Ltd celebrated 75 years of sales at Burra. They began on 25 November 1887 with their first monthly sale at the Bon Accord Yards. 25,000 sheep and 300 cattle were advertised; 15,000 of them from Paratoo. At the time Liston, Shakes & Co. held sales monthly at Young’s Yards and Morris, Sandland & Barritt also operated at the Bon accord Yards. On 16 November 1962 the combined agents will yard 22,000 sheep. Now Elders have merged with Goldsbrough, Mort & Co. Ltd. The record yarding for SA occurred when Elder’s yarded 44,000 sheep and 750 cattle on 27 September 1895.

85, 45 (2), 13 Nov. 1962, page 3 [This number first used in 1955.]

85, 45 (2), 13 Nov. 1962, page 7 [This number first used in 1955.]

Birth. To Audrey and Bob Angel on 13 November, a son, Stephen Eric.

Tennis. Burra Association

‘A’ Grade Kooringa 11-94 defeated Mt Bryan 9-84

Aberdeen 18-122 defeated Willalo 2-47

Hallett White 11-84 defeated Booborowie 9-87

‘B’ Grade Leighton Black 14-98 defeated Booborowie 6-70

Spalding Red 12-82 defeated Aberdeen 8-76

Mt Bryan 13-90 defeated Aberdeen 7-80

Obituary. Mr Keith Nivien [sic: for Vivian] Jones died at Jamestown Hospital 3 November. He was born in Burra almost 38 years ago, the younger son of Mrs C.R. and the late Mr W.T. Jones and spent most of his life in Hallett. He served for over two years in the AIF in WWII and on his discharge married Miss Irene Morris of Norwood. They made their home at Hallett. Keith took an interest in the town and district and was a member of the School Committee for many years and a prominent member of the Bowling Club and Football Club. At his death he was engaged in his own business as a general contractor and wood merchant. He is survived by a widow, daughter Heather, son Geoffrey, mother Mrs C.R. Jones of Hallett, brother Ray Jones of Melbourne and sister Mrs B. Smith of Booborowie North.

[Keith Vivian Jones born 14 November 1924 Redruth: died 2 November 1962 Jamestown, residence Hallett.]

85, 45 (2), 13 Nov. 1962, page 8 [This number first used in 1955.]

Burra High School. The Jubilee History concluded by R.V. Mueller.

1961

The staff comprised R.V. Mueller headmaster, J.D. Sladden, K.G. Hicks, R.D. Hillman, B.I. McElroy, N.I. Lawes, J.E. Bogisch (TVA 0.6), E. McCabe (TVA 0.2) and K. Horsnell (Junior Teacher). The enrolment was 125.

The Hanson bus run commenced and a new bus was put on the Booborowie run. The headmaster was absent for six weeks due to illness and Mr J. Sladden was Acting Headmaster. New pictures worth £50 worth were hung. Desks were planed and varnished. Two rain water tanks were installed. A new Banda duplicating machine was purchased. £120 was spent on hurdles. The wood heap was enclosed in a galvanised iron fence and doors were hung on the tank stands.

Tothill Creek School celebrated its centenary on 3 November with a ‘Back-to-School function.

[Details in 3⁄4 column.]

85, 46, 20 Nov. 1962, page 1

Sir Edric Bastyan writes a letter of thanks for his recent visit to Burra.

E.T. Baulderstone writes to thank all who helped to make the Governor’s visit a success.

Photos of Lady Bastyan at the CWA Rooms and of Sir Edric addressing the school assembly are printed.

Mr & Mrs Norm Fairchild are leaving Booborowie at the end of the month to live in Whyalla. Mrs Fairchild was given a farewell by the school welfare club, of which she had been an active member for seven years and President for three. She also received a presentation from the congregation of St Edmund’s Anglican Church.

The Catholic Church of the Holy Angels at Farrell Flat celebrated its Golden Jubilee, which is reported in c. 2⁄3 column.]

Annual Booborowie Methodist Strawberry Fete was held on 17 April and raised £230.

John Ryan won the novice event in the Shearing Competition at the Kalangadoo Show on Saturday and Michael Ryan came third.

Grasshoppers are quite numerous at Mt Bryan East.

Adelaide Wool Sales last week saw Mackerode Ltd top local district prices at 75d.

[Other local district prices are printed.]

Burra Sales by Associated Agents on Friday saw 23,425 sheep yarded and 21,894 sold.

St John’s Ambulance Appeal has reached £190-18-0.

85, 46, 20 Nov. 1962, page 7

Road Rule. Rear reflectors are now compulsory.

Obituary. Mr George Bass died at Dawes Road Repatriation Hospital last Saturday after a long illness. He is survived by a widow and two daughters. He will be remembered by old Burra residents as a good Burra footballer, tennis player and athletic runner. After leaving Burra he played some matches for West Torrens in the SANFL.

[George Ernest Bass born 25 April 1911 Kooringa: died 17 November 1962 Springbank, residence Adelaide.]

Burra & District Floral Art Club was formed on 12 November. President, Mrs Ray Lloyd and Secretary-Treasurer, Mrs Brian Thamm. Mrs Ray Mueller is the modern art demonstrator. The club will meet monthly in the Domestic Arts room at the school.

85, 46, 20 Nov. 1962, page 8

Burra Town Council, 5 November

A further letter is to be sent to the Attorney General about the closing of [old section of] the cemetery, saying the previous reply did not clarify matters and they require some definite direction.

Permission was granted for R.D. Riggs to demolish an old building.

45°parking lanes are to be marked from the ANZ Bank to the Catholic Church and from the corner of Thames Street to the corner of Queen Street, in front of the Burra Hotel and in the parking bay of the RSL Hall. A prohibited area is to be declared on west side of Market Street 60 ft from lots 82 & 83 [Cold Stores – in 2010 the Butcher’s] and south for 12 ft except for the doctor living adjacent.

85, 47, 27 Nov. 1962, page 1

Redruth Methodist Ladies Guild held its Annual Fete, this time in the theme of a ‘Fan’ Fair on 24 November in Redruth Memorial Hall. It raised a nett £260. [Details in c. 1 column.]

The Governor’s Visit. Photos are printed of Sir Edric Bastyan and Mr S. Woollacott and of Sir Edric Bastyan and a group at the Burra Mine.

Fuel Prices have fallen by 1⁄2d a gallon at Burra from 26 November.

At Burra Standard petrol is now 3/6 a gallon and premium is 3/101⁄2 a gallon.

Burra High School. Another £4,000 bus has come into use for the Hanson run. Illness has prevented Mr L. Carthew, a former headmaster, from speaking on speech night on 29 November, but Dr Steele has consented to fill in.

Burra Pictures have been running at a loss of £4 to £5 a night on Wednesdays with patronage as low as 25-30 people. If these figures do not improve with the warmer weather Wednesday screening will have to cease.

Burra Burra DC, 5 November

The District Clerk is to try to obtain land at Farrell Flat for a fire shed.

Tenders are called for a Fire Shed at Farrell Flat 30 ft x 15 ft x 10 ft.

Burra CWA celebrated its 36th birthday and International Day at its November meeting. Guest speakers were Mrs Badman – on the history of International Day by the CWA from its inception in 1937. Mrs Jim Warnes spoke on her visit to USA (with slides).

85, 48, 4 Dec. 1962, page 1

Burra Swimming Pool

On 28 November a decision was made to make an all-out effort to install a filtration plant in the pool at a cost of c. £4,000, to be subsidised pound for pound by the SA Government Tourist Bureau. Admission charges for casual swimming will rise to 2/- (1/- for juniors). Members’ Season Tickets £2-2-0 (over 14 years) and £1-1-0 (juniors).

Burra Small Bore Club. Gordon Webster was top off the rifle in the double 25 yards shoot.

Goldsbrough, Mort & Co.’s off shears sale at Burra recently – photo.

Burra Lawn Tennis Club has raised £60 from recent functions.

Weather. It has been hot recently in Burra!

Monday 100°F, Tuesday 102°F, Wednesday 101°F, Thursday 105°F and Friday was 112°F.

Burra RSL held its Annual Dinner on Saturday night. The State Vice-President Mr E. H. Smith attended and delivered an address. [Details in c. 11⁄2 columns.]

85, 48, 4 Dec. 1962, page 2

Elder, Smith & Co. on instructions from Robert C. Warnes invites tenders for 25,759 acres of perpetual lease in two lots 19-35 miles east of Burra.

Lot 1. ‘Chalk Cliffs’ of 9,874 acres 19 miles east of Burra comprising Sections 140-142, 143-144, 156N, 156S, 157-159, 161-163 Hd King. Sections 2-8, 19-23, 150 & 152-153 Hd Rees. Disposed as 5 sheep paddocks, with a stone house of 4 rooms etc.

Lot 2. ‘Nolans’ 15,885 acres 35 miles east of Burra. Block 64 East Hd King disposed as 7 sheep paddocks with two-roomed wood and iron cottage etc.

85, 49, 11 Dec. 1962, page 1

Adelaide Wool Sales. The top district price was 741⁄2d by Wandillah Ltd.

[Other local district prices are printed.]

St Joseph’s Convent. Results for the year are printed, including music results.

Progress Certificates were given to Angela Ryan and Brian Kakoschke.

Angela also won a three-year boarding scholarship tenable at St Joseph’s Convent Peterborough.

Kooringa Methodist Ladies’ Guild has raised £408 in the past nine months.

Burra Library Committee has reorganised the library into sections, so making it easier to find books of a similar nature.

Burra Town Council has given permission for the Department of Mines to enter the Burra Mine area to conduct tests for the next two years.

Kooringa Tennis Club’s Amateur Hour on Friday raised £40.

Burra Small Bore Club. W. Corner had the best score over a double 100 yards shoot.

Local Board of Health

Again the condition of the ladies’ toilet is of concern. It is cleaned every Friday morning and its state on Mondays suggests the travelling public is to blame rather than local residents. It will be cleaned each morning for the next month and the situation will then be re-assessed.

Mr & Mrs Keith Schiller and family of Mt Bryan will transfer to Pt Lincoln. Mr Schiller has been headmaster at Mt Bryan School and becomes deputy headmaster at Port Lincoln. A farewell was tendered at St Andrew’s Patronal Festival on 2 December.

Mr & Mrs Des Lubcke of Burra North will move to Millicent where Mr Lubcke has been appointed stationmaster. Mr Lubcke has been associated with Burra Lawn Tennis, Football and Golf Clubs and been active in the Anglican Church.

85, 49, 11 Dec. 1962, pages 1 & 8

Twenty Henley High School boys arrived by train on Wednesday night and were billeted locally. On Friday they visited the Burra Mines and the local swimming pool. Sports versus Burra are reported on page 8.

In tennis Burra High 14-127 defeated Henley High 3-81.

In Cricket Henley 7 for 186 declared defeated Burra 65 & 3 for 84.

85, 50, 18 Dec. 1962, page 1

Burra High School held its speech night in the Town Hall on Thursday. Chairman of the High School Council H.J.B. Jennison presided. After several items a moving address was given by Dr D.M. Steele, a former Chairman of the High School Council. Then Mrs M.T. Kellock handed out the certificates and Mrs Steele gave out the prizes and sports awards. Further items and reports followed. [A list of prize winners is printed.]

Skeleton Weed has been found near Mt Bryan and at Farrell Flat. Control measures are being taken.

Mr Syd Pearce, who has driven the Hanson school bus for the past two years, was given a presentation yesterday.

He is going to reside in Adelaide.

Burra Traders will open to 9 p.m. on 24 December. A merry-go-round will operate and Father Christmas will come at 9.10 p.m. There will be a tea break from 5.30 to 7 p.m. Recorded music will be played. A dance will be held in the Show Hall from 9 p.m. to midnight.

85, 50, 18 Dec. 1962, page 4

Burra Town Council, 3 December

Cr Jeffery reported that the Young St Footbridge had collapsed and he moved it be closed. Carried.

Burra Cold Stores apparently sought an extension of the prohibited area in front of the doctor’s house because the Council replied that it did not feel inclined to restrict parking any further at this time.

Council approved placing a Christmas tree in Market Square.

Council agreed to pay water rates for the Aberdeen Croquet Club – except for excess water.

A letter of sympathy was sent to Mrs Tanswell on the death of D.E. Tanswell in recognition of the services rendered to the Corporation by her late husband.

Burra Small Bore Club. The Double 75 yards Championship was won by G. Webster who was best off the rifle and on handicap.

85, 50, 18 Dec. 1962, page 8

Burra Burra DC, December meeting

It was decided to re-issue the call for tenders for a Farrell Flat Fire Shed – apparently with new dimensions – 30 ft x 20 ft x 10 ft.

Obituary. A decision to send a letter of condolence to the family reveals the death of A.D. McDonald.

[Archibald Donald McDonald born 22 December 1872 Baldry near Gum Creek: died 30 November 1962 Adelaide.]

Characteristics of the paper in 1962.

Generally there was a fair coverage of Burra and District. The areas beyond Farrell Flat and Booborowie have generally not been noted. Type-setting seems to have been rather better, with fewer inaccuracies.

Photographs became much more common, bur blocks were not prepared locally and so they are often a week or even more later than the story.

Page 1.

News – Local, but ranging from Riverton to Spalding.

Page 2.

Smaller advertisements especially sales, local government notices and local entertainment and social events.

Page 3.

A mixture of larger advertisements and overflow of page 2 type of material. Sometimes room for a little news.

Pages 4-6.

Dominated by sports news mixed with a little other stuff. More than half the page is large advertisements.

Page 7.

‘Cash Column’ advertisements – though this can wander to other pages. Large advertisements and a little news.

Page 8.

Large advertisements and perhaps two columns of sport news or news of local clubs and associations. The schools get considerable coverage, including those of Riverton and Spalding.

Sometimes there is an extra page or even two.

86, 1, 8 Jan. 1963, page 1

Weather. December 1962 was the wettest on record with district falls ranging from 2 inches to 6 inches. Burra had rain from the Sunday before Christmas to the following Sunday. Christmas day was wet and cold and many people sat around fires. Burra rain: 24th 18 points, 25th 0, 26th 124, 27th 30, 28th 64, 29th 151, 30th 0, 31st 58 points for a total of 445 points for the week and 456 for the month. The previous wettest December was 426 points in 1929. The yearly total was 20.11 inches for 1962; about 2 inches above average.

This rain damaged wheat crops, where some grain gas shot in the heat. Some bagged wheat has also shot and will need to be re-bagged. Considerable reaping is yet to be done and damage there is yet to be assessed. From Burra to Saddleworth farmers report bleaching of wheat, with one bag in nine lost on account of weight. In the pastoral country the rain was welcomed. Some areas had not had significant rain for three or four years. Falls to the 31 December: Oakbank 525 points, Pine Valley 411, Kia Ora 340, Poonunda 584, Oakvale 561, Woolgangi 480 and Koomooloo 402. Practically all dams are full. [Photo of the St Just Street Ford in flood.]

Learn to Swim Campaign this year saw 120 children take part.

Vandals on New Year’s Eve uprooted sign posts and shifted warning signs from a shaft at the Mine entrance.

Mt Bryan CWA Christmas Social is reported in 1⁄2 column.

Christmas in Burra

Christmas Eve was busy and trading was equal to previous years, though the numbers around were less, no doubt due to the cold conditions. Father Christmas arrived on schedule. The merry-go-round did not operate in the afternoon due to rain. The Rural Youth Dance did well and raised £26 for Rally Funds this year.

B.J. (Bill) Lee of Burra celebrated his 80th birthday on 13 January.

86, 1, 8 Jan. 1963, page 2

Advt. Booborowie Pictures are advertised and this continued each week throughout 1963.

86, 1, 8 Jan. 1963, page 5

Cricket. Inter-Association Match

86, 1, 8 Jan. 1963, page 6

Bowls

Burra Blue 115 defeated Spalding 78

Burra Gold 98 defeated Clare Blue 91

Burra Green 86 defeated Saddleworth Blue 93

86, 1, 8 Jan. 1963, page 7

Floods. The creek through West Ward overflowed twice during the December rains. On 28 December following 133 points in 20 minutes and secondly on 30 December when 58 points fell in 30 minutes. Debris from the first flood and trees growing in the creek made the second flooding worse. Water ran down Commercial Street 6 inches deep and then flowed down the full width of Thames Street. Some damage was done to businesses in Commercial Street.

Obituary. Harold Vivian Lord was the eldest son of the late Mr & Mrs J.V. Lord and was born at Burra in 1888. He spent his early life at the Barrier in the early days of prospecting and mining at Thackaringa, Silverton, Daydream, Broken Hill and Pinnacles. He lived on Silverdale, a pastoral property owned by his father, which was later incorporated into ‘Thackaringa’ Station, a family holding still occupied by his nephews. He was educated at Prince Alfred College and the SA School of Mines in wool-classing. After a short while at his father’s southern home at Sandergrove, he took over management of Pine Valley Station east of Burra and actively ran this property for forty years and at his death was the owner within the interests of J.V. Lord & Sons. He introduced deep boring to the east country, sinking Cockatoo Bore to 680 ft. As partner in J.V. Lord & Sons he had an interest too in Kalkaroo, Oakvale, Lord’s Well and Balah and was consultant for his sister’s property Eureka NSW and a director of the family’s pastoral companies at Yardea in the northwest and Tresant in the South East of SA.

[Died 1 December 1962 Unley Park. The birth does not appear on SA Births CD.]

86, 1, 8 Jan. 1963, page 8

Burra Burra DC, December 1962

The Minister of Local Government approved the payment of £250 from surplus funds of the Terowie Electricity Supply to the Terowie Institute.

Application to install petrol pumps adjacent to the main road at Terowie was refused and notice served on A. & F.T. White to remove the pump already installed. (This followed advice from the Highways & Local Government Department.)

Request to C.B .Nourse, as owner of the lot, to remove the petrol pumps installed on the kerbside of MR 45.

SAR’s intention concerning the future of cottages adjacent to the northern crossing at Terowie (west of the cemetery) is to be sought.

86, 2, 15 Jan. 1963, page 1

Marriage. Kooringa Methodist Church, 29 December

Barry Allen, only son of Mr & Mrs Fred Allen of Burra, married

Raelene Clark, daughter of Mr & Mrs A.J. Clark of Sturtvale Station.

[Further reported 86, 3, 22 Jan. 1963, page7 printed as 3.]

Fred, Walter and Paddy Williams had Christmas together at Burra for the first time in 61 years – arranged by Mr & Mrs Fred Williams Jnr. Fred from Burra North is 73, Walter from Mildura in 74 and Paddy of Burra is 80.

Mr Clive Hope of Waikerie Gliding Club made a forced landing in a stubble paddock near Burra when the wind failed him. The landing was perfect on A.G. Heinrich’s property.

A Swimming Carnival scheduled for Sunday between Clare, Spalding and Burra, was postponed due to the bad weather.

Members of the Department of Mines will shortly begin drilling at the Burra Mine site, beginning east of the old workings and will test over a distance of 1,500 ft to a point beneath the open cut.

West Street Burra North should be sealed in eight days of work commencing next week.

86, 2, 15 Jan. 1963, page 3

Note: Stop Signs are being changed to Red and White [from Black & Yellow]. The related rules are unchanged.

86, 2, 15 Jan. 1963, page 4

Burra High School Speech Night and 50th Annual Report.

In the last year the school celebrated it Golden Jubilee, had a Vice-Regal Visit and was host for the combined High Schools Sports Day.

The year opened with an enrolment of 146: made up of 77 boys and 69 girls and we expect it to be 160 in 1963. If staff permits we will make a second 1st Year Class. The only staffing changes in 1962 were the resignation of Junior Teacher Kym Horsnell and the arrival of J. Murphy from England. Now we say farewell to Mr Sladden and Mr Hillman; the former to Gawler and the latter to Henley High.

Religious Instruction continues to run smoothly.

Last year I reported the Education Department agreed to rent the area southwest of the school and to make available a subsidy and to grant £135 for initial ground formation. This has allowed the completion of two tennis courts (also two basketball courts) and two half cricket pitches in the last year and the grassing of the area for athletics, football and softball, together with a water reticulation system. Backstops are now planned for the courts at the front of the school.

The Parents & Friends’ Association has continued its good work and catered very well at the school’s sports day and also the combined schools’ sports, when they catered for 300 adults and 700 students. £100 was raised. At the Jubilee Ball the gross takings were £160. The Jubilee Birthday Party was also organised. The Jubilee ‘Statton’ playing area will be a memorial to their effort to mark the school’s 50th birthday.

Improvements this year have concentrated on improving the playing facilities. 56 girls can now be absorbed in basketball at a time, compared with 14 previously. Cricket and tennis facilities have also increased. On Arbor Day trees were planted. This year the asphalt paving area was resurfaced, a gas stove installed and two new £4,000 buses for the Hallett & Hanson runs arrived. A new £5,000 laboratory is to be commenced in January 1963.

The Jubilee Celebrations in brief:

Thursday 30 August. Inspection of the school at work.

A ‘Back-to-School Class’ was conducted by Mr. L. Carthew.

Mr A.K. Statton Superintendent of High Schools opened the Sports Area.

Birthday Celebrations and the cutting of the cake by Mr J. Statton, the first headmaster.

Evening Concert in the Town Hall

Friday 31 August Football & Basketball Matches v. Old Scholars

Jubilee Ball

In the year Intermediate and Leaving classes went to Adelaide to see plays and the Leaving Students also went to Clare.

[Leaving Teaching Scholars for 1962 and those applying for 1963 are listed.]

Burra Town Council, 7 January

A report was received on the Young Street footbridge and it was decided to close it again.

W. Nankivell was appointed Hall Caretaker 12 January 1963.

86, 3, 22 Jan. 1963, page 1

Learn to Swim Campaign at Burra had 147 children enrolled from 7-18 February [sic: for January]. Forty children were taught to swim at least ten yards. 25 gained their Beginners’ Certificate, 13 got a Progress Certificate and there were 19 Junior and 12 Senior Certificates awarded. [The successful scholars are named.]

Burra Bowling Club has let the tender for the new toilet block to F.M. Pearce & Sons.

Burra Small Bore Club. The best on Tuesday over double 25 yards were Jack Mitchell, M. Thomas and R. Gilbert.

Market Square. The planting of the traffic islands with couch grass seed was done by Mr E.T. Baulderstone.

Accident. A semi-trailer with a load of 12 tons rolled over yesterday morning on the hill near Mr Herb White’s home. It was en route from Radium Hill to Melbourne. The turntable snapped and the trailer rolled over. Part of the load of steel principals entered the driver’s side of the cabin, but fortunately the driver, sensing the danger, had just moved to the other side of the cabin. The driver Donald William Richardson had a lucky escape.

Burra RSL held its AGM on Friday night. Mr H. Cornelius retired as President after two years due to ill health. The new President is Mr T.R. Rogers with Mr H. Cornelius as Vice-President, Pensions Officer and Ambulance Representative. C.L Phillips is the second Vice-President and also carries on as Acting Secretary pro tem. Mr Ben Kotz is Treasurer.

86, 4, 29 Jan. 1963, pages 1 & 4

RSL Annual Report 1962

Attendance has been just enough to keep the branch open. During the year two sets of indoor bowls were procured with money left by the estate of the late Mrs Sara Gare, which made for many happy evenings for the Ladies’ Auxiliary. On Anzac Day the march and parade was led by the Port Pirie Pipers’ Band and the evening service was held in St Mary’s. Eighteen members attended. Remembrance Day was observed with the usual service at the Memorial in Market Square. Held on a Sunday when a number of members were absent, it drew only sixteen of them. The Ministers’ Fraternal did not reply to the invitation this time and the President read Mr Bean’s Requiem instead. The annual ball was successful thanks to the Ladies’ auxiliary in particular. Forty-six members attended the annual dinner, with visitors also from headquarters, Saddleworth, Jamestown, Farrell Flat and Hallett. It was very successful from a social point of view. The Christmas party was a small event, but most enjoyable. The Burra RSL continues to support two Legacy wards – largely from money from bottles collected by people of the district. The Governor, Sir Edric Bastyan paid a visit on 9 November and shook hands with each of the approximately 60 members present.

86, 4, 29 Jan. 1963, page 4

Burra Small Bore Club fired a double 50 yards shoot when the best off the rifle was Ross Gilbert and with handicap the best scorers were M. Thomas, M. Alderson and P. Mengersen. The half-yearly aggregate was won by R. Angel.

86, 5, 5 Feb. 1963, page 1

Adelaide Wool Sales, 4-6 December. [Local district prices are printed.]

Mr N. Sieber of the Burra branch of the ANZ Bank will be transferred to Mt Barker on 13 February. [Corrected 86, 6, 12 Feb. 1963 to 13 March.] He will be replaced by Mr Harold Crump from the Jamestown branch.

Burra Small Bore Club. The best scorers for the double 75 yards shoot were M. Alderson, J. Taylor & M. Thomas.

Tennis. Burra Association

‘A’ Grade Aberdeen 11-99 defeated Mt Bryan 9-80

‘B’ Grade Aberdeen 12-93 defeated Mt Bryan 8-75

Burra Mine. Vandals have continued to move survey pegs at the Mine and so disrupt the Mines Department research at the site and causing extra cost. The test work is continuing. Equipment using induced polarisation has been used. Electrical pulses are polarised by ore pockets and the degree of polarisation can indicate the metals present. Drilling is also continuing, though problem with sand falls and the need to cement sections have delayed this work.

86, 6, 12 Feb. 1963, page 1

Burra Mine. Officers of the Mines Department advise that their survey has been extended south-southwest of the town and to the east.

Burra Small Bore Club. Best scores for the 100 yards shoot were from R. Alderman, Ron Kellock & P. Mengersen.

Skeleton Weed Outlook. Four sites have now been identified; the latest in the Springbank area. Earlier discoveries have been at Mt Bryan, Hanson and Springbank.

Burra & District Swimming Club will discuss the installation of a filtration plant with the Town Council and an engineer from the manufacturers.

Burra Town Council

Mr Baulderstone has suggested a passageway and small room at the rear of the clerk’s office would be ideal for hanging large photos and keeping old relics etc. The Library wishes to dispose of some large pictures as it is overcrowded.

Burra High School reopened this year with an enrolment of 151: 1st Year 53, 2nd Year 56, 3rd Year 26 and 4th Year 16. There are two 1st Year classes and although 2nd Year is one class, it divides for all subjects. The Head Prefects are Barbara Hogan and Bill Standing. [New enrolments are listed, as are the prefects and house leaders.]

Burra & District Swimming Club annual carnival was held at the weekend and was successful, with 85 events decided and a profit of £65. T. Higginbottom [sic] of BHAS Club won the 800 yards Country Championship. [Results are printed.]

Burra Primary School

New on the staff is Mr Kevin Pope. [New students are listed.]

On 21 February the children will go to Elizabeth to see H.M. the Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh. They will need to be at the station at 6.45 a.m. with a cut lunch. The train arrives back in Burra at 3.42 p.m.

St Joseph’s Convent School. The staff is unchanged. [New students are listed.]

Farrell Flat School has an enrolment of 54 and new Grade I students are listed.

Willalo School has 14 students with one new Grade I student and one student doing 2nd Year High School by correspondence.

Mt Bryan School has an enrolment of 47 with four new students in Grade I. Mr & Mrs Shaughnessy are the new staff.

Hallett School has an enrolment of 57 and the 6 new students in Grade I are listed.

Gum Creek School has an enrolment of 37 and there are 4 new Grade I pupils.

[This seems odd in view of the advertisement: 86, 3, 22 Jan. 1963, page 6, but numbered 2

Department of Lands calls for offers for Pt Section 757 Hundred of Hanson: 1 acre: the old Gum Creek School property. This is certainly the school site.]

Burra Mine. The Department of Mines is presently doing a geophysical survey of the mine and a deep diamond drill hole is being put down adjacent to the old mine workings.

Burra Town Council, 4 February

Mrs M.S. Bown asked Council to close and sell to her the lane adjoining her home as far up as Lancelot Street, so that it could be used for the disposal of waste water.

It was moved and seconded that a portion of the road be sold to Mrs Bown with provision for a footpath, subject to the Opening and Closing of Roads Act. [Presumably passed.]

The Triangular Swimming Carnival on Friday resulted in Burra retaining the shield with a 29 point win over Clare. Burra 148, Clare 119 and Spalding 82. [Results of events are printed.]

Burra Station was busy on Thursday when 262 children went to see the Queen at Elizabeth. At one stage between 6.30 and 7 a.m. there were 100 cars at the station.

Obituary. Rev. Albert Bell died suddenly on Wednesday night and was buried at Centennial Park Cemetery.

37, 9, 5 Mar. 1963, page 1 [Note anomalous volume number: check issue number.]

Burra Football Club held its AGM 26 February at Burra Town Hall. It resolved to stay in the NEFL for the coming season. The club will support a special meeting called by the War Memorial Committee to discuss oval improvements. John Ayliffe was appointed Captain-Coach. He is a teacher at Burra High School. Elected: Patron, Mr Reg. Warnes; President, Mr L.A. Beinke; Vice-President, Mr E. Orchard and Secretary-Treasurer, Mr D. Zanker.

37, 9, 5 Mar. 1963, page 4

Obituary. Rev. Albert Bell, Secretary of the Home Mission Department.

A photo in the Home Mission Office taken thirty years ago shows a Federal Inland Mission vehicle in front of Parliament House Canberra and Albert Bell is pointing to the legend on the bonnet of the Didge Truck – ‘Derby to Sydney via the Granites’. One is not surprised that Rev. Albert Bell should have been the first to cross Australia between those two points in a motor vehicle. He was born at Hetton Down, County Durham, UK, on 29 December 1896 and migrated to WA where he entered the service of the Methodist Church. The WA Home Mission Department appointed him a missioner to Kojonup in the far South East agricultural and pastoral area of WA in 1928. The mission had only been established in the north of WA for three years when Rev. Bell volunteered to go there in 1930 and was appointed to the Kimberley Patrol. He had an area of nearly 100,000 square miles and was at Derby in ‘the wet’ and at Wyndham in ‘the dry’. At Wyndham he established a debating society with an average attendance of 100 and basketball and athletic clubs flourished under his infectious enthusiasm. In eight years Rev. Bell made the Methodist Mission there widely known and respected. He then came south in 1938 and married Ivison Holliday of Victor Harbor on 19 February 1938 and they enjoyed a wonderful partnership for twenty-five years and one day. There was a honeymoon voyage to England in the sailing ship Pommern via Cape Horn. On returning to Australia he became pastor to the Port Adelaide Central Methodist Mission and assistant to the late Rev. A.D. McCutcheon for eleven years. In 1948 he applied for ministerial status and was ordained with status retrospective to 1938. From 1950 he served circuits at Angaston, Red Hill and Hallett-Terowie, where he was beginning his fifth year. He was an artilleryman in the Imperial Forces in WWI and spent ten months as a POW. He was a member of the RSL and Treasurer of the Hallett Sub-branch, a Vice-President of the Cricket Club and Chaplain to the local Lodge of Freemasons, a member of the Hallett Institute and of the Bowling Club. He was a forthright preacher whose sermons were original and arresting.

[Born 29 December 1896 Hetton Down, Co. Durham, UK: died 20 February 1963, Hallett.]

37, 9, 5 Mar. 1963, page 6

Burra Institute Library Annual Meeting. Elected: President, Miss E. Tiver; Vice-Presidents, Mr C. Haythorp & Mrs B. Kotz; Secretary, Mr Bill Nankivell and Treasurer, Mrs K. Treleaven. Membership has fallen due to removals and television. About 130 new books were added in the year, which ends in credit with £13-11-4 in the bank and £9-16-0 cash in hand.

86, 10, 12 Mar. 1963, page 1

Debra Brereton aged 51⁄2, the eldest daughter of Mr & Mrs Colin Brereton of Hanson has entered the RAH for a hole in the heart operation.

Burra High School. The prefects’ induction ceremony is reported.

Another student gained an Intermediate Certificate with the awarding of and English Q to Rosemary Brown. Barbara Hogan in Leaving has upgraded her English Q to a pass in the Supplementary Exam.

Mr G.C. Heinrich (84) took a short cut at the oval on Sunday evening and attempted to climb over the gate between the oval and the Small Bore Club Range. He fell from the top of the gate and the cuff of his trousers caught on a spike, leaving him suspended upside down for several hours. He spent a comfortable night in hospital, but was apparently not in bad condition.

Theft. Intruders entered the Burra Dry Cleaners and the Bowling Club room on Friday night. It is thought £6 to £7 in silver is missing from the former and a packet of biscuits from the latter.

Advt. Oates Ltd will auction a house and contents on Friday 22 March in the Estate of the late M.M. Bown; situated at the corner of West and Morehead Streets. (Allotments 39, 40, & Pt 41 of a subdivision of Section 4, Hundred of Kooringa.)

86, 10, 12 Mar. 1963, page 7

Burra Town Council, 4 March

Cr Jeffery asked that the Young Street Bridge [closed] be demolished and the pieces be placed in the depot. Agreed.

PMG is to be informed that the Council will erect street names before allotting house numbers.

Approval was given for the erection of the Bowling Club toilet block.

L.M. Gordon was asked to remove a dangerous piece of wood overhanging the footbridge in Commercial Street and also asked to clear the mortar wall from the creek.

86, 10, 12 Mar. 1963, page 8

86, 10, 12 Mar. 1963, page 9 numbered 6

Mr N. Sieber manager of the ANZ Bank in Burra for 51⁄2 years was farewelled at Burra Hotel on Monday. This week he will take up duties at Mt Barker.

86, 11, 19 Mar. 1963, page 1

Annual St Patrick’s Ball at Mt Bryan on Friday was most successful. Takings exceeded £50.

Marriage. Redruth Methodist Church

Photograph of Miss Glenda Rawlins of Mt Bryan married Mr Peter Jenvey.

The marriage was performed by the late Rev. Albert Bell.

[86, 14 (2) 9 Apr. 1963, p.7 adds the information that Glenda Enid Rawlins was the eldest daughter of Mr & Mrs C. Rawlins of Mt Bryan and Mr Peter John Jenvey came from Mogumber WA.]

Burra Hospital. A new electric bell system is being installed. The surrounding area is being bituminised and the lawns top dressed. The Nurses’ Home and the Midwifery quarters will soon be re-painted. The cropping program has yielded £500-11-0 for the first advance on this season’s wheat.

Burra Burra Show Inc.

Mr Rex Warnes was re-elected President at the AGM. The financial statement showed a deficit on the year’s workings due to the maintenance costs and improvements and a wet day for the 1962 show. Mr T.G. Perry has resigned as Secretary and anyone interested in the position should contact Mr Perry. Others elected: Patron: G.S. Hawker and Vice-Presidents, B.A. Riggs and B. W. Humphrys.

Burra Gold 98 defeated Spalding 89

Burra Green 99 defeated Saddleworth Gold 113

Burra Blue 102 defeated Hallett Red 91

Burra Burra Show Inc. The President Presents the 88th Annual Report.

The Annual Show was held on 6 October in vile, cold and windy conditions with hail. The gate takings fell to £145-17-0, aided by £16-4-6 from the dance conducted by the Rural Youth Club. Entries were numerous (2,500). Exhibits in the main hall benefited from the fine improvements carried out by Mr R. Fuss. For the first time a buffet lunch was served for official guests, which proved successful. Membership remains steady, but the financial position has deteriorated.

Burra Small Bore Club. The best results over double 75 yards came from W. Corner, P. Mengersen and M. Alderson.

86, 12, 26 Mar. 1963, page 1

Burra Races

Despite a good track, good facilities and trophies that were magnificent, the races on Wednesday last were not well supported by owners and trainers and the public generally failed to attend. The weather was ideal and the track and surroundings were in excellent condition. The Club consequently suffered a considerable loss.

Fire destroyed c. 300 acres of feed and half a mile of fencing on Wednesday afternoon on Koonoona property near the old Sod Hut Hotel. It seems to have been caused by a cigarette butt or match.

PMG advises that from 22 March there will be three additional phone circuits between Burra and Clare.

Koonoona Stud celebrates its centenary with its annual Field Day on Thursday. It was founded by Hon. Walter Duffield and Mr T.S. Porter with 50 selected ewes from ‘Hill River’ and rams from Mount Crawford. It remained in the same ownership till 1875 when Mr Porter retired and was replaced by Col. F. Makin. When Mr Duffield died in 1880 the trustees of the estate administered the property till 1918, when it was sold to the beneficiaries and the then manager, Mr W.G .Hawkes. The name was changed then to Koonoona Proprietors. Mr Hawkes retired in 1930 and his son, Mr Glen Hawkes, acquired an interest as Managing Director, which position he held till his death in 1961. The present Managing Director is Mr R.K. Pearse, who first came to Koonoona in 1938 as a jackeroo and returned as manager in 1952. The present overseer is Mr R. Osborne. The first Field Day (then called an Inspection Day) was held in 1946. Koonoona was the first SA stud to fly rams to the Sydney Sheep Show and the first SA stud to sell a ram in Sydney for 1,000 guineas. Since 1910 it has been a closed stud, producing a particularly even type of sheep that have proved their worth in all states and New Zealand with a reputation for heavy wool cutting ability. It comprises 22,600 acres and presently carries 16,000 sheep.

Burra Burra Show Inc. Since the report last week Mr R. Fuss says the major credit for improvements in the Flower Pavilion must go to Mrs Sid Scroop for fixing valances to the tables, assisted by Mr Scroop.

Adelaide Wool Sales. The best local district price went to Canopus Pastoral Co. at 803⁄4d [Other local district prices are printed.]

86, 12, 26 Mar. 1963, page 2

Tenders are called for the erection of a new kitchen and general repairs to St Mary’s Church Hall, Burra.

Allan Day was farewelled by over 40 players and supporters of the Burra Football and Footballers’ Cricket Club at the Golf Clubhouse on Saturday night. He was presented with a travelling rug.

Eaglehawks have invaded Mt Bryan East and are taking young lambs. Mr George Dare has declared war and has quite a show of dead eagles on his fences. Mr Brian Riggs saw ten eaglehawks dining of one of his ewes’ new born lambs yesterday.

86, 12, 26 Mar. 1963, page 4

86, 13, 2 Apr. 1963, page 1

Burra Town Oval Project

At a public meeting in Burra Town Hall on 25 March it was decided after lengthy discussion to endeavour to raise £1,500 for the purpose of erecting suitable toilet facilities and turfing the Memorial Oval. A public appeal has been launched. Mr Baulderstone in addressing the meeting outlined the work of the War Memorial Committee over the years. The appeal so far has £25.

The Burra Pre-School Association was formed at a meeting held on 26 March and elected: President, Mrs Pitcher; Vice-President, Mrs Broad; Secretary, Mrs Holness and Treasurer, Mrs Nourse.

Vandalism. Two youths have been fined in Burra. They had damaged a telephone booth at the local Post office, causing about £18 damage. They were fined £20 each plus £1-10-0 costs, plus £9 each for the damage.

Mrs Dorothy Carpenter won a camera and a 34 lb box of biscuits in a phone call from the TV program ‘Wheel of Fortune’.

R.G. Bernhardt’s photo is printed on the occasion of his 65th birthday along with others including Mr Guy Dollman.

86, 13, 2 Apr. 1963, page 2

Notice. Compulsory Chest X-Ray Survey of the Mid North. All persons aged 15 and over. Location at Burra: the parking area near the Burra Hotel. 2 April to 16 April.
