86, 13, 2 Apr. 1963, page 8

Tennis. Finals

‘A’ Grade Aberdeen 15-110 defeated Mt Bryan 5-67

Bowls: Champion of Champions was won by C. Treloar of Saddleworth.

Burra Primary School Committee

After 14 years on the committee and 11 as chairman, Mr Stockman felt he should hand on to someone else. Elected: Chairman D.H. Field and Secretary-Treasurer, D.F. Bannister.

Retiring Chairman, M.G. Stockman, presented the 88th report.

The staff position changed with the transfer of Mr King. Two replacement teachers, Mr Pope and Miss Ronan gave us the full staff for a Class III school and allowed the Head Teacher Mr Horsnell the freedom to do his administrative duties. The highlight of the year was the Vice-Regal visit of Sir Edric and Lady Bastyan. The sports day at the oval was very successful. Visiting Day drew many parents and friends. Arbor Day was held at the beginning of winter and a variety of trees were planted. We have not been able to get a school crossing sign or flashing lights, as the Highways Department will not sanction these when the school is not adjacent to the road. The most they will sanction is the NSC sign and red flags and these were duly erected by the Town Council. We are keeping the matter in mind if the Road Traffic Act is changed. Tenders should soon be called for a new block of lavatories for Primary School use, for the asphalting of the balance of the yard on the eastern side, the fencing of the new Drill Hall block, which has been added to the playing area and a retaining wall and backstop for the tennis courts. [Thanks to various people are also expressed.]

86, 14 (2), 9 Apr. 1963, page 1 [This number first used in 1957.]

Robberies. Two Burra stores were broken into on the night of 4 April. The premises of P.H. & P.M. Sandercock (Sandy’s Serv-Wel Store) were entered and about £ stolen. The front door was forced. The intruder(s) left by the back door. Pearce’s Hardware Store was also entered and a number of watches and a ring stolen. Total value of goods taken was c. £130. Police enquiries continue.

Football. Burra Football Club will support the Colts this year. It will but a set of jumpers and supply umpires for home games. Last Saturday Darrell Field was elected Captain and Graham Benger Vice-Captain.

Burra Table Tennis Club held its AGM on 2 April and elected: President, Peter Sandercock and Secretary-Treasurer, Roger Jenkins.

Obituary. Mrs Hedley Pearce died at her home last Tuesday aged 62.

[Born Rena Ann Harris 11 March 1901 Kooringa: died 2 April 1963 Burra.]

Obituary. Mr Brian Halls died in Adelaide yesterday. [Born Gordon Brian Nelson Halls 23 July 1925 Redruth: died Brian Gordon Nelson Halls 8 April 1964 Adelaide, residence Burra North.]

Obituary. Mr E.J. Davey, the former Town Clerk, died last Wednesday aged 94.

[Edward James Davey born 26 July 1869 Kooringa: died 3 April 1963 Burra – so aged 93.]

North Eastern School Sports were held at Leighton Oval on Friday. Mr Quirke MP opened the event. He mentioned the recent raising of the school leaving age to 15. Participating schools were: Leighton, Spalding, South Booborowie, Hilltown, St Joseph’s Convent, Booborowie & Willalo. [Check this list.]

Cricket. Mokota Association Premiership

Hallett 152 defeated Burra Footballers 122.

After deciding the Premiership in the first innings Hallett batted again and were dismissed for 88.

For the Mayfield Shield North Booborowie 7 for 298 declared defeated Leighton 158.

Burra Rural Youth recently had a weekend trip to Loxton and the article records visits to a Friday night dance, the pumping station, winery, vineyard, fruit packing sheds, a barbecue, Saturday night dance and a trip on Sunday to Renmark and Berri.

Bowls. At the Blyth Annual RSL Tournament the Burra team of T. Rogers, Cliff Turner, O. Holmes and A. Ford fought through to the final where it was defeated by West Croydon.

86, 14 (2), 9 Apr. 1963, page 6 [This number first used in 1957.]

Mr George Dare at Mt Bryan East has trapped 35 Eaglehawks with the help of a white rooster and a decoy eagle.

Mr Theodore Pohlner visited the Merino Field Days from WA. He moved to Cranbrook in the West 18 years ago from Mt Bryan East.

Burra Small Bore Club. Best scores for a double 25 yards match were by K. Spackman, R. Gilbert & R. Kellock.

86, 14 (2), 9 Apr. 1963, page 8 [This number first used in 1957.]

Burra School Welfare Club Annual Report is printed.

Membership was 54 and average attendance 29. During the year various items of sporting equipment were bought and a reading laboratory and other teaching aids and a cupboard and bed for the sick bay.

We provided a buffet meal for 50 people when teachers from the district and inspectors visited the Burra School in June.

Burra High School. Parents & Friends’ Association AGM

Elected: President, Mrs P. Sandercock; Vice-President, Mrs P. Murphy; Secretary, Mrs E. Benger; Assistant Secretary, Mrs P. Field and Treasurer, Mrs F. Brook. The report on the year noted the near completion of the Jubilee Sports Area. The Association provided luncheon at the Sports Day at the racecourse for the first time. It was also associated with the Inter High School Sports and the Jubilee Celebrations. The annual High School Ball this year took £159-11-3. £500 was donated to the Jubilee Committee for the Sports Area and this attracted a Departmental subsidy. Thanks go to W. Carpenter for re-lettering the Honour Roll in the Avenue of Remembrance for past students and teachers who fell in WWI & WWII. The High School Banquet and the Vice-Regal visit were other highlights of the year. There are now 53 financial members and average attendance was 27.

86, 15 (2), 16 Apr. 1963, page 1 [This number first used in 1957.]

Mr & Mrs Jim Prior of Hallett celebrated their Golden Wedding with a dinner for 150 people at the Hallett institute on Saturday 6 April. In 1918 Jim married Miss Ruby Brown at Broken Hill at the first motorised wedding there. [If this was their golden wedding they should have been married in 1913!] The couple moved to SA when their daughter Elva was three weeks old. In the 1920s Jim, known as ‘Nigger’ played football and cricket for Hallett and more recently he was runner-up in the singles bowls championship. He has always been a strong supporter of the athletics clubs in the district. Mr Pryor thanked the many friends he had in the district over 46 years there [suggesting he arrived in 1917.] The cake for the occasion was made by daughter Elva, Mrs Backshall of Mt Barker WA. Joyce, Mrs L.H. Aldridge and her husband were also present from WA. [Details of this event extend for 2 columns with 2 photographs: one of the couple and one of Mr A.G. Owen-Smyth proposing a toast.]

Drew Lane will be sealed at a cost of £60 to save maintenance costs due to erosion.

Burra Town Council. Highways and Local Government Department has said an interest free loan to finance a new tractor and equipment was unavailable. The Council, after consideration of finances, has decided to call tenders for the same and to make an outright purchase.

86, 15 (2), 16 Apr. 1963, pages 1 & 4 [This number first used in 1957.]

North Eastern Small Bore Association held a Prize Shoot at Burra on 7 April and drew shooters from Broken Hill, Renmark, Morgan, Waikerie, Burra, Riverton, Clare, Terowie, Peterborough, Port Pirie, Port Augusta and Whyalla. The only possible for the day was scored by W. Jenkins of Clare. In the aggregate M. Anderson of Pt Augusta was first and in the handicap aggregate S. Birt of Terowie came first with W. Corner of Burra in second place.

On Tuesday night over double 50 yards M. Thomas, P. Mengersen & M. Alderson scored best.

Burra Town Council, 8 April

Tenders are called for re-roofing and painting the roof of the Clerk’s residence.

It was resolved to remove the rockery in Market Square and have it replaced with a flower garden.

86, 15 (2), 16 Apr. 1963, page 5 [This number first used in 1957.]

Burra Primary School will compete in the combined school sports against Mt Bryan, Hallett, Whyte-Yarcowie and Terowie at Hallett Oval on 19 April.

86, 15 (2), 16 Apr. 1963, page 6 [This number first used in 1957.]

Burra Bowling Club’s Easter Tournament was a great success. The final was played at night in bitterly cold conditions. K. Collins’s rink defeated E. Curtis’s rink. In the Mixed Rinks Tournament on Monday a Peterborough Rink was successful.

86, 15 (2), 16 Apr. 1963, page 8 [This number first used in 1957.]

Mr E.A. (Curly) Wohling & Mrs Wohling are leaving Burra today after Mr Wohling has spent 64 years in the town, while Mrs Wohling was born here 73 years ago. They will live with their son Ken and his wife Pat at Maylands. Mr Wohling was born at She-Oak Log 80 years ago and was educated at Lindley (between Morgan and Florieton) and came to Burra at the age of 16 when he began to work on Redcliffe Station. This was then owned by Messrs Scott & Son and from there he went to Braefoot owned by Mr Henry Scott. After a spell of several years in Victoria he returned to Braefoot where a Mr Hill had taken over. His work comprised shearing, farming, blacksmithing and sheep work etc. His sporting interests included football, cricket and cycling. Fifty-three years ago he married Miss Laura Lihou and they have lived in Burra ever since. Mr Wohling commenced work as a barman at the Burra Hotel when Mr Carl Heinrich was the proprietor and has seen many changes there over 38 years. When Mr Tom and Miss E.A. Scovell took over the Commercial Hotel Mr Wohling went there for 13 years before retiring. Mr Wohling recalled riding against the cyclists Jack Richards (the first man to sell cars in Burra), Syd Grivell, Charlie Waldie [sic: Wardle?], ‘Pop’ Gardner, Albert & Bill Lomman (still riding), Harry & Oliver Baynes, Bill Bartel, Jim Bradley, J.D. ‘Duncan’ Kelly, Tommy Hogart and Alf & Albert McWaters. His best distance was the half mile and most races were at Victoria Park. He recalls playing football when Aberdeen and Kooringa played in snow and Aberdeen 0.5 defeated Kooringa 0.3. When working at Woolgangi and Bungunya he would ride his bike into Burra on Saturday morning to play football and return on Sunday.

North-Eastern Schools Sports. [Individual results are printed.]

86, 16 (3), 23 Apr. 1963, page 1 [This number used twice in 1957.]

Bowls. The season closed on Saturday.

The club had enjoyed an outstanding year. The Burra Gold team won the pennant in the Mid-North Association. In the North-Eastern Association Burra Blue failed by only two points from achieving a tie for top position. The Easter Tournament was very successful. The ladies had a successful year in raising £250 for the Men’s Club.

Trophies:

Club Champion Brian Riggs

Handicap Singles K. Phillips

Consistency J. Minchin

Men’s Night Pairs C. Turner & E. Pietsch

Championship Pairs O. Holmes & W. Shipard

Mixed Pairs V. Hood & O. Holmes

Associates’ Champion Mrs D. Field

Associates’ Handicap Singles Mrs D. Field

Burra High School. Work has begun on a new £5,500 laboratory at the school and a new classroom. Work should be completed within six weeks, though the plumbing requirements may delay opening for a time. The new classroom promised for 1964 is ahead of schedule. The old small laboratory is due for conversion to a staff room. The Jubilee Plaque will be mounted on a cairn of local slag stone at the entrance to the new tennis courts on the Statton Sports Area.

Anzac Services and parades were held at Burra, Riverton, Saddleworth, Booborowie and Hallett on Sunday. The weather at Burra was perfect for the March and Service at the Memorial in Market Square at which Rev. T.G. Drought and Rev. R.S. Jenner officiated. Thirty-six members of the local RSL took part in the march, led by the Port Pirie Pipers’ Band, which also played at the Burra Hospital from 1-2 p.m. Wreaths were laid by Vice-President H. Cornelius for the RSL, President T.R. Rogers for the Air Force Association, A.C. Heinrich for Demobilised Soldiers, E.T. Baulderstone for the Town Council and T.G. Perry as District Clerk for the DC. The public attendance was poor.

Burra Golf Associates met on 8 April and elected: Patron, Mrs A.L. Collins; President, Mrs D.H. Field; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames R. Pearse & H. Topsfield; Secretary, Mrs A. Wright; Treasurer, Mrs R. Mueller; Captain, Miss E. Tiver and Vice-Captain Mrs M.R. Nicholls.

Burra Small Bore Club.

M. Alderson, R. Kellock and R. Alderson were best scorers over 25 yards on Tuesday.

For the Championship R. Gilbert with 737.14 out of 800 defeated R. Kellock with 515.0.

For the Handicap Championship R. Kellock & R. Alderson on 800 met in a shoot-off in which R. Kellock 94.2 defeated R. Alderson 92.2.

86, 17 (3), 30 Apr. 1963, page 1 [This number used twice in 1957.]

CHECK SEQUENCE OF PAGES IN THIS ISSUE

Weather. The month has been the wettest April since 1889 with falls of 3 to 4 inches across the district. The east has also received good falls. Burra had 361 points, but Mt Bryan only 130 and Booborowie 91 and Farrell Flat 229, reflecting the nature of thunderstorm activity across the district. Eastern Stations report from 100 points at Braemar and Kia-Ora to 288 at Redcliffe.

M & BHA raised £31-4-6 at a street stall on 26 April.

Burra Oval Appeal has stalled at £30-5-0. A picture night at the Town Hall is planned to get the total moving again.

Graziers are complaining of spotlight shooters to the east, shooting cattle and sheep and destroying fencing.

Burra High School Intermediate and Leaving students visited Clare on Monday 22 April to see the Young Elizabethan Players present Richard III and Henry V. Recently Intermediate students went to Adelaide to see a different production of Henry V at the Union Hall in the University of Adelaide.

86, 17 (3), 30 Apr. 1963, page 2 numbered 6 [This number used twice in 1957.]

Basketball

Spalding A 23 defeated Burra 16

Burra B 31 defeated Spalding B 22

Mt Bryan C 10 defeated Burra C 8

Leighton C 21 defeated Spalding C 15

Burra Small Bore Club. Best over double 75 yards were Margaret Alderson, M. Thomas and R. Alderson.

86, 17 (3), 30 Apr. 1963, pages 1 & 8 [This number used twice in 1957.]

The 36th Annual Hallett & District Schools’ Athletic Assoc. Meeting was held at Hallett Oval on 19 April in ideal weather. Burra Primary School competed for the first time. Willalo & Canowie Belt had moved to another association, leaving only four of the original schools from 1928: Terowie, Whyte-Yarcowie, Hallett and Mt Bryan. Burra entered as four houses to make an eight team competition. Results:

Hallett 107

Aberkoorie (Burra Green) 78

The Bednall Trophy for Teams’ Races went to Hallett.

Hawker Cup for the Girls’ Championship to Susan Brown (Hallett).

Tiver Trophy for Boys’ Championship to Geoffrey Jones (Hallett).

The Highest Aggregate for boys was a tie between G. Jones of Hallett and K. Bannister of Aberkoorie (Burra Green).

The Highest Aggregate for girls went to Alison Miller (Hallett).

The gate was £45-17-0 and there was a good profit of £72-12-8 on cool drinks.

86, 17 (3), 30 Apr. 1963, page 6 numbered 2 [This number used twice in 1957.]

86, 17 (3), 30 Apr. 1963, page 7 numbered 3 [This number used twice in 1957.]

Bowls. Annual Riverton Bowls Tournament

Four Burra members: Mr & Mrs H. Crump and Mr & Mrs Keith Phillips were successful in playing off with a Saddleworth rink to win the tournament.

86, 17 (3), 30 Apr. 1963, page 8 numbered 4 [This number used twice in 1957.]

86, 18 (3), 7 May 1963, page 1 [This number used twice in 1957.]

Burra Pre-School Association raised £64 with a Devonshire Tea and a trading table at the home of Mrs Pitcher on Friday. This will allow them to go ahead with the erection of cupboards, some new plumbing and general improvements.

Hanson Hall has had its interior repainted.

Burra Small Bore Club. The season ended with a double 100 yards shoot. In the handicap section Margaret Alderson narrowly defeated K. Spackman to win the yearly trophy.

For an unnamed trophy (probably the Championship) R. Gilbert took the honours [named elsewhere as getting the Marksman’s Trophy.]

In the Handicap Championship R. Kellock defeated R. Alderson in a shoot-off.

Yearly Trophy went to M. Alderson.

Trophy for first half-year went to R. Angel and for the second half-year to P. Mengersen.

86, 18 (3), 7 May 1963, page 4 [This number used twice in 1957.]

86, 19 (3), 14 May 1963, page 1 [This number used twice in 1957.]

Mid North High Schools Combined Sports were held at Balaklava on Thursday. Burra with a total of 147 points won both the Championship and the handicap sections – perhaps for the first time since the five schools have competed. Rules prevent the same school from receiving both shields in the same year, so the Handicap Shield was awarded to the runner-up, Kapunda.

A. Thomas of Burra broke to 440 yards record.

In the Intermediate Girls’ 220 yards H. Angel broke the record.

Aggregate Scores

[Other results were published later.]

Burra Town Council Elections

When nominations closed the only nominations received was that of R. J. Jeffery for North Ward.

A Supplementary Election will therefore be called for Mayor and Councillors for East and West Wards.

Nominations close 31 May.

Burra Burra DC Elections

Nominations

Hanson Ward S.T. Miller

Baldina Ward M.T. Kellock

Mt Bryan Ward G.H. Cockrum

Booborowie Ward H.B. Quinn

All were duly elected unopposed.

Mokota Cricket Association held a celebration dinner at Booborowie Hall Supper Room last Wednesday night to bring a successful season to a close.

Burra Memorial Oval Appeal reaches £67-12-0.

Table Tennis. North Eastern Association

Willalo 25 defeated Booborowie 0

Burra Gold defeated Spalding Blue 12

Burra Blue defeated Spalding White 10.

St Joseph’s School, Burra held its sports day on their fine new playground.

Photo of Miss Reever Kotz & Mr David Kellock, winners of a recent Twist Competition at Farrell Flat.

Weather. Good follow-up rains fell over the weekend. Burra recorded 109 points. Falls to the east ranged from 50 to 70 points.

Don Barker, who was with the National Bank in Burra (1956-59) and was an active member of Rural Youth while here, has been a member of the ‘Therry Society’ and of the ‘Adelaide Theatre Group’. He played in the world premier of [Patrick White’s] Season at Sarsaparilla staged recently in Adelaide. He is presently in Sydney for a six week season with the Australian Elizabethan Theatre Trust. He recently got married.

Adelaide Wool Sales. The top district price was 841⁄2d for Kia-Ora. [Other local district prices are printed.]

T.B. Lynch of Burra writes supporting the US Communications Base at Exmouth Gulf and condemning those expressing opposition to it.

Marriage. Kooringa Methodist Church Saturday 4 May. [Photo page 1; description page 8.]

Kevin Ayliffe, second son of Mr & Mrs C.L. Ayliffe of Riverton, married

Lorraine Baulderstone, youngest daughter of Mr & Mrs E.T. Baulderstone of Burra.

Burra High School. Hirschausen Bros. have the contract to improve the front of the school by extending the area of the present courts, resurfacing them and erecting chain wire surrounds.

National Trust

The Mayor Mr E.T. Baulderstone has called a public meeting to consider the formation of a branch of the National Trust in Burra. The guest speaker will be the President in SA Mr Morphett. In the Mayor’s Parlour at the Town Hall on Friday 24 May at 8 p.m.

Burra Burra Hospital has been granted a three year lease by the Burra Burra DC to cultivate the Hanson Park Lands.

86, 20 (3), 21 May 1963, page 6 [This number previously used in 1954 & 1957.]

Weather. Further rains have been general, adding 50 to 60 points in the past week. Burra recorded 60 points. The pastoral country received up to an inch. It is understood that the mail truck was again bogged over the weekend and local firms were unable to truck sheep to the Burra Market on Friday.

86, 21 (3), 28 May 1963, page 1 [This number previously used in 1954 & 1957.]

Hallett CWA Debutante Ball is reported with 1 column of detail, including a photo.

Tennis. Completion of the Aberdeen Tennis Club Easter Tournament.

Mixed Handicap Doubles: Mrs C. Kotz & Mr L. Hopgood.

P. Dinham s/c Royal Military College Duntroon writes in support of Mr T.B. Lynch’s letter – stressing the threat of Communism in the countries to our north and of Indonesia’s eye on Papua New Guinea.

Mr R.G. (Jock) Bernhardt, who is so well known in Burra’s grocery trade, has retired. He was given a retirement dinner at the Sandercock’s home on 15 May when the presentation of a carved wooden standard lamp was made.

Burra Memorial Oval Appeal benefited by only £10-4-6 from the picture show, but got £25-8-0 from the gate at the football on Saturday.

86, 21 (3), 28 May 1963, page 8 [This number previously used in 1954 & 1957.]

Inter-High School Sports were contested recently at Balaklava. [Individual results are printed.]

Fortnightly Dances will be held in the Oddfellows’ Hall at Burra North commencing 1 June. The Twist and Pride of Erin competitions will be held on alternate Saturdays. 3/- admission will aid the St John Ambulance and the Aberdeen Football Club Women’s Auxiliary.

86, 22 (2), 4 June 1963, page 1 [This number previously used in 1954.]

Weather. General rains throughout the district have delivered 2-3 inches in the past week. 242 points were recorded in Burra and 384 for May. World’s End received 331 for May and just over 2 inches for the week. The ground is now wet and rain causes run-off. Porter’s Lagoon was filling strongly on Sunday and all dams in the area are full. Farmers need two or three weeks of fine weather now for weed control and seeding. Star thistles are a problem in fallow and clover is growing rapidly. In sheep fly strike is widespread.

Burra Silo. Work on the new silo at the railway station was begun just after Easter and is progressing satisfactorily.

The Methodist Executive Committee of Laymen, led by H.J.B. Jennison, drew 350 people to the Church Family Dinner to hear about the Circuit Planned Giving Program. Mr E.T. Baulderstone chaired the meeting. Mr S.J. Woollacott told the history of Methodism in the community. Services were held first here in 1847 and few communities in SA could boast almost 120 years of service to the community. Other speakers were H.J.B. Jennison, F.W. Aitken and M.R. Humphrys. The final speaker was Rev. R.S. Jenner.

Cricket. Burra Footballers Cricket Club held a trophy night and annual dinner at the Commercial Hotel last week.

Best Batting Aggregate B. Eberhard

Best Batting Average B. Eberhard

Best Bowling Aggregate J. Semmler

Best Bowling Average B. Taylor

Best All Rounder B. Taylor

Most Catches K. Wall

Best fielder in Grand Final K. Wall

Best Fielder for the Season D. Edwards

Most Improved Junior A. Day

Burra North Red Cross held a Musical Luncheon and trading table. Ninety ladies from the district attended despite the bitterly cold conditions and c. £40 was raised for the Burra Hospital.

Burra Hospital currently has 132,000 gallons of rainwater – all tanks are filled to capacity.

Burra Town Council has taken delivery of a new tractor.

Burra War Memorial Oval Project it to have a ‘Down Every Street Appeal’ on 24 June. The fund presently stands at £103-14-6.

Burra Town Council Supplementary Election

Mayor E.T. Baulderstone

East Ward R.J. Broad

West Ward C.L. Phillips

All were declared elected unopposed.

86, 23 (2), 11 June 1963, page 1 [This number previously used in 1954.]

Burra Camera Club has run competitions recently that have been keenly contested. Merit cards have been awarded to:

R. Sandercock Garden Study

R. Sandercock Outdoor Sport Study

R. Broad Child Study

Rev. R.S. Jenner & Sgt F. McGrath both received Merit cards in the open section.

W.B .Ashby & Sons Ltd of Hallett have bought the reserve grand champion ram from the Sydney Sheep Show 1963 for Ashmore Stud for 3,000 guineas.

National Trust of SA

At a meeting held on 17 May called by the Mayor it was decided to form a branch in Burra. Mr Morphett, Chairman of the National Trust in SA outlined the aims: to preserve land and buildings of outstanding beauty or of architectural, historic or scientific interest and to protect the flora and fauna of SA. The branch will be known as the Burra Burra & District Branch. Elected were: Chairman, A. Tennant; Secretary, Mrs R.B. Pitcher and Treasurer, Miss E. Tiver. [Page 2 adds that the first branch meeting will be in the Mayor’s Parlour on Friday 14 June.]

86, 24 (2), 18 June 1963, page 1 [This number previously used in 1954.]

Adelaide Wool Sales achieved the highest prices for about five years.

Weather. Weekend rain brought falls varying from 22 points at Mt Bryan to 92 at Booborowie. Burra recorded 74. To the east the range was similar with 27 at Braemar and 62 points at Old Koomooloo.

Bob Fricker, of radio station 5AD compered a Variety Show at the Burra Town Hall to aid the Swimming Club and the M & BHA. About £60 was raised.

86, 24 (2), 18 June 1963, page 8 [This number previously used in 1954.]

Obituary. Ben Dunstan of Mt Bryan East died at Burra Hospital 3 June aged 87. He had been President of the Mt Bryan Agricultural Bureau for many years and was a life member. He was also President of the Mt Bryan East Fire Fighting Association; a member of the Oddfellows and Masonic Lodges and of the Liberal and Country League, and was very interested in politics. He was the first scholar (of 7) enrolled at the Mt Bryan East School when it opened in 1885 under the tuition of Mr Whittington. His knowledge of the early days of the district’s settlement was second to none. In his youth he was a keen cricketer. He had charge of the Mt Bryan East Post Office till it closed a few years ago. His wife died in 1957. The only children were Mr Jack Dunstan of Mylor and Mr Hugh Dunstan of Whyte Yarcowie. There is one granddaughter. [Benjamin Hugh Knuckey Dunstan born 28 August 1875 Redruth: died 3 June 1963 Burra, residence Mt Bryan East.]

86, 25 (2), 25 June 1963, page 1 [This number previously used in 1954.]

Miss Australia, Miss Tricia Reschke, will visit Burra on 5 July in conjunction with the entry of Miss Eileen Nelson in the 1963 Miss Australia Quest. Miss Nelson is on the nursing staff at the Burra Hospital.

Burra Pictures. Attendance at the Wednesday pictures has fallen so much that the committee has recommended to the Council that they be discontinued. The present takings of £6-£7 fall about £5 short of running costs.

Photo of Mr Rob Ashby with Ashmore Stud’s new 3,000 guineas Champion Poll Merino Ram at its arrival at Adelaide Airport. [Reported in 86, 23 (2), 11 June 1963, page 1.]

Photo of Mr & Mrs A.D. Radford of ‘Glenora’ at the last Adelaide Wool Sales with Mr R. Toms of Goldsbrough’s.

Golf. Burra’s annual inter-club match against Jamestown resulted in a win to Burra 12 matches to nil with one all square. The Associates were also successful, beating Jamestown 4 to nil.

Burra Associates Open Day was held on Thursday last and was played in ideal conditions after the early morning frost.

Marriage, St Paul’s Anglican Church, Solomontown

Lenore Dawn Grenfell, younger daughter of Mr & Mrs A.W. Grenfell of Solomontown, married

Donald Stewart Irlam, younger son of Mr & Mrs Cyril Irlam of Burra North.

86, 26 (2), 2 July 1963, page 1 [This number previously used in 1954.]

L.W. Gare & Sons of Hallett have sold two selected Poll Hereford bulls to a NSW stud for 200 guineas each.

Burra Memorial Oval Appeal gained £60 from a ‘Down Every Street Appeal’ and now stands at £233-17-0.

The Elephant Race to be run this afternoon at 5.15 p.m. has created much interest. The Memorial Oval Project Committee has organised the event through the courtesy of Ashton’s Circus. The riders will be Messrs L.P. Bence and K. Flaherty.

Rev. Father Laurence Joseph Quinn aged 31 was ordained on Saturday at St Joseph’s in Burra by the Bishop of Pt Pirie, the Most Rev. Dr Bryan Gallagher. It is the first ordination in Burra after 81 years of St Joseph’s existence. About 250 attended the two hour service at 9.30 a.m. and 140 attended a reception afterwards in the RSL Hall. Father Quinn is the second son of Mr & Mrs J.T. Quinn of Mt Bryan. On Sunday Fr Quinn offered his first Mass and Benediction to a congregation of about 320 members of the parish. Before entering the seminary six and a half years ago Father Quinn studied Latin to matriculation standard in one year (instead of the usual four). He was tutored in this by Fr Hughes.

86, 26 (2), 2 July 1963, page 2 [This number previously used in 1954.]

Advt. Goldsbrough, Mort & Co. on instructions from P.B. Byles & Son invite tenders for the purchase of 1,095 acres freehold in the Booborowie District: Sections 467, 468, 483, 484, 485 & 489 Hundred of Ayers disposed as 12 main paddocks with two stone houses etc.

86, 26 (2), 2 July 1963, page 3 [This number previously used in 1954.]

Obituary. A return Thanks Notice reveals the death of Nellie M. Smith.

[Not traced in SA Deaths CD.]

Burra Methodist Church is holding a Mission Week 8-14 July. The aim of the two evangelists Rev. Wedd and Alan Bailey will be to increase the church’s spiritual life and to appeal to those outside the church. The climax will be a rally in the Kooringa Methodist Church on 14 July.

86, 26 (2), 2 July 1963, page 4 [This number previously used in 1954.]

The RAA is withdrawing the last motor cycle outfits from service after 30 years of operation.

Obituary. A Return thanks Notice reveals the death of the mother of Mrs P.D. Ryan.

[Born Ethel Maude Crew 7 November 1899 Wirrabara: died 4 June 1963 Gladstone, residence Burra. She was the wife of Edwin (Ted) Alfred Clifford Bevan.]

86, 27 (2), 9 July 1963, page 1 [This number previously used in 1954.]

Adelaide Wool Sales. The top district price went to G.R. Thomas & Sons of Hogback at 86d.

[Other local district prices are printed.]

Miss Australia, Miss Tricia Reschke, was entertained in Burra on 5 July at a Devonshire Tea at the Kooringa Hotel. She was greeted by the Mayor & Mayoress and congratulated Eileen Nelson for entering this year’s quest.

Obituary. Mrs Frank Jefferies died on Sunday night. [Born Ada Lillian Crossley 29 January 1896 Renmark: died 7 July 1963 Colonel Light Gardens. She was the wife of Frank Milton Jefferies.]

The Burra Memorial Oval Appeal has reached £268-5-5.

The Grand Elephant Race

Messrs Bence and Flaherty raced elephants from Ashton’s Circus down Commercial Street at 5.15 p.m. on Tuesday. The aim was to raise funds for new toilets at the oval. Sahib Bence drew Jahore and Sahib Flaherty drew Jumbo. There was a preliminary canter from Jennison’s Garage to the Post Office, where the race proper began. In the run back to the garage Jumbo looked like an easy winner at first, but Sahib Bence drew big Jahore to the outside and with more courage than control went on to win by four lengths. Sahib Bence’s descent over Jahore’s head and down its trunk was most undignified, but can be excused on the grounds of youthful exuberance and the flush of victory. The collection for the event amounted to £23-12-0.

Weather. Rain for the week fell practically every day and for Burra totalled 205 points. The Burra Creek ran strongly and deposited quite a load of rubbish at the Pig and Whistle Crossing. The Young Street Ford was closed, but a car was caught in the water and came to rest against the concrete pillar of the old footbridge. The occupants of the car climbed to the roof and awaited help. Mr S. Irlam later towed it out of the creek. Mr R. Sandercock’s garage took off in Saturday afternoon’s strong wind. The wind lifted it neatly, leaving Mrs Sandercock’s car standing in the open without damage.

Other falls for the week included 226 points at Mt Bryan, 195 at Booborowie and 317 at Farrell Flat.

Floodwaters from the property of D.H. Adams and properties to the west caused a large volume of water to cross the bitumen road about 150 yards north of Mr Adam’s home on Saturday evening. A large bank of sand and silt was deposited across the road. Mr Adams and Mr Colin Pfitzner hauled a number of cars out with a tractor until Constable P. Logan closed the road. At 9 a.m. Sunday the Council grader cleared the obstruction and the road, though still flooded, was re-opened. Floodwaters also crossed the road from Coghill Creek near the town where two and a half feet of water stopped traffic for many hours. Other district roads have been damaged.

86, 27 (2), 9 July 1963, page 2 [This number previously used in 1954.]

Audie Murphy & Barry Sullivan in Seven Ways from Sundown

Maureen O’Hara & John Forsyth in Everything, but the Truth

Burra High School

The new classroom is now completed and can be used next week if the furniture arrives. The new laboratory has been delayed and requires about three weeks’ work. Hirschausen Bros. have commenced work on the old courts in front of the school. They will be extended and resurfaced and cyclone surrounds added.

Cr Jeffery suggested something be done about the footbridge in Lake Street.

J.G. Carpenter is to be advised that the Council will go ahead with the closure of part of Kangaroo Street.

86, 28 (2), 16 July 1963, page 1 [This number previously used in 1954.]

Burra Show will be on 12 October.

Burra Memorial Oval Fund stands at £300-2-2.

Photo of Miss Eileen Nelson, entrant in the 1963 Miss Australia Quest, with Miss Australia.

Photo of K.R. Phillips, grazier, of ‘The Gums’.

Photo of Mr K. Flaherty on the back of Jumbo.

Belinda Fare writes about a planned horse ride from Gosford NSW to Kellerberrin in WA, starting 14 July and expecting to pass through Burra 25 August. She seeks overnight accommodation en route for two horses and a dog.

Burra Primary School held its Arbor Day on 12 July. Trees were donated by the Town Council. Heavy rain delayed the planting for at least a week. Tenders have been called for the new toilet block on the east side of the school and for fencing off the sports area.

Weather. Burra recorded another 44 points to 9 a.m. yesterday.

86, 28 (2), 16 July 1963, page 2 [This number previously used in 1954.]

Advt. Elder’s will auction the pastoral holding of 318 square miles known as ‘Quondong’ on 3 September, for Gallagher Bros. who are relinquishing their pastoral interests. The property has been held by the family for over 60 years. There is a stone homestead of six rooms etc.

[The description occupies almost 2⁄3 column by 2 columns in width.]

Burra North Red Cross held its AGM 3 July.

Elected: President, Mrs H. Jennison; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames V. Cox & I. Hirschausen; Secretary, Mrs E. Heinrich; Assistant Secretary, Mrs R. Reed and Treasurer, Mrs S. Scroop.

Membership for the year was 39 and average attendance was 14. Through the year their Patroness Mrs [F.M.] Pearce died. In December £40 was donated to the Burra Hospital. £55 was sent to Headquarters for the March Appeal. The group met in the Aberdeen Croquet Hall.

Burra Burra DC

Cr A.D. Radford was elected Chairman for 1963-64.

86, 28 (2), 16 July 1963, page 10 [This number previously used in 1954.]

Burra CWA held its AGM. President Mrs H.L. Riggs welcomed members. A minute’s silence was observed for the late Mrs F.M. Pearce. Elected: President, Mrs H. Riggs; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames H. Jennison & S. Scroop; Secretary, Mrs Ford; Assistant Secretary, Mrs Benger & Treasurer, Miss Tiver.

The Secretary gave the 36th annual report. Membership was 68 with an average attendance of 30. Regrets were expressed concerning the death early in the year of foundation member Mrs A.L. Kellock and also at the death of Mr H. Oates with whom the CWA was happily associated at the film evenings so much enjoyed by all and again most recently at the death of Mrs F.M. Pearce. The debt on the CWA Rest Room has been substantially reduced.

[Details of the year’s work follow and in total the report extends for 11⁄4 columns.]

86, 28 (2), 16 July 1963, page 11 [This number previously used in 1954.]

A blitz began on 15 July on radio and television licences.

86, 29 (3), 23 July 1963, page 1 [This number previously used in 1954 & 1957.]

Burra Town Council

Council intends to reclaim a portion of the cemetery.

For some time now the question of reclaiming a portion of the cemetery has been debated by Council. Although the period of the leases of 99 years has expired on the majority of blocks in the central portion of the cemetery, certain legal questions needed to be checked and permission obtained from the attorney General. This has now been completed and Council is now prepared to clear and reclaim this part of the cemetery. This is required because at the average rate of burials the cemetery will be filled in two or three years. Any person holding a block with an unexpired lease in this area is asked to contact the Town Clerk, Mr Holness – the block numbers to be cleared are listed elsewhere in this paper. As well as making more blocks available, this move will also make the area clean and tidy.

[Page 2 had a list of block numbers involved: 542 to 699, 704 to 753 and 758 to 1,271.]

Football. Inter-Association Match

Northern Areas Association 13.5 defeated North Eastern Association 12.9

Northern Areas has eight teams to choose from and North Eastern has four. Peter Sullivan of Booborowie won the trophy for the North Eastern Association and Peter Kitschke won the trophy for the Northern Areas.

SA Police Band & Mounted Cadre will visit Burra on 7 & 8 December and will aid the Memorial Oval project.

Mt Bryan CWA 17th birthday is reported in 1⁄4 column.

Photo of Elder’s Country Staff Football Team. The Burra representative was John de Vries.

Burra Pictures

The first country release of Sodom and Gomorrah was expected to draw a respectable attendance, but with only about fifty present on Friday and somewhat more on Saturday it is unlikely takings will cover costs.

86, 29 (3), 23 July 1963, page 7 [This number previously used in 1954 & 1957.]

Obituary. Hugh Allan Parker of Spalding died at his home last week aged 91. He was born at Clunes in Victoria and his early days were spent in the northeast of SA driving bullocks and dam-sinking.

[Died 9 July 1963 at Spalding aged 92.]

Burra Homing Club. The race from Belair on Saturday was won by S. Kellaway.

Mt Bryan Hogget Competition was won by Jack Connors. Finals of the North Eastern Hogget Competition were held at Max Rayner’s ‘The Bluff’. The winner was Mr S. Wood of Yarcowie. In the single hogget section the Miller Bros. of Hallett came first.

86, 29 (3), 23 July 1963, page 8 [This number previously used in 1954 & 1957.]

Burra Town Council, 15 July

The Mayor’s allowance for the year was set at £100 and the usual committees were established.

Dr L.G. Miller was appointed Medical Officer of Health to the Local Board of Health for £25 p.a.

Subdivision of Allotment 61 of Section 1 was approved.

The portion of Kangaroo Street required by J.G. Carpenter will be sold to him for £10.

A notice advising the Council’s intention to level and reclaim a portion of Burra Cemetery containing allotments 542-699, 704-753 and 758 to 1,271 is to be inserted into the Burra Record for three consecutive weeks and in the Advertiser for three consecutive Fridays.

Burra Jubilee Benevolent Society held its AGM 16 July in the Mayor’s Parlour. Elected: President, Rev. Drought; Secretary, Mrs H. Jennison and Treasurer, Mr F. Atkin.

In the year the sewing machine was repaired and lent to a family who will make good use of it. A good second hand stove was supplied to one home and a holiday was funded for a young mother who much needed it.

80, 30, 30 July 1963, page 1 [Note the change of volume number.]

Weather. Light showers fell early in the week and then on Sunday a further 50-100 points fell throughout the district. The Burra creek ran strongly and cut roads in several places. Burra 122 points for the week, Mt Bryan 111, Booborowie 132, World’s End 56.

Aberdeen Football Club held a car trial on Sunday: won by Barry Allen and Jim Richards.

80, 30, 30 July 1963, page 2

Notice. Benoco Manufacturing Co. calls for expressions of interest in subscribing capital for expansion. The intention, if interest is sufficient, is to form a private company. [Manufacturers of clothing in the old Burra powerhouse: see 85, 18 (2), 8 May 1962, page 1.]

80, 30, 30 July 1963, page 6

Teachers’ In Service Training. Eighteen teachers from the district spent a day at Burra School on Wednesday 26 July and Thursday 27 July, when the focus was on Physical Education. The sessions were led by Leon Barker, a Physical Education teacher.

Lobethal Harmony Choir of 22 men visited Mt Bryan Hall on Sunday 28 July for an afternoon concert. The hall was filled to capacity.

80, 30, 30 July 1963, page 7

Basketball

‘A’ Grade Burra Grey 31 defeated Spalding 29

Burra Blue 34 defeated Hallett 6

‘B’ Grade Terowie 25 defeated Spalding 23

‘C’ Grade Spalding 20 defeated Burra 16

Burra Homing Club. The race from Tintinara was flown in very rough weather and was won by Stan Kellaway. Only 7 of the 35 birds arrived home in race time.

80, 30, 30 July 1963, Supplement [6 columns – sheet about 2⁄3 usual size.]

Burra Wheat Silo. After difficult work due to cold, wet and windy conditions during construction the concrete gang completed their job last Thursday. Other gangs will now complete the roofing, windows, machinery etc.

M & BHA held its AGM and elected: President, Mrs H. Jennison; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames Odgers & Bannister; Secretary, Mrs McGee; Assistant Secretary, Mrs R. Thamm and Treasurer, Mrs Barry.

The report showed an average attendance at meetings of 12. Clinic attendance was 513 for an average of 43 per month. Many thanks to the CWA for agreeing to sell the M & BHA part of their land on which a temporary Housing trust home will be placed and established as a Clinic Centre and meeting room. To help finance the new room a street stall in April raised £32. [This building later became a private home and was eventually demolished in 2008.]

Burra Bowling Club held its AGM 17 July and elected: Patron, Guy Dollman; President, D. Jacka; Vice-Presidents, Messrs J.B. Topsfield & C. Leslie Phillips; Secretary, Mr Darrell Field, Treasurer, B. Riggs and Greens Manager, W.G. Terry.

Plans for the immediate future include lighting the two northern greens (with cost to be considered) and the lining of the men’s section of the clubhouse with Gyprock. The President reported a very active year in which Burra Gold won the pennant in the Mid North Association and the Blue team were runners-up in the North Eastern association. Associate Members were a tower of strength and donated £250 to the improvement debenture fund and gave great help in the Easter Tournament. Membership was 61 plus 12 night members. The debenture scheme to finance a new toilet block was oversubscribed. General finances are sound.

Burra CWA had Mrs Hallion of Bumbunga, President and Secretary of the Warnes Group, as speaker for its July meeting. She spoke of a recent trip to Alice Springs and Brisbane and of various aspects of the CWA, especially of the opening of the new building at headquarters by Sir Thomas Playford, scheduled for 9 August.

80, 31, 6 Aug. 1963, page 1

Burra Homing Club. The race from Belair was won by S. Kellaway.

SA Stockowners’ Association, Burra Branch held its AGM and elected: President G.S. Hawker, Vice-President, M. de N. Lucas and Secretaries, Messrs A.L. Wright & E. Orchard.

President for the past year, G.S. Hawker, greeted visitors and delivered his report. Mr H. Pick, State President, addressed the meeting on the Wool Promotion Levy. Mr H.G. Brooks, a member of the State Executive, addressed the meeting on the importance of improved wool production.

Burra Choral Society. A trial period of three months to gauge interest in forming such a society is nearing its end and interest has been growing. The fate of the plan will be determined at a meeting at Burra High School next Thursday.

80, 31, 6 Aug. 1963, pages 1 & 7

The Rural Youth Rally at Burra for 1963 opened with a Friday night Ball and there were competitive events on Saturday. On Saturday night the finals for the Upper North Zone in Public speaking and Debating were staged as well as a Mannequin Parade. The Hawker Shield for the club with highest overall points went to Burra. At the Ball Miss Rosemary Blight of Clare was judged Miss Upper North by Miss Glenys O’Brien of Channel 9 and Mr & Mrs L.P. Bence of Burra. Door takings were £176-6-0. [Competition results are on page 7.]

On Sunday there was a combined Church service conducted by Rev. Jenner at the gorge, followed by a barbecue, but the novelty sports had to be cancelled due to rain.

Constable P. Pritchard of Burra has been transferred to Yunta as Officer-in-Charge. In Burra he has been active on sporting committees and teams including football, cricket and bowls.

80, 33, 20 Aug. 1963, page 8

Mid North District Synod of the Methodist Church held at Crystal Brook 6 August, is reported.

Burra Bowling Associates held their AGM. The President reported a successful year in which £317 had been raised and the Associates donated £250 to the Men’s Club plus £50 subscriptions. During the year Associate membership declined to 26. This year two Associates died: May Kellock and Rene Pearce. Burra Gold won the pennant this year. Elected: President, D. Pietsch; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames P. Murphy Jnr & D. Crump; Secretary, E. Mitchell and Treasurer, P. Sandercock.

80, 33 (2), 27 Aug. 1963, page 1 [Second use of No. 33 in this sequence.]

Adelaide-Burra Road Race was run on Saturday in heavy rain and gale force winds. Thirty-seven riders departed Cavan at 10.04 a.m. and took three hours to reach Tarlee and arrived in Burra just after 4 p.m. The time was 5 hours 36 minutes 52 seconds, which was good in the conditions. The winner was Bob Panter of Whyalla. Mayor E.T. Baulderstone presented the prize money to the winner and the place-getters. Next year the race will be from Burra to Adelaide.

Basketball. First Semi-Finals

‘A’ Grade Burra Blue 21 defeated Spalding 7

‘B’ Grade Booborowie 23 defeated Spalding 21 in a play-off

‘C’ Grade Hallett 24 defeated Burra 14

Table Tennis Semi-Finals

Spalding Blue 18 defeated Burra Gold 7

Willalo 21 defeated Hanson 4

Burra Homing Club. Saturday’s race from Belair was won by Stan Kellaway.

Adelaide Freemasons visited Burra & Hallett at the weekend. They attended a Hallett Lodge meeting on Saturday night and toured the Burra Mine on Sunday. Rain caused a proposed barbecue to be cancelled.

80, 33 (2), 27 Aug. 1963, page 5

Burra Town Council, 19 August

Council voted to donate £50 to the Memorial Oval Project.

The Highways & Local Government Department asked for a plan of the proposed Young Street Bridge.

It was resolved that the rate be 46d in the pound, plus a special rate of 4d in the pound.

80, 33 (2), 27 Aug. 1963, page 7

Obituary. Mrs Charles Lomman of Burra died suddenly at her home on 18 August. She was formerly Miss Violet Webber of Mt Bryan East and her father was one of the district’s pioneers.

[Born Violet Preece Webber 12 April 1903 Aberdeen: died 18 August 1963 Clare.]

80, 34, 3 Sep. 1963, page 1

Burra Swimming Pool. On Wednesday the Savings Bank of SA handed over £2,500 of loan money as part payment for the filtration plant and a £2,400 Government subsidy has also been approved.

Miss Valmai Williams will represent Rural Youth from the Upper North Zone Clubs for a Western Australia trip for service to the clubs. It lasts five weeks and will begin on 23 September.

Burra Memorial Oval. The work on a new toilet block will soon begin. The block will be 16 ft x 12 ft ‘with a petitioned entrance’ [sic]. It will be locked except during functions. Donations have reached £357-2-2.

Mr & Mrs McCann of Burra achieved five Firsts and a Second Place when they exhibited their Bulldog pup at the Gawler Show on Saturday.

Accident/Obituary. Robert Douglas Bone (21), bank clerk of Mile End, died almost instantly at Bendigo Station on Sunday [1 September] when his brother Graham John Bone (19), draftsman of Mile End, accidentally discharged a rifle and hit the deceased in the stomach. They were setting up a photograph for a mock hold-up scene using a delayed action setting on the camera when the accident occurred. Dr L.G. Miller of Burra and the Burra ambulance attended. Police are investigating.

Burra High School took part in a lightning sports carnival on Thursday at Clare, Riverton and Balaklava. [Results are printed.]

Burra Homing Club. The race on Saturday from Dimboola (Victoria) was won by Stan Kellaway.

Burra Footballers Cricket Club held its AGM last week and elected: Patron, L.A. Beinke; President, R.B. Jennison and Vice President, B. Eberhard. Retiring President Peter Pritchard gave a report on a satisfactory year and was awarded the club’s first Life Membership.

Mokota Cricket Association met on Thursday night and decided to open the season on 19 October.

‘Quondong’ situated approximately 100 miles east of Burra was sold at auction today for £137,000 to the adjoining owners ‘Oakbank Investments Ltd.’

80, 35, 10 Sep. 1963, page 1

Burra Pictures. The committee has decided to close down pictures on Wednesday nights during the 1964 winter – from April to September inclusive. Attendance does not justify continuing.

Football. Barry Eberhard has won the Record Trophy for 1963. In the contest for the Mail Medal Don Villis of Burra was the winner.

The Burra North Dance organised by the Women’s Auxiliaries of the Aberdeen Football Club and the St John’s Ambulance Brigade was successfully held at the Oddfellows’ Hall on Friday night. Door takings were £38. In the Pride of Erin contest the winners were Miss Marie Nourse and Mr A. Quirke of Clare, while the Twist Contest winners were Mrs & Mrs Gordon Wooton.

Burra Homing Club. The race from Tailem Bend was won by Stan Kellaway; making it eight in a row.

80, 35, 10 Sep. 1963, page 8

Burra Hospital. 86th Annual Report of the Chairman to 30 June 1963.

The hospital is in a sound financial position.

The overdraft has been reduced from £5,369 at 30 June 1960 to the present figure of £2,292. There is £2,595 in our Maintenance Reserve and £3,019 in the Donations Account and £418 in the Building Fund. The year’s operations had a surplus of £1,791. The improvement has been due to a greater number of patients and an increase in the number of patients in a Hospital Benefits Fund, which has greatly reduced bad debts. The Board has plans to build four new private rooms, a duty room and a secretary’s office. A master plan for future improvements is being worked out. Daily patient numbers rose from average 10.1 in 1962-63 to 14.9. [Sic: but presumably this must be to 14.9 in 1962-63.] Outpatients rose from 430 to 454. Births fell to 59.

[Acknowledgement was given to the Women’s Auxiliary and the Fund Raising Committee.]

Last year the cropping program raised £583. Seasonal conditions have not permitted any seeding this year. Improvements this year have been new cupboards, a new electric bell system, new mattresses, blankets and chairs and a range of new fittings and furnishings. The surrounds were also improved. Matron Fyfe and Secretary H.L. Foote continue to offer excellent and efficient service, as do the rest of the staff. Over 900 polio injections were given in the year.

80, 36, 17 Sep. 1963, MISSING

Andrew Tennant writes as President of the National Trust in Burra about their attempt to set up a Historical Museum. He makes an appeal for historic records and relics. They are presently negotiating to buy a suitable building.

Burra Races were held on Wednesday in perfect weather and receipts were up, with an expected profit of about £180. The crowd was estimated at 1,000 and the gate takings were £244. The Burra CWA again catered for lunch and afternoon tea. The racing was good. [Results are printed on page 6.]

Beverley Collins Christine Finch Graham Benger

Herbert Fridd Rosemary Jenner Geoffrey Collins

Heather Lloyd Mary McGrath Cynthia Oates

[Results of earlier years in the course are printed.]

Photos

E.W. Dunhill

Andrew King & Heather Bellman at Chamberlain Field Day at Saddleworth.

Mr E.W. Dunhill (89) has completed 72 years of service as a lay preacher – a record unequalled in the Methodist Church in Australia. Mr Dunhill was born at Kersbrook in SA and in his early life went to WA. He married there in 1908 and returned to SA in 1909, taking up residence in Burra in 1915. He carried on business as a blacksmith for 65 years until he was 83. He took his first church service at the age of 16 years 11 months. He was the first person in Australia to hold a certificate recognising 60 years service as a lay preacher. He was also active in Sunday school work for many years and was Sunday School Superintendent for 37 years.

85, 39 (4), 8 Oct. 1963, pages 1 & 8[Number used before in 1955 (twice) & 1962.]

85, 39 (4), 8 Oct. 1963, page 4 [Number used before in 1955 (twice) & 1962.]

Football. The voting of umpires for the 1963 season in the North Eastern Association is printed.

Burra & District Swimming Club. The President’s Annual Report by E. Orchard reveals a very successful season for 1962-63. Burra retained the Eric Tilbrook Shield. The annual club carnival in February attracted record entries. Vacation Swimming Classes were very popular. With the need to install filtration plant fees were raised and takings for the year reached £485. There is a credit balance of £500. Arrangements for a £2,500 loan have been completed through the efforts of the Town Council and a pound for pound subsidy has been arranged with the SA Government Tourist Bureau. Contractors should start work within two weeks and be finished by the start of the 1963-64 season. During the year Secretary David Clarkson was transferred to Eudunda and was replaced by Mr Roger Jenkins.

85, 39 (4), 8 Oct. 1963, page 6 [Number used before in 1955 (twice) & 1962.]

J. Carpenter writes asking for support for the TPI Badge Day on 11 October. Their main project currently is building fourteen additional flats for the aged at the rear of their club rooms in Davaar Place Adelaide, at a cost of £50,000.

85, 39 (4), 8 Oct. 1963, page 7 [Number used before in 1955 (twice) & 1962.]

Burra-Clare Rifle Club. In the first round of No. 4 Rifle Union Teams Championship at Clare on 5 October Burra-Clare 628 defeated Hamley Bridge 616.

85, 40 (3), 15 Oct. 1963, pages 1 & 4 [Number used before in 1955 & 1962.]

Burra Show

There were a record number of entries at 2,600 and the show was a great success despite the day starting out with light showers and a cold south-easterly wind. Conditions improved later. The gate takings were £190 and about 2,800 attended. The Central Command Band attended and was much appreciated. The British Trade Commissioner visited and was impressed by the standard generally and by that of the cooking in particular.

The Flower Section was outstanding this year.

Horses in Action were the centre of keen competition and of much interest; as usual.

Sideshows were better this year with several tents new to the area. The small merry-go-round was popular with tiny tots and the bucking horses with the older ones.

Rural Youth Club had a very original collection of noxious weeds.

Industrial displays may have been down in numbers, but were comprehensive and up-to-date.

President Mr Rex Warnes welcomed visitors and the Band and called on Brigadier W.W. Wearne to open the show.

Results for Art & Photography, Birds, Cattle, Cookery & Dogs are printed, with the other sections to follow in the next issue.

85, 40 (3), 15 Oct. 1963, pages 1 & 5 [Number used before in 1955 & 1962.]

Burra Golf Associates held their AGM and elected: President, Mrs R. Pearse; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames D. Field & T. Padbury; Secretary, Mrs R. Jeffery; Assistant Secretary, Mrs E. Jeffery; Treasurer, Mrs R. Mueller; Captain & Handicap Manager, Miss E. Tiver and Vice-Captain, Mrs M. Nicholls.

The annual report showed 35 members including social members. The open day on 20 June was held under ideal conditions and entries exceeded expectations. The project for this season was to raise money for a change room and this was completed and ready for the Men’s Open Day. Associates donated £100 towards this. In Pennant matches with Clare and Blyth, Clare was victorious. Club champions for the year:

‘A’ Grade Miss E. Tiver

‘B’ Grade Miss R. Mueller

‘C’ Grade Mrs Bob Gebhardt

85, 40 (3), 15 Oct. 1963, page 6 [Number used before in 1955 & 1962.]

Albert Sampson writes from Mosman Park WA mentioning some former Burraites now in WA.

At Esperance: Clem Sampson, Ron Sampson & Harold Pearce.

At Kalgoorlie: Cliff Lee, son of Mr & Mrs Bill Lee.

At Arthur River: ‘Zac’ Humphrys, stepson of the late Tod Sandland.

At Kulicup: Ralton and Tom Wardle.

At Korredocking in the northern wheat belt: Bill Woollacott (General Store).

At Fremantle: Albert Sampson has his hairdressing & tobacconist business.

He included an article from the Westralian on his brother, Ron Sampson, who moved to 2,500 acres at Dalyup, 25 miles west of Esperance in 1952 and became a pioneer farmer. Though he started with no experience he now has a property carrying 600 cattle and 2,200 sheep and has built a second house for a son-in-law.

[Details in 11⁄4 columns.]

Les Phillips bowling at Holdfast Bay.

Architects’ sketch of the proposed new building at Burra Hospital.

85, 42 (3), 29 Oct. 1963, pages 1 & 4 [Number used before in 1955 & 1962.]

Burra Hospital

Plans for a new private room wing have been drawn up and examined by the Board last week. The plans are for four private rooms, matron’s office and a secretary-manager’s office. The building would make the hospital more compact and easier to run. The cost of the new proposal is estimated at £15,000. Government subsidy is available on a two for one basis and an appeal has been launched to raise the £5,000 needed. It would be a continuation of the present Women’s Ward, extending out and beyond the men’s yard, with a verandah. It would have an entrance hall between it and the Women’s Ward. It would harmonise aesthetically with the Women’s Ward and would improve the overall ‘semmetry’ [sic] of the hospital with a balanced frontage and common entrance for visitors.

Donations to date: £372-10-0.

The Masonic Lodge installed Bro. J.W. Riggs as Worshipful Master of the Kooringa Masonic Lodge on Wednesday 23 October. A ball followed in Burra Town Hall.

Weather. After a dry period a light, but useful fall of 55 points has been appreciated. Falls varied considerably across the district with 71 points at Hallett and 120 at Booborowie. Mongolata are reports 40-50 points.

J. Carpenter writes to thank Burra donors for £80-12-0 from the TPI Badge Day.

Porter’s Lagoon. Boating enthusiasts from Clare and Burra Districts have combined with Burra Demobilised Soldiers Association and the previous Porter’s Lagoon Committee to form a club to be known as the Porter’s Lagoon Project. President Mr Max Hilton of Hilltown, Secretary, Mr D.K. Springbett of Clare. They have leased the north shore area and have plans for new change rooms, showers and toilets etc. Functions will be held to raise money. The first will be a carnival by the Adelaide Outboard Club with 11 events next Saturday and Sunday.

Cricket. Mokota Association has arranged for a number of matches through the season to help foster junior cricket. Starting on 9 November, six teams will take part. Teams will comprise Primary School boys and First Year High School boys.

Morgan-Whyalla Pipeline Duplication. Sir Thomas Playford said recently in Parliament that in 1963-64 some 36 miles of pipe will be laid and the 100 million gallon reservoir at Lincoln Gap will be completed. By the end of 1964 it is anticipated 83 miles will be laid.

85, 46 (3), 3 Dec. 1963, page 1 [Number used before in 1962.] Numbering uncertain

Burra Hospital Appeal reaches £4,276-13-2.

F. Dainty & Bill Hobba were struck in the face by an explosion of gas on Sunday Afternoon while checking a refrigerator unit. After examination in Adelaide by a specialist both are now recovering in the Burra Hospital.

The Gala Sports Day will be opened by Inspector S.N. Smith, Officer in Charge of the Far Northern Police Division.

Burra Youth Club. This recently formed club now numbers 137. Friday’s meeting heard a First Aid talk by Mr R. Thamm, using an amplifier supplied by Gerald Baulderstone. On Sunday there was a 25 mile cycling tour. Arrangements are in hand for a week’s camp at the Gorge from 5 January.

Adelaide Wool Sales are reported and local district prices are printed.

85, 46 (3), 3 Dec. 1963, pages 1 & 5 [Number used before in 1962.] Numbering uncertain

Elaine Broderick of Burra Primary School won the Local government Essay Competition on How Do Councils Safeguard Our Health? The winning essay is printed.

85, 46 (3), 3 Dec. 1963, page 4 [Number used before in 1962.] Numbering uncertain

Gala Day at Burra North

On Saturday 30 November a Children’s Fancy Dress Frolic was held at the Memorial Hall Burra North.

[Results are printed.]

At 6 p.m. a delicious tea was served and in the evening a concert was presented by the Burra & District Choral Society with Mrs Evehback & Mrs Tucker from Blackwood. The Choral society was led by Mr R. Mueller with Mrs J. Oates as pianist. There was a clear £87 profit, which will aid the Freedom From Hunger Campaign.

85, 46 (3), 3 Dec. 1963, pages 4 & 5 [Number used before in 1962.] Numbering uncertain

Burra Town Council

The report on reclaiming the cemetery was held over to the next meeting.

It was resolved that the old rockery and island opposite the [Burra] Hotel is to be planted with roses at the right season.

85, 46 (3), 3 Dec. 1963, page 5 [Number used before in 1962.] Numbering uncertain

Burra Small Bore Club. Best scorers in the 75 yards shoot were M. Thomas, K. Spackman and R. Gilbert.

85, 46 (3), 3 Dec. 1963, page 6 [Number used before in 1962.] Numbering uncertain

Bowls

Burra Green 103 defeated Clare Red 84

Burra Gold 111 defeated Auburn 93

Burra Blue 96 defeated Hallett White 88

85, 46 (3), 3 Dec. 1963, page 7 [Number used before in 1962.] Numbering uncertain

St Mary’s Church was packed on Sunday for services conducted by Bishop the Rt Rev. Donald Redding, who had been Rector in Burra from 1933-39. The service began with the dedication of two new stained glass windows given by Lady Swift and Mr Andrew Tennant in memory of their mother the late Mrs Margaret Barr Tennant. Those windows are in the church porch. Sir Brian Swift and his daughter Mrs Andrew Tennant and Mr & Mrs John Barker were the donors of windows in the porch. Mr Andrew Tennant unveiled the windows as the Bishop dedicated them. The service continued after all had returned to their seats and twenty-four candidates from Burra, Booborowie, Mt Bryan, Hallett and Farrell Flat were confirmed. A splendid supper in the church hall allowed many old acquaintances to be renewed with the Bishop. The portion in red needs clarification

Burra-Clare Rifle Club. On Sunday Adelaide 573 defeated Burra-Clare 570 at Clare.

Tennis

‘A’ Grade Spalding Blue 14-105 defeated Willalo 6-64

Spalding 12-98 defeated Kooringa 8-83

85, 46 (3), 3 Dec. 1963, page 8 [Number used before in 1962.] Numbering uncertain

Hallett CWA International Day is reported. The country for 1963 was Thailand and the speaker was Miss D. Parker, State International Secretary.

Cricket. Mokota Association

Junior Cricket

85, 49 (2), 10 Dec. 1963, page 1 [Number used before in 1962.]

M & BHA reported at a meeting on 2 December that the temporary Trust House had arrived and had been erected on the site next to the CWA Rooms. After renovations it will be used as a clinic.

The Town Hall Project Fund has reached £500.

Carols by Candlelight will be held at Burra for the first time at the War Memorial Oval on 22 December. The assistance of the Burra Choral Society has been enlisted. Proceeds will aid the Freedom From Hunger Campaign.

Burra Hospital Building Appeal reaches £4,700-14-2.

Tennis. ‘B’ Grade: Booborowie 11-86 defeated Leighton Gold 9-70.

Burra Kindergarten has come near the top of the list for affiliation with the Kindergarten Union following a most generous lease arrangement granted by the RAAF Association for their premises, which conform without alteration to the standard required. A grounds committee under Mr Gordon Nourse will set to work on the site.

85, 49 (2), 10 Dec. 1963, pages 1 & 4 [Number used before in 1962.]

Gala Weekend

The Police Band provided music at the Town Hall on Friday night for the Gala Ball. There was an abundant supper and door takings amounted to £82. On Saturday Mr R.V. Mueller marshalled the procession, which was led by the Police Greys and the Police Band. Amusing and ingenious floats followed with cycles and fancy dress etc. [Entries are listed.] At the oval the Mayor E.T. Baulderstone welcomed everyone and introduced Inspector S.N. Smith to open the event. There were displays by the Police Vaulting Team and Police horses. Races were run for children and there were other events. Results of the fancy dress section are printed.

The Police Concert in the Town Hall that evening drew a capacity crowd and on the following morning their appearance at the Hospital was much appreciated, after which the Mayor entertained them at a barbecue luncheon. £220 was raised for the Town Oval by the weekend.

85, 49 (2), 10 Dec. 1963, page 3 [Number used before in 1962.]

Burra Hospital Building Appeal reaches £5,056-14-11

Burra Memorial Oval Project Appeal

The committee on Thursday wound up its affairs when accounts totalling £458 were passed for payment and the balance of funds of £278 will be handed to the War Memorial Committee.

Mr Norman H. Tosh JP has donated a handsome trophy to be allotted to the Sportsman of the Year in Burra District. It will be decided at the end of the next football season.

Burra Youth Club will have a hayride on 20 December with carol singing in chosen locations.

Elder, Smith & Goldsbrough, Mort will merge on 1 January 1964 and will operate in SA as Elder Smith Goldsbrough Mort Ltd. [Details of managers and organisation are printed.]

Carols by Candlelight

Mr Dick Moore, organiser of Adelaide Carols Evening has arranged for Mr Charles Norton to act as compere at Burra. Those attending are asked to park as usual around the oval and then move onto the oval with a rug or ground sheet.

85, 50 (2), 17 Dec. 1963, page 4 [Number used before in 1962.]

Photo. John Bailey, candidate for LCL endorsement for Northern District in the Legislative Council.

Mr Barney Rogers suffered burns to the face and arms when the spray nozzle of a blow lamp he was using broke off, spraying him with burning kerosene. He extinguished the fire by rolling in a piece of cocoanut matting and was treated at Burra Hospital by Dr Pitcher.

85, 50 (2), 17 Dec. 1963, page 5 [Number used before in 1962.]

Burra RSL held its Annual Dinner and about 60 members attended on 7 December. The spread was prepared as usual by the ladies of the Auxiliary. Mr Eric Smith, Deputy State President was the speaker for the evening.

Miss B. Preiss will be 93 on Thursday.

Characteristics of the paper for 1963

This year was something of a mixed bag. Sometimes it seems reasonably comprehensive, but at other times it is rather thin on local news. Almost all the news is carried on page 1 except for sports results, which dominate the rest of the paper. Pictures appear regularly, but as the blocks were not made locally, the pictures are at least a week later than the events.

Page 1

News: ranging from Hallett-Terowie to Tiverton-Tarlee.

Pages 2 & 3

Smaller advertisements dominate – sales, public notices, coming events, entertainment, films, tenders and smaller business advertisements.

Pages 4-8

Dominated by larger advertisements – mostly local.

News is dominated by sports and occupies perhaps two of the seven columns.

Somewhere in the mix, but wandering from page to page, is a ‘Cash Column’ of small advertisements similar to classified ads.

Note: The volume numbers are chaotic.

Volume 86 runs from 8 January to 26 February

The issue on 5 March is Volume 37

Volume 86 then continues from 12 March to 23 July

It is followed by Volume 80 from 30 July to 1 October

Volume 85 runs from 8 October to the end of the year.

This in turn creates chaos with the numbering of issues.

86, 1 (2), 7 Jan. 1964, page 1 [Number used before in 1963.]

86, 1 (2), 7 Jan. 1964, page 1 [Number used before in 1963.]

Burra Carols by Candlelight raised £120 for Freedom From Hunger. It was held at the War Memorial Oval on 22 December. Attendance was c. 750. 5AD Radio compere Charles Norton was MC and R.V. Mueller led the Burra & District Choral Society. After 9.30 p.m. gusty winds and a few spots of rain slightly marred the otherwise very successful occasion. The Mayor Mr Baulderstone donated the soft drinks’ profit to the cause and he also delivered his Christmas message. Mrs Odgers of the Catholic Church suggested the idea and the Methodist and Anglican Churches eagerly responded. Father Hughes, Rector Drought and Rev. Jenner worked together on the planning committee. The Mayor made the point that this coming together of Catholic and Protestant effort was a significant point in the town’s history. The combined choir had been practising for some weeks under the High School Headmaster Mr Mueller.

Mr E.T. Baulderstone has a bumper crop of onions this year in his Quarry Street garden. On an area of just less than a square chain he produced three tons, equivalent to 30 tons per acre, when 20 tons per acre is considered a good rate.

Burra Hospital Building Appeal has reached £5,182-13-8.

Burra Youth Club camp at the Gorge on Sunday had to cope with a temperature of 108°F and a similar temperature was reached on Monday.

Weather. The year ended with only 115 points for the last three months, to make it the driest final quarter for 75 years.

Photo. SA Police Band and Mounted Cadre in a procession in Commercial Street to Memorial Oval on 6 December for Sports Day to raise funds for a new toilet block and to turf the oval.

86, 1 (2), 7 Jan. 1964, pages 1, 3, 4 & 8 [Number used before in 1963.]

Burra High School held its Speech Night in the Burra Town Hall on 17 December. Headmaster R. Mueller delivered his annual report.

The enrolment in January was 151, up 7 on 1962. First Year numbers were lower, but retention was better in the upper years. First Year 53, Second Year 56, Intermediate 26 and Leaving 16. In 1965 c. 170 are expected – an increase due to an anticipated increase in Intermediate to 40. Numbers are expected to plateau briefly and then decline slightly in 1966. In 1963 Mr J. Sladden and Mr R. Hillman were transferred and in 1964 Mr T. O’Connor came from Salisbury High and Mr J. Ayliffe and Miss M. Callier came from Teachers’ College. Mr W. Standing and Miss B. Hogan were appointed Junior Teachers. During the year Mrs Bogisch resigned and was replaced by Mrs Aistrope from Riverton to handle Home Science. At the end of this year Miss Lawes and Mr McElroy will be transferred and Junior Teachers Barbara Hogan and Bill Standing will attend Teachers’ College in 1964.

Rev. Jenner and his wife are also leaving and we thank them for taking 90 students each week for Religious Instruction. Rector Drought and Father Hughes are also thanked.

The High School Council has kept the machinery going without having a particularly busy year.

The Parents & Friends’ Association continues to be efficiently run and the completion of the sports area in front of the school is the culmination of one of their major projects.

In sports the outstanding event of the year was the winning of the Open Shield (the Ohlmeyer Shield) at the Mid North Combined High schools Sports Day. Burra also got the highest points for the Handicap Shield, but the rules prevent the holding of both shields in the same year.

A school excursion of over 300 miles was in part a reward for this effort. Places visited included Para and Warren Reservoirs, Mt Crawford Pine Forest, Mannum, Murray Bridge and Mt Lofty.

In February the whole school travelled by train to see the Queen and the Duke of Edinburgh. Other successful occasions were the Annual Swimming Carnival, Sports Day, Prefects’ Induction, Arbor Day and Visiting Day.

The Intermediate and Leaving classes travelled to Adelaide and Clare to see performances of plays they were studying. Leaving Teaching Scholarships were awarded to:

Peter Benger Barry Carpenter Kerry Costello

Raelene Hirschausen Claire Kellock Margaret Murphy

Pam Zanker

For the second year the school magazine has been printed out of the school.

In 1962 134 subjects were passed in the Intermediate. (The highest number previously had been 111.) Leaving passes were the second highest ever. Keith Neill had the best Leaving results with six subjects and Barbara Hogan with five. In Intermediate Peter Benger passed 8 subjects and was awarded the A.B .Riggs Prize and Patricia Ryan passed seven subjects.

[Mr Mueller then went on to discuss the non-Publicly Examined Subjects to be offered in 2nd and 3rd Year and their internal assessment. He thought the Intermediate would fall into disuse with the new Leaving and Matriculation Exams to come into operation from 1966.]

Burra is not going to have these new courses in 1964, but will do so in the next few years.

In 1958 the enrolment was 70 and next year we expect 170. This has meant a number of new buildings. In the last year a modern laboratory and a classroom were added. There are now six classrooms, Home Science and Woodwork Centres, a Science Laboratory, a Typing room and an assembly hall. The old laboratory will soon be converted to a staff room. The area around the new rooms is yet to be paved. The toilets have been enlarged and improved. The old tennis courts have been extended, resurfaced and fenced this year. A fence was also erected around the lawn and 80ft of seating was provided. The school now has four basketball courts instead of one, four tennis courts instead of two and two new practice cricket pitches. The graded area has been sown and watered and has greatly improved facilities for athletics training, softball and football in the future.

New buses have been provided for the students. The increase in numbers has seen the appointment of more specialist teachers and a sound range of subjects and Leaving subjects no longer have to be combined with other classes as in the past.

[The Prize List and Exam Results are printed.]

Burra Town Council, 16 December 1963

Council resolved to go ahead with levelling and clearing the old part of the cemetery according to the prepared plan.

The donation of the resuscitation unit [from BP Australia Ltd] was accepted with gratitude.

Crs Cornelius and Phillips moved and seconded that the 1914-19 Honour Roll be stored at the RSL Club Rooms. Carried.

Resolved that the disposal of Council relics be left in the hands of the Mayor.

Aberdeen Basketball Club held a successful New Year’s Eve Ball in the Oddfellows’ Hall with dancing to 1 a.m.

86, 2 (2), 14 Jan. 1964, page 1 [Number used before in 1963.]

Burra Mine. The SA Government survey has found encouraging signs in its search for copper at the Burra Mine and has decided to spend a further £8,000 in addition to the £10,000 already spent. The bore is down to 812 ft and will now be taken further. Drilling is difficult as the bore has to be cased. Polarisation techniques have indicated three anomalies worth further investigation.

Wool. A price war has begun between synthetic fibres and wool, with makers of ‘Terylene’ cutting prices significantly. This threatens wool prices.

W. Young has decided to end his services on the World’s End School Bus run after 81⁄2 years. We understand Mr W. Robinson will take over the service.

The Methodist Church

Rev. R.S. & Mrs Jenner have been transferred to Kapunda.

Rev. & Mrs Lind come to Burra, having previously had circuits at Largs Bay and Whyalla. The Linds have one daughter, Katrina, aged 18 months.

Rev. L. Kelsall has gone from Hallett to Salisbury and will be replaced by Rev. A.M. Houston and family from Pt Pirie.

Fire. Lightning started a fire at Hallett on Tuesday last. It burnt out 250 acres of scrub and grass.

Burra Hospital Building Fund stands at £5,297-13-8.

Ray Jennison & Ron Wuttke were fishing off Wallaroo on Sunday and tried to catch a 10-12 ft shark they had spotted. It took the bait, but in doing so revealed itself as about 20 ft in length and of immense girth. They were relieved when it spat the hook out and they lost no time in hauling in the line and heading for shore in their 17 ft boat.

Burra Roads to be Sealed:

Justice Lane (presently being re-formed.)

Ayre St [sic] from Kooringa Hotel to the bend east of the cemetery.

The Morgan Road from Kooringa Hotel to H. White’s.

Redruth Road from the Bridge to Tiver’s. [Ludgvan St from Redruth Bridge east to the entrance to Abberton Park.]

Swimming. The Learn to Swim Campaign in Burra had an enrolment of 173 for classes from 6 January to 17 January. 72 learned to swim ten yards. These are listed and so are those gaining Beginners’ Certificates, Progress Certificates, Junior Certificates, Senior Certificates, Safe Swimmer Awards, Intermediate Star and the Bronze Medallion.

Burra racing Club Ltd re-elected its committee with only one change.

Photographs

Two photos of the demolition of the old Burra Mill known as Roach’s or Thomas’s. The ruin was owned by A.W. Baker and demolition was carried out by M.E. Mitchell of Burra North.

Burra RSL held its AGM on 17 January. Elected: President, H. Cornelius; Vice-Presidents, T. Rogers and B. Riggs; Secretary, J.T. Murphy and Treasurer, B. Kotz.

[Burra-Clare?] Rifle Club. The first trophy shoot for the year over the 600 yards range saw best scores from B. Blatchford, W. Jenkins and T. Dixon.
