Burra Small Bore Club. Over double 50 yards the best scorers were M. Alderson, R. Angel and R. Gilbert.

86, 4 (2), 28 Jan. 1964, page 1 [Number used before in 1963.]

Burra Silos

The new wheat silo at Burra Railway Station took its first grain on 9 December 1963 and filled within seven days. Heavy intakes began on 13 December and by the 20th the capacity of 100,000 bushels had been reached. [Daily intake figures are printed.] Since then there has been direct loading via the conveyor to the rail trucks, which elevates the grain at 70 tons per hour. Trucks carrying 40 tons can be loaded in 15 minutes. [This doesn’t seem to conform to the rate cited.] Inferior wheat still has to be bagged and stacked. With silos filled throughout the country there is not the storage space to separate hard and FAQ wheat and this will cost growers 3d to 4d per bushel on their hard wheat. At Burra only 12,000 bushels have been able to be taken and trucked directly as hard wheat, with the rest taken as FAQ. Wheat came first from the early harvest areas of Peterborough, Yarcowie and beyond Spalding and this meant that some Burra District wheat had to go to silos at Farrell Flat, Saddleworth, or even Wallaroo and Adelaide. The Burra silo has taken 200,000 bushels so far this season, with some 20,000 still to come. Photo of loading wheat into a railway truck.

Photographs.

Three photos from the Burra Learn to Swim Campaign. Two show the pool, but are mirror images, with St Mary’s shown to the south of the pool.

Bowls. The tournament aided the Hospital Building Fund by £39-12-0.

Burra Pictures. Regular Wednesday night screenings will cease after tomorrow night’s pictures. The special final screening will feature twenty selected cartoons for the children, prior to their return to school next week.

Rev. D.G. Haydon, formerly at Burra for the Methodist Church, has since completed a BA and this past year passed five subjects to complete the first part of a Bachelor of Divinity. He has achieved all this while being a Circuit Minister and Chairman of the District.

86, 4 (2), 28 Jan. 1964, page 3 [Number used before in 1963.]

86, 4 (2), 28 Jan. 1964, page 6 [Number used before in 1963.]

Accident/Obituary. Wayne Raymond Jones of Hallett aged 16 was accidentally shot on Sunday when a .22 rifle was discharged on a shooting expedition on the Collinsville Road. Four youths were homeward bound when two rifles resting against the front seat fell over when the car stopped. One discharged as a passenger picked it up. The deceased was the son of Mr & Mrs Ray Jones.

Burra Small Bore Club. Over a double 75 yards shoot the best scorers were Ray Alderson, Mike Thomas and R. Gilbert.

86, 5 (2), 4 Feb. 1964, page 1 [Number used before in 1963.]

Adelaide Wool Sales 28-29 January. Top district price was 921⁄2d obtained by S.J. Woollacott of Burra North.

[Other local district prices are printed.]

Burra Hospital Building Fund Appeal stands at £5,509-7-3.

Women’s World Day of Prayer began 78 years ago and this year’s service in Burra will be held on the 14 February at 7.30 p.m. in St Mary’s Parish Hall.

Football. The North Eastern League will have new team boundaries this season.

Weather. Temperatures have been over 100°F for most of the past week. Many residents are running out of rain water.

Sgt F. McGrath of Burra Police will move to Enfield on 26 February. Sgt W. Teague will come to Burra from Milang. Mr McGrath has been on the High School Council and has been an active member of the Camera Club.

A storm on Saturday evening blew iron from the tennis shed across the bowling green, chopping holes in the green. One light was blown down. Damage was soon repaired.

86, 5 (2), 4 Feb. 1964, page 6 [Number used before in 1963.]

Rev. & Mrs Lind were welcomed at the Methodist Church last Sunday.

86, 5 (2), 4 Feb. 1964, page 8 [Number used before in 1963.]

Burra Town Council, 28 January

Aberdeen Tennis Club was permitted to play competitive tennis on Easter Sunday.

J.L. Allen & Son were permitted to install a dual petrol pump at Burra North.

86, 6 (2), 11 Feb. 1964, page 1 [Number used before in 1963.]

Burra High School had an opening enrolment of 185; up 34 on 1963. First Year 68, Second Year 56, Intermediate 43 and Leaving 19.

New staff: Messrs R. Wright, I. Norton & E. John and Miss L. Briggs.

Head Prefects are Helen Phelps and Kerry Costello.

[New enrolments are listed, as are Prefects and House Captains.]

Weather. A severe storm struck Burra last Wednesday afternoon and deposited up to an inch of rain in fifteen minutes. Most shopkeepers suffered some stock damage when gutters failed to cope with the flow, but little water entered tanks, as most was lost over the edge of gutters. Some shops and homes lost roofing iron and many homes suffered damage to floor coverings when water entered houses. The Burra Hospital had water through it and suffered minor damage, though much cleaning up was required. Burra officially recorded 68 points in the storm and 94 points for the day. Some properties recorded up to 150 points.

Lightning caused many fires. Most were extinguished almost at once, but two or three acres were burnt in some places. Across the town reported falls varied from 150 points on the west side to 50 on the east.

Trevor Richardson in his school bus loaded with children was in the midst of it when the storm broke along Johnson’s Creek with hail and flying tree branches. At its peak the bus was being blown along in second gear with its engine off. He had stopped to clear debris from the road. Just after crossing a creek to join the old Adelaide Road a great wall of water came down it. Princess Royal shearing shed lost its verandah, which was carried some 500-600 yards.

Photographs: two photos show Johnson’s Creek area before and after the storm.

In that area dozens of large gum trees were uprooted and smashed to pieces. Others were stripped of every leaf, twig and branch, leaving only the main trunk. The destruction was in a strip along the creek for a mile with another line of it running over the hills towards the homestead and another leading west.

[This would seem to be describing a tornado.]

Burra Swimming Carnival attracted over 350 entries and gate donations reached £35. Spectator numbers were not great. [Results are printed. There were no local winners.]

Football. In the Mid North League it has been decided to amalgamate Saddleworth & Marrabel Clubs.

86, 6 (2), 11 Feb. 1964, pages 1 & 5 [Number used before in 1963.]

Burra Primary School enrolment is 117 boys and 114 girls (231). Miss Langsford, who moved to Elizabeth Downs last July, has returned. [New enrolments are listed.]

[Single-sided: a little more than A4 in size.]

Accidents

On the Black Springs-Robertstown Road – UNREADABLE

Mr W. Rosborough escaped injury when the utility he was driving overturned on the Mt Bryan Road four miles north of Burra on Saturday evening.

Mr & Mrs D. Irlam were admitted to the Clare Hospital on Saturday after the utility they were travelling in hit a heap of rubble used in road works between Farrell Flat and Clare.

86, 7 (2), 18 Feb. 1964 [Number used before in 1963.] MISSING

86, 8 (2), 25 Feb. 1964, page 1 [Number used before in 1963.]

Burra Kindergarten has been operating successfully from late in 1962 and has now decided it needs more suitable accommodation and equipment. The number attending has been about 30. Steps taken so far include the negotiation of a 21-year lease on the Burra Air Force Association rooms in Queen Street, where the kindergarten is now located. Affiliation with the SA Kindergarten Union is being established. Work to meet the Union’s standards is being undertaken. On Thursday collectors will call on families seeking donations towards a £150 appeal fund.

Burra & District Choral Society resumed in the High School Assembly Hall last Thursday evening. Mrs Jack Oates took her place as accompanist.

St John’s Burra Unit met for its AGM in the Town Hall Supper Room on 17 February. Sgt R.L. Thamm hoped more young people would join. Members man the local ambulance.

Burra Burra DC was represented at a conference at Morgan on Friday presenting evidence to Mr Jackman, Commissioner of Highways about the sealing of the Morgan-Burra-Gulnare Road. District Clerk T.G. Perry and Cr H. Cornelius represented the Council.

86, 10 (2), 10 Mar. 1964, page 1 [Number used before in 1963.]

Burra Burra Show Inc. 3 March

It was decided to ask the Governor to open the 1964 show. Elected: Patron, G. Stanley Hawker; President, Rex C. Warnes; Vice-Presidents B.A. Riggs & M. G. Stockman.

Report on the 1963 Show.

Gate takings were £190 and £30 came from a dance organised by Rural Youth in the Show Hall. The show was opened by Brigadier W.W. Wearne OBE, Commander of Central Command and the Central Command Band also attended. Membership has increased slightly. The financial position is sound, but needs watching. It was decided to increase admission charges by 1/-. Secretary Mr Perry resigned during the year and we thank Mr & Mrs Barry Taylor for taking over that role. There were 2,610 entries for the 1963 Show.

Burra High School. Three Leaving students sat for Supplementary Exams and this brings to 13 the number of certificates gained by 14 students and a further certificate was completed. Pam Zanker, who had been awarded an English Q, passed English, Barry Carpenter passed English and Valerie Donhardt passed Modern History. English Qs were awarded to Ray Pietsch & Arnold Lomman, who had both passed six subjects and who now get an Intermediate Certificate.

Pooraka Wool Pty Ltd will open a wool depot in Burra. Mr Dudley Cockington will be appointed to purchase wool, skins, hides (including kangaroo), tallow, beeswax, etc. If receivals warrant a wool cleaning and crushing plant could be installed, which would provide local employment.

[A half-page advertisement on page 3 indicates that the company had acquired the old Power House as a site for their operations.]

Obituary. Dr D. McDonald Steele died recently aged 78. He was the first President of the Burra High School Council. He came to Burra after graduating in 1909 and practised here for over 30 years. He took great interest in the welfare of Burra High School and was President of the High School Council for 26 years. He was also interested in golf, tennis and bowls in Burra. Since retiring to Adelaide he often visited the district in connection with his Koo-owie Stud and it was only last year that he finally relinquished his interest in that property, when it was sold to Barton Hill Proprietors. In 1962 he was to have been a guest speaker at a High School Jubilee function, but was prevented by illness from attending. He did attend the High School speech night in 1962 in December and gave an interesting address. At the recent High School swimming Carnival, at which Steele House won the cup, a minute’s silence was observed. He is survived by a widow and two sons, Dr D.M. Steele of Strathalbyn and Mr J.R. Steele and also by one daughter Mrs George Mollard-Humphrys. He was cremated at Centennial Park after a service at St Matthew’s Church.

[The paper then reprints Dr Steele’s views on education from the History of Burra High School. He was answering a view of a Professor who deplored wasting money educating the masses. Dr Steele said: ‘It might be dangerous to educate the masses, but personally, he felt it right to give the boys and girls every chance, this was a duty parents owed the child and the nation.’]

[David McDonald Steele born 9 January 1886, East Adelaide: died 25 February 1964, Adelaide, residence Tusmore.]

86, 10 (2), 10 Mar. 1964, page 3 [Number used before in 1963.]

86, 11 (2), 17 Mar. 1964 [Number used before in 1963.] MISSING

86, 12 (2), 24 Mar. 1964, page 1 [Number used before in 1963.]

Burra Hospital has installed an oil-fired boiler to supply 270 gallons of hot water per hour for the new laundry and all other requirements. It replaces an inadequate coke boiler at a cost of £1,505 (subsidised on a two for one basis). The old boiler was left in place and so the hospital was without hot water for less than four hours. There is a 500 gallon tank for oil.

Aberdeen Basketball Club held a successful Gala Afternoon on Saturday at the Burra North Playground. Children came in fancy dress and with decorated bikes and prams. Club funds were boosted by c. £73.

Farrell Flat. Several roads in the town have been sealed to reduce dust.

Farrell Flat Golf Club has a successful season even though its open day was virtually washed out.

Adelaide Wool Sales 17-19 March. Wandillah topped local prices with 89d.

[Other local district prices are printed.]

North Eastern Association Champion of Champions Rinks

86, 13 (2), 31 Mar. 1964, page 1 [Number used before in 1963.]

Burra Mine

Officers of the Department of Mines are hampered in their testing and searching at the mine by incomplete records of the old workings and they are seeking any help available. Having used drilling and induced polarisation, they are now using the geochemical method, but are hampered by a lack of factual information in the mine workings below the open cut. If any local or former resident of Burra has any old plans or reports etc. they would be gratefully received. They would particularly like any first hand knowledge of the two diamond drill test holes put down in the vicinity of the open cut in about 1900. One was completed in 1897 and the other early in 1900, but the exact locations are not known. Details from a log book would be valuable. It would be wonderful if findings warranted the opening of operations in the area. Geochemical prospecting relies on the changes in the composition of overlying soils caused by the decay of the bedrock. Soil movement and ground water movement mean the minerals sought are in trace element proportions.

Mr Don Zanker, accountant at the ANZ Bank in Burra for 21⁄2 years, has been transferred to Millicent. He has been active in many areas particularly in the Memorial Oval project. He has also been secretary of the Football Club for two years and of the Lawn Tennis Club and is presently Chairman of the Primary School Committee. He will be replaced by Mr Don Ebsary from Naracoorte, who has been at Burra before, about eight years ago. His wife was formerly Coralie Ellis, who also worked at the Burra branch at that time.

The Highways Department has offered to take over the main roads in the town:

Entrance from Adelaide down Commercial Street

Kingston Street to Mr H. White’s

Market Square [sic: actually Market Street] through to the Racecourse [including Bests Place, Young Street and Watt Road.]

Burra War Memorial Oval Committee has sanctioned spending up to £250 for a bore to supply water to the oval. The high cost of E & WS water has so far limited improvements to the oval. The cost of reticulation etc. would be a later additional charge. A.C. Thomas has offered either free boring for 25 ft of a rebate of £50 – the normal cost of drilling being £2 per foot, including casing.

Burra Small Bore Club. The championship Rounds were completed on Tuesday night. Ross Gilbert won the Championship and the handicap honours went to John Bowden.

86, 13 (2), 31 Mar. 1964, page 2 [Number used before in 1963.]

Mid North Football Association held its AGM on 19 March. There was a long debate over policy, especially when AI and AII clubs differed. Elected: Patron, W.E. Blatchford (President 1945-63), President, L.A. Twarts [sic] (Saddleworth); Senior Vice-President, Stan Noske (Robertstown) and secretary-Treasurer, Arthur Kench (Auburn).

The new Saddleworth-Marrabel United team was admitted. Blyth was admitted to the AII Division.

Obituary. Mr George Terry died suddenly this morning aged 62. He had taken part in the Burra Bowls Tournament over the weekend.

[William George Terry died 31 March 1964 Burra North aged 62. Birth not in SA Births CD]

Obituary. Mrs Tilley, the wife of Mr John Tilley of the staff of Elders-GM, died yesterday aged 26.

[Margaret Tilley died 30 March 1964 Adelaide, residence Burra aged 26.]

Obituary. Mr Alec Nairn of Morgan died in the Waikerie Hospital on Friday aged 55.

[Robert Alexander Nairn died 27 March 1964. Birth not in SA Births CD.]

Obituary. Mr A.G. (Tom) Heinrich of Dutton’s Trough was buried at Point Pass Cemetery on Thursday.

[Anton Gotthelf Heinrich born 16 October 1890 near Burra: died 23 March 1964 North Adelaide, residence Burra.]

86, 13 (2), 31 Mar. 1964, page 4 [Number used before in 1963.]

Burra Town Council, 24 March

Council voted to approve a takeover of the town’s main roads by the Highways Department.

A letter is to be sent to the Police Department expressing concern at the delay in building a new Police Station at Burra: the matter having been investigated several years ago.

The Council will advertise for a part-time typist to assist the Town Clerk.

[The advertisement appeared in the paper of 7 April page 2, for a job 2-5 p.m. Monday to Friday.]

An Aberdeen team was admitted and will field teams in the A Grade, B1 Grade and C2 Grade.

86, 13 (3), 7 Apr. 1964, page 1 [Number used before in 1963 & 1964.]

Trevor Denton of Farrell Flat won the Australian National Kart Championship run at Bolivar last week. In the 1963 Championship, held in Victoria, he was placed third.

North East Combined Schools Sports were held at Hilltown on 4 April.

Shell Northern 300 Car Trial was organised by the Snowtown & District Car Club. Provisional winner is L.L. Fiebig of Burra in a Holden.

Burra Small Bore Club’s Range was the site for the W. Jenkins’ Prize Shoot at the weekend. The winner was W. Jenkins of Clare. Best scorers on Tuesday were P. Mengersen, A. angel and R. Angel.

Weather. The six months ending 31 March were the direst for 31 years. The 273 points were the lowest since 230 in 1932-33. The driest ever was the 1896-97 season with 203 points.

Burra Golf Club held its AGM and elected: President, T. Richardson; Vice-Presidents, R. Wuttke & J. Murray; Secretary, J. Murphy; Treasurer, R. Mueller; Captain, J. Bogisch and Vice-Captain, L. Bence.

86, 13 (3), 7 Apr. 1964, page 2 [Number used before in 1963 & 1964.]

Advt. Dalgety & NZ Loan have instructions from A.G. Blieschke to sell his land three miles south of Hanson. Section 833, Pt Sections 611 & 614 totalling 2411⁄2 acres with 4-roomed stone house etc. Burra RSL Hall 14 April.

Burra Youth Club met on 3 April. A committee was established and is organising a concert. The club could do with some adult assistance and with more teenage members.

86, 13 (3), 7 Apr. 1964, page 7 [Number used before in 1963 & 1964.]

Obituary. Bridget Teresa Preiss died 3 April at Burra Hospital. She was 93 and was the wife of the late Charles William Preiss and mother of Sylvester, Elizabeth, Margaret, John, Joseph, Veronica, Irene and Francis (deceased). There are 25 grandchildren and 37 great-grandchildren.

[Born and married as Bridget Clark, but had children as Bridget Teresa, Bridget Theresea and Bridget Theresia Preiss. Born 19 December 1870 South Rhine SA. See also 87, 50 (3), 15 Dec. 1964, page 5.]

86, 13 (3), 7 Apr. 1964, page 8 [Number used before in 1963 & 1964.]

Bowls

Burra Green was runner-up in the Champion of Champion Rinks event at Saddleworth in the Mid North Association.

86, 14 (3), 14 Apr. 1964, page 1 [Number used before in 1957 & 1963.]

Weather. A good rain last week delivered up to 155 points across the district. Burra recorded 154 points.

John L. Phillips, son of C.L. Phillips, who joined the staff at Burra ANZ on 24 February, has been transferred to Adelaide.

Burra Small Bore Club. Best over double 75 yards on Tuesday were R. Angel, M. Thomas and K. Spackman.

Cricket

Hallett 7 for 333 (J. Honan 162 retired) defeated Booborowie and will play Burra Footballers in the Grand Final.

Burra High School Sports were held in ideal weather on the school’s newly grassed area in the morning and on the Memorial Oval in the afternoon. Results next issue. Cup winners:

Senior Boys’ Cup J. Edwards

Junior Boys’ Cup A. Thomas

Senior Girls’ Cup K. White

Junior Girls’ Cup J. Kleinig

Photo. Mr & Mrs Syd. Scroop of the former’s 60th birthday, with Mr Charlie Griffiths of his 50th.

Merino Stud Field Days were held last week. Collinsville sold 6 rams for over 1,000 guineas each, two of them at 2,000 guineas, both of which went to WA. Other studs visited were Barton Hill, The Grove, Woollana, Mackerode, Mt Glen View, The Bluff, Narowie, Cappeedee, Ashrose, Willogoleche, Greenfields, Melton, North Bungaree and Somme Brae.

Rev. M.A. Lind writes a letter protesting about some activity that happened on a Sunday. The event is not clearly stated, but seems to have been about an activity to retain an unspecified relic and Rev. Lind believed it should not have occurred on the Lord’s Day.

86, 14 (3), 14 Apr. 1964, page 2 [Number used before in 1957 & 1963.]

Steve McQueen & Brigid Bazlen in The Honeymoon Machine

1 & 2 May

The Mutiny on the Bounty

86, 14 (3), 14 Apr. 1964, page 4 [Number used before in 1957 & 1963.]

Obituary. Mr William George Terry, who died suddenly at his home in Burra North on 31 March, was born at Broken Hill 7 January 1902. He was the eldest son of Mr & Mrs William Terry and moved to Burra in 1911 when Mr Terry Sen. became manager of Sturt Vale Station. He completed his schooling at Gawler and returned to work at Sturt Vale before taking work with the District Council. Later he joined the tailoring staff of the late E.C. Hammond, whose business he acquired in 1930 and which he continued in until 1962. He was active in the town’s sporting activities and in community affairs. He was a keen bowler and was Burra Bowling Club’s singles champion several times. He was instrumental in forming the North Eastern Bowling Association and skippered a mixed rink at the recent Easter Tournament to second place, only a few hours before his death. He was secretary of the Burra Racing Club for some time before ill health forced him to retire. He is survived by his widow Edith nee Harris, son Jim of Sydney and daughter Val. Mrs John Taylor of Tarlee. There are four grandchildren. His two surviving brothers are Jack of Burra and Tom of Adelaide.

Marriage. Hallett Methodist Church 28 March

Judith McDonald, only daughter of Mr & Mrs Frank McDonald, married

Barry Eberhard, eldest son of Mr & Mrs Eberhard of Burra.

86, 14 (3), 14 Apr. 1964, page 5[Number used before in 1957 & 1963.]

Burra High School Parents & Friends’ Association AGM elected: President, Mrs A. Benger; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames D. Thomas & A. Williams; Secretary, Mrs G. Lomman; Assistant Secretary, Mrs D. Field and Treasurer, Mrs W. Brook. About 50 people attended.

The main project for this year is a dressing shed for the girls.

Attendance at meetings for 1963 averaged 33 from 52 members. [These are from the President’s report. The Secretary’s comments suggest an average attendance of 25.]

In the year £335 was given to improve the old tennis courts and surroundings. The Ball raised £87-11-4. With the increasing number of High School students it has been necessary to limit the Christmas Banquet to staff, students and the President of the High School Council and it was decided to dispense with the services of a guest speaker, so making the event somewhat less formal. Sporting equipment was purchased throughout the year for the school.

86, 14 (3), 14 Apr. 1964, page 8 [Number used before in 1957 & 1963.]

Football. W.E. Blatchford, President of the Mid North Football Association, gives a résumé of the 1963 season and looks back over twenty years of development of the grounds and the game in some 21⁄2 columns.

86, 14 (3), 14 Apr. 1964, Supplement [Number used before in 1957 & 1963.]

[Double-sided of 5 columns – about A4 sized.]

Burra Bowling Club observed a minute’s silence for Mr G. Terry on 6 April at the committee meeting. Mr Terry had been recommended to become the club’s first Life Member at the next general meeting.

North Eastern Schools Combined Sports Results are printed. [Burra was not a participant.]

Tennis. Finals

‘A’ Grade Aberdeen 15-123 defeated Mt Bryan 5-94

‘B’ Grade Aberdeen 10-94 defeated Spalding Red 10-98 CHECK: this is clearly incorrect.

86, 15 (3), 21 Apr. 1964, page 1 [Number used before in 1957 & 1963.]

The Anzac Day Parade and Service was held on Sunday 19 April. About 60 RSL members and a crowd of about 300 attended. The RSL members were led by the Port Pirie Pipe Band and marched along Commercial Street to Stock Street and then returned to the War Memorial for the service.

[Since Stock Street is parallel to Commercial Street this is clearly not correct. Previous marches would suggest that Kangaroo Street or perhaps Ware Street is more likely.]

Wreaths were laid by representatives of the RSL, Air Force Association, and Fathers’ Association and for the Town by Mayor E.T. Baulderstone and the District Council by Cr Quinn.

Rev. Lind delivered the address. The commemoration service in the evening was held at Kooringa Methodist Church.

M & BHA. Lady Bonython, State President of the Mothers & Babies’ Health Association, will open the new clinic in West Bridge Street Burra on 24 April. The committee has £350 in hand and requires a further £450 to open free of debt. Donations will be acknowledged. Mrs G. Stanley Hawker has donated £20.

Burra Hospital. A tender has been let to Mr A. Mass for four private rooms and offices for the Matron and the Secretary-Manager. Building should start within four weeks and the cost of the project, including furniture, equipment, architect’s fees and a new septic tank should be £UNREADABLE.

Burra High School. The results for the school’s sports day are printed.

86, 16 (4), 28 Apr. 1964, page 1 [Number used before in 1957 (twice) & 1963.]

Burra High School and Heathfield High School tied in winning the State Savings Bank award in their section. It is worth £20 (£40 with subsidy) for books for the school library.

The PMG will install a small country automatic telephone exchange at Hallett Gap with three telephone circuits between there and Hallett.

Burra Bowling Club raised £29 for Legacy at their recent Bowls Tournament.

Deaconess Bonython, Superintendent of Kate Cocks’ Babies’ Home, spoke on the work of the Home at Redruth Memorial Hall on Thursday 23 April. A collection raised £20 for her cause.

Burra CWA visited Mrs A.D. Radford’s home ‘Glenora’ for their April meeting.

M & BHA. Lady Bonython, State President of the organisation opened the new Burra Clinic on Friday. Donations on the afternoon totalled £150-9-0 and a trading table raised a further £30. This reduces the debt owing on the clinic to £270.

Cricket. Mokota Association Final.

Hallett 180 & 2 for 79 defeated Burra Footballers 160.

86, 16 (4), 28 Apr. 1964, page 7 [Number used before in 1957 (twice) & 1963.]

Obituary. Mr A.G. (Tom) Heinrich died 23 April. He was a well-known farmer and grazier. He died at Ru Rua Hospital in North Adelaide aged 73. He was born 16 October 1890 at the Heinrich Homestead of Dutton’s Trough. He received his early education at World’s End Creek School and later attended Point Pass College for UNREADABLE and was confirmed at Immanuel Lutheran Church, Point Pass by the late Pastor G.T. UNREADABLE. Having spent all his life on the family homestead, Mr Heinrich took over the property from his parents. In 1930 he married Miss Melva Riesson who died in 1934. On 24 June 1937 he married Miss Rosa Wittwer at St Peter’s church, Point Pass. They had seven children. In his youth he played cricket for World’s End and football for Apoinga, but his great love was rifle shooting and he took an active interest in the Burra Rifle Club, winning many trophies, including Club champion and the Baldina Trophy for yearly aggregate as recently as 1955. He represented Burra with other members in the big shoots in Sydney in the late 1930s. He was a foundation member of the Burra Small Bore Club and active in the early years of its existence. He served a term as Chairman of the Burra Primary School Committee. He is survived by his wife and children: Cynthia, Annette Mrs Paul Sabel (of Hope Vale Lutheran Mission in Queensland), Graham, Maxine, Delrose, Kathlynn and Stephney. The funeral cortege of more than 100 cars attended the funeral at St Peter’s Cemetery, Point Pass.

[Anton Gotthelf Heinrich born 16 October 1890 near Burra: died 23 March 1964 North Adelaide, residence Burra.]

86, 16 (4), 28 Apr. 1964, page 8 [Number used before in 1957 (twice) & 1963.]

[Photograph, page 1.]

86, 17 (4), 5 May 1964, page 1 [Number used before in 1957 (twice) & 1963.]

Burra Golf Club opened its season on Saturday.

Accident/Obituary. Robert Bruce Irlam aged 19 died when shot accidentally in the chest when a .22 automatic rifle accidentally discharged. The accident occurred five miles north of Redbanks about 9.30 p.m. on Tuesday night. The deceased, a son of Mr & Mrs Stan Irlam presently of Terowie, had been spotlighting with Trevor Menz and Brian Kakoschke. He was driving with the rifle leaning against his left leg with the butt on the floor. He managed to almost stop the car and his companions placed him on the back seat and got him to the Burra Hospital at about 10 p.m. where Dr Miller pronounced him dead.

[Born 29 April 1943: died 28 April 1964 near Burra, residence Burra North.]

86, 17 (4), 5 May 1964, pages 1 & 6 [Number used before in 1957 (twice) & 1963.]

Mothers & Babies’ Health Association. Lady Bonython opened the new clinic on 27 April. The building required a further £270 to be free of debt. Lady Bonython is State President of the M & BHA. Upon arrival she was entertained at luncheon at the Kooringa Hotel. The Mayor Mr E.T. Baulderstone attended the opening, despite being the only male present. Local Association President Mrs R.B. Jennison welcomed the visitor and called on Lady Bonython to open the door. It is seven years since clinic services opened in Burra and the number of mothers and babies using the service has increased every year. Mrs Jennison said she could not mention the individual names of the many who had helped, but she did single out Mr Baulderstone who made the Mayor’s Parlour available for the clinic and Mr [R.] Fuss, without whose help, advice and labour it would have been practically impossible to open the building. The aid of the CWA has also been greatly appreciated, along with the husbands of the committee members. The M & BHA now has 84 buildings. It had started in 1909, when it was called ‘The School for Mothers’. It was started by Dr Helen Mayo with some helpers because she was appalled at the infant mortality rate, which was then over 70 per 1,000 births. Last year it was 18.67.

[Donors are listed on page 6.]

[Two photographs: one shows Lady Bonython opening the door and the other Mesdames M. Odgers and M. Carmody at the trading table.]

86, 17 (4), 5 May 1964, page 3 [Number used before in 1957 (twice) & 1963.]

Burra Town Council

The Mayor and Town Clerk are to discuss with ETSA the establishment of a depot and its likely sites.

Mrs Baynes will be appointed office assistant for six three-hour sessions per fortnight, until the end of the financial year.

SA Housing Trust is to be asked to consider building rental accommodation in Burra due to the lack of rental houses in the town.

[In response to this it was reported on page 1 that the Trust had sent up application forms.]

86, 17 (4), 5 May 1964, page 6 [Number used before in 1957 (twice) & 1963.]

Table Tennis. North Eastern Association held its AGM and elected: Patron, W. Warner; President, Graham Ashton and Secretary, Robert Bruce.

86, 17 (4), 5 May 1964, page 7 [Number used before in 1957 (twice) & 1963.]

Mr John D. Murphy will retire from the ANZ on 7 May. He is manager of the branch at 394 Collins Street, Melbourne and retires after 43 years’ service, having joined the Bank of Australasia in 1921 at Kooringa, as a country boy from Oakbank SA. In WWII he served in the Middle East and New Guinea. He became a sub-inspector in 1947 and served briefly in Wellington, New Zealand, in that year also. He held a number of executive positions in Melbourne and Sydney 1947-54 before becoming Senior Administrative Officer, General Manager’s Office, Melbourne, in 1955. He has been manager of his present branch since 1958. He married Miss Lila Thomas of Burra.

Burra Primary School

On 24 April Mr H. Cornelius addressed the students on Anzac Day and presented prizes in connection with an Anzac Project.

Primary winners were Kym Bannister and Melva Ellery.

Secondary winners were Helen Wurfel and Garry Costello.

Hanson 23 defeated Mt Bryan 2

Hanson 14 defeated Burra Blue 11

86, 18 (4), 12 May 1964, page 1 [Number used before in 1957 (twice) & 1963.]

ETSA intends to build a modern office and depot in Burra, with a permanent maintenance staff and a small construction gang stationed here. ETSA has been operating in the district from Clare, but growth of services in this area has led to the decision to establish a depot for line maintenance and minor construction work. It will serve the area from Ulooloo almost to Morgan in the southeast and will include Hallett, Booborowie, Hanson, Burra and Robertstown. It will maintain two major transmission lines providing power to the Upper Murray.

Dave Moore’s utility was stolen from a vacant block by his house in George Street on the night of Saturday/Sunday last. A stolen Holden from Adelaide was left in George Street. Mr Moore’s vehicle was discovered in Hindring [?] on Monday morning.

Mid Northern High Schools Sports were held at Riverton Oval on 7 May.

In the open section for the Ohlmeyer Shield In the Handicap Section

Riverton 171 Riverton 215

Burra 140.5 Burra 194.5

Clare 132 Clare 132

Balaklava 107 Balaklava 131

Kapunda 32.5 Kapunda 123.5

The Handicap Shield thus went to Burra.

[The open winners are not able to hold the Handicap Shield in the same year.]

[Results are printed.]

Rev. T.G. Drought & family have moved to Lockleys-Kidman Park Parish. Rev. Drought had been at St Mary’s for 51⁄4 years. The new Rector will now take up his duties till August.

86, 18 (4), 12 May 1964, page 8 [Number used before in 1957 (twice) & 1963.]

Burra Burra DC

It was resolved to continue with the proposal to have Redbanks Reserve dedicated under the care, management and control of the Council.

Burra Primary School Committee AGM elected: Chairman, D. Zanker and Secretary, K. White.

Retiring Chairman Darrell Field presented the 86th report. In the past year the school was accepted as a participant in the Hallett and District Schools Association Sports Day and the school competed in 1963 and 1964. This year has seen the building of the new toilet block and the fencing of the playing area between the school and the old Drill Hall, now the Postal Department Depot. The retaining area south of the tennis courts and the paving of the rest of the school yard. Sports Day on 25 October was very successful. The Welfare Club ladies are doing magnificent work and this year they are putting down a cricket pitch on the new oval.

86, 19 (4), 19 May 1964, page 1 [Number used before in 1957 (twice) & 1963.]

Burra Hospital. Construction by Mr A. Mass of the new block has begun, comprising private rooms, Matron’s Office and Secretary-Manager’s Office. The project will cost about £22,000. Donations have reached £5,673-8-2. The Hospital’s financial position has improved with better collection of patient fees and more patients in Hospital Benefits Funds. Costs have fallen while wages are static.

Burra Burra DC has taken out a loan of £3,000 repayable over five years at £4-17-6 per cent per annum. This has enabled the District Council to carry out healing [sic: for sealing] of streets in Booborowie and Farrell Flat to reduce the dust nuisance.

Keith Horsnell headmaster of the Burra Primary School has been transferred. Mr Ian Auhl, a former Mt Bryan resident takes over.

Adelaide Wool Sales. The top local price of 80d was obtained by wool from D.C. Gebhardt & Son of Mt Cone and also by Bunyung Proprietors. [Other local district prices are printed.]

L.L. Fiebig will take part in the 1964 Ampol Trial, starting on 14 June for 7,000 miles through four states.

Accident. L.B. Lucas escaped injury on Thursday when the front suspension of his car collapsed, causing it to roll over near the Burra Racecourse.

Accident. B.E. Kemp of North Bungaree received a minor scalp injury when his Land Rover overturned on Friday near Mt Bryan.

Accident. Mrs E.V. Blythman’s vehicle sustained c. £300 damage when it collided with a heap of road rubble on the Farrell Flat-Clare Road.

86, 19 (4), 19 May 1964, page 3 [Number used before in 1957 (twice) & 1963.]

86, 20 (4), 26 May 1964, page 1 [Number used before in 1954, 1957 & 1963.]

Accident/Obituary. Three people died when two cars collided near Hallett on Sunday evening. Of three people injured, one is in a critical condition, another is serious and the third is satisfactory. The accident occurred about one mile south of Hallett. A sedan car driven by H.R. Edwards of Cockburn was travelling north and collided with a car driven by Leo K. Collins of Olary, travelling south. In Mr Collins’ car there were four passengers and of them Mrs E.D. Gurr died almost immediately. From the other car Mr Edwards died shortly after being admitted to Burra Hospital and Mr Collins also died in the Burra Hospital. All three of the deceased suffered multiple injuries, including fractured skulls. Wayne Gurr (13) received head injuries and Deidre UNREADABLE of Nailsworth is in a critical condition. Both were transferred to Adelaide yesterday. Deidre suffered head injuries and fractured legs. Sheryl Turner of Clearview suffered lacerations, but is in a satisfactory condition. The accident was attended by Constable R.F. Heath of Hallett, Constable A. Conroy and Constable K. Watts of Burra. Sgt S. Swaine and Constable P. Black of the Accident Investigation Squad from Adelaide have also attended.

[Doreen Eleanor Gurr died 24 May 1964 Hallett, residence Olary, aged 39.

Leo Keith Collins died 24 May 1964 Burra, residence Olary, aged 29.

Horace Reginald Edwards born 17 September 1907 Tarcowie: died 24 May 1964 Burra, residence Cockburn.]

Wool Prices have fallen sharply due to economic problems in Japan, Italy and to a lesser extent in the UK and also due to the increased use of synthetic fibres. Recent sales have featured a bigger proportion of faulty and less stylish wools.

ETSA has been advised by the Town Council that it is willing to negotiate the sale of land needed by them for the Burra Depot at valuation prices. The area involved is the triangular piece of land near the old sale yards. [Bounded by Tomkinson and Smelts Roads.]

Highways & Local Government Department has been advised that the Town Council will make available Reserve Number 5 (Baker’s) for the use of that Department. [Between Redruth and Llwchwr.]

Burra Hospital. During building operations delivery vehicles will have to use the rear entrance and visitors and walking patients will use the doorway near the Secretary-Manager’s Office.

The Elizabethan Theatre Trust will present And the Big Men Fly by Alan Hopgood, in Burra in June.

Comalco presented a trade night in Burra on 20 May to introduce the new low cost aluminium roofing and cladding sheet, Double Rib. It is proving popular for pig pens and poultry sheds as it reflects heat and makes buildings up to 15° cooler in the summer heat. It requires no painting.

Obituary. Ralph Thomas of ‘Hogback’ Station died in Adelaide on Friday aged 73. He had been ill for some months. RSL members formed a guard of honour at the Burra Cemetery and bearers were A. Benger, A. Hempel, A.C. Ford, P.B .Byles, A. Wright and J. Murphy.

[George Ralph Thomas born 15 April 1891 Hundred of Wonna: died 22 May 1964, Adelaide, residence Hogback Station. See a little more at 89, 25, 30 June 1964, page 3.]

Burra Town Council, 18 May

ETSA will be advised the Council will negotiate the sale of the land they require at valuation price.

It has come to the Council’s notice that the Swimming Pool Committee is withholding £464 of the Filtration Plant contract price and this could interfere with the Government subsidy. Council will try to arrange a committee meeting as soon as possible.

The Highways & Local Government Department is to be advised that the Council is prepared to make Reserve No. 5 available to them. Council is prepared to negotiate the sale of land to G.R. O’Connor as soon as it is valuated.

Resolved that the matter of a shed for the jinker and other relics be left in the hands of the Mayor.

86, 21 (4), 2 June 1964 [Number used before in 1954, 1957 & 1963.] MISSING

86, 22 (3), 9 June 1964, page 1 [Number used before in 1954, & 1963.]

Theft. Police are warning people against trespassing on property and stealing sheep, baled wool and firewood. G.F. Lomman of Murong, twenty miles east of Burra, reports the loss of 107 mixed sheep and 50-60 lambs. K.R. Phillips of ‘The Gums’ reports the loss of a bale of wool. E.G. & D.M. Kellock are missing three bales of wool.

(Bales of wool are valued at c. £100 each.

Mr & Mrs I. L. Auhl have been introduced to the Burra Primary School Welfare Club. Mr Auhl takes over as headmaster from Mr K. Horsnell.

The Farrell Flat by-pass road has now been completed along with the new access roads to the town.

Burra & District choral Society has elected: President, Mr J. Oates; Secretary-Treasurer, Mrs T. O’Connor and Conductor, Mr R. Mueller. Accompanist is Mrs J. Oates and assistant is Mrs J. Carpenter.

86, 22 (3), 9 June 1964, page 3 [Number used before in 1954, & 1963.]

Jacques Bergerac & Fred Demara in The Hypnotic Eye

The Elizabethan Theatre Trust presents the play And the Big Men Fly. 20 June.

Mr & Mrs D. Zanker were farewelled by the Cricket & Football Clubs in the RSL Hall on Saturday. Don has been Secretary of the Football Club and Mrs Zanker received a token in recognition of her Social Club activities.

86, 23 (3), 16 June 1964, page 1 [Number used before in 1954, & 1963.]

Burra Show on 10 October will be opened by the Governor of SA Sir Edric Bastyan. An attempt will be made to get the Central Command Band to attend. Membership fees have risen for the first time since 1937. Mr R. Humphrys has been made an Honorary Life Member. Other Life Members are: T.D.J. Beckwith, W.H. Lloyd, A.B. Riggs and R. Fuss.

Weather. The temperature at Ulooloo on Thursday 11 June was 16°F early in the morning.

The Baby Train will soon make its last visit. It will not be continued after 22 June.

Kindergarten Week will see the Burra Kindergarten open to the public on Saturday 20 June from 10 a.m. to 12 noon. On Wednesday 24 June the Kindergarten will be open for inspection on a normal working day.

SAR Commissioner J.A. Fargher reports that the railway from Broken Hill to Port Pirie is being converted to standard gauge and the question of a standard gauge connection with Adelaide is being discussed. Though not yet decided, it would probably be along the Port Pirie line, at least as far as Merriton. He considered that even when constructed such a line would have little if any affect upon the number of railway workers living in Riverton.

86, 23 (3), 16 June 1964, page 2 [Number used before in 1954, & 1963.]

Obituary. A Return Thanks Notice reveals the death of the husband of Mrs W. Lomman.

[Walter Lomman born 30 October 1887 Kooringa: died 29 April 1964 Booborowie.]

[Born Ada Chynoweth 24 May 1880 Kooringa: died 28 May 1964 Burra.]

Burra Primary School Committee

Mr Don Zanker has resigned as Chairman and Mr Ken white has been elected to the position. Mr White welcomed Mr Auhl as the incoming headmaster.

A Teenage Group of the Oddfellows’ Lodge was recently formed and has arranged a Lodge Ball to be held in the Lodge Hall on 19 June. Dominos Band will play.

Burra Marching Girls. For the last five weeks girls have been practising marching and are setting about forming a committee and raising money for uniforms in order to form a Girls’ Marching Team.

86, 24 (3), 23 June 1964, page 1 [Number used before in 1954, & 1963.]

Weather. General falls of 40-60 points have given a good opening to the season.

Burra Youth Club will meet in the old Salvation Army Hall opposite the Burra dry Cleaners from 26 June. This will be more convenient as the majority of members come from the south end of town and also because they will have exclusive use of the building. It is intended to form an Adult Advisory Committee. The idea is to form a coffee bar type club where teenagers can drop in for a game, record session, dance and chat. The club is affiliated with SA Youth Clubs who run a variety of competitions through the year – indoor bowls, darts, dominos, volley ball, table tennis, vaulting apparatus, basket work, art, a library and weekend activities.

Burra Homing Club. The race of 13 June was won by Stan Kellaway. The race on 20 June was won by Stan Kellaway. Also doing well are G. Kakoschke, D. Irlam and Danny O’Brien.

Adelaide Wool Sales last week saw J.V. Lord & Sons of Balah top district prices with 771⁄2d.

[Other local district prices are printed.]

Burra Hospital. The work on the new building is progressing. Foundations have been laid and 1,600 bricks have been used to bring them to the floor level of existing buildings. The interior of the Nurses’ Home and the dining room are being painted. An 8 x 5 ft cool room has been installed. 54 acres of wheat have been sown for the Board at Hanson. Donations have reached £5,688-0-2.

86, 24 (3), 23 June 1964, page 2 [Number used before in 1954, & 1963.]

Advt. Elders-GM will sell the Burra North Shops on the corner of Young and Moorehead Streets on the instructions of M.W. Bednall & Co. acting for the late Alison Bentley and Miss M.G. Bentley. The two shops are on allotment 47 of Section 4 of the Hundred of Kooringa.

Obituary. The sale of the Burra north Shops above reveals the death of Miss Alison Bentley.

[Born 14 October 1883 Redruth: died 11 May 1964 Burra, residence Burra North.]

Notice. Burra Rifle Club. A General Meeting is called for 4 July at the home of R.J. Kellock. J. Brown, Captain.

Obituary. Edith Terry, the wife of the late George Terry died on 19 June at Dubbo NSW. She was the mother of Jim and Val (Mrs J. Taylor of Tarlee.) [Born Edith Emily Harrison Harris 25 May 1896, Kooringa.]

Obituary. A Return Thanks Notice reveals the death of Walter Henry Williams of Farrell Flat.

[Born 4 May 1886 Farrell Flat: died 28 May 1964 Clare, residence Farrell Flat.]

Veteran’s Event Mrs E.S. Chapman (Clare)

89, 25, 30 June 1964, page 1 [Note new and irregular volume number.]

Note that issue numbers will require correction after 1960 has been noted.

Mr Howard Griffen of Mt Bryan has developed a fleece weighing table. The table measures 10 ft x 5 ft and weighs up to 30 lb. It has been under test at the Agricultural Research Station Trangie and results suggest it would be a sound purchase where fleece measurement was an integral part of the breeding program. Tests show it to be as accurate as a standard balance, allowing for the fact that some locks will fall through when a fleece is thrown onto the table – the difference from the pan weight being between nil and 0.2 lb. Overall it was accurate and simplified the board boy’s routine. A NSW firm has agreed to manufacture the table.

Booborowie CWAAGM is reported.

SAR Commissioner J.A. Fargher is of the opinion that a standardised rail link to Adelaide via Crystal Brook would not affect passenger services via Riverton to Peterborough and Broken Hill and the freight services between Adelaide and Peterborough would not be materially affected.

Burra Homing Club. The race from Tailem Bend was won by Stan Kellaway – making three in a row.

Burra Memorial Oval. The bore is progressing well and water has been struck at 80 ft, but the work continues, as the contractor, A.C .Thomas, expects the main stream to be at 150-160 ft.

M & BHA will provide a Child Health Centre service from 29 June, conducted by an Infant Welfare Sister who will travel by road. She will be at Burra on Friday 10 July 10.30 a.m. to 1 p.m. and 2 p.m. to 3.30 p.m. and fortnightly thereafter.

Weather. 80 points of rain were recorded in Burra in the past week.

Burra High School farewelled Mr K. Hicks on Friday, as he has been transferred to Nuriootpa High School. Mr R. Haywood has been welcomed from Streaky Bay Area School.

89, 25, 30 June 1964, page 3

Advt. Burra Pictures, 11 July

Gary Cooper & Deborah Kerr in The Naked Edge

Accident/Obituary. A 30-year-old man died when the car he was driving overturned about fourteen miles north of Booborowie on Saturday on the Booborowie-Jamestown Road. Mr Robert Walker McFarlane (30) was a station hand of Gulnare and was thrown from the car and died in the ambulance on the way to hospital.

Burra Blue defeated Booborowie

Obituary. Albert Henry Moore died 25 June at Pt Augusta Hospital aged 71. He was the husband of Alma and the father of Audrey (Mrs Voumard of Nuriootpa), Cliff (Yardea Station) and Valda (Burra). There are 11 grandchildren and 12 great-grandchildren. [Born 6 October 1892 Kooringa: died 25 June 1964 Pt Augusta, residence Pt Augusta West.]

Obituary. Mr Ralph Thomas, well-known grazier of the Eastern Pastoral District, died on 22 May. He was born at Tooralie north-east of Burra 15 April 1891 and died at the Royal Adelaide Hospital aged 73. He was educated at Mt Bryan East and served in WWI. He married Miss Tryphosa Thamm at Redruth Methodist Church 26 January 1921. He lived at Mt Bryan East and served on the Hallett District Council for some years. He then moved ‘out East’ where he remained until his death. He is survived by his wife and children: Linda (Mrs Jones), Ida (Mrs Afford), Stuart and Bert. There are 11 grandchildren. He was buried at Burra Cemetery on 25 May. Burra RSL Members conducted a ceremony of remembrance.

[George Ralph Thomas born 15 April 1891 Hundred of Wonna: died 22 May 1964, Adelaide, residence Hogback Station.]

89, 25, 30 June 1964, page 4

89, 25, 30 June 1964, page 8

CWA Burra Branch held its AGM. Mrs H.L .Riggs reported a membership of 70 with an average attendance of 27. [Details of the year’s activities are given in c. 1 column.]

Burra Town Council

Council approved the price of £200 for Pt Section 14 required by G.R. O’Connor.

Building approval was granted for a House for O.A. & D.F. Tattersall.

A subsidy is to be sought from the Tourist Bureau for a shed to protect the old jinker.

A letter will be sent to the Department of Highways & Local Government complaining that the by-pass road to the Bon Accord Bridge is used extensively by heavy traffic and this is unsatisfactory.

Burra Marching Girls were granted the use of Burra Memorial Oval on Sunday afternoons.

The sale of land to ETSA was approved for £100.

87, 26 (2), 7 July 1964, page 1 [Note the reversion to volume 87 – previously used in 1956.]

Burra Memorial Oval. The bore has progressed from 80 ft to 170 ft and it is intended to stop at 175 ft. A test at 95 ft made 400 gallons. A test on Wednesday last at 115 ft made 1,000 gallons, with the static level of water at 45 ft from the surface. A test at 145 ft yielded 1,200 to 1,300 gallons per hour. On Monday morning a test at 100 ft yielded UNREADABLE with the bore then at 160 ft and in the afternoon it was making 2,000 gallons per hour and with water of reasonable quality.

Burra Hospital. Sir Lyell McEwin, the Chief Secretary, visited the Hospital on Friday afternoon. He was met by the Board Chairman Mr R.K. Pearse. He was accompanied by Messrs John Gebhardt and A.D. Radford. They inspected the new building, the walls of which should be completed this week and also the kitchen, which is being converted from coke cooking to gas and the pantry, which is due to be enlarged to cope with more patients. Sister Leader, a triple certificated Sister from WA, is due to begin work here from mid-July.

Burra Town Council. Election for East Ward. (Turn-out was 51.7%)

H. Cornelius 94

L.P. Bence 29

Accident. A semi-trailer rolled onto its side in Market Square on Sunday when its load shifted. The driver Mr J.L. Carroll of Prospect did a good job in managing to avoid the War Memorial when the load of pre-fabricated huts, destined for Moree in NSW, shifted as he turned from Commercial Street into Market Square heading north. The driver was not injured. Numerous people took photos. A crane arrived from Adelaide on Monday morning to unload the vehicle and right it. The vehicle was driven off once it regained its wheels with damage of only £30-£40. Damage to the huts was also slight and it is thought that spectators damaged more roses than the accident itself. Alan Baulderstone removed a dozen or more to save them and 19 of the 48 are still standing.

87, 26 (2), 7 July 1964, page 3 [Note the reversion to volume 87 – previously used in 1956.]

Advt. Burra Pictures, 11 July

Gary Cooper & Deborah Kerr in The Naked Edge

Anthony Quinn in The Ride Back

18 July

Bob Hope & Lucille Ball in The Facts of Life

Mr & Mrs Bert Samuels, who have run the Mt Bryan Post Office for 19 years, left on 1 July to retire to Elizabeth Grove. Mr & Mrs Fraser have taken over at Mt Bryan, having had post office experience in Queensland.

Burra Homing Club. The fourth race of the season was also the fourth win to Stan Kellaway.

Burra CWA election of officers in June: President, Mrs H.L. Riggs; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames H ,Jennison & E. Baulderstone; Secretary-Reporter, Mrs A.C .Ford; Assistant Secretary, Mrs S. Scroop and Treasurer, Miss E. Tiver.

87, 27 (2), 14 July 1964, page 1 [Number previously used in 1956.]

Weather. Last weekend wind and rain persisted, but the rain fell at night. For the week Burra reported 146 points, Farrell Flat 172, Booborowie 81 and World’s End 147.

Arbor Day at Booborowie saw school children plant trees in the parklands adjoining the school.

Adelaide Wool Sales 7-9 July saw top district price of 793⁄4d for Alexandrina Ltd of Burra.

[Other local district prices are printed.]

Mr Neil Crisp, a member of the National Bank staff, has been transferred to Mt Gambier to be replaced by Mr G.M. Walker from the Gouger Street branch.

Mr Bryan Hogget Competition was won by T.P. Griffen.

Burra Homing Club. The race from Keith was won by Stan Kellaway.

Advt. Full page Bence’s Ltd End of Season Sale.

87, 27 (2), 14 July 1964, page 8 [Number previously used in 1956.]

Obituary. Mr Arthur James Prior died at the Repatriation General Hospital Springbank, Adelaide 26 June aged 76. He was born at Burra North on 11 July 1887 of parents who were both born in Burra. His father was the late Elijah Thomas Prior who was born in 1861 and his mother nee Elizabeth Owens was born in 1857 and lived to 93, dying in Adelaide in 1950. He father was one of the original Burra miners and she was born and lived for some years in the old miners’ dugouts in the banks of the Burra Creek. Mr Arthur Prior lived for many years in the district and later in Burra itself. Before WWI he worked on farming and station properties in the Burra, Mt Bryan and Gumbowie districts and was employed for a number of years by the late Mr John Collins of Collinsville. He enlisted in WWI and served in France with the 48th Battalion. He was wounded in the Bullecourt Campaign and was taken prisoner by the Germans. He spent almost two years as a POW and suffered great hardships. After the war he returned to the Burra district with his brother Gilbert, who had been wounded on the same day and in the same battle in France, but who had been repatriated to Australia some time before him. He took up farming as a soldier settler in the Springbank area and at Hanson and was successful until selling out just before WWII. For some years Mr Prior than conducted a confectionery business in Market Square in the premises now occupied by Mr Alan Baulderstone. After selling that premises he went into retirement in Adelaide for about 12 years. He never married. He is survived by four sisters and three brothers. [Arthur James Jubilee Prior born 11 July 1887 Aberdeen SA: died 26 June 1964 Daw Park, residence Kilkenny.]

87, 28 (2), 21 July 1964, page 1 [Number previously used in 1956.]

Burra Ambulance membership has fallen to 60. The ambulance was purchased in July 1960 at a cost of £1,500. A subscription drive is now on.

Burra Homing Club. The race from Hamley Bridge was won by G. Kakoschke.

Glen McBride writes thanking the citizens of Burra and District for their support of the play: And the Big Men Fly.

Rural Youth Merino Stud Tour 1964 was held last Tuesday and Wednesday. 36 members took part, each representing a different club. Studs visited were Cappeedee, Gum Hill and Mackerode.

Weather. Burra received 128 points of rain in the last week.

87, 28 (2), 21 July 1964, pages 1 & 8 [Number previously used in 1956.]

Burra Bowling Club held its AGM on 15 July in most inclement weather. The President Mr Dudley Jacka took the chair. Members stood as a mark of respect for the late A.L. Kellock who died 2 July 1964. Elected were: President, Jack Topsfield; Vice-Presidents, Les Phillips and Murray Stockman; Secretary, D. Field; Assistant Secretary, B. Riggs and Patron, G. Dollman.

President’s Report

The past year has been most active and successful.

Membership is c. 61 full members, as it has been for the past three years.

During the year we farewelled Peter Pritchard and Keith Horsnell and two night members in Errol Hood and Ron McCann. The club was shaken by the sudden death of George Terry, an excellent bowler, coach and greens manager. He would have been made the 1st Life Member at the next general meeting of the club. The club team won the Premiership in the North Eastern Association and players in the Mid North Association also did well. This year the club room has been painted and had new lining and a new glass front. Thanks go to Stan

Woollacott and Bert Wardle for making this possible. The telephone has also been installed. The support of the Associates has continued to be a great help. Alan Benger’s work as gardener has been much appreciated.

Obituary. A mention in the report of the Bowling Club AGM reveals the death of A.L. Kellock.

[Arthur Lillie Kellock born 19 December 1886 Thistlebeds, Baldina: died 2 July 1964 Northfield, residence Burra.]

87, 28 (2), 21 July 1964, page 2 [Number previously used in 1956.]

Basketball. The State Under 16 Team visited Burra to play a combined Burra-Booborowie team. The party with officials etc. numbered 34. They visited the Mine area and had a barbecue lunch at the Small Bore Club.

Burra M & BHA held its 7th AGM on 13 July. Elected President was Mrs M. Odgers. Vice-Presidents are Mrs R. Thamm and someone. [Not named.] Mrs R. Jennison is the Secretary and Mrs D. Banister is the Treasurer.

Mr Ron Thamm from Burra St John’s Ambulance Brigade gave an interesting talk on mouth to mouth resuscitation. The secretary’s report showed an average attendance at the clinic of 40 per month. Sister McMahon will retire at Christmas and from 10 July Sister Moody will come from Balaklava every alternate Friday. On 24 April Lady Bonython opened the Burra Clinic. Thanks to the CWA for the use of their rooms and to Mr Baulderstone for the use of his parlour for clinic days.

Burra Town Council, 20 July

Kooringa Methodist Tennis Club was given permission to remove the shed only from the Kooringa Tennis Courts.

Burra Burra DC is to be advised of the Town Council’s intention to level a portion of the old cemetery and to be asked what assistance they would be prepared to give.

The men’s toilet block opposite the Town Hall is to be refaced with Besser Brick, new plastering where necessary and a new pan.

Estimates are to be obtained for a new ladies’ and gent’s toilet between the present ladies’ and gent’s toilets.

In view of this latter move notice was given to rescind the preceding decision.

87, 29 (2), 28 July 1964, page 8 [Number previously used in 1956.]

Mt Bryan CWA AGM is reported in 3⁄4 column.

87, 30 (2), 4 Aug. 1964, page 1 [Number previously used in 1956.]

River Murray Water for Burra

The Minister of Lands Hon P.H. Quirke has informed us that cabinet has approved the extension of Murray water to Burra and Booborowie. There will be a pumping station near Hanson with three pumps and total power of 165 BHP. There will by 44,000 ft of 10 inch AC pumping main along the main road adjacent to the railway line leading to the existing Burra Tanks. The scheme is based on an annual consumption of 60 million gallons. The Booborowie scheme will supply the town and some farmlands that have petitioned for supplies, but some farms are too high to be supplied. There will be 33,600 ft of 8 inch AC feeder main from the Morgan-Whyalla pipeline to the township with 46,800 ft of 6 inch, 4 inch and 3 inch AC reticulation main at an estimated cost of £50,000. Provision is made for an 8 inch spur main eastwards to supply a future service tank.

Miss Judy Field has passed the final examination of the Nurses Board of SA, coming 3rd in the state, claiming three credits and a gold medal. She is at the RAH and will complete her training in September.

[Photo at her 21st birthday party at Burra RSL Hall.]

Miss Beverley Phillips, daughter of Mr & Mrs K.R. Phillips of Mt Bryan also passed her final nurses exam. She is at the QEH.

Mr Harold Raymond and his ‘Gloombusters’ will present their final show at Booborowie on 12 August. He has been touring and entertaining for some 40 years throughout the country and will now confine his work to the city. Mr Raymond was honoured with an MBE by the late King George VI. He has travelled over 700,000 miles to present upwards of 7,000 shows and has raised many thousands of pounds for his cause.

[He raised money for the Blind, Deaf & Dumb Children’s Home at Brighton; later called Townsend House.]

Cricket. A meeting at Willogoleche on Wednesday night of delegates of five clubs of the Mokota Association decided to form a Junior Association. The clubs represented were Hallett, Booborowie, Spalding, Burra and Leighton. Matches will be played in conjunction with ‘A’ Grade teams and the rules of the Senior Association will apply. For the new Association: Patron, Michael Hawker; President, M. Carmody; Vice-President, H. Black and Secretary, J. Costello. Juniors must be under 15 years of age on 1 September to be eligible to play. The minimum age is at the discretion of the club. Burra will field two teams to be known as Burra Footballers and Koonaburra.

THIS PAPER APPEARS TO BE MISSING, BUT IN THE HARD COPY THE ISSUE FOR 18 August is curiously dated:

Page 1 is unclearly indicated either 11 overprinted 18 or 18 overprinted 11

Page 2 18th, page 3 18th, page 4 11th, page 5 11th, page 6 18th, page 7 18th, page 8 11th.

Check with microfilm.

87, 32 (2), 18 Aug. 1964, page 1 [Number previously used in 1956.]

Golf

The 10th Bronze Meeting of the SA Ladies’ Gold Association was held at Burra last Tuesday, Wednesday & Thursday. The winner was former Burra golfer Mrs M. Scriven of Mt Barker. Monday saw many competitors practising in cold and wet conditions. Tuesday was finer, but very cold. Wednesday was sunny. Windy and cold conditions returned for the final day. The 128 golfers who participated fully taxed Burra’s hotel accommodation. Mrs Scriven is the wife of a former Burra High School headmaster.

Mrs John Simpson celebrated her 95th birthday at her daughter’s, Mrs Charlie Prior of Jamestown, on Sunday. She remains ‘hail [sic] and hearty’. [Born Eliza Jane Beckwith 16 August 1869 Canowie: died 17 December 1966 Felixstow.]

Saddleworth Hogget Competition was won by R.G. Baldock of ‘Hazeleigh’.

CWA Warnes Group held a Wool school function in Burra Town Hall on 12 August. These are conducted by the Wool Board to teach people the many valuable properties of wool and the money raised goes to CWA headquarters’ building fund. The Mayor and Mayoress attended. The principal speaker was Mr Higgins.

The RSL Annual Ball was held on Friday at the Burra Town Hall. Door takings were £110. A sherry party at the RSL clubrooms preceded the ball. Dave Marshall’s Morgan Band supplied the music. The ladies excelled themselves this year for the supper.

87, 34 (2), 25 Aug. 1964, page 1 [Number previously used in 1956.]

Weather. Soaking rains were general over the weekend. Registrations varied from 61 to 305 points. The inside country recorded generally about one inch, while parts of the Eastern Pastoral area received 70-80 points and other parts 150-200. Burra recorded 101 points.

Shearing. A film on the Tally-Hi Shearing Method will be shown in the Show Pavilion at Burra at 7.30 p.m. on Wednesday 2 September.

Burra Hospital AGM was held in the Burra Town Hall last Friday. It was chaired by Mr R. K. Pearse, Chairman of the Board of Management. A minute of appreciation was recorded for the services rendered by Mrs Andrew Tennant (perhaps 13 years, but not legible) and Mrs John Gebhardt (10 years), both of whom have retired. Another minute of appreciation was recorded for Secretary-Manager Mr H.L. Foote, who has resigned.

The Burra-Adelaide Cycling Classic will be held next Saturday. It has attracted entries from around the state to compete for the £100 prize money.

Sheep Sale. The combined agents’ sheep sale at Burra on 21 August saw 21,366 sheep yarded and sold.

87, 34 (2), 25 Aug. 1964, pages 1 & 10 [Number previously used in 1956.]

Golf. The 10th Bronze Meeting was held at Burra 11, 12 & 13 August.

The meeting was a great success and a tribute to the organisers. There were 128 entrants for the three days.

Obituary. Nellie Jane Woodgate aged 74 died 24 August at Jamestown Hospital. She was the wife of the late Brassy Hamilton Woodgate, late of ‘Kentish Hills’ North Booborowie. She was the mother of Marion N., Mrs K.W. White of Burra North. [Born Nellie Jane Jones 9 July 1890 Quorn: died 24 August 1964 Jamestown, residence Booborowie North. Her husband was Hamilton Ernest Brassey Joseph Woodgate.]

87, 35 (2), 1 Sep. 1964, page 1 [Number previously used in 1956.]

Burra Cemetery

For many years the condition of the cemetery has caused the Council concern and has been the subject of much criticism. Legal issues have hampered Council action. There has been a long wait for approval to reclaim and level a portion of the area. Much research had to be done into particulars of leases, dates of burials etc. and many letters were sent to the concerning authorities. Moves for the central portion of the cemetery to be levelled commenced six years ago and approval to carry out the work has finally been given. Tracing lessees of blocks or members of the family concerned, calling for objections and so on has taken all that time. Last week the Council, with the use of District Council plant, commenced the levelling work. Large shrubs, large trees, broken and crumbling mounds, have been removed and the area flattened. There is a large heap of rubbish to be burnet and the headstones removed will be placed along the boundary wall. A vast improvement is already evident. The 99 year leases on the blocks in this area had already expired. New laws grant the period of 50 years only for the lease of these blocks.

Tally-Hi Shearing. Vin Parks, Field Officer with the Australian Wool Board is conducting two shearing schools in the district this week. They are arranged in conjunction with the Department of Agriculture to teach professional shearers the Tally-Hi method of shearing developed by the Wool Board.

THE NEXT PARAGRAPH IN COLUMN 1 IS UNREADABLE

Mr Parks will be at ‘Abberton Park’ on Thursday morning and at Mrs Ashton’s on Thursday afternoon. There will be an Australian Wool Board film and Queensland Department of Agriculture film at the Burra Show Pavilion in the evening. Mr Parks will be available for discussions and question in the evening.

Kevin Coulter of Clare North Football Club has won the Record trophy for 1964. He was also the leading goal kicker in the North Eastern League for 1964. Kev. Cousins has won the Mail Medal. He won the Record Trophy in 1956 and the Mail Medal in 1958.

Cycling. Professional cyclist Roger Nicholls of Pt Pirie was successful in winning the 100 mile Burra-Adelaide Road Race on Saturday. Fastest time was 4 hours 26 minutes by R. Panter of Victoria. Quite a crowd gathered at Burra to see the limit man ‘pushed off’ by the Mayor Mr E.T. Baulderstone.

Burra High School Ball was held in the Burra Town Hall on Friday night. Door takings were £132-10-0. The local Dominos Band provided the music. The ladies of the Parents & Friends’ Association provided a truly wonderful supper.

W.E. Blatchford was made the first Life Member of the Mid North Football Association on Monday night. He retired as President of the Association this year after 22 years in the job.

Aberdeen Basketball Club held its wind-up function for the 1964 season, with a dinner at the Oddfellows’ Hall Burra North on 22 August. Awards:

‘A’ Grade Best player was Yvonne Williams

Most improved player was Lynette Gill

‘B’ Grade Best player was Kaye Heinrich

Most improved player was Susan Gill

‘C’ Grade Best player was Rosalind Gill

Most improved player was Susan Richards

The ‘C’ Grade team was runner-up in their final.

87, 35 (2), 1 Sep. 1964, page 6 [Number previously used in 1956.]

Burra Rural Youth held its AGM. 22 members and 3 advisory members attended. The President Roger Humphreys delivered the annual report. Numbers were slightly down. David Kellock had replaced Josie Orchard as Secretary. Valmai Williams, one of the most active members, had left the district during the year. Several foundation members had left the club on reaching the age limit. (Kevin Williams, Rex, Peter & John Stockman.) The club had a stand showing noxious weeds at the 1963 Burra Show. It also hosted 36 members for the Merino Tour in the Burra District this year. A Mock Debutante Ball was held on 24 July and raised c. £50 for the Burra Hospital. Public speaking competitions proved the club had some promising public speakers.

[A range of other club activities is also reported.]

Membership was 64 and average attendance was 18. Valmai Williams had represented SA Rural Youth at the 1963 Perth Royal Show and David Kellock represented the club on the 1964 Merino Stud Tour. Robert Neill has been elected to represent the club on the 1964 bus trip to Gippsland. New office bearers: President, David Kellock; Vice-President, Keith Neill; Secretary, Lynette Nicholls; Assistant Secretary, Sandra Field and Treasurer, Robert Neill.

87, 35 (2), 1 Sep. 1964, page 7 [Number previously used in 1956.]

Aberdeen Tennis Club held its AGM 26 August and elected: Patron, F.H. Reed; President, Robert Reed; Senior Vice-President, Kevin Lane; Secretary, Sid. Scroop and Financial and Minute Secretary, F. Scroop.

It is intended to have two ‘A’ Grade and two ‘B’ Grade teams if the players are available. It was resolved to hold an Easter Tournament. Mr Ivan Hirschausen was made a Life Member.

The President reported on a successful year in which the ‘A’ Grade team won the Premiership. Membership was c. 60. Just over 90 competitors took part in the Easter Tournament.

87, 35 (2), 1 Sep. 1964, page 8 [Number previously used in 1956.]

Obituary. Mr William Garden Gunn died 4 August at the Burra hospital. He was born at Birkenhead and his father was Harbour Master at Pt Adelaide. The family attended Port Adelaide Presbyterian Church for many years. As a lad he went to Victoria to learn farming and returned to SA with his then employer, to live at Mundalla in the South East. He bought his first property at Booborowie over forty years ago and developed virgin land into a most productive farm for Hunter River Lucerne seed growing. He gradually increased his acreage and became so well known that orders for his seed came from interstate as well as locally. He also had a small Friesian Herd. He was a member of Willalo Methodist Church and a trustee for 32 years. He is survived by a widow, Rachel Gunn of Melbourne. [Born William Garden Gunn 26 February 1887 Birkenhead SA: died William Gardner Gunn 4 August 1964 Burra, residence Booborowie. Since a wife Areta Lizzie Grace nee Chantrill died in 1945, his widow must be a second wife.]

87, 36 (2), 8 Sep. 1964, page 1 [Number previously used in 1956.]

Burra Small Bore Club held its AGM last Wednesday night. The new season begins on 9 September. Elected were: Captain, W. Corner; Vice-Captain, K. Spackman; Secretary, M.D .Thomas and Treasurer, R.E. Angel.

Adelaide Wool Sales last Wednesday and Thursday saw top district price go to R. Warnes & Sons of Woolgangi at 78d. [Other local district prices are printed.]

Cricket. The AGM of the Mokota Association decided that a round of one day matches will be played commencing on 17 October. Each team will be limited to two hours batting with a minimum of 28 overs. A second round of two day matches will then be played.

Cr Riggs reported on the Burra cemetery renovations.

87, 36 (2), 8 Sep. 1964, page 8 [Number previously used in 1956.]

Burra Town Council, August

A motion that tenders be called for refacing with Besser Brick, a new pan, replastering (where necessary) and repainting of the men’s toilet be rescinded, was carried.

A General Rate of 46d in the pound was declared.

Delegates were appointed to meet the District Council to finalise the clearing of the old portion of the cemetery.

Aberdeen Tennis Club was granted permission to erect a three-sided shelter shed.

Plans for new public toilets were received and will be discussed at the next meeting.

87, 37 (2), 15 Sep. 1964, page 1 [Number previously used in 1956.]

Weather. Light soaking rain fell throughout the agricultural district on Wednesday night and Thursday, yielding from 65 to 100 points. The best falls were in the East. Burra received 77 points for the week and Mt Bryan 65, but to the East Woolgangi reported 137, Old Koomooloo 180, Braemar 155, Kia-Ora 127, while Oakbank received only 68.

Football. Ray (Jimmy) James of Burra has won the G. Gilles Trophy for 1964 for gaining highest points in ‘B’ Grade football. He also gained highest points in 1963, but no trophy was available that year. Jimmy won the Mail Medal in 1950, 1951 and 1955 and now aged 43 and having completed 27 seasons of football, has decided to leave it to the younger generation. His ambition to be in a Premiership final has been denied him. Although he was Captain-Coach of the Premiership side when Burra won in 1956 for the first time in 18 years, he was out of the Grand Final through injury. The same fate befell him in 1960. Last year in B Grade the team made the final, but were defeated.

B. Meyer for Clare South has won the Medal for Colts donated by the SA Umpires’ Association.

87, 37 (2), 15 Sep. 1964, page 2 [Number previously used in 1956.]

Advt. Oates Ltd will conduct a Clearing Sales for G.J. & K.M. Dare at their property 11 miles east of Mt Bryan on 5 October. The property has been sold. [Details in 11⁄2 columns.]

87, 37 (3), 22 Sep. 1964, page 1 [Number previously used in 1956 and 1964.]

Burra Show. The Governor is to open the show this year and the SA Police Band will attend.

Riverton Town Councillors fear that a new standard gauge line between Merriton and Crystal Brook will direct traffic from the line to Broken Hill via Terowie [and Riverton and Burra]. Most Gawler Councillors are not perturbed by this proposal. The SAR is probably the largest single employer of personnel in Riverton and also in Gawler.

Burra Football Club held its Annual Dinner and Presentation Night in the RSL Hall last Saturday. About 130 attended. President L.A. Beinke welcomed those who attended. Trophy winners:

‘A’ Grade

Fairest & Most Brilliant R. Jenkins

Most Consistent D. Buckingham

Most Effective B. Eberhard

Best Backman J. Phillips

Best Forward W. Holness

‘B’ Grade

Fairest & Most Brilliant R. James

Most Consistent K. Southall

Most Effective R. James

Best Backman F. Fennell

Best Forward K. Pope

Mr & Mrs A. Kotz of Welsh Place celebrate their Golden Wedding on 23 September. The marriage was celebrated at Manoora Catholic Church 23 September 1914.

Adelaide Wool Sales. Top district price was obtained by Mrs B .Hannaford of Hallett at 801⁄2d.

[Other local district prices are printed.]

Mr E.W. Dunhill of Burra North completed 73 years of service as a Local Preacher in the Methodist Church on 20 September. This is a record unparalleled in Australia. Mr Dunhill was born at Kersbrook and in early life went to WA. He married there in 1908 and returned to SA in 1909. He took up residence in Burra in 1915 and carried on a business as a blacksmith for 45 years, relinquishing it only five years ago at the age of 83*. Mr Dunhill was the first man in Australia to receive a certificate recognising 60 years of service to the Church as a Lay Preacher. He has also given long service in Sunday school work, with 37 years as Superintendent. The President of Conference sent a letter of congratulations to Mr Dunhill, who will be 90 on 19 October.

[Clearly this does not accord with his being 90 in October.]

87, 37 (3), 22 Sep. 1964, pages 1 & 5 [Number previously used in 1956 and 1964.]

Burra Races last Wednesday were well attended. On Tuesday night 37 points of rain fell, but although Wednesday was windy, it was dry. The track was in good condition. There was good racing, although there were only four starters in each of five races and five in the other two. G. Petty, riding Golden Viking fell heavily in the second race when the horse clipped the heels of Fords Bay [or Ford’s Bay?] as they entered the straight. He was not seriously hurt, but did not ride again for the meeting. The Burra Cup resulted in a dead heat. An anonymous donor provided an identical trophy for the event. The CWA ladies provided the catering. [Results are printed on page 5.]
