87, 37 (3), 22 Sep. 1964, page 8 [Number previously used in 1956 and 1964.]

Obituary. Alfred Stanley Barrett

Mr Barrett was born at Goodwood in 1887. He was a member of the gifted Barrett family which conducted many evangelical meetings throughout the state. When he joined his brothers he played the music at their meetings and the elder brothers gave the messages. He became a Home Missionary and worked on Home Mission Stations where his practical help in building Churches was appreciated. He was received into the Ministry in 1919 and ordained in 1923. He worked in churches in the following circuits: Penong, Lameroo, Tailem Bend, Kulpara, Tumby Bay, Broken Hill, Minlaton, Nairne, Burra, Quorn and Woodside. He married Miss Alice Whitbread on 20 August 1914. His wife greatly assisted in the ministry. Ill health forced his retirement, but he continued to do the work of his ministry through writing. The funeral service was held in Redruth Methodist Church on Saturday and was conducted by the President of the Sa Conference Rev. B.H. Phillips, assisted by Chairman of the District Rev. C.F. Wells and the local minister Rev. M.A. Lind.

[Born 29 January 1887 Goodwood: died 17 September 1964 Burra. He had been the minister for the Burra-Redruth Circuit 1943-47.]

87, 39 (2), 29 Sep. 1964, page 1 [Number previously used in 1956.]

Weather. Further general soaking rains of between one and two inches have made this one of the best Septembers for years. On the inside country crops have been progressing very favourably. Over the weekend Burra recorded 81 points and rain continued on Monday. Many areas close to the town received up to 150 points. Mt Bryan East recorded 165 and Farrell Flat 132. To the east Woolgangi received 131, Baldina 130, Pine Valley 116, Quondong 134, Old Koomooloo 150, Balah 94 and Mongolata 175 and still raining there heavily.

Bowls. A meeting sponsored by the local RSL at Booborowie has resolved to form a Bowling Club. Mr A. Pearce was elected President, Mr F. Dinham is Secretary, Mr H. Quinn is Treasurer and Mr T.J. Bailey is Patron. Mr A. Seekamp is Vice-President. The green will be located on the Recreation Ground.

Burra Town Council has decided to build a public toilet block on the site adjoining the present men’s toilet. It will be built of coloured Besser Brick 38 ft x 9 ft high. [And the other dimension?]

Burra Small Bore Club opened its season on Wednesday night. The range fired was double 25 yards. Ross Gilbert was best off the rifle and A. Angel won on handicap.

Kooringa Methodist Church will celebrate the Golden Jubilee of the present building next Sunday 4 October. Rev. G.C. Hutchinson, a former minister of the Kooringa Church, will return as guest speaker. He was stationed at Burra 1933-36. The first Wesleyan Methodist church was built on the present site in 1847 by Rev. John Harcourt and enlarged under Rev. H.A. Wilson who was in charge 1854-58. A gallery was added in the time of Rev. R.C. Flockhart, who followed Rev. Wilson. The building served for 66 years before being replaced in 1914 under the direction of Rev. J.H. Nield. A capacity crowd of 400 filled the church to commence the three day celebration of its opening. Guests at the time included the President of the SA Conference, Rev. G. Hall, the Rev. Samuel Knight (a former minister), Rev. Henry Howard (a notable preacher from Pirie St Methodist Church, Adelaide) and His Honour the Chief Justice, Sir Samuel Way, whose father was a Primitive Methodist Minister in Burra.

87, 39 (2), 29 Sep. 1964, page 3 [Number previously used in 1956.]

Advt. Burra Pictures, 3 & 5 October

The Beatles in A Hard Days’ Night

87, 39 (2), 29 Sep. 1964, page 4 [Number previously used in 1956.]

Marriage. Church of the Good Shepherd, Plympton, recently

Catherine Helen Langsford, elder daughter of Mr & Mrs G.C. Langsford of Pt Elliot, married

Peter Ronald Sandercock, elder son of Mr & Mrs R.H. Sandercock of Burra.

Obituary. William Henry Lloyd died 7 September 1964. He was born at Erskine in 1889 and came with his parents to the Ironmine district and took up a property for farming. He has remained there ever since. He married Ivy Flower 28 July 1917. He was a tower of strength in the Ironmine and Redruth Methodist Churches, serving in many ways. For 26 years he was Superintendent of the Sunday school and a leader in young people’s organisations. He was Secretary of the Ironmine Trust until he retired to Burra and he served many times as Circuit Steward. He was a life member of the Burra Show Society and President of the Burra Show Committee and of the Burra Library Committee. He was a member of the Masonic Lodge. He leaves a widow and two children: Mr Ray Lloyd and Meryl, Mrs R.J. White.

[Born 17 September 1888 Erskine: died 7 September 1964 Adelaide, residence Burra North.]

Burra Town Council, 21 September

ETSA is permitted to erect a temporary office at Burra North for a maximum period of 12 months.

A plan for erecting a combined toilet block on the site of the existing men’s toilet, opposite the Town Hall was adopted.

87, 40 (2), 6 Oct. 1964, page 1 [Number previously used in 1956.]

Kooringa Methodist Church Golden Jubilee

Members past and present filled the church on Sunday 4 October for the Jubilee Service. The Resident Minister Rev. M.A. Lind conducted the morning service. In 1914 the late Rev. J.C .Jennison had read the Old Testament Lesson and at the Jubilee his grandson Mr Ray Jennison read the lesson in his stead. Sir Philip McBride, who was the first bridegroom married in the present building, read the New Testament Lesson. The guest preacher was the Rev. G.C. Hutchinson, ex-President of the Methodist Conference and Kooringa Minister from 1933-36.

Mr & Mrs Robert Broad acted as Host and Hostess at the luncheon. Mr Broad is Trust Secretary. The ladies of the church catered for 160 guests. The afternoon was a great time for reunion. Among the large congregation for the Evening Service were Rev. R. Jenner, the immediate past minister and his family and Rev. M.S. Martin and his family. The Jubilee of the building was also the Kooringa Church’s 118th Anniversary. The guest speaker again gave the address. Supper followed in the hall.

‘Grateful’ writes in appreciation of the work done at the Burra Cemetery, congratulating the Council and all those connected with the task.

J. Carpenter writes on behalf of the TPI Badge Appeal in Burra on 9 & 10 October.

Aberdeen Football Club held a wind-up dinner at the Oddfellows’ Hall on Saturday night.

Burra Catholic Ball. Although this was an enjoyable function, the response was rather disappointing and door takings amounted to only £45. Mayor E.T. Baulderstone opened the Ball. During the evening the Sportsman of the Year was announced by Mr Norman H. Tosh JP. The three contenders were Kevin Lane of Aberdeen Football Club, Heather Angel of Burra Basketball Club and Barry Taylor of Burra footballers Cricket Club. The award went to Heather Angel. Profit for the evening should be £40-£50.

87, 40 (2), 6 Oct. 1964, page 8 [Number previously used in 1956.]

Burra & District War Memorial Committee held its AGM. President D. Halliday reported that had raised £940 over several months to provide for a new toilet block and the grassing of the oval. £231 was left over and transferred to the account to provide reticulation services. A bore was sunk 180 ft by Mr Thomas for a cost of £200. The flow was less than hoped for, but advice is being sought and quotes obtained for reticulation. Elected: President, D.A. Halliday; Vice-President, P.W. Holness; Secretary, A.C. Heinrich and Treasurer, T.G .Perry.

87, 41 (2), 13 Oct. 1964, page 1 [Number previously used in 1956.]

Burra Golf Associates closed their season on 30 September and held their AGM. They elected: Patroness, Mrs A.L. Collins; President, Mrs R.K. Pearse; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames T. Padbury & H. Topsfield; Secretary, Mrs E. Jeffery; Assistant Secretary, Mrs A. Wright; Treasurer, Mrs R. Mueller; Captain and Handicap Manager, Mrs M. Nicholls and Vice-Captain, Mrs D.H. Field.

Weather. The paper reports 117 points of rain so far for October. This it says is for the past week, but does not include Saturday for some reason, even though the report of the show on the same page says it rained persistently. Then in a postscript it adds that 15 points fell before 9 a.m. on Saturday and a further 36 points to 9 a.m. Monday.

Daisy Kennedy and Mr A.L. Kennedy

This brother and sister returned to Burra for a visit, having left the town in 1895. Daisy was born at the Commercial Hotel in 1893.

‘She was to become the world’s greatest violinist of her day.’

She went abroad for her training and stayed overseas, although she made a number of triumphant tours of Australia after 1914. The family lived in a house in Kangaroo Street (now occupied by Mr & Mrs M.W. Eberhard and family). She also had a look at the school where her father was headmaster from 1892 to 1895. Her brother Mr A.L. Kennedy, who accompanied her, was one of Mawson’s companions on his Antarctic journeys. Later he surveyed the vast area of the Kimberley in WA and became one of Australia’s leading geologists and mineralogists. The pair spent an hour visiting their old home in Kangaroo Street, where they met Mrs Eberhard’s mother, Mrs Quinn, who had been at school with A.L. Kennedy. Daisy Kennedy was first married to the great pianist Benna Mosceiwitsh and then to John Drinkwater, the English poet, writer and playwright. She now lives in London and her brother in WA.

[Of the six Kennedy children, only Daisy Fowler Kennedy was born in Burra (Kooringa) 16 January 1893. Alexander Lorimer Kennedy had been born 23 April 1889 at Woodside.]

87, 41 (2), 13 Oct. 1964, pages 1 & 6 [Number previously used in 1956.]

Burra Show 1964

The show last Saturday was opened by the Governor Sir Edric Bastyan. Attendance was about 2,000 and the gate takings were £179, only about £10 below 1963 despite a showery morning and a persistently wet afternoon. Previous rain meant the grounds were probably the wettest ever underfoot. Despite this the crowds came and ring events and other activities continued. The SA Police Band made a small contribution at the opening, but was otherwise prevented from performing by the rain and returned to the city at about 3 p.m. The Governor opened the show at about 12.45 p.m. He arrived in the morning and stayed at the Commercial Hotel, due to the changed arrangements because of the weather. There he was surprised to find himself speaking Arabic with Mr Rasheed. After the Governor’s speech [which is printed] the band played The Song of Australia and the official party then adjourned for luncheon. After lunch the Governor toured all the exhibits and watched some of the ring events.

Industrial displays occupied more space than for many years.

Side shows were more numerous, but patronage was quiet due to the rain.

The Schools’ Display was a fine effort and Rural Youth had a display on Bush Fire Prevention.

Young’s Caterers of Melrose did an excellent job with the catering.

The Rural Youth Club organised a dance in the pavilion in the evening and door takings were £22.

[Judges’ comments on each section are then printed.]

87, 41 (2), 13 Oct. 1964, page 3 [Number previously used in 1956.]

87, 43 (3), 27 Oct. 1964, page 1 [Number previously used in 1956 & 1957.]

Burra & District Swimming Pool will open on Saturday 21 November. The pool will be cleaned and painted this week and should be filled with water by Wednesday next week. Applications are called for the position of caretaker. Season tickets will cost £1-1-0 and £2-2-0.

Burra Small Bore Club

The annual teams shoot was fired at Burra on Sunday. Morgan nominated two teams and Morgan No. 1 team won the Williams’ Shield. Other teams competing were Burra, Peterborough and Clare.

Burra Bowling Associates opened their 1964-65 season on Wednesday 21 October.

J. Carpenter writes as Hon. State Secretary of TPI to thank Burra and District for contributing £84-7-10 at the Badge Day Appeal this year.

St Mary’s Anglican Church

The organ in St Mary’s was installed in 1904 when provision was made to add several ranks of pipes, or ‘stops’ so complete the tonal range. To date this has not been done, but now the Rector Rev. G.D. Sibly has been able to purchase a second hand rank to complete the ‘Great Organ’. These pipes will be installed this week. Rev. Sibly hopes to be able to announce that the £75 cost has been donated. £20 has already been received. Organist Dr J.V. Peters will give a recital for the 116th Patronal Festival of the parish next Sunday.

87, 43 (3), 27 Oct. 1964, page 2 [Number previously used in 1956 & 1957.]

Notice. Redruth Methodist Sunday School will hold its Anniversary Services next Sunday at 11 a.m. and 3 p.m. Preacher Rev. M. Lind.

Burra Town Council, 19 October

The Council will seek a discussion with the Education Department Inspector concerning the maintenance of unmade tracks through Council property leased by the Department.

The footbridge opposite Justice Lane is to be repaired.

Council will advance £50 towards the purchase of pumping equipment at the oval, repayable at the rate of £100 p.a.

87, 43 (3), 27 Oct. 1964, page 8 [Number previously used in 1956 & 1957.]

Collinsville Stud Ewe Sale of 15 October is reported in detail.

87, 44 (3), 3 Nov. 1964, page 1 [Number previously used in 1956 & 1957.]

St Mary’s Patronal Festival was observed on Sunday. Rev. G.D. Sibly was the preacher and Dr J.V. Peters played the organ for the sung Eucharist. Over 250 people attended the evening service, which was followed by an organ recital by Dr Peters. The recital was a balanced selection of music by Bach, Buxtehude, Stanley, Purcell and Clérambault: Bach Toccata & Fugue in D Minor

John Stanley Suite

Clérambault Dialogue for Organ

Bach Fugue in B Minor

The Rector was able to announce that the cost of the new stop has been raised. The stop was made good use of in the Suite by John Stanley.

Mr Wayne Dodds, Burra manager for Oates Ltd, was severely injured on Sunday when he fell from a 50 ft pine tree at Brown Hill Creek in Adelaide. Details of the incident are not known, but Mr Dodds is suffering from head and internal injuries, broken ribs, pelvis and ankle.

Mt Bryan Agricultural Bureau held their Annual Inspection of Pastures on 27 October, which this year was entitled Farm Field Day and Pasture Inspection. Mr Bruce Hall of the Department of Agriculture in Jamestown attended. Properties inspected were those of Mr McInnes and Mr Dave Thomas.

Weather. The rainfall so far this year is 17.49 inches. This is 18 points above the average annual rainfall for the town.

Bowls

Burra Green 107 defeated Clare Red 79

Burra Blue 96 defeated Clare Green 90

Burra Gold 92 defeated Auburn 89

‘Mt Torrens’ writes urging the effort put in by country women towards Flower Day in Adelaide be diverted to beautifying the approaches to country towns, with the removal of dead trees etc. and plantings of new trees, with the lower branches not trimmed so as to provide better shelter.

87, 46 (3), 17 Nov. 1964, page 1 [Number previously used in 1956 & 1957.]

Kindergarten Day in Burra, 13 November

Last Friday the Hon. Sir Bruce Ross LLB officially opened the newly registered Kindergarten in the morning and in the afternoon the Christmas Tree Carnival in the Town Hall. The functions were well attended and the District Ladies’ Organisations raised £190. The official party at the Kindergarten comprised: Sir Bruce Ross & Lady Ross; Mrs R.B. Pitcher, President of the Burra Branch; Miss Mellor, Superintendent of Kindergartens; The Mayor & Mayoress, Mr & Mrs E.T. Baulderstone; Mr Rex Warnes & Mrs Warnes; Mr L.A. Beinke President of the Burra Air Force Association and Mr G.R. Finch, Chairman of Burra Burra DC. [The punctuation makes it unclear whether Rex Warnes or L.A. Beinke was President of the AFA, but I am not aware Rex Warnes was in the RAAF.]

Mrs Pitcher welcomed the guests. She thanked Mrs J. Carpenter for her great effort in getting the Kindergarten started and the Air Force Association for granting a 20 year lease at £1 p.a. Sir Bruce Ross said Mrs Carpenter had started the effort with a small band of children in the Methodist Church Hall and as interest grew it was decided to join the Kindergarten Union, which was done on 1 April 1964. The Kindergarten began with half day periods, but now two afternoons have been added and no less than 43 young children attend. He unveiled a plaque and opened the door. Sir Bruce said the first Kindergarten had been founded in SA in 1906 and by 1945 there were still only 10, but now there were 119. Sir Bruce Ross also opened the Christmas Tree Carnival in the Town Hall. The best exhibit was the entry of the ‘Eastern Dorcas Society’. [Photo in 87, 47 (3) 24 Nov. 1964.] Takings for the day amounted to £190. [Kindergarten or Christmas Tree: or are they the same thing as far as the money goes?

Mr Wayne Dodds is slowly recovering from his fall. He suffered concussion, a fractured pelvis and ankle, a punctured bladder and broke all his left ribs.

Mr J.R. Barker of Baldina has found an interesting item on his property. It was a pile of thin plastic 12-15 ft across and 2 ft high and far too heavy to lift. Attached to either end was a solid round cylinder and to one of them a long nylon rope was fixed. It appears likely to have been a large tethered balloon, perhaps 100 ft across, which has escaped from somewhere. So far no one has reported seeing it in flight.

Remembrance Day was commemorated on 11 November at the Fallen Soldiers’ Memorial in Market Square. Rev. Lind officiated at the service and wreaths were laid by representatives of the RSL, AFA, Demobilised Soldiers’ Association, the District & Town Councils and the Pensioners’ League. [Rev. Lind’s address is printed.]

87, 46 (3), 17 Nov. 1964, page 3 [Number previously used in 1956 & 1957.]

87, 47 (3), 24 Nov. 1964, page 1 [Number previously used in 1956 & 1957.]

Housing Trust. The Town Council has offered the remainder of the triangular portion of land alongside the PMG line shop to the SA Housing Trust for the purpose of erection of 4 or 5 rental homes. This portion of land is about 1 acre immediately behind the new Electricity Trust’s £17,000 Office and Depot. It is understood a start will be made on the new depot early in 1965. A new Electricity Trust home is to be built on the east side of the block previously owned by the late Mr Luke Day. [Luke Day died 30 August 1962 and this seems to be the first reference to his death. CHECK THIS.]

The Old Jinker. The SA Government Tourist Bureau has advised the Town Council that a subsidy of £230 has been granted towards the cost of housing the old jinker at the Burra Mine. The total cost is estimated at £460 and the other £230 will be found by the Town Council and the Burra Branch of the National Trust. The building is to be erected on the site where the jinker now stands and must be completed by 28 February 1965.

Marriage. Phyllis Willis has married Peter Abbott and the couple will live in Adelaide. [Farrell Flat news.]

Councillor R.B .Pitcher has resigned because he is leaving the district. He has represented West Ward since July 1960. Nominations are called by 4 December for his replacement.

[A Supplementary Election Notice appears on page 3.]

School Safety Zones. The recently completed Safety Zones for Burra School are the result of a co-operative effort by the Headmaster, the Primary School Committee and the High School Council, with the help of the Town and District Councils.

Burra Burra Hospital Inc.

The completion of the new private rooms and administrative block is now in sight. Furnishings have been selected and an effective call system and telephone switchboard has been installed. A car park has been provided and lawn areas are being prepared. Vinyl tiles have been laid and painting is in progress. J.W.M. Gillieson will take over from H.J .Foote as Secretary-Manager on 1 December 1964 and the new building will be opened by the Chief Secretary Hon. Sir Lyell McEwin on 11 December 1964.

87, 47 (3), 24 Nov. 1964, page 2 [Number previously used in 1956 & 1957.]

Advt. Kearns Brothers Pty Ltd will conduct an auction at the Burra RSL Rooms on 27 November under instructions from solicitors acting for the trustees in the Bessie Drew settlement.

Lot 1. Land 85 ft 3 inches frontage to Commercial Street and a depth of 221 ft, running back to Mt Pleasant Street, on which is erected a stone and brick building of four shops with plate glass windows, storerooms and conveniences, subject to a lease to Bence’s Ltd, expiring in March 1965. (One shop is subleased to Serv-Wel stores.

Lot 2. Four lock-up shops built of bluestone and brick with plate glass windows. Two let at £2 a week and two vacant. Located in Market Street.

87, 49 (4), 8 Dec. 1964, page 7 [Number previously used in 1956 & twice in 1957.]

Burra National Trust held its first AGM in the CWA Rooms 16 November. Mr Andrew Tennant was re-elected Chairman. Miss E. Tiver was re-elected Treasurer. Mrs R. Pitcher resigned as Secretary and Misses P. & C. Brown were appointed Joint Secretaries. During the year Aboriginal carvings at Baldina Creek were inspected and so were dugouts, Paxton Square and several shops and buildings.

87, 50 (3), 15 Dec. 1964, page 1 [Number previously used in 1956 & 1957.]

Christmas Eve in Burra will see shops open till 9 p.m. Father Christmas will arrive at 9.10 p.m. to distribute free ice creams and sweets. A merry-go-round will operate in the day and evening. Shop will be closed on Saturday 26 December and on Saturday 2 January.

Carols by Candlelight was held on Sunday 13 December and despite the rather cold conditions about £60 was raised. Compere for the evening was Mr Alec Macaskell of Radio 5AD and guest artist was Mr Eric Smart, tenor. The Pre-School Kindergarten presented a Nativity Scene and the Mayor delivered a Christmas message.

The Burra RSL held its Annual Reunion Dinner on Saturday night with State President Mr Eric Smith as the guest speaker. The excellent buffet dinner was provided by the Ladies’ Auxiliary.

87, 50 (3), 15 Dec. 1964, pages 1, 4 & 12 [Number previously used in 1956 & 1957.]

Burra Hospital

Last Friday afternoon the Hon. Sir Lyell McEwin opened the new building at the Burra Hospital. The Vice-Chairman of the Hospital Board Mr Eric Ashby introduced the Mayor E.T. Baulderstone, who extended a welcome to Sir Lyell. The Mayor said that Burra had played an important part in the economy of SA for almost 120 years, first through the days of the copper mine and later with the sheep industry. The Mayor also welcomed Mr G. Gilfillan, Matron Croeser and two Hospital Inspectors, Messrs O’Donnell & Kelly. He also welcomed the presence of Miss Siegele who took up duties at the Hospital in 1924 and was appointed Matron six months later. She held the position for ten years. Mrs Peak and the Misses G. & E. Williams were representatives of pioneer families. Mrs Peal and Miss Gertrude Williams were daughters of Mrs E.C. Williams nee Kathryn Watson, the first fully trained nurse at the Hospital, who came from England in 1876. Other Hospitals were also represented at the opening.

Mr Ron Pearse spoke as Chairman of the Hospital Board. He said Sir Lyell had been the obvious choice to open the building, not just because he was Chief Secretary and Minister of Health, but also because he had taken a personal interest in the Hospital.

Sir Lyell recalled earlier visits as the work was in progress and visits too when Dr Steele was in the town and the hospital faced drainage problems and all sorts of embarrassments. Out of these troubles had emerged the most attractive development seen today. Burra was one of about three places which had started a hospital before any assistance was available from Government. [He went on to recount how Government had moved from a pound for pound subsidy to a two pound for one pound subsidy and that subsidies now also covered furnishings and other items, which had only gained such recognition in recent years.]

Sir Lyell went on to praise the development plan for the Hospital and of course the Government policies supporting hospitals generally and their equipment. He had words of praise for the contractor Mr Mass and the architect Messrs Stapledon [sic] & Michael. He also had praise for the staff and the Women’s auxiliary and the Board of Management.

Mr Glen Finch moved a vote of thanks to Sit Lyell, which was seconded by Dr L.G. Miller.

Mr Pearse then handed Mrs John Gebhardt and Mrs Andrew Tennant Honorary Life Membership Certificates.

87, 50 (3), 15 Dec. 1964, page 3 [Number previously used in 1956 & 1957.]

87, 50 (3), 15 Dec. 1964, page 5 [Number previously used in 1956 & 1957.]

Obituary. Bridget Teresa Preiss died 3 April aged 94. She was born 19 December 1870, the daughter of the late Matthew & Ellen Clarke of Pekina. She was the eldest of a family of eight, all of whom predeceased her. She married Charles William Preiss on 12 April 1893. There were nine children, of whom Lawrence Vincent died in infancy. The family lived at Spalding, Pekina, Yongala and Carrieton before finally settling at Burra. Bridget Teresa Preiss lived in Paxton Square for 53 years. For 46 years she was the honorary caretaker of St Joseph’s Church, which was her second home. [See also 86, 13 (3), 7 Apr. 1964, page 7. Born and married as Bridget Clark, but had children as Bridget Teresa, Bridget Theresea and Bridget Theresia Preiss. Born 19 December 1870 South Rhine SA.]

Burra War Memorial Oval. A new pump has been fitted to the bore. Most of the spray equipment has arrived and it is hoped it can be fitted early in the New Year.

Weather. Cool weather has delayed reaping. On Monday rainfall of 74 points was recorded at the post office.

87, 51 (2), 22 Dec. 1964, pages 1 & 4 [Number previously used in 1957.]

Burra High School Speech Night

Headmaster R. Mueller’s Report for 1964.

The School re-opened with an enrolment of 185, up 34 on 1963. This is due to the retention of students in the upper school, possibly influenced by the raising of the school leaving age to 15. It is likely the future enrolment will fluctuate around the 200 mark. Staff changes: Miss N. Lawes resigned to change her name to McElroy. Mr B. McElroy transferred to Gilles Plains. Miss A. Aistrope moved to Adelaide. Miss E. McCabe went overseas and Miss B. Hogan and Mr W. Standing were appointed to Teachers’ College. Mr K. Hicks was transferred to Nuriootpa during the year. Mr R. Wright came from Gladstone, Mr I. Norton from Salisbury, Mr E. Johns & Miss L. Briggs were appointed from Teachers’ College. Local, Miss P. Zanker, was appointed a Junior Teacher. Mr Heywood from Streaky Bay replaced Mr Hicks. This year we have been informed that Senior Master Mr O’ Connor, is moving to Peterborough. Miss Callier is moving to Darwin. Mr Johns is also being transferred. Miss Zanker moves to Teachers’ College. I am being transferred to Naracoorte. Replacements for 1965 will be Mr Farrow as Headmaster from AHS, Mr Brand from Peterborough as Senior Master and Mr Morris as Junior Assistant.

The High School Council has given the school sound support under Mr Jennison’s leadership.

The Parent & Friends’ Association has been very active. They provided afternoon tea for Sports Day and arranged a most successful Ball (profit £100). Tomorrow they will provide a sit-down banquet in this hall for over 200. £200 has been spent on library books and physical education equipment. The prefects have set a high standard of conduct and served the school well.

The successful Swimming Carnival was won by Steele House.

There was a whole school excursion to Renmark via Truro, Blanchetown, Waikerie, Kingston, Berri and Morgan. Many people are thanked for the provision of transport.

The variety evening performance in the Town Hall was an innovation, which proved very successful and raised over £30 for the magazine fund. Many parents and friends took advantage of the visiting day.

The Intermediate Class visited Clare to see a performance of The Merchant of Venice.

Last week an Advertiser tennis coaching school was run on the school’s tennis courts.

Clubs were introduced this year: public speaking, Red Cross, gymnastics, motor mechanics, musical appreciation, athletics, clay modelling and dramatics.

Burra won the Handicap Shield at the Inter-High School Sports.

The school won £40 from the Savings Bank Award.

Various speakers addressed the school about employment prospects. A new tennis wall has been erected on the Statton Sports Area and a large area asphalted for playing space. The newly developed playing ground is covering well with grass. Books worth £170 have been added to the library and £100 worth of physical equipment has been purchased. A new record player has been purchased. Some improvements have been made to toilets and others await completion. Approval has been given to convert the old laboratory to a staff room, but so far this has not happened. Other approvals have been for a new change room, a chain wire boundary fence and repainting.

PEB results in 1963 were outstanding with an 88% Leaving subject pass rate and 84% for Intermediate subjects. In Leaving 14 of the 15 candidates gained certificates and in Intermediate 15 of the 22. Dianne Wood is congratulated for obtaining a Continuation Exhibition and the A.B. Riggs Award.

The beneficiaries of the estate of the late Dr David MacDonald Steele have made available the income from the sum of £250 to be awarded to the Dux of the School or for any other purpose designated by the High School Council on the recommendation of the Headmaster. For this year £12 is made available with £6 for the Dux and £6 for the library (the latter being subsidised pound for pound).

87, 51 (2), 22 Dec. 1964, page 3 [Number previously used in 1957.]

Burra Small Bore Club. On 9 December a double 50 yards shoot saw P. Mengersen top both off the rifle and on handicap. On Wednesday over double 75 yards Ross Gilbert was best off the rifle and Kevin Pope led on handicap. On Monday night ten members took part in Morgan Club’s Christmas Shoot over 25 yards. On Saturday night members visited Peterborough for that club’s Christmas Shoot.

Night Basketball

Comets 43 defeated Aberdeen 13

Polka Dots 41 defeated Booborowie 19

Obituary. Roy William Lloyd died suddenly 25 November. He was born at Erskine 10 May 1895 to pioneering Methodist parents who instilled in him and all their children the great wealth of Christian character. Roy came to this district as a child with his parents, who took up the property known as Braefoot. He began his education at Erskine and finished it at Copperhouse. He was deeply respected in the community. In WWI he enlisted in the AIF and served in the 32nd Battalion in France and Belgium and on his return took up a Soldiers’ Settlement Farm at Flagstaff. On March 16 ‘of that year’ [sic: for 1927] he married Annie May Morgan in the Ironmine Methodist Church. Roy Lloyd had that rare gift of dependability and was often selected as a spokesman. His leadership was noticeable in his WWI service and in WWI, in which he gave service in the VDC. The Methodist Church, especially at Ironmine pays tribute to his unassuming service. He gave great support to the interests of young people and supported also the RSL. He contributed a unique service to the community through his gift of water divining and over 100 bores and windmills stand as a memorial to this gift. He is survived by his widow and four children: Colin, Mary Mrs Don White, Claire Mrs Athol Tiver and Donald. There are eight grandchildren.

[Born 10 May 1895 Hundred of Morgan.]

87, 51 (2), 22 Dec. 1964, page 6 [Number previously used in 1957.]

Notice. Burra Town Council

Pursuant to Section 139 of the Local Government Act 1934-62, the Council has appointed C.H. Cummins to act as Councillor for West Ward to 30 June 1966.

[When no nominations had been received for the vacancy when the period expired on 4 December, Council acted on 21 December to co-opt C.H. Cummins as Councillor for West Ward.]

87, 51 (2), 22 Dec. 1964, page 8 [Number previously used in 1957.]

Burra Hospital

The speech made by Mr R. Pearse, Chairman of the Board, at the opening of the new hospital building, is printed.

He thanked the staff for handling all the inconveniences during building operations without complaint. The District Council and its employees also provided unpaid help. The Town Council attended to cleaning of the footpaths and streets associated with the building. The doctors also spent much time giving aid and advice. The Board members and the Secretary Mr H. Foote also contributed a great deal of time and effort. The architects are commended for blending the new building in with the old. The public also had a huge role to play by contributing £5,000 between 29 October and 16 December 1963. Further contributions would be welcome because over the past 12 months costs have increased between 20 & 25%. Mr Pearse then said a few words on the history of the hospital. The first hospital [Bleak House] was built by the mining company, just the other side of the old power house. In 1876 the Burra Hospital was formed in what had been the original Burra hotel, then owned by the licensee Mr Alfred Barker. (Mr John Barker is a grandson and the only family representative in the district today.) Later Men’s and Women’s Wards were added, followed by a theatre block and some private rooms. Later still, through the courtesy of Mr James Gallagher, an Isolation Block was added. (His child was the first patient there.) In 1924 the Maternity Wing was added. A major plan for redevelopment was formulated in 1953 and the Nurses’ Home was erected. This plan’s other aspects were not proceeded with and the present Board thought it rather too big for the present needs of the district and the cost would have been excessive. The present building is stage one of three of the new plan for redevelopment. Next the pantry will be modernised. The aim is to reduce the number of levels in the hospital. We want to alter the theatre block and casualty to place all on one level, except for the Maternity Wing.

Mrs Alice Peak & Miss Gertrude Williams attended the hospital opening and reported on Nurse Catherine Watson, who was the first fully trained nurse at the Burra Hospital. She came from England on the Oaklands in 1876 as a nurse, attending on one of the passengers. She had intended to return, but instead agreed to go to Burra. She found conditions primitive at the converted hotel that was the hospital. Her first meal was on the end of the kitchen table, from a tin plate and pannikin, while the cook did the washing up at the other end. She soon managed to introduce china for staff and patients. Rubbish was emptied into a disused shaft on the grounds. She was bothered by the continuous noise from the ore crushers, but the mines closed down soon after she arrived. Equipment was minimal and at least one man’s leg was amputated using the meat saw from the kitchen. Operations were performed on the counter of the old bar. A typhoid epidemic struck while the railway was being extended to Terowie and so many patients arrived that they had to be accommodated on the floor of the old bar. The cook had no idea of an invalid diet and provided a thick Scotch broth for the typhoid patients. Nurse Watson sent the orderly to fetch the doctor. The orderly was Mr William Wilson, who had resigned from the Police Department and helped Nurse Watson with the male patients. He held the position for about 20 years until retiring. Changes came gradually. The bar was converted to a Women’s Ward. The long room became the Men’s Ward. The smaller rooms were assigned to domestic uses. After two years Nurse Watson decided not to return to the Royal Berkshire Hospital in Reading, where she had been trained. She married C.C. Williams. Soon after this the Hospital purchased its first surgical instruments and Dr Brummitt came and took her to see them. She was delighted at this advance in the treatment of the sick.

Characteristics of the 1964 paper.

The paper had a standard size of 8 pages of 7 columns, with occasional supplements, but more usually extra material was accommodated by expanding the paper to 10 or even 12 pages. These expanded issues often had very confusing numbering of the pages.

Most news was carried on page 1 with sport a big part of subsequent pages. Another feature of other pages was the printing of reports from district towns – Spalding, Farrell Flat and Booborowie in particular, but sometimes from Riverton and Saddleworth. Spalding was more regularly represented than others.

The layout of the paper was less regular than in earlier years. The suggested page usage is therefore more approximate than in some years. Coverage of Burra news seems to be quite reasonable.

Page 1

News

Page 2

Sales advertisements and public notices. Smaller advertisements. The Cash Column with its smaller classified type of advertisements may appear here, but migrated to almost any of the other pages except page 1.

Page 3

This could be a continuation of page 2 or may be dominated by larger advertisements. News usually occupies less than one column.

Pages 4-8

Most advertisements are larger; generally at least two columns wide and two inches or more in depth. News on these pages is usually two to three columns in total and is dominated by sport and/or reports from other parts of the wider district. Occasionally there are full page advertisements.

Photographs of local events have become more common. This year some accompany the news reports; rather than being a week or more later. Some still lag the event.

Photographs are still not included every week, however.

88, 1 (4), 12 Jan. 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1955, 1957 & 1958.]

Harvest. 190,000 bushels have been taken at the Burra Silo and the harvest is almost complete. Rail trucks were loaded yesterday and more are expected today to relieve the position.

R. Fuss of Burra North reports a strange and interesting visitor at the weekend – a porcupine or hedgehog. Ian Barry and Chris Bevan were playing in the yard and saw it sunning itself in front of the wood shed, where it seems to have established itself. It appeared several times throughout the day. Its appearance is a mystery, as they are not known around Burra, but have occasionally been seen at the Gorge at World’s End. [Presumably an echidna.]

Learn to Swim Campaign. The Education Department’s campaign is in progress and at Burra 192 are taking part, an increase of 30 on last year.

Weather. Burra recorded 124 points for December and for 1964 a total of 1,913 points, nearly 2 inches above average, although 33 points less than the 1963 total.

St Andrew’s Anglican Church at Mt Bryan held services on Sunday to celebrate its Golden Jubilee. Rural Dean of Clare Rev. S.M. Smith and Rev. G.D. Sibly of Burra officiated. A lych-gate has been erected as part of the beautification of the grounds. [The newly erected Lych-gate is pictured.] The land for the church was given by W.A. Gebhardt. He and Mr H.L. Hatherly were the first Wardens of the Church. The foundation stone was laid and dedication services were conducted by the Broughton Archdeacon Bussell. The building and furniture cost £650 and the debt of £150 was paid off on 4 February 1921. The consecration was not carried out till 1933. This was the second church built in the parish. (The Black Springs Church was purchased from the Methodists.) There are two stained glass windows in the Sanctuary.* One is in memory of Andrew Barker Hooper, who died 28 November 1914. The altar cross and candlesticks were given by the UNREADABLE Family at Eudunda. The Sanctuary hangings and altar linen were made and given by Mrs Bloyd (the wife of the Parish Rector in 1915) and Mrs Hatherly. Several items of furniture have since been added: pews in 1960. It has twice been renovated; in 1935 at a cost of £95 and in 1958-59 at a cost of £375. Pine trees planted in the grounds are in memory of parishioners who went to WWI. The lych-gate and stone path were added in 1964. The Church is past of the Parish of Burra, which is in the Arch-Deaconry of the Broughton, within the Diocese of Adelaide. It is anticipated that the Deanery of Broughton will be ceded to strengthen the Diocese of Willochra in 1966. Present Wardens are G.S. Hawker, People’s Warden from 1949 and M. Collins, Priest’s Warden from 1960. Rectors of Burra Since St Andrew’s was built have been:

S.J. Bloyd 1910-18 (With F.H. Durford as Assistant Curate in 1915)

F.B. Hewitson 1921-27

J.S.W. Coles 1927-32

D. Redding 1933-38

C. Gray 1939-42

M.P. Cowle 1942-47

R.S.T. Pettet 1948-52

L.R. Lenthal 1953-58

T.G. Drought 1959-64

G.D. Sibly 1964-

[* St Andrew’s closed in 1998 and in March 2002 the two stained glass windows were relocated to St Mary’s in Burra.]

88, 3 (4), 26 Jan. 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1955, 1957 & 1958.]

Burra Swimming Pool

The Town Council is concerned that several items connected with the filtration plant have not been completed. The filtration plant began operation on 22 December 1963, but negotiations with the contractor continued to May 1964 with no result. Then the Council still did not know why the whole thing had not been finalised. The Club advised the Council that it owed the contractor £496 or 10% of the initial cost. This meant the Club could not claim £900 of subsidy from the Tourist Bureau because things were not up to scratch and the E & WS would not give a certificate of satisfaction. Despite repeated visits and specific requests nothing was done and at the December Council meeting it was decided to give until 21 January to have work commenced. On 18 January a Council meeting resolved to tell the contractor that if work was not completed within 14 days they would have the job completed and debit the cost to him. This follows legal advice through the Municipal Association. It should be noted that the problem is not with the actual filtration process, which is quite normal, but refers to ancillary work like cement work, pipe diameter etc.

Obituary. Mr George Bromson of Clare has died. He was well known as Secretary of the Clare North Football Club.

[George Charles Bromson died 20 January 1965 Adelaide, residence Clare aged 39. Not found on SA Births CD.]

Ken Wall of the National Bank in Burra has been transferred to Strathalbyn and will leave in about three weeks. He has been closely associated with sporting and other committees. His place will be taken by Mr R.A. Linke from Mt Gambier.

Fire. A grass fire occurred on Friday afternoon on the properties of Messrs H.J. Topsfield & S.J. Woollacott on the east side of Brewery Hill. About 75 acres of grazing was burnt.

Pranks. On Monday Mr T.G. Perry had to remove a very smelly dead rabbit from the flagpole of the District Council. Three more were seen swinging from the flagpole near Gill’s store at Burra North. Following New Year Eve Mr Terry had to remove a pushbike from the flagpole.

The Smelts Chimney. After the reference last issue to a chap named Lewis climbing the Smelts Chimney, we have been advised by W. Voumard, who saw the incident, that it was a lad named ‘Pudden’ Jordan.

[See Burra Record 57, 45, 10 Nov. 1936, page 3: Memories of Burra by Elizabeth A. Ward. Arthur Jordan was at the time a schoolboy of 12 years of age, son of the late J.D. Jordan, watchmaker, of Kooringa. He was still alive at the time of this article: Arthur Dawson Jordan born 8 March 1873 Kooringa: died 28 October 1965, Gawler. See also 88, 5 (4), 9 Feb. 1965, page 6.]

Mr J.P. Costello Headmaster of Hallett School has moved to Littlehampton, to be replaced by Mr P.J. Horgan from Seaton Park.

Swimming. The first Carnival for the Tilbrook Shield between Burra, Spalding and Clare Clubs was held at Spalding on Friday night in rather cold conditions. Spalding Club won the pennant for this meeting.

88, 4 (5), 2 Feb. 1965, pages 1 & 8 [Number previously used in 1955, 1957 & twice in 1958.]

Marriage. St Michael’s Church of England, Mitcham, Saturday

Jillian Ruth Sawtell, elder daughter of Mr & Mrs M.J. Sawtell of Lower Mitcham, married

Malcolm John Goodridge, elder son of Mr & Mrs J.E. Goodridge [sic] of Crystal Brook.

The couple will make their home at Stevenage near London in the UK. Malcolm is the son of Mr & Mrs J.C. Goodridge* [sic], who commenced business in Burra as ‘Burra Radio & Electrical Service’. Malcolm completed his secondary education in Burra and then obtained a Bachelor of Technology at Adelaide University. Following his marriage he will go to England to take up duties with the British aircraft Corporation as an Electronic Engineer. This will be his third trip to England in three years. He was Dux of Burra Primary in 1949 and of Burra High School in 1953.

[* Without the availability of birth data, parentage is uncertain, but John Consul Goodridge seems likely.]

88, 5 (4), 9 Feb. 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1955, 1957 & 1958.]

Burra Sewerage Scheme

Don Wilson Chief Inspector of the Central Board of Health has outlined a sewerage system to serve the main business section of Burra. It could be operation as early as 1966. Mr Wilson visited Burra on Wednesday and with the Mayor E.T. Baulderstone and Town Clerk W.A. Holness, inspected the shopping area, which has most problems regarding the installation of septic toilets and hand-washing facilities. A meeting of the Local Board of Health discussed ways and means of overcoming this problem. Mr Wilson outlined a scheme to provide 50-60 premises with a full sewerage system at a comparatively low cost per owner. The plan would have one sewerage pipeline commencing at the Post Office Exchange building and extending round to the vicinity of Dr Miller’s residence. A second would commence at the rear of Jennison’s used car lot and extend along Commercial Street to the main creek, taking in all businesses on the south side of Market Square. These pipes would connect with a treatment plant on the bank of the creek and effluent could possibly be used for the establishment of trees and shrubs etc. A similar scheme recently installed for the whole of Berri cost £25,000. At Berri the effluent is being used on the golf links. There is no likelihood of unpleasant odours from the treatment plant. Soakage pits and septic tanks would not be needed on the properties concerned. It is unlikely that if it were decided on, it could be in operation before January 1966. Once this scheme was decided upon the installation of septic tanks would become compulsory, without exception throughout Burra, unless connected to the sewerage drain. Depending on demand the Council is likely to term this phase 1, with other areas perhaps eventually added to the service. The Central Board of health would handle the survey, designs, plans and estimates of cost, at no charge to Burra.

Fire. A grass fire at Hallett consumed about 70 acres and several outbuildings adjacent to the railway line just south of the Hallett Station, on the western side of the station yards, on Tuesday morning last.

The Housing Trust of SA has accepted the offer of the Burra Town Council and will purchase land near the PMG line shop. An early start on building in that area is likely.

The Swimming Carnival planned for 21 February has attracted 55 swimmers from Broken Hill. Others will come from Gawler.

Burra Racing Club has been allotted Wednesday 15 September and Saturday 23 October for race meetings in 1965.

Accident/Obituary. An accident about one mile north of Saddleworth on Sunday morning [7 February] resulted in one man’s death and serious injuries to another. The accident was almost opposite the Catholic Church at about 2.45 a.m. The driver, aged 35, was dead when found at about 7 a.m. and another man aged 24 was unconscious with severe head and other injuries. The deceased, from Peterborough, was Gordon Desmond Lacey and injured was Neil Millard, also of Peterborough.

88, 5 (4), 9 Feb. 1965, page 7 [Number previously used in 1955, 1957 & 1958.]

Advt. Full page advertisement for Bence’s Ltd End of Season Clearance.

88, 5 (4), 9 Feb. 1965, page 8 [Number previously used in 1955, 1957 & 1958.]

Arthur Jordan. An article from the Gawler Bunyip of about 12 months earlier is reprinted.

Arthur D. Jordan of Gawler is 90 today. One of his most vivid recollections is likely to be the day, 78 years ago, that he climbed the Smelters’ Chimney at Burra. The young ‘Art’ Jordan shinned up the 85 ft stack with townspeople looking on. Since then he has become a citizen of Gawler and a Life Member of the Gawler Jockey Club. He managed A. Sheard’s Essex House in Gawler for 25 years and had his own drapery business for 27 years in the store occupied by Gordon Ames. He was Secretary of the Gawler Chess Club during its active years. He was born in Clare. [Born at Kooringa: see below.]

[A couple of verses of the poem When Arthur Climbed the Chimney are printed.]

[See Burra Record 57, 45, 10 Nov. 1936, page 3: Memories of Burra by Elizabeth A. Ward. Arthur Jordan was the son of the late J.D. Jordan, watchmaker, of Kooringa. Arthur Dawson Jordan born 8 March 1873 Kooringa: died 28 October 1965, Gawler.]

88, 5 (4), 9 Feb. 1965, Supplement [Number previously used in 1955, 1957 & 1958.]

[Single-sided approximately A4 size carrying 5 columns.]

Darts Club. The old Burra Hotel Darts Club has virtually been in recess. The shield is currently held by Burra and after a visit to Morgan on 21 February, which will decide who retains the shield; the club will cease to exist. A new Darts Club will be formed, to be called the Burra Darts Club.

88, 6 (4), 16 Feb. 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1955, 1957 & 1958.]

Burra High School. The enrolment on 9 February was 186, an increase of 1 on 1964. The new Headmaster is R.M. Farrow and senior Master is N.R. Brand. Also new to the staff are Messrs P. Morris & K. Schwartz and Miss D. Jones. [New students are listed.]

Hallett Primary School. Miss J. Overton has replaced Miss Hughes. The enrolment is 59 and the intake in Grade I was 9. [New students are listed.]

Leighton School. The Head Teacher Mr R. Osman reports no staff changes and an enrolment of 30 with new students John Hogan and Janette Ramm.

Farrell Flat School has 40 pupils. Miss Marie A. Green has come from Teachers’ College. [Three new students are listed.]

Mt Bryan School has no staff changes. There are 32 enrolments with three more likely to be added soon. [Three new students are listed.]

Eagle Hawks are proving troublesome at the lambing season at Mt Bryan East. Scarcity of rabbits is encouraging them. Wing spans of 7 ft 6 inches to 8 ft are reported.

Burra Darts Club has had another successful working bee at Redbanks and is ready to accept challenges from other clubs.

Walter Tiver turns 85 tomorrow.

Swimming. Preliminary Finals of the Mid North Shell Age-Group Swimming Championships were held at Burra on Sunday. 47 Finalists took part. [Winners are listed.] Almost 400 entries have been received for the Open Carnival at Burra next Sunday.

88, 6 (4), 16 Feb. 1965, pages 1 & 8 [Number previously used in 1955, 1957 & 1958.]

Burra Primary School. The enrolment is 230: 114 boys and 116 girls, which is an increase of 14 pupils on last year. There are 33 new enrolments in Grade I. Miss Kathlyn Rayner from Teachers’ College takes over Grade I from Miss Reid. [New enrolments are listed.]

A new Art Room has been established to meet the needs of the new Art & Craft Course in Primary Schools. Water has been laid on and the oval seeded. The new room will be completed at the school by mid-year, which will enable the school to set aside one room for a school library.

Burra Library held its AGM. President Miss Eunice Tiver reported a successful year. Elected were President, Miss Eunice Tiver; Vice-Presidents, Messrs W. Carpenter & P. Byrne; Secretary, R.W. Nankivell and Treasurer, H. Cornelius. During 1969 the President reported they had taken out another box subscription and had added two new books each month. The institutes Association presented 120 books and there had been private donations as well. Membership was up 2 or 3. Subscriptions were 30/- p.a. and 4/- for juveniles. The annual trading table brought in £52. During the year all duplicate books were culled and a number of juvenile books were also culled. Committee meetings were held monthly. The committee greatly regrets the loss of Mr W. Lloyd and the departure of the Treasurer Mrs K. Treleaven, who has moved to Woomera with her family. Mr H. Cornelius stepped into that role.

88, 6 (4), 16 Feb. 1965, page 2 [Number previously used in 1955, 1957 & 1958.]

Advt. Elders GM & SAFU advertise a Clearing Sale on 11 March on the property of P.B. Byles 7 miles southeast of Booborowie.

Advt. Burra High School advertises adult classes in Woodwork, Typing and Dressmaking.

Swimming. At the Inter-Club Carnival on Friday Burra took the second pennant.

88, 6 (4), 16 Feb. 1965, page 8 [Number previously used in 1955, 1957 & 1958.]

Booborowie School has no staff changes. Mr Gower remains Head Teacher with Miss T. Brooks as Assistant. Enrolment is 53, which is two less than last February, but an increase of one on December last.

[Newcomers are listed.]

St Joseph’s School has enrolled five new students. There have been no staff changes.

88, 7 (4), 23 Feb. 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1955, 1957 & 1958.]

Fire. On Sunday afternoon a bushfire began south of Clare and burned on area of some 50 to 60 square miles, devastating country between Clare, Mintaro, Farrell Flat and Hill River. A number of homes were destroyed along with many outbuildings and haystacks, sheep, cattle and miles of fencing. The fire was brought under control in the early hours of Monday morning. Patrols are still watching hot spots for potential outbreaks.

Weather. A freak windstorm on Sunday afternoon caused the collapse of a large implement shed on Mr Gordon Webster’s property at Springbank. In the process a utility was blown across the yard into the house fence, which was flattened by the impact.

Swimming. The Open Swimming Carnival at Burra on Sunday was not well attended due to the extreme heat. Some also left when new of the fire between Clare and Farrell Flat was received. The carnival itself went relatively well. For Burra Garry Hirschausen, Sandra Williams and Jill Eberhard gained trophies.

Burra High School Parents & Friends’ Assoc. welcomed new staff to the school on 18 February. Prefects for the year have been elected: Brian Simpson (Head), Graham Brook (Deputy), Darrell Field, Garry Disher, Geoffrey Collins, Trevor Willis, Jan Seekamp (Head), Jill Przibilla (Deputy), Vicki Standing, Susan Murphy, Lynette Winders and Naomi Dare.

Mr & Mrs A.J. (Tony) Ryan were tendered a farewell social in the RSL Hall on Saturday night. Mr Ryan has taken a position with the Waite Research Centre as a Shearing Instructor for SA. Planned dancing was cancelled due to the heat. The Mayor and Mayoress attended and the Mayor presented a wallet of notes to Mr Ryan.

Darts. On Sunday the Burra Dart Club journeyed to Morgan to play for the shield held by the Burra Hotel Dart Club. Burra defeated Morgan 12 games to 11 to take the shield. The new club is anxious to gain new members for greater competition.

Winston Churchill Memorial Trust

Mr T.G. Perry is in charge of the collection of funds locally for the Trust. The Trust will fund Churchill Scholarships, which will be available to anyone whose value to the community, calling or occupation would be increased by personal study and travel abroad.

88, 7 (4), 23 Feb. 1965, page 2 [Number previously used in 1955, 1957 & 1958.]

Notice. AOF Meeting to be held Friday 26 February.

Advt. Point Pass Speedway Saturday 27 February 8 p.m.

Advt. Richardson Salon will be in our new premises adjacent to the Burra Post Office from Wednesday 24 February.

88, 7 (4), 23 Feb. 1965, page 3 [Number previously used in 1955, 1957 & 1958.]

Night Basketball. Top four teams at the end of the minor rounds were: Comets, Booborowie, Spalding Blue and Hallett.

Notice. Mr & Mrs Bill Byles & Family and Mr & Mrs Summers & Family will be tendered a farewell at the Leighton Hall on Saturday 27 February.

88, 7 (4), 23 Feb. 1965, page 4 [Number previously used in 1955, 1957 & 1958.]

Burra Town Council, February

Council will meet at 9 a.m. 16 February to inspect a site for the jinker and act accordingly.

Permission was granted for the Aberdeen Tennis Club to play competitive tennis on Easter Sunday.

The matter of hiring the hall to the Methodist Youth Council for country style dancing was left in the hands of the Mayor.

Mr E. Wall’s tender for the Town Hall Toilets was accepted.

A letter will be written to the Fire Brigade complaining that members of the Brigade are arriving at the Station in response to emergency calls in a manner dangerous to the public, driving at high speed in the wrong direction on the one way [section of] street.

88, 7 (4), 23 Feb. 1965, page 5 [Number previously used in 1955, 1957 & 1958.]

Burra Gold 100 defeated Hallett White 97

Fire. A balloon released from Mildura to analyse dust in the air caused a 100 acres fire in stubble at ‘Blink Bonnie’ this afternoon when its parachute attached to its instruments fouled power lines.

Burra Small Bore Club. The 50 yards Championship was won by R. Gilbert on Wednesday 10 February.

Last Wednesday a shoot over double 75 yards saw Ross Gilbert best off the rifle and Keith Spackman win on handicap.

88, 7 (4), 23 Feb. 1965, page 7 [Number previously used in 1955, 1957 & 1958.]

Burra RSL held its AGM on 19 February. The meeting was well attended. Elected: President, H. Cornelius; Vice-Presidents, T. Rogers & A. Benger; Secretary, J. Murphy and Treasurer, B. Kotz.

The President reported a very quiet year with a very small committee and the General Committee doubles as the House Committee. There were 10 general meetings and 10 committee meetings. 53 were on parade for the Anzac Parade with the service conducted by Rev. Lind and the march led by the Pt Pirie Pipers’ Band. 19 members attended the evening service at the Kooringa Methodist Church. Remembrance Day was observed on 11 November. The Burra Primary and High Schools attended. 121 crosses were planted in memory of the fallen. The annual ball was a success. The Annual Dinner was held on 12 December and was attended by 40 locals and 18 visitors. Successful badge days were held for Legacy, Myrtle Bank, Anzac Day and Poppy Day Appeals. The branch continues to support two Legacy Wards with the money for that coming from bottles left at the club rooms. Bert Samuels left the town during the year. We provided funeral escorts for the late Ralph Thomas and Roy Lloyd.

Indoor bowls have been a success on Tuesday evenings. Bowls games were played on Anzac Day. The Ladies Auxiliary again provided great support at activities throughout the year.

88, 7 (4), 23 Feb. 1965, page 8 [Number previously used in 1955, 1957 & 1958.]

Marriage. St Mary’s Burra. Gladys Muller married Peter Hall and they have settled at Leighton.

88, 8 (4), 2 Mar. 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1955, 1957 & 1958.]

Swimming. At the Inter-Club Carnival between Clare, Spalding and Burra on Friday night Burra regained the Swimming Shield. Mr Eric Tilbrook, standing in for his father, presented the Tilbrook shield to the Captain of the Burra Club, Heather Angel. [Results are printed.]

A leading swimming coach, Mr Tony Wall, who is sponsored by ‘Rothmans’, will visit Burra on Monday 8 March. He will give instruction to swimming instructors on how to teach children.

Vandals struck the Burra Swimming Pool on Friday night and dumped many items into the pool, including tables, chairs, trestles, poles lifebuoys and a steel grating weighing half a hundredweight.

Weather. January and February 1965 have been the driest two months on record in Burra, with a registration of nil. This equals the records of February-March 1893 and December-January 1905-06.

Mt Bryan Methodist Church held its harvest festival on Sunday 28 February. A dedication service was held when Mr Horrie Edwards and family presented a lectern and Bible to the church in memory of their late husband and father. Mr Edwards had been a local preacher in the circuit for over 40 years. He was a member of the Order of Knights and Sunday school Superintendent for many years at the old church. Mr George Goodridge and Mrs Crew presented to the church an engraved music stand in memory of Mrs Goodridge who started teaching in the Sunday school of the old church when she was 17 and continued till she moved to Ironmine in 1906. She then taught there for five years. She married in 1911 and again took a Sunday school class and with her brother Horrie worked in the Sunday school till the church closed in 1939. Both Mr Edwards and Mrs Goodridge also worked in the Town Church and Sunday school for many years.

Fire. The large fire on Sunday 21 February gave Farrell Flat an uneasy time. Strong southwest winds and a temperature in excess of 100°F blew the flames from Mintaro towards Farrell Flat. Several times men fighting the fire were in danger of being trapped in pockets of fire. Units managed to check the fire three miles south of the town and a wind change swept it northeast* until it was checked at the stone wall on the Clare-Farrell Flat Road. There were heavy losses of sheep, fodder and fencing.

[* The description suggests it was swept northwest rather than northeast.]

Adelaide Wool Sales. S.J. Woollacott & Co. of Burra topped local prices with 721⁄4d.

[Other local district prices are printed.]

88, 8 (4), 2 Mar. 1965, page 3 [Number previously used in 1955, 1957 & 1958.]

Burra Gold 92 defeated Clare green 86

Saddleworth Gold 103 defeated Burra Blue 64

Hallett White 119 defeated Burra Green 72

88, 8 (4), 2 Mar. 1965, page 4 [Number previously used in 1955, 1957 & 1958.]

Burra High School. Changes to exam results are announced following supplementary exams.

Judy Dare passed 2 subjects to complete a certificate.

Leonora Snell and John Teague completed certificates by adding one subject each.

In Intermediate Lynette Winders gains a subject by being awarded an English Q.

88, 9 (3), 9 Mar. 1965, page 8 [Number previously used in 1957 & 1958.]

Burra Primary School Welfare Club held its AGM on 2 March.

The headmaster Mr Ian Auhl asked that the objectives for 1965 should include reference books for the new library. The Department will furnish the room, but reference books will be the town and district’s responsibility. A subsidy was available for preparing the lunch room for use as an art room as well as the addition of heaters to another room, the renovating of school drums and the grassing of the oval. Elected were: President, Mrs J.R. Carpenter; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames R. Thamm & D. Bannister; Secretary, Mrs J. Taylor; Assistant Secretary, Mrs D. Broderick and Treasurer, Mrs Benger. The retiring President Mrs Edith Carpenter reported that they had 54 financial members and an average attendance of 24 for 1964. In the year they had financed the preparation of a cricket pitch and purchase of sand for the sand pit and also library books, pin-up boards, maps, paint brushes, pitch pipes, a motor mower and sports equipment. The staff room had been improved. At Burra Sports Day they had run cool drinks, ice cream, sweets and afternoon tea stalls. New uniform material had been chosen.

88, 9 (3), 9 Mar. 1965, page 9 [Number previously used in 1957 & 1958.]

Burra Pre School Kindergarten held its AGM on 17 February. Attendance was poor, though 40 Children are enrolled this year. 16 people attended the meeting and elected: President, Mrs C. Brereton; Secretary, Mrs G. Webster & Treasurer, Mrs D. Ebsary. The project this year will be to add new toilets and a washroom.

88, 9 (3), 9 Mar. 1965, page 10 [Number previously used in 1957 & 1958.]

88, 9 (3), 9 Mar. 1965, page 12 [Number previously used in 1957 & 1958.]

Burra & Districts Children’s Hospital Auxiliary held its AGM and elected Mrs Baulderstone President for 1965 with Mrs Benger as Secretary. There were 11 financial members in 1964. The collection of rags and paper raised £29-13-8. The 5AD Good Friday Appeal brought in £12-3-0 and a badge day in September raised £23-10-0.

Burra Small Bore Club. The shoot over double 25 yards saw best scores from R. Gilbert and D. Griffith.

88, 10 (3), 16 Mar. 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1957 & 1958.]

Lucerne Down, located six miles north of Booborowie and comprising 2931⁄2 acres freehold was sold on 10 March for £85 per acre to East Bungaree Pty Ltd of Mt Bryan.

E. Wall & Son have started work on the new public toilet block opposite the Burra Town Hall.

Bill Lomman, 82 on 19 March, is still riding his bicycle.

The Army is continuing its recruiting drive throughout the Mid North. The team with its caravan was at the RSL Hall in Burra on 15 March and will stay until leaving at 8 a.m. on 17 March for Peterborough. Jamestown, Gladstone and Clare will follow.

88, 10 (3), 16 Mar. 1965, page 2 [Number previously used in 1957 & 1958.]

Advt. ‘Circle M’ Country Style Dancing, Burra Town Hall, 8 p.m. 26 March. Associated with Colin Huddlestone Country Style Dancing Group. Sponsored by the Burra Methodist Youth Council. Teachers are Mr & Mrs C. Everett of Brinkworth.

Obituary. Myrtle Venetta Metcalf died on 24 February. She was the wife of the late Percy Metcalf, late of Booborowie and royal Park and mother of Edie Mrs Glaetzer of Seaton Park.

[Born Myrtle Venetta Webb 6 October 1891 Hundred of Parnaroo: died Hillcrest, residence Royal Park.]

88, 11 (3), 23 Mar. 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1957 & 1958.]

State Election

On Wednesday morning Mr T.G. Perry as Returning Officer declared Mr P.H. Quirke (LCL) elected for Burra for the next term of Parliament. Final figures:

P.H. Quirke (LCL) 3467

J.H. Phelan (ALP) 2101

Adelaide Wool Sales 16-18 March saw C.J. & R. Simpson of ‘Aldina’ Mt Bryan top local prices at 651⁄4d.

[Other local district prices are printed.]

Burra Primary School annual parents meeting was held on 15 March with a pleasing attendance of 40. The Headmaster Mr I. Auhl gave an interesting address on the Democratic System of Public Schools and reported that the school is to get a new library room. The school will be 100 years old in 1877. Elected: Chairman R. Moreland and D.F. Bannister as Secretary-Treasurer.

Circle M Country Style Dancing as viewed on the television program The Country and Western Hour will be provided at Burra Town Hall fortnightly. Mr & Mrs C. Everett of Brinkworth will be teachers and callers. All over the age of 14 are welcome.

Burra Swimming Pool. A wind-up swim for the season was held on Saturday morning with a party of 21 swimmers and guests at the home of Mr & Mrs Ken Williams afterwards. Trophies were presented to Rosemary Ryan, Michael Broderick, Andrew Ryan, Christine O’Brien, Dawn Britton & Julie Britton.

Burra High School. Over 100 parents and friends attended the school on 12 March for the induction of the year’s prefects and House Captains. Headmaster Mr Farrow gave the address.

Prefects are: Brian Simpson (Head), Graham Brook (Deputy), Darrell Field, Garry Disher, Geoffrey Collins, Trevor Willis, Jan Seekamp (Head), Jill Przibilla (Deputy), Vicki Standing, Susan Murphy, Lynette Winders and Naomi Dare.

Night Classes. A high enrolment has been received for Dressmaking and a second class may have to be established. A few places remain in typing and woodwork.

88, 11 (3), 23 Mar. 1965, page 3 [Number previously used in 1957 & 1958.]

Pest Reduction. At Mt Bryan East Terence and Arnold Lomman have been laying traps around the carcases of two dead sheep. They have trapped one eagle hawk, four foxes and some crows. Mr Len Dare has reduced the local eagle population by 10.

88, 11 (3), 23 Mar. 1965, page 4 [Number previously used in 1957 & 1958.]

Bight Basketball. Grand Final

Burra Comets 23 defeated Booborowie 22 after extra time. Scores had been 18-18 at the end of time and 22-22 after time on.

Redruth Methodist Ladies guild held its AGM. Secretary Mrs H. Jennison reported a successful year’s activities. Membership was 43 with an average attendance of 27. [Details of the year’s activities in c. 1 column.]

Burra Youth Club. Ten members competed in the SA Youth Club Swimming Championships at the Unley Pool on Friday 19 March. Burra was the only country club of the 18 clubs entered, but they arrived late and the under 12s were unable to compete. Lynette Corner returned with four second place certificates: two gained in the under 15 events and two in open events (up to 18). Brenda Willmott came second in the Under 15 breaststroke. The boys were less successful, but nevertheless enjoyed the meeting. They got home at 1.40 a.m. on Saturday morning.

88, 11 (3), 23 Mar. 1965, page 5 [Number previously used in 1957 & 1958.]

Burra Town Council, 15 March

Alterations to the men’s section of the toilet block were approved.

Council will contribute £20 towards the building of the toilet block at the Aberdeen tennis courts.

It was resolved that the shed for the ‘Old Jinker’ be erected on a site adjacent to the Fire Station in Market Street.

Junior Cricket

Hallett Colts 183 defeated Booborowie Colts 105

Burra Footballers 9 for 97 defeated Koonaburra 84

Bowls

Burra Green 108 defeated Clare Blue 91

Hallett Ted 113 defeated Burra Blue 85

Burra Gold 110 defeated Clare Red 72

Clare Green 103 defeated Hallett White 77

These results mean that Burra Green have won the 1964-65 Pennant on percentage from Saddleworth Gold after both teams finished with 24 points.

Burra Small Bore Club. Last Wednesday the double 50 yards shoot saw best scores from J. Bowden, Ross Gilbert and M. Thomas.

Aberdeen Football Club at its AGM last Tuesday elected: Patron, L.W. Gare; President, B. Hirschausen; Senior Vice-President, R.M. Reed; Secretary, J.J. Richards and Assistant Secretary, R. Heinrich.

Burra Football Club has elected: Patron, Rex Warnes; President, Mr E. Pietsch; Vice-President, A. Baulderstone; Secretary, J. Herde and Treasurer, R. Pietsch.

Hallett Football Club elected President, Don Gare; Patron, A. L. Collins, Vice-President, K.G. Deer, secretary, Jim Sullivan, Assistant Secretary, R. Dawson and Treasurer, Laurie Sullivan.

[Slightly larger than A4 – 6 columns on one side and 2 on the other about 3⁄4 column deep.]

Tennis

‘A’ Grade Aberdeen 11 sets defeated Spalding 9 sets

Mt Bryan 12 sets defeated Hallett 8 sets

Booborowie 14 sets defeated Kooringa 6 sets

‘B’ Grade Aberdeen 15 sets defeated Spalding Blue 5 sets

88, 12 (3), 30 Mar. 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1957 & 1958.]

Bowls

Burra hosted the Champion of Champions matches on Saturday. 62 bowlers contested the title. The final in the rinks competition saw Clare White (Alick Byrne, Max Hand, G. Tilbrook & Ray Leak) defeat Clare Red. In the singles final Harold Crump of Burra was defeated by Gerry McDermid of Auburn.

Les Phillips Vice-President of Burra Club welcomed guests and A.J. Cornish [perhaps: not very clear] President of the Mid North Association also welcomed contenders. A fine luncheon was served at the RSL Hall and morning and afternoon teas at the clubhouse. Last Thursday Harold Crump won the Burra Club Championship for the second year in succession, with Edgar Pietsch as runner-up. He also skippered the leading rink in the teams’ event – Burra Green, which won the 1964-65 Mid North Association Pennant.

Swimming. Twelve members of the Burra & District Club took part in the age group Championships at the Olympic Pool in Adelaide and gained great experience. Peter Broderick was in the final for 8 and Under 55 yards freestyle and Rosemary Ryan was 3rd in the 12 and Under 3 m diving.

Burra Red Cross Badge Day on Friday last raised £33.

‘Circle M’ Country Style Dancing Group got off to a great start on Friday night. The Town Hall was very effectively decorated and at least 40 people were involved at all times in learning the dances.

Burra & District Floral Art Club elected at its AGM: President, Mrs R. Thamm; Vice-President, Mrs H. McGee and Secretary-Treasurer, Mrs M .Pettet.

88, 12 (3), 30 Mar. 1965, page 5 [Number previously used in 1957 & 1958.]

Cricket. Burra Juniors 99 defeated Parents 80.

‘A’ Grade: First Semi-Final Aberdeen 15 sets defeated Mt Bryan 5 sets

Second Semi-Final Booborowie 15 sets defeated Spalding 5 sets

‘B’ Grade: First Semi-Final Spalding White defeated Aberdeen White 6 sets

88, 12 (3), 30 Mar. 1965, page 6 [Number previously used in 1957 & 1958.]

Cricket

Booborowie 2 for 147 defeated Mt Bryan 146

Leighton 208 defeated North Booborowie 204
