88, 12 (3), 30 Mar. 1965, page 7 [Number previously used in 1957 & 1958.]

Burra Primary School Committee: Annual Report. Chairman K.W. White.

Mr D. Zanker was elected Chairman in 1964 and served very actively until his transfer from the district. Headmaster Mr Horsnell was transferred at the end of Term 1, to be succeeded by Mr I. Auhl. Both headmasters have given strong support to the committee. A picture evening with Gilbert Valley Camera Club in April raised £10-17-6. Arbor Day was successfully held in July. School Sports were keenly contested at the War Memorial Oval. The Committee helped in completing the new cricket pitch and in getting power lines removed where they crossed the new area and water has now been laid on. Entrance gates in the oval fence were fitted to allow direct access. The proposed resurfacing of the tennis courts and provision of backstops is in abeyance. The approach to the school has been made safer with the co-operation of the Town Council.

Burra Small Bore Club fired a match over double 75 yards at which the best scorers were D. Griffiths, M. Thomas and R. Angel.

88, 12 (3), 30 Mar. 1965, page 8 [Number previously used in 1957 & 1958.]

Football

The Mid North Association held its AGM at Saddleworth Institute 12 March and elected: President, L. Twartz (Saddleworth), Vice-President, S. Noske (Robertstown) and Patron, W.E. Blatchford. A.E. Bannear of Saddleworth will be approached to take on the position of Secretary, for which no nominations were received.

Auburn, Riverton, Robertstown, Aberdeen and United will field A1, B & Colts teams.

Mintaro, Manoora, Sevenhill, Blyth and Farrell Flat will field A2 teams.

Watervale was granted 12 months recess.

[Other details are covered in the 21⁄2 column report.]

88, 12 (3), 30 Mar. 1965, Supplement [Number previously used in 1957 & 1958.]

[Single-sided, A4 sized.]

Advt. Jennison’s Tyre Service Pty Ltd advertisement for the New Falcon.

[Printed in pink.]

88, 13 (3), 6 Apr. 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1957 & 1958.]

CWA Country Woman of the Year

Mrs Bruce Stockman, who was nominated in this state-wide contest by the Hanson Branch, was declared the winner of the Warnes’ Group section on Friday night. The winner of the grand final on 29 April receives a trip to New Zealand for two. Other Warnes’ Group candidates came from Black Springs, Burra, Clare, Farrell Flat, Riverton, Spalding and Yacka.

[Photograph of Mrs Stockman being crowned by Sir Richard Hawker at a Cabaret in Clare Town Hall on Friday night last. Other details are given in the 11⁄4 column article.]

Burra Public Speaking Club has elected as President Rev. G.D. Sibly, with Mr D. Ebsary as Secretary and Mr D. Farrow as Critic.

National Trust

Mr Andrew Tennant has donated Dower’s shop in Market Square to the Trust. There is also a donation of £50 towards renovations. The building is of solid stone. It will be used as a museum. The old jinker from the mine has been housed on a site adjacent to the building. The housing for the jinker consists of roofing only and was subsidised by the Tourist Bureau.

Burra Caravan Park. At present this is only a camping area, but the matter will be discussed at the next Council meeting.

SA Annual Merino Field Days drew interest from all around Australia. WA graziers were particularly interested. An East Bungaree ram went to Northampton WA for 2,000 guineas. A Koonoona stud ram went to F. Mosey of Robertstown for 1,500 guineas. W.B. Ashby & Sons sold a ram to WA for 2,000 guineas. Crowds were a record.

Burra Burra Show Inc.

Report of President Mr Rex Warnes

The last show was on 12 October 1964. Conditions were shocking. It poured with rain from morning to late afternoon, marring what deserved to be a record day. Gate takings were down £30. The Governor Sir Edric Bastyan and Lady Bastyan attended and his Excellency opened the show in heavy rain, making light of the circumstances. After lunch he toured the soggy grounds and inspected the exhibits. The Police Force Band attended, but rain prevented them from playing after lunch and they left. Exhibits were of a high standard and numbered 2629. Membership has fallen by 30 and this needs to be rectified. Generous donated [from people who were listed] have helped to reduce the society’s overdraft. Young’s Caterers of Melrose did an efficient job. During the year death removed some staunch supporters in the persons of Mr W.H. Lloyd (a Past President), Mr C.T. Beckwith and Mr M.A. Radford. Mr Lloyd and Mr Beckwith were both Honorary Life Members.

[The usual thanks to stewards and committees follows.]

Elected were: Patron, G. Stanley Hawker; President, M.G. Stockman and Vice-Presidents, Rex C. Warnes & B.A. Riggs. The next show will be held on 9 October 1965.

[Personal interest: R. Fuss was on the Produce Committee.]

88, 13 (3), 6 Apr. 1965, page 2 [Number previously used in 1957 & 1958.]

Notice. Burra Town Council. Members retiring on 3 July due to the effluxion of time:

Mayor Edward Thomas Baulderstone

North Ward Roy Joseph Jeffery

East Ward Robert J. Broad

West Ward Charles Leslie Phillips

Nominations are called by 14 May with elections on 3 July if required.

88, 13 (3), 6 Apr. 1965, page 4 [Number previously used in 1957 & 1958.]

Polio Injections. 2nd, 3rd & 4th polio injections are to be given at Burra Hospital on 30 April.

Sandra Williams of Burra won a camera as a prize in a recent stamp collecting competition run by the Shell Company of Australia.

Telephone. An extra line to Gum Creek automatic exchange will be available from 14 April.

Dollar Bill’s 7th crossword appeared.

88, 13 (3), 6 Apr. 1965, page 5 [Number previously used in 1957 & 1958.]

Burra High School Parents & Friends’ Association held its AGM at the school on 16 March and elected: President, Mrs A. Benger; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames D. Thomas & A.H. Williams; Secretary, Mrs G.F.J. Lomman, Assistant Secretary, Mrs D.H. Field and Treasurer, Mrs W.H. Brook.

Headmaster R.M. Farrow handed over a cheque for almost £100 representing the initial instalment of the Voluntary Contributions for the year.

The President reported a membership of 61 and an average attendance of 37. The project for the year was the erection of a dressing shed for girls, but later we learnt the Department might supply this, so it was decided instead to spend £100 on Physical Education equipment and £100 on the library. Income from the school sports afternoon tea was used to offset bus expenses for the Inter-High School Sports trip to Riverton in May. The High School Ball at the end of Term 2 was a social and financial success and just over £100 was made. The Christmas Banquet was a very enjoyable occasion when approximately 200 were catered for. Approximately 120 parents attended an informative talk by Mr Farrow in February – on the coming year’s work.

‘B’ Grade Aberdeen White 11 sets defeated Aberdeen Blue 9 sets

88, 13 (3), 6 Apr. 1965, page 7 [Number previously used in 1957 & 1958.]

Burra Small Bore Club. Best at a double 100 yards shoot were D. Griffiths, M. Thomas & K. Spackman.

On Sunday the Annual Prize Shoot was held. Best off the rifle were Jack Cattermole (Peterborough) and W. Jenkins (Clare), while G. Frost of Peterborough was best on handicap.

88, 14 (3), 13 Apr. 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1957 & 1958.]

Weather. The long dry spell continues with 161 dry days since October and just 174 points of rain in that time. Things are not as bad as might be thought due to the good spring rains last year and another month could pass before any great hardship results.

Burra High School Sports were held on 8 April in glorious weather.

[Cup winners are not very clearly identified in the paper. Where two names are given it is not stated whether they are reporting a tie or a winner and runner-up. The absence of other runners-up makes a tie likely, but on the other hand three ties seem unusual to say the least.]

Burra Primary School

The annual parents’ meeting and the Welfare Club meeting on Tuesday were both well attended with more than 50 at each. Sports Day will be on 23 April. Twelve members of the ABC Symphony Orchestra visited the school last week and entertained the children from Grades IV to VII for an hour.

Burra Small Bore Club. Best over double 75 yards were D. Griffiths, M. Thomas and R. Angel.

Burra Darts Club. At the Aberdeen v. Kooringa match on 8 April Aberdeen was successful in all games, winning the teams’ match 501 up! Most bullseyes were thrown by Bob Elliott. Mrs V. Elliott was the most successful lady and Stan Goul won the individual score contest.

88, 16 (2), 27 Apr. 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958.]

G.A. Bywaters, Minister for Lands, writes explaining the Government’s policy on land tenure. It is Government policy not to convert Crown Lands on lease to freehold. This does not apply to Crown Lands within subdivisions in towns.

Burra Small Bore Club. The season’s Trophy Shoot has been completed:

Ross Gilbert won the Championship and came second in the Handicap Contest.

He won the Marksman’s Trophy, was second in the early aggregate and won the second half-yearly aggregate.

John Bowden won the Handicap Trophy and was second off the rifle.

Don Griffiths won the yearly aggregate and the first half-yearly aggregate, coming second in the Marksman’s Trophy.

Burra Camera Club had an outing to Dare’s Hill on 24 May.

Accidents

On the Thursday before Easter a car rolled over in Murkaby Lane about 30 miles east of Burra. The driver was unhurt.

On Good Friday at 2.30 a.m. a car rolled over 3 miles north of Mt Bryan. No one was hurt, but the car was a write off.

On Easter Monday a car overturned on the Burra-Booborowie Road. Again the car was written off, but the driver was uninjured.

At 4.30 a.m. on Tuesday a car overturned on the Burra-Mt Bryan Road near the racecourse. The driver escaped without a scratch, but the car was extensively damaged.

On Thursday morning a collision occurred between a utility and a truck at Cobb & Co.’s Corner. No one was hurt, but the utility was badly damaged.

Burra CWA held a picnic at the Gorge for their April meeting.

Burra Town Council has decided to enclose the northern section of the jinker shelter to house mine relics or material associated with the jinker. Some old bullock yokes have already been donated. A call is made for other items.

Anzac Day in Burra. Rev. G.D. Sibly conducted the service on Sunday at the War Memorial. The Marananga Band and about 40 ex-servicemen took part in a march before the service. Wreaths were laid by H. Cornelius for the RSL, T.R. Rogers for the AFA, Arnold Heinrich for the Demobilised Soldiers, W. Carpenter for the Fathers’ Association, E.T. Baulderstone for the Town Council and G.R. Finch for the District Council.

This year’s church service was held at St Mary’s, conducted by Rev. G.D. Sibly. The Mayor and Mayoress attended, with President H. Cornelius of the RSL and 14 ex-servicemen. The Burra Choral Society, conducted by M.D. Ebsary, led the music and the occasional sermon was by Rev. M.A. Lind of the Burra Methodist Circuit. More than 200 people attended and supper followed in the Parish Hall.

88, 16 (2), 27 Apr. 1965, pages 1 & 5 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Obituary. [M. Kellaway] Pound Keeper.

St Joseph’s School held a sports day at the school on Saturday 24 April.

88, 16 (2), 27 Apr. 1965, page 5 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Burra Town Council

The amount of £139 plus £7 for the jinker shed to be paid as soon as accounts arrive so that the subsidy can be returned from the Tourist Bureau.

It was resolved that the north end of the shed be enclosed to house mine relics and items appertaining to the jinker.

L.W. Gare to be sold 1 chain x 12 chains of the north side of the Mine Paddock for £10 plus the transfer costs and with him to shift the trough to a suitable site. [This needs clarification.]

Obituary. Albert Gustav Blieschke of Farrell Flat died at Burra Hospital 13 April aged 73. He was the son of the late Mr & Mrs Henry Blieschke and was born at Melrose 23 July 1891. On 9 May 1922 he married Miss Gertrude Gersch of Kilkerran and began farming at Booleroo Centre. Later in 1928 he farmed at Edillilie on Eyre Peninsula and in 1948 moved with his family to farm three miles north of Farrell Flat. He retired in 1964 to live in Farrell Flat. He is survived by his widow and two sons: Ron of Farrell Flat and Eric of Leigh Creek.

[Born 22 July 1891 Hundred of Wongyarra.]

88, 16 (2), 27 Apr. 1965, page 6 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Burra High School. A combined Methodist and Anglican Easter Service was held in the School Hall on Wednesday 14 April.

On Friday 23 April the school held an Anzac Assembly. Mr Cornelius recited Binyon’s lines.

Football

A1 Grade Riverton 9.14 defeated Robertstown 6.6

United 11.14 defeated Aberdeen 8.7

A2 Grade Blyth 19.17 defeated Sevenhill 10.12

Mintaro 8.5 defeated Farrell Flat 7.10

88, 17 (2), 4 May 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Burra Golf Club held its opening day on Saturday.

Miss Jennifer Field of the ANZ Bank in Burra since January 1962 has been transferred to Adelaide. Mr Ray Pietsch who joined the bank in February will remain in Burra in place of Miss Field.

Mr Charles Schell aged 70, a station hand of Balah, was admitted to Burra Hospital on Sunday morning with a lacerated scalp and bruises to the body. Police are investigating the possibility he may have been assaulted.

CWA. The Country Woman of the Year Quest climaxed with a Ball at Wonderland Ballroom in Adelaide. Some 1,300 attended. Floral decorations were magnificent. Sir Edric and Lady Bastyan attended and group winners were presented to the Governor. The winner was Mrs B. Spilsbury from the Hindmarsh Valley Branch. All other 24 finalists will travel by bus to Canberra and the Snowy Mountains, while the winner goes to the North Island of New Zealand for a week and gets a £100 wardrobe from John Martins.

88, 17 (2), 4 May 1965, page 3 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Basketball

‘B’ Grade Aberdeen 17 defeated Tarlee 12

Cricket. Mokota Cricket Association Premiership

Hallett 264 defeated Booborowie 223 for their 3rd successive premiership.

88, 18 (2), 11 May 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Inter-High School Sports were held at Clare on 6 May. Burra, the smallest school competing, was only narrowly beaten for the Championship Shield and won the Handicap Shield.

Aberdeen Football Club Women’s Auxiliary held its AGM at the home of Miss C. Reed. In the year this small group handled £495. Elected: President, F. Scroop; Vice-Presidents, P. Kakoschke & V. Fiebig; Secretary, D. Gill; Assistant Secretary, D. Reed and Treasurer, C. Reed.

Meeting will be held in the Club Rooms previously known as Bentley’s Shop.

Table Tennis. 4 May

Hanson 13 defeated Burra Gold 12

Burra Blue 20 defeated Mt Bryan 5

Willalo 17 defeated Spalding Blue 8

Spalding White 21 defeated Booborowie 4

Burra Youth Club. Four boys from the club will go walking in the Flinders Ranges for five days. Last September four other boys of the club climbed Mt Mary.

L.L. Fiebig of Burra is taking part in the 2,000 mile 1965 BP Rally, which started on 5 May.

ETSA has started work on its new £17,000 Depot and Office Block south of the PMG Line Shop at Burra. The resident engineer for ETSA will soon get a new house in Kingston Street.

The Highways Department will get a new Depot on Baker’s Reserve at Burra North, levelled by the Town Council. The depot and office will be a building 40 ft x 50 ft to be completed by the end of this financial year.

SA Pensioners’ League members from Adelaide visited the Burra Group and gave a concert on 4 May, from which a collection raised £11 for the Burra Branch.

Weather. The long dry spell finally ended with falls of up to an inch through the district, beginning last Friday. Burra registered 81 points. Rain to the East was patchy, but some places recorded 50-60 points.

88, 18 (2), 11 May 1965, page 3 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Dollar Bill’s Crossword No. 12 continues the lead-up to decimal currency.

88, 19 (2), 18 May 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Burra Town Council Elections

E.T. Baulderstone was re-elected for the twelfth consecutive year in Council. This also means he has been 20 consecutive years in Council. He first took his seat for East Ward in July 1946 and became Mayor in July 1954.

Mr T.H. Woollacott served 14 years as Mayor, but in two periods 1931-37 and 1940-46.

[This is in fact only 121⁄2 years. Until 1936 elections were for a calendar year and the term of office ran from December to November. Subsequently the term was for the financial year July-June. T.H. Woollacott was elected in December 1931 and effectively served as Mayor in 1932, 1933, 1934, 1935, 1936 and half of 1937 and later for 39/40, 40/41, 41/42, 42/43, 43/44, 44/45 & 45/46.]

E.W. Crewes was Mayor for 11 years in three periods. [1900-02, 1914-19 & 1921-22.]

When nominations closed on Friday:

Cr R.J. Jeffery was returned for North Ward, Cr C.L. Phillips for West Ward and Mr Ken Williams replaces Cr R. Broad in East Ward.

Burra Burra DC Elections.

Hanson Ward S.T. Miller re-elected

Baldina Ward M.T. Kellock re-elected

Booborowie Ward H.B. Quinn re-elected

Mt Bryan Ward T.J. Quinn elected when Cr Cockrum did not seek re-election.

Mr H.R. Shakeshaft will take up duties as Burra postmaster on 3 June. He has previously worked at Burra Post Office for four years, since when he has served as Senior Postal Clerk at Gladstone and as Postmaster at Hawker. His interests include swimming, golf, cricket and photography. He was Secretary of the Burra Cricket Club for two years while here previously. He has been successful in National and International Photographic Exhibitions.

[Photo printed.]

The Dance arranged in the RSL Hall by the ‘Cascades’ in aid of the Burra hospital on Saturday was poorly attended. Door takings were c. £8.

Cricket

The annual wind-up and social evening of the Mokota Cricket Association was held at Booborowie on 6 May. Patron Mr W.B. Ashley presented the Mokota Shield, for competition among the top four teams, to the Hallett Captain John Honan. For competition among the lower four teams the Mayfield Shield was presented to Messrs Holmes and Matt Carmody of the Leighton Club.

Adelaide Wool Sales. J.F. & D.H. Keane of Farrell Flat topped district prices at 703⁄4d. Eastern Pastoral wool was fetching 64-661⁄2d. [Other local district prices are printed.]

St Mary’s. At a Special Parish Eucharist on Sunday next the Lord Bishop’s Licence to act as a Lay-Reader will be given to:

Mr I.T. Allen of Burra

Mr D.R. Burge of Farrell Flat

Mr D.H. Campbell of Booborowie

Mr G.W. Dare of Mt Bryan.

Harold Raymond, the blind violinist, retired last year after years of raising funds through his Gloombusters Concerts. A gigantic embezzlement of the institution’s funds, which led to the imprisonment of the offender, has caused him to come out of retirement and the Gloombusters will appear at Burra for 1965 on 3 June, at Spalding on 4 June and at Manoora on 5 June.

Decimal Currency

With the Commonwealth Mint busy making the decimal coinage, they cannot manufacture more pennies and half-pennies. These are in short supply, it is believed because people think they will be able to make a profit on them after decimal currency comes in. This is not so; half-pennies, pennies and threepences will only be exchanged in multiples of sixpence, which have exact equivalents to multiples of five cents.

88, 20 (2), 25 May 1965, page 2 [Number previously used in 1958.]

[Pages 2-8 were misdated 25 April 1965.]

Football

‘A’ Grade Booborowie 7.12 defeated Spalding 4.3

Obituary. Mr Albert Stephen Fahey died at Jamestown Hospital 28 April aged 56. He was the second son of the late Stephen & May Fahey. In 1936 he married Ida Przibilla of Bundaleer. The couple became well known in the hotel business at Robertstown, Caltowie, Spalding, Adelaide, Peterborough and Gladstone. He was residing at Spalding at the time of his death. He is survived by a widow, two daughters and one son: Patricia Mrs Joyce of Cleve, Vivienne Mrs Page of Millicent and Gregory of Spalding. [Born 10 March 1909 Spalding.]

88, 21 (2), 1 June 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Burra Stockowners’ Association met at the RSL Hall on Thursday to discuss the proposed reserved price for wool scheme and the narrowing of existing stock routes. Elected: President, H.C. Radford and Vice-President, Don Lord. On the question of stock routes the meeting decided to recommend to the Burra Burra DC:

King or Florieton S.R. be reduced to 3 chains for its entire length.

The Eastern S.R. be reduced to 10 chains as far as Baldina Creek and from the west to 3 chains.

The Baldina-Robertstown S.R. be reduced to 3 chains.

Redbanks Reserve be declared a dedicated reserve under the Burra Burra DC.

State President J.W. Andre, P.A. McBride of the Australian Wool Board and R.J. McCauley, Treasurer of the Association gave interesting addresses on the reserve price scheme, pointing out the advantages and disadvantages.

The Government has agreed in principle if the woolgrowers agree at a referendum. The Wool Industry Conference has recommended the woolgrowers would contribute £20 million over 8 years. The agreement is now for £30 million over 7 years. The money would come from a levy not exceeding 3% of the gross proceeds of wool sold.

This money would cover:

Their contribution to the scheme’s capital.

Commitments for the promotion of wool.

Commitments for wool research.

88, 21 (2), 1 June 1965, page 2 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Weather. Steady showers in Burra from Thursday morning to Monday morning brought 84 points. Hallett reported 43, Booborowie 46 and Mt Bryan 52.

Two Escapees from Gladstone Gaol on Thursday tried to get to Victoria. A De Soto car was stolen from Gulnare and found about 7 miles from the Cockrum homestead at Mt Bryan East. Mr Cockrum’s Austin truck was stolen from an open shed on Thursday night. Food and clothing was also taken. The homestead of E.S. Wilks’ ‘Wallinga’ property was apparently entered in a search for food and clothing. The men were arrested on Friday afternoon near Tutye on the Ouyen Highway and the missing truck was found nearby.

88, 21 (2), 1 June 1965, page 3 [Number previously used in 1958.]

88, 22 (2), 8 June 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Robberies in Burra

On Sunday night three Burra businesses were broken into and goods to total values of £800 were stolen.

Mr Ken Murphy’s Burra Gift Shop, J. Hill’s Burra Menswear Store and the Burra Motor Co. were all robbed. From Mr Murphy’s the thieves took 20 wrist watches, 40 rings, brooches, necklets, pens and other items as well as razors and electric hair clippers and Pall Mall cigarettes. About £200 worth of clothing was taken from Mr Hill’s shop and Burra motor Co. lost a small amount of change from the till. The breakings were noticed by Mr R. Webb who was going for a daily paper at about 7.30 a.m. and by Mr M. Beinke.

The Bishop of Polynesia Dr J.C. Vockler will visit St Mary’s on Thursday 24 June. The local Methodist Church will join with the Anglicans in this special Burra Missionary Rally.

Mr O.A. Tattersall, Burra Postmaster, retired last week in his 51st year of service with the Department. He entered the service in 1914. He began his term at Burra on 18 August 1965 [sic] and completed it on 26 May 1965.

[Correction 88, 23 (2), 15 June 1965, page 4 to: began his term at Burra 18 August 1950.]

Mr & Mrs Tattersall have had a new home built on Smelts Road, opposite the oval, for their retirement. A farewell was held in the Post Office on Tuesday 25 May for Mr Tattersall and for ex-postman P.S. Bampton, who has retired through illness. [Those present are listed.]

Burra High School held an open night for parents and friends last Thursday. Over 80 people visited to see class and subject teachers.

Papal Honour for Burra’s Parish Priest

The Most Rev. B. Gallagher DD, Bishop of Port Pirie, has received news from the Apostolic Delegation in Sydney that Pope Paul VI has created Patrick Valentine Hughes a domestic Prelate with the title of Monsignor. Monsignor Hughes was born in Victoria and educated at Christian Brothers in Geelong. He studied for the priesthood in Europe: in Ireland and Rome. He was ordained at St John Lateran Basilica in Rome in 1926. He is also an Arts graduate of Melbourne University. He has worked in the northern part of SA, notably at Port Augusta, Port Pirie, Peterborough, Carrieton and Renmark. He has been at Burra for 15 years. This is the first occasion when this parish has been tended by a Monsignor.

88, 22 (2), 8 June 1965, page 3 [Number previously used in 1958.]

[Born Hilda Fuss 20 January 1886 Aberdeen SA: died 18 May 1965 Burra, residence Burra North.]

88, 22 (3), 15 June 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958 & 1965.]CHECK ISSUE NUMBER

[Page 1 only carries the incorrect date 15 May 1965.]

Adelaide Wool Sales. Top district price of 661⁄2d was achieved by R. M. Gebhardt & Co. of Mokota.

[Other local district prices are printed.]

Burra Break-ins. Investigations into recent break-ins continue.

Mr & Mrs H. Foote, formerly of Burra, have purchased a home at 8 Esplanade, Golden Beach, Caloundra, Queensland and have named their new home ‘Aber-Koorie’.

Bishop Vockler, Bishop of Polynesia is pictured.

Accident. On Thursday a 10-year-old cyclist travelling north on the Mt Bryan Road got something caught in his wheel, causing him to swerve suddenly into the path of an oncoming semi-trailer loaded with 30 head of cattle. The semi-trailer driver was quick to react and swerved off the road, colliding with a telegraph pole. The boy ran into the rear of the trailer and suffered bruising and slight concussion. Sgt Teague and Constable K. Terry of Burra attended the scene and praised the driver for his effort, which had averted a more serious result. PMG linesmen soon repaired the damaged lines.

88, 22 (3), 15 June 1965, page 2 [Number previously used in 1958 & 1965.]CHECK ISSUE NUMBER

[This seems to be the club’s last reference.]

Advt. Elders-GM announce a property and clearing sale in the Estate of the late George Brittle [sic: for Brettle] Morgan, of that land comprising part allotments 43 & 47 [of Kooringa] subject to rights of way and a particularly described right of way – being a private road 25 ft x 188 ft 7 inches from Kangaroo Street to Ware Street and likely to be declared a public road. With a substantial stone house of 9 main rooms etc. with cellar, 10,000 gallon underground tank and galvanised iron garage 35 ft x 13 ft; known as ‘Somerset House’. Also furniture and sundries.

88, 22 (3), 15 June 1965, page 7 [Number previously used in 1958 & 1965.]

Burra Primary School. The new classroom being erected to allow one room in the main building to be used as a Central Library is completed except for painting.

88, 24 (2), 22 June 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Weather. Good general soaking rains have fallen. Falls of an inch and more have been general. Mt Bryan East had 116 points and ‘The Gums’ reports 80. Mr G. Webster reports 120 points at Hanson. Burra had 98 points to 3.45 p.m. Out East, Old Koomooloo had 83 points and Thistlebeds 80.

Cattle Theft. The head of a freshly slaughtered calf has been found at Baldina Creek without any trace of a carcase. Police are investigating and point out there are severe penalties for cattle stealing – up to seven years in gaol.

Burra Break-ins. Some of the property stolen from Messrs K. Murphy & J. Hill was found on two men arrested in Victoria. They were at the time also in possession of a motor vehicle stolen from Queensland. They will also be charged at Mt Gambier with other offences committed in the South East of the state.

Burra Dart Club. Burra 32 defeated Morgan 13.

Best players for Burra were K. Jones & Wasley.

Lance Fiebig with Peter McArthur as Navigator placed third in Class D of the BP Rally for 1965, fifth overall and leading entrant from the Adelaide starters.

Vern Drew, teller at the ANZ Bank since September, has been transferred to Salisbury. He will be succeeded by Mr Kevin Maloney from Glenelg. Vern has agreed to see out the season with the Burra Football Club.

Circle M Country Dancing continues to be popular among the young people of Burra, but the support of adults is much to be desired.

88, 24 (2), 22 June 1965, page 2 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Advt. Elders-GM have instructions from R.J. & E.S. Gillett to sell their ‘Farella’ property 15 miles east of Robertstown on 23 July.

Table Tennis, 15 June

Burra Blue 23 defeated Booborowie 2

Spalding White 15 defeated Mt Bryan 10

Willalo 16 defeated Burra Gold 9

Hanson 17 defeated Spalding Blue 8

88, 25 (2), 29 June 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Burra Town Council has accepted recommendations from the Road traffic Board concerning traffic in Market Square. Senior constable Harvey recommended banning parking on the western side of the Square between the Serv-Wel store and the cycle rack near Gill’s store. On the south side of the Square from Thames Street to Chapel Street parallel parking only to be allowed. A parking area for about 20 cars is available in front of the RSL Hall.

The Council will also enforce the By-Law XXVII requiring taxi and hire car licences.

Clare High School teams visited Burra High School on Friday 25 June.

The teams were ‘A’ Football and B, D, & F Basketball for Burra and for Clare ‘B’ Football and A, C, & E Basketball. Clare won all except the C Basketball game.

Stanley Teachers’ Association met at Burra High School on Monday 21 June. Mr R.M. Farrow, Headmaster of Burra High School, spoke on ‘Catering for all: has the American High School anything to offer.’ Mr Farrow has been a Fulbright exchange teacher in the US.

Mr & Mrs Barrie Biggs and their family of two young sons will arrive in Burra on 3 July to begin business. They have purchased Sandy’s Serv-Wel Store and will begin trading on 5 July. Mr & Mrs Biggs are both country born and bred. Mr Biggs is a keen photographer and golfer and a football supporter. Mrs Biggs has been an ‘A’ Grade country district tennis player. [Family photograph printed.]

88, 25 (2), 29 June 1965, page 2 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Advt. Elders GM will sell the property of Messrs R.J. & E.C. Gillett on 22 July in Robertstown Town Hall, comprising 4,858 acres [corrected by hand to 4,860] leasehold and 801 acres freehold. Sections 56, 57, 72, 73, 74, 75, 76, 77, 78, 79, 80, 81, 82, & 85 Hundred of Bundey.

Obituary. Cecil George Parker died 20 June at Brisbane Hospital aged 68. He was the husband of Amy and sone of the late George & Rebecca Parker and brother to Vida, Mildred, Cass and Lill and of Joe, deceased.

[Born 27 August 1897 Stony Gap.]

88, 26 (2), 6 July 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Weather. Further rain has fallen throughout the district. Burra recorded 34 points to 9 a.m. Friday, while falls to the north and east were generally heavier. Hallett received 59 points. To the east falls ranged from 15 to 60 points with many in the 40-60 range.

Mr Donald Topsfield celebrated his 21st birthday yesterday. Don works for the ANZ Bank at Norwood, but returns to Burra each weekend to play football.

Mr & Mrs Don Halliday will leave shortly to make their new home in Adelaide. They will be greatly missed on the Memorial Oval Committee. Mr Halliday has also been a member of the Burra Town Hall Picture Committee for many years and helped with door-keeping etc. A presentation was made at the meeting of the Memorial Oval Committee on Monday night.

Mr Ken Williams used the fire brigade on Saturday to rescue a magpie caught by a leg in a gum tree off Ayers Street. The bird was in a bad way, having been pecked by others and ‘Dr’ Bob Broad amputated the damaged leg. The bird seemed to be responding well, but died today.

John Freebairn MP will address the Burra Methodist Men’s Fellowship on Sunday 11 July.

North Eastern Table Tennis Tournament

Open Events:

Men’s Championship Singles P. Basham

Women’s Championship Singles D. Grocke

88, 26 (2), 6 July 1965, page 2 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Obituary. A Return Thanks Notice reveals the death of Albert Stephen Fahey.

[Born 10 March 1909 Spalding: died 28 April 1965 Jamestown, residence Spalding.]

Notice. Burra Town Council has declared a prohibited parking area at all times on the southern side of the boundary of allotments Pt 78 & Pt 79 and thence north for 155 ft. Cars must also rank parallel to the kerb in Market Square between Thames and Chapel Streets.

Notice. Adult Education Classes at Burra. Enrolments are being received for mid-term enrolments in Woodwork, Dressmaking and Typing. Courses of five weeks in Decimal Currency will also be conducted in the coming months.

Burra CWA held its AGM and elected: President, Mrs E.T. Baulderstone; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames H. Jennison & J. Allen; Secretary & Reporter, Mrs A.C. Ford; Assistant Secretary, Mrs S. Scroop & Treasurer, Mrs H. Crump.

The report records a membership of 68 with an average attendance of 27. The passing of Mrs H. Finch was noted with regret. Activities for the year are reported in c. 11⁄4 columns.

88, 27 (2), 13 July 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Break-ins. For the second time in five weeks the shop of Mr K.J. Murphy has been broken into. Fancy goods, cigarettes, tobacco and razor blades have been stolen. The theft took place on Saturday night. Entry was obtained to Burra Meat Stores as well, but nothing was stolen. The value of cigarettes and tobacco taken was £120-£130 and losses in all were c. £180.

R. Sandercock was given a farewell by members of the Burra Traders’ Association at the Burra Hotel on Wednesday afternoon. Mr E.T. Baulderstone led the well wishers. Mr Sandercock has been Secretary of the Association for four years. A presentation was made and Mr Burnie Biggs was welcomed to the town and Association.

The Burra Basketball Club will benefit by c. £26 from a dance held in the Burra Town Hall on 9 July.

Burra & District Choral Society is preparing a production of Gilbert & Sullivan’s Trial by Jury. Extra singers would make the production easier.

Burra Caravan Park. The Town Council is currently working on plans for the park and application has been made to the Government Tourist Bureau for a subsidy of £1,500 towards a park. An RAA survey of the old park near the swimming pool has been completed and plans submitted for approval of the subsidy.

Adelaide Wool Sales. The top price for the district was 731⁄4d by Alexandrina Ltd of Sturt Vale.

[Other local district prices are printed.]

88, 28 (2), 20 July 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Burra Bowling Club held its AGM last Wednesday in the club rooms. The family of the late George Terry donated £25. Elected: Patron, G.H. Dollman; President, J.B. Topsfield; Vice-Presidents, C.L. Phillips & M.G. Stockman; Secretary, D.H. Field & Treasurer, B.A. Riggs. Full membership at £6-10-0 remains unchanged. Night members pay £3-10-0.

Weather. Burra recorded 138 points in the past week. There was a severe frost on Saturday and some reports of lights snowfalls.

Phyl Sandercock was given a farewell by Bowling Associates with a sumptuous luncheon of Mornays, sweets etc. Phyl had been a foundation member and treasurer for five years.

Circle M Country Style Dancing continues to attract dancers and despite very bad weather on Friday, 50 enjoyed the square dancing.

Vandals have been breaking windows at Burra North. Two breakages at Redruth Methodist Hall caused c. £5 damage. Two small windows were broken at the Aberdeen Croquet Club. Six skylights were broken at the showground and four sets of louvre windows.

Accident. Kevin T. Dixon of Merilden was travelling on the Leighton Road near ‘Blink Bonnie’ when the car overturned at a bend on Saturday evening. The driver and passenger, Miss Janis Drew, escaped with minor injuries.

88, 28 (2), 20 July 1965, page 2 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Notice. Broad Brothers of the Modern Meat Store have sold their business to Mr & Mrs Peter McCann. The services of Mr John Heard have been retained by the new owners.

Burra North Red Cross AGM. Though there are many financial members, only an average of 12 attends meetings. This small group has been quite active. Mrs D. Reed presented a report on the year’s activities. [About 3⁄4 column.]

M & BHA held its AGM at the clinic on 12 July. Twenty members attended. Elected: President, Mrs M. Odgers; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames R. Thamm & B. Bevan; Secretary, Mrs M. Tiver Jnr and Treasurer, Mrs D. Bannister. Mrs P. Kirk was guest speaker.

1st Division Northern Areas 47 defeated North Eastern 27

2nd Division Northern Areas 40 defeated North Eastern 11

3rd Division Northern Areas 32 defeated North Eastern 14

88, 29 (2), 27 July 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Man Lost at Thistlebeds

Two inexperienced shooters got into trouble at Thistlebeds-Baldina area on Sunday when one became lost. Hendrick Westerlaken (26) and Gunther Fromel (28) were five miles from Thistlebeds when the latter became lost about 10 a.m. After searching for his friend Westerlaken sought help at Thistlebeds at about 5 p.m. F-C Watts, R. Moreland, W. Corner, Constable Terry and Jim Brown of Baldina searched till midnight. Mr Kellock searched on horseback until dawn and others joined the search on Monday. Mr M. Tiver used his plane to help at 11 a.m. on Monday. Fromel was found at 12.40 p.m., having spent the night in Mr G. Lomman’s crutching shed. The men were questioned at Burra Police Station concerning trespassing and shooting on the properties concerned.

Burra Library’s Annual Trading Table raised £36.

Burra Businessmen are opposed to the new parking restrictions in Market Square. And have sent letters to the Council. Council is prepared to meet a delegation. Concerns have been expressed by Messrs R.A. Gill, R.A. Opperman, L. & T.K. Richardson, C & J. Pearce, M.G. Stockman and Burra Serv-Wel Store.

Football. Commissioners of the Mid North Football Association have suspended two Aberdeen ‘B’ Grade players for disputing an umpire’s decision and for using threatening and abusive language. One was suspended for ‘one match each on both charges’ and the other for 4 matches for an incident in the dressing rooms at the recent match.

Burra Town Council. The Mayor’s Report 1964-65

The Council budgeted for a debit of £1,700 for the year and finished at approximately that amount. Over the past three years the Council has expended over £3,000 on new plant and is now reaping the benefit. The main improvement this year has been the erection of a new toilet block opposite the Town Hall. The Council has agreed to clean up the creek area and develop a park which together with the swimming pool and proposed Caravan Park will create a real beauty spot for the town.

The Memorial Oval Committee has been financed to the extent of £500 to help with water reticulation. The cemetery is nor a credit to the town and if looked after should not get into the condition it previously was in. Thank go to the DC for grading etc. at the cemetery.

The old jinker has been housed in the main street. Some ratepayers may think this a waste of money, but it is possibly the only one of its kind in Australia and a relic of early days in Australia. It fits in well with the developing park and the National Trust building in the vicinity.

A spraying program has been effective in managing water tables. Progress on eliminating horehound has been made, but it is slow.

The Council passed a vote of gratitude for the outstanding work in public affairs and town progress by the Mayor and Mayoress.

The Rural Youth Ball was a great success and raised £150. The debutantes were presented to Mr & Mrs G. Gilfillan:

Valerie Griffiths Marilyn Hirschausen

Beverly Atkins Rosemary Brown

Margaret Murphy Helen Phelps

Kathryn Simpson Leonora Snell

Dawn Bogisch Dianne Williams

Dianne Gill

‘Farella’ the property of R.J. & E.C. Gillett of Burra, located 15 miles east of Robertstown was sol on Thursday at the Robertstown Institute for £4-2-0 an acres to Messrs Eberhard & Co.

On Friday another small property of 52 acres was sold by the same owners to J.G. Carpenter for £28-10-0 per acre.

88, 31 (2), 10 Aug. 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Burra Catholic Ball on Friday night at Burra Town Hall drew a good crowd. Proceeds were about £100.

The Dominos Band played.

Accident. Miss D.A. Ezra of Broken Hill lost control of a VW sedan on the bend at Burra Racecourse on Friday at 10.45 p.m. The car rolled over. Of the four occupants two suffered bruising only and one was treated at the Burra Hospital for a lacerated forehead. The front passenger was the only one wearing a seat belt and the only one uninjured.

Fire. A chimney fire at the home of Mr & Mrs D. Klose on Sunday night was soon extinguished without damage.

The Mid North Methodist Synod met at Yacka. Gladstone sought to be relieved of its ordained minister due to financial problems in a depleted community. Gladstone and Jamestown circuits will discuss a solution.

Wesley College has 22 ministers in training. Only four will enter circuit work in the coming year.

In September Mr William Dunhill completes 75 years as a lay preacher for the Methodist Church. Synod recommends that his name be put forward for the Queen’s Birthday Honours.

The Synod supported the general basis for the proposed Church Union.

The National Bank, Burra, has decimal currency machines installed at a cost of c. £2,000. The local branch manager is Mr Benger.

Weather. At 6 a.m. on Monday in Burra it was 28°F.

Mr Roy Sellars of Burra North has completed 60 years as a shearing shed worker. He first began work in 1905 on Mt Bryan Station of Mr Charles Bowman. Over the years the property has been split up, but in the past week Mr Sellars has been working in the same shed – presently owned by A.B. & B.A. Riggs on their ‘Kabymur’ property. It is thought the property is almost 100 years old. Roy is at present pressing bales for Messrs Riggs exactly 60 years after he first slept there and over the years has pressed bales in most woolsheds east of Burra and in many parts of the State. The ink from branding the bales gave him the nick name ‘Inky’ and many who would not know Roy Sellars know ‘Inky’ Sellars. It would be interesting to know how many bales he has pressed in 60 years.

The Burra Fire Brigade

The chief officer of the SA Fire Brigades Board has had discussions with the Mayor Mr Baulderstone, the Councillors and the Town Clerk re the town brigade. It was decided some facts needed to be publicised.

The Burra Fire Brigade is part of the Auxiliary Fire Service maintained by the Board to afford fire protection to certain country centres where the Fire Brigades Act Applies.

It is manned by an Auxiliary Foreman and Auxiliary Fireman, who have permanent employment in the town and who are available to answer fire calls on a 24 hour basis.

Auxiliary Firemen needed to be fit and undergo a medical examination when they join. They are provided with uniforms and equipment and must attend drills and instruction as required.

They are expected to devote a reasonable proportion of their time to the Brigade and take their turn of duty at the station as required.

They receive an annual retainer payable monthly plus 15/- per hour or part thereof when at fires or cleaning up afterwards. The Foreman gets £130 p.a., the Firemen £100 and the Standby £25.

The retainer is payable for the first three months of sickness.

Auxiliary Firemen are covered by Workmen’s Compensation for death or accident while on duty.

Absence due to holidays from his permanent job does not interfere with his retainer.

Burra Town Council, 2 August

Building applications for two Housing Trust homes were approved.

88, 31 (2), 10 Aug. 1965, page 8 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Burra Rural Youth held its AGM 26 July and elected: President, Geoff. Dare; Vice-President, Robert Neill; Secretary, Hazel Hentschke; Social Secretary, Bev. Atkins & Treasurer, John Teague. The report was of a very successful year with a variety of informative speakers and visits. There was a Debutante Ball 23 July, which raised £85. Membership was 33 to 36. Through the year 15 members left and 18 joined. Average attendance was 17 persons. A bag and bottle drive was raising money for the Flying Doctor Service.

88, 32 (2), 17 Aug. 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Burra Catholic Fete was held in the RSL Hall on Friday and raised c. £250. [Details in 3⁄4 column.]

Burra Racing Club. This year’s meetings are scheduled for 15 September and 23 October.

Burra Kindergarten Car Trial was held on Sunday in difficult conditions following rain on Saturday night. The winner was D. Woolley from L. Fiebig. The winner of the ladies’ section was Miss Jill Stolte.

Circle M Square Dancing Class has decided to continue to the end of October because ‘although it is not a success, yet it is not a failure.’

Weather. Rain in the past week has been general with totals of an inch or more reported: Burra 103 points, Mt Bryan 125 and Mt Bryan East 92. Falls to the east were generally in the range 20-50 points.

Mr John Tilley of Elders-GM in Burra has been promoted to officer-in-charge at Wirrabara from 6 September, after nearly two years in Burra. Mr Robert Upton will come from Wentworth to replace him as Branch Salesman.

Murray Water. A start will soon be made on a 10 inch main from Hanson to Burra. E & WS have chosen a site for a pumping station 50 ft x 100 ft near Hanson on property of S.J. Woollacott and construction will begin early in 1966. The Booborowie water scheme is nearing completion.

Mrs E. Simpson, born at Mt Bryan, but now living in Adelaide, was 96 yesterday. Two of her children are Messrs Jack and Vic. Simpson. [Born Eliza Jane Beckwith 16 August 1869 Canowie: died 17 December 1966 Felixstow.]

Burra Primary School held its Arbor Day on 13 August and it was well attended by parents and friends. Trees were planted in fine weather. Mr John Riggs gave the address and 14 Fuchsia Gums were planted; two by each grade, on the eastern boundary of the new oval. [Planters are named.]

[A recent photograph of the old building is printed.]

Burra Dart Club

Last Sunday week Morgan 26 defeated Burra 21 for the Shield.

On 29 August a match will be played against Broken Hill.

In the Royal Exchange Hotel Championship M. Broad 140 and R. Raines 140 lead Hartley Phillips 130.

88, 32 (2), 17 Aug. 1965, page 5 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Burra Bowling Associates AGM elected: President, Rube Phillips; Vice-Presidents, Dulc. Crump & Dorothy Kellock; Secretary, Dorrie Pietsch & Treasurer, D. Crump.

For the past year £200 was donated to the men’s club and £62 in membership fees. The Associates were currently £115 in credit. The group catered for the Easter tournament, the Mid-North Champion of Champions and a visit of RSABA delegates.

Club Champion was Pat Field, who also won the Consistency Trophy.

The Handicap Singles trophy went to Estelle Mitchell and the Pairs winners were Dorothy Kellock and V. Allen.

The season ended with a very enjoyable dinner at the Burra Hotel.

88, 33 (2), 24 Aug. 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Ian Auhl & R.M. Farrow, headmasters of the Primary & High schools respectively, wrote to make a general appeal for funds to upgrade the two schools’ libraries. The Education Department has just made available a room and furnishings for a library for the Primary School in addition to the High School Library. Approximately £1,000 is needed to adequately stock the two libraries – to be made up of 75% reference and 25% fiction. Donations would be subsidised pound for pound.

Burra High School Ball had an attendance reduced by influenza that has been serious in the past week or two. Still, the door takings were over £100 and the event was both enjoyable and worthwhile.

Weather. Further falls of 60-80 points were widely reported in the past week from the agricultural areas.

Accident/Obituary. Desmond Elliott aged 5, son of Mr & Mrs V. Elliott of Burra North, was electrocuted in the bathroom of their home on Thursday evening and failed to respond to treatment.

[Desmond George Elliott died 19 August 1965 Burra North aged 5.]

Obituary. Mr Les. Hirschausen died in the last week. [Leslie Robert Hirschausen born 20 October 1919 Aberdeen: died 17 August 1965 Burra, residence Burra North. A Return Thanks Notice 88, 36 (2), 14 Sep. 1965, page 2 adds that he was the husband of Beryl.]

Obituary. Mr J.R. (Bert) Field died in the last week.

[John Robert Field born28 March 1908 Kooringa: died 19 August 1965 Adelaide, residence Burra.]

Burra Town Council has declared a minimum rate of £5 on properties within the town. Rate revenue will be £9,000 instead of the £8,000 of 1964-65.

A Naturalization Ceremony will be held at the Burra Town Hall on 9 September for Mrs Mietje Pike and Mrs Jacob Brak.

88, 33 (2), 24 Aug. 1965, pages 1 & 8 [Number previously used in 1958.]

The Burra-Adelaide Road Race was held on Saturday 14 August with Mr L. Wells, President of the League of SA Wheelmen sending off riders at 10 a.m. Riders first went to Mt Bryan before returning and setting off for Adelaide. The winner was M. Turner on a handicap of 25 minutes, in a time of 4 hours.

Fastest time was by Bob Thomas in 4 hrs 7 minutes from scratch.

88, 34 (2), 31 Aug. 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958.] MISSING

88, 35 (2), 7 Sep. 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Burra Schools’ Libraries’ Appeal has reached £195-5-0.

Burra Branch of the National Trust continues to collect items for its museum and plans to open its new premises by the end of the year.

Quality Shearing Coaching Course will be offered at Burra 6-15 September. It has been arranged by Mrs M.R. Ashton of ‘Hillside’ and her shearing contractor Mr J. Ryan. The shearing instructor will demonstrate ‘Tally-Hi’ shearing technique. A visiting afternoon will be held on Tuesday 14 September from 2 p.m. in Mrs Ashton’s shearing shed about two miles north of the Burra Racecourse – just east of the railway line. It is essential that young men given the courses have follow-on sheds immediately to consolidate the coaching given.

Weather. Useful rains in the Eastern Pastoral Country over the weekend brought falls varying from just less than one inch to a little more than two inches, with most falls between 100 and 130 points. Burra received 70 points for the weekend and 80 over the week.

Burra Marching Girls. The final meeting of the committee decided to donate the remaining funds to the Burra Youth Club in the form of games and equipment. The books can be examined at Burra Dry Cleaners for the next two weeks, after which they will be destroyed.

Adelaide Wool Sales, 1 & 2 September, saw top district prices go to Eastern wool.

[Local district prices are printed.]

RSL Ball drew about 180 people to the Burra Town Hall on Friday despite the inclement weather. Electricity failures reduced lighting to candles in bottles, but this did not curb the gaiety of the atmosphere at the pre-ball sherry party. Guests adjourned to the hall at 9.20 p.m. after lights returned. Supper was lavish with two sittings and quite a bit left over, which was sold.

Burra Kindergarten held a social on 27 August and raised £30.

88, 35 (2), 7 Sep. 1965, page 2 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Advt. Farmers’ Union has instructions from Miss E.M. Bailey to sell her property ‘Bayfield’ comprising 795 acres freehold at Gum Creek, in the Burra RSL Hall 8 October.

Lot 1. ‘Homestead’ 537 acres with stone homestead etc.

Lost 2. ‘Davistown Block’ 258 acres.

[Details occupy 11⁄4 columns.]

In the North Eastern Association the Mail Medal for 1965 has been awarded to Kym Kelly of Riverton for the second year in succession.

‘A’ Grade Auburn 7.12 defeated United 7.9

Marriage. Spalding Methodist Church, Saturday 21 August

Gaylene Gericke, youngest daughter of Mr & Mrs C.W. Gericke of Spalding, married

Anthony Treloar, only son of Mr & Mrs C. Treloar of Spalding.

88, 36 (2), 14 Sep. 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Nurse Christine Heinrich of Burra Hospital has passed her first exams for Anatomy and Physiology with a credit. She is the daughter of Mr & Mrs George Heinrich of Reedy Creek and began training in April 1964 under Matron Fyfe of the Burra Hospital.

Burra Colts Football Club held its wind-up dinner at the RSL Hall on Saturday. Trophies were presented:

Fairest & Best P. Brown

Best Backman G. Nankivell

Best Forward G. Benger

Most Improved G. James

Most Consistent S. Anderson

In the Junior Colts trophies went to K. Spackman, D. Spackman and D. Bogisch.

Basketball. Preliminary Finals

‘A’ Grade Burra Gold 40 defeated Booborowie 27

‘B’ Grade Booborowie 32 defeated Hallett 26

‘C’ Grade Spalding 22 defeated Booborowie 9

Burra School parent bodies have been negotiating with the Burra Town Council and Council has now agreed to consider favourably the purchase of Council land in front of the school. This comprises the area now used for the High School Oval etc. and the vacant land in front of the Primary School now used as a parking area. Negotiations with the Highways Department should see approach roads to the school sealed by the end of the year.

Burra Schools’ Libraries’ Appeal stands at about £250.

88, 36 (2), 14 Sep. 1965, pages 1 & 8 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Mobil Shearing Championship 1965 was won by Peter Kelly of Buninyong, Victoria, repeating his 1962 effort.

Contenders were required to shear four sheep in twelve minutes for maximum points for speed. Other points are awarded for the quality of the shearing: Style and handling control 5

Absence of skin cuts 25

Absence of second cuts and wool

left on sheep 35

Position of fleece at finish 3

Workmanship 17

Speed 15

100

Second place went to S.C. Pittaway of Tarlee.

Naturalization Ceremony

About 80 people attended the naturalization ceremony for Mrs Berendina Brak, Mr Jacob Brak and Mrs Mietje Pike, who became Australian citizens last Thursday evening at the Burra Town Hall. The three had been citizens of Holland. Mr Baulderstone administered the oath and Mr C.R. Kelly MHR & Mr P.H. Quirke MP attended the ceremony.

Accident/Obituary. On Friday 10 September at about 5.15 p.m. a car with three young men in it crashed at Burra North. The car with the three, who had been working on the new railway line at Olary, failed to take the bend at the Bon Accord Bridge and landed upside down in the creek. The vehicle caught alight and incinerated the occupants. Local police and the Accident Investigation Squad carried out enquiries. The vehicle was a try top Land Rover. The deceased were Graham Trevor Jackson (23) of La Trobe St, Blair Athol (driver)

Hugh McEvoy (22) of Olary – a Scottish migrant of about 12 months

Allan Howe (17) of Elizabeth Field.

[SA Deaths CD records McEvoy as McAvoy and names Allan Graham Howe as a resident of Olary.]

88, 36 (2), 14 Sep. 1965, page 3 [Number previously used in 1958.]

88, 36 (2), 14 Sep. 1965, page 7 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Burra Footballers’ Cricket Club failed to attract a quorum for its AGM. Only three members attended and unless at least ten give notice of their intention to attend a meeting on 22 September in the Town Hall Supper Room, the club will reluctantly be disbanded.

88, 37 (2), 21 Sep. 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Kooringa Methodist Church will celebrate its 118th Anniversary on 3 October when the President of the SA Conference, Rev. Vivian R. Secombe will preach. Rev. Secombe was appointed to the circuit in 1939.

Burra Schools’ Libraries’ Appeal has reached £402. [Donors are listed.]

Country–style Dancing did not gain the anticipated following, but 40 regular dancers and viewers will continue at the Kooringa Methodist Hall instead of at the Town Hall.

Burra War Memorial Oval Committee will, at its next AGM move to change its name to Burra Memorial Oval Improvement Committee. The AGM is called for next Monday.

Accident. A driver collided with an electricity pole between Burra and Burra North on Friday at about midnight, when he swerved to avoid several sheep on the road. He suffered minor injuries, but did about £200 damage to the car.

Basketball

Elaine Broderick, playing in Burra ‘C’ Grade, registered 583 goals for the season.

The ‘C’ Grade team won the Grand Final on Saturday, beating Spalding 42 to 20.

In ‘A’ Grade Burra Gold 41 defeated Burra Blue 37.

In ‘B’ Grade Leighton 31 defeated Booborowie 29.

Burra Races were held last Wednesday in rather windy conditions, with early showers. The gate takings were £242and the racing was good. [Results printed on page 6.]

Obituary. John Keain of Spalding died last week. He is survived by a sister, Miss Ann Keain and two brothers, Bernard and Tom. [Born 10 July 1893 Willow Plains: died 5 September 1965, Clare, residence Spalding.]

Obituary. Ronald Eric Stahlhut (46) (a returned man) and Robert Brian Stahlhut (18) were killed in a road accident on the West Coast. Mr Stahlhut is survived by his wife Daisy, a son Darryl and a daughter, Vicki.

[Died 4 September and 5 September respectively at Streaky Bay, residence Spalding.]

Nurse K. Clapp has passed her 2nd examination.

Football. Mid North Association Preliminary Final

‘AI’ Grade Robertstown 8.11 defeated Auburn 6.9

‘B’ Grade Robertstown 10.6 defeated Riverton 9.2

Colts Riverton 11.11 defeated Robertstown 5.2

88, 38 (2), 28 Sep. 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Obituary. Mr Gus Mas late of Saddleworth died two hours after getting off the liner Orsova following his return from Spain. After living in Australia for just over 60 years, he returned to his native Spain about two years ago and had just decided to live out his days back in Australia. [Augustin Mas died 22 September 1965 at Woodville, being of no fixed abode. He was aged 74.]

Burra Schools’ Libraries’ Appeal has reached just a little more than half way to its £1,000 goal.

[Donors are listed.]

Burra Pre-School Kindergarten has been granted a loan from the Kindergarten Union to allow them to go ahead with their toilet and playground.

Accident. A semi-trailer accident at Saddleworth resulted in the loss of more than 2,000 gallons of claret, 40 dozen bottles of beer and thousands of champagne corks.

Burra Hospital. The Secretary-Manager L.H. Parker reports tenders for phase 2 of planned renovations and additions. The men’s ward will be divided and the ceiling lowered. Ramps will replace steps at the rear of the building. General renovations and painting will also be undertaken.

Kooringa Methodist Church celebrates its Anniversary next Sunday. The first Methodist service in Burra was probably conducted in the home of John Chapman, a dugout in the Burra Creek. Services continued there till the first chapel was built in 1847. The people were given permission to build provided it was opened free of debt. It cost £250. The present building is only 51 years old. Rev. Vivian Secombe will be guest preacher on Sunday. He was appointed to the Kooringa Circuit in 1939 and served for two years.

88, 38 (2), 28 Sep. 1965, page 3 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Cliff Robertson, Jane Fonda & Rod Taylor in Sunday in New York

Plus News & Shorts

Advt. Elders GM will conduct a clearing sale for R.J. & E.C. Gillett on their property, which has been sold. It is situated six miles south of Burra and two miles north of Hanson.

Football. Mid North Grand Finals

‘A’ Grade Robertstown 15.9 defeated Riverton 11.14

This is the first time Robertstown have been Premiers in the Mid North Association.

‘B’ Grade Saddleworth & Marrabel United 5.6 defeated Riverton 4.6

Colts United 7.6 defeated Riverton 4.6

88, 39 (2), 5 Oct. 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Booborowie Pictures will cease from 6 November. For the past three years they have been conducted by the Institute Committee, who have been selling and collecting tickets. Fred Dinham, Brian Billing and Alan Dewhirst have been honorary operators. In this time about £100 had been raised for the hall, but now lack of support and falling attendances have made it a losing proposition.

Accident/Obituary. Last Tuesday at about 5.30 p.m. Virginia May Quinn aged 4 and Adrian Peter Quinn aged 2, children of Mr & Mrs J.V. Quinn of Mt Bryan were drowned in a dam on the property. They had been playing on a pony near the woolshed and on being missed a search found them floating in the dam. Artificial respiration was ineffective.

Kevin J. Schmidt of Farrell Flat was committed for sentence at the Supreme Court, having been charged with house breaking and larceny at Burra. He was also committed for sentence for killing a sheep with intent to steal the carcase in the World’s End area. On this charge Victor Edward Gill and Leonard Campbell also of Farrell Flat were committed for trial.

Accident. On Friday at about 11 p.m. a car driven by Alan Dennis Beros of Broken Hill overturned at a bend near Burra Racecourse and hit a telegraph pole. The driver and a passenger from Broken Hill both escaped injury, but the car sustained c. £250 damage.

Trespassing on Eastern Properties

Gunther Fromel of Whyalla was fined £2 plus £2 costs for not possessing a gun licence, plus £15 for being an alien and not holding a firearms licence, plus £15 for being on land without permission. Gerrit Hendrik Westerlaken of Stepney was fined £15 plus £2 costs for being on land without permission. The offences occurred at Thistlebeds.

Burra Schools’ Libraries’ Appeal has reached £833 with a week to go. [Donors are listed on page 6.]

Burra & District Swimming Pool

Only seven persons attended a public meeting to discuss the future management of the pool and this included the Mayor and two Councillors. The others were two members of the Swimming Club and one newcomer to the town. Discussion disclosed the view that the control of the pool by the Burra & District Swimming Club resulted in the needs of the competitive swimmer being placed before the needs of the public and casual swimmers. A resolution was passed that a recommendation be made at the Swimming Club’s AGM that the management and control of the pool be vested with the Corporation and the Club concentrate on running competitive swimming.

J. Carpenter writes as Hon. Secretary of the T & P Disabled Soldiers’ Assoc. concerning their annual badge day at Burra on 8 & 9 October.

88, 39 (2), 5 Oct. 1965, page 2 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Burra Town Council, 20 September

Crs Jeffery & Cornelius moved the Council sell Pt Section 13A of 1 acre 36 perches for £1 to the Education Department with the Department to bear all costs and the Department to be advised also that Sections 33 and Pt 13A of 3 acres 36 perches are being held in trust for the High School Council, which is also to be advised.

Council advises it will declare certain private streets public streets.

Cr Williams moved that Council allocate house numbers in the 1965-66 year for postal purposes.

The Clerk was instructed to check records concerning the possibility of lending specimens to Burra High School.

88, 39 (2), 5 Oct. 1965, page 7 [Number previously used in 1958.]

St Mary’s. The Lord Bishop of Adelaide the Rt Rev. Dr T.T. Reed will visit the parish next Sunday for a confirmation service and Holy Eucharist. There will be eleven candidates, of whom nine are adults.

Table Tennis. Premiership

Division I Willalo 13 defeated Hanson 12

Division II Spalding Blue 21 defeated Burra Blue 4

88, 39 (2), 5 Oct. 1965, page 8 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Aberdeen Tennis Club held its AGM 17 September. In the next season the club will enter one ‘A’ Grade team and two ‘B’ Grade teams (Blue & White). It will support a move for a junior team. President R.R. Reed reported on a successful year in which the ‘A’ Grade was narrowly defeated in the grand final and the ‘B’ Grade White team took the premiership. The club undertook the erection of toilet blocks this year. Dudley Jacka drew up plans and the work was done by F.M. Pearce & Sons. The Easter Tournament was a great success.

88, 40, 12 Oct. 1965, page 1

Burra Show was held on Saturday in fine weather and drew a record number of entries and a record gate taking of £258. Mr Res Warnes, as President of the Royal Agricultural and Horticultural Society, opened the show. The day dawned with misty rain, but soon cleared to a fine day. The Flower Pavilion looked a picture. The display of school work was excellent. Grain and fodder, fruit and vegetables, cooking, needlework and Youth Club displays combined well. The strong support of exhibitors from the Clare District was evident throughout. There was a good variety of sideshows. Samson the Strongman proved the most popular of the tent shows. Young’s Caterers of Melrose again did a good job. Local and visiting businesses provided a variety of machinery merchandise and vehicles. Quite a good crowd attended the dance in the main pavilion at night, when door takings amounted to £50. The Cascades Band provided the music for this event arranged by the Rural Youth Club.

Burra Schools’ Libraries’ Appeal reaches £935.

Burra Bowling Club will open the 1965-66 season on Saturday 16 October. The greens are in good order and new lighting is being installed to ensure good light for 10 rinks. Associates will open their season on 20 October.

Accident. A Volkswagen sedan driven by Mr Carl Lawrence of Campbelltown collided with a Holden sedan driven by David Phillips of Burra at about 8 p.m. on Friday 8 October about 5 miles south of Hallett at Shattock’s Corner. The Holden rolled over and the driver and his passengers, Angela Ryan and Mrs Joan Barrett, both of Burra, were admitted to the Burra Hospital. Mrs Barrett was transferred to Adelaide Hospital the next day, it is believed with a shattered ankle. Both vehicles were extensively damaged.

Accident. On Thursday a car driven by Kingsley Broad of Peterborough overturned near the junction of the Black Springs and Adelaide Roads about a mile outside Burra. The car skidded on loose gravel. The driver’s two daughters were passengers. Rosemary (6) suffered lacerations and a fractured left leg. Deborah (5) sustained lacerations and shock. The three occupants were admitted to the Hospital and damage to the car was estimated at c. £300.

88, 40, 12 Oct. 1965, page 7

Miss E.M. Bailey’s property was sold at the RSL Hall on Friday.

Lot 1. ‘Homestead’ of 423 acres was bought by Messrs S.T. Miller & Son for £49 per acre.

Lot 2. 258 acres went to Broad Bros. for £37 per acre.

Lot 3. 114 acres was bought by C.T. Bailey & Sons for £36 per acre.

88, 40, 12 Oct. 1965, page 8

Note land transfer of 1 acre in Hd Wonna Section 130 from the Education Department to H.M. Queen Elizabeth.

88, 41 (2), 19 Oct. 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Burra Mine

The Burra Mine was inspected on Friday by Mr S. Bevan the minister of Mines, Mr T.A. Barnes the Director of Mines, the Deputy Director Mr Parkin and the Senior Geologist Mr Nixon. The Minister said the Mines Department had been carrying out extensive geological, Geophysical and Geochemical surveys of the district for several years, coupled with a drilling program. This had established substantial ‘leavings’ of oxidised copper in and north of the old open cut. It is estimated to comprise over one million tons of low grade oxidised copper. Trial recovery from parcels of the material by Australian Mineral Development Laboratories had been encouraging. The interest of major exploration companies was being invited and if further work confirms the Mine Department’s findings an industry would be established at Burra to recover the copper. This would involve open cut mining and the removal of overburden and oxidised copper to at least 100 ft below the present water level in the old open cut, followed by acid leaching of the ore to recover copper concentrate in a treatment plant. Employment for over 50 men would last from 5 to 10 years. Also several targets for deeper drilling had been suggested and any company selected for the project would be required to continue vigorous and substantial exploration, which if successful could lead to a major mining operation. Mr Baulderstone and Mr Finch were very interested in the tour of inspection and appreciated the action of the Minister in including them and the Town & District Councils in the inspection.

Mr W. (Bill) Voumard is 90 today and still going strong on his bicycle.

The Burra Schools’ Libraries’ Appeal has reached £1008, with donations still coming in.

Peter Maynard was riding his bicycle on the main road near the Mine entrance on Monday 11 October when he encountered a 4 ft 6 inch snake. The startled snake attempted to strike Peter on the leg, but only left two small marks on his boot about one inch below the top. Peter was saved by his ‘Beatle boots’.

Accident. A car driven by Mrs R.J. Jeffery of Burra was struck by the Adelaide bound morning passenger steam train at the Manoora crossing on Saturday morning. The car was picked up and rammed into the culvert and bank. Mrs Jeffery was not seriously hurt, but her passenger, Mrs H.J. Topsfield, is still in a serious condition in the Royal Adelaide Hospital after being transferred from the Riverton Hospital.

Burra National Trust continues to collect items of historical interest for its museum. Mr R. Fuss has donated many items of historical value and has made a perfect replica of a Cornish wheelbarrow. Mrs Jessie Rooke has given an old reaping machine and a cart. The Trust is seeking a two furrow plough and a German wagon.

Elders-GM Annual Stud Ewe Sale was held on Wednesday 13 October and drew a small, but very interested group of local and interstate buyers. There was keen support from WA buyers. The highest price went to John Collins & Sons for eight specially selected strong woolled 11⁄2-year-old May-born ewes, which sold to 52 guineas and went to W.J. & J. Wade of Narrogin WA. [Prices are printed, with other details and the promise of more in the following issue.]

The Burra Bowling Season was opened by President Jack Topsfield on Saturday. He presented the plaque to Les Phillips as a member of the Burra Green Team, which won the Mid North Association pennant last season. Dick Harris, as longest serving member, rolled the first jack and Charlie Dare put down the first bowl.

Burra Darts. George Earle won the Royal Exchange Hotel Darts Championship on Saturday with Peter Nourse as runner-up. Mrs R. Spackman won the Ladies’ Trophy.

88, 42 (2), 26 Oct. 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Burra racing Club

The experimental Saturday meeting was socially successful, but a financial failure. Attendance was about 450. The date granted unfortunately clashed with so many other functions in the district. The racing was quite good despite small fields. [Results are printed.]

The Town Clerk has advised the postmaster that premises within the town area would be numbered in January 1966. Mr Shakeshaft said this would enable more efficient letter delivery and facilitate the training of new staff.

Theft. A bale of wool valued at c. £95 was stolen at the weekend from the property of P.J .Thomas at World’s End. Burra Police and Adelaide CIB are investigating.

Weather. Only 20 points of rain have fallen in the past six weeks and many crops are past the recovery stage, but some could save the farmer from complete despair if rain comes soon.

J. Carpenter, Honorary State secretary of the TPI Association, thanks Burra for the £68 raised in its annual badge appeal.

Cheryl Finch (11) of Burra has won a copy of Colin Thiele’s February Dragon in the ‘Smokey Contest’ on fire safety rules and precautions.

Burra Schools’ Libraries’ Appeal has reached £1033.

Senior Officer K. McNab of the Repatriation Department will visit Burra RSL on 4 & 5 November to give advice. Appointments should be made with Mr Wilf Nankivell.

88, 42 (2), 26 Oct. 1965, pages 1 & 7 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Hallett Red Cross Flower Show on Friday 15 October was most successful and the profit should be c. £80.

[Trophy winners are listed on page 7.]

88, 42 (2), 26 Oct. 1965, page 3 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Cricket

Leighton 114 v. Koonaburra 4 for 116

Burra Footballers 4 for 155 defeated Booborowie 148

88, 42 (2), 26 Oct. 1965, page 4 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Burra Town Council, 4 October

Among land transfers were Pt Block 13 from the Corporation of Burra to the SA Housing Trust and Pt Block 13 from the Corporation of Burra to ETSA.

Cr Cornelius resigned from the War Memorial Committee on account of poor health.

Council will write to Mr Quirke MP to find out what has developed re a Court House and Police Station at Burra.

Several private streets were declared public.

88, 42 (2), 26 Oct. 1965, page 5 [Number previously used in 1958.]

‘Collinsville’ Ewe Sale details are printed.

Booborowie School held its Annual Pet Show and raised c. £13. [Results are printed.]

88, 42 (2), 26 Oct. 1965, page 6 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Burra Show list of prize winners is concluded.

88, 42 (2), 26 Oct. 1965, page 7 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Cricket. Hallett 9 for 124 defeated Spalding 101.

Burra Small Bore Club. J. Bowden shot a possible at 25 yards, but best off the rifle was Ross Gilbert. K. Spackman led on handicap. Kath Rayner was welcomed as a new member.

Tennis

‘A’ Grade Kooringa 17-114 defeated Spalding 3-49

Mt Bryan 11-94 defeated Aberdeen 9-79

Hallett 19-96 defeated Booborowie 7-89 [? 1-89?]

Juniors Aberdeen 10 sets defeated Mt Bryan 5 sets

Spalding forfeited to Kooringa

Miss G.M. Jordan, whose brother is renowned for climbing the Smelts’ Chimney, visited Burra this week from Broken Hill after an absence of 67 years. She went to Broken Hill in 1898, having attended Burra School. She later became a teacher and at her retirement was a headmistress. Mr Jordan, now 92, is presently in the Hutchinson Hospital, Gawler. Miss Jordan resides in Sydney and is staying in Gawler for the time being.

[Gertrude Mary Jordan 1882-1973. Her brother, Arthur Dawson Jordan died 28 October 1965.]

88, 43 (2), 2 Nov. 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958.]

St Mary’s Guild held a very successful Musicale in the Town Hall on Tuesday. It was organised by the Guild President Mrs Arthur Wright and over 150 people enjoyed the program by Mrs Joyce Thomas and other Adelaide artists. In the official party were the Rector & Mrs Sibly, Rt Rev. Monsignor P. Hughes, The Mayor and Mrs Baulderstone, Mrs Thomas (pianist), Mrs Moss (Contralto), Mrs Drew (Soprano) and Mrs Oaten (Elocutionist). The delightful afternoon raised £95, which will be shared between Guild funds and the Mitchell River Aboriginal Mission.

The new Tally-Hi Shearing Technique triumphed when an Australian Wool Board shearing instructor Kevin Sarre achieved a world record 346 sheep in a day, using the technique at ‘Batesworth’, Penshurst, Victoria. (In 7 hours 48 minutes.) This is a world record for Merino sheep using narrow combs. A team of three shearers managed 824 sheep. The previous record for Merinos was 329 sheep in 7 hours 4 minutes.

The Stolen Bale of Wool from P.J. Thomas’s property at World’s End has been recovered. Mr L.C. Phillips of Koonoona found it on the side of the Burra-Black Springs Road near Black Springs.

Burra Mine

In response to a question from the Hon. R.A. Geddes, the Minister of Mines Hon. S.C. Bevan has assured him that if a lease is let on the Burra Mine ‘a condition of the lease will be that the company will not merely hold the lease without performing work for some specific reason. It will be a condition that the company works the mine to the best of its ability.’

Miss Lynette Nicholls has been nominated by Burra Rural Youth as ‘Miss Rural Industry’ in the Miss Industry Quest to aid the Home for Incurables.

Dr J.V. Peters will give a recital on the St Mary’s organ on Sunday 14 November in connection with the instrument’s 60th anniversary.

Burra Caravan Park will receive up to £1,500 subsidy provided all works and claims were completed by 31 March 1966. The amenities block should be completed by early February to serve 16 stands for caravans.

Burra Hospital has received a £5,552-14-7 bequest from the estate of the late Miss A. Collins. This attracts a two for one subsidy from the Government, making it worth £16,658-3-9. This will cover the cost of phase two of the overall modernisation plan for the hospital. Phase three, which will include the demolition of the ‘old hotel’ section and the erection of a new operating theatre and out-patient clinic, will be commenced as funds become available.

Tennis. A tournament at the Leighton courts on 31 October resulted in a win to Jill McRae for the ladies and Olly Drew for the men.

Local Government Essay Competition

This year’s topic was ‘How does vandalism affect the community?’

All three winners for the Burra Town Council come from Burra Primary School:

1st Prize of £3 Phillip Grubb

2nd Prize of £2 Jillian Hobba

3rd Prize of £1 Bruce Woodman

H. Cornelius & E.T. Baulderstone write urging support for the Anzac Remembrance Appeal, which aims to raise £100,000 for additional Veterans’ Homes and ‘Darby & Joan’ Cottages for aged ex-servicemen and their wives.

88, 43 (2), 2 Nov. 1965, pages 1 & 6 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Burra Small Bore Club. The Annual Inter-Club Shoot between Burra, Morgan, Clare and Peterborough was held at Burra on Sunday to decide the Williams Shield. Ross Gilbert elected to shoot for Clare.

The order of the clubs was:

Morgan 2229.62

Clare 2193.44

Peterborough 2148.53

Burra 2092.24

On Tuesday night a 75 yard shoot was fired. Ross Gilbert headed both the handicap and rifle results.

88, 43 (2), 2 Nov. 1965, page 2 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Obituary. Martin Vincent Mannion died suddenly on 27 September at his home ‘Washpool’ via Spalding. He was brother to Annie (Mrs Fahey dec.), Mary, Michael, Nellie, Bartley, Joe, Peter, Pat and Margaret (Mrs Quinn).

[Born Martin Mannion 17 August 1892 Uroonda.]

Weather. Continuing dry conditions with high temperatures and hot winds continue to reduce the season’s prospects for grain production. About 8 points over the weekend did little good.

88, 44 (2), 9 Nov. 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Kooringa Methodist ‘Rose Fair’ was held at Burra RSL Hall on Friday afternoon and raised c. £200.

[Details in 1 column.]

Theft. Entry was gained to the Burra Primary School through an open window and then a window in the headmaster’s office was forced on Friday night. The contents of the cash tin of the cool drinks stand were taken. In the High School two bottles of mercury weighing about four pounds and valued at £5 were stolen along with some magnesium ribbon.

Miss E.M. Bailey’s clearing sale at Gum Creek is reported.

Fires. At about 3 p.m. on Thursday 4 November a young child started a grass fire in the back of Paxton Square, which was soon put out by the Fire Service. At about 5.45 p.m. the same day fire in the roofs of unoccupied homes in Paxton Square had to be put out. It is thought this fire started from sparks from the first fire.

Adelaide Wool Sales 2 & 3 November. Mackerode Ltd topped local prices at 793⁄4d.

[Other local district prices are printed.]
