88, 44 (2), 9 Nov. 1965, page 7 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Weather. 28 points of rain for the week offered a little hope until several days of strong hot winds dried it all out. The total rainfall of 123 pions for September and October is the fourth lowest on record.

88, 44 (2), 9 Nov. 1965, Supplement [Number previously used in 1958.]

[Single sided 4 columns about A4 size.]

The Ikeya-Seki Comet has been reported as clearly visible at Burra on several mornings recently between 4 and 4.30 a.m.

88, 45 (2), 16 Nov. 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Dogs Attack Sheep. In the past week in the district 15 sheep have been killed and 100 mauled by dogs. One dog was destroyed on Friday night, but more sheep were killed and mauled on Saturday night, proving that more than one dog has been involved. Sergeant Teague is investigating and warns dog owners they can be held responsible for loss or injury caused to stock. Uncontrolled dogs in any paddock etc. can be destroyed if worrying stock or in any paddock etc. where stock has recently been worried.

Weather. In the past week 55 points of rain fell and reports in the district range from 80-90 points. It is too late to do much good.

Accident. A truck overturned at Hanson on Friday night. It was owned by G.H. Adams, carrier of Camden Gardens and driven by James G. Beckett of Thebarton and was heading for Broken Hill. The driver was dazzled by on-coming lights at the sharp turn and in avoiding the approaching car, rolled his vehicle. The driver and passenger, A.S. Jones of Thebarton, escaped with minor injuries, but damage to the truck and its load is estimated at £1,000.

Transport Controls. A move by the Government to reintroduce a fee on vehicles competing with the railways is opposed by stockowners, graziers, primary producers, businessmen and transport operators. A committee has been formed at Clare to oppose the legislation.

[See also an advertisement on page 6 for a public meeting at the Clare Town Hall for 19 November.]

Mr S.J. Britton of Burra Post Office will move to Hawker as Postmaster early in December. Mr Colin Heinrich of Marree will replace him in Burra.

Christmas Eve. Burra traders will stay open till 9 p.m. on Christmas Eve. A merry-go-round will operate free day and night and Father Christmas will visit at 9.15 p.m. Shops will close for a tea break from 5.30 to 7 p.m.

Remembrance Day was marked by a service at the War Memorial in Market Square conducted by G.D. Sibly. Wreaths were laid by T. Rogers, E.T. Baulderstone, T. Perry and R.G. Bernhardt.

Theft. R.J. Hill Menswear Store was broken into on Tuesday night last week. Sports coats, vests, suits, socks, trousers, jumpers and suit cases to the value of £729-9-4 were stolen. Det. J. Williams of Pt Pirie CIB was called in. The previous theft from Hill’s occurred on 6 June, when clothing to c. £200 value was stolen. Jewellery and other items to c. £600 value were then stolen from K.J. Murphy’s gift shop on the same night.

88, 45 (2), 16 Nov. 1965, page 8 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Burra Town Council, October meeting

The Town Clerk is to investigate methods of financing a house for occupation by the Town Clerk.

Council resolved to take over the assets and liabilities of the Burra & District Amateur Swimming Club and the Burra Swimming Pool be thereafter under the control and management of the Council.

Resolved that the position of Pool Attendant be advertised.

Resolved an immediate start be made to prepare the pool for use and a Swimming Pool Account be set up by Council.

1 November

The Town Clerk is to obtain plans and estimates of solid brick and brick veneer houses.

L.L. Fiebig to be advised ‘that the care, maintenance and control of the toilet block adjacent to his Service Station is his soul [sic] responsibility.’

Swimming pool admission is to be 2/- (20 c) and 1/- (10 c) for a child under 14.

Season’s tickets £1-10-0 ($3) for children and £3 ($6) for adults.

Pool Hours 1.30-6.30 p.m. Saturday, Sunday and School Holidays & 2.30-6.30 p.m. school days.

88, 46 (2), 23 Nov. 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958.]

The Transport Bills

The leading article discusses the Government’s proposed bills. One sought to decrease the maximum weight carried on the front axle of a commercial vehicle and the other would impose a fee of up to 2 cents per ton/mile on transport competing with the railways. The writer was against the moves, which were seen as ‘Forcing Centralization’.

Burra Youth Club will celebrate its second birthday with a party and concert in the Salvation Army Hall.

Thefts. Burra police are investigating thefts of petrol from depots and of tools from tractors at Flagstaff.

Tony Wall, NSW Swimming Coach, sponsored by Rothman’s Sport Foundation, will visit the Burra Pool on Friday between 10 a.m. and noon.

St Mary’s. A special Advent Service will feature special music on Sunday by a quartet comprising Mrs Kelly (soprano), Miss R. Reed (contralto), Mr A. Edwards (tenor) and Mr D.J. Sibly (bass). Rev. G.D. Sibly will accompany on the organ.

Snakes are plentiful this year.

Leighton Tennis & Basketball Clubs organised a dance from which takings and associated donations have reached £67-18-0, with more to come. The money will aid the Burra Hospital.

Marriage. Valmai Williams will marry John Secomb on Saturday 4 December.

Marriage. Gloria Moxham will marry John Rowe on Saturday 11 December.

Marriage. Judith Field will marry Kevin Pope on Saturday 18 December.

Booborowie Methodist Christmas Fair raised £263.

Burra Hospital. Phase II of the redevelopment will begin next Monday. Work on this phase should be completed early in the New Year. The casualty room has recently been repainted and a new automatic sterilizer installed. Asbestos & vinyl tiles have been laid in the Midwifery Section on the floors of the four private rooms and the Labour Ward. Effluent from the septic tank has been directed into a recently sunk bore. Phase III of the redevelopment should follow immediately.

Referendum on a Lottery for SA.

Results for the Division of Burra: Yes 2722 and No 1960.

88, 46 (2), 23 Nov. 1965, page 3 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Advt. Burra Pictures, 27 November

Love is a Ball

Stowaway in the Sky

Mr & Mrs Pat Griffen celebrated their Golden Wedding at ‘Delora’ Mt Bryan on 20 November. Some 30 friends and family attended. Their daughter Kathleen (Mrs Max Mudge) came from Whyalla. The couple were married in the Mt Bryan East Methodist Church 23 November 1915.

88, 46 (2), 23 Nov. 1965, page 4 [Number previously used in 1958.]

St Mary’s Organ Recital

On Sunday 14 November a concert celebrated the anniversary of the installation of the pipe organ. Dr J.V. Peters, University of Adelaide Organist and Senior Lecturer of the Elder Conservatorium of Music, played the organ. Over 150 people attended. Scripture readings and prayers accompanied the music. Music included three pieces by Samuel Wesley, a voluntary by William Walond and Henry Purcell’s Trumpet Tune & Air. The Rector, Rev. G.D. Sibly, gave an address on the history of pipe organs and traced the origins of the St Mary’s instrument. It was decided on 20 January 1901, after much discussion, to purchase a pipe organ costing not more than £350. The instrument was dedicated and opened by the rector, Rev. Wightwick, on 22 October 1901. Dr Harold Davies of the Elder Conservatorium played at the dedication. The organ has 588 pipes ranging from 16 ft to 2 inches. The second part of Dr Peter’s recital comprised music pf J.S. Bach: three chorale preludes and the Prelude and Fugue in G. major.

88, 46 (2), 23 Nov. 1965, page 5 [Number previously used in 1958.]

88, 47 (2), 30 Nov. 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Redruth Methodist Guild Gala Day raised £150. The main feature of the day was a Mannequin Parade arranged by three of the younger members, Judy Humphrys, Judith Eberhard and Annette Cameron, assisted by Coralie Eberhard, Dawn Bogisch and Maryanne Stockman. The afternoon concluded with a tea and then there was an evening concert.

Burra Caravan Park. Foundations for the amenities block are due to be poured on Monday.

Land Sale. The 498 acre freehold property of Mr & Mrs S.A. Pearce and Miss D.L. Pearce was sold by Elders-GM in the Burra RSL Hall on Friday. The property is at Leighton and went to Mr W. F. & Mrs I.J. Byles of Burra for £36-5-0 an acre.

James Lawrie & Sons’ old chaff mill at Manoora was totally destroyed by fire on Thursday afternoon. The mill had been unused for more than two years.

A Dog has been worrying fowls at Burra North and was destroyed last week. Another raided Ron Wuttke’s duck yard on Friday, killing five young ducks and a breading hen. Foxes have also been taking poultry within the town.

Carols by Candlelight will be held this year in the Burra Town Hall on Sunday 19 December and proceeds will aid the same charities as the Adelaide event. (The War Memorial Oval is unavailable due to the turfing program there.)

Adelaide Wool Sales last week saw Mt Bryan and Gum Creek wool to the fore. Best district price was 76d by both P.O. & R.J. Drew of Gum Creek and Dave Thomas & Sons of Mt Bryan.

[Other local district prices are printed.]

Anzac Remembrance Appeal donations reach £432-5-0.

88, 47 (2), 30 Nov. 1965, page 4 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Mr Mel Rasmus & family left Farrell Flat to live in Clare last week, having conducted the business known as ‘Sunshine Supplies’ for many years.

Birth. To Mr & Mrs Reg. Baum at Clare on 15 November, a son. Mrs Baun was formerly Miss Karen Smart of Hilltown.

Birth. To Mr & Mrs Peter Abbott of Myrtle Bank Adelaide, on 13 November, a daughter. Mrs Abbott was formerly Miss Phyllis Willis of Farrell Flat.

Obituary. Ethel Kirk, wife of Mr Arch. Kirk, died on 26 November. They were formerly farming west of Farrell Flat and went to live in Adelaide in the 1940s.

[Born Ethel Bessie Longbottom 19 June 1894 Belalie: died 26 November 1965 Prospect.]

Hallett 193 defeated North Booborowie 110

Booborowie Christmas Fair. Now full details are to hand and the amount raised was £269.

CWA Branches Celebrate International Day. This year the selected country was Ireland.

Burra met on 19 November for its 39th birthday. President Mrs E.T. Baulderstone welcomed members. Mrs Watts gave the talk on Ireland.

Mt Bryan met at the home of Mrs John Quinn and Mr & Mrs J. Mannion gave a talk on Ireland after a recent trip there.

Hallett held its day on 19 November when the speaker was Mr T. Casey MP.

88, 48 (2), 7 Dec. 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Cricket. The Mokota Cricket Association honoured its new life members at a dinner in the Booborowie Hotel on 1 December. Life Membership was conferred on Messrs Kitch Miller, Ken Deer, Bill Ashby, Ken Gill and A.L. Collins. President J. McMahon presided. Mr Ken Deer was Association secretary and a long term player. Kitch Miller played in the early matches and in Association teams, including a game on the Adelaide Oval when the Queen visited and met the players in 1954. Mr Bill Ashby had a long association with the game as an administrator. He was wicket keeper in Association matches for a long time. Ken Gill was a fine batsman for Spalding and the first to score a double century in carnival matches in Adelaide and held the record for an opening partnership of 236. Under his captaincy Mokota won three successive carnivals from 1953-55. A.L. Collins made many centuries and his astute handling of the Mt Bryan team kept them on top for many years.

Miss Judith Field, daughter of Mr & Mrs Darrell Field of Burra, has had a most successful nursing career. Last July, while nursing at Royal Adelaide Hospital, she obtained three credits and a gold medal in her examinations. In the past year at Queen Victoria Maternity Hospital she topped the State in the Nurses’ Board Midwifery Examination. She will marry Mr Kevin Pope on 18 December and hopes to continue nursing wherever Mr Pope serves as a school teacher.

Weather. Patchy rain came from thunderstorms on Saturday. Falls varies from a few points to an inch and a half. Burra received 8 points, Balah 67, Koomooloo 120, Woolgangi 41, Braemar 57, Oakbank 10 and Koonoona 8.

Burra School Libraries

Following the success of the appeal for library funds, strong representations had to be made to the Education department to have the promise of subsidies honoured in full. Upon realising that the general public was involved, the Education Department agreed to honour the promise and books are being purchased to the full value of £2,000. The Department has also agreed to proceed with the necessary alterations to the library rooms as soon as possible. The Appeal Committee is not satisfied that, after some delay and discussion, the Department is fully supporting and granting all requests made. A large proportion of the indexing and cataloguing of library books has been completed and hours have been spent covering books. The final cost of the libraries will be in the region of £7,000. The sum raised in the appeal for book funds was £1,100.

Burra High School. A group of 44 First & Second Year students had a recreation weekend camp at Parnanga National Fitness Council Camp at O’Sullivan’s Beach near Adelaide. The group with the Headmaster, Miss D. Jones and Mr K. Schwartz travelled by train to Adelaide and then by hired coach. The weekend was a tremendous success.

Burra RSL held its Annual Reunion Dinner with about 60 participants. The buffet meal was prepared by the Ladies’ Auxiliary and was of the usual high standard.

88, 48 (2), 7 Dec. 1965, page 3 [Number previously used in 1958.]

The 1965-66 Harvest has been delayed by rain and though the Burra silos took their first delivery on 24 November, only about 20,000 bushels have since come in. This is about one day’s taking in a normal year. The quality of the grain is good, but the quantity will be down. Mr Graham Heinrich for example at Worlds’ End reaped an 8-9 bag crop, but this year only a 3 bag crop. The late rains evidently did more good than was expected and many farmers are reporting better results than they had feared.

Cricket. Hallett 7 for 248 v. Burra Footballers.

Marriage. At St Andrew’s Anglican Church, Mt Bryan

Valda Edwards, daughter of Mr & Mrs A.A. Edwards of Mt Bryan, married

Donald Henriks of Willalo.

‘B’ Grade Aberdeen Blue 12-94 defeated Booborowie 8-73

Aberdeen White 14-98 defeated Leighton Black 6-60

Spalding white 12-80 defeated Leighton Gold 7-62

Hallett 12 sets defeated Kooringa 8 sets

Spalding Blue 11 sets defeated Mt Bryan9 sets

The Burra Swimming Pool. Letter from E.T. Baulderstone.

He explains that for the last few years the pool has been administered by the Burra & District Amateur Swimming Club, which has had a lot of difficulties in doing so. At the recent AGM it was decided to ask the Corporation to take over the administration. The Council saw the possibility of the pool not functioning and realised its importance in teaching young people to swim and in the relaxation and enjoyment it offered citizens. The Corporation also considered the amount of effort and capital invested and so decided to accede to the request and to take over the administration. The Council advertised for an attendant, but so far without success. Finally the late Mr D. Morrison agreed to help, but unfortunately he fell ill and was confined to hospital. Mr & Mrs W. Holness have opened the pool at weekends and some afternoons, but due to a lot of undue criticism do not feel inclined to continue.

[Mr Baulderstone says he does not blame them.]

The pool is in excellent condition, but will have to stay closed until we can get an attendant or attendants. In conclusion he thanks, on behalf of the young people in particular who have enjoyed their swimming in the last two weeks, to thank Mr & Mrs Holness for their kind gesture.

88, 48 (2), 7 Dec. 1965, page 8 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Burra Town Council, 15 November

Burra hospital renovations were approved and the usual building fees were waived.

88, 49 (2), 14 Dec. 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Burra Swimming Pool is still without an attendant following the illness and subsequent death of Mr D. Morrison, who had been appointed caretaker on a five day basis with someone else to open it at weekends. Mr G. Baulderstone opened it on Saturday and Sunday. A public meeting is called for 2.30 p.m. tomorrow (Wednesday) to discuss the possibility of a roster system. The attendant opens the pool and handles the sale of drinks etc. A standard of discipline must also be enforced. Without an attendant the pool will have to remain closed.

[Obituary: David Norman Morrison born 18 December 1899: died 5 December 1965 Adelaide, residence Burra.]

Fires. Hallett fire fighters had to attend to two fires in the last week. Goods and clothing in a Lands Department Cruiser caught fire on Thursday night just north of Hallett. It was extinguished within a few minutes. On Friday at 1 p.m. 150 acres of grass feed at ‘Willogoleche’ in the Tommy’s Gap area was burnt. Despite difficult terrain it was put out without stock or property loss.

Burra Marching Girls. The final balance of £2 has been handed to the Burra Youth Club.

Burra Camera Club held its AGM and elected: President, H. Shakeshaft; Vice-Presidents, M. Lind & R. Broad; Secretary, G. Dollman and Assistant Secretary, Mrs D. Dollman. The club will investigate the possibility of purchasing a building to be erected at the show grounds for use by the club at shows.

Accident. A car driven by R.W. Feddern of Kidman Park struck loose gravel and rolled over near the Burra Racecourse at about 4 p.m. last Saturday. The driver suffered a lacerated right elbow.

Decimal Currency. Businesses will be able to get supplies of one and two cent coins from banks in the week before C-Day, 14 February. These are the only coins which do not have equivalents in existing coins and so will be necessary for the changeover.

The Reserve Price scheme for Wool. At the recent referendum of woolgrowers NSW & SA voted NO. The result overall was YES 51,388 and NO 59,235.

Burra High School held its first Valedictory Service last Sunday evening in the Kooringa Methodist Church. About 130 people attended a family tea followed by the service with the theme ‘The New Vision for the New Age’. The guest preacher was Rev. Douglas Hosking, Associate Director of Christian Education for the Methodist Church.

88, 49 (2), 14 Dec. 1965, page 2 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Obituary. A Return Thanks Notice reveals the death of V. Bailey’s husband.

[Wilfred George Bailey born 24 November 1890 Gum Creek: died 8 November 1965 Farrell Flat. He married Violet May Rice 4 April 1931 at Iron Mine Methodist Church.]

Notice. ETSA advises that the new mains depot in Welsh Place has been occupied by the District Supervisor for Burra, Mr D.J. Braun and staff and the depot will be open each day from 7.30 a.m. to 4.15 p.m. Monday to Friday for enquiries regarding electricity supply.

In the Christmas Shoot last Saturday R.G. Bernhardt, K. Lewis of Morgan and W. Hempel had the best scores.

88, 50 (2), 21 Dec. 1965, page 1 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Booborowie School held its annual Christmas Tree on Friday 17 December. Father Christmas came at 9 p.m. Progress Certificates were presented to:

Billy McMahon Kathryn Quinn Kathleen Benton

Lynette Broad Colleen Crowhurst

Burra Swimming Pool. About 20 people attended the public meeting called by the Mayor to discuss a roster system to allow the pool to open daily. Arrangements to use about 30 people were made, enabling the pool to open daily, including weekends. The Education Department’s learn to swim campaign will be run 3-14 January.

Mr R. Fuss of Burra North has constructed and presented to the town a full scale working model of gear used by tributors who worked at the mine after it closed. They are being set up at the end of the jinker shed and comprise a Cousin Jack wheelbarrow, a windlass, an ore dressing table with a peculiar shaped hammer and an ore washing plant.

Adelaide Wool Sales 24-26 November. The top price for the district of 771⁄4d was achieved by J.N. McBride of Kia-Ora. [Other local district prices are printed.]

The Carols Evening in the Town Hall on Sunday Night was not overwhelmingly supported, but was thoroughly enjoyed by those who attended. Mr Arthur Verco of 5AD was the compere. The sale of programs and donations amounted to £40.

88, 50 (2), 21 Dec. 1965, pages 1, 4 & 5 [Number previously used in 1958.]

Burra High School Speech Night was held in the Burra Town Hall on 14 December. S.L. Tregenza, retired Principal of Brighton High School was the guest speaker. The Hon. Member for Burra, P.H. Quirke, also attended. Mrs Tregenza presented the prizes and Mr Quirke presented certificates and trophies to the boys and Mrs Quirke did the same to the girls. Mr Darrell Field as Chairman of the High School Council was in the chair.

The headmaster Mr R.M. Farrow reported on the year:

We have recently seen the election in Mr Field of only the fourth Chairman of the High School Council. This is a fine record of service for chairmen over such a long period. Both Mr A.B. Riggs and Mr H.J.B. Jennison, past chairmen, are present and the latter only retired after 18 years of service and 12 as chairman. Their wives also served long periods as members of the Council as well as on the Parents & Friends’ Association.

[Mr Farrow also welcomed the Mayor & Mayoress, Mr Finch Chairman of the DC and Mr Auhl, Headmaster of the Primary School and Mrs Auhl, as well as the religious instructors.]

Last year’s public examinations resulted in the awarding of 24 Intermediate Certificates and the completion of two others. Four Leaving Certificates were gained and one was completed. Three others were gained in the Supplementary Examinations. Lynette Robinson and Denise Griffen won Intermediate Exhibitions and Eleanor Miller and Gregory Short gained Continuation Scholarships.

This year the club period has continued and sport has continued to play its vital role with inter-house matches and inter-school exchanges against Balaklava and Clare High Schools, while matches against Riverton will be played tomorrow. In the Inter-High School Sports Day Burra won the E.E. Williams Handicap Shield for the second successive year and only narrowly missed the Championship Shield.

The swimming carnival in March was an outstanding success.

In September 36 Intermediate and Leaving students accompanied by Miss Jones, Miss Briggs, Mr Morris and myself undertook a ten day tour to Sydney and Canberra – a very exciting and worthwhile trip and recently a party of 44 First and Second Year students had a recreational weekend at the Parnanga National Fitness Council Camp at O’Sullivan’s Beach, at which Mrs Jones, Mr Ayliffe, Mr Schwartz and Mr Hayward were energetic leaders.

The parent bodies have been very helpful and valuable. Traditions such as the annual ball and the banquet always receive 100% support. The banquet is to be held this coming Thursday.

Money has been set aside for the erection of changing rooms and the installation of fans in the iron rooms. Subsidy will be granted when funds become available. The Association has also provided additional furnishings for the sick room and crockery and an electric urn for what is still only a temporary staff room.

The High School Council in conjunction with the Primary School Committee has done excellent work and this has made successful representations to the Education Department to purchase land in front of the school. The Council also supported my moves to have pathways in front of the school repaired.

Other moves, which I anticipate will come to fruition soon, are for the remodelling of the toilets and headmaster’s office, paving of the yard and the provision of proper staff facilities. The school still lacks many of the desirable features that modern education needs for effectiveness.

One innovation this year was an open night when teachers were available for interview by parents who were also invited to visit classrooms as they saw fit.

For a long time the High school has followed the traditional academic courses leading to Intermediate and Leaving Public Examinations. I am pleased, if a little apprehensive that next year we are to have an alternative course leading to an internal Intermediate Certificate. This should cater for a large percentage of students, while still giving the enlightenment which we claim an education should do.

In spite of all the promise here; I still fear the problem of the closed mind. There is an absence in the district at large and in the school itself of an academic climate. There is little point in the school trying to open up the mind of the child unless firstly he is encouraged and inspired by at least some other lively minds and worthwhile intellectual pursuits outside of school and unless there is some opportunity to continue his intellectual growth once he has left school.

[Mr Farrow then developed this theme at some length. He went on to speak of the donors of prizes and trophies and to thank those who organised the hall. He spoke also of the House system and wished departing students well.]

Staff changes: Mr Ayliffe has transferred to Norwood High School and Miss E.J. Newman of Findon High School has been appointed Senior Mistress at Burra.

88, 50 (2), 21 Dec. 1965, page 3 [Number previously used in 1958.]

88, 50 (2), 21 Dec. 1965, Supplement [Number previously used in 1958.]

[Single-sided of 5 columns about A4 size]

Burra Burra DC

Among other transfer notices is one from M.L. Rasmus & another to Ian Joseph Denton and Trevor Bruce Denton of Lot 13 of 13perches and Lot 14 of 1 rood 8 perches and Section 417 Torreston.

Characteristics of the paper in 1965

A fair coverage for Burra, but a lot on outlying areas like Hallett, Spalding and Farrell Flat.

Page 1

Dominated by news, but this is by no means confined to Burra news.

Pages 2 & 3

Large advertisements and public notices and sales and these often extend to page 3. There may be some news also on page 3.

Pages 4, 5 & 6

Half at least is advertising. As far as news is concerned these pages are dominated by sports results. Other prominent features are reports of Annual General Meetings of clubs and other organisations such as church organisations and the CWA along with some reports of their meetings.

Page 7

The ‘Cash Column’ is often here, though it sometimes appears elsewhere and shares space with other items typical of pages 4, 5 & 6.

Page 8

Advertising and a large section of 50 and 25 years ago in the paper, along with news from other districts. The reports from past years can also wander onto other pages.

Pages 9 & 10

These extra pages sometimes appear and continue the style of pages 4, 5 & 6.

Supplements are not uncommon, but vary in size and are sometimes single-sided.

NOTE THAT WHEN 1959 IS NOTED IT SHOULD BE FOUND TO BE VOLUME 89

IF THIS IS SO THE ISSUE NUMBERS FOR 1966 WILL ALL BE (2)

89, 1, 11 January 1966 page 1

Burra CWA building is now free of debt. Treasurer Mrs H. Crump made the last payment to the Savings Bank after the last meeting. It is hoped a new fence will soon be erected between the CWA property and those of the M&BHA and Mr & Mrs P. Byles.

A minute of appreciation was recorded for the effort of Mrs Phillips in hiring out crockery over recent years. This has raised almost £80, but will now be discontinued due to the time and effort required. Following the Christmas meeting the branch has gone into recess until 17 March.

The rainfall for 1965 was 1159 points: about six inches below average.

Swimming. The first round of the annual triangular inter-club swim between Burra, Clare and Spalding has resulted in Burra and Clare being equal on points with 42 each and Spalding has 38. [Results are printed.]

Elders-GM. After a stay of 61⁄2 years the Chief Clerk at Burra Mr R.N. Jenkins has been transferred to Bordertown. While in Burra ‘Jenks’ has been associated with the football, tennis and table tennis. He was also for a time secretary of the Swimming Club and a member of the Rural Youth Club. He is replaced by Mr G.J. Timmins of Strathalbyn.

From Alice Springs, after a stay of several years, Mr Ray Kotz transfers to Gawler later this month.

The Learn to Swim Campaign has about 160 children taking part at Burra. This is about 30 fewer than in 1965, but on a par with 1964.

Jack Kellaway (82) of Croydon has renewed his subscription to the paper and says most of his family worked in the old Burra Mine at some time or other. His grandfather, William Kellaway, came out from Cornwall about 106 years ago and worked in the mine.

BHS. Intermediate craft subject results are printed.

New staff:

Mr D. Pennington replaces Mr Ayliffe. He will live at Hallett and drive the school bus in each day.

Miss E.J. Newman has been appointed Acting Senior Mistress.

New Year’s Eve prank. Someone plastered shop windows and doors etc. with white paint as a joke. Some of it has proved very difficult to remove and was hardly funny.

Burra Silos have received an intake closer to normal than had been expected, with about 175,000 bushels up to yesterday. This compares with 190,000 bushels taken to the same time in the 1964-65 season. The quality has been good.

Fires. The Farrell Flat area has had two fires recently.

On 30 December 20-30 acres of grass and some fencing was burnt when fire broke out just north of the town.

On 7 and 8 January there were fires near Lodge Hill.

Accident/Obituaries.

Over the New Year weekend five young people were killed in a light plane crash at Canopus Station east of Burra. The pilot was Russell Tiver (23) the son of Mr & Mrs M.H. Tiver of Burra. He had been conducting sight-seeing tours over the 400,000 acre property, owned by Mr W.G. Snell, when the accident occurred. The passengers were:

David Stanley Radford (15) and William John Radford (12) who were the only children of David Radford of Canegrass Station. And also Janne Elizabeth Daniel (16) and Peter John Daniel (13) who were the only children of Mr & Mrs S.D. Daniel of Kulpara.

A private funeral was conducted at Burra Cemetery for Mr Tiver and for the others private services were held in Adelaide.

[Russell Gordon Tiver born 8 July 1942 Abberton Park, Burra: died 1 January 1966 Canopus Station.]

89, 1, 11 January 1966 page 2

Burra to North Booborowie six times a week.

Burra to Oakvale once a week.

Hallett to Braemar once a week.

Hallett to Mt Bryan East twice a week.

Cricket. Inter-Association Match.

Mokota 211 defeated Belalie 99 (1 innings each).

89, 2, 18 January 1966 page 1

Learn to Swim Campaign. 120 certificates were earned. Those receiving them are listed.

Weather. Rain in the past week fell from patchy thunderstorms across the pastoral areas. Dams were filled on Oakvale, Koomooloo, Old Koomooloo, Morganvale and Sturtvale, where falls ranged from 110 to 140 points. Elsewhere fall varied from 16 to 70 points, while in Burra only 3 points were recorded.

Burra Hospital. Work on alterations is progressing.

Accident. A utility turned over near Hallett on Saturday morning. Two men received leg injuries: the driver Michael John Chamberlain of Modbury and passenger Ross Arbon of Goodwood Park.

The Adelaide Festival of Arts is being supported by country people who have booked more than 11,000 seats for the events in March.

89, 2, 18 January 1966 page 2

Obituary. Dorothy Monica Preiss died at Broken Hill Hospital on 21 December 1965. She was the wife of John Matthew Preiss and the mother of Brian, Kevin, Clair, Shirley (Mrs Rose of New Zealand), and Trevor (deceased). She was aged 57. [Born Dorothy Monica Allen c. 1908, Broken Hill, NSW (family records): married John Preiss St Joseph’s, Burra 15 April 1929.]

89, 3, 25 January 1966 page 1

Burra Town Council

Following the resignation of the Town Clerk Mr W.A. Holness after four years, the Council last night appointed Mr A.R. Graham in his place. Mr Graham has previously been Town Clerk at Jamestown. He is married with two young children.

Farrell Flat Silo has closed after receiving 426,560 bushels of wheat.

Fire. A flock of galahs on power lines is thought to have sparked a fire about 5 miles north of Farrell Flat on Saturday 15 January.

Farrell Flat Leaving Students who have gained certificates are Jill Przibilla, Lynette Robinson, Geoffrey Short and Graham Brook, who all attended BHS and Rosemary Klem, who wen to Immanuel College in Adelaide.

Jill Przibilla will begin as an assistant at Clare Pre-School Kindergarten in February.

Burra Caravan Park

In the new caravan park near the swimming pool the walls of the amenities block have been completed. It is hoped the new park will be ready by the end of March.

A New Road Law, effective from 1 January has made it an offence to drive with any portion of the body projecting from the vehicle – so watch out for elbows and gutter clutching.

Accident. A car carrying Mrs S. Kirk and her young son and daughter overturned near Snowtown on Sunday evening. The three escaped injury.

89, 3, 25 January 1966 page 3

Burra Mine

Exploration rights for the Burra Mine have been let. Drilling will start within a few days. The Minister of Mines Mr S.C. Bevan announced this today. The rights have been granted to Mines Exploration Pty Ltd on behalf of Broken Hill South Ltd, North Broken Hill Ltd, Electrolitic Zinc Co. of Australia Ltd and McPhar Geophysics Ltd. Exploration work by the Department of Mines has shown that redevelopment of low grade oxidised ore in the old mine was a sound economic proposal and that further exploration for primary ore near the old workings was worth while. Mines Exploration Pty Ltd represented a predominantly Australian group. The company would expend a large sum in further testing of the low grade oxidised ore and also the deep ore deposits. A decision on whether it would be economic to establish a mining treatment project for oxidised ore can be expected within twelve months.

Burra Town Council, 20 December

A man from the SA Archives will be allowed to inspect old Council records.

Elders-GM are to be advised that the Council is interested in the purchase of Pt Section 13 for use as a public reserve for the town.

The Town Clerk’s resignation was accepted and applications for a replacement will close on 14 January.

89, 4, 1 February 1966 page 1

Adelaide Wool Sales. The top price for local producers was 801⁄4d per lb by ‘Ashrose’, W.B. Ashby & Sons of Hallett. [Other local prices are printed.]

Cricket. The ‘Advertiser’ Cricket Coaching School will be held at Burra Primary School Oval on Thursday 24 February. Mr Allen Lyon will conduct the school.

Burra Mine. Representatives of Mines Exploration Pty Ltd arrived in Burra last Thursday. Two surveyors and a drilling team arrived and began erecting a diamond drilling rig on Friday on ‘Look-out Hill’.

Burra High School. 15 students gained Leaving Certificates at the 1965 examinations.

[4 subjects including English were required. Numbers indicate how many subjects were passed.]

Brook, Graham 6 Catt, Christopher 6 Disher, Gary 6

Josephs, Raelene 5 Miller, Eleanor 5 Murphy, Susan 6

Burra Hospital. The alterations and additions of phase two are now taking shape. A new pantry has been completed. Modifications to the Men’s Ward are progressing. Steps between all levels have been eliminated and air conditioning has been installed.

Decimal Currency

The Burra Post Office is well organised to handle the change to decimal currency on 14 February.

Letters for one ounce will then cost 4 c.

Each additional ounce will cost 3 c.

Aerograms will cost 9 c.

Airmail letters to Europe will be 25 c. per half-ounce.

A three-minute telephone call to Adelaide will be 40 c. at day rates and 30 c. for evening rates.

Decimal currency postage stamps will be available from 7 February, but must not be used before 14 February.

In this week the stamps will only be available in full sheets or booklets of 15.

£.s.d. stamps will remain valid for two years.

From 14 February banks will operate in decimal currency and all banking documents including deposits and cheques must be written in decimal currency from 14 February.

89, 4, 1 February 1966 page 2

Advt. Burra Pictures, 5 February

Jerry Lewis in The Errand Boy

Ben Gazzara & Sammy Davis Jnr in Convicts 4

89, 4, 1 February 1966 page 3

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club

11 January fired over double 50 yards. Best were: R. Gilbert, J. Bowden & R. Angel.

18 January fired over double 75 yards. Best were: R. Alderson, A. Angel & P. Mengersen.

Burra Town Council, 24 January

Mr A.R. Graham of Jamestown was appointed Town Clerk.

‘Dollar Bill’ educational comic strip.

89, 4, 1 February 1966 page 6

Burra Sub-Branch of ALP

Senator Reg Bishop was guest speaker on 24 January. Others were Senator Arnold and the endorsed candidate for Wakefield, Jack Phelan. Senator Drury outlined efforts of Labor Members to get improved benefits for ex-servicemen from the Boer War and WWI.

Burra Primary School. Staff changes:

Miss Brenda Richards comes from Mt Bryan

Miss Lucy Raggio comes from Western Teachers College

Mt Ian Raftery comes from Loxton Primary

Mr Philip Lannan comes from Pooraka Primary

Mr Kevin Pope has been transferred to Wallaroo

Mrs Peter Sandercock has been transferred to Willunga Primary.

89, 5, 8 February 1966 page 1

Burra Choral Society has vacancies for singers in all departments. It has its first meeting for 1966 on 17 February. The conductor is Rev. G.D. Sibly, Secretary Mrs Edith Carpenter and Mrs J. Oates is the pianist.

The Burra Oval grassing project is progressing well, though there are still some bare patches. The growing season has been particularly dry, which has hindered the efforts of Mr Baulderstone and Mr Arnold Heinrich.

Nigel Dollman (4), son of Mr & Mrs Guy Dollman, vanished from the Burra Street when his mother popped into Wilkinson’s for a moment. A family and then a police search proved fruitless, but at 2 p.m. the police were advised that he was at Yunta, having boarded a tourist coach at Burra.

Swimming. In the triangular contest between Burra, Clare and Spalding, Burra and Clare tied in the first meet, but Spalding established a lead of almost 80 points at the second meet and consequently it is unlikely Spalding can be overtaken in the third contest at Clare on Friday. Spalding will therefore hold the shield for the next twelve months.

Mr A.R. Graham the new Burra Town Clerk will take up his duties on 14 March.

Alan Williams of Chapel Street left Burra this week to take over the Caltex garage at Mt Gambier. Alan’s wife came from Mt Gambier.

89, 5, 8 February 1966 page 3

Advt. Burra Pictures, 12 February

Samuel Bronston & Claudia Cardinale in Circus World

Margaret Beth Prior, youngest daughter of Mr & Mrs A. Prior of Hallett, married

Barry Ellis, son of Mr & Mrs J.C. Ellis of Crystal Brook.

89, 6, 15 February 1966 page 1

Weather. Light Rain on Saturday night brought falls of 35-60 points to agricultural and pastoral districts. Burra recorded 60 points.

Kevin Maloney, teller at the ANZ in Burra since last June, has been transferred to the Somerton branch. Mr John Phillips will replace him from the Gawler branch.

Farrell Flat Methodist Church will hold its Harvest Thanksgiving service on 20 February.

Mr & Mrs Mel Rasmus and family have moved from Farrell Flat to Clare after c. 17 years there.

Swimming. Spalding has won the Tilbrook Shield at the third meet on Friday night at Clare. Totals over the three rounds were: Spalding 1971⁄4, Burra 1251⁄2 and Clare 1061⁄4.

[Friday’s results are printed.]

Break-ins in Burra

On the night of Friday-Saturday last the office safe was stolen from the Kooringa Hotel. The premises of T.W. Wilkinson & Co. were also entered. Change amounting to $22 and a transistor radio were taken.

Obituary. Mr Willie (Bill) Voumard died on Thursday night aged 90. [There was also a death notice on page 2.]

He was born in Berne, Switzerland, 19 October 1875 and came to Australia aged 6.* The family came to live at Copperhouse and moved into Burra when he was aged 9. He died in the house that had been his home for 81 years. In early life he worked on a number of eastern pastoral properties. He was an enthusiastic cyclist and on many occasions would ride 50 or 60 miles from his place of employment to a sports meeting and then compete in events. He won a number of medals and trophies and on one such occasion won a 50 mile race in a little over two hours. He continued to ride his bike in Burra up to the time of his death. In 1906 he married Florence Minetta Brandt and they had eight children before she died in 1924. He then left the ‘Eastern’ Country and came to work in Burra for the Burra Town Council until retiring some years ago. In 1927 he married Clara Ellen McLennan who died in 1957. He is survived by Fred, Ruby (Mrs Jack Rowe), Jack, Lance, Jean (Mrs Murray Opperman), May (Mrs Joff Parkes), Ida (Mrs Norman Hyde) and Edna (Mrs Jack O’Keefe).

[William Voumard died 10 February 1966, Burra.]

[*A correction was printed 89, 7, 22 February 1966, page 4. Mrs M.A. Taylor of Burra North has advised that the late Mr W. Voumard came to Australia in 1876 aged 6 months not 6 years. Mrs Taylor is a sister to Mr Voumard and was born at Copperhouse 27 April 1878.]

Milk Prices in Burra

The Prices Commissioner has approved a rise in the price of milk in Burra:

Bulk milk 9c. per pint.

Pasteurised TetraPak 10 c. per pint.

89, 6, 15 February 1966 pages 1 & 4

Mid North Football Association met at Saddleworth on 11 February. The meeting thrashed out a proposal to be put to the annual meeting that the 1966 teams should be:

‘A’ Grade ‘B’ Grade (‘A2’ Grade merged with ‘B’) Colts

Auburn Auburn

Sevenhill & Watervale

Riverton Riverton Riverton

Mintaro Farrell Flat

Aberdeen Aberdeen Aberdeen

S-M United S-M United S-M United

Manoora

Robertstown Robertstown Robertstown

[S-M United = Saddleworth & Marrabel]

Blyth indicated by letter that it would not be a member of the association for 1966.

Farrell Flat & Aberdeen indicated an openness to consider amalgamation.

Robertstown included Julia and Point Pass.

There was a further suggestion that the following amalgamations be undertaken:

Aberdeen & Farrell Flat

Auburn & Sevenhill

Mintaro & Manoora

Riverton & Tarlee

And that Colts teams then match ‘B’ Grade teams.

A decision will be made at the AGM.

89, 5, 8 February 1966 pages 1 & 5

School Enrolments

Burra Primary School

Headmaster Mr Ian Auhl reports an enrolment of 247 (124 boys and 123 girls); up 20 on last year. There are 36 new students in Grade I to bring it to a total of 40. [They are listed.]

Miss Kathlyn Rayner will teach 30 of them and Miss Lucy Raggio will take a composite of 20 students from Grades I, II and III.

Miss Brenda Richards comes from Mt Bryan School and takes Grade III.

Mr Ian Raftery comes from Loxton School and takes Grade IV.

Mr Philip Lannon has come from Pooraka School and takes Grade VII.

Mrs Perry, Mrs Jeffery & Mrs Pens are in charge of Grades VI, V and II. Mrs Perry is Senior Assistant.

The Library is in the final process of establishment. Books have been purchased and covered and the furniture is arriving.

The Chairman of the School Council Mr Ron Moreland is finalising the work of sealing the access roads.

Burra High School

Mr D.K. Pennington has replaced Mr John Ayliffe, who was transferred to Norwood High School.

Miss L. Newman comes from Findon High School as Senior Mistress.

[New enrolments are listed.]

Burra Kindergarten

There is an enrolment of 51 compared with 42 last year. This gives a maximum daily attendance of 30.

22 are enrolled for daily attendance and 29 for several times a week. [All are listed.]

It is worth noting the district importance of the kindergarten is shown by the 5 children from Hallett, 4 from Booborowie, 4 from Gum Creek and 2 from Mt Bryan.

St Joseph’s Convent School

There are 2 new students and a total of 25. At the same time in 1965 there were 26.

Leighton School

Six new members in Grade I are listed. The total enrolment is 28 compared with 30 in 1965.

The Head Teacher is Mr R. Osman.

Hallett School

There are 53 enrolments compared with 58 last year. [They are listed.]

Teachers are:

Miss Genevieve Overton: Grades I, II & III.

Mr P.T. Hogan (Head Teacher) Grades IV, V, VI & VII.

Mt Bryan School

There are 4 new students: 3 in Grade I and 1 in Grade VI. [Listed]

Enrolment is 31 compered with 34 last year. Two new teachers have been appointed.

Mrs P.L. Weston takes Grades I, II & III.

Mr I.R. Weston takes Grades IV, V, VI & VII.

Booborowie School

There are 14 new enrolments. [Listed]

Enrolment is 66; an increase of 13 on January 1965 and of 10 on December 1965.

Farrell Flat School

There are 43 pupils; up 4 on 1965. [New pupils are listed.]

Miss Anita Archure has come from Western Teachers College to take charge of the infant section.

Spalding School. [Note this information was added in 89, 7, 22 February 1966, page 8.]

There were 86 on the roll; up 2 from January 1965.

89, 6, 15 February 1966 page 3

Salvation Army

The Peterborough Salvation Army members visited Burra recently to collect for their Harvest Thanksgiving and to investigate the possibility of recommencing activities in Burra. Those interested should contact Bro. S.D. (Stan) Sullivan c/o Jennison’s Tyre Service or at Graham Street.

89, 6, 15 February 1966 page 7

Weather. Further rain from thunderstorms has brought up to an inch fairly widely since Saturday, but it has been patchy. Falls since Saturday include: Old Koomooloo 68 points, Pine Valley 101, Woolgangi 22, Glenora 16.

Burra recorded 70 points.

‘Dollar Bill’ educational comic strip. This time Bill is buying a surf board and receiving his pay packet.

89, 7, 22 February 1966 page 1

The Rural Youth Amateur Hour at the Burra Town Hall on Friday drew a disappointingly small audience. The event was to raise money for their entrant in the Miss Industry Quest, Miss Lynette Nicholls. [The items are reviewed.] About $96 was raised.

Burra RSL called its AGM for 18 February, but it had to be postponed when the meeting lacked a quorum.

Burra National Trust Branch has recently acquired the building next to the Fire Station in Market Square with the object of preserving items of historical interest. Officers of the branch are: President, Mr A. Tennant; Secretary, Miss M. Woollacott and Treasurer, Miss E. Tiver.

The ‘Advertiser’ Cricket School at Burra on 24 February will see Mr M. Hodge instruct the interested cricketers aged 10-14.

The Annual Open Swimming Carnival was held at the Burra Pool on Sunday and attracted a large number of swimmers. Patron Mr G. Stanley Hawker made the presentations. [Results are printed.]

Denise Griffen, an outstanding Leaving student at BHS in 1965, has been awarded a Commonwealth Open Entrance Scholarship to study at the University. This provides free tuition, a living allowance and other benefits at the University. Denise is presently taking matriculation at Norwood High School.

BHS. Parents met staff at a meeting organised by the Parents & Friends’ Association at the school on 17 February. President Mrs A. Benger chaired the meeting. Chairman of the High School Council Mr Darrell Field spoke briefly and the Headmaster Mr R.M. Farrow introduced the two new members of staff: Miss Newman and Mr Pennington.

Last Thursday the ‘Advertiser’ Tennis School squad visited the school and there was a demonstration match between two of the Linton Cup squad: Ian Bidmeade and Michael Kenny.

Advt. Mr F.H. Goodridge has instructed Farmers’ Union to conduct a clearing sale at his property on 26 March. He has sold the property and is leaving the district.

89, 8, 1 March 1966 page 1

Accident. Two utilities driven by Mr L. Polgar and Mr A.W. Menz (both of Burra North) collided on Morehead Street on Monday evening. Mt L. Polgar was admitted to Burra Hospital for treatment.

Burra Auxiliary of the Adelaide Children’s Hospital held its annual meeting and Mrs E.T. Baulderstone was elected President. Mrs A. Benger is the Secretary-Treasurer. A quiz and rag sales etc. raised £58. £70 was sent to the 5AD Good Friday Appeal. The bank account at the close of 1965 held £65-2-3 or $130.22.

Burra & District Choral Society met recently and elected Mr J.P. Oates as President. Miss M. Woollacott is Secretary and Mrs J.P. Oates is pianist. The conductor is Rev. G.D. Sibly.

Burra Camera Club members were very successful at the Mid North Photographic and Art Exhibition held at Clare last Saturday.

Mr H. Shakeshaft received the First Trophy for highest aggregate points in the coloured slides group.

Mr K. Watts received the First Trophy for the highest aggregate points in the black and white prints group.

The Salvation Army will resume activities in Burra with a meeting at the Citadel on 6 March.

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club on Tuesday over double 50 yards, the best were R. Alderson, A. Angel and M. Thomas.

Burra Youth Club will continue to meet in the Salvation Army Citadel each Friday from 7-9 p.m. despite the recent announcement by the Salvation Army that it was to resume activities in Burra. The Youth Club has no connection with the Salvation Army and merely rents the hall from that body.

89, 9, 8 March 1966 page 1

Burra Primary School Welfare Club held its annual meeting recently. Mrs A. Benger submitted the balance sheet. After spending c. $800 for the year, they had $300 and with the voluntary contributions due in this week would have c. $450. Elected were: President, Mrs J. Carpenter (3rd year in office); Vice-Presidents, Mesdames R. Thamm & P. Kirk; Secretary, Mrs C. Brereton and Treasurer, Mrs A. Benger.

Burra & District Floral Art Club held its AGM recently and drew up an interesting program for the year.

Burra National Trust is calling for material for its historical museum in Market Square. The building is one of the early shops with rods for hanging outside shutters. During last year the exterior was renovated and the front room repaired. Historical items concerning the mine and town will be displayed in the front room and later it is hoped to repair the back rooms, making one a typical bedroom and another a typical kitchen of the mining era. Both funds and items are needed. [Photo of building.]

Fire. Morganvale homestead was destroyed by fire on Tuesday last. It is owned by Mr Snell.

Fire. Old Caroona homestead was destroyed by fire on Sunday afternoon, 6 March. Over $4,000 was done. The cause is unknown, but may have been a kerosene refrigerator. The fire was discovered by new employees who were due to occupy the premises, but not until the building was completely burnt out. The manager Mr Ian McWaters was at his new homestead three miles away.

Burra Swimmers went to the SA Youth Clubs Swimming Championships at Unley Olympic Pool on Friday night and returned with five certificates and a medallion. Jull Eberhard won the medallion for the Ladies Under 13 Years Championship.

Mt Bryan defeated Spalding Blue

Hallett forfeited to Kooringa

Spalding White 16 defeated Leighton Gold 4

Aberdeen Blue 15-103 defeated Booborowie 5-56

89, 9, 8 March 1966 page 5

Burra Branch of the National Trust of SA: Letter to the Editor

Burra is a unique town and this is often more apparent to visitors than to the locals. Its history lies not so much in written records as in its buildings and walls, its Cornish cottages and its place names. [A discussion of some of these places then follows.]

The National Trust Branch was formed because a number of people felt that the preservation of Burra’s fascinating past could not much longer be left merely to chance, especially with the possibility of renewed mining and the expansion which could result. Items of historical interest are scattered in homes and sheds and are hidden in places where they could be forgotten. The Trust aims to collect such items and to house them in a proper building where they can be preserved and made available to all our people, visitors and tourists and to our children as a record that can be seen and touched. Other towns in SA with a much smaller role in the history of the state have begun to preserve their past and we are sure the people of Burra and District will also want to preserve their own history.

If there is a symbol of Burra it surely is Johnny Green.

Your donation can help our efforts to do this, whether with money or historical items. The aim is to raise $1,600 to set up the museum.

89, 9, 8 March 1966 page 6

Bowls

Burra Blue 124 defeated Spalding White 85

Saddleworth Blue 112 defeated Burra Gold 86

Burra Green 116 defeated Spalding Blue 93

Burra Library. Report of President, Eunice V. Tiver for 1965.

There were approximately 70 subscribers. There are 27 juvenile subscribers. The annual trading table suffered from bad weather this year, but still raised £37. Thanks go to librarian Mrs Steer and to all members of the committee and to Mr W. Carpenter for various painting jobs. Mr Ben Kotz worked hard raising funds and Mrs Ben Kotz convened the trading table.

Burra Primary School Welfare Club 1965 Report.

There were 55 financial members and an average attendance of over 30.

The year’s opening balance was £114-7-9 and is now £150-15-0.

During the year we purchased sports equipment, library books, towel racks, clocks, equipment for the oval, art materials and teachers’ aids. The school did not go to the Inter-School Sports at Hallett this year, but held its own sports day where more students could participate. On that occasion the Welfare Club raised £57-11-9 at a trading table, a raffle and an afternoon tea. The main drive this year was held in conjunction with BHS School Committee, the High School Council and the Parents & Friends to reach the target of £1,000 for a reference library. In that effort we were successful. At present the room to house the library is being prepared. Fans will be installed in the prefabricated rooms as soon as possible.

Burra Salvation Army held its first Gospel Meeting at the Citadel on Sunday. Captain B. Jasvey was assisted by S. Sullivan and five bandsmen from Peterborough took part. Another meeting will be held on 20 March.

BHS held its Annual Swimming Carnival last Friday. Steele House won the Swimming Cup with Draysey a close second. [Results are printed.]

89, 10, 15 March 1966 page 1

Burra Show Society held its AGM on Friday. Mr M.G. Stockman was re-elected President. He appealed to local sheepbreeders for greater support. G. Stanley Hawker remains the Patron. The Vice-Presidents are Mr Rex Stockman and Mr M.T. Kellock. Applications are called for the position of Secretary, as the previous Secretaries Mr & Mrs Barry Taylor have been transferred from the district. Mr Roy Jeffery was made a Life Member.

Leighton Hall. The committee has decided to spend $300 on repairs to the hall and locals will be contacted through the mail to raise the money.

Burra Pre-School Kindergarten held its AGM on 7 March. Attendance was a disappointing 17, considering that enrolment this year was over 50. Elected: President, Mrs G. Brereton; Vice-President, Mrs B. Stockman; Secretaries, Mesdames Frank Fennell & John Nankivell and Treasurer, Mrs Guy Dollman Jnr. The main object this year will be to complete the building project presently under way.

Mr A.E. Graham the new Town Clerk took up his duties yesterday.

Burra Football Club held its annual meeting and revealed it was in a sound financial position. The General Account stood at $627.26 with $310.35 in the Benevolent Fund and $400 in the Social Fund. Elected: Patron, Reg. Warnes; President, E.C. Pietsch; Vice-President, A. Baulderstone; Secretary, G. Baulderstone and Treasurer, Ray Pietsch. The trainers are W. Corner and M. Anderson, while A. Fillmore will manage the Colts.

BHS held its annual ceremony to induct prefects and house captains last Friday. Over 100 parents and friends attended. Prefects for 1966:

Heather Lucas (Head) Geoffrey Collins (Head)

Angela Ryan (Deputy) Terry Blieschke (Deputy)

Rosemary Field Lindsay Gent

Jenette Kleinig Graeme Nankivell

Heather Riggs Gerald Pans

Annabel Wright Robert Perry

Ironmine Methodist Church will hold its Anniversary Service at 11 a.m. [Date not stated, but the following Sunday is presumed.]

A Shearing Competition is planned for this year’s Burra Show. The timber supply company ‘Lloyds’ has undertaken to provide a timber framework for a truck to act as a stage. (Free) Mr Tony Ryan of the Department of Agriculture will assist in staging the event.

National Trust. The appeal for funds has reached $274.

Willalo Methodist Church will honour district pioneers at a service on 20 March. Newly installed lighting will also be dedicated in their memory by Rev. David Pill. The early lamps have been retained, but converted to electricity. The occasion is also the 38th anniversary of the church, the foundation stone of which was laid by Mrs Hanlin in 1927.

Sevenhill Football Club was granted permission to go into recess for 12 months.

No Inter-Association games are to be played this year, but the Association will play in the Central Districts Zone Carnival.

The Association’s Accident Fund is to be wound up and the money returned to affiliated clubs, who will in future run their own accident funds.

89, 11, 22 March 1966 page 1

Burra RSL. The AGM on Friday night failed for the second time to elect an executive committee. On the first attempt there was not a quorum present. On Friday 12 attended, but there was no response when a call was made for nominations. For the present the old executive will carry on and the Chairman Mr H. Cornelius and other stalwarts are making arrangements for Anzac day. If no more interest is shown the sub-branch may close.

Burra National Trust. The appeal for donations has reached $481.20.

BHS. The Parents & Friends’ Association held its annual meeting on 15 March. Elected: President, Mrs D.H. Field; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames J.L. Riggs & R.F. Lloyd; Secretary, Mrs R.C. Gent; Assistant Secretary, Mrs G.F. Lomman and Treasurer, Mrs P.W. Carpenter.

In the past year there were 57 members and an average attendance of 33.

[The year’s activities are reported.]

This year it is intended to install four fans in the two iron classrooms and $400 is made available fro a dressing shed when needed.

Adelaide Wool Sales were held on 17-17 March. [District prices are printed.]

Obituary. David Bradtke aged 3 drowned in a dam on his parent’s property at Manoora on Saturday night.

89, 11, 22 March 1966 page 2

Advt. Burra Pictures, 26 March

Elizabeth Taylor & Richard Burton in The Sandpiper

Laurel & Hardy in Laughing 20s, (A compilation of their funniest scenes.)

89, 11, 22 March 1966 page 7

‘Dollar Bill’ educational comic strip. Bill is buying 12 oranges for 40 c. and 1 lb of grapes for 25 c.

Kooringa in 1866 from the SA Gazetteer of 1867.

Kooringa is a postal township on the Burra Creek about 50 miles from Kapunda and has daily communication with Adelaide by mail coach to Kapunda and thence by rail to Adelaide. It is situated on very irregular ground, broken by fissures and watercourses. The situation and creek divide the township, which is scattered over a considerable area. There is no corporation or district council, though efforts are being made to obtain the former. It has an Institute, post office, money order office and telegraph station. It is surrounded by a chain of undulating hills in many parts of which copper is found along with promising specimens of silver and lead ore – this in addition to the Burra Burra Mine.

While there are no rivers near Kooringa there are the Burra, Baldina and Gum Creeks – but in summer only waterholes can be relied upon. Kooringa has no mills, but there is a brewery and candle manufacturer. It is principally a mining and pastoral centre with a few sections under wheat cultivation.

On addition to the Burra Burra Mine there are the All Nations Mine, Flinders Mine, Scrubbers Camp Mine, Kingston Mine and Karkulto Mine. The two former are worked by a Melbourne Company who are sanguine of success. Scrubbers Mine is about 28 miles north and a main lode is expected to be struck soon. Kingston Mine is a further 7 miles northeast. Karkulto Mine is owned by the SA Mining Association and is 15 miles southeast of Kooringa. It principally produces iron ore used in smelting copper. The nearest places are:

Redruth, 1 mile northwest

Hampton, 11⁄2 miles northeast

Copperhouse, 2 miles west

Sod Hut, 8 miles along the Adelaide Road.

The nearest townships are Mintaro and Clare, with which there is communication by Rounsevell’s Coach. Though Kooringa has no benevolent asylum, a benevolent association has been active for the relief of the poor. There is a hospital built by the SA Mining Association expressly for the accommodation of their miners, but accessible to the poorer classes on obtaining the permission of the mining authorities.

Hotels in Kooringa are the Burra, Miners’ Arms and the Pig and Whistle.

There is a National Bank branch, a public pound and a Masonic Lodge, Oddfellows’ Lodge and a Foresters Court. The population of Kooringa, Redruth, Aberdeen and Hampton is about 3,100 with about 460 houses, but of these about 120 are uninhabited. A corporation would remedy many of the evils. The approaches to the cemetery are extremely bad and even dangerous. In crossing creeks and water courses the remains of the dead have more than once been precipitated to the ground. The present road between Kooringa and Redruth is extremely bad. The Burra Electoral District is represented in the Legislative Assembly by J.B .Neales and A. McCullock [sic].

89, 11, 22 March 1966 page 8

Burra Show Society

Annual Report of the President, M. Stockman.

Burra show was held on 9 October in ideal fine cool weather. It was very successful with gate takings of £258 – a record for many years. Immediate Past President Mr Rex Warnes, who is also President of the Royal Adelaide Show, opened our show.

Horses in action had a record 548 entries. Mr Roy Jeffrey had the marathon job of judging this section. We must consider having two rings going at once to reduce the time this year.

The number of entries in the sheep section continues to disappoint.

Wool was well represented.

I regret to report the deaths of two valuable supporters: Mr J.R. Field who was a member of the finance committee for a number of years and Mr Roy W. Lloyd who was a head steward and exhibitor for many years.

Thanks also go to Mr Bob Fuss for his ongoing work in altering fixtures and undertaking repairs. He has been doing this for years and we hope will do so for many more.

Thanks also go to our secretaries Mr & Mrs Barry Taylor and the society will be the poorer for their transfer to another district and, of course, thanks go to the Vice-Presidents and the committee.

Burra Town Council, 28 February

The caravan park will be rubbled.

The playground will be sheeted with skimps.

Permission is granted for the Aberdeen Tennis Club to use the tennis courts on Easter Sunday from 1 to 6 p.m.

89, 12, 29 March 1966 page 1

Burra Caravan Park with its facilities on the north side of the swimming pool is expected to be sufficiently advanced to allow its opening over the Easter weekend. Work on the amenities block is advancing with plumbing almost completed and electric wiring installed and ready for connection. Concreting of floors and plastering is under way. Painting may not be completed in time for Easter, but that would not prevent use. The park will be completed for a cost of $6,000 and is eligible for a $3,000 subsidy from the SA Government Tourist Bureau.

Roads Ready for Sealing by next Monday:

School approach roads.

Smelts Road.

The area near L.L. Fiebig’s.

The Burra Hospital has benefited by $56 from a tillage field day at Hanson on the property of S.M. Stockman & Son on 21 March. Hanson CWA ladies supplied luncheon at the hall for 71 people. The day was organised by the Agricultural Bureau. (President Don Stockman & Secretary Ron Shipard.)

Kooringa Tennis Club raised $80 from a barn dance and barbecue at ‘Studholme’ on Saturday night.

St Mary’s. Burra will be the scene of a special Ecumenical Service on Sunday. The Burra Choral Society will provide the music and the sermon will be delivered by the Rector of Clare.

Patrick Brown, the son of Mr & Mrs W. Brown of Burra, has been achieving well in athletics at Rostrevor College Sports Day:

He broke the under 14 100 yards hurdle record

Won the under 14 high jump

Was runner-up in the under 14 Cup.

Bowls

Ben Tucker of Spalding is the singles Champion of Champions.

Clare Red won the rinks final.

The Miss amateur Photographic Quest, part of the Adelaide Festival of Arts International Competition, was won by Miss Janet Mackay, who was sponsored by Burra Camera Club. [Photo.]

89, 12, 29 March 1966 pages 1 & 7

Burra Primary School, Annual Parents’ Meeting

Last year 40 attended. This year was closer to average with just 19, even though 129 families are represented in the school. This is disappointing.

Elected: Chairman, Mr R. Moreland; Secretary-Treasurer, Mr D. Bannister.

In the past year the new school oval was sown and is now in an excellent condition. Goal posts will be erected next week. Sports Day 1965 was held on the War Memorial Oval and was a great success. Arbor Day was held on 13 August when John Riggs was guest speaker. The Passing Out Parade was held on 16 December, when R. Moreland and Mrs Carpenter presented the prizes. Following discussions with ETSA and the Public Buildings Department a new power line has been laid and rewiring of the school is about to commence. This will allow more lights and heaters. Four fans have been purchased for the wooden rooms. All subsidies have now been granted for the library and we can now go ahead with the final setting up of the library. The school is to be repainted at the end of April at a cost of $11,000. A grant of $3,000 from the Highways Department will allow all access roads to be sealed. The grounds in front of the school are in the process of being transferred to the Education Department with the aid of the Town Council.

89, 12, 29 March 1966 page 2

Obituary. A Notice to Creditors reveals the death of Walter James Millard of Thames Street Burra on 20 December 1965. [Born 27 September 1888, Inman Valley. Died in Burra.]

Advt. The Trustees in the Estate of D.N. Morrison deceased have instructed Farmers Union to conduct a property and furniture sale at Allotments 99, 100 & 101 George Street, Mitchell Flat on 8 April. On the property is erected an old stone house of five rooms with one iron room adjoining.

Advt. Now Open. Peter Christoforou Men’s Hairdresser of 25 years experience opposite the Royal Exchange Hotel.

89, 12, 29 March 1966 page 5

Burra RSL President (H. Cornelius) Annual Report

The Anzac Parade and Service were held as usual. Attendance was somewhat marred due to the parade the following day in Adelaide. Rev. G.D. Sibly conducted the service. The Marananga Band led the march and supplied the music for the service. The evening service was held in St Mary’s and was conducted by Revs Sibly and Lind. Rev. Sibly also conducted the Remembrance Day Service on 11 November. David Marshall’s Band from Morgan supplied music for our annual ball. This was successful despite heavy rain with thunder and lightning and a power failure during the preceding cocktail party. Badges were sold for Anzac, Legacy, Myrtle Bank and Poppy Day. On each occasion $40 to $50 was taken. We continue to support two Legacy wards. Two of our members left the town during the year: Herb. Riggs, a WWI digger and W. (Bill) Kotz, A WWII digger. Two diggers died during the period: Les. Hirschausen and Les. James.

[The usual thanks were extended to the committee members, the Ladies’ Auxiliary etc.]

Burra 100 Years Ago. (Continued from last week.)

Redruth or Aberdeen is a small mining township in the Hundred of Kooringa. It adjoins the Burra Mine on the eastern side of Burra Creek. On the western side is a small township called Aberdeen.

[This messy description is in the original.]

The two are united by an excellent stone bridge with one arch and a span of 60 feet.

[This is incorrect: while there were probably stone abutments, the bridge was of timber and by 1879 the decay of the wood caused its replacement with a steel structure.]

The towns are supplies with water from wells about 30 feet deep on the surrounding hills. Redruth is chiefly occupied by miners from the Burra Mine and smelters from the Kooringa Smelting Works. There is a mine, the Bon Accord, not now working, adjoining the Burra Mine, and although large sums have been spent no copper has been found over the Burra Burra Mine boundary, though within a few yards of that boundary some of the richest ore raised ahs been discovered.

Communication with Hampton (1⁄2 mile), Kooringa (1 mile) and Copperhouse (11⁄2 miles) in by rough bush roads and with Adelaide by four-wheeled coach via Kapunda and thence by rail. There is one hospital for miners’ use only, supported by the mine.

Hotels are in Redruth, the Bushman’s Home and the Court House and in Aberdeen, the Smelters’ Home and the White Hart, recently transferred from Copperhouse.

[This ‘transfer’ has no support elsewhere. The archaeological survey when the Ludgvan Street deviation was put in during the late 1980s reported the following points about the White Hart:

Allotments 147 & 148 of Aberdeen were sold September 1849 from Morehead & Young to William Spargo for £20.

Spargo erected a dwelling house and brewery.

13 March 1851 Spargo sold the site to John Magor for £200. The conveyance is dated 16 July 1852. The issue of a liquor license [in 1852] suggests the White Hart was constructed by then.

The report then traces the ownership of the property and of the licence to its demise as a hotel. Mrs Mary Mowatt was the last licensee.

She surrendered the licence in 1892, but apparently left in 1888 to run the Old Lion in North Adelaide.

The owner in 1888 was Mrs Mary Ann Reed who died in 1889 and the property then vested in her son Richard Reed.

An advertisement in the ‘Burra Record’ 18 November 1887 says it is being conducted as a Temperance Hotel, suggesting that Mrs Mowatt had left by then and the hotel licence was no longer active.

References to its operation as a temperance hotel continue through to at least 1894.

The same paper records the destruction of the building by fire 14 March 1916, when it is said to be owned by James Reed and to have then been used as the home of Mrs A. Sara and also in part to have housed the Boy Scouts. James Reed was a son of Richard Reed.

Mrs A. Sara (1859-1931) was the widow of George Sara (1839-1903) and a sister to James Reed.]

There are more hotels in these towns than in Kooringa because there the land is on leasehold from the mining company and the landlord will not allow more than three hotels. In Redruth and Aberdeen they are built on freehold land.

The surrounding country is undulating and hilly. All timber within 20 miles has been cut and used on the mine. Not a tree can be seen within five miles and beyond that only on long purchased property.

Redruth contains a commodious court house, a well-built gaol (the furthest north) capable of accommodating 30 prisoners, and a police station. It also contains a Wesleyan, a German Lutheran and a Primitive Methodist Chapel. There is a private licensed school of nearly 100 scholars.

89, 13, 5 April 1966 page 1

The Mid North Field Days were very successful with a good influx of visitors from across Australia. At Booborowie about 1,100 were served with lunch and at Mt Bryan and Hallett about 800. Collinsville scored two $5,000 ram sales and Rayner & Sons of Hallett sold their stud ram for $4,000. [Others details are printed.]

St Mary’s Church. The ecumenical service on Sunday was attended by more than 150 people. Burra Choral Society led the singing. Rev. Baxter from Clare conducted the service. A highlight was the rendition of Psalm 86 and a motet by the quartet of Miss R. Reed, Mrs D. Cockington and Messrs A. Edwards and Fr Sibly. Fr Sibly played the organ and Rosemary Reed also sang He was Despised from Handel’s Messiah.

89, 13, 5 April 1966 page 6

Rev. Roger Brown, President of the Methodist Conference, met members of the community at Redruth Memorial Hall last Tuesday evening. He spoke on the missionary work and the essence of change sweeping through the Christian Church everywhere. The meeting was also attended by Monsignor Hughes and Mr S. Preiss representing the Catholic Community and Rev. Sibly representing the Anglican Church.

89, 13, 5 April 1966 page 7

Mr Len Dare has killed 50 foxes and 30 eagles to date this year, so the lamb population is larger that it might have been.

Obituary. The retired Burra postmaster Mr O.A. (Ossie) Tattersall collapsed on the Clare Bowling Green on Thursday. He was buried at Burra on Saturday morning. [Oswald Ambrose Tattersall died 31 March 1966 at Clare, residence Burra, aged 65. Birth not on SA Births CD.]

Burra Town Council, 21 March.

The Caravan Park will be ready by Easter.

ETSA is to place a sixth all-night light by the caravan park.

Cr K. Williams’ resignation has been tendered.

He is to be asked the reason for his resignation in view of the responsibilities to ratepayers that were accepted when he took office.

89, 14, 12 April 1966 page 1

Burra Burra DC

The installation of a second-hand crusher should result in improved open surface roads in the district.

The resultant materials are more easily consolidated prior to the application of bitumen. This has been seen in the Burra School approaches and sections of Smelts Road.

The Council investigated the use of a grid-roller, but this left two-inch stones embedded in the surface. Initially the results were good, but subsequent grading saw this larger material ripped from the surface. Trials using a ‘rock-buster’ also proved unsatisfactory. A unit available at Penola proved to be the answer. At Penola it was a fixture, but it has now been made mobile. This second-hand crusher with modifications has been obtained for $7,000. A new crusher of this type would cost $20,000 to$ 24,000. Depending on the size of the stone required it can produce from 200 to 400 yards per day. [The report goes on to give further details of its operation.]

Basketball. North-Eastern Association.

Clare has been admitted with two ‘A’ Grade teams. The line-up this year will therefore be:

Burra 2A B C

Hallett A B C

Mt Bryan B C

Booborowie A B C

Spalding A B C

Terowie B

Clare 2A

Burra Kindergarten

The new building will be opened on Friday 13 May. A Devonshire Afternoon Tea will follow the opening and a trading table will be convened. The new building adjoins the present building and entrances will be constructed between the two. On completion there will be an L-shaped playroom and a washroom with toilets.

North-Eastern Football League will begin its season on three weeks.

89, 14, 12 April 1966 pages 1 & 8

Burra National Trust held its AGM at Burra Town Hall on 5 April. Elected: President, A. Tennant; Vice-President, S.J. Woollacott; Treasurer, Miss Marcia Tiver and Secretary, Miss Mary Woollacott.

The Trust is still collecting items and donations for its Market Square Museum project. The appeal will close on 29 April, with the opening of the museum scheduled for late September.

The President’s Report

The Trust wishes to see Paxton Square preserved and made enquiries about taking over from the Lewis Trust. This revealed that it would be likely to involved long and costly legal proceedings and so further action has been deferred indefinitely. The Trust appreciates the moving of the jinker to its present central site.

Dower’s old shop was purchased by the President for $1,000 and presented to the National Trust Burra Branch free of encumbrances. The title is held by Headquarters, but control of the building and its maintenance rests with the Burra Branch. The cost of repairs has been $1,186. This is much more than anticipated, but involved repairs common to old buildings to most of the guttering and the complete replastering of the front room. A wall was removed to make a good-sized room for display. The three other rooms have not yet had work done on them and in time they will need replastering and new floors due to termite damage. Headquarters loaned $420 for repairs (to be paid back without interest). The appeal for funds so far has realised $895.80 of the $1,600 aimed for.

Some gifts for display have been received for which the Trust is appreciative.

Trust Headquarters feels that the dugouts are in such a poor state of repair that maintenance is beyond the present finances of the branch. Headquarters is also addressing the old Reformatory and is contacting the appropriate authorities to prevent demolition.

89, 14, 12 April 1966 page 2

89, 14, 12 April 1966 page 7

Salvation Army. There was a good attendance at the Easter Meeting conducted by Stan Sullivan assisted by bandsmen from Peterborough. On 24 April the Kent Town Salvation Army Band will be in Burra and an open air meeting will be held in Market Square at 6.15 p.m.

Burra Methodist Men’s Fellowship will have Mr Ray Jennison as its guest speaker on 17 April. He will give an illustrated address on his recent trip to Japan.
