Mixed Rinks were played on Monday and won by Balaklava.

89, 14, 12 April 1966 page 8

North Eastern Table Tennis Association held its AGM in the RSL Room on 29 March. Willalo had won the 1965 ‘A’ Grade shield with Hanson as runners-up. In the ‘B’ Grade Spalding Blue won with Burra Blue as runners-up.

Elected: Patron, W. Warner; President, R. Shipard; Secretaries, A. Cameron & A. Webster.

This year there will be eight teams: Spalding White, Spalding Blue, Burra White, Burra Blue, Hanson, Booborowie, Mt Bryan and Willalo. Matches begin 26 April with the Grand Final on August 30.

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club

[Results of the Prize Shoot are printed in full.]

On Tuesday fired over double 75 yards the best scorers were: R. Alderson, K. Spackman and A. Angel. As usual Ross Gilbert took the marksman’s points.

89, 15, 19 April 1966 page 1

RSL Anzac Day Service

The Kent Town Salvation Army Band will attend on 24 April for this year’s Anzac Service at the Market Square Memorial at 2.45 p.m. The band will afterwards play at the Hospital. The combined evening service will be in the Kooringa Methodist Church. On 6 May the State President of the RSL, Brigadier Eastick, will visit Burra to discuss League matters.

Burra Primary School Sports Day was held last Friday. Takings for the day were a record $177. The House Competition was won by Redruth.

Lisle Pearce has given a piece of cedar to the National Trust. It was originally part of the specimen shelves in the Assayer’s Office at the Burra Mine. The Assayer at the time was Mr Andrew Thomas who came from Scotland with his wife in 1853. Mr Pearce is a grandson of Mr Thomas. He says it is clear the shelves were built before the walls were plastered.

Marriage. 30 April.

Miss Helen Hurley of Clare will marry Trevor Denton of Farrell Flat.

North Eastern Football League. Presidents’ Report for 1965.

Unreadable

Mt Bryan Sunday School Picnic will be held on Saturday 23 April in Mr H. Dunstan’s ‘Mount Paddock’.

National Trust. The appeal now has donations to value of $1,084.90.

Football. A Lightning Carnival will be held at Clare on Anzac Day, beginning at noon. Five leagues will be represented.

The Jubilee of Kooringa Mark Lodge was celebrated on Saturday night. About 160 brethren attended, including a full representation from Adelaide. Sixteen reigning masters attended and 20 lodges were represented.

89, 15, 19 April 1966 page 3

Notice. The 115th Anniversary of the Redruth Methodist Church will be held on 1 May. The guest speaker will be Rev. H. Alvey. He was circuit minister 1924-27. The Mr & Mrs Edward Finch Memorial Organ will be dedicated. On Monday 2 May there will be the anniversary Tea at 6 p.m. and at the public meeting at 7 p.m. Rev. H. Alvey will deliver his historical paper on Burra Methodism, which he presented to the Methodist Historical Society.

89, 16, 26 April 1966 page 1

Burra Burra DC is concerned about the dumping of rubbish over a broad area at the rubbish dumps instead of concentrating it. Neither are people covering material that otherwise blows around.

Aberdeen Football Club Women’s Auxiliary held its AGM on 19 April and reported that £768 had been raised during the year. Elected: President, Mrs S. Scroop; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames I. Hirschausen & R.M. Reed; Secretary, Mrs R. Gill; Assistant Secretary, Mrs J. Wall and Treasurer, Miss C. Reed.

A gala or sports day is planned for this year and a paper drive will be conducted.

The RAA inspection of the Caravan Park in column 1 is unreadable.

Mr Pollnitz, Director of the SA Tourist Bureau has been invited to open the park.

Mr & Mrs E. Carpenter of Burra North attended the RAAF Passing Out Parade at Edinburgh last Wednesday where their only son Bryan had successfully completed his training. On Thursday Bryan left for an interstate air base where he will undergo specialist training for six years.

The Burra Anzac Service was impressive, but not particularly well attended. Thirty-four ex-servicemen took part in the parade led by the Kent Town Salvation Army Band. Rev. M. Lind conducted the service.

Burra War Memorial Oval

Now that the War Memorial Oval Improvement Committee has been disbanded, a management committee will be formed to assist the Council.

Obituary. One of Burra’s most esteemed residents Mr A.B. Riggs (Alf.) died over the weekend aged 86.

[Alfred Benjamin Riggs born 26 March 1881, Mullaby Station: died 24 April 1966 Burra North and so aged 85.]

89, 16, 26 April 1966 pages 1 & 5

Burra Primary School Sports Day.

[Further details are printed.]

89, 16, 26 April 1966 page 3

Bowls. The season closed with presentation night on Saturday. Trophies:

Championship J. Hill

Handicap R. Shipard

Consistency R. Shipard

Championship Pairs R. Harris & J. Topsfield

Night Pairs B. Riggs & T. Emmerson

Mixed Pairs O. Holmes & L. Kellaway

Veterans W. Shipard

On Wednesday the Associates voted to donate $300 to the men’s club.

Associates’ Trophies

Championship Pat Field

Handicap Estelle Mitchell

Consistency Pat Field

Pairs Dorrie Pietsch & Nellie Benger

Frank Goodridge & Family were given a combined church and district farewell at Leighton Hall. Rev. Lind spoke of the family’s service to the community where Mr Goodridge had been the Sunday School Superintendent for a long period. A Ranleigh tray was presented. Mr Colin McDonald spoke on behalf of the district and a series of presentations followed.

Football. The Mid North Association

A meeting at Saddleworth on Friday will decide on the fate of the ‘A2’ grade competition. Farrell Flat has notified that it cannot field a team in this category and will either have to withdraw or amalgamate with Mintaro. This would enable Farrell Flat-Mintaro to field ‘A’, ‘B’ and Colts teams, but would leave only Manoora and Watervale in the ‘A2’ competition.

89, 16, 26 April 1966 page 4

Burra Town Council, 4 April

Mr Pollnitz is to be invited to open the Caravan Park.

The Town Clerk reported the dissolution of the War Memorial Oval Improvement Committee with its assets to revert to the Council.

The RAA representative inspected the Caravan Park and suggested that Council apply for a survey for the erection of signs on the road approaches.

St Joseph’s Convent School held its sports day on Saturday 15 April. [Results are printed.]

89, 16, 26 April 1966 page 6

Loss of Rams

East Bungaree has lost six rams from a property six miles north of Booborowie. Their total value is $420. Police are making enquiries.

The Burra Salvation Army will hold Sunday School in the Citadel each Sunday from 1 May.

89, 16, 26 April 1966 page 7

Marrabel Fox Destruction Committee has destroyed 152 foxes in a series of shoots over four days recently.

89, 16, 26 April 1966 page 8

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club on Tuesday held the final round of the trophy season with a shoot over double 25 yards. Best scorers were W. Corner, J. Bowden and P. Mengersen.

89, 17, 3 May 1966 page 1

Redruth Methodist Church

Last Sunday the Rev. H. Alvey dedicated the new electronic Hammond organ to the memory of the late Edwin and Hilda Finch. He was assisted by Rev. M. Lind. The organ was presented to the church by the sons of the deceased, Norman and Murray Finch. The organist, Mrs J. Oates, brought out the full capabilities of the organ in a first class manner. The occasion was the culmination of the church’s 115th Anniversary celebrations. Rev. Alvey was the guest speaker, having been the circuit minister 1924-27. At the public meeting last night he presented his informative address on Burra – its Mines and Methodism, which he had presented first to the Methodist Historical Society in 1960.

Pensioners’ League Concert

The item in column 1 is unreadable

National Trust Appeal has reached $1,216.90.

Mr & Mrs Jim Riggs were farewelled at a gathering at Farrell Flat Institute on Friday 29 April. They had lived in the district for 16 years. The Chairman of the Institute Mr E.R. Crossing was MC. Presentations were made.

[Various speakers are reported.] The family is leaving for a farming property in the Waikerie District.

Mr A. Benger, manager of the National Bank in Burra, has been appointed relieving manager of the SA Relieving Staff. He will be succeeded here by Mr F. Matthews who comes from the Kapunda branch.

Burra Salvation Army Sunday School was well attended on Sunday and a Gospel Meeting will be held in the Citadel on Sunday 8 May.

Mid Northern Swimming Association held its AGM recently at Clare. Elected: Patron, Dr Chambers of Clare; President, Mr S.E. Gill of Spalding; Chairman, Mr F. Meyer of Clare and Secretary-Treasurer, Mr W. Corner of Burra.

Marriage. Saturday 30 April

Helen Hurley, elder daughter of Mr & Mrs J. Hurley of Broken Hill, married

Trevor B. Denton, younger son of Mr & Mrs J.O. Denton of Farrell Flat. The couple will live at Farrell Flat.

CWA Warnes Group held its 22nd Annual Conference at Auburn on 27 April. 118 members representing all 16 branches attended.

89, 18, 10 May 1966 page 1

Mid North High School Sports were held at Dutton Park, Kapunda, on 3 May.

They were opened by Mr John Freebairn MP.

Burra High School had a comfortable win in the Handicap Shield section. [Results are printed.]

Leighton Tennis Club’s dance on 7 May raised $64 for Burra’s Miss Industry Quest entrant, Miss Lynette Nicholls. Domino’s Band supplied the music.

Weather. General gentle rains in the last week delivered from about 60 points to almost an inch over the agricultural areas. The rain extended to the east, but falls there were more typically between 20 and 40 points.

Burra Basketball Club raised $45 at its Children’s Fancy Dress frolic on Friday night in the Town Hall.

[Results are printed.]

89, 17, 3 May 1966 pages 1 & 7

Burra RSL was visited by State RSL President Mr Eastick on Friday night. Mr Eastick came to answer questions and to see why the Burra Sub-Branch seemed to be in imminent danger of closing down. After discussion a call was made for someone to nominate as President so a committee could be formed, but there was no response. A second call for someone to come forward to try to form a committee also elicited no response.

89, 19, 17 May 1966 page 1

Burra Kindergarten

The newly completed extensions were opened on Friday by Mrs R.B. Pitcher, original President of the Pre Schools Association. The associated Gala Afternoon raised $168. Mrs Pitcher paid tribute to the Burra Branch of the Air Force Association.

Football. The Sa National Football League has gain this year refused affiliation to the Mid North, North-Eastern, Barossa & Light and other associations because they use the services of the SA National Football Umpires’ Association, which is not approved by SANFL.

Accident/Obituary. Mr Max C. Kerslake aged 52, a contractor of Burra, was engaged in transferring drilling equipment from one site to another at the Burra Mine yesterday when the crane fell sideways and he was struck on the head by the falling jib. He died instantly.

[Maxwell Carl Kerslake born 13 May 1914, New Glenelg: died 16 May 1966, Burra.]

Another Theft of Wool

Some 400 lb of wool valued at c. $200 was stolen over the weekend from the property of Mr Perc. Mosey of Robertstown whose land adjoins ‘The Gums’ Station.

Burra National Trust Appeal has reached $1,279.90.

Council Election Results

Burra Town Council

Mayor E.T. Baulderstone re-elected for his 13th consecutive year as Mayo and 21 years on Council

(unopposed)

West Ward Cr Cummins was re-elected unopposed

North Ward Cr Mitchell was re-elected unopposed

East Ward Ordinary vacancy - No nominations

East Ward Extraordinary vacancy due to the ill health and resignation of Cr Williams – No nominations

A supplementary election will be called.

Burra Burra DC

The four retiring Councillors were all re-elected unopposed:

Farrell Flat Ward J.H.J. Stevens

Kooringa Ward G.R. Finch

Mongolata Ward B.A. Riggs

Leighton Ward R.J. White

Burra Camp Site has been the place for a spate of recent thefts. A portable barbecue was stolen on Saturday night and four wheels have been taken in the past month.

Burra Bowling associates held their AGM on 9 May and elected: President, D. Crump; Vice Presidents, B. Kellock & P. Murphy; Secretary, E. Emmerson and Treasurer, L. Neill.

The President reported on a successful year. £150 had been given to the men’s club. This was £50 less than in the previous year due to the Association’s own needs. They had purchased 12 stack-em chairs, a coat and hat rack, new lino and cutlery. They had catered for the Easter Tournament and had run monthly trading tables.

89, 19, 17 May 1966 page 8

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club

At the end of the season top scorers in the handicap competition were: R. Angel, D. Trenery and M. Thomas.

Obituary. The late Maurice Ignatius Williams was the eldest son of Mrs and the late Mr T.M. Williams of ‘Willila’ Carrieton and was born at Quorn. He was educated at Carrieton and Rostrevor College and spent his youth at Cultana via Whyalla and at Carrieton, Mt Bryan East and ‘Baldina Downs’. In latter years he had been an ardent supporter of the Burra Football Club. He was an enthusiastic worker for St Joseph’s Church and Convent. He died aged 56 and is survived by a wife, daughter Pauline, his mother and five brothers and five sisters. A Requiem Mass was held at St Joseph’s on 7 May.

[Born 26 May 1909 Quorn: died 5 May 1966, Burra. Note: incorrectly entered on SA Deaths CD as Maurice Igantius Williams.]

89, 20, 24 May 1966 page 1

Adelaide Wool Sales 18 -19 May. Top district price went to D.G. & S.M. Radford with 731⁄4c for 11 bales AAA M wool. [Other district prices are printed.]

St Andrew’s Anglican Church Ladies’ Guild is arranging a musical luncheon at the Mt Bryan Hall on 31 May.

Burra Hospital. The secretary Mr L.H. Packer advises that the phase II building modifications have now been completed and they are open for inspection. To help with the cost the Board is hoping to receive the use of land suitable for cropping.

Burra Camera Club held an outing last Saturday attended by 34 people. They held a barbecue further along Burra Creel than the Gorge.

Harold Raymond & his Gloombusters are in their final year of touring and will present an excellent Vaudeville Show at Burra on Friday night.

Burra RSL Chairman, Mr H. Cornelius says a meeting called for Wednesday 1 June will be the final attempt to form a committee. Ill health will prevent his continuing and if no committee can be formed the doors of the Burra RSL Sub-branch will close.

89, 20, 24 May 1966 page 2

Advt. SA Farmers’ Union, having sold her property, has instructions from Mrs F.J. McWaters to conduct a furniture sale on her property in Kingston Street on 27 May.

Notice. Poliomyelitis Immunization should be available this month for 1st, 2nd, 3rd & 4th injections for applicants aged 6 months to 55 years. Applications to be made by 25 May for injections at Burra Hospital 10 June.

Notice. Burra Football Picnic at Redbanks Sunday 29 May.

Barbecue, soup, married v. singles football match and married women’s Sheffield.

Notice. Burra Town Council Supplementary Elections for East Ward.

  1. Two-year term due to the effluxion of time.

  2. One-year term due to the resignation of Cr K. Williams.

Nomination date has been changed to 27 May.

George Segal & Tom Courtenay in King Rat

Hugh McDermott & Helen Cherry in Delayed Flight

89, 20, 24 May 1966 page 3

Weather. In the last week Burra received 53 points – 48 of them last Thursday. Rainfall was patchy, with some farms to the west receiving up to 110 points, while neighbours got only 30 or 40.

Obituary. The late A.B. Riggs.

Mr Alf Riggs was born in Burra 26 March 1881 and was engaged in the pastoral industry, while also taking a very active part in civic affairs. After his education at Burra School he took the position of book-keeper with Drew & Crewes before joining his father and brothers on their Murkaby property east of Burra. In 1913 he married Miss Myrtle Fuss of Aberdeen and they lived first at Murkaby before moving to Burra North in 1919 and in 1924 to his later residence on Smelts Road. In 1924 he was also made a JP. He was a Town Councillor for North Ward for several years before becoming Mayor for 1929-30. He was also a member of the Burra Hospital Board and active in the Redruth Methodist Church, being a Circuit Steward. He maintained a keen interest in the pastoral industry and was a member of the Stockowners’ Association of SA. He was made a life member of the Agricultural Bureau and was an active committeeman of the Burra Show Society, and had also held the presidency. He was actively associated with the sheep dog trials when they were held in Burra. Mr Riggs had great interest in Burra Primary and High Schools. He was a member of the Primary School Committee and later of the High School Council, of which he was Chairman for several terms. Riggs House at BHS is named after him, in recognition of his years of service. He was interested in most of the town’s sports, but most particularly in rifle shooting. During WWII he was a member of the Fathers’ Association and secretary of the committee that farewelled servicemen. He was a keen Freemason and was Master of all the Kooringa Lodges as well as treasurer for many years. He was also a keen reader and served on the Committee of the Burra Library, where he was granted Life Membership. He is survived by a widow, two daughters and one son.

[Alfred Benjamin Riggs born 26 March 1881 Mullaby: died 24 April 1866 Burra North.

Daughters, Mavis Jean and Lois and son, Brian Alfred.]

89, 21, 31 May 1966 page 1

Burra Silo

The new grain silo now under construction at Burra North will enable bulk barley to be handled in the coming season. Although this second silo at Burra is intended primarily for wheat, it will accept barley for direct trucking during the coming season. Two grades can be accepted – one in each cell, but this will only be prior to the commencement of the wheat intake or during a break in the wheat harvest. Work has been going on for some time. Pouring of the cells began at 7.30 a.m. yesterday.

The rest of column 1 is unreadable

Once pouring begins it is necessary to continue in 12-hour shifts with 25 men employed on each shift. The large mixer handles half a cubic yard of mix every three minutes. The forming, about four feet high all round the complete shape of the silo, is automatically lifted in a working cycle of three-quarters of an inch every four minutes. About 30 hydraulic jacks are attached to the one inch rods, which continue up through the walls, forming part of the reinforcing. Parallel reinforcing rods are also placed every five inches for the first 50-60 feet and then every three inches, reverting to every five inches near the top. The concrete is tipped from the hopper into a holding bin and is distributed manually around the forming using a wheelbarrow and then consolidated with a vibrator. Given good conditions 15 to 16 feet can be poured in a 12-hour shift.

The contracting party is C.H. Martin Ltd. When completed the silo will hold 111,000 bushels of grain.

Burra Primary School has won an award of $100 from the Savings Bank of SA for ‘thorough and effective instruction in the subject of thrift’. Since it will attract a 100% subsidy, it will enable the purchase of $200 worth of library books.

Accident. Karen Don, the 9-year-old daughter of Mr & Mrs Don, employed at Stud Park, Mt Bryan, was taken to the Children’s Hospital on Saturday after her nightdress caught alight while she was standing near the fire. Her condition is said to be satisfactory.

Burra Library street stall on Friday raised $85.

Burra High School Open Night

Column 1 is unreadable

The conversion of the old laboratory in the main building into a staff room is almost complete.

89, 21, 31 May 1966 page 8

Burra Town Council, 16 May.

The Town Clerk reported attending the funeral of the former Mayor, A.B. Riggs.

A representative of the Botanic Gardens will be invited to visit Burra to advise on ways of beautifying the Burra Creek.

The Council will lay the concrete floor in the new lunch room at the oval.

A message of sympathy will be sent to the widow and family of the late A.B. Riggs.

89, 22, 7 June 1966 page 1

Burra Silos. The pouring of the walls of the new silo was completed on schedule despite wet and cold conditions.

Burra Basketball Club raised $39 at a trading table on Friday.

Eagle Hawks (i.e. Wedge-tailed eagles)

This bird (Uroaetus andax) is unprotected north of 34°30’ south – approximately the latitude of Gawler. Some 160 eagles have been destroyed in the Hallett area in the last few months.

Burra Catholic Ball was held in the Burra Town Hall on Friday night. It was not very well attended and takings were considerably down on the previous year. It is expected to clear $120.

Vietnam Service

Corporal John Henderson, younger son of Mr & Mrs J. Henderson of Burra North, arrived in Sydney on Thursday after twelve months in Vietnam. He intends to spend a portion of his leave with his parents. He has completed seven years’ service with the Regular Army.

Lt Peter Dinham, son of Mr & Mrs Barry Dinham of Booborowie and a member of the Regular Army, leaves this week for Vietnam.

Burra RSL

At a special meeting at the RSL Club rooms last Wednesday a new committee was formed. Mr Wilf Nankivell was elected President. Others elected: Vice-Presidents, B.A. Riggs & C.L. Phillips; Treasurer, R. Wuttke and Secretary, B. Kotz.

Season/Weather. In the past week Burra recorded a further 48 points. Seeding operations in the district are nearing completion.

89, 22, 7 June 1966 page 2

Advt. Elder Smith-GM has instructions from Mr Frederick Loffler to sell his property of four acres, as he is leaving the district. Situated in Ayers Street; allotments 339-344N and Pt 531 & 531 Hundred of Kooringa, with a solid stone house of five main rooms etc. The property is disposed as three paddocks.

89, 23, 14 June 1966 page 1

St Mary’s will hold a special musical afternoon on Sunday 26 June featuring soprano Rosemary Reed, tenor Alan Edwards and organist Geoffrey Sibly.

A collection will be made towards grounds beautification.

Burra & Hallett Police are investigating reports of indiscriminate shooting at the Mt Bryan and Hallett area, involving sheep and water troughs.

Marriage. St Mary’s, Burra, last Sunday

Andrea Christoforu married Nicholas John. A reception for 300 followed in the Burra Town Hall.

This was the first Greek Orthodox wedding in Burra.

89, 23, 14 June 1966 page 7

Burra Town Council, 6 June

Fortnightly garbage collection will come into operation from July 1966 on Fridays.

89, 24, 21 June 1966 page 1

Burra Caravan Park was officially opened on Friday morning by the Director of the SA Government Tourist Bureau Mr P.F. Pollnitz, in fine, but very windy conditions. Mr Pollnitz said the first class facilities would bring added prosperity to the town.

C.P. Mountford, the noted anthropologist, was born in Hallett and educated there until the age of 11. Mr Mountford passed through Burra on Friday on his way to inspect some cave paintings in a remote part of Wilpena Pound. As a colleague of Mr Pollnitz he was present also at the opening of the caravan park. He describes himself as an amateur anthropologist, but has spent forty years in study and practical research. One of his best-known books is entitled Brown Men and Red Sand.

Burra Town Council intends to beautify the Burra Creek area between the Red Bridge and the northern end of the caravan park, by planting additional trees and/or shrubs.

Postal Transfer to Meekatharra

This item is unreadable

Burra EFS demonstrated working operations to students at Burra Primary and High Schools recently.

Adelaide Wool Sales, 14 & 16 June

Local growers were again led by D.G. & S.M. Radford of Canegrass with a price of 713⁄4c per pound for AAA M wool. [Other local district prices are printed.]

Hallett CWA Debutante Ball was held at the Hallett Institute last Friday. Over 400 attended and it was the best such ball for some years. The debutantes were presented to the National President of the CWA Mrs Hallion.

89, 24, 21 June 1966 pages 6 & 7

Football. Mid North Association

A Grade Auburn 16.15 defeated Aberdeen 7.7

Robertstown 16.18 defeated Mintaro 3.7

B Grade Aberdeen 6.7 defeated Watervale 6.3

Manoora 2.12 defeated Robertstown 2.5

Colts Aberdeen 6.7 defeated Auburn 3.3

Robertstown 10.10 defeated Mintaro 3.3

89, 25, 28 June 1966 page 1

Burra & District Ambulance Association has decided to apply to the St John Council for a subsidy on a new ambulance. The present ambulance is considered inadequate. It would be retained as a mobile first aid room as its trade in value is negligible. It has completed c. 25,000 miles. The Association also feels it is time for the erection of a worthy building. A membership drive will also be held.

Aberdeen Basketball Club organised an entertainment at the Burra Town Hall on Friday night with Eddie white’s Band from Adelaide and with TV personality Ernie Sigley as guest artist. 315 people attended. Car troubles delayed Me Sigley’s arrival, but be compensated by performing for the entire evening instead of for a much shorter period. The evening was a success.

Messrs H.L. Cullen & Son will complete 17 years on the Eastern Mail Run when the contract with the PMG expires at the end of the month. They have covered nearly 350,000 miles on the 376 mile trip each week. Added to that is the general carrying of many more thousands of miles. In the earlier days the route was a mere track and occasionally the truck was bogged down to its tray. Despite this there has been only one occasion when the run was not completed in the three day schedule of Friday to Sunday. On that occasion they were not back until the following Thursday. On the 376 mile trip there are only five ramps, but over 100 gates to open and close. Mr Cullen will continue his general carrying business, but from Friday the mail run will be operated by Mr I.T. Allen.

89, 25, 28 June 1966 page 3

Advt. Burra Pictures, 2 July

Audrey Meadows & Robert Morley in Take Her, She’s Mine

Ken Scott & Meny Anders in Police Nurse

89, 25, 28 June 1966 page 4

M & BHA held its AGM on 20 June and elected: President, Mrs Barry Riggs; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames Odgers & McGee; Secretary, Mrs M.A. Tiver; Assistant Secretary, Mrs P. Dignan; Treasurer, Mrs D. Bannister. The guest speaker was Sister Moody who spoke on ‘The Penguin Club’. Secretary, Mrs Jan Tiver, reported on a successful year with a monthly attendance of 30 babies at the clinic. A second-hand clothing mart and street stall had raised $178 and the annual badge day raised $43, while a Devonshire tea afternoon in March raised $78.

89, 25, 28 June 1966 page 7

Mr & Mrs Murray Finch will soon leave the district to take up residence in the South East.

The Old Court House & Police Station at Burra North and the Police Residence in Chapel Street are resplendent with renovations and a new coat of paint.

88, 26, 5 July 1966 page 1 [Note volume number reverts to 88 from 89.]

Burra Rural Youth held a very successful Debutante Ball in the Burra Town Hall on Friday night. Attendance was c. 400. Eight debutantes were presented to Mr Casey MP and Mrs Casey of Peterborough. They were:

Susan Murphy with Michael Scholz

A Grade 27 Hole Championship Mrs E.S. Chapman

B Grade 27 Hole Championship Miss J. Oates

C Grade 18 Hole Championship Mrs John Riggs

A Grade 18 Hole Handicap Mrs E.S. Chapman

B Grade 18 Hole Handicap Mrs N. Finch

C Grade 2nd 9 Holes Handicap Mrs D. Bundey

B Grade 9 Hole Handicap (Afternoon) Mrs A. Wright

C Grade 9 Hole Handicap (Afternoon) Mrs Kirk

Veterans Mrs E.S. Chapman

Teams of Three Event Eudunda No. 1

Aberdeen Football Club Women’s Auxiliary will open an Opportunity Shop next to Topsfield’s Butcher Shop at Burra North.

Mr B.G. Dangerfield, Tree Advisory Officer for the Botanic Gardens, inspected the Burra Creek area from the Red Bridge to the Caravan Park. He has recommended the removal of 25 pines because they are growing too close together and the thinning will allow each to achieve a better shape. Their loss should be compensated by replanting with variations in species at strategic points. He has recommended planting 7 red gums, 9 red ironbarks, 3 SA bluegums. Rather surprisingly he also recommended planting 10 pepper trees to act as screens hiding the ugly rear of buildings and sheds. Three kurrajongs were recommended for shade in the parking area at the swimming pool and four claret ashes for shade in the lawned areas. He also recommended two more weeping willows.

88, 26, 5 July 1966 page 2

Advt. Oats Pty Ltd has instructions from Messrs M.E. & E.A. Finch to sell all their properties known as ‘Pencarrow’ and ‘Bundey and Bright’.

  1. ‘Pencarrow’ of 766 acres freehold, located c. 3 miles north of Burra and comprising sections 169, 46, 45, 58 & 59 in the Hundred of Kooringa with a 10-roomed stone house etc.

  2. Bundey & Bright of 4,067 acres perpetual lease, located c. 25 miles southeast of Burra and comprising sections 54, 55, 56, 59, 213 & 214 in the Hundred of bright and sections 143 & 144 in the Hundred of Bundey.

[Details occupy 2 columns wide x 1 column deep.]

88, 27, 12 July 1966 page 1

Adelaide Wool Sales 5-7 July. Alexandrina Ltd topped the district prices with 721⁄2c per pound.

[Other district prices are printed.]

St Mary’s will hold its second Music Afternoon on Sunday 24 July at 2 p.m. Artists will be: soprano Miss Rosemary Reed, tenor Allan Edwards and organist Geoffrey Sibly. Proceeds will aid the grounds improvement scheme.

Mr A.J. Hill (Joff) began as Assistant District Clerk with the BBDC in 1936 and later became Town Clerk and Chief Administrative Officer of Northcote in Victoria. He was educated at Burra and apart from five years in the RAAF has pursued a career in Municipal Government. After the war Mr Hill resumed work with the BBDC before moving to the position of Treasurer and Accountant with the city of Williamstown in Victoria. After nine years in this capacity he accepted the position of Town Clerk with the Kyabram Borough Council and after eighteen months moved to Northcote as Deputy Town Clerk, a position he has held for the past ten years. While living in Burra, Joff was well known as a keen tennis player and was a popular member of the Kooringa Football Team.

Burra’s National Trust Museum will be opened by the Premier Mr Walsh on 23 September at 2 p.m.

Mr Jack Oates recently bought a four foot reaper for a nominal sum and donated it to the museum. It is in perfect order.

Mrs J. Rooke has given a cart more than 70 years old and an early bridle type three-furrow plough.

Mr Dudley O’Brien acquired and donated a tip dray, originally owned by the Burra Town Council.

Mr Les Warnes donated an old dam-sinking plough constructed by Henderson’s blacksmiths who occupied the site of the present RSL Hall. [In 2014 the site of the Goyder Council Offices.]

Burra Town Council has received a grant for $2,700 towards the $3,400 needed for reconstruction and sealing of Mt Pleasant Road.

Burra Racing Club Inc. will this year hold meetings on Wednesday 14 September and Saturday 22 October.

88, 28, 19 July 1966 page 1

Burra Burra DC, 4 July

Council adopted a new assessment based on that of the State Land Tax Department. A general rate of 8c* in the dollar has been struck.

At the recent elections all retiring councillors were re-elected unopposed:

Farrell Flat Ward J.H.J. Stevens

Leighton Ward R.J. White

Mongolata Ward B.A. Riggs

Kooringa Ward G.R. Finch

G.R. Finch was re-elected Chairman 1966-67, with J.H.J. Stevens as Deputy Chairman.

[*Later in the same report the more realistic rate of 0.8 cents on the dollar is referred to and in 88, 29, 26 July 1966 page 1, the paper printed an apology for the mistake.]

‘Non-Local Music Lover’ writes condemning the district residents for not supporting local talent when it appears in concerts, recitals etc. Such events are never attended by more than 100 and takings are less than $100. It is a pity.

Mr John Phillips, teller at the ANZ Bank in Burra for some months has now been caught in the draft and departed on Thursday last for National Service training at Puckapunyal in Victoria. His replacement is Mr Trevor Phillips from the Port Adelaide Branch.

Burra Youth Club has been given the rent free use of their hall by Burra RSL. The club will therefore meet there in future on Saturday evenings from 7 to 9 p.m. This venue will have more amenities and more hygienic premises.

[Note. The club had been formed in November 1963 and from 26 June 1964 had been meeting in the Salvation Army Citadel. At the time this was not being used by the Salvation Army, but they revived services in Burra from 6 March 1966.]

88, 28, 19 July 1966 page 2

Advt. Tenders are called for painting the interior of the main hall at Leighton.

Advt. Tenders are called for the erection of overhead lights at the Aberdeen Basketball Court.

88, 28, 19 July 1966 page 4

Mr F. Loffler will leave Burra shortly to reside in Esperance WA.

Cpl Peter Teague, son of Sergeant & Mrs W.R. Teague, is at present serving in the Army in Borneo and hopes soon to return to his family in Malaya.

Aberdeen Football & Tennis Clubs will tender a ‘tea’ in the Oddfellows’ Hall on 23 July at 6.30 p.m. to Mr & Mrs Lloyd Turner and Family who have given much to the clubs and are being farewelled.

Advt. Burra Pictures, 23 July

Sidney James & Kenneth Williams in Carry On Cleo

Helen Shapiro & Bobby Vee in Play it Cool

Obituary. A Return Thanks Notice reveals the recent death of Myrtle Morgan James.

[Born Myrtle Lillian Morgan James 13 February 1885 Robertstown: died 8 June 1966 Burra, residence Burra North. Her husband was Walter Burton James 1865-1950 whom she married in 1907.]

88, 29, 26 July 1966 page 1

Burra Town Council, 18 July

The Council declared a general rate of 19.75c in the dollar and a special rate of 12⁄3c in the dollar. Minimum rate payable to be $12.

The proposed works program will concentrate on Burra North roadworks.

Other aspects include extension of street lighting, the Memorial Oval fence, weed spraying, more street names, tree planting and general painting.

The Burra North Playground will receive some attention and the park by Merther Street and the Creek Reserve [from the Red Bridge to the Caravan Park] will both receive some beautification.

Weather.

Sunday’s weather was dominated by gale force winds, but also featured rain, hail and snow. East of the ranges it was dust that accompanied the wind. Early on Sunday night light snow fell in Burra with heavier falls at Booborowie North and Hallett. Light rain fell on Monday and the post office registered 33 points to 9 a.m. At Princess Royal 58 points fell. By Tuesday morning falls of up to one inch were reported from Hanson, Farrell Flat and Koonoona. Mongolata reported 33 points and Baldina 38. Mt Bryan East received 63.

St Mary’s Music Recital on Sunday last was held in icy conditions and only about 35 people braved the weather. [The program is reviewed.] The collection has brought the total to within a few dollars of the $400 target for improving the church’s surroundings.

Burra Bowling Club held its AGM last Thursday week. Elected: Patron, G.H. Dollman; President, C.L. Phillips; Vice-Presidents, M.G. Stockman & C. Dare; Secretary, D.H. Field and Treasurer, B.A. Riggs.

Burra Senior Rural Youth Club held its AGM 18 July. Elected: President, Phillip Lannon; Secretary, Beverley Atkins; Assistant Secretary, Jan Drew and Treasurer, C. Colmer.

88, 30, 2 August 1966 page 1

Weather. Burra received 144 points for the week. This amounts to only 786 points for the year.

Vandals have damaged three fluorescent street lights near the swimming pool in the past week.

A streetlight in Hanson has also been damaged.

Accident. A utility driven by Ian Cameron of Elders-GM left the road at Hanson on Friday evening and struck the railway fencing. Mr Cameron was unhurt, but damage to the vehicle was estimated at c. $200.

Sale. The auction of ‘Pencarrow’ at the RSL Hall on Friday realised $115 per acre. It was bought by Messrs W. Brown & Co. of ‘The Grove’ Burra who also bought the Bundey & Bright property for $8.70 per acre.

Table Tennis. North Eastern Association Tournament. Winners:

Men’s Handicap Singles W. Warner

Men’s Championship Singles R. Bruce

Women’s Championship Singles C. Mitchell

Men’s Championship Singles D. Leske

[Lilian Alexia Moore died 12 July 1966 at Burra, residence Andrews.]

Advt. Burra Pictures, 5 & 6 August

Julie Andrews & Dick Van Dyke in Mary Poppins

Burra Rural Youth – There is a report of a little more than 2 columns on the past year’s activities. Items of note include:

The Burra Show night dance netted $68 for the Show Society.

Christmas Eve and Easter dances were successes both financially and socially.

The Debutante Ball took $342.

Merino Stud Tour.

Seminar on Rural Youth movement at Georgetown.

Inter-club debating.

Miss Industry Quest entrant Lyn Nicholls raised $600 for the Home for Incurables, attracting a $1,200 subsidy.

The Show Hall has been repainted and the lighting improved.

$68 was raised for the Royal Flying Doctor.

[The year’s program is printed.]

88, 30, 2 August 1966 page 8

Obituary. Mrs Gertrude Mabel Gillett died 29 July aged 84.

[Born Gertrude Mabel Wise 24 September 1881 at Hallett: died 28 July 1966 at Burra. Married Walter Bendell Gillett in 1906.]

Marriage. New Lambton NSW 6 August

Faye Cooper of Canberra will marry Terry Opie, son of Mrs N. Lihou of Burra & the late Mr B.V. Opie.

Mr Keith Hicks, formerly a teacher at Burra, has been accepted to work in the Methodist Missionary Field in Northern Australia.

Burra Burra DC, 4 July. (Partly already reported.)

A general rate of 0.8 cents in the dollar was declared with the following differential rates:

10c in the dollar for the townships of Booborowie, Farrell Flat and Mt Bryan and Pt Section 90 Pt Section 75 Mt Bryan East. 5c in the dollar for the Township of Hanson. Minimum rate to be $3.

The Department of Lands advises that the Battery Reserve at Mongolata has been resumed.

88, 31, 9 August 1966 page 1

The Burra Catholic Fete raised $480. [Details in 1 column.]

Johnny Green is to be transferred to a position above the building housing the old jinker.

Mr D.F .Bannister, branch manager in Burra at the Savings Bank of SA, has been transferred to Hindmarsh. From 11 August the new manager in Burra will be Mr W.L. Moore.

The rest of this article is unreadable.

Obituary. Mr John Macke Gebhardt of ‘Mackerode’ Mt Bryan died yesterday morning.

[Born 15 January 1908 at Mackerode: died 8 August 1966 at Mackerode.]

The 1966 Rural Youth Rally for the Northern Areas took place at Crystal Brook over the weekend. 34 Burra members attended. In the competitions the overall winner was Snowtown followed by Jamestown and then Burra. Ten clubs were represented by 150 visitors.

Burra & District Ambulance Association has been granted a subsidy of $1,000 for the purchase of a new ambulance. Headquarters has allowed the old ambulance to be retained as either a second vehicle or a mobile first aid room. A fully equipped new ambulance will require the branch to find $2,000 from its own funds. A site for a new ambulance building has yet to be decided. Until a decision is made Dr L.G. Miller has offered the facilities of his double garage.

88, 31, 9 August 1966 page 2

Gregory peck & Anthony Quinn in Behold a Pale Horse

Dudley Foster & Derek Francis in The Little Ones

88, 31, 9 August 1966 page 3

Obituary. Jillian Pearl Lally, only daughter of Elwyn has died aged 28.

[She was the wife of John Patrick Lally and died 4 August 1966 at Adelaide, residence Farrell Flat.]

Salvation Army. Captain B. Jarvey from Peterborough and 12 teenagers from there with the Salvation Army Band will attend a special meeting in the Burra Citadel at 7 p.m. on Sunday 14 August. There will be an open air meeting in Market Square at 6.15 p.m.

Basketball

A Grade Spalding forfeited to Burra Gold

88, 31, 9 August 1966 page 4

Obituary. W.V. Ford of Mile End writes a tribute to the late Mr William (Bill) Kellaway of Copperhouse, who spent his last years in Adelaide and died on 28 July. For many years he played football for Aberdeen and did not retire from the game until about his fifties. He continued to take an interest in the welfare of the Aberdeen Club and will always be remembered for his cheerful acceptance of whatever came along.

[Born 1 September 1882 Kooringa: died 28 July 1966 Hyde Park.]

88, 31, 9 August 1966 page 8

Jennison’s new property has been greatly improved in the last few days by repainting and rebuilding.

The Court House and Police Station painting has been completed and work has started on repainting Burra High School.

88, 32, 16 August 1966 page 1

Burra & District Ambulance Association has placed an order for a new ambulance. A new Holden panel van will be converted. The cost to the Association will be $1,800, including the $500 cost of conversion.

The Annual Mid Northern District Synod of the Methodist Church has been held at Hallett. It was resolved to dissolve the present Synod and Crystal Brook, Gladstone and Jamestown will now join the Northern District. Red Hill and Port Broughton will join the Yorke Peninsula District and Clare, Spalding, Hallett-Terowie and Burra will go to the Middle District.

While there was general dissatisfaction with the present system of religious instruction in schools, it was decided to continue for the present.

Tributes were paid to Mr Dunhill of Burra who, in September, will have been a local preacher for 75 years – surely a record term.

Mr W.L. Moore [Photo] has taken over a manager of the Savings Bank of SA at Burra following Mr D.F. Bannister’s transfer to Hindmarsh.

An Interdenominational Red Cross Service will be held at St Mary’s on Tuesday 23 August. Mrs Lance Lines will give the address.

Hanson Agricultural Bureau arranged for a soil school at Hanson Hall conducted by Mr Gavin Young, the soils advisor with the Department of Agriculture, stationed at Jamestown. There was a field day on 9 August attended by 30 farmers. The course comprised two field days and six lectures, one night a week for six weeks.

Burra High School. Thirty-seven students will go to Melbourne and then fly to Launceston on 27 August on a school excursion.

Weather. Rain is urgently needed in the pastoral areas.

St Mary’s Anglican Church is to have a special day on Sunday 21 August.

More than a dozen candidates will attend a Confirmation Service presided over by Bishop Donald Redding.

The new historic room, arranged as a memorial to past parish priests, will be opened by Mrs John Jacka, a great-great-granddaughter of the first resident priest, James Pollitt.

A new sanctuary lamp designed by Neville Rohlach of Whyalla and shaped like a miner’s lamp in copper will be dedicated. It is a gift of Mrs Field and her daughters Jennifer, Susan, Lucy and Helen, in memory of Robert Field who died a year ago.

Some of the 24 choir boys from Hillcrest will sing at the service. They will be accommodated at ‘Kookaburra’ by Mr & Mrs F. Reed.

88, 32, 16 August 1966 page 2

Advt. Miracle Smith – Clairvoyant

Burra Institute Tuesday 23 August

Spalding Wednesday 24 August

Jamestown Thursday 25 August

Burra Friday 26 August

Gladstone Saturday 27 August.

88, 32, 16 August 1966 page 6

Mr Don Bannister, manager of the Savings Bank of SA in Burra, was given a farewell by the Primary School Committee before he moved to Hindmarsh, in recognition of his six years as Secretary of the school.

88, 32, 16 August 1966 page 7

Obituary. Mr R.W. (Dick) Harris died at his home on Sunday night aged 70. He had just completed 46 years service on the ‘Barker’ Property at Baldina. He took a keen interest in flowers and was for many years an active helper at the Burra Show. [Richard Walker Harris born 26 December 1895 at Kooringa: died 15 August 1966. He was unmarried.]

Football. Mid North Association.

The Association’s goal-kicking trophy for 1966 goes to Graham Giles of United with 50 goals.

Aberdeen’s top goal kicker was Kevin Lane with 26.

A Grade Mintaro 11.10 defeated Aberdeen 9.11

Riverton 11.16 defeated Auburn 11.2

Robertstown 9.15 defeated United 5.14

B Grade Aberdeen 9.8 defeated Manoora 8.7

Riverton 14.3 defeated Watervale 6.7

United 72 [sic: perhaps 7.2] defeated Robertstown 3.8

Colts Mintaro 8.9 defeated Aberdeen 2.4

Riverton 12.15 defeated Auburn 1.1

Robertstown 5.4 defeated United 3.2

88, 33, 23 August 1966 page 1

Burra Mine

The Minister of Mines Mr S.C. Bevan, in response to a question in Parliament said that exploration work at Burra Mine was continuing. At present there were two percussion drills operating in and around the open cut and a diamond drill south of the open cut. A fourth (diamond) drill is on a site about a mile south and is awaiting a crew to continue. Metallurgical work is also continuing on the problem of extracting the copper from the oxidised leavings.

The Minister also assured the Hon. R.A. Geddes that not only was the company exploring to ascertain whether copper in commercial quantities could be found, but under the terms of the lease the company will be finally treating the proven low grade ore and extracting copper from the mullock that will be left.

Members of the Gem & Mineral Section of the Weapons Research Establishment Institute will hold a field day at the Burra Mine. Extensive notes have been prepared for the group on the history of the area – much of the material from Rev. Harry Alvey now living in Payneham. About 100 people are expected to participate in the inspection of the mine area.

Thefts. For the second time since the start of July articles have been stolen from a station sedan garaged at the Bon Accord Hotel. On Saturday the car was broken into and a new tyre stolen. Early in July the items stolen included a spare wheel and tyre, a car jack, wheel-brace, transistor radio and an umbrella. The vehicle is owned by the licensee Mr F.K. Thurgood.

Booborowie Methodists & Anglicans will hold a joint service at the Anglican Church on Sunday 28 August. Spalding Methodist Circuit Minister Rev. David Pill will read the lesson. The address will be given by Rev. Keith Seaman of the Central Methodist Mission, who will speak on the work of the Christian Television Association.

Miss Margaret Brereton of Mt Bryan won the title of ‘Deb of the Year’ at the Annual RSL Ball held at Yongala last Friday night.

Burra Sewerage Scheme. Mr D. Wilson of the Central Board of health paid a visit to Burra in the week and advised on progress of the communal drainage scheme for sewage in Burra’s main street area. Plans and specifications would be made available to the Town Council within a month, he said.

Burra High School held a successful Ball in Burra Town Hall on Friday 19 August. It was organised by the Parents & Friends’ Association. Door takings exceeded $200. Music was provided by a seven-piece orchestra from the city.

88, 33, 23 August 1966 page 2

Advt. Oates Ltd will conduct a clearance sale at ‘Pencarrow’ Burra on Thursday 15 September, the property having been sold. [Details in 2 columns wide by 3⁄4 column deep.]

Antoinette Harris of Booborowie will marry Peter Morris of Mile End.

Marlene Gallas of Farrell Flat will marry Leslie Broad of Burra.

Obituary. Mrs H. Wilson formerly of Burra died in Adelaide aged 80.

[Born Pauline Emma Stasinowsky at Baldina 21 May 1887: died 19 August 1966 Magill. Married Hugh James Wilson 1910.]

Mr Vic Simpson on Mt Bryan’s mother was 97 on 16 August.

[Eliza Jane Beckwith was born 16 August 1869 at Canowie and married John Simpson in 1886. She died 17 December 1966 at Felixstow.]

88, 33 (2), 30 August 1966 page 1 Check the number!

Football. North Eastern Association

The ‘Mail’ Medal for the best and fairest player was decided at Booborowie on Friday night last. The winner was Barry Eberhard of Burra. The runner-up and winner of the ‘Burra Record’ Trophy was Don Villis of Booborowie.

In the B Grade the winner was R. Sanders of South Clare.

For the Colts the winner was G. Milgate of South Clare.

The Learn to Swim Campaign of the Education Department will take place at the Burra Swimming Pool 9-20 January.

John Martin & Co. of Adelaide has requested paintings or other important works for display at their centenary celebrations. Burra Town Council has agreed to make available at least one of the Burra Mine paintings by S.T. Gill.

Basketball. North Eastern Association. A Grade

First Semi-Final Burra Gold 43 defeated Spalding 27

Second Semi-Final South Clare 38 defeated Burra Blue 21.

Burra North Red Cross street stall raised $39.50.

The W.R.E. Institute Gem & Mineral Group visited Burra on Sunday in a contingent of over 40 cars. They visited the town’s historic sites and fossicked at the Burra Mine. Many visited the Market Square Museum and were most interested in the display of polished malachite and other local ore samples and the S.T. Gill paintings.

Work on the New Young Street Bridge will begin soon. During construction Young Street will be closed to through traffic.

The Burra Town Council has applied to the Department of Agriculture for a subsidy to aid horehound control.

Burra Hospital Board held its AGM on Tuesday. The Chairman R.K. Pearse said the financial position had improved considerably compared with last year. Mrs A.D. Radford and Messrs M.F. Carmody and R.B. Jennison were elected unopposed as ratepayers’ representatives.

[The lengthy report is strong on procedural matters, but conveys little real information.]

Mr & Mrs H.R. Earle of Burra celebrated their Golden Wedding on 6 September.

Obituary. James Thomas Shattock died in Burra Hospital last week aged 74.

[Born 3 September 1891 Jamestown: died 24 August 1966 Burra.]

Obituary. Mrs Ethel M. Murphy of Booborowie died last week in Adelaide aged 83.

[Born Ethel Wall 31 January 1884 at Hampton, Burra: died Ethel Mary Murphy 27 August 1966 Magill, residence Booborowie. She married James Michael Murphy as Ethel Mary Wall in 1908.]

88, 33 (2), 30 August 1966 page 8

St Mary’s Church, Burra, Sunday 21 August

Almost 400 people attended special services. At 10 a.m. a procession entered the church for the dedication of the sanctuary lamp. Among those entering were the designer of the lamp, Neville Rohlach, the Sub-Deacon for the service the Rector Rev. Geoffrey Dean Sibly and the Bishop the Rt Rev. Donald Redding. The lamp had been hung and wired by Messrs B. & M. Beinke and was dedicated by Bishop Redding in memory of John Robert Field.

The lamp was then switched on and will glow all the year except for Good Friday and Holy Saturday.

A service of the Sacrament of Confirmation followed. [Those received into the church are listed.]

The solemn Eucharist followed with almost 200 communicants. After that the Historic Room was opened by Mrs John Jacka of ‘Myola’ Gum Creek. Bishop Redding dedicated the room, which is intended as a memorial to former parish priests of Burra Parish. A plaque above the doorway records main events. Among other historic items are photographs of all the former priests and details of the church buildings and of that proposed for Burra North (but never built).

The church grounds have recently been renovated and the toilets rebuilt.

A luncheon followed.

A hand-woven scarf made by Mr Jack Clemson in Burra Hospital was presented to Bishop Redding. Special thanks were expressed to Dr J.V. Peters who came to play the organ and to the choir of Hillcrest and their choirmaster John Symons and to Mr & Mrs Frank Reed for hosting the choir. In all over 70 people had contributed to making the day a success and a remarkable occasion in St Mary’s history.

88, 34, 6 September 1966 page 1

The Market Square Museum is to be opened by the Premier on 23 September. It is planned that the Premier will be greeted at the entrance to the town by a procession of horse drawn vehicles and vintage cars. It is also expected that ABC television will televise the event.

Burra Races are to be conducted on Wednesday and at the close of nominations 75 horses had been entered.

[Weights were listed on page 6.]

Many Visitors came to Burra over the weekend and they included a busload of Norwood Technical High School boys en route from White Cliffs on a gem hunting trip. They visited the Mine on Monday and the mineral collection at the Museum.

Burra & District Choral Society will reconvene after its winter recess on 15 September.

Burra Youth Club will conduct this year’s ‘Down Every Street Appeal’ for the Crippled Children’s Association of SA.

Mr E.W. Dunhill will celebrate 75 years as a Methodist Local Preacher on Sunday 11 September. He will take the morning services in the Burra Circuit after which a luncheon will be held in the Redruth Memorial Hall. Mr Dunhill began his preaching in the Gumeracha Circuit and has served the church in WA as well as in SA.

Adelaide Wool Sales, 31 August & 1-2 September.

The top district price was achieved by ‘Ashrose’ at 67c. [Other local district prices are printed.]

Laurence Harvey & Claire Bloom in The Wonderful World of the Brothers Grimm.

Advt. Elders-GM under instructions from R.W. Humphrys, who is relinquishing his stud, will auction the property ‘Bonnie Brae’ at Burra RSL Hall on 23 September.

The property of 6621⁄2 acres freehold is situated 14 miles west of Burra and comprises sections 398, 400, 401 and 403 Hundred of Ayers and is subdivided into ten paddocks with a substantial stone house etc.

[Details occupy 3⁄4 column.]

88, 34, 6 September 1966 page 4

Senior Constable R. Heath of Hallett has passed the second grade sergeants’ exam.

F.C. Constable Ken Watts of Burra has passed the third grade sergeants’ exam. Only 29 of more than 200 entrants were successful in that exam.

An Echidna [described in the paper as a porcupine] was seen in Queen and Chapel Streets on Saturday.

88, 35, 12 September 1966 page 1

Burra Races will be held tomorrow with 56 accepted of the 77 nominations for the meeting.

21 bookmakers are registered to bet for the meeting. The track is well grassed and catering will be by the ladies of the Aberdeen Football Club Auxiliary.

The Young Street Bridge. Preparatory work along the creek is in progress. Areas along the bank are being cleared.

Football. Mid North Association: Presentations.

The ‘Mail’ Medal for fairest & most brilliant Lyall Ackland (Auburn)

A.E. Bannear Trophy for leading goal-kicker Graham Giles (United) (50 goals)

Jenner Trophy for best and fairest ‘in that grade’ [?] Barry Dixon (Manoora)

Best & Fairest Colt, Twartz Trophy & SANFU Assoc. Medal Grantley Cullen (Riverton)

S.T. Gill’s paintings of the Burra Mine, owned by the Burra Town Council and on loan to the National Trust Museum, have been valued by officers of the Art Gallery and insured against theft.

The Burra-Adelaide Cycling Classic was held without any publicity last Saturday. A junior Port Adelaide rider [unnamed in the report] won the event.

Mr E.W. Dunhill celebrated his 75 years as a local preacher for the Methodist Church with a service at Redruth Methodist Church last Sunday. He spoke on the subject ‘All Men Seek Thee’. Rev. M.A. Lind on behalf of the Methodist Church of Australasia presented Mr Dunhill with a certificate. The service was followed by a luncheon. His service is a record in Australia and possibly in the world.

Plus This Air Age

Burra Football Club Colts held a dinner at the RSL Club Hall on Saturday 10 September at 6.30 p.m. About 80 colts, parents, officials and supporters attended. Team manager A. Fillmore said the main lack in the team’s activities was parental support. He hoped that for next year a full set of jumpers could be purchased for the junior colts’ team. Trophy Winners:

[Collectors are listed.]

88, 35, 12 September 1966 page 5

88, 35, 12 September 1966 page 6

Burra Town Council & the Hospital Board are concerned at delays in getting Murray water at Burra. The Hospital id particularly concerned because of corrosion problems with piping and plant. The Engineer-in-Chief of the E & WS Department advises that completion of the pipeline was dependent upon the delivery and installation of a pumping plant and it is not anticipated that the scheme will be operational before July 1967.

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club held its AGM last Tuesday night and it was decided to open the season on 27 September. Elected were: Captain-Treasurer, R. Angel; Vice-Captain, M. Thomas; Secretary, J. Bowden and Handicapper, R.J. Kellock.

88, 35, 12 September 1966 page 7

Football. Mid North Association. Premiership Games.

A Grade Riverton 16.8 defeated Robertstown 14.4

B Grade Riverton 11.12 defeated Manoora 8.9

Colts Riverton 8.8 defeated United 4.4

Basketball. North Eastern Association. Preliminary Finals

A Grade Burra Blue 45 defeated Burra Gold 41

B Grade Spalding 26 defeated Booborowie 22

C Grade Spalding 21 defeated Booborowie 9

Burra Oval Improvement is to continue. With the football season over and cricket clubs having made other arrangements, it is intended to completely top dress the playing area. A section of the front wall (on the western side) is to be removed and replaced with cyclone fencing. The material from the wall will be used to form a parking area around part of the western side. Changes will be made to the road around the oval to delete most traffic hazards and make for freer movement, particularly around the dressing and refreshment rooms.

88, 35, 12 September 1966 page 8

Football. Mid North Association. ‘Mail’ Medal voting details are printed.

  1. R.E. Duggan of Victoria.

  2. B.J. Morrison of Victoria.

  3. S. Pittaway of SA.

89, 36, 20 September 1966 page 1 Note reversion to Volu8me number 89!

Market Square Museum

Unforseen circumstances have prevented the Premier from opening the Museum and this will now be done by the Chief Secretary and Minister for Health Mr Shard next Friday at 2 p.m.

Also attending will be the Mayor Mr E.T. Baulderstone and Mrs Baulderstone, Mr Quirke MP, Mr H.C. Morphett immediate past president of the National Trust and Mr J.H.J. Stevens as Acting Chairman of the District Council and Mrs Stevens. Pamphlets giving a brief history of Burra and District have been prepared an in the past few days the museum has been wired for electricity. [Photo of the museum.]

Farrell Flat Tennis Club benefited by $92 from a fashion parade at the local institute on 17 September, showing spring and summer wear from Miller Anderson’s of Clare.

89, 36, 20 September 1966 pages 1 & 8

Burra Race Meeting was held in fine weather last Wednesday and the track and grounds were in fine condition. Fields were small, but there was good racing. It was disappointing that only two of the acceptors started in the Burra Cup, but they fought it out neck and neck. (The three non-starters were scratched to take part at Gawler on Saturday.) Bookmakers turned over c. $50,000. A profit of $300 to $400 is anticipated for the club.

[Details are given on page 8.]

89, 36, 20 September 1966 page 2

Notice. Mrs F. Rosborough advises that she has sold her shop at Mt Bryan to J.A. & P.V. Bird.

Advt. Burra Pictures, 24 September

Dan O’Herlihy & Walter Matthau in Fail Safe

Anita Sands & Ronald Foster in Diary of a High School Bride

Advt. St Mary’s Ladies’ Guild will present a brunch at Burra Town Hall Tuesday 27 September, followed by a screening of Carousel.

89, 36, 20 September 1966 page 3

Fire. Messrs L.B. Rayner & Son of ‘The Bluff’ Hallett suffered a loss of c. $40,000 when 18 prize rams were destroyed by fire while en route to the Perth Show. The rams were to be sent by rail from Port Pirie, but the truck caught fire between Gladstone and Crystal Brook at c. 11 a.m. yesterday. The driver Mr Rob Burgess suffered shock and burns to his hands when he tried to save the rams. Unfortunately those not killed in the fire had subsequently to be destroyed. Damage to the truck was severe.

Burra High School. Burra St John Ambulance visited the school on Thursday and Mr Ron Thamm and Mr Ron Moreland addressed the school assembly on first aid and the local ambulance.

Obituary. Herbert Oswald (Bert) James died suddenly on 10 September. He was the husband of Edith and father of Cecil and Malcolm. [Born 26 August 1897 at Baldina: died 11 September 1966 Nuriootpa, residence Torrensville.]

Basketball. North Eastern Association Grand Final.

A Grade South Clare defeated Burra Blue

B Grade Spalding defeated Leighton

C Grade Burra defeated Spalding

89, 36, 20 September 1966 page 4

Burra High School

Thirty-two students and four teachers undertook a nine-day trip to Tasmania in the recent vacation. They visited Launceston, Hobart, Zeehan, Port Arthur, Rosebery, Queenstown and Ulverstone.

They travelled to Melbourne by coach overnight and then flew to Launceston. The next day they went by coach to Hobart for four days, which included a trip to Port Arthur. They then went to the west coast to visit Queenstown, Zeehan, Rosebery and Savage River.

89, 36, 20 September 1966 page 6

Obituary. Norman R. [Rudolph] Kakoschke of Whyalla died last week aged 39. His parents were Burra residents.

[Born 12 September 1927 Kooringa: died 12 September 1966 Whyalla.]

89, 36, 20 September 1966 page 7

Hallett Flower Show on 6 September was well attended despite the cold and rainy conditions.

Accident. Forty-three sheep were killed or had to be destroyed when a semi-trailer overturned near Mt Bryan last week. The load of 150 sheep and 6 pigs was en route to the abattoirs.

89, 36 (2), 27 September 1966 page 1 CHECK NUMBERING

[This issue is wrongly dated 20 September on page 1 only.]

Spalding-Burra-Morgan Road

The Minister of Roads has advised that funding will be available to upgrade this road.

[The editor summarises the announcement by saying that over the next three years:

$60,000 will be available for use by BBDC

$100,000 is available for the Morgan end of the road and $40,000 for the Spalding end.]

[Check these figures; they don’t seem to make much sense.]

Hallett RSL dinner dance was held last Saturday in the Hallett Institute. 130 people attended. John Kleinig’s Band ‘The Dominos’ provided the dance music.

Accidents

A car was involved in an accident at the Farrell Flat crossing when it failed to take the bend and hit a fence and the warning lights. The driver Mr K.L. Gum was uninjured, but F.J. Leonhardt and D.N. Jones of Burra were transferred to the Burra Hospital in a car driven by Mr T. Vesz. This car in turn left the road and struck a fence at Brown’s Corner. Mr Vesz was slightly injured and so the three injured men were transferred to hospital in a third car.

‘Bonnie Brae’ Sale. In the RSL Hall on 23 September Mr R.W. Humphrys’ ‘Bonnie Brae’ was sold at $100 per acre to R.J. White of Burra.

Burra Cemetery – improvement works

Weeds have been regularly sprayed in the last four years.

Tree suckers have been removed.

Footpaths are due for reconstruction in this financial year.

A new toilet has been installed and a men’s toilet will be added soon.

89, 36 (2), 27 September 1966 pages 1 & 6

The Market Square Museum Opening

Proceedings began with a small procession of horse drawn vehicles and Mr Les Warnes in his Newton Bennet car c. 1910 vintage. Mr Bob Radford drove the governess cart from Princess Royal, Mal Kellock drove a buggy and Mr Arnold Heinrich drove a cart. [Official guests were as listed in last week’s paper.]

Several people spoke before Mr Shard declared the Museum open.

Mr Baulderstone said that for quite a while the old jinker had been parked in a corner of the Wayville Showgrounds and had been returned to Burra through the efforts of the Town Council, to be housed now near the National Trust Museum.

Mr Tennant said that Mr H.C .Morphett, a past president of the National Trust had come to Burra in about 1963 and following his visit a meeting was called to see if a branch could be formed here. The museum was a modest beginning to look after items of past years before they were lost forever. Mr Tennant thanked all those who had donated items. Mr Shard spoke of the National Trust in general and its expanding role in the preservation of the past. Afternoon tea in the Town Hall followed an inspection of the Museum.

89, 36 (2), 27 September 1966 page 3

Advt. Burra Pictures, 1 October

James Garner & Eve Marie Saint in 36 Hours

Harry Guardino & Shirley Eaton in Rhino

89, 36 (2), 27 September 1966 page 5

Adelaide Wool Sales 13-15 September. The top district price of 671⁄4c was achieved by Willogoleche Ltd.

[Other local district prices are printed.]

89, 36 (2), 27 September 1966 page 6

A Penguin Club has been launched in Burra. The movement began 29 years ago in Sydney to train women in the correct use of the English language and to help them in public speaking. The State President of the Penguin Club chaired the meeting and introduced the guest speakers: Mrs Phyllis Ward, Mrs Grant Williams and Mrs Tyler.

Elected were: President, Mrs M .Odgers; Secretary, Mrs J. Murphy and Treasurer, Mrs R. Jennison. Forty-five ladies attended the meeting. Membership is limited to 25 and is already fully subscribed.

Leighton Hall has been repainted and a good deal of repair work done to walls and windows.

89, 36 (2), 27 September 1966 page 7

The Hallett Red Cross Flower Show recently raised $171.

Obituary. Mr H.W. Tiver of Flagstaff died on 25 September aged 87.

[Harold Walter Tiver born 17 February 1880 at Aberdeen.]

Mr Binks-Williams, former manager of Elders in Burra, was in the town yesterday. He is now with their wool department at Port Adelaide.

Among visitors at the opening of the Museum were former residents Mr & Mrs Arthur Harris and Rev. Harry Alvey.

89, 36 (2), 27 September 1966 page 8

Aberdeen Basketball Club held their annual dinner in the Oddfellows’ Hall and c. 50 attended. Trophies were presented:

A Grade Best Player Leonie Ryan

Most Improved Player Kay Boulger

B Grade Best Player Susan Gill

Most Improved Player Raelene Hawke

C Grade Best Player Wendy Spackman

Most Improved Player Sandra Jones

A dance followed the dinner.

89, 39, 4 October 1966 page 1 CHECK NUMBER

Burra Show will be held next Saturday. It will be opened by Mr G. Stanley Hawker.

Murray Water

Mr Quirke MP says Murray Water will be pumped to Burra soon after Christmas. A manually operated pump will be installed before Christmas and will be in action soon after. The planned automatic pump will still be installed, but probably not before July 1967.

The National Trust Museum will be open to the public from 2 p.m. to 4 p.m. Wednesday s and Fridays and on Sundays. Curators are Mr S.J. Woollacott and Mrs A.D .Radford.

Burra CWA Street Stall raised $85 for their ‘Hospital Effort’.

Fire

A fire broke our just before 6 a.m. in the home of Mr & Mrs R. Spackman in Chapel Street. Mr & Mrs Spackman were awakened by the smell of smoke and saw flames coming from the back bedroom where their six-year-old son Peter was sleeping. He escaped with slight burns to his head. Mr Spackman attempted to extinguish the fire with a garden hose while Mrs Spackman was getting four other children out of the house. (Two of the boys were not at home at the time.) The fire brigade saved the front area of the house, which was not insured. Damage is estimated at c. $1,500. The cause of the fire is unknown. Many locals have given donations of clothing etc. and money has been given by the Burra Benevolent Fund and the PMG Distress Fund. Mrs D. Carpenter of Burra North has provided temporary accommodation. The adjoining home of Mr & Mrs W.H .Wahlert was saved, but suffered extensive smoke damage.

Burra Town Council will soon conduct soil tests along the route of the proposed sewerage scheme.

Weather. Patchy rainfall across the district over the weekend produced falls of from 20 to 70 points.

Aberdeen Football Club wind-up dinner was held on Friday night and the usual excellent spread was provided by the Women’s Auxiliary, who also presented a cheque for $120 as the final payment on the recently erected toilet block.

St Mary’s Ladies’ Guild held a successful brunch and film afternoon in Burra Town Hall on 27 September. A trading table was also held. Proceeds were c. $250.

89, 39, 4 October 1966 page 2

Advt. Elders-GM has instructions from Mr E.S. & Mrs E.L. Wilks to conduct a land auction at Burra Institute on Friday 4 November.

  1. ‘Wallinga’ Homestead – 342 acres – Section 68 Hundred of Hallett with a seven-roomed stone house etc.

  2. ‘Wallinga’ Paddocks of 890 acres perpetual lese – Sections 71 & 77 Hundred of Hallett.

  3. ‘Stone Hut’ 507 acres perpetual lease – Sections 74 & 75S Hundred of Hallett.

  4. ‘Kalcootra’ (Lily’s) – 795 acres perpetual lease – Sections 55 & 59 Hundred of Hallett.

  5. Paradise – 1,210 acres perpetual lease & 389 acres freehold – Sections 58M, 58S, 57, 56, 50 & 49 Hundred of Hallett and Sections 105, 137, 108 & 144 Hundred of Mongolata.

  6. ‘Bertieowie’ – 751 acres perpetual lease – Sections 84 & 87 Hundred of Hallett.

  7. ‘Back Paddock’ – 719 acres perpetual lease – Sections 79N, 79S, 76NE, 76SE Hundred of Hallett.

[Details in one column.]

89, 39, 4 October 1966 page 3

Advt. Burra Pictures, 8 October

Frank Sinatra & Dean Martin in Sergeants 3

Craig Hill & Paula Raymond in Flight that Disappeared

Burra Town Council, 26 September

At the oval all the front wall has been dozed down as there was sufficient soil to cover the stones.

Reconstruction of St Dye and Chapel Streets has begun.

The garden area by the bridge in Main Street has been cleared out and in future will be maintained as a lawn.

‘The main Adelaide road has been cleaned so that it can be mowed.’

[The last two sentences would seem to be garbled and presumably they should convey that the garden areas around the bridge in Commercial Street between Ware and Kangaroo Streets have been changed from garden to lawn.]

The Bridge by the Kindergarten [in Queen St] will be started this week.

[Presumably the footbridge on the eastern side?]

As there has been no reply concerning the specimens lent to Thebarton Boys Technical High School, the matter will be referred to the Director of Education.

89, 39, 4 October 1966 page 6

Aberdeen Tennis Club held its AGM recently. The club was in credit $164.

President Robert Reed reported at length.

The season had one A team and two B teams as well as a junior team. The A and junior teams were premiers.

The three courts were top dressed. A cyclone fence was erected and the toilets were painted and the new toilets have been paid off. Lloyd Turner and his family were farewelled in late July, having been stalwart supporters. The Easter Tournament was the highlight of the year and saw record entries and excellent weather. Thanks are extended to I. Hirschausen and to BHS for the use of their courts.

[Details of the President’s Report extend for c. 11⁄2 columns.]

89, 39, 4 October 1966 page 7

Marriage. At Robertstown on 15 October

Miss Hazel Hentschke will marry Mr Rex Stockman.

89, 39, 4 October 1966 page 8

Hallett Red Cross Flower Show 1966. [Results are printed.]

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club. A shoot over double 25 yards saw best results from R. Angel, R. Gilbert & P. Mengersen.

89, 40, 11 October 1966 page 1

Adelaide Wool Sales, 4-6 October. Top district price went to Gum Creek at 663⁄4c.

[Other local district prices are printed.]

Burra Youth Club collected $111 in its ‘Down Every Street Appeal’ for the Crippled Children’s Association.

Burra Primary School

The Director of Education Mr E. Mander-Jones will open the new library at the school and inspect additions to the High School Library on 28 October. This will also be school visiting day.

It is hoped that Mrs Reg. Warnes Sen. will be able to attend and will present a picture of her grandfather Mr James Cater, the first headmaster of the school in 1878.

89, 40, 11 October 1966 pages 1 & 8

The Burra Show was held last Saturday in perfect weather and attracted about 1,900 people. The $545 gate set a new record. [Claims of records need to be taken with a pinch of salt. This was the best gate for many years, but the 1926 gate for example was £276-15-6 or $553 without making any allowance for inflation! Admittedly for a two-day show.]

In most sections entries were up, though there were fewer ring entries.

Mr G. Stanley Hawker opened the show.

The sheep section could do with a lift, though it was stronger than usual.

The Flower Pavilion looked a treat.

The schools deserve to be congratulated for their display.

Grain, fruit and vegetables, cookery and needlework all received strong support.

Sideshows this year lacked variety and those present complained of a lack of business.

Burra Rural Youth and the Burra Youth Club had creditable displays.

Industrial displays were about average.

[The speeches by President M.G. Stockman and Mr G. Stanley Hawker are printed.]

89, 40, 11 October 1966 page 3

Gerard Barray & Gina Canale in Clash of Steel

Steve McQueen & Leo Remick in Baby the Rain Must Fall

89, 40, 11 October 1966 page 4

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club. On Tuesday they fired over double 50 yards and best scorers were R. Gilbert, P. Mengersen & R. Angel.

Burra Primary School

Grade VI students visited Mt Bryan (courtesy of Mr Keith Gare) and spent an afternoon climbing the mountain of over 3,000 ft. Grades V & VI visited the National Trust Museum. Check the highlighted numbers.

89, 40, 11 October 1966 page 5

Aberdeen Football Dinner

Mr R.M. Reed said that this year two things had stood out:

  1. The amalgamation of the A1 and A2 teams.

  2. The match versus North Eastern.

The Aberdeen Colts had done well.

The Aberdeen Club has meant that there are now six teams in the town whereas six years ago there were only two and it was hard for a lad to get a game.

Mr B.L. Hirschausen said the club’s defeats were due to a lack of training. This should improve next year when the club hopes to erect lights on the oval and so have one big training night per week.

89, 40, 11 October 1966 page 6

Burra Golf Club held its AGM 4 October

Elected: President, M. Stockman; Vice-Presidents, J. Gordon & R. Mason; Secretary, L. Braendler & Treasurer, H. Shakeshaft.

89, 40, 11 October 1966 page 7

Obituary. Mr T.H. Woollacott died in Adelaide on 5 October aged 85. He was mayor of Burra for many years in the period of the Great Depression and WWII. For his outstanding service in those hard times he was awarded an MBE. He is survived by two sons and a daughter. His wife and three sons predeceased him by many years.

[Thomas Henry Woollacott born 1 October 1882 Nelson, Burra: died 5 October 1966 North Adelaide.]

89, 41, 18 October 1966 page 1

Burra Racing Club will conduct a meeting on Saturday when five events will be run.

89, 42, 25 October 1966 page 1

Burra Racing Club’s meeting on Saturday proved enjoyable, though the crowd was small. Racing was good for all but the first event.

89, 42, 25 October 1966 page 3

Advt. Burra Pictures, 29 October

Terry Thomas & Eric Sykes in Kill or Cure

Connie Francis & Jim Hutton in Looking for Love

The Burra Methodist Circuit held a local church conference last Sunday at Kooringa Church. Those attending have declared it a decided success. The possibility of merging the two Sunday schools from next February was discussed. Changes to the form of evening service were considered and so was the purchase of a bus to transport adherents and students to the Sunday school.

89, 42, 25 October 1966 page 4

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club. A shoot over double 100 yards resulted in best scored from P. Mengersen, A. Angel and K. Spackman.

89, 42, 25 October 1966 page 5

Legislative Council

The death of the Hon. C.C. Dudley Octoman has caused a by-election for the Northern District next Saturday 29 October. [In the advertising article for the Liberal Party a neat constitutional history is given of the Legislative Council over the preceding century or so.]

1836-42 The control of the colony was largely in the hands of the Governor with the Board of Colonization Commissioners in control of emigration and revenues from the sale of land.

1842 SA became a Crown Colony with the Governor controlling the administration, aided by a seven-man nominated Council.

1851 The Council was changed to 16 elected members and 8 nominated members.

1857 Responsible Government was granted with a bicameral system using the secret ballot for the first time. From 1857 to 1882 the Legislative Council comprised 18 members elected on a property qualification and returned by the whole province.

1882-1902 The 24 members were returned from 4 districts.

1902 The Legislative Council was reduced to 18 members.

1915-1966 The Legislative Council comprised 20 members. The state was divided into three Country and two Metropolitan Districts, each returning four members. (Northern, Midland, Southern Districts in the Country and Central No. 1 and Central No. 2 for the city.)

The Northern District is vast, stretching from Renmark to Port Lincoln and to the Northern Territory border and from the western to the eastern borders. It covers nine House of Assembly electorates.

The four members are elected for six year terms, with half retiring usually every three years.

Membership is restricted to:

British subject for at least 30 years and resident in SA for 3 years.

Voters must be either owners of a freehold estate of clear value $100, leaseholders of an estate of clear annual value of $40 on a lease for at least three years or with right of purchase.

Or be a registered proprietor of a Crown Lease on which improvements value at least $100.

Or be an inhabitant occupying a dwelling house. (i.e. anyone paying rent.)

Or be a returned serviceman or woman.

Be aged at least 21 years (unless entitled under the serviceman or woman provision.)

Voting is not compulsory.

Had Mr Playford been returned at the last election the vote would have been extended to spouses of those entitled to vote.

[The article is inserted by the Liberal Party and authorised by P.H .Quirke MP and ends by urging a vote for Arthur Whyte, the Liberal Candidate.]

89, 42, 25 October 1966 page 6

Tennis

A Grade Aberdeen 10-79 defeated Mt Bryan 10-74

Spalding forfeited to Kooringa

Mr Dunhill turned 92 on Wednesday.

Obituary. Mr William A.T. Lomman died 17 October at Burra Hospital aged 83.

[Birth registered as William Arthur Thomas Loman 19 March 1883, Paradise, SA: died as William Arthur Thomas Lomman Burra 17 October 1966, Burra.]

Dalgety & NZ Loan, Burra has taken over the old Elder Smith Building and it is looking very smart under a new coat of paint. The building has accommodation for its staff as living quarters on the upper floor, which will aid Dalgety’s single men who find it hard to get rooms in the town.

Patron, Mrs A.L. Collins; President, Mrs T.A. Padbury; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames M. Nicholls & R. Wuttke; Captain, Mrs D.H. Field; Vice-Captain, Mrs N. Finch; Treasurer, Mrs H. Crump; Secretary, Mrs E. Jeffery and Assistant Secretary, Miss Judy Oates.
