89, 42, 25 October 1966 page 8

Burra Town Council, 11 October

The swimming pool will be ready for the last week in October.

Murray Water will be available in Burra after Christmas says Mr Quirke MP.

The National Trust was given permission to send the original copy of [the plan of] Morphett’s Shaft to the Archives for preservation.

The Methodist Tennis Club is to be advised that the Town Council is the sole owner of the shed on Corporation land opposite the High School and that the club can lease it for 12 months at a peppercorn rent.

Twenty-five RAA direction signs have been ordered.

89, 43, 1 November 1966 pages 1 & 6

Burra Primary School & Burra High School

The school libraries were opened by the Director of Education Mr E. Mander-Jones last Friday. Among the official party were the Mayor Mr E.T. Baulderstone; the Chairman of the Burra Burra DC Mr G.R. Finch and the District School Inspector Mr E. Gann. [A complete list is printed.]

A summary of a speech by Mr Auhl is printed.

More extensively there is a report of the speech by Mr Darrell Field, Chairman of the Appeal Program, who outlined the appeal process.

Mr Mander-Jones’ speech appears to be printed in full.

Mrs Reg. Warnes then presented a photo of her grandfather Mr Cater, the first headmaster of the school in 1878.

After inspecting the Library and classrooms of both schools the Director was entertained at luncheon in the Commercial Hotel before going on to inspect the Farrell Flat School.

Cricket. Mokota Association

North Booborowie 6 for 165 defeated Burra Footballers 130

Hallett 145 defeated Leighton 117

Spalding 5 for 17 [sic] defeated Koonaburra 152. [Clearly an error, but the runs cited only total 153 so the truth is not easily discernible.]

Hallett 145 defeated Leighton 117.

Obituary. May Elizabeth Murray died 30 October at Burra Hospital aged 81. She was the wife of Donald James Murray and the mother of Irene (deceased) and Madge. She is survived by 7 grandchildren and 12 great-grandchildren.

[Born Mary Elizabeth Morris 24 July 1884 Adelaide. Died as May Elizabeth Murray 30 October 1966 Burra, residence Burra North. Married in 1907 and had children as Mary Elizabeth.]

89, 43, 1 November 1966 page 6

Mr Roy Pollard of Tanunda paid Burra a visit recently. He was here with the National Bank in the 1920s.

Constable Ken Watts will be transferred as Officer in Charge of Beachport Station on 17 November. Constable Muldoon will come here from Port Pirie to replace him.

89, 44, 8 November 1966 page 1

Accident. A sedan driven by Brian Kakoschke of Burra North overturned about 3⁄4 mile south of Hallett at about 4.15 p.m. on Saturday. The driver and passengers, Trevor Menze and Ian Jones, also of Burra North, all escaped with minor injuries, but the vehicle was extensively damaged.

Burra Primary School

The visit of the Director of Education on 28 October marks the completion of a complete overhaul of the Library following a public appeal. Books to the value of $2,000 have been added, new furniture has been supplied, the room has been painted and new curtains were supplied by the Parents & Friends’ Association. Proper cataloguing of books has been undertaken. After the opening ceremony the Director visited the other rooms in the school and also addressed the High School students briefly. [His speech is printed.]

St John Ambulance is to undertake a state-wide campaign to raise funds for a building campaign. The aim is to place everyone in the settled areas within 30 minutes of an ambulance. Burra’s new ambulance is expected to arrive this month. In 1962 $208,000 was raised. The target this time is for $200,000. The Government will offer a dollar for dollar subsidy.

89, 44, 8 November 1966 page 3

Notice. A memorial plaque to Sir Hubert Wilkins will be unveiled at the Hallett Institute on 29 November at 2.30 p.m.

Notice. The Burra Choral Society will hold a concert at Farrell Flat Institute 19 November.

Marriage. Sacred Heart College chapel on Wednesday 9 November

John Gabriel Quinn of ‘Coolangatta’ Mt Bryan, only son of Mr & Mrs John L. Quinn.

89, 44, 8 November 1966 page 4

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club fired over double 25 yards and the best scorers were A. Angel, K. Spackman & J. Bowden.

89, 44, 8 November 1966 page 5

Burra Cup Committee held a Melbourne Cup Party again this year to raise funds for Burra Hospital. It was held this year at ‘The Pines’ courtesy of Mr & Mrs Keith Gare and raised $331 for the Hospital.

89, 44, 8 November 1966 page 6

Straying Stock remains a problem both in the township and the district. On Saturday evening a vehicle driven by Mr Harold Moxham of Burra North struck two sheep and a lamb about a mile beyond the ‘Baldina’ turn-off on the Eastern Road. Two of the sheep were killed and the other had to be destroyed later.

Leon Wayne Hawke was charged with two counts of breaking and larceny and committed for trial on Wednesday.

Mr & Mrs Roy Humphrys were given a farewell at Leighton Hall on Sunday 30 October. They are leaving to live in Burra.

Accident. A Victorian car collided with an electricity pole at Cobb & Co.’s Corner. The left side of the vehicle was severely crushed and the car was a write-off. The pole was flattened, but fortunately the wired were not brought right down. The driver escaped injury.

89, 45, 15 November 1966 page 1

The Remembrance Day Service at Burra was conducted by Rev. M.A. Lind. About 20 ex-servicemen attended and also Grades V, VI, VII and the First 7 Second Year students from the High School. [Details in 3⁄4 column.]

The Broken Hill Road will be sealed by the end of 1968. Eight level crossings will be cut out and all bridges except one have already been widened. [The article goes on to urge the promotion of the route from Broken Hill to Adelaide via Burra & Riverton over the one via Clare.]

Burra’s Festival of Carols will be held at the Swimming Pool on Sunday 18 December.

Mr C.R. Kelly, Member for Wakefield, is meeting constituents at local post offices in November. He will be in Burra at 3 p.m. on 16 November.

Burra Pictures

The Secretary of the Burra Pictures Committee Mr A.R. Graham reports on a severe decline in attendance. The operation has been making a loss for the past twelve months except for a few nights. The cost of running is c. $40 a show, but on some nights receipts have been as low as $16 and on a number of nights in the range $20-$25. In eleven weeks since 5 September the average attendance has been 64, including children, with a low of 31 and a high of 109. The secretary seeks any suggestions, as he would like to see the pictures continue, but this cannot be done with continued losses.

St Stephen’s Catholic Church at Saddleworth was officially re-opened on Sunday after extensive renovations. Special guests included His Grace Archbishop Gleeson, the Premier Mr Frank Walsh MP, Messrs J.S. Freebairn MP and P.H. Quirke MP. The service was conducted by Rev. Fr K. Hay.

Ken Watts & Family will leave on Thursday for Beachport where Ken will be Officer-in-Charge of the Police Station.

Jim Kelly has done a fine job on smartening up the ‘new’ Dalgety NZL building in Market Square with a new paint job.

Mr & Mrs Sam Sara left Burra yesterday to make their home in Mile End in the City.

Murray Water will soon be here. I noticed the little pump shed just the Burra side of Hanson the other day.

Birth. To Jeanette & Jim Sullivan at Burra Hospital on 14 November, a daughter.

89, 46, 22 November 1966 page 1

Burra CWA, the first branch in SA, has celebrated its 40th birthday, having been established by the late Mrs I.J. Warnes in 1926.

The CWA now has some 13,000 members.

At the Burra celebrations on Friday seven of the foundation members were present when Mrs E.T. Baulderstone was host to a largely attended birthday party in the RSL Hall. This meeting was also the branch’s ‘National Day’ meeting, with Mexico as the subject for 1966.

[A photo in the paper of 29 November 1966 shows the seven foundation members, left to right: Mrs Steer, Mrs Marks, Mrs Warnes, Mrs Marchant, Mrs Sandland, Mrs Hogan and Mrs Jettner.]

Past Presidents present included Mesdames Jennison, Pietsch, Riggs and Warnes.

Among guests was Mrs Zerbe, State President.

Mrs Badman, Divisional President gave a brief address ‘Coins for Friendship’.

Mrs Zerbe spoke on dress fashion in the 1920s and since. A cake with forty candles was cut.

Accident

This report at the bottom of page 1 column 1 is unreadable.

Rev. Ian George will be special preacher at St Mary’s next Sunday.

Accident. A semi-trailer driven by Mr Les Robinson overturned at Hanson at the Farrell Flat Road junction in the early hours of Friday morning, while bound for Broken Hill. The vehicle continued into the yard of one of the railway cottages, struck a heap of rubbish and overturned onto the rear of the building. The driver was unhurt and damage to the building was slight.

89, 46, 22 November 1966 pages 1 & 4

National Trust – Burra Branch held its 3rd AGM on Tuesday in the CWA Rooms.

Elected: President, Mr S.J .Woollacott; Vice-President, Mr I.L. Auhl; Secretary, Miss M.S. Woollacott; Treasurer, Mrs C. O’Connor. A minute of appreciation was recorded for retiring President Mr A. Tennant.

The President’s Report is printed on page 4. Highlights:

An appeal was launched for funds to repair the building purchased as a museum and of a target of $1,600 a sum of $1,261 was collected.

Headquarters loaned $420 to enable repairs to be completed.

The front room has been thoroughly renovated and the outside has seen new guttering, roof repairs, paving in the verandah, and has been repainted.

A committee was set up to sort donated exhibits.

In 3 to 4 months articles were sorted, labelled and arranged.

The Museum was opened by the Chief Secretary the Hon. A.J. Shard when the Premier was unable to come at the last minute.

[Details are given in c. 1 column.]

The Jamestown Choral Society conducted by Graham Krieg presented Handel’s Messiah at St Mary’s on Sunday night. Over 400 people attended. [Soloists as noted 89, 43, 1 November 1966 page 1. The performance is reviewed in c. 3⁄4 column.]

89, 47, 29 November 1966 page 1

Redruth Methodist Ladies’ Guild held a Gala Fair at the Redruth Memorial Hall last Saturday. There were decorated bikes and trikes and a doll competition, musical items, stalls, slot cars and electric trains. [Results of competitions are printed.] The Christmas Bowl Appeal will benefit by c. $340.

Burra Traders will sponsor Christmas activities as usual and there will be late trading on Friday 23 December to 9.00 p.m. Father Christmas will arrive at 9.10 p.m. On Saturday 24th December shops will trade till 11.30 a.m.

Dalgety NZ Loan Ltd will move into their new premises in Market Square [formerly Elder’s Building] and will be open for business there on Friday 25 November. [Check tenses in this.]

St Mary’s will have a special Advent Service on Sunday night with a special quartet comprising Rosemary Reed, Jan Cockington, Alan Edwards and Geoffrey Sibly.

Accident. A utility overturned on the Burra side of Brewery Hill on Sunday, but the driver Frank Baigent and passengers Dianne Menz and Ray Swinson all escaped injury.

The St John Appeal stands at $752.

Earthquake

A tremor shook the district at 6.15 a.m. on Thursday morning for 8-10 seconds. No damage has been reported.

Adelaide Wool Sales 22-24 November

Top local district price went to F.H. Reed & Co. of Kookaburra with 63.5c.

89, 47, 29 November 1966 page 6

Mr Bryan Tennis Players are disappointed that no one from any club in the Burra Association came to their American Tournament, although they patronise other clubs’ tournaments. Thirty-four Mt Bryan players competed with two from the Cavandale Association and two from Georgetown. The trading table did well and in all club funds will benefit by $70.

Burra North Red Cross Christmas Social will be held on 7 December in Redruth Memorial Hall. Northern Regional President Mrs Harding will present 20-year long service medals to Mesdames Schwier, L. White, R. Kelly and I. Hirschausen.

Basketball

Burra Comets 44 defeated Spalding Polka Dots 42

Spalding Blue 45 defeated Aberdeen 2

89, 47, 29 November 1966 page 7

Margaret Loutit, daughter of Mr & Mrs Roy Jeffery of Burra has obtained a PhD for research in Microbiology at the University of Otago in New Zealand. Her early education was at Burra School followed by MLC, where she gained scholarships for Intermediate, Leaving and Leaving Honours years and in her final year was Head Prefect of the Boarding House and Dux of the College. She won a scholarship to the University Adelaide and was awarded the John Bagot Scholarship in her first year. She obtained a Master of Science Degree at the University of Adelaide before marrying Dr John Loutit.

Birth. To Helen & Keith Cockrum of Mt Bryan on 25 November, a daughter.

Obituary. Mrs Guy Dollman Sen. died last Tuesday after a long illness.

[Born Doris May Bryant 22 May 1896 Davenport, SA: died 22 November 1966 Kingswood, residence Burra. Married Guy Herbert Dollman 1920.]

Obituary. Clara Bartholomaeus died in Adelaide last week.

[Clara Wilhelmina Bartholomaeus born 10 June 1892 Aberdeen: died 24 November 1966 Leabrook.]

Rev. G. Sibly Rector of St Mary’s preached at the Church of St Richard of Chichester at Lockleys last Sunday on the occasion of the dedication of a new pipe organ by the Bishop of Adelaide Dr T.T. Reed.

Tennis

A Grade Aberdeen 18-116 defeated Mt Bryan 2-57

Spalding White 15-103 defeated Leighton Black 5-61

Leighton Gold 12 defeated Hallett 8

Juniors Spalding white 7-59 defeated Leighton 5-44

89, 48, 6 December 1966 page 1

Weather

November was very dry and farmers were preparing to harvest grain following several centuries. The eastern pastoral areas have been in drought. It began to rain on Wednesday and continued through the week with falls of from 3 to 5 inches.

Until Saturday night the rain had been fairly light, but constant with only a few heavy showers. Thundery conditions on Saturday and Sunday brought much heavier falls and run-off resulting in some washaways and damage to fencing. Some water catchments to the east were replenished, but not to the same extend as in the inside country. Most wheat seems to be standing the wet quite well with only a few reports of ‘shooting’.

Some barley and oats crops have been badly affected. Considerable sheep losses have been reported due to the sudden change in temperatures and crowding in the corners of paddocks, leading to smothering. Losses of up to 300 and perhaps more have been mentioned. Overall these have been the best pastoral rains for years.

During the week Booborowie reported 343 points, Hallett 362, Mt Bryan 451, Burra 384, World’s End 327 and Mt Bryan East 431. To the east Balah got 212, Braemar 379, Woolgangi 309, Redcliffe 500, Koomooloo 290, Pine Valley, 358, Old Koomooloo 300, Glenora 359, Thistlebeds 448, Baldina 480 and Mallett 400.

Burra Swimming Pool has had some minor repairs and will be ready to open again in a day or two. It is to be open every night when practicable in the swimming season.

Burra Primary School has announced that through the generosity of Mr Andrew Tennant an annual prize will be awarded in perpetuity to the Dux of the school each year. A sum has been invested to yield approximately $20 p.a. The award will go to the student with best results in the Progress Certificate Examination.

Burra Town Council will sponsor trial runs of salvaging paper waste through the town. A suggestion has been made that any income so derived should go towards replacing the badly worn floor in the Town Hall.

The St John Appeal has reached $928.

Twenty Persons were fined in the Burra Police Court on Wednesday for failure to have a licence as required under the Broadcasting and Television Licensing Act.

A Plaque to Commemorate Sir Hubert Wilkins was unveiled at the Hallett Institute on Tuesday by Sir Lyell McEwin. Mr Ian Auhl was the guest speaker and he outlined the adventures and achievements of Sir Hubert. [Further details in a 1 column report.]

A meeting on 18 December at 11 a.m. will be led by Captain J. Jarcey of Peterborough with the Salvation Army Band. The band will play carols in the street on Sunday afternoon.

Tennis

Most games were washed out.

C Grade Spalding Blue 11-71 defeated Leighton 1-33

Spalding White 8-63 defeated Kooringa 4-33

Burra RSL held its annual dinner at the clubrooms on Saturday night. This coincided with the opening of the sub-branch 20 years ago. [This is not a reference to the opening of the sub-branch, but to the opening of the new club rooms in what had originally been the SAFU store. The sub-branch was actually formed on 10 August 1918 and before 1946 the clubrooms (from 1919) were located in the Eastern Telephone Syndicate Building on the south side of Commercial Street.]

About 60 members and visitors attended.

89, 48, 6 December 1966 page 7

Advent Carols at St Mary’s last Sunday drew a congregation of 28.

[The writer is clearly disappointed that a group of locals had attracted so few – especially when the turn-out for Messiah had been so large.]

Burra High School. The headmaster Mr Farrow in conjunction with Rev. M.A. Lind and Rev. G.D. Sibly has arranged for a Valedictory Service to be held in St Mary’s next Sunday night at 7 p.m. The preacher will be the Rector of Clare Rev. Alan Baxter, former Director of Religious Education in the Diocese of Adelaide.

Obituary. William David Work, formerly of Booborowie died 2 December aged 78.

[Born 26 November 1888 at Georgetown: died 2 December 1966 at Malvern.]

Mrs Mavis Satchell and her sister Miss Joan Fairchild were spotted in Burra on Sunday.

The Catholic Parish of Burra held a Family Dinner in Redruth Memorial Hall. About 100 attended. During the dinner c. 70 children were entertained in the St Joseph’s School Hall with a film show of cartoons and comedy films.

89, 49, 13 December 1966 page 1

Burra Primary School

The winner of the Andrew Tennant Award for Dux of the School for 1966 was Ann Brak, the eldest daughter of Mr & Mrs J. Brak of Burra North. She obtained 961 out of a possible 1,000. The Brak family migrated from Holland about 14 years ago and Ann has attended school at Burra since Grade I. [Top positions in other classes are listed.]

The New Burra & District Ambulance was handed over on Thursday and will be temporarily garaged at the residence of Dr L.G. Miller.

Burra North Red Cross Branch entertained the elderly womenfolk of Burra North at their Christmas ‘break-up’ on Wednesday 7 December.

Shooting of Cattle. It has been reported that a number of cattle have been shot along the stock road between Burra and Florieton. Police are investigating.

Burra High School

On Sunday 11 December the school’s Valedictory Service at St Mary’s saw about 300 present from the Anglican and Methodist families of the school. The service was inaugurated last year to mark the end of Religious Instruction for the year. Rev. A. Baxter of Clare was to have been the guest preacher, but he collapsed that morning and instead Rev. Blades of Riverton stepped in at short notice. A social hour followed in the RSL Hall where about 150 people were entertained by Robin, David and Jenny Jarman of Adelaide who delighted with their music.

Burra Mine

Burra Town Council extended the right of entry to the Mine Paddock for twelve months to Mine Exploration Co.

Burra Burra DC has purchased a Caterpillar 12E of 115 h.p. Highways and Local Government Department provided $9,000 and the Savings Bank of SA a loan of $12,000.

Burra Festival of Carols was held by the Swimming Pool on Sunday night and drew a crowd of 450 to 500 adults and children – warmly wrapped against the bite of the wind. There was a nativity tableau on the eastern side of the pool. [Details in 2⁄3 column.]

89, 50, 20 December 1966 page 5

Accident.

Minor damage occurred to two vehicles that collided in Commercial Street yesterday when one was backing out from the kerb. The drivers were Mr M.J. Sparks of Whyte Yarcowie and Mr G. P. Beinke of Booborowie.

Burra Camera Club. At the AGM elected were: President, L. Moore; Vice-Presidents R. Blackwell & H. Shakeshaft; Secretary, G. Dollman; Assistant Secretary, Mrs R.D. Dollman.

The president reported on a successful year. Membership had increased to 25 and meetings had been a mixture of lectures, practical nights and social occasions.

90, 1 (2), 10 Jan. 1967, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Silos wheat intake is expected to reach 300,000 bushels this season. The first load from V.G. & M.K. Simpson of Mt Bryan was delivered on 29 November. The wheat has been of good quality despite the rains in December and has averaged 62 lb per bushel. The 264, 324 bushels received to Monday is the greatest intake since bulk receivals at Burra. The second silo has contributed to this. Very little local wheat has gone elsewhere and very little from outside the district has been delivered at Burra. Both silos were filled to capacity on 3 January.

Learn to Swim Campaign. At Burra 140-160 youngsters are receiving instruction. About 70 of them are taking part for the first time. Mr Paul Tattersall is being assisted by Miss Rosemary Reed and Russell Nicholls. Miss Sue Murphy will join them next week.

Weather. December in Burra was the second wettest on record and the total of 427 points recorded was exceeded only in 1962 with 456 points. 1929 recorded 426 points in December.

Seat Belts. New cars registered after 1 January 1967 must be fitted with seat belts for the driver and one front seat passenger.

Swimming. The first night of the Inter-Club Carnival between Spalding, Clare and Burra was held at Clare on Friday night. Clare came first followed by Burra and Spalding. The next round is at Burra on 27 January.

[Results are printed.]

Burra Small Bore Club

90, 1 (2), 10 Jan. 1967, pages 5 & 8 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra High School: Headmaster’s Report for 1966

The Headmaster welcomed Mr & Mrs Baulderstone and the guest speaker Dr Southgate & Mrs Southgate and other guests. He regretted the death in the year of Mr [A.B.] Riggs, one of the House Patrons and a former Chairman of the High School Council.

The year began with 170 students, slightly down on 1965, due mainly to a very small Leaving Class. Numbers should be steady for some time to come and the emphasis in coming years will be on lengthening the time at school. 1965 produced the most successful Leaving Class ever, with 18 Certificates and a Commonwealth Open Entrance Scholarship won by Denise Griffen. The Intermediate results were unfortunately far less satisfactory.

The school is in the process of being painted and structural alterations have been made to the Headmaster’s Office, the Library and the Home Science Room. At last a comfortable and roomy staff room has been provided. Portions of the yard were repaved and the toilets remodelled. Thanks to the Parents & Friends’ Association changing rooms on the playing fields were completed and put to use.

Prefects were inducted in March and the Parents & Friends’ Association Annual Ball was held at the end of Term 2. Arbor Day was celebrated in July by planting trees along the Burra Creek.

Two special religious services were conducted – a combined Methodist and Anglican Easter Assembly, and a Valedictory Service for the second successive year was held in St Mary’s last Sunday evening.

In October the Director of Education, Mr Mander Jones, visited and after opening the new Primary School Library, he addressed the High School Students and reviewed a display of work in the school hall and saw the excellent range of new library books.

Open Night was again held at the start of Term 2, but this year fewer parents came along.

Sport has again played an important part in the school, with a very successful Sports Day in April. Steele House won the Swimming Cup in March.

At the Inter-High School Sports Day at Kapunda, Burra was successful in retaining the Handicap Shield. Inter-school winter sports matches were contested against Balaklava and Riverton High Schools (but the less said of the results the better). Summer sports will be played against Riverton tomorrow.

Another highlight of the year was the tour by 32 senior students and four teachers to Tasmania in September. Unfortunately the planned camp at Melrose 10 days ago for the Junior School had to be cancelled due to wet weather. It has been postponed to February.

The club period changed this year. In Term 1 the lesson was given over to cultural activities such as drama, musical appreciation, singing and art work. In Term 2 the whole school engaged in debating and public speaking.

Future changes. The Intermediate Examination is to be abandoned, with no external examination staged by the Education Department at that level either. It is also probable that the Alternative Course will be extended into the Leaving year. It remains to be seen how many students will wish to study a PEB type course where there will be no external examination until Leaving level and how many will take the High Schools Alternative Course. The nature of the gap between the two courses is also as yet unknown.

Commonwealth Secondary Scholarships will be available, awarded on the results of a special mid-year examination (held for the first time this year). Two of our students gained one this year: Christine Reincke & Shirley Crew – both of them are leaving Burra.

[The Headmaster then discussed the problem of student boredom, their wandering the streets at night and their lack of manners. He went on to the usual acknowledgement of the work of the Parents & Friends’ Association, the High School Council, the High School staff and the religious instructors.]

Changes for 1967: Miss Briggs moves to the new Elizabeth West H.S. and Miss Jones will return as Mrs Day.

90, 1 (2), 10 Jan. 1967, page 6 [Number used before in 1961.]

Birth. To Mr & Mrs Roger Humphrys, on 1 January 1967, a son, John Robert.

Robert Heinrich of Elders-GM has been transferred to Gladstone.

90, 2 (2), 17 Jan. 1967, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Accident/Obituary. Retired grazier Mr Donald Roy McInnes aged 75 of ‘Donara’ Hallett, was killed instantly in a level crossing smash on Thursday. He was travelling in a car, which was struck at a level crossing between Mt Bryan and Hallett at about 8.45 a.m. by a goods train travelling south. He had been going to collect the daily paper from a roadside delivery box. The RSL funeral was arranged by the Hallett Sub-branch for Friday afternoon. 130-140 cars formed the cortege. Mr McInnis was born in the Hawker District and transferred to Gulnare as a share farmer in 1914. He enlisted in the First AIF from Spalding. He was wounded in action in France and returned home, purchasing a property at Hallett in 1919. He married Miss Clara Scholz. He worked hard and established his four sons on the land. In his early days he was a keen and active member of Hallett Tennis Club and a follower of the football team. Later in life he was interested in bowls. ‘Donara’ Stud was established in 1945 on the original property, but later in 1958 it was transferred to the old ‘Cartapoo’ property, which still remains the registered stud of ‘Donara’. Mr McInnis was a keen judge of sheep and was very astute when it came to their value. He enjoyed a success in the show ring as well as stud breeding in general. He was a foundation member of Hallett RSL and was about to retire to Adelaide.

[Born 24 December 1892 Willow Plains: died 12 January 1967 near Hallett, residence Donara Station.]

Road Blocks were set up in various places after an armed robbery at Klemzig ANZ Bank branch on Thursday. One was on the Burra-Hanson Road near the by-pass turn-off. Four men have since been arrested.

Theft. Jennison’s Tyre Service was broken into on the night of Monday 9 January and goods to a value in excess of $500 were stolen. The rear door was forced. Several of the items stolen were apparently later thrown from a car on the Morgan Road and found on Wednesday morning by Mr Alec Ford.

Burra Primary School. A large number of students gained certificates in the Lear to Swim Campaign. Mr Lannan and Mrs Said volunteered for the teaching job. [A list of certificate winners is printed.]

90, 2 (2), 17 Jan. 1967, page 2 [Number used before in 1961.]

St John Ambulance Building Appeal Fund final total is $959-60.

Theft. More of the goods stolen from Jennison’s Tyre Service have been found and handed to Burra Police. On Thursday last several radios, an ice box and three new tyres were found between St Mary’s Hall and the home of Mr & Mrs Jim Kelly. A tape recorder and a new car radio are still missing.

90, 3 (2), 24 Jan. 1967, pages 1 & 6 [Number used before in 1961.]

The Learn to Swim Campaign ended on Friday. In Burra 57 children who could not swim were taught to swim at least 10 yards and 45 gained Beginners’ Certificates, 30 got Progress certificates, 15 the Junior Certificate and 28 the Senior Certificate. Four earned Bronze Crosses in the Life Saving Section. [Names of award winners are listed.]

90, 3 (2), 24 Jan. 1967, page 3 [Number used before in 1961.]

Weather. Rain began last night and so far falls of up to 50 points have been reported across the district. Burra reports 44 points, Poonunda 50 and Mt Bryan East 45.

Television. Spencer Gulf Telecasters Ltd have not attracted enough local shareholders yet. Shares are offered at 50 cents. Interstate interest is being displayed, but the company wants local interests to hold the majority of shares.

Obituary. Jim Schwier died at Burra Hospital last week aged 81.

Birth. To Delrae & Jeffery White of Booborowie, a daughter, at Clare Hospital this week.

Claire Kellock, youngest daughter of Mr & Mrs E.G. Kellock of Burra, has completed her Teachers’ College training and has been posted to McRitchie Crescent School in Whyalla.

Mr & Mrs Peter Dignan leave Burra today. Peter will take up duties with the Eudunda branch of Elders-GM. Jacqui was an energetic worker for the Burra Branch of the M & BHA.

Graham Mudge will take Peter’s place in Burra.

Marlene Kakoschke is leaving Burra after 13 years working as the local dentist’s nurse. She will work as a dental nurse in Adelaide.

Jack Lockett turned 80 recently. [Actually records show he was born 12 January 1889: so he was 79.]

Colin Morrison, formerly a teacher at Burra High School, has been transferred from Lucindale to Woomera Area School.

Geoffrey Collins, Head Prefect at Burra High School 1966, will shortly join the staff at the ANZ Bank.

90, 4 (2), 31 Jan. 1967, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra National Trust met at the Mayor’s Parlour on Wednesday and discussed the future of the Redruth Gaol. The building stands on 8 acres of Crown Land and until recently was the property of the Gaols & Prisons Department. The Lands Department has agreed to give the Wardenship of the building and grounds to a local body. The Burra Town Council and the National Trust have both been interested in preserving and partially restoring this fine example of early SA architecture. It has long been an attraction to tourists and without any local authority having responsibility for it has been subject to an increasing amount of vandalism. The meeting decided it was best regarded as a joint undertaking of the National Trust and Council. The Council should be the body to approach the Lands Department and it was also in the best position to approach the Tourist Bureau for financial help. The fate of other historic buildings in the town came under discussion. Tourist interest in the town is rapidly increasing. Burra is fortunate not to have become subject to ruthless changes and remains a rare example of a town whose history can readily be traced by any exploring visitor. Its tourist potential is great, but is only gradually being realised.

The Gaol was erected in 1852 at a cost of £3040 and occupied in 1853. It was the first Gaol outside of Adelaide and served the whole of the north for many years. It could hold about 30 prisoners. The first gaoler was Mr Thomas Perry, who was paid £168 p.a. There was also a turnkey and a warder. ‘It remained a Gaol well into this century when for a few years it became a Girls’ Reformatory.’

[This information is incorrect. The Gaol was built in 1856 and operated until 1894. In 1897 it was refurbished as a Girls’ Reformatory and had this role until 1922.]

Burra Camera Club held its first meeting for the year at Mr & Mrs Lind’s. The club aims to attract more entries to the Photographic Section of the Burra Show. [Ideas for the year’s meetings are listed.]

Adelaide Wool Sales 24-26 January. ‘Ashrose’ Hallett topped district prices at 64 cents.

[Other local district prices are printed.]

Burra High School. Leaving results are printed. The new system gives each subject a grading from 1 to 6 and a certificate gives the result of all entrants, rather than just those who ‘pass’ certain requirements.

‘Inky’ Sellars came in recently with a query concerning the date of Queen Victoria’s death. He recalled getting a half holiday at school, but couldn’t recall whether it was 21, 22 or 23 January 1901. Mr Auhl, the present headmaster, was able to discover that ‘Inky’ was there in Grade II, having transferred from Miss Bentley’s School after Grade I. Queen Victoria died on 22 January and the school got a half holiday of 23 January.

[A list of ‘Inky’s’ classmates is printed. ‘Inky’ was Roy Sellars 1891-1969. See 88, 31 (2), 10 Aug. 1965, page 1.]

90, 4 (2), 31 Jan. 1967, page 2 [Number used before in 1961.]

90, 4 (2), 31 Jan. 1967, page 7 [Number used before in 1961.]

Topsfield’s faithful old draught horse is about 30 years old and has just been pensioned off after a lifetime of drawing the butcher’s cart to and from the slaughterhouse beyond the railway station each day.

Obituary. Mrs E.H.B. (Effie) Holmes died in Adelaide on 25 January.

[Born Elfreda Hesbie Flower 29 August 1888 Hundred of Mannanarie: died Elfleda Hesbie Holmes 26 January 1967 Hove, residence Burra North.]

Mr Bill Rule visited Burra on Sunday after an absence of 50 years.

Misses Alice & Lilly Snell and their sister Mrs Johns visited Burra. The family moved to Broken Hill in the 1890s.

‘Out & About’

The swimming pool water needs a good clean up and is presently a disgrace to the filtration plant. Part of the lighting system doesn’t work and the lawn needs cutting.

Burra National Trust, 25 January

The branch conceded temporary wardenship of the Gaol to the Town Council to take care of and maintain the building when it is released by the Lands Department. On 3 January Messrs Game & Cooper of Adelaide National Trust inspected places of historical interest in Burra and were impressed by the town’s tourist potential. Rev. Maurice Lind has produced a brochure concerning the history and places of interest in Burra District, which will be sold in Burra. It is the result of painstaking research. It is hoped to open the Museum more regularly, but it is not easy to roster an attendant. Mr R. Fuss has done a fine job in opening it twice a week through the holidays and often more than that. Recent gifts to the Museum are a ‘tumbling tommy’ plough and a sheep bell.

90, 5 (2), 7 Feb. 1967, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra High School

The results of the Intermediate Examination for 1966 are printed. Under the new system all candidates get certificates listing their results. Subjects are graded with numbers from 1 to 6. 1 signifies the top 10%, 2 the next 25%, 3 the next 15%, 4 the next 25%, 5 the next 15 % and 6 the bottom 10%.

Old Burra Photographs

Mr R. Noye has sent to this office some photographs of Burra and the Burra Mine taken in 1905. While rummaging through the old blacksmith’s shop in Riverton, belonging to Mr Scholz, he came across nearly 200 dry plates. Mr Scholz had taken these photographs in 1905 and the plates were in excellent condition. A number of them show Burra and the Mine. Views include Graves’ Shaft, Johnny Green, Market Square, the treeless Burra Creek, the Open Cut, the Ballast Quarry and a general panorama of Kooringa. This discovery followed a hint obtained by Mr Noye of their whereabouts. He is making a collection as a keen photographer and researcher into early photography, for the Public Library of SA. He would welcome any dry plates or old prints for copying. Copies will be made available to the National Trust.

90, 5 (2), 7 Feb. 1967, page 2 [Number used before in 1961.]

90, 6 (2), 14 Feb. 1967, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

District School Enrolments

Burra High School enrolments remain steady at approximately 170, but the Leaving Class of 21 is the biggest in its history. Miss c. Hodges has joined the staff as teacher of Girls’ Craft Subjects and she replaces Miss L. Briggs who has gone to Elizabeth West HS. [New students are listed.]

Prefects elected for 1967:

James Braendler (Head), Stewart Catt (Deputy), Donald Griffen, Andrew Pearce & Roger Przibilla.

Angela Ryan (Head), Bronwyn Disher (Deputy), Beverley Collins, Rosemary Field, Lorraine Hyde & Heather Riggs.

House Captains etc. were also elected.

Leighton School. Enrolments this year at 26 are two less than last year. [New enrolments are listed.]

St Joseph’s, Burra. At 29 enrolments are four more than in 1966. [New enrolments are listed.]

Burra Primary School. Enrolments at 257 are up 10. There are 127 boys and 130 girls. New enrolments of 36 in Grade I bring the total in that grade to 41. [New enrolments are listed.]

Miss Raelene Poticary is in charge of Grade I. She has come from Pt Augusta. Miss Brenda Richards has returned to the staff as Mrs Don Villis. Mrs Perry remains Senior Assistant. With most classes at or near 40, it is hoped an extra classroom will be granted to relieve the very heavy loading in Grades I & II.

Painters have nearly completed their long job of painting the school. They have been around for the last six months.

Burra Kindergarten has 46 students, which is down 2 from last year. Daily attendance is 25 compared with 28 last year. [New enrolments are listed.]

St Joseph’s Spalding has no new students this year and enrolments are steady at 27.

Farrell Flat School. The enrolment is 36, with three new Grade I students. Mr A. Buckingham came from Glenburnie near Mt Gambier to become Headmaster. He replaces Mr K. Reincke who has gone to Ramco School as Headmaster. Miss A. Archer is in charge of Grades I, II & III.

Burra Small Bore Club. Best scorers at the double 100 yard shoot were A. angel, P. Mengersen and M. Thomas.

Decimal Currency. Today is the first anniversary of decimal currency. The public has made many complaints about the continued use of £.s.d. in advertising, but from 1 August no contract entered into in £.s.d. will be enforceable. 75% of business machines have been converted and more than 75% of monetary transactions are done in decimal currency. Nearly all business machines will have been converted by 1 August. Most 3d pieces and half-pennies and pennies will have been returned to banks by then (though they remain legal tender for amount in multiples of 5c. (6d). One of the biggest conversions yet to be completed is that of 100,000 price computing petrol pumps in 30,000 sites around Australia.

Historical Maps found at Steelton

When the old Steelton Post Office was demolished Mr V.R. Schmaal found some old maps and charts. The old building was on the Marrabel-Waterloo Road and was built over 100 years ago. It served as a post office until eight or ten years ago. It was the former home of the late Mr H.G. Parker, who was the former postmaster and District Council Overseer. He was also the District Clerk of the old Waterloo DC. When it became unsafe in recent years, the owner, Mr B.T. Schmaal, decided to demolish it. On receiving advice of the discovery Messrs A.E. Bannear, R.J. Noye and D.S. Overton visited Mr V.R. Schmaal and took over the historical documents. A large SA Directory of 1915, which for many years was used as a door stop, was also taken over.

The collection comprises one lithograph map and five hand-drawn maps. The lithograph shows the area in SA cultivated for wheat in the years 1870-1882 and the average yield per acre. In 1870, the year the railway came to Saddleworth, the Saddleworth DC has 16,282 acres of wheat yielding 14 bushels per acre. In the 1870s the Council area was 39,680 acres. For the 13 years 1870-1882 the average wheat yield overall was 8 bushels per acre, which was amongst the highest in SA. Three hand-drawn maps were prepared by the late F.G. Richardson, licensed surveyor, in 1871 & 1877 and dealt with changes to Government Reserves. They are on linen.

The other two maps are the most interesting and are of Emuville and the Midland Road District. The map of Emuville is a certified copy drawn in 1883 and recalls the early mining era and its effect on the Black Springs area. In 1846 a well-known brewer, David Cudmore, built the Emuville Hotel alongside Emu Springs and the Government trough about two miles northeast of Black Springs. The troughs are still in existence, but the hotel is a heap of rubble. Cudmore stayed only a short while, as he inherited a small fortune in Ireland.

Thomas Tapley took over and dispensed drinks to the thirsty teamsters working between Burra and Kapunda for the next seven years. The hotel was at the junction of three roads to Burra and would have done a roaring trade in beer and hard liquor.

About 1850 the Karkulta Mine, a few miles north of the hotel, was expected to become another Burra Mine and two towns were laid out near the springs. One was Glandore [sic: for Glendore] (now known as Black Springs) and the other, right adjacent to the Emu Hotel was Emuville, comprising 36 blocks of one to four acres; laid out by Edmund Bowman. However, the Karkulta Mine proved a disappointment and today Emuville is just a name on the map.

The other map of 1875 shows the roads under the care of the Midlands Road Board – an area extending from Pt Wakefield to Morgan and from Kapunda to Burra and it clears up much of the doubt which exists about the routes of the early roads. At this time the main road to Burra was the ‘Middle Road’ via Kapunda, Hamilton, Waterloo and Black Springs. The other route was via the ‘West Road’, which in a general way followed the modern bitumen road. ‘Morris Bridge’ on the Saddleworth-Steelton Road was constructed by the Road Board and named after its secretary. One variation shows that in 1875 the route south of Riverton went through the small settlement of Navan, east of the present bitumen. The discovery of these maps brings home the importance of preserving such relics before they are lost forever or are snapped up by hungry antique dealers.

90, 6 (2), 14 Feb. 1967, page 2 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Town Council, 6 February

Council approved in principle a proposal from the Camera Club for making the back rooms of the Town Hall into a suitable small meeting room and an agreement is to be drawn up for Council to consider at its next meeting.

It was proposed that the land adjacent to the Town Hall be made available for the erection of an ambulance building. Consideration was deferred.

90, 6 (2), 14 Feb. 1967, page 6 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Floral Art Club held its AGM on 7 February. Elected: President, Mrs Ron Thamm; Vice-President, Mrs Roy Lloyd; Secretary, Mrs Malcolm Pettet and demonstrator, Mrs Roy Lloyd. The secretary reported a very successful year with 17 financial members and an average attendance of 10. [Details in a 1-column report.]

Burra Penguin Club resumed activities for 1967. Two 10-minute speeches were presented: Mrs Murphy on ‘Federation’ and Mary Woollacott on her collection of famous autographs.

Tasmanian Fire Relief Fund

Mayor E.T. Baulderstone and DC Chairman G.R. Finch write in support of donations for the Lord Mayor of Hobart’s Bushfire Relief Appeal.

Cricket. Koonaburra 215 v. North Booborowie.

Mobile Kitchen Destroyed by Fire.

A party comprising Gordon Wooton, Stan Beinke, Jimmie Taylor, Trevor Baker, Bob Taylor and Jack Stannard are part of a Highway’s Department gang road making 100 miles north of Yunta. On Tuesday last week, with temperature about 118°F they were transferring the camp and machinery from Wertaloona to Curnamona. The 18 ft x 20 ft [sic:!] caravan kitchen, which accommodated twelve men at meal times, caught fire about four miles south of Frome Downs. The ‘train’ of vehicles was turned into the wind and an attempt was made to extinguish the fire, but all that could be saved of the kitchen was the bottled gas container. The truck and smaller van were not damaged, but all the food, furniture and utensils were lost. The cook, Jack Stannard, lost a deal of personal belongings. The roads in these areas of drift sand and watercourses will enable large numbers of cattle to be transported from the northern areas to Frome Downs by road. Temperatures like Tuesday’s have been experienced for a week and for the preceding four days a severe dust storm had raged.

90, 6 (2), 14 Feb. 1967, page 7 [Number used before in 1961.]

Marriage. This week

Linley Jeffery will marry Peter Noonan at Sacred Heart College Chapel, Somerton Park.

Obituary. Mrs Casabohm, who died in Adelaide recently, was the mother of Mrs Lance Fiebig of Burra.

[Born Florence Clara Burton 25 July 1887 Williamstown: died Florence Clara Cassebohm 6 February 1967 Henley Beach, residence Burra North.]

Lieutenant P.N. Dinham of Booborowie arrived home from Nui Dat, Vietnam, on 26 January, having contracted malaria while serving with the 6th Battalion Royal Australian Regiment there for eight months. He is expected to be posted within Australia at the end of his sick leave.

Mr Kerin has been welcomed as the new Headmaster at Booborowie Primary School.

90, 7 (2), 21 Feb. 1967, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Swimming. The final round of the triangular contest with Clare and Spalding was held at Spalding on Friday night. Spalding won the night, but Burra’s overall scores gave them an aggregate lead of 49 points, so they regain the Tilbrook Shield. [Results are printed.]

Burra’s Annual Open Carnival was held on Sunday under perfect conditions. [Results are not printed.]

Tasmanian Bushfire Appeal. Donations handed in locally to a total of $272 are acknowledged.

A Paper Drive continues to raise money for a new floor for the Town Hall. 80 bales have been sent away since Christmas, but many more will be needed.

Burra Rural Youth has had a busy week with about 40 members off to Elders-Gm Wool Stores at Pt Adelaide on Monday. The ABC Competition saw two candidates go to Clare on Tuesday. They were Anita Archer and Geoffrey Dare and the latter was placed second.

Inter-club debating between Clare and Burra was held on Wednesday. On Friday a small group travelled to Crystal Brook to participate in their swimming carnival.

90, 7 (2), 21 Feb. 1967, page 5 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Library AGM was presided over by President W. Carpenter who welcomed members and in particular the

Increased interest of juvenile members. There are 77 members and 20 juvenile members. 120 new books came from the Institutes’ Association. The annual trading table raised $82.24. Thanks go to Mrs Bex Kotz as convenor and to her helpers. Mr Ben Kotz also ran a competition, which raised a further $61. In the year Mr Bert Cornelius had to resign as Treasurer for health reasons and the librarian, Mrs Steer, also had to resign for the same reason. Miss Rosalind Parks has taken over as librarian. Mrs Teague and Mrs Braendler have helped me [W. Carpenter] keep the library open during the holidays. During the year we also lost our only life member with the death of Mr A.B. Riggs; a past president and long-serving committee man. Mrs Braendler has taken over the role of Treasurer.

Burra Small Bore Club. Best scorers at the double 25 yard shoot were R. Alderson, R. Gilbert & J. Bowden.

90, 8 (2), 28 Feb. 1967, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Brian Jefferies RDA, BAgSc, formerly of Mt Bryan, who also holds a wool classing diploma, has accepted a four year assignment with the Argentinean Government to set up a sheep breeding program based on Australian lines. Brian was with the SA Agricultural Department for seven years and has recently resigned from his position as Chief Sheep & Wool Adviser for Tasmania, where he had served for seven years. Brian demonstrated wool classing and Australian shearing methods on a trip to Uruguay in September 1956 for the UN Food & Agricultural Organisation.

Redruth Gaol. Burra Town Council has been granted a licence for 12 months to control the old gaol as an interim measure to limit vandalism and further deterioration of the building.

Booborowie Primary School. Attendance is 67 compared with 65 on 10 February 1966. Mr John P. Kerin has replaced C.J. Gower as the Headmaster. [New students are listed.]

Adelaide Wool Sales 21-23 February. [Local District prices are listed.]

Des Woolley of Jennison’s Tyre Service has won a Ford Professional Salesmen’s Pacemaker Award for the second year in succession.

90, 8 (2), 28 Feb. 1967, page 2 [Number used before in 1961.]

Advt. Rick Chad & Thel Morgan present their 1967 All-Star Western Variety Show in Burra Town Hall 8 March.

90, 8 (2), 28 Feb. 1967, page 3 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Mines. The Minister of Mines Mr S.C. Bevan says Mines Exploration Pty Ltd is continuing its detailed exploration of the Mine area and the northerly and southerly extensions. Much drilling and sampling has been done and continues. The existence of a substantial quantity of low grade oxidised ore has been established. Metallurgical investigations into recovery methods are meeting with some difficulties because of the nature of the accompanying waste rock. This work is also continuing.

Obituary. Mrs Phillips, late of Burra, died last week at Peterborough.

Obituary. Clem Bailey died on Saturday. He is survived by a widow, three sons and one daughter: Keith, Don, Rodney & Patricia.

[Clement Thomas Bailey born 24 May 1900 Redruth: died 25 February 1967 Leabrook, residence Dulwich.]

‘Mrs Maggs’ reports trying out the new footbridge near the Kindergarten. It is well made and provides a safe crossing in place of the narrow road bridge in Queen Street, for children as well as adults in the area.

90, 9 (2), 7 Mar. 1967, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra’s Population

Note: the district figures include the townships of Farrell Flat, Hanson, Mt Bryan and Booborowie.

There has been an increase in the size of holdings and in the number of vacant houses on properties.

[A hand-written comment on the office hard copy says the figures for 1959 and 1961 are estimates only.

Another hand-written comment suggests that the increase between 1954 and 1959 reflects seasonal conditions.

Figures are also printed for Clare, Jamestown, Peterborough, Kapunda, Spalding, Hallett, Riverton, Robertstown and Morgan.]

Burra Camera Club will get a 10-year lease on the old dressing rooms at the Town Hall. Two enthusiastic members began work and two walls have been removed for the renovation of the main meeting room. The room will be available for hire to others.

Burra Hospital will benefit from the proceeds of a social function at Booborowie last Friday, organised by Fiebig Motors. Compere was Rory Jay of Adelaide. The music was provided by two local bands: Dominos and Woodpeckers.

Halbury School students visited Burra last Friday. The President of the Burra National Trust Mr Stan Woollacott showed the party over the Museum, after which they visited the Bon Accord Shaft and Engineer’s Shop, at the invitation of Mr Joe Edwards. They then went on to the Mine area, the old Redruth Gaol and other places of interest. Mr Ian Auhl outlined the story of the Mine and of the historic buildings. Teamsters from Burra were often bogged near Halbury en route to Pt Wakefield and later a corduroy road of split pine logs was laid across this boggy section. Some 40 adults accompanied the students and some of the farmers among them said the old bullock tracks across their properties are still well defined, as wheat does not grow as tall along the 100-year-old tracks as in the rest of the crop.

Burra High School. Thirty-four students and seven teachers enjoyed a school camp and trek up Mt Remarkable at the weekend at a camp, which had been postponed because of heavy rain at the end of 1966. Luncheon was taken at the summit of the climb. The camp was a great success.

90, 9 (2), 7 Mar. 1967, page 5 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Small Bore Club held a shoot on Tuesday at which best scorers were L. Moore, J. Bowden & Ross Gilbert.

90, 9 (2), 7 Mar. 1967, page 6 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Choral Society held its AGM. Fourteen people attended and re-elected President, Jack Oates; Pianiste, Mrs Oates; Secretary-Treasurer, Mrs J. Nankivell and Conductor, G.D. Sibly.

Burra Kindergarten Association’s AGM drew only ten interested mothers. Office bearers elected were: President, Mrs M. Lind; Vice-President, Mrs B. Stockman; Secretary, Mrs J. Nankivell and Treasurer, Mrs Dean More.

Burra Camera Club. When changes to the dressing rooms at the Town Hall have been completed it is intended to make the now 17 ft x 17 ft room into a theatrette to be called the Johnny Green Theatrette.

Tennis

‘A’ Grade Aberdeen 12-102 defeated Booborowie 8-78

Mt Bryan 20-120 defeated Spalding 0-0

90, 9 (2), 7 Mar. 1967, page 8 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Football Club held its AGM last Wednesday with a good gathering of 37 players and supporters. The general account shows a credit balance of $439.34 and the Benevolent Fund has a credit of $437.43. Elected were: Patron, Reg Warnes; President, E. Pietsch; Vice-President, A. Baulderstone; Secretary, G. Baulderstone and Treasurer, B. Simpson. The President reported a successful year in social and financial terms. Barry Eberhard is to be complimented on his work as coach. Tony Fillmore was responsible for the efficient management of the Colts and Barry Eberhard was also successful in winning the Mail Medal. Improvements for the year were the erection of a tea room at a cost of $350, repairs to the showers and hot water system costing $70 and a new set of guernseys and tracksuits at $133. In addition $150 was contributed towards oval improvements.

90, 10 (2), 14 Mar. 1967, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Burra Show Inc. AGM

The date for this year’s show will be 7 October.

M.G. Stockman was re-elected President for a third term. Mr Rex Stockman was elected Senior Vice-President and Mr R. Mason is the Junior Vice-President. G. Stanley Hawker is the Patron. The distribution of electricity on the grounds has to be reorganised because of the unsafe condition of existing poles. A sub-committee will go into the matter and various other matters relating to improving the show were considered. It was decided to ask the minister of Agriculture Mr Bywaters to open the 1967 show, or failing him, Mr C.R. Kelly MHR. A minute of appreciation was recorded for the services of Mr H.J.B. Jennison over a long period. He had earlier indicated he would like to retire from the committee in favour of a younger member.

The President reported a successful 1966 show, held in perfect weather with a total of 2,450 entries. Horses in Action remained a highlight. Numbers were down on the previous year’s record, but quality was much in evidence. Wool entries were up with the best types in the district. The Sheep Pavilion was nicely filled and young breeders are to be commended for entering.

The Flower Pavilion was a picture despite some rough weather in the days leading up to the show. Mrs Scroop and Mr R. Fuss are congratulated on the painting of the walls and tables.

District schools produced a fine display. Industrial displays were numerous and comprehensive. The Agricultural Pavilion was well filled with quality produce. Dog and goat entries were of a high standard and poultry and birds were well represented as usual.

The death during the year of Mr A.B. Riggs is the loss of a valued member. He was a life member and past president who did a great deal to support the show over many years. Thanks to the new secretaries Mr & Mrs A. Graham, who learned fast and did a fine job.

Financially the show was a success and the overdraft is being slowly reduced.

Burra Primary School Welfare Club held its AGM, which about 60 mothers attended representing about 50% of the families at the school. Mrs J. Carpenter was elected President for the fourth year in succession. The club had expended nearly $600 in the year. Mr I.L. Auhl the Headmaster thanked office bearers and members for their support. Other officers elected: Vice-Presidents, Mesdames P. Kirk & R. Pearse; Secretary, Mrs L. Braendler; Assistant Secretary, Mrs T. Pendlebury and Treasurer, Mrs R. Broad.

Burra High school held its induction ceremony for Prefects and the Acceptance of House Captains in the Avenue of Memory last Friday. Nearly 150 parents and visitors attended. [Details in 1 column.]

The RSL AGM was held last Friday night in the club rooms with the best attendance of members since 1961. Mr Wilf Nankivell was re-elected President with Messrs B.A. Riggs and T.R. Rogers as Vice-Presidents. Ben Kotz continues as Secretary with Mr Arthur Wright as Treasurer. Mr Bert Cornelius reported that 1966 did not get away to a good start and when he could not continue in May due to ill health it looked as if the club might close. In June one of the oldest members in Mr Wilf Nankivell consented to take over as President. The work of the Women’s Auxiliary was much appreciated and through their efforts the club had been able to maintain its Legacy commitments. Mr Nankivell thanked the headmasters of the schools for allowing students to attend the Armistice Day Service. He hoped members would take a more active role in 1967.

Burra Primary School Welfare Club

The activities of 1966 are reported by Mrs J. Carpenter. [In just over 1 column of detail.]

There were 62 financial members. Some major activities included financing the installation of a backdrop for the tennis court (subsidised by the Education department). They assisted at the school’s sports day in April when stalls raised $177.25. There was some difficulty in getting the subsidy paid by the Education Department on the funds raised for library books, but after Mr Ron Moreland personally met with the Director of Education Mr Mander Jones, the problems were resolved. Mr Mander Jones visited the school to officially open the painted and furnished library on 28 October.

The ‘A’ Grade will have six teams.

Farrell Flat and Sevenhill are in recess.

Adelaide Wool Sales 14-16 March. [Local district prices are printed.]

Accident. A car driven by Warren O’Brien of Burra North, with passenger Miss Gwen Foyle of Burra, overturned on Saturday night on the Hanson-Springbank Road. The vehicle damage was extensive, but the occupants were unhurt.

Night Basketball. Grand Final

Booborowie Checkmates 23 defeated Spalding Blue 18.

Bowls. The Club Championship was played on Sunday and Joe Lloyd 25 defeated Bill Corner 19.

Saddleworth & District Historical Society has acquired a thrashing roller donated by Otto Pfitzner and his son Roy of Tarnma. Over 100 years ago some German settlers of Friedrichswalde (Tarnma since 1918) felled a huge red gum 23 feet long and over 4 feet in diameter. In its green state Mr Bob Noye has estimated it weighed ten tons and seven tons when dry. For months they worked on the log chipping away about five tons with hand tools to leave the two ton roller we see today. It is a long tapered object with fluted sides. It was fastened to a pole at its pointed end and rolled in a circle by two horses harnessed to a spindle on the larger end. Large quantities of wheat could be threshed with a fraction of the effort of hand flailing. Wally and Darryl Baldwin transported the item to Saddleworth, where it will be treated with preservative and mounted on a concrete base by the Institute.

90, 11 (2), 21 Mar. 1967, page 2 [Number used before in 1961.]

Bill Wasley has been fruit picking at Cadell and has managed a hundred buckets of grapes a day.

‘Not bad when you’re 88.’ [Bill died 27 June 1970 aged 92.]

90, 11 (2), 21 Mar. 1967, page 8 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Burra DC, 7 March

Chairman G.R. Finch reported on a ratepayers’ meeting at Booborowie, which supported roadside cropping to provide public amenities. The Booborowie Recreation Committee sent a letter re cropping leases. Permission was granted for the committee to lease roadsides for cropping as per schedule provided the land cropped be no closer than half a chain from the centre line of road and the lessee is to be responsible for weed control for the term of the lease. M.T. Carmody requested permission to crop the roadside for Hospital revenue and this was granted.

90, 12 (2), 28 Mar. 1967, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Stud Merino Field Days. The annual round of Field Days will commence on 3 April at Para Glen Stud near Gawler and work north. [Arrangements for the week are printed.]

Burra Town Council will take action shortly to recover outstanding rates. The total rate income of Council is $19,789, of which $1,208 is in arrears. The District Council has a rate income of c. $57,000 and is only $1,511 in arrears – mostly connected with estate dealings taking longer than normal to settle.

Ambulance Depot. Following the purchase of a second ambulance for the Burra District the question of a suitable building to house the vehicles has been discussed on various occasions. Now the Burra & District Association has invited the District EFS to join in the construction of a suitable Ambulance & EFS building to house both organisations and provide facilities for their crews. Before this decision the Association had decided to draw up plans and specifications for an ambulance building and get estimates. The most favoured site is on Council land adjacent to Richards Garage at Burra North. Some financial assistance is anticipated from St John’s Brigade Headquarters. It is felt that Civil Defence needs might be considered at the same time and an invitation has been extended to Mr Nicholls of the Civil Defence Department to address a public meeting on the matter.

St Mary’s Anglican Church

After years of discussion a big transfer of area from the Diocese of Adelaide to the Diocese of Willochra will take place on 1 April 1967. The result will treble the number of priests and communicants in the Diocese of Willochra. The enlarged Diocese will cover over 75% of SA, but will have less than 10% of the state’s population. The area includes Yorke and Eyre Peninsulas, the Mid North and North of SA. The occasion will be marked in Burra by a special service on 7 April to which leaders of all Christian denominations are invited. The Bishop of Willochra Dr T. Jones will be tendered a Liturgical Reception in St Mary’s and Dr J.V. Peters will play the organ. He has composed a special Introit to be used and the Quire of St Nicholas is coming from Adelaide to lead the singing.

Burra Primary School Parents’ Meeting was held last Monday. A special request for ‘Dads’ to attend received a good response and 52 parents attended. Mr Moreland was elected Chairman of the School Committee for two years. [Members of the Committee are listed.]

North Eastern Football League

The season begins on 29 April. Elected were: Patron, A.L. Collins; President, J. Jenner; Senior Vice-President, W.B. Ashby and Secretary-Treasurer, G. Baulderstone.

90, 12 (2), 28 Mar. 1967, page 5 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Primary School Committee: Chairman Ron Moreland’s Report

The work on the school roads was started on schedule and with very satisfactory results. Sports day was a great success and the Welfare Club ran a successful stall. Arbor Day saw trees planted on the oval and in front of the school. On 28 October the new library was opened by the Director of Education Mr E. Mander Jones. The passing out parade was held on 15 December with Mr Farrow, Headmaster of the High School. For the second year in succession we have had a teacher transferred within a week of commencing first term. This is most undesirable, but answers from the Department have been neither helpful nor very satisfactory. The long process of painting the building inside and out has resulted in a work of credit to the painters. The creek through the oval is now ready to be levelled over thanks to donors of filling. Halbury School Committee, teachers, pupils and parents visited on 3 March. During the year we lost the services of Secretary Mr D. Bannister and we were fortunate that Mr L. Moore, manager of the Savings Bank, filled the position. The Andrew Tennant Award is the first award the Primary School has received. It was an award of $400 on which the amount is about $20 p.a. The first award has gone to Ann Brak.

90, 12 (2), 28 Mar. 1967, page 6 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Small Bore Club. Best over double 25 yards were P. Mengersen, K. Spackman & A. Angel.

90, 13 (2), 4 Apr. 1967, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

District Main Roads. Announcement by S.C. Bevan, Minister of Roads.

Construction and sealing of the Spalding-Burra Road is not scheduled before 1970-71 because of the need to complete construction and sealing of the Clare-Hanson section of the Lochiel-Burra main road 46, which has commenced and is programmed for completion 1969-71.

Burra-Morgan Road should be upgraded to ‘open-surface’ standard beginning 1967-68.

National Route 23 to Broken Hill presently is the Tarlee-Clare-Jamestown-Peterborough road, but the best route would be Riverton-Saddleworth-Burra, which is shorter. Route 23 signs will be re-allocated to it within the next three weeks.

Hanson Field Day. The Hanson Agricultural Bureau organised this function on Thursday 30 March. Five machinery firms were represented: Ferguson, Shearer, Chamberlain, Ford and International and also John Deer Tractors. Hanson CWA catered for 120 at a light luncheon in the Hanson Hall. Proceeds will aid the Burra Hospital. The location of the demonstrations was at Tom Rogers, just west of Hanson. Demonstrations were held in very windy and dusty conditions. In the afternoon Mr Hal Bannister demonstrated the latest techniques in bulk handling of super. The use of bulk super has increased in the past six years from 1.1% to 34%.

Burra Small Bore Club. The Annual Prize Shoot

Accident. Five youths from Waikerie District were injured when a car they were travelling in rolled over on Sunday morning about a mile on the Morgan side of ‘The Gums’. All five were conveyed to Burra Hospital by Mr Jeff Arnold. Four will likely leave hospital by tomorrow and one will stay a little longer.

Burra Rural Youth Concert in Burra Town Hall on 31 March served up a very varied program. The compere was Ron Dewhirst of Booborowie.

Overture Duet played by Mrs Jack Oates and daughter Judy

& Beach Wear Eight Lovely ‘Girls’ compered by Naomi Dare

The profit of $85 will benefit the Burra Hospital by $45.50.

90, 13 (2), 4 Apr. 1967, page 2 [Number used before in 1961.]

Obituary. Mary E.C. O’Connell (nee Howell) died 15 March in hospital, late of Kensington Gardens and Burra. She was the mother of Kath Mrs Sowter (Kensington Gardens), Jo (Kensington Park), Bill (Pt Lincoln) and Mary Mrs Kotz (Prospect). There are nine grandchildren.

[Born Cora Howell 18 October 1883 Mt Bryan: died Mary Elizabeth Cora O’Connell 16 March 1967 Prospect, residence Kensington.]

Obituary. A Return Thanks Notice reveals the death of Miss Jean Honeychurch.

[Born 21 September 1916 Kooringa: died 28 March 1967 Burra.]

[An item on page 7 adds the information that she was the only child of the late Mr & Mrs Philip Honeychurch of Burra.]

Advt. On instructions from Mr A.C. & Mrs J.R. Ford, who are relinquishing their grazing interests, Elders-GM will auction ‘Basin Farm’ comprising 1,006 acres freehold at the Burra RSL Hall 28 April.

The Land comprises Sections 156, 142, 132 & Pt Section 1 Hundred of Kooringa and includes a stone homestead of 8 rooms etc. ‘Basin Farm’ has been in the Ford Family for over 100 years and is close to the Burra Township, silos and saleyards. It is suited to wool and cereal or stud purposes. 400 acres are arable and it enjoys a safe rainfall.

Advt. On instructions from J.L. Riggs, whose property they have sold, Dalgety & NZ Loan Ltd will hold a clearing sale on the property situated 16 miles south of Burra and 6 miles east of Farrell Flat on 12 April.

90, 13 (2), 4 Apr. 1967, page 3 [Number used before in 1961.]

90, 13 (2), 4 Apr. 1967, page 5 [Number used before in 1961.]

Accident/Obituary. On Easter weekend Peter Wurst of Saddleworth aged 22 was killed in an accident on the Marrabel-Eudunda Road when the car he was driving collided head on with another about five miles from Eudunda. Peter was a police officer returning to duty in Adelaide, via Eudunda. He was educated at Saddleworth Primary School and Riverton High School, after which he worked at postal delivery for a number of years before doing farm work with his father. He was also employed by A.W. Vater & Co. before joining the SA Police Force about two years ago. He was a prominent player in the Saddleworth-Marrabel United ‘A’ Grade football and played tennis for Saddleworth. He was a foundation member and instructor of Saddleworth Pony Club and was training for the SA Mounted Police. He was a leader in the Midland Civil Defence Rescue Parties and active in the EFS. He was also active in the Saddleworth Show and for several years, even at his young age, was chief steward of the Swine Section. He was a member of the Saddleworth Buffalo Lodge.

[Peter James Wurst died 25 March 1967 near Hampden, residence Saddleworth aged 22.]

John Teague left Burra on Sunday to take up duties with the National Bank at a city branch.

Frank Pascoe, who worked in the shop of R.D. Pascoe & Sons (now occupied by Beinkes), collapsed at work recently and although there has been a slight improvement since, he will never be able to work again.

Aberdeen Tennis Club Easter Tournament

90, 14 (2), 11 Apr. 1967, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

St Mary’s. The Lord Bishop of Willochra Rt Rev. Thomas Edward Jones was welcomed to St Mary’s with an impressive Liturgical Reception last Friday night. After the service supper was served in the hall.

The Mayor & DC Chairman Mr G. Finch welcomed the Bishop on behalf of the civic authorities. Father Hay of Farrell Flat Catholic Church, Rev. M. Lind from the Burra Methodist Circuit and Mr E. Pietsch of the Burra Lutheran Congregation welcomed the Bishop on behalf of their churches. Bishop Jones recounted some of his life, his interests and his duties. Robert Reed, a Trustee and Warden was a most capable compere.

[Details in about 1 column.]

Burra Golf Club will open the season on 29 April. A tractor has been purchased, nut weed growth will be reduced, a refrigerator has been purchased and an electrical stove is being provided by the Associates. A sub-committee is looking at ways of extending the existing clubhouse.

Bowls. Trophies decided:

Handicap Singles Bill Corner defeated Murray Stockman

Consistency Ken Short defeated Tom Emmerson

Lower North Champion of Champions

The Rink Contest went to Jack Arbon’s Balaklava Team

Singles went to O. Kurtzer of Eudunda.

Pensioners’ League. The visit of the Norwood and Payneham Branches was a great success with their concert in the Town Hall very nearly filling it to capacity.

Leighton School had an educational tour to Burra on 3 April, visiting the Gaol, dugouts, cottages, Burra Museum, a Council meeting, the Deep Creek Aboriginal carvings and the Mine. Rev. Maurice Lind acted as guide for the day.

Men’s Handicap Doubles R. Gebhardt & R. Hillman

90, 15 (2), 18 Apr. 1967, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra on TV

On Thursday last a film crew from National Television recorded the historical sites of Burra. Well known Sydney cameraman Mr John Kingsford-Smith (nephew of Sir Charles) was in charge. He has been the cameraman for the National TV series ‘Australian Heritage’. Mr Ian Auhl provided the local historical background notes. Mr Arthur Hiles, Secretary of the National Trust in Adelaide, had negotiated the choice of Burra on behalf of the Burra District National Trust. Although the final film will run for only about five minutes, a great deal will be packed into the period. It was shot in colour so it would not become dated when colour TV is introduced in a few years. Mr Kingsford Smith decided the outstanding feature of the town compared with other Australian historical sites was the masonry of its old buildings. He said he was astonished that with its tourist features Burra was so little known, even in SA. The film will be shown on 38 stations of the ABC from time to time and will help to put Burra on the tourist map. It is hoped to have it ready for TV within a month.

Ray Pietsch of the ANZ Bank in Burra has been transferred to Elizabeth Centre Branch after two years here. Geoff Collins has joined the staff in Burra.

Burra High School Drama Club is seeking some adults to join them in a production later in the year. They are considering doing G.B. Shaw’s Pygmalion. The production would help raise funds for an interstate trip in September.

Drama. The Young Elizabethan Players will visit Burra on 5 May to present extracts from Shakespeare’s Merchant of Venice and King Lear. Both are studied by senior students at the High school. Entrance is 65 cents on 5 May at 9.30 a.m. at the Town Hall. The public is welcome to attend.

Fires

Three night fires have occurred in a fortnight in Burra.

On Saturday the brigade extinguished a blazing tree, which had been removed from Chapel Street some weeks earlier and dumped further along.

On Thursday night the old wood and iron toilet in the southeast corner of the Memorial Oval burnt down.

Yesterday morning the hedge at the home of Mr Bert Wardle in Mt Pleasant Road needed attention.

[‘Mrs Maggs’ column on page 7 adds that Mr & Mrs Wardle slept right through the excitement at their property.]

None of the fires caused any serious damage.

90, 15 (2), 18 Apr. 1967, pages 1 & 5 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra High School Sports Day was held on 6 April at the Racecourse Oval at Burra North. The weather was good and a good crowd of spectators attended. Jennison House won the shield – regaining it from Draysey.

[Results are printed.]

Burra Branch of the M & BHA held a Past & Present Fashion Parade in the Burra Town Hall on Friday Night. It was organised by Mrs Barry Eberhard. President Mrs B. Riggs welcomed those who attended. Mrs Jack Oates played melodies from popular musicals in the background. The organisation expects to clear $80.
