Spencer Gulf Telecasters

Following completion of arrangements for underwriting the ordinary share issue, plans and specifications for the studio to be erected in Pt Pirie are being prepared. Equipment has been ordered and transmission should be gin later in 1967. The station will be GTS 4.

Burra Burra DC will support a petition requesting reticulated water for Mt Bryan.

90, 16 (2), 25 Apr. 1967, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Anzac Service. The annual event was conducted last Sunday afternoon by the Rev. G.D. Sibly. The Marananga Band attended and a fair number of the public. Wreaths were laid on behalf of the Burra RSL, Demobilised Soldiers’ Assoc., Air Force Assoc., Fathers’ Assoc., Burra Town Council and the Burra Burra DC.

The evening ecumenical Anzac Service at Burra was held in St Mary’s conducted by the Rector Rev. Sibly with the sermon preached by Rev. M.A. Lind of the Methodist Church.

At Hallett the service was held in the Hallett Institute Supper Room, conducted by Rev. A. Houston.

Accident/Obituary. Dudley Harold Garrard aged 32 of Booborowie died at Curnamona Station on Monday last week [17 April]. He was riding through saltbush country when he fell from his motor cycle about three miles west of the homestead and seems to have died instantly. He was found by Mr Brian Treloar of Mooleulooloo Station from his aircraft, following unsuccessful searches on Tuesday and Wednesday.

The New Bridge at Burra North has now been completed, but a good deal of filling etc. is still required and the approaches have yet to be made. This work will be done by the Burra Burra DC directed by the District Engineer of the Highways Department.

Adelaide Wool Sales last Tuesday to Thursday produced firm values. [Local district prices are printed.]

Burra BurraDC has a larger assembly of plant than ever before in its history. It has received an advance of $20,000 to complete payment of a new D6 tractor and dozer. It now has three tipper type trucks, one Falcon utility, four motor graders, two front end loaders, one dozer, tractor rollers, stone crusher, compressor and jack hammers, chain saw, weed control plant and a well equipped depot.

Stockowners’ Association Burra Branch. At the annual meeting David Cowell gave an interesting address on the Australian Wool Industry Conference, outlining the main factors of marketing, reform and promotion, as well as the embargo on Merino sheep.

Burra & District Young Liberals met in Clare on 19 April. More than 60 people attended. Lorraine Weckert was chosen as the Group’s entrant for Miss Young Liberal to be chosen at the Ball in Adelaide on 19 May. The candidates for pre-selection were given seven minutes each to address the meeting.

Brian Jefferies writes from Argentina. [The letter extends for c. 2⁄3 column.]

90, 16 (2), 25 Apr. 1967, page 2 [Number used before in 1961.]

Obituary. Violet Wear died 12 April. She was the sister-in-law of Hilda and George Earle of Farrell Flat.

[Born Violet Theresa Knoblanch 7 April 1898 Mellor Park (Pt Adelaide): died Violet Tresa Wear, Birkenhead.]

90, 16 (2), 25 Apr. 1967, page 3 [Number used before in 1961.]

Tourism. Mr E.T. Baulderstone outlined Burra’s tourism potential and its tourism facilities at a special meeting of the Riverton District Chamber of Commerce in the RSL Rooms Riverton on 20 April. Representatives discussed the facilities available along the newly proclaimed National Highway 32 from Tarlee through Riverton, Saddleworth and Burra to Hallett. An action committee was formed and a committee of two representatives from each district was formed to promote facilities for tourists along Highway 32 from Adelaide to Broken Hill. The next meeting will be in Burra 25 May. Burra’s representatives will be Mr E.T. Baulderstone and Rex Hurley.

90, 16 (2), 25 Apr. 1967, page 4 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club fired a double 100 yards shoot with best scores from R. Alderson, R. Gilbert & A. Angel.

90, 16 (2), 25 Apr. 1967, page 5 [Number used before in 1961.]

Marriage. St Mary’s, Burra, 14 April

Diane Gill, second daughter of Mr & Mrs R.A. Gill, married

Donald Bernhardt, younger son of Mr & Mrs R.G. Bernhardt.

90, 16 (2), 25 Apr. 1967, pages 5 & 8 [Number used before in 1961.]

Rural Youth gathered at Spalding for the Upper North Zone Rural Youth Rally. Overall Burra was placed 5th, but some individual members did well. Burra’s debating team was narrowly defeated by Zone winners, Gladstone. Mary Woollacott won the public speaking competition and will go on to the State Final.

In the Miss Rural Youth contest Burra’s entrant was Heather Angel. Zone winner was Valerie Noble of Mt Remarkable.

Other contests involved home crafts for the girls and agricultural and pastoral skills for the boys. Other contests involved nail driving, car reversing, a shovelling race and a fire alarm race. A mannequin parade was staged on the final night. There was a church service on Sunday morning at Bundaleer Reserve. The Shield went to Spalding with Crystal Brook second. [Actual results are printed on page 8.]

90, 16 (2), 25 Apr. 1967, page 6 [Number used before in 1961.]

Football

Burra 7.14 defeated United 6.5

G. Baulderstone has resigned as Secretary of the Burra Club, having taken the position of Association Secretary. Mr Tony Fillmore has consented to fill in as Secretary for this year.

Gladstone 9.12 defeated Spalding 10.4

Senator Arnold Drury has been invited by Burra ALP Sub-Branch to address their AGM in the RSL Hall tonight, on the subject of the approaching referendums on the possible increase in the size of the House of Representatives and on the rights of Aborigines.

[Born Olive May Phillips 31 July 1912, Redruth. She was first married to Kenneth Max Auhl.]

Methodist Circuit Picnic at Redbanks yesterday was highly successful.

90, 16 (2), 25 Apr. 1967, page 8 [Number used before in 1961.]

The Mt Bryan Reunion at Mt & Mrs Bill Winchester’s ‘Roraka’ on 16 April is reported and those attending are listed in 2⁄3 column.

The Penguin Club welcomed the State President Mrs J. Grant-Williams to their last meeting. Over 30 people attended, including the Mayor and Mayoress.

90, 17 (2), 2 May 1967, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

CWA. The Annual Warnes Group Conference was held at Burra Town Hall on Wednesday 26 April. Group President Mrs W. Klem of Black Springs introduced the President of the Burra Branch Mrs Baulderstone who welcomed all. Members decided to continue with the Group Objective of training a pre-school teacher for the children at Musgrave Park on the Northwest Aboriginal Reserve. Mr K. Martin, Research officer for the Department of Aboriginal Affairs, gave an interesting address on the works undertaken by his Department. Mrs L.J. Burton, Hon. State secretary of the CWA, spoke on branch activities and aspects of CWA work. As guest speaker Miss Ruth Gibson took UNESCO’s Campaign Against Illiteracy as her topic. Thirteen tables of handicrafts were staged by branches and winners were auburn and Riverton who both had 391⁄2 points. Mrs Klem was re-elected President and she named Mrs G. Harding of Black Springs as her Secretary, Miss F. Pattulo of Clare was re-elected Handcraft Secretary. A trading table convened by the Mt Bryan Group raised $43.42 for the Musgrave Park Fund.

The Northern Regional Red Cross Conference was held at Jamestown. Mrs Roy Jeffery of Burra was elected new Regional President with Mrs John Murray of Hallett as her deputy and Mrs E. Teague of Burra as Secretary.

‘Basin Farm’ the well-known property of Mr A.C. & Mrs J.R. Ford was passed in at auction in the RSL Hall Burra on 28 April, but later sold for an undisclosed figure to K.R. Phillips Pty Ltd of ‘The Gums’, Burra.

Burra Sub-Branch of the ALP held its AGM on 26 April. Elected were President, Jack Phelan; Vice-Presidents, W. Carpenter & V. Preiss and Secretary Mr Ben Kotz. The guest speaker Senator Drury gave an informative address on the forthcoming Federal Referendums (27 May) urging a YES vote to both parts. One part breaks the nexus between the House of Representatives and the Senate. The other part relates to changing Section 127 of the Constitution to allow Aborigines to be counted as citizens.

Mr & Mrs H. Shakeshaft were given a farewell presentation by rhe Burra Camera Club on Monday 24 April in their new (but unfinished) accommodation at the Town Hall.

Accident. A Utility driven by Peter Dare of Mt Bryan East was badly damaged when it rolled over on the Mt Bryan East Road 12 miles south of Hallett at about 1 a.m. Sunday morning. Peter received a fractured arm and was later transferred from Burra Hospital to the RAH.

Weather. Only 11 points of rain were recorded for the months of March and April. This is the second driest April-May on record, exceeded only by 3 points for each of those months in 1949 – though that year ended with about average rainfall.

90, 17 (2), 2 May 1967, page 2 [Number used before in 1961.]

30th North Eastern Combined School Sports Meeting was held at Spalding. The host school was Willalo. Mr George Harris of Adelaide opened the event. Mr Harris was a former Booborowie resident and was the first Secretary of the Combined Sports, holding the position for 10 years. Schools participating were St Joseph’s, Hilltown, Booborowie, Spalding, Leighton & Willalo. Mr & Mrs Keith Rogers leave for Mt Isa in Queensland with daughters Christine and Sue, tomorrow. Mr Rogers has been working as the geologist at the Burra Mine for some time.

Accident. Master Kim Donhardt has been discharged from hospital after a recent wrangle between a car and his bike.

Bowls. Stan Woollacott won the Veteran’s Bowling Championship.

Don Topsfield is spending a week at home after a holiday in WA before he resumes duty with the ANZ Bank in Pt Lincoln.

Mr & Mrs John Riggs have left Farrell Flat for their new property ‘Table Top’ at Walcha in NSW.

Mr & Mrs Jack Stevens have moved from Farrell Flat to Sevenhill.

A Hirschausen Family Reunion at Meningie Oval on 23 April is reported in c. 1⁄3 column.

St John’s Ambulance. There was poor attendance at the AGM. Ron Thamm was elected Officer-in-Charge of the Burra Division. Bill Corner is Secretary and Bill McGee is Treasurer with Jim Brown as Statistics Officer.

90, 18 (2), 9 May 1967, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Mid Northern Secondary Schools Athletics Day was held last Thursday at Burra Racecourse Oval. Schools competing were Balaklava, Clare, Burra, Kapunda, Riverton and Eudunda. Riverton gathered most points in both the Champion and Handicap Divisions, but as the rules say a school cannot win both shields in the same year, Burra retains the Handicap Shield. Mr Quirke MP opened the day’s activities and Mr J.H. Pash, Inspector of High Schools presented the Shields. [Results are printed for events, but aggregate scores are not given.]

Cricket. Mokota Cricket ‘A’ Grade Final

Booborowie 6 for 500 defeated Hallett 494.

Burra National Trust has been given the minute book of the original Burra Automobile Club from Mr Reg. Warnes. It lists members present at one of the early meetings held in Landseer’s Store at Morgan on 10 February 1908. The club had two sections: Car and Motor Cycle. The book ends early in 1914.

RSL. Monday night last week 50 members of Burra and surrounding sub-branches attended a dinner at the Burra RSL Club Rooms in honour of the touring New Zealand delegation. The visitors were amazed at the condition of stock here under such dry conditions. They decided on Tuesday to leave early and travel to Morgan via Saddleworth, Marrabel and Eudunda instead of the very dusty road via Florieton.

Weather. Seasonal conditions.

April was mild to cool with scattered light showers. Feed remains adequate, but a shortage is approaching as ‘green pick’ dries off. Supplementary feeding is increasing. Sheep are generally in good condition. Market prices remain firm. Autumn lambing rates appear to be good on preliminary figures.

Burra Town Council, Wednesday night.

Mr Graham has accepted the position of District Clerk on Kangaroo Island from 1 July and his resignation was accepted with regret.

90, 18 (2), 9 May 1967, page 8 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Small Bore Club. On 2 May over double 100 yards A. Angel, R. Gilbert & P. Mengersen had the best scores. Over double 25 yards on 9 May the best scorers were M. Thomas, K. Spackman & R. Gilbert.

TV Channel 4. There has been more local interest in the station since it has been underwritten by A.C. Goode & Co. and quite a number of applications for shares have been received. The station hopes to be on the air before Christmas 1967. Share application lists will close on 10 May.

Burra Primary School Sports Day was held on 28 April at the Memorial Oval. The weather was kind and the Welfare Club’s arrangements had takings of $203. The House competition was won by Aberdeen House.

[Results are printed.]

Applications for the position of Town Clerk close tomorrow.

Burra Burra DC Elections

Hanson Ward S.T. Miller

Baldina Ward M.T. Kellock

Mt Bryan Ward T.J. Quinn

Booborowie Ward H.B. Quinn

All were elected unopposed.

Burra Rural Youth. Bill Brown of ‘The Grove’ Burra was the guest speaker on the topic of the Merino Sheep Industry in SA. Burra was the best area in SA for the Merino. This resulted in the development of the Stud Merino Industry here and in the Field Days, which are unique in Australia.

Burra Floral Art Show. The first such show was held in the Burra Town Hall last Friday. Mrs H.L. Riggs opened the event. [Exhibitors are listed and the event reviewed in about 11⁄4 columns.]

Attempted Theft. Mr Graham Mudge found on intruder in Elders-GM when he returned at 7 p.m. on Thursday night. The man had found the key to the safe, but was unable to put it to use. The intruder escaped in a red and white Holden sedan.

Hallett 3.1 defeated Booborowie 2.3

Obituary. Olive Hempel had lived with her husband and family in the Spalding District for about 14 years and was an energetic worker in local organisations. She was a member of Spalding CWA and had been President for three years. She was a keen handicraft worker. She was an active member of the Methodist Ladies’ Guild, a Past President of the Welfare Club and was Vice-President of the Ladies’ Bowling Club at the time of her death. She will be remembered for her fine needlework and cake decorating.

[See also 90, 16 (2), 25 Apr. 1967, page 7.]

[Born Olive May Phillips 31 July 1912, Redruth. She was first married to Kenneth Max Auhl.]

90, 19 (2), 16 May 1967, page 8 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Small Bore Club. Over double 25 yards the best scorers were L. Moore, R. Angel and R. Gilbert.

Burra Burra DC, May

Mt Bryan Tennis Club was given permission to crop land adjoining Section 342 Hundred of Kingston.

Private sales of slag are to be made available at $3 per ton.

30, 20, 23 May 1967, page 1 [Note irregular Volume Number.]

Accident. A car failed to negotiate a right hand bend near Brewery Hill and careered down a steep grade at about 9 p.m. on Saturday. Fortunately it did not roll over and the four occupants were saved from serious injury. The driver, Mrs Matson of Tea Tree Gully, sustained minor injuries and of the three children Mark received head injuries and the two younger were unhurt.

Burra Pictures. Attendances have been rising in recent weeks. For April they averaged 140 compared with 110 for the first three months of 1967. A patronage of 90 is needed to cover costs.

Hallett Methodist Church celebrated its 87th Anniversary on Sunday. The preacher was the Chairman of the District Rev. W. Stafford.

The Australian Five Dollar Note will be issued on 29 May. It will be printed in mauve with Sir Joseph Banks featured on the front and Mrs Caroline Chisholm on the back. [Pictures of the front and back are printed.]

Question 1 allowed the number of members in the House of Representatives to be increased without increasing the number of Senators.

YES 557 NO 1219 Informal 34

Question 2 allowed Aborigines to be counted in reckoning the population.

YES 1377 NO 396 Informal 37

The Post Office is about to allocate every city, town, suburb and small centre with a four figure postal location number to be entitled its Postcode.

Mr Bob Fuss remembered recently that a rabbit he had chased 60* years ago had led him into a cave in the banks of the Burra Creek. Thinking it over he returned to the scene and his memory had served him correctly. The rabbit had its home in an old miner’s home in the bank of the creek. The home is still there and if the cave-in was dug out it probably still has two of the rooms intact behind it. Bob feels he is a little too old to excavate it. Perhaps someone younger will undertake the job. [*Corrected 90, 22 (2), 6 June 1967, page 7 to 70 years ago.]

Adelaide Wool Sales 23-25 May. Collinsville topped district prices at 653⁄4c.

[Other local district prices are printed and the list completed 90, 22 (2), 6 June 1967, page 5.]

New Burra Town Clerk Appointed

Following the resignation of A.R. Graham as Town Clerk, the Town Council has appointed Mr R.K. Baker from a group of five applicants. Mr Baker is 24 and married. He is presently a clerk in the Rate Department of the Mitcham City Council. He will take up his position on 1 July, but will come to Burra a week before to familiarise himself with the office routine.

Leighton School Welfare Club Debutante Ball was held last Friday at Leighton Hall when a crowd of over 300 attended. Maurice Collins was the MC and Mr & Mrs Gerald Gask received the debutantes:

Coralie Eberhard with John Teague

Christine finch with Robert Long

Jenette Kleinig with Andrew Riggs

Janice Pens with Gerald Pens

Merle Lomman with Robert Edwards

Elizabeth Sutton with Alan Possingham

The Dominoes provided the music and the door takings if $250 will aid the school.

90, 22 (2), 6 June 1967, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Weather. The May rainfall was an inch below average and the total rainfall for the year is 209 points: the third driest period on record. There is still time for crops to produce well if the break of season comes soon.

Accident. A driver of a NSW utility escaped injury when it overturned on the Burra-Adelaide Road at the Hanson-Farrell Flat Junction on Friday night.

Theft. It is understood that a young man arrested at Pt Pirie in the past week has admitted breaking into the Record Office recently.

The Mokota Cricket Wind-up function was held at Booborowie on Thursday. About 50 cricketers and supporters attended. Mr W.B. Ashby, Patron of the Association, presented the Mokota Shield to First Division winners Booborowie. It was received by David Drew. Mr Alan Baulderstone received the Second Division Shield (Mayfield Shield) for the Burra Footballers, from the President Mr J. McMahon. The Cricketer of the Year Award went to Rob Ashby of North Booborowie.

Burra Creek Dugouts. Following Mr Bob Fuss’s locating of an old dugout, members of the local football club have decided to dig out the discovery. [There follows a reprint of a report from an old paper the South Australian of Friday 13 June 1851.]

Kooringa Flood

This occurred on 8 June and destroyed much property and the loss of a life. On Whitsunday at about 3 p.m. it grew very dark in the southeast and there were occasional peals of thunder till 6.15 p.m. when a terrific peal broke as if over the mine. Rail and hail fell in torrents and continued till about 10 p.m. when the heaviest weather passed to the northwest, but the rain continued. About 3 in the morning huts in the bank were washed in and inhabitants driven out. About 11 a.m. the Smelting Company’s bridge was washed away and in succession every bridge across the creek. (They were all wooden bridges in 1851.) Where the homeless will shelter is a puzzle. A great many heaps of ore are lost and worst of all one life. William Box aged 45, a widower with three children: the eldest aged 5 and the youngest a baby in arms, was killed. His housekeeper says she went to bed about 11 p.m., but the baby was troublesome and she was worried about the floodwaters. She awoke him and after putting her and the children in a higher house in the bank of the creek, he and a neighbour began removing the furniture. By 2 a.m. the water was about two feet deep in the hut and while they were removing an article the roof fell in, knocking his comrade on the face. He managed to crawl away, but Box was thrown onto his back with a large quantity of material on him, so he could not move. It was daylight before he was got out and the body was taken to the nearest hotel [The Miners’ Arms: now the Burra] to await an inquest. He apparently had about £400 in the hut. There are few huts remaining, chiefly near the [old] cemetery. In Kooringa shops were swamped with the street a complete river. Last night the street was more than three feet deep by the post office. A quantity of flour was destroyed and flour was selling for 58/- a bag. The Smelting Works were stopped for want of fuel. [It was later rumoured that the £400 had been recovered.]

90, 22 (2), 6 June 1967, page 2 [Number used before in 1961.]

Obituary. Mr Adam Boulton who died at home suddenly on 22 May was the son of the late Elizabeth & George Boulton, being the youngest of their eleven children. He was born at Gulnare 13 May 1884 and came to Spalding with his parents in 1893 and remained till his death. In 1924 he married Miss Alice Gale of Yacka.

90, 23 (2), 13 June 1967, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Decimal Currency

Australia’s dual currency period will end on 1 August 1967. From that date £.s.d. will have no legal standing. All retailing must be in dollars and cents and all contracts must be dollars and cents to have any legal standing. The exception to this is in wills, which will not be invalid simply because it is made out in terms of £.s.d.

90, 23 (2), 13 June 1967, pages 1 & 5 [Number used before in 1961.]

The ‘Murdered by a German’ Tombstone

The Burra tombstone which has perhaps aroused most interest reads:

ERECTED

HIS BROTHER SEAMEN

TO THE MEMORY OF

JOHN SMITH

OF LONDON AGED 20 YEARS

WHO WAS MURDERED

BY A GERMAN

IN THE TOWNSHIP OF KOORINGA

ON CHRISTMAS EVE

1849

‘Murders in the mining town were not altogether uncommon.’

Burra in 1849 had a population of some 4,000 and was a roaring town of eleven inns with hard drinking bullockies and hard working miners in crude dugout homes in the banks of Burra Creek, of an incredible mixture of wild Irish teamsters, of hard drinking and hard fighting Cornishmen, tough Welsh and German smelters and an even more incredible mixture of the dialects from every part of Wales, Scotland and Cornwall according to a visitor of 1849. Christmas Eve was traditionally a time for letting off steam in the mining town. Christmas Eve was one of the few holidays granted by SAMA. Bare-fisted fights and traditional Cornish wrestling matches took place each year, generally behind the one-storied Miners’ Arms Hotel (now the Burra Hotel in Market Square). Sometimes as many as 500 miners came to watch the action. Fights would be coming off all the afternoon and evening, a ring formed and kept by three policemen, powerless to do anything but watch for fair play. There was no 6 o’clock closing and often no Sunday closing. It is no wonder the gaol behind the Redruth Police Station had to be enlarged and a new one built in 1856. Violence was always possible on such occasions and on Christmas Eve 1849 it led to murder.

Mr W. (Bill) R. Marchant, son of the late Jack Marchant of Hanson, returned recently to Burra and visited the cemetery. He was following up a hunch that his great-uncle Mr T.B. Marchant aged 33 of Mannanarie, who was killed in a fall from a horse in 1854, while riding from Mannanarie to Burra, might be buried in the Burra Cemetery. He found the grave and headstone of his great-uncle and noted that unusually for a headstone the name was preceded by ‘Mr’. He also noticed the John Smith headstone and decided to look up the story.

The SA Government Gazette of January 1850 records that a murder lately occurred at Kooringa, committed by a German named Gottlieb Kiernall. The deceased was a runaway sailor from the Macedon and he came to the German’s house and asked for a light for his pipe. A lighted candle was handed to him, but being intoxicated he let it fall and it went out. He insisted on another light, which was refused and the door closed. He forced it open using threatening language to the German, who then threw a stool at him and then several items were thrown by both sides. The German then suddenly picked up an axe and struck Smith on the head and repeated the blow, killing Smith almost instantly. The case was investigated by Mr Lane, who committed Kiernall for trial.

This was held in Adelaide 1 March 1850.

The SA Register newspaper reported that the judge in summing up said it was a sad case and the jury would have to consider what motive the prisoner had. There appeared to be great provocation. The deceased had thrown stones and threatened or attempted to set fire to the prisoner’s home. The jury had to consider how far the provocation reduced the sentence. After twenty minutes the jury returned a verdict of manslaughter. The judge agreed with the verdict and sentenced Kiernall to be transported beyond the seas for seven years. This meant to be sent to the Penal Settlement in Tasmania.

90, 23 (2), 13 June 1967, page 2 [Number used before in 1961.]

90, 24 (2), 20 June 1967, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Thefts. Two young men working in the Burra area have been charged with a number of ‘breaking’ offences and with the theft of various items from the properties concerned. It is understood a quantity of stolen property has been recovered. The men have been remanded to Adelaide.

Theft. On 9 March 1963 Burra Dry Cleaners were broken into and a cash box among other things was stolen. Now, when the garden block of the late Luke Day was being levelled, the box has been discovered. It contained various papers and the war service medals of Mr Williams, but not the £7 in silver it had originally held. Also in the box was a silver medallion inscribed ‘Best Player in Star Football Club 21/9/09’ on one side and the initials L.H. on the other. It was probably removed from clothing left for dry cleaning and placed in the box for safe keeping.

Polio. The Health Department has announced a changeover from Salk Vaccine to Sabin (oral) Vaccine for polio from 1 July.

Katie Treweeke, daughter of Mr & Mrs F.H. Treweeke of Petherton, Mt Bryan, is the local entrant in the SA section of the Miss Australia Quest. A chief source of funding raised will be the Miss Australia Ball at Mt Bryan Hall on 7 July. Proceeds aid the Woodville Spastic Centre. Katie is 18 and is closely connecte4d with the Burra & District Branch of the Young Liberals. She has aims of becoming a psychologist or a librarian and hopes to go to university next year to begin an Arts degree.

Weather. On Tuesday a severe thunderstorm brought two inches and more of rain and hail in a short time to an area east of Burra. The area was north of the west end of Princess Royal and the massive run-off went east rather than towards Burra. Mr George Woodman said that for the short time it took to fall the whole side of the range looked like a moving mass of water. At Klaebe’s Creek near Studholme a wall of water at least four feet high crossed the spillway. At Pine Creek crossing where 5 ft pipes have recently been installed the flow was 2 ft above the roadway. A vast sheet of water and hailstones swept across the road at the four mile corner and through the property of Mrs J. Rooke. Deep Creek and the Baldina Crossing were flooded when water from Mullaby area cascaded down. At Mrs V. Bruce’s ‘Armonda’ Mr R. Alderson reported a fall of 140 points in less than 50 minutes. Roof guttering could not cope and very little of it went into tanks. He reports a lot of fencing is down and a lot of rubbish and old tyres etc. deposited by the receding water. The property gained a lot of silt. During the height of the flooding the Morgan and Eastern Roads were cut and the school bus and other vehicles were held up for some time. All dams in the area were filled and several burst, causing a further rush of muddy liquid. At one stage along the main road hail was stacked up two feet high against the netting fence.

Princess Royal recorded 80 points, Mrs J. Rooke 104, Armonda 140, Baldina 70, Mongolata 17 and J. Oates 7.

West of Burra there were isolated heavy falls. J. Lockett at Springbank gauged 112 and Old Koonoona 53, but Burra recorded a mere 9 points.

Mr & Mrs Bill* Sampson, formerly of Burra and now of Esperance WA, are back in SA for a six week holiday and will celebrate their Golden Wedding next Tuesday. [Corrected 90, 25 (2) 27 June 1967, page 7 to Mr & Mrs Clem Sampson.]

90, 24 (2), 20 June 1967, page 8 [Number used before in 1961.]

Mr R.J. Noye of Saddleworth writes an article on the rise and fall of the Apoinga Smelters.

A small piece of cast iron handed in to Saddleworth District Historical Society has proved to be one of the few remaining links with this pioneer local industry. It is part of an ingot mould from the Apoinga Smelter, which flourished and then died over 100 years ago.

After the discovery of copper at Burra in 1845 a never ending stream of laden bullock drays wound its way to Port Adelaide. At the wharves it was auctioned and most was purchased by the Swansea (England) [sic] Smelters. With little or no competition the mines were not receiving a fair price for their ore. The SA smelter was to be one of the answers to this lack of competition. The first smelting attempt at Burra failed miserably and some years passed before the town had its own efficient works. Meanwhile some South Australians with overseas experience and their own patented copper refining process were attracted to the dense forest of peppermint gums then at Tothill’s Scrub about 20 miles south of Burra. This was an ideal fuel for their smelting furnaces, which at their peak used 150 loads of wood a week. These men, Penny and Owen, began planning as early as 1847 and in June 1848 they were ready for building to commence and drays carrying fire bricks, clay and ironwork left Adelaide for Tothill’s Scrub. Batches of Burra ore were bought and in January 1849 the furnaces produced their first batch of molten copper. The single stage process was claimed to produce copper as tough and fine as any made overseas using up to seven processes. Later that year works at Burra and Yatala near Pt Adelaide came into production. Initial difficulties were overcome and by March 1849 a ton of copper per day was being produced.

This was increased to 50 tons per week by 1851. By then the works supported a village of 100 people living in c. 30 houses with a post office, hotel, blacksmith, shoemaker and general store. Apoinga seemed set for a rosy future. The discovery of gold in Victoria dealt a staggering blow. Almost every able man rushed to Victoria to make (as he thought) his fortune. Production at Burra fell and the Burra Smelter closed down. The reduced production was sufficient to keep Apoinga going. Penny’s men wanted to leave, but they were under contract and he held them to it. They dealt with this very effectively. When the slag was drawn off they ensured a generous amount of good copper went with it. Expenses thus remained high, but production of copper fell. The works were forced to close and the men rushed to the gold fields. Some years later when the works were re-opened for a short period a huge lump of solid copper was found at the bottom of the furnace and it took eighteen bullocks to drag it out.

Today sheep graze over the site and all that remains is the slag heap and a scattering of firebricks, still bearing the imprint of a long forgotten brick maker called Ramsay. The ranges to the east and west are still heavily timbered. The only remaining building in the village is the hotel, fairly sound considering its age. Today it is empty. A few more years will see the last remnants of the Apoinga post office’s mud walls dissolved away. More permanent are twisted jagged lumps of slag to remind us of a remarkable, but shot-lived era of colonial enterprise.

More could be told of Mr Penny and his fear of escaped convicts and his petition for police protection and the challenge to his patent by the mighty Patent Smelting Co.

90, 25 (2), 27 June 1967, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Weather

Hailstones from the storm a fortnight ago were still intact after fourteen days. Large volumes of hailstones washed up against fences and collected in watercourses. The survival of the hail was first noticed by Messrs Richard Riggs and Brian Woodman when repairing sections of damaged fencing on the property of B.A. Riggs at the end of last week; some 8-10 days after the storm. Some hail remained where it had been washed along the fencing with silt. The main area, however, still to be seen, is around the edge of a dam on P.J. Thomas’s property adjoining that of Mr Riggs. During the week a large tin of hail was brought in by Bruce Woodman and many people observed its contents at the Record office. Mr Riggs also had a container of them till Monday. Inspection yesterday at 1.30 p.m. found quite a large mass of the hailstones still present at the water’s edge. Though the top was covered by a slight layer of silt, the whole mass is fully exposed to the weather and a handful of singular crystal ice particles was easily obtained. A phone call to the Bureau of Meteorology confirmed that this was an uncommon event and the temperature would have to be constantly 40°F or below for them to have survived for so long. Also in the debris from the flood Messrs Riggs & Woodman found a large number of frogs, toads and small snakes up to two feet long. The hailstones look like being there for some time yet.

M.E. & E.M. Mitchell’s clearing sale on23 June was a great success with a total clearance of all machinery and furniture.

Burra Burra Show Inc. With the resignation of A.R. Graham as Secretary, Julie Sara has been appointed to fill the position.

Burra Rural Youth held a progressive tea and navigational trial on 19 June. Soup was at Mr Neil’s cheerful kitchen (near Farrell Flat), then the participants moves on to Mr & Mrs [illegible] and Mr & Mrs Nicholls at Blink Bonnie with sweets at Mr & Mrs Kitch Miller’s at Hallett. Dennis Miller and crew in a Falcon were declared winners.

Telephone Services will improve with two additional trunk line channels between Burra & Booborowie from 30 June 1967.

Burra National Trust will host visitors from the Adelaide Branch at the weekend. The visitors will tour Burra’s historic places and be entertained at a buffet tea on Saturday evening (courtesy of the CWA). Work has started on repairs to the back rooms of the Museum and it is hoped these will be ready and in use before the visitors arrive. From February to mid-May 400 persons signed the visitors’ book and besides these there are many who did not sign. Mr Bayfield of Spalding has completed repairs to the pack saddles and the camel saddle given to the Branch.

Mr Alec Ford has donated the pay table from the Burra Mine to the Trust. It is long and narrow and contains approximately ten drawers. It is some 120 years old and is being reconditioned for use by the branch.

Rural Youth held a Merino Stud Tour in the Clare-Burra-Mt Bryan-Hallett districts for two days from 20 June.

Burra Creek area from the Red Bridge to the old swing bridge site is being cleaned up using District Council plant.

Mrs M.E. Mitchell was given a farewell by Burra Bowling Associates on Tuesday evening. She was a founding member and has three times been club champion.

Obituary. Mrs Alice Barrett died at the Burra Hospital.

[Born Alice Invermay Whitbread 21 July 1895 Mallala: died 26 June 1967 Burra. Wife of Alfred Stanley Barrett.]

Obituary. At Booborowie we hear of the death of Harold Robert Ramage aged 74.

[Born 29 November 1892 Adelaide: died 23 June 1967 Booborowie.]

Mr & Mrs Milton Mitchell have left Burra to live at Dernancourt.

Mr & Mrs Andy Graham leave Burra for Kangaroo Island on Thursday.

John & Nelda Bruce are leaving Leighton for Bungaree via Brinkworth.

Michael Jones has passed the final exams of his apprenticeship with three credits in five subjects.

THE BOTTOM OF COLUMN 7 UNDER BENCE’S ADVT. IS MISSING

90, 25 (2), 27 June 1967, page 8 [Number used before in 1961.]

F.M. Jefferies has written again from Argentina and a précis of the letter is printed.

CWA Burra Branch AGM is reported from 16 June. Thirty members attended. President Mrs E.T. Baulderstone reported on a successful year. [Secretary Jennifer Ford’s report is printed in just under 1 column of detail.]

Average attendance was 25.

Highlight of the year was the birthday party with the State President Mrs Zerbe as guest speaker.

The Warnes Group Conference was held at Burra this year in April with members from 16 branches present. The CWA did not cater this year for the Burra Races and fund raising efforts were a street stall, an apron afternoon, an oil heating demonstration and the monthly trading table.

During the year a plaque was put on the Mrs A.L. Kellock memorial gate. (She was a foundation member.)

The appearance of the rest room has been enhanced by the gravel surrounds (given and spread by R.W. Humphrys) and the gay kitchen curtains made and hung by Mrs S. Scroop. Mrs A.B. Riggs has maintained the UK links. Mrs A. Phillips aided by Mrs Gallagher has continued the weekly hospital visits.

Elected were: President, Mrs E.T. Baulderstone; Vice-Presidents, Mrs H. Jennison and one yet to be elected; Secretary, Mrs R. Jeffery and Treasurer, Mrs H. Crump.

90, 26 (2), 4 July 1967, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Weather. The first six months of 1967 were the driest start to a year on record, with just 246 points recorded.

The hailstones reported last week as surviving are still in evidence, though much reduced by melting and disturbances from visitors.

Burra Camera Club. The Johnny Green Theatrette is nearing completion and only needs to be painted.

Burra Town Council Election

West Ward Extraordinary Vacancy R.A. Moreland 48

R.G. Allen 27

Art Exhibition. Paintings at the Clare Town Hall this week feature, among locally prepared works, two aspects of the well-known property ‘Mackerode’ by Sydney artist Mr Robert Liddicoat ASTC. As well as this artist’s work others featured include Lionel Bull MVAS of Melbourne and Alan Kidd of Queensland and original oils by London artist Jon Peaty.

The new bridge at Gully’s Wharf was opened for traffic last week. The approaches will be allowed to consolidate before they are sealed.

Accidents

A car driven by Gregory J. Adam of Tea Tree Gully overturned on the Booborowie-Spalding Road at about 5.30 p.m. on Saturday when a rear tyre blew out. The driver and passengers Misses Raelene Hood, Judith Beinke and Sandra Williams were not injured.

At about 6.30 p.m. a car driven by Mr Roy Popplewell of Cappeedee rolled over in loose gravel on the way to the station from Hallett. Neither the vehicle nor the driver suffered damage.

At about 2.45 p.m. Saturday a car driven by Mrs Trenowden of Hanson rolled over on the Farrell Flat-Clare Road about seven miles from Clare. The car was extensively damaged, but neither the driver nor her children passengers were seriously injured.

Burra Swimming Pool had an operating probity for the last season with an income of $2,071.41 and costs of $1,474.35 giving a profit of $597.06. Loan repayments and interest charges, however, amounted to $656.72, leaving a deficit of $59.66. The balance of the outstanding loan is at present $3,548.58.

90, 27 (2), 11 July 1967, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Women’s LCL Branch AGM. Elected: President, Mrs J. Drew; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames Pearse & Miller; Secretary, Mrs R. Collins and Assistant Secretary, Mrs I. McWaters.

[Mr Condor Laucke’s address is reported in 1 column.]

The Miss Australia Ball at Mt Bryan on Friday was a big success with door takings of over $200 and after expenses a tidy profit should result for local entrant Miss Katie Treweeke.

Weather. Some useful rain in the week delivered up to 30 points, but this is still not enough to complete seeding operations.

90, 27 (2), 11 July 1967, pages 1 & 6 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Bowling Club held its AGM on 5 July with C.L. Phillips in the chair.

Elected: Patron, D. Jacka; President, C.L. Phillips; Vice-Presidents, M. Stockman & C. Dare; Secretary, D. Field continues pro tem and Treasurer, H. Crump.

The club resolved to forward to the MNBA a notice of motion seeking the Association be divided into a First and Second Division and that the Association lay down conditions of play for the Champion of Champion rinks and singles events. Congratulations were extended to Stan Woollacott for winning the veterans’ event, which had not been finalised on closing day. The President reported that most clubs seemed dissatisfied with the arrangements for a minor round with play-offs through semi-finals, finals and a grand-final for the pennant competition and changes are desirable for the 1967-68 season. Burra Blue reached the semi-finals. The greens were first class this year, especially later in the season. Thanks go to Dudley Jacka for this and to Charlie Dare for looking after watering, assisted by Joe Lloyd and also to Joe Lloyd, Bill Corner and Merv Burt for cutting and rolling. Club tournaments seem to start too late and this causes a rush to finish them before the season closes. An earlier start seems desirable. Valued members who have left the district are Alex Ford and Milton Mitchell and Bill Teague is also moving on.

90, 27 (2), 11 July 1967, page 3 [Number used before in 1961.]

Accident. A car driven by Robert John Evans, Postal Officer of Burra and one driven by Ronald Keith McWaters, sailor based at Nowra NSW, collided at the junction of Commercial and Market Streets [?] on 10 July. Neither driver suffered injury.

90, 27 (2), 11 July 1967, page 7 [Number used before in 1961.]

Miss Gertrude M. Jordan of Ashford NSW wrote to ‘Mrs Maggs’. She said she left Burra School in 1898 and worked her way through various teaching appointments in NSW to retire as a headmistress. She is the only surviving member of the original Jordan Family of Burra.

[The children in the family were:

  1. William Edgar JORDAN

Burra Pound will be re-activated following the r-emergence of a straying stock problem.

Accident. At about 8 p.m. on Friday a car driven by Mr Graham Wiseman of Campbelltown overturned at the junction of the Burr-Adelaide and the Burra-Farrell Flat Roads. The driver escaped injury, but the damage to the car was estimated at $400.

90, 29 (2), 25 July 1967, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Theft. The Burra Motor Co. was broken into on Friday night and electrical goods and motor accessories to the value of $256 were stolen. Entrance was effected through breaking a window in the Lubritorium close to Burra Creek. The safe was interfered with, but nor opened.

Football Trophies. The Caltex Oil Co. awarded trophies to:

Barry Eberhard Best & Fairest ‘A’ Grade Player (A gold watch)

J. Dewhirst North Eastern 1st Eighteen

D. Sommerville North Eastern 2nd Eighteen

G. Coombe Northern Areas 1st Eighteen

T. Beare Northern Areas 2nd Eighteen

Leighton School began a series of discussions on the ‘New Maths’ for parents on Thursday night.

Young People of Burra were addressed by Rev. David Merriman at a social evening on Friday night. He talked on young people confronting the conformity of the day. The evening included a number of musical items and concluded with dancing. Rev. Merriman is a Baptist minister from Semaphore. A collection of district clergy also attended.

Note that pages were printed in the order: 1, 6, 7, 4, 5, 2, 3, 8.

Mt Bryan CWA celebrated its 21st anniversary with a luncheon. About 40 people attended, including eight of the foundation members. [Details in c. 1⁄2 column.]

Burra Primary School held Arbor Day on Friday. It was also a visiting day at the school. Mr R. Moreland addressed the students as Chairman of the School Committee. Fourteen trees were planted at the school oval.

Advt. Burra Pictures, 29 July

Debbie Reynolds in The Singing Nun

Ricardo Montalban in Tarzan

90, 29 (2), 25 July 1967, page 8 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Red Cross held its 49th AGM in the Mayor’s Parlour on 11 July at 2.30 p.m. In the year a record sum of $301.26 had been raised for Red Cross purposes. Elected: President, Mrs Crump; Vice-Presidents; Mesdames Baulderstone & R. Pearse; Secretary, Mrs J. Murphy and Treasurer, Mrs A. Wright. [Details in c. 1 column.]

Obituary. Mrs Alice Barrett died 26 June 1967. She was the wife of Rev. A. Stanley Barrett and came from the Whitbread family of Mallala. She had been a tower of strength to her late husband, especially during his early ministry on the West Coast. With her husband, she raised a large amount of money for the wider church through their musical abilities with the chimes of bells. Her husband was forced to retire prematurely due to ill health and together they spent their retirement in Burra.

90, 30 (2), 1 Aug. 1967, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Decimal Currency. From today the dual currency period ends; six months earlier than originally contemplated. From today all sales, contracts and legal documents must be in dollars and cents. All payments must be in terms of dollars and cents. Advertisers are urged to drop the use of £.s.d from today. Old notes and coins remain legal tender for the payment of amounts expressed in dollars and cents. Halfpennies, pennies and threepences can be used in lots worth six pence, which is equivalent to 5 cents. Old coins are being replaced. The vast majority of accounting, and adding machines and cash registers have already been converted. Petrol pumps and scale conversion is just over 50%. (Petrol pumps are at about 60 %.)

Weather. Patchy, but useful rain has been reported ranging from 26 points at World’s End through 39 at Burra and 50 points at Farrell Flat. Robertstown received only 19. Between 7 and 8 a.m. yesterday both Hallett and Mt Bryan reported light snow accompanied in some places by hail.

Mid North Bowls Association held its AGM at Hallett 26 July. It was decided that the pennant competition would be decided by a points system instead of by semi-finals and finals. [Further details of the meeting extend for 2⁄3 column.]

90, 30 (2), 1 Aug. 1967, page 2 [Number used before in 1961.]

Terry Opie and wife Faye were farewelled at the home of his mother, Mrs Norm Lihou before he leaves on a tour of duty with the RAAF in Malaysia for two years.

Mary McDonald of Leighton has completed her final nursing exams and is working at the Queen Elizabeth Hospital where in January she will begin training in midwifery.

Birth. To Gloria & John Rowe of Burra at Burra Hospital on 27 July, a son, Ricky John.

Obituary. Mrs Lisle Pearce died on Friday, just a week after celebrating her Golden Wedding.

90, 30 (2), 1 Aug. 1967, page 8 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Rural Youth Annual Report compiled by Past-President Phil Lannon.

The stand at the Burra Show was a creditable effort by the members and the Show Dance went well.

There were successful dances on Christmas Eve and Easter Saturday. A concert early in 1967 aided the Burra Hospital. Inter-club activities have increased and included:

A visit by Gawler for the Burra Show weekend.

A sporting evening with the Crystal Brook Club.

A bowls night with the Clare Club.

A visit by Saddleworth Club for our Christmas Social

A visit to Pt Lincoln over the Queen’s Birthday Holiday weekend.

Burra also hosted the Stud Merino Tour and again reached the finals in Zone Debating, only to be defeated by Gladstone.

[Lannon continues to detail their agricultural, cultural and social program.]

Through the year numbers on the roll increased from 49 to 63. Average attendance has been 40 in recent months.

Richard Riggs was a successful applicant for the Beef Stud Tour.

Geoff Dare was awarded a Leader’s Badge.

Bob Neill and Geoff Dare hosted an overseas visitor, Bill Hamilton.

Mary Woollacott won the Public Speaking at the Spalding Rally and now proceeds to the State Finals.

90, 30 (2), 1 Aug. 1967, page 8 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Branch M & BHA held its AGM and elected: President, Mrs P. Biggs; Vice President, Mrs Maria Norton; Secretary, Mrs Di Beinke; Assistant Secretary, Mrs B. Christie and Treasurer, Mrs J. Bowden.

The 10th Annual Report recorded an average of 43 babies at the monthly clinic.

Fund-raising for the year centre upon a ‘Parade of Fashion’ in April. This raised $75.80 and the annual badge day in November raised $21.68.

90, 31 (2), 8 Aug. 1967, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Racing Club AGM was held and Mr W. Brown of ‘The Grove’ Stud was elected Chairman. Andrew Tennant was elected Patron. Race dates for this year are Wednesday 13 September. And Saturday 21 October. The committee is calling for new members in the face of falling numbers of financial members in the past year.

Mr John Robert Barker marked the 50th anniversary of his elected as a Trustee of the Church of St Mary the Virgin on 7 August. This is the longest anyone has held this position in the local church. The family has a long association with the church, both in England and Australia and has always taken a keen interest in all church affairs. His late father William Pitt Barker was also a Trustee of St Mary’s. Mr Barker is a widower who lives with his two step-daughters, Priscilla and Catherine Brown at the Baldina Homestead. To commemorate the occasion Mrs Sibly entertained Mr Barker and the other Trustees at the Rectory on Sunday.

Accident. On Saturday night Mr Peter Fiebig and Miss Marilyn Anderson were travelling to the Clare ‘Drive-in’ [Cinema] when just after the Farrell Flat railway crossing they were confronted by a car on the wrong side of the road. At the last minute Peter swung right and his car was just clipped by the other vehicle causing it to overturn. Both young people escaped with bruises and a shaking. Mr & Mrs Thurgood of the Bon Accord Hotel were following close behind and also had to swerve off the road to avoid the oncoming car, which did not stop.

Accident. On 1 August a car driven by Mr Tibor Vesz damaged the ‘Keep Left’ standard at the commencement of the median strip in Market Square. He was not injured, but the damage to the car was put at $80.

Theft. Last Tuesday night thieves broke into the Burra Golf Clubhouse and stole goods to the value of $120. Electric strip heaters were taken from the walls, along with an electric kettle, cutlery, linen and cool drinks.

Leighton School celebrated Arbor Day last Friday. Six trees were planted in continuation of a plan for the planting of native trees in the school grounds.

90, 31 (2), 8 Aug. 1967, page 4 [Number used before in 1961.]

Football

‘A’ Grade Clare South 10.11 defeated Spalding 9.8

Booborowie 15.13 defeated Hallett 5.9

Burra 9.15 defeated Clare North 6.11

Burra North Red Cross held its AGM and elected President, Mrs I. Hirschausen; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames H. Jennison & V. Cox; Secretary, Mrs R. Thamm, Assistant Secretary, Mrs Henderson and Treasurer, Mrs S. Scroop.

The last year was successful with an average attendance of 13. In August a street stall raised $40.42. Catering for the Masonic Ball in October raised $100.70. Headquarters was given $400 to purchase a medikit to send to Asia. Eight Christmas cakes were sent for distribution to sick ex-servicemen and women. $220 was sent to Headquarters for their March Appeal.

90, 31 (2), 8 Aug. 1967, page 7 [Number used before in 1961.]

Dianne Williams of Burra is leaving Richardson’s Beauty Salon to take up nursing at Kate Cocks Memorial Babies’ Home.

Mr & Mrs Art Barker have left Burra North for Crystal Brook where Art will be Far Northern Supervisor for the Highways Department. He was three years on the Woomera-Pt Augusta Road and in June 1952 was foreman of the Burra Gang. In 1955 he took over the North Eastern Gang with 1,300 miles of road and in 1966 became supervisor of Northern Roads with 6,500 miles to cover, worked for the E & WS Department by 100 men.

Advt. Burra Pictures, 12 August

Omar Sharif, Alec Guinness, Tom Courtney, Geraldine Chaplin & Julie Christie in Dr Zhivago

90, 32 (2), 15 Aug. 1967, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Weather. Rain and hail in the last week brought varied falls across the district from 59 points at Spalding to 89 at Mt Bryan. Burra managed 75 points.

Polio Vaccine. The first batch of Oral Sabin Vaccine will be available at Burra Hospital 25 August.

Burra Camera Club will join forces with Ian Auhl on Saturday to take photographs of places of historical interest in Burra.

Theft. Tyres worth $700 were stolen from the premises of G.R. O’Connor & Co. of Burra, last week.

Burra Kindergarten is becoming more attractive. A stalwart group of women have been painting the inside. There is an enrolment of 47 children. A successful luncheon in July had a guest speaker from the Welfare Department and raised $120.

The Burra to Adelaide Cycle Race was held last Saturday. It was won by 56-year-old Keith Thurgood for the second time. He had previously won it in 1935 and until 1967 the race had never been won twice by the same rider. The route started in Burra, went five miles towards Mt Bryan and returned via Burra and the Main Adelaide Road to Elizabeth and on to the finish at Modbury via Golden Grove Road. Riders faced a fierce head wind for much of the way. Results:

K. Thurgood (14 minutes)

I. Hennig (14 minutes)

The fastest time was by K. Smoker of Whyalla in 4 hours 18 minutes and he was also the first country rider to finish.

90, 32 (2), 15 Aug. 1967, page 7 [Number used before in 1961.]

‘Mrs Maggs’ reported that the ‘child gathering wildflowers’ version of the discovery of copper at Burra on 12 June 1845 came from a ‘prominent ladies magazine’.

Rev. Philip Potter, now President of the Methodist Conference of SA, is visiting Burra after an absence of 25 years. He was in Burra from April 1941 to April 1942.

Obituary. Mr Reg. Warnes, formerly of Burra and Woolgangi Station and recently of Glenelg, died last week.

Obituary. Mrs Laurie Clode died last Friday aged 72.

[Constance May Clode (second wife) died 12 August 1967 St Peters.]

90, 33 (2), 22 Aug. 1967, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Weather. Last week excellent follow-up rains delivered 50-100 points across both the agricultural country and the eastern pastoral area. Burra 48 points, Spalding 100, Mt Bryan 88, World’s End 54, Koomooloo 60, Balah 35 and ‘The Gums’ 84 points.

Football. Mid North Association Sunday Mail Medal has gone to Brenton Kluska of Auburn Football Club. In 1966 L. Ackland of the same club won the award.

In the ‘B’ Grade the Jenner Trophy again went to Barry Dixon, Captain-Coach of Manoora.

In the Colts the Twartz Trophy was won by Bernie Schroeder of Riverton.

The Burra High School Ball was held at the Burra Town Hall on Friday night and was very successful. The ‘Astronotes’ provided the music. The Parents and Friends’ Association sponsored the event and arranged a sumptuous supper. Peter Morris of the High School staff was a capable MC.

Geoff Dare of Mt Bryan East has won a trip to the USA next year. He is 21 and a prominent Rural Youth Club member, being President 1965-66. He recently won a Leadership Badge and was a member of the Burra ‘A’ Grade Debating Team. He is editor of the Zone Magazine ‘Maunari’. There were 70 applicants for three trips.

[The selection process is described.]

Accidents

Two minor collisions occurred in the week.

On Friday about noon a utility driven by C.F. Pearce collided with one driven by Mr E. Heinrich on the main road near Richard’s Garage.

At 6.50 p.m. a sedan driven by Mr C.H. Nourse collided with another driven by Mr R. W. Coventry at the Junction of Market and Commercial Streets near the Post Office.

Paskeville Rural Youth were guest of the Burra Club over the weekend. They went to a Saturday evening dance at Leighton and had a barbecue dinner on Sunday and indulged in sports as well as visiting places of interest around the town.

90, 33 (2), 22 Aug. 1967, page 3 [Number used before in 1961.]

Lutheran Church. The amalgamation of the United Evangelical Lutheran Church and the Evangelical Lutheran Church became effective on 1 January 1967. Parishes have been re-aligned and congregations united where both churches existed in the same town. An amalgamation took place between Clare and Blyth. As a result a number of churches were closed. In SA fifteen closed in January. Some of the closed churches became halls, some were sold to other denominations and some that were moveable were transferred to areas where no Lutheran congregations existed. Yesterday morning a timber-framed asbestos church 44 ft by 18 ft plus the front porch was moved by Low Loaders Ltd from Hansen [sic] Road Woodville Gardens to Burra. It arrived in good shape and was positioned on a block of land on the corner of Morehead Street and the road leading to the old Reformatory. [Actually the corner of Ludgvan and Tregony Streets.] Two men managed to unload and set the building in position in four hours. Furnishings had already been redistributed, so the Burra congregation is seeking necessary items from other closed churches and some fine donations have already been received. The Burra congregation numbers only about twenty at present and is part of the Clare-Blyth Parish served by Pastor H.H. Schmidt of Blyth. Services are held fortnightly and up ti now have been in St Mary’s Parish Hall. The new building should be ready for use in about eight weeks.

Rev. P.N. Potter, President of the Methodist Conference of SA, visited Burra last Wednesday. 160 guests welcomed him and his wife at the Redruth Hall where he met the Chairman of the Middle District, Rev. W. Stafford & Mrs Stafford. Also in the official party were Rev. & Mrs Lind, Mr & Mrs B.P. Thamm and Mr R.M. Farrow who acted as MC. Mr Thamm as Senior Circuit Steward welcomed the guests and the Mayor Mr E.T. Baulderstone also extended a welcome on behalf of the Town Council. Rev. Stafford briefly explained the workings of the Middle District and Rev. Potter gave an address. He had been stationed in Burra some 26 years ago. Rev. Potter’s address was on Church Union. It is hoped a Union of Presbyterian, Congregational and Methodist Churches will be finalised by 1971. There are about 24 united parishes at present. He also spoke on the need to adapt forms of worship for the young and for some new twentieth century hymns.

Colts Burr14.7 defeated Hallett 5.1

Junior Colts Burra 10.7 defeated Hallett 0.1

Burra History: According to a ‘women’s weekly paper’ of 14 June 1967 in an article by Bill Beatty.

In 1845 when the colony was only seven years old and on the verge of ruin a child gathering wildflowers brought news of a patch of pretty blue ground in a valley called Burra Burra, near where she lived. Her father investigated and found traces of copper, then worth a king’s ransom. Miners were brought from Wales, Spaniards and mules from South America and for the next twenty years 1,000 men were employed on a twenty-four hour shift that yielded copper worth millions of dollars. Today they are a memory and the Burra is a centre of a farming and pastoral area.

Ian Auhl writes commenting on the article.

While it is true that the Burra Mine did save the young colony from ruin, the other aspects of the above article are wrong. The colony was nine years old not seven. The mine opened on 29 September 1845 with the firing of the first blast and closed on 29 September 1877 with the dismissal, with a day’s notice, of 360 men employed. The mine thus had a life of 32 years rather than 20. Miners came largely from Cornwall rather than Wales, though Welshmen came later to work in the smelting works of the English & Australian Copper Co. The story of the discovery seems to have been confused with that of the Kapunda Mine three years before. Copper was discovered at Burra by the shepherds Streair and Pickett. Streair was working for James Stein who held a pastoral lease along the creek when he found copper near the southern boundary of what is now Section 2 of the Hundred of Kooringa. He kept quiet about it and in June 1845 tried to sell his secret in Adelaide. An Adelaide mining syndicate refused to give him £6 for it. He went to the Rundle Street shop of Bunce & Thomson, where he sold the information to Bunce for £8. Streair then fades out of the story. A company formed under George Kingston (later Sir George) went to investigate the claim and while there heard of another discovery further up the Burra Creek by a shepherd called Thomas Pickett who worked for William Robinson on his ‘Gum Creek’ lease. Pickett had a hut near a spring on Diprose Creek and its ruins are still to be seen on the north bank a little east of the junction of the roads from Kooringa and Aberdeen to Morgan. Neither of the shepherds was married or had wildflower-picking children. Pickett was driving to his hut with provisions from Gum Creek when his wagon wheel broke off a rock to reveal the ‘blue ground’. The discovery soon became widely known and the difficulty then was to find the £20,000 in SA that was needed to purchase the 20,000 acre special survey. Governor grey insisted on payment in gold sovereigns. Neither of the rival companies in SA could raise this much and to forestall a Sydney company waiting in the wings, they united to get the survey. Once the survey was made though, instead of combining, they drew lots to see who should have Streair’s find and who should have Pickett’s discovery. In the long run the SA Mining Association obtained Pickett’s discovery and made £5,000,000. The rival Princess Royal Mining Co. got Streair’s find and lost £5,000. Streair made £8, which in the final analysis was not a bad result for a failed mine. Pickett received a bonus from the SA Mining Association of £1 per week for life. He continued as a shepherd on Gum Creek Run about eight miles north of the mine and a few years later was burnt to death. He was buried at Kooringa, probably in the old cemetery across the creek from the present Burra Cemetery. Perhaps the names of the shepherds will live on and Burra like Kalgoorlie with, Paddy Hannan, will have a statue to its discoverer. When the mine was a success Pickett was sent for and asked what he desired as a reward and it was his choice to opt for £1 a week and a team of bullocks. He ended tragically. After buying a small keg of rum he went off in his dray and the next morning some drovers found the burnt fragments of the vehicle, the iron hoops of the keg and beneath it the charred remains of the old shepherd.

90, 33 (2), 22 Aug. 1967, page 6 [Number used before in 1961.]

Accident. A car driven by Stewart S. Meyer of Andrews overturned on Flagstaff Hill on the Burra-Booborowie Road on Thursday. The car was travelling north on the Copperhouse Stock Road and failed to take the corner at ‘Flagstaff’. The driver was unhurt and a passenger, John Hancock, suffered bruising.

Accident. A utility driven by Christopher M. Reed collided with a car parked alongside of it while he was reversing from the kerb at the Burra Town Hall on Saturday night. Only minor damage resulted.

Weather. Showery conditions have produced 27 points at Burra over the weekend.

Redruth Gaol

The Burra Town Council has received a grant of $475 from the Government for the preservation of Redruth Gaol. After a meeting between representatives of the Council and the National Trust it was decided to remove boxthorns and the present fences and then to re-fence the area granted to the Council, to renovate the façade and to give the building a facelift inside and out and to build an access ramp to the property. The Tourist Bureau believes Burra has sufficient buildings to make it a first class tourist attraction. Tours to Burra will be the next step to be organised. The Corporation and the National Trust consider these moves are in the best interests of the town and deserve general support.

Redruth Gaol and Reformatory: Some Historical Notes by Ian Auhl.

The Gaol is important because it was the first to be erected in a country area. This was because in the 1840s there were no other country towns of any size in SA. The population of the Mine area rose to 5,000 between 1845 and 1850. The population of Adelaide at the time was not much more than 20,000. Redruth Police Station was erected in the late 1840s in the Government Town of Redruth, rather than in the SA Mining Association town of Kooringa. A temporary gaol was built on the police block with stables for the police mounts and an exercise yard and cells. This building still stands with a shingle roof, covered now with iron. The new official gaol was built in 1856 at a cost of c. £3,800. It included a residence for the Gaoler and two Turnkeys, with a kitchen, wash-house and storeroom. There were three sells for males and three for females. The cells were ceiled with four inch gum planks to prevent escapes. The first Gaoler was Mr T. Perry (his wife was Annie). (The present Tom and Anne Perry disclaim any relationship.) The Gaol became known as Perry’s Hotel and this term was even used in the Law Court reports. Mr Perry was keeper 1856-79 and he and his wife are buried in the Burra Cemetery. Messrs Pollitt & Young were Gaol Keepers 1880-84 and Mr Criddle took over from 1885 till closure in 1894. In 1858 Mr Perry complained that the Gaol was overcrowded with ‘prisoners and lunatics’. Gaol sentences were handed out for offences that now would warrant only a fine and the court was always crowded to hear the details of the more horrible or salacious offences. Court reports of the day were detailed and left nothing to the imaginations. Today such reporting would bring action for libel. When the Gaol closed in 1894 there were suggestions it could be used as an abattoirs and a freezing works. For a few years it was occupied by the Woollacott family and Mr Stan Woollacott was born in it. In 1897 it was renovated and became a Girls’ Reformatory. The girls arrived in December 1897. There was fist, second and third class accommodation. The more incorrigible girls were sent from Adelaide. About 30 girls were house, some as young as 15. They worked in the garden, laundry, kitchen, rooms and the wood heap. From time to time there were escapes. The first matron was Mrs Holden and there was a sib-matron and a wards woman. The cost was recorded as 17/53⁄8 per girl per week. The place was grim and forbidding as is its story.

90, 33 (3), 29 Aug. 1967, page 5 [Number used before in 1961 & 1967.]

Burra Hospital AGM

Chairman Mr R.K. Pearse reported that the general layout of phase three of the building project had been approved and tenders will be called soon for submission to the Chief Secretary. Phase 3 of the original plan is expected to cost up to $100,000. At present hospital funds are in credit $24,000. Phase 2, the middle section of the building, was completed at a cost of $14,000 from the hospital’s own resources, as were the complete exterior repainting and repairs at a cost of $9,000.

Mr Baulderstone congratulated the Chairman and the Board on the improvements made over the last four years.

The Chairman reported a sound financial position. The overdraft had been reduced by $2,142 to $5,991 and there is an overall credit balance of $24,114.

Repairs and replacements have risen by $6,743.

Patient fees have risen by $4,647 and Government subsidy and Council contributions are up by $1,304.

The daily average of Inpatients increased by 0.3 to 16.3.

This has helped keep average costs under control.

The collection of patient fees is 98%.

Births fell by 7 to 43.

[He then lists a number of items bought to improve the hospital’s equipment.]

A major program of maintenance cost $9,000. [This is then detailed.]

The third phase is the building on the old Burra Hotel site of the theatre and casualty wing and turning the old theatre block into domestic quarters and a sewing room. The Mining Company has been consulted before drawing up these plans. When the new Theatre Wing – ‘which I recommend to the incoming Board be known as the Alice Collins Wing’ – is completed, we will have a most up-to-date hospital. We must acknowledge the great help in planning given by the Director General of Medical Services, Dr Rollison and architects Stapleton, McMichael and Loveday.

In the cropping program this year there is only about 30 acres under crop, thanks to Don Stockman and land leased from the Burra Council. Mr Tom Rogers has sown 50 acres of Hanson Reserve to clover. Last year we received $1,416 from wheat sales.

The Auxiliary remains active and the maintenance of the linen and the stocking of shelves with preserves and jams owes much to them.

The Burra & District Fund Raising Committee raised $850 this year.

The high standard of service and efficiency has been maintained by Matron Fyfe, ably assisted by Sister Taylor and on a part-time basis by Sisters Leedham and Byles.

The trainee nurses have done their jobs well and the cleanliness of the buildings inside and outside is a credit to the domestic staff.

The financial stability of the Hospital has been strengthened by the work of our Secretary-Manager Mr L.H. Packer.

[Acknowledgement of other helpers and donors follows.]

[The whole report occupies some 31⁄2 columns.]

90, 33 (3), 29 Aug. 1967, pages 3 & 6 gutter [Number used before in 1961 & 1967.]

Adelaide Wool Sales. Kia-Ora topped district prices with 593⁄4c. [Other local district prices are printed.]

Burra North Red Cross arranged a screening of Snow White and the Three Stooges on Tuesday last and raised nearly $100.

Burra Town Council has decided on a rate for 1967-68 of 22c in the dollar and a special rate of 12⁄3c in the dollar. This should raise $21,750 compared with $19,418 the previous year. The Council says the increase is needed to keep pace with rising costs.

Florence Scroop writes explaining the ownership of items at the Racecourse Pavilion. The two coppers were donated to the Aberdeen Football Club by two supporters and may be used by anyone holding a function there. The two wood stoves belong to the Aberdeen Football Club Ladies Auxiliary and can be used on written application to Mrs R. Gill or Mrs F. Scroop. The Auxiliary has conditions of cleanliness of oven slides to be adhered to.

Sgt Bill Teague is being transferred to Burnside on 26 September.

90, 35, 12 Sep. 1967, page 2

Burra Town Council

R.K. Baker, Town Clerk, advises owners of land adjoining the private road between Kangaroo Street and Ware Street and bounded on the northeast by part allotments 43 & 47 and on the southwest by other portions of the same allotments, to remove any erection or obstruction on the road or after one month the Council will carry out the work and recover costs from the owners.

90, 35, 12 Sep. 1967, page 6

Seasonal Conditions. Burra rainfall is well below average with the crop outlook grim.

90, 35, 12 Sep. 1967, page 7

Theft. Dinham Brothers premises at Booborowie were broken into yesterday morning. About $1,000 worth of cigarettes and $300 worth of electrical appliances were stolen.

Mr Noel Tiver of Toorak Gardens has celebrated his 70th birthday with a cruise with his wife to Singapore and Kuala Lumpur.

Fiebig Motors’ entry ‘Pirate’ came second in its class at dragster racing at Two Wells on 10 September.

Obituary. John Murphy, late of Burwood, Victoria and formerly of Burra has died.

90, 36, 19 Sep. 1967, page 1

Hallett Red Cross Annual Flower Show was held in the Hallett Institute on Friday and takings were a record $277.

Weather. Showers over five days of the past week brought 52 points of rain to Burra. On Wednesday there was a short, but heavy fall of hail at about 8.55 a.m. It banked up against fences and buildings and lingered till the afternoon. To the east the falls have been only 10-20 points.

Burra Races were held last Wednesday and proved enjoyable, although the winds were at times rather gusty. John Letts, a vastly improved jockey over recent months, created a new record for himself by scoring five wins and a third place from six mounts. [Results are printed.]

Adelaide Wool Sales12 -14 September. District prices were topped by Ulooloo Proprietors at 563⁄4c.

[Other local district prices are printed.]

Football. Trophies were presented at the North Eastern Association Premiership games at Clare on Saturday.

The ‘Ashrose’ Shield went to the Burra Colts.

The Umpires’ Association Medal for the best and fairest in Colts was won by N. Smith of Clare North.

The ANZ Savings Bank Shield for the ‘B’ Grade was won by Clare South.

R. Brandt of Burra won the Gilles Trophy for fairest and most brilliant in ‘B’ Grade.

The Burra Record Trophy went to Don Villis of Booborowie.

The Mobil Oil Trophy and the Mail Medal went to Barry Eberhard of Burra.

90, 36, 19 Sep. 1967, page 3

Football. Burra Senior & Junior Colts held their end of season dinner at the RSL Hall, Burra, on Monday 18 September. Approximately 100 people attended. D. Anderson won the award for best & fairest senior Colt and Robin James was the best and fairest Junior Colt.

90, 37, 26 Sep. 1967, page 1

Burra Tennis Association held its AGM 19 September and elected President, David Jones; Vice-President, John Quinn and Secretary, Trevor Phelps. The season will begin on 14 October.

Aberdeen Tennis Club AGM was held recently and all past officers were re-elected.

Sharon Burke is an International Farm Youth Exchangee from Vermont USA. She is presently staying with Mr & Mrs N.D. Tiver at Hallett and is a guest of the Burra Rural Youth Club. [Other details in a 11⁄2-column article with a photograph.]

The National Trust of SA has organised their first two-day tour to Burra for Saturday 30 September and Sunday 1 October. Waikerie Branch members will also visit Burra that weekend.

Unattended Stock is believed to be causing a problem on roads and stock routes and owners are reminded that depasturing stock on roads is illegal and stock on roads must be accompanied and be moving at a specified rate per day.

90, 37, 26 Sep. 1967, page 2

Advt. Dalgety-NZL offers for sale by tender on instructions from Messrs A.K. & M.A. Hanlin, Section 497 in the Hundred of Anne comprising 187 acres freehold with improvements of a six-roomed stone house etc.

Notice. The street between Ware Street and Kangaroo Street, adjacent to my property is a private street and has been declared so by the court. Unauthorised users will be treated as trespassers. D.A. Bown.

90, 37, 26 Sep. 1967, page 3

Football. The Burra Football Club held its wind-up dinner-dance at Burra Town Hall on Friday night.

Trophies were presented:

‘A’ Grade Fairest & Most Brilliant Barry Eberhard

‘B’ Grade Fairest & Most Brilliant R. Brandt

Forard Medal for Burra Player with most votes for the Mail Medal: Barry Eberhard.

Mt Bryan School students had an excursion to Peterborough (40 students and 20 parents). They visited Mr Bradtberg’s poultry farm where they saw kangaroos, emus, deer, cockatoos, Cape Baron Geese and several types of duck. They also went to the Northern Meat Packing Works and the Peterborough Railway Workshops, which included a ride on a locomotive for seven or eight children at a time.

90, 37, 26 Sep. 1967, page 7

Birth. To Brenda & Don Villis yesterday, a son, Kym Richard.

Birth. To Pat & Rex Hurley, a daughter, Karen Anne.

Mr & Mrs Morgan are welcomed to Burra. Mr Morgan is the new Burra postmaster.

Rosemary Field is the new office girl at Elders.

90, 37, 26 Sep. 1967, page 8

The Hallett Flower Show Prize List is printed.

90, 38, 3 Oct. 1967, page 1

National Trust. The visitors from the city had a very interesting weekend as guests of the Burra Branch. When they arrived in two buses at 12.30 on Saturday they were given a tour by Messrs Auhl and Woollacott. Mrs A.D. Radford showed them around the Museum. The tour covered the town and took them out to Breakneck and Moonlight Hills to give them some idea of the eastern plains and the Murray Scrub. A special display was arranged at the Museum of maps, old newspapers and other items of interest. Burra CWA prepared a buffet style evening meal at the RSL Hall. Mr S.J. Woollacott welcomed the guests as President of Burra & District National Trust. Mr E.T. Baulderstone welcomed the visitors on behalf of residents and spoke of the role of the Town Council in the preservation of the mine precincts and he predicted a great future for the tourist industry. Mr Ian Auhl was guest speaker for the evening. Films taken by Mr John Kingsford –Smith some months ago at Burra were shown. On Sunday morning a visit was made to the Brewery Cellars and some of the group attended the 9.30 a.m. service at St Mary’s, having been shown through it by Rev. Sibly the previous day. Adelaide and Waikerie members of the National Trust gathered with Burra members at Princess Royal at 11 a.m. Misses Josephine Morphett and Alison Wood conducted visitors through the ground floor of the stately home and the garden was enjoyed by all. After lunch at their respective hotels the guests departed for Adelaide at 2 p.m. Waikerie visitors were shown over the town in the afternoon.

Ten O’clock Closing of Hotels was introduced on 28 September, bringing to an end the 6 p.m. closing introduced in 1916. The change was greeted quietly at Burra where hotel proprietors report only a slight increase in sales in the few days since the change. Normal day trade seems not to have been affected. On Thursday night the drinking population appeared to go from one hotel to another and a few curious non-drinkers looked in for the occasion. Friday and Saturday nights are expected to be the busiest when things settle down.

The Burra Show will be held next Saturday. There are record entries in several sections. It will be opened by Hon. C.R. Kelly MHR at 12.45 p.m.

Burra Red Cross street stall on Friday raised $105.

Obituary. Hedley Bradtke Stockman, husband of Xenia, died on 3 October aged 69. He was the father of Avis (Mrs J.N .Clarke), John, Rex and Peter. There are five grandchildren.

[Born 4 April 1898 Hundred of Mannanarie: died 3 October 1967 Broadview Estate, District of Burra.]

90, 38, 3 Oct. 1967, page 5

Aberdeen Tennis Club. President Robert R. reed reported on a successful season at the AGM recently. The club was able to field one ‘A’ Grade team, two ‘B’ Grade and one Junior team in the Burra Tennis Association. The ‘A’ team gained the premiership. The Easter Tournament was a great success, with excellent entries. The club is indebted to Burra High School, Mr & Mrs M. Eberhard and Mr & Mrs I. Hirschausen for the use of their courts, which allowed tournament games to be completed in daylight on the final day. During the year electricity was installed at the clubhouse, a refrigerator was purchased, the front of the clubhouse was enclosed and two small sheds were lined. The clubhouse was also painted inside and out and we thank our Patron, Mr F. Reed, for donating the cost of this painting.
