90, 38, 3 Oct. 1967, page 8

Scotty’s Grave. Reprinted from the Adelaide Chronicle of 15 November 1934. The grave is alongside the road between Marrabel and Kapunda. ‘Scotty’ was among other things paymaster at the Burra Mine and made weekly trips to Adelaide for the Mining Company.

90, 39, 10 Oct. 1967, page 1

90, 39, 10 Oct. 1967, pages 1 & 4

Burra Effluent Drainage Scheme

At a meeting in the Town Hall on 2 October Health Department officers gave an illustrated account of a drainage scheme to dispose of waste water. Messrs Wilson & Smith were representatives at the well-attended meeting. The first such scheme had been a success at Pinnaroo, after which they had been installed at places like Berri, Maitland, Nuriootpa and Barmera. There are thirty more towns at present ready to go ahead with schemes. Rates applicable to cover the original cost are less than the Government sewerage rate. Costs vary from town to town due to varying soils, underground water, rock types, etc. The Central Board of Health will design a scheme; prepare plans, specifications and estimates at no cost to the Council or ratepayers. For Burra they have prepared a scheme designed to cover the business area from the old Post Office to the Hospital, with a capacity for fifty homes or buildings on the south side of Commercial Street. The drain would run from the treatment area at the rear of the Bowling Green, up the lane behind the Post Office, through the lane by the Police Station to Chapel Street, along behind the Commercial Hotel and Hurley’s Road House to Kangaroo Street to the Hospital septic system on the north side of Commercial Street. A connection from Chapel Street to the front of Bence’s premises would then run as far as Dr Miller’s in one direction and to the old Post Office in the other. The treatment portion near the Bowling Green would comprise a biological filter and pond. There would be no odour from the pond. There are already two small biological filters in Burra; one on the creek side of the old Post Office and the other near the Red Bridge behind the Burra Motor Co.’s premises. The stone in the filters lasted a long time – one at Glenelg had not been renewed in 30 years. Mr Topsfield asked about the possibility of a double pond system to take raw sewage. Mr Wilson said this was not recommended because it would cost three times as much. In the unit under consideration it would be necessary to have septic treatment on the individual properties before connection to the main drainage. It could handle laundry, kitchen and ordinary waste water without prior treatment – but would not handle storm water. The cost was estimated at $12,000. This would be a cost of $200 per premises for the initial scheme, which could be extended to the rest of the town later. It was intended to site the drain under the footpaths. Council would have to repair or replace the footpaths involved. It would generally be about four feet from foundations and about four feet deep.

Mr Jacka moved a recommendation the system be enlarged for the whole town and the original treatment tank site be used as a pumping point with a larger oxidation pond further down the creek. Seconded by Mr Topsfield. It was pointed out that the extra surveys etc. would delay the scheme by three or four years. The recommendation was withdrawn on the request of the Chairman E.T. Baulderstone and replaced by a suggestion that the proposed limited scheme be implemented, but the disposal unit be further downstream with a pump behind the Burra Bowling Green and the oxidation pond be large enough to take on the whole town drainage at a later time. On E.T. Baulderstone’s request this was also withdrawn in the interests of not delaying the project. After discussion L. Bence moved a recommendation be made to the Local Board of Health that the scheme as presented be adopted subject to the Central Board investigating the possibility of installing a pump in lieu of the biological filter and determining the availability of land at reasonable cost to install an oxidation pond which would eventually take the effluent from the whole town. This was seconded by Dr Miller.

[Presumably this was carried, though it is not so reported.]

90, 39, 10 Oct. 1967, pages 1 & 6

Burra Show was held last Saturday in perfect weather when a new record in overall entries was created. It was opened by the Hon. C.R. Kelly MHR. [His speech is printed.] Attendance was average and the gate was down at $384 compared with $545 in 1966. Horses in Action entries came from Broken Hill, Adelaide and beyond. Sideshows were fewer than in the past and there was no small merry-go-round for the tiny tots.

90, 39, 10 Oct. 1967, page 7

Obituary. Lindsay Hood has died after being confined to his home for some time.

[Lindsay Hurtle Hood born 5 January 1907 Mt Pleasant: died 6 October 1967 Burra.]

Obituary. Horton Jennison died on Sunday. He was an ex-Mayor and a man vitally interested in all organisations such as the schools, his church and the well-being of all residents.

[Horton Joseph Barraclough Jennison born 30 January 1898 Fiji: died 8 November 1967 Burra.]

Burra Lutheran Church is the site of much work as volunteers are busy setting it to rights.

Birth. To Jeanette & Jim Sullivan at Burra Hospital on Saturday, a son.

Chris & Glenn Tiver of Hallett, Jack Sullivan & John Tiver have gained their pilots’ licences after flying lessons.

90, 40, 17 Oct. 1967, page 1

Burra Mine

The Minister’s reply to a question in Parliament.

Drilling operations by the Department of Mines and the ‘present company’ have not been encouraging. Drilling has proved difficult because the porous nature of the ground has made it hard to keep water on the drill. Both the company and the Mines Department drillers have found this a difficulty, which has threatened the diamond drills when they run hot. At present only one drill is operating to test deeper possibilities. Results so far have not been encouraging. Several million tons of low grade copper have been indicated in the oxidised ‘leavings’ and a feasibility study into the commercial possibilities of treating this is expected to be completed soon.

Accident/Obituary. Two elderly Mt Bryan East residents were killed instantly on Friday at about 2.30 p.m. some four miles north of Mt Bryan when their car collided with a truck laden with sheep skins. The truck was driven by P.G. Dunn of Kilburn and was travelling south. The small sedan was travelling west from the Mt Bryan East road to join the main road. Mr Arthur E. Goodridge (67) a retired labourer was driving the sedan, which was practically destroyed on impact. The driver and passenger, Mary Olive Jean McKay (53), also of Mt Bryan East, were both thrown from the car and are believed to have died instantly. The truck driver swerved right to try to avoid the impact, but the truck rolled over completely after the collision and ended back on its wheels, facing west and blocking the roadway. The driver and six-year-old passenger in the truck seem to have been saved from being crushed by the high load of skins. The young boy received some lacerations and stayed in Burra Hospital overnight for observation.

[Arthur Emmanuel Goodridge born 14 June 1900 Booborowie: died 13 October 1967 near Mt Bryan, residence Mount Bryan East. Mary Olive Jean McKay born 26 February 1914 Loxton: died 13 October 1967 near Mt Bryan, residence Mount Bryan East.]

Burra Bowling Season opened last Saturday. The club paid tribute to two former club champions who died recently within a few days of each other: Horton Jennison and Lindsay Hood.

Accident. On 10 October about 8 p.m. a car driven by George Poulas of Plympton skidded at the intersection of the by-pass road and Koonoona Road and hit a steel pole. The vehicle was extensively damaged and the driver suffered lacerations to his left arm, elbow, leg and nose and bruised kidneys.

90, 40, 17 Oct. 1967, pages 1, 4, 5, 6, & 8

Burra Show: Judges Comments and List of Prize Winners.

Pigeons. On the whole a nice lot.

Champion Pigeon D.A. Schirmer

Champion Fancy T.W. Broad

Champion Utility K.B. Worden

Bantams. A fine display.

Champion T.W. Broad

Poultry. A good display.

Champion was an Old English Cock of C.F. Pearce.

Champion water fowl was a Buff Orpington Duck of J. Coulter.

Budgerigars. Entries were down, but quality was better.

Cooking. The children’s section was particularly good; up the standard of the Adult Class.

Fruit & Vegetables. These sections were small, but of good quality considering the dry season.

Flowers. These were good considering the dry season and especially notable were the Nemesia, Sweet peas, Iceland Poppies, Pelargonium and the cut flowers.

Floral Art. This has improved and the children’s floral designs were really good.

Grain and Fodder entries were few in number, but the quality was very satisfactory.

Goat entries were of a very high standard.

Senior Champion W.L. & N.B. Barker

Needlework entries were excellent and very pleasing in the teenage section.

Farm Produce showed an improvement.

Medium Wool Sheep showed the best quality for many years.

Champion Ewe S.H. & W.N. Wood

Strong Wool Sheep were excellent.

Champion Ram S.H. & W.N. Wood

Champion Ewe S.H. & W.N. Wood

Wool. Fleeces shown were very good and some were outstanding considering the adverse season.

Wool exhibited by K.R. Phillips Ltd was prominent with ten first prizes and seven seconds.

90, 40, 17 Oct. 1967, page 3

LCL Burra & District Women’s Branch held a successful barbecue at Petherton attended by over 200 people.

90, 40, 17 Oct. 1967, page 3 & 6 gutter

Burra Golf Associates held its AGM on 4 October. President Mrs T. Padbury reported on a very satisfactory year. The Zone 36 Open Day on 6 June was enjoyable, though with not as many entries as hoped for. A profit of $33 resulted. Our own open day 29 June also saw a pleasing profit of $58. Congratulations are extended to Club Champion Mrs Nicholls, ‘B’ Grade Champion Mrs Wuttke and ‘C’ Grade Champion Miss Lines. Two thefts during the year of items accumulated over the years were disappointing, but these have been replaced and members reimbursed from the insurance company. An electric stove and twelve new chairs have been added. Elected were: President, Mrs M. Nicholls; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames R. Wuttke & E. Jeffery; Captain Mrs D. Field; Vice-Captain, Mrs L. Braendler; Treasurer, Mrs H. Crump & Secretary, Mrs F.H. Reed.

[Born 24 February 1880 Redruth: died 10 October 1967 Burra North.]

[90, 41, 24 Oct. 1967, page 7. The R. Fuss information was corrected to 82 on 25 October, which was when his birth was registered, though within the family it was always believed to be the 19 October.]

90, 40, 17 Oct. 1967, Supplement

[One-sided 5 columns in width – approximately A4 size.]

Cricket. Mokota Association.

North Booborowie 144 v. Hallett 5 for 160

Booborowie 9 for 122 v. Koonaburra 115

Burra Footballers 1 for 172 v. Mt Bryan 9 for 159

90, 41, 24 Oct. 1967, page 1

Burra Hospital. A start will soon be made on Phase 3 of the building plan and the Board is this week launching an appeal for funds. In this phase a new operating theatre and facilities, casualty room and domestic quarters will replace the old theatre block and old hotel section of the building. The Government has approved the plan and will, as in the past, offer a subsidy on a two for one basis and donations are tax deductible. The approximate cost of the alterations will be $100,000. Funds already held by the Hospital are insufficient to enable completion so an appeal is being made for $25,000. Donations are acknowledged for $2,117.

Burra Races on Saturday proved more successful than in 1966. Gate takings were up $70. The weather was ideal and there were some exciting finishes. CWA ladies provided lunch and afternoon teas. [Results are printed.]

Burra Primary School. Headmaster Mr Ian Auhl, has been transferred for next year to Para Hills west Primary & Infant School. Mr Auhl has been a man most concerned with the welfare of the children in his charge. His replacement will be Miss Marlene Spratt who has been Deputy Headmistress of Northfield Primary School for the past four years. She is something of a pioneer, being the youngest of three women who have been appointed to head larger State Primary Schools. Another change at the school sees Miss Meredith Satchell transferred and she will be replaced by Mrs Carpenter. Mrs Carpenter regrets having to leave the Kindergarten, which she has pioneered through its teething troubles.

Adelaide Wools Sales17-19 October saw Willogoleche top district prices at 565/6c. with Princess Royal at 561⁄2c. and Gum Creek at 56c. [Other local district prices are printed.]

Burra Lutheran Church will be dedicated on 5 November. It was transported on 18 August from Mansfield Park and has since been renovated and refitted. There will be a special service at 2.30 p.m. conducted by Rev. G.O. Minge, President of the Lutheran Church of Australia, SA District, assisted by Rev. A.E. Thiele of Saddleworth, a former Pastor of the Burra Congregation and Rev. A.H. Schmidt, the present pastor. Members have spent many hours setting up the church. The porch had been removed for transportation and was rebuilt. The whole building was repainted. Fittings for the interior have come from other congregations.

The Clare Congregation presented furniture for the sanctuary, of the altar, pulpit, font and an organ.

The Blyth Congregation provided the sanctuary carpet, the aisle runner and the notice board.

Both these congregations are in the same parish as Burra.

The Palmer Congregation gave the pews. These were old and had to be shortened, but are quite comfortable. Seating is provided for more than 80 people.

Robertstown Church donated a fine set of paraments [robes] in the five different colours and a clergy chair.

The history of the Lutheran Church in Burra goes back to 1847 when the mining company brought out a group of smelters from the Hanz mountains [sic: for Harz] in Germany. These and other Germans, who hoped to make their fortunes in copper mining, formed a congregation in 1851 and built [actually began to build] a church near the courthouse. Many of them left, however, in 1852 for the Victorian gold rush. A struggling congregation remained for a number of years. Later the church was rented to a Lodge and was destroyed by fire after one of their meetings on 20 July 1910. [This is an inadequate and misleading summary of the history of the building, which was actually completed only in 1861. It continued to have Lutheran services from visiting pastors as well as being used as the Wesleyan Sunday school for over twenty years, by the Aberdeen Oddfellows’ Lodge and as a general meeting place.] The records show that from 1905 Lutherans living in Burra were served by different pastors. Services were generally conducted in homes of members of the congregation and alternated between Booborowie and Mt Bryan. Later services were commenced at Flagstaff. In 1939 services were conducted at Burra when the congregation rented the old Copperhouse Methodist Church. [Actually the Westbury Methodist Church.] Then at the end of 1940 it moved to the old Westbury Church in Burra, where it worshipped till the building became unsafe. [This is incorrect. The church used in Burra North was Jubilee Hall, the former Primitive Methodist Chapel and later the Methodist Sunday school. But the dates are also incorrect.] The congregation then transferred to St Mary’s [Anglican] Parish Hall where the last service was held on 22 October. The present minister is Pastor A.H. Schmidt who lives at Blyth. It is planned to hold services fortnightly with lay readers on alternate weeks. Chairman of the Congregation is Mr Edgar Pietsch and the secretary/Treasurer is Rupert Kleinig.

[A photograph of the church before it was moved from Mansfield Park is printed.]

[This account is rather inaccurate. After the 1910 fire the places for services were:

1911-1921 Jubilee Hall, Burra North, formerly the Primitive Methodist Zion Chapel.

1922-27 At private homes at Mt Bryan & Booborowie

1927-34 At private homes at Mt Bryan & Flagstaff

1934-39 At a private home at Flagstaff

1939 From August 1939 to 1947 at the former Westbury Methodist Church (adjacent to Copperhouse). The church actually in Copperhouse was a Primitive Methodist Church, which had become the Copperhouse School.

1947-57 The Oddfellows’ Lodge Hall at Burra North.

1957-67 St Mary’s Anglican Parish Hall

Please refer to the book History of the Lutheran Church in Burra 1851-2007, compiled by Ron Smedley, Barb. Secomb & Jack Kleinig and published in 2007 to mark the 40th anniversary of St John’s Evangelical Lutheran Church in Burra, for a more reliable account of the history of the Burra Lutheran Congregation.]

90, 41, 24 Oct. 1967, page 2

Editorial. There is a rare editorial article printed two columns wide by 2⁄3 column on the subject of the need for a Commonwealth funded drought relief scheme for farmers.

Burra Small Bore Club. On Tuesday evening best over double 25 yards were R. Gilbert, J. Bowden & A. Angel.

Best over double 50 yards were M. Thomas, L. Moore & R. Gilbert.

Obituary. Mr Horton Joseph Barraclough Jennison

Mr H.J.B. Jennison died at Burra Hospital on 8 October at the age of 69. He was one of the town’s best known and most respected businessmen, citizens and philanthropists. He first came to Burra in 1914 when his father was appointed minister of the Redruth Methodist Circuit. Later he married Miss Reta Thomas, daughter of Mr & Mrs H.H. Thomas of Aberdeen. Mr Ray Jennison of Burra is a son and two daughters, Barbara and Josephine are married and living in Melbourne. Another daughter, June, is deceased. Mr Jennison established the firm of Jennison’s Tyre Service in Commercial Street and was an active partner in the firm up to the time of his death. Mr Jennison loved his family, his town, his country, his church and his fellow men. For two years in the 1940s he was Mayor of Burra. He was always dignified, loyal and eloquent, making him a capable Mayor whose service will not be forgotten. He was one of the forces behind the establishment of the Mar Memorial improvement Committee and rendered valuable service as a Justice of the Peace.

Mr Jennison was a volunteer for service in both World Wars. The continued welfare of ex-servicemen was close to his heart and he was active in the local RSL sub-branch, serving as its President for some time. He was also most dutiful in attending to the needs and education of Legacy wards. He gave more than a fair share of his time to local schools. For many years he was a member of the Primary School Committee and of the High School Council, being Chairman of the latter from 1953-64. When the present House System was established at the High School in 1961 he consented to have one of the Houses named after him. One of the last memories many students will have of him will be his presence at their sports day this year, urging on his House.

He was an ardent Lodge man, being a member of several. He was Right Worshipful Brother in the Grand Mark Lodge and Lodges were well represented at his funeral. He was a staunch member of the Redruth Methodist Church and since its amalgamation with the Kooringa Circuit, of the new Burra Circuit. He was a Church steward and Circuit Steward for Redruth 1939-42 and Secretary of the Redruth Trust, which he served for many years, from 1951 till his death. He was born on the Mission Fields of Fiji and was the local Secretary for Overseas Missions for a long period. The funeral was held most appropriately at the Redruth Church, which he had loved so well.

[Horton Joseph Barraclough Jennison born 30 January 1898 Fiji: died 8 November 1967 Burra.]

90, 42, 31 Oct. 1967, page 1

Burra Hospital: Work begins on Phase III

Local contractors, Hirschausen Bros., M.G. Wardle and D.T. Jacka & Co., are demolishing the old hotel building.

Mr Ian Auhl has delved into the history of the building. Ninety years ago on Tuesday 27 February 1877 rain and nature seemed determined to upset the arrangements of humanity. A half holiday had been declared and the town was looking forward to a day of celebration with ‘a grand blow-out’ to follow and a concert in the new Institute at night. Eminent visitors arrived by train the night before for the double event of the opening of the Burra Hospital and the laying of the foundation stone of the new Model School. The old Burra Hotel had been acquired from the SA Mining Association ‘on very generous terms’. It had been renovated and painted and a Wardsman and Matron, Mr Wright Heath and his wife, had been appointed at a combined salary of £100 with rations and accommodation. The hotel had been erected in 1849, taking the placed of a wooden one on the same site in 1847. In 1849 it was known as Wren’s Hotel and was the largest in SA. It was owned by Mr Paxton who also owned, like a good Mine Director, the four inns in Kooringa. The Burra Burra Hotel was the first encountered on entering the town and was patronised by the ‘quality’ and always used by the Mine Directors on their visits to the Burra Burra Mine. Attached to it was a very spacious room 50 ft by 30 ft and 15 ft high, which had been more particularly built as a Freemason’s Hall, it being the largest room in the colony. The spacious cellars held a large supply of wine, liquors and other tavern stores from Burra Directors’ Port to hams, loaf sugar, pewter pots, glass and crockery. In this hall were held all the public and political meetings of the day and all the major functions of the town. The hotel with its shingle roof closed as a hotel in the year before it opened as a hospital. Now ninety years later it is being demolished to make way for a new wing of the hospital and for a few days its shingle roof was again exposed when the iron was removed. There are few 120-year-old buildings as well preserved as this one. Its cellars are still there.

The Burra Model School still stands and its foundation stone was laid on the same Tuesday.

After the hospital had been opened by Sir Henry Ayers the party went to the Institute where a procession was formed headed by the Burra Brass Band followed by some twenty Freemasons and then the Oddfellows, Foresters and Rechabites, each in full regalia and then the members of the Ministry present, the Mayor and Corporation and Mr Bath. The stone was laid on 27 February 1877 by Thomas Bath, the oldest business resident in Burra. The inhabitants turned out en masse and must have numbered nearly 1,500. The building was intended to accommodate 800-900 children and was due to be completed by the end of 1877. The cost was £6,976 including furniture.

During the National Trust weekend visit to Burra recently Mrs Halliday visited Burra and brought with her the silver trowel with which her grandfather, Mr Thomas Bath, had laid the foundation stone. She has generously presented the trowel to the school and it will be displayed in a place of honour in the Primary School Library.

She has also stated that she might be persuaded to donate the wooden mallet given to her grandfather by the contractors for the building, Messrs Sara & Dunstan. The mallet is hollow and inside has been stored a copy of the Burra News of 1877, giving an account of the events on that day. Perhaps on the opening day of the new hospital a thought can be spared for the old Burra Burra Hotel and the hospital building that has now disappeared and also for the silver trowel that brought the story to light again.

Notes:

The old Mining Association Hospital became known as Bleak House. It has recently been purchased by Mr Johnson Carpenter and is being renovated. After 1877 it became a private school and was known as the Burra High School.

The present Burra Hotel was earlier called The Miners’ Arms and the name the Burra Hotel was given to it after the old Burra Burra Hotel had become a hospital.

Burra hospital Building Appeal Fund donations have reached $2,454.

The Burra Film recently made by John Kingsford-Smith of Sydney is a five-minute feature and will be shown on 4 December as part of a series of similar features on historic towns and homes of Australia. The script is by Ian Auhl and the film shows many places of interest in Burra.

Weather. The dry spell continues. October rain was only 38 points and the year’s total is only 6.27 inches. Hot windy conditions have also contributed to deterioration in the country and to crop yields enormously.

Accident. A car driven by Mr Jack Gordon of Black Springs and formerly of Koo-Owie swerved off the road 11⁄2 miles north of Manoora and rolled over twice, ending back on its wheels. In the car were Mr & Mrs Gordon, their four children and Mr Gordon Sen. Remarkably none of them were injured.

Type % fall

64s 11.88

60s 17.70

58s 24.44

56s 29.88

50s 30.32

The editor was critical of broker’s official reports which could convey more and also more meaningful information.

90, 43, 7 Nov. 1967, page 1

Dedication of St John’s Lutheran Church, Burra.

Visitors from other mid-northern Lutheran Congregations combined with members of the Burra congregation, representatives of other denominations and other special guests for the dedication of St John’s Evangelical Lutheran Church at Burra North by Pastor G.O. Minge, President of the SA District of the Lutheran Church of Australia. Incidentally, his first public sermon was preached on Christmas Day 1922 at Mt Bryan. The church has seating for 80, or at a pinch 100, and about as many had to remain outside to hear the service over a loud speaker. Participating in the service was Pastor Thiele of Saddleworth, a former pastor to the Burra congregation and Pastor Schmidt, the present pastor. Mrs Zweck of Blyth played the organ and the small but effective Blyth Choir led the singing. Pastor Thiele thanked the Anglicans for the use of their hall in recent years and Rev. Sibly of St Mary’s gave greetings from Anglican parishioners. Monsignor Hughes spoke on behalf of the Roman Catholics and thanked the congregation for inviting him to be present. Pastor Schmidt said members of the Burra congregation were overwhelmed by the attendance and that to date the undertaking was debt-free. He thanked all helpers and donors very sincerely. Afternoon tea was served in the RSL Hall. The next service at St John’s will be on 19 November at 9 a.m. [The photograph of the church before it was moved from Mansfield Park is reprinted.]

Burra Police report quite a few people have taken advantage of an amnesty for unregistered firearms. Many people think that once a firearm is registered it is for all times, but a change of ownership requires the new owner to register the firearm.

Sgt N. Orford from City Headquarters will replace Sgt W. Teague and he will take up duty in Burra early in the New Year.

Kooringa Methodist Guild Fete was opened by Mrs Lind. She said this was probably her last official duty before the family transferred to the Yankalilla Circuit early in 1968. The fete made a profit of $250. [Details in 3⁄4 column.]

Burra Hospital Building Fund Appeal. Sufficient funds were raised in 1963 to open the new administration block and private rooms etc. in Phase I of the plan. Phase II saw the remodelling of the wards, kitchen etc. and this was completed from the Hospital’s own funds. Phase III has been in the processing stage for some time.

Editorial on the mining boom in iron, nickel, oil and natural gas. The editor urges a view to be taken of the medium to long term and makes specific reference to the Kambalda nickel project.

Strawbridge & Vice-Captain, J. Bogisch. The President reported on a successful year. The open day attracted 106 nominations and was played in perfect weather. The Club Championship was won by Stan Longford for the 15th time in 18 years.

90, 43, 7 Nov. 1967, page 8

Burra Small Bore Club. In a double 100 yards shoot best scorers were L. Moore, C. Collins and R. Gilbert.

90, 44, 14 Nov. 1967, page 1

Burra Hospital. The demolition of the old hotel section is almost complete and excavation work is in progress. Some 2,000 cubic yards of rubble has been handled. Excavation work will allow continuation of the one floor level for the new building. In the last four years district residents have contributed about $16,000 including $11,000 for Phase I. Subsidised by the Government, this represents a total of roughly $50,000. Phases I & II of the plan plus maintenance and repairs have amounted to well in excess of $100,000 with the balance coming from Hospital revenue and subsidies. The complete value of the whole plan will amount to over $200,000. This means the present donation when subsidised $15,000 will represent one sixth of the second $100,000.

Donations presently stand at $5,263.70.

Car Thefts. A utility owned by Malcolm Pettet was stolen from the depot of Burra Rural Supplies in Morehead Street, Burra North on Tuesday afternoon and was later recovered near Yunta undamaged. At c. 9 p.m. Thursday Burra Police recovered a vehicle stolen in Adelaide and abandoned on the Morgan Road. On Saturday morning Burra Police also recovered a vehicle stolen in the Northern Territory last May, following up on information supplied.

Accident. Frank P. Sullivan of Hallett was injured on Sunday morning when the small sedan he was driving overturned at c. 7.30 a.m. on the Jamestown Road at a bend. He suffered severe lacerations and bruised kidneys. A passenger Adrian Phelps of Pt Pirie received cuts and bruises. Both were admitted to Jamestown Hospital.

Burra High School has obtained a television for school telecasts, courtesy of the Parents & Friends’ Association.

The Garden of Memory lawn has been reseeded and the Parents & Friends’ Assoc. will provide a new cairn recording the names of scholars who gave their lives in WW II. This will replace the plaque, which is no longer legible.

The Valedictory Service will be held in Kooringa Methodist Church on 10 December and will be a ‘Mod Service’ using modern music. Speech Night will be in the Town Hall on 12 December and the Annual Banquet will also be in the Town Hall, on 14 December. There will be a social in the RSL Hall on 14 December.

Adelaide Wool Sales 7-9 November. Prices were slightly lower. The top district price of 541⁄2c was obtained by L.G. & F.C. Woodman of ‘Hillview’. [Other local district prices are printed.]

90, 44, 14 Nov. 1967, page 2

Editorial on the local water supply.

An apparent fall in water quality has apparently prompted some people to believe that local underground water is being mixed with River Murray water. This is not the case except for 90 minutes on 18 October when local water was pumped while Hanson pumps were changed over. Murray water appears to have deteriorated.

90, 44, 14 Nov. 1967, page 5

A Tale of the Burra Smelters

[Charles Barber Griffiths (a grandson of John Barber Griffiths) was 83 in 1967 and wrote an article concerning an incident at the time of building the stack of the smelters chimney at Burra.]

In 1855-56 John Barber Griffiths came to Australia from Cardiff in Wales. He was a stone mason who built and maintained furnaces. He came to Burra as an employee of the English & Scottish Copper Co.

With him were his wife Sarah and son Charles Barber and five daughters: Sarah, Addie, Elizabeth, Prisilla [sic] and Polly. Two more children, John and Francis, were born in Australia. Charles Barber had been apprenticed in Wales as a stone mason at the age of 8 and was 12 when he arrived in Burra where he continued as an apprentice with his father.

Before telling of the incident, I would like to say something of the building of the smelting works. It was a well-built place. The front was about 200 feet long with one big arch after another and the height of the wall was c. 15 feet. Inside, down the centre was another row of arches and the back was the same. Both ends walls were, I think, without openings. The whole building had a big iron gable roof. The furnaces were built at the back of the arches. The smoke was taken from the earth furnace into a big tunnel, which ran along the back row of arches and then went underground for c. 20 ft before going up the chimney stack. The tunnel had smoke boxes off the side of it about the size of a room. I remember there were two of them. They used to tell me they were used to stop the smoke from turning round and round and if there was too much smoke all at once it would go back into these boxes. My father used to tell me about the building of this chimney, which was said to be 100 ft high. It was c. 12 ft square at the bottom and my father said it was 4 ft 6 inches square at the top.

This is the incident about the building of the chimney.

It was built from the inside with all the scaffolding on the inside of it. When the masons were building the cap to the top of the stack an inspector came and climbed the scaffolding to near the cap. The masons were commenting on its great height, but the inspector said ‘You don’t call this stack high do you?’

One of them said it was the highest the inspector was every likely to get off the ground.

‘Tell that to the Marines.’ Said the inspector.

‘Why, I’d jump off this thing any day for a bottle of brandy.’

‘Well, jump,’ said one of the masons ‘and we’ll give you a bottle of brandy, but you had better drink it before you jump, for you will never drink anymore after you do jump.’

He accepted the dare and they accepted his wager.

The next day he returned with an umbrella and climbed to the top of the stack and asked if they had the bottle of brandy. They said they had.

‘Well, I’m going to jump now; you can come down after me and give it to me then.’

His umbrella had chords attached to the top. They crossed over the top and then were attached to the handle and he then fastened those chords to his wrist. He then stepped onto the cap on the northeast corner and jumped off. He landed on a heap of sand and was not hurt in any way. He got his bottle of brandy.

My father said they all needed a bottle of brandy when they saw him jump, as they thought to see him get killed.

When I was a boy of 8 I used to play in this smoke tunnel. After the mine closed the furnaces were pulled down and the tunnel where the smoke entered was opened up and another new hole made in the top of the tunnel. At the foot of the stack we used to get inside and look up. The stack would sway as all stacks do in the wind. Looking up you would see blackness and then a thin strip of light would appear and gradually it would grow into a square before slowly narrowing again until all the light would be gone.

Birth. To Raylene & Colin Landorf of Booborowie, at Burra Hospital last week, a daughter, Christine June.

90, 45, 21 Nov. 1967, page 1

Burra’s Tourist Potential was assessed at a visit to Burra on Tuesday by the minister of Lands Hon. J.D. Corcoran and the Director of the SA Tourist Bureau Mr P. Pollnitz. They were responding to an invitation from the Mayor E.T. Baulderstone and his Council. They were accompanied by Mr P.H. Quirke MP and had a tour of the town with the Mayor and Town Clerk, local historian, Mr I.L. Auhl and the Revs G.D. Sibly & M. Lind. They visited the old Brewery Cellars, the Lock-up and Stables at Burra North, the Redruth Gaol, Bon Accord Waterworks, Miners’ Dugouts, the Mine and Aboriginal carvings in Stone Chimney Creek, etc.

They felt tourist interest in Burra had grown considerably in the past two years as a result of efforts by the National Trust and the Town Council. Mr Pollnitz believes Burra has more tourist potential than any other SA town. The party was conducted over the Museum by Mr S.J. Woollacott. As a result of the visit the Tourist Bureau and Government have a better knowledge of the extent of the tourist area and any case for preservation will be given good priority. As no Government money is available to the National Trust, the best approach will be through the Town Council.

Accident. At about 6.15 p.m. on Saturday three miles southwest of Hanson Miss Pauline Miller of Hanson lost control of her Mini-Minor in dusty conditions caused by other vehicles and it rolled over. She was found trapped in the upturned vehicle by members of the Bowling Club returning from Clare. They turned the vehicle over and forced the doors open to free Miss Miller, who was unhurt except for some cuts to an ankle.

A Guided Tour of Burra has been organised by the Rector and Wardens of St Mary’s on Sunday at 1.30 p.m. from the Parish Hall. Locals are invited to join visitors to learn more about their town. At 4.30 p.m. Mr Ian Auhl will show the coloured film made about Burra by Mr John Kingsford-Smith and Ampol for the National Trust. Mr Auhl will also give a lecture.

Burra Hospital Building Fund Appeal stands at $6,687.

Disorderly Car Activities continue to annoy locals and have led to complaints to police.

90, 45, 21 Nov. 1967, page 2

Editorial. The editor draws attention to the recent reports on the less than encouraging indications for mining copper at Burra, but adds that there is also a statement that work by the Mines Department and Mines Exploration Co. gives promise of $30 million worth of copper could come from redevelopment of the upper part of the old mine. But if this development occurs and disturbs old mine buildings, shafts, etc. would we want to see an activity that lasts just long enough to destroy a tourist industry that could be developed permanently?

Theft. Two youths have been apprehended for the theft of Malcolm Pettet’s utility recently. They are a pair of 15-year-old absconders from Magill Reformatory.

Booborowie Summertime Fair drew a large crowd to the hall for strawberries and other fare. The event raised $533. [Details in 11⁄4 columns.]

Burra Hospital. Work has begun on the foundations for Phase III.

Booborowie Tennis Club conducted an Amateur Hour on 11 November and raised $135.

90, 45, 21 Nov. 1967, page 8

Thomas Bath’s Letter

A letter written 116 years ago by Thomas Bath to his mother in England was recently discovered among family treasures in Bournemouth, Hampshire. Mrs G.G. Halliday, a granddaughter of the writer gave permission for its printing. Mrs Halliday recently donated to the school the silver trowel used by Thomas Bath to lay the foundation stone of the school in 1877.

Bath St. Kooringa

Oct. 25 1851

Dear Mother,

[Thomas apologises for not writing more often, but says a long letter of July 1850 must have miscarried and the fault is not one-sided, as he has not received a letter for nearly two years. He then continues:]

A person, who came out in the unfortunate vessel the Naraion, by the name Jennings, told me he had brought a letter for me, but he lost everything but the clothes he was wearing when the vessel ran aground in our gulf. All hands were landed safely though spread along 200 miles of coast. One woman died when she fell from a dray on the road to town.

I heard from Jennings that you had heard from brothers John and Henry and that was the first I had heard of them since their arrival in San Francisco, though a great many people are coming back here that went to California about the same time as my brothers. I hope you will write to me immediately on receipt of this and give me every information about my brothers etc.

I herewith enclose half a £5 note of Bank at East Cornwall. The other half I will forward by next mail as a precaution in case one of the letters might miss. I am still at Kooringa as the heading of this letter indicates and the town has gone ahead wonderfully with now a population of 6,000. We have a church, 2 Wesleyan chapels, an Independent Chapel, Baptist, Primitive, Bible Christian, German Lutheran, Roman Catholic etc.

The Burra Burra Mines are still holding on as well as ever, though not quite as profitable to the shareholders, being unable to declare the usual quarterly dividend of 200% this time due to the long and wet winter. There are 30,000 tons of ore accumulated at the mine with an estimated value of £120,000.

We have extensive Smelting Works in successful operation, but these too have been idle in winter on account of being unable to get firewood, the roads being in such a wretched state. Now with the dry weather they are again in full work. They have 16 furnaces at work. They principally use coal, part of which comes from England and part from Newcastle NSW. It is landed at Port Wakefield 60 miles from Kooringa and is carted here at 33/- per ton in winter and 25/- in summer each way, up and down – they take down copper and copper ores.

This summer they will employ all the drays they can get which will be I think about 400 besides their own drays, which is about 150 more. Their circulation amounts to upwards of £161,320 p.a.

Kooringa has been much affected by the discovery of gold in NSW. Some 300 persons have gone. One party of five men left for the gold diggings and returned after ten weeks without any success. On Friday I saw a man called Hall who left the smelting works when earning 30/- a week and on his return was glad to get the same place at 25/- per week. Letters from men at the diggings appear very contradictory.

[He mentions as at Sydney diggings: William Dunstan, Willy & Benny Dunstan from Burra, Edward Moyle and William Dower.]

Within the last few days there has been nothing talked of but Port Phillip where gold has been found in immense quantities says the report. A great many have left already with a great many more about to go.

I am carrying on business as before in General Store – my stock consists of Drapery, Grocery, Ironmongery, Glass and Earthenware etc. I also have a Timber Yard and a banking [baking?] business here. At my bakehouse I employ two men and a horse and cart to ??? the bread around town. In my shop I have three shopmen besides myself and a clerk at the books. I have another shop where I carry on business of the same kind as in Kooringa, where I keep two men, a draper and a grocer and am doing business in each place – except in timber. There has not been much doing due to so many leaving for the gold diggings. I sometimes get a whole cargo of timber consigned to me and my name has always been A1 since my arrival, or since I commenced business.

Benny Dunstan has returned from the gold diggings with about 30 others from this place and another of others since. They say a great many there are doing well and hundreds not earning their salt and many who would return, but have not the means. Pt Phillip is now all that is talked of and thousands are leaving this Colony for that place. I expect they will be as much disappointed as those who went to Sydney.

Since the former part of this letter was written three of my hands have left me for the diggings. In consequence I have sold my baking business, which I did not much care about, as the profit was not large and I find I have quite enough without it in my two shops.

I will write again in the course of a few days. Mt respects to all my brothers, sisters, uncles, aunts, cousins and enquiring friends.

You Most Dutiful Son,

Thomas Bath.

90, 46, 28 Nov. 1967, page 1

Burra Hospital Building Fund Appeal. Further donations are acknowledged to a total of $8,473.

Senate Election Result for the Burra District.

LCL Team Laucke 973

Buttfield 37

Young 11

ALP Team Bishop 617

Cavanagh 11

Nielson 2

The Tour of Burra organised by the Rector and Wardens of St Mary’s was a success and attracted many residents as well as visitors including Adelaide people and two New Zealanders. Over 100 adults and children spent an interesting afternoon led by Mr Ian Auhl. St Mary’s church was comfortably filled as others joined to see the films on Burra and to hear Mr Auhl’s address. The Anglican Quartet rendered a motet. Jan Cockington and Rosemary Reed played a duet and Rev. Sibly played an organ solo and accompanied hymn singing.

Late Night Closing of Shops will operate in Burra for Friday 22 December. Businesses will open from 7-9 p.m.

A Nuisance. A 19-year-old youth was fined $10 plus $4 costs for causing an excessive noise while riding a motor cycle in Commercial Street.

Mt Bryan CWA. The visit of the members of the Indian Club of SA is further reported in 1⁄2 column of detail.

A Pet Show was held at Burra North at the Redruth Memorial Hall on Saturday. There was also a Doll Show and Yo-Yo Competition and a Lucky-Dip. For the adults there was a White Elephant Stall and stalls selling strawberries, cake, ice cream and cold drinks. Members of the Burra & District Choral Society staged a concert. Proceeds were $305, which will be divided among various charities. [Prize winners are listed.]

90, 46, 28 Nov. 1967, page 2

Editorial on a new era in farm management, with new technologies including computers to keep business records. There are more scientific approaches to stock keeping and to growing grain and fodder crops, along with greater care of lambs, both before and after birth. Consultant services are becoming more important and present the farmer with a wider range of strategies, policies and ideas. Wool is being classified into trade types to sell in big even lines. Insurance and travel arrangements are all changing and can be attended to over the phone.

Obituary. Mr Guy Dollman died last week.

[Guy Herbert Dollman died 22 November 1967 Northfield, residence Burra aged 75.]

Mr & Mrs Colin Heinrich & family leave Burra today bound for Leigh Creek and its Post Office. Colin has been treasurer of the local football club for the past year.

Cricket. Burra Footballers 127 v. Hallett 207.

90, 47, 5 Dec. 1967, page 1

Burra Hospital Building Fund Appeal stands at $10,135.

The Chairman of the Board said despite the poor season the building project could not be postponed because of the poor state of the operating theatre, which is completely outdated and building should start in summer to minimise delays due to weather. The appeal will officially close on 12 December.

[Also printed is an artist’s impression of the planned new building and a photo showing the remaining portions of the old Hotel Building as it was being demolished, with the old cellars in the foreground.]

The Harvest. Results seem to be better than feared, with 13,000 bushels delivered to the Burra Silo by Saturday. The current harvest appears to be running 2-3 weeks earlier than last year.

Burra Cricket Club held a cabaret at the Town Hall on Friday. Bob Cunningham, well known from television was a guest artist, but failed to boost attendance, which was not great. Patrons again commented on the poor floor surface for dancing.

Adelaide Wool Sales 28-30 November. [Local district prices are printed.]

90, 47, 5 Dec. 1967, pages 1 & 4

Rosemary Reed, who will be married early in the New Year, was given a farewell at the conclusion of the Advent Carol Service at St Mary’s on Sunday night. It was noted that this probably meant the end of the Burra Anglican Quartet, whose members were Rosemary Reed, Jan Cockington, Alan Edwards and Geoffrey Sibly: the last being the founder. It had been intended to farewell Mrs Mavis Kelly prior to her departure, but this had not been possible. A presentation was made to Rosemary of a nest of tables. [Details in c. 1 column.]

90, 47, 5 Dec. 1967, page 2

Editorial on where to start to promote tourism in Burra. The editor concludes some things would be: better signage, organised tours and particularly a motel and a good roadhouse with extended hours and improved services.

Mr & Mrs Jim Kelly have moved to Kadina. [He had worked at Princess Royal.]

Mr Len Braendler & family are moving on Monday next to Woomera where he has been transferred with the PMG Department.

Burra RSL held its Annual Dinner on Saturday night with possibly the best spread ever prepared by the Ladies’ Auxiliary. Attendance of local members was rather disappointing, but there was a good muster of visitors.

90, 47, 5 Dec. 1967, page 8

Burra CWA celebrated International Day. The guest speaker was Mrs Clatterton [sic here, but in other places Chatterton] of Lyndoch. A special welcome was given to a visiting foundation member, Mrs S.M. Sandland, now living in Adelaide.

90, 49, 12 Dec. 1967, page 1 [Check the omission of a number 48]

Burra Hospital Building Fund Appeal raised $11,311, of which the committee raised $840. The Board is gratified with this sum, given the poor seasonal conditions. When subsidised this will give a total of $34,000, which when added to funds already in hand will enable the completion of the building. Funds in hand include a bequest from the Alice Collins Estate of $11,000, or $33,000 when subsidised. It has as a consequence been decided to call the new building the Alice Collins Wing. It will house an up-to-date X-Ray Department, Operating theatre and Casualty Ward. Although funds will cover the building operations the actual cost of equipping the various sections is not easily assessable. The overall plan is expected to cost $200,000 and of this residents of the district have contributed $11,000 for Phase I and a similar amount for Phase III. With a bequest of $11,000 this makes a total of $33-34,000, giving $100,000 with subsidy. Towards this end the ladies of various district committees which combined to form the Fund Raising Committee are to be congratulated on their annual effort.

Accident. Mr Leonard William McCann of Whyalla lost control of his car one mile east of Burra en route to a holiday in Sydney last week. The car overturned, plunged through a fence and into the gully below. The vehicle was a write-off, though neither the driver nor a passenger was injured.

The Burra Swimming Pool. The cost of repairs to the chlorination plant has been advised to total $150. This is felt to be satisfactory due to the very satisfactory way it now operates.

Burra Cemetery. The shelter shed [i.e. the Mortuary Chapel] is to be repainted and have its guttering renewed.

The footbridge opposite the Town Hall is to be reformed and bituminised.

Jack Jenner of Spalding, President of the North Eastern Football League for the past 12 years, has been voted the first Life Member of the League.

Burra High School held its third Valedictory Service very successfully. It took place in the Kooringa Methodist Church. There was also a Valedictory Smorgasbord Tea. The church was filled to capacity. Rev. Dr M. McArthur, Associate Director of the Department of Christian Education of the Methodist Church, was a very capable preacher for the occasion. The High School Choir made a worthwhile contribution led by Mr Peter Morris.

Headmaster Mr Robert Farrow conducted the service assisted by the Parish Priest of St Mary’s Rev. G.D. Sibly and the Minister of the Burra Methodist Circuit, Rev. M.A. Lind. [Details in 1 column.]

90, 49, 12 Dec. 1967, page 7

Burra district Fund Raising Committee held its AGM. The committees that combine to make this committee have raised $12-15,000 in the past ten years. This money has been spent on hospital equipment and amenities for patients. The Hospital Board had asked that this year an amount of $840 be allowed to be used for the building fund, with any surplus to go towards equipment and amenities. The delegates present agreed. Committees represented were:

The Hallett Committee

Burra North Hospital Aid

Farrell Flat CWA

Burra Cup Committee

Leighton Tennis Club

Booborowie CWA

Hanson CWA

Mt Bryan CWA

Burra CWA

W.H. Dawson’s 270 acre property 7 miles north of Booborowie was sold by Dalgety-NZL on Friday in the Burra RSL Hall to Allen Pearce & Co. of Booborowie for $275 per acre.

Burra Mine. The Chairman of Broken Hill South Ltd at its annual meeting said that at Burra percussion drilling of the oxidised ore was completed. Indications are of 3.3 million tons at 1.6% copper and a waste to ore ratio of 1.4 to 1. The economic feasibility of an operation at Burra is marginal. More sampling and a pilot testing is needed to determine the mining recovery.

Clem Sampson sends Christmas wishes to Burra friends from WA.

The Harold Footes in Queensland also send Christmas greetings.

Birth. To Paul & Jill Tattersall nee Arnold at Kingston SE last week, a daughter, Rebecca.

Birth. To Mr & Mrs Howe of Burra at Burra Hospital last week, a son, Graham Robert.

Jan McInnes, daughter of Melva & Angus McInnes of Booborowie, has been awarded a Commonwealth Secondary Scholarship. She is a student at Methodist Ladies’ College.

John Murphy, studying at Rostrevor College has won a Commonwealth Secondary Scholarship.

Christopher Ryan, a scholar at St Joseph’s Convent in Burra has won a half scholarship to Rostrevor College, starting next year.

Dennis Cutting, teller at the Savings Bank has been transferred to the city.

The footpath between Burra and Burra North is being sealed.

Mrs Ted Lehman writes to say her three sons are in the navy.

Barry is in HMAS Perth in waters off Vietnam.

David on HMAS Moreby is somewhere north of Australia.

Morris is at HMAS Albatross, Nowra, NSW.

89, 50, 19 Dec. 1967, page 1 [Note reversion to volume 89: check with 1959 & 1966 for previous uses.]

Burra town Council representatives visited the Renmark Effluent Drainage Scheme and said they were impressed. The co-operation given by the Public Health Department was excellent said Mayor E.T. Baulderstone. Representatives of seven Councils attended the field day. Problems caused by underground water and cracking soil had been solved using Ceramiflex flexible plastic jointed clay pipes. The scheme would cost ratepayers about $20 p.a. for the average property. An impressive aspect was the way in which soil was removed from the trenches, carted away and returned when filling was needed. The streets were thus kept free from unsightly heaps of soil and dust problems were reduced. The speed of laying the pipes at up to 1,000 feet per day was also impressive.

Vandalism has occurred at the Burra Swimming Pool where the culprits were apparently throwing stones at light globes erected to decorate the Carols Evening on Sunday. A number of the stones ended up in the pool.

Trunk Lines for telephone services have been expanded with one extra channel between the following places:

Hallett-Mt Bryan

Burra-Mt Bryan

Hallett-Whyte Yarcowie

Burra Hospital Building Fund Appeal has received further donations to bring the total to $12,210.

Accident. A car driven by W. Odgers of Burra overturned on a bend on the Leighton Road about 5 miles from Burra at about 11.20 a.m. on Wednesday 13 December. No one was injured, but the car was extensively damaged.

Burra Rural Supplies opened in Morehead Street Burra North on Friday and about 200 people came to the launch. It is a joint venture of I.T. & M.L. Allen and M.T. & I.J. Pettet. The Bulk Store proved to be a most satisfactory place for Mr I. Allen to explain the 1968 catalogue of products and services. The Mobil Agency and carrying service previously run by J.L. Allen & Son will continue under Burra Rural Supplies. New services will be Bulk Super Spreading, Horwood Bagshaw Machinery franchise and agencies for Portagas and Charlicks Feeds (bulk or bagged). Light refreshments were provided at the opening.

Christmas Eve. Town Traders will offer late night shopping till 9 p.m. when they have arranged for Father Christmas to arrive. A merry-go-round will offer free rides to children the whole of Friday.

89, 50, 19 Dec. 1967, pages 1 & 4

Burra Primary School

Mr Ian Auhl was farewelled by students on Thursday afternoon at a ceremony at the Burra Primary School. With his great knowledge of local history he proved to be a teacher to many adults as well as to his school pupils. Mrs Perry spoke for students and staff and said that both students and staff were deeply sorry to be losing both Mr & Mrs Auhl. Penny Miller made a neat little speech, and helped by Debbie Kirk, made a presentation of a silver jug. Chairman of the School Committee Mr R. Moreland added his appreciation. Mrs Carpenter spoke on behalf of the School Welfare Club and also as a staff member. Rev. Geoffrey Sibly spoke for the religious instructors. Mr Auhl replied saying it was hard to leave a school where he had a school and student to be proud of. He paid tribute to the great assistance of his wife. Prize-giving and presentation of Progress Certificates was also held on Thursday.

Alan Braendler & Robert Padbury shared the Andrew Tennant Award for Dux of Grade VII.

Dux of the Girls was Carolyn Nicholls.

This is likely to be the last year Progress Certificates will be awarded.

Mrs N. Said was farewelled.

[Various prizes and awards are listed.]

Progress certificates were presented to:

Raymond Allen Vicki Bernhardt Julie Bevan

Alan Braendler Betty Brak Peter Byles

Ann Cornelius Jilian Foyle Bruce Fyfe

Lester Gare Peter Gilbert Shane Ginnane

Heather Greet John Hallion Robin James

Sandra Jones John Lloyd Mark Moreland

Carolyn Nicholls Robert Padbury Peter Seaford

Kym Spackman Robert Wall Kerry Ward

Andrew Webster Wayne Williams Russell Williams

Robert Williams Stephen Woolley

89, 50, 19 Dec. 1967, pages 1 & 5

Burra High School held its Speech Night at Burra Town Hall last Tuesday night and drew a near capacity crowd. The guest speaker was John Freebairn MP. Prizes were presented by Miss Clare Freebairn, sister of the guest speaker. Certificates and trophies were presented by the Mayor & Mayoress Mr & Mrs E.T. Baulderstone.

The Headmaster’s Report will appear in a later paper. The annual swimming carnival was postponed from Term 1 and was held on 8 December. [Results are printed.]

The end of the year social was held in the RSL Hall on Thursday evening with music supplied by Mr Darrell Field and from recordings. Father Christmas paid a visit. The annual banquet was also held on Thursday, organised by the Parents & Friends’ Association at the town Hall before the social. A staff versus students cricket match was played at the end of the term. Students 4 for 61 defeated staff 5 for 48.

Inter-School sports with Eudunda Area School were held on 7 December and against Riverton High on 13 December. [Results are printed, together with the results of the House Competition for the year.]

89, 50, 19 Dec. 1967, page 2

Burra CWA. The Burra Branch awarded only its second Life Membership on Friday last when Mrs A.I.M. (Matty) Phillips was honoured for her tireless devotion to the Association. Mrs W. Klem, the Warnes Group Divisional President, pinned the badge onto Mrs Phillips’ dress and Mrs R. Jeffery, Secretary of the Burra Branch, read the citation [which is printed]. The late Miss Minnie Rogers was the first Life Member.

Carols by the Pool were held at the Burra Swimming Pool on Sunday night. The weather was mild. Guest compere was Mr Ern Lawrie from Manoora. Mr G.M. Baulderstone supplied lighting effects and amplification and Mrs Jack Oates was the indispensable pianist. The Burra Choral Society led the singing. Bible readings were given by Revs G. Sibly and M. Lind. Rosemary Reed sang two solos and children from St Joseph’s Convent School put on an impressive tableau. The Mayor Mr E.T. Baulderstone delivered his Christmas message. He reviewed the town’s progress for the year and made reference to the apparent tragic loss of the Prime Minister, Mr Holt.

89, 50, 19 Dec. 1967, page 7

Kooringa Tennis Club held its Christmas Tree Festival on Friday in the Burra Town Hall. Proceeds were $110

[Details in c. 1⁄2 column.]

Birth. To Ron & Betty Thamm on Sunday, a daughter, Patricia.

Mrs Edith O’Leary nee Berryman celebrated her 100th birthday on 8 December. She was born on a sheep station near Burra. [This would appear to be Ada O’Leary who was born Ada Berryman 8 December 1867 at Spring Bank, Burra, and who died 22 March 1971 at Dulwich. She married Arthur O’Leary in 1919.]

Mr & Mrs Schonburgh celebrate their Golden Wedding tomorrow.

[Rudolph Herman Schomburgk & Ethel Isabell Willcocks.]

Trooper John Billing arrived home from Nui Dhat, Vietnam, last week after 10 months service there. He is spending eight weeks leave home at Spalding.

Mr L.S. Penrose of Mt Gambier wrote to the paper. He worked for Drew & Crewes for over 30 years and was a great amateur photographer. He is now 84.

Characteristics of the paper in 1967

Generally quite a good coverage of local news, though a considerable amount of the material refers to more distant mid north centres like Spalding, Saddleworth, Manoora and Riverton. After the first couple of page sport dominates the paper.

Page 1

This carries most of the news.

Page 2

For much of the year this was the familiar mixture of a few large advertisements with public notices, advertising for land sales and for district events. This changed late in the year (from 24 October) when editorials reappeared for the first time in many years. The page was then typically: Editorial, Cash Column, some larger advertisements and local news and sports, with the previous page two material moved on to page 3.

Pages 3-8 & from October page 2 & 4-8

Typically dominated by larger advertisements with perhaps 2 to 4 columns devoted to sports and some news. Of the latter District Council reports comprised a large, but rather unedifying part. Some non-local pieces were common, including a regular column on ‘Last Week in State Parliament’ by the local MP John Freebairn.

Out and About by ‘Mrs Maggs’ (Mary Woollacott) was an important and very useful column for local births, birthdays, deaths and other events. This is a valuable help for local historian, even if the obituaries etc. are exceeding brief. This varied in location, but was often on page 7 and varied generally from one to two column

1, 1, 9 Jan. 1968 MISSING

91, 2, 16 Jan. 1968, page 1

Adelaide Wool Sales. [Local district prices are listed.]

AS Stockowners’ Assoc. Burra Branch had a meeting on 10 January which drew 82 people to the Burra RSL Hall. Mr P.A. McBride, President of the SA Association, spoke on ‘Wool Marketing Prospects’.

Swimming. At the inter-club swimming carnival at Spalding on Friday night Burra won by one point from Clare, with Spalding another point away in third place. [Results are printed.]

The Learn to Swim Campaign for 1968 has concluded in Burra. 173 children received instruction from Messrs Paul Tattersall and Russell Nicholls assisted by Randal Miller.

Burra Town Hall Pictures

Attendances have dropped rather drastically in the last six months.

This represents a fall in attendance of 26% in the last half of the year. Over the last six months the venture has been operating at a small loss. This cannot continue. Attendances were bad in 1966, improved in the first half of 1967 and then fell again. Some special bigger films have been booked and will carry slightly greater admission charges. Let’s hope attendances will improve. For the first night of 1968 it was 126.

91, 2, 16 Jan. 1968, page 7

Burra High School. Photograph of the Inter-School Cricket Team 1966.

Bill Lee was 85 on Saturday 13 January.

Des Byrnes has been selected to attend the Officer Cadet School at Portsea, Victoria. He is at present serving in Vietnam. He is the son of Mr & Mrs Percy Byrnes of Burra.

Mark O’Callaghan is a new face at Elders-GM.

Ian & Annette Cameron and daughter are moving from Farrell Flat to Hawker to represent Elders. Ian will be replaced by Mr M. Bond.

Nurse Melva Catford is leaving Burrs after two years at the Burra Hospital.

Mr & Mrs Tom Emmerson and son Brian are moving to Norseman district in WA.

Rev. & Mrs Maurice Lind and children Katrina, David and Joanne will soon move to Yankalilla.

Elizabeth McDonald of Leighton is training as a nurse at Memorial Hospital.

Dr & Mrs John Loutit and three sons are visiting from New Zealand. Mrs Loutit is a daughter of Mr & Mrs Roy Jeffery.

Obituary. Mr & Mrs Hammer, parents of Mr Hammer, late of the ANZ Bank in Burra, were killed in a car accident. Mr Hammer Jnr married the daughter of Mr & Mrs Roy Bourman of Burra.

91, 3, 23 Jan. 1968, page 1

Learn to Swim Campaign. Last Tuesday the campaign for 1968 ended with 188 certificates being awarded. 42 youngsters were taught to swim at least 10 yards. Listed are those awarded:

42 10 yards

39 Beginners’ Certificate

40 Progress Certificate

20 Junior Certificate

15 Senior Certificate

32 Royal Life Saving Award

Burra Hospital Building Fund Appeal stands at $12,452.50

Burra Hospital. Work is progressing on roofing the new building.

Weather. Patchy, but useful rains have fallen over much of the pastoral areas. Some stations will be able to stop carting water for the first time in two years or more.

91, 3, 23 Jan. 1968, page 5

Burra National Trust held its AGM and elected: President, S.J. Woollacott; Vice-President, W.L. Moore; Secretary, Mrs B. Fitzpatrick; Treasurer, Mrs C. O’Connor.

The President reported visitors to the Museum from around the world as well as many district organisations and schools. Some 1,300 have signed the visitors’ book. The Museum has helped put Burra back on the map. The highlight for the year was the visit of the National Trust from Adelaide, which was a great success. The other three rooms of the building have now been renovated and we now have our own meeting room and a building and museum of importance to Burra.

Bowls

Burra Green 97 defeated Hallett Red 85

Burra Gold 108 defeated Burra Blue 64

Ladies

Burra Green defeated Peterborough Red

Burra Gold defeated Spalding White

Obituary. Frederick H. Collins died 12 December 1967 in NSW. For the past 20 years Mr Collins lived at the home of his daughter Mrs Glasson at ‘Mt Pleasant’ Dungowan, via Tamworth. He was the second son of John & Catherine Collins of ‘Collinsville’, Mt Bryan and is survived by his brothers: Newton, Arthur and Lindsay. He had an abiding love of cricket and was one of the founders of the Country Carnival and Captain of the Stockbreeders side until he left the state. [Frederick Henry Reginald Collins born 20 April 1885 Aberdeen, Burra.]

91, 3, 23 Jan. 1968, page 6

Jack Webster was 80 last week.

Birth. To Annette and Ian Cameron at Burra Hospital last week, a son, Timothy John.

Vivienne Packer, daughter of the local hospital secretary-manager Mr Len Packer & Mrs Packer, has been awarded a four-year scholarship after her first year of university studies in Arts.

Mr & Mrs Rod Cornelius will move into a new home on Smelts Road this week.

Porter’s Lagoon is almost dry, with just a few pools of water.

91, 4, 30 Jan. 1968, page 1

Burra High School. Examination Results. Grade 4 or higher results are published. The most outstanding result was that of Intermediate student Christopher Allan Freeman, son of Mr & Mrs A. Freeman of Booborowie, who gained English 3, History 1, Maths I 1, Maths II 1, Physics 1, Chemistry 1 and Woodwork 1.

(Grade 1 is the top 10% in the state, 2 is the next 15%, 3 the next 25%, 4 the next 25%, 5 the next 15% and 6 the last 10 %.)

In the following list the number of grades 4 or better are indicated with the number of grade 1 results in brackets

Staff Changes: Messrs D. Alfred and R. Johnson replace Messrs Morris and Norton.

Burra Primary School. Staff Changes:

Miss Neumeister comes from Adelaide.

Miss McKenzie comes from Mt Gambier.

Miss Marlene Spratt will be the non-teaching Headmistress. (Except when required by emergencies.)

Mr Lannan is the only male teacher at the Primary School.

Burra Mine. Drilling operations continue.

About 70 holes have been put down, some to 300 ft and samples are being analysed and the results checked with small shafts to about 50 ft, ten of which are to be sunk over ten of the 70 drill holes. Each will yield about 40 tons of material for checking at the Cobar facilities. It is hoped to complete one shaft each week. Bill Wiseman from Adelaide is in charge assisted by Supervisors Mr M. Corradini & Mr J. Boyce of Broken Hill.

Weather. A severe thunderstorm with hail struck an area between Farrell Flat and Hanson at about 2 p.m. last Wednesday. Hail as large as marbles fell and torrential rain for about 80 minutes with a total of about 320 points. Homes were flooded at Farrell Flat. The Burra Burra DC road gang was at work in the midst of it on the main road, which turned into a quagmire. On the other side of Farrell Flat the road’s top metal was washed away, but six miles on, where a Clare Council gang was working only about 60 points fell. The railway line was damaged and goods trains were delayed for some time. Water ran into Porter’s Lagoon, which had been practically dry. Water was a foot deep over the road at the Koonoona turn-off. Fences were washed away in the vicinity.

At C.W. Neill’s property 150 points fell and on the section known as ‘Riggs’ half the area was too wet to inspect and the rest received almost nothing. Piggott’s got an inch, but Ron Winders said he got nothing worth mentioning. At Gum Creek Robert Neill was harrowing on Thursday morning with one section of paddock providing good working and the other two or three hundred yards away was too hard to work. In all it did more harm than good except for the water catchment value.

91, 4, 30 Jan. 1968, page 6

Accident. A drawbar coupling a truck to a semi-trailer broke when it was on Moonlight Hill allowing the semi-trailer to roll backwards down the hill. With no brakes it mounted a three foot embankment and came to rest 70 yards inside Eberhard’s paddock. The semi had broken down on the way from Morgan and was being towed to Pt Augusta. It has now been decoded to effect repairs on the spot.

Advt. Burra Pictures, 2 February

Doctor in Charge

That Swinging City

Bowls. Associates: Burra Green defeated Burra Gold.

Weather. Patchy, but heavy rain has fallen in the east on Oakvale Station. Across the station falls in January have been: ‘Homestead’ 302 points, ‘Jacks’ 606, ‘Pearces’ 599, Mulga Bore 614 and Brook Bore 609. Last year the rainfall was 301 points for the year. All lakes and dams on the property have filled and the place is full of bird life.

91, 4, 30 Jan. 1968, page 7

John Simpson is 80 on 1 February.

Porter’s Lagoon received water the day after being reported almost dry last week. In 1917 it is said to have been 27 feet deep in parts.

Grant Matthews will begin work for the National Bank at Pt Augusta soon.

Marriage. At Grange last Saturday

Sandra Edwards married Captain Peter Dinham.

91, 5, 6 Feb. 1968, page 1

Saddleworth Cheese Factory. There is and article of c. 11⁄2 columns on the temporary closure of this enterprise.

Swimming. In the final round of the inter-club swimming competition at the Burra Pool on Friday night Spalding won the shield. [Results are printed.]

Football. Kevin Lane [Photo] has been appointed coach of the Burra ‘A’ Grade side for 1968. R. James withdrew his application and has been appointed coach of Aberdeen. In recent years Kevin Lane has been coach of Aberdeen in the Mid North Association.

Adelaide Wool Sales 30 January-1 February. Burra District was not strongly represented.

[Local district prices are printed.]

Theft. Burra Motor Co. was broke into for the second time in six months on Saturday night. Motor tyres and electric fans to the value of $350 were stolen along with some parts. Last July goods to the value of $256 were taken.

Rev. Milton Edwards was inducted into the Burra Methodist Circuit at Redruth on Sunday evening. The service was conducted by Rev. D.U.G. Mack of Riverton and the address was by Rev. B. Miche of Eudunda. Also present were Rev. D. Catford of Spalding and the [Anglican] Rector of Burra Rev. G.D. Sibly. A choir of 13 was accompanied by Mrs J. Oates at the organ. A social gathering followed. Mr & Mrs Edwards come to Burra from Hawker. The Mayor E.T. Baulderstone extended a welcome from the town.

91, 5, 6 Feb. 1968, page 2

The Burra Methodist Circuit has formed a Youth Movement open to all children in three groups: 7-8 year, 9-10 years and 11+ years.

Jack Lemmon & Shirley MacLaine in Irma La Douce

Plus Short Features

91, 5, 6 Feb. 1968, page 3

Advt. Elders-GM will sell on instructions from A.A. Guthrie at Booborowie Hall on 19 February, 306 acres of freehold land located four miles northeast of Booborowie, being Section 847 Hundred of Ayers with a four-roomed stone dwelling etc.

Obituary. Tom Edwards died at Broken Hill, suddenly on 30 January. He was a brother to Joe Edwards and brother-in-law of Doris.

[This would appear to be Thomas James Edwards born 2 November 1901 Copperhouse; given that his brother Joseph Leonard married Gwendoline Doris Kemble.]

91, 5, 6 Feb. 1968, page 6

Cricket. Booborowie 5 for 272 including D. Drew 102 retired v. Leighton 220.

John Richards the driver of the semi-trailer mentioned last week thanks all for their help, especially Jennison’s Tyre Service, Des Woolley and Mr & Mrs Brian Bevan. His motor blew up at Florieton when the cab temperature was 147°F. A day or so earlier near Hay he had been behind a transport driven by a mate when it burst into flames, killing the driver and his 10-year-old daughter. He hopes for an uneventful trip now to Perth and intends to give up driving and settle in Burra.

91, 6, 13 Feb. 1968, page 1

Burra Primary School. Enrolment for 1968 is 119 boys and 139 girls for a total of 258. Last year’s enrolment of 41 in Grade I compares with this year’s 27. [They are listed.]

New staff:

Miss Brigitte Neumeister comes from Western Teachers College

Miss Nadine McKenzie comes from Wattle Park Teachers College

Allocation of classes:

Miss Raelene Poticary takes Grade I, as she did in 1967.

Mrs Pens has Grade II.

Mrs Carpenter has Grade III.

Mrs Perry has Grade VI and Mr Lannan has Grade VII.

Burra High School has about the same enrolment as last year.

[The new students are named.]

New staff members are: Mr D. Alfred and Mr R. Johnson from Teachers College.

1968 will be the last year for both the Internal and Externally Examined Intermediate Certificate.

Prefects for 1968:

Girls: Elaine Broderick (Head), Beverley Collins, Lynette Griffen, Janet Harris, Alison Miller and Rosemary Ryan.

Boys: Christopher freeman (Head), Phillip Byles, Brian Josephs, Roger Przibilla, Andrew Ryan and Dennis Short.

Willalo School has 21 students; the same as in 1967. [New students are named.]

Mr B.R. Smith continues on as Head Teacher.

Leighton School has two more students this year, with a total of 28. [New students are named.]

Mr D. Munzberg is the Head Teacher.

Booborowie School, with an enrolment of 63, is down 3 on last year. Mr J. Kerin is Head Teacher, assisted by Mrs E. Brooks.

Telephone. A new trunk line between Burra and Mt Bryan will be in service from 20 February.

Des Woolley of Jennison’s Tyre Service has won the Ford Motor Co.’s Pacemaker’s Award for the third year in succession. He averaged four vehicle sales per week throughout the year.

91, 6, 13 Feb. 1968, page 7

J.H. Phelan is ALP Candidate for Burra. He is a 46-year-old shearer of Hallett. He is President of the Hallett RSL, on the Hallett Institute Committee and a member of the Burra RSL Committee. He is a former potato grower and farmer in the South East and was wounded in action in New Guinea in WW II.

Obituary. Mr Patrick Joseph Shane of Spalding died suddenly yesterday.

[Born 1 May 1909 Spalding: died 12 February 1968 Spalding.]

Shirley Simpson of Burra North has started nursing at Burra Hospital.

Marriage. At Redruth Methodist Church next Saturday

Lynette Gill will marry Peter Griffiths.

Birth. To Jean & Ray McInnes at Burra Hospital last week, a son, Alexander Duncan.

91, 6, 13 Feb. 1968, page 8

Ernest Claude Allen JP, LCL Candidate for Burra is a farmer of Andrews who has served 12 years on the Spalding District Council; eight as Chairman. He has been an advisory member of Spalding Rural Youth and a former Fire Controller for the area. He has been greatly involved with cricket, tennis and bowls in Spalding and Andrews.

W.J. Ahern is the DLP Candidate for Burra. He was born in Port Lincoln and educated there. He served an apprenticeship as a carpenter and joiner at Whyalla. For the last ten years he and a partner have established a business as building contractors. He is a member of the Clare Hospital Board and a Committee Member of Nadjuri Lodge Home for the Aged and Chairman of Clare Inter-Church Council and President of the Clare Branch of the DLP.

91, 7, 20 Feb. 1968, page 1

Burra Swimming Pool. There are rumours about the water treatment of the pool this year. In fact the water is very clean and has been in excellent condition throughout the season. There are, however, some dead algae on the floor of the pool, which vacuum cleaning alone cannot shift due to the rough surface. After consultation with experts it is now being moved using stainless steel brushes, though a stain on the bottom will remain. The pool is still open and has not been closed or condemned.

Fire. A fire in the Koomooloo Station homestead on Tuesday last caused damage estimated at $12,000. It began at about 7.45 a.m. in the domestic section of a building attached by verandah to the main homestead and occupied by Mr & Mrs Michael Avery and family. Mr Avery was working at the woolshed drafting sheep when smoke was noticed coming from the house. Mrs Avery tried to enter the kitchen, but was driven back by the heat. She ran around the outside to an end entrance where Miss Davies, the governess, was called from the room. Mr Avery tried to hose down the fire, but the pressure was inadequate and a thousand gallons tank and pump was brought by truck from a nearby paddock. The connecting verandah was torn down to save the rest of the house. Only a small part of the attached building was saved. The source is unclear, but probably one of two kerosene fridges or a combustion type water heater was the origin. Temperatures on the day were well over 100°F. Sgt Orford and Constable K. Terry of Burra are preparing a report for the coroner.

Burra High School. Christopher freeman, son of Mr & Mrs A. Freeman of Booborowie has gained an Intermediate Bursary.

Malcolm White, son of Mr & Mrs K. White of Burra North and Andrew Ryan, son of Mr & Mrs J. Ryan of Burra won Continuation Exhibitions. All of the scholarships are for two years and worth $50 for the first and $60 for the second year.

The Advertiser tennis coaching school visited on Tuesday last with Messrs Clem Teague and Alan Rose.

91, 7, 20 Feb. 1968, page 2

Born Free

James Stacy in Winter A Go Go

Burra Annual Open Swimming Carnival was held in ideal conditions last Sunday. The profit is expected to be $40-$50 from 400 nominations for the events of the day. [Results are printed.]

Tennis

‘A’ Grade Mt Bryan 15-107 defeated Spalding 5 sets
