91, 7, 20 Feb. 1968, page 5

Burra Hospital. Work on the new theatre building is progressing to the stage where the roof is being put on. The building contains sixteen rooms and includes a new casualty department. When work on this section is completed the old theatre and casualty section will be demolished or converted to two domestic bedrooms and sewing room etc. A parking area is being created across the road with 2-3,000 cubic yards of filling from the site and trees have been planted there. Donations for the building fund have now reached $12,518.50.

91, 7, 20 Feb. 1968, page 6

Weather. Thursday had showers and on Sunday there were variable falls from a few points to 160 at Morgan. Princess Royal recorded 156 points, ‘The Gums’ 100, World’s End 80, Mt Bryan 10, Burra 44, Balah 21 and Mt Bryan East 3 points. More rain fell at ‘The Gums’ today with 50 points to 11 a.m. and rain still falling. A further 30 points have been reported from Princess Royal.

Mrs Lorna Norris nee Bowen sent in a photo yesterday of the business premises of A.J. Hunt, saddler, now K.J. Murphy’s and before this the shop was owned by Mr Nicholls, the jeweller. Three men in the photo were the owner, Alfred Hunt, his son Reuben and nephew William Hunt. William Hunt said it was taken 56 years ago when he was 17 and had completed almost five years of his apprenticeship. At 73 he still wears a white apron and works with leather. The shops on either side of Hunt’s then were both owned by C.C. Williams, ironmonger. (Now the Record office and J. Hill’s.)

91, 7, 20 Feb. 1968, page 7

91, 8, 27 Feb. 1968, page 1

Adelaide Wool Sales. Most bales were from higher rainfall areas. [Local district prices are listed.]

Burra Pictures have shown improved attendance figures. The average for January and February was 131 per week compared with an average of 70 for the previous six months. On Saturday Born Free attracted 310.

Roadwork. Next week the Burra Town Council will construct and seal St Just and Sancreed Streets. A grant of $2,700 and Council input of $700 has made this possible. It is hoped also to be able to seal the road from the new bridge to the Showgrounds.

91, 9, 5 Mar. 1968, page 1

State Election

[Figures by booth are printed.]

Legislative Council

LCL 1011

ALP 684

Burra Burra Show Inc, AGM

M.G. Stockman reported on the 93rd show [It was nothing like the 93rd!] opened by Hon. C.R. Kelly MHR on 7 October 1967. With a new record number of entries it was a great success. Horse in Action Section was again the highlight. Wool entries were satisfactory despite the poor season. The sheep pavilion was nicely filled. Flowers were very good again despite the dry season. The district schools put on a good display and the Industrial Displays were numerous and comprehensive. The Agricultural Pavilion was well filled with produce, vegetable, cookery, art and needlework. Poultry and birds were well represented and dog and goat entries are increasing each year. Many thanks go to the stewards and convenors and to the new secretary, Julie Sara. Financially it was a success and the overdraft is gradually being reduced.

91, 9, 5 Mar. 1968, pages 1 & 4

Postal Deliveries in Burra will be made easier by the allocation of street numbering, which will also benefit visitors to the town. East and West Wards have been completed and North Ward will follow soon.

Numbering began from the creek for streets running east-west. Other streets are numbered from the Main Street, Commercial Street and Kingston Street. Corner blocks were allocated the number of the main street. Where there are houses on only one side (as in Bridge Terrace) numbers are consecutive.

Page 4 carries the addresses for each person in East and West Wards.

91, 9, 5 Mar. 1968, page 2

Advt. Dalgety-NZL on instructions from Mr J.L. Connors of Mt Bryan will sell 471 acres freehold at the RSL Hall, Burra, 8 March. It is located 3 miles south of Mt Bryan and 9 miles north of Burra, comprising sections 174 and 33 of the Hundred of Kingston with a five-roomed stone dwelling etc. [Improvements are described.]

Advt. Burra Pictures, 9 March

Carry on Screaming

Herbert Lom, John Gregson & Sean Connery in The Frightened City

Burra Basketball Club held it AGM, but only nine members attended. Elected: President, Mrs A. Day; Vice-President, Miss J. Pens; Joint Secretaries, Mrs M. Anderson & W. Anderson. This year it is intended to field one team in each of the A, B, & C grades.

91, 9, 5 Mar. 1968, page 6

Burra Football Club held its AGM on Friday in the Town Hall Supper Room with 42 members and supporters present. Elected: President, L.A. Beinke; Vice-President, A.G. Baulderstone; Secretary, Russell Nicholls and Treasurer, G. Short. Outgoing President E.C. Pietsch reported on a successful year financially and socially. [Thanks are expressed all round.] Special thanks went to Coach, Barry Eberhard; Colts Manager, Tony Fillmore; Colts Coach, Jimmy James and his assistant Max Anderson and to Malcolm Beinke for wiring the new training lights without charge and to Mr Fuss for alterations and changes to the dressing rooms. Congratulations went to Barry Eberhard for winning the Mail Medal for the second year in succession and for winning the Umpires’ Trophy for the State. Significant costs for the year had been the installation of quartz floride [sic] lights at $518, new guernseys at $142, changes to the dressing room $63 and contribution to oval improvements $400.

91, 9, 5 Mar. 1968, page 7

Cricket. Hallett 270 v. Burra Footballers.

Colin & Essie Morison & family are now living in Guildford in Surrey, England.

For Flower Day in Adelaide for the Festival of Arts Burra’s contribution is lot 249 in Victoria Square, courtesy of the Floral Art Club’s Mesdames Pettet & Lloyd: gold and white flowers on a frame 7 ft high made by Dudley Jacka.

Marriage. Adelaide last Saturday

Judith James, daughter of Mr & Mrs Ken James of Burra North married Kevin Kellaway.

Obituary. Mrs Baulderstone Sen. mother of Mr Ted Baulderstone has died aged 87.

Burra Mine. Three men, ‘Jock’, Hugh and Andy Brown, are working there at present. They recently put in a small shaft near Peacock’s and at about 43 ft broke into a drive off the main shaft and found an old four pint billy-can and small pannikin and a ‘pickaxe’ bottle, which they gave to the local museum.

Television. Many people found GTS4 a welcome addition to their television – though some only get pictures and other only get sound.

91, 10, 12 Mar. 1968, page 1

The RSL held its AGM on Friday night. Elected: President, Wilf Nankivell; Vice-Presidents, B.A. Riggs & T.R. Rogers; Treasurer, A. Wright; Secretary, Ben Kotz and Pension Officers H. Cornelius and B.A. Riggs.

The President reported on a successful year with better attendance. The Anzac Day service was conducted by the Ministers’ Fraternal and was preceded by a march of ex-service personnel led by the Marananga Band. Remembrance Day was also observed and badge days conducted for Legacy, Poppy Day and the Anzac Appeal. With reduced income the Legacy Wards supported were reduced to one. Four ex-servicemen of the club died during the year: S. Moore, Lindsay Hood, Horton Jennison and Roy Earle. Three members left the district in Alick Ford, Jim Kelly & Vern Riggs. A contingent from New Zealand was entertained at a Dinner Social in November when about 55 members attended. The club rooms have been painted and a new iron façade placed on the verandah and a new fence erected. The Pt Pirie Pipe Band will attend and lead the annual Anzac Parade this year.

Neil Humphrys, son of Mr & Mrs Mervyn Humphrys of Hanson, who is 21 this month, has been working for two years at Radio 5AU and has now accepted an offer to go to Radio 3HA at Hamilton in Victoria, where he will work with Victoria’s top DJs.

Leo Kelly of Sydney writes seeking any stories and reminiscences of the construction of the Overland Telegraph from Pt Augusta to Darwin in 1870-72.

Burra Kindergarten held its AGM 4 March and elected President, Mrs W. Salter; Vice-President, Mrs G. Nourse; Secretary, Mrs E. Clode and Treasurer, Mrs Dean Bernhardt.

Dalgety-NZL’s auction of M.J.L. Connor’s land at Mt Bryan saw bidding start at $90 per acre and it was passed in at $116.

Burra Town Council will improve the safety of school children by installing large ‘Children’ signs on the highway opposite the Town Hall and swing bridge approach. [The swing bridge had been demolished in 1960 and closed for some time before that!] ‘School’ signs will be installed on Bridge Terrace near the school and ‘Children’ signs in Kingston Street.

Burra Camera Club continues to be active and meets on the fourth Monday each month at their ‘Johnny Green’ Theatrette at the rear of the Town Hall.

91, 10, 12 Mar. 1968, page 2

North Eastern Football League made Mr Jack Jenner of Spalding its first Life Member at a cabaret at Booborowie on 8 March. He had been President of 13 years.

Ronald Foster & Merry Anders in House of the Damned

91, 10, 12 Mar. 1968, page 4

Burra & District Floral Art Club held its AGM and elected: President, Mrs R. Fuller and Secretary, Mrs R. Pritchard. A flower display will be held again this year to aid the floor appeal. Membership in 1967 was 25, up from 17 in 1966. Average at meetings was 11.

Obituary. Annie (Nance) Fitzgerald of Spalding died at Jamestown Hospital on 13 February after a long illness aged 71. [Born Annie Crichton 6 October 1896 Alberton.]

Aberdeen Basketball Club held its AGM and elected: President, Mrs B. Stockman; Vice-Presidents, Mrs F. Ford & Mrs R. Steele; Secretary, Mrs R. Cullen and Treasurer, Mrs H. Kakoschke. The club had a good last season, being successful to the finals. The court is now lit for night play in a project which cost $693 and the court has been top dressed for $330. A number of successful money-raising events were held.

91, 11, 19 Mar. 1968, page 1

State Election

Declaration of the Poll for Burra at Burra Town Hall on Friday:

Ahearn (DLP) 601

Allen (LCL) 3128

Phelan (ALP) 1767

Informal 96

Total 5592

Mr Quirke, who had retired from the seat after 27 years, addressed the gathering, as did the candidates.

Football. Northern Areas Association has eliminated club boundaries and raised the age limit of colt’s players from 15 to 16 as at 1 January.

Burra Fire Brigade was put through its annual inspection on 9 March. Chief Fire Officer T.J. Murray was pleased with the result. No penalties were incurred on the report sheet, which is an exceptionally good effort.

Burra High School held its annual induction of prefects and acceptance of House Captains at a ceremony on Friday in the rejuvenated Garden of Memory. More than 150 parents and friends attended. Mayor Baulderstone then unveiled the Memorial Cairn erected by the Parents & Friends’ Association to commemorate old scholars who paid the supreme sacrifice in WW II.

91, 11, 19 Mar. 1968, page 2

John Mills, Michael Cane, Tony Hancock & Peter Sellars in The Wrong Box

The American Grand Prix film: Road Racers

Redruth Methodist Guild held its annual meeting on 14 March. Mrs R.M. Jennison reported on a busy year. Average attendance at the 16 meetings had been 26. Elected: President, Mrs V. Cox; Vice-Presidents, Mrs Edwards & Mrs N. Baynes; Secretary, Mrs R. Jennison and Treasurer, Miss C. Reed. [Details in 3⁄4 column.]

Burra Primary School held its Annual Meeting on 18 March when 50 parents and teachers met in the Assembly Hall. Parents were able to meet their children’s teachers for an informal chat as well as attend the AGM. Many aids and much equipment was purchased by the Welfare Club in the past year. Mr R. Moreland reported on the work done by the School Committee in the past twelve months. It is suggested improvements to the oval and area in front of the school could be a project for 1968. Mr R. Moreland was elected Chairman of the School Committee and Mr L. Moore is the Secretary.

91, 11, 19 Mar. 1968, page 5

Burra Primary School Welfare Club had 65 members present at its first meeting for 1968. Retiring President Mrs J. Carpenter reported on a busy year in which $900 had been spent on the school. Elected were: President, Mrs S. Kirt; Vice-Presidents, Mrs L. Jennison & Mrs C. Stockman; Secretary, Mrs A. Webster; Assistant Secretary, Mrs M. Alderson and Treasurer, Mrs M. Broad.

The President reported on four main projects for the year.

A 10 ft cyclone backdrop was placed on the eastern side of the tennis court for $300.

New curtains were hung in the school library. They are lined to make film projection possible in the day time.

A new typewriter was purchased.

The publication of a recipe book for which many thanks go to Mrs Ray Alderson for her editing work and to the Grade VII children who canvassed the town and sold $100 worth of the books.

(Items 1 & 3 were subsidised by the Education Department.)

The sports day and birthday social were both successful as social events and as money-raising efforts.

The Welfare Club also provided the usual expendable materials used in sports and maths, in first aid and in the library. Expenditure for the year amounted to about $900 and there is still a balance of approximately $370.

In the semi-finals

Koonaburra 221 v. Hallett 0 for 28

North Booborowie 186 v. Booborowie 1 for 100

Phil Rule of Hamilton Place, Adelaide, writes wondering if sports at Burra could be given a boost by making the racecourse property into a Community Sports Arena. He suggests that if it is done it be called the James Gallagher Memorial Sports Ground, in tribute to the man sho did much work and dug deep into his own pocket to support sports in Burra and was the first Chairman of the Syndicate which started the idea of the grounds many years ago. The avenue of pines could be named Birdseye Avenue in honour of the late Alf Birdseye, who planted and tended the trees in their early stages.

91, 12, 26 Mar. 1968, page 1

The Rural Youth Ball was organised as a Reunion Ball and many former members came for the occasion on Friday night. Past Presidents entertained past members at a pre-ball party in the RSL Hall. Miss Shirley Thomas was judged Belle of the Ball and Mrs John Quinn was deemed Matron of the Ball. Music was supplied by Damon Harding’s ‘Modernaires’ of Clare. Mr Maurice Collins was MC. Door takings were $409 and it is hoped to clear about $300. [Photo 91, 13, 2 April 1968, page 1.]

1968 Stud Merino Field Days are listed. The program runs from 1 April at Gawler to 5 April at Whyte Yarcowie.

Thursday 4 April features Hanson, Burra & MT Bryan with M.R. & E.J. Humphrys ‘Glenowie’ Hanson, W. Brown & Co. ‘The Grove’ Burra, L.W. Gare & Sons ‘Mt Glenview’ Burra North, John Collins & Sons ‘Collinsville’ Mt Bryan, Mackerode Pty Ltd ‘Mackerode’ Mt Bryan, M.A. Gebhardt & Son ‘Woollana’ Mt Bryan and Melton Stud Pty Ltd ‘Melton’ Mt Bryan.

Aberdeen Tennis Club held an outdoor luncheon in the garden of Mr & Mrs Geoff. Pearce. It raised c. $130 towards the relating of the surface on No. 2 court. Guest speaker was Mrs N. Orford, wife of the Sergeant in charge of the Burra Police, who spoke on ‘The Life of a Police Recruit’. Takings were $167.40.

Geoff. Dare of Mt Bryan has been chosen to represent Australia as an International Farm Youth Exchangee. He leaves Adelaide on Sunday for the USA. He is a prominent member of Burra Rural Youth Club and of the Upper North Zone Committee. He will take the P & O liner Canberra from Sydney to Vancouver and then travel to Seattle for orientation. He will return to Australia in January. He was farewelled at the Burra Rural Youth meeting last night.

91, 12, 26 Mar. 1968, page 7

Warnes’ Fiat. A local resident went to town recently to see the display of old cars at Wayville and met a member of the Warnes Family there with an old Fiat on show. [A 1924 Fiat 510.]

91, 12, 26 Mar. 1968, page 8

Burra Primary School Committee. Chairman R.A. Moreland’s Report

Discussion has resulted in the Public Buildings Department being about to install a fire hydrant. Sports day on the War Memorial Oval on 28 April was a great success. Many parents attended Arbor Day. Burra Burra DC has helped in filling and levelling the creek area of the oval. It was decided to crop the old garden area to produce hay for sale, but although the ground was sown by Mr K. Gare and germinated well, the rains failed and the crop was lost. Mr Wardle purchased the paddock at the rear of the school, impeding access to Burra North. He agreed to allow access along the side of Mrs Tattersall’s residence and the Public Buildings Department is preparing to provide an access path there. The Town Council has tidied up and screened the section of footpath to Mrs Tattersall’s and provided a pipe for the drain. A school crossing has been made in front of the Town Hall. We are negotiating with the Education Department for future accommodation to be supplied in Burra. Mr & Mrs Auhl were farewelled. In 1967 Mrs Villis resigned and her position was taken by Miss Satchell. Miss Satchell was later transferred and Mrs Carpenter filled the position. Mrs Said was also transferred. This year there are two new teachers and a new Headmistress. The Town Council advises that the land in front of the school has been transferred to the Education Department.

91, 13, 2 Apr. 1968, page 1

Accident. A semi-trailer loaded with cattle overturned at Hanson on Friday night. The driver suffered broken ribs. Two transports owned by Whittam Transport Pty Ltd of Strathalbyn were taking cattle from Strathalbyn to Broken Hill. The second vehicle overturned at the Hanson corner. The driver was Mr Darrell Malcolm Wray of Meadows. Most of the 68 cows and calves were roaming around. One calf was killed and another three cows had to be destroyed. The lost animals were valued at $500. Damage to the vehicle was estimated at $3,800. Mr Tom Rogers and others helped round up the cattle. The district Council grader and bulldozer were used to right the vehicle on Saturday morning. Another prime-mover was brought in and the damaged one returned to Strathalbyn.

Burra High School Parents & Friends’ Association

After two years as President Mrs D.H. Field retired. Elected were: President, Mrs F. Matthews; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames R. Francis & H. Griffen; Secretary, Mrs B. Bevan; Assistant Secretary, Mrs J. Bogisch and Treasurer, Mrs P.W. Carpenter. The big events for the year were the Annual Ball, the Annual Banquet and the Northern School’s Athletics Day, held at Burra in May 1967. This year’s School Social will be held on 5 April in the Town Hall as the climax to Sports Day. Certificates for the Alternative Course examinations in 1967 will then be presented.

St Mary’s Church will mark the beginning of Holy Week with a special Ecumenical Service next Sunday. Music will be provided by the Burra Choral Society, the Anglican Church Quartet and a special trio with Dr J.V. Peters at the organ.

Aberdeen Basketball Club held its annual Gala Day at the Oddfellows’ Hall and as a result c. $140 will go to club funds. [Prize winners for the Pet Show section are listed.]

Turning Indicator Lights will be required on vehicles from 1 July 1968. [Certain exemptions are listed.]

Vandalism. Damage totalling c. $44 was done to the grandstand at the racecourse where twelve windows were broken over the weekend. Also broken were twelve platform lights and the signal arm and glass of the Permission Signal north of the station.

Mr G. Morgan, Burra postmaster, is disappointed that local use of postcodes is about 65%. The State average is 70% for business and 69% for private mail.

Rev. & Mrs G.D. Sibly and family will be farewelled in the Parish Hall after Sunday’s Ecumenical Service.

Burra Mine Copper Specimen. The News reports that the SA Museum has acquired what is believed to be the largest piece of uncut malachite in the world. It comes from Burra and weighs 69 lb. It won a copper medal at the 1868 Philadelphia Exhibition.

91, 13, 2 Apr. 1968, page 8

Burra Small Bore Club. Best over double 75 yards were L. Moore, J. Bowden and K. Talbot.

91, 14, 9 Apr. 1968, page 1

Vandalism. Police have apprehended young offenders responsible for damage at the Railway Station, the Slaughterhouse and a house in West Street. They believe they have also identified those concerned with breaking the windows at the racecourse grandstand.

Burra High School Social on Friday night was a highly successful event with 350 attending. The ‘Cascades’ provided music for dancing. Intermediate Alternative Course Certificates were distributed.

Cricket. Phillip Byles (16) has won the 1967-68 H. Black Trophy presented to the most outstanding cricketer in the Mokota Association. It is calculated on batting, bowling and fielding votes and on the number of catches. Phillip scored 170 points, ahead of J. Honan with 156. He is in his second season with the Koonaburra Club and is still eligible for junior cricket, but elected to play with the senior team. For the season the highest run scorer was Kevin Cousins with 874. Phillip Byles captured the most wickets at 54 and Kevin Cousins had the most catches with 19.

St Mary’s Ecumenical Service on Sunday required extra seating in the church. After a fine service the congregation crowded the Parish Hall to farewell Rev. Sibly and his family. Robert Reed called on the Mayor to speak. Mr Baulderstone said Mr Sibly had served as a Councillor for almost a year and had been a wonderful asset to the town. Mr Stanley Hawker spoke for the other centres and Mrs Matthews spoke for the Ladies’ Guild. Mr Bob Farrow spoke of the wonderful spirit of co-operation between Methodists and Anglicans in the community and thanked Mr Sibly for his ready help in all things. Mr Tom Perry spoke as a Warden.

Table Tennis Tournament at the Oddfellows’ Hall 1 & 2 April.

Women’s Handicap Singles Dianne Day

Men’s Championship Singles Allen Day

Women’s Championship Singles Dianne Day

Men’s Handicap Doubles Kevin Lane & Don Lloyd

Women’s Handicap Doubles Kath Christie & Dianne Day

Mixed Handicap Doubles W. Warner Sen. & A. Warner

Men’s championship Doubles W. Warner Sen. & W. Warner Jnr

Women’s Championship Doubles Kath Christie & Dianne Day

Mixed Championship Doubles W. Warner Sen. & A. Warner

91, 14, 9 Apr. 1968, pages 1 & 3

The Annual Field Days organised by 46 studs were concluded on Friday on a satisfactory note. The wool market has been depressed and seasonal conditions have been adverse. Daily following this year was between 700 and 1,000, estimated to be 25% down on last year’s record. Mr Cowell, a representative of SA Stud Breeders, said stockowners favoured a lifting of the ban on exporting Merino sheep, because the world needed to produce more good apparel wool – in India for example the average fleece was only 2 lb. The embargo was introduced in 1929. Mr Simpson from Queensland agreed. Mr Toll of WA said the Wool Conference in Perth favoured lifting the ban on the export of rams, under controlled conditions. [A summary of sales is printed on page 3.]

91, 14, 9 Apr. 1968, pages 1 & 4

Junior Boys’ Cup Peter Byles & Michael Broderick (tie)

[Results are printed.]

Advt. Elders-GM will well on instructions from K.R. Phillips Pty Ltd 461 acres of freehold lucerne property at Mt Bryan on Wednesday 17 April in Burra RSL Hall.

Located close to Mt Bryan Township.

Advt. Burra Town Hall, 15 April 8 p.m.

Brian Young presents The Sound of Country Music

Featuring Paul Lester and The Spring Dusters.

91, 15, 16 Apr. 1968, page 1

Burra Hospital

The new theatre and casualty block at the Burra Hospital is nearing completion. The new building will have the same floor level as the remainder of the Hospital and its tiled floors, shining fixtures and fittings will lend itself to sterility and efficiency. A diesel plant automatically comes into operation when a power fault occurs; the changeover takes fifteen seconds and this is covered by a battery operated second auxiliary, whose batteries are automatically kept charged. As soon as the new theatre is ready the old theatre block will be reconstructed into domestic quarters, a board room and a sewing room. Despite the difficult seasons lately the Departmental Inspector reports that the district has raised $12,565 to the 29 February. The Hospital’s financial position is satisfactory. Average costs have fallen because occupied bed strength has increased by 2.3 per day and this has resulted from the increased use of beds by pensioner patients. Mrs G. Stanley Hawker and other members of her family have presented a painting The Bark Painter by George Chaloupka, which will hang in the main hallway. It is a memorial to their mother the late Mrs E.M. Fetherstonhaugh.

Steele Hall, Leader of the Opposition, writes an article on the subject of State Electoral Boundaries.

The Miss Industry Quest of SA raises money for the Home for Incurables at Fullarton. [There is a 1-column article on the work of that institution.] The Burra entrant this year is Kathryn White [photograph printed] and for Robertstown is Miss Leslie Mosey.

Paxton Square

The Lewis Trust which owns historic Paxton Square has recently been expanded to include local trustees as well as two trustees from the Lewis family. Mr Robert Lewis, former Master of St Mark’s College, Adelaide, resigned as Public Officer and Chairman of the Lewis Trust earlier this year when he went to become Master of Menzies College at Latrobe University, Melbourne. He is a son of the late Essington Lewis. Rev. G.D. Sibly was elected in his place as Chairman and Public Officer and five other prominent leading citizens were elected to the Board of Management. Some tidying up has followed and the trustees now intend to evaluate the whole position of the buildings forming the square. Paxton Square is unique in Australia, not only as a well-preserved example of Cornish architecture, but because it marks the first attempt by an employer to provide mass housing for its employees. The employer was the SA Mining Assoc., which had established Kooringa as their private town on Section 1, which they had bought for $20,000. Until the Mine closed in September 1877 all houses and shops in Burra were leased from the Mining Association.

[This is incorrect. Initially SAMA granted only leasehold in Kooringa, but from 1868 freehold was granted and was encouraged through the 1870s, though SAMA remained a significant landlord well into the 20th century, with a final attempt to sell off remaining properties in 1912 in its winding up operations.]

Early in 1852 the bulk of the men employed in the Mine left for the Victorian gold-diggings and it was well into 1853 before they returned and work could be resumed at the Mine. In the meantime the Association had taken steps to bring out miners from England and it was to provide homes for these underground workers that Paxton Square was built.

[This is also incorrect. See Ian Auhl, Paxton Square Burra South Australia, Investigator Press, n.d. in which he cites the evidence for the construction of the cottages earlier than this. A painting of 1850 by S.T. Gill shows 11 cottages on the western side and some on the southern side. They are also marked on the 1849 plan of Kooringa. There construction was a response to flooding of dugouts in the creek banks. Of course, some of the miners mentioned above could well have been housed there.]

The 33 cottages were built by Cornishmen for Cornish miners. In later years [1913] when the Mining Association was selling its properties in Kooringa, the Hon. John Lewis, father of Essington Lewis, purchased the Square and at his death [1923] the houses were left in trust to house the needy and poor of Burra.

[This had been his intention in 1913 and he had hoped to see nominal ownership vested in the Town Council. They declined because they feared being saddled with the maintenance costs.]

In 1845 William Paxton was a young chemist living behind his shop in Rundle Street, Adelaide, when Burra copper was discovered. Paxton with Bunce and other Rundle [& Hindley] Street shop-keepers subscribed the necessary capital. Paxton invested $240. Within a year the $10 shares were worth $200 and the dividend was 600%. Paxton bought more shares and became a Mine Director and a wealthy man. He acquired large properties in Kooringa, owning the two hotels and Paxton Square, where the cottages were later built. He later ran for Parliament for Port Adelaide, but his interests in politics gave way to pastoral pursuits. The cottages originally had dirt floors and no verandahs. There have been few changes to them over the years.

91, 15, 16 Apr. 1968, page 2

Burra Burra DC. Annual Elections.

The following members retire due to the effluxion of time and nominations are called by 10 May for their replacement, with elections on 6 July if required.

Farrell Flat Ward J.H.J. Stevens

Kooringa Ward G.R. Finch

Leighton Ward R.J. White

Mongolata Ward B.A. Riggs

Accident/Obituary. C.W. (Bill) Knight of Burra aged 56 died as the result of an accident at Booborowie in the early hours of Friday morning. Mr Knight had been working north of Broken Hill for the past five weeks and was coming home for Easter. He dropped a workmate off at Caltowie at about midnight and then proceeded to Burra. Near Booborowie Hall he failed to negotiate a bend and the station wagon he was driving ran into a culvert on the right hand side of the road, resulting in his death. [Clarence William Knight born 8 December 1911 Thebarton: died 12 April 1968 Booborowie, residence Burra North.]

Stockowners Association of SA. The Burra branch held its AGM in the RSL Hall last week and elected: President, E.L. McWaters; Vice-Presidents, D.V. Lord & F.H. Treweeke and Joint Secretaries, A.L. Wright & R.L. Wuttke.

91, 15, 16 Apr. 1968, page 4

Cricket. Mokota Cricket Association.

K. Cousins of Booborowie topped the batting with 874 runs.

He also topped the catches with 19.

P. Byles of Koonaburra took most wickets with 54 for 285.

For Koonaburra:

Top run scorer was A. Fillmore 483.

R. Brandt took 18 catches.

For Burra Footballers:

A. Baulderstone was best batsman with 325.

Alan Baulderstone was also best bowler with 27 for 585.

No one in this team took 10 or more catches.

91, 15, 16 Apr. 1968, page 5

Ivon Wardle JP was born in Burra and is now assistant Town Clerk of Murray Bridge. He has just won the seat of Murray in the House of assembly for the LCL. He was born at Burra 23 April 1919 to Stanley and Victoria Wardle, nee Smelt. Mr Bert Wardle and Mr Lewis Gare are his uncles. The family moved to Murray Bridge district in 1927. He was educated at the Institute of Technology, the Adelaide Conservatorium and Wesley College. After service in the RAAF he was ordained a Methodist Minister and served the Booborowie-Willalo Circuit 1949-53, while living at Spalding. In 1953 he was appointed Immigration Chaplain and visited many parts of Europe and the UK. Family health reasons compelled him to retire from the ministry. He married Miss Dorothy Briggs and has three children. The eldest, Malcolm, is a bank officer, Lynette is an infant teacher and Ian is a trainee teacher.

Notice. Burra Town Council, Annual Elections.

The following retire on Saturday 6 July due to the effluxion of time.

91, 16, 23 Apr. 1968, page 1

Weather. Light patchy rain has been general. For the week the agricultural areas have reported 25-40 points. To the east the falls have been more varied, from 34 at Woolgangi to 110 at Quondong and 150 at Faraway.

Rev. John Stephenson will be inducted as Rector of St Mary’s tomorrow.

Accident. A car driven by Mr C. Stannard of Burra North overturned at Steelton, and was extensively damaged without injuring the driver.

Anzac Service. The Port Pirie Pipe Band led the march at Burra on Sunday. After the wreath laying at the Memorial the service was conducted in the RSL Hall. In the evening a combined service was held in the Redruth Methodist Church, conducted by Rev. Milton Edwards with Rev. Geoff Sibly (Anglican) giving the address and reading the lesson, as his last official function as Rector of Burra.

[Services at Spalding, Saddleworth, Hallett and Booborowie are also reported.]

Football begins next Saturday. The Football Commissioners of the Mid North and the North Eastern League have met for the first time in many years to discuss some difficulties, mainly in respect to granting clearances and issuing permits. One of the issues was the matter of players between Aberdeen and Burra and this was resolved with a number of automatic clearances between the clubs to close a matter running for a long period of years.

Burra Primary School Sports were held 19 April in poor conditions, with rain, wind and dust at times. Despite all this it was a good day’s sport. Aberdeen House was eventually victorious. [Details in 11⁄3 columns.]

91, 16, 23 Apr. 1968, page 2

Burra Small Bore Club. Best over double 50 yards were K. Talbot, L. Moore & P. Mengersen.

Ernest Stanley Brown born 22 March 1895 Narridy near Crystal Brook: died 21 April 1968 Magill, residence Burra North.]

A Bowls Tournament on Thursday night raised $30 for the Miss Industry Quest.

Marriage. St Paul’s Anglican Church Naracoorte next Saturday

Keith Neill of Farrell Flat will marry Heather Lucas. He is bank officer at Millicent.

Don Bruce of Farrell Flat and his mate Bob Searle of Snowtown have been working at Winnininnie, thirteen miles from Yunta and last week they came across a slab of slate inscribed T J. McInnes 1884, but with the J and 4 reversed. Was slate ever mined at Winnininnie and who was T.J. McInnes?

[SA Births, Marriages and Deaths offer no immediate suggestions.]

91, 17, 30 Apr. 1968, page 1

Burra Hospital has received a further $500 from the Frank & Hilda Perry Trust. Last year this trust provided $1,000 for the Building Fund.

91, 17, 30 Apr. 1968, page 1 CHECK DATE: my notes have 23 April

Football Anzac Day Lightning Carnival

Burra 3.2 defeated Blyth 1.2

Semi-Final: Burra 4.5 defeated Watchman 1.1

Final: Burra 11.8 defeated Mintaro 1.2

St Mary’s. Rev. John H. Stephenson was inducted at St Mary’s on Wednesday evening. The service was conducted by the Bishop of Willochra, Rt Rev. T.E. Jones.

Rev. G.D. Sibly was the organist. Church Warden Robert Reed presented the minister elect to the Bishop.

After the service the welcome to the Stephensons continued in the Parish Hall. Mayor E.T. Baulderstone welcomed the Stephensons to the town. Mrs Matthews spoke for the Ladies’ Guild. Mr John Murray of Hallett spoke for the Wardens. Rev. Milton Edwards spoke for the Methodists and Monsignor Hughes represented the Catholic Church. A number of other Anglican ministers were present.

Mr R. Thamm had two bicycles stolen from the rear of his home on Monday. They were later recovered, badly damaged.

Shooting at Burra North. On Tuesday night police were summoned to the railway camp train at Burra Station. Mrs Bessie Emma Treloar, cook, had suffered multiple shots to the abdomen from a .22 rifle. The shooting occurred in the cook’s sleeping quarters at the end of a carriage used as a kitchen. After preliminary treatment at Burra hospital, the victim was rushed to the Adelaide Hospital accompanied by Dr L.G. Miller. After an operation she is in a satisfactory condition. Police have charged a 47-year-old SAR cook, Colin James Kavanagh, with attempted murder.

Obituary. Lance-Corporal Leon Fisher, eldest son of Mr & Mrs Len Fisher of Mintaro, was killed in Bien Hoa Province, South Vietnam, on Friday. Leon was well known in football circles in the district.

91, 17, 30 Apr. 1968, pages 1 & 6

Weather. In the last week there has been high wind and two heavy dust storms, but on Saturday steady soaking rain fell. The dust has been worse to the east where some homesteads reported removing a wheelbarrow of dirt per room. Some sheep have been weighed down by the weight of the dust followed by the rain. At Mt Bryan East 120 points caused a medium flow in Dust Hole Creek. Weekend falls in the agricultural areas varied from 46 points at Booborowie to 80 at Hallett. Burra recorded 64 points. Eastern falls were more varied: Quondong 32 points, Balah 26, Braemar 55, Woolgangi 40, J. Oates [Poonunda] 101, Hogback 68 and Old Koomooloo 26.

91, 17, 30 Apr. 1968, page 2

Advt. Elders-GM have received instructions from the proprietors to conduct a clearing sale at Old Canowie on Wednesday 22 May at 10 a.m. on the property on the main road midway between Jamestown and Hallett.

[Details in the advertisement 3⁄4 column deep x 3 columns in width.]

Arnold Lucas was 80 last Saturday. Though born in Broken Hill he will have been a resident of Hallett for 80 years in three weeks’ time.

Marriage. St Augustine’s Unley, last Thursday

Ashley Phin, formerly of Hallett, married Mary McFarlane

Obituary. Hedley (Ted) Lomman of Camden Park died aged 69. He was born at Mt Bryan East, where he was a resident for 40 years. [Born John Hedley Lomman 8 February 1899 Kooringa: died Hedley John Lomman 28 April 1968 Adelaide, residence Camden Park.]

Obituary. Mrs Frank Cahill nee Kathleen Quinn died in Adelaide on Good Friday. She was a teacher before her marriage, travelling to Streaky Bay by boat and coming home to Mt Bryan once a year for holidays. She is survived by three sons and three daughters, all of Adelaide. [Born Elizabeth Kathleen Quinn 23 January 1896 Mt Bryan East: died 12 April 1968 Myrtle Bank, residence Walkerville.]

Obituary. Bertie Dawson, formerly of Burra, died at the weekend aged 78.

[Not traced in SA Births, Marriages or Deaths.]

Obituary. Mrs Jane Phillips of Mt Bryan died on Saturday at Burra Hospital aged 85.

[Born Jane Parker 21 August 1883 Brady Creek: died 27 April 1968 Burra, residence Mt Bryan.]

Joe & Ruby Pascoe, formerly of Burra, celebrated their golden wedding yesterday.

Arthur (Pincher) Harris, formerly of Burra, was 75 on Easter Monday.

Mrs M.A. Taylor celebrated her 90th birthday at Burra Hospital on 27 April. She is a sister to the late Mrs A. Hirschausen and the late Mr W. Voumard and the only surviving member of a family of 13 children, being one of five of them who came to Australia from Switzerland, taking six weeks in a sailing ship. Messrs Bert & Ivan Hirschausen and Mrs S. Scroop and Mrs J. Rowe Sen. are nephews and nieces resident in Burra.

[Marie Adelaide Taylor nee Voumard died 11 January 1971 Burra, residence Burra North.]

Tony Fillmore made his debut as a football umpire on Saturday at Alberton and I hear he impressed officials.

91, 18, 7 May 1968, page 1

Burra North Street Numbering

Names and numbers are printed for all of Burra North.

Common Effluent drain for Burra

The Department of Public Health is drawing up final plans for Burra’s effluent drainage. It will include Commercial Street, Market Square, Hill Street, Ware Street, Kangaroo Street, Queen Street, Chapel Street, Lloyd Street and Thames Street. The proposed site for the biological filter is in Thames Street on land adjoining the Council Pound. Because of the terrain in some streets only those on the high side will be connected. Houses on the low side will have backyards to sink soakage wells, whereas many on the high side have no land on which to drain septic tank overflow. The Corporation has requested the Department to install the drain in the water table rather than in the footpath, but that will be up to the Department.

91, 18, 7 May 1968, page 2

Advt. Burra Pictures, 11 May

Lee Barker & Donald Fraser in Code 7 Victim 5

Audie Murphy in The Quick Gun

Burra Hospital. The new operating theatre became ready for use yesterday. The equipment is fully up-to-date and the new radium theatre light, counterbalanced and moveable in any direction, comes directly from Germany and is the latest in design. The theatre is air conditioned and has anti-static floors and X-ray viewers for on the spot checks. Gasses are automatically fed and water in the scrub-up room is pre-heated and sterilised by ultra-violet light. The automatic back-up power and light system adds to the efficiency. Work on clearing the old theatre block has commenced in preparation for renovations to produce an all purpose lounge, lecture, sewing and Board room. The remaining section of the building will be converted into domestic quartes for live-in staff where necessary.

91, 18, 7 May 1968, page 3

Obituary. Miss Ruth Sara died 4 May. She was a daughter of the late Mr & Mrs F.T. Sara of Burra.

She was the cub or scout mistress here in the 1930s.

[Pauline Ruth Sara born 18 January 1921 Aberdeen: died 4 May 1968 Adelaide, residence Toorak Gardens.]

Jim Cains, police cadet, is training here for five weeks. His father, Harry Cains, a former Burra resident, is now head of the Police Accident Investigation Squad.

Jack Oates scored a hole in one at golf on Saturday.

Burra Kindergarten held a Variety Night which attracted about 200 adults and children. It was compered by John Secomb and raised $76 for the cause.

91, 18, 7 May 1968, page 7

Land Tenure. The Minister for Lands has decided that Crown Perpetual Leases in agricultural areas can be converted to freehold. This can be done either by an agreement to purchase over a period of up to 30 years, or by cash payment.

Weather. Burra had 139 points for the week. The district generally reported falls of over one inch.

91, 26, 2 July 1968, page 1.]

Burra Town Council. Elections. Nominations:

Mayor E.T. Baulderstone elected unopposed

West Ward R.A. Moreland elected unopposed

East Ward B. Kotz elected unopposed

North Ward No Nominations

A Supplementary Election is called for North Ward with nominations closing on 31 May.

An Extraordinary Vacancy has been caused in East Ward by the resignation of Cr Rev. G.D. Sibly.

Nominations for this Extraordinary Election will also close on 31 May.

Burra Rural Youth has had a busy week, centred upon the Australian Stud Merino Tour, which was an outstanding success. The tour gave 33 boys and 3 girls an opportunity to compare and inspect the local stud sheep breeding industry. Most of the visitors were from the eastern states. There was a social on Monday night in the Show Hall. The event continued through Tuesday with farewells on Wednesday morning.

Burra Floral Art Club held its second floral display in the Town Hall on Friday. This year there were fewer displays, but the standard was higher. In the centre was a reconstruction of Burra’s entry in the Adelaide Flower Day display in March and Mesdames Lloyd and Pettet are to be congratulated for this. The day’s takings of $94.70 will aid the Town Hall floor appeal.

91, 19, 14 May 1968, page 2

Accident. Walter Nankivell was involved in a collision at Gepps Cross on Sunday evening. He was bringing his wife home after some weeks in hospital and she now has to stay in Adelaide with bruised ribs etc.

91, 20, 21 May 1968, page 1

Adelaide Wool Sales 14-16 May. Top district price was for E.L. McWaters & Co. Sampson’s Well at 623⁄4c.

[Other local district prices are printed.]

Theft. Mr Norman of Hillcrest was a visitor at Burra Caravan Park last Wednesday and Thursday and had $140 worth of belongings stolen while visiting the Mine area.

Burra Police Court, last Wednesday. Colin James Kavanagh was committed on a charge of attempted murder.

Burra Library has been struggling for some time to make ends meet and to add new material for readers. On Friday a trading table will be held to raise funds and its success or otherwise will decide the library’s immediate future.

Weather. Rain in the last week gave a total of 56 points in Burra. The district falls in the agricultural area were from 50-60 points.

91, 20, 21 May 1968, pages 1 & 8

Burra Bowls Associates held their AGM 6 May. President Mrs H. Crump reported on a successful season. The Green Team finished second on the premiership list and was runner-up in the championship rinks. Elected: President, Mrs D. Field; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames J. Murphy & M. Kellock; Secretary, Mrs E.C. Pietsch & Treasurer, Mrs C. Neill.

91, 20, 21 May 1968, page 6

Football

North Eastern

91, 21, 28 May 1968, page 1

Burra & District Ambulance Committee met on 22 May. In the past 12 months Members’ subscriptions have fallen by $90. Membership subscription is $2 or $1 for pensioners. This gives free coverage for the district and for a trip to Adelaide a fare reduction of 50%. Non-members pay $2 flagfall and 25 cents per mile. Distance is calculated both ways, so a trip to Adelaide will cost a non-member at least $54.

Accident. At about 9.50 p.m. on Saturday a small sedan overturned at Mt Bryan. The car was driven by Miss Susan Jackson of Cawker’s Well Station, Broken Hill, who was travelling to Adelaide. The driver suffered minor injuries and a passenger, Robyn Jackson, was not injured, but a second passenger, Howard Rolfe of Hove, sustained a fractured cheek bone, concussion and bruises. The car was extensively damaged.

Accident. A car driven by Robert Radford of Glenora was extensively damaged when it hit a fence about 19 miles east of Burra at 4.30 a.m. on Saturday. The driver was not injured.

A Week of Prayer for Christian Unity will be marked by an Ecumenical Service at the Burra Town Hall on Sunday 2 June at 7 p.m.

91, 21, 28 May 1968, page 2

Advt. Burra Pictures, 1 June

A Funny Thing Happened on the Way to the Forum

A Dog’s Best Friend

Weather. Good soaking light rain in the past week has been general. Some damage to fallow has been done by heavy falls in places and very windy conditions have been general – probably the worst for many years on Sunday night. For the week Farrell Flat reported 130 points, Hallett 108 and Burra 89. Light rain is falling today.

91, 21, 28 May 1968, page 3

Andy Andrews, who in 1926 or 1927 was the first person to use one of the paper’s linotypes, has been back in Burra with his wife for the weekend.

Mrs J.M. Gebhardt of Mt Bryan married Mr D.H. Laidlaw.

91, 22, 4 June 1968, page 1

Weather. Several fine days have allowed seeding to proceed. Burra recorded 143 points over 12 days up to last week’s paper. On Tuesday came 54 points and on Wednesday a further 9. Dust storms have occurred to the east, which has missed out on the rain.

Hanson CWA raised $40 from a Children’s Fancy Dress Frolic on Friday night. [Details in 3⁄4 column.]

Burra Institute Library held a successful trading table and raised $107.29, which will enable the Library to carry on for the year. In the year to March 1968 approximately 110 new books were added at an average cost of c. $1.25 per book.

Burra Town Council. Elections

Supplementary Election for North Ward R.B. Jennison elected unopposed

Extraordinary Election for East Ward M.D. Thomas

R.E. Angel

An election for East Ward will be held on 6 July.

Pensioners’ League. Port Adelaide Branch members gave their annual concert in the Burra Town Hall on 28 May. The Mayor Mr Baulderstone welcomed them as did the local secretary of the League, Mr R.G. Bernhardt. A bus load of pensioners attended from Peterborough.

Accident. Mr G.A.E. (Gus) Kakoschke of Burra North was injured when a car driven by William R. Irlam (18) of Burra collided with Mr Kakoschke’s bicycle just south of the Mine entrance. Mr Kakoschke suffered a broken leg and concussion and after local treatment was sent to RAH where his condition is said to be satisfactory.

Accident. Mr O.H. Rooke’s car slid off the road and struck a fence post on the Morgan Road on Wednesday night. Damage was slight.

Accident. At c. 8.15 p.m. on Wednesday a petrol tanker slid off the by-pass road and became stuck. The DC grader was required to free the vehicle.

Accident. A vehicle driven by Mr Peter Moxham of Redcliffe Station slid off the Robertstown Road about 15 miles from Robertstown on Tuesday. It was extensively damaged when it hit a bank of earth and a tree. Neither driver nor passengers were injured.

Accident. Mrs V. Donhardt of Burra’s car collided with a tree on Smelts Road on Friday night, when a tyre suddenly deflated.

Mrs H. Crump & Mrs K. Phillips have been farewelled by the Burra Bowling Associates. Both members are leaving Burra.

91, 23, 11 June 1968, page 1

Weather. More rain has halted seeding operations, though falls to the east have been very light and some parts have experienced their worst dust storms for some time. In the agricultural areas for the past week to Friday morning falls were: Mt Bryan 119 points, Mt Bryan East 58, Hanson 194, Booborowie 100 and Burra 116 points.

Burra Primary School. A new prefabricated school room is expected to be in use in a fortnight. The first occupants will be Grade VII pupils with Mr P. Lannan. Grade VI will move into the room vacated by Grade VII and Grade IV will change rooms to leave one of the smaller classrooms empty. It is hoped to convert that room to a larger staff room with some space taken up by the book cupboard, now standing in the corridor.

Theft. $20 worth of pre-decimal coinage was stolen from Mrs E.M. Carpenter’s Burra North home on Tuesday night.

Adelaide Wool Sales. Top local price of 611⁄2c was obtained by G. & D.M. Kellock, Woolamba.

[Other local district prices are printed.]

Fire/Obituary. Mr Donald Simmons (46) a bachelor farmer of Whyte Yarcowie was a guest at the Burra Hotel on Thursday night. He retired to an upstairs bedroom and apparently was smoking in bed when his bedding caught alight early on Friday morning. At 6.25 a.m. the proprietor Mr King Grubb arose and found smoke in the building, which he traced to the upstairs room. He groped his way to the bed and found it still occupied by Mr Simmons. He pulled the man into the passage and called the fire brigade, the doctor and the police. Both Doctors Kirk and Miller attended and found the man dead. The bedding was not actually in flames, but the smoke had suffocated the victim and smoke damage to the room was estimated at $300.

[Born 5 September 1919 Terowie, died 7 June 1968 Burra, residence Whyte Yarcowie.]

91, 23, 11 June 1968, page 3

Accident/Obituary. The SA President of the Merino Stud Breeders’ Association Mr K.W. Gare of Burra North was seriously injured in a car accident on Sunday morning. It occurred 28 miles east of Balranald on the Sturt Highway at about 10.30 a.m., when the car was involved in a collision with a semi-trailer. A passenger, Mr Peter Anderson, well-known in this district, was killed. Mr Gare was treated at Balranald Hospital and later transferred to Adelaide. [Keith Weseley Gare born 29 April 1926 Kooringa: died as Keith Wesley Gare 11 June 1968 Adelaide, residence Burra North.]

Accident/Obituary. Retired grazier Mr Ross Rayner aged 90, of Whyte Yarcowie, was killed yesterday when the vehicle he was driving was struck by a train at a level crossing at Whyte Yarcowie at about 2 p.m. The train was a special chartered by the Australian Railways Historical Society. [Ross Rayner born 26 February 1878: died 10 June 1968 Whyte Yarcowie.]

Mrs Sellars will be 91 tomorrow. She has been at the Burra Hospital for the last five years.

[Born Adelaide Jessie Victoria Holmes 12 June 1877 Yarcowie: died 29 July 1968 Burra, residence Burra North.]

91, 24, 18 June 1968, page 1

Mayor E.T. Baulderstone wrote to the paper. He called for more community effort and involvement in Burra. He said that having been Mayor for 14 years he would do his best, but it gets harder as he gets older and he needs more help. Burra lacks the assistance other places get from having a Progress Association, a Junior Chamber of Commerce, Rotary of Apex Clubs. During the coming year he will be calling a meeting to discuss future arrangements for the Burra & District Swimming Pool. He will also be seeking help later to form a Tourist Committee, which is important for the town. He also flags his opinion that Local Government must get bigger to be more efficient and says that his Council has already commenced negotiations with the Burra Burra DC on the subject of a merger.

Hallett RSL Debutante Ball is reported in c. 1 column.

Obituary. Keith Wesley Gare died on Tuesday as a result of an accident [near Balranald] when he was returning from judging at the Deniliquin Show in NSW. He was born at Burra in 1926. He received his primary education at Mt Bryan East School and his secondary education at Burra High School and Prince Alfred College. As a member of the ATC he enlisted in the RAAF as soon as he was eligible by age and trained as a fighter pilot, serving until the end of WW II. At the end of hostilities he returned to the family property ‘Glenview’ at Mt Bryan East where he worked with his father Mr Lewis Gare. In 1952 he married Miss Shirley Seal and continued to work at Mt Bryan East until the family purchased ‘The Pines’ at Burra North, when he and his family took up residence there. The scope of his interests and abilities is shown in the number of organisations to which he belonged. A president of the Mt Bryan Cricket Club, he was also a member of the Burra Hospital Board, the Primary School Committee and the Burra Show Committee. He was a keen supporter of the Rural Youth movement and the first President of the Hallett Agricultural Bureau after its transfer from Mt Bryan East and remained a member of the Hallett Branch. He was a Past Master of the Hallett Masonic Lodge. Mr Gare employed his wide knowledge of sheep breeding as a judge in the Merino Section of shows throughout Australia, in capital cities and country centres. Although ‘Glen View’ Stud was registered in 1927, its development to the present high standard was largely due to the recent management of Mt Gare and his interest in breeding lines took him all over Australia. He travelled long distances to assist breeders and growers in classing lambs bred from his lines. In 1966 he became President of the SA Branch of the Studbreeders’ Association. He was keen to have the embargo on Merino sheep export lifted. At his funeral over 700 mourners paid their respects and with 80 Masons present it was one of the largest gatherings of the Masonic Lodge at any country funeral in SA. He is survived by his wife Shirley, and children Kay, Lester, Julie and Gregory and by brother Donald and sisters Melva (Mrs A. McInnes) and Glenda (Mrs D. Bailey) and his parents Mr & Mrs Gare Senior. [Keith Weseley Gare born 29 April 1926 Kooringa: died as Keith Wesley Gare 11 June 1968 Adelaide, residence Burra North.]

91, 24, 18 June 1968, page 3

91, 24, 18 June 1968, page 7

Advt. Burra Pictures, 22 June

Audrey Hepburn & Peter O’Toole in How to Steal a Million

Plus Walk Stall [Sic.?]

91, 25, 25 June 1968, page 1

Weather. This season has had a pattern of weekly rains, which are hampering seeding operations, but benefiting pastures, filling surface catchments and replenishing aquifers. Wheat already sown is doing well. Some areas are suffering lucerne flea or mite. Roads have suffered damage and streams are generally flowing. Falls in the last week have been between 50 and 100 points generally. Burra recorded 75 points. [There is an extended summary of seasonal conditions.]

Burra Rural Youth held a trading table and contest in miserably wet and cold conditions and managed to raise $64 for Kathryn White’s entry in the Miss Industry Quest.

Members had a tour of the Clarevale Winery on the evening of 17 June.

Golf. Children are annoying golfers at Burra by darting out and retrieving balls that are in play. There is also a danger of their being hit. [The suggestion was that they were unsupervised children of parents attending adjacent football games.]

Marrabel Catholic Church [of St Agnes] will celebrate it centenary with a service on 30 June, when Archbishop Gleeson will officiate. [A brief history of the church is printed.]

Red Cross held a gold day at Burra and raised $53 for the cause.

Obituary. Jeanette Dulcie Murray died suddenly while visiting the home of her parents at Mt Bryan during the illness of her father, Mr C. Rawlins. She, her husband and family recently moved to a new property at Gosse on Kangaroo Island.

[Born Jeannette Dulcie Rawlins 3 June 1944, Burra: died 23 June 1968 Mt Bryan, residence Gosse KI.]

91, 25, 25 June 1968, page 2

Table Tennis. Burra Table tennis Association hosted 30 visitors from Waikerie last Sunday. Play was in the RSL Hall. Waikerie defeated Burra 24 rubbers to 23. [Results are printed.]

Booborowie 6.4 defeated Hallett 5.5

Booborowie 4.6 defeated Hallett 2.2

91, 26, 2 July 1968, page 1

Weather. In the past week rains came in from the east with falls of up to 150 points in the pastoral areas. Run-off was generated. Germination of grasses and rapid growth has followed. Rains continue to hamper sewing in the agricultural areas. Crops already sown continue to prosper. Dust Hole Creek flooded on Friday after 154 points in the area. It is now running with clear water from seepage, a thing Me Les Thomas says he has not seen for some 40 years.

Burra High School. A new building for boys’ craft is being erected. The room presently used is crowded and will be converted to a classroom and storeroom. This will free the library from being used as a classroom. The Intermediate Class recently had a day in Adelaide to view the film To Sir with Love and in the afternoon visited Parliament House as guests of Mr E.C. Allen MP.

Miss Industry Quest Ball was held at the Burra Town Hall on Friday night and grossed $250. The profits will help construction of a new building at the Home for Incurables, so easing the waiting list. The Ball aided local entrant in the Quest, Miss Kathryn White and was attended by the 1967 winner, Raelene Hele.

Accident. A car driven by Ian Lovell of Burra overturned on the Burra North-Morgan Road on Saturday on loose gravel. It landed on its wheels without injury to the driver.

Accident. Minor damage occurred in a collision on a side street corner off Smelts Road between a car driven by Joanna Simpson of Burra North and Trevor Williams of Burra North.

Accident. In another minor accident near the Telephone exchange on Tuesday a car driven by Miss Rosemary Griffiths collided with one driven by Alec Williams.

91, 26, 2 July 1968, page 2

Advt. Ashton’s Circus and Zoo: The Tommy Hanlin Show, will appear in Burra, Tuesday 9 July on Smelts Road opposite the ETSA Depot

91, 26, 2 July 1968, page 3

Obituary. Mr Lisle Pearce of Malvern died last week.

[Wilfred Lisle Pearce born29 September 1887 Kooringa: died 28 June 1968 Daw Park, residence Malvern.]

Obituary. Mr David Eig of Hamley Bridge and formerly of Burra died recently.

[David Cecil Eig died 27 June 1968 Hamley Bridge aged 77.]

Obituary. Mr Ken Seigert of Hallett died recently.

[Kenneth Hugh Seigert born 23 December 1896 Hallett: died 30 June 1968 Burra, residence Hallett.]

Obituary. Mr Clark, father of John Clark of Elders-GM in Burra, died last week in his home at Largs.

[Probably John James Clark born 10 June 1907 Adelaide: died 29 June 1968 Largs, but at death only James Clark.]

Birth. To Mr & Mrs Don Schwier at Riverton, a daughter, Debbie. Don works in the Riverton Post Office and has ties with Burra.

Theft. The store shed at Hanson Tanks has been broken into for the second time in a few weeks. The first time three life jackets were stolen and now a fireside heater and tools are missing.

91, 26, 2 July 1968, pages 3-6 gutter

Ruth Woollacott leaves Burra on Sunday to take up nursing training at Eden Park, Marryatville.

91, 26, 2 July 1968, page 5

Advt. Full page advertisement ‘Channel SAS 10 Comes to Riverton, Friday July 5.

Popular Compere of 10’s Today Show – Paul Griffiths – Your Host

O’Connell’s Electronic Services Presents ‘Simpson Day.’

91, 26, 2 July 1968, page 7

Advt. Burra Pictures, 6 July

James Garner & Sidney Poitier in Duel at Diablo

Plus The Satan Bug

Burra Swimming Pool. At a public meeting called by the Mayor E.T. Baulderstone a management committee was formed to operate the pool and its facilities. At first it was run by the committee which oversaw its construction. This was then replaced by the Burra & District Swimming Pool Committee. Over the years interest apparently waned and two years ago it was virtually forced onto the Council. Since then, despite an operating profit, the pool has not made enough to meet the repayment of the loan incurred for the filtration plant. The average attendance of 85 makes it clear that maintenance and operation of the pool has to be on a volunteer basis. It would be disastrous to take the pool away from the youth of the town. The committee of twelve will be elected annually.

91, 26, 2 July 1968, page 8

Football

North Eastern

91, 26 (2), 9 July 1968, page 1 [Second use of this number in this volume.]

John McDouall Stuart. An Article by Mr Ian Auhl requested by the PMG Department, Canberra.

On 25 July 1860 John McDouall Stuart, in his third attempt to cross Australia, reached the north coast some 50 miles east of the present site of Darwin. After raising the flag etc. he and his party set out on the 2,500 mile journey to Adelaide. Four months later on 27th December they reached the edge of settlement at Mt Margaret Station, west of Lake Eyre. A month later they reached Mt Remarkable and caught the mail coach to Burra. Burra had the most northerly telegraph station in SA in 1862. Stuart was anxious to let the world know that he had accomplished his task. In Adelaide anxiety was being felt for his safety after not hearing from him for almost a year. When the coach reached Kooringa at about 6 p.m. on 16 December Stuart sent the telegram:

John McDouall Stuart, Commander of the South Australian Northern Exploring Expedition, to the Commissioner of Crown Lands.

Kooringa, Dec. 16th 1862

‘Through you I beg to inform His Excellency the Governor-in-Chief and the Government that I have accomplished the object of the expedition. Party all well. I will be in town by the evening train tomorrow.’

This was followed by a second telegram by Chambers at 6.30 p.m. on the same afternoon.

Dec. 16th Kooringa

Telegram to Mr Finke from Mr Chambers.

‘Stuart, Auld and self home by last train tomorrow. Party all well!’

The Register correspondent reported Stuart was greeted by a large crowd and presented with an address.

The last train referred to in Chamber’s telegram was from Kapunda, then the northern terminus and about 50 miles from both Adelaide and Burra. Register correspondent again reported next day that Stuart had arrived accompanied by Mr Auld and his party, Capt. McKay of Mt Deception and Mr John Chambers. Mr Stuart was enthusiastically received by a large crowd. He appeared in a very low condition, having suffered from scurvy for a great part of the trip and alighted from the coach with difficulty. Mr W.H. Wilkinson read the address.

[The address is printed together with Stuart’s reply.]

The correspondent also reported Stuart’s departure by the Adelaide Mail for the city. Another large crowd assembled and another address was read and presented to Stuart. Mr McDermott SM read this address. He and Mr Mayne JP and Mr J.B. Anderson JP had escorted the explorer from his room in the hotel to the Mail bus. Nine carts full of people followed the Mail bus for about three miles, where they gave three hearty cheers before returning to Kooringa.

[The address read by McDermott is also printed.]

THE DATES ABOVE CANNOT ALL BE CORRECT!]

91, 27, 16 July 1968, page 1

Dogs Attack Sheep. Killer dogs have attacked sheep in Burra and Leighton areas in the past week. In the early hours of last Wednesday 33 ewes owned by Mr J.G. Carpenter were killed and many injured in the Smelts Paddock. On the same night about 30 ewes of Mr Ross Berry of Leighton were killed and others injured. On Thursday morning Mr Murray Stockman was awoken by a disturbance among sheep in a paddock near his house. Two sheep had been killed and others injured. He shot and killed a dog near the sheep. In all over $600 worth of sheep have been killed.

St Mary’s. Steps have been taken to elect a new trustee to replace the late Mr G.H. Dollman. Mr Dollman had replaced Mr M.W. Bednall and had served for 16 years. The present trustees are: M. de N. Lucas, J.R. Barker, A. Tennant, R.K. Pearse and R.R. Reed.

Burra Bowling Club held its AGM 10 July and elected: Patron, D. Jacka; President, M.J. Stockman; Vice-Presidents, C. Dare & E.C. Pietsch; Secretary, D. Field & Treasurer R.G. Bernhardt.

Advt. Elders-GM on instructions from M.R. & E.J. Humphrys of Hanson will auction ‘Glenowie’ Hanson of 917 acres in the Burra RSL Hall on 9 August. To be offered in three lots:

487 acres of freehold: sections 49, 50 & 842-845 in Hd Hanson in 9 paddocks with a seven-roomed stone house etc.

288 acres of Crown Perpetual Lease: sections 471-473 & 38 in Hd Hanson in five sheep-proof paddocks with a modern textured brick home of three bedrooms etc.

1411⁄2 acres freehold: sections 36 & 37 in Hd Hanson in two paddocks.

Burra Town Council

The financial statement to 30 June 1968 showed the bank overdraft had been reduced from $4,312 to $1,342. Council will continue to provide trees to persons prepared to care for them. The opening of a new section for burials at Burra Cemetery will be discussed at the next meeting. A Federal Rural Areas Grant of $600 was allotted for the construction of Hardy Street. (Along the edge of the Burra North sale yards.)

91, 28, 23 July 1968, page 1

Peter Thomas Fairchild, eldest son of Mr & Mrs Norman Fairchild of Mitchell Park and late of Booborowie, leaves Adelaide on 29 July to spend a year in the USA as an American Field Service Exchange student. He is 18 and born at Booborowie and received most of his primary schooling there. He has three brothers: Roland 14, Brenton 12 and Colin 7.

Sir Frederick Holder has been remembered with the naming of a new metropolitan electorate for the House of Representatives after him. He was closely connected with Burra. He was born 12 May 1850, the son of Morecott Holder of Happy Valley and trained as a teacher. He felt that journalism would hold greater opportunities and while still a young man secured possession of the Burra Record. He was described as a ‘trenchant and graceful’ writer and contributed to the Adelaide Register and high class English newspapers. He became Town Clerk of Burra from 1879 to 1884 and was Mayor in 1887. [And 1889.] In 1887 he was elected to the House of Assembly and two years later was first Treasurer in Sir John Cockburn’s cabinet. He was Premier of SA briefly in 1892 and for 1899-1901. In 1901 he was made a Knight Commander of St Michael & St George. When the Commonwealth was established he became the first Speaker of the House of Representatives. He was a greatly respected Speaker, known for his fairness and the dignified way he carried out his duties. He collapsed at his post with an apoplectic seizure at 6.30 a.m. on 23 July 1909 following a strenuous all-night sitting on the subject of the old age pension. He died at 4 p.m. the same day without regaining consciousness. Thousands lined the route of his state funeral in Adelaide on 26 July despite torrential rain.

Arbor Day was held at Burra Primary School last Friday and more than 110 visitors attended. The school was open for visitors and the theme for the day was Australian Trees. Mrs M. Rayner of Hallett delivered the address after which 14 trees were planted around the school oval. [Tree planters are listed.]

Advt. Burra Pictures. The secretary of the Burra Town Hall Picture Committee reports a drop in attendance for the past financial year of 416 or 9% and consequently a loss of $110.

Attendances:

If attendances do not significantly increase serious consideration will have to be given to closing down the Town Hall Pictures. This would be a pity, but it is hardly worthwhile obtaining the better films available if the residents are not going to patronise them. Three persons work voluntarily each Saturday night. It costs $17 plus the film hire (average $24) to put on a show. To cover this attendance will have to rise considerably from the present average of 87. One need to lift attendance is the better behaviour of children and teenagers present. Parents could help by coming along and keeping their own children under control. The outcome is in the hands of the residents of Burra. It is stressed that the aim of increasing attendance cannot be achieved without a great improvement in the behaviour of the children attending. The committee has found it necessary to abolish the front stalls and charge 30c for children anywhere downstairs – they had been buying 20c seats and moving into 30c seats during the program.

Burra Bowling Club. The President C. Leslie Phillips’ report on 1967-68.

[He reported on a falling off of interest in Pennant Bowls in the latter part of the year because the result was decided on the number of wins and percentage rather than on semi-finals and finals. He thought the latter a better option.]

Last year there were 54 members – up 4 on the previous season. During the year death claimed Guy Dollman, Horton Jennison, Jack Lockett, Roy Earle and Lindsay Hood. Harold Crump had moved to Adelaide.

The Club Champion for the season was Bill Corner.

[The President’s discussion on a range of issues affecting bowls generally and the club in particular is printed in about 13⁄4 columns.]

Aberdeen 7.8 defeated Mintaro 0.0

United 6.7 defeated auburn 0.3

Junior Colts Riverton 4.6 defeated Robertstown 1.1

Visit of the Minister of Local Government

The Hon M. Hill with Mrs Hill and Mr Claude Allen MP & Mrs Allen visited Burra as part of a two day tour of the area. Members of the Town and District Councils and their wives met the visitors at the Town Hall. The ladies visited the National Trust Museum and the CWA rooms for afternoon tea. The Minister and Mr Allen joined the Town Council in the Parlour. The main discussion centred upon reclaiming the central portion of the cemetery. This discussion had gone on for some years and Mr Hill brought with him the complete file. His explanation showed the reclaiming was not simple and could, in the future, have repercussions. He felt the opening of a new section on the eastern side of the cemetery would be more satisfactory. Grant monies were also discussed. The large length of roads and small population and other difficulties in qualifying for grants were mentioned. Mr Hill was sure there was no special grant for cemetery maintenance. He agreed with Council amalgamations in principle, but it was up to individual Councils to come to terms. Mr Hill then had afternoon tea with the District Council. Again he heard of the difficulties the Council was having – especially the sealing of the Spalding-Morgan Road and of the Farrell Flat-Hanson Road. Councils, he said, could do the work more cheaply than the Highways & Local Government Department. He repeated his comments on Council amalgamations. A deputation from Booborowie lobbied for sealing of town streets.

91, 29, 30 July 1968, page 1

Accident. On Thursday c. 11.30 a.m. a sedan driven by Mr Ian James Diack of South View Downs overturned on the Booborowie-Burra Road on loose gravel on a bend. The driver was uninjured, but the damage to the car was more than $800.

Accident. On Wednesday evening a vehicle driven by J.V. Ryan overturned on the Adelaide Road about 13 miles south of Burra. Damage was c. $200.

Burra & District Swimming Pool Management Committee met on 24 July for the first time. Chairman is I. Allen, Secretary G. Baulderstone and Treasurer Mr A.D. Bernhardt. Mr E.T. Baulderstone thanked all participants before handing over to the new Chairman. A constitution is being drafted. A representative of Berger Paints will be consulted about the best preparation for the new season to make the surface easier to care for.

91, 30, 6 Aug. 1968, page 1

Burra Hospital

The Hon. R.C. De Garis, Chief Secretary and Minister of health opened the Alice Collins Theatre and Casualty Block on Friday. The Vice-Chairman Mr A.J. Ashby introduced the Mayor E.T. Baulderstone, who gave a brief address in which he went through some of the recent history of the redevelopment of the Hospital. Chairman of the Board Mr R.K. Pearse spoke, saying that since plans were formulated in 1963 $160,000 had been spent in capital outlay and $40,000 in maintenance. The work had been done in three stages. Stages 1 7 3 had been accomplished through public subscription from appeals [subsidised by Government]. The second stage had been financed by a bequest from the estate of the late Miss Alice Collins who had spent her last four years as an inmate of the hospital. Mr Pearse then asked Mr De Garis to declare the wing open. A plaque bearing the words Alice Collins Wing was unveiled by Mr A.K. Hanlin of Burra.

Accident. A car driven by Mrs A. Cullen and one driven by Mr P. Lockett collided at 7.45 p.m. on the Burra-Burra North Road. Both vehicles were extensively damaged and Mrs Cullen received a neck injury.

Burra Town Hall. The floor surface has been of concern for some time and collections of paper and other donations have raised $562. Council has decided to go ahead with a hard board covering. The work of preparation, laying and two coats of Estapol has a quoted price of $810. It is hoped an opening function will raise the $248 gap.

Accident/Obituary. On Thursday afternoon on the main road near Black Springs a sedan car driven by Mrs R.E. Dewhirst and a utility driven by Mr C.C. Hopgood of Black Springs collided at the intersection with the Merildin chain road. It was raining at the time. As a consequence Mr C.C. Hopgood aged 72 was killed and Mr C.K. Hopgood (36) received severe chest and head injuries and died at the Burra Hospital about four hours later. Mrs R.E. Dewhirst received head, facial and leg injuries and was taken to Riverton Hospital and later to Adelaide where her condition is now described as satisfactory. [The ages cited are incorrect: see below.]

[Cecil Charles Hopgood born 14 January 1898 Snowtown: died 1 August 1968 Black Springs.

Colin Keith Hopgood born 12 March 1928 Porter’s Lagoon: died 1 August 1968 Burra, residence Black Springs.]

Accident. A semi-trailer driven by Mr Robert Rohrlach of Tanunda was severely damaged when its load struck the overhead railway bridge at Burra North at about 5 p.m. on Wednesday. The load was a large crane jib, which struck the bridge, moving it slightly out of alignment. Train services were not disrupted, though train speeds slowed to a minimum until repairs were effected. Damage to the vehicle was c. $800.

Burra Town Council, 29 July

A plumber is to put the Town Hall toilets in order.

St Mary’s was given permission to have a winding pathway from the footpath erected.

Extra power outlets at the caravan park will be installed at a cost estimated at $324. Application will be made to the Tourist Bureau for subsidy.

The Town Hall floor was discussed as noted above.

91, 31, 13 Aug. 1968, page 1

Golf. The annual Silver Salver event in the Mid North District Ladies’ Association was held at Farrell Flat on Tuesday 6 august and was won by Miss Judy Oates with a course record of 85 off the stick. She also won the 18 hole handicap event.

Marriage. St Laurence’s Church North Adelaide, Saturday

Sheila Sullivan, only daughter of Mr & Mrs John Sullivan of ‘Greenfields’ Hallett married William Strong.

Mr Strong is a lecturer in Science at a University in Oswego, New York, where the couple will live.

Main Road 46 (Burra-Lochiel) is slowly being sealed and a question in Parliament elicited the answer that three or four of the final 10 miles should be sealed this financial year.

Burra Rural Youth have had several interesting meetings recently. Last night they visited NWS9 TV Station in Adelaide. Shirley Gilbert, NZ girl exchange spoke on 15 July. At the last meeting a tape from Geoffrey Dare was played. He is currently in Iowa, having spent three weeks in Texas.

Weather. In the past week Burra recorded 87 points with 1,402 for the year so far.

Accident. Two cars were extensively damaged in a collision on Sunday near the Hanson Pumping Station. One driver, Trevor Williams of Burra, spent a day or so in hospital and the other, Malcolm Kakoschke, was not injured.

91, 32, 20 Aug. 1968, page 4

Marriage. St Mary’s, Burra, 3 August

Maralyn Anderson, daughter of Mr & Mrs A.M. Anderson, married Peter Fiebig.

91, 32, 20 Aug. 1968, page 5

Obituary. Mr J.B. (Jack) Rowe died at Burra Hospital on 12 July. His death severs one of the last links with the sheep droving era of the pastoral lands east and north of Burra. He was born in Burra on 12 January 1907, the eldest son of the late Jack and Helen Rowe. He worked with sheep practically all his life and was a well known figure around the sale yards. He was regularly sought when sheep had to be mustered for shearing and was employed on most of the properties in the eastern pastoral area. He worked for over a period of thirty years or more on Mr J.R. Barker’s property at Baldina. In his early life his dray, horse and several dogs were a familiar sight throughout the district. Some droving trips took him as far away as Wentworth in NSW. In more recent years the dray gave way to a motor vehicle and motor cycle. He was a member of the RAOB Lodge. He is survived by his widow, daughter Joan and son John and three grandchildren. Also by three sisters and two brothers: Dorrie, Flora, Fan, Alf and Harry. [Jack Birkenhagen Rowe born 21 January 1907 Redruth: died 12 July 1968 Burra.]

91, 33, 27 Aug. 1968, page 1

Burra racing Club will receive $540 from the TAB operations in SA for the 15 months of operation since its inception on 29 March 1967.

Burra High School Ball was held on Friday night in the Burra Town Hall. The event made a profit of nearly $200 for the Parents & Friends’ Association. Music was by Pfitzner’s Band. Mr Maurice Collins was MC.

Football

In the Mid north Football League the winner of the Mail Medal for Fairest and Most Brilliant Player for 1968 was L. Schmidt of Robertstown on a count-back from Glen chamberlain of Saddleworth-Marrabel United.

The Twartz Trophy for Colts was won by L. Wanganeen of Mintaro and the Jenner Trophy for the ‘B’ Grade went to B. Dixon of Manoora. The leading goal-kicker was T. Mosey of Robertstown with 33.

Accident. The driver of a laden semi-trailer parked on the newly graded section of the caravan park last week. The surface was soft and wet and the vehicle slid sideways, ending with the load resting against a tree and the front of the load wedged in a forked branch. The District Council grader was needed to pull the vehicle away from the tree with cabled and then to tow the semi from the park.

Electoral Districts Re-Division Act 1968.

The speech of the Member for Burra, Mr E.C. Allen on this Bill is reported in some 22⁄3 columns. He believed the Bill was a fair attempt to obtain electoral reform.
