91, 34, 3 Sep. 1968, page 1

District Roads. Answers to question in Parliament.

Traffic densities justify the sealing of Main Road 140 from Burra to Booborowie. Preconstruction activities will mean this is not expected to commence before 1969-70.

The Burra-Morgan Road will be developed to open surface standard over a period of years. $20,000 has been provided to begin work. This is not a high priority and work on the Morgan end will now commence in 1970-71.

When the Burra section is complete work on the Robertstown section will begin, but this is not likely before 1970-71. Over the next five years it is expected $20,000 will be available annually for work in the Burra District. From 1969-70 $50,000 p.a. should be available for the Morgan area.

Burra Caravan Park. The Minister of Tourism has advised of a grant of up to $162 on a dollar for dollar basis for six additional power points for caravans in the Burra Caravan Park.

Burra Town Hall Floor. It is anticipated the new floor surface will be completed by the middle of this month.

Bryan Keatley showed slides of his experiences of National Service in Vietnam to Spalding Rural Youth. Bryan was formerly active in Spalding Rural Youth.

Bungaree Ewe Sale. The 6th Annual Ewe Sale was held at Burra on Wednesday 28th August. [Prices are listed.]

91, 34, 3 Sep. 1968, pages 1 & 6

Burra Primary School held a Gala Evening at the Burra Town Hall last Thursday to celebrate the Welfare Club’s 30th birthday. Stalls were well stocked. A series of Dutch auctions proved to be rewarding and it is estimated that profits of $220 will be added to the club’s funds. Phil Lannan was MC. Each child at the school appeared in at least one item. Mr G. Baulderstone set up the lighting. [Details of the performances are given in c. 11⁄2 columns.]

Burra Town Council, 26 August

Garden seat to be installed on the footpath near Matthews in Market Square.

The ladies’ toilet in the Town Hall has been repaired.

The new surface for the Town Hall floor is to be installed by mid-September.

A general clean-up of the cemetery has been effected.

The Minister of Tourism advises a grant of up to $162 for power points in the Caravan Park – to be completed by 21 December.

The Burra Oval Management Committee wants the Education Department to pay $50 p.a. rental of the oval – an increase from $20.

J.J. & B.C. Richards were granted approval to install one dual petrol bowser on their Burra north property.

The Town Clerk will negotiate with A.L. Clode & Son about selling a portion of Mary Crescent with a 25 ft frontage to Best Place to allow expansion of his business.

It was decided to declare a rate of 23 cents in the dollar and a special rate of 12⁄3c in the dollar with a minimum rate on any one property of $14.

A meeting will be arranged on 21 September to discuss all matters relating to the amalgamation of the Burra Town Council with the Burra Burra District Council.

Football. Votes for the Mid North League Fairest and Most brilliant Player are printed.

91, 34, 3 Sep. 1968, page 8

Football. North Eastern First Semi-Finals

‘A’ Grade Hallett 12.9 defeated Clare North 3.4

‘B’ Grade Spalding 5.1 defeated Clare South 2.9

Colts Spalding 5.8 defeated Burra 4.3

Burra Hospital. Chairman R.K. Pearse’s Report 1967-68. The 91st Annual Report

Capital assets increased by $78, 921 due to the extensive building program. Liquid assets stand at $21,890; down $8, 215. The general account overdraft is $1,649 compared with $4,342 last year. The overall credit balance is $17,548. The Government subsidy increased by #3,090 and patients’ fees rose $4,765. At present there is no need to increase patients’ fees, which were last raised in November 1965.

The average number of in-patients rose by 2.5 to 18.5 – an all-time high.

The average cost of out-patients fell by 50c to $2.30.

Births at the hospital rose to 50.

The year saw the completion of the ‘Alice Collins’ Theatre and Casualty Wing and the domestic quarters. These additions plus equipment will cost approximately $100,000, not all of which is subsidised. Since the building program was commenced we have expended $160,000 on capital improvements and $40,000 on maintenance. The new wing was opened on 2 August by the Chief Secretary Hon. R.C. De Garis. There are now plans to modernise the Maternity Wing and the kitchen. The equipment for the Intensive Care Ward has to be purchased and the Board hopes to standardise on St Andrew’s type beds throughout the hospital. The cropping program is receiving little support unfortunately and this year wheat sales produced only $229. The Ladies’ Auxiliary continues its good work in sewing and stocking jams and preserves and now operates in adequate facilities. The Fund Raising Committee contributed $840 towards equipment purchases.

The Matron and nursing staff have given excellent service as have the domestic staff and handy man. The appeal for building funds produced a generous $13,302 despite the dry season, and this was greatly appreciated.

The death of respected Board Member Mr Keith Gare was deeply regretted. We thank Mrs A.D. Radford for her services and we lose her this year and welcome Mrs H. Treweeke and Mr W.A. Field to the Board.

91, 35 (2), 10 Sep. 1968, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Adelaide Wool Sales. District prices were topped by Reg. Warnes & Sons, Woolgangi, at 673⁄4c.

[Other local district prices are printed.]

Leighton School Welfare Club held its ball at Leighton Hall on 30 August. The Astronotes Band supplied the music and proceeds amounted to $211.

Burra Mine. The Minister of Mines in Parliament, Hon. R.C. Geddes:

Earlier in 1968 several shafts were sunk in the oxidised leavings to obtain a sample of copper lodes for testing. Metallurgical difficulties have been encountered in doing so, but investigations are proceeding. Drilling to ascertain deeper lodes has taken place, but is stopped at present due to discouraging results.

Major Peter Phillips was born at the Burra Hospital in 1935. His father was Ray Phillips, who lived in the house which Goldsbrough’s managers have occupied for many years. Ray Phillips was in partnership with his brother in a dental practice for many years before opening a practice at Kadina and Wallaroo, where he remained until enlisting in the AIF during WWII. He died on active service in 1943. Peter Phillips was educated at Rostrevor College and then went to Duntroon. After graduation he served as a Lieutenant in Malaya and this year was awarded the Military Cross for bravery in Vietnam.

[Charles Leslie Phillips born 7 August 1903: died 1 October 1988 Daw Park.

Walter Raymond Phillips born 25 June 1908 Glenelg: died 29 September 1943 Daw Park.

C.L. Phillips came to Burra in June 1930. The partnership is advertised from at least January 1934 and in 1935 & 1936. In January 1937 C.L. Phillips’s name appears alone in advertisements.]

Burra Swimming Pool. A working bee on Sunday will aim to remove old paint from the pool in preparation for new paint and the coming season.

Football. In the polling for the Mail Medal in the North Eastern Association Don Villis of Booborowie was the winner with 17 points from B. Eberhard of Burra with 16. Barry Eberhard gets the Record Trophy.

In the ‘B’ Grade the Gilles Trophy went to D. Coulter of Clare North with A. Ryan of Burra in second place. In the Colts L. Victor of Clare North was the winner, with S. Anderson of Burra runner-up.

In the Mid North League the Mail Medal went to Lindsay Schmidt of Robertstown from Glen Chamberlain of Saddleworth-Marrabel United. The ‘B’ Grade Jenner Trophy was won by Barry Dixon of Manoora and in the Colts Leon Wanganeen of Mintaro was the winner. Leading goal kicker in the league was Trevor Mosey of Robertstown.

Fairest and Best trophies for 1968:

‘A’ Grade Beverley Dewhirst (Booborowie)

‘B’ Grade Beverley Collins (Leighton), Theresa Quinn (Mt Bryan) and Anna Marie Cousins (Spalding) tied.

‘C’ Grade W. Dare (Mt Bryan)

‘D’ Grade Louise Catt (Booborowie) and Jenny Keane (Leighton) tied.

Accident. Ronald W. Munn (13), a passenger in a vehicle driven by John Munn of Coonamia (Pt Pirie), suffered internal injuries and a fractured left leg when the vehicle overturned at the top of Flagstaff Hill on Saturday. The driver received severe lacerations to his head, but did not seek treatment. Another passenger Kenneth H. May (16) suffered severe bruising. The vehicle was written off.

Accident. At 2.30 a.m. on Saturday a utility driven by Robert Neill collided with the railway guard rail on the Hanson Road about 5 miles west of Burra. A passenger bus took him to Riverton Hospital for treatment to a lacerated top lip. Damage to the vehicle was estimated at $1,000.

Accident. A.S. Mickel of Farrell Flat was involved in a minor accident in Harcourt Gardens on Saturday morning.

Burra Town Hall. The new floor surface has been laid and the surface was polished and finished with one coat of Estapol – said to be more effective that the proposed two coats of Estapol. Papers will continue to be collected to pay for the shortfall in funds for the floor. Papers brought in $421 and other donations etc. another c. $220. The account stands at $656, which leaves about another $200 to be raised.

91, 37 (2), 17 Sep. 1968, page 3 [Number used before in 1961.]

Marriage. Next Saturday Trevor Gould of Booborowie will get married.

Rev. Tom Drought will visit St Mary’s on Sunday and will dedicate new altar rails in the Holy Family Chapel on the side of the church. These rails match those of the sanctuary and were given by the Rector and Wardens of St Augustine’s Unley.

Obituary. Miss Jean M. Harris OBE, BSc, Dip Ed died in Melbourne on Sunday after a short illness. She had been Headmistress of Methodist Ladies’ College, Adelaide, for 32 years and had retired in May.

[Jean Margaret Harris born 19 January 1902 North Adelaide: died 15 September 1968 Melbourne, Victoria.]

Football. North Eastern League Preliminary Finals.

‘A’ Grade Hallett 9.15 defeated Booborowie 6.5

Obituary. Mrs Lillie May Cheffirs of Spalding died at the residence of her daughter Mrs K. Larwood at Jamestown. She was born at Parnaroo in March 1896, a daughter of the late August and Anna Hennig. She was one of a family of eight children. In 1914-15 she moved with her parents to Bundaleer and on 10 March 1926 married Thomas Clarence Keith Cheffirs of Spalding. He husband died some years ago. She is survived by three sons and one daughter. [Born Lillie May Hennig 20 March 1896 Parnaroo: died 11 August 1968 Jamestown.]

91, 38 (2), 24 Sep. 1968, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Ambulance & EFS Building. A tender was accepted on Monday last week for a building to be completed by 31 January 1969. It will be situated opposite the Buffalo Lodge Hall on land leased from the Town Council by St John Council of SA and the Burra Burra DC. The building will be approximately 40 ft x 38 ft and will comprised a Board Room, kitchen, storeroom, shower, toilet, two ambulance bays and an EFS bay. A project committee will manage the project. There were seven tenders and that of D.T. Jacka & Co. was successful. Finance will come from Burra District Ambulance Assoc., St John Council Subsidy, Burra Burra DC and a subsidy from the EFS. Building is expected to commence on 1 October. At present the Holden Ambulance is based in a shed at the rear of the shops in Market Square and the VW Ambulance is in a building over the Red Bridge owned by E.T. Baulderstone. The EFS Unit takes up valuable space at the District Council Depot.

Burra Swimming Pool. The opening of the swimming season has been put back two weeks by lack of support for the working bee on 15 September. Apart from committee members or their families only one other person turned up. Preparation and painting will cost $300. High School boys are helping preparations in their sports period and further working bees are called for 5 & 6 October to paint the surface. If these are successful the plant should be able to be operated the following weekend and the pool opened on either 26 October or the 2 November.

91, 38 (2), 24 Sep. 1968, page1 & 8 [Number used before in 1961.]

Walk Against Want. The Freedom from Hunger campaign will benefit from a sponsored walk from Burra Town Hall at 11.30 a.m. Sunday 29 September to Hallett. Walkers will have 61⁄2 hours to get to Hallett. Mr Claude Allen MP will open the Walkathon at 11.25 a.m.

91, 38 (2), 24 Sep. 1968, page 2 [Number used before in 1961.]

Advt. Burra Pictures, 5 October

The Ugly Dachshund

Winnie the Pooh

Burra Mine

The Mine area was visited yesterday by the Minister of Mines the Hon. R.C. De Garis, the Director of Mines Mr Barnes, the Local MP Mr E.C. Allen and a representative of Mines Exploration Ltd Mr Roberts. It is part of a familiarisation study by Mr De Garis of areas of the state with mineral resources. Mr De Garis said studies had shown the presence in Burra of sufficient copper ore (something like 11⁄2%). There remains the problem of gaining the ore on a commercial basis. Tests continue, but how long it will take to get a breakthrough is unknown.

91, 38 (2), 24 Sep. 1968, page 3 [Number used before in 1961.]

Errol Hood has been promoted to General Clerk in the main branch of the National Bank at Whyalla. He succeeds Mr Bob Linke, former teller at Burra, to this position.

Burra Penguin Club will celebrate its second birthday with a dinner tomorrow night.

91, 38 (2), 24 Sep. 1968, pages 3 & 6 gutter [Number used before in 1961.]

Football. North Eastern Grand Finals

Colts Clare South 9.4 defeated Clare North 4.5

Junior Colts Spalding 2.4 defeated Clare North 2.4

Presentations were made to Lindsay Victor as Best & Fairest Colt and to Don Coulter as Best & Fairest of the ‘B’ Grade. L. Gordon of Clare South received the Ashrose shield on behalf of the Colts Team. The Burra Record Trophy to the runner-up in the Mail Medal was presented to Barry Eberhard and the Mail Medal and the Mobil Oil Trophy was presented to the Best & Fairest ‘A’ Grade Don Villis.

91, 38 (2), 24 Sep. 1968, page 6 [Number used before in 1961.]

Football. North Eastern Grand Finals

‘A’ Grade Burra 15.14 defeated Hallett 13.10

‘B’ Grade Burra 9.12 defeated Clare North 6.13

91, 38 (2), 24 Sep. 1968, page 8 [Number used before in 1961.]

Aberdeen Tennis Club held its AGM on Friday 6 September and elected President, Robert Reed; Vice-Presidents, M. Nicholls & M. Tiver; Secretary & Treasurer, F. & S. Scroop; Patron, F.H. Reed. For the coming season it was decided to have two ‘A’ Grade teams, one ‘B’ Grade and one Junior Team. R. Reed reported on the past year. One ‘A’ Grade team (Blue) reached the grand finals and lost to Mt Bryan. In the season the old grandstand behind the numbers 1 & 2 courts was dismantled and new piping stands erected. No. 2 court had to be resheeted for which money was successfully raised. The Easter Tournament was a success, though wet weather and bad light meant three events had to be completed later.

Adelaide Wool Sales, 3-5 September. Prices firmed 21⁄2%. [Local district prices are printed.]

Adelaide-Burra Road Race. This 100-mile handicap event was held on Saturday and was won by the 53-year-old veteran Vic. Dodman (off 45 minutes). The fastest time was 4 hours 12 minutes 8 seconds by B. Gould.

[Details in 3⁄4 column.]

Accident. 12.30 a.m. on Wednesday a car driven by Mr D. Pennington, a teacher of Burra, overturned on the Hallett-Burra Road two miles south of Hallett. The driver suffered concussion and a severely lacerated leg. Damage to the vehicle was estimated at $900.

Accident. At c. 6.10 p.m. on Friday a vehicle overturned on the Morgan-Burra Road five miles east of ‘The Gums’. A woman passenger was taken to the RAH by the Burra ambulance.

91, 39 (2), 1 Oct. 1968, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Junior Cricket Club held its AGM. A practice match at the Memorial Oval next Saturday will decide whether the club fields one or two teams. President, W. Byles; Secretary, A. Fillmore; Patron, R. Opperman and Junior Vice-President, P. Byles.

91, 39 (2), 1 Oct. 1968, pages 1 & 6 [Number used before in 1961.]

The Walk Against want organised by Burra Rural Youth saw 237 starters and raised $1,950 in rather wintry conditions. Mayor E.T. Baulderstone congratulated walkers and hoped their effort would return many dollars for the worthy cause. Sgt Orford urged walkers to take care, as the route was a main highway. Mr Claude Allen MP said a similar event at Berri the week before had raised $1,400. Mrs Allen cut the ribbon to start the walk. The oldest contestant was Barney Rodgers at 67, who completed the course and added $50 to the fund. The youngest was Heather Hanlin of Hallett whose 1 mile added $1. Wally Scott’s sponsorship of $4 per mile raised the most: $80. Raymond Spackman was the fastest to Hallett and won a turkey donated by Mrs A.J. Broad.

[Walkers completing the various distances up to the complete 20 miles are listed and some more were added in 91, 40 (2), 8 Oct. 1968, page 6. Two were added 91, 41 (2), 15 Oct. 1968, page 6 and more were added 91, 42 (2), 22 Oct. 1968, page 6.]

91, 39 (2), 1 Oct. 1968, pages 1 & 8 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra High School. A group of students went to Kangaroo Island during the September holidays. They flew to and from the island. On day 1 they went on a fishing trip and in the afternoon visited Stokes Bay & Emu; two of the beaches. On day 2 they visited Kelly Hill Caves on the South Coast and in the afternoon Vivonne Bay and Baile’s Beach. Other places visited were Flinders Chase, Rocky River, Cape de Couedic, American River, Penneshaw and Cape Willoughby.

At the beginning of this term Miss P. Wilkinson came from Pt Adelaide Girls’ Technical HS to replace Mrs Wilson, who resigned as teacher of Girls’ Craft.

The Parents & Friends’ Association will meet on Thursday to try to get fathers more involved and to discuss the project of erecting a recreation room for students.

The annual Junior School Camp this year will be at the Diocesan Centre at Melrose 8-10 November.

91, 39 (2), 1 Oct. 1968, page 2 [Number used before in 1961.]

Advt. Southern Farmers have instructions from E.W. Satchell to auction his home at 10 Paxton Terrace; a five-roomed stone and concrete house, etc. Also a vacant building block directly behind the house and facing Kingston Street, on which there are the foundations for a four-roomed cottage.

Advt. Southern Farmers offer by tender a 24431⁄2 acre portion of ‘Petherton’ Mt Bryan. Tenders maybe for the whole or in three different sections:

Lot 1. Comprising 10311⁄2 acres Sections Pt 114, 550, Pt 579, Pt 557 & Pt 2539.

Lot 2. Comprising 712 acres Sections 576, 574, 573 & Pt 572.

Lot 3. Comprising 700 acres Sections Pt 566, 551 & 567. (All in the Hundred of Ayers.)

[Herbert Vincent Cox born 7 October 1898 Redruth: died 1 October 1968 Burra, residence Burra North.]

91, 39 (2), 1 Oct. 1968, page 4 [Number used before in 1961.]

SAR will discontinue the passenger service on the Eudunda-Kapunda line from 1 December.

Advt. Burra Pictures, 5 October

Peter Sellers, Peter O’Toole & Romy Schneider in What’s New Pussycat?

Plus Sentenced for Life

91, 39 (2), 1 Oct. 1968, page 7 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Mine. Mr Gilfillan MLC advises that there is an estimated 3 million tons of low grade ore at Burra in the form of copper carbonate impregnated in carbonate rock. The usual method of extraction by the use of acid would not be economic with this volume of rock and the problem is to find a cheaper recovery method.

New Road Rule. From 1 October 1968 flashing lights to indicate turns are required. Trafficators are an acceptable alternative only if the arm is at least six inches long and an inch wide for its entire length.

91, 40 (2), 8 Oct. 1968, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Ian Auhl gave an address entitled Burra the Anatomy of a National Trust Town, as part of a Seminar: Where now with the National Trust? This was held at Adelaide University on Saturday. Mr Auhl gave a convincing case for the preservation of Burra’s historic buildings and walls.

Leighton Public Hall Committee under the Chairman Mr Rod Bailey & Secretary Tom Lynch, recently had the hall painted outside and completed repairs inside. Stage curtains have been fireproofed. The building is used once a month for a dance. When the present debt is paid the next project is a new toilet block.

Burra High School Parents & Friends’ Assoc. had c. 100 to a meeting on Thursday to hear about courses for 1969 and likely changes in the coming years and to discuss the possibility of building a recreation room for students. It was decided to investigate this further. New staff member Miss Wilkinson was introduced and Senior Mistress Miss Newman spoke of the new summer uniform for girls, to be introduced in 1969.

91, 40 (2), 8 Oct. 1968, page 2 [Number used before in 1961.]

Notice. Mr Alf Cornelius has taken over the Men’s Hairdressing Salon of Mr K.J. Murphy.

91, 40 (2), 8 Oct. 1968, pages 3 & 3-6 gutter [Number used before in 1961.]

Cricket

Burra Footballers 107 defeated Mt Bryan 87

Koonaburra 2 for 231 defeated Booborowie 137

91, 40 (2), 8 Oct. 1968, pages 4 & 4-5 gutter [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra & District Tennis Association held its AGM recently at Booborowie. The President reported a successful 1967-68 season with inter-association matches against Pt Broughton and Peterborough, in which the ‘A’ Grade was victorious, but the ‘B’ Grade went down. The Association was also represented in the Country Tennis Carnival at Memorial Drive in January with three gents’ and two ladies’ teams. Mt Bryan’s ‘A’ Grade won their first premiership in over 35 years of competition. Spalding had its two ‘B’ Grade teams play off for the shield and Mt Bryan Juniors won their second successive premiership. Mr L. Matters of Spalding has donated a new ‘B’ Grade Shield to commence the 1967-68 season.

91, 40 (2), 8 Oct. 1968, page 5 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Swimming Pool. There was a pleasing response for the working bee at the pool on Saturday. While only three adults and ten children were there in the morning, about 32 people arrived in the afternoon. The first coat (a sealer) was put on in just over four hours. Unfortunately bad weather prevented further painting on Sunday and this has been postponed till next Sunday. The opening of the pool is scheduled for the first Saturday in November. The paint being used is an Epoxy Resin based paint, which should give a smooth finish and is hoped, will not lift with normal use.

Burra Football Club celebrated premierships in ‘A’ & ‘B’ Grades with a dinner dance on Friday night. Presentations were made:

Best & Fairest in ‘A’ Grade Barry Eberhard

Best & Fairest in ‘B’ Grade A. Ryan with Adrian Johnson as runner-up.

Barry Eberhard also won the Forard Medal for most Mail medal votes for a Burra player.

Kevin Lane received the A.L. Collins Shield as Captain of the ‘A’ Grade team and Graham Kellock received the ANZ Bank Shield as captain of the ‘B’ Grade team.

Rev. Milton Edwards of Burra will be ordained at a service in Kent Town Methodist Church on Thursday night.

Lynette Winders of Black Springs left Jennison’s on Saturday morning to take up a new position in Adelaide on 21 October. Mary Lewis of Hallett replaces her at Jennison’s.

Marriage. Raelene Hawke will marry Graham Waters at St Mary’s next Saturday.

Jack Kellaway of Croydon and formerly of Burra will be 85 on 10 October.

Janet Salter is leaving work at Burra Hospital after three years for a position in Adelaide.

Obituary. Mr Frank Sumner of Hallett died yesterday.

[Frank William Sumner born 5 October 1896 Croydon: died 7 October 1968 Hallett. A Notice to Creditors 91, 13 (2), 8 Apr. 1969, page 6 states he was a farmer and grazier.]]

Obituary. Mr Bob Fuss died recently aged 82. He will be buried at 11 a.m. tomorrow. A life member of the Show Society, he will be missed for his years of voluntary work in the pavilions.

[Lawrence Robert Fuss born 25 October 1885 Aberdeen: died 7 October 1968 Prospect, residence Burra.]

91, 40 (2), 8 Oct. 1968, page 8 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Town Council, 23 September

The Mayor’s action in having D.T. Jacka & Co. cover the area under the Town Hall balcony with hardboard was endorsed.

Weeds in the cemetery have been sprayed.

Cemetery charges: grave digging weekdays $20 and weekends and public holidays $30. There will be a surcharge of $5 for filling in a grave on weekends or public holidays.

The cost of electrical work at the Caravan Park rose $33 due to the need to install circuit breakers rather than fuses. A subsidy will be sought to cover this charge.

The Highways & Local Government Department will be asked to investigate damage done to Taylor Street when the bridge on Highway 32 had been closed. [The Bon accord Bridge.]

The Department of Agriculture advises of a subsidy of $45 for spraying the stock route. ($120 had been requested.)

The Burra Small Bore Club was given permission to close the gateway in the northern stone wall to a gate 2 ft 6 inches wide.

Advertising slides shown at the Town Hall will be updated by Monks & Blanks Ltd.

Burra Golf Associates held their AGM on 25 September.

President Mrs M. Nicholls welcomed Associates. The highlight of the season was Judy’s winning the Zone Silver Salver. Another highlight was Burra’s win in the Pennant Competition after having played in it for years without a win. Open Day entries were down and it was not a financial success, but it was enjoyable. Congratulations go to the ‘A’ Grade Champion Mrs Jeffery, the ‘B’ Grade Champion Mrs Oates and ‘C’ Grade Champion Mrs Gebhardt.

Elected were: Patroness, Mrs A.L. Collins; President, Mrs M. Nicholls; Vice-Presidents, Mrs R. Wuttke & Mrs E. Jeffery; Treasurer, Mrs R. Gordon; Secretary, Mrs F. Reed, Assistant Secretary, Mrs E. Oates; Captain, Mrs D. Field and Vice-Captain, Mrs J. Oates.

The pennant was presented to Mrs D. Field, Captain of the Burra Team, at a social game at Clare on 26 September.

91, 41 (2), 15 Oct. 1968, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Kindergarten Gingham Fair was held in the RSL Hall on Friday and raised over $170 for the cause.

Adelaide Wool Sales. Local district prices are printed.

91, 41 (2), 15 Oct. 1968, pages 1 & 5 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Show was held on Saturday in perfect weather. Gate takings of $486 were up on the previous year and overall entries of 2527 were just under the 1967 record. Secretary Miss Judy Beinke had arrangements well in hand. There were 900 entries in Horse-in-Action. The opening was performed by Mr E.C. Allen MP.

[In his speech Mr Allen referred to activities at the Burra Mine. He said drilling there had revealed approximately 3.4 million tons of ore, which could be mined by open cut, though there remained the problem of separating the copper from the rock. At present they can recover 60%, but 80% is needed to make it a payable proposition and work on a process is continuing. Id they are successful the Mine should employ 35-50 men directly for approximately 10 years. This would be a great boost for Burra economically.]

Industrial stands were filled to capacity.

Sideshows were both more numerous and more varied than in past years.

Flower entries were down, but standards were maintained.

Needlework entries were well up with a good juvenile section, but the CWA section only had two entries. The standard was very good.

School Displays were pleasing with entries from Burra High and Burra Primary Schools, Burra Kindergarten, Leighton, Farrell Flat, Mt Bryan and St Joseph’s Convent.

Art entries were down and the standard was not particularly high. Some sections were poorly represented.

Budgerigars were of a good standard and bantams a creditable display.

Poultry entries were not high, but included some nice birds.

The pigeon section was a big improvement on 1967.

The cooking standard was down.

Grain and fodder entries were good, but few.

Goats were of an exceptionally high standard.

Sheep entries were down, but quality was good.

Fruit and vegetable entries were few, but of good quality.

Flowers were good for late in the season, especially in pelargoniums, fuchsias, poppies, cinerarias, stocks and anemones.

Floral Art was good, with the flowers fresh and of excellent quality.

Horses-in-Action produced very high standard jumping. Novelty events were keenly contested.

Wool entries were well grown with good character.

91, 41 (2), 15 Oct. 1968, page 3 [Number used before in 1961.]

Hallett Red Cross Flower Show was held on 4 October. A list of prize winners is printed.

The National Trust Museum has been given a book of cheque stubs from the Burra Mine dated November 1849. The receipts are often signed with a cross.

E.W. Dunhill is 94 on 10 October.

Burra Rural Youth Dance on Saturday night made a profit of $41.

91, 42 (2), 22 Oct. 1968, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Ian Allen writes on behalf of the Management Committee of the Burra Swimming Pool to thank those who helped get the pool painted and to report that only minor maintenance jobs now remain and if weather permits it should now be able to be opened on 26 October.

Burra Bowling Club held a general meeting on 17 October. There will be two teams this season in Division 1 (Gold & Green) and two in Division 2 (Blue & White). The 1868-69 season was opened last Saturday by Mayor E.T. Baulderstone. The President of the Associates, Pat Field, cast the first jack and Bill Corner, the 1967-68 Club Champion, put down the first bowl. The North Eastern Women’s Bowling Association competition was opened for 1968-69 at Peterborough on 16 October. Pennant matches begin 23 October.

91, 43 (2), 29 Oct. 1968, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Swimming Pool. Charges for 1968-69.

Season Family Ticket $12.00

Season Adult Ticket $6.00

Season Child Ticket $3.00

Session Tickets Adult 20c and children 10c.

Silverware Exhibition

Adelaide’s only silversmith Mr John Hale will stage an exhibition of his craftsmanship at the Burra Town Hall on Tuesday 26 November. The exhibition is being brought to Burra to aid the Burra Hospital. A feature will be a 60-piece silver dinner service and there will be examples of church silverware. There will also be examples of Georgian silverware and paintings by the artist Mr Bruce Swann.

Burra Town Council has accepted the resignation of the Town Clerk, Mr R.K. Baker, who will transfer to Henley and Grange on 14 November. Mr F. Ascott, who has been Acting District Clerk during the absence of Mr T.G. Perry, has accepted the position of Acting Town Clerk till mid-January. With amalgamation of the two Councils being discussed this will allow time for arrangements to be made. The Town Councillors agreed unanimously in principle for amalgamation and will meet District Council members on early November to discuss acceptance or otherwise.

Bomb

‘On Friday, members of the Homicide Squad, of the Adelaide CIB, visited Burra to further enquiries concerning the bomb incident of Mr E.C. Allen MP of Spalding.’

[There were brief references to this at the opening of the Burra Show, but they revealed no more than this statement, but see 91, 47 (2), 26 Nov. 1968, page 1.]

Burra Railway Station

The old overhead steel tank of some 30,000 gallons capacity was demolished last Thursday. It was understood to be about 50 years old and was mounted on stone walling about 15 ft x 30 ft x 30 ft high and some 2 ft thick. A previous attempt to blast the walls had little effect, but this time the tank was toppled and has been broken up for scrap. A large ‘Blackstone’ motor and pump was used on the bore underneath to fill the tank.

91, 43 (2), 29 Oct. 1968, page 2 [Number used before in 1961.]

Lot 1. ‘Coralinga’ 1,422 acres comprising sections 502-506 & 511-514 Hd Ayers, disposed as six paddocks with stone house, etc.

Lot 2. ‘Finch’s’ 521 acres comprising sections 507, 509 & 510 Hd Ayers, disposed as two paddocks.

Both have been part of Bungaree Stud since 1922 – on the Burra-Booborowie Road, some four miles southeast of Booborowie.

91, 43 (2), 29 Oct. 1968, page 8 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Small Bore Club. Over double 50 yards the best scorers were R. Gilbert, J. Bowden & K. Talbot.

91, 44 (2), 5 Nov. 1968, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

A History of Seven Mid-Northern Hundreds

The publishing committee of the Terowie Branch of the CWA advises its publication Deceptive Lands: a History of Seven Mid-Northern Hundreds, will be released before Christmas at a cost of $5. The Author is Roma Mattey (now Mrs Hans Schultz). It is an attempt to cover the early pastoral history of the Hundreds of Terowie, Whyte Yarcowie, Wonna, Gumbowie, Ketchowla, Yongala and Parnaroo.

All surveyed towns in the area except Peterborough have been described and there are many historic photographs in the book of over 250 pages. The foreword is by His Excellency W.R. Crocker, now Australian Ambassador in Rome. He spent his early childhood at Parnaroo.

Burra Swimming Pool. The season was opened last Saturday. About 30 keen swimmers braved conditions a little colder than desired. Norm Lihou has the filtration system working well. Mr Stan Kellaway is taking care of the vacuuming of the pool. Other tasks concerning the pool and canteen have been rostered.

The Hospital Department has increased Burra Town Council’s contribution to the Burra Hospital from $973 to $1,373 – a 41% increase. The Council is strongly objecting, as this has occurred after the budget for 1968-69 has been prepared and the rate declared. The Hospital Board has not requested an increase in contributions. Increases have not been ordered for the Burra Burra DC, the Robertstown or the Hallett Councils.

91, 44 (2), 5 Nov. 1968, pages 1, 4, 5 & the 4-5 gutter [Number used before in 1961.]

Ian Auhl’s Address: Burra The Anatomy of a National Trust Town is printed.

[Auhl begins by talking about the problem of Burra’s name as a town and the Burra of the Five Towns – choosing as his five Kooringa, Copperhouse, Redruth, Aberdeen and Hampton. He goes on to speak of how it is still in some ways three towns – Kooringa, Aberdeen and Redruth. He goes along with the story of ‘the early separation of the towns upon distinct nationalistic lines – Cornish, English and Welsh. For nearly 20 years there was no direct road for traffic between the northern and southern towns. He then says that there was no Corporation or Council of Burra until after the mines closed in 1877. This is such a bad error that it is hard to believe that Auhl would have said it and it casts doubt on the authenticity of the text – though it is early in the period of his historical research. He also says that only two hotels were allowed to operate inside the Mining Association’s area. This is another error which it is hard to believe Auhl would have made. The Burra Hotel, the Miners’ Arms and the Pig & Whistle operated in Kooringa for a long period and for shorter periods there were also others. The Commercial Hotel also began operation near the end of the mining period. In addition the Smelters’ Home, while at Burra North, was still within the Mining Association’s area. He goes on to discuss how the Mining Association kept the railway outside their section and to talk of the term ‘The Burra’, supposing it to be a contraction of ‘The Burra Mine’, given that the name did not then apply to the town properly speaking.

He considers that the focal point for Burra: an Historical Town is the old mining area and its destruction would destroy any prima facie case for Burra as an Historic Town. The retention of the unity of the town is also important. He draws a distinction between a place of the past and a place with a past. Burra is definitely the latter. Burra once saved a struggling SA from bankruptcy and he believes it is now time for SA to save Burra.

History, for Historic Towns, must be more than interesting, it must be important and to attract money that importance must be at the state level, not merely parochially. Time, he says, is running out. Auhl then goes on to acknowledge the National Trust Museum, but considers it more important to see the town itself as the museum.]

Burra’s claims, he considers, are:

Except for Kapunda it is the oldest mining town in Australia. Kapunda began in 1842-43 and Burra two years later. Coppermania was the predecessor of gold fever in the eastern states. When gold was first discovered near Bathurst Kapunda had a population of 1,000 and Burra one of 5,000. There were deserted mining villages in SA before there were any mining camps in NSW or Victoria.

Mere age is, however, not enough; the town must be capable of survival. Kapunda the mining town, survived, but it has been much outgrown by Kapunda the agricultural centre. Burra, unfortunately for its growth and development, remained isolated and its population declined from 5,000 in 1850 to 3,000 in 1877 to now 1,000 or so and it has tended to make use of what buildings it had. When the mine closed it became a forgotten town, struggling to survive – almost a frontier town on the edge of Goyder’s Line, with empty saltbush plain to its east. The district turned from mining to wheat and sheep and from that to stud breeding.

Another reason for its survival has been its physical solidity. Knocking things down has been an Australian pastime. Burra buildings are solidly built of a hard carbonaceous shale, which splits easily, but presents a face which withstands weathering. The mine buildings at Burra have withstood neglect, time and weather much better that the limestone structures at Kadina and Wallaroo. Progress which involves the modernisation of shop fronts etc. is not necessarily progress in a tourist town.

‘It is my firm belief that Burra’s biggest business lies in its possibilities as an historic town. The destruction or radical alteration of its buildings to me constitutes the destruction of its assets.’

Auhl thought the Burra Town Council more far sighted in this respect than most others. Of course Burra will need modern buildings and institutions, such as for its hospital and school and a motel, but it does not need modernisation of its existing buildings, which are the very assets of its future.

Happily Burra has largely used the buildings it had and its walls are largely intact, though some are sadly neglected. Hardly any street of sector of the town lacks the sort of place which a visitor cannot find with delight.

The isolation of Burra has, in large measure, been responsible for its preservation, but this is at complete variance with its early history, when it was the economic heart of the colony. Many towns on the Copper Road and from Gawler to Burra grew around the wayside inns marking the end of a day’s journey for the bullock teams to and from Burra.

The history of Burra is visual rather than written. There are very few living in Burra who could remember even the closing of the mines. Few locals know the story of their town and fewer realise its significance. Since the visit of the Adelaide National Trust to Burra there has been some revival of interest and a subsequent tour for local people brought an almost overwhelming attendance.

Written History

When Burra’s history comes to be written it will almost be the history of SA for 1845-60. It took ten years for SA’s population to reach 20,000, but in the following four years it jumped to 60,000. By 1848 its mineral exports were £320,000 out of a total of £465,000. Shipping increased from 10,000 tons in 1844 to 80,000 tons four years later. At times the mine had 6,000 bullocks on the road, with at least 1,000 drivers and drays. Burra’s population was 5,000 when Adelaide’s was 20,000. This history remains to be told, though Geoffrey Blainey made a beginning in his book The Rush that Never Ended.

Vandalism

The slow vandalism of time and weather has had little impact on Burra’s native stone buildings. The vandalisms of individuals, often thoughtless, but sometimes deliberate or inspired by greed, or sometimes almost sadistic, have had their effect. There is also the vandalism of indifference. This is the most dangerous, as it allows the other forms to go unchecked. This cannot be checked without the help of Acts of Parliament.

There is also the vandalism of snobbery, which believes a mansion is intrinsically more worthy of preservation than the houses of common people. To me the preservation of the miners’ huts in the Burra Creek is as important as the preservation of Ayers’ House. Let us remember that the former preceded and were responsible for the latter. Country museums have a bad habit of beginning to look alike.

‘And a natural corollary of a museum in a town is plaques in the rest of the town. Nothing to me is more pathetic than a plaque. It is a symbol of defeat.’

‘Plaques are epitaphs.’

‘A book – a record of some kind – yes!’

‘This type of preservation is the basis of National Histories and the flesh of our National bones.’

‘Buildings lead to questions – and questions lead to research – and research leads to preservation.’

[Auhl then goes on to say he has been encouraged by the responses he has had to requests to Government Departments. He says while the National Trust has as yet no access to Government funds, Councils and Corporations have, through Tourist Grants. This means working with the Tourist Bureau.]

The Town Planning Act has yet to be tested as far as historic towns and their buildings are concerned, but the 1965 Aboriginal and Historic Relics Act is perhaps the most hopeful piece of legislation. Local business organisations take even more convincing than politicians, but once convinced are the most useful and energetic of the lot.

‘If…as I believe that Burra did indeed save the young South Australia, surely it is not too much to ask South Australia to now save Historic Burra.’

91, 44 (2), 5 Nov. 1968, page 2 [Number used before in 1961.]

91, 45 (2), 12 Nov. 1968, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

The 50th Anniversary of Armistice Day was commemorated yesterday at a short ceremony at the Burra War Memorial. Eight returned representatives of the armed services attended with civic leaders. Eighty primary school children swelled the numbers. Flags flew at half mast and shops were closed for the duration of the service. Rev. J.H. Stephenson gave the address. Messrs Nankivell, Young, Baulderstone and Finch laid wreaths.

Kooringa Methodist Guild Fete was held in the RSL Hall on Friday. Mrs M. Edwards (wife of Rev. Milton Edwards) opened the fete. Proceeds amounted to $224.

Weather. 50-60 points fell throughout the district in the week, but strong winds on Sunday and Monday reduced the benefit from it.

Burra Town & District Councils held a combined meeting on 5 November in the [District] Council Chamber in Commercial Street. The Town and District Clerks, R.K. Baker and T.G. Perry respectively, also attended. DC Chairman Cr G.R. Finch presided. Cr Finch spoke in favour of the union of the two councils.

Mayor Baulderstone then also spoke in favour, mentioning points where improvements could be made. Each member of the councils than spoke in favour of union. Cr T. Quinn moved that the meeting was in favour of the union of the two councils. Cr B. Kotz seconded and the motion was carried unanimously.

Cr T. Quinn moved and Cr C.L. Phillips seconded that the petition include a request for the mayor of the district to be retained. Carried unanimously. The meeting adjourned to a combined meeting to be called as soon as possible after the 2 December.

91, 45 (2), 12 Nov. 1968, pages 1 & 4 [Number used before in 1961.]

Ian Auhl writes in response to remarks made by E.C. Allen MP when opening the Burra Show, when he mentioned the possibility of a short term re-opening of the old Burra Mine:

While the facts given by Mr Allen are no doubt correct, there are many unanswered questions in people’s minds. Mr Allen does not know the town well enough to realise that the short term future he envisages is in direct conflict with its long term future role as a tourist town and Australia’s oldest mining area. If what was being offered was another Mt Isa or even a new Burra Mine there would be no doubt about the benefits, though even then some would no doubt regret the passing of the old mine area. Bur exactly what will Burra (or SA) gain by the destruction of the old mine area and all its buildings – by the destruction of an area unique in Australia and which is Burra’s central asset as a tourist attraction? Mt answer is, it would be exchanging its unique heritage for a mess and not for any real gain. Among the questions that need to be answered are:

What percentage of copper does the 3.4 million tons of ore body contain? The correct answer, I believe, is an average 1%.

How much of this 1% can be extracted by present processes? About 60%. So the useful part of the ore is about 0.5%. This would be unprofitable at present, even with the high price of copper. An efficient metallurgical process would apparently make it profitable by managing to extract another 0.25%. We are not told what the profits of the mine would amount to, but surely they would be marginal.

Who would profit? Mainly the shareholders of Broken Hill South of which Mines Exploration Ltd is a subsidiary company.

What would Burra get out of this? Extra trade as the result of employing some 35 or so men. Other benefits have not been specified.

Where would they be housed? Perhaps in company caravans or units, as they have been for the past few years or perhaps on Housing Trust land near the Redruth Gaol.

Past experience suggests they would be single men.

Would they be Burra men? It is not stated.

What houses would be affected? What area of the town would the open cut affect? What would be the length and width of the open cut? Would it be about 3⁄4 mile long by 1⁄4 mile wide and 500 ft deep?

What effect would the pumping have on the Burra watertable?

Would any of the ore body be processed in Burra? Or would it be transported 600 miles to Cobar for processing?

Is there any indication that after a maximum of ten years mining there would be any permanent benefit for Burra?

Some twelve months ago I mentioned these questions to an officer of Mines Exploration Ltd and spoke of the relative value to Burra of such a small mining venture compared with the value of the town’s long term tourist possibilities. The answer was ‘So what?’ as if this could be of no concern to the people of Burra and was evidently of little concern to someone chasing a quick quid.

Is Mr Allen aware that the Corporation of Burra owns the mine area and the mineral rights?

What compensation is likely to be paid whether the mine opens or not?

Is Mr Allen aware that Mines Exploration Ltd used the old powder magazine for storing bags of samples and this has resulted in the cracking of the roof of this, the oldest mine building in Australia?

Does Mr Allen know the company fenced around the chief tourist attraction – Graves’ Shaft and Engine House? Was permission sought or given for these acts? What compensation arrangements have been made for the loss of the mining area and its buildings or for damage done? Is the establishment of a small mining venture in the heart of a town really wanted? Id Burra needs a boost it is already getting one from the growing tourist traffic and the value to the town of thousands of tourists will be much greater than the value of an additional 35 men or so for a maximum of ten years. Various Governments have spent a considerable sum in exploring the mine area, but the answer is a doubtful one and of comparatively little value to Burra itself. This apparent boost could be more of a kick in the pants than a shot in the arm. I would like to see a public meeting to give the people of Burra a chance to express their opinions and ask their own questions on the matter of Burra’s future.

91, 45 (2), 12 Nov. 1968, page 2 [Number used before in 1961.]

91, 45 (2), 12 Nov. 1968, page 8 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Town Council, 28 October

The Mayor reported on the subject of the union of the Corporation and the District Council.

Burra CWA has donated a further $56 towards a new centre carpet for the Town Hall.

The Tourist Bureau has ruled that the Council should meet the small extra cost of the Caravan Park.

The Hospital Department advises of an increase of $400 or 41% in payment due to the Burra Hospital by the Council: and increase from $973 to $1373. The Department is to be advised that with the budget adopted and the rate declared by the Council is at a loss to know where they are to get the increase and also drawing attention to the reduction in rates allowed to the hospital for many years. A copy of this letter will also be sent to C. Allen MP. If necessary he will be asked to arrange for a deputation on the matter to the Chief Secretary, Mr De Garis.

The Minister of Tourism complains about the public toilets in Burra. He is to be advised that they are cleaned each morning.

The Department of Agriculture advises a further subsidy of $70 for noxious weed control, for a total of $115.

Burra Small Bore Club lease was renewed for ten years.

Action is to be taken re the safety of the old open tank in the Redruth Gaol.

R.K. Baker was thanked for his work for the short time he has been Town Clerk.

91, 46 (2), 19 Nov. 1968, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Football

After a meeting on Wednesday the possibility of the affiliation of SANFL and SA Country Football League seems closer. A twenty year dispute over umpires has moved a step closer to resolution. SABFL will mow consider the proposal.

The Crown Lands Act Amendment Bill now before Parliament proposes to remove the existing limits of 4,000 acres or $36,000 unimproved value on the holding of Crown Perpetual Leases. There are c. 16 millions acres freehold in SA and c. 20 million acres of Crown Perpetual Lease.

91, 46 (2), 19 Nov. 1968, page 2 [Number used before in 1961.]

Advt. Southern Farmers. Land for sale by tender.

Lot 1. On account Mrs E.W. Woollacott & Miss M.S. Woollacott. Freehold of 145 acres 2 roods Pt Section 1 Hd Kooringa with old stone house and sheds. House presently unoccupied, but usable.

Lot 2. Account of Miss R.J. Woollacott. ‘Nankivells’ 124 acres 3 roods 20 perches Pt Section 143 Hd Kooringa. Grazing land with dam, bore, troughs, etc.

Lot 3. Account of Mrs E.W. Woollacott. ‘Villis’s’. 678 acres Section 102 & town allotments in the Township of Douglas Hd of Baldina. 108 acres 37 perches freehold and 565 acres 1 rood leasehold.

Advt. Elders-GM. Land for sale by tender on account of Mrs S.J. Woollacott & Miss M.S. Woollacott.

Lot 1. ‘The Farm’ 377 acres freehold Pt Section 9 Hd Kooringa with shearing shed, two bores, etc. Disposed as two paddocks.

Lot 2. ‘Shorts’ 436 acres freehold Block 91 Hd Hanson 21⁄4 miles east of Hanson. 2 dams etc. Disposed as five paddocks.

Lot 3. ‘Woollacott’s’ 567 acres 2 roods freehold. Pt Sections 182 & 183 Hd Hanson with two roomed old stone house etc. Disposed as seven paddocks.

Lot 4. ‘Turner’s’ 278 acres 2 roods freehold. Pt Section 85 Hd Hanson 4 miles south of Burra. Disposed as two paddocks.

Lot 5. ‘Pumping Station’ 57 acres 1 rood 17 perches freehold. Pt Section 146 Hd Hanson. One paddock adjoins Township of Hanson. Murray water connected.

Lot 6. ‘Township Block’ 16 acres 1 rood 8 perches. Hanson Township blocks 1-8, 10-12, 80-87 and a road. Annual licence 5580. Murray water.

Lot 7. ‘Kalcootra’ 795 acres Sections 55 & 59 Hd Hallett. Perpetual lease. 14 miles northeast of Mt Bryan. Disposed as three paddocks.

91, 47 (2), 26 Nov. 1968, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

E.C. Allen’s Bomb

On 27 September a parcel bomb was addressed to E.C. Allen MP for Burra at Parliament House, Adelaide. It had been posted in a letter box in Adelaide in the afternoon of 27thand delivered to Mr Allen at Parliament House. Believing it to be a parcel of goods his wife had purchased at John Martin’s, because of a label on it, he took it home to Spalding without opening it. Mrs Allen opened the parcel slowly and the bomb, which was exposed when she removed the lid of the box, failed to explode. CIB members attended with the Army bomb disposal squad and rendered the bomb harmless. It was in a parcel 6 inches x 21⁄2 inches x 21⁄2 inches. It was rigged so that a Schermuly ‘Mars’ hand flare connected to a .243 Metallverken make cartridge would trigger gelignite. Scientists discovered that dust on the wood in the bomb has come from the Burra North area. Detectives have been conducting investigations in the area from 12 November and the Government has offered a $2,000 reward for information leading to the apprehension of the sender.

Burra Cards

The Burra Branch of the National Trust is sponsoring the book Burra Sketch Book with text by Ian Auhl and 30 drawings by the young Burra architect Maurice Perry. From the 30 drawings five have been selected and reproduced on cards in time for Christmas. The set of five with envelopes will cost 75c and individual cards will cost 20c. The five selected are: Morphett’s Engine House [Pictured in the paper.]

Redruth Gaol

Market Square

Bon Accord Mine Manager’s Residence & Engineer’s Shop

Burra Railway Station

St Mary’s Burra will have a service of Advent Carols on Sunday night. Fr G.D. Sibly, a former Rector, is returning to play the organ. Mrs J. Nairn, formerly Miss Rosemary Reed, will sing soprano again.

Land Sale. Corolinga Pty Ltd (C.R. & P.M. Earle) bought the property known as ‘”Corolinga” and “Finch’s” comprising 1,943 acres of freehold on the Burra-Booborowie Road, 4 miles southeast of Booborowie, for $74 per acre.

Obituary. Miss Ida Harris of Burra died suddenly last week.

91, 47 (2), 26 Nov. 1968, pages 4 & 5 gutter [Number used before in 1961.]

Obituary. The late Mrs Mabel Gill of Spalding died at Jamestown Hospital on 1 November. She was born Mabel Elliott at Wilmington in 1888 and was educated first at Wilmington and then moved to Jamestown to complete her education. At a young age she married Percy Gill and she lived at Spalding for over 60 years. At first they attended the Presbyterian Church, but when it was demolished she joined the Methodist Guild. She was also a member of the Spalding CWA and Red Cross. Her husband predeceased her. [Born Mabel Maud Elliott 29 March 1888 Wilmington: died Mabel Maude Gill 1 November 1968 Jamestown, residence Spalding.]

91, 47 (2), 26 Nov. 1968, page 5 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Golf Club AGM was held 7 November.

The year had been a social and financial success. All scrapes had received a heavy coating of slag, which served well. A major project saw additions to the clubhouse and toilets, to enable the club to get a permit for refreshments. Open day drew over 100 entries. Club Champion this year was Hartley Strawbridge. The heavy expenditure had left the club in debt, but this position was righted by members paying subscriptions in advance. Elected were President, John Gordon; Vice-Presidents, R. Mason & I. McWaters; Captain, S. Longford; Vice-Captain, J. Bogisch, Treasurer, J. Bonython and Secretary, R. Jeffery.

91, 47 (2), 26 Nov. 1968, page 6 [Number used before in 1961.]

The Swimming Pool Committee organised a Continental at Market Square for Friday, but wet and wintry conditions saw it moved to the Town Hall. The Rural Youth Club ran a barbecue with chops and sausages. [Details in 3⁄4 columns.) $420 was raised.

91, 47 (2), 26 Nov. 1968, Supplement [Number used before in 1961.]

This was larger than a normal full-sized page and was an advertisement celebrating SAGASCO’s 10th birthday – the Burra Agent was Guy Dollman’s Burra Motor Co. It featured four colour printing and was folded into quarters.

91, 48 (2), 3 Dec. 1968, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Mr Ralph Oakley of Mt Bryan has an injury to his lower back after being struck by the wheel of an aircraft that was carrying out aerial spraying. He and two others were ‘flag-marking’ when the accident occurred. He was grazed by the wheel as he flung himself to the ground. His condition is painful, but satisfactory.

Booborowie School Pet Show was very successful and is reported in c. 1⁄2 column.

St Mary’s Advent Carol Service was attended by about 40 people. Fr Geoffrey Sibly came from Adelaide to play the organ and a there was a quartet of Rosemary Nairn (soprano), Jan Cockington (contralto), Alan Edwards (tenor) and John Stephenson (bass). John sang six items and Rosemary & Jan also sang two duets.

Burra Hospital Funds benefited by $150 from a display of handmade silverware and pictures at the Town Hall on Tuesday evening. It featured work by silversmiths John Hale and John Hooft. Other items were on loan from churches. The paintings were by Bruce Swann and 26 of the 32 were for sale and were bought for prices ranging from $18 to $50.

Swimming Pool Committee Continental. Donations have boosted the total raised to $501.

Burra Mine.

[E.C. Allen writes seeking to clarify the implications of the possible re-opening of the Burra Mine.]

Too many assumptions have been made by people not in possession of the facts. On 10 January 1966 the then Minister of Mines Hon. S.C. Bevan MLC advised Mines Exploration Ltd of his acceptance of their proposal to explore the area. Both the present and the previous Government have placed much emphasis on mineral exploration in SA to directly help state income. Indicated reserves at Burra are 3.3 million tons of possible ore at an average 1.6% copper. The problem of how much of this can be extracted is being investigated. Consequently it is not yet possible to say how much the mine would be worth – a figure also affected by changing copper prices. A rough estimate, however, suggests that 3.3 million tons yielding 1% copper at the present price of $1,000 per ton would realise $33 million. Some 60-70 men would be directly employed with a payroll of about $5,000 per week or $260,000 per year. As many local men as were available would be employed and housing would be built as needed – men would not live in caravans or units. No homes would be affected by the possible open pits, the largest of which would finally be 1,100 feet x 750 ft and the smaller 800 ft x 300 ft, separated by some 300 ft and the deepest would be some 300 ft in depth. Experience suggests the water table would not be affected except in the immediate mine area. Ore would be treated to the concentration stage at Burra, as otherwise transportation cost would be prohibitive. I asked a question in the House on 28 November to see if provision could be made when laying the natural gas pipeline through Gum Creek and Leighton areas, for a later connection to Burra. Arrangements were completed some time ago with the Corporation to realign the fence in the Graves’ Shaft area to allow access to the shaft (the cost to be borne by Mines Exploration Ltd.) and this has been attended to. It is expected the life of operations would be 10-15 years. I have no doubt that both mining activities and tourist activities could work together. The Department of Mines Exploration have expressed a keen desire to do everything possible to preserve the early relics of mining in this area and I have been given to understand they would be prepared to remove and re-erect any of the buildings considered to be of value. I have supplied a map showing the extent of the proposed operations.

[Editor: the map will be displayed in the Record Office window.]

91, 48 (2), 3 Dec. 1968, page 3 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Cards. The Market Square card is reproduced with the comment that ‘Market Square has changed little since the mines closed down in 1877.’

[This is an odd comment when of the structures shown none were there in 1877. The scene shows Drew & Crewes Store (1880), Elders Building (Visitor Centre) (1890) Burra Hotel with its second floor (1912), the Fallen Soldiers Memorial (1922) and some shops which replaced those destroyed by a fire in 1883.]

91, 49 (2), 10 Dec. 1968, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Councils to Unite

A joint sitting of the Burra Burra District Council and the Burra Town Council was held in the [DC] Council Chambers in Commercial Street on 3 December. DC Chairman G.R. Finch presided. Cr B.A. Riggs moved and Cr T. Quinn seconded that the merged Council comprise eight councillors from the District Council of Burra Burra and three from the Corporation of Burra. Carried.

It was also resolved that in the new Council the Corporation would be represented by three Councillors from one ward, to be known as Burra Town Ward and that the ward boundaries would be those of the present Corporation. The New Council will be called the District Council of Burra Burra.

It was also resolved that the rates would be levied under the unimproved land value system.

Offences

Vandals have been damaging the Burra North Playground and tennis courts. Last week some young offenders were apprehended.

Saddleworth police are investigating a number of cases where vacant houses in the Porter’s Lagoon area have been broken into.

A five-ton stack of sheaved hay owned by L.E. Taylor on the property of E. Landorf, Booborowie was destroyed by fire.

Black Springs School. The students had an excursion to Adelaide by rail on 4 December. They visited the Children’s Library, the Public Library, and the top of the AMP Building, witnessed the arrival of the new Governor, Major General Sir James Harrison and visited the Magic Cave, the Botanic Gardens, the Zoo and the SA Parliament.

Mr Bob Farrow was given a farewell after the evening service at the Redruth Methodist Church on Sunday last. He has been junior circuit steward and preacher’s assistant. Mr E.T. Baulderstone thanked him on behalf of the town. Mr Jack Oates sang Where e’er you walk and Elizabeth Oates & Mary Woollacott gave a musical tribute in a specially written song. A presentation was made of a recording of Handel’s Messiah.

Mr Farrow is moving to become Headmaster of Kadina High School. He also expressed his support for the Methodist Church’s decision to withdraw from teaching Religious Instruction in State Schools and hoped a more effective means of teaching the subject would soon be evolved.

Burra’s late shopping night will be held on Tuesday, Christmas Eve. Shops will stay open till 9 p.m. A merry-go-round will be provided all day Tuesday near the Burra Hotel. Father Christmas will arrive soon after 9 p.m. Rural Youth will arrange a dance in the Show Hall to follow the proceedings in the street.

Lynette Griffen, Angela Quinn and Christine Steele; all of Burra High School.

91, 49 (2), 10 Dec. 1968, page 8 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Town Council, 26 November

The Mayor reported that the old Redruth Gaol had been improved.

The Swimming Pool Committee was working well and a Ladies’ Committee had been formed.

The Oval Committee was functioning well.

It was suggested that a committee to run the Town Hall be formed next year. Left in the hands of the Mayor.

It was resolved that the pictures on loan to the National Trust remain on loan only to the National Trust and are to be retained at the Burra Museum at the pleasure of the Corporation. The action of repair is endorsed.

The closure of a road at the cemetery was in the hands of surveyors.

The renting out of the Corporation house was left in the Mayor’s hands.

91, 50 (2), 17 Dec. 1968, page 1 [Number used before in 1961.]

Adelaide Wool Sales 10-12 December. G.G. Lines & Son of Gum Hill topped local prices at 573⁄4c.

[Other local district prices are printed.]

Fires

Fire destroyed 65 acres of crop on the property of Mr D.C. Gebhardt north of Mt Bryan township. The fire was confined to Mr Gebhardt’s property, on which 40 acres of wheat and 25 acres of oats were lost.

A truck exhaust is believed to have been the cause of a number of roadside fires on Tuesday morning in the Hanson area. They were brought under control before serious damage was caused.

Football. No decision to affiliate the Country Football League with SANFL has yet been made.

Burra Swimming Pool

An appeal using over 200 notices to get fathers to enter a roster system to assist in management and discipline at the pool on weekends and to attend to cleaning of the dressing rooms has failed to elicit sufficient replies. They were only 16 responses. [And what those replies said is garbled in the report.] The committee is faced with the expense of employing help – perhaps people not prepared or able to offer direct help could offer financial assistance.

Burra High School. The Annual Swimming Carnival was held on Friday last. The competition was a great success with Draysey House coming out the victors. Cup Winners:

Senior Boys’ Cup David Popplewell

Senior Girls’ Cup Jillian Eberhard

Junior Boy’s Cup Michael Broderick

Junior Girls’ Cup Vicki Bernhardt

Burra High School held its Valedictory Service in the Kooringa Methodist Church on Sunday evening last, attended by students, old scholars, parents and members of the local Methodist congregations and other denominations. The BHS Girls’ Choir was led by Mrs Edith Carpenter. Rev. Milton Edwards conducted the service. Rev. John H. Stephenson and Headmaster R. Farrow read the lessons. Rev. Principal K.B. Leaver gave the address. The headmaster gave a small presentation to Miss C. Read, who has long been a religious instructor at the school.

Mr G. Arnold Lucas was given a farewell at Wildongoleche Hotel, Hallett on 11 December, when he retired from Elders-GM Agency. He has been associated with Goldsbrough, Mort Ltd and Elders-GM for 31 years.

Burra Primary School. With Progress Certificates dropped this year, the Year 7 students will have no Passing Out Ceremony, but have been spending half an hour a day for some days at the High School. There will be a Grade 7 social tonight. Inter-school sports were played on Monday. Some students have been acquiring swimming certificates and the Primary School Swimming Carnival was held today. On 18 December a Christmas service will be conducted and class parties will follow that. The last day of school on 19 December will be busy generally tidying up the place.

91, 50 (2), 17 Dec. 1968, page 4 [Number used before in 1961.]

Burra Mine

Mr Allen MP recently asked in Parliament whether there will be provision made for natural gas to be supplied from the pipeline to Burra. Premier Hon. R.S. Hall undertook to bring the matter to the notice of the Minister of Mines and to get a reply. The reply was that while technical problems re the economic recovery of the copper remain to be solved the question is somewhat academic, but there is no doubt that if the economics justify it, gas could be made available.

Pensioners’ League held its AGM. President Mrs E. Ryan reported on a happy year. [Activities are reported in c. 1⁄2 column.] One member died in the year: Mrs Ida O’Brien.

[The report mentions as office bearers in 1968: President, Mrs E. Ryan; Secretary, R.G. Bernhardt and Assistant Secretary, Mr Rodgers.]

Obituary. John Alfred Scott Fisher was born at Kilmore, Victoria, the youngest of three children. He attended Moorabbin State School and later Rochester High School. As a youth he worked at the Electricity Power House and the butter factory, where he gained a suction gas certificate. He was a keen footballer and member of the Rochester Brass Band. In Melbourne he joined Hume Steel Pipe Construction and came to Thevenard as a qualified welder on the Tod River Scheme. Later he joined the E & WS Department and became second-in-charge of the Tod River Pumping Station. In 1931 he married Irene Sheridan at Pt Lincoln. He was later transferred to Burra as District Superintendent and was in charge of the gas engines used to pump the town water supply. Here he was active in the Burra Rifle Club, Koonoona Cricket Club, Aberdeen Football Club, the War Memorial Committee, and the Burra Pictures. (He held an ‘A’ class projectionist’s licence.) He was an advisor to Rural Youth and was on the Burra Library Committee and a keen worker for St Joseph’s Church and School, Secretary of the High School Council and the Burra Racing Club. He was a North Ward Councillor and was appointed a JP in 1950 and acted as local coroner for many years. He retired due to ill health and died at the QEH 15 October 1968 [aged 63]. He is survived by his widow and three daughters: Joan Mrs Laredo, Margaret Mrs Deer and Helen Mrs Clark. Mrs Hamilton of Tongala, Victoria is a sister and Mr H. Fisher of Christchurch, New Zealand is a brother.

91, 51, 23 Dec. 1968, page 1

Land Sales. On account of S.J. Woollacott & Co.

“Turner’s” 278 acres to P.R. & R.M. Stockman

Burra & District Ambulance. A two way radio will be fitted to the new Burra Ambulance. This will be useful for summoning police assistance or when a patient has to be redirected to another hospital or to summon additional help.

Burra high School. The prize list is printed.

91, 51, 23 Dec. 1968, pages 1 & 8

Burra High School Speech Night was held last Monday night. Headmaster Farrow expressed his concern at falling enrolments. The Mayor and Mayoress, Mr Allen MP & Mrs Allen, Chairman of the District Council Cr G. Finch & Mrs Finch, Miss Sprat Headmistress of Burra Primary School and the religious instruction teachers attended. The guest speaker was Mr White.

The post war boom and raising the school leaving age led to increased school enrolments, but now the increasing size of farm holdings and migration out of the mid-north to other areas is presenting the school with a period of stability, or even of decline. The year started with 170 students and finished with 150 – the smallest for some years. The loss of 20 students during the year is perhaps of more concern than the overall decline. The 1967 exam results were particularly pleasing with 90% satisfying subject grades in PEB Intermediate and Leaving. All candidates presenting for the Alternative Certificate (Internal Intermediate Course) were successful. We congratulate Christopher Freeman who gained 7 subjects with 6 grade 1 passes. He won an Intermediate Bursary. Malcolm White and Andrew Ryan were awarded Intermediate Continuation Scholarships.

Recently three students were given Commonwealth Secondary Scholarships based on special examinations taken in July this year: Lynette Griffen, Angela Quinn and Chrystine Steele. In 1969 the Intermediate Certificate, both internal and external, will be abolished. The path to University matriculation will also be modified. The new Junior Secondary Curriculum will provide a challenge to all. We should guard against judging what a child is asked to do by some vocational yard stick. Life is big and marvellous and to be enjoyed. Our concept of it needs to be panoramic and not narrow and hazy. But the school is not all hard work. The extra-curricular life is rich and rewarding. Burra High School has provided the breadth of sport, travel, club, social and involvement in other worthy causes. I am concerned that on leaving school in country areas like Burra there is something of a dearth of such wider experiences in the community – a lack of cultural groups, of adult education, recognised community groups and projects. Parents too have a role to play. There have been instances this year of incidents of deliberate mischief. If your child has access to a vehicle, make sure it is for legitimate purposes and is handled properly. If the child has access to a phone at will, should they? If a child is involved in an incident away from school premises don’t blame the school. Nine times out of ten it is the parents’ upbringing of the child which is at fault. And if you are the type to blame the school, don’t then turn around and blame the staff if they do take action.

We are once again very grateful to the Parents & Friends’ Association and the High School Council for all the amenities provided and improvements made.

The triennial election for the School Council in June saw Mr D.H. Field re-appointed as Chairman; Mr T.G. Perry as Secretary and Mr R.B. Jennison as Treasurer. Thanks to Mr D. White, who has been Acting Secretary while Mr Perry has been overseas. The Parents & Friends’ Assoc. has been led by President Mrs F. Matthews with Mrs B. Bevan Secretary and Mrs P. Carpenter as Treasurer. It has sponsored the annual ball, catered for sports day and will on 18 December provide the usual annual banquet. This year they have provided a portable amplifier, new tennis nets, additions to the library and a television receiver. The Government has made improvements to school buildings and there is a project to have a recreation room for students.

Thanks are extended to Mrs Cockington for playing the accompaniment for the Girls’ Choir and to Mrs Carpenter for leading them. Also to the religious instruction staff for doing so well a job that is all too often thankless.

[Mr Farrow went on to thank a variety of people, to wish departing students well and to farewell some staff members.]

Six staff members are known to be leaving:

Miss Newman to Mannum

Mr Murphy to Angle Park Boys’ Technical High School

Mr Schwartz to Norwood

Mr Alfred to Daws Road

And Mrs Day has been promoted to Acting Senior Mistress.

91, 51, 23 Dec. 1968, page 4

Burra Small Bore Club. Best over double 50 yards were L. Moore, M. Thomas and P. Mengersen.

91, 51, 23 Dec. 1968, page 5

Burra National Trust held its AGM recently and elected: President, L. Moore; Vice-President, S.J. Woollacott; Secretary, Mrs C .O’Connor and Treasurer, R. Broad.

The retiring President S.J .Woollacott reported on a year when the Museum had been a success. Thanks go to Ian Auhl for bringing Burra to the fore with his pen and the Mayor Mr Baulderstone, who has done so much to bring Burra’s tourist possibilities to the notice of those in authority. The drive down Commercial Street to Market Square and thence to Burra North reveals a town that has more attractions than any other of a similar size. Now we need to make the rest of the town as attractive. Here the Council can assist in keeping the place tidy and in properly caring for the trees. Success requires money and that requires an income from customers. During the year the Museum had over 1,000 paying adults and received over $100. We note with regret the passing of Mr Robert Fuss who was a good and practical citizen and we are grateful for the services he rendered the Trust.

After the business section of the meeting Mr Hans Mincham gave an illustrated lecture on the Flinders Ranges.

91, 51, 23 Dec. 1968, page 6

Weather. Yesterday was hot and windy, but overnight 52 points of rain were recorded and reaping has had to be suspended for the time being.

Accident. At about 11.30 p.m. on Friday a semi-trailer owned by S.E. Schulz of Renmark and driven by Peter E. Size of Renmark overturned on the Burra North-Morgan Road near Basin Farm. It was taking 240 wethers for Elders-GM from Peterborough to Loxton. Attending police worked till 3.30 a.m. freeing sheep from the bottom tray. 70 head of stock were killed or had to be destroyed. The driver was kept in Burra Hospital over night for observation and was severely bruised. Another truck picked up the sheep on Saturday morning and the District Council plant pulled the vehicle back onto its wheels. Damage is estimated at $3,000.

91, 51, 23 Dec. 1968, page 7

1st Division Saddleworth Gold 88 defeated Burra Green 75

2nd Division Saddleworth Red 86 defeated Burra Blue 60

South Booborowie 8 for 183 defeated North Booborowie 126

Spalding 113 defeated Mt Bryan 88

Koonaburra 329 defeated Hallett 218

91, 51, 23 Dec. 1968, page 8

Obituary. William Joseph Lee was born at Marrabel 13 January 1883 and moved with his family to live at World’s End when 13 years old. He began school at Marrabel and finished it at World’s End. He then became a blacksmith and farrier’s apprentice at Riverton and later came to Burra to work for the late Sam Burns for 11 years. When that business closed he worked for Mr Max Morton, after which he went into business on his own and retired after about 20 years. In 1909 he married Miss Julia Barrow. He became a member of the Foresters’ Lodge in 1911 and was its secretary for many years, retiring from the position at 80 years of age. He became a member of the Kooringa Masonic Lodge in 1929 and was Grand Master [sic: for Worshipful Master] in 1945. He became a member of the Grand Lodge in 1960. He was a member of the Burra Brass Band, Burra Institute Library and foreman of the Burra Fire Brigade for several years. He is survived by a wife and children: Cliff (Kalgoorlie), Ilene Mrs Campbell (Burra), Robert (Charters Towers, Qld), Ron (Townsville, Qld), Joyce Mrs D. Pexton (Poolaijelo, Victoria) and Phyllis Mrs McWaters (Melbourne). [Died 27 November 1968 Burra.]

Characteristics of the paper in 1968

In general a good coverage of local news, though local extends to Spalding and Hallett and south towards Riverton. Council matters are perhaps less revealing than in some periods, but a mostly reported adequately.

Page 1

Almost entirely local news with 1 or 2 advertisements.

Page 2

Usually dominated by large advertisements for perhaps one third and then by public notices and the like – but proportions fluctuate considerably and there is sometimes a news story as well.

Page 3

Important snippets of what is going on locally and news about past and present resident in very brief form in ‘Out & About’ column. Births, deaths and marriages tend to get at least a brief mention, making this an important record, though often lacking useful details. Large advertisements occupy about half the page or more.

Page 4

About half the page is occupied by large advertisements. The rest is news and items of general interest.

Page 5

Large advertisements occupy perhaps three-quarters of the page with the rest the 50 years Ago Column.

But note that pages 4 & 5 are somewhat interchangeable in content.

Pages 6 & 7

Large advertisements and sports, which is the dominant news on this page, though not limited to it. The ‘Cash Column’ of small advertisements is usually on one of these pages, but can wander elsewhere.

Page 8

This is a mixture of advertisements of varying size for some 4 of the 7 columns. The rest is the overflow of sport and general news and items of general interest.

Supplements were not frequent, but overflow was often accommodated by printing in the gutters. This was usually in the 306 gutter, but sometimes in 4-5 gutters and occasionally in the 207 gutter and sometimes in more than one of them.

The supplement on 26 November was larger than a full-sized page and was an advertisement celebrating Sargasso’s 10th birthday – the Burra Agent was Guy Dollman’s Burra Motor Co. It featured four colour printing and was folded into quarters.
