92, 1 (2), 14 Jan. 1969, page 1 [Number used before in 1962.]

Burra Silos wheat intake to yesterday equals the record 1966-67 season of 295,000 bushels. It began a fortnight later, with the first delivery on 10 December when Mr Graham Heinrich of World’s End and then Mr Gordon Webster of Springbank delivered a load and deliveries here have been more concentrated this year. A number of farmers have already delivered their quotas of 75% of their harvest. Some have decided to bag the other 25%, while most have converted to bulk storage. Burra has the capacity to stack 17,000 bags and Norm Maxted of Mt Bryan delivered the first bags on Friday. Not much remains locally to be reaped.

Obituary. The body of Mr George Alfred Crawford, the Saddleworth District Clerk, was found about 300 yards from his car on a seldom used road in the Belvedere Range about three miles due east of the town on 11 January.

[Born 26 March 1912 Saddleworth.]

Theft. $10 was taken from the till at Opperman’s Saveway Store in Burra on Saturday night. Cash is not usually left in the store, but this night two $5 notes had been left in the till. The large sliding door at the rear had been forced. The space for entry is small, suggesting a child was the person who entered.

Mrs P. Thomas of Burra North has reported to police damage to a sleep-out window caused by a rifle bullet or high powered air gun.

Accident. A Volkswagen sedan driven by Emilio Nellie of Unley overturned near Hanson on 3 January without injuring the driver.

Lottery Win. Four local men shared in $30,000 for a lottery win last week: Ron Wuttke, Bill Field, Ron Shipard and Noel Webb.

92, 1 (2), 14 Jan. 1969, page 3 [Number used before in 1962.]

92, 1 (2), 14 Jan. 1969, page 5 [Number used before in 1962.]

Burra Town Council, 18 December

The Town Clerk reports on a meeting with the Minister of Local Government about the merged Council. It seems certain that the appointment of a Mayor for the new Council in 1969 will be by nomination of the ratepayers. The first step towards amalgamation has been a Notice of Amalgamation published in the Government Gazette and local paper.

The Town Hall Pictures showed a loss in November of $15 with an average attendance of 90. Three nights ran at a loss and two shows in December also ran at a loss of $18 to give a loss over seven weeks of $33.

A window has been broken in the Camera Club room and is to be replaced.

Mr Perry has been appointed Acting Town Clerk.

Learn to Swim Campaign. The Education Department’s annual campaign ended on Friday when 150 certificates were issued to those who reached the standards set for the various divisions. [Those receiving certificates are listed.]

Vandalism. The top ten feet of a thirty foot pine tree has been taken from Fairchild’s Reserve at Burra north; no doubt for use as a Christmas tree.

Fire Alert Day. The local EFS unit complete with a full crew drove along the street and demonstrated fire fighting apparatus on 16 January as part of Fire Alert Day. In the afternoon a fire broke out on Anama Property and private units as well as those from Burra, Booborowie and Spalding attended.

Burra Pictures. On Wednesday night the Town Council discussed the on-going losses of the Burra Pictures. One possibility is to decrease the frequency to fortnightly or monthly. The future of the pictures and the election of a body to run the Town Hall will both be considered at a public meeting to be called by the Mayor Mr E.T. Baulderstone. One wonders whether it is the noise and behaviour of some patrons that keeps others away.

Burra Footballers 95 v. Koonaburra 4 for 218

92, 3 (2), 28 Jan. 1969, page 1 [Number used before in 1962.]

Amalgamation of Councils

No objections have been received to the proposed union of the Burra Burra District Council and the Town Council and the period for objections has now passed.

The area of the proposed union will be divided into nine wards: Burra Town, Kooringa, Baldina, Booborowie, Leighton, Mt Bryan, Mongolata, Farrell Flat and Hanson. Each ward except Burra Town is to have one Councillor, with Burra Town to have three. Provision is to be made for the election of a Mayor as in the Corporation. Assessments will be on the basis of unimproved land values. There has been no call for a poll of ratepayers and so the petition has been drawn up and will be signed and sealed at a special combined meeting of the two Councils tonight. It is hoped that the proclamation of the union will enable the combined Councils to sit as one commencing in April. This would give time for the preparation of and the calling of nominations for Councillors for all wards to form the new Council to operate from 1 July 1969. The February and March meetings of both Councils will remain divided. A Bill to amend the Local Government Act 1934-67 to cover the election of a Mayor under circumstances similar to those which exist here will go before the Legislative Council when it sits next. It is anticipated that a Mayor for the whole area will be elected by ratepayers and in turn be appointed Chairman of the Council. Previously it had been understood the Mayor would be elected by ratepayers and a Chairman elected by Council. With Mr T.G. Perry acting as Town Clerk all business of the Town Council is being conducted from the District Council Office in Commercial Street.

Adelaide Wool Sales 14-16 January. Prices were similar to those in December. [Local district prices are printed.]

Wheat. With trading of bulk wheat delayed, the bagged wheat at Burra has amounted to 11,000 bags. Some trucks with bulk wheat have lined up for a fortnight with no immediate prospect of rail trucks to clear the silos.

Weather. A line of thunderstorms on Thursday dumped heavy falls across the district. A half mile wide strip of North Booborowie was flooded when 2 inches fell in half an hour. Terowie reported another deluge. Leighton also received heavy rain. At Hanson and Farrell Flat falls varied from 60-70 points. Erratic falls are reported from the east; Old Koomooloo 15 points, Koomooloo 2 points at the homestead, but over 200 on the western end of the property. Woolgangi received 40 points. The Booborowie deluge included hail, some of which was the size of pigeons’ eggs and creeks ran eight feet deep. Fencing was swept away. Damage to fallow was extensive, but areas of flooded lucerne will benefit. The trench for the gas pipeline became a flowing stream and quite a deal of clean-up is needed. Booborowie post office officially registered 120 points.

Burra Sketch Book

It is expected this book will contain about 24 original sketches by Burra architect Maurice Perry, accompanied by explanatory text by local historian Ian Auhl. Burra Branch of the National Trust is sponsoring the book and will receive Mr Auhl’s share of the profits. Mr Perry will be paid a reasonable sum for the use of his sketches.

[The Burra Railway Station sketch is reproduced.]

Burra Railway Station: the first train steamed into the station at 12.45 p.m. on 27 August 1870. [actually 29 August] It carried eight carriages and 400 passengers, without distinction of class or other distinction. Fifteen minutes later the select train bearing H.E. Sir James Fergusson, Lady Fergusson and other dignitaries arrived, hauled by a decorated engine. The engine had made the 100 mile journey in five hours. Three thousand locals were on hand to greet it and the town was enjoying a public holiday. Welcoming archways had been erected. The station and goods shed had been festooned with greenery, which must have occasioned havac [sic] on the trees for 15 miles around. Feasting went on all day. The official luncheon with speeches in the goods shed lasted so long that the Vice-Regal party had only time for a quick tour round the town before departing at 4.50 p.m. On the return there was a delay at Farrell Flat when the train ran over [and killed] a signalman sho was to have waved the red flag at the crossing.

At Burra the celebrations continued with a concert in the Lodge Room of the Burra Hotel, followed by a ball till dawn. The twelve hotels [?] remained open all night. Bonfires were lit up and down the street.

The transportation of ores had been a problem for SAMA since the mine opened in 1845, when the colony had no railways. Bullock drays at first took the ore to Pt Adelaide via Kapunda, for shipment to Swansea in Wales. Later, from 1847, the road to Pt Wakefield shortened the journey by 30 miles, but was so difficult through the hills that the company tried replacing the bullock drays with pack mules – hundreds being brought from Montevideo with Spanish-American muleteers. Towns grew up along the route, but both the route and the towns were abandoned by the Smelting Company in 1857 when the railway reached Gawler. When the railway arrived at Kapunda in August 1860 the old copper road to Kapunda was resumed. The Burra Burra Mine was almost exhausted by the time the first rain reached Burra in 1870.

92, 3 (2), 28 Jan. 1969, page 2 [Number used before in 1962.]

Burra Small Bore Club. Best scorers over double 50 yards were R. Gilbert, J. Bowden & L. Moore.

Accident. A vehicle driven by Alfred Thomas Mildred of Somerton Park, who was travelling to Broken Hill, overturned on the old Black Springs Road at about 8.50 on Saturday morning. It rolled over three times. The driver and his wife Colleen were both wearing seat belts and were saved from serious injury. The vehicle, only six weeks old, was a write off.

Accident. On Sunday at c. 1.30 a.m. Mr Allen Hutchins of Ridgehaven was travelling to Broken Hill to visit his seriously ill mother when, about two miles south of Burra, he was dazzled by oncoming headlights on high beam. In avoiding the vehicle the car rolled over. He suffered concussion and should and neck injuries. The damage to the car was relatively minor.

Accident. Two trainee nurses travelling to Burra were involved in a collision with another vehicle at Saddleworth on Saturday morning. They were Norma Alvena Palmer and Rosemary Brown. The Morris Mini was considerably damaged.

Burra Town Council, 15 January

Burra Pictures lost $57 in the past month with only 215 people attending.

It was resolved to appoint T.G. Perry as Acting Town Clerk till 30 June 1969 for two days a week and that the business of the Corporation would be conducted at the District Council offices.

92, 4 (2), 4 Feb. 1969, page 1 [Number used before in 1962.]

Paxton Square was declared an Historic Reserve under the Aboriginal & Historic Relics Preservation Act 1965, on 9 January 1969. William Paxton was a Hindley Street Chemist. In 1845 he and three other Hindley Street businessmen formed a company to light Adelaide streets with gas. The scheme was quickly shelved when one of them, Thomas Bunce, shared the news he had of the discovery of copper on the Burra Creek. A shepherd named Streair had come to Adelaide and traded his knowledge of it for £8. Paxton invested £140 in the get-rich-quick scheme and became one of the first directors of the new SA Mining Association. The shop-keeping nobodies were wealthy men within two years and the Burra Burra Mine became a bonanza.

Paxton acquired a number of choice sites in the private town of Kooringa and soon owned the hotels: the Burra and the Miners’ Arms (now called the Burra Hotel). One of his properties on the east side of the creek became known as Paxton’s Square, though when he sold it the only building on it was the Bible Christian Chapel, now Baulderstone’s storeroom. The Mining Association acquired it from him in 1852 and engaged Cornish masons to erect 33 cottages on three sides. The eleven cottages on each side enclosed common land for the tenants. The cottages were erected to house Cornish deep miners brought out especially from Cornwall in the 1850s to work the deeper lodes where water was a problem. Each had two or three rooms with floors of packed clay and cost 5/- a week. When SA Mining Association went into liquidation in 1914 the cottages were acquired by John Lewis, then of the Burra stock and station firm of Liston, Shakes & Lewis.

[Note: the cottages were passed in at auction in October 1912 and Lewis purchased them towards the end of 1913.]

Lewis later became Hon. John Lewis MLC, Father of Essington Lewis the great industrialist.

[Actually Lewis was already an MLC, serving in the SA Legislative Council 1898-1923.]

Mrs Jane Melrose of Kadlunga, Mintaro, is a daughter.

In March 1923 Paxton Square was incorporated into a trust by Lewis who arranged for it to be managed by a Board of Management. Hon. John Lewis died a few months later. [25 August 1923]

The cottages were to house the poor and needy of Burra. The trustees for many years were Stanley Kellaway, Isaac Warnes & Mrs Jane Melrose. In 1968it was being administered by members of the Lewis family: Mr R. Lewis, Mrs Melrose & Mrs J. Gosse. Until last year Mr Stan Kellaway Jnr acted as Curator for the Lewis Trust.

Following a meeting between representatives of the Burra Town Council and the Burra National Trust early in 1968 a common approach was made to the Lewis Trust to consider the appointment of local trustees. The meeting was chaired by R.B. Lewis and considered ways of bringing the cottages up to an acceptable standard while still fulfilling the original purpose of the trust. It was realised that Paxton Square could not be sold nor the trust dissolved without a special act of Parliament.

It was decided to bring some cottages up to standard while respecting their original external features. New trustees were appointed, with Rev. G.D. Sibly as Chairman and the Board of Management was enlarged to include local trustees: Mr R. Jennison, Mr L. Phillips, Mr G. Finch, Mr S. Woollacott, Rev. G.D. Sibly and Mr E.T. Baulderstone. A plan of modernisation was drawn up by S.J. Woollacott, who has already made substantial improvements to the living amenities of the cottages. He is the present curator.

Realising their important significance in Australia’s mining story, Mr Ian Auhl submitted an application in 1968 to the Board administering the Historic Relics Act, asking that Paxton square be proclaimed an Historic Reserve. He was supported by representatives of the Lewis family. At a meeting of the Lewis Trust in Burra the Secretary of the Relics Board, Mr R. Edwards, acting on behalf of the Board and the Protector of Relics, Dr Inglis, asked the trustees to consider giving their support to the move and they agreed. The application was also endorsed by Mr Dean Berry, President of the Sa National Trust.

Professor Geoffrey Blainey also lent his support. Paxton Square is the first building in SA to be proclaimed an Historic Reserve under the Act. The present trustees are appointed Wardens under the Act. More and more people in Burra as well as those who study Australia’s pioneering past are realising that Burra has a whole series of buildings which make the town unique in SA.

Fires. On Friday a fire burnt 50 acres of stubble on the property of Mr Ken Phillips of World’s End. A number of sheep in the paddock were moved to safety. In the clam conditions it is thought to have been slowly burning for about two hours before being noticed as about 3 a.m.

On Saturday it was discovered that a fire on the property of P.J. Thomas east of World’s End had burnt itself out in clam conditions. Quite a lot of fencing was destroyed before the fire halted at a well-used track. There is evidence that a person or persons were in the vicinity at the time.

Mr Malcolm Blight and wife visited Burra on Sunday. He taught at Burra High School in 1945 and is now at King’s College in Adelaide. His great-grandfather had a blacksmith’s forge in Burra in the mining days, but when the mine closed he moved to Clare.

92, 5 (2), 11 Feb. 1969, page 1 [Number used before in 1962.]

Burra Mine

Through the efforts of Mr Ian Auhl, Mr Alister Colebatch, a surveyor for ETSA and Mr Claude Allen MP it has been confirmed that the Burra Town Council owns the mineral rights to the Mine site. It has been understood for many years that the mineral rights were owned by Mr P.A.M. McBride, even after the purchase of the property by the Corporation in 1960. Searches through various Departmental records have now satisfied Mr Auhl and Mr Colebatch that the rights lie with the Town Council. It was arranged through the Mayor Mr E.T. Baulderstone that they attend a meeting of Council to pass on the news of this discovery. This was done on 27 May last year and it was then resolved that establishment of the ownership of the mineral rights be obtained from the Minister of Mines. No answer had been obtained when Mr Allen spoke on the possible re-opening of the Burra Mine when he opened the Burra Show. This prompted a letter to the Record from Mr Ian Auhl in which he asked among other questions whether the MP was aware that the mineral rights belonged to the Town Council and if so what compensation they could expect. Mr Allen replied in a letter published on 3 December which addressed a number of the questions, but not that related to mineral rights; apparently because there remained some doubt about it. We now have a letter from Mr Allen with a response from the Minister of Mines.

The area of rights so far as the Corporation is concerned covers the whole of the open cut section and area to the west and south. Mr Allen has asked what progress has been made on the metallurgical problem.

Hon. R.S. Hall replied that for the period to 31 December 1968 three independent avenues of research are being pursued and the company (Mines Exploration Pty Ltd) said it would probably take six months to finalise these investigations and the Department is confident that the company is doing its best to find a satisfactory solution.

[A table of the ownership of mineral rights is printed.]

[Title references are also printed.]

Accident. A car driven by Mrs C. Skilton, resident at the Bon Accord Hotel, Burra North, skidded and overturned, ending back on its wheels at about 6 p.m. Friday. The incident occurred on the Burra-Booborowie Road. A seat belt helped Mrs Skilton to escape with only bruising and a shaking.

Junior Cricket Carnival at Burra Oval

4 February

Spalding 153 defeated Burra No. 1 134

Burra No. 2 116 & 3 for 57 defeated Auburn 25 & 132

Weather. The weekend rains generally delivered 50-80 points, though World’s End reported 179 and Robertstown 2 inches. Burra 137 points, Booborowie 108, Old Koomooloo 66, Balah 58, Pine Vallet 50, Thistlebeds 125, Braemar 60, The Gums 125, Glenora 63 and Canegrass 50.

92, 5 (2), 11 Feb. 1969, page 7 [Number used before in 1962.]

Bowls. Rain caused all games to be abandoned except at Hallett where Hallett White 74 defeated Burra Blue 56.

92, 6, 18 Feb. 1969, page 1 [Actually dated 1968 in error.]

The Department of Adult Education is arranging a weekend seminar on the Historic Copper Towns of SA for early in May. Lectures will be given on Friday evening with visits to Kapunda and Burra on Sunday. Lecturers would give a solid treatment of the history of copper mining in SA with particular reference to Moonta, Kadina, Wallaroo, Kapunda and Burra, with geological background and the technical aspects of copper mining. Ian Auhl will visit Burra on Monday 10 March and talk about the seminar so that local people not attending the University on the Friday and Saturday will still be able to be in the picture. If it generates sufficient local interest a weekend school in Burra may be arranged at a later date.

92, 6, 18 Feb. 1969, pages 1 & 5 [Actually dated 1968 in error.]

School Enrolments 1969

Burra Primary School

Enrolments in 1969 are 107 boys and 116 girls: total 223 or 35 less than in 1968. 28 were enrolled in Grade I. [New admissions are listed.] Mr John Cain comes from Teachers College. He will drive the World’s End bus and teach Grade V.

Willalo. The enrolment of 20 is the same as in 1968. [New enrolments are listed.] Mr B. Smith continues as head teacher.

Burra Kindergarten has 46 children. [Names of those attending are given.]

St Joseph’s Convent School has 20 students and the four new enrolments are named.

Leighton School has 27 students compared with 30 in 1968. Mr D. Munzberg remains in charge.

[New enrolments are listed.]

Black Springs School has no new enrolments this year. The new teacher in charge is Jan Richards. Enrolments are down 7 on 1968 to 11: Grade II, 1; Grade III, 4; Grade IV, 1; Grade VI, 2; and Grade VII, 3.

Booborowie School had 8 new admissions and 2 transfers for an enrolment of 62, but with the 4 Mellor children leaving, the actual enrolment will be 58. [Newcomers are listed.]

Burra High School has 180 on the roll. Seven of the staff of eleven are new faces. L.D. Beare comes as Headmaster from being Deputy Headmaster at Kadina. Other newcomers are Miss J. Russell, Miss K. Strahan, Miss L. Pfitzner, Mr D. Molze, Mr C. West and Mr K. Salt. 1968 was the last year for both the external and internally examined Intermediate courses.

For the internal course 15 of the 17 students gained their certificates:

Marie Berryman Jennifer Carpenter Deborah Drew

Elizabeth Earle Lucy Field Joy Goodridge

Brian Hempel Lorraine Jones Heather Keane

Marian Kotz William McMahon Barbara Phelan

David Poppelwell Francis Richardson Annette Ward

[New enrolments are listed.]

92, 6, 18 Feb. 1969, pages 1 & 4 & 4-5 gutter [Actually dated 1968 in error.]

Mt Bryan & Hallett Water Scheme

Mr Allen MP undertook to look into the report on the proposed water scheme for Mt Bryan and Hallett made by the E & WS Department. The Department found that such a scheme would not be practical. The towns are too small to recover even the interest on the capital invested. Clare for example used 90 million gallons in 1967-68 and the cost of getting water pumped from Farrell Flat to Clare was 75 cents per 1,000 gallons. Burra receives water pumped from Hanson and used 41 million gallons at a cost of $1.05 per 1,000 gallons. The Minister of Works states the cost of supplying River Murray water to Mt Bryan would be $175,000. If all landowners between Mt Bryan and Burra paid the normal rate of 27c per acre on all land within one mile of the pipeline the revenue would be c. $3,456. Rates from the town would not bring in more than $1,000. This would represent 21⁄2% interest on the capital cost and this does not include the actual cost of pumping or general maintenance. Some landowners are not prepared to contribute so the Minister is correct in saying it is impracticable. An alternative local source is also full of difficulties. Good supplies of [bore] water are available, but are too poor for use in hot water systems. Also, if supplied, all vacant blocks would be rateable for the minimum rates of $8 per year.

The Minister of Works said the matter had been investigated following a petition from landowners between Mt Bryan and Burra for Murray water to be extended to Mt Bryan with a pipe of sufficient size to enable later extension to Hallett. Two pumping stations and two tanks would be needed. The proposal needs 10 miles of 8 inch main and a 100,000 gallon surface tank at Mt Bryan. Expenditure of $170,000 to reach Mt Bryan and a further $145,000 to include Hallett. Three landowners indicated intention to irrigate lucerne. All properties have adequate stock water supplies and it is unsound for the E & WS to provide Murray water for lucerne irrigation. Neither scheme can be justified. A report on the likelihood of obtaining supplies from bores in Mt Bryan area has been asked for.

92, 6, 18 Feb. 1969, page 2 [Actually dated 1968 in error.]

Saddleworth Wheat Silos are almost completed. The final four feet were poured on Sunday. Work on the roof will commence this week. The extra four cells have been completed in 12 days.

92, 7, 25 Feb. 1969, page 1

Weather. Good rains fell in the pastoral country last Friday. The heaviest falls were further east. Oakvale 148 points, Quondong 134, Sturt Vale 105, Canegrass 76, Balah 32, Woolgangi 33, Braemar 82 & Old Koomooloo 50.

Joe Edwards the local representative of the E & WS Department retired on 6 January. The Town Council wants him to be replaced. At present a man from the Spalding Depot has to respond to problems. The E & WS Department has had a man in Burra since it took over pumping of the local water supply from the Town Council over 60 years ago.

Wheat. Burra has received 24,000 bags of wheat, but the season is nearing a close.

Theft. Petrol and other goods have been stolen from the Highways Camp at Murkaby Lane in the Eastern Pastoral Area, apparently while the men were at work. Police are investigating.

A second penguin litter box is to be placed on the corner near Hurley’s road-house following the success of the one in front of the Market Square Café some time ago.

Caravan Park. Drivers have been doing ‘hill climbs’ between the main road and the Caravan Park level just north of the swimming pool. More posts will be placed along the road to prevent such practices.

Burra Court House is to be inspected to see if its acoustics can be improved. JPs have long complained of the difficulties in hearing some evidence.

Burra High School Parents & Friends’ Assoc. had over 100 at its first meeting for the year. President Mrs F. Matthews chaired the meeting. The new headmaster Mr Beare explained the introduction of continuous assessment and interim reports to parents. The Association’s AGM is planned for Tuesday 18 March.

Council Merger. Preliminary discussions have been held between the DC of Saddleworth and the DC of Upper Wakefield with a view to union.

Burra Oval. Costs are to be obtained for a new fence along Smelts Road.

92, 7, 25 Feb. 1969, page 2

Methodist Women’s Fellowship. The inaugural meeting will be held at the Redruth Memorial Hall on 19 March at 7.30 p.m.

Bob Crewes (K.R. Crewes) welcomed retired French Colonel Andre Gaugier to SA as reported in yesterday’s Advertiser. Bob was a lieutenant in D Coy 27th Battalion AIF in WWI and was one of seven officers billeted in the French village of Le Grand Fayt late in the war. Their billet was a partly wrecked factory and also living there were Madame Gauguir [sic] and her children Andre (11) and Paul (7) – a refugee family. The officers became good friends with the Gauguiers [sic] sharing rations and playing games. Andre and three of the officers met on Sunday at Outer Harbour when the Colonel disembarked from the liner Galileo for a few hours.

Marriage. Saturday next in Adelaide

Trevor Simpson of Mt Bryan, son of Mr & Mrs Colin Simpson, will marry Veronica Matthews of Adelaide.

Marriage. Recently

Mrs Dorothy Willmott of Burra married Mr C.W. Parker. Mr Parker runs the popular Bird Circus at Reynella.

Birth. To Geoffrey & Beverley Arnold recently in Adelaide, a daughter.

Obituary. Alice Norris died in the past week at Burra Hospital.

[Alice Mary Norris, wife of Ronald Charles Norris, died 19 February 1969 Burra aged 48. Note in 91, 9 (2), 11 Mar. 1969, page 2 (numbered 3) she is cited as Alice May in a Return Thanks notice.]

92, 7, 25 Feb. 1969, page 3

Burra & District Floral Art Club held its AGM. Annual Report.

The club has grown too large for Mrs Allen’s house and has had to move elsewhere. Financial members are 25 compared with 17 last year and the average attendance is 15. The club now has a library and a store and the club was invited by the Burra Town Council to represent them at the Adelaide Flower Day. The arrangement created by Mrs Lloyd and Mrs Pettet was so impressive it was recreated in May for the club’s Floral Art Display, which enabled us to donate $90 to the Burra Town Hall Floor Appeal. During the year we made posies for balls throughout the district and flowers were arranged for the Miss Industry Ball in June, the Hospital Board’s Silver and Art Display at the Town Hall and at the Hospital for Christmas. [Activities at meetings are also listed.]

Burra Small Bore Club. Best over a 50 metre shoot on 16 February were P. Mengersen, R. Gilbert & J. Bowden. Best over a double 50 yard shoot on 18 February were J. Bowden, P. Mengersen and M. Thomas.

92, 7, 25 Feb. 1969, page 4

Advt. Elders-GM will auction the well-known Merino Stud ‘Melton Park’ situated 2 miles north of Mt Bryan on 14 March in the Burra RSL Hall on instructions from Melton Pastoral Co. (713 acres freehold.) To be offered as a whole and then if not sold in three lots.

Advt. Dalgety & NZ Loan will auction the house and furniture etc. at 22 Queen Street Burra on 28 February on instructions from the trustees in the estate of the late K.J. Murphy. (A 5-roomed ‘Trust Home’.)

Burra Kindergarten. For 1969 there are just under 50 enrolments. The new Director is Miss Judy Ashby with assistant Miss Therese Quinn. A meeting is called for 26 February to consider forming a Fathers’ auxiliary. Over the past three years $1,200 has been paid off the new building loan and this leaves just $600 to pay. On 18 April we will hols a Mock Debutante Ball.

Accident. A car driven by John Gilbert Cain, schoolteacher of Burra, overturned on the Burra-Robertstown Road last Sunday night. The driver was not injured and there was little damage to the vehicle.

92, 7, 25 Feb. 1969, page 5

Notice. The Burra Burra DC calls tenders for a seven-ton truck fitted with a six yard tray with telescopic hoist.

92, 7, 25 Feb. 1969, page 6

Burra Institute Library. Mr W. Carpenter reported a difficult year. Financial constraints have been a worry and purchasing has had to be somewhat curtailed. Acquisition of about 100 books was balanced by discarding about 100. At present the library holds about 6,100 adult books and 950 juvenile books. The usual trading table netted $112.75. Rural Youth donated $20, the Town Council $20 and the District Council $10. Subscribers are 60; down from 70 last year. Fifteen years ago there were 340. Secretary Ben Kotz and Treasurer J.R. Carpenter have done an excellent job. Mrs Baker has continued to catalogue and cover books. Unfortunately the librarian Mrs Broad is leaving to take up duties elsewhere. She has been an efficient librarian for some sixteen months.

Kooringa forfeited to Spalding Blue

Mt Bryan 10-65 defeated Leighton 2-38

92, 8, 4 Mar. 1969, page 1

Mt Bryan Wheat Growers held a meeting in the Mt Bryan Hall on 10 February to press for the erection of silos at Mt Bryan. Present also were Mr Venning of CBH Ltd and Mr Claude Allen MP. It was resolved that some form of temporary storage be erected at Mt Bryan and more rail trucks be made available for Burra and Hallett to help the clearance of this year’s crop. CBH says the bountiful harvest this year has added to the problem – the harvest is about four times the previous year’s and 30 million bushels over the highest ever delivery in SA of just over 50 million bushels. There was also about 25% carry-over from the old season, as the Wheat Board was unable to sell all of last year’s crop before this year’s harvest and even at this time some 10% of last year’s wheat remains in the silo system. It is not the policy of the company to erect temporary storage at non-silo stations, but we can say that extensions due to be finalised at Saddleworth next September will now be completed by next month and by 20 March we will have space for an additional 330,000 bushels of wheat at Saddleworth in these new cells. A new steel structure at Hamley Bridge will have a capacity of 70,000 bushels at about the same time.

Mr Bill Mierke addressed a meeting of farmers at Burra last week at the Burra Town Hall on the subject of nitrogen fertilizer urea. Mr Mierke is an agronomist with Australia Pacific Fertilizer Ltd.

World’s End Methodist Church was broke into in the early hours of Sunday morning. It had been set up on Saturday night for its Thanksgiving Service. A window was broken and some of the produce spattered over the walls. Vases of flowers were knocked over and some boxes of produce were found outside the church. Members cleared up as well as they could and the service went ahead, but it lacked the usual feelings associated with thanksgiving. Windows in a nearby unoccupied house owned by Mr Ken Phillips were also damaged by rifle bullets.

Roy Wilfred Humphrys was 80 yesterday. He was born in George Street Kooringa and after spending most of his life on the land in the Hanson area moved to Burra with his wife two years ago.

Ian Auhl’s address in Burra on the seminar to be held at the University in May has been postponed from 10 March to 14 April. (Due to Mrs Auhl recently having her appendix removed.)

Birth. To Barbara & John Schmerl at Burra Hospital on 2 March, a daughter, Robyn Sheila.

Obituary. Walter Brown of Jamestown died on Sunday. He was brother to Mrs Clarrie Woodman. He died on his golden wedding day. [Walter Leonard Brown born 27 August 1900 Hanson: died 2 March 1969 Jamestown.]

Obituary. Rev. Geoff. Sibly conducted the funeral service of Mr Jack Clemson who had been a long term patient at Burra Hospital and who was well known for his hand loom weaving.

Marriage. 19 April

Marilyn Hirschausen married Robert Brandt.

Robert has scored over 1,000 runs, including four centuries and a top score of 183, for the season, as captain of the Koonaburra team. Yesterday he began work at Woomera where the couple will live after their marriage.

The Burra Bowling Club will be 50 years old on 6 March.

2nd Division Clare White 94 defeated Burra White 67

91, 9 (2), 11 Mar. 1969, page 1 [Note change of volume. This number used before in 1968.]

Fire. Following a burning off operation by the railway ganger that got out of control on 10 January a meeting was held by landowners at Hallett. The meeting requested that all landowners be notified of burning off operations, that burning off be commenced as early is the season as possible and that farmers be allowed to plough breaks on railway land to add to their protection. The Railway Commissioner Mr Fitch replied that landowners had been notified in writing of the intent to burn off. Burning was done as soon as possible, but the ganger had a large area to cover and burning off could not be done when fewer than four men were present. In the Burra District the burning is done as a joint operation and the railways would be happy to extend such co-operation to the Hallett area.

Burra High School. Prefects for 1969 were inducted in a ceremony in the School Memorial Gardens before a crowd of over 150 parents. House Captains were also inducted.

Chrystine Steele (Head) R. Przibilla (Head)

Mr J.H. Pash, Inspector of High Schools gave a brief address.

Burra Football Club held its AGM in the Burra Town Hall Supper Room on Friday. No one was prepared to stand for President, Secretary of Vice-President. Eventually Allan Baulderstone was re-elected President with J. Secomb as Vice-President and Alan Day as Secretary. [Page 3 mentions that Ken Salt was the Treasurer.]

Burra won the Lightning Carnival and both the ‘A’ and ‘B’ Grade Premierships. The active social club had raised $550. The coach Mr Kevin Lane was congratulated on a fine job. Financially the club was sound with more than $700 in hand. The club will again play in the North Eastern League in 1969.

Saddleworth and Upper Wakefield DCs could amalgamate within four months. [Details in 11⁄2 columns.]

Accident. A car driven by Mr Bertram and a bicycle ridden by Adrian Ford collided in Best Place on Saturday at 4.30 p.m. The lad was shaken, but not injured.

Burra Basketball Club held its AGM on 6 March and elected as President Mrs Matthews; Vice-President, Diane Beinke and Secretary-Treasurer, Dianne Day. 1968 was the first season that saw ‘A’, ‘B’ & ‘C’ teams in the same uniforms, at a cost to the club of $215.75. ‘D’ Grade was introduced for the first time and is for Primary School Children only. Burra had one team. The ‘B’ team got as far as the preliminary final. ‘A’ team won the shield for the second time in succession.

91, 9 (2), 11 Mar. 1969, page 7 [This number used before in 1968.]

Burra Primary School Parents Meeting was held 3 March. Over 40 parents and teachers attended. T. Moreland was elected Chairman for 1969 with L. Moore as Secretary. R. Moreland as retiring Chairman reported on 1968. The additional fire hydrant should be installed during March. Sports day on 19 April was a great success, as was the swimming carnival. Mrs Rayner spoke on Arbor Day. The access path near Tattersall’s seems to have fallen by the wayside, with so far no action from the Public Buildings Department. I believe the Department will acquire Mrs Sara’s house on Smelts Road as accommodation. (Mr & Mrs Lannan are presently living there.)

[There is an extensive list of thanks to various people and groups.]

Burra Small Bore Club. On 22 February a shoot over 25 yards saw best scores from P. Mengersen, M. Thomas & L. Moore. On 4 March over 100 yards the best scorers were P. Mengersen, M. Thomas & J. Bowden.

91, 9 (2), 11 Mar. 1969, page 9 [This number used before in 1968.]

Burra Primary School Welfare Club held its AGM 4 March.

Classrooms were open to inspection before the meeting. Though it had spent over $900 for the year, it still held $450. It was decided to put $60 towards a new Gestetner machine, to buy new sprinklers for the oval, to purchase a Freeway Sports Combination Unit and to donate $15 to each teacher for the purchase of aids etc. Elected: President, Mrs Lola Jennison; Secretary, Mrs Avis Webster and Assistant Secretary & Treasurer Mrs Margaret Alderson. Mrs Kirk, the retiring President, reported that the expenditure for the year had been $932 and the balance was $454. The library received $457 worth of new books. Service provided at the annual sports day raised $157 despite unkind weather. Instead of a number of smaller events, money making was concentrated on the Gala Evening, which raised a nett $261. When the new prefabricated building was completed the teachers gained a staffroom and curtains, paint, a cupboard etc. were provided by the Welfare Club. The Club will contribute $150 towards a new amplifier, which has been ordered. A variety of teaching aids and sports equipment has been purchased.

Burra Primary School Headmistress’s Report

1968 was a busy year. Several sporting fixtures were held. In Term 1 the swimming carnival was held on 23 February when Hampton House won. The School Sports Day was held on a 19 April which was variously dusty, wet, and windy. Aberdeen won the Gebhardt Cup. On 22 March we entered two teams in the State Schools Swimming Championship in Adelaide. On 3 May we fielded two tennis teams in the District Sports Day at Hallett. The Purple Team returned with the Open Aggregate Shield and the Green Team was runner-up in the Team Games. Interschool basketball and football games were held in Term 2.

In 1968 there was a mid-year exam and a final exam for promotional purposes. ACER tests in reading, spelling and number processes were given in Term 1. End of year awards went to:

Deborah Kirk & Penelope Miller gained the Andrew Tennant Award

Deborah Brand won the Most Consistent Effort Award

John Brak gained the Service to School Award.

In April each class visited the National Trust Museum in Burra. Grade I visited the Post Office, the bakery and the Fire Station and with Grade II had a train & bus trip to Hanson. Grades V & VI visited the Town Hall Library. Grade V went to a shearing shed. Junior Red Cross was active in the year and held its own fete as well as having several visiting speakers. Grade VII produced its own magazine ‘The Monthly Review’.

Special Days observed were: Anzac Day, Pioneers’ Day, Conservation Day, World Children’s Day (featuring an austerity meal of rice) and United Nations Day (featuring clothes from other lands).

The Gale Evening saw each class present an item. Parents too had a busy year with the Welfare Club providing sports equipment, aids for teachers, curtains, fans, cupboards and a table cloth for the staffroom and an amplifier (not yet arrived). The Welfare Club ran stalls on Gala Night, a library service roster and donated ice creams and drinks for the children’s parties and the Swimming Carnival. Mrs Perry was away overseas for a term and a half. At the end of 1968 Miss McKenzie left to get married and to live in NSW and Mr John Cain has come from Western Teachers College in her place. This year numbers have decreased to 222 at present.

[Some dates for events planned for 1969 are then given, along with some discussion of the increasing role of group work.]

91, 10 (2), 18 Mar. 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1968.]

Local Government Amendment Act

Some changes made will affect Local Government procedure. Certain District Councils will be able to ask the Government to proclaim that the chief elected member be a Mayor in lieu of a Chairman. Wives of owners of rateable property are enfranchised. Councils will be able to set revenue aside in Reserve Funds for certain projects. Councils will be able to proceed with schemes of development or re-development providing the scheme has been approved by the State Planning Authority. Postal voting procedures have been revised – in particular it will be easier to find authorised witnesses.

Burraite writes on Paxton Square. Following your recent article on Paxton Square a visit to two of the modernised renovated cottages was certainly an eye-opener. Each has a new bathroom with electric hot water system, shower, new toilet connected to a new septic system and the quite large rooms are in excellent condition. These flats will enable an aged pensioner couple to enjoy good living conditions as a low rental in a solid, well insulated building, cool in summer and warm in winter. Much credit goes to Mr Stan Woollacott for getting maximum results at minimum cost. As Paxton Square is now an Historic Reserve, the buildings cannot be pulled down, so unless an effort is made to restore them to habitable conditions, they will deteriorate into unsightly ruins. ‘Please Burraites show your pride in your town as it is today, and also in its unique history as an early mining town, as evidenced by its many fine old buildings.

Editor:

Mr Woollacott has carried out a great deal of work not only on four of the houses, which have had the attention mentioned above, but in cleaning up the central area at the rear of the houses. Quite a number of old toilets have been removed. Mr Woollacott has certainly shown that as far as he is concerned he is not going to let it deteriorate further.

RSL Rooms. It was mentioned at the RSL AGM on Friday that their billiard table is the only full-sized table in the town and it is getting very little use from members. Not since the late George Terry conducted snooker tournaments have any organised billiards been played in the town. Are there enough snooker players to run such a tournament?

1969 ‘Field Day’ Week for stud Merino Breeders commenced yesterday at Gawler with midday lunch at Mintaro and the day ending at Koonoona. Today inspections are in the Hallett area, tomorrow the Mt Bryan area and at Booborowie on Friday.

Mt Bryan Reunion was held at Botanic Gardens Kiosk in Adelaide on Sunday 9 March. [Those present are listed.]

Burra Red Cross Branch has been awarded the 1968 pennant for the best effort per capita with its Red Cross Gold Day competition. Mrs Baulderstone will present the pennant to the Burra Golf Club on their opening day.

Mid North Adult Education Classes. Burra has three classes (all new): Woodwork, Dress-making & Conversational German.

91, 10 (2), 18 Mar. 1969, page 2 [This number used before in 1968.]

Junior Cricket Grand Final

Burra 197 defeated Aberdeen 86. A wind-up barbecue was held for both teams at the Gorge on Sunday.

91, 10 (2), 18 Mar. 1969, page 3 [This number used before in 1968.]

Birth. To Judy and Peter Gill of Spalding, at Calvary Hospital last week, a son, Stephen Mark.

Obituary. Dick Price of Booborowie died at Burra Hospital on Sunday.

Obituary. Lt Col Glan Tiver, formerly of Burra, died suddenly at Box Hill North, (Melbourne). He was educated at the Burra Schools and later became a partner in the Burra Motor Firm of Whitney and Tiver. He enlisted as a private in WW II and was commissioned in New Guinea. When hostilities ceased he held the rank of Major. He became a member of the regular army and at the time of his death was a Lt Colonel. He was accorded a full military funeral. He is survived by a wife and two married daughters. Mrs Tiver was formerly Miss Corris Walker. Mrs Roy Jeffery of Burra is a sister to the deceased.

[Glanville Hilary Tiver born 15 July 1907 Kooringa.]

Marriage. Last Friday at Black Forest Methodist Church

Anne Pettet married Tom Burns, both formerly of Burra.

Burra’s Fun Club Committee has called a final meeting for Friday night. The lack of adult support is causing concern. Parents and those interested in keeping the group going are urged to attend the Kooringa Salvation Army Hall at 8 p.m.

Arch. Jones has won the Bowls Singles Championship. Mrs Arch. Jones has won the Bowls Ladies’ Singles Championship.

Mr & Mrs Gus Kakoschke celebrated their Golden wedding with a party on Saturday night.

Barry Thompson of Booborowie spent a week’s leave with his parents recently. He expects to go to Vietnam at a later date.

91, 10 (2), 18 Mar. 1969, pages 3 & 6 gutter [This number used before in 1968.]

Melton Stud was sold at Burra RSL Hall on Friday to Mr Bruce Lehmann of ‘Flairville’ Georgetown, at $137 per acre.

91, 10 (2), 18 Mar. 1969, page 4 [This number used before in 1968.]

Mid North Football League held its AGM 7 March.

The President B.A. Kench reported on a year of successful football competition, at times of a very high standard of play. Auburn Club built fine dressing rooms. Plans are in hand to resurface the Saddleworth Oval. The Premiership went to Saddleworth-Marrabel United in the ‘A’ Grade, to Auburn in the ‘B’ Grade, and to Riverton in the Colts and also in the unofficial Junior Colts. Permit and clearance concerns between Mid North and North Eastern were resolved, but discussions about affiliation with SANFL have a gain lapsed. The introduction of a function for the counting of the Mail Medal Voting was a success. Elected were: President, B.A. Kench; Vice-President, S. Noske & Patron, W.E. Blatchford. Manoora and Mintaro Clubs are in the process of merging with Manoora agreeing and Mintaro to meet next Tuesday to confirm the decision. Clubs nominated teams as below:

It was resolved that Junior Colts become official with an age limit of 12 years on 1 January.

It was proposed that Mintaro-Manoora United have colours red & white.

Burra Small Bore Club fired a double 50 yards on 9 March and best scorers were J. Bowden, P. Mengersen & R. Gilbert.

91, 10 (2), 18 Mar. 1969, page 5 [This number used before in 1968.]

Kindergarten Fathers’ Auxiliary. Only five fathers attended the meeting on 26 February, but with apologies pledging support, it is hoped their work can go on. Since the meeting considerable work cleaning up the grounds had been done. Native plants for shade are being investigated. [Details of the work in 3⁄4 column.]

Aberdeen Football Club held its AGM with 42 players and supporters attending. R. James was appointed to coach ‘A’ & ‘B’ Grade. Bert Seaford will coach the Colts. Elected were: Patron, R.M. Reed; President, Bruce Stockman; Vice-President, B.L. Hirschausen and Secretary-Treasurer, Arnold Heinrich. The club will play in the Mid North League and use SANFL umpires.

Burra Town Council, 17 February

Hill Street is to be sealed for 7 chains.

R. Toms was granted permission to camp in the mine area.

The Gestetner machine is to be sold to the DC of Hallett for $100.

The cost of a three foot chain fence with two double gates with a 12 ft opening it to be obtained for the next meeting.

Penguin rubbish bin to be placed at Hurley’s road-house.

Council requests an E & WS employee be stationed at Burra for maintenance work.

91, 11 (2), 25 Mar. 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1968.]

Weather. Thunderstorms brought useful rain over the weekend. Falls varied widely: Burra 47 points, Mt Bryan 60, Hallett 54, Farrell Flat 21, Canegrass 172, Woolgangi 112, Koomooloo 50, Braemar 143, Baldina 66 & Lilydale 45.

Accident. A vehicle driven by Herbert A. Fridd of Burra North collided with one driven by Peter F. Jamieson of Mt Bryan near the Ironmine Church at about 12.05 a.m. Sunday. The drivers were not injured.

Accident. Two vehicles were involved in a collision two miles east of Burra on Friday. Injuries were relatively minor. One vehicle was driven by Mr H. Lance Phillips and the other by Cynthia E. Jungfer.

M & BHA. Despite 39 babies attending the clinic in January and February and 30 in March, only five members attended the Association meeting in March and none of those had babies attending at present. Money has to be raised to maintain the building, which has recently been painted at a cost of $100 and each year $100 has to be sent to Headquarters as part of the Sister’s wages. Within the next two years $250 has to be raised as part of the cost of a small transportable house at Clare for a resident Sister for the district. The attendance of mothers and their help is thus vital.

Mr H.H. Cullen of Burra North has won the contract for the weekly Eastern Mail.

Adelaide Wool Sales 18-20 March. The best district price was 55c on account M.T. & B.M. Kellock of Thistlebeds. [Other local district prices are printed.]

Football. The Mid North Football League held a special meeting at which the age limit for Junior Colts was raised to 131⁄2 on 1 January. Mintaro and Manoora clubs have now officially amalgamated.

91, 11 (2), 25 Mar. 1969, page 2 [This number used before in 1968.]

Burra Pre-school Kindergarten held its AGM on 10 March. Eighteen ladies attended, which is disappointing given that there are over 40 enrolments. Elected: President, Mrs M. Slater; Vice President, Mrs M. Tiver; Secretary, Mrs P. McDowell; Assistant Secretary, Mrs Male and Treasurer, Mrs Dean Bernhardt. The main efforts this year will be to repay the loan and to complete alterations to the kindergarten.

91, 12 (2), 1 Apr. 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1968.]

Mr & Mrs Frank Arnold were given a farewell at Hanson Hall on 14 March by members of the Hanson Agricultural Bureau, the CWA and residents of the Leighton District. Mr Ron Shipard was MC. Dancing was interspersed with other items, games and speeches. The evening ended with a delicious supper.

St Mary’s Ladies’ Guild held its annual meeting 25 March when 17 members attended. Elected: President, Mrs F. Matthews; Vice-Presidents, Mrs J. Stephenson & Mrs R. Thamm; Secretary, Mrs R. Shipard & Treasurer, Mrs R. Thamm.

Mr Ian Auhl will show a 1915 movie film made by Mr Lester in Burra as part of an illustrated talk in the Burra CWA rooms on 14 April. The film in five parts was taken on five occasions in 1915.

Burra Belgian Flag Day 10 May 1915

Where’s the Kaiser? A Burra Procession

All the nice girls love a Soldier

Australia Day Procession in Burra Friday 30 July 1915

Burra en Fete: Anzac Day 13 October 1915

The 16 mm film is from a copy held in the National Library, Canberra. Most of it is very clear.

Marriage. Port Broughton Methodist Church 15 March

91, 13 (2), 8 Apr. 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1968.]

Burra Burra Show Inc. AGM

The President Mr Rex Stockman expressed pleasure at the results of last year’s show both with respect to exhibits and financially. It was decided this year to ask the Premier Hon. Steele Hall to open the 1969 Show. Cadell Training Centre will be approached to exhibit its produce.

The 1968 Show was opened by Mr E.C. Allen MP, Member for Burra. The 2527 entries were just below the previous year’s record. With 500 entries in the Horses-in-Action, the event ran throughout the day. The Hack Section was among the best in the state. Sheep entries were down, but quality was very good. The wool display was good, but considering Burra’s position as the centre of a major wool district, it could be larger. Industrial sites were filled and included a light aircraft display from Air Mist. The agricultural pavilion had a good display of fruit, vegetable, needlework, grain and fodder, but lacked support in art and cooking sections. The Rural Youth display was the same as was entered for the Royal Adelaide Show, and was of a very high standard. Poultry and birds were well represented and although flowers and floral art entries were down by nearly half, the exhibits were up to the usual high standards. Sideshows were very numerous and of greater variety than in previous years. Thanks, of course, go to the convenors, stewards, judges and exhibitors and especially to our new secretary, Miss Judy Beinke.

Burra Rubbish Dump. An anonymous invitation was extended to the Town Clerk and Councillors to attend a social gathering at the Council Dump. The Council has long been aware of the untidiness of the dump, but it is due to ratepayers who insist on dropping their rubbish where they like, rather than in the designated place. The Council will cover the existing mess and appeals to people not to dump rubbish outside the official site.

Burra Town Hall interior has had a face-lift. The interior has been painted, new lighting installed and shortly new carpet will be laid on the stairways to the lounge. The ceiling over the lounge area has been replaced. The new lighting should benefit balls in the coming season.

Council Elections

Mr T.G. Perry, District and Acting Town Clerk, advises that nominations for the annual elections for the two Councils should be called during April. Owing to the amount of time necessary before the Combined Council can be proclaimed, the nominations will not be called until after 26 April 1969. It is expected that nominations will be called for the now Combined Council, to close on the usual date; the second Friday in May – the 9th. One member for each ward of the district and three members for Burra Town Ward will be required to give a Council of eleven members. The position of Mayor is in doubt till the first meeting of the Combined Council. To complete the official current term the two existing Councils will meet as a combined body for two meetings in May and June. The new Council asked for a commencement following the first Saturday in July after the elections are completed.

91, 13 (2), 8 Apr. 1969, page 3 [This number used before in 1968.]

Women’s Championship Doubles E. Ross & C. Kotz

91, 13 (2), 8 Apr. 1969, page 7 [This number used before in 1968.]

Accident. On Thursday afternoon a semi-trailer loaded with 117 bales of wool tipped over at Hanson, blocking half the road, which was busy with Easter traffic. It was owned by Hi-Speed Transport of Broken Hill who sent two more vehicles and a forklift to reload the wool. These arrived about 9 p.m. Complications arose in trying to unload the forklift when the truck got bogged across the railway line when an attempt was made to unload the forklift onto the platform. That delayed the northbound passenger train for 70 or 80 minutes. Eventually the forklift had to be unloaded at the Burra Council Depot and driven to Hanson.

Another accident was luckily averted when a connecting bolt on a towbar broke and sent a caravan careering across the road at the scene above. Fortunately no damage was done and repairs could be effected to allow it to continue. Police eventually were able to leave the scene after 14 hours at Hanson.

91, 14 (2), 15 Apr. 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1968.]

Mokota Cricket Assoc. will hold an End of Season Social and Wind-up on Friday night 18 April at Booborowie Hall. Mr Barry Jarmyn has been invited to be guest speaker.

Weather. Rain over the weekend added 37 points to the annual total by 9 a.m. Monday. To the east gaugings were in the order of 30-40 points.

Kooringa Methodist Church was filled on Sunday morning when a special Confirmation Service was held. Twenty young people were received into full membership of the Church; seven being baptised during the service, which was conducted by Rev. Milton Edwards.

Burra Burra DC has received a small grant for preliminary work on realigning the Burra-Morgan Road near Diprose Creek. The new section will begin just past the bridge near ‘Fords’, will delete the bridge over Diprose and re-enter the existing road halfway up ‘Breakneck’. A further grant next year is expected to allow the work to be completed.

Burra High School. Leaving Students organised a dance on Friday night, which was well attended. Profit was $170.

The school’s sports day was held in difficult weather conditions with strong wind all the time. Riggs House was successful. Cup Winners:

Senior Girls’ Cup C. Finch

Senior Boys’ Cup R. Przibilla

Junior Girls’ Cup B. Kleinig

Junior Boys’ Cup S. Lane

[Other results are printed.]

Ironmine Methodist Ladies Guild. The year’s activities are summarised in 1⁄2 column. Average attendance was 10 from a membership of 17.

Burra Small Bore Club. Best in a double 25 yards shoot were R. Gilbert, P. Mengersen & M. Thomas.

91, 15 (2), 22 Apr. 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1968.]

Burra District Ambulance has had the service of 7 or 8 crews for some time, but at present only three are available at short notice, while others are available from Mt Bryan, Hallett and Booborowie. The number of members that have left the district means that the service is seeking new crews.

Weather. Rain over the weekend from thunderstorms brought falls ranging from 54 points at Mt Bryan and 72 at Burra and 77 at Booborowie to much lower figures for eastern properties, where most were in the range 10-20 points.

Obituary. Mrs Stella Floyd Hawker, wife of Mr G. Stanley Hawker of ‘Belcunda’ Mt Bryan, has died.

[Born Stella Floyd Featherstonhough 19 February 1898 Albany WA: died 15 April 1969 Hamilton, Victoria. See extended obituary 91, 16 (2), 29 Apr. 1969, page 4.]

Burra National Trust held a meeting in the CWA Rooms on Monday 14 April. Mr Alexander from the National Trust in Adelaide spoke first, followed by Mr Ian Auhl. He paid tribute to Mr A.E. Hiles, Hon. Secretary of the National Trust who was also present and who is soon to retire. Mr Auhl stressed the extraordinary advantage Burra has over other SA towns in its wealth of historic interest and well preserved buildings. He then showed the 1915 film of Burra. Many present were able to identify people they had known and themselves as well. A film of Willunga was also shown.

Burra Hospital Bowls Tournament

72 bowlers took part last Sunday despite the cold and wintry conditions. After a play-off Frank Matthews’ rink came out winners with Ron Gordon, Vi Allen & Geoff Male. The runners-up were skippered by Ken Williams with Tom McWaters, Hilda Earle and Darcy Tiver. The result of the tournament was $500, which with Government subsidy will be worth $1,000 for the Burra Hospital.

Weekend School 9-11 May. The Department of Adult Education at the University of Adelaide will run the school on The Historic Copper Towns of SA. In their heyday these were the mainstay of the colonial and then the state economy and in the mid 19th century the main suppliers of copper to the world. The aims of the school are:

To give an account of the fascinating social and industrial history of the copper towns.

To stimulate discussion and action on the care, understanding and preservation of their historic relics.

The school begins with lectures in the University of Adelaide’s Lecture Theatre No.5 Napier Building on Friday evening and Saturday morning and afternoon. On Sunday there will be a guided tour to Kapunda and Burra. You can enrol for the lectures only.

Friday 7.45 p.m. Copper SA by Dr John Tregenza, Senior Lecturer, History Department, University of Adelaide.

Saturday 10.30 a.m. The Geological Background to Copper Mining in SA by Mr Keith Johns, Supervising Geologist, Mineral Resources Division SA Department of Mines.

Saturday 2 p.m. Burra in Historical Perspective by Ian Auhl, Burra Branch of the National Trust.

Saturday 4-5 p.m. Panel Discussion: Preserving the Historic Copper Towns.

The excursion will depart the University of Adelaide 8.30 a.m. Sunday 11 May and visit Kapunda Copper Mines before having lunch at Princess Royal Station – members must take packed lunches. Then a tour of Burra town, mine are, old gaol and museum. After refreshments at the CWA Rooms the coach will depart for the city at 5 p.m.

Fees: for the lectures and refreshments and buffet luncheon $4 and for the coach excursion $3.50.

91, 15 (2), 22 Apr. 1969, page 2 [This number used before in 1968.]

Burra Golf Club opened its season on Saturday. Club President Mr John Gordon declared the season open and asked Club Champion Captain Stan Longford to drive the first ball off for the season. Prior to the competition getting under way Mrs E.T. Baulderstone, President of the Burra Branch of the Red Cross, presented the Club with the winning pennant for donating the most money to Red Cross in the 1968 season.

Obituary. The sudden death last week of Mrs Stella Hawker came as a shock. For many years she had contributed greatly to the community life and welfare of the Mt Bryan and Burra areas.

[Born Stella Floyd Featherstonhough 19 February 1898 Albany WA: died 15 April 1969 Hamilton, Victoria. See extended obituary 91, 16 (2), 29 Apr. 1969, page 4.]

Obituary. Mrs Ada James died at Burra North on Saturday aged 88.

[Born Ada Anne Lawn 1 February 1879 District of Kapunda: died 19 April 1969 Burra, residence Burra North.]

Mr & Mrs H.W. Phillips of Booborowie celebrate their Golden Wedding tomorrow.

A Tin-kettling was arranged for Trevor and Veronica Simpson on 12 April by a group of Mt Bryanites.

The Mid North Football League met at Saddleworth on 18 April to arrange clearances and permits. [Details in just over 1 column.]

Cricket. The wind-up of the Mokota Association for the season was held at Booborowie on Friday. The guest speaker was test cricketer Barry Jarmyn and he was accompanied by Mr Arthur Lee. Barry Jarmyn presented Philip Byles with the Cricketer of the Year Trophy.

91, 15 (2), 22 Apr. 1969, page 4 [This number used before in 1968.]

Mt Bryan CWA Branch at their last meeting honoured the late Mrs Hawker who was the chief instigator 23 years ago in the formation of the branch and was its first President. It was chiefly her untiring effort and enthusiasm in the early years that helped mould an active and interesting branch at Mt Bryan.

91, 15 (2), 22 Apr. 1969, page 6 [This number used before in 1968.]

Burra Primary School held its sports Day last Friday. The day was marked by dust, wind, thunder, lightning and then torrential rain. The march past and part of the House Competition took place before the day had to be abandoned, with events to be run if possible on the school oval during the week. Despite the weather the competition for a donated lamb (from Mr Ray Alderson) raised $76.50, the gate was $30, the trading table took $50 and drinks raised $21 for a total nearing $180. [Results will be printed next issue.]

North Eastern Combined District School Sports at Spalding suffered the safe fate, with only part of the program completed. [Results will be printed next issue.]

Advt. Burra Pictures, 26 April

Bandolero

The Murder Game

The Anzac Commemoration Service at Burra War Memorial was attended by a fair number on Sunday afternoon. Many stayed in their cars due to the bad weather. Rev. John Stephenson conducted the service. The Pt Pirie Pipe Band led a march of some 20 ex-servicemen. Wreaths were laid by Mayor E.T. Baulderstone, Cr. G.R. Finch for the DC, Mr T.R. Rogers for the RSL and Mr P. Williams for Demobilised Soldiers. The Anzac Church Service this year was held at St Mary’s Anglican Church. Mr Geoffrey Dare conducted the service with Rev. Stephenson playing the organ. Mr Norrell Baynes and Rev. Milton Edwards read lessons and Rev. Edwards preached the sermon.

91, 16 (2), 29 Apr. 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1968.]

Burra Corporation Ceases to Exist

From 25 April 1969 the Burra Corporation has amalgamated with the District Council. The last meeting of the Burra Town Council was held on Monday 21 April and ended at 12.45 a.m. on Tuesday 22 April. The Town Council had existed for almost 93 years, with its first meeting being on 10 July 1876. It had been established by a proclamation of the Governor on 28 June 1876 and published in the SA Government Gazette of Thursday 29 June 1876. This established a Council with Philip Lane as the first Mayor with six Councillors:

North Ward George Sara & August Bartholomaeus

Middle Ward Robert Saunders [Sanders] & Edward Lipsett

South Ward Joseph Roberts & John Snell

The last Mayor Mr E.T. Baulderstone served on the Council for 23 years, the last 15 as Mayor. He has seen the service of eight Town Clerks, several of whom had no previous local experience, which did not help to make Mr Baulderstone’s term an easy one. The old Corporation comprised an area of 3,015 acres with some 53 miles of roads. The existing Town Councillors will see out the final two months of the term they were elected for, as members of the amalgamated body, except for Councillors Moreland and Kotz, who, as employees of the District Council, are not permitted to serve as Councillors. At the last meeting of the Local Board of Health for the Corporation Dr L.G. Miller was thanked for his services to the Board.

The District Council of Burra Burra was formed in 1935 as a result of the amalgamation of the District Councils of Hanson, Mt Bryan, Burra and [part of] Booborowie. The new Council will encompass an area of 800 square miles with over 1,100 miles of road. The new Council will meet for the first time on 14 May. Councillors are:

Chairman G.R. Finch

E.T. Baulderstone S.T. Miller

B.A. Riggs J. Burge

R. White M.T. Kellock

W.H. Quinn H. Quinn

R.B. Jennison C.L. Phillips

R.E. Angel R.J. Jeffery

District Clerk is T.G. Perry.

Because the first meeting of the new Council will be on 14 May this year’s call for nominations for Councillors has been delayed. They will be called at this meeting with nominations to close 30 May.

[There are several errors in this list:

  • 1887 was omitted and F.W. Holder was the Mayor for this year.

† In November 1888 P.L. Killicoat was elected unopposed for 1889, but on seeing the election results he immediately resigned, citing personal reasons. In fact it seems he was unwilling to work with Cr Sampson. As a result of nominations called for 24 December 1888 F.W. Holder was elected unopposed and served as Mayor for 1889

‡ This should read P.L. Killicoat

§ In November 1901 Alexander Harris was elected unopposed for 1902, but he died on 25 December 1901 without attending a meeting of Council. E.W. Crewes was elected unopposed to replace him on 10 January 1902 and served as Mayor for 1902.

║ William Charles Leonard West was Mayor from December 1906-November 1908. Dr John Ikin Sangster Jnr was Mayor from December 1908-November 1909.

¶A new Act of Parliament, effective 2 November 1934 changed the Municipal Year from approximately a calendar year (actually December to November) to one running from July to June. The life of the 1934 Council was extended to the 1st Saturday in July 1935. This means that the later Mayors, beginning their terms in July, should be:

1937-39 S. Kellaway

1939-46 T.H. Woollacott

1946-48 H.J.B. Jennison

1948-50 F.T. Marston

1950-54 W. Carpenter

1954-69 E.T. Baulderstone.]

St Mary’s. Rt Rev. George Quarterman, Bishop of the Diocese of North-West Texas will be guest preacher on 5 May. He is on a ten day visit to the Diocese of Willochra and will dedicate a new chapel at the Anglican Conference Centre at Melrose. It has been paid for by the members of the church in Texas and children of his diocese have raised money for the chapel’s furnishings. An organ recital by Rev. Geoffrey Sibly will precede the service.

Offences. Two Adelaide youths were fined $27 each for the theft of petrol from cars in the car lot of Fiebig Motors of Burra North.

Two Broken Hill youths were each fined $42 for being unlawfully on the premises of Jennison’s Tyre Service.

Redruth Methodist Church will celebrate its Anniversary on Sunday with two services at which Rev. Graham Knill of Yacka will preach in the morning and Rev. Milton Edwards in the evening.

91, 16 (2), 29 Apr. 1969, page 4 [This number used before in 1968.]

Obituary. Stella Floyd Hawker died suddenly on 15 April at the home of her brother Cuthbert Ford Featherstonhough at Hamilton, Victoria. She was buried at Bungaree Church, Clare after a service at St Andrew’s, Mt Bryan. She was born at Albany, WA on 19 February 1898, the eldest child of Mr & Mrs Percy Featherstonhough and she married George Stanley Hawker of Clare 21 October 1931 and resided in that district till February 1935 when Mr & Mrs Hawker made their home at ‘Belcunda’ Mt Bryan, where they resided till her death. Mrs Hawker took an active part in community affairs at Mt Bryan and Burra. She was a Director of East Bungaree Stud and kept the books and managed the stud for nine months while Mr Hawker was in camp. During WW II she was leader and organiser of the Mt Bryan VSD. She was made a Life Member of the Burra Women’s Branch of the LCL on 5 July 1963 for services to it, having retired as President of the branch in 1959 after years in that post. She was a member of the Council from 1947-60. Mrs Hawker was the foundation President of Mt Bryan CWA branch when it was formed after WW II. She had also put in years of service for the Red Cross during the war. She had earlier been active in the Burra CWA branch and many CWA garden parties were held at her home over the years. Although she had no children of her own, she took an interest in the M & BHA. She was a keen supporter of the Burra Show and exhibited in the Floral and Vegetable Sections. She was responsible for many improvements to the two churches where she worshipped, most recently for the steps up the embankment from the street [at St Mary’s]. The Sanctuary Light and Litch [sic] gate [lych-gate] at Mt Bryan were the brain children of Mrs Hawker. She believed strongly in improving the district one lived in.

SA Stockowners’ Association Burra Branch held its AGM in Burra RSL Hall 21 April 1969. Elected were: President, E.L. McWaters; Vice-Presidents, D. Lloyd & F.H. Treweeke and joint secretaries, A.L. Wright & R.L. Wuttke.

91, 16 (2), 29 Apr. 1969, page 5 [This number used before in 1968.]

Burra Town Council, Final Meeting, 21 April

The meeting began at 7.30 p.m. in the [District] Council Chambers in Commercial Street.

An application will be made for a subsidy on Mine Area improvements to the value of $2,000.

It was resolved that Council call tenders for the supply and installation of heating at the Town Hall.

A penguin rubbish bin is to be bought and placed at Burra North at a site to be selected.

Crs Moreland and Kotz were thanked for their contribution during their terms as Councillors.

Burra Small Bore Club. Best over double 50 yards were, J. Bowden, M. Thomas & R. Gilbert.

91, 17 (2), 6 May 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1968.]

Adelaide Wool Sales 29-30 April & 1 May. [Local district prices are printed.]

Tennis. An end of season Tennis Ball was held at the Booborowie Hall on Friday. Miss Jenny Kleinig was judged Miss Tennis 1968-69. The Association expects to benefit by c. $100 from the event.

Burra Railway. The centenary of the first train on 29 August 1870 is approaching and the National Trust is arranging with the Australian Railway Historical Society to run a steam train to Burra for the occasion.

Theft. A motor mower and rubber-tyred wheelbarrow have been stolen from Burra Golf Club House.

Burra Floral Art Display at the Town Hall was opened by Mrs Johnson of Clare. Attendance was disappointing. 203 entries were received. The CWA served afternoon tea.

Accident. Miles Cockington aged 2 was knocked down by a car in Best Place on Saturday morning, but escaped serious injury, suffering concussion and lacerations. He ran across the road into the path of a car driven by Mr David Loffler of Burra North. Fortunately the car was travelling slowly.

Pt Adelaide Pensioners’ League members gave their annual concert at the Burra Town Hall on 29 April. Mr E.T. Baulderstone introduced them and gave them a hearty welcome. Mr Carpenter spoke on behalf of the Burra Pensioners’ League.

91, 18 (2), 13 May 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1968.]

Weekend School: Historic Copper Towns of SA

This began at the University of Adelaide on Friday evening with a seminar in the Napier Building addressed by men knowledgeable in the area and continued there on Saturday. Ian Auhl spoke on the history of Burra. On Sunday morning participants toured Kapunda and then over 100 people picnicked at Princess Royal lawns, where they were joined by local members of the National Trust. Clouds gathered, but the rain held off till evening. In the afternoon the group visited the dugouts, Paxton square, the Burra Mine, the Redruth Gaol and the Museum. Guides were Ian Auhl and the President of the National Trust in Burra Mr Lewis Moore. The CWA provided afternoon tea and the whole event was deemed a great success.

Burra Basketball Debutante Ball at Burra Town Hall on Friday night took $350 at the door. Eight debutants were presented to Mrs Wendy Ey. Debutants and partners were:

Elaine Broderick with Peter Brown

Joy Goodridge with Robert Gilbert

Lynette Corner with Glen Brumley

Lorraine Jones with Ian Jones

Suzanne Richards with Michael Scholz

Marlene Rooke with Alan Drew

Allison Miller with Andrew Pearce

Judy Beinke with Kenneth Jones

Christine Baulderstone was flower girl and David Rasheed was a page boy. Maurice Collins was MC.

Lutheran parishioners of Blyth, Clare, Robertstown & Burra will gather at the Burra Town Hall on Sunday morning for a special service. Special guests will be Rev. Martin Winkler, Director of Broadcasting for the Australian Lutheran Hour and Rev. Ron Gerhardy, Director of Missions in the South-West Pacific. A luncheon will follow the 10.30 a.m. service. The Blyth-Clare-Burra Parish Pastor is Rev. C.A. Scherer.

Accident. A sedan driven by R.F. Pearce overturned on the Burra Road one mile east of Booborowie on Saturday morning. The driver escaped injury.

Riverton 13.14 defeated Aberdeen 0.0

[Presumably these results are from two weeks.]

91, 18 (2), 13 May 1969, page 3 [This number used before in 1968.]

Obituary. John Kellaway, husband of the late Rachel Anne Kellaway of 58 Wood Ave Croydon and late of Burra, died at the Repatriation General Hospital 9 May aged 85. He was the father of Lorna, Jack and Verna and step-father of Dick and Bill (deceased). [Born 9 October 1883 Kooringa: died 9 May 1969 Daw Park, residence Croydon.]

Marriage. St Joseph’s Burra, next Saturday

Colleen Fahey, daughter of Mr & Mrs T. Fahey of Hallett will marry Pierre Vermeeren.

Clem Davey, who presently teaches Music at a Hobart School, visited Burra recently and played the organ at St Mary’s last Sunday.

Marriage. This week at Pirie Street Methodist Church, Adelaide

Miriam Reed, youngest daughter of Mr & Mrs Ted Reed of Finniss and formerly of Burra will marry Peter Glazbrook.

Accident/Obituary. Following a road accident, the death has occurred of Sister Jeanette O’Connell, late of Burra Hospital. [The only death of a female O’Connell in SA in 1969 was that of Jessel Dawn O’Connell, single, 25 March at Gilles Plains aged 32.]

Obituary. Mrs Ashdown Sen. died at Burra Hospital on Saturday.

[Constance Lucy Ashdown died 10 May 1969 at Burra, residence Springwood, NSW aged 71.]

Obituary. Mr Bill Heinrich died suddenly at his home yesterday aged 51.

[William Percival Heinrich born 25 December 1917 Redruth: died 12 May 1969 Farrell Flat. See extended obituary 91, 21 (2), 3 June 1969, pages 4 & 5 gutter.]

Obituary. Paris Fuller of Crystal Brook and late of Burra died recently at the Queen Elizabeth Hospital aged 70. His late parents were former Burra residents and his widow was Miss Mary Brooks of Booborowie.

[Paris Nesbit Fuller born 7 June 1898 Jamestown: died 10 May 1969 Woodville, residence Crystal Brook.]

91, 18 (2), 13 May 1969, page 37[This number used before in 1968.]

Bishop Rt Rev. George Quarterman, of the Episcopalian Diocese of North-West Texas, visited Burra last week, where he was guest preacher at St Mary’s. Rev. Geoff. Sibly played the organ. Bishop Quarterman outlined the history of his diocese of 77,000 square miles. Supper followed in the Parish Hall.

91, 19 (2), 20 May 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1968.]

A Lutheran Mission Festival was held at Burra on Sunday at the Burra Town Hall. Lutherans from Blyth-Clare-Burra Parish attended. Guest pastors were Martin Winkler & Ron Gerhardy, Directors of the Australian Lutheran Hour and Lutheran Mission Field respectively. Parish Pastor P.A. Scherer conducted the service. Members of the choir came from Blyth. Pastor Gerhardy spoke of the Mission work in New Guinea and Indonesia in particular and Pastor Winkler of the work of the church within Australia. A buffet luncheon followed in the supper room.

Weather. Rain this week has been steady across the district with falls totalling about 1 inch, though falling to about half that towards World’s End. Burra 90 points, Mt Bryan 121 and Booborowie 109.

Fire. The Royal Exchange Hotel had a chimney fire on Sunday at about 5.30 p.m., which was soon extinguished.

Inter High School Sports were held at Clare last Tuesday. Overall results

Championship Shield Handicap Shield

Clare 241 Riverton 358.5

Riverton 215.5 Burra 337.5

Eudunda 168.5 Eudunda 323.5

Burra 158.5 Kapunda 317

Balaklava 143.5 Clare 241

Kapunda 101 Balaklava 229.5

[Other results are printed.]

Burra Burra DC has decided to continue with a Chairman as head, rather than appoint a Mayor. Nominations for a complete new Council are now being called. Mr T.G .Perry has been appointed as District Clerk and Mr R.A. Moreland as Overseer. A new assessment is being prepared to bring the town under the land values system of rating.

Burra Hospital. The Inspector’s report says the hospital is financially sound and average costs per bed have been falling. The position re outstanding fees is very satisfactory.

91, 19 (2), 20 May 1969, page 2 [This number used before in 1968.]

Advt. Southern Farmers announce a house and furniture sale on instructions from executors in the estate of the late Mr G.H. Dollman.

Accident. A car driven by Mr W.G. Robinson collided with a panel van driven by Mr R.A. Opperman at Burra North on Saturday at about 7 p.m. Both drivers escaped injury.

91, 19 (2), 20 May 1969, page 3 [This number used before in 1968.]

Police Cadet Robert Orford is in Burra for some practical experience. He is son of Sgt & Mrs Norm. Orford of Burra.

Birth. To Elwyn & Lin Muldoon at Burra Hospital last Thursday, a son, Simon Paul Edward.

Birth. To Val & John Secomb of Burra, a daughter, Kathryn Lee.

Mr & Mrs Hughes have taken over the Burra Hotel.

Obituary. Mr William Francis McEvoy formerly of Booborowie died 19 May aged 91.

[Died at Myrtle Bank, residence Allenby Gardens. M. Satchell Burra database says born 1877 Booleroo Centre, but the birth is not found on SA Births CD.]

Obituary. Mr Harry Taylor of Booborowie died at Burra Hospital last week.

[Born 20 November 1899 near Clare: died 16 May 1969 Burra, residence Booborowie.]
