[Lancelot Luxford Swann Matters born 5 April 1908, Adelaide: died 21 April 1969 Adelaide, residence Spalding.]

Mrs J. Trallagan, formerly of Mt Bryan East, will be 99 on 27 May. She now lives in a Resthaven Home in Adelaide. [Born Helena Jane Bailey 27 May 1870 Wallaroo: died 14 July 1971 Kingswood.]

91, 19 (2), 20 May 1969, page 4 [This number used before in 1968.]

Burra Burra DC, first meeting of combined Councils 14 May

G.R. Finch was elected Chairman and E.T. Baulderstone was elected Deputy Chairman.

Department of Public Health is to be asked to give early attention to drafting plans for a common effluent drainage scheme.

Cr Baulderstone moved the Council make provision for the office of Mayor. Motion lost.

Nominations for Council were called for 30 May.

Resolved that the Burra Pictures be placed in the hands of Burra Town Ward representatives, J. Topsfield and S. Kellaway with the District Clerk to act as secretary.

Burra Ambulance-EFS Centre will be officially opened by the Hon. C.R. Story MLC, Minister of Agriculture, 1 June.

Burra Oval afternoon tea room has been extended by the construction of a glass-fronted room 14 ft x 12 ft.

Obituary. Robert Ladner died at Burra suddenly on Thursday night aged 23. He was the son of Mrs E.H. Ladner of Burra North and leaves a widow and four children.

[Robert Edward Ladner died 22 May 1969 Burra North aged 23.]

Mid North Basketball Ball was held at Burra Town Hall. Door takings were $341. Prior to the ball the presidents and secretaries of the clubs and judges of the Miss Mid North Basketball Competition were entertained by the committee of the Aberdeen Club, which hosted the event. Mr & Mrs Scott of the Kooringa Hotel catered for the event. Miss Carol Twigden of Riverton was chosen as Miss Mid North Basketball for 1969.

91, 21 (2), 3 June 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1968.]

‘Gum View’ at World’s End was sold by auction on Friday by Elders-GM on account of J.E. Rooke & Mrs E. Rooke. The homestead block of 1,136 acres went to Ken Phillips at $33 per acre. Two lots of 395 and 45 acres went to Dalgety & NZ Loan of Burra for $34 & $10 per acre respectively. Ken Phillips also bought 132 acres at $26.50 per acre and 197 acres at $20.50 per acre. The last section of 982 acres went to Mrs J.M. Rooke at $9.50 per acre.

Photo of Miss Mid North Basketball entrants:

Belinda Afford, Sue Ward, Katherine Rohde, Jennifer Schunke, Susan Richards, Carol Twigden (winner), Christine Gill, Margaret Schoenberg, Myra Schmidt, Sue Fettke and Jean Williams.

Dogs have again been mauling sheep at Burra. A number of sheep were killed and injured on Rex Stockman’s property and dogs were seen on D.M .Tiver’s property too.

Burra Burra DC Elections

All district wards were filled without a contest:

Kooringa Ward G.R. Finch

Baldina Ward M.T. Kellock

Booborowie Ward H.B. Quinn

Leighton Ward R.J. White

Mt Bryan Ward T.J. Quinn

Mongolata Ward B.A. Riggs

Farrell Flat Ward J.W. Burge

Hanson Ward S.T. Miller

For the three vacancies in Burra Town Ward there were seven nominations and an election will be held on 5 July.

Nominated were:

R.E. Angel

E.T. Baulderstone

R.J. Jeffery

R.B. Jennison

N.W. Orford

L.H. Packer

C.L. Phillips

Except for the last two the others have been serving on the Combined Council for the past 12 months.

91, 21 (2), 3 June 1969, pages 1 & 7 [This number used before in 1968.]

Burra EFS-Ambulance Centre was opened by Hon. C.R. Story, Minister of Agriculture on Sunday afternoon 1st June. [The official party is listed.] At 12.45 the St John Brigade Band played at the Hospital and at 1.20 it and the service personnel marched from Burra North to the Centre. Mr E.T. Baulderstone was in charge of the ceremony and welcomed the official party and other guests. The new centre was erected to give a home to the ambulance and units of the EFS and to the volunteers of both bodies. Mr T.G. Perry thanked the contractors Messrs D.T. Jacka and Co. Redruth Sunday School ladies provided refreshments. G.R. Finch, Chairman of the Burra Burra DC said the ambulance had answered 52 calls in the past year and 17 of them had been trips to Adelaide. There were four EFS units in the district – Burra, Mt Bryan, Booborowie and Farrell Flat. Various others spoke. Rev. J.H. Stephenson blessed the building. Mr Story congratulated the members of the committee and the contractors on the project and declared the building open. Mr Moreland on behalf of the EFS and Mr Ron Thamm on behalf of the Ambulance Service accepted the building and expressed their thanks. After that those present inspected the building before adjourning to the Redruth Sunday School for afternoon tea.

91, 21 (2), 3 June 1969, page 2 [This number used before in 1968.]

Weather. In the past week good soaking rain has been general. Burra received 110 points, Mt Bryan 159, Booborowie 176 and World’s End 57.

91, 21 (2), 3 June 1969, page 3 [This number used before in 1968.]

Accident. At 8.20 p.m. on Friday a car driven by Richard F. Waters collided with one driven by Alec C. Williams on the Kingston Street Bridge. The drivers were not injured.

Carl & Joyce Pearce have left Burra for Adelaide.

Birth. To Pat & Ian Weston of Mt Bryan on 29 May, a son, Ian Andrew.

Birth. To Neil & Susan Prosser (nee Gill of Burra) now of Melrose, a daughter.

Birth. To Joan & Don Edwards at Tumby Bay on 13 May, a daughter, Tracie Lorraine.

Andrew Bence was home for a few days on R & R from Vietnam. A few months ago we published a letter which said he hadn’t seen much action. This is not quite the case now.

Mrs R. Chambers of Kilburn and formerly of Burra will be 100 on Friday 6 June.

[Rosamund Eliza Beatrice Chambers died 8 February 1970 aged 100.]

Mrs F. Longbottom of ‘Carinya’ Clare will be 90 on 9 June.

91, 21 (2), 3 June 1969, page 4 [This number used before in 1968.]

Spalding CWA Debutante Ball is reported.

91, 21 (2), 3 June 1969, pages 4 & 5 gutter [This number used before in 1968.]

Obituary. William Percival Heinrich died suddenly at his residence in Farrell Flat on 12 May. He was born at Burra, the eldest son of Mrs M.A. Heinrich of Black Springs and the late Mr C.A. Heinrich. He spent his early life at Black Springs and began working there on his father’s property. Later he was employed by Horwood Bagshaw & played football for North Adelaide. After five years in the CMF he married Joyce Olds in 1945 and after his discharge from the army they lived at Porter’s Lagoon. For the last 16 years he has lived at Farrell Flat. He was a keen sportsman and active in the Vigilance and Institute Committees and with the tennis and football clubs. He was also a foundation member of the Farrell Flat Golf Club and its secretary for five years.

[William Percival Heinrich born 25 December 1917 Redruth: died 12 May 1969 Farrell Flat.]

91, 22 (2), 10 June 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1968.]

Council Elections. A recent amendment to the Local Government Act gives a vote to the spouse of a person who owns a rateable property. Persons wishing to vote in the Council election on 5 July must have their name on the roll by 20 June. To be eligible rates must have been paid at least six days prior to the election.

Accident. A vehicle driven by Mr D. Baker collided with another driven by Mrs W. Thomas at the intersection of Welsh Place and Kingston Street yesterday.

A semi-trailer could not get over the wet and slippery section of the new road to Morgan just beyond the Eudunda turn-off yesterday and was helped over it by the Council grader.

Burra CWA members visited Moonta, where they saw over the Miners’ Cottage, the Town Hall and the Museum, as well as enjoying a social afternoon in the CWA Room. The group returned to Burra by 7 p.m.

Weather. Good follow-on rains fell in the past week. Burra recorded 77 points, which was typical of the inside country.

Booborowie might get street signs following a discussion in Council.

Theft. A person has been charged with the theft of $100 and clothing from the Bon Accord Hotel.

Burra Rural Youth Club’s Peter Brown has been appointed Chairman of this year’s door-knock appeal for the Heart Fund.

91, 22 (2), 10 June 1969, page 3 [This number used before in 1968.]

Russell & Margaret Woolford of Booborowie have moved to Cowell.

Football. Mid North League

Robertstown 11.7 defeated SM United 8.13

Junior Colts SM United 8.15 defeated Robertstown 1.0

Riverton 1.3 defeated Aberdeen 1.0

91, 23 (2), 17 June 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1968.]

Mrs Reta Jennison has been awarded the British Empire Medal in the Queen’s Birthday Honours for dedicated community service over many years. She has also received a congratulatory telegram from the PM Hon. John G. Gorton. Mrs Jennison has lived in the Burra area all her life. In 1947-48 she was Mayoress when her late husband was Mayor. In 1947 she was appointed a JP. She was foundation President of the Primary School Parents & Friends’ Association from 1939 for eleven years and was secretary for three years. She was also a member of the High School Council for a number of years and during WW II was active in the Fighting Forces Comforts Fund and other patriotic committees. She has been active in the Burra RSL Auxiliary, being its President and Vice-President for a number of years. She joined the Burra North Red Cross in 1941 and remains a member, having been its President for 23 years as well as being a member of the Burra CWA for twenty years, its President for eight years and Secretary for four. She has been a Vice-President and member of the Burra Hospital Women’s Auxiliary for many years and a Vice-President and member of the Burra Branch of the Adelaide Children’s Hospital Auxiliary.

She is a member of the Burra Burra Branch of the National Trust and of the Lewis Trust controlling Paxton Square. She joined the Redruth Methodist Guild in 1926 and has been its secretary for 43 years and is also a member of the House Committee for the Methodist Manse. She has been choir Mistress at Redruth church and served with the Burra Choral Society when it was active. A member of the Burra benevolent Society for 27 years and its secretary for ten. She has served on committees for Freedom from Hunger, the Swimming Pool, Town Hall and Carol Evenings. We warmly congratulate her on being finally recognised for her services to the community.

Burra Red Cross Branch is to send parcels to men serving in Vietnam. Only two local boys are known to be serving at this time: Andrew Bence and Keith McWaters.

Opening of EFS & Ambulance Centre. Two photographs are printed:

The building and the crowd attending

The official party

91, 23 (2), 17 June 1969, page 4 [This number used before in 1968.]

Advt. Burra Pictures

William Holden & Susannah York in The Seventh Dawn

Plus Gentle Terror

Mr Hartwell of NSW visited Burra on Friday. He was very pleased to visit his birthplace of 65 years ago: the Market Square Museum, where he lived with his parents, three sisters and four brothers.

[This was Cornelius Greville Hartnett born 30 March 1903 to Jeremiah & Catherine nee Wade. However, SA Births CD only records two girls and four boys in the family.]

91, 23 (2), 17 June 1969, page 7 [This number used before in 1968.]

The Penguin Club held its 56th meeting in the Primary School library on 11 June. Four members gave speeches.

Burra Burra DC, 4 June. Burra Football Club was granted permission to extend the tea room at the oval.

91, 24 (2), 24 June 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1968.]

Heart Fund Door Knock Appeal in Burra, run by Rural Youth, raised over $500.

Willalo School will benefit by c. $180 from a dance in Willalo Hall on Saturday night.

Mr C.G. (Con.) Hartnett visited Burra last week. He was born there 65 years ago to Jerry & Kate Hartnett. The tailoring business of Mr Jeremiah Hartnett was conducted in the building now housing the museum. Mr Stan Woollacott showed Mr Hartnett over the old family home. Mr Hartnett recently retired as Deputy Director of the Department of Decentralisation and Development in NSW.

Obituary. The body of missing Peterborough man, Mr Noel Rowe, a retired grazier, was recovered from a 200 ft shaft at the Golden Junction Mine near Oodlawirra yesterday afternoon. Mr Rowe had been missing since the previous weekend and his car was found near the mine on Friday.

[Noel Lawrence Rowe born 21 February 1919 Peterborough: died 15 June 1969 near Oodlawirra, residence Peterborough.]

Accident. A car in which three young Broken Hill men were travelling overturned near Hallett on Saturday at about 6.30 a.m. Driver Jeffery Colley (20) and his brother Graham (17) were treated at Burra Hospital for head injuries and Barry Squire (21) was sent to the RAH with spinal injuries.

Burra Golf Associates held their Open Day on Thursday 19 June. Results:

‘A’ Grade Championship Mrs D. Baker

‘B’ Grade Championship Mrs H. Prior

‘C’ Grade Championship Mrs R. Hillman

‘C’ Grade 1st 9 Mrs D. Woods

‘C’ Grade 2nd 9 Mrs R. Hillman

‘B’ Grade 9 Hole Handicap (afternoon) Mrs B. Scholz

‘C’ Grade 9 Hole Handicap (afternoon) Mrs L. Sobels

Team event Hallett, comprising Mesdames Prior, Phin & Disher

Fire. A caravan owned by Mr K.R. Phillips of Burra was destroyed by fire while being towed to Basin Farm on Wednesday.

91, 25 (2), 1 July 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1968.]

Burra Young Liberals Held their AGM at Clare on 18 June. Elected: President, Paul Kirchner; Vice-President, Michael Smith; Secretary, Dianna Lines and Treasurer, Andrew Sandow.

Telephone Lines

[Inadequate capacity existed for the demand for services between Willalo, Spalding and Booborowie and between Booborowie and Mt Bryan.] The Director of Posts and Telegraphs Mr J.R. O’Sullivan wrote in response to a query from Mr E.C. Allen MP explaining the situation and indicating that additional lines would be provided in the 1970-71 financial year.

Accident. A cow owned by P. & R. Stockman of Burra and valued at $100 was killed when struck by a car driven by Mr Herb White of Mongolata on the Burra-Mongolata Road. Damage to the car was estimated at $350.

Advt. A TAB Sub-Agency, attached to the Clare Agency, will operate from Hurley’s Road House, Burra, from Wednesday 2 July.

91, 25 (2), 1 July 1969, pages 1 & 6 [This number used before in 1968.]

N.R. Brand of Smelts Road, Burra, writes concerning a National Conference on Education held on Saturday in Adelaide. He complains that the conference received notice in the Advertiser ‘in that day’. He goes on the outline the points made at the conference. Check to see if it received no notice.

91, 25 (2), 1 July 1969, page 2 [This number used before in 1968.]

Burra High School visiting night was successful in drawing a high number of parents and friends last Thursday night.

The Footbridge across the Burra Creek near the Bowling Green is expected to be open to pedestrians tomorrow or Thursday. The old bridge was unsafe and was removed several weeks ago. Mr Thamm constructed the new bridge, which was placed in position by DC plant units. It has a 62 ft span.

[It had been closed in April. See 91, 12 (2), 1 Apr. 1969, page 4.]

Notice. J.L.N. Winter, liquidator for Fiebig Motors (Burra) Pty Ltd invites tenders for the purchase of the business or for the assets of the business in separate lots.

91, 25 (2), 1 July 1969, page 3 [This number used before in 1968.]

Ian Masters of Elders-GM has been transferred to Peterborough and Geoff Hams from Peterborough replaces him at Burra.

91, 26 (3), 8 July 1969, page 1 [This number used twice in 1968.]

Burra Burra DC Elections for Burra Town Ward. There was a 48% turnout.

R. Jeffery 177

R.B. Jennison 168

E.T. Baulderstone 138

C.L. Phillips 126

R.E. Angel 116

N.W. Orford 45

L.H. Packer 34

The first three were elected. Elections were not needed in the other wards.

N.R. Brand writes complaining about the lack of attendance at the Burra Swimming Pool Management Committee when only nine people attended, causing a postponement to 25 September. This lack of interest is causing problems in getting the pool opened on schedule – or indeed at all.

Adelaide Wool Sales. Returns were down 21⁄2%. Alexandrina Ltd with wool from Sturt Vale got top district price with 551⁄4c for AAA M. [Other local district prices are printed.]

Boy Scouts. A meeting is called for 17 July to see if there is sufficient interest to form a Boy Scout Group.

91, 26 (3), 8 July 1969, pages 1 & 5 [This number used twice in 1968.]

Burra LCL Women’s Branch held its AGM and elected: President, Mrs R.K. Pearse; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames J.T. Drew & W. Miller; Secretary, Mrs R. Collins; Assistant Secretary, Mrs J. Collins and Treasurer, Mrs R. Dunn. The guest speaker was Sir Thomas Playford. Sir Thomas spoke of the difficulties facing the LCL at this time:

Competition in overseas markets for primary products at a time of rising production costs.

The redistribution of electoral boundaries

Previously the country has 26 seats and the city 13

Now the country has 19 seats and the city 28.

Mr & Mrs Bill Wood of Booborowie have good news concerning two of their sons. Their third son received the Michegan Trophy for best all-round sportsman at the passing out parade at Fort Largs Police Academy recently. Their second son Petty Officer R.S. Wood of HMAS Melbourne suffered no ill effects from the vessel’s collision with a US destroyer.

91, 27 (2), 15 July 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1968.]

Weather. Patchy rain has fallen on Friday & Saturday last and extended to the east. Burra recorded 65 points, Braemar 28, Pine Valley 65, Old Koomooloo 68, Woolgangi 72, Oak Vale 50 and Mallett 47.

Booborowie District wants a separate bus run for Booborowie Primary School. At present students travel on the same bus that brings students to Burra High School. This means an earlier start and a later finish.

91, 28 (2), 22 July 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1968.]

Weather. On 21 July an inch of rain with some hail and fairly heavy snow fell throughout the district. The rain began about 5 p.m. Sunday and continued to about 3 a.m. when heavy hail fell. Snow began to fall at about 7.10 a.m. becoming quite heavy by 7.30 a.m. and continuing until 8.15 a.m. Burra and the surrounding hills were covered in snow. At Hallett it lay two to three inches deep for miles and also at Mt Bryan, where it remained on the Mount till late afternoon. Snow was also reported at Clare, Mintaro, Whyte Yarcowie, Booborowie and Farrell Flat, where there was a further light fall at 2.30 p.m.

In the hills between Mt Bryan and Booborowie it lay six inches deep for some time. The main street of Burra was covered by three to four inches. Mr George Fairchild reported heavy snow on the Booborowie mail run via Leighton. Power failures were reported from Booborowie, Mt Bryan and Hallett. Between Waterloo and Burra power interruptions have occurred in the past few days, but magpies were to blame, having been building nests with short lengths of fencing wire. It was generally said to be the heaviest fall of snow for at least 40 years and possibly since 1901. It will easily be remembered as occurring on the same day man first set foot upon the moon. Burra’s 105 points of rain includes 21 points of snow.

Thefts. In the past six months the theft of sheep from Burra properties has been prevalent. The police are only now discovering that a large number of missing sheep have not been reported.

91, 28 (2), 22 July 1969, page 2 [This number used before in 1968.]

91, 27 (3), 29 July 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1968 & 1969.]

The Burra Show this year will be opened by the Minister of Agriculture Hon. C.R. Story. A new activity will be a shearing competition organised by Mr Tony Ryan.

Weather. Burra’s rainfall for the week totalled 178 points. Mt Bryan reported patches of snow remaining till yesterday from last week’s fall.

Burra Mine

The MP, Hon. G.J. Gilfillan made a statement and asked a question in Parliament, of the Minister of Mines. He said that previously the lage low grade deposit of copper ore at Burra had been considered too expensive to treat to be a viable operation. Now further experiments had taken place. He asked: ‘Can the Minister say whether sufficient progress has been made to make the extraction of such ore a commercial proposition?’

The Hon. R.C. DeGaris confirmed the problem and said a process called the Glyserol Process had been shown by CSIRO to work in the laboratory. The Government is examining the process at the Australian Mineral Development Laboratories to see if it is practical as a commercial operation and results are awaited.

91, 27 (3), 29 July 1969, page 2 [This number used before in 1968 & 1969.]

Advt. Elders-GM will auction Nariowie on instructions from Mr C.T.K. Turner. It is located 12 miles south of Burra comprising sections 158-163, 167-168 & 172-173 Hd Apoinga, totalling 1,174 acres freehold.

Burra RSL Hall 22 August.

Advt. Southern Farmers will auction the property ‘Petherton’ Mt Bryan on instructions from F.H. Treweeke, comprising 2,251 acres freehold and located 61⁄2 miles northwest of Mt Bryan. To be offered in two lots:

Lot 1. ‘Homestead’ 746 acres sections 539 Hd Anne and 533 Hd Hallett.

Lot 2. 1,505 acres comprising sections 550, 567, 551, Pts 566, 114 & 25, 39 Hd Ayers.

91, 28 (3), 5 Aug. 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1968 & 1969.]

Freedom From Hunger Campaign

Attendance at a public meeting on Thursday was disappointing. A new committee was formed in Burra to address the challenge. Rev. Milton Edwards is Chairman of the District Committee.

Mr E.C. Allen, MP for Burra, is pushing for lights or reflecting strips on the sides of goods and passenger vehicles on trains following a recent accident. [The railways officials and government firmly resisted this idea.]

The Burra District Swimming Club & Burra Football Club have been granted use of the Burra Town Hall on 30 August and 4 October and pictures will be cancelled on those nights. Some people argue that the pictures are run at a loss and the hall could be let more often for other functions. Picture attendances have improved somewhat since the hall modifications have been completed. There are at present no intentions to further disrupt the pictures.

The Burra Schools have poor water pressure making the additional fire hydrant installed last winter ineffective. The E & WS Department will provide an alternative feed by laying a main across the creek from the Telephone Exchange.

Bruce Stockman was successful in the recent SA Porker & Baconer Carcass Competition. He was 4th in the Porker Section from 15 entries. It is the first time he has entered.

Football. North Eastern League

‘A’ Grade Burra 6.10 defeated Booborowie 2.8

91, 29 (2), 12 Aug. 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1968.]

A Boy Scout Troop may be established in Burra. About 40 enthusiastic boys and six parents attended a meeting on Friday in the Town Hall. The Clare Troop would provide guidance and leadership for the first six months. The co-operation of a solid body of parents id needed and the willingness of persons to fill the vital positions of Club Leader, Scout Master and Group Scout Leader.

A new Burra Police Station will be built on the site of the existing station and police residence in Chapel Street. Whether it will include court accommodation is not known.

Matthews Emporium has purchased the adjoining Gill’s Store. It is expected that a new frontage for the whole building and extensive modifications will enable the store to hold greater drapery stocks and a complete range of furniture and furnishings.

Burra Swimming Pool will be aided by the Kapunda Musical Society’s production of The White Horse Inn at the Burra Town Hall on 4 October at 8 p.m.

91, 29 (2), 12 Aug. 1969, page 8 [This number used before in 1968.]

Football. North Eastern League

‘A’ Grade Clare North 9.14 defeated Burra 7.8

Hallett 12.11 defeated Booborowie 11.11

Clare South 15.10 defeated Spalding 13.12

‘B’ Grade Burra 11.19 defeated Clare North 7.2

Clare South drew with Spalding 6.7 each

Colts Clare North 14.11 defeated Burra 3.2

Junior Colts Burra 3.5 defeated Clare North 2.1

Hallett 7.11 defeated Booborowie 1.0

91, 30 (2), 19 Aug. 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1968.]

Methodists from the Burra Circuit met in the Redruth Sunday School Hall on Sunday to consider the practical issues facing the local church. The presence of two churches in Burra has been an issue since the 1957 Methodist Conference sanctioned the amalgamation of the Kooringa and Redruth Circuits. It was now evident that enough people were convinced that a complete union in the circuit was needed and the discussion had to consider the closing down of one of the centres of worship. 64 people attended in the morning session and 50 in the afternoon. The discussion resulted in four recommendations:

The church worship and Sunday school should be in one property and that should be the larger Burra [Kooringa] Church.

The other property would be the focus of all the fellowship groups – for all business meetings, educational meetings, adult and youth groups and the guild meetings.

The surplus church (whichever was ultimately decided upon) should be offered to the Lutheran Church, should they desire to take control of it.

The Burra Guilds should unite.

Rev. Milton Edwards was pleased with the growing sense of unity and of strengthening ties within the circuit.

A Burra Boy Scout Troop came a step closer when 13 parents visited Clare Troop on Friday as observers. A parent committee was formed afterwards to advance the cause: Chairman, Rev. Milton Edwards; Secretary, Peter Mengersen; Treasurer, Rob Mason; Group Scout Master, Brian Ashdown. Gordon Webster and Bill Barker have expressed willingness to be Scout Masters. The Committee would like to hear from those willing to lead a Scout Troop or Cub Pack. Women Cub Leaders are most acceptable. Two possibilities for Scout Rooms are the old Methodist property at Hanson or the Burra Salvation Army Citadel.

Burra Gold Club Open Day was held on Sunday and drew 102 players.

Open winner H. McKeough of Marrabel

‘A’ Grade 18 Hole Handicap W. Mosey

‘A’ Grade 9 Hole Handicap M. Pearce

‘B’ Grade 27 Hole Championship R. Hillman

‘B’ Grade 18 Hole Handicap R. Hillman

‘B’ Grade 9 Hole Handicap P. McColl

‘C’ Grade 27 Hole Championship H. Willard

‘C’ Grade 18 Hole Handicap H. Willard

‘C’ Grade 9 Hole Handicap C. Porter

Teams Match Spalding No. 3

Burra Golf Club. Stan Longford defeated Jack Bogisch on Saturday to become Club Champion for 1969.

Union of Councils. A recent meeting has decided to unite the District Councils of Saddleworth and Upper Wakefield to form the District Council of Saddleworth & Auburn. [Further details are given.]

Birth. To Andrew & Wendy Bence, a son. Andrew is at present serving in Vietnam.

Obituary. Mrs B.H. Kleinig.

[Bernard Herbert Kleinig’s first wife (Antonie Hedwig Schoenberg) died in 1956 and this wife: Minna Elsa Kleinig died 15 August 1969 Burra, residence Burra North. She seems likely to have been born Minna Elsa Radke 30 June 1900 Robertstown, but there is no CD of marriages for the date required.]

Obituary. Mr Herb. Billing of Booborowie died last week.

[Herbert Arthur Billing was born 27 July 1898 according to a family history of the descendants of Thomas Sargent, but his birth was not registered in SA. He died 13 August 1969 Booborowie aged 71.]

91, 30 (2), 19 Aug. 1969, page 4 [This number used before in 1968.]

Bowls. The 1968-69 Burra Bowls season was summed up by the club President Mr M.G. Stockman in c. 11⁄4 columns. Shades at the greens had been improved. The outside of the clubhouse and the seats and forms had been painted. The Mayor E.T. Baulderstone opened the season. The Club Championship was won by Bill Corner. The Easter Tournament was a great success. The Associates were again a great help to the club and made a nice donation of $391. The greens were kept in excellent condition.

Football. North Eastern League

‘A’ Grade Burra 18.25 defeated Spalding 7.8

Booborowie 18.16 defeated Clare South 9.5

91, 31 (2), 26 Aug. 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1968.]

Burra Burra DC has adopted a new assessment with a total assessment value of $7,325, 130. In most cases the rating will be lower in the Town Ward than previously. There has been a proposal to improve the Town Hall by adding toilet facilities and building administration offices on the vacant land adjoining the hall. It has been found that the new Council, having eleven elected members and at least two officers with the Clerk and Overseer, meetings can build up to 15 members, which is greater than the present offices can accommodate. Office staff are cramped for room and storage is inadequate. [The rate for the Town Ward was 10c from a notice on page 6.]

New Sale Yards. Oates Ltd is erecting new yards in tubular steel on land recently acquired on the by-pass road at Burra North. Construction should be completed by A.J. Stock & Co. of Adelaide by the end of next week and the yards opened by R.J. Jeffery Chairman of the Burra Burra DC before the market opens on 5 September at 1 p.m.

C.T.K. Turner’s ‘Nariowie’ 12 miles south of Burra was passed in at $54.00 [per acre] when auctioned on 22 August. It was later bought by P.F. & T.C. Ross of Emu Downs for an undisclosed sum.

Property in the Estate of E.T. Phillips was also passed in at auction and later bought by A.W. Arbon of Mundoora for an undisclosed sum.

91, 31 (2), 26 Aug. 1969, page 2 [This number used before in 1968.]

Bon Accord Bridge. An interstate truck driver was fined for driving a truck carrying over 10 tons across the bridge, which has a 3 ton limit.

Accidents. On Thursday a PMG vehicle driven by R. Spackman collided with a car driven by Mrs D. Cockington near the Burra Post Office.

On the same day a car driven by Herbert Fridd of Burra North collided with one driven by Mr G. Male of Burra near the modern Meat Store. Damage to both cars was minor.

A dog or Dogs mauled five lambs paddocked near the Pig and Whistle crossing on Saturday night and the sheep, owned by Mr Chris Queissner had to be destroyed.

Obituary. Mrs Jim Lomman was buried at Booborowie on Saturday. She was living at Balaklava, but was formerly of Booborowie. [Ethel Cecilia Elizabeth Lomman died 22 August 1969 Balaklava aged 74. On death registration said to be widow of Francis James Lomman, but no marriage on SA CD. The only woman with these given names seems to have been born Ethel Cecelia [sic] Elizabeth Slee 12 June 1895 Melrose, making her the right age, but she married Edward William John Summers in 1917. He died in 1949, so Jim Lomman could be a second marriage. The husband is equally elusive. Births suggest a Francis Joseph or a Frederick James. The latter was of Booborowie 1892-1962, but any marriage is after available CD dates.]

Kevin Kleinig took up a position with Southern Farmers in Burra yesterday.

Marriage. Blair Athol Methodist Church 1 September

Ann Beckwith, daughter of Mrs Melva Beckwith of Blair Athol and formerly of Mt Bryan, will marry

Spencer Langman.

91, 32 (2), 2 Sep. 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1968.]

Burra Hospital held its AGM. Chairman R.K. Pearse claimed the Hospital had the lowest fees of Government subsidised hospitals in SA. The Hospital was in a sound financial position.

Photo of Mr C. Griffiths, Burra plumber, at a roofing trade fair at Clare recently. Also shown are Mr Lietzke of R.H. Lietzke & Son of Adelaide, R.G. Sutton a Booborowie farmer and Mr Les. Hore a plumber from Balaklava.

Accident. A car driven by R.P. Gebert of Hanson overturned on the Booborowie-Hanson Road on Friday in heavy fog. The driver escaped injury.

Burra Boy Scouts

The Group Committee now numbers 12 adults. The committee has decided the old Methodist Church property at Hanson is an ideal location and the ten minute drive from Burra is not considered significant. Negotiations with the trustees are under way. The advantages are that the Cubs and Scouts can each have a separate building and can meet simultaneously. Equipment can be left in situ from one meeting to the next. The distance will test scout and parent loyalty to the cause and the necessary roster to get scouts to the site will cement parent involvement. The first meeting of the First Burra Boy Scout Troop and the First Burra Cub Pack is scheduled for Friday 26 September. Parents are urged to attend. Registered Scout Leaders to date are Mr G. Webster, Mr W. Barker, Mr W. Salter and Cub Leader is Mrs I. Tamassy. Costs are 50 cents on nomination and 10c per night. Uniforms will not be required for four or five months, which is time enough to predict the success or failure of the venture.

91, 32 (2), 2 Sep. 1969, pages 1 & 4 [This number used before in 1968.]

Burra Primary School Gale Evening at the Burra Town Hall on Thursday raised over $300.

[The whole report runs to c. 2 columns.]

Advt. Burra Pictures, 6 September

Don Knotts & Joan Staley in The Ghost and Mr Chicken

Booborowie people are moving to establish a Bowling Club.

Petty Officer Russell Wood RAN, son of Bill & Carol Wood of Booborowie was married recently in Sydney before he and his wife left for the USA where Russell is taking a special course on guided missiles in Illinois.

Birth. To Pat & Ron Gebert of Hanson, a son, Darren Scott, born last week.

Don Murray, living at the Burra Hospital is 90 today.

Mrs Mary Heinrich is 91 on 3 September.

91, 32 (2), 2 Sep. 1969, page 4 [This number used before in 1968.]

Burra Burra Hospital Inc. The Chairman R.K. Pearse presented the 92nd Annual Report.

The financial position was very sound. [Details are given.]

No major improvements were made in 1969. The total cost of the Alice Collins Wing was $98,892 and payment of $2,392 was yet to be made.

An intensive care unit has been installed and thanks go to generous donations from the late Mrs G.S. Hawker, Mr F. Reed and Mr J. Barker towards that unit. This is the only intensive care unit in a Government Subsidised Hospital in SA. A new ironing machine has been placed in the laundry, the parking area has been fenced and heating installed in the kitchen and domestic dining room. There are plans in the hands of the Hospital Department to modernise the Maternity Wing and kitchen. The cropping program this year delivered $1,307. We continue to be indebted to Mrs S. Scroop and her energetic helpers in the Auxiliary. Staffing remains difficult.

91, 32 (2), 2 Sep. 1969, page 7 [This number used before in 1968.]

Burra Show. The prize money for the shearing competition has been increased to $200.

Football. Don Villis, Captain of Booborowie, has won the Burra Record Trophy as runner-up for the Mail Medal. Barry Eberhard of Burra won the Mail Medal.

Adelaide Wool Sales saw little change in values. Willogoleche Ltd Hallett got the top district price of 55c.

[Other local district prices are printed.]

Weather. Light rains in the week brought 65 points to Burra, but did not extend to the east.

Vandalism. Two pages have been torn from the Visitors’ Book in the Historic Room on Friday. No other damage is evident. [At St Mary’s? Check.]

91, 34 (2), 16 Sep. 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1968.]

Weather. Rain was general throughout the district with falls in agricultural areas of 121 points at Burra to 146 at Farrell Flat. To the east falls were also good, ranging from 50 to 95 points.

Rev. A.M. Jackson, President of the Methodist State Conference, will visit Burra Circuit for a fellowship meal on Friday 19 September.

Burra Police station & Court House

In answer to a question in Parliament the Hon. J.W.H. Coumbe replied that the new premises in Burra will combine a residence, sergeant’s office and separate cell block. The general police office will be used for certain minor court actions, but the Burra North Court House will be retained for general court purposes. Tenders to improve acoustics there are a separate matter and planning is continuing with tenders expected to be called at an early date.

Burra to Adelaide cycling Classic will be held this Saturday. 21 riders will start in the 100 mile handicap departing Market Square at 10 a.m. and travelling via Manoora, Saddleworth, Riverton, Tarlee, Kapunda, Greenock, Daveyston, Sheoak Log, Gawler By-Pass to finish at Waterloo Corner.

Burra RSL will conduct a snooker tournament as soon as possible.

91, 34 (2), 16 Sep. 1969, page 2 [This number used before in 1968.]

‘D’ Grade Spalding 18 defeated Burra 14.

In ‘A’ Grade the Best &Fairest Trophy went to D. Day of Burra.

Marie Wisbey. Marie’s father managed John Martin’s store at Booborowie many years ago.

91, 34 (2), 16 Sep. 1969, page 6 [This number used before in 1968.]

Advt. Burra Pictures, 20 September

Grand Prix

Jack Lines has turned 90. An item is reprinted from the Barrier Miner of 9 May.

Mr Lines was born in Burra and has been associated with the pastoral industry for 58 years. He worked as a station hand on Mulyungari Station 70 miles west of Broken Hill. He fought in the Boer War and is now a resident of the War Veterans’ Home. He also worked on Welcome Change Station in NSW for Mr Oakes.

[Born 8 May 1879, Kooringa. He served 8th Battalion Australian Commonwealth Horse. Departed Australia. 26 May 1902. Arrived in South Africa after end of war and arrived back in Australia 24 July 1902.]

91, 34 (2), 16 Sep. 1969, page 7 [This number used before in 1968.]

Football. Voting figures for the Mail Medal and the Burra Record Trophy are printed.

Obituary. Barry Robert Angel died at Burra Hospital 13 September 1969 aged 22. He was the son of Audrey and Bob Angel and brother to Heather, Cheryl and Stephen.

Obituary. Mrs Hilda Grace Pryde of Spalding died at Jamestown Hospital on 21 July aged 86. She was born Hilda Grace Miller at Leighton 1 July 1883 and married David Pryde in 1908.

[SA Births CD shows her birth as Halda Grace Miller 3 July 1883 Leighton, but that may be a transcription error.]

Burr-Adelaide Cycling Race was won by 45-year-old Norwood professional cyclist Colin Shaw who started off 9 minutes.

Ian Fisk, a native of British Columbia, has been appointed to Burra High School.

Elizabeth Sutton of Booborowie will marry Ron Callary of Hilltown.

Obituary. Mrs Nellie Bloyd, wife of the late Rev. S. Bloyd, a former Rector of Burra many years ago, died last week. [Born Nellie Bessie Allen 13 December 1884 New Thebarton: died 16 September 1969 Grange. She married Sydney John Bloyd (c. 1878-1941) in 1905.]

91, 35 (3), 23 Sep. 1969, page 6 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Advt. Burra Pictures, 27 September

Ann Bancroft & Dustin Hoffman in The Graduate

John Saxon & Robert Redford in War Hunt

91, 36 (3), 30 Sep. 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Police Cadet K.R. Harris, son of Mr & Mrs M. Harris of Burra North, was presented with the Advertiser Efficiency Trophy upon graduation on Thursday.

Burra Primary School had a tree planting afternoon on Friday. Since Arbor Day is no longer held, this event was a preliminary to Conservation Day to be held on 10 October. Each class and each school house planted a tree. [Planters are listed.]

Princess Royal Homestead is featured in October’s Walkabout Magazine, with an article and cover photo. Ian Auhl wrote the text. The article is based on the forthcoming book Historic Homesteads of Australia in which five SA homesteads appear. Mt & Mrs Andrew Tennant have agreed to open their house and grounds for inspection on Sunday 16 November. Proceeds will aid the National Trust branch in Burra.

Architecture in Australia magazine for August featured a four-page article on Burra’s buildings, written by Adelaide architect R.N. Ward, based on information from Ian Auhl and with sketches by Maurice Perry.

Burra Sketchbook with text by Ian Auhl and sketches by Maurice Perry will soon be published by Rigby. Burra is the first SA country town to feature in the sketchbook series.

RSL Snooker Tournament has been drawn up and is about to start.

Burra Swimming Pool Committee had a well-attended meeting on Thursday and elected: President, Mr Phil Lannan; Secretary, Mr Gerry Baulderstone and Treasurer, Miss Elaine Broderick.

Burra Boy Scouts had their first meeting on Friday evening at the former Methodist Church property at Hanson. Twenty-five parked cars indicated an unusual gathering. 26 Cubs and 24 Scouts were inside for their induction to the organisation. Mr Maurice Davey the District Commissioner presided. Over 30 parents also attended and were thanked by the Chairman of the Parents’ Committee Rev. Milton Edwards. At the next meeting Hon. C.R. Kelly MHR will present the group with a flag (17 October).

Cycling. Brian Gould (photo) top SA and former Broken Hill cyclist will attempt to lower the 39-year-old Broken Hill-Adelaide cycling record on 3 & 4 October and will stop in Burra for 10 minutes. The record was set 6 September 1930 by Jack (Count) Stafford who covered the 314 miles in 22 hours 40 minutes. His route will follow the highway to Broken Hill via Oodlawirra, Terowie, Burra (c. 8 a.m. Saturday), Manoora, Riverton, Tarlee, Gawler to Adelaide Town Hall. [Details in 3⁄4 column.]

91, 36 (3), 30 Sep. 1969, page 2 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

New Parliamentary Electorate. The ‘Burra’ Electorate will disappear and be absorbed in ‘Frome’, which becomes the second largest in area and the smallest in population in the redistribution. Mr Claude Allen, the present member for Burra, will contest Frome if endorsed by the LCL. [Details of subdivisions and their populations are given.]

Advt. Burra Pictures, 4 October

No Pictures due to the presentation of the operetta White Horse Inn by the Kapunda Musical Society.

Advt. Southern Farmers will conduct a clearing sale of farming plant and earth-moving equipment on 3 October for S.J. Woollacott & Co. at the home property at Burra North.

91, 36 (3), 30 Sep. 1969, page 4 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Burra Tennis Association held its AGM in Booborowie Hall 15 September.

President D. Jones said he regretted that Hallett would not be fielding any teams this season. There will be seven ‘A’ Grade teams, with Spalding fielding two. Eight teams would contest the ‘B’ Grade and there would be seven ‘C’ Grade (Junior) teams. The President reported a successful year financially because of a $104 profit from the Association Ball, which helped them to a credit of $58 for the year. In ‘A’ Grade Mt Bryan were undefeated to win their second successive premiership. In ‘B’ Grade the two Spalding teams dominated. Junior teams remain strong and Mt Bryan won for the third year in succession. At the successful ball Miss Jenny Kleinig of Leighton was Miss Tennis for 1968-69. He noted the regrettable death of Mr Lux Matters, who gave many years of dedicated service to tennis as a player and administrator. [Lancelot Luxford Swann Matters born 5 April 1908, Adelaide: died 21 April 1969 Adelaide, residence Spalding.]

Advt. Oates Ltd will conduct a clearing sale on the property three miles east of Mt Bryan on 2 October for Messrs R.J. & H.I. Jarmyn, whose property they have sold.

91, 36 (3), 30 Sep. 1969, page 5 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Burra Golf Associates. The AGM was held at the clubhouse 17 September.

[Mrs E. Nicholls] as President reported on a very successful season. [She uses only first names in referring to the trophy winners, but Open Day winners are listed at 91, 24 (2), 24 June 1969, page 1.]

Elected were: Patroness, Mrs A.L. Collins; President, Mrs R. Wuttke; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames D. Field & M. Nicholls; Secretary, Mrs R. Hillman; Assistant Secretary, Mrs F. Reed; Treasurer, Mrs R. Gordon; Captain, Mrs J. Oates and Vice-Captain, Mrs J. Wiseman.

91, 36 (3), 30 Sep. 1969, page 6 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Birth. To Joy & Morris Broad at Burra Hospital on Sunday, a daughter, Lesley Anne.

Birth. To Bev & Peter Grindell of Spalding at Jamestown Hospital recently, a son.

Marriage. At Clare Methodist Church next Saturday Jill Przibilla will marry Ron Piggott.

Burra Malachite worth $3,000 was displayed in the basement of Regent Arcade in Adelaide last week as a part of an exhibition of jewellery and gems.

Obituary. Some weeks ago Mr Simon Dollard of Pt Pirie died. He was a brother to Nick Dollard of Burra and a former resident of Leighton.

The ‘A’ & ‘B’ Grade wind-up dinner will be held 18 October when the Best and Fairest trophies will be presented to Dianne Day for ‘A’ Grade and to Ann Matthews for ‘B’ Grade.

Murray Norman Mickel, son of Mr & Mrs N. Mickel of Farrell Flat. The couple will live at Farrell Flat.

91, 36 (3), 30 Sep. 1969, page 8 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Adelaide Wool Sales 16-18 September saw prices largely unchanged. [Local district prices are printed.]

The name Burra is still of doubtful origin, but much of the evidence suggests a Hindustani origin. The name was first used in 1843 by Captain Charles Frome, Surveyor General of SA – two years before copper was discovered. In his Northern Expedition sketch book he has a water colour entitled ‘Shepherd’s Hut on the Burra Creek’. The hut is undoubtedly that of William Streair, who first found copper on the present Princess Royal property. He worked for James Stein, who in 1843 held a lease along the Burra Creek and Indian coolies worked for him and gave the name Burra Burra to the creek – it being Hindustani for big-big or great-great. Streair’s hut was near the present Princess Royal homestead. The directors of Sammie first called their mine Wheal Grey after the Governor, but soon changed it to the Burra Burra Mine. The directors always assumed it to be a Hindustani name without giving a reason. Later it was suggested it was of native origin, but the early evidence points to the Hindustani origin. The collection of towns around the mine gradually came to be called ‘The Burra’, though the name was not used officially until after the opening of the railway station in 1870 and did not come into local use until after the foundation of the Corporation in 1876.

91, 39 (3), 7 Oct. 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.] [Numbers 37 & 38 omitted.]

Burra Mine

Mr E.C. Allen today announced plans for the mining of copper at Burra, as advised him by the Hon. Minister of Mines Mr R.C. De Garis.

A consortium of companies comprising Broken Hill South Ltd, North Broken Hill Ltd, E.Z. Industries Ltd & McPhar Geophysics Pty Ltd, advised they were relinquishing interest in the area after almost four years examining its prospects. The Minister then accepted a proposal from another group, which was prepared to start mining copper at Burra within a few months. Details of this new group are not yet finalised, but the technical staff will be headed by Mr B.H. Lewis, until recently Chief Geologist with Broken Hill South Ltd. The company will be mainly Australian, but Mc Phar Geophysics Pty Ltd of Canada has expressed an interest. The operation will centre upon the recovery of copper by ammoniacal leaching of oxidised ore in and near the old open cut where reserves of c. three million tons of 1.6% copper have been established. Initially they would treat 200 tons per day and would have a labour force of about twenty men. This would be scaled up to 500 to 700 tons per day over 18 months and stabilize at 180-200,000 tons per annum to give the known reserves a life of at least 20 years. This would require a labour force of about 50, which the company would hope to recruit locally. The Minister was delighted with this development.

The re-opening of the mine has long been sought and although this was a comparatively small operation, it would give the town a boost and continued exploration could reveal greater reserves.

Ore would be mined, taken to the crushing plant and then leached with ammonia in 500 ton vats. The process would take about one week per vat. Two vats would be used initially to handle 100 tons per day. The product would be copper oxide. The production of copper sulphate is also being investigated. It is hoped to use natural gas as the heat source required – the nearest connection is 15 miles away.

The open pit operation would involve moving about 700 tons of ore and 1,000 tons of waste per day, or a total of between 1,500 and 2,000 tons of material daily. It was hoped local operators could do this. The aim was for a long-life operation.

The company has been incorporated in the name of SAMIN Ltd. It is a public company formed for the purpose of mining Burra copper ore and having also interests in other states in perhaps lead and tungsten production. As income permits it is intended to continue exploration in the mine area as well as north and south of the deposit. When work began it was expected extraction of ore for four or five days would be followed by seven days of processing using three shifts a day.

Burra Football Club held a wind-up dinner-dance for the season in the Burra Town Hall on Friday night. Club trophies were presented:

Best & Fairest ‘A’ Grade went to Barry Eberhard

Best and Fairest in ‘B’ Grade went to Alan Day.

The ‘B’ Grade team received the ANZ Shield as premiers.

Burra on Canvas. Twenty-two artists displayed their works on Burra at the Burra Hotel on Friday evening. All except the spritely 75-year-old Miss A. McNamara were amateurs. The group was welcomed on Thursday by Council Chairman Mr Roy Jeffery. The works were executed in a variety of media. The group has such an outing annually and has previously visited Pt McDonnell and the Flinders Ranges (twice).

The White Horse Inn performance by the Kapunda Musical Society attracted an appreciative audience and it was a fine night’s entertainment. Half the takings will benefit the Burra Swimming Pool.

91, 39 (3), 7 Oct. 1969, page 3 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Cycling Record. The 30-year-old cyclist Brian Gould broke the 39-year-old record for the Broken Hill-Adelaide distance by covering it in 5 hours 4 minutes less than the 1930 time of 22 hours 40 minutes. He left Broken Hill at 6 p.m. Friday. He stopped for ten minutes in Burra. He covered the 314 miles in 17 hours 36 minutes.

[Details in 11⁄2 columns.]

Local Crime. Two break-ins on Thursday night have been reported.

Burra Motor Co. in Thames St was entered and thieves used the company’s own oxy-torch on the safe to steal c. $60.

At the Burra Hotel a window was forced and c. $25 taken from the till.

Attempts to enter T.W. Wilkinson’s & Co. and the Burra Stationers were unsuccessful.

Accident. A truck driven by Brian Kakoschke overturned at or near Terowie early on Friday morning. The driver went to Peterborough Hospital, but is now home.

Adelaide Wool Sales saw values fall c. 21⁄2%. [Local district prices are printed.]

Burra High School

When asked by Mr Allen whether she would consider a new school for Burra in the light of the expected boost to the town from the re-opening of the Mine, the Minister the Hon. Joyce Steele said yes. The High School shares the old building with the Primary School, plus a number of temporary classrooms.

Mr W.A. White, President of the SA Institute of Teachers, spoke in the Burra High School Hall on 30 September on the crisis in SA education under the heading Deficiencies in Education. Mr N. Brand, Senior Master at the High School, also spoke on the local problems with make-shift specialist rooms, lack of science facilities, overcrowding in temporary buildings, lack of planning in the yard and poor physical education facilities. Mr Wood, Head Teacher at Booborowie, also spoke, saying he thought Primary Schools were the ‘Cinderella’ of the Education Department and small schools fared worse than larger ones. Other problems were the stresses of multi-grade classes, the need to be teacher-drivers and accommodation difficulties.

Russell McDonald writes from NSW in appreciation of receiving the Record while serving in the Army. He was at Burra for schooling and his parents now live at Redcliffe Station.

Burra Burra DC has appointed a Health & Building Inspector to report on all premises and where necessary to require repairs and renovations. Many old houses and other buildings are cracked and have damp walls and lack proper bathrooms and toilets. It is important for tourism that eyesores are eliminated. These also lower the value of adjoining properties.

91, 40 (3), 14 Oct. 1969, pages 1 & 8 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Burra Show. Burra Show was held in perfect weather on Saturday. The shearing competition and improved pavilion exhibits made it the best show for some time. It was opened by the Minister of Agriculture Mr C.R. Story. There were nearly 500 hoses-in-action entries. President Mr Rex Stockman introduced Mr Story.

The industrial sites provided a varied display of vehicles, household appliances and rural equipment.

Exhibits in the two pavilions were exceptional this year. The Art Section was up by 70, Photography by 36, Cookery by 140, Flowers 85, Floral Art 62, Needlework 119 and Produce by 90.

The School Display was commendable. The Rural Youth display was of the Wool Industry.

Entries were a record 2,986, beating the 1967 total of 2,778.

In the shearing contest winners were:

Novice: Tim Kakoschke

Open & Mid North Championship: J. Hutchins (Currently Australian Champion).

Sideshows were disappointing both in number and variety.

91, 40 (3), 14 Oct. 1969, page 7 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Burra Mine

A meeting at Burra Town Hall on Friday was arranged by the Burra Burra DC to consider the implications of the re-opening of the mine and the impact on historical buildings there. The Directors of the new company were anxious to give information to the district as soon as possible.

Mr Claude Allen said that on 10 January 1966 the then Minister of Mines Mr S.C. Bevan accepted a proposal from Mines Exploration Ltd to commence test drilling. The present Minister gave them till 16 September 1969 to decide on continuing. They declined and SAMIN will commence preliminary operations shortly. With respect to Mr Ian Auhl’s concerns expressed in the Advertiser about the protection of historic buildings he said several years would pass before decisions had to be made, but every care would be taken to preserve whatever was possible. It is the opinion of those concerned that tourism and mining operations can work together.

It is anticipated the company is likely to pay about $50,000 per annum to the Council in royalties. Mr E.T. Baulderstone asked about what would happen to waste water.

Mr Lewis said it would be recirculated or run into the creek as pure soft water. With 70-80,000 gallons used each day, the creek could be dammed to hold water six to ten feet deep and it could also be used to beautify the banks with lawns and shrubs etc. Jobs would be offered to locals, but outsiders could be brought in if needed. It was thought only two or three female workers would be required. (Probably in laboratory work.)

It was likely the mine would hasten a decision on building a new High School.

Table Tennis. North Eastern Grand Finals

‘A’ Grade Willalo Gold 11 sets defeated Spalding 10 sets

‘B’ Grade Spalding 12 sets defeated Burra Blue 9 sets

91, 40 (3), 14 Oct. 1969, page 8 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Burra Small Bore Club. Double 25 yards shoot on Saturday 5 October:

Best were M. Thomas, J. Bowden & P. Mengersen.

On 7 October over 50 yards the best were L. Moore, P. Mengersen & M. Thomas.

Mrs L. Flynn of Pennington SA writes seeking information on the family of John & Mary Treweek for a family tree project. They migrated from England to Enfield SA and then to Hallett c. 1872 to c. 1878, where he was a blacksmith. Mrs Flynn’s mother was Mary Treweek who married Andrew Tobin of Burra.

Burra Mine. Mr Allen MP asked a question in Parliament concerning the possibility of a gas line from the main pipeline to Burra. He also corrected a mistake in the newspaper report, which said production would increase to 500-700 tons per day over 18 months to stabilize at 200,000 tons a year and this would yield 200 tons of copper metal per annum. Actually it will yield 2,000 tons of copper metal valued at $3 million. Initially the company will use fuel oil so will the Minister take up the question of supplying natural gas to the mine? The Hon. F.W.H. Coumbe undertook to bring the matter to the attention of the Natural Gas Pipeline Authority.

91, 41 (3), 21 Oct. 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

The Princess Royal Visit by members of the National Trust has had to be postponed due to the illness of Mr Andrew Tennant.

Mr Ian Auhl & Mr Maurice Perry have collaborated to produce a second series of cards with sketches of Burra sights. They are available with or without Christmas greetings at 75c for a set of 5.

Accident. A semi-trailer transporting an eighteen-ton crane unit lost its load four miles east of Burra on the Morgan Road on Sunday. The vehicle was driven by Mr Franz Mattasch and was going from Perth to Melbourne. The Council grader and two heavy jacks were used to assist in putting the unit back onto its wheels. Both the tray of the semi and the crane sustained considerable damage.

91, 41 (3), 21 Oct. 1969, pages 1 & 6 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

91, 41 (3), 21 Oct. 1969, pages 1 & 3 (unnumbered) & 10 (numbered 3)

[This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Spalding Centenary Celebrations are reported.

91, 41 (3), 21 Oct. 1969, page 3 [unnumbered] [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

T.G. Perry writes. [He is responding to an assertion apparently made on a Channel 9 Newsbeat program on 14 October that NOTHING was being done about developing Burra’s tourist potential.]

In 1959-60 the Corporation of Burra purchased the Burra Mine Paddock. With the drive of the Mayor E.T. Baulderstone and the then Town Clerk Mr R. W. Fullgrabe and the co-operation of the District Council the area was provided with access roads and the mine workings were fenced for safety. On Friday 17 November the area was opened as a tourist attraction by the Director of the SA Government Tourist Bureau Mr P.F. Pollnitz. At the same time a souvenir brochure was produced giving historical details. This was followed by investigation of the ore at the site by the Department of Mines and Mines Exploration Ltd. In the time in question the Corporation developed a Caravan Park and a swimming pool. Burra Creek has been improved by the Council and a picnic ground developed on the bank opposite the Caravan Park. A brochure outlining the town’s items of interest is in its second printing. Rev. G.D. Sibly developed a Historical Room at St Mary’s Church. The National Trust has assisted with historical matters in the town and maintains a Museum in the town. It has also helped to restore Redruth Gaol with a subsidy from the Tourist Bureau. Colour slides and gift cards of historic buildings have been made available. The National Trust and Mr Ian Auhl produced one of the National Heritage films presented on ABC TV, dealing with Burra and its historic buildings. Work is presently being done to preserve Burra Miners’ Dugout Homes. With much work from Mr S.J. Woollacott Paxton’s Cottages have begun to be restored. The RAA has improved signage. Improvements have been made to the golf course, bowling green etc. To say nothing is being done is a wild statement born from a lack of investigation. Requirements for the preservation of historic sites and buildings in the re-opening of the mine are being supported.

91, 41 (3), 21 Oct. 1969, page 4 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

The Burra Hospital Ball on Friday in Burra Town Hall was a wonderful success with door takings of $312 and donations of $52. These, with a competition and prior ticket sales ensured a profit of $220. This will attract a two for one subsidy making it effectively $660. The ball was organised by nine staff members with Nurse R. McDonald as Secretary and Nurse W. Anderson as Treasurer. [The report extends for 3⁄4 column.]

Obituary. Keith John (Peter) Hammat died suddenly at Clare Hospital on 13 August after a short illness. He was born in Burra 12 August 1915. He attended Magill Boys School and Scotch College. In 1941 he married Gladys Piggott of Spalding. He worked in his early life on family properties of Bundaleer and Cutana Stations and then settled on land north of Bundaleer. He was an active member of Spalding Amateur Swimming Club, timekeeper with the SA Amateur Swimming Association and officiated at many country carnivals. He was a keen supporter of and a donor to many district projects. In 1966 he was appointed a JP. He is survived by a wife and three sons: Glenn, Robert and Phillip and also by his father J. Hammat of Clare and two sisters, Mesdames Bowman & McPherson.

Accident. A truck travelling towards Morgan collided with a mob of sheep on ‘The Gums’ property on Friday killing 15 of the sheep valued at c. $105, the property of K.R. Phillips Ltd.

Obituary. Rt Rev. Donald Redding died suddenly last week. He was the parish priest of St Mary’s, Burra 1934-38. He later became Bishop of Bunbury. He saw active service in WWI and WW II.

[Donald Llewellyn Redding died 15 October 1969 Plympton aged 71.]

Anthony Human has been a visiting chiropractor to Burra for some years; visiting the town on Thursday s. He has now returned permanently to city life and is succeeded by Brian Jenkins.

91, 42 (3), 28 Oct. 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Bush Fire Threat

The whole district is concerned with the fire hazard this year, which is deemed to be particularly high in the Eastern Pastoral Area where shooters have been prohibited from the entire area. A break will be burnt along the railway line to create a fire break through the whole district.

A Veteran & Vintage Motor Cycle Rally will come to Burra on 1 & 2 November. 38 machines are expected to take part. (32 solo and 6 with sidecars.) [Further details are given.]

Accident. $3,000 damage was done to a semi-trailer when it struck a culvert four miles south of Burra on Thursday. The bogey was torn off and the chassis considerably bent. A crane had to come from Adelaide to clear the road and this took till 2 p.m. Friday.

Adelaide Wool Sales 28-30 October saw values generally unchanged. [Local district prices are printed.]

Fire. A grass fire east of Burra on “Motherall’s” on Sunday was quickly extinguished. It started from an improperly extinguished fire used to cook a meal. [Skewers of rabbit meat were found at the site.]

Veteran Motor Cycles invaded Burra on Saturday as part of the annual rally of the Veteran & Vintage Motor Cycle Club of SA. Some 30 vehicles were involved. [Those taking part and their machines are listed.]

Mrs Roy Jeffery was presented with a bar to her 40-year service medal by Lady Harrison, wife of the Governor, at the annual meeting of the Red Cross Society.

Burra Swimming Pool season opened yesterday. Hillary and Nigel Kirk were first in the water.

Accident. A car driven by Grant Matthews, a bank officer of Pt Augusta, overturned near the entrance to Burra Golf Course on Friday. The driver escaped injury.

Accident. A car driven by Peter McGowan overturned about five miles east of Spalding on the Booborowie Road on Saturday night. He suffered a fractured jaw, but two passengers escaped with minor injuries.

Burra Scouts have set a target of $500 to be raised. So far 50 boys from 39 families are involved in the Cubs or Scouts. Mr Ashdown, Group Master, said the first year would be the most expensive because basic equipment has to be acquired. It is hoped each family might contribute $10 and so avoid the more exhausting forms of fund-raising – though no family is bound to pay that sum. That would leave about $100 to be raised by other means.

Burra Mine

SAMIN Ltd has announced the acquisition of three mineral claims in the Murchison area of WA, containing tungsten reserves. It has acquires 200,000 shares in Poseidon in return for technical services. It will also soon seek to raise $1.75 million through an issue of 3.5 million fully paid 50c shares. McPhar Geophysics Ltd & Western Collieries will participate in this issue considerably and it will also be open to the public.

91, 43 (3), 4 Nov. 1969, page 3 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Advt. Burra Pictures, 8 November

The Ten Commandments

Obituary. Mr John Robert Barker was born 6 November 1895 at Baldina Station nine miles east of Burra. His grandfather Alfred Barker has taken up this property and it had been carried on by his father, William Pitt Barker. When W.P. Barker died in 1914, Mr Barker assumed responsibility and ran Baldina and Grassville stations until his sudden death at Baldina on Friday 31 October. He was associated with many town and district activities. He served as a Councillor on the Mt Bryan DC prior to its amalgamation with the Burra DC, on which he then served for many years. As Councillor for Mongolata Ward. He was for 52 year a trustee of St Mary’s Church, a position his father had held before him. He was keenly interested in sporting bodies and played golf and tennis and was a member of the Burra Sports Association for many years. He continued the family’s long standing active support of the Burra Hospital.

91, 43 (3), 4 Nov. 1969, page 4 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

91, 43 (3), 4 Nov. 1969, page 7 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Booborowie Young Peoples Group raised $150 for M & BHA with a Walkathon.

91, 43 (3), 4 Nov. 1969, page 8 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Mr Allen MP asked in Parliament shy the road eastward between Glenora and Murkaby Stations – about 25 miles – had been upgraded. There had been complaints re destruction of too much vegetation and the dust created. The Hon. Robin Millhouse said the road served a number of stations to the east and into NSW as well as providing links to the north to the Terowie and Broken Hill Road. There were no plans at present to extend the up grade any further.

91, 44 (3), 11 Nov. 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

EFS School was held at Burra. About 100 members of the SA Emergency Fire Services and District Fire Control Officers will attend a one-day school at the Burra Showgrounds on Wednesday 12 November. Instructions will be given in First Aid, Electrical Fire Hazards, Powers and Duties of Fire Control Officers, Recommended EFS Radio Procedure and Chemical Fire Extinguishers.

RSL Snooker tournament is nearing the finals.

Vandalism by irresponsible shooters is concerning residents on the outskirts of town and in the Eastern Pastoral Area. Tanks have been holed and the danger of fire in the east is a general concern.

F-C L. Muldoon has been transferred from Burra to Frances.

Council Amalgamation. Upper Wakefield voters agreed to the amalgamation of their Council with Saddleworth DC by 198 votes to 192 on Saturday.

Melbourne Cup Luncheon

Since 1955 a Melbourne Cup Luncheon has been held to support the Hospital. In that time the committee has raised some $14,000 with Government subsidy. The President of the Committee in 1969 was Mrs L. Bence. Last Tuesday the tradition continued with 200 women at the luncheon in Burra Town Hall, which this year raised over $500.

Burra Small Bore Club. On Sunday the Burra team won the annual teams’ shoot for the Williams’ Shield held at Burra. The shield has been competed for each year for ten years and at last Burra has won it. Burra 2,624 defeated Morgan 2,408 and Clare 2,327. Top scorer for the day was M. Stanley (Morgan) 380.6 and for Burra L. Moore, 351.3.

91, 44 (3), 11 Nov. 1969, page 2 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Advt. Elders-GM will auction 15, 885 acres perpetual lease known as ‘Nolans’ 35 miles east of Burra, comprising Block 64 east of Hundred of King. RSL Hall in Burra on 5 December. Instructions from Dr T.J. Ashton.

T.G. Perry, District Clerk writes to say the Council has instructed him to advise that they strongly support the proposal of Samin Ltd to rework the Burra Mine. During the work it is expected as many of the historic buildings will be preserved as possible. The Council will continue to be in touch with the project, as the mine is on Council property. Council appreciates State Government support through the Department of Mines and the project is a practical application of continued support for country areas. Councillors are in touch with local opinion, which supports the new project.

91, 44 (3), 11 Nov. 1969, page 3 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Cricket

Koonaburra 8 for 171 v. Spalding 9 for 136

North Booborowie 6 for 272 v. Burra Footballers 73

Burra Small Bore Club. Best on 2 November over 50 yards were M. Thomas, L. Moore & P. Mengersen.

Best on 5 November over 50 yards were I. Lovell, P. Mengersen & L. Moore.

91, 44 (3), 11 Nov. 1969, page 4 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Burra Burra DC, 3 November

Burra Cemetery. A letter was presented from the Bishop of Port Pirie re transfer of the [Catholic] cemetery lot. It was resolved that application be made to the Diocese of Pt Pirie to transfer the cemetery lot to this Council with the Council to bear the cost of the transfer.

It was resolved that Council supports the proposals of Samin Ltd to rework the Burra Mine area, but is anxious to see as many of the mining relics as possible preserved.

It was resolved to endorse the Clerk’s decision to give Samin authority to enter the Mine area.

A letter is to be sent to the editors of the Advertiser and the News supporting mining operations.

Resolved that a meeting be arranged with three members of the National Trust to inspect the Mine area and arrange for the removal of historical items.

The fence [along the eastern side of Market Street] between Burra and Burra North is to be removed and cleaned and later a fence will be erected if required.

91, 44 (3), 11 Nov. 1969, page 5 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Birth. To Malcolm & Roslyn Campbell (nee Hogan) at Memorial Hospital 5 November, a daughter, Fiona Jane.

Trevor Denton of Farrell Flat has won the title ‘Australian Pilot of the Year’ at a contest held at Moorabin, Victoria, at the weekend.

Obituary. Alf Gebhardt died last week.

[William Alfred Gebhardt born 19 June 1879 Kooringa: died 4 November 1969 Burra.]

The old wooden fence between Kooringa and Aberdeen (Burra & Burra North) [on the eastern side of Market Street] has been removed.

91, 44 (3), 11 Nov. 1969, page 10 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Burra Golf Club held its AGM in the Clubhouse 5 November.

Only 14 members attended. President John M. Gordon reported on a successful season. Club Championship was won by Stan Longford. Elected: President, J.M. Gordon; Secretary, H. Burnett and Treasurer, T. Jackson.

91, 45 (3), 18 Nov. 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Booborowie Methodist Fair raised $560 [Stallholders and income generated are listed.]

Kooringa Methodist Fete raised $290.70. [The sum raised by each stall is listed.]

Burra Branch of the National Trust has acquired a full-sized colour print of the 1859 William Bentley water colour of the Burra Mine. The original is held by the National Trust in Adelaide. The print is on display in the Market Square Museum.

The Burra Sketch Book by Ian Auhl with sketches by Maurice Perry will be available soon. Mr Auhl has donated his share of any proceeds to the National Trust in Burra.

Burra RSL Snooker Tournament. The final is expected to be played straight after the semi-final on Friday, in which David Bednall will play Ron Wuttke.

Burra Anglican Social Club organised a Wine Tasting Dinner and raised $200 in the Burra Town Hall on Friday night.

Bowls

91, 46 (3), 25 Nov. 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Burra Hospital has been advised by the trustees in the estate of the late John Robert Barker that there is a bequest to the hospital of $70,000 for the purchase of land and the erection of cottage homes for the aged. They are to be known as the Barker of Baldina Cottage Homes and are to be erected on land adjoining the hospital. The suggested model to accommodate 16 persons is ten motel type single units comprising a bed-sitting room, small kitchen, bathroom and private verandah. Two motel type single units slightly larger with the possibility of an additional bed or divan and two double units for couples with a bedroom, living room, kitchen, bathroom and private verandah. Communal facilities will include recreation-living room, laundry, storage and boiler rooms etc. Each unit would have a small flower garden and there would be seven vegetable plots. There would be areas of lawn with shrubs and concrete paths. Each unit would have reticulated hot water radiators and air conditioning. The estimated cost of the project is $108,000.

$90,000 for land and construction costs, eligible for a two for one subsidy.

$14,000 for furnishings and equipment, eligible for a one for one subsidy.

$4,000 for lawn and paths, which would not receive a subsidy.

Of the total the subsidy would amount to approximately $60,000 and the cost to the Hospital would be approximately $50,000. The late Mr Barker’s will also provides for a special donation of one nineteenth of the balance of his residuary estate after certain bequests, to be made available to the Hospital for building or an addition to such Hospital property.

The Burra Benevolent Society has also been advised it will benefit from the J.R. Barker estate.

St Mary’s will hold an advent carol service next Sunday.

RSL Snooker Tournament. In the second semi-final Ron Wuttke defeated David Bednall. Ron then went on to defeat Les. Phillips in the final.

Burra Schools were visited by the Hon. Minister for Education Mrs J. Steele. At the Primary School Mr E.C .Allen MP introduced the Head Mistress Miss M. Spratt who introduced Mr R. Jeffery Chairman of the DC and others, including staff. There was an assembly of the students from Grades V, VI & VII. Mrs Steele spoke to students of her visits to schools in the NT & SA after which the Minister visited the classrooms of the remaining students. After morning tea Mr R. Moreland chaired a discussion which aired many questions including the future of the Primary School. At the High School Mrs Steele addressed the students and inspected the grounds, where the lack of yard facilities and of room for further buildings was recognised. She inspected the site for the proposed new school.

Mrs Steele also visited the Convent School of St Joseph and received a deputation from the Lewis Trust.

New Burra Police Station. The Hon. D.N. Brookman has advised that tenders for the new police station will be called in January 1970. Work can be expected to begin in March 1970.

91, 46 (3), 25 Nov. 1969, page 2 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Raelene Potticary has been transferred from Burra Primary School to the Alawa School in Darwin. She will also be missed at Rural Youth where she has been an efficient secretary.

Mr & Mrs Herb. Woodman of Glenelg will celebrate their Golden Wedding tomorrow.

Erica Blieschke of Farrell Flat has taken up work in the DC office.

Obituary. Don (Coogan) Kerin died at the Royal Adelaide Hospital on Sunday.

[Donald John Kerin died 23 November 1969 Adelaide, residence Pt Pirie aged 53. Burra DB says he was born in Burra 10 October 1916, but there is no record on the SA Births CD.]

91, 46 (3), 25 Nov. 1969, page 3 numbered 8 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Art Exhibition in RSL Hall

On Friday 5 & Saturday 6 December the group of artists who recently spent a week at Burra will display their works in the RSL Hall. About 40 of their Burra paintings have been framed. Some are members of the Citizens Art Group and others belong to the Royal SA Society of Arts. Some works are oils and others are water colours. Most are priced between $20 and $40. 20% of the profits will go to the Burra National Trust.

91, 46 (3), 25 Nov. 1969, page 5 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Adelaide Wool Sales last Tuesday to Thursday. The top price locally was 53c on account of ‘Ashrose’ & ‘Princess Royal’. [Other local district prices are printed.]

91, 46 (3), 25 Nov. 1969, page 9 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Kooringa Christmas Amusements taken from the SA Register for Friday 4 January 1856.

Wrestling matches in front of the Miners’ Arms Hotel on Friday.

On Monday a fine bullock was roasted whole by Mr Watts & Mr Stevens near the Burra Hotel. Some fine slices were cut at noon and by 6 p.m. it was considerably diminished. J. Pearce then gathered about 40 natives together and after three cheers for the Queen, three for Prince Albert and three for the Royal Family, he helped them to the roast beef so that in a short time only bones remained.

Several foot races were run between men, boys, girls and blackfellows.

Jingling and jumping in sacks concluded the sports.

On Tuesday rifle shooting at a target was held for a first prize of a revolving rifle and second of a revolving pistol.

There were also horse races at the Cross Roads Inn (Nankervis’s). [For which details were printed.] After the races the usual sports continued.

Outside the Miners’ Arms wrestling continued on Sunday morning.

Notes. The Miners’ Arms is the present Burra Hotel, then a single storey building. It was Burra’s second hotel, built in 1847 with H. Chandler as the first licensee. The Burra Hotel was the old wing of the Burra Hospital. It was demolished in 1967. Erected as Burra’s first hotel in 1846, its licensee was Abraham Wren. In 1856 the licensee was A. Barker, grandfather of the late John Barker. Cross Roads Inn, a few miles west of the Mine on the bullock road to Pt Wakefield, stood from 1853 to 75 on the ‘site of the present home of Glen Finch’s old home’. [Sic.]

91, 46 (3), 25 Nov. 1969, page 10 numbered 5 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Vandalism. St Mary’s has had vandals in who stole two small organ pipes, misplaced others and damaged two. Replacement pipes will cost c. $10. The theft was from the 15th stop added recently by Rev. G.D .Sibly. It is not known when the theft could have occurred.

St Mary’s Advent Carol Service was attended by c. 200 people on Sunday evening. Interdenominational representation was strong. The organist was Rev. John Stephenson. [Details in c. 1 column.]

Football. Leagues such as the North Eastern, Mid North and Adelaide Plains, which are not affiliated with the SANFL, will not be included in the competition at the mid-season carnival for 1970.

Accident. Mrs P.J. Kirk’s car was sideswiped while parked outside her residence. Police are investigating.
