91, 48 (3), 9 Dec. 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Burra Town Hall Pictures

In recent months efforts have been made to improve the hall and a good deal of money has been spent. At the pictures, unfortunately, good programs are being spoiled by children tracking in and out at any odd time and youths making a nuisance of themselves. The police have been advised and in future those who disturb the theatre risk being removed. Parents are asked to exercise control over their children. The program regularly runs at a loss.

Booborowie Town Streets will all be sealed by the end of the week. Some sealing has been done in Farrell Flat last season and a similar program is planned for Mt Bryan in the near future.

Accident/Obituary. Julie Kathleen Cullen (3), the daughter of Mr & Mrs Henry Cullen, died on Thursday after being run over by a truck being prepared for one of its regular trips to eastern stations. At about 10.25 a.m. it ran forward and passed over her as Mr Cullen was about to enter the cab. She was taken to Burra Hospital with internal injuries and died within half an hour.

91, 48 (3), 9 Dec. 1969, pages 1 & 8 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Burra RSL Annual Dinner was held on Saturday night. Guest speaker was Mr Perce Crook, Councillor for Barossa & Light Group, who spoke on the work of the League.

Advt. Burra Pictures, 12 December

Brigitte Bardot & Jeanne Moreau in Viva Maria

Veronica Hurst & Phil Brown in The Boy Who Cried Murder

Dr & Mrs Peter Kirk, Hilary & Nigel will leave Burra tomorrow to live at Blackwood. Their elder daughter, Debbie, has been at school in Adelaide throughout this year.

Jenny Kleinig left Jennison’s on Friday and was given a farewell. She has a position with a city bank.

Burra Scouts are collecting bottles, scrap metal and bags in a fund-raising drive.

Marriage. Friday next at the Church of St Richard of Chichester at Lockleys

Pat Kemp of North Adelaide will marry Paul Boucher of Mt Bryan.

The Rotunda in Market Square received a new coat of paint last week.

Hartley Harris sends Christmas greetings from Reservoir in Melbourne.

The Art Show in the RSL Hall at the weekend saw 21 paintings sold.

Mr & Mrs Jack Jenner were farewelled at Spalding on 28 November at a social organised by Spalding Football and Cricket Clubs. The couple have been active in sporting circles for the past twenty years.

Mr & Mrs Jim Shane have been given a farewell from Spalding upon retiring to Kapunda.

91, 49 (3), 16 Dec. 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Burra High School held its Swimming Carnival last Wednesday. Draysey House took the honours. Trophy winners were:

Senior Boys’ M. Broderick

Junior Boys’ P. Broderick

Allcomers’ J. Eberhard

Burra High School held its Valedictory Service at Kooringa Methodist Church last Sunday with a near capacity congregation. Guest preacher was Rev. Daniel Pill.

Accident. A car driven by Peter Opperman of Burra overturned on the Leighton Road on Saturday afternoon following a blow-out. Peter and passenger Phillip Edwards both escaped injury. They were on their way to play cricket at Leighton.

Boy Scouts and Cubs

After several weeks of tests and acquiring of uniforms the investiture of Burra Scouts and Cubs is scheduled for Friday 19 December. This will be the last meeting for 1969. Money raising is proceeding well, but the $500 has not yet been reached. Four Scouts have already been invested: Andrew Thamm, Andrew Webster, John Brak and Kym Spackman. [The Scouts and Cubs to be invested are listed.]

91, 49 (3), 16 Dec. 1969, pages 1 & 6 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Adelaide Wool Sales 18-20 November saw prices firm with better quality wool up 21⁄2 to 5%.

[Local district prices are printed.]

91, 49 (3), 16 Dec. 1969, pages 1 & 6 & 3-6 gutter [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Burra National Trust held its AGM in the CWA Rooms. Elected: President, L. Moore; Vice-President, G. O’Connor; Secretary, Mrs C. O’Connor; Treasurer, D. Cockington and Research Officer, Ian Auhl. Tribute was paid to Mr & Mrs S.J. Woollacott for their work in keeping the Market Square Museum open. The Trust has purchased a line and wash drawing of Market Square from Mrs J. Barker’s exhibition of paintings and drawings at the RSL Hall last weekend.

The inspection of Princess Royal has been rescheduled for April. G.S. Hawker urged the Trust to apply to the Stud Breeders’ Association for a few representative photographs of important sheep to be displayed in the Museum. The meeting concluded with T.G. Perry showing slides of the way buildings in the UK and Europe were being preserved.

91, 49 (3), 16 Dec. 1969, page 2 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Advt. Burra Pictures, 20 December

Rod Steiger, Lee Remick & George Segal in No Way to Treat a Lady

Frankie Avalon, Deborah Walley & Cesar Romero in Sergeant Deadhead

Ann Brak has been awarded a Commonwealth Secondary Scholarship.

School Teachers moving:

Mr & Mrs Nigel Brand with Debbie, Stuart & Nicola will move to Willunga where Nigel will be Deputy Headmaster of the High School.

Ross Johnson & his wife move to the city where he has a position at Taperoo High School.

Miss Raelene Potticary will go to Darwin.

Mr & Mrs Bill Wood from Booborowie School will move to an outer metropolitan school.

Mr John Ayliffe, well know here, has been appointed Senior Master at Burra High School.

Marriage. Last Saturday

Pam [Wilkinson] and Ian Fisk [both teachers at Burra High School] were married last Saturday.

Marriage. At Scots Church Adelaide next Saturday

Katie Treweeke, daughter of Mr & Mrs Hamline Treweeke of Petherton, Mt Bryan, will marry Richard Bucknell.

The couple will live in Melbourne.

91, 49 (3), 16 Dec. 1969, page 8 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Burra Burra DC, 1 December

Resolved that Samin be asked if the Powder Magazine will be left and that costs of repairs necessary are to be obtained.

Resolved that tenders be called for a new toilet block to serve the shops on Market Square.

Council is to endeavour to assist Samin Ltd to find a suitable air strip.

Signs are to be purchased and selected area [for] car body dump to be advertised.

91, 50 (3), 23 Dec. 1969, page 1 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Burra Oval. The bore has not been able to supply a sufficient flow to water the oval adequately in a reasonable time. Now a 22,000 gallon tank will receive bore water continually and this will then be delivered to the oval at an adequate rate by pump.

Fire Prevention. A ‘Best Fire Prevention Poster Competition’ for Primary School children has been won by Stephen Hall of Booborowie. He wins $10.

Boy Scouts & Cubs. The investiture of the boys was held at the Scout Hall in Hanson on Friday night when 18 Scouts and 25 Cubs were invested. Mr Maurice Davies invested the Cubs and Mr Bill Barker conducted the ceremony for the Scouts. The movement now goes into recess till 6 February.

Carols by the Swimming Pool drew a large crowd on Sunday evening in perfect weather. Chairman of the Burra Burra DC Mr Roy Jeffery delivered his Christmas message. The greatest event of the year was the amalgamation of the Town and District Councils. The opening of the Burra Mine is expected to be a reality within a few weeks. Rev. John Stephenson compered the evening. A highlight was the tableau presented by the children of St Joseph’s Convent School. About $XX? Will be forwarded to the Crippled Children’s Association from the evening’s collection.

Accident/Obituary. A 19-year-old driver died in Burra Hospital yesterday morning [22 December] after the car he was driving overturned on Sunday afternoon on the Burra-Hanson Road near the railway crossing at Brown’s Corner. He was Brian James Howe, a press operator of Elizabeth Field. He was thrown from the vehicle. A passenger, Robert Mitchell of Wingfield, escaped with bruises.

91, 50 (3), 23 Dec. 1969, pages 1 & 8 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Burra High School Speech Night was held in the Burra Town Hall on Tuesday night. Dr D.C. Paul was guest speaker and Mr & Mrs Roy Jeffery presented the trophies and prizes. [The prize list is printed.]

Boys’ Trophies:

Athletics Senior Roger Przibilla

Junior Stephen Lane

Swimming Senior Michael Broderick

Junior Peter Broderick

Girls’ Trophies

Athletics Senior Cheryl Finch

Junior Beverley Kleinig

Swimming Senior Jill Eberhard

Junior Carolyn Nicholls

The Headmaster presented the school’s 57th Annual Report.

[He welcomed the guest speaker who was Senior Lecturer in Education at Salisbury Teachers College and also Mr E.C. Allen MP.]

The year opened with 180 students, an increase of 12 and there were eleven staff members, of whom seven were newly appointed to Burra. I came from being Deputy Headmaster at Kadina. Mr Moyle came from Murray Bridge, Mr West, Mr Salt, Miss Russell, Miss Pfitzner and Miss Strahan were appointed from college. Mrs Brand was part-time librarian from the start of second term. At the end of second term we lost the services of Miss Strahan due to illness and she was replaced by Mr Fisk, a recent arrival from Canada.

Paving of the school grounds remains in a shocking state, but we hope for improvement shortly. Work was begun on a retaining wall around two of the tennis courts, but although begun in September, it is yet to be completed and in the meantime half of the court surface is broken and useless. The grassed area is in good condition.

The Parents & Friends’ Association has been active and very helpful this year and many thanks go to the President Mrs Matthews.

[School visitors and speakers are then listed, followed by a report on internal sporting activities.]

Last year’s Leaving results were disappointing. The average result of Grade IV or better was 63.4% compared with a state average of 75%.

The Intermediate Examination was held for the last time and Burra did very well with a Grade IV or better result reached by 85.9% of subjects compared with a state average of 75%. Especially noteworthy were:

Lynnette Griffen 7 subjects and six at Grade 1 level

Neville Hyde 7 subjects and five at Grade 1 level

Angela Quinn 8 subjects and four at grade 1 level

David Francis 7 subjects and four at Grade 1 level.

In this year’s Leaving Class seven students held scholarships and recently it was announced that Ann Brak has won a Commonwealth Scholarship.

The failures would seem to be less a lack of ability than a lack of drive.

[The Headmaster then went on to discuss the division of students into different tracks corresponding to differing abilities and interests. He also discussed promotion for the first three years of High School on the basis of continuing assessment.]

Staff changes at the end of the year:

Mr Brand has been promoted to Deputy Headmaster of Willunga High School.

Mrs Day has decided to resign.

Mr Johnson has been transferred to Taperoo High School.

Mrs Fisk (formerly Miss Wilkinson) has been moved to Nailsworth Girls Technical High School.

Mr Fisk also leaves.

[The Headmaster then thanked the Prefects, the Clergy, the Choral Group and the cleaners.]

91, 50 (3), 23 Dec. 1969, page 2 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Burra Pre-School Kindergarten had a successful year with the Director Miss Ashby and Assistant Miss Quinn. There were 19 applicants to replace Miss Quinn, who will be married in the New Year and from them Mrs Dean Bernhardt has been selected. An end of year Christmas Nativity was well attended and enjoyed by the children and visitors.

Vandals have damaged trees etc. in the Booborowie Recreation Ground and stolen items from it.

Dr Robert Heddle Jnr gained 2nd distinction in the final medical examinations recently. He is son of the former Burra GP.

Teachers’ Moves

Ian Weston, teaching at Mt Bryan, his wife Pat and baby Ian will move to Ardrossan.

Another teacher, David Munzberg, his wife and family will move to Pt Pirie.

Laurie Golding of Hallett moves to Monarto.

Pam Zanker will marry Raymond Wride.

Marriage. Kooringa Methodist Church, 10 January 1970

Joan Kellock will marry Kevin Schwartz.

Pam Collins will marry John Nitschke.

91, 50 (3), 23 Dec. 1969, page 8 [This number used before in 1961 & 1968.]

Obituary. Henry Edgar Atkins aged 85 died at Keith and District hospital recently. He left Hanson in 1947 where he and his wife had lived for over thirty years and he went to take up land at ‘Mount Charles’. He later sold this and took up ‘Almond Vale’ at Keith, where he lived until retiring two and a half years ago. He had been in ill health for twelve months. He leaves a widow, two sons and two daughters: Edgar (Ashton), George (Maitland), Edith Mrs I. O’Brien (Keith) and Christine Mrs K. Burgess (Tintinara). There are 12 grandchildren and 1 great-grandchild.

[Born 23 May 1885 Blyth: died 2 November 1969 Keith.]

Characteristics of the 1969 paper.

There was a good coverage of local news for the year.

Page 1

News.

Page 2

Mixture of news and advertisements and possibly the ‘Out & About’ column, though this wanders about quite a bit.

Page 3

Notices, advertisements and some news.

Pages 4 & 5

Generally dominated by the 50 Years Ago and 25 Years Ago columns with advertisements and a little news.

Pages 6 & 7

Generally carries the Cash Column, news, sports results and advertisements.

Page 8

News and advertisements.

BUT there was really no clear allocation of pages and topics and even the previous regular placement of sales advertising and public notices on page 2 is no longer guaranteed.

A few issues were extended beyond 8 pages.

92, 1 (3), 13 Jan. 1970, page 1 [This number used before in 1961 & 1969]

92, 1 (3), 13 Jan. 1970, page 1 [This number used before in 1961 & 1969]

Railway Timetable Changes

With delayed opening of the new standard gauge railway line there is also news that the rail service to Broken Hill via Burra will depart Adelaide over one hour later. Mr Allen MP said passengers at Peterborough had to rise at 3 a.m. to catch the morning train and could not return till 11.47 p.m. Departure from Adelaide at 7.10 was long after shops had closed. He felt that at least on nights other than the Broken Hill express the train could depart at 6.10 p.m. The answer was that the fast goods train had to depart at 5.30 p.m. and it was essential it keep ahead of the passenger train all the way to Peterborough. The changes also affected mail closing times.

Thefts. A 1964 Holden owned by Trevor Menz of Burra North was stolen from in front of the Bon accord Hotel on 29 December.

A caravan type gas cylinder was stolen from a Highways Dept. camp nine miles east of Sturt Vale last week.

Hoons. Police are investigation drivers doing wheelies in the Caravan Park.

Accidents

A car driven by Gregory D. Robson of Seaton Park overturned on the corner near the Burra Golf Course on Christmas Eve. Two juvenile occupants were treated for bruises, shock and abrasions.

A car driven by William J. Corner of Burra collided with a strainer post on the Mt Bryan Road on 1 January. The driver suffered abrasions and concussion.

Christmas Eve in Burra was rather wintry, but trading was brisk. Father Christmas distributed ice cream and the merry-go-round was popular. Some other centres were less lucky, with rain forcing the cancellation of some events.

92, 1 (3), 13 Jan. 1970, page 2 [This number used before in 1961 & 1969]

‘William’ writes in support of the Vietnam War and cites five reasons for opposing any allied withdrawal.

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club. Over double 25 Yards on 6 January the best were A. Pearce, P. Mengersen and M. Thomas.

Birth. To Pat & Adrian Morgan of Spalding at Jamestown Hospital recently, a daughter.

Burra Learn to Swim Campaign continues under instructors Randal Miller & Russell Nicholls.

Mr Ron Blackwell is the new Headmaster at Booborowie School. He, his wife and three children have arrived from Whyalla.

Constable Lyn Muldoon is on leave and will transfer to Francis early in the year.

92, 1 (3), 13 Jan. 1970, page 7 [This number used before in 1961 & 1969]

Cricket

Koonaburra 150 & 9 for 78 defeated North Booborowie 109 & 1 for 112 declared.

92, 1 (3), 13 Jan. 1970, page 8 [This number used before in 1961 & 1969]

Burra National Trust held its AGM. President W.L. Moore summarised the year’s work in the 6th annual report. With the opening of the Mine proposed, the Trust has been working to preserve the Engine Houses. Mr Lewis, General Manager of the enterprise, assures us he is as interested in the history of the area as we are and every effort will be made to preserve the buildings.

[Mr Moore said he would like to see a meeting between the Branch and Samin.]

Early in the year the National Trust acquired the land containing the two remaining dugouts and it will now be the task of the trust to restore them. The proposed visit to Princess Royal Homestead has had to be postponed due to Mr Andrew Tennant’s ill health. The visit in November would have coincided with the release of the book Historic Homesteads of Australia in which Princess Royal is featured.

In conjunction with the District Council the dugouts area has been cleaned up and the Trust now awaits prices for the restoration work.

Adult Education ran a School on Historic Copper Mines of SA early in May with Mr Ian Auhl giving a paper on Burra. The climax of the school was a bus trip to Kapunda and Burra with lunch at Princess Royal. The Burra Branch of the National Trust supplied afternoon tea for the visitors.

In August we were requested to roster people at the Museum in the absence of Mr Woollacott. This will also be needed next year when Mr Woollacott and family are abroad. This year the Museum had 1,530 visitors compared with 1,140 last year.

In November two members, Mr O’Connor and Mrs Radford attended on Adult Education School on Folk Museums and we look forward to making use of new ideas from them.

We are indebted to Mr & Mrs S.J. Woollacott for opening the Museum on Friday and Sunday afternoons.

In the year a plaque has been made in memory of Thomas Pickett and it is now ready for erection near the site of his shepherd’s hut on the bank of Diprose Creek.

The Museum also now has a tinted photographic copy of the Bentley painting recently presented to Head Office. With the permission of the District Council many of the relics from the mining era were moved from the mine to the area adjacent to the Museum.

This year we printed another set of five cards making ten in all. Thanks to Mr Maurice Perry for permission to draw on his splendid drawings. A sketchbook of Burra is in the process of being printed at present and we thank Mr Auhl for transferring his royalties to the Branch.

We have had a visit from the Renmark Branch and an exhibition of paintings by a group of artists who previously spent a week in the town.

92, 2 (3), 20 Jan. 1970, page 1 [This number used before in 1961 & 1969]

The Learn to Swim Campaign had larger classes this season despite the very cool conditions on some days. A total of 180 children attended at Burra with instruction from Paul Tattersall, Russell Nicholls and Randall Miller.

11 learned to swim 10 yards

38 gained a Beginner’ Certificate

27 got Progress Certificates

10 earned Progress and Junior Certificates

14 Junior Certificates were awarded

14 Senior Certificates were awarded

9 Intermediate Stars were earned

2 candidates won a bar

4 gained a Bronze Medallion

3 gained a Bronze Bar

[Participants are listed.]

Burra Silos wheat intake is down 145,000 bushels compared with the same time last season. The quota system has reduced the intake with 147,000 bushels of quota wheat delivered. No call has been made in the area for ‘over quota’ wheat.

92, 2 (3), 20 Jan. 1970, page 2 [This number used before in 1961 & 1969]

Accident/Obituary. A two vehicle head-on accident occurred at about 5 p.m. on the Manoora-Burra Road [19 January] and as a result two men, two women and two young girls from four different families are dead. The only survivor is a ten-year-old girl [Leanne Affolter] who suffered a broke leg. She is the daughter of Mr & Mrs Colin Affolter of Booborowie. The accident occurred on a slight bend about sixteen miles south of Burra and involved a sedan driven by Dudley Ronald Field of Golflands and a utility driven by Russell Edward Nicholas aged 44 of the Wellington Hotel, Waterloo. There were five passengers in the car. Two died at the scene and two at Riverton Hospital. The driver died while being conveyed to Adelaide. The driver of the utility died at the scene soon after being released from the wreckage, which took about an hour. Riverton and Burra ambulances attended the accident. Dr L.G. Miller of Burra attended and police from Burra, Riverton and Saddleworth. The deceased are:

Dudley Ronald Field (45) of Golflands [Died Gawler, residence Golflands.]

His wife Jean Kathleen Field (43) [Died Riverton, residence Golflands.]

His daughter Jennifer Mary Field (9) [Died Black Springs, residence Golflands.]

His mother Dorothy [Caroline] Vincent Field (71) of Leighton [Died Black Springs, residence Leighton.]

A niece Julie Anne Affolter (14) [Julie Dawn Affolter died Riverton, residence Booborowie.]

[Return Thanks Notice 10 March 1970 page 6 also says Julie Dawn Affolter.]

Russell Edward Nicholas (44) of Waterloo. [Died Black Springs, residence Waterloo.]

[SA Deaths CD confirms the above. Other CD information is in square brackets.]

92, 2 (3), 20 Jan. 1970, page 3 [This number used before in 1961 & 1969]

92, 3 (3), 27 Jan. 1970, page 1 [This number used before in 1961 & 1969]

Merino Ram Embargo Relaxed

On 15 January the ban on the export of Merino Rams was relaxed. Mr W. Brown of ‘The Grove’ Burra is President of the SA Merino Breeders Association. He said it was a step towards the unity of the wool world. The rest of the world had resented the embargo. There can still be no export of semen or ewes and only 300 rams can be exported. Mr Brown doubted whether that number would be reached. There will be only one auction sale in each state in the twelve months before the policy is reviewed. Mr Brown thought that 300 rams would not affect the Australian Stud or Commercial Breeder. In 1967 he said from 1,850 registered Merino Studs 202,000 rams were sold. In that year 11⁄2 million Merino Ewes were mated. Unsold rams that year totalled 294,000. Given this scale of operation the 300 will have little impact. He does, however, think the change might encourage breeders to produce more top sheep as has occurred with other breeds. He also thinks it will foster the International Wool secretariat in obtaining support from all wool producing countries.

Burra School will soon have better water pressure. A 4 inch main is being run across the bridge in front of the Town Hall. The work has been delayed by fire bans hampering the use of hot lead at many connections along the way, but the project should be completed before school resumes.

Burra Memorial Oval

Following the installation of a 22,000 gallon concrete water tank, the pumping equipment was connected to the power on Wednesday. It will take 24 hours to fill the tank and a line of 11 sprinklers can empty it in 5-6 hours; delivering the equivalent of an inch and a half to the irrigated area. A complete watering once a fortnight will now be possible.

Robyn Barratt of Adelaide, daughter of Mrs Joan Barratt, has been awarded a scholarship to the University. She lived in Burra some years ago.

Mr & Mrs Bernie Smith and family, formerly of the Willalo schoolhouse, are moving to Seaton. Mr Smith will teach at Seaton Park Primary School. Jan Richards replaces him at Willalo.

92, 3 (3), 27 Jan. 1970, page 4 [This number used before in 1961 & 1969]

Obituary. Mrs Bridget Eileen O’Dea, wife of the late John Charles O’Dea died 16 November 1969 aged 71. She was born at Cavenagh, the second daughter of Mr & Mrs T.F. Kilderry, late of Peterborough and pioneers in the Northern Areas. Mrs O’Dea was educated at Peterborough Convent School and Convent of Mercy in Angas St, Adelaide. With her husband and family she was engaged in mixed farming and cattle and horse breeding at Canowie, Hallett. After her husband’s death she continued with dairying and stud cattle breeding until recently. She was a devout Catholic and active in the community. She had a great love of horses, being an adept rider and lover of horse racing. She is survived by two sons and four daughters: Jim O’Dea (Peterborough), Tom O’Dea (Brisbane), Mrs L. Appleby (Spalding), Mrs E. Young (Croydon), Mrs J. McLean (Maylands), Sister Mary O’Dea (Cemdowie Private Hospital Semaphore).

[Born Bridget Ellen Kilderry 2 January 1898 Cavenagh: died Bridgid Eileen O’Dea 16 November 1969 Adelaide, residence Hallett.]

92, 3 (3), 27 Jan. 1970, page 6 [This number used before in 1961 & 1969]

Advt. Burra Pictures, 31 January

Julie Andrews & Richard crena in Star

Accidents

On Saturday at 8.30 p.m. about a mile the Burra side of Klaebe’s Creek near Studholme a fully laden semi-trailer bound for Queensland overturned. It landed upright with the trailer straddling the creek. The driver Kenneth Payne of NSW was transferred from Burra hospital to the Adelaide Hospital suffering from a broken arm, lacerations and concussion. The load of aluminium chairs, personal goods, data processing paper, children’s school shoes, drums of grease and cow hides was scattered about. Four trucks were used to convey the salvaged goods to the Burra Police Station. About 95% of the load was saved. The Council grader and front end loader salvaged the damaged vehicle. Damage to the vehicle was estimated at $3,500.

A car driven by Alan Day of Burra overturned on the Spalding-Burra Road yesterday near North Bungaree. The driver and passengers Ashley White, Philip Byles and Andrew Phillips escaped with a shaking and bruises. They were returning from a cricket match.

Lost Purse Found

A purse lost by a visiting woman from Christies Beach was found by Messrs Fred Allen & John Nankivell. When handed to police it was found to contain $2,329-23 and £9 Sterling. The grateful owner rewarded the honest finders with $100 each.

92, 3 (3), 27 Jan. 1970, page 7 [This number used before in 1961 & 1969]

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club. Over double 50 yards the best were R. Williams, I. Lovell and L. Moore.

92, 4 (3), 3 Feb. 1970, page 1 [This number used before in 1961 & 1969]

Swimming. The triangular swimming contest between Burra, Clare and Spalding was finalised at the Burra Pool on Friday. Clare was leading from the previous stages and clinched the shield by winning again on Friday.

[Results are printed.]

The Wheat Harvest. Local wheat agent Mr Fred Atkin advises that with almost all quota wheat having been delivered, over quota grain is now being received.

Fires. Three fires occurred in quick succession last week:

At 8 p.m. Friday at Burra North a fire near the ballast quarry was soon extinguished by the EFS.

Soon after that one broke out on W. Brown’s property on the Mt Bryan Road. The Burra Fire Brigade soon extinguished this fire.

A little later a fire broke out on the property of Mr N. Finch and this was soon extinguished by the EFS.

The occupant of a white sedan car has been questioned about these three outbreaks.

Colin Lloyd writes questioning the access of the general public to the acquisition of Samin shares.

Adelaide Wool Sales 27-29 January saw prices firm. [Local district prices are printed.]

Burra High School. Leaving Exam results are printed and were generally pleasing. Noteworthy were:

Lynette Griffen with four Grade 1 results, Angela Quinn also with four, and both David Dare and Chrystine Steele with three.

92, 5 (3), 10 Feb. 1970, page 1 [This number used before in 1961 & 1969]

Town Hall Concert. A fine concert will be presented at the Burra Town Hall on 28 February featuring Thomas Edmonds (tenor), Genty Stevens (soprano) and accompanist Peter Tillett. The evening is being sponsored by the Aberdeen Tennis Club. Adults $1.

Redruth Methodist Church

The service to be held at Redruth Methodist Church on Sunday at 11 a.m. will be the last regular service there. It will be conducted by Rev. A.R. Medson, State Secretary of the Methodist Church. It will end almost 118 years of Methodist services at Redruth. Services will now be centralised at the Burra [Kooringa] Methodist Church. The trustees of the church will meet on Wednesday to consider the future use of the property when the District Chairman the Rev. D.V.G. Mack from Riverton will preside.

Weather. Despite good rains last year to the east, there was little run-off and thunder storms are needed to fill surface catchments.

92, 5 (3), 10 Feb. 1970, pages 1 & 8 [This number used before in 1961 & 1969]

District School Enrolments. Generally they are little changed from 1969.

Burra High School

At 174 enrolments are down 6 on last February, but about the same as for the second half of 1969. There are five new staff:

Mr J. Ayliffe is Senior Master and had been a teacher at the school in the past. He replaces Mr Brand who has gone to Willunga High School as Deputy Headmaster.

Miss B. Kussadias is Senior Mistress.

Mr M. Allen comes from Pt Augusta.

Mr N. Williams and Miss J. Urlwin have been appointed from Teachers College.

[New enrolments are listed.]

Burra Primary School

The enrolment is 115 boys and 121 girls for a total of 236, which is 13 more than at the start of 1969.

[New students are listed.]

Booborowie School

The Head Teacher is Mr Blackwell, who comes from Whyalla. The other teacher is Miss Brooks.

Enrolment is 56, which is 4 fewer than at the end of 1969.

[New students are listed.]

Willalo School

Miss Jan Richards comes from Black Springs as teacher. There were 20 at the start of 1969 and 18 for 1970.

Jenny Steer is the new student in Grade I.

St Joseph’s Convent School, Burra

There are 27 students and two teaching Sister, but no new students this year.

Hallett School

The Head Teacher is Mr D.J. Pitcher, who comes here from Pt Augusta. Assistant Primary Mistress is Miss M. Saunders and the Infant Assistant is Miss A. Bartell, both from Teachers College. There are 65 students, up 9 from 1969. [New students are listed.]

Mt Bryan School

Head Teacher Mr John Thompson has come from Millicent. 26 students are enrolled. [New students are listed.]

Advt. Burra Pictures, 14 February

Dick Van Dyke & Sally Ann Howes in Chitty Chitty, Bang Bang

92, 6 (2), 17 Feb. 1970, page 1 [This number used before in 1969]

Wool Production. [There is an article discussing the problems in wool marketing caused by rising production costs, inflation and the failure of indirect subsidies to primary industries and suggesting that a new marketing scheme may be the only solution.]

House Breaking & Larceny

Three youths from Adelaide aged 14, 15 & 16 have been apprehended at Clare after breaking into and ransacking a furnished house owned by Mrs E.M. Carpenter at Burra North.

Weather. During a thunderstorm at Kia-Ora Station last week lightning struck a tower-type TV antenna. The bolts at the base sheered off and the tower was completely flattened. The TV set was undamaged.

Accident. A mini-sedan overturned on the road near Florieton on Saturday at about 10 a.m. and was discovered by Messrs Ron Thamm and John Taylor. The 21-year-old driver was a school teacher of Berri who was travelling to Burra to visit her parents, who began working at Princess Royal yesterday. She was shocked and bruised, but otherwise uninjured.

Redruth Methodist Church

About 150 people crowded into the church on Sunday morning for the service which marked the discontinuance of weekly worship there. State Secretary of the SA Methodist Conference Rev. A.R. Medson preached the sermon. Brian Thamm, who is Circuit Steward and Secretary to the Redruth Trust, read a statement outlining the reasons for the ending of services at Redruth and outlining the history of the church. The decision ‘was made in the good faith that a unified congregation and a centralised witness of Methodism to the town and district, was the only attitude which could be rightly adopted by an authentic twentieth century church.’

The Past. [Based on an article compiled in 1961 by Rev. Harry Alvey.]

The first mention of Redruth appeared in the minutes of the Kooringa Circuit in 1850.

Later in that year Redruth received from the Government 20 acres of glebe land and half an acre in the township. The foundation stone of the first chapel was laid in February 1851. Soon afterwards the gold rush began and the chapel was deserted except for a few women and children and in 1854 it was dismantled, to be reconstructed when the men returned in 1857.

In August 1873 the Trustees resolved to build a chapel on the present site. It ultimately cosy £1,340 and was later extended to become the building it is today. Kooringa Circuit was divided in 1889 with Redruth becoming a separate circuit with Rev. T.M. Rowe as its minister, living at Aberdeen. When Methodist Union took place in 1900 the Primitive Methodist Chapels at Redruth, Ironmine and Copperhouse became part of the Redruth Circuit. As the town’s population declined it could not support two Methodist ministers and the SA Conference approved the amalgamation of the Kooringa and Redruth Circuits in 1956. For the past 14 years the two churches have been continuously used and maintained for weekly worship. It is now acknowledged that the church in Burra must now become a united family. The Trustees do not want to see the buildings stand neglected and unused. The best solution would be for Christians of another Communion to take over and to this end a delegation will confer with the local Lutheran Pastor.

92, 6 (2), 17 Feb. 1970, page 2 [This number used before in 1969]

Advt. Elders-GM will conduct a clearing sale on the property two miles south of Hanson on the Burra-Adelaide Road on instructions from M.R. & E.J. Humphrys, whose property has been sold.

[Born Hilda Lillian Goodridge 22 November 1889 Redruth: died 28 December 1969 Burra, residence Booborowie.]

Burra Institute Library. Annual Meeting

The President P.J. Byrne reported for the year. The committee began in credit $10.11 and ended in credit $63.31.

Membership fell slightly. Mr Perc. Byrne and Mrs Byrne will soon leave Burra to reside in the city. He will be missed by the Library Committee, with which he has been associated for the past fourteen years.

92, 7 (2), 24 Feb. 1970, page 1 [This number used before in 1969]

The Methodist Church will sponsor a new Junior Youth Group to be called ‘Burra Junior Hi’, which will be inaugurated at Redruth Memorial Hall on 27 March. It will have the aim of ‘strengthening the physical, social and spiritual development of young people’.

Burra Primary School Parents’ Meeting

The Welfare Club reported on an active year of support for the school with the Treasurer reporting the spending of more than $1,800 on a wide range of purchases. The Treasurer of the School Committee reported the sale of the school crop for more than $70. As Chairman Mr R. Moreland outlined the year’s work. Headmistress Miss Spratt spoke on aspects of child development and the school. The School Committee for 1970 was elected. Notable achievements during the year had been:

The easement for use of the Burra North children is underway with tenders called for fencing and paving.

E & WS Department has just finished laying the new main to serve the school hydrants.

92, 8 (2), 3 Mar. 1970, page 1 [This number used before in 1969]

E.C. Allen writes with the response from the SAR to his request for better train times. The SAR offers the possibility of departing Adelaide 5.25 p.m. Monday & Thursday and 6.35 p.m. Friday to Sunday OR departing Adelaide 6.35 p.m. daily. He seeks feedback before responding to the offer.

Adelaide Wool Sales 24-26 February. Prices were firm. [Local district prices are printed.]

92, 8 (2), 3 Mar. 1970, pages 1 & 8 [This number used before in 1969]

Burra Town Hall Concert

The Hall was well filled when over 300 people attended the concert given by Thomas Edmonds, Genty Stevens and Peter Tillett on Saturday night. After the National Anthem Robert Reed welcomed the artists. The excerpts from opera were accompanied by the story and anecdotes, which ensured the audience understood the scene.

Program:

Miss Stevens Love and Music from ‘Tosca’ (Puccini)

As I Sit Here (Sanderson)

The Stars (Montague Phillips)

Poor Wand’ring One from ‘The Pirates of Penzance’ (Gilbert & Sullivan)

Mr Edmonds The Stock-Rider’s Song (William James)

The Scottish Soldier

Drake Goes West Sanderson)

Danny Boy

Peter Tillett accompanied the above and played the solos:

Toccata (Paridies)

Andante Cantabile (Mendelssohn)

Rondo Capriccioso

Duets:

From ‘La Boheme’ (Puccini)

Your Tiny Hand is Frozen

They Call Me Mimi

Lovely Maid in the Moonlight

From ‘Madam Butterfly’ (Puccini)

Love Duet

INTERVAL

Miss Stevens Love I Give My All (Besley)

Strange Music (Greig)

Waltz of My Heart from ‘The Dancing Years’ (Novello)

You’ll Never Walk Alone from ‘Carousel’ (Richard Rogers)

Mr Edmonds My Heart and I (Richard Tauber)

Take a Pair of Sparkling Eyes from ‘The Gondoliers’ (Gilbert & Sullivan)

The Exodus Song (Gold)

Serenade from ‘The Student Prince’ (Romberg)

Mr Tillett Claire de Lune (Debussy)

Warsaw Concerto (part)

Mr Roy Jeffery moved the vote of thanks.

Mr Reed thanked the Aberdeen Tennis Club for arranging the evening and in particular Mrs S. Scroop.

The evening concluded with the duets:

Dare I Believe My Heart from ‘The Gipsy Baron’ (Strauss)

Nobody Could Love You More (Lehar)

Merry Widow Waltz from ‘The Merry Widow’ (Lehar)

Deep in My Heart Dear from ‘The Student Prince’ (Romberg)

Telephone Lines. Three additional trunk line channels will be available between Burra & Clare from 11 March.

Mulesing has been growing in popularity at marking time as owners recognised the advantages of early fly protection, quick healing and no set back in growth rate. The 350,000 sheep mulesed last year showed a 75% increase on the previous year.

92, 8 (2), 3 Mar. 1970, page 8 [This number used before in 1969]

Burra & District Floral Art Club annual meeting reported on a most successful year. Average attendance at meetings had been 12. [Details are given in c. 2⁄3 column.]

Elected: President, Mrs Brian Thamm; Vice-Presidents, Mrs Ron Thamm & Mrs McGuire; Secretary, Mrs D. O’Connor; Treasurer, Mrs Ron Thamm and Demonstrator, Mrs R. Lloyd.

92, 9, 10 Mar. 1970, page 1

Solar Activity Research Station

A field station as part of a triangle of radio telescopes is nearing completion on the property of Don. White. The other two sites are at Buckland Park (Two Wells) and at Kadina. The work is being carried out by the University of Adelaide and will study the outflow of gases from the sun. This array is the first of its kind in the Southern Hemisphere and the research should last five to ten years. [Further details in 3⁄4 column.]

Burra Basketball Club held its AGM and elected: President, Mrs M .Beinke; Vice-President, Mrs L. Beare and Secretary-Treasurer, Mrs A. Day. There will be five teams this year – Two ‘A’ Grade, and one in each of ‘B’, ‘C’ & ‘D’ Grades. Heather Angel will coach the senior teams and Dianne Day the ‘D’ Grade.

Vandalism of railway signals and crossing warning systems has become serious with 83 cases of the former and 40 of the latter in the 12 months to June 1969. [The article fails to specify the area involved, but presumably it is SA.]

Visit of the Minister of Education

As a result of the Minister’s visit to Burra schools in 1969 Mr E.C. Allen has been advised of the following results:

An attempt will be made to upgrade the Home Science Centre and orders have been prepared for new student work benches and a demonstration bench.

An additional gas cooker will be provided.

The old laundry facilities will be removed and a new washing machine and stainless steel trough will be installed.

A clothes dryer will be installed.

Present cookers will be relocated more conveniently.

A new ablution trough will be installed.

A full treatment for white ants will be undertaken.

Wire proofing to combat birds has been approved, but a contractor is hard to find. Investigations of other ways to discourage birds will continue.

Burra Pre-School held its AGM at the Kindergarten on 2 March. Only 17 members attended and elected: President, Mrs D. Cockington; Vice-President, Mrs M. Tiver; Secretary, Mrs R. Pritchard; Assistant Secretary, Mrs J. Clark and Treasurer, Mrs Kempster. The main objective this year is to clear the $210 debt on the building.

Burra & District Tourist Promotion Committee was formed at a well attended meeting on Wednesday night. Mr Correll of the Government Tourist Bureau was the main speaker and he stressed that tourists needed access to good food and accommodation and had to feel welcome. A good caravan and camping site was essential.

[Other details in the 1 column article.]

Cricket. Mt Bryan 275 v. Koonaburra 362

Burra Methodist Circuit Family Camp at ‘Nunyara’ Belair is reported in c. 11⁄4 columns.

92, 9, 10 Mar. 1970, page 3

Cheryl Finch became the State Junior 100 m Hurdles Champion when she won the event on Saturday in 15.6 secs.

Obituary. Mr Dougald Phillips died in Perth WA last Tuesday aged 76. He lived in Booborowie district some years ago. His family had taken the property ‘Eringunda’ when the land was subdivided early this century. His mother was Katie Phillips. He is survived by a widow, a daughter, Judith (WA) and son Peter (Willalo).

[Thomas Dugald Phillips born 26 May 1895 Wirrialpa Station. His mother was Catherine Phillips nee McTaggart. The son, Thomas David Peter Phillips was born 9 October 1926 Kooringa and his sister Judith was born there two years previously. His wife was Marjorie Millicent nee Melville.]

Obituary. Mrs Pearl Nickles, formerly of Hallett, died in Adelaide aged 59.

[Born Pearl Hazel Linda Kelly 11 June 1910 Redruth: died 6 March 1970 Adelaide, residence Oaklands Park.]

Marriage. Kooringa Methodist Church next Saturday

Geoffrey Short, eldest son of Mr & Mrs Ken [K.D.] Short of Farrell Flat.

Marriage. At St Columba’s Church, Hawthorn, last Friday the marriage was celebrated of Mr & Mrs Don Stockman. They will live at Hanson.

The National Trust tour of Princess Royal Homestead is scheduled for 19 April.

92, 9, 10 Mar. 1970, page 5

Burra Small bore Rifle Club. Best over double 50 yards on 24 February were P. Edwards, L. Moore & P. Opperman. Best over double 75 yards on 1 March were M. Thomas, P. Mengersen & J. Bowden.

Burra Primary School Welfare Club held its AGM.

The Club with the Parents’ Committee, Students and Teachers purchased in 1969:

A public address system

A Gestetner duplicating machine

A tape recorder

Class pictures

A Freeway sports combination unit

Drawing boards

Physical activity equipment

150 books for the library (from a donation of $20 per month)

Other financial donations were made for a variety of purposes

The major fund raising events were Sports Day and Gala Night.

Sports Day was eventually washed out, but not before $178 had been raised. (When completed some days later Aberdeen House won the shield.)

Gala Night raised over $300.

[Details of other events at the school follow.]

70 mothers attended the meeting.

After spending $1,202-32 for the year the balance stood at $671-62.

Elected were: President, Mrs R. Jennison; Vice-Presidents, Mrs B. Stockman & Mrs M. Tiver; Secretary, Mrs B. Thamm, Assistant Secretary, Mrs G. Webster & Treasurer, Mrs R. Alderson.

92, 10, 17 Mar. 1970, page 1

St Mary’s will have a festival of Easter music this Sunday. The service will be conducted by the Rector of St John’s Auburn, Rev. Fr L.E. Sutcliffe assisted by Rev. Milton Edwards of the Burra Methodist Church. The music has been arranged by the Rector of St Mary’s Rev. John Stephenson who will play the organ. The Quartet comprises Elizabeth Beare (soprano), Jan Cockington (alto), Allan Edwards (tenor) and Lynden Beare (bass).

Burra Traders’ Association will meet tonight to select their representatives for the Burra and District Tourist Promotion Committee.

Burra RSL held its AGM on Friday 13 March and elected: President, T.R. Rogers; Vice-Presidents, B. Kotz & W.H. Nankivell; Secretary, W.J. Fridd and Treasurer, R.J. Kellock.

The President reported ten meetings for the year with an average attendance of eight. New lights were installed in the Hall and Clubrooms. A liquor licence was obtained and a bar room was furnished. An Anzac Service was held on 22 April and a Remembrance Day service on 11 November, which was attended by the upper grades of the Primary School and representatives from the High School. Badge Days were held for Anzac Day, Legacy, War Veterans’ Home and Poppy Day. A snooker tournament was won by Ron Wuttke. The annual dinner was held in the club rooms with food prepared by the Ladies’ Auxiliary.

Burra High School inducted its prefects at a ceremony in the Memorial Garden on Tuesday 10 March. D. Woolley is Head Boy Prefect and Jill Napper is Head Girl Prefect. House Captains and Vice-Captains were also inducted.

Advt. The Slim Dusty Show will play at the Burra Town Hall on Monday 30 March.

National Trust. The Chairman of the Historic Horse drawn Vehicles Branch of the National Trust, Mr T.E. Downer, visited Burra his wife on Tuesday 10 March and was shown around the Museum and historic sites.

Burra Hospital has received cheques totalling $604 from the land cropped for donation. This will attract a two for one subsidy. Mr T.R. Rogers reaped the wheat grown on land loaned by Koonoona Proprietors. Mr Don Stockman reaped the wheat grown on the Hanson Reserve.

Accident. A station wagon owned by Miss L. Tsacos of Burra North was damaged when a vehicle driven by William Dee of Eastwood ran into it while it was parked alongside the Best Place Café on Sunday.

92, 10, 17 Mar. 1970, page 2

Cricket. North Booborowie 61 & 1 for 22 v. Mt Bryan 171

Burra Methodist Guild reported a good year with 20 members attending per week.

Obituary. Mr Charles Pohlner died at Daylesford in Victoria on 8 March aged 72.

[Charles Alick Herman Pohlner born 7 November 1898 Hallett.]

The Commercial Hotel is being renovated and in the process a Dry Ginger Ale bottle was found wrapped in a note reading: ‘Alterations to this Bar completed July 10th 1925 by C.J. Pearce & Son, Contractors. Signed Lisle Pearce Architect & witnessed by R.H. Sharp Commercial Traveller, J.H. Murison, Motor Salesman, Con Lynch Hotel Proprietor.’

92, 10, 17 Mar. 1970, page 8

Tennis. Semi-Finals

‘A’ Grade Mt Bryan 11-86 defeated Aberdeen Blue 9-90

Aberdeen White 11-4 [sic!] defeated Kooringa 6-92

‘B’ Grade Mt Bryan Green 15-114 defeated Leighton Black 5-85

Mt Bryan Gold 12-108 defeated Leighton Gold 8-95

‘C’ Grade Aberdeen 8-64 defeated Spalding Blue 4-53

Leighton 7-57 defeated Kooringa 5-48

Burra Boy Scouts held their AGM in the Scout Hall Hanson on 12 March and elected: President, Rev. M. Edwards; Vice-President, Mr Ron. Gordon; Secretary, Mr Peter Mengersen and Treasurer, Bob Mason.

The year has been very successful.

On 8 August 1969 Mr Brian Ashdown was elected Group Scout Master at a Burra Town Hall Meeting.

Clare was visited on 15 August and a committee was then formed.

The disused Methodist Church and Church Hall at Hanson was chosen as the most suitable venue.

On 19 December 22 Scouts and 24 Cubs were invested.

Many thanks go for the assistance of Mr Maurice Davey, the District Commissioner.

[Details extend for 13⁄4 columns.]

92, 11, 24 Mar. 1970, page 1

St Mary’s Passiontide Service on Palm Sunday was attended by about 70 people.

Adelaide Wool Sales 24-26 February. Merino prices were down, but crossbred wools were dearer.

[Local district prices are printed.]

SAR

Since the opening of the [standard gauge] Indian Pacific rail link from Sydney to Perth through Peterborough traffic on the Burra line has increased. There are now 52 passenger and goods services per week compared with 41 previously. An express goods using bogey exchange facility at Peterborough goes through each night.

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club. Over double 50 yards the best were P. Opperman, A. Pearce and P. Mengersen.

92, 12, 31 Mar. 1970, page 1

Burra Show Society AGM

Elected were: Patron, Mr Rex Warnes; President, Mr R. Mason; Vice-Presidents, Mr G. Kellock & Mr M.G. Wardle. A secretary is required following the resignation of Miss Judy Beinke after two years. Retiring President Mr R.H. Stockman reported on a successful 1969 show held on 11 October in perfect weather. Gate takings were $681-16, which was up $200 on 1968. The 2,986 entries were a record. The Mid North Sheep Shearing Competition was a very successful innovation. There were 432 Horses-in-Action entries. Wool display was up to its usual high standard and though sheep numbers were down, the standards were well maintained. Industrial displays were numerous. The pavilion displays contained good quality in all sections and flowers and floral art entries had increased. The school displays were pleasing. Sideshows were down in number and less varies. Financially the success of the show means the Society is without debt for the first time in years and there is a credit balance of $73-08.

Burra Methodist Church on Sunday will feature the quartet which has sung a number of times in St Mary’s Church: Elizabeth Beare (soprano), Jan Cockington (alto), Allen Edwards (tenor) and Lynden Beare (bass).

Burra Sketch Book. A favourable review is printed.

Burra National Trust has applied for a subsidy to restore the dugouts. The road past them has been sealed in the past week or two.

The Tourist Promotion Committee is active and will approach the Tourist Bureau re publicity for the town. The question of a large scale street directory to help tourists find sites was raised. A letter from the Railway Historical Society said they intend to run a vintage train to Burra on 29 August to mark the centenary of the opening of the line. If the Governor can make the journey the SAR has approved the addition of the Vice-Regal carriage. Only three steam locomotives are operational and they are maintained by the society for their exclusive use. Two are Rx class locomotives, which is fortunate as they can be turned on the small turntable at Burra. SAR has approved a double headed steam train for this occasion. 500 people are expected to travel by this train and about 200 of them could be expected to be interested in a town tour.

St Mary’s. With the usual organist Mrs John Gordon absent for Easter, Mr R.J. (Dick) Sibly stepped in. He is the eldest brother of the former Rector Geoff. Sibly.

92, 12, 31 Mar. 1970, page 3

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club. On Tuesday the best over 50 m were P. Opperman, M. Thomas and I. Lovell.

92, 12, 31 Mar. 1970, page 4

Burra Burra DC, 16 March

It was resolved that an architect draw up block plans for new Council Chambers and the matter be advertised.

It was resolved that a price be obtained for the renovation of the Council house.

The Highways Department will be asked to close the Bon Accord Bridge and provide a ford in its place.

The SA Housing Trust will be asked to provide rental housing in Burra.

Mr E.C .Allen MP is to be asked to enquire about a Burra North by-pass.

Application is to be made for a special grant of $1,000 for the Eastern Road.

Redruth Methodist Guild reported it activities for 1969 in 2⁄3 column. There were 40 members with an average attendance of 22.

Obituary. Mrs Mary Longbottom died at Clare on Sunday aged 90.

[Born Mary Edith Haines 9 June 1879 Mundoora: died 5 April 1970 Clare.]

Obituary. Mrs Marjorie Bell died on Sunday. She was the widow of the late Rev. A.H. Bell, at one time Methodist Minister at Hallett.

[NOTE: corrected 92, 14, 14 Apr. 1970 page 7. This report is not true. Rev. Albert Bell was born 29 December 1896 Hetton Down, Co. Durham, UK and died 20 February 1963, Hallett. See extended obituary 37, 9, 5 Mar. 1963, page 4. He is said to have married a Miss Ivison Holliday. The mistake came from the death of Marjorie Gladys Bell on 6 April 1970 at Brighton aged 79, the widow of an Arthur Hammond Bell.]

92, 14, 14 Apr. 1970, page 1

Hallett Fire Station has been opened by the Chief Secretary, Hon. R.C. De Garis MLC. [Report in c. 2 columns.]

Burra Methodist Circuit will hold a special Circuit-wide combined service in the Booborowie Hall on Sunday 19 April. Changes to the Circuit boundaries in 1969 brought Booborowie into the Burra Circuit and this service will help awareness that there is a ‘District Church’.

Theft. A car owned by David J. Jones was stolen from Market Square on Monday night 6 April. An employee of Golden Copper Exploration Co. is suspected of the theft.

Vandalism to a water trough and windmill is reported from the property of B.A. Riggs Mr Bryan. Wilful shooting caused the damage. Gate signs were shot out. Two rifles and 100 rounds of .22 ammunition were stolen from the Lomman property at Mt Bryan East. Several youths were seen in the area in an old Vauxhall Velox.

Adelaide Wool Sales. Values increased by 21⁄2 to 5% in the sales on 7-9 April. [Local District prices are printed.]

Cricket. Phillip Byles has been named Mokota Association Cricketer of the Year for the third successive year.

Burra High School Sports were held last Friday in perfect weather. Jennison House won the day.

Senior Girls’ Cup C. Finch

Junior Girls’ Cup G. Peters

Senior Boys’ Cup M. Broderick

Junior Boys’ Cup S. Lane

[Other results are printed.]

Weather. Thunderstorms borough variable falls across the agricultural and pastoral parts of the district in the past week: Burra 104 points, Mt Bryan 50, Hallett 100, Booborowie 79, Collinsville 122, Canegrass 62, Woolgangi 25 and Old Koomooloo 18.

92, 14, 14 Apr. 1970, page 2

SA Stockowners’ Association, Burra Branch

Retiring President E.L. McWaters. After three dry years last year produced good rains for stock feed in the pastoral part of the district, but little water in the dams. Getting suitable employees has become very difficult and it is very hard to pay them adequately. Wool prices are very unsatisfactory and the situation with wheat (for those combining wheat and wool production) is also unsatisfactory. I believe a nation-wide organisation is needed. Elected: President, D.V .Lord; Vice-Presidents, F.H. Treweeke & R.R. Cooke; Joint Secretaries, A.L. Wright & R.L. Wuttke.

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club. Best over double 25 yards were J. Bowden, I. Lovell and C. Bevan.

92, 14, 14 Apr. 1970, pages 3-6 gutter

Bowls. At the close of the bowls season in Burra President Murray Stockman reported on an enjoyable season, even if no team had won a pennant. He reported that the club had now paid back all debentures and was left with a credit in the bank. Consideration was being given to alteration or replacement of the clubhouse. The Easter Tournament had been a success. Trophies were presented:

92, 15, 21 Apr. 1970, page 1

Princess Royal

Last Sunday the Princess Royal homestead was open for inspection. Mr Tom Downer of Woodside took a full load of passengers out on his drag drawn by five black horses. On the day Mr Downer made c. $140 for the Horse Drawn Vehicles Exhibition at Magill. Many people picnicked in Burra or at Princess Royal or along the road. A highly appreciative crowd streamed into the house from 11 a.m. to 1 p.m. and 2 p.m. to 4 p.m. to appreciate the historic building, exquisite furnishings and carefully tended garden. For the day over 1,100 people visited the property. Many of the visitors also toured Burra itself. Over $900 was raised for the dugouts restoration project. A contract has been let to a local tradesman for the rebuilding. The Woods and Forests Department is advising what trees and shrubs grew in the area so they can be replaced.

Football. A lightning Carnival was held at Clare over the weekend and picked up $120 in prize money.

Round 1. Burra 7.6 defeated Min-Man 6.6

Round 2. Burra 11.5 defeated Clare North 6.4 or 0.4?

Round 3. Burra 11.9 defeated Riverton 3.4

Basketball. In the lightning carnival the Sevenhill team won the contest.

92, 15, 21 Apr. 1970, pages 1 & 6

Back to Saddleworth celebrations are reported.

92, 15, 21 Apr. 1970, page 3

Advt. Burra Pictures, 25 April

Hell Fighters

Did You Hear the One About the Travelling Sales Lady?

Burra Hospital Cabaret was sponsored by Amoco Ltd and featured Johnny Mac as guest star. Burra Town Hall was comfortably crowded. With subsidy the Hospital will benefit by about $950.

Weather. Rains have been general over the north eastern pastoral areas, but little surface water has flowed.

Advt. Elders-GM will auction 18,174 acres of perpetual lease on instructions from Reed Bros in the RSL Hall 1 May. Location: 58 miles northeast of Burra abutting ‘Loch Winnoch’.

Burra Anzac Service was held at the Memorial in Market Square last Sunday. The Pt Pirie Pipe Band led 20-30 ex-servicemen in the march. Rev. Milton Edwards conducted the service. Wreaths were laid by Ben Kotz for the RSL, B.A. Riggs for the District Council and Peter Williams for the Demobilised Soldiers Assoc. A combined church service was held in the evening at Burra Methodist Church, conducted by Mr N. Baynes.

North-Eastern Combined School Sports took place at Spalding Oval Friday 10 April. The event was opened by Lady Hawker. School teams competing were: Spalding Hut, Spalding Hill, St Joseph’s, Booborowie Green, Booborowie Red, Leighton, Willalo & Hilltown. [Results are printed.]

92, 15, 21 Apr. 1970, page 7

Cricket. At the annual wind-up function for the Mokota Cricket Association Matt Carmody, C. [Cletus] Furst & Ron Dewhirst were made life members. Phillip Byles received the Cricketer of the Year Trophy for the third year in succession. The Mokota Premiership Shield went to South Booborowie.

Glenda Bidgood, teacher at Mt Bryan, is leaving the district, bound for England with her family.

Berger Henriks of Magill and formerly of North Booborowie is 88.

Fr Laurie Dower of Sydney is visiting his brother Vin Dower of Burra.

92, 15, 21 Apr. 1970, page 8

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club. On Tuesday over double 50 yards the best were I. Lovell, P. Mengersen & J. Bowden.

On Sunday 12 April the NESBRA Prize Shoot was held at Burra. Best in ‘A’ & ‘B’ Grade was M. Stanley, in ‘C’ Grade was L. Moore and in ‘C2’ Grade P. Mengersen.

Burra Women’s Bowls AGM. Elected: President, D. Pietsch; Vice-Presidents, R. Phillips & E. Scott; Secretary, L. Neill & Treasurer, I. Jacka.

Outgoing President P.M. Field reported on a successful year in the 14th Annual Report. Burra Gold finished one point behind the winners, Spalding Blue, for the 1969-70 pennant. Burra Gold won the North Eastern Association Champion Rink Tournament. The Champion of Champions Singles were held at Burra and won by Peterborough.

92, 16, 28 Apr. 1970, page 1

The Tennis Ball of the Burra & District Tennis Association was held at Booborowie on 24 April. The profit will amount to c. $85. Jim Quinn was MC and Miss Jan Drew of Leighton was chosen Miss Tennis for 1970. Kevin Lane for Aberdeen White received the ‘A’ Grade Shield. A. Thomas for Mt Bryan received the ‘B’ Grade Shield. S. Lane for Aberdeen received the ‘C’ Grade Shield. Mr & Mrs S. Scroop were congratulated and thanked on completing thirty years’ continuous service as joint secretaries of the Aberdeen Tennis Club.

Mid North Football League. Plans are in hand to write the History of the Mid North Football League. Mr A.E. Bannear has undertaken the task and seeks co-operation of the clubs. Minute books from 1923 have been examined. Records from the period before 1923 are sought and players of the past with stories to tell should contact the League Secretary.

Burra Cubs and Scouts had a barbecue at the Gorge on Sunday. Scouts hiked from ‘The Gap’ to the Gorge.

92, 16, 28 Apr. 1970, page 7

E.C. Allen MP writes expressing disappointment at SAR’s decision on train times. He says feedback he got suggested the preferred option was a 5.25 p.m. departure Monday to Thursday and 6.35 p.m. Friday to Sunday.

Burra Methodist Sunday School held a picnic at Clare on Saturday.

Mr & Mrs Woollacott, Mary & Ruth leave for Melbourne on Friday, heading for Sydney and their overseas trip by P & O liner Iberia. They are due back in mid-November.

92, 17, 5 May 1970, page 1

Ernest Claude Allen MP has been endorsed to contest the Electorate of Frome for the LCL in the election on 30 May. The ALP candidate will be Mr G.L. Casanova, a hotel licensee of Peterborough. Mr Allen of ‘Glen-Rae’ Spalding was born 24 October 1910 at Blyth and is married with one daughter. He has been MP for Burra in the House of Assembly since 1968, a JP for 21 years and President of the Spalding Branch of the LCL for ten years. He was a member of the District Council of Spalding for twelve years and a member of a string of district committees. [Which are listed at length.] He was a farmer and grazier for 37 years and sold his property to become a legislator. [Photo.]

92, 17, 5 May 1970, pages 1 & 4

New Home for Burra Burra DC?

The new enlarged Council was one year old on 24 April. In that year the Council has become aware of the need for more space. Records for the merged Council are temporarily stored in the existing DC Office. Space is very limited and the space for office staff is overcrowded. There is a need to house up to four members of office staff each day and allow for visits from the Health Inspector and Weeds Officer.

There is no space for the Overseer or for the plan storage he needs. The present space is too small to reasonably accommodate Council meetings. There is a lack of secure storage (in a fire-proof walk-in size strong room) for records. These include assessments, accounting records, wage records, the leave register, road rental records, cemetery leases and burial records, dog registration, minutes of meetings for Council, committees and Board of health, machinery working records and quarry returns, among others.

Planning consideration has been given to the useful spaces at the Burra Town Hall – with its lack of toilet facilities and meeting rooms. The Burra Library is in a remote location and could be moved to the present Council Chambers in Commercial Street where it could become a greater asset. The Council decided after considerable discussion to approach a firm of architects to present plans of possible solutions for their problems. The proposal includes:

A new block of administrative offices and Council Chamber on the block between the Town Hall and the [former] Post Office property. [The eastern elevation is shown as a sketch on page 1, with a ground plan on page 4.] This proposed new building would include:

A Council Chamber

An enquiry area and general office

A store room and strong room

A ledger room (for an accounting machine)

Offices for senior officers

Toilets

All records would move to the new office

The Reception Room in the Town Hall (formerly the Mayor’s Parlour) would be renovated.

Burra Library would be relocated to the existing Council Chamber in Commercial Street.

The existing Town Hall rooms would be remodelled to include a meeting room and toilets for both sexes.

A smoke lounge would be added on the south side.

The existing steep front steps would be replaced by two levels of wide steps.

Council staff at present comprises:

District Clerk

Two assistants

Health Inspector & Weeds Officer

Works Overseer

Ganger

15 Members of Council

[Items of Council plant for road works etc. are then listed.]

Ratepayers can be assured of continued improvements to services, especially with growing tourist interest.

The architects were Messrs Brown, Davies, Reynolds & Doley Pty Ltd. The completed work is estimated to cost $75,000, of which the new office and administration block would account for c. $60,000. Changes to the Town Hall would amount to c. $15,000.

It is hoped ratepayers will approve of this forward move. Detailed enlarged plans are on view at the Council. Questions may be addressed to Councillors or the Council Office. The Town Hall would still have a rather Spartan stage, no theatre lighting, lack of backdrop changes and difficult changing from picture theatre to concert hall etc.

Advt. Burra Pictures, 9 May

The Assassination Bureau

Robinson Crusoe on Mars

92, 17, 5 May 1970, page 7

Basketball

Burra Kindergarten held an op shop last week in Johnny Hill’s old shop and raised c. $350 to be used in flooring the wash room.

Birth. To Bob & Pat Greet, a son. (Missed last week.)

Birth. To Marleen & Les Broad, a daughter.

Mr & Mrs Ron Gordon & family of the ANZ Bank are transferring to Kangaroo Island from next Friday. They will be replaced by Mr & Mrs Hank Heitbrink and son (16) and daughter (13).

92, 17, 5 May 1970, page 8

Hallett & Districts Athletic Assoc. combined sports was held at the Hallett Oval 24 April. The school teams were Burra Green, Burra Purple, Hallett, Whyte Yarcowie, Mt Bryan. [Results are printed.]

Trophy for the Highest Aggregate for an individual boy went to Geoffrey Bernhardt of Burra Green.

Trophy for the highest aggregate for an individual girl went to Sue Talent of Mt Bryan.

The Boys’ Championship was won by Stephen Lake of Hallett.

Keryl Kakoschke of Burra Purple won the Hawker Cup.

Upper North Zone Rural Youth Rally was held at Snowtown 17-19 April. Burra came last of the nine clubs competing.

92, 18, 12 May 1970, page 1

St Dymphna’s Church, Booborowie

Over 500 attended St Dymphna’s on Sunday 10 May for the opening of renovations to the church by His Lordship Bishop Brian Gallagher of Pt Pirie. A luncheon in the Booborowie Hall followed the Mass. Mr Harry Queen [Quinn?] Chairman of the Church Committee responsible for the work gave a talk outlining the history of the Catholic Community in Booborowie. St Dymphna’s was blessed and opened on 20 September 1903 by Monsignor F. Byrne. The Bishop spoke expressing his appreciation of the committee’s effort.

Burra Basketball Club organised a ball at the Burra Town Hall on Friday night. Door takings were $276. The Matron and Belle Competition was judged by Miss South Australia, Miss Christine Howard. Mr Graham Kellock was MC. The Senior Matron was Mrs Brian Riggs. Senior Belle was Miss Lyn Richardson. Junior Matron was Mrs John Tiver and Junior Belle was Miss Joanne Matulick.

The Burra Methodist Circuit is almost certain to host an American Exchange student through the courtesy of the Clare Rotary Club. The boy being considered is 15-year-old Thomas Frederick Eastman of Kimball Nebraska.

Mr Neil Hurst will take up his position as postmaster in Burra on 14 May. He has been in charge at Morgan for three years. He began as a Junior Postal Clerk in 1951 at Tanunda. He has a wife and two daughters and is interested in golf, cricket and night bowls. He has also been a Warden of the Church of England. [Photo]

Dudley Jacka will draw up plans and estimates for two options for the Burra Bowling Club.

Removal of the old clubhouse and provision of a new one

Building a new bar-clubroom in harmony with the existing toilets and with the retention of existing rooms as luncheon rooms.

Burra Burra DC Elections: All vacancies were filled unopposed.

Burra Town Ward C.L. Phillips replaces E.T. Baulderstone who has decided to retire.

Kooringa Ward G.R. Finch (re-elected)

Farrell Flat Ward J.W. Burge (re-elected)

Leighton Ward R.J. White (re-elected)

Mongolata Ward B.A. Riggs (re-elected)

Inter-High School Sports were held at Riverton on Tuesday 5 May between Balaklava, Burra, Clare, Kapunda, Riverton and Eudunda. Burra came fourth in the Championship Shield; won by Clare and second in the Handicap Shield; 41⁄2 points behind Eudunda. [Burra results are printed.]

Burra & Clare Cubs had a combined camp at Halbury on Saturday and Sunday 2 & 3 May. It was rather marred by constant showers of rain. [Description extends for 1 column with a list of those attending.]

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club. In the final shoot for the season over double 25 yards the best were M. Thomas, I. Lovell and A. Pearce.

T.G. Perry District Clerk writes in answer to a query to say that the intended means of financing the proposed Council Office building was to raise a debenture loan of $75,000 repayable over 15-20 years on the terminal annuity system.

Rosemary McDonald has successfully completed two years of training at the Burra Hospital and will now transfer to the Royal Adelaide Hospital on 18 May.

Marriage. St Andrew’s Church, Walkerville, next Friday

Mary McDonald will marry Malcolm Pimm.

Mr Lewis Gare has been re-elected to the Banbury Ward of the Hallett DC. He has served a term of 30 years in this capacity.

Lance-Corporal Russell McDonald, who has completed a year’s service in Vietnam, arrives home tomorrow.

92, 18 (2), 19 May 1970, page 1

Barkers of Baldina Cottage Homes

Under the terms of the will of the late Mr J.R. Barker $70,000 was set aside for the purpose of erecting cottage homes for the aged on land adjoining the Burra Hospital. Before the work could begin the Barkers of Baldina Cottage Homes had to become an incorporated body, completely separate from the Hospital. This has now been done. Plans have been drawn up and as soon as finance comes to hand an immediate start can be made.

Weather. Patchy rain fell in the past week. World’s End and some eastern properties got much less. Burra 100 points, Hallett 77, Mt Bryan 121, Booborowie 146, Mt Bryan East 70 and World’s End 48.

Aberdeen Basketball & Football Clubs have organised a Walkathon on Sunday. The distance is six miles to Bruce Stockman’s. Walkers are seeking sponsors for 50 cents per sponsor (not per mile).

Burra High School. Water pressure at the school has been the subject of a complaint. Mr E.C. Allen made enquiries and E & WS Inspectors report that at the school boundary pressure was 74 lbs per square inch and the flow 95 gallons per minute. At one point within the school the flow was only 54 gallons per minute and the pressure 40 lbs per square inch. It is the state of the internal plumbing that is causing the problem. This can be rectified on order from the Public Buildings Department.

Burra Mine

It is expected the Mine will be in production by the end of 1970 and will employ 60-70 men when in full production in 1971. This was announced in an election speech by Mr E.C. Allen MP in Burra Town Hall on Thursday night. Samin Ltd has called tenders for the removal of waste material and of the ore itself. The necessary plant to do that is estimated to cost $2 million.

Stage 1. The company will treat 250 tons of ore per day.

Stage 2. By October 1971 this figure will increase to 1,000 tons per day and will involve the removal of up to 7,000 tons of waste per day.

It is thought there are about 4.3 million tons of copper ore.

Samin Ltd is negotiating with the SA Housing Trust for houses to be erected in Burra.

92, 18 (2), 19 May 1970, page 12

Mr Gerry Casanova ALP Candidate for Frome. A profile is printed. He was aged 47, married with five children and he was a hotel licensee of Peterborough, having lived in the area for 20 years. He was a Corporation Councillor. [Other community interests are listed.]

92, 19, 26 May 1970, page 1

Thieves

Mr Lloyd Parks saw two young males in his yard at about 11.40 p.m. They fled on hearing his approach and Mr Parks found that a car belonging to his neighbour, Mr Brian Mitchell, had been pushed into the street and attempts had been made to start it. Sgt Orford was notified and about 12.05 a.m. he heard attempts to start a vehicle in Ware St. where a car had been pushed from the home of Mr & Mrs Bill Byles. The would-be thieves escaped. On Saturday evening a ute owned by T. Ryan of Mt Bryan was left on the side of the road four miles south of Hallett when it had a flat tyre. It was subsequently stolen and apparently driven with the flat tyre until abandoned a mile south of Yunta.

The Spalding-Burra-Morgan Road will be upgraded between Burra and Morgan to ‘open surface standard’ over the next four years and the Spalding-Burra section will be sealed.

St Mary’s Church. On Sunday next Fr W.G. Williams of Clare will celebrate Holy Communion and will baptise three candidates.

Adelaide Wool Sales. Prices eased by 21⁄2 to 5%. [Local district prices are printed.]

Brompton Pensioners’ League presented their annual concert to a crowded hall at Burra.

92, 20, 2 June 1970, page 1

State Election last Saturday

The count for Frome is incomplete with 6,926 votes counted out of 8,296. Mr Allen LCL has a lead of 319 over Mr Casanova of the ALP. Overall at this stage the ALP has taken 26 seats and the LCL 18 with Chaffey, Frome & Hanson still in doubt. Frome totals at this stage of the count:

Allen 3440

Casanova 3121

McMahon 258

Informal 107

6926

Clare Cubs will visit Burra next Friday.

92, 21, 9 June 1970, page 1

Accident. A car driven by Ian Moore (19) of Gladstone overturned about four miles east of Booborowie on Sunday. The driver sustained serious head injuries and was transferred to the RAH. Two passengers Miss J. Moore of Ceduna and Miss C. Brown of Gladstone escaped serious injury.

Straying Livestock are a problem at present in the Burra District both on stock routes and in the town. Sheep, cattle and goats are all involved.

Booborowie Basketball & Football Club Debutante Ball was held on Friday with debutants presented to Lady Hawker. Door takings were c. $300. Debs and their partners:

Jennifer Catt and Stuart Catt

Suzanne Collins & Phillip Gale

Debbie Drew & David Riggs

Veronica Berryman & Gerard Scholz

Heather Keane & Andrew Pearce

Marie Berryman & Andrew Scholz

Kathryn Henriks & John Beshara

Burra Kindergarten requires $1,700 annually. The Kindergarten Union receives an annual SA Government grant which is used to maintain the Kindergarten Training College and subsidise salaries at branch kindergartens. Local kindergartens must fund and maintain buildings and pay the balance of salaries. Burra Kindergarten receives $850 in voluntary contributions, which almost covers salary costs. A further $600 is needed to cover running and maintenance costs and $200 is needed to repay the building load.

Accident. Grant Williams McCall aged 30 of Melbourne suffered concussion, lacerations and abrasions when he fell forty feet down a cliff at the Burra Mine on Sunday.

Accident. A car driven by school teacher Sandra F. Bailey collided with one driven by W.G.A.R. Moore of Burra North at the junction of Commercial Street and Market Square this morning. Damage was minor.

Mary Woollacott provides a letter covering her trip through parts of Hawaii and then on to Suva, San Francisco and Vancouver; though the order in the printing is somewhat jumbled.

Notice. Burra Burra DC gives notice of intention to borrow $75,000 by means of a debenture loan over 15 years at 7.4% p.a. in order to:

Construct new Council Chambers and an administrative block.

Renovate the Burra Town Hall frontage.

Relocate the Burra Library to the present Council Chambers at 14 Commercial Street.

Install new toilets in the Burra Town Hall.

Final: Gawler Districts 6.10 defeated Adelaide Plains 2.10

Obituary. Arthur Gaynor Owen-Smyth of Ulooloo Station, Hallett.

A.E. Bannear of Saddleworth recalls Captain Gaynor Owen-Smyth at Wayville in 1940, when as a training officer he welded the men for infantry and cavalry trained units into the reinforcement group of the 2/7th

He recalls his great sense of humour, his generosity with small loans to those in financial trouble and his ability to sort out the problems when his ‘boys’ ran into trouble with various authorities and he retells a couple of anecdotes about Owen-Smyth.

92, 24, 23 June 1970, page 1

Burra & Districts Ambulance held its AGM. A new schedule of benefits was adopted to bring the Association in line with the other associations in the state. [Details are printed.]

Accident. Gerald R. Pens (20) of Burra was seriously injured when the vehicle he was driving went over the bridge at Ford’s Corner on Friday night. The car landed upright twenty feet below. Mr Pens was not found till 8.15 a.m. by Mr Colin Earle. Dr L.G. Miller of Burra attended and Mr Pens has been transferred to the Royal Adelaide Hospital.

Showgrounds Shearing Shed Fund. Donations to a total of $310 are acknowledged.

Junior Colts Min-Man 4.5 defeated Aberdeen 3.2

Riverton 7.10 defeated Robertstown 1.1

Ratepayer of Burra Ward writes:

I hope the Council will bear in mind when they start receiving significant royalties from the Burra Mine that in the past Burra has paid higher rates than most of Adelaide suburbs. Despite some reductions last year, further cuts could be considered. The improvements to the Town Hall are to cost ratepayers $125,420 (thirty payments of $4,180). This is mainly for office requirements, so why not wait a few years and then build a complex to meet all purposes. In the meantime rent or buy a house or hall. Make the scheme wait till there is cash on hand and save more than $50,000 in interest. A more immediate need is an Effluent Disposal Scheme, Reconstruction of the Main Highway and water tables through Burra, redevelopment of the shopping area and cement footpaths and curbs.

If the Council could advise ratepayers of its long term plans it would get support. Silence breeds rumours.

B.H. Rogers of Paxton Tce writes questioning the wisdom of proceeding with the Town Hall alterations and Council Chamber at a cosy of $75,000 plus interest. He considers the signs for the future of the economy are not promising. If the Mine should boom again the proposed changes might prove to be inadequate. All in all the ratepayers need to consider the proposal very carefully.

92, 25, 30 June 1970, page 1

Housing Trust Homes for Burra

The District Council and Housing Trust met last week with the result that a number of houses are due to be built in Burra. The District Clerk Mr Perry said the move follows requests from Samin Ltd and the Council. The Company expects to employ up to 60 men and some of them will require homes in Burra. The Housing trust has bought several parcels of land in the town, of which the most important is that which fronts Smelts Road and Paxton Terrace, formerly owned by Mr M. Pritchard. This will be sub-divided for 32 homes. It is expected construction will begin in July and the first allotment will possibly be for 12 houses. Investigations are under way to see if an effluent scheme will be necessary. Road works will also be required. A plan of this subdivision is available at the Council office. It is expected the open cut will soon be fenced to ensure safe operation.

Effluent Drainage Scheme

The expected plans from the Central Board of health had not arrived and a further request has been made. When the plans arrive a meeting will be called so that those affected can ask questions.

Bowls. Burra members are discussing the possibility of a new clubhouse. Two proposals to either demolish and rebuild or to extend the present building were considered at a recent committee meeting.

At the AGM last Tuesday elected were: Patron, Dudley Jacka; President, Edgar Pietsch; Vice-Presidents, Darrell Field & Brian Riggs; Secretary, Wally Scott and Treasurer, Barry Biggs.

The plans of clubhouse changes presented by Dudley Jacka for consideration are available for inspection at the clubhouse and constructive criticism is being sought.

92, 25, 30 June 1970, page 3
