Rock Hudson & George Peppard in Tobruk

Don Knotts & Barbara Rhoades in The Shakiest Gun in the West.

The Rt Rev. S.B. Rosier, recently enthroned as Bishop of Willochra, will be in Burra on Friday to confer with clergy of the Clare Deanery and will attend Eucharist at St Mary’s at 10 a.m.

92, 25, 30 June 1970, page 4

T.G. Perry District Clerk writes:

I have heard of vocal opposition to the Council proposals to improve accommodation for administration. There is a real need to keep records safer and in a fireproof facility. Opposing to the proposal is to oppose Councillors who have been elected to attend to the ratepayers’ affairs – not the clerk or office staff. Councillors presently meet in very cramped quarters. [He then lists the proposed changes.]

I suggest that those who consider the move to be progressive make their views known and also suggest that Councillors are ready to hear words of encouragement because they quite often hear words of criticism. The details of the scheme are available at the Council Office.

92, 25, 30 June 1970, page 6

Centenary of the Burra Railway

The Australian Railway Historical Society will bring a special vintage train to Burra on 29 August to mark the 100th anniversary of the opening of the line. Anyone wishing to ride on the train should contact Mrs Kath Christie at 10 Thames St Burra.

Obituary. Mr Bill Wasley died suddenly at midday Saturday aged 92. He worked for many years on boats and barges on the Murray and later worked in the Morgan District.

[William Wasley died 27 June 1970 Burra aged 92.]

92, 26, 7 July 1970, page 1

Burra Burra DC

Two petitions were received at yesterday’s meeting of Council objecting to the Council’s intention to raise $75,000 for the Town Hall Project and asking for a poll of ratepayers on the subject. The notice of intention to borrow was published on 9 & 16 June. The loan would be repaid over 15 years at 7.4% in half-yearly payments of $4,180.67.

The petitions come from ratepayers in the Mt Bryan and Farrell Flat Wards. The poll has been set for Saturday 1 August.

Break-ins. On Tuesday night last week three of the five Burra Hotels were broken into and cigarettes and cash were stolen.

Kooringa Hotel: 3,200 cigarettes, cigars, tobacco, matches, a transistor radio and $33.80 for a total value $152.80.

Burra Hotel: $30.

Royal Exchange Hotel: 6,660 cigarettes, tobacco and cigars.

Hotels in Peterborough and Riverton were also broke into.

Adelaide Wool Sales last Tuesday and Wednesday saw very firm prices. [Local District prices are printed.]

Burra High School. Three Year 10 students took part in the TV show It’s Academic, which screened on 7 July. They were Andrew Webster, John Hallion and Stephen Woolley. Though not successful, they acquitted themselves well.

The Methodist Circuit Rally at Farrell Flat Hall on Sunday attracted 150 people with the Burra Circuit well represented. Rev. Milton Edwards of Burra conducted the service.

[The headline says ‘International Gathering’ though why it says this is not apparent from the 3⁄4 column report.]

Burra Burra Show Inc. Shearing shed donations have reached $412.

Burra Women’s Branch of the LCL held its AGM and elected: President, Mrs Ron Pearse; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames Ron Collins & Hamline Treweeke; Secretary, Mrs Norman Finch; Assistant Secretary, Mrs Ron Collins and Treasurer, Mrs Roger Dunn.

Guest speaker was Mr Don Jessop, who is seeking a Senate seat at the next election. He spoke on the role of the Senate, seeing it as a house of review. Mrs Ron Pearse as President of the branch reported on the year’s activities.

92, 26, 7 July 1970, page 3

Burra Rural Youth held its AGM. The President reported on an active year in which attendances had been rather low and it was hoped numbers would grow. Secretary Raelene Potticary had to resign due to a teaching transfer and Lyn Willis was elected in her place.

Burra Bowling Club held its AGM.

President M.G. Stockman reported on the 1969-70 season. The greens were in good shape thanks to greensman Chas. Dare. The Club had two teams of twelve players in each of two divisions of Pennant Bowls. The Easter Tournament had been a great success. Catering was done on site this year with an annex erected for the occasion by Dudley Jacka. The present clubhouse is comfortable, but too small and there are moves to rebuild or enlarge it, subject to finance availability. Brian Riggs was Club singles Champion for the season.

Burra Burra DC made a presentation at their annual meeting yesterday to Mr E.T. Baulderstone who had served as a Councillor and Mayor for 24 years. Chairman Mr R. Jeffery spoke of the service of Mr & Mrs Baulderstone to the Town and District. He was supported by Cr B.A. Riggs, Cr C.L .Phillips, Cr G.R. Finch & Cr R.B. Jennison. Mr Baulderstone replied on behalf of his wife and also acknowledged the wonderful support she had given him throughout the period of his service. He hoped the Mine might last the 15 years anticipated, but if it should not go longer, then he was sure tourism would play a big part in the future of Burra. He hoped the mining operation would not destroy too many relics of the old Mine.

92, 26, 7 July 1970, page 12

Burra CWA. The annual report of activities by Secretary N. Nankivell runs for 11⁄3 columns. Membership was 55 and average attendance was 25. Mrs Jennison was the President. Five weddings were catered for. State and Group Officers and branch members visited the cemetery in July to pay homage to Mrs Warnes, the first President and to mark the 40th anniversary of the CWA in SA. The exterior of the CWA rooms were painted and six roses and a shrub were planted to mark the 40th anniversary of the CWA. Mrs Baker had to resign as Treasurer and Mrs Bill Salter took over.

92, 27, 14 July 1970, page 1

Centenary of the Railway to Burra

A double-headed steam train pulled by two Rx class locomotives (numbers 207 & 224) will bring 250 passengers to Burra to celebrate the centenary of the opening of the railway. They are scheduled to arrive at 12.45 p.m., the same time the first train arrived at the opening of the line. Rx locomotives were used on the line from 1906 to 1926. They will use the old turntable before starting for Adelaide at 3 p.m. 100 years ago 3,000 people gathered for the arrival of the first train. The select train bearing the Governor of Sa arrived at 1 p.m. This year’s trip has been organised by the Australian Railway Historical Society in conjunction with the Burra Tourist Committee. The passengers will invade the town in chartered buses to visit local points of interest. Other visitors will come by car. Dr John Wilson has written a publication commemorating the event with many photographs of locomotives and trains on the Northern Line. It will be available on the day at c. $1.50.

Obituary. People of Hallett and District were saddened by the death of Lillie Owen-Smyth of Ulooloo Station, who died suddenly only a fortnight or so after the death of her husband the late Gaynor Owen-Smyth. She seemed forever young and enthusiastic with a disciplined and determined approach to the many tasks she undertook for the local community despite exceeding her three score years and ten. Her great love was the Red Cross, for which she was approaching her 50th year of service and a laurel wreath.

Spalding RSL celebrated its 50th anniversary. [Report extends for c. 1 column.]

Obituary. A Notice to Creditors reveals the death of Mary Lloyd of 8 Paxton Terrace Burra on 6 January 1970.

[She was unmarried, aged 83.]

B.H. Rogers of 18 Paxton Terrace writes querying the District Clerk’s observation that ‘at any given time he expects opposition from half the Ratepayers.’ This is the Rule he said. Mr Rogers wonders where the rule is inscribed and he reminds everyone that the right to criticise or applaud elected members is a privilege of democratic society.

92, 28, 21 July 1970, page 1

Weather. It was extremely cold on Saturday afternoon when hail and light snow fel across the district. At Mt Bryan snow was fairly heavy on the mount and was still visible at Sunset on Sunday.

Thomas Eastman, the Rotary Exchange student from Nebraska USA will arrive at Adelaide airport on Saturday at 10.15 a.m. He will be under the care and responsibility of the Methodist Circuit in Burra during his stay here. His first host family will be Mr & Mrs Gordon Webster where he will spend the first six weeks.

Cr R.B. Jennison writes about the Council’s intention to borrow $75,000, in an attempt to counter some prevalent misconceptions. He says:

It is quite untrue that rates would have to rise as a consequence.

It is not true that the 1970-71 rates are higher than those of last year: they are the same.

It is not true that a consequence will be less money spent on district roads – in fact it is expected to increase.

The amount is not too large. In fact the Council at present is using less than one quarter of its borrowing capacity and this also answers the other false assertion that it is a very big project. Council has borrowings of about half this every year for plant.

In fact the project is vital for the future and with royalties from Samin Ltd we could expect to pay off the loan in c. 5 years.

92, 29, 28 July 1970, page 1

Burra Centenary Train. Locals will be able to travel on the train from Hanson to Burra for 50c one way and $1 return. The full Adelaide-Burra trip will cost $10 for adults and $5 for children.

The Annual Rural Youth Deb of the North Ball was held at Spalding Hall on Friday 24 July. Twenty-two debs were presented to Miss SA Charity Queen Elizabeth Litchfield. Miss Marjorie Wilson of Pt Broughton was Deb of the North for 1970.

Thomas Eastman’s arrival has been delayed. (The Rotary Exchange student from Nebraska.)

Burra Football Club staged a social game between basketball girls and footballers on Sunday afternoon. The game was drawn 4.6 to 3.12 and raised $226.

Franco Zefferelli’s 1968 film of Romeo and Juliet will be screened in Redruth Memorial Hall on Friday evening by the committee of the Methodist Youth Fellowship. Takings will aid the United Development Appeal.

[An overseas aid project of the Methodist and Congregational Churches of Australasia.]

Samin Ltd has announced their intention to spend $2 million in opening up their venture at the Burra Mine. Tenders have closed and are being considered for the construction of operational and administrative buildings and for the removal of overburden.

Burra Bowling Club held a meeting recently of its sub-committee on building plans for the clubhouse. Four plans were considered and they will now go to a special general meeting of members.

Burra Methodist Church will hold a Pleasant Sunday Afternoon on 2 August featuring the popular local quartet led by the Anglican Rector Rev. John Stephenson, the visiting young trio ‘Folkus Pax’ with guest speaker Rev. Kyle Waters, Chaplain to Prince Alfred College.

C. Leslie Phillips writes to urge participation in the poll of ratepayers on the intention of the Council to borrow $75,000 for building at the Town Hall. He says he considers the Town Hall as belonging to the whole district in the same way that the Hospital, Schools, Swimming Pool, Showgrounds and churches etc. do. All the fine buildings of the town were built at a time when many must have doubted whether the time was opportune for the expenditure: ‘surely our generation has not become so selfish that we want to accept all the benefits handed down to us and put nothing back.’

Mary Woollacott writes on her world trip with comments on New York, where she saw Anna Moffo in La Traviata at the Metropolitan Opera. She also tells of crossing the Atlantic in the QE 2.

92, 29, 28 July 1970, page 6

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club

The Department of the Army has inspected the Burra Small Bore Rifle Range and the position of the Housing Trust homes to be erected in Pritchard’s Paddock. The Housing Trust has been able to give only 60 ft clearance from the butt and for safety reasons 80 yards is needed for the range to remain open. The Army has declared the range closed for all shooting. Negotiations are under way for a new site.

At the recent AGM Captain Mike Thomas made the report for the year.

Two new members moved away during the year: Bill White and Phillip Byles of the National Bank (transferred to the Adelaide branch). This year Burra won the Williams Shield for the first time it has been competed for. The club decided to accept the quote of J. Carpenter for cementing the top of the mound. (The next step would be to erect a roof over the mound.) This work has been deferred pending a decision on whether firing can continue at the site as a result of housing being built on the south side. The financial cost of moving would be substantial. Special congratulations go to a new shooter Andrew Pearce, who has made rapid and sustained progress.

[Details continue for 11⁄3 columns.]

92, 29, 28 July 1970, page 7

92, 29, 28 July 1970, page 8

Burra Red Cross held its AGM on 14 July and elected: President, Mrs Baulderstone; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames L. Bence & T. Padbury; Secretary, Mrs S. Gare and Treasurer, Mrs A. Wright. The past year saw six meetings with an average attendance of 10. [Details in 3⁄4 column.]

Burra M & BHA held its AGM and elected: President, H. Stockman; Vice-President, V. Secomb; Secretary, G. Hall; Assistant Secretary, P. Male and Treasurer, J. Broad.

The secretary’s report.

It was a financially successful year, but a disappointing lack of interest was shown by mothers using the clinic. The Baby Boutique in the Burra Town Hall on August was well supported and takings were $254.62. The Annual Badge Day raised $56.80 and a trading table and raffle in November raised $63. Booborowie Young People’s Group Walkathon raised $168.17. This income enabled us to donate $250 as our share of the house at Clare for the Sister in Charge.

92, 30, 4 Aug. 1970, page 1

Burra Ridge Pty Ltd has been impressed by very favourable reports on mineralisation in the area and intends to begin a $200,000 exploration project soon. An office will be established in Burra. The Directors have appointed Southern Cross Explorations as the Manager Operator of its Special Mining Lease covering 990 square miles around Burra. Southern Cross has also acquired 50% interest in the private areas the company holds and a right to acquire 50% interest in the mining titles arising from the Special Mining Lease after exploration. Investigations have found the presence of gold, copper, silver, lead, zinc, vanadium, fluoride, asbestos and phosphate among others. Some copper samples from Princess Royal area have ranged from 7.5 to 14.5% copper and a drilling program has been prepared for this area. Authority to enter areas has been arranged and is being arranged for other sites.

Accident/Obituary

A car and a water truck collided in dusty conditions on Friday about 12.30 p.m. just east of ‘The Gums’ Station on the Bower Road about half a mile from the Burra-Morgan Road. The truck was owned by D. &. K. Launer and driven by Dennis Semmler. The car was driven by Dudley Albert Launer. There were three other passengers in the car and the four occupants were returning from Robertstown, having attended their uncle’s funeral there. After the collision the driver of the truck went to ‘The Gums’ homestead and Dr G. Miller, Burra police and ambulance were summoned. Three occupants of the car were killed instantly and John Lawrence Sachse (22) was found to be dead on arrival at Burra Hospital. The other victims were:

Dudley Albert Launer (38) employed by the Robertstown Council and his brother

Kingsley Norman Launer (24) an earth moving contractor and their cousin

Clarence Norman Launer (40) a share farmer.

All sporting fixtures involving Robertstown Clubs were cancelled for Saturday and a triple funeral was held on Sunday in Robertstown. Mr Sachse’s funeral was held on Monday in Adelaide.

As a result of the above Robertstown Football Club advised that all its teams would forfeit their matches to Auburn on Saturday. On hearing the news the Auburn committee decided to forfeit to Robertstown. Association delegates will now have to decide on the outcome.

92, 30, 4 Aug. 1970, pages 1 & 8

Mid North Bowling Association held its AGM last Friday and elected Murray Stockman as President. Burra will host the Champion of Champions events. Arrangements for the year’s programs are reported.

92, 30, 4 Aug. 1970, page 2

Robert Brandt has won the Fairest & Best Award for the Woomera Football League. He plays for the Village Club.

*These results do not make sense. The absence of Colts results would suggest they are mixed with the above. In the ‘A’ Grade the description says Riverton won by 31 points and this fits neither of the results, but perhaps the second of them is the ‘A’ Grade and the first the Colts. In the ‘B’ Grade the match was described as evenly contested with Aberdeen winning, so perhaps the first is the ‘B’ Grade and the second the Colts, but that can only be speculation.

92, 30, 4 Aug. 1970, page 4

Mary Woollacott writes about attending the Oberammergau Passion Play.

The Burra Railway

A report is printed from the SA Register of 6 January 1869 from a local reporter at Burra.

The railway works here are well advanced and could be completed ahead of contract. Much curiosity is expressed regarding the site of the proposed terminus. Four places are discussed:

Paxton Square, Kooringa.

The Courthouse allotments at Redruth.

An allotment near the Smelting Works on the Burra Survey, Redruth.

The Bon Accord Mine.

The arguments for and against each are:

Paxton Square is in the Township of Kooringa and a station here would increase property values, (the town is the property of the SA Mining Association) but against it is the cost of £20,000 to £40,000 to build bridges over the Burra and Welsh Creeks and in the cuttings and embankments, given that such expenditure would not increase the income by a single shilling.

The Courthouse and Smelting options at Redruth have similar cost objections.

The Bon Accord site is situated at the junction of the North and North-East Roads and is 3⁄4 mile from Kooringa, with which it is connected by a good metal road. There are no allotments on the site which would have to be purchased and it is the nearest possible site to the Burra Mine, with which it could be connected by an inexpensive tramway. There is an abundance of splendid water and it is central to the freehold townships of Copperhouse, Hampton, Nelson and half a dozen others yet to be built on. Its nearness to the Government Township of Redruth means business may be diverted from Kooringa, but the experience from other stations in SA suggests they do not become the best business sites.

92, 30, 4 Aug. 1970, page 5

Rural Youth Movement

There is a 2⁄3 column article on the aims of the movement.

The Upper North Zone Conference was held at Jamestown.

92, 30, 4 Aug. 1970, page 7

Hallett 4.2 defeated Clare South 2.11

Burra North Red Cross held its AGM on 1 July [check this date]

Elected: President, Mrs I. Hirschausen; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames V. Cox & H. Jennison; Secretary, Mrs H. Jennison & Treasurer, Mrs Scroop (as she has been since 1943). Mrs J. Henderson as retiring Secretary reported on the past year. They had 64 members with an average attendance of 15. They had catered for the Masonic Ball in October. Red Cross Calling collected $57.30 and this, together with another $240, was sent to Headquarters for the March Appeal. Our Patroness Mrs Heinrich was 91 in September and in November she received a long service medal. Mrs V. Cox received a long service medal in December. [Further details in the report of c. 1⁄2 column.]

Burra Methodist Church

About 240 people attended the Pleasant Sunday Afternoon. Tom Eastman, the Rotary Exchange student from Kimball, Nebraska, was welcomed. Entertainment was by the local quartet of singers and ‘Folkus Pax’, a young trio from the city. Rev. Kyle Waters gave an address on the subject Give Them to Eat. [Concerning overseas aid projects to increase food production in under-developed countries.]

92, 31, 11 Aug. 1970, page 1

Burra Mine

Roche Bros. Pty Ltd have won the tender for mining the waste and ore at the Burra Mine. The treatment plant, which will comprise an ammonia leach operation producing copper oxide, will be designed and installed in two stages.

Stage 1 will be designed to use 300 tons of ore per day.

Stage 2 will allow this to increase up to 1,000 tons per day.

Tenders have been called for installation of Stage 1.

Removal of waste and preparation for ore extraction will begin in September with the Stage 1 plant expected to be commissioned early in 1971. Stage 2 is in the design stage and should be commissioned by November 1971.

The plan is to site the administration office, workshops and amenities buildings on vacant land south of the Burra Railway Station.

The open cut and treatment areas will be securely fenced and tourist roads will either be maintained or re-routed where necessary.

Mr H.J. Rich has been appointed manager of the operation.

It is estimated 60-70 people will be employed fairly evenly split between the mining and the treatment-administration sites.

Burra Burra DC has asked the Central Board of Health to call tenders for the proposed Burra effluent drainage scheme. When costs are known a public meeting will be called to discuss the matter with those to be connected.

The Council will provide several thousand yards of ‘crusher run’ material from its quarry at the Mine for road sealing. Roche Bros. huge D8machine is working up the metal for crushing. Sealing will be carried out for Samin Ltd around its administration building.

The Savings Bank of SA has given awards for savings to Burra Primary School ($100), Booborowie Primary School ($60) and Burra High School ($50). The awards come in the form of library books.

92, 31, 11 Aug. 1970, page 2

Advt. Burra Pictures, 15 August

Ken Shorter & Rowena Wallace in You Can’t See Round Corners

Rosalind Russell & Sandra Dee in Rosie

Obituary. Mr P.T. Sandland died at Moora WA 13 July aged 87. He was born in SA and his home was part of the Koonoona Station. He spent the greater part of his life in WA, buying the property ‘Burrabidgy’ at Moora in 1908. As a young man he was a prominent footballer and at the time of his death the oldest holder of the Magarey Medal.

[Philip Thomas Sandland born 5 December 1882 Mannanarie, SA.]

Obituary. Mr George McLean of Gawler died recently. He was a strong supporter and exhibitor at Burra Shows in the poultry and pigeon sections and a judge in these sections at many shows including Burra.

[George Albert William McLean born 5 August 1896 Gawler: died 24 July 1970 Gawler.]

SA Housing Trust in Burra

The first of the new homes arrived yesterday with three or four more to follow in this and the next week. Several brick homes will then be erected.

92, 32, 18 Aug. 1970, page 1

Burra Cemetery. The new section on the eastern side has been fenced and made stock-proof, with ramps incorporated in the fencing on the northern and eastern entrances. The general section of the cemetery has been filled and the new area is ready for use.

St Mary’s. The 4th Bishop of Willochra the Rt Rev. S.B. Rosier will visit Burra on Monday. The special Liturgical Reception service will be preceded by an organ recital by Dr J.V. Peters. The Quire Saint Nicholas will also come from Adelaide for the occasion. Supper in the Parish Hall will follow. The Bishop will address the St Mary’s Guild in the Parish Hall on Tuesday at 2.30 p.m.

Burra Methodist Church.

The recent Pleasant Sunday Afternoon raised just over $100 and the young people have since raised another $100. The church has arranged for the screening of the new film Australian Football in the Town Hall on Wednesday 26 August, which will also aid the United Development Appeal.

Burra Railway Centenary. Arrangements are well in hand for the arrival of the special centenary train on 29 August. [Details in 3⁄4 column.]

Burra Golf Club held its Open Day and 97 players braved the trying weather conditions.

92, 33, 25 Aug. 1970, page 1

Mr H. Picken of Victoria writes to complain of loutish behaviour in the Caravan Park. A utility was driven at speed close to their caravan at about 9.30 p.m. and in doing so wrenched the power lead from the van. His wife picked it up before noticing the plug had been torn off and the live wires were protruding. She was lucky to escape electrocution.

Weather. Rainfall to the east has delivered 23 points to Braemar, 55 at both Glenora and Redcliffe and 81 at Glenora Dam. Burra recorded 18 points.

Mid North Adult Education Centre conducted a Living History School for 50 people at Burra on 16 August. Mr Ian Auhl travelled from Adelaide to conduct the event. In the morning participants visited the Mine site, the old Redruth Gaol and the Dugouts. After lunch Mr Auhl gave an address on the history and development of the area, illustrated with slides. This group will be among the last people to visit the old mining area, as this week it will be fenced off for the new mining operations.

Burra Railway Centenary. The book on the illustrated history of the Northern Railway Line to Burra by Dr J.L. Wilson will be available for $1.50 on the day of the Centenary Train. There will be an Art Group Exhibition at the RSL Hall, including some of Maurice Perry’s sketches from Burra Sketch Book.

92, 33, 25 Aug. 1970, page 2

Birth. To Tim Kakoschke of Booborowie last week, a son.

Marriage. Due to an accident at Gawler the marriage of Coralie Eberhard and Darrell Field has been postponed from last Saturday to next Friday.

Accident. Darrell Field [Jnr] was involved in a collision on the Gawler by-pass road last Saturday and was taken to the Lyall McEwin Hospital for observation and stitches to a cut knee. He was not seriously hurt and returned home yesterday.

Sergeant Terry Opie, who has been serving in Malaya for three years, has been transferred to Edinburgh RAAF Base.

92, 34, 1 Sep. 1970, page 1

Weather. Rainfall throughout the district averaged about 2 inches in the past week. While this has been the best rainfall in the agricultural areas for 14 years, the pastoral areas to the east still require a good rain.

Red Cross Sunday was observed nation-wide on 16 August. Locally a service was held at Mt Bryan Methodist Church, which brought together members from all over the Northern Region of Red Cross SA. Mrs Don Bailey gave an inspiring address.

92, 34, 1 Sep. 1970, pages 1 & 4 & 4-5 gutter

92, 34, 1 Sep. 1970, pages 1 & 8

Burra Railway Centenary

On Saturday a train hauled by two Rx class locomotives and carrying approximately 600 passengers drew into Burra station 100 years to the minute after the arrival of the first train in 1870. The train carried 340 passengers from Adelaide and an additional 178 from Hanson. It arrived at precisely 12.45 p.m. It was greeted by Mr R. J. Jeffery, Chairman of the Burra Burra DC. [Mr Jeffery’s speech is printed.] Mr E.C. Allen MP then also spoke. [His speech is printed.] Mr Peter Shearer, Acting Traffic Manager for SAR then spoke. [His mother was formerly Miss Elsie Tiver of Burra.] Mr P.F. Pollnitz spoke for the SA Government Tourist Bureau followed by Mr Ken Wicker. The train then broke through a commemorative ribbon.

A number of people dressed in period costume. Countless photographs were taken of the train in the station before it moved on to the cutting at the rear of the showgrounds for further photographs. Some 200 of the passengers had a bus tour of Burra and another bus ran a commuter service between the station and Market Square. Burra Kindergarten ladies provided hot soup and a cake and sweets stall in the goods shed. An official afternoon tea was held in the Kooringa Hotel hosted by Mr & Mrs Jeffery.

The engines were turned on the turntable near the Bon Accord crossing and they were watered and coaled for the return run. The train left for Adelaide at 3.40 p.m. [Photo at the Burra Station of Rx 224 & 207.]

92, 34, 1 Sep. 1970, page 2

Burra Mine. T. O’Connor & Sons of Adelaide have won the main contract for construction of the Burra Copper Mine plant – valued in excess of $1.2 million.

92, 35, 8 Sep. 1970, page 1

Burra Mine

The Mine area has been closed to the public for safety reasons. Large earth-moving machinery is moving through the area. Recently a near fatal accident occurred when a big fully-laden water tanker was climbing out and encountered tourists heading down in a car. The car driver did not reverse out and it was only with difficulty that the truck driver was able to engage reverse gear and control its descent to the bottom. It could have careered out of control to the depths below. Once the eastern side is fenced the District Council will complete new scenic roads to enable operations to be observed. A new access road ahs been opened to the rubbish tip from opposite the hospital and the Burra North access has been closed.

Mining equipment is arriving at the Burra Railway Station. New site offices will arrive tomorrow. Building of offices, amenities block, control rooms and magazines will be carried out by Jaxon Constructions Ltd. McMahon Constructions Pty Ltd will be responsible for earthworks and concrete construction – both are subcontractors for T.C. O’Connor & Sons. Roche Bros are building the main haulage road for the quarry or mine to the primary crushing area and the main Fines Dam. They have been moving 4-5,000 yards a day and it will be necessary to move another 140-150,000 yards to provide a cutting down to the mine.

Burra Burra Show Inc.

Donations for the Shearing Shed have reached $758. The shed will be erected shortly and will be 40 ft x 20 ft. Further donations will reduce the deficit of c. $100.

Burra Rail Centenary

Photo of the double-headed Rx-hauled train on the embankment leading to the showgrounds cutting.

92, 35, 8 Sep. 1970, pages 1 & 8

Burra Rail Centenary. Extract from the SA Register, 30 August 1870.

Monday 29 August was set for the opening of the North Extension Line. The date was chosen chiefly because the MPs legislative duties prevented them from visiting Burra on the four successive days.

A local committee of 30-40 residents arranged the public demonstration, chaired by Mr W.H. Rosman, manager of the National Bank. The select train started soon after 8 a.m. with a Vice-Regal and Ministerial Party. [The official party is then listed.]

There was an official welcome at Saddleworth and then at 12.45 the special came within inspection distance of the Aberdeen terminus where it was met by ‘a host of strong, healthy looking men, hearty matrons, rosy cheeked damsels and a reserve of children such as only a mining community can boast of.’

All available space was adorned with pine and wattle boughs and the buildings set off with a display of evergreens ;which might have been Birnham Wood come back again to Dunsinane, as in the days of Macbeth.’

The goods shed had been clothed in evergreens till it looked like a bower 100 ft x 40 ft and the Carriage shed was similar on a smaller scale. The select carriages arrived at 1 p.m. and His Excellency and party were conducted to a special reserve adjoining the cattle platform. A round of loyal cheers followed from the crowd of c. 3,000

‘The local ordnance had fired an irregular salute.’

[Mr W.H. Rosman’s address to the Governor is printed as is His Excellency’s reply.]

92, 35, 8 Sep. 1970, pages 2 & 3

Cycling. The Burra-Adelaide Cycling Classic will be held next Saturday. This year it will be run by the Norwood Cycling Club, which id the oldest Cycling Club in the Southern Hemisphere. The route will be: Market Square, Mt Bryan, Market Square, Manoora, Saddleworth, Riverton, Tarlee, Kapunda, Greenock, Sheoak Log, Gawler, Elizabeth Yorketown Road and Elizabeth Shopping Centre.

Obituary. Curio, the wonder buck jumper died earlier this year aged 28, but her offspring will not let her be forgotten. It took ten years before anyone stayed on her for the required ten seconds and that was Allan Wood in 1953. Offspring include: Son of Curio, Curio’s Special, Curiosity and Curio’s Last.

Best Players for 1970

92, 36, 15 Sep. 1970, page 1

Burra Mine

Scenic Roads are expected to be open for tourists by mid-October.

It is impossible to open the area at present due to the amount of large machinery working in the area, to constructional changes made to roads and to landslides. Blasting in the near future is also a concern. Fencing of the dangerous area will begin this week, after which work will be undertaken to admit tourists, possibly by mid-October, with views from near the water tank on the hill and from the southern hill.

The Kapunda Musical Society will present Lilac Time at Burra on 17 October at 8 p.m. [in the Town Hall] to aid the Burra Swimming Pool.

Vandals and careless tourists are causing concern to the Lewis Trust. The site is a gazetted Historic Relic and under an Act of Parliament damage can earn a fine of $200 or six months in gaol.

92, 36, 15 Sep. 1970, pages 1 & 8

Burra-Adelaide Cycling Race

The winner of the 100 mile handicap event was the 56-year-old President of the Norwood Cycling Club, Ira Steele. This is the fourth time in as many years that an older rider has triumphed.

1969 Colin Shaw (44)

1968 Vic Dodman (54)

1967 Keith ‘Jock’ Thurgood (58)

Mr Steele lives at Torrensville. He in fact started 21⁄2 minutes after his co-markers as he had gone off to loosen up and arrived a bit late. The winner’s time was 4 hours 13 minutes 15 seconds. The fastest time was B. Gould in 3 hours 33 minutes 40 seconds, which was a race record. [Details occupy c. 2 columns.]

92, 36, 15 Sep. 1970, page 5

Aberdeen Tennis Club held its AGM, which was poorly attended as usual. The bank balance was in credit $121. Mr 7 Mrs S. Scroop resigned the joint Secretary-Treasurer position after thirty years. President Robert Reed reported on a successful year in which the ‘A’ Grade White team and the Junior team won their respective premierships. Number one court was re-laid by Mr I. Hirschausen during the year. Elected were: President, R. Reed; Vice-Presidents, Messrs C. Lloyd & S. Scroop and secretary-Treasurer, M. & D. Lloyd.

Advt. Burra Pictures, 19 September

David Niven & Lola Albright in The Impossible Years

Hugh O’Brien & Cyd Charisse in Assassination in Rome

Weather. Snow fell yesterday at Mt Bryan, Hallett, Ulooloo and Peterborough.

92, 36, 15 Sep. 1970, page 7

Burra High School will have a group of students taking part in a test to survey the science knowledge of 5,500 Australian 14-year-old students and 60,000 students world wide.

92, 36, 15 Sep. 1970, page 8

Football. The Mortlock Cup, the Champion Club Award, was presented for the first time this year and was won by Riverton Football Club, with the Premiership.

Basketball. North Eastern Grand Finals

‘A’ Grade Booborowie 44 defeated Burra Gold 24

‘B’ Grade Spalding Red 37 defeated Leighton 30

‘C’ Grade Leighton 47 defeated Booborowie 19

‘D’ Grade Hallett 14 defeated Spalding 13

Best ‘A’ Grade Player Award, the Julie Affolter Trophy, was awarded for the first time and went to Heather Short of Burra Gold. The award commemorates Julie Affolter who died this year in a car accident.

[Julie Anne Affolter (14): see 92, 2 (3), 20 Jan. 1970, page 2.]

92, 37, 22 Sep. 1970, page 1

Burra Mine

The newly formed local company Howe Enterprises has won a large sub-contract to fence the Burra Copper Mine. This involves about two miles of six-foot-high chain mesh fencing. Howe Enterprises is a consortium of Messrs O’Connor & Co., Hirschausen Bros. and Wardle & Sons. Mr Hope, Site Manager of the Burra Mine, says work is well under way. About 40 men are currently working on the site.

Burra Hospital Board thanks Mrs J.M. Rooke for the gift of a piano.

‘Baldina’ the 59,231 acres property, was sold on Friday for $126,000 after being passed in at $110,000. The buyer was Deveri Pty Ltd of Adelaide.

Burra High School

Mr E.C. Allen MP asked the Minister of Education to report on the inspection of the site recently and to say when the new Burra High School would be commenced. [He provided background information of the present situation with its 100-year-old building, shared site with the Primary School, temporary classrooms and crowding at the present site.

The Minister said the inspection confirmed the need for a new High School. It was presently programmed to have the new school ready for the start of 1974 and an endeavour would be made to advance this date, but that would depend on Commonwealth funding. The existing building would then be upgraded to meet the needs of the Primary School.

92, 37, 22 Sep. 1970, page 2

Football. North Eastern League Grand Finals

‘A’ Grade Burra 13.13 defeated Booborowie 11.8

‘B’ Grade Burra 7.8 defeated Clare North 6.7

Colts Clare South 7.8 defeated Clare North 6.9

Junior Colts Booborowie 11.7 defeated Burra 1.2

The Burra Football Club created a record by completing the season without a defeat. Last year they almost achieved this, only to lose the Grand Final to Booborowie. This is a Club record, but in the League Booborowie has won 28 matches straight, taking it beyond one season.

92, 37, 22 Sep. 1970, page 3

Mr & Mrs F.E. Williams (nee Alice Byrnes) today celebrate their Diamond Wedding solemnised at Kooringa Methodist Church by Rev. Farley on 22 September 1910. [Frederick Edward Williams.]

Football. Inter-League Match at Riverton

Woodville 16.25 defeated Mid North 13.3

Hallett district Clerk Mr Max Petersen, who has been on the position for three years, suffered severe spinal injuries in a car accident recently. He will probably be confined to a wheelchair. A cabaret at Hallett on 24 October will raise funds to assist the family in this time of financial difficulty.

92, 37, 22 Sep. 1970, page 4 & 4-5 gutter

Football. The North Eastern Mini-League sent a team to the State Mini-League Championships. They did not reach the finals and achieved only one win when they beat Broken Hill by a point 1.1 to 1.0.

92, 37, 22 Sep. 1970, page 5

Burra Burra DC, 31 August

Crs Kellock & Finch moved that the new Housing Trust area street be called Lewis Street.

Crs Jennison & T. Quinn moved that Mr Stirling arrange a meeting with the SAR concerning road closing. Carried.

The CWA offer of a stove for the kitchen was accepted with thanks.

It was resolved that as the Convent is closing* the Education Department be informed that the Primary School could expect an increase in students and the priority for the new High School should receive attention.

Note the transfer from M.F. Pritchard to the Housing Trust of SA of lots 5, to 14, Pt lot 10 of Section 1 Hd Kooringa and lots 1 to 4, 15, 16, 17 & 22 laid out in Burra (Kooringa) and also from D.C. Campbell of lot 37 Section 1 to the Housing Trust of SA.

[* Rather strangely not only is this the first intimation of this move, but in fact the closure of the convent and school after almost a century at the present site is not otherwise reported.]

92, 37, 22 Sep. 1970, page 6

Advt. Burra Pictures

Tom Jones & Michelle Morgan in Ben Jamin

John & Eileen Wilkin are running the new roadhouse in Hallett. The grocery section should open in about three weeks.

Several prefabricated buildings arrived this morning. [Presumably Housing Trust homes for the Smelts Road area.]

92, 37, 22 Sep. 1970, page 7

Burra Golf Club. The ‘A’ Grade Champion for 1970 is S. Longford.

Accident. A car carrying four Adelaide Youths rolled over on the Collinsville Road at Mt Bryan East last night. The occupants escaped with a shaking.

92, 38, 29 Sep. 1970, page 1

Weather. A good soaking rain has at last fallen throughout the pastoral area. Falls were generally in the range 150 to 200 points for the week, but in most places it provided little run-off. Over the weekend Burra recorded 148 points and World’s End 173.

St John Ambulance Brigade is launching a state appeal for $250,000 to provide 24 new centres across the metropolitan and country areas. The Burra Branch quota to raise is $1,000.

Burra Boy Scouts will celebrate their first birthday with a camp fire social with parents and friends on Friday 16 October. More adult leaders are urgently needed.

Burra Library has decided to make books available to construction workers and other workers at the mine.

World’s End Methodist Church will host a Circuit Rally and Anniversary Service next Sunday. A picnic at the Gorge will follow.

92, 38, 29 Sep. 1970, page 3

Burra Penguin Club celebrated its 4th birthday in the Town Hall Supper Room on Wednesday. About 70 guests attended; many from groups in other centres across SA. President Mrs A. McInnes welcomed all present.

Oraparinna Station has been purchased for a National Park. The 150,000 acre station includes a wide range of vegetation and country types in the Flinders Ranges.

Burra & Districts Swimming Pool Auxiliary presented its annual report. Only two meetings were held in the year and no fund-raising took place. All members were in favour of the Burra Burra DC taking over future management and maintenance with a full-time supervisor appointed.

92, 38, 29 Sep. 1970, page 4

Mary Woollacott writes again of her trip ‘Around the World in Seven Months’. This time she writes of South England and Wales before going on to Northern England and Scotland.

92, 38, 29 Sep. 1970, page 5

Advt. Burra Pictures, 3 October

Paul McCartney & Haley Mills in The Family Way

George Montgomery & Gilbert Roland in Samar

92, 38, 29 Sep. 1970, page 6

Weather. Heavy rain on Saturday damaged some of the new concrete poured at the Burra Mine.

Geoffrey Jones of Hallett graduated last Tuesday from the Police Academy at Fort Largs. He is the son of Mrs Irene Jones.

Marriage. Redruth Methodist Church, 3 October

Sue Kakoschke will marry Ken Fiebig.

Marriage. At Menindie, NSW next Saturday

Miss Margaret Conrick will marry Tom Jackson of Elders-GM.

Burra Golf Associates held their AGM on 23 September and elected: Patroness, Mrs F. Reed; President, Mrs R. Wuttke; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames D. Field & E. Jeffery; Secretary, Mrs r. Hillman; Treasurer, Mrs R. Gebhardt; Captain, Mrs J. Oates and Vice-Captain Mrs D. Kempster.

Trophy winners were:

‘A’ Grade Champion Mrs E. Jeffery

‘B’ Grade Champion Mrs J. Wiseman

‘C’ Grade Champion Mrs. D. O’Reilly

92, 38, 29 Sep. 1970, page 8

Burra Burra Show Inc. Shearing Shed donations have reached $931.

92, 39, 6 Oct. 1970, page 1

The Burra Show will be opened by the Governor Sir James Harrison, who is on a three day tour of the area. He will meet Councillors on Saturday morning at the Town Hall at 10 a.m. before going on to the showgrounds. A shearing shed has been erected for this year’s show, which will feature a good range of sideshows and motor cycle trials as a new feature.

Thefts.

The safe at T.W. Wilkinson & Co. was broken into on the night of Tuesday-Wednesday last week and $350 in cash was stolen.

A stolen car with three young occupants was stopped at Burra on Wednesday morning. It had been taken from Campbelltown.

Petrol was stolen from a car at the Burra Telephone Exchange on Tuesday night and 43 gallons has also been stolen from a container at the Mine.

Adelaide Wool Sales last Wednesday and Thursday. The top local price went to ‘Ashrose’ Hallett at 411⁄2c.

[Other local district prices are printed.]

Accident. A car driven by Miss Deidre Sutton of Booborowie overturned on the Emu Downs Road near Koonoona last Tuesday. The driver and passenger, Terry Hocking, were admitted to the Burra Hospital and Hocking was later transferred to Adelaide.

Burra Mine.

Blasting operations will commence in the next fortnight. It is vital that no one except authorised persons enter the quarry through any other entrance than Linkson Street. The area is being fully fenced. No one is admitted to the site without a pass from the office of O’Connor & Son in Linkson Street.

The Bon Accord pipeline, a six inch main from the old mine shaft to the Processing Plant is three quarters completed. All sewerage services for the administration and plant area have been laid. Storm water service for the area is nearing completion. Work has started of the primary crusher footings and the leach tank footings. The 1.5 million gallon reclaim dam has been started. It will reclaim all used water on the site for re-use. The ‘Fines’ dam of 110,000 cubic yards has been completed. The fines will be processed later in stage 2 of the project. ETSA supply to the site should be completed by the end of this week. Fencing is ahead of schedule and should allow tourist facilities to be provided near the E & WS water tank for the show weekend. At present about 80 men are employed and this should rise to about 250 by mid-November.

92, 39, 6 Oct. 1970, page 3

Obituary. A Notice to Creditors reveals the death of James Francis Hogan, a retired pensioner, at Clare 14 June 1970. [Born 6 May 1894 Redruth, SA.]

Cricket.

Koonaburra 96 v. Booborowie 62

Spalding 9 for 126 defeated Leighton 8 for 112.

Mary Woollacott continues her account of ‘Around the World in Seven Months’. She writes of London, Scotland and the return to London via York, Harrogate, Nottingham, Coventry, Stratford-on-Avon and Oxford.

Notice. Tenders are called for the purchase of lot 25; 9 St Just Street – property of the late Alfred Thomas Brandon.

Bank Merger. The ANZ Bank and the ES & A Bank merged on 1 October to form the Australian & New Zealand Banking Group Ltd.

Vandalism. The recently restored miners’ dugout has been defaced with initials, drawings and obscenities.

92, 40, 13 Oct. 1970, page 1

Vandals again rendered the telephone at the Burra North Post Office useless on Sunday morning.

Accident. Garry James of Koomooloo Station suffered a severely broken upper arm and the loss of a thumb when the car he was driving overturned on the Mt Bryan Road near Cobb & Co.’s Corner. He and a passenger, Andrew Phillips of Burra, were taken to Burra Hospital by Patrick Brown of ‘The Grove’. Garry was later transferred to Adelaide. [An item on page 6 adds that Garry will be 19 next Saturday.]

92, 40, 13 Oct. 1970, pages 1 & 7

Burra Show

Overall entries were down slightly, but birds and ring events were in record numbers. The gate was $656; down about $25. The show was officially opened by His Excellency the Governor in perfect weather.

[The headline wrongly describes this as the 96th show – an error repeated by the President.]

Mr Roy Humphrys, who unfortunately was in hospital, was thanked for his untiring efforts in cleaning up the grounds. The Governor arrived on Friday afternoon by train from Peterborough and in the morning had a look around the town. The official party was entertained at luncheon.

Shearing was a major attraction. The open event was won by S. Pittaway and the novice by K. Bruce, who also won the ‘Local Shearer’ prize.

Miss E. Russell was Miss Show Girl.

Ian Auhl and Samin Ltd arranged a series of photographs of the old mine area from 1870-1875.

The Rural Youth display had the theme of Farm Safety.

School displays were a credit to students and staff and the industrial displays were varied.

The motor cycle trials were run for the first time this year and were a great success. The winner was B. Diener of Mt Bryan.

The Rural Youth hosted the Show Night Dance in the RSL Hall. ‘Sound and Image’ supplied the music, ensuring that the dance appealed only to young people. The behaviour of a few in attendance was not very ‘becoming’.

[Main prize winners for the show are listed.]

92, 40, 13 Oct. 1970, page 2

Advt. Gent’s Hair Stylist, 11 Commercial Street, Burra. Under new management from 19 October.

Governor’s Visit. The members of the Burra Burra DC and their wives were introduced to the Governor, Sir James Harrison and Lady Harrison at the Town Hall. On behalf of the Council Mr Brian Riggs presented the Governor with a framed sketch of Market Square prepared by Maurice Perry and a copy of the Burra Sketchbook.

Mary Woollacott continues her letters from Around the World in seven Months. This week she writes of Spain and heading into Portugal.

92, 40, 13 Oct. 1970, page 6

Mr Dunhill turned 96 yesterday. On Saturday he enjoyed a visit to the show. He is now a resident at Burra Hospital.

Treven Burnett, elder son of Mr & Mrs H. Burnett of Burra North, will marry

Gayle Lawson of Pt Wakefield. Treven is a PMG technician and the couple will live at Balaklava.

Market Square Museum had over 250 signatures in its visitors’ book over the weekend.

92, 40, 13 Oct. 1970, page 7

Ironmine Methodist Church was crowded on 30 September when about 80 ladies gathered to hear a musical program presented by visitors from Adelaide: Mrs Melva Bartel (piano), Mrs Dorothy White (soprano), Miss Greig (contralto) and Mrs Crane (humorous recitations).

Football. At Manoora on Saturday

West Whyalla Colts 12.5 defeated Mid North Colts 7.11

92, 41, 20 Oct. 1970, page 1

Burra Mine

The new scenic road will be open by next weekend 24 October. It will not be a 60 m.p.h. road, but a plain access road to be updated as time moves on. Access is at the bend on the road between Burra and Burra North, known as Carpenter’s Corner. From there it crosses the creek, turning south, skirts the old mullock dump and joins the old scenic lookout road at the top end of the dump. You can then follow the road to the lookout point over Burra and carry on around past echo point to the old powder magazine. From there you can look down on the new processing plant under construction and also into the open cut. The site engineer, Mr R.E. Hope, emphasises that tourists are not allowed within the fenced mine area.

Tom Eastman the Rotary Exchange student has moved to the home of Mr & Mrs John Drew of Booborowie. Until now he has been staying with Mr & Mrs Gordon Webster of Burra. In the September school holidays he had the opportunity to visit the Snowy Mountains and early this month went to Adelaide to a botany Convention. Over the Christmas Holidays Tom will be with Mr & Mrs W. Klem of Farrell Flat.

Burra Burra Show Inc. Shearing Shed donations have now reached $1,029.

Bowls. Associates President Dorrie Pietsch welcomed about 100 bowlers and guests to the opening of the season on Wednesday 14 October. The opening was performed by SAWBA Vice-President Mrs Ruth Dall. The President of the Burra Club Mr Edgar Pietsch welcomed visitors and players to the opening of the season on Saturday last and called on Mr Binks-Williams to declare the season open.

92, 41, 20 Oct. 1970, pages 1 & 6

Messrs Ian Tiver & Roger Nutt welcomed persons interested in inspecting the shearing of their fine wool ‘Merryville’ sheep for the first time on Friday 17 October. The sheep have been in the district for twelve months. Mr Tiver and Mr Nutt bought 300 ewes of pure ‘Merryville’ blood twelve months ago to introduce fine wool Merino sheep to their Hallett properties. The wool was a remarkably attractive clean staple with very little variation in the staple of 70’s quality wool. The ewes averaged 10 lbs of wool from Mr Nutt and Ian Tiver expected about a pound less from his, due to a harder time through winter. The beautiful handling wool is brighter and softer than their own type of wool and everyone was interested to see that such wool could be grown in country with an average rainfall of c. 16.5 inches. [Further details are given in an article of c. 11⁄4 columns.]

92, 41, 20 Oct. 1970, page 2

Weather. Eastern pastoral areas received about half an inch of rain on Sunday night.

Notice. The SA Housing Trust calls tenders by 11 November 1970 for the erection of a residence, station and cell block at Burra.

92, 41, 20 Oct. 1970, page 3

Cricket

Spalding 4 for 177 defeated Mt Bryan 5 for 176

Hallett forfeited to Koonaburra

Burra Mine

The Department of Mines Chief Inspector was in Burra today to make tests in relation to blasting. Work will commence this week on installing a new pump in the Bon Accord Shaft to supply water for the Burra area. This replaces the old pump in the Bon Accord.

ETSA has completed its supply to the Samin site and the Mine has been fenced. About 100 men are currently employed.

Michael York & Jeremy Kemp in The Strange Affair

Nick Adams & Jeanine Riley in Fever Heat

Mt Bryan Methodist Sunday School held its Anniversary last Sunday. The preacher was Rev. Trevor O’Brien.

Geoffrey Collins has transferred to Kadina with the ANZ Bank.

Marriage. At Plympton next Saturday

Don Griffiths will marry Barbara Waters.

Marriage. At Maitland next Saturday

Judith Hallett will marry John Teague, formerly of Burra.

Lilac Time was quite a successful production at the Town Hall last Saturday. Takings were $150 and the Burra Swimming Pool will benefit by $65.

Notice. The Burra Burra DC intends to close and sell to the adjoining owner the following road: That portion of Elphick Terrace between lots 214, 213, 212 and 205, 203 and 204 in the Town of Burra.

92, 42, 27 Oct. 1970, page 1

Burra Mine

Unfortunately the scenic drive was not open at the weekend because the fence was not quite finished. It is hoped it will be ready this weekend. Tourists must observe the signage at the Mine and severe penalties face anyone who enters forbidden areas. Work is proceeding on the large leach tanks. The first of the tank bases and tops arrived last week by road. They are over 22 ft in diameter. The remainder are due within weeks. The 150,000 gallon storage tank for the Bon Accord water supply should be completed, tested and filled in the next 18 days. Other site services are well advanced. Tests on blasting noise and vibrations showed ‘the effect very negligent [sic] and will not effect [sic] people in the district.’ A siren will warn of blasting, which will normally be once a day.

Accident. Peter Brown of Burra escaped serious injury when his car overturned on the Burra-Hallett Road on Sunday morning.

The Hallett Cabaret to benefit accident victim Max Petersen on Saturday night, was very successful and it seems it will realise something over $620 after deducting expenses of about $240.

The Adelaide Harmony Choir under conductor Lewis Dawe will visit Burra on Saturday 7 November to present a series of selected carols, spirituals and traditional songs. The main work will be Hiawatha’s Wedding Feast by Coleridge Taylor, with tenor Malcolm Potter as soloist.

Adelaide Wool Sales 29-30 September saw values fall by 5-71⁄2%. [Local district prices are printed.]

Harold Bughurst of Hyde Park writes to acknowledge the great holiday weekend enjoyed by members of the Cowell-Cleve and Unley Camera Clubs, who visited Burra for their fifth annual inter-club competition. Some 60 visiting photographers enjoyed the hospitality of the town and the Burra Camera Club, which provided a picnic lunch at the Gorge and arranged visits to Redbanks and Mongolata Goldfield.

Burra Town Hall Pictures has long relied on volunteers. Projectionist Walter Nankivell and assistant Guy Dollman, with ticket-seller Jack Topsfield and doorkeeper Stan Kellaway. There is presently a vacancy on the gallery door.

92, 42, 27 Oct. 1970, page 2

Burra Primary School

59 students from Grades VI & VII visited Adelaide on 22 October. They travelled by coach to Adelaide and visited Parliament as guests of Mr E.C .Allen MP and then went to Port Stanvac Oil Refinery. After lunch they visited Adelaide Airport and the Chrysler factory on South Road. At 4 p.m. they visited Cowandilla Demonstration School where they viewed new open unit type class rooms. There was a final stop at Parliament House to see a sitting of the House before leaving at 5.40 p.m. They got back to Burra at 9.10 p.m.

92, 42, 27 Oct. 1970, page 3

The Mid North Football League met at Saddleworth on 19 October in a special meeting to settle the question of umpires for 1971. Rex Crouch of Rhynie was granted life membership.

Samin Ltd advises it will be interviewing people on 28 & 29 October for positions as unskilled labourers, boiler attendants (certificate needed), tradesmen fitters, welders, electricians and storekeeper.

92, 43, 3 Nov. 1970, page 1

Milton H. Edwards writes to explain the necessity of suspending the Church Youth Programme, but his letter fails to make the cause clear at this distance in time, though presumably it was well understood when he wrote.

He speaks of the difficulties which have existed from the first instance that the group was formed and which it has not been possible to resolve.

‘This action is symptomatic of a deep-seated social problem which exists at the very heart of the Burra Community. Different expressions of the same problem are occurring at every level of social activity. It is not only the youth who are irresponsible.’

[Rev. Edwards refers to the circular he sent to parents in September, apparently spelling out the problem. He does not now make it more explicit than in the sentence quoted above.]

St John Ambulance Building Campaign. The total raised to date is $159. [Check if this is pages 1 & 7]

Hallett Flower Show attracted 579 entries plus 439 in the Juvenile Section. 150 people attended.

[The list of prize winners is printed.] [Check if this is pages 1 & 7]

Obituary. Mr Walter Stanley Ellery aged 56 of Burra North died on Wednesday as the result of a gunshot wound. He died several hours after being admitted to hospital. [Born 2 January 1914 Undalya.]

St Mary’s Ladies’ Guild held a Children’s Fancy Dress frolic on Friday night and raised $180 for Missions.

Fireworks will from now on only be legally sold for one week concluding with the Saturday of the Queen’s Birthday Holiday weekend. This is a reduction from two weeks concluding 24 May.

Booborowie Football & Basketball Clubs held a presentation dinner at the Memorial Hall on Friday night.

[Details in a little more than 1 column.]

92, 43, 3 Nov. 1970, page 3

Chapel Street Bridge. When a loaded petroleum transport and trailer drove across the bridge on Wednesday some of the jarrah cross members gave way allowing some of the roadway to collapse. The gross weight of the vehicle was about 36 tons. The collapse occurred when the trailer was on the bridge and eighteen of the thirty-two drums of distillate slid into the creek. They were reloaded per chain attached to a Council tractor.

Tennis

Mt Bryan Green 14-98 defeated Mt Bryan 6-84

‘C’ Grade Mt Bryan 12-72 defeated Spalding white 0-14

Juniors Mt Bryan 14-72 defeated Spalding 0-12

92, 43, 3 Nov. 1970, page 8

Mary Woollacott continues ‘Around the World in seven Months’. This account places her in London and preparing for their departure on the Orcades from Southampton.

92, 44, 10 Nov. 1970, page 1

Burra Caravan Park

Burra Burra DC has applied for a subsidy on an extra Caravan Park to be located opposite the existing park on the other side of the creek. With the increasing number of tourists an extension of existing facilities is necessary. The proposed new facility would cost about $8,000, of which half should be granted as a subsidy. This would allow powered sites for twenty vans with toilets, showers etc. This is an increase of 50% on the present facility. Camp sites for twenty tents with the possibility of at least ten more power points on the northern end if necessary. In the twelve months to 30 June the number of ‘caravan days’ has doubled on the previous year to bring in the fees of $1,365.

The Bon Accord Bridge has been demolished in the last few days. It is understood to have been erected in 1898.* E.R. Way & Sons of Thebarton won the contract to demolish and remove the structure. The bridge will not be replaced, but a concrete causeway is likely to keep the road open.

[* The bridge was erected in 1892: see XV, 221, 7 Dec. 1892, page 3.]

Cattle for Koonoona. Possibly the largest consignment of cattle ever to arrive in Burra by rail was unloaded yesterday en route to Koonoona. The cattle left Oodnadatta on Saturday morning and were transhipped at Marree and Peterborough, arriving at Burra at 11.30 a.m. yesterday. The mob of 510 cattle was walked to the property.

St Mary’s. The Bishop of Willochra, the Rt Rev. S.B. Crosier will conduct a confirmation service in St Mary’s on 15 November for 18 candidates.

Kooringa Methodist Fete raised $204. [Details in 2⁄3 column.]

92, 44, 10 Nov. 1970, page 2

Bon Accord Museum

The Director of the SA Museum Dr W. Gran Inglis visited Burra yesterday to meet the Burra Branch of the National Trust and to inspect the proposed site for the museum at the Bon Accord Mine buildings. He thought the buildings could become one of the biggest drawcards in the future of tourism in Burra. He inspected the site with Mr L. Moore President of the Burra Branch and Mr R.K .Pearse President of the Merino Stud Breeders Association. He said the exhibition relating to the Merino Studs of the district could well be of more importance than the mining relics; located at the centre of the SA Merino Stud area, it could assume national importance.

The Ambulance Building Campaign Fund has reached $209.

Tennis

‘A’ Grade Mt Bryan 14-106 defeated Aberdeen White 6-80

Kooringa 13-97 defeated Aberdeen Blue 7-85

‘B’ Grade Spalding 10-84 defeated Mt Bryan Green 10-82

Aberdeen Black 13-103 defeated Aberdeen Red 7-73

Juniors Leighton 7-50 defeated Spalding White 5-36

Mt Bryan 6-46 defeated Spalding Blue 6-42

Aberdeen 7-58 defeated Kooringa 5-54

92, 44, 10 Nov. 1970, page 3

Dr Fuller of the School Health Branch and colleague Dr Alexander addressed 70 people at the Burra Town Hall on the problems arising from the abuse of certain medications.

92, 44, 10 Nov. 1970, page 4

Burra Golf Club held its AGM and elected President, R.E. Mason; Vice-Presidents, D.A. Jones & D. Kempster; Secretary, H.C. Burnett, Treasurer, R. E. Jackson, Captain, R. Hillman & Vice-Captain N. Hurst. Retiring President John M. Gordon reported on a successful year with increases in numbers of both men and lady members. The introduction of grazing sheep during the playing period had enabled play to continue in spring. The open day had been a great success. Mr Stan Longford won the Championship.

Mary Woollacott and her trip ‘Around the World in Seven Months’. The manuscript about Spain and Portugal was delayed in transit and this letter concerned London.

92, 44, 10 Nov. 1970, page 6

Advt. Burra Pictures, 14 November

Elvis Presley in Live a Little, Love a Little

Plus Our Mother’s House

Michael Broderick has won the Best & Fairest award for Pt Adelaide Colts.

Ben Kotz on the grader and the other Council boys have done a neat job of clearing and levelling the new caravan park site.

92, 44, 10 Nov. 1970, page 7

Bowls

Auburn 70 defeated Burra Gold 68

Spalding Blue 81 defeated Burra Green 65

Watervale 75 defeated Burra Blue 52

92, 45, 17 Nov. 1970, MISSIMG

92, 46, 24 Nov. 1970, page 1

Senate Election

Comparison of voting in Burra

Thefts

A 1970 Holden Kingswood sedan owned by Elders-GM was stolen from an employee’s home in Queen St on Friday night.

On the night of Tuesday/Wednesday last week the home lighting batteries were stolen from Murkaby Station and radiators were taken from a Chevrolet 4 truck and a tractor, as well as a tool box and tools from a Fordson Tractor.

Rural Youth promoted a cabaret to aid the Ambulance Building Fund. It was a great social success, but raised only $123-63.

Accident. A semi-trailer with a load of mixed goods valued at $30,000 capsized at the corner of Paradise and Quarry Streets on Thursday. It was bound for WA. Driver Sipke Poede of Swan Hill, Victoria, escaped injury. Mrs Poede, a passenger, received bruising and a lacerated forehead. Vehicle damage was estimated at $2,000 with unknown damage to the load.

92, 46, 24 Nov. 1970, page 2

Advt. Burra Pictures, 28 November

Audrey Hepburn & Richard Crenna in Wait Until Darl

Robert Preston & Tony Randall in Island of Love

Tennis

‘A’ Grade Aberdeen Blue 14-105 defeated Spalding 6-54

Aberdeen White 15-108 defeated Booborowie 5-56

Mt Bryan 10-97 defeated Kooringa 10-83

‘B’ Grade Mt Bryan Gold14-104 defeated Spalding 6-76

Aberdeen Black 14-109 defeated Mt Bryan Green 6-75

‘C’ Grade Spalding Blue 10-68 defeated Spalding White 2-33

Mt Bryan 7-49 defeated Kooringa 5-55

Aberdeen 12-72 defeated Booborowie 0-19

Burra Methodist Youth Fellowship

The temporary suspension of the program gave the committee time and opportunity to look at the aims and purposes of the group. The MYF will sponsor a Dance and Social Evening at the Redruth Hall on 18 December. Proceeds will aid the Annual Christmas Bowl Appeal. For 1971 members will be issued with a card clearly stating the aims and objectives of MYF. To be valid it will have to bear the signatures of the member, the member’s parent or guardian and the minister. [The Pledge of Membership and objects of MYF are printed and are suggestive of some of the problems recently experienced.] In brief they included:

A promise to attend their church of choice as often as possible

To co-operate with appointed leaders

To respect the property and furnishings of the Methodist Church and to acknowledge that failure in this area could lead to closure of the group

To acknowledge that persistently unco-operative members shall, after due warning, be expelled.

92, 46, 24 Nov. 1970, page 3

Cricket. Mt Bryan 195 v. Koonaburra 2 for 248

Burra Mine

[The procedure for sounding of sirens associated with blasting at the Mine is explained.]

Generally work is progressing well.

Administration buildings are nearing completion.

ETSA is completing cable work.

PMG is laying permanent cables.

92, 46, 24 Nov. 1970, page 6

The Woollacott Family has arrived home after their world tour.

Mr & Mrs John Murray of Cappeedee are being farewelled by various bodies at Hallett prior to their removal to the city next month.

Misses Priscilla & Catherine Brown are leaving ‘Baldina’ to live at Payneham.

Obituary. Mrs Stan Dunow an ex-Burra identity has died.

[Born Helene Elisabeth Kuss, 8 January 1900 Adelaide: died Elizabeth Helena Dunow 22 November 1970 Adelaide, residence Mile End.]

Birth. To Rod & Judy Blake 23 November, a daughter.

Marriage. Mr & Mrs John Cain, schoolteachers who married in the September holidays, had to endure a tin kettling last Thursday.

Mr Dennis Pitcher, Headmaster at Hallett Primary School, has won a scholarship to study in Adelaide next year.

Mr Robert Schuyler has been visiting from Tambellup WA. He has been visiting his nephew George Gallagher and visiting his old home area at Mt Bryan. He hopes to return to Burra next May when he is 83.

SA Housing Trust. Another couple of houses arrived yesterday for the Smelts Road area.

Trevor & Jenny O’Brien of Hallett Methodist Manse go to Adelaide in January where Trevor will study for two or three years at Wesley Training College. Rev. Diprose and family from Kimba will replace him at Hallett.

92, 46, 24 Nov. 1970, page 7

Bowls

1st Division Saddleworth Blue 79 defeated Burra Green 70

Saddleworth Blue 96 defeated Burra Gold 57

2nd Division Burra White 96 defeated Burra Blue 59

Cricket. Hallett 191 defeated Burra Footballers 157

92, 47, 1 Dec. 1970, page 1

Co-operative Bulk Handling Ltd says the Burra silo is at present empty and ready for the new season’s intake. It should be able to take all quota wheat. Barley will be received on a through-put basis or at any time in bags. The company seems likely to be able to take over quota wheat this season, BUT

Only when space is available in silos.

No farmer is to deliver more over quota wheat than 100% of the actual quota.

Total SA receivals of over-quota wheat do not exceed 50% of the state base quota.

These arrangements are not to be taken as a precedent for the 1971-72 season.

Litterbugs. Gabriel Bammer writes on behalf of a group of University students who are usually the butt of criticism. She expresses their disgust when they were at World’s End Creek recently when a group of local immature youths arrived with bottles in hand and proceeded to overturn everything moveable in sight and then to throw their empty bottles down to shatter among the dead trees and rocks.

Booborowie Methodist Garden Fair raised $553 on 21 November.

Burra Swimming Pool filtering has started and the pool is expected to be clean enough to open by 5 December.

The North Booborowie School Bus. The Education Department has advised Mr E.C. Allen MP that a small Departmental bus will operate on a circuit of about 22 miles to collect children living north of Booborowie starting from 8 February 1971.

St Andrew’s Anglican Church at Mt Bryan celebrated the Patronal Festival of the church beginning on the Eve of St Andrew’s Day with a Burns Night Dinner at ‘Petherton’, home of Mr & Mrs F.H. Treweeke.

92, 47, 1 Dec. 1970, page 2

Advt. Burra Pictures, 5 December

Shirley MacLaine & John McMartin in Sweet Charity

Booborowie School. 63 pupils visited Pt Pirie on Friday 20 November. They visited BHAS Smelters and SA Bulk Handling, the Police & Ambulance Stations and a bakery, Northern Bottlers and had a ride on the Pt Pirie Pilot Launch.

92, 47, 1 Dec. 1970, page 3

Notice. A.T. Cornelius advises the sale of his business Modern Meat Store to F.W. McLeon, who takes over on 12 December.

Notice. The Burra Burra DC announces the closure of the following roads and their sale to the adjoining owners.

The road between sections 3040 and 193 Hundred of Kooringa.

Prince Street and Ware Streets in the Township of Millerton, Hundred of Kooringa.

Yongala Rural School will not be closed as was proposed because it has 25 students and so there would be no saving of a teacher.

Peterborough Primary School is in a poor condition.

Mannanarie parents, whose children were to have shared the bus to Peterborough, have now asked that they go instead to Jamestown.

Obituary. Mrs McInnes died on Friday.

[Born Clara Isabella Scholz 9 January 1897 Hallett: died 27 November 1970 Eastwood.]

Miss B. Northmore of Ulooloo is moving soon to live in Adelaide.

Accident. A car driven by Christine Raines collided with two sheep on the Farrell Flat-Clare Road on Saturday night causing about $150 damage to the car.

92, 47, 1 Dec. 1970, page 7

The Ambulance Building Appeal Fund has reached $490-63 on the way to Burra’s target of $1,000 for this state project.

Cricket. Burra Footballers 6 for 158 defeated Mt Bryan 133

92, 47, 1 Dec. 1970, page 8

Burra Burra DC, 2 November meeting in the Town Hall.

Elphick Street will be closed and sold to L.E. Fuller for $10 plus legal fees.

The National Trust, three Town Ward Councillors and the Clerk will visit the old Redruth Gaol and list repairs.

Load limit signs are to be placed on town bridges:

5 tons on the Thames Street, Chapel Street, Queen Street and Kangaroo street bridges.

12 tons on the Ayers Street Bridge.

Burra Burra Sports Association wrote concerning the sports ground. Council resolved to accept the Burra Sports Ground.

The Education Department wrote about closing of the road at Burra School.

92, 48, 8 Dec. 1970, page 1

Adelaide Wool Sales 10-12 November. Merino fleeces were up 5%. Best price in the district was 48c for AAA M on account Ashrose Ltd, Hallett. [Other local district prices are printed.]

Accident. A car driven by Rev. J.T. O’Brien collided with another driven by Mr J.H. Carver of Glengowrie on the Burra by-pass road on Tuesday. Greg William Carver (13) and Alec Potts in the ‘Carver’ vehicle received cuts and bruises. Damage to the vehicles was estimated at $2,500.

St Mary’s. The Quire St Nicholas visited St Mary’s for the Advent Carol Service. Wet weather reduced attendance this year. [The report suggests that the number present was disappointingly small given the quality of the Quire.] Details in c. 2⁄3 column.]

Theft. A car stolen from Crystal Brook on 29 November was later found abandoned in World’s End Creek with about $1,000 to $1,200 damage. The offender seems to have continued his journey by stealing a Valiant utility in Robertstown on 1 December.

Burra Mine

Heavy equipment has begun to arrive in the past week. The secondary crusher of 13 tons arrived, with the primary crusher of 32 tons due on 17 December. The crusher plant is beginning to take shape. The Bon Accord 150,000 gallon tank has been tested and filled. The administration buildings will be ready for occupation 14 December. It is hoped to begin ore quarrying next week.

92, 48, 8 Dec. 1970, page 2

Advt. Burra Pictures, 12 December

Omar Sharif & Lotte Lenya in The Appointment

Jim Brown & Diahann Carroll in The Split

Carol Night. The Annual ‘Burra Festival of Carols’ will be held on the Sunday before Christmas, 20 December. Proceeds will go to the Save the Children Fund this year. Rev. John Stephenson will act as compere. As in the past years children of St Joseph’s Convent will present a mimed tableau of the Nativity of Christ. This will be the last year the tableau will be presented by the Convent children and the Sisters themselves will be unable to see it, as they will have left Burra by that date.* It is hoped this year that the carols will be held in Market Square subject to police approval concerning traffic control.

[* This brief reference, plus another equally short one in the next issue and an oblique reference earlier in Council notes appear to be the only recognition the Convent school gets after more than a century of operation in the town!

BUT check 92, 45, 17 Nov. 1970, MISSIMG for a possible article.]

92, 48, 8 Dec. 1970, page 6

Mrs Jim Peake now of St Peters, but formerly of Burra, was 90 last week. Her father operated a tinsmith’s business on the present site of the Record office.

Birth. To Rosemary & Jim Quinn at Burra hospital on Friday, twins, Leonie Majella & Damian Paul.

Birth. To Mr & Mrs Stan Beinke, a son.

Birth. To Mr & Mrs Cec. Jones, a daughter.

Obituary. The brother of Mrs Maureen Bevan was killed in a motor accident near Peterborough on Sunday.

[Martin John McMorrow died 6 December 1970 Ucolta, residence Peterborough aged 26.]

Burra Hospital has been re-instated as a Nurses’ Training Hospital.

Burra Mine. The workforce is now 110.

RSL held its Annual Reunion Dinner. The President T.R. Rogers welcomed members. John Bailey, a State Councillor, represented the League. State membership of 23,579 is 1,090 down on last year’s figures. 859 members had died during the year. Only five WWI veterans were present: Wilf Nankivell, Gilbert Prior, G. Stanley Hawker, Bob Crewes and Jack Williams.

92, 48, 8 Dec. 1970, page 7

Bowls

1st Division Burra Green 76 defeated Burra Gold 57

2nd Division Spalding Red 84 defeated Burra White 50

Auburn 84 defeated Burra Blue 50 [This suspicious-looking coincidence checks out when the individual scores are totalled.]

Cricket

Hallett 190 defeated Koonaburra 187

Leighton 122 defeated Burra Footballers 102

92, 49, 15 Dec. 1970, page 1

Christmas Eve in Burra will see businesses provide the usual merry-go-round, gifts and sweets. This amounts to contributions of c. $200 each year. This year a group of businesses will offer a bonus for customers. Another $200 will be distributed throughout the day. When an alarm clock rings the customer being served will receive goods to the value of $1 or a $1 discount. [13 businesses appear to have taken part.]

Burra Burra DC is at present studying a plan to improve the creek area from Burra North to the cemetery. It is a long term project, but if implemented will see tree planting and walkways ultimately extend from Hampton to the cemetery.

St John Ambulance Building Fund Appeal has reached $522.83.

Burra Methodist Church. The Burra Methodist Choir and vocalists from Mt Bryan and Farrell Flat have united to present a performance of John W. Peterson’s Christmas Cantata Night of Miracles at a service at the Burra Methodist Church on Sunday at 11 a.m. The choir has been led by Mrs Reta Jennison.

Dr R.C. Heddle, Director of Student Health at Adelaide University, gave an informative lecture on Drugs and Their Effects at the Spalding Hall recently.

92, 49, 15 Dec. 1970, page 1 & 4-5 gutter

Burra Primary School held its swimming carnival in pleasant conditions. Hampton House came out victors.

Senior Girls’ Championship Margaret Allen

Senior Boys’ Championship Shane Matulick

Junior Girls’ Championship Jenny Bernhardt

Junior Boys’ Championship Phillip Edwards

92, 49, 15 Dec. 1970, page 3

Burra High School held its annual Valedictory Service at St Mary’s Church on Sunday at 7 p.m. The church was almost filled. The service was conducted by Rev. John Stephenson, who also played the organ. Special preacher was Assistant Chaplain of Pulteney Grammar School, Rev. J.G.M. Gent. Lessons were read by Headmaster L. Beare and the Methodist Minister Rev. M.H. Edwards. Supper followed in the Parish Hall.

92, 49, 15 Dec. 1970, page 6

Senior Citizens Annual Christmas Afternoon will be held at Redruth Memorial Hall at 2 p.m. tomorrow.

Sgt Orford of Burra Police has been transferred to Region G in Adelaide.

St Joseph’s Convent. During the past 99 years many children have gained an excellent primary education at St Joseph’s Convent in Burra, but now the doors have closed. Sister Mercedes left yesterday for Spalding and Sister Vianey for Pt Lincoln.
