Marriage. Spalding Methodist Church, 21 November

Judith Longbottom, only daughter of Mr & Mrs H.B. Longbottom, married

Bret Walkington, elder son of Mr & Mrs K. Walkington, both of Spalding.

92, 50, 22 Dec. 1970, page 1

Aberdeen Football Club & Aberdeen Basketball Club Auxiliary held a Christmas luncheon at Burra North. A presentation was made to Mrs Harold Kakoschke who is moving to Yunta. [Pauline Kakoschke, who had been the treasurer.]

Christmas Eve. Father Christmas arrives at Market Square at 7.30 p.m. The merry-go-round offers free rides all day.

The New Burra Police Station/Court House is expected to be completed by June 1971. The old station and residence in Chapel Street is currently being demolished and should be cleared by Thursday. The SA Housing Trust will erect the new building. The old residence had not been occupied since the transfer of Constable Muldoon to Frances earlier this year.

Rev. Milton Edwards of Burra will go to Perth on the East-West Express on Saturday, leading a group of 18 young people giving voluntary service at the Mogumber Aboriginal Training Centre. Work parties have been doing this for 15 years. The Mission farm has 3,000 sheep. The party returns to Adelaide on 15 January.

Burra Primary School. End of year activities:

Monday. Grade VII children and parents social in the RSL Hall. Dancing was of a high standard. For the Andrew Tennant Award there was a tie between Brenda Harris and Tony Jennison. Brenda Harris thanked Mr & Mrs Cain for their dancing lessons.

Tuesday. Grade VII visit to the Burra Mine. Tennis tournament to continue through the week.

In the afternoon the school presented the operetta Cowboys and Indians to parents.

Wednesday. Party Day. Mrs Marlene Richards shows slides.

Thursday. Assembly and presentation of prizes.

Earlier in the week Mr Ron Thamm spoke on St John Ambulance.

92, 50, 22 Dec. 1970, pages 1 & 4 & 4-5 gutter

Burra High School held its speech night on 15 December.

Judge Olsson was the guest speaker, who chose as his theme Liberty and Licence, under the heading The Law – Is it an Ass?

[The prize list is printed.]

Trophies

Athletics:

Senior Boy Michael Broderick

Junior Boy Stephen Lane

Senior Girl Cheryl Finch

Junior Girl Geraldine Peter

Swimming

Senior Girl Cheryl Finch

Junior Girl Sybil Wright

Senior Boy Michael Broderick

Junior Boy Peter Broderick

The Headmaster presented the 58th Annual Report

[He welcomed Judge Olsson, Federal MP C.R. Kelly and State MP E.C. Allen.]

The school re-opened in 1970 with 175 students, the same number as at the end of 1969. There were eleven staff members of whom five were newly appointed to Burra. Mr Ayliffe returned as Senior Master after a period at Norwood High School and a year’s study leave. Miss Kussadias came as Senior Mistress from Henley High School. Mr Allen transferred from Pt Augusta. Miss Urlwin and Mr Williams were newly appointed from Teachers College. At Easter Mr Williams was transferred to Coomandook where the school needed a bus driver and Miss Lupascu was sent her. Mrs Day continued part time; teaching one subject and acting as librarian. The time when we need a full-time librarian is fast approaching. This year we have been greatly assisted by the appointment of a part-time clerk for ten hours a week, where Mrs Ashdown has been of great help. (At least half-time would appear essential.)

Last year I was disappointed with the poor condition of the paved area and the loss of two tennis courts. This year unfortunately there has been no improvement in that. But I have been notified that tenders to remedy both deficiencies will be called in the first quarter of 1971. The Memorial Garden continues to thrive and the flat, with some areas re-seeded, continues to make progress. The fence to keep motor traffic off is appreciated.

The statement in Parliament that it is intended to have a new High School by 1974 means we may not be responsible for the care of these areas for much longer.

[The headmaster then goes on to praise and thank in the usual way the High School Council and the Parents & Friends’ Association.]

The Commonwealth grants are supplying some needed equipment, but other items need to be purchased; for example we have been supplied with a video-tape recorder, but tapes are needed for it and they cost over $27 each.

School assemblies this year included interesting talks by Miss Boona Ruhs, an Indian lady who has recently taught in Vietnam, Sally Valiente (a Rotary Exchange Student at Clare) and Mr Hope (Site Manager at the Burra Mine).

Through the sponsorship of the Methodist Church we have had a Rotary Exchange Student, Tom Eastman [from the USA].

There was a school trip in September to Sydney, Melbourne and Canberra – accompanied by Mr West, Miss Pfitzner and Mr & Mrs Salt. The Junior School had a camp at Woolshed Flat.

[There is then a section on internal sporting and House activities.]

In examinations the results were not disappointing. Overall subject ‘passes’ i.e. Grade IV or better was 85.6% compared with a state average of 75%. Outstanding results were achieved by Lynette Griffen and Angela Quinn. John Lloyd has been awarded a Commonwealth Scholarship.

This year we have completely dispensed with school examinations and promotion has been on the results of continuing assessment. Leaving has an increasing focus on research and the library and out extremely small library is another reason why we need a new school. This new approach to learning is an evolving process for both staff and students. French was introduced in 1st Year for the first time to be extended to 2nd Year in 1971 and Leaving Typewriting will be introduced in 1971.

Some staff changes are expected.

Mr Moyle will be promoted to Senior Master and moves to Strathmont Boys Technical High School.

Miss Kussadias and Miss Urlwin are expected to move on.

[The next section dealt with the roles of House Captains and Prefects and was followed by general thanks to cleaners, the Burra Record, Mrs Carpenter for training the choir, the Primary School for co-operation, donors of prizes and Judge Olsson.]

Obituary. Ernest William Dunhill of Burra North died 21 December aged 96. He was the husband of the late Dora Dunhill. [Born 19 October 1874 Maidstone SA: died 21 December 1970 Burra North.]

92, 50, 22 Dec. 1970, page 6

M.J. Kellock 12 years

Garry Disher of Booborowie has gained his BA at the University of Adelaide.

Vivian Packer, daughter of the Burra Hospital Manager-Secretary, has gained her BA.

Pte R.D. Radford, son of Mr & Mrs A.D. Radford of Glenora Station, went to Vietnam last week.

Ross Drew is settling in as Manager of Matthews Emporium.

Mrs L. Davey, nee Longmire, formerly of Burra and now of Henley Beach, reads the Record avidly each week and is much interested in the 50 years ago column – she was married on 23 December 1920. He husband learned his trade at the Record office as a printer when his father owned the business. He continued with the late E.F. Marston for many years before moving to Adelaide where he continued in the trade till his death in 1965.

Carols in Market Square was held in fine weather and attracted a large gathering. Compere was Rev. John Stephenson with Mrs J. Oates at the piano and the lessons read by Mrs M. Odgers, Edith Carpenter, Rev. M. Edwards, Rev. Stephenson, Alan Baulderstone and Ian Allen. The children of St Joseph’s Convent presented the usual tableau. The Methodist Church Choir rendered pieces from the Cantata Night of Miracles with soloists Mrs Carpenter and Mr Allen Edwards. Donations for the evening raised $55 for Save the Children Fund.

The Chapel St Bridge was re-opened to traffic towards the end of last week.

Obituary. Mr Hawkins, brother of Mrs Bagg has died. [Clarice Winifred Bagg nee Hawkins.]

[Arthur Keith Hawkins died 16 December 1970 Burra aged 63. Not traced on SA Births CD.]

Michael Broderick, Julie Bevan & Mark Hurley acted promptly at the swimming pool last week and no doubt saved the life of Shane Towle, grandson of Mr & Mrs Vic. Elliott.

Maurice Perry has earned his Bachelor of Architecture Degree, coming equal second in the final thesis.

92, 50, 22 Dec. 1970, page 8

Burra Burra DC, 17 December

Burra National Trust will accept an offer of spending $200 on materials with Council to supply labour for works at the Redruth Gaol.

Roads as set out in advertisements [presumably the notice 92, 47, 1 Dec. 1970, page 3.] will be offered at $50 plus legal, survey and transfer fees.

The National Trust wrote concerning the Mine buildings. Samin Ltd is to be asked if its policy in this regard has changed.

The National Trust to make the miners’ dugouts chimneys safe.

Characteristics of the 1970 paper.

Generally there seems to be a good coverage of local news, although some snippets in ‘Out and About’ hint at stories that did not appear. For example there is a reference in December to a near drowning at the Burra Swimming Pool, which is not elsewhere reported. St Joseph’s Convent closed with only very brief incidental references. The Bon Accord Bridge was demolished with only the briefest of notes. These do leave you wondering what else might have been missed. The Burra Mine seems to be quite well documented.

Page 1 was reserved almost entirely for news. Beyond that pages carry perhaps two columns of news out of the seven. There is, however, little consistency about where regular features are located.

Articles are often printed in the pages 4-5 gutter and sometimes in the 3-6 gutter.

There are quite a lot of general interest stories and articles, including items direct from Parliament or from the Member of Parliament. These are almost exclusively from the Conservative side of politics. Other items seem to have been press releases from the Australian Canned Fruits Industry, the Federal Government, the State Government, the Wheat Board etc.

Photographs continue to be few in number, but occasionally they appear in the same week as the event occurred.

93, 1, 12 Jan. 1971, page 1

Burra Mine

Work has resumed after the Christmas shut-down. The aim is to start production on 31 January. The general administration block and amenities section has been completed. The plant workshop, stores and the large mine workshop are nearing completion. The Boiler house and process plant are well advanced. The primary and secondary crushers have been installed. The ammonium storage facility will be filled this week. Production is well underway in the quarry area. Samin Ltd staff have arrived in the town and taken up residence.

Accident/Obituary. A 50-year-old Victorian man died at Burra Hospital after his car overturned near Florieton on New Year’s Eve. He was Donald Alfred Reynolds of Windsor, Melbourne. A passenger, Eugene Ronald McCabe of North Sunshine escaped unhurt.

Keith Basterfield of the Aerial Phenomenon Research Group thanks those who replied to his previous letter concerning UFOs.

Fire. On Saturday 26 December a station sedan driven by John Joseph Hoare of Plympton was destroyed by fire near Hanson Tanks while travelling from Adelaide to Broken Hill.

Burra Burra DC has received an $18,500 grant for work on the Burr-Booborowie Road.

Sgt G.B. Haynes has been transferred from Whyalla to become Officer-in-Charge at Burra, though the date he commenced duty has not yet been announced.

Accident. A sedan driven by Anne Elizabeth Hall rolled over the bridge at Ford’s Corner on the Burra-Morgan Road. Neither the driver nor passenger Michael Gee was injured.

Obituary. Rev. Milton Edwards conducted the funeral service for William Ernest Dunhill at Redruth Church on 23 December 1970. [Officially Ernest William Dunhill.] He was born at Kersbrook 18 October 1874 and died at Redruth 21 December 1970 aged 96. He had long been a faithful servant of the church. His ministry as a local preacher covered a continuous period of 77 years. He lived as he preached, in utter sincerity. [Rev. Edwards reported hearing Mr Dunhill preach only once on 8 September 1968 and he preached only twice after that before failing health forced him to give up the work.]

He was essentially a nineteenth century man with an uneasy tolerance of the technological changes around him. He was forty when WWI broke out and he came to Burra a year later. In his teens he had gone to Orroroo to work on his uncle’s farm and in his mid 20s went to WA working in a timber mill in the jarrah forests. He was at a blacksmith’s shop at Iron Knob when the iron ore industry began, before the town was built. He then worked for some years at the mines in Broken Hill and was a handy blacksmith by the time he reached Burra in 1915. He married in the first decade of the twentieth century [1908] and his wife died in 1950. He outlived each member of a long-lived family. Almost every Sunday for 50 years he rang the bell of the Redruth Church and for many years sang in the choir. His work as a Sunday school Superintendent and teacher helped to mould the lives of successive generations of children now grown to adulthood. He has a self effacing modesty and the strength of an independent spirit that refused to accept defeat. The President of the Methodist Conference A.D. Blunt sent a telegram to ‘acknowledge the long life of service rendered by William Dunhill.’

[Note from earlier 85, 39 (4), 8 Oct. 1963, page 1

Mr E.W. Dunhill (89) has completed 72 years of service as a lay preacher – a record unequalled in the Methodist Church in Australia. Mr Dunhill was born at Kersbrook in SA and in his early life went to WA. He married there in 1908 and returned to SA in 1909, taking up residence in Burra in 1915. He carried on business as a blacksmith for 65 years until he was 83. He took his first church service at the age of 16 years 11 months. He was the first person in Australia to hold a certificate recognising 60 years service as a lay preacher. He was also active in Sunday school work for many years and was Sunday School Superintendent for 37 years.]

93, 2, 19 Jan. 1971, page 3

Obituary. Arthur P. [Patrick] Keain died at Aquinas College 17 December 1970 aged 35 [residence Somerton Park]. He was the eldest son of Mr & Mrs B.V. Keain of Spalding. He was born at Blyth and educated at St Joseph’s Convent Clare, Euromina School, Clare High School and Sacred Heart College. He graduated with a BA (Hons) from the University of Adelaide and was a teacher at Woodville and Renmark High Schools before taking an administrative post at Adelaide University and then becoming Academic Registrar at Flinders University. He was a keen bridge player and the Australian Open Individual Bridge Champion for 1964.

93, 3, 26 Jan. 1971, page 1

St Peter’s Anglican Cathedral Choirboys will arrive by train on Friday with choirmaster Mr David Swale and Cathedral Precentor Rev. D.K. Rowney. Mr Swale will play the organ at St Mary’s on Sunday at the 10.30 am sung Eucharist and the choirboys will lead the singing. Rev. Rowney will be the preacher. The boys are in Burra for their annual camp as part of their summer break while the Quire St Nicholas takes their place at the Cathedral.

Wal Watkins writes to the Burra Burra DC informing them that he is about to start writing a dramatic novel. Having recently toured the state seeking a location for the novel, he was most impressed by Mongolata and congratulates all who have contributed to the preservation of the site and battery. He says he was born at Burra and reared at Hallett. Mongolata suits the needs of the novel admirably. It will be his tenth.

[Walter James Watkins was born at Redruth 10 March 1922 to Albert Morton Watkins and Tillie Maria nee Smart.]

93, 3, 26 Jan. 1971, page 5

Obituary. Sydney Malcolm Sommerville died at the Clare Hospital 17 December 1970 aged 62. He was the eldest son of the late Mr & Mrs Malcolm Sommerville of Hilltown. After three years at Scotch College he went to live with his uncle at Spalding. Thirty-five years ago he bought land in partnership with his brother Tom and lived there till his death. He was active in local affairs. He was Vice-President of the Bowling Club for three years and in 1970 resigned from the Presidency due to ill health. He was the treasurer of the Spalding Presbyterian Church for thirty years. He is survived by a wife, three daughters and two sons: Merilyn Mrs J. Wehrmann, Aileen Mrs M. Robinson, Lynette, Norman and Eric. There is one grandson, Darren Robinson.

[Born at Clare 17 December 1908.]

93, 4, 2 Feb. 1971, MISSING

93, 5, 9 Feb. 1971, page 1

Preservation of Historic Relics

When it comes to keeping local heritage we can think about it, talk about it and argue about it, but are we prepared to pay for it? In the past year there has been much heard about the historic mine buildings and their preservation. The District Council and Samin Ltd have investigated the question. Samin Ltd has identified the buildings which will remain and which will be demolished in the progress of their activities in the next two or three years. Samin reports that operations starting early in 1971 will open cut the section of the ore bodies which were mined by underground methods in the last century. The ore will be leached by an ammonium process for the recovery of copper oxide. This is expected to extend the present open cut to approximately 2,000 feet in length by 900 ft in width. The dimensions are based on the need to create wall slopes flat enough to ensure the safety of the open cut when it is mined to a depth of 300 ft.

The structures to be affected will be those on the western side of the open cut, namely the two old winding houses and old offices. Three small roofless buildings closest to the southern end of the open cut will also be affected. The old magazine to the west and the buildings at Morphett’s Shaft will not be affected.

Mining is expected to start at the northern end, which means the buildings affected will be preserved for at least two years, but will be removed within the next three years. So the buildings in danger of demolition in the next three years include Grave’s Shaft and Pit Head and the round chimney at Peacock’s Shaft. It has been suggested these two examples of old Cornish building could be relocated for tourist interest. It is thought the cost of each would be $7,000. Time would be limited to 1971 for the operation and funds could be sought state-wide. Site Engineer Mr E.L. Hope has suggested, and arrangements have already been made to restore the old Powder Magazine. And the Morphett Shaft Poppet Head could be restored with the necessary working pieces to effect the past appearance and purpose of the building. This would be the cheaper operation and most interesting from a tourist point of view.

District Clerk Mr Perry felt the Council would not be prepared to spend rate money on such a project and neither would it have other than a low priority for any royalties from the Mine.

This leaves public donation as the source.

Samin are prepared to alter their program of works to allow the removal of the buildings.

Adelaide Wool Sales, 12-14 January. [Local district prices are printed.]

Mrs Ruby Rowe has donated the trolly and other items used by her late husband* in droving, to John Hanrahan of Naracoorte aged 81, so that he can return to droving. He had received plenty of offers of work in the Naracoorte District, but Mrs Rowe’s offer was the only one to supply a vehicle and equipment to set him up for it. Mrs Rowe’s gift included harness, three tents, tarpaulins, leggings, leather gloves, hurricane lamps, ropes etc. The trolly left Burra by rail on Thursday.

[* Jack Birkenhagen Rowe 1907-68.]

The Director of Meals on Wheels Lt Colonel (Rtd) H.G. Frith MBE will visit Burra Methodist Women’s Fellowship on 17 February to explain the running of the organisation and outline the steps to be taken in the formation of a Meal on Wheels Service in towns of limited patient potential.

Mr K. Costello comes from Teachers College.

The 1970 Leaving Exam results are printed. Two outstanding students were Anne Brak and Lynette Kelly. Each passed six subjects with three grade ones.

Reprint from the Advertiser 5 January 1891 of an article by ‘Melas’.

A few remains of old huts will enable a visitor to Burra to form some idea of what and where they were when occupied, but they are crumbling away and in a few years hardly a vestige will remain. Only a few of their occupants now survive and materials for this sketch came from their lips and pens. The first two huts it seems were formed by the late Messrs John and Robert Collins, not far from the site of the Kooringa Hotel. Soon huts lined the sides of the creek for nearly two miles and over 2,000 people lived in them. The clay banks were almost ten feet high and easily excavated. The roof was pierced and stones or a small flour barrel formed a chimney. From the footpath one could see the fire places, the tea kettle and frying pan in use. When an opening was left without a chimney persons sometimes fell in and many amusing stories are told of the tricks played by boys dropping things down. The number of rooms varies from two or three to five and six and at least one resident wrote to a friend in England saying he had ‘an eight roomed house with a river frontage’. A row of large gum trees lines the creek. The sight at night with lights shining through the windows was imposing. The huts were cool in summer, dry in winter and cosy. Lime was freely applied and some rooms were papered and carpeted and the crude furniture of early days gradually became very comfortable and even luxurious.

Our informant spoke of the great weakness of the women of the creek to bake rich fruit tarts on Sunday afternoons and to their being annoyed if the visitor did not eat and drink a cup of tea with them, even if he had done so with others six times before.

Flood made havoc of the huts when the calling of geese, squealing of pigs, quacking of ducks and the roaring of water mixed with the screaming of women and children and the struggle of men to rescue their effects.

A witness described the flood of 12 May 1851.

People were getting their clothes ready for the tea meeting when a few large drops of rain fell near Longmead’s Store. Soon people ran towards the creek from all directions. The witness saw one man hand his children up to his wife on the bank as the water rushed past. Sofas, boxes, beds etc. were being rescued or were floating towards the cemetery. In the main street the water was ‘up to my body’ and a new bullock dray was swimming down with the wheels going round like the paddles of a steamer. There were some narrow escapes and much loss and ruin. The flood of 1859 did so much damage that few persons lived in the huts after that. In 1877 the flood rose above the banks and carried away the old Kooringa Bridge for over a mile. Cooper and Bailey were unable to display their menagerie.

Mr James Blatchford reached Burra in 18847 after a week’s journey from Adelaide by bullock dray. He dug a hole near the smelting works and never lived more comfortably in his life. He sold it for $28 and it was destroyed in the next winter.

The late Mr Daniel Llewellyn came to SA in the Prince Regent in June 1849 and proceeded to Burra where he bought a creek hut for $7. It comprised a kitchen 10 ft long and 8 ft wide and a bedroom 8 ft square. Both were 7 ft high. A third room was formed 15 ft x 10 ft. The walls were smoothed with an adze and whitewashed. Five feet was curtained off for a bed and in the rest Welsh services and a Sunday school were carried on for a year, with a good attendance. This hut was destroyed by the flood of 1851 and everything within it buried. A large costly Welsh Bible was dug out along with other books. Mr Llewellyn agreed to buy another hut for $10 and paid $10 deposit. [sic?] Within a month the second flood came. He hurried from church to save his effects, caught a chill and died.

[Died 26 June 1851 aged 34.]

93, 6, 16 Feb. 1971, page 1

Burra Mine

A meeting of the National Trust on Friday decided to launch a state-wide appeal for funds to resite as many old mine buildings as possible. Mr S.J. Woollacott spoke on their historic value. The first priority for saving buildings was decided as the Chimney at Waterman’s Shaft known as ‘Peacock’s’. Elected were: President, L. Moore; Vice-Presidents, G. O’Connor & Les. Warnes; Secretary, Mrs C. O’Connor; Treasurer, D. Cockington; Research Officer, I. Auhl, Curator of Historical Properties, S.J. Woollacott and Early Buildings Officer, G. O’Connor.

Ready-Mixed Concrete (SA) Pty Ltd is to establish a permanent service for the mid-north this month, with a facility based at Clare.

Fire. Fire on the property of N.J. Baynes caused damage of $250 to tools and equipment on Thursday.

St Mary’s. Two vacancies in the Trustees of the Church occurred with the death of J.R. Barker and the resignation of Mr Andrew Tennant. Mr John Burge was appointed to replace Mr Barker and Mr Ronald Thamm to fill Mr Tennant’s vacancy.

93, 6, 16 Feb. 1971, pages 1 & 8

Mt Bryan School opened in 1970 with 26 and this year has 29. [New students are listed.]

The Head Teacher is Mr Thompson.

Leighton School. Head Teacher is Mr Ogden with Mrs Ogden. There are 29 students, an increase of 2 on 1970.

[New students are listed.]

Hallett School. Head Teacher is Mr Whittington with Misses Polmear & Johnson. The enrolment has risen by 1 since 1970 to reach 67. [New students are listed.]

Willalo School. The Head Teacher is Mrs Harvey from the Permanent Relieving Staff. Enrolments have fallen by three to 15. [New students are listed.]

Farrell Flat School. Head Teacher is Mr R. Hurrell with Miss A.B. Schuyler. In 1970 there were 25 pupils and in 1971 there are 29. [The new student in Grade I is named.]

Football. The Mid North Football League, after an association with the SA National Football Umpires Association for 22 out of 23 years of the association’s existence, will now affiliate with the SANFL and ask them to supply umpires. This follows a special meeting at Saddleworth on 9 February. [Circumstances have led to the SANFUA going into recess.]

Lutheran Church. The new Trinity Lutheran Church at Blyth was built by the Snowtown firm of C. & R. Ouwerkerk and will be opened and dedicated by the President of the Lutheran Church in SA, Rev. L.B. Grope on 21 February. It cost $32,440. [Details of the building are given in an article of 2⁄3 column.]

93, 6, 16 Feb. 1971, page 3

Ian Auhl letter concerning the resiting of Burra Mine buildings.

Now that Grave’s Pump House and Peacock’s Chimney Stack and Pump House are not in immediate danger of demolition, attention can be given to dismantling, resiting and re-erecting the buildings. There appears to be a two year reprieve dating from September 1970, which gives a breathing space of eighteen months.

I am sure that with a little good will this is possible. Problems are architectural and financial.

I submit the following steps as a plan of action:

Request the Minister of Conservation (Mr Broomhill) to call a meeting of interested parties. (A request made perhaps jointly by the Burra Burra DC and the National Trust.)

Survey, planning and numbering of the masonry. (A major and expensive task for the two pump houses.)

I have been contacted by a professional and reputable architect who will undertake the initial survey voluntarily.

Samin is interested in the speedy removal of the buildings and have expressed a willingness to assist in demolition and storage of the stone work.

My suggestions for resiting:

Peacock’s Chimney and Pump House to be re-erected on the mine hill where they would be visible from the by-pass

Grave’s Pump House to be re-erected at the old Mine entrance close to the Burra-Burra North Road.

An architect and contractor I consulted both see these position as suitable.

  1. Little finance would be needed to this stage.

  2. These are state heritage items so finance should not be just a local issue.

  3. A building contractor has suggested re-erection costs should be considerably less than $10,000 per building, given free architectural services and help from Samin in demolition.

  4. This money does not have to be found immediately.

  5. Sources of Funding:

The Government has accepted some of the moral responsibility for the future of the buildings and could contribute something each financial year.

The National Trust, both Burra and Adelaide.

Public subscription – making this via the National Trust would make donations tax deductible.

Burra Burra DC – I cannot believe, despite the article in last week’s Record that they would contribute nothing.

Tourist grant.

Re-erection as funds permit. The contractor has consented to give a detailed estimate. This broad outline only comes from five years’ involvement with the town I love and is aimed at one thing only; the preservation of the Burra Mine buildings. I am willing to come to Burra at any time with the architect, building contractor and others who are offering help.

93, 6, 16 Feb. 1971, page 6

93, 6, 16 Feb. 1971, page 8

Burra Library held its AGM last week. Mr J. Topsfield reported on a difficult year. The year finished financially secure, but the committee was hampered by the Council’s failure to supply three committee members as required. Membership was 53 full members and 7 juvenile. This year it became possible for a person to borrow by paying a refundable deposit fee. Thanks go to librarian Mrs Fennell and to the Secretary Mr Ben Kotz. Elected: President, J. Topsfield; Vice-Presidents, Jean Kotz & W. Nankivell; Treasurer, E. Carpenter and Secretary, B. Kotz.

Booborowie 8-57 defeated Spalding White 4-41

93, 7, 23 Feb. 1971, page 1

Burra Hospital has since 1929 been a part-time training centre for girls wishing to become nurses and has over the years prepared many for this career. Under a scheme introduced in 1970 the Burra Burra Hospital was classified as a training school only for Enrolled Nurses – previously called Nurses Aids. The matter has now been reviewed and the hospital can now accept student nurses – aiming to become Sisters as well as Enrolled Nurse Trainees. From January 1972 student nurses will do one year at BBH and then transfer to RAH. In her first year the student nurse will attend the RAH for three period (of 3, 4 and 5 weeks) to undertake instruction in Theory of Nursing. From January 1972 entry level will be a pass in four subjects at Leaving level. Enrolled Nurses do a one-year course, which includes two periods (4 weeks and 2 weeks) at Glenedon School of Nursing in Adelaide. By 1972 it is expected entry requirements will be third year of High School.

E.T. Baulderstone writes:

The buildings in the old copper mine played an important part in the early days of SA and of mining in Australia. They have been well publicised in recent years by the efforts of Mr Ian Auhl. The Burra Corporation bought the mining area about ten years ago so that the relics could be restored to attract tourists. Lack of finance has allowed little restoration, but extensive visits by tourists have occurred.

I like the suggestion by Mr Hope that the Morphett Shaft poppet head be restored. I consider as many buildings as possible should be preserved and if this is not possible then the main round chimney stack should be placed as close as possible to Morphett’s poppet head. I feel this should be a Commonwealth and State project, not just a local and SA project. I agree with the District Clerk that local rates should not be used, but disagree that any royalties from the mine should have a low priority as far as restoration of historic items is concerned. They should have a very high priority in this respect and he should realise the mine area was bought for historical and tourist purposes. I trust the District Council will give the matter plenty of thought. If any buildings are resited:

‘I hope they are placed in a position which will not spoil our pretty street, like the stone recently placed in Market Square.

Floods. Thunderstorms in the Booborowie area dumped heavy falls of rain locally. 187 points at Booborowie and 380 at the home of Jeffery Wedding. Other people reported falls in excess of two inches. Near the Booborowie cemetery the Big Creek ran a banker and 17 inches of water flooded the home of Dawn Taylor.

Mr Ron Dewhirst’s Austin Lancer stalled when wires got wet and was pushed to higher ground, but when he returned some time later it was found ‘hanging in a tree’, having been washed downstream in a flash flood. Water entered the home of Lindsay McWaters. Les Thomas reported 78 points at Mt Bryan East, but Burra recorded only 22.

S.J. Woollacott writes endorsing the desirability of launching a fund to save the old mine buildings and also that it be administered by the Burra Branch of the National Trust so that donations would be tax deductible. He appeals for widespread support, repeating the oft-used phrase ‘Burra once saved South Australia’ – now it is time for South Australians to save part of Burra. He was willing to start the fund with a donation of $5.00.

93, 7, 23 Feb. 1971, pages 1 & 6

93, 7, 23 Feb. 1971, page 5 & 4-5 gutter

Burra & District Floral Art Club held its AGM and elected: President, Mrs S. Thamm; Secretary-Treasurer, Mrs D. O’Connor and Librarian, Mrs L. White. In the year there were 21 financial members with an average attendance of 16 at meetings.

93, 7, 23 Feb. 1971, page 5

Burra Burra Branch of the National Trust: Annual Report.

An important event was the open day at Princess Royal thanks to Mr & Mrs Andrew Tennant. It is much as it was when built in 1864 and approximately 800 people visited it. Mr Downer operated a five-in-hand drag to take passengers to and from Burra and for short rides around the grounds. It was decided to use the money raised on the dugouts project. A contract has been lent to Mr Jacka to do the restoration work and planting of native trees and shrubs has begun.

On 29 August the Australian Railway Historical Society ran a special train to Burra for the centenary of the line and we were fortunate to have a display of Maurice Perry’s pencil sketches from the Burra Sketchbook in the RSL Hall along with items by the Art Group. Tours of the town were arranged with Trust members as guides.

Mr Auhl also conducted a Living History School for Mid North Adult Education with an address and tour. Approximately 50 attended.

We regret to record the death of J.R. Barker and in accordance with his wishes the Misses Brown have offered the branch several horse drawn vehicles, which are presently housed in the Bon Accord Buildings. When these buildings become available it is hoped to form another museum there for agricultural implements and the stud Merino industry. Mr Edwards Group (from SA Museum) has agreed to erect an Aboriginal artefact display in another room. Considerable work is needed on the buildings before this can be done.

Of major concern now is the preservation of old mine buildings with Samin Ltd now at work on the site.

The Museum in Market Square has had about 2,500 paying visitors this year.

Burra Sketchbook sales have been c. 600. We have also printed Historic Perspective of Burra by Ian Auhl – a paper given by Mr Auhl at an Adult Education seminar in Adelaide.

93, 7, 23 Feb. 1971, page 6

Fire. Lightning started a fire on Les Woodman’s property in the Hallett District and he lost two sheep and 20 acres was burnt. Lightning also started a fire which burnt about 150 acres of Koonoona.

The Annual Reunion of Mt Bryan Residents will be held in the Botanic Gardens in Adelaide on Sunday 7 March at 2 p.m.

Pam Biggs won the Championship Singles for the Burra Bowling Associates on Sunday.

Birth. To Mr & Mrs Bob Tohl of Booborowie at Burra Hospital last Thursday, a daughter, Julie Marie.

Kevin O’Reilly has been transferred from Hallett Police Station and will be replaced by Constable Colbert.

93, 8, 2 Mar. 1971, page 1

Adelaide Wool Sales 23-25 February. [Local district prices are printed.]

Weather. Thunderstorms have delivered patchy rain in the east. Old Koomooloo had the house dam filled. Mt Bryan East received 60 points. Burra received 33 points on Sunday.

Burra Associates Cosmopolitan Fours Tournament was played on 28 February and won by the Burra team John Mitchell, Rube Phillips, Ken Short and Les. Phillips.

Burra Methodist Church is organising a second camp at Nunyara Youth Centre at Belair over the coming weekend. 60 will attend comprising 24 adults, 15 children and 21 children. 35 will attend from Burra, 11 from Booborowie, 12 from Farrell Flat and 1 from Ironmine.

Burra Primary School has been presented with an Honour Roll by Mr & Mrs Padbury to record the winners of the Andrew Tennant Award.

Burra & District Young Liberals had Mr H. Venning, Member for Rocky River, as guest speaker on 17 February. Geoff Dare chaired the meeting. Mr Venning spoke on problems facing rural industries.

93, 8, 2 Mar. 1971, page 2

Advt. Southern Farmers will conduct a clearing sale on 15 March for M.J. & H.E. Miller, proprietors of Illangi, who are relinquishing dairying and leaving the district.

Advt. Dr R.C. Heddle will address a meeting in Burra Town Hall on 12 March on drugs and their associated problems in youth. Sponsored by the M & BHA.

North Eastern Football Association. The annual report by President W.B. Ashby.

The Association lost to Gawler League in the 1st match of the Central Districts Carnival, but defeated old rivals Mid North on the Monday. We beat Northern Areas on 4 July at Booborowie and won comfortably, and were then defeated by Broughton Football League on 25 July.

Congratulations to Russell Nicholls for winning the Mail Medal and to Brendan Kluska as runner-up and winning the Burra Record Trophy. Congratulations to Burra for winning the Premiership for 1970. The Junior Colts Shield went to Booborowie.

[Thanks were extended to various people, especially yo Tony Fillmore for his work as Secretary-Treasurer.]

Gwendolyn Tennant wrote supporting Ian Auhl’s proposals for preserving Burra’s heritage mine buildings.

93, 8, 2 Mar. 1971, page 7

Obituary. Former Burra Hotel licensee Mrs King Grubb has been killed in a car accident near Horsham in Victoria. The Hamilton Spectator reported the accident on 23 February. Two Hamilton people were killed in a car smash near Horsham on Friday. They were not wearing seat belts and were thrown from the car. Two others in the car were wearing seat belts and survived. Killed were Terrence Atholstone Cowley (45) and Aileen Jean Grubb (50). The car collided with one driven by Harold Roy Bailey of Goroke, the occupants of which escaped with minor injuries. Mr & Mrs Grubb held the licence for the Hotel Hamilton, but it is understood it changed hands recently.

2nd Division Burra Blue 72 defeated Auburn Black 71 [check]

Spalding 71 defeated Burra White 54

Cricket. Koonaburra 138 defeated Spalding 98.

Burra Primary School Welfare Club held its AGM.

About 41,200 was spent during the year. Attendance and membership had both been up on the previous year. During the year they had purchased sports gear, desk bags, a porta amp, a projector and in conjunction with the High School first aid equipment, library books and teachers’ aids. Plans were in hand to buy a TV receiver. Funds were raised at sports day and by catering for a wedding. Elected: President, Mrs Lola Jennison; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames Elizabeth Beare & Celine Stockman; Secretary, Mrs Shirley Thamm; Assistant Secretary, Mrs Elva Clode and Treasurer, Mrs Margaret Alderson.

93, 9, 9 Mar. 1971, page 1

Burra Mine

Last Friday exploratory talks were held in the office of the Director of Mines Mr L. Parkin re the removal and resiting of Graves’ Pump House and Peacock’s Pump House and Chimney. The meeting was initiated by the National Trust in response to a request from Mr B.R. Lewis Chairman of Directors of Samin Ltd, that any interest in doing this movement of buildings should be expressed as soon as possible.

Mr Auhl’s ‘Course of Action’ letter was the basis of the discussion. Present were:

Director of the SA National Trust Mr Ashley Cooper

Mr Roberts representing Samin Ltd

Mr Ian Auhl representing the Burra Branch of the National Trust

Dr Grant Inglis Protector of Historical Relics as observer.

Mr Roberts said Samin was not yet producing an income and was there fore not in a position to spend shareholders’ money, but they were prepared to offer mechanical help – making available machinery on the site and to help in the demolition and transport of masonry to sites for proposed rebuilding. This was considered a valuable offer.

Mr Auhl outlined the reason for having submitted his plan. Success depended on the State Government and public support. Dr Grant Inglis considered there had in the past been a lack of adequate liaison between the National Trust, the District Council and Samin. All agreed that this was important.

The proposed sites for relocation were then discussed.

An offer from Mr G. O’Connor of a site close to the Mine Entrance was noted and acclaimed.

The Burra Burra DC also was considering making another site available.

All parties agreed the first priority was the chimney stack. Second came Graves’ Pump House and 3rd Peacock’s Pump House. The Director of Mines in summing up stressed the need for action in the next few weeks. Mining developments would make it difficult to remove buildings within the next month or so.

Telephones. Extra trunk lines will be available from 17 March.

Burra-Hallett 1

Burra-Booborowie 3

Burra-Gum Creek 1

Burra Pre-School Kindergarten has 37 children this year with 22 new enrolments [New enrolments are listed.]

The Inter-School Swimming Carnival at Riverton on Wednesday was contested between Balaklava, Riverton, Clare, Kapunda, Eudunda and Burra. Burra finished equal fourth in the Junior Division and fifth in the Senior Division.

Flood Waters are approaching SA via the Darling River. At Bourke the official level is 41 ft 6 inches and the level is now 44 ft. The flow in SA is rising.

93, 9, 9 Mar. 1971, page 5

Burra Primary School Parents held their annual meeting on 1 March. Over 40 parents and teachers attended.

The Welfare Club had spent more than $1,200 in the year. [The new school committee is listed.]

Outgoing Chairman R.A. Moreland reported:

The oval had been ripped up, top dressed, regularly watered and cut and is now in good condition.

The walkway to Burra North benefits children from there and provides a short cut to Burra Oval.

A wet sports day did not dampen the children’s enthusiasm.

Hallett Sports Day was on 24 April. Burra was again successful. This year Burra is host school.

The Education Department changed the type of playground equipment that is approved, involving expenditure of c. $400 on new equipment.

The school market garden, in lieu of a cropping program, was successful. Yesterday morning $100 worth of onions was pulled.

Mr & Mrs Tom Padbury have donated an Honour Board to record the names of winners of the Andrew Tennant Award.

Staff. In Mat we lost Miss Spratt as Headmistress and Mr Sid Allan became the new Headmaster.

The School Welfare Club has again been active and spent more than $1,200 on the school during the year.

The committee has received a grant of $100 to be spent on maintenance etc. of the school grounds.

93, 9, 9 Mar. 1971, page 6

Birth. To Robert & Marilyn Brandt at Woomera on 9 March, a son, Michael John.

Pte Trevor Phelps of Hallett is home from final leave before going to Vietnam. He will be 22 on Thursday.

Basketball. From now on the name will be Netball.

Mr & Mrs Ted Hope leave Burra on Saturday. They will go to Windara [Windarra?] in WA where Mr Hope becomes Senior Site Engineer at a mine. [Near Laverton.]

Rosemary & Alec Williams leave for Darwin on Thursday, where Alec takes up duty in the Post Office on 16 March.

A mannequin parade planned by a firm for the Town Hall has been cancelled because the facilities for the mannequins are inadequate.

Mt Bryan Reunion in Adelaide on Sunday was a great success.

Obituary. The father of Mac. Anderson of Burra died recently.

Hazel O’Connor writes as Hon. Secretary of the National Trust:

The National Trust in Burra endorses the course of action proposed by Mr Ian Auhl in his recent letter. The branch has decided to raise funds to resite the threatened mine buildings. An appeal committee has been formed.

Weather. The best rain for years has fallen in the pastoral areas of the north, but falls to the east of Burra were less than 1 inch and often less 50 points.

93, 10, 16 Mar. 1971, pages 1 & 8

Dr R.C. Heddle gave an enlightening talk on drugs at the Town Hall on Friday night. Door takings were $114. It was organised by the M & BHA. Dr Heddle had been overseas to assess the situation, attending conferences in Holland and New Zealand. The news seemed to indicate that Adelaide had perhaps four or five years to prepare to handle drug problems of the proportions experienced overseas.

[Dr Heddle’s address is reported at length in about 12⁄3 columns.]

93, 10, 16 Mar. 1971, page 2

93, 10, 16 Mar. 1971, page 3

New Freeling-Kapunda Road

The new sealed road between Freeling and Kapunda was opened to traffic on 15 March. The new road cuts three miles from the route via Greenock and has fewer bends and easier grades. It also has the advantage of not cutting through built up areas.

Burra Mine Buildings Preservation Committee

A three hour meeting was held in Burra last Friday evening. Mr H. Rich of Samin outlined what help the company could give. He outlined what they had done at Cobar in restoration and setting up of a local museum. He stressed the urgent need for action and outlined the time limits. Mr Auhl was asked to report on steps taken to implement the course of action.

At a personal interview with National Trust President Mr Berry the President had offered the support of the National Trust executive. This means an appeal can be launched by the Trust and donations will be tax deductible.

On 17 March the supervising architect Mr G. Krause and official Trust photographer Mrs Barbara Toope will make their survey of the buildings concerned. This work is on a voluntary basis. Mr Rich is giving access to the buildings.

Builder Mr Geoff Lloyd was prepared to undertake the demolition and reconstruction on a cost plus basis. He is a master builder recommended by Mr K. Gill of the Master Builders Association. He knows the Burra buildings well and will co-operate with all voluntary help that can lower costs.

The Master Builders Association has recommended the engagement by Mr Lloyd of a Danish steeplejack now resident in SA and he and Mr Lloyd will visit Burra in the next fortnight to assess methods of demolition and reconstruction.

The Committee then considered other matters:

Access to site

Priorities 1 & 2 Peacock’s Chimney and Graves’ Pump House. Priority 3 Peacock’s Pump House was not thought tenable. Stone from here would be needed by Samin for repairs to the Powder Magazine and by builders to replace stone in other buildings.

The site offered by Mr G. O’Connor near the Mine entrance was accepted as appropriate and would give Burra a complete Cornish Unit of a chimney and Pump House in an appropriate area. Also the area could then become malineable [sic: but not found in OED.] as the property of the National Trust.

Publicity. Much free publicity seems on present indications to be available in the media. It is clear that with the all round help being given, the scheme has moved, within a few weeks, from possible to probable and now to certainty.

93, 10, 16 Mar. 1971, page 4

Mid North Football League, met on 5 March. It elected: Patron, W.E. Blatchford of Riverton; President, S. Noske of Robertstown; Senior Vice-President, C.S. Rowett of SA United and Assistant Secretary, Mrs A.E. Bannear.

[The report on 1970 and arrangements for the 1971 season are printed.]

Life Membership is to be given to Mr R.G. Crouch prior to the Grand Final.

93, 10, 16 Mar. 1971, page 8

Burra Burra DC, 2 March

Following objections from C.P. Thamm and Brian Thamm it was decided not to proceed with the closure of Stronach Street.

Council resolved to borrow $20,000 from the Savings Bank of SA by means of a debenture loan for a period of 5 years at 7.1% p.a. interest.

Council said it was in favour of preserving as many of Burra historic buildings as would interest tourists, but the sum envisaged to resite the chimney and other mine buildings was beyond the Council’s resources. It would make available a suitable site and render whatever assistance was possible.

There was a letter from Alexander re the closure of Elphick Street. Plans to be signed.

93, 11, 23 Mar. 1971, page 1

Burra Mine Buildings

Preliminary work on resiting began with the visit of an architect Mr Krause and photographer Mrs Barbara Toope last Wednesday. The builder Mr G. Lloyd will be in Burra this week.

Vandalism. The tyres of three vehicles parked at the Bon Accord Hotel were punctured on Friday night. A transistor radio was stolen from one of them.

M.J. & H.E. Miller’s clearing sale at ‘Illangi’ Gum Creek was very successful. Ninety cattle were sold with milking cows making up to $169.50, heifers to $120 and bulls to $170. [Other significant items are listed.]

Adelaide Wool Sales. [Local district prices are printed.]

Back to Leighton Weekend

Rex Warnes opened the Ball at 9.30 p.m. and the hall was crowded. Numerous pre-ball parties were held. There were four sittings for supper and door takings were $380. Open Day at the school attracted many on Saturday morning and $120 was taken for the light luncheon provided. Following the afternoon tour of the Mine a barbecue began at 4.30 p.m. Profits will improve ticket [sic] facilities at Leighton Hall. [Perhaps toilet facilities?]

93, 11, 23 Mar. 1971, pages 1 & 8

Centenary of Ironmine Methodist Church

About 400 people attended the celebrations last Sunday. Rev. C.L.H. Pitman a former minister in the Redruth Circuit preached the occasional address to a congregation which packed the church and overflowed into a covered area of shade outside. The Burra Circuit Choir sang the anthem and Mrs Mavis Satchell sang a solo. Luncheon was provided by the Ironmine Ladies. In the afternoon people with a past association with the church were given the opportunity to speak and Mrs G. Murray and Mr N. Baynes were the first to contribute. Afternoon tea followed. The Trust Steward made a statement welcoming those who had returned for the occasion.

[Check who it says this was because in 93, 12, 30 Mar. 1971 a correction is made to say it was Ray Lloyd.]

The Lloyd family have been connected with the Ironmine Church for many years, my father holding the position of Trust Secretary for 25 years and I have held it since 1948. Today not many families are left in the immediate locality who take an active interest in the church. The congregation, small as it is, has looked forward to the centenary, the celebration of which is an ambitious undertaking. A letter received this week from retired Congregational Minister Rev. W.R. Trestrail says it was his grandfather, the late Philip Oates, who gave the land on which the church was built and that it was his late mother, Elizabeth Mary Oates, who played the organ when the church was opened. It seems the Oates family featured well in the earliest days of this church’s life. It is known that the father of Mr Percy Oates of Burra, the late John G. Oates, carted the first load of stone to the site.

An account of the first service came to light, preserved in a report in the SA Register. It was actually opened in October – knowledge of this only came to light after the date had been fixed for the centenary. The entry in the SA Register 10 October 1871 says:

At Iron Mine Gum Creek the opening sermons of the new Primitive Methodist Chapel were preached on Sunday 1 October 1871 by Rev. H.J. Pope, minister of the circuit, to large congregations.

On Monday the tea was well patronised by friends from all parts of the district. Mr T. Hutchens presided and Mr T. Clapp gave an address on forming character and the perpetual freshness of Bible Truth and the necessity of Bible education. Mr T. Pedler closed his speech with recitation on Christ’s commission. Mr J. Barrows referred to the absurdity of remarks by grumblers who were perpetually regretting the lack of pulpit talent, power and faithfulness. The Redruth Primitive Methodist Choir sang well chosen anthems. The new chapel was built by Messrs J. & T. Pearce of Kooringa for a total cost of c. £140 and proceeds from the service were £40.

[A list of people apologising for being unable to attend the centenary follows and thanks are expressed for all those who made the occasion such a success.]

93, 11, 23 Mar. 1971, page 2

Birth. To John & Kathryn Beshara nee Henriks at Burra Hospital 16 March, a son, Luke John.

Cricket

Booborowie 5 for 178 defeated Spalding 7 for 176

Burra Footballers 206 defeated Leighton 171

Obituary. Glenton Charles Frederick Eig was born at Burra 7 August 1920. He was the eldest son of Mrs G. & the late Mr D. Eig. In WWII he served in the Middle East and in New Guinea. After the war he joined the PMG and was stationed at the Adelaide GPO for 27 years. He is survived by his mother, a brother David and sister Dorothy.

[Born Glenton Charles Fredrick Eig 7 August 1920 Kooringa: died Glendon Charles Frederick Eig (single) 3 February 1971 Adelaide, residence Hamley Bridge.]

Burra High School Parents and Friends Association AGM.

Elected: President, Mrs Nicholls; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames Carmody & Disher; Secretary, Mrs Webster; Assistant Secretary, Mrs Brereton and Treasurer, Mrs Kempster.

Burra RSL held its AGM 12 March in the clubrooms. Elected: President, B. Kotz; Vice Presidents, T. Rogers & R. Steele; Secretary, W. Fridd and Treasurer, R. Kellock. In 1970 the ten meetings had an average attendance of 8. Services were held for Anzac Day and Remembrance Day in November. The annual dinner was catered for by the Ladies’ Auxiliary.

Mrs Reta Jennison reported on the activities for 1970 in c. 2⁄3 column. The Gala Day in November was on a smaller scale than in previous years, being an afternoon function only and lacking the customary tea and evening concert. Mr & Mrs Scroop attended to the planning and erecting of stalls.

Marriage. At St Andrews Mt Barker on 26 March

Catherine Fife-Smith will marry David Jones of Mt Bryan.

Early Bakers in Burra

[There had been some discussion about early bakers in the town, but I did not note it because it was vague and generally uninformative. You will get some idea of the vagueness when I now note that one of the bakers had been referred to as Mr Holman or Hallman or Aulman. This issue now says he was Mr Ullman, who at one time owned the property now known as ‘Stud Park’ at Mt Bryan and the land on which the Mongolata Gold Mine was later situated. He was a bachelor and c. 1901 returned to visit his former home in Stuttgart, Germany, for a holiday and died aged 95 in Adelaide. He was a great uncle of Mrs May Cox of Burra North.

It is difficult without further knowledge of the family to be sure about these facts, in part because bachelors leave few records and because I do not have easy access to relationships in Germany before migration. But evidence from the Burra Record in 1902 suggests that Mr Ullman the baker operated in Kooringa on the corner of Bridge Terrace and Kingston Street from c. 1869 to 1902. The landowner at Mt Bryan would seem to be Charles August William Ullman 1830-1891. He and his wife died in November 1891 in an influenza epidemic. May Cox was his granddaughter. If the baker was a great uncle, he was a brother to C.A.W. Ullman, but this connection is not traceable in SA records. The reference to the baker’s returning to Germany is verifiable from the Record:

XV, 529, 3 Sep. 1902, page 2

Kooringa Court, 30 August.

John Lines was charged on the information of Charles Ullmann, baker, with being unlawfully on the latter’s premises on the night of 29 August. John Lines and James Knevitt entered Ullmann’s bakehouse in Kingston St and asked for a loaf of bread. Ullmann said he didn’t have a loaf, but would give them a piece. They then entered his bedroom and bread and a candle were thrown at him and one of the two then assaulted him. Panes of his window were broken and later he noticed some buns and a white pudding were missing.

XV, 532, 24 Sep. 1902, page 3

Mr Ullmann, the baker, has been so upset by the assault on him that if he can dispose of his business he will return to Germany.

XV, 534, 8 Oct. 1902, page 2

C. Morgan, who carried on a bakery business for many years in Burra, has purchased the goodwill of Mr W. Ullmann’s business and intends to carry on the business in his own name.

Note that the paper refers to Mr Ullmann as Charles and W. Ullman. There are other references to him as W.

There is only one Ullman registered in SA as dying aged 95: Frank Louis Ullman who was born 3 December 1874 at Kooringa and died 18 March 1970 at St Peters, residence College Park. He was a son of C.A.W. Ullmann. He could not have been the baker who had been in business in Kooringa by c. 1869 as stated in the Record:

XV, 534, 8 Oct. 1902, page 2. Mr Ullmann has been completely shattered by the recent assault and having lived alone in the baking business for over 33 years, has not had a complete night’s rest since. He is going to Pt Pirie for a few weeks and then on to Germany via Sydney.

And

XV, 548, 14 Jan. 1903, page 3

Advt. Charles Morgan takes over the Kingston St Bakery from W. Ullmann after the latter’s 33 years in business.

It seems unlikely that Mr Ullmann the baker returned to SA.]

Mrs May Cox brought in an obituary for a pioneer of Burra, Mr Henry Nourse Thompson, who died at 2 a.m. on Monday morning 21 September 1908:

Obituary. Henry Nourse Thompson, aged 82 years 6 months died at ‘Three Trees’ near Burra on 21 September 1908. He was born 15 March 1826 at Kings Lynn, Norfolk and came to SA in 1852. He was thus a colonist of 56 years. He was an accountant at the Burra Mine and later storekeeper there. He planted the Moreton Bay figs at the Mine Store. (Only one now survives.) He was a great friend of Josiah Thomas’s father and for that reason Mr Thomas took the deceased to live with him at Three Trees. He was there for 40 years. One of his legs was amputated when he was 12 years old owing to ‘white swelling’. He was a well educated and widely read gentleman and was a relative of the Mine’s chief accountant, Mr Challener [sic] [Challoner]

[Henry Nourse Tomson died 21 September 1908 at ‘Three Trees’ near Burra aged 81.]

[Originally reported in the Burra Record VX, 820, 23 Sep. 1908, page 2.]

93, 11, 23 Mar. 1971, page 7

93, 12, 30 Mar. 1971, page 1

Burra Burra Show Inc. AGM

Mr R. Mason was elected President.

There was a credit balance of $227.73 after paying $1,295 for the erection of the shearing shed for which donations of $1,044 had been received. Mr Mason reported on the 1970 show, which was opened on 10 October by the Governor, Sir James Harrison. The weather was fine, but gate takings were down $30 to $650. The star attraction was the Mid North Shearing Championships, held for the first time in the new shearing shed. Horses in Action attracted a record 514 entries. The wool display was up to its usual high standard and a new event was the Honda Agricultural Motor Cycle Trials, which proved a great success. Poultry and Birds also had record entries. Burra & District Schools display was also of a high standard. Industrial displays were numerous. Thanks also go to Mrs Val Secombe for her work as secretary.

Accident. On Monday last week a car driven by Miss Raelene Bottrell of Adelaide struck and killed four sheep near the Hanson Tanks. They were owned by Mr Don Stockman. Damage to the car exceeded $500.

Post Offices from next year will no longer be open for one hour on Easter Saturday and there will be no postal deliveries on that day.

Barkers of Baldina Cottage Homes

Representatives of Commonwealth Social Services attended a Board of Management meeting to set out facts relating to the homes as required by the Government. It is hoped to begin construction soon on 16 units. The committee has purchased the block of land next to the Burra Hospital from the Hospital Board and the adjoining block from Mr J.G. Carpenter. This will give room to duplicate the original set of units should demand warrant it. It is understood the minimum age of admission will be 60 for women and 65 for men and other details regarding costs etc. are yet to be finalised.

Burra Mine ‘Course of Action’

Work will begin within the next two weeks to dismantle the huge Cornish buildings which have stood for 120 years. Mr G. Lloyd has been contracted to remove the buildings from their present sites. He is a noted Adelaide builder known for his magnificent stonework around Adelaide and Sydney. Mr Ian Auhl has been working tirelessly in bringing the project to this stage.

93, 12, 30 Mar. 1971, page 8

Ironmine Reunion 21 March

A list of those who gave short speeches is printed.

The oldest past member present was believed to be Mrs Jettner – first President of the Guild.

Mrs Alderson (recitation)

A long, but incomplete list of those who had some connection with the church and returned for the occasion is printed.

A correction is made to say the Steward’s Report was by Ray Lloyd.

93, 13, 6 Apr. 1971, page 1

European Carp. Reports have confirmed the spread of European Carp throughout the River Murray in SA.

Football. In a pre-season game at Loxton Burra Footballers lost both the ‘A’ & ‘B’ Grade matches.

Ron Wuttke was farewelled by the RSL on Friday night. He had been an active member of the RSL here for 20 years. He was formerly manager of Dalgety’s at Burra and has been transferred to Pt Augusta.

Burra Railway Station acquired a new ‘track-placer’ on Thursday. This will enable shunting of loads of up to 180 tons. Engines from goods trains had previously done this work and the change will reduce travel times for goods trains as a result. Transfer of single trucks has long been done by a Loco Pulser, which has a single rubber tyred wheel driven by a JAP motor and is believed to be the last one in SA. It has now been returned to Adelaide.

The Track-Placer is essentially a tractor with hydraulic hoist and a turntable attached underneath, a railway track coupling hydraulically operated at the front and back and a small pair of ‘railway’ wheels front and back, also hydraulically operated. It can be used for normal road travelling and be driven up to the railway line at right angles, the hoist lowered to the ground and the vehicle raised and swung into position along the track. The railway wheels are then lowered onto the line, the hoist raised and the Track-Placer is ready to do shunting. The hydraulic coupling is raised to lift the front of the railway truck, placing sufficient weight on the front wheels of the Track-Placer to provide traction. The rear wheels of the tractor will be raised above the railway line during shunting.

Fifty-two regular trains pass through Burra each week. The office/control room at the station will undergo complete renewal in the next few weeks due to the white ant damage to flooring and cupboards.

93, 13, 6 Apr. 1971, pages 1 & 8

Burra Primary School Sports this year were won by Hampton House, breaking the run of successive wins by Aberdeen. [Results are printed.]

Cricket. Mokota Association Grand Finals

93, 14, 13 Apr. 1971, page 1

Burra Mine

Samin Ltd’s plant has now been commissioned and has a treatment capacity of 250-300 tones per day and is working 24 hours a day, 7 days a week. The stock pile is being roofed to reduce dust and keep ore dry during wet weather. The finished product is a black powder of copper oxide assaying at 70% copper and will be shipped to smelters or to chemical plants. Washed ore is loaded into five large tanks of some 350 tons capacity and subjected to four days of leaching with a 10% ammonia solution. The solution containing some copper is pumped into the product recovery section where it is washed and steamed to recover any remaining copper and ammonia. These washings are made up to strength by adding fresh ammonia and become the leach solution for the next tank of ore. The copper rich solution is steamed or boiled in an evaporator and the ammonia is driven off and reclaimed in the scrubbing section, to be reused once the copper precipitates as copper oxide. After steaming the evaporator is discharged into a thickening tank and the oxide settles to the bottom and the clear hot water overflows from the top of the tank to be used again. Copper oxide is removed from the bottom of the tank as a black slurry and pumped to a continuous filter which removes most of the water, leaving a semi-dry cake of copper oxide. In total 46 are employed at the mine and of the 10 staff members 5 are local. Of the 21 employed on plant operation 16 are local and 15 are employed in quarrying. When the fourth permanent Housing Trust home is completed two will be occupied by members of Samin and two by Roche Bros.

There are ten transportable houses; seven occupied by Samin employees and three by employees of Roche Bros. The company has also bought three established houses in Burra, occupied by Messrs:

H. Rich, Operations Manager

A. McFarlane, Metallurgist and Mill Superintendent

N. Van Buuren, Works Maintenance Engineer.

Roche Bros have bought a Burra North home, which is occupied by Mr Lyle Quinn.

[Three photos are printed:

Ross Groth, process operator at the control room instrument panel.

A view of the five copper leaching tanks and ore charging conveyors.

The four evaporators – four vessels in mild steel, 12 ft in diameter and 35 ft high, forming the initial stage of recovery of copper oxide from the copper ammonia solution. The ammonia is recovered using steam in water sprays and used again in the next leaching cycle.

Burra Mine Buildings Preservation Fund

S.J. Woollacott started the fund with $500. National Trust members have spent the last couple of weeks sending letters appealing for donations which are tax deductible. Graves’ Pump House contains some 2,000 tons of stone. Mr Ian Auhl points out a building similar to Graves’ was transferred from Kadina to Wallaroo in 1876 and they were commonly moved in Cornwall when an ore body was worked out – it being cheaper than quarrying and cutting new stone.

Monday: Mixed Rinks won by Zoe Wood, Reg Corner & Estelle Mitchell.

Burra Mine

[Two photographs of operations:

A view of the office block and laboratory.

93, 14, 13 Apr. 1971, page 5

Burra Cub & Scout Group Committee is raising funds to erect a shower and toilet block at the hall. A bottle drive is being held with a sorting day 17 April at the Burra North Depot.

Milton Edwards as President of the Group Committee reports on their second year:

They have solid backing and support. Regular bottle drives would be sufficient to provide funds now that the initial needs have been met, but it has proved difficult to co-ordinate them and establish a routine. The facilities at the Cub and Scout Halls have been improved and the change to ETSA power has been a great help. A shower and toilet block is essential for weekend camping at the Halls. The birthday social on 16 October was a wonderful success. Thanks go especially to Secretary, Mr Peter Mengersen, Treasurer, Mr Bob Mason and Group Scout Master Mr Brian Ashdown.

93, 15, 20 Apr. 1971, page 1

Weather. Good opening rains have fallen in both the agricultural and pastoral areas, though totals vary considerably. Burra recorded 136 points, Cappeedee 215, Old Koomooloo 101, Sturt Vale 130, Woolgangi 130, Glenora 100, Hallett 231 and Booborowie 160.

Burra High School Sports Day was held at the Burra Memorial Oval in ideal weather last Thursday. Cup winners:

Senior Girls’ Cup B. Kleinig

Junior Girls’ Cup S. Spackman

Senior Boys’ Cup M. Broderick

Junior Boys’ Cup R. Wade

The House Competition went to Steele House.

Richard J. Sinclair of the Railway Camp was sentenced to six months on Thursday for larceny from the Used Car Yard of Jennison’s Tyre Service on Wednesday night and three months concurrently for driving whilst under suspension. Later on Thursday he escaped from the police cell at Burra North by tearing out the inner sheet of iron and bashing out the outer sheet. He was found hiding in the ceiling space of a House in George St about 3.30 p.m. He was sent to Pt Pirie lock-up and on Friday had another month added to his sentence.

93, 15, 20 Apr. 1971, pages 1 & 2

Burra North Recreation Rooms were opened on Saturday night in unfavourable weather. Burra Burra DC Mr R.J. Jeffery declared the rooms open. President of the Aberdeen Football Club Mr Bruce Stockman hoped the rooms would be used for organised recreation. The committee still has to raise about $1,200, having spent $2,500. The AFC had donated $1,475 ($1,327 from the Women’s Auxiliary), the National Fitness Council $500 and the Basketball Club $300 to get the project started. Mr Jeffery said there was some doubt about when the Aberdeen Football Club had been formed and 1911 had been suggested. Mr Jeffery thought a much earlier date was needed, possibly 1896, as his father walked in from Copperhouse to play for it about that time. Mr Stan Noske as President of the Mid North Football League added his congratulations to those of Mr Jeffery. He appealed for people to enjoy the new facilities, but not to abuse them. Mr Reed had been going to present Ivan Hirschausen with Life Membership of the Club, but was prevented by illness. Mr Stockman made the presentation. For her work, tolerance and time Mrs S. Scroop was also honoured with Life Membership.

[The paper’s reporting of football is rather erratic, which makes any history of the clubs in the town impossible to construct from this source. There is a report of the formation of an Aberdeen Football Club in May 1881, but then no reports of matches until 1892.

From 1892 to 1897 there was an Aberdeen Club and a Burra Club.

In 1898 there is no mention of football in the town.

In 1899 there is one club: Burra.

In 1900 there seems to have been an Aberdeen Club and a Kooringa Club – although the former is once reported as Redruth and the latter occasionally called Burra.

In 1901 the Burra Club is mentioned, but not the Aberdeen.

In 1902 & 1903 there were three town clubs: Aberdeen, Kooringa (Burra) & Ramblers.

In 1904 there appears to have been no local competition and one game with Burra v. Clare.

From 1905 to 1912 there were three town clubs: Aberdeen, Kooringa & Ramblers.

In 1913 Ramblers merged with Kooringa to form Kooringa and Aberdeen continued, and a Light Horse Club was formed.

These three continued for 1914, though the Light Horse had to forfeit its matches after the 1st Semi-Final due to the outbreak of WWI.

In 1915 Kooringa & Light Horse merged to form Kooringa and Aberdeen continued.

1916-1918 Kooringa & Aberdeen were in recess due to WWI, though an occasional game was played for patriotic causes.

1919-1924 the two town teams were Kooringa & Aberdeen.

1925 & 1926 saw three town teams: Kooringa, Aberdeen & Ramblers.

1927-1929 there were two town teams: Aberdeen & Ramblers.

From 1930 to 1933 the two town teams were Aberdeen & Kooringa.

After that there was one town team called Kooringa and later Burra until Aberdeen was re-established in 1961. The variations in the Associations within which these teams played are even more complicated]

93, 15, 20 Apr. 1971, pages 1 & 7

Burra Mine Buildings Preservation Fund. Donations have reached $1,595.60.

Scaffolding is being erected inside Peacock’s Chimney. The stonework will be lowered from the top by crane to local trucks below, ready for transport to the new site.

Burra Burra DC, 5 April

The Overseer is to expedite the Bon Accord Bridge road construction.

It was resolved to give $500 towards the repair of the Powder Magazine.

The Town Clerk is to draw up recommendations for the Burra Town Hall dressing room improvements.

Council resolved to close and vest in the Minister of Education that portion of Tomkusson [sic: for Tomkinson] Street dividing Pt Block 13A CT 1593/90 in GRO plan 20 of 1905 from Pt Block 13 CT 3726/50 in GRO plan 20 of 1905 and other portion of Pt Block 13 CT 3351/162 in GRO plan 20 of 1905 etc.

[It would seem that the National Trust had asked for the mine buildings that were to be demolished to be donated to them, because it was resolved to donate the buildings as requested.]

93, 16, 27 Apr. 1971, page 1

Vandalism. Police were notified that on Saturday fifty panes of glass had been broken at the Racecourse Oval. On investigation they found attempts had been made in four places to burn down the grandstand.

Theft. Men’s clothing to the value of $246 was stolen from Bence’s Ltd last night. Thieves broke the glass door of the Men’s Department.

The Anzac Commemoration service was held at the Market Square War Memorial on Sunday afternoon. The address was given by Rev. Milton Edwards.

Burra & District Tourism Committee held its AGM in Burra Town Hall on Thursday night, but it was poorly attended. Only the committee and R.J. Jeffery of the Burra Burra DC attended.

The St John Ambulance Building Campaign total has reached $1,000.

93, 16, 27 Apr. 1971, pages 1 & 4

Burra Mine Buildings Preservation Fund has reached $3,717.70. All the brickwork has been removed from the top of Peacock’s Chimney and stacked at the reconstruction site.

93, 16, 27 Apr. 1971, page 7

Ironmine Ladies’ Guild held its AGM and elected President, Mrs R. Gent, Vice-Presidents, Mesdames A. Lloyd & M. Edwards; Secretary, M. White; Assistant Secretary, Mrs C. Lloyd and Treasurer, D. Lloyd. In 1970 the membership had been 15 and average attendance 9.

93, 16, 27 Apr. 1971, page 8

Anzac Day. Burra’s Anzac March took place as scheduled on Sunday, but the weather was cold and windy and kept most people indoors.

Ashton’s Circus was prevented from erecting its big top for its show scheduled for last night and their vehicles had trouble negotiating the slippery surfaces of the old sale yards. They had to resort to tractor assistance for some heavy vehicles.

The Burra Methodist Sunday School Picnic was cancelled due to the weather conditions.

Birth. To Marlene & Brian Richards of Hallett yesterday at the QVMH, a daughter, Christie Lee.

93, 17, 4 May 1971, page 1

North Eastern Combined Schools Sports were held at the Spalding Oval on Thursday. The winner for the day was Leighton. Competing schools were Leighton, St Joseph’s Convent, Booborowie Red, Booborowie Green, Spalding Hill, Spalding Hutt, Hilltown and Willalo. [Major winners are listed.]

The Art Display at the RSL Hall in Burra on Friday drew a steady stream of visitors. Ron Kellock’s display of gemstones, minerals and Aboriginal artefacts created much interest. His display of malachite was a highlight for many. The works by eleven of Mr Len Bence’s students were also impressive and the Floral Art Group gave a fine display despite the wild winds of the recent past.

93, 17, 4 May 1971, pages 1 & 8

Burra Mine Buildings Preservation Fund stands at $5,078.40, which includes $500 from Roche Bros.

93, 17, 4 May 1971, page 2

Obituary. A Notice to Creditors reveals the death of Jane Florence Melrose of ‘Kadlunga’ Mintaro, widow, who died 24 August 1970. [Born Jane Florence Lewis 17 March 1884 Kooringa: died at Clare, residence Mintaro. She was the daughter of the Hon. John Lewis MLC and husband of Alexander John Melrose, son of Sir John Melrose of Ulooloo.]

93, 18, 11 May 1971, page 1

Adelaide Wool Sales. [Local district prices are printed.]

Burra Burra DC will adopt an emblem and to this end a competition will be held open to all to design and draft a suitable emblem. Entries to the District Office 14 Commercial St Burra.

Burra Mine: The Powder Magazine

What is the evidence for its erection in 1847?

Ian Auhl forwards copies of the letters written at the time by Thomas Burr, Superintendent of the Burra Burra Mine, to the Directors in Adelaide.

Letter 1: 18 September 1847

The plan and sections of the new powder magazine have been drawn by me and in a day or two the builder will give an estimate. Dimensions are 12 ft x 20 ft x 6 ft to the springing of the arch, which is semi-circular. Side walls are to be 2” in thickness and the end walls 2 feet. [Sic: this must be an error, presumably for 2 ft.] To be roofed in slate. [Auhl says this was an overall roof – long since dismantled.]

I will forward plans as soon as I can make duplicates, but given the heat and the unsafe nature of the present structure and situation, I will proceed with the new one without delay. To secure life and property I advise that shoes of a peculiar construction be made forthwith (three or more pairs) for use of those visiting the magazine or engaged in moving powder. To be made of soft leather and fitting like a sock. Having visited the magazine and seen loose powder scattered on sandy and gravely floor, it is apparent a most disastrous consequence might ensue with total destruction of the workings and great loss of life.

Letter 2. 20 September 1847.

I have marked out the site and work will commence at once and should be done in a month. Site chosen is on top of a hill in front of this house. (Auhl says that is the Mine Manager’s residence – now destroyed.) From its commanding view it will be a landmark and will be well ventilated.

Letter 3. 25 November 1847.

I would be obliged if you would expedite the sheeves (i.e. the slates) as the building cannot be completed without them. I wish to have the powder moved before the height of summer and we usually get a day or two of rain at the end of November or early December, which would be a good time to move it.

The sheeves arrived and the powder was moved early in December 1847.

Evidence for the laying out of Kooringa in 1845.

See SA Register 18 October 1845 and Minutes of the Directors of SAMA Saturday 18 October 1845. Directors intend immediately to accompany Captain Ey and Messrs Dreyer & son to the Mine to make arrangements for the erection of a smelting house and to select the site for a township.

Saturday 22 November 1845.

Site for the smelting house has been selected and one street of the township has been laid out. Different names for the township were considered. The first suggestion of the Directors was Redruth and the second was Truro. On 4 November 1845 the name Kooringa was chosen. The first hotel was erected and licensed in 1846, later the old hospital, which was knocked down a few years ago to make way for the new hospital wing.

93, 18, 11 May 1971, page 2
