Sgt Norm Orford will begin duties in the City on 18 June and his successor Sgt Haynes commences here on 16 June. It sounds as if the new Police Station is almost ready for occupation.

Mrs Matthews, daughter of Mrs E. Simpson of Burra North, will return to Burra from Townsville during her husband’s tour of duty in Vietnam.

Terry Rule succeeds Daryl Hardy at the National Bank in Burra. Daryl has gone to Renmark and Terry comes from Robertstown.

Tom & Marg. Jackson have transferred to the city.

Mike Hammer of Elders-GM has been transferred to the South East.

Geoff. Male and his wife will leave Burra shortly for Wilmington.

Mr & Mrs S. Thompson have closed their Terowie store and are holding a clearing sale of drapery and groceries in the shop next to Burra Meat Stores.

93, 18, 11 May 1971, page 8

Aberdeen Football Club Women’s Auxiliary held its AGM and elected: President, Mrs Scroop; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames J. Wall & R. Kelly; Secretary, Mrs I. Hirschausen and Treasurer, Miss C. Reed. In conjunction with the Basketball Club they have been able to raise $1,610.98 in the past year.

[Details of these money-raising activities are given.]

Burra Bowling Associates held their AGM and elected President, Dorrie Pietsch; Vice-Presidents, Rube Phillips Sen. & Ellen Scott Jnr; Secretary, Laurel Neil and Treasurer, Isla Jacka. The associates raised $967.11 in the past year. Membership rose from 24 to 29. [Other details are given in a 2⁄3-column report.]

93, 19, 18 May 1971, page 1

Burra Mine

A trial shipment of 15.5 tons of copper oxide was railed out on Thursday to Pt Kembla, where a company will determine the smelting quality of Samin’s Burra product. During the commissioning stages of the plant there have been some problems, but Mr Harry Rich thinks these have now been ironed out. The original aim was to produce 2.5 tons of copper oxide per day. One day in the commissioning stages they produced 3.5 tons.

The product that is scraped from the filters is deposited in 44 gallon drums, each weighing half a ton. It is expected the plant will be able to ship out 70-80 drums each fortnight, representing 35 to 40 tons of copper oxide. The actual copper content is 75%. At present the material being treated is from the dump, from the previous mining operations. The roofing over the stockpile at the crusher is nearing completion.

Peacock’s Chimney has now been completely dismantled and carted to the new site and the foundation is being dug there.

Burra Burra DC, 3 May

Tenders are to be called for construction of caravan park amenities.

Plans for office alterations are to be submitted next meeting. The plans are to include access to the ladies public toilet.

Burra Town Hall renovations are to include

Installation of one pedestal in the men’s toilets.

Replacement of ladies’ toilet pedestals.

Floor coverings for the dressing room.

A moveable screen to divide the dressing room.

Costs for the maintenance of the Ambulance-EFS building are to be apportioned 60% Ambulance and 40% EFS or DC.

Cr Jennison’s motion to donate $100 to the Burra Mine Buildings Preservation Fund lapsed for want of a seconder.

Crs T. Quinn & Phillips motion to donate $50 was carried.

Burra Tourist Promotion Committee wrote about re-instating the old drinking fountain. Council will inspect it and ascertain the cost.

Reprint from SA Register 18 May 1871

‘With sincere regret we notify the sudden death of Mr John Winnall, draper of Rundle Street. He was an old colonist and was formerly in business at the Burra where he will be interred in the family vault.’

93, 19, 18 May 1971, page 7

Burra Mine Buildings Preservation Fund has reached $6,006.50.

93, 20, 25 May 1971, page 1

Junior Ballet Classes drew an overwhelming response in Burra and this term extra classes will be added. The teacher is Mrs Lorraine King who has danced with the Queensland Dance Company. Classes are conducted under the auspices of the Mid North Adult Education Centre. [Mrs King’s address was 22 Taylor Street.]

Port Adelaide Pensioners’ Club gave their annual concert at the Burra Town Hall on Friday afternoon to a well filled hall. The format resembled an old time Music Hall.

Burra Mine Buildings Preservation Fund has reached $6,441.50.

Burra Mine

The foundations for the resited Peacock’s Chimney are to be poured next weekend by voluntary labour under the direction of the builder Me Geoff. Lloyd. Dudley Cockington reports seeing the sketchbook of Col. E.C. Frome who was the third Surveyor-General of SA after Col. Light and Captain Sturt. Among the paintings there are some of the Burra area in 1843-45 before the town existed. They include scenes of Burra Creek, World’s End, Smokey Valley, Razor Back and Mt Bryan. The collection was purchased last year from London by the SA Art Gallery.

93, 20, 25 May 1971, page 6

Bill Ryan, formerly a dental mechanic for Les. Phillips at Burra, visited the place last week after an absence of 31 years.

Darle Baker also visited Burra after living here 30 years ago. His father was then with the railways.

[Born Gawler East 10 December 1926.]

Paxton Square Cottages are proving popular with visitors.

Moving House

A house 27 ft x 19.5 ft high was moved to Burra last weekend. It had lain empty for some years near the main Adelaide Road near the Holme Hill turn-off. It was placed on a low loader on Sunday and escorted by Constable Miller of Burra. On the main road every overhead telephone line had to be lifted over the house. At Burra the idea was to enter the town via Burra North and Smelts Road to Mr & Mrs N. Fuller’s property south of the cemetery, but the load was unable to negotiate the narrow bridge on Ayers Street, south of Welsh Place. The next idea was to travel behind the hospital, up Kangaroo Street and then down to the Pig and Whistle Crossing and along Ayers Street. Except for a few tree branches and wires all went as planned until the load slipped at the turn at the top of the hill and slid gently to the ground. Not much damage was done, but it took from 1.30 p.m. to 5.30 p.m. before it was reloaded and it was dark by the time the load reached Thames Street. The area was closed to traffic for the night and the journey began again at 7.30 a.m. on Monday. The ford was safely crossed and the home was at its new site by 10.30 a.m.

93, 21, 1 June 1971, page 1

Adelaide Wool Sales last Tuesday to Thursday. Top local price was 401⁄4c for R.M. Gebhardt & Co. of Mokota. [Local district prices are printed.]

Austcare Doorknock Appeal in Burra failed to get support from young people. Rural Youth decided it was unable to assist and a hastily organised effort saw only about three quarters of the town covered for $116.75.

Inter-School Sports were held at Kapunda last Wednesday in near perfect weather conditions in contrast to the original day planned at the end of last term. Burra was placed 4th in the Championship event (Ohlmeyer Shield) and 2nd in the Handicap Shield. Burra has now been runner-up for this shield in three successive years. Notable winners:

Michael Broderick Open 100 m hurdles

Open High Jump (record)

Stephen Lane U15 100 m hurdles (record)

U15 triple jump (record)

U15 discus

Tony Wall U15 400 m (record)

Shane Wilkin U13 long jump

Beverley Kleinig Open 60 m hurdles

Open discus

Brenda Harris U13 60 m hurdles

(Mt Bryan)

93, 21, 1 June 1971, page 6

Peacock’s Pump House will be blown up at 12.15 p.m. on Friday. Members of the public can view the event from the area near the water tank only, with entrance through the Council’s gate at West Street Burra North.

‘Although it would seem that not too many people care much, the onus is on the whole town to save what we are able. To outsiders it would surely appear that apathy and/or lethargy are enjoying gracious living here in quite a few places.’

Birth. To Errol & Kay Hood of Whyalla on 21 May, a daughter, Natasha Colette.

Birth. To Dawn & Richard Tennant at Lyell McEwin Hospital on 31 May, a daughter, Jodi Michelle.

Birth. To Barbara & John Schmerl last week at Burra Hospital, a daughter, Bronwyn Jean.

Debbie Kirk, formerly of Burra and daughter of Dr & Mrs Peter Kirk of Blackwood, recently won the talent quest ‘New Faces’ on TV Channel 10.

Monsignor Clune, parish priest at Spalding, was ordained 50 years ago and celebrations are being held today in Spalding.

Obituary. George Brown died at Burra Hospital on Friday. He was the father of Bill Brown.

[Born George Michie Ian Brown 26 August 1888 Hundred of Colton: died George Michi Ion Brown 28 May 1971 Burra, Residence Elliston.]

Obituary. Mr Osbertus Finch, formerly of Burra, died in Adelaide 29 May.

Tony Fillmore has lost his car after it was struck by another vehicle while parked in front of his house.

93, 22, 8 June 1971, page 1

Football. The finals of the 16th Central Districts Carnival will be played at Burra for the first time next Monday 14 June.

CWA members from Marrabel, Lyndoch and Mt Bryan met Mr S.J. Woollacott of the National Trust outside the Burra Museum on 27 May to have a good look at Burra’s past. After the museum they visited the dugouts, Paxton Square, the Reformatory and St Mary’s Church. Lunch was taken in the Burra CWA rooms. In the afternoon they visited Samin for a look at the Mine and the processing plant with Mr G. O’Connor.

M & BHA. Mothers of young children are urged to attend the next branch meeting on 15 June. The President and her committee are concerned at the dwindling interest being shown. Only four attended the last meeting and this could soon mean that with no meetings there will be no clinic. Average attendance has often been about 10.

93, 22, 8 June 1971, pages 1 & 3

Monsignor Clune was honoured at Spalding on 1 June when almost 400 people attended the Golden Jubilee of his ordination despite continuous rain. Bishop Gallagher of Pt Pirie and Monsignor Clune celebrated Mass at11 a.m. and the procession before Mass included Archbishops Beovich & Gleeson from Adelaide. [The large list of clergy present is printed and the whole report extends for c. 13⁄4 column.

Birth. To Susan & Rob Ashby last Friday, twin daughters.

Obituary. Mrs Ann Bourne died on Saturday at the Clare Hospital. She was the grandmother of Mrs Leo Robinson of Burra. [Died 5 June 1971 aged 83.]

Obituary. Mr Frank Richards of Goodwood died 25 May. His father was stationmaster at Mt Bryan many years ago and the late Mr Richards was a soldier in WWI and married one of the Misses Quinn of Mt Bryan.

[Frederick Francis Watts Richards born 26 November 1895 Littlehampton: died 25 May 1971 Goodwood. He married Ellen Veronica Quinn, daughter of W.H. Quinn.]

Peacock’s Pump House was blown up before a large crowd. We hope to have photographs next week.

93, 22, 8 June 1971, page 7

Netball

‘A’ Grade Burra Blue 43 defeated Clare South 22

Burra Gold 58 defeated Booborowie 23

‘B’ Grade Clare South 34 defeated Burra 25

‘C’ Grade Leighton 49 defeated Burra 16

‘E’ Grade Leighton 19 defeated Burra 10

93, 23, 15 June 1971, page 1

Burra Town Hall Pictures are losing patrons due to the rowdy behaviour of some of the young ones attending.

Burra Burra DC. Because of insufficient office accommodation the Council is considering enlarging the present building, or making some modified additions to the Town Hall.

Caravan Park. Plans have been accepted for the second caravan park to be located opposite the present park and swimming pool. Tenders have been called for an amenities block and installation of power and water points. D.T. Jacka’s tender has been accepted. Council has applied for a grant of $4,000 for this purpose. The park, of proceeded with, will accommodate 20 vans and will be screened from the road by trees, now ready to be planted. The present park has earned $2,200 this financial year, making it a payable proposition.

Morgan Road. The realignment of the road in the vicinity of Klaebe’s Creek is being supported by grant money and should be completed in the next financial year – probably in August.

Burra Mine. Peacock’s Pump House was demolished on 4 June. It had stood for over a century before being blown up. The adjacent chimney has already been removed for resiting at the Mine entrance on the main road. The explosives were arranged to do as little damage to the actual stones as possible. There is still time to save Graves’ Pump House. It can be re-erected on the site by the main road where the chimney is to stand. The lack of support from local people is staggering and the apparent indifference is saddening.

‘It is imperative that we save what we can and see that the skill of those Cornish stone masons doesn’t become just a memory and a legend.’

[Three photos of the event are printed.]

93, 23, 15 June 1971, page 2

Bond it is

The Boy Scouts and Cubs made a nice sum at their barbecue and bonfire on Friday night.

93, 24, 22 June 1971, page 1

Meals on Wheels

A public meeting will be held on 12 July in the Town Hall to form a local branch of Meals on Wheels. Members of the Methodist Women’s Fellowship have done the ground work in ascertaining the need for such a service and so far 10 elderly residents have been accepted as prospective clients. Meals will be prepared at Burra Hospital and delivered to the homes of recipients by voluntary helpers five days a week. Recipients will pay a small sum each week. A good attendance at the meeting is needed to make the project a reality.

The Kapunda Music Society will present The Mikado at Burra Town Hall on 24 July with proceeds to aid the Burra & District Swimming Pool.

Monsignor Clune celebrated his golden jubilee of ordination at St Augustine’s. [Two photos.]

Accident. A stock transport owned and driven by Mr James G. Cranston of Broken Hill overturned when the trailer came a drift from the prime mover. The stock crate collided with a telephone pole bringing down communications between Burra and Booborowie. The crate was wrecked and three cattle were killed instantly. Another six had to be destroyed subsequently. Stock losses were estimated at $800 to $1,000. The driver and a passenger escaped injury.

Burra School Grade III visited the Burra Record last Thursday. They were fascinated to see how the different machines worked and to see how printing was done. [The names of those who visited are listed.]

93, 26, 6 July 1971, page 1

Organised Purchasing Power (OPP) was a group of firms planning to lower prices to the farmer through cut price outlets. There is an article of 22⁄3 columns outlining the pros and cons, given that such a plan could have an impact on the survival of rural towns.

Mr & Mrs P.J. Thomas’s home at Burra North was broken into on Saturday. Items to the value of about $55 were stolen.

Robertstown National Bank was robbed by a young man armed with a sawn-off shot-gun on Thursday. He escaped with $740.84.

Maurice Fenton has written a book on the nineteenth century Savings Bank manager William Kingsworth Mallyon. Among churches he designed was St Aidan’s Church of England at Saddleworth in 1894.

Adelaide Wool Sales last Tuesday to Thursday were the last to use the Avoirdupois system of weights. [Local district prices are printed.]

Burra Bowling Club. The annual report by E.C. Pietsch.

Season 1970-71 was opened by a past-president Mr H. Binks-Williams. Charles Dare the greens manager did a great job, but had to retire during the year. This year the clubrooms were extended and the extensions were declared open on 31 January 1971 by the President of RSABA, Les. Luke. The Easter Tournament was a great success. On 20 March the Mid North Champion of Champions Day was held on the Burra Greens. Club Champion this season was Bill Corner. [Various people are then thanked for their help in the past season.

93, 27, 13 July 1971, page 1

Burra Burra DC, 5 July

Rates were left unchanged from 1970-71.

Mr Roy Jeffery was elected Chairman for the ensuing year.

Burra Primary School Grade VI students visited the meeting.

Since 1965 plans have been drawn up and altered for a common effluent scheme, but so far no action has followed. Now a new scheme of limited extent to be achieved at a reasonable cost has been designed to serve the most difficult areas and it is hoped this will receive ratepayer support. Council also discussed vandalism at Redruth Gaol, noisy patrons at the Burra Pictures, pedestrians and school children not using the pedestrian crossing at the Town Hall and control of horehound in Burra.

93, 28, 20 July 1971, page 1

Tom Eastman, Rotary Exchange Student writes thanking the people of Burra for showing him such a wonderful time during his stay in Australia.

93, 28, 20 July 1971, pages 1 & 8

Peter C. Morris of Niusawa School, Fiji, writes with information about the story of Rev. Jennison in Fiji and with the suggestion that H.J.B. Jennison had been born in the house that the writer presently occupied. He had some information from a young New Zealand student doing research on missionary correspondence in the late 19th and early 20th century.

Rev. J.C. Jennison was the resident missionary on Taveuni in the 1890s to at least 1905. Until 1900 the mission was based at Vuna on the southern end of Taveuni because it was furthest from the warlike chief of Somosomo. In 1899 the church decided to relocate to the northern section and purchased the plantation named Niusawa. This was a narrow strip only 17 chains wide, but extending up the mountain for about 3 miles, to give an area of over 400 acres. Rev. Jennison and family moved into the previous home of the plantation owner in 1900. It was in a very poor condition and close to the sea. A new house was begun in 1901. By February 1902 they had moved into the house while part was still under construction. The house was 66 ft wide x 56 ft deep, with half a dozen rooms and a 10 ft 6 inch wide verandah. So H.J.B. was not born at Niusawa, but spent some of his earliest years there. The house has not been much changed despite some modifications in the 1930s. The surroundings have, however, been transformed. It is surrounded by the buildings of a large secondary school accommodating nearly 400 children from class 1 to Form 5 (equivalent of Leaving Standard). Almost 150 secondary students live in the school hostel on the site. The buildings are arranged around the playing field and the school serves a large area of Fiji. Students are a mixture of Fijians and Indians as well as from the islands, with a few Chinese and part-Europeans.

Editor: Peter Morris is a former member of staff of Burra High School and his wife was born Antoinette Harris, daughter of Mr & Mrs V.R. Harris of Booborowie.

93, 28, 20 July 1971, page 2

Advt. Burra Pictures, 24 July will be replaced by Kapunda Musical Society’s production of Gilbert & Sullivan’s The Mikado.

Weather. A severe hailstorm hit ‘The Gums’ last Thursday evening. Today (Tuesday) many still remain en masse in many spots and one dam is so packed with them you could almost walk over it.

93, 29, 27 July 1971, page 1

M & BHA held its AGM and elected: President, Mrs R. Stockman; Vice-President, Mrs S. Allen; Secretary, Mrs P.F. Hall; Secretary, Mrs L. Reed & Treasurer, Mrs J. Hirschausen. The branch has 21 financial members.

The average attendance for the first half was 10, but then fell away to be very poor, being below quorum for one meeting, with just four present. Sister Mudge resigned in May and Sister Conlon took her place.

Luke Day’s old house was demolished yesterday.

The Kooringa Hotel is having $15,000 worth of alterations to feature a large lounge and bar and new toilets. D.T. Jacka & Co. are the contractors.

93, 30, 3 Aug. 1971, page 1

Absconders Apprehended in Burra

Two absconders from McNally Training Centre with two city companions were apprehended in Burra on Thursday. They were aged 14 & 16. They absconded on Monday and stole a utility, picked up two companions aged 14 & 15 on Wednesday and headed north. They were seen getting petrol at Hurley’s Roadhouse and fled, leaving the car and running off on foot. After considerable trouble they were all caught.

Burra Traders’ Association held a dinner meeting at Burra Hotel, which was addressed by Mr Ron Dewhirst.

93, 30, 3 Aug. 1971, page 2

Advt. Burra Pictures, 7 August

No pictures due to Burra Football Cabaret.

Hanson CWA held its AGM. The report extends for 3⁄4 column.

Flexmore Hudson, the well-known author, will give a public lecture at Burra High School Assembly Hall at 8 p.m. on Monday 9 August. His subject will be The nature of poetry with special reference to Rex Ingamells.

Burra Small Bore Rifle Club elected for 1971-72 Captain, A. Pearce; Vice-Captain, M. Thomas and secretary. A new range will be built this year.

Monsignor P.V. Hughes will be given a farewell tea in Burra Town Hall on Tuesday 24 August.

Debutante of the North Ball was held at Spalding on 23 July. Miss Josie Evans of Pt Broughton was the winner of the title.

The Hanson Store closed at noon on Saturday after many years of trading. The post office will continue to be run by Mr Robinson.

93, 30, 3 Aug. 1971, page 8

Football. North Eastern League

‘A’ Grade Clare South 14.7 defeated Burra 13.10

93, 31, 10 Aug. 1971, page 1

Kapunda Musical Society’s Mikado season was a great success. The society now regretfully bids farewell to Mr Richard Walker and Miss Helen Roberts who now leave Kapunda after producing the 1971 production of The Mikado. The production contributed to many district charities including the Burra & District Swimming Pool.

Burra Caravan Park

The Government has granted $5,000 subsidy on the new Caravan Park, which will cater for twenty vans on the opposite bank of the creek from the present park. It will offer toilets, showers and laundry facilities and will also cater for tent campers. The work is due for completion by 21 December next. Annual income from the present park is $1,600 to $1,700. The total cost of the new park is expected to be $12,000.

93, 31, 10 Aug. 1971, pages 1 & 5

The Clare-Spalding Railway

Mr E.C. Allen MP has warned that this line may close in the near future. Following sharp increases in freight costs in 1966, which added about 3c per bushel in the district, much grain transport has moved to road. Also transporting grain 50 miles to Pt Pirie is cheaper than using the rail for over 100 miles to Pt Adelaide. Andrews is the only rail grain terminal north of Clare. Passenger services were discontinued about 14 years ago.

[Further financial details and other arguments are reported.]

93, 31, 10 Aug. 1971, pages 1 & 7

Burra Burra DC has kept its rate unchanged despite rising costs because of the difficult state of primary industries at the moment. The collection of rates this year has also proved difficult. The Council presently employs 19 men on outside work plus some owner-driver contractors on roadwork funded by Government grants. Council work has reached a high level of efficiency. [There is then a lengthy analysis of income and expenditure giving figures.]

93, 31, 10 Aug. 1971, page 5

Syd. & Blanche Robinson thank customers for their support for nearly 26 years at the Hanson Store, which they closed on 31 July.

93, 31, 10 Aug. 1971, page 6

Commercial Hotel. Dion Biggs put his foot through a piece of cement in the yard of the Commercial Hotel and revealed an old well 6-8 ft across, 35 ft deep and containing 10 ft of water. The Well will be filled in with debris from demolished walls from renovations at the Kooringa Hotel.

Obituary. Mrs Harriet Campbell of Mt Bryan died last week aged 89.

[Born Harriet Ann Emma Pike 18 January 1882 Tungkillo: died 4 August 1971 Burra, residence Mt Bryan.]

Mr W.B. Ashby of Hallett is to be made a life member of the North Eastern Football League.

Netball

‘A’ Grade Clare South 42 defeated Burra Gold 39

Burra Blue 20 defeated Spalding 17

‘B’ Grade Spalding 43 defeated Burra 9

‘C’ Grade Burra 24 defeated Spalding 21

‘D’ Grade Spalding 16 defeated Burra 3

‘E’ Grade Burra 12 defeated Spalding 9

93, 31, 10 Aug. 1971, page 7

Burra Mine Buildings Preservation Fund reaches $7,692.48.

93, 32, 17 Aug. 1971, page 1

Burra Mine

245 representatives from the Adelaide Regional Conference of the Australasian Institute of Mining and Metallurgy visited Burra on Sunday. [Key members are named.] The Samin Ltd plant was inspected, followed by a buffet lunch at the Town Hall organised by ladies of the Burra Primary School Welfare Club, with drinks from the Commercial Hotel. After lunch the visitors were shown around the open cut and other historic town sites. Market research by Samin shows the copper oxide product is likely to find a market as an ingredient in fertilizers. This will require a drying kiln to reduce the moisture content from the present 10% to 1%.

Mid North Football League held a special general meeting. Negotiations about amalgamation with the north Eastern League are to continue, but there is no likelihood of amalgamation before the 1973 season.

93, 33, 24 Aug. 1971, page 1

LCL, Burra Men’s Branch AGM was held at Burra Hotel 16 August. Guest Speaker was the Leader of the Opposition, Hon. Steele Hall. Elected were: President, Jock Duncan; Vice-President, Don Stockman and Secretary, Peter McGregor-Reid.

Manoora-Black Springs Road railway crossing will get flashing lights this financial year and provision has also been made for lights at the Saddleworth-Marrabel crossing. The wig-wag signal at the Eudunda-Kapunda crossing will be changed to flashing lights.

Young Liberals held a successful barbecue at ‘Bungaree’ Station north of Clare on Sunday.

Football. North Eastern League

‘A’ Grade The Mail Medal went to Darrell Field Junior of Burra for 1971

The runner-up Rob Ashby of Hallett won the Burra Record Trophy

Barry Eberhard of Burra was third.

‘B’ Grade The medal went to Geoff. Pink of Clare [North or South?]

Colts Kym Spackman of Burra won the medal.

93, 33, 24 Aug. 1971, page 2

Advt. Burra Pictures, 28 August

Dean Jones & Michele Lee in The Love Bug

Charles Chaplin in The Funniest Man in the World

Burra High School. Plans are in hand for a new Burra High School with building due to start in early 1973. The Minister for Education Mr H. Hudson confirmed this on a visit to the Burra Schools on Friday. The new school should be occupied early in 1974. The move will allow the Primary School more room.

93, 33, 24 Aug. 1971, page 5

Burra Burra DC, 2 August

Repairs to slate footpaths in Market Square are to be made.

The Overseer reported that costs to repair the old [Jubilee Avenue] drinking fountain would be over $100. Consideration was deferred.

Aberdeen Tennis Club was given permission to erect pillars as agreed with Burra Town Councillors.

[Erected at the entrance to Burra North Playground with plaques to honour the service of Sid and Flo Scroop to the club. See 94, 11, 28 Mar. 1972, page 1.]

93, 33, 24 Aug. 1971, page 6

Birth. To Noel & Val Webb (nee Griffiths) last Friday at Ashford Community Hospital, a son, Daniel Ralph.

Noel is the son of Mrs Charlie Griffiths of Burra.

Mr & Mrs George Langsford of Burra North celebrated their Golden Wedding on 13 August.

Obituary. Mrs Emily Spratt, mother of Mrs Brian Richards of Hallett, died in Adelaide last Thursday.

[Born Emily Beatrice Bennett 5 May 1895 Alford: died 19 August 1971 Adelaide, residence Warradale.]

Obituary. The father of Colin Brereton of Hanson died in hospital on Friday.

[James Brereton born 26 January 1891 Brendleby: died 19 August 1971 Adelaide, residence Salisbury.]

Burra Mine. The rebuilding of Peacock’s Chimney has started. The square base has been completed and the round stone section has been begun.

Burra High School Ball on Friday was a great success with door takings of $420. Mr & Mrs Claude Allen were guests.

93, 34, 31 Aug. 1971, page 1

Football. Mid North League

‘A’ Grade The 1971 Mail Medal went to Barry Kotz of Robertstown. The count was held at the Oddfellows’ Hall and organised by the Aberdeen FC.

‘B’ Grade The Jenner Trophy went to Bradley Heinrich of Robertstown.

Colts The trophy went to Ron Sandercock, Captain of Auburn.

Junior Colts The trophy winner was Trevor Mullins of Riverton.

[Voting details 93, 35, 7 Sep. 1971, page 3]

Mrs Donald Campbell of Booborowie writes a letter condemning drinking and driving.

Mt Bryan CWA celebrated its 25th birthday on 19 August. Life membership was bestowed on Mrs Heneker.

[Report in 3⁄4 column.]

Weather. The past week has been wet and windy. Burra had 138 points for the week and the total of 308 for August is 74 points above average. Burra Creek was running strongly yesterday and has probably had more water through it this year than for many years.

93, 34, 31 Aug. 1971, pages 1 & 8

Burra Hospital. The annual meeting was held on Thursday night.

Chairman Mr R.K. Pearse said the board was preparing for a major building program including a new maternity wing, private, share, and children’s rooms as well as a kitchen and toilet block on the same level as the present building. The Barker Cottage Home Project will be carried out at the same time. He reported a surplus of $10,424, a credit balance in all accounts of $22,807 and investments of $25,000. The overdraft had been liquidated. The daily patient number averaged 20.3 – the highest for 20 years and 52 babies had been born. This resulted in a better financial position. The Chief Secretary has advised that a subsidy is available for the building project. The cropping program had yielded $191.

The Auxiliary again did fine work on maintaining the linen and supplying jams and preserves. The fund-raising committee donated $1,027 this year. From 27 July the hospital kitchen had supplied food for Meals on Wheels. Matron Fyfe’s excellent service had continued, helped by Sisters Moller, Byles, Brown and Ward and by part-time Sisters Carmody and Jones, assisted by a full compliment of nurses.

93, 34, 31 Aug. 1971, page 2

Advt. Burra Pictures, 4 September

James Caan & Joanna Moore in Count Down

Football. North Eastern League 2nd Semi-Final

‘A’ Grade Clare South 12.13 defeated Burra 11.7

‘B’ Grade Clare South 14.11 defeated Burra 8.6

Colts Clare North 6.6 defeated Burra 5.9

Junior Colts Spalding 6.7 defeated Clare South 3.1

93, 34, 31 Aug. 1971, page 2-7 gutter & 7

Monsignor Hughes Retires

On Tuesday 24 August Monsignor P.V. Hughes said his last Mass at St Joseph’s to bring to an end 22 years as Parish Priest. At age 80he has been called to live with Bishop Bryan Gallagher at Pt Pirie with the title ‘Pastor Emeritus of Burra’. A tea followed at the Town Hall with Eric Clode providing the music. Bishop Gallagher made some remarks and provided details of Monsignor Hughes’ career. Monsignor Clune of Spalding also spoke of a long association with Monsignor Hughes, dating from his ordination in 1926. Roy Jeffery spoke on behalf of the District Council. Jim Quinn as Chairman of the Burra Parish Committee also spoke, expressing the congregation’s gratitude for his service and presented him with a wallet of notes. Mr Laurence Sullivan of Willalo endorsed the sentiments. Monsignor Hughes responded.

93, 34, 31 Aug. 1971, page 3

93, 34, 31 Aug. 1971, pages 6 & 7

St Mary’s Service

The Anglican Bishop of Willochra Rt Rev. S.B. Rosier will attend the St Mary’s service on Sunday, as will former Rector, Arch-Deacon Ross Lenthall. Former organist Clem Davey will play the organ.

The Bishop will dedicate two memorials:

The set of bookshelves in the porch in memory of the late Guy Dollman and his wife Doris Mary Dollman.

An aumbry placed over the chapel altar to house the sacrament for the communion of the sick will honour the late Bishop Donald Llewellyn Redding, Rector of Burra 1933-39.

The Ven. Arch-Deacon Lenthall (Rector 1953-58) will be guest preacher who had a long association with Mr & Mrs Dollman and with Bishop Redding. The aumbry has been designed by Mr N.C. Rohrlach of Whyalla who also designed the Sanctuary lamp some time ago. A parish lunch will follow in the RSL Hall.

93, 34, 31 Aug. 1971, page 8

Burra Primary School & Clare Primary met at Farrell Flat on 26 August for football and netball matches.

Football: Burra 8.6 defeated Clare 4.4

Netball: Clare 24 defeated Burra 10 and in another game Clare 31 defeated Burra 12.

93, 35, 7 Sep. 1971, page 1

St Mary’s Church. Service of Dedication

The dedication of the bookshelves and aumbry [see last issue pages 6 & 7 for further details] was done by the Bishop of Willochra Rt Rev. S.B. Rosier who then celebrated Holy Communion with the assistance of the Rector Fr John Stephenson, the visiting Rector of Christ Church Mt Gambier and the Arch-Deacon of The Murray the Ven. L.R. Lenthall. Fr Lenthall gave the address outlining the service to the church and community of Mr & Mrs Dollman and the career of Bishop Redding. All members of the Dollman family were able to be present: Frances Mrs breeze of Adelaide, Helen Mrs Clark of Adelaide, June Mrs Burdon of Burnie Tasmania, Peg Mrs Stephenson of Redcliffe Brisbane and Guy of Burra.

Clem Davey played a brilliant fanfare and sympathetic accompaniment.

The bookshelves were made by Mr Dudley Jacka, but unfortunately a family bereavement prevented him from attending.

The aumbry was designed by N. Rohrlach of Whyalla who attended with his wife and the steelwork of the aumbry safe was fabricated by Mr R.L. Thamm. Beaten brasswork overlays the safe and this was the work of Adelaide silversmith John Hale. The late delivery of the safe prevented its being lined with silk, but this will be done as soon as possible. The front panel depicts the Lamb of God and on this occasion it is portrayed as a stud Merino ram. The luncheon at the RSL Hall was attended by more than half the congregation. The Bishop and family stayed overnight and intended to have a barbecue at he World’s End Gorge the next day, but rain prevented this.

Weather. The eastern pastoral country reports generally useful falls – many between 60 and 80 points.

Willalo Rural School will be closed at the end of 1971 as one of 23 small rural schools to close this year. A school bus run will replace it.

93, 35, 7 Sep. 1971, pages 1 & 8

93, 36, 14 Sep. 1971, page 1

Burra Mine Buildings Preservation Fund has reached $7,791.11.

Burra Mine. The rebuilding of Peacock’s Chimney has been temporarily halted by bad weather and will resume in about six weeks. The Urban District Council of Cambourne, Redruth, Cornwall has sent $20 to aid the cause.

Burra District Emblem Competition

The entry of Malcolm John Pym of Tea Tree Gully was chosen. The design is an oval shape with a ram’s head at the top left, a chimney and pithead across the centre and a sheaf of hay at the bottom right, with the Council name underneath.

[Shown thus inDiscovering Historic Burra by Greg Drew.]

93, 37, 21 Sep. 1971, page 1

Burra District Ambulance Association

All forms were signed on 15 September for the incorporation of the St John Ambulance Service, Burra & District. There will be higher call-out fees for non-members with a minimum $10 plus 25c per ambulance mile.

[Benefits for members are then listed.]

Adelaide Wool Sales. [Local district prices are printed.]

The Morgan Dockyard will be closed and facilities progressively moved to Murray Bridge. Appropriate housing will be provided at Murray Bridge for employees choosing to move there and those not so choosing would be employed at the Morgan Depot of the Highways Department.

The Thomas Pickett Memorial will be dedicated at 11 a.m. 29 September. Mr Ian Auhl will give an occasional address. Mr Stanley Woollacott with make the dedication.

Advt. A 20-unit motel complex is planned for Burra with construction to begin as soon as sufficient funds are available. Shares are offered in multiples of $500 exclusively to residents of Burra and District and a meeting is to be held at the Burra Town Hall 23 September for details of the proposal to be outlined.

E. Clode, Burra 341

G. O’Connor, Burra 402.

93, 37, 21 Sep. 1971, page 8

Aberdeen Tennis Club AGM elected: Patron, Mrs A. Lloyd; President, Mr D. O’Reilly; Vice-Presidents, Mr R. Reed & Mr M. Tiver and Secretary, Mrs D. Lloyd.

In the past season the club fielded two ‘A’ teams 2 ‘B’ teams and 1 junior team. All grades were represented in the Grand Finals, with Juniors and ‘B’ Grade Red being successful. The year was financially successful. After 30 years as joint Secretary-Treasurers Mr & Mrs S. Scroop resigned from this important position. Don & Marg Lloyd took over this role.

Aberdeen Colts Presentation Night

About 40 young men made short work of the tea. Trophies were presented:

Junior Colts

Fairest & most brilliant Rodney Elliott

Best forward Brenton Ford

Most consistent Mark Liharski

Best backman Richard Thamm

Most improved Terry James

Colts

Fairest & most brilliant Stephen Lane

Most consistent Stephen Lane

Best placed Peter Seaford

Best forward Robin James

Best backman Andrew Thamm

Most improved Robert Gill

[In the paper of 28 September it says the most improved junior was Robert McBride and this was said to have been accidentally omitted, but this doesn’t seem to fit with the above.]

93, 38, 28 Sep. 1971, page 1

Burra Motel Plans

The meeting at the Burra Town Hall on Thursday indicated sufficient support for further investigations. Expected cost for 20 units and dining room facilities is c. $120,000 and this is to be raised by the formation of a private company. The number of shareholders for a private company is limited to 50. At a meeting in the RSL Hall next Tuesday other methods of arranging finance will be investigated to allow the participation of those with less capital to invest. Five possible sites are being considered. Mr Allen MP is urging the sealing of the Morgan-Burra Road and this would certainly help this project.

Burra Police Station. The new Chapel Street Station will be open from 1 October. Sgt Haynes and family will reside at the rear of the station.

93, 38, 28 Sep. 1971, pages 1 & 8

Morgan Dockyard

[There is a lengthy article considering the effect of the closure of this dockyard on the township of Morgan. It had 21 employees, of whom 12 had their own homes in Morgan. The fortnightly paycheque was $2,300. This blow to the town followed the closing of the railway.]

93, 38, 28 Sep. 1971, page 2

93, 38, 28 Sep. 1971, page 5

Burra Burra DC, 30 August

S.J. Woollacott was thanked for his efforts to preserve Redruth Gaol.

The Premier’s Department advises a subsidy on a one for one basis to a maximum of $5,000 is available for the proposed caravan park and amenities block – to be completed by 21 December 1971 and claimed for by 28 February 1972.

Mr F. Fennell is to be allowed to rent the ambulance shed until the Council requires it.

Burra Footballers Cricket Club held its AGM and elected: Joint Patrons, L.A. Beinke & S. Rasheed; President, S. Allen; Senior Vice-President, Rex Opperman; Secretary-Treasurer, J. Aylice and Assistant Secretary, A. Day.

Railway Accident. The ‘Bluebird’ Railcar was derailed at Tarlee last Thursday. (One carriage stayed on the line.)

British & Foreign Bible Society will hold a street stall next Saturday. (Run by the Burra Methodist Youth Fellowship.)

Obituary. Mrs Fleming, the mother of Mrs Doug Burton of Mt Bryan, died at Burra Hospital on Saturday.

[Born Bessie Eileen Jolly 2 July 1911 Gladstone: died 25 September 1971 Burra, residence Gladstone.]

93, 39, 5 Oct. 1971, page 1

Stolen Truck Recovered. A Bedford truck stolen from L.W. Gare & Sons’ property last week was recovered by police at Brighton on Thursday. A few weeks ago a utility stolen from Gare’s Dilowie property was recovered at Pt Adelaide.

93, 39, 5 Oct. 1971, pages 1 & 5

Thomas Pickett Memorial. On Wednesday the plaque fixed to a counterweight from the old mine workings was dedicated by S.J. Woollacott to the shepherd, Thomas Pickett, who discovered the Burra Mine. Burra School children were among those who witnessed the event near Diprose Creek opposite the remains of Pickett’s hut. The President of the Burra Burra Branch of the National Trust introduced Mr Ian Auhl who recounted the story of Thomas Pickett. Mr S.J. Woollacott made the dedication and Mr Warren Bonython moved the vote of thanks to the Burra Burra Branch. [Auhl’s speech is printed.]

Pickett came to the area in 1842 to live in his shepherd’s hut alongside the springs in Diprose creek. There had been no memorial in Burra to the Cornish Miners, or to the Welsh or German Smelters until a recent memorial in Market Square. Burra was for twenty years SA’s second largest town with a peal population of 5,000 and was for 12 years SA’s only industrial town, with its smelting works. The present Government seems to favour Wallaroo, Kadina and Moonta as SA’s historic towns, but Burra contains the greatest collection of original buildings still in existence of any town in Sa and has Australia’s oldest mining buildings. Captain Hancock came to Burra to get his first Moonta miners and the first Headmaster of Moonta Mines School was an old Burra boy Dr William Toor [sic: for Torr]. The scene her is little changed from 1842 when Pickett lived here. Only a few stones of his hut now remain.

Colonel Frome, SA’s Surveyor General would have seen it when he passed in 1842. Once a month Pickett would yoke up his bullocks and go to Gum Creek Station 14 miles away to report to the Station manager William Robinson, get his stores, tobacco and rum and return to his hut. He was paid 12/- a week, most of which went to pay for his rations. The nearest village was then Gawler 75 miles away, with just nine houses. Pickett’s hut was then the furthest dwelling north. Another shepherd, William Streair lived eight miles south, where Princes Royal Homestead now stands and where some Indian coolies also worked for the leaseholder Mr James Stein. Both shepherds learnt to recognise copper ore after the Kapunda Mine opened in 1843 and in 1845 both found it, but all they ever made of the discovery was £20 each.

[Auhl had documented Pickett’s story in a booklet published by the Burra National Trust and which was given to most of those present.]

Pickett’s story is one of almost unbelievable meanness on the part of the proprietors of the SA Mining Association. The Burra Mine began on 29 September 1845 and closed on 29 September 1877. Pickett showed his discovery to a group who had ridden north to see Streair’s find. He was paid £10 for revealing the site. A month later the 20,000 acres had been paid for and surveyed. At the mine’s opening ten miners were present:

Robert Mitchell Grant

Gillard R. Jones Jnr

Jenkins R. Jones Sen

William Roberts I. Crillas (a blacksmith to sharpen picks)

Jonathon Roberts Carter

Thomas Roberts was in charge and was appointed Captain at 35/- a week.

The first load was a two-ton lump of red oxide that assayed at 711⁄4% copper.

Pickett lives a further six years and died 18 November 1851 of accidental burns in a hut near the present crossing of the Baldina creek. He was given a pauper’s burial in the old Burra Cemetery. On an appeal from Mr Ware, the owner of the present Burra Hotel (then called the Miners’ Arms) the SA Mining Association forwarded 5 guineas to cover the funeral expenses. Today at long last the discoverer of the Burra Mine is being honoured.

[Mr Auhl then referred to several letters he had received from descendents of the first miners.]

Mr Stanley Woollacott then dedicated the plaque to Thomas Pickett and Mr Warren Bonython then moved a vote of thanks to the Burra Burra Branch of the National Trust in his capacity as President of the National Trust of SA.

93, 39, 5 Oct. 1971, page 2

Changes to the times for clearances of letters reveals the location of letter receivers at this time.

Burra North boxes previously cleared at 4.30 p.m. Monday, Tuesday, Wednesday and Friday will have this clearance deleted and in future be cleared 2.15 p.m. and at 4.30 p.m. Thursday.

Ludgvan St

In Burra clearances will be at 2.30 p.m. and at 4.45 p.m. on Thursday.

93, 40, 12 Oct. 1971, pages 1, 6 & 7

Burra Show was held last Saturday in cold, windy conditions and achieved a total of 3,325 entries and a gate of $655. It was opened by His Excellency the Japanese Ambassador Shizuo Saito, whose speech is printed.

The shearing competition was popular and the open class went to S .Pittaway and the novice class to Keith Weich.

Creditable displays were arranged by the Schools, Rural Youth and Samin Ltd.

Industrial stands attracted quite an interest.

The motor cycle trials were popular and the winner was R. Wakefield.

The usual dance in the evening was arranged by the Rural Youth in the RSL Hall where $227 was taken at the door.

Art entries were impressive.

The standard of goat entries was exceptionally high.

Pigeons had a very good section.

The judge was disappointed with most of the large fowls and though the bantams were good birds their presentation suffered because it was somewhat ragged after a long show season.

Grain and fodder entries were good and wheaten and oaten chaff exhibits were excellent.

Best in show for dogs was Mr Cuthbert’s Bull Terrier.

There were 75 entries in the wool fleece section, which was very pleasing.

Though sheep numbers were not high, the quality was very good.

Cookery produced many very good entries, especially in fruit cakes and it was pleasing to see many juveniles entering.

Vegetables were reasonable to good this year, with increased numbers.

Needlework was pleasing.

The judge said the display of flowers was excellent.

Horses in action numbers were slightly down.

Richard Harris & Vanessa Redgrave in Camelot

Plus Blue Danube

The Kooringa Masonic Lodge installed Bro. Jeff. White as Worshipful Master on Wednesday followed by a ball in the Burra Town Hall attended by over 400. With over 30 visiting Worshipful Masters, this was perhaps the most successful function in the history of the lodge.

93, 42, 26 Oct. 1971, page 1

Burra Motel. A meeting on Thursday decided that plans should be drawn up and a prospectus prepared. On Thursday it was decided to use a site near the resited Peacock’s Chimney. At least eight possible sites were inspected and discarded. Messrs Peat Marwick, Mitchell & Co. are drawing up the necessary documents. The plan is for 16 or 20 units plus dining facilities.

St Mary’s dinner dance in the Town Hall on Friday was a social and financial success and the Parish Committee hopes to clear nearly $300.

Burra EFS held its AGM on Wednesday. 23 people attended. Only two call outs were attended in the past year. Elected: President, Bruce Stockman and Secretary, Ron Shipard. It was proposed the EFS co-operate with the SAR in burning grass along the railway line which makes a great firebreak through the district.

Obituary. Mrs Esther Ann Pearce died suddenly at her residence in Spalding on 30 September aged 85. She was a daughter of the late Mr & Mrs Joseph Elliott and was born at Wilmington 26 December 1885. She married Frederick George Pearce in 1916 and came to live at Spalding until her death. She was a regular attender of the Methodist Guild, Red Cross, CWA, RSL Auxiliary and Senior Citizens and ‘actively associated with the Presbyteri it was disbanded in 1968’ [sic: text corrupt]. She is survived by a daughter Leila Mrs M. Dunn of Kangaroo Island and son Mervyn of Spalding. Another son, Fred, was killed on active service in WW II. Her husband died many years ago.

93, 42, 26 Oct. 1971, page 3

Burra Primary School Grade VI children climbed Razorback near Mt Bryan on Saturday 16 October. Mrs Carpenter and the children hiked seven miles while Mr & Mrs Cain took the bus to the barbecue. After lunch the boys played football and the girls played softball before climbing the hill, led by Mr Cain. Some children made sketches and others made jam dampers in the coals.

Aberdeen Tennis Club offers its toilets as public toilets with Council to maintain. Council accepted the offer and the old toilets will be removed.

93, 43, 2 Nov. 1971, page 1

Apex Club

The inaugural meeting at the Burra Hotel on Tuesday last saw 64 Apexians attend. The Chairman of the Burra Burra DC Mr Roy Jeffery attended and Mr Bob England the Zone 8 President from Adelaide. The Burra Club at present has 20 members and will receive its charter in about six months, after its contribution to the community and membership is reviewed. Apex has some 16,000 men in 630 clubs internationally and is for young men 18 to 40. It was founded in Geelong in 1931 and has spread throughout Australia and SE Asia. One project in Burra could be the restoration of the old drinking fountain near the caravan park. Officers for 1971-72: President, Terry Rule; Secretary, Don Topsfield; Service Director, Don Kempster; Treasurer, Murray Mitchell; Programs & Notices, Tony Fillmore; Fund Raising, Allan Day; Social Director, Bob Richter; Membership Director, Russell Campbell; Public Speaking & Debating, Alan Langham & Public Relations, Gordon Wooton. A meeting on 28 October decided to repair and improve the playground facilities in Burra and to restore the drinking fountain.

Christmas Plans. Burra traders have decided the children’s merry-go-round will again be engaged for the day and Father Christmas will arrive at 8.30 p.m. The ‘give away’ plan for shoppers, used last year, will operate again.

Fire Danger this season out east is high due to heavy growth of vegetation and reduced man power. The Eastern Districts Fire Fighting Organisation met at Koomooloo with guest speakers Andrew Brown of the Department of Agriculture and Mr Brian Menadue of the EFS. Elected were: Chairman-Supervisor, R.R. Clarke and Secretary, A.L. Wright.

93, 44, 9 Nov. 1971, page 1

Burra Mine

Sales of copper oxide are satisfactory on both local and the overseas markets. One hundred and forty-three thousand pounds have been produced since 30 June. Stage 1 of construction at the Mine has been completed. Design and stage two of the operation has proceeded. Pilot plant tests have been partially completed to enable the selection of a final design for the roasting plant. Stage 2 will see production of ore rise to 1,000 tons per day. Recently installed drying equipment is operating satisfactorily. Samin Ltd and Roche Bros have agreed to supply the Burra Burra DC with metal for road making. The existing Council quarry has almost been cleaned out. The new supplies will come from the northern open cut section, which will not be mined in Stage 1 of operations.

The late Lily Owen Smyth has been remembered with a fine plaque at the Hallett Institute. It was unveiled during the Red Cross Flower Show by Chairman of the District Council Mr Eric Ashby. She worked on many organisations and committees and especially for Red Cross.

Weather. Rainfall for the weekend at Burra was 78 points and was accompanied by some hail. All tennis matches for the Burra Association were cancelled and pennant bowls matches were also cancelled for Burra teams. Cricket games began, but had to be abandoned when Spalding was 1 for 23 v. Burra Footballers.

93, 44, 9 Nov. 1971, page 2

John Baker the Burra Bushranger by Ian Auhl: Part 1.

Baker was arrested on Monday 16 October 1871 outside the Burra Court House. There was a price on his head. He was arrested by Lance Cpl Smith and Constable Noble. The charge was horse stealing and robbery under arms, which carried a sentence of death by hanging. He had eluded police for two years in the Barrier Ranges, so why had he come to Burra? There was always a touch of bravado about him. He had stood trial at the Supreme Court in Adelaide in August 1866 aged 21 on a charge of horse stealing. The judge took the view that his reasons for taking the horse were at least plausible and the police could be driving him into a life of crime. He was acquitted and released. He immediately stole a horse from the Napoleon Hotel and headed to Glenelg. The police caught up with him five weeks later in NSW and this time the judge sided with the police. In his teenage years he had worked at the Cross Roads Inn [near Burra] grooming and caring for travellers and coaches. Then he was employed by the Burra firm of McDonald & Hosking breaking in horses for their northern mail runs. He was described as a ‘smallish man, very active and a daring rider’. He liked horses and objected vehemently when a trooper ill-treated his horse.

After leaving Burra he spent a few years around Gawler and Adelaide, apparently making a living collecting stray horses and returning them to their owners. It was when he began ‘collecting’ them from their owners’ paddocks and from public pounds that he struck trouble. Such behaviour saw him facing court aged 21. His sentence some five weeks later following his capture in NSW was one year’s hard labour at the Dry Creek Stockade (Yatala Prison). It was there that he met another horse thief ‘Billy’ Bertram and probably formed the partnership which ended in Bertram’s hanging at Bathurst Gaol in 1871 and Baker’s own arrest at Burra later in that year.

Bertram was a German with a lisp and one eye and was an ex-Tungkillo butcher who had talent and notoriety as a cattle thief and it was his carelessness in leaving a cow’s tail in his yard that led to a conviction for stealing free meat and a sentence in the stockade at the same time as Baker.

After their release Baker and Bertram continued their life of petty crime in the hills around Gumeracha and out to the River Murray. When SA got too hot for them they headed north up the Darling to the Barrier Ranges. In the 1860s this became the haunt of cattle duffers, bushrangers and other undesirables. The notorious Morgan and Captain Thunderbolt paid a few visits to this frontier area. Baker and Bertram operated unhindered for a while with water and hiding places readily available. In October 1869 Baker was charged at Wilcannia with three assaults: one on a boarding-house keeper and two on the NSW constables who arrested him. He was fined $14. Mr Bellamy, an admirer of pluck, raised the fine money from Baker’s admirers. The next morning four horses, the property of Mt Murchison Station, were missing. The outlaws always had plenty of sympathisers, which explains some of the cockiness and cool daring common to bushrangers in general. A few days later Baker and Bertram held up the manager of Mt Arrowsmith Station, Mr George Urquhart and took horses and stores. Station hands and shearers looked on. The partners began to hold a contempt for law and the police that would lead to their downfall.

By November 1869 they were labelled ‘The Darling Bushrangers’. On 9 November they bailed up a hawker Charles Young and when he asked who they were Bertram boasted that he was Billy Bertram who had robbed O’Brien and taken four horses from Murchison Station. After threatening to blow out his brains, they robbed Young of $100 and rifled his van for guns and stores. This made them guilty of robbery under arms, leading to their being declared outlaws, each with a price of $100 on his head. After robbing Young they separated.

Bertram was finally captured late in 1870 near Cobham Lake where he was living in an Aboriginal camp. By this time he was wanted for murder, having killed the same Charles Young he had previously threatened. He was tried at Wilcannia and hanged at Bathurst Gaol early in 1871.

Baker eluded police for nearly two years and was undone by his arrogance. L-Cpl Smith heard news that Baker was en route from the Barrier Ranges with a small band of stolen horses. He had known Baker a few years earlier at Burra. Baker, travelling without disguise, arrived after dark on Sunday evening. On Monday he went to the barber’s shop in Kooringa [In 1971 Bert Beinke’s Paper and Book Shop] and asked for a hair cut and to have his hair dyed red. The barber refused to dye it and Baker abused the barber for taking so long about cutting it. Baker then walked to Redruth with two other men and sat down outside the court to cut up tobacco for his pipe. The court was a cheap source of entertainment for idlers, sight-seers and moral busy-bodies in Victorian times and so the place was crowded. When Smith and Noble approached him and declared he was arrested, Baker attempted to escape, but was chased and brought back.

He was placed in one of the cells behind the police station after a violent struggle. They found a revolver in his swag, but no arms on his person. The next day he was taken to Redruth Gaol and within a few days was planning his escape. [To be continued.]

Kooringa Methodist Ladies’ Guild Fete was held in the RSL Hall on Friday. $194.11 was raised. [Stall holders are listed.]

93, 45, 16 Nov. 1971, page 1

Publicly Examined Leaving & Matriculation

The Hon. M.B. Cameron asked a question in Parliament about what could be done to change the situation where employers were not recognising internally assessed courses to the detriment of many students. The Hon. T.M. Casey in reply acknowledged the difficulty and suggested there would soon be a committee established to investigate alternatives to the PEB Leaving and Matriculation examinations. The alternative would put every student more or less on an equal footing, removing the distinction between internal and externally examined certificates.

93, 45, 16 Nov. 1971, pages 1 & 2

Burra Primary School held a walk-a-thon on Sunday and raised $550. The route was three laps from the Memorial Oval to Burra Post Office, Burra North and back to the Oval via Smelts Road plus 10 laps of the oval to total 10 miles. 168 starters took part and over 90 completed the course. Sharon Lane topped the money collection with $32.50. Other notable achievements were Philip Turner, Andrew Spackman & Ray Irlam who completed the course in 1 hour 55 minutes. Grade 1 couple Jane Hurst and Wesley Bratten completed the course. Headmaster Sid Allen pushed a wheelbarrow over the course to collect $25.

[There is a list of those who completed the course and another of others taking part.]

93, 45, 16 Nov. 1971, page 2

Basketball

Women’s Torreston 50 defeated Burra 16

Men’s Torreston 28 defeated Burra Blue 27

Burra Green 41 defeated Burra White 39

Burra & Tourism

Mr J. O’Sullivan of Australia National Travel Association inspected tourist attractions and Samin Ltd operations at Burra last week. He met Council representatives and various groups forming the Burra & District Tourist Promotion Committee. He said Burra was ideally situated to exploit its great historical heritage and well situated on a sealed route to Broken Hill and the Flinders Ranges. It would greatly benefit from the sealing of the Burra-Morgan Road and the Burra-Spalding Road to form the east-west link across the country. The potential for tourist development was virtually untouched.

Spalding 136 drew with Burra Footballers 9 for 87 when rain stopped play.

Advt. Burra Pictures, 26 November

Peter O’Toole, Sir Michael Redgrave & Petula Clark in Goodbye Mr Chips

93, 45, 16 Nov. 1971, page 8

The Bushranger Baker (Continued) By Ian Auhl.

A report from the SA Register newspaper of 30 October 1871.

The desperado was held in Redruth Gaol. A man named Dolson also in prison on a charge of horse stealing managed to feign illness and was placed nearer to Baker, doubtless in order to speak to him.

Gaoler Perry overheard the pair planning to escape by forcing a hole in a lath and plaster ceiling with a wooden ford and thence to remove a sheet of roofing iron to effect an escape. Perry heard them wrench a form from its mortice and replace it, preparatory to the escape. Next day he placed the men in irons. On Monday a search found that Dolson had concealed a hammer in his boot. Baker asserted his intention to escape on his overland journey to NSW, where he faced charges of stealing four horses from Mt Murchison, robbery under arms at Cobham’s Station and theft of a revolver, gun and 4 or 5 horses. A man named Edwards and Mr Curtis of the Pig & Whistle Inn at Kooringa was there at the time. Bertram, who had since been hanged, was with him and was foremost in the action while Baker kept guard. The horses on which he came down were stolen from O’Leary in the North East, the owner residing at Pallammicca. On his way down from the Barrier Ranges the bushranger had 2 revolvers conspicuously in his belt and £3 given him by a hawker and it is said others also handed him money. On his way to Burra he proposed to a person well known in Kooringa to join him and they would soon make £200 or £300 each.

(Paper report ends.)

Baker was taken from Redruth Gaol in November and escorted to Adelaide. The judge in Adelaide heard the charge and ordered him taken to Wilcannia for trial, in the custody of Constable Murphy. He was placed in irons and travelled to Kapunda by rail and thence to Wentworth on the Murray for delivery to the NSW police. Murphy had little sleep on the four day journey and handed the bushranger over to Constable Makin of Booligal for transfer to Wilcannia. On 18 December he was tried at Wilcannia in a crowded court.

Baker remained alert and defiant and put on the appearance of impudent bravado. He cross-examined each witness and complained to the judge about brutal treatment from his police escort. He was found guilty and remanded to Bourke for sentence. Constable Murphy was again in charge of the transfer by coach for 200 miles.

It is reported that at Dasham and McGovern’s Tankarooka Station 75 miles up the Darling River he attempted to escape, although chained. He broke the handcuffs, struck Murphy twice on the Temple and kicked him in the stomach. Murphy got him by the throat and held him down and was assisted by Captain Parker of the steamer Kennedy. Baker’s hands were then strapped behind his back. He was placed in the mail conveyance and after some time, at the prisoner’s entreaty, his hands were released. They reached Bourke on Sunday between 3 and 4 p.m. Constable Murphy deserves great praise for his pluck and skill in handling such a ruffian.

Baker served three years hard labour at Bourke. The robbery under arms charge had been dropped, as it was the late William Bertram who had pointed the revolver each time. As far as can be discovered his bushranging days finished at Bourke.

93, 46, 23 Nov. 1971, page 1

Women’s Fellowship Concert in Redruth Hall on Friday evening saw the hall packed. Concerts these days are a relatively rare event and it was pleasing to see the full hall. Door takings were $112. Program:

Compere: Mr Lynden Beare

Piano Duet Mrs Dudley Cockington & Miss Carolyn Nicholls

Three Songs Primary School Music Club directed by Mrs J. Carpenter

A Little Opera ‘Mother Goes Out’ Fellowship Members

Two Brackets of Folk Songs Debbie Kirk

Hornpipe Rev. Milton Edwards on his invention the ‘Oopsharmonia’

Novelty Fashion Parade

Two Popular Songs Mr Ron Blackwell, accompanied by Mrs Blackwell

Skit ‘Some Get All the Breaks’

Club Swinging Dianne Day accompanied by Mrs Cockington on piano

Bracket of Songs Debbie Kirk

Men’s Ballet ‘The Dew Drop Fairies’* Extract from the Nutcracker Suite featuring Ian Allen as the Fairy Queen

[* The ‘girls’ are names on page 3: Barry Eberhard, Sid Allan, Morris Allen, Brian Thamm, Dudley Cockington, Alan Baulderstone and Ian Allen.]

Burra Apex Auction Sale raised between $150 and $180, which will allow the club to begin carrying out its projects.

The Rural Youth Cabaret took c. $410 with the profit going to the Burra Hospital.

Booborowie Methodist Ladies’ Guild ‘Space Age’ Fete raised $520 on Saturday afternoon.

West Beach Primary School students from three Grade VI & VII classes visited Burra last week. They visited the usual places in Burra, drew sketches and surveyed the local shopping centre. The visit was run in co-operation with the Burra Primary School and its Headmaster Mr Allan.

Burra Golf Club held its AGM on 11 November and elected: President, R.E. Mason, Vice-Presidents, Don Kempster & I. Allen; Captain, R. Hillman; Vice-Captain, N. Hurst, Secretary, H.C. Burnett and Treasurer, S. Allan.

At the start of a successful year the scrapes were re-slagged and oiled and new cups were installed. The open day was a success.

93, 46, 23 Nov. 1971, page 8

Burra Burra DC, 1 November

It was decided that the whole of the Burra Recreation Ground and part section 9 be dedicated as a recreation reserve.

93, 47, 30 Nov. 1971, page 1

Burra & District Tourist Promotion Committee has been advised that if suitable arrangements can be made in Burra a major bus line is prepared to operate coach tours to the district. The Committee has called for property owners ready to cater for morning and afternoon tea and/or lunch (barbecue style). A number of people are needed to allow for varied itineraries. One plan being considered is for a three day tour:

Day 1 Adelaide to Burra, morning tea, National Trust Museum, luncheon, town tour, hotel overnight.

Day 2 Visit a Merino Stud, perhaps see shearing, morning tea, a trip to the north eastern scenic hills, barbecue lunch, Mongolata, Burra.

Day 3 Free time in Burra in the morning and return to Adelaide by a different route.

Burra Caravan Park. The new area is progressing and should be ready by 21 December. The amenities block has been erected by D.T. Jacka & Co.

Water Pressure at the schools has been increased, easing concerns about fire fighting there.

Burra Schools are collecting blankets for Austcare’s appeal for refugees from East Pakistan in India.

Weather. Rainfall in Burra has been the highest for a November in ten years, with 216 points to 9 a.m. yesterday. In 1961 259 points were recorded and the highest ever was 449 in 1917. The lowest was 2points in 1905.

The Eudunda-Morgan Railway. The line has been sold to Midalia & Benn Pty Ltd of Subiaco WA. The rails will be lifted and exported.

Ros. Edwards & Elizabeth Beare will be farewelled at a morning tea at the Women’s Fellowship next Tuesday at the Redruth Hall.

Trevor Phelps, son of Mr & Mrs Len Phelps of Hallett is home from service in Vietnam and is discharged from the army. He was a National Serviceman.

Burra Mine. Work has begun again on Peacock’s Chimney.

93, 48, 7 Dec. 1971, page 1

Christmas in Burra. Late night shopping will operate on Friday 24 December. Father Christmas will arrive at 8.30 p.m. A merry-go-round or boat ride will operate in the day and evening. A dance will be held in the RSL Hall in the evening.

Mr W. Miller of Hallett RSL has been awarded a Life Membership of the RSL.

Methodist Circuits

In the New Year the Hallett-Terowie Circuit will be dissolved. Terowie will move to the Peterborough-Yongala Circuit. Whyte Yarcowie & Hallett will go to the Jamestown United Parish and Willalo & Mt Bryan will join the Burra Circuit.

Rev. Kyle Waters President of the Methodist Conference will give the address at Burra High School’s Valedictory Service on 12 December at Burra Methodist Church. After the service a farewell will be given to the Headmaster Mr Lynden Beare who is going to Willunga.

The Burra Methodist Circuit Choir will sing the Christmas Cantata Night of Miracles in the Burra Methodist Church at 11 a.m. Sunday 19 December. The Choir will be led by Mr Fred Atkin.

Rev. Edwards and family will be farewelled at a luncheon in the Church Hall after the service. He will take up his new appointment at Elizabeth Downs on 23 January. The incoming minister Rev. C.F. Hore will be inducted at a service at 7.30 p.m. on Friday 21 January.

RSL Annual Reunion Dinner

About 55 attended the dinner on Saturday night. Representatives came from Riverton, Farrell Flat, Jamestown, Spalding, Booborowie, Hallett and Adelaide. Rev. John Stephenson proposed ‘Fallen Comrades’ and R.J. Steele proposed ‘The League’. Ben Kotz as President read the apologies and other toasts were proposed by Keith Hanlin & Arthur Wright.

Bob Crewes Sen. came back to Burra for the RSL Dinner on Saturday.

Burra Pictures. The costs of running the show are about $40 per night. At times ticket sales struggle to reach a third of this. Few adults attend because of the behaviour of ill mannered children.

‘I wonder if it’s really worth continuing weekly shows here at all after the current series of films runs out next year? It’s debateable.’

93, 49, 14 Dec. 1971, page 1

Barkers of Baldina Cottage Homes

Approval has been given for the drawing up of specifications for the erection of nine cottage homes on the site west of the Burra Hospital. The architects will now draw up plans and specifications for submission to Federal and State authorities for subsidy approval. The late J.R. Barker bequeathed $70,000 for the project and nominated a board comprising: R.K. Pearse, R.B. Jennison, Mrs L.M. Fyfe, Mrs M. Odgers, E.J. Ashby, J. Dewhirst, D.M. Bednall, J. Gordon, M. Carmody, R. Reed and L.H. Packer as Administrator.

The nine cottages will be self contained and run east-west parallel to the main road. Each will be air conditioned with a bedroom, kitchen-lounge, laundry, toilet and front verandah, carport and garden space. They can be used as double or single units. In the event of more applicants than there are vacancies preference will be given to residents or persons with an association with the area within the District Councils of Burra, Hallett and Robertstown. Rental is estimated to be $12 for a double unit and $8 for a single, payable fortnightly in advance. Occupants are to pay for telephones, electricity and power. The board will pay rates and taxes and maintenance. Standard built-in furniture will be supplied and a washing machine, electric range, refrigerator, air conditioner, wall heater, curtains, floor coverings, beds, mattresses, pillows and bed spreads. Any gift or donation on occupancy would be appreciated, but is not a requirement, nor will it affect priority of acceptance. It is expected that tenders for erection work will be called soon.

The Anglican Bishop of Willochra Rt Rev. S.B. Rosier will officiate at Burra 19 December. He will conduct four services.

Adelaide Wool Sales 7-9 December. [Local district prices are printed.]

Burra Burra Hospital Board conferred Life Membership on Mr Glen Finch at its November meeting to mark his ten years of service. He is the third Life Member. The other two being Mrs Andrew Tennant and Mrs Don Laidlaw.

Willalo School held a reunion to mark its closure after 60 years. 250 attended at the school on 45 December. Chairman Mr Eric Ashby gave a résumé of the 60 years history of the school.

The school commenced in the newly built hall with Miss Herd as the first teacher. She was followed shortly by Miss N. Daly, a lady of stout heart, stout cane and much discipline.

Several of the first pupils were present:

Ivy Affolter Edith Jefferies

Janet Dawson May Thomas

Thelma Bernhardt Arnold Hanlin

John Sullivan Joe Mannion

Former teachers attending:

Miss Betty Nobel Ken McPherson

Miss Gert Madigan G. Shaughnessy

Miss Vera Murray G. Aesche

Miss Masey Sullivan B. Brooks

B. Smith

Rick Adams (the present teacher)

In 60 years the school had an average attendance of 14. In 1947 after many years of petitioning a new school was provided after strong support from Mr P.H. Quirke, a former MP. This little school was well equipped and it is with regret that it is being closed and in the New Year a bus will provide a round-about 17 mile long daily trip to Booborowie School. Tom Ashby and Keith Hanlin reminisced before an adjournment to the hall for luncheon.

[A number of those attending are listed.]

Burra’s Festival of Carols will be held beside the Swimming Pool on 19 December (Sunday next) at 8.30 p.m.

A Blessing of the Fleece service was held at Teetulpa Station on 14 November. It was conducted by Peterborough Ministers Fraternal aided by Salvation Army Bandsmen, some from Adelaide. Former Burra man Harold Kakoschke did the actual shearing. Over 80 people attended.

Mr Roy Jeffery Chairman of the Burra Burra DC delivered a Christmas message at the Carols Festival on Sunday evening.

Burra High School held a Swimathon on 10 December and raised $315. Fifty swimmers took part.

Burra Caravan Park on the east bank of the Burra Creek has been completed and is open for business with accommodation for 24 vans.

Burra Festival of Carols at the Swimming Pool on Sunday drew a smaller crowd this year, but was still a successful and pleasant event. Rev. Milton Edwards was compere and Mrs Jack Oates played the organ. A collection of $45 will aid the Save the Children Fund.

Break-in. An intruder got into Bence’s Ltd through the skylight and proceeded to a manhole, but there was no sign they descended to the shop or stole anything.

93, 50, 21 Dec. 1971, pages 1, 4, 5 & 4-5 gutter

Burra High School Speech Night

[The 1971 prize list is printed.]

Dux of the school was Andrew Webster (Leaving Class). [Personal interest: First in Class 1A was Brenda Harris.]

The Headmaster presented his third and the school’s 59th annual report.

He welcomed Professor Flentje who was the guest speaker.

The Report

At the start of the year there were 174 pupils, one less than at the start of 1970. During the year about 20 pupils left, mainly due to transfer of parents from the town. One extra staff member was appointed this year, which enabled some combined subjects to be split. There are now 12 full-time staff.

[Staff duties and changes through the year were then detailed.]

The election due for the High School Council this year was deferred pending a decision on the form and function of the Council following the Karmel Report Recommendations.

Councillors and the ladies in the Parents & Friends’ Association have given the school great support and are thanked for it. Parents & Friends’ Assoc. will conduct a sale of second-hand school uniforms during the Learn-to-Swim Campaign in January. The four pie, pasty and soup days raised considerable money and a record amount was taken at the school ball. I would enter a plea for more mothers to attend the regular meetings and to spread the work load.

Purchases this year were fewer due to some uncertainties about subsidies, which have only just been resolved. Nevertheless the year saw over $200 spent on library books, two Maths Laboratory Kits, a kit to aid spelling and nine sets of headphones for a listening post. The Parents & Friends’ Association’s healthy bank balance will be needed when the school moves to its new position and some items will no longer be shared with the Primary School.

The plans for the new school have been sighted and were forwarded to the Public Works Standing Committee in September. The new school envisages open unit class areas, an activity room, facilities for typing, home science, needlework, woodwork, metalwork, and art as well as a library and assembly hall and change room facilities for physical education. Meanwhile an annex to the Science Laboratory and installation of ceiling fans in wooden buildings has improved the existing school.

Excursions this year included Adelaide, Flinders Ranges, World’s End creek, River Murray irrigation and packing systems and Wirrabara Forest, as well as several local visits, including to the Mine. The usual sporting activities were held through the year, including a Swimming Carnival and a Sports Day. The Interschool Athletics were successfully held on the second attempt after being washed out on the first. Burra came second in the Handicap Shield for the third year in succession. There was also a lightning carnival for winter sports.

I pay tribute to all those teachers and parents who put in so much extra time to make the school’s sporting activities successful and thank the Burra Burra DC for use of the town oval and the Aberdeen Tennis Club and the Convent for the use of their courts and the Burra Primary School for use of their facilities.

The Leaving PEB results last year were good and the 88% Grade IV or better subject results compere with 75% state-wide. Two third year students have recently been awarded Commonwealth Scholarships: Monica Hillman and Michael Carmody. Two Leaving students won Commonwealth Technical Scholarships: Ann Hillman & Russell Disher. Next year French will flow to third year after a successful start in the first two years. A scheme to enable ‘2’ track students to do a limited Leaving in Burra from 1973 will be continued. (Limited in the sense that their subject choice will be limited to subjects chosen for them.) Staff transfers known at present are:

Mr West to Blackwood

Mr Salt to Christies Beach

Miss Pfitzner to Northfield

Mrs Allen is resigning from teaching

Miss Helbig to Murray Bridge

[The Headmaster then thanked the school prefects and house leaders and other students who carried out a range of services.]

Thanks also go to the chief organizer Gary Heinrich and the participants in last Friday’s Swimathon, which has raised about $300. Thanks also to staff who have put in the extra work for organizing individual study programs as an experiment in the last fortnight.

Religious instruction has continued for two groups this year: Anglicans with Rev. Stephenson and Roman Catholics with two Sisters from Georgetown. Last year we were shocked by the sudden death of the school cleaner Mr Hawkins on the day after speech night. He had been a cleaner at the High School from 1958 and for both school for some years before that. Mrs Bagg said she could not continue alone and so another cleaner was found. Mr Brak has done a very efficient job. The Burra Record is thanked for printing news concerning the school and Mrs Carpenter & Mrs Cockington for continuing the singing tradition at the school.
