93, 50, 21 Dec. 1971, page 7

Advt. Burra Pictures, 27 December

Elvis Presley & Shelley Fabares in Clambake

Plus Thunderbirds Are Go

1 January 1972

Lee Marvin & Toshiro Mifune in Hell in the Pacific

Christopher Lee & Charles Gray in Devil’s Bride

8 January 1972

Rod Taylor, Catherine Spaak & Karl Malden in Hotel

George Montgomery & Neville Brand in Badman’s Country

15 January 1972

Tommy Steele in Half a Sixpence

Characteristics of the 1971 paper.

A fair coverage of local issues along with a number of general interest articles. There are very few photographs of local events and generally they appear well after the occasion.

The Burra Mine and associated activities like saving the old mine buildings get good coverage and sport, as usual, is quite well covered, but it is disappointing to find a number of other things are only referred to in the briefest terms in the ‘Out and About’ column.

Obituaries with any significant detail are rare and editorial comment on the changes occurring in the town is completely lacking. Much of the news comes from beyond the town and immediate district and there is a lot of space devoted to articles of a generic nature; such as advice to primary producers. Questions in Parliament are another significant input; usually with a clear right wing bias, which is unsurprising given the electorate.

Rather than print supplements the practice this year was to print in the gutters, which poses a problem for any binding of the paper’s archived copies.

Overall the decline in quality and local relevance noted in the last few years is continued.

There is no hard and fast location for most items, but the following gives an idea of where they commonly appear.

Page 1 is devoted to news.

Page 2 is half news and half advertisements.

Page 3 is similar to page 2.

Page 4 is mostly advertisements and the ‘50 years Ago’ column.

Page 5 is mostly advertising and sport.

Page 6 carries the ‘Out and About’ column, which is at once valuable and informative and annoyingly brief on some matters. The ‘Cash Column’ of small advertisements is usually here and the rest of the space is given over to public notices and advertisements.

Pages 7 & 8 are split fairly evenly between advertisements and news, along with items of general interest.

In the football season the equivalent of a full page of results is scattered about, but even so they are often incomplete.

94, 1, 18 Jan. 1972, page 1

____________ Burra Cold Stores

94, 1, 18 Jan. 1972, page 1

Weather. The January rainfall has been well above average. Burra so far has recorded 219 points.

To the east the rains have been the best for nearly twenty years. Several watercourses have run and excellent intakes have been reported for dams on most properties.

Sturt Vale 510 points, Braemar 401, ‘The Gums’ 277, Thistlebeds 261, Koomooloo 205, Woolgangi 308, Canegrass 209 and Hogback 462 points.

Business Takeover

The Modern Meat Store of Fred & Jan McLean has taken over the butchering business of Messrs Harold and Jack Topsfield, effective midday Saturday. The Topsfields have been in business 261⁄2 years. The new proprietors will continue to operate Topsfield’s shop in Burra North, but in Burra only McLean’s shop will remain open.

Postal Deliveries. Tenders are called for the mail runs:

Hallett to Braemar via Hughes’, Mt Bryan East, Collinsville, Mallett, Ketchowla and Oaks. Once a week.

Hallett to Mt Bryan East via Hughes’ twice a week.

Keith A. Spackman of Burra Fire Brigade has been awarded the Fire Brigade’s Long Service & Good Conduct Medal. It is a recognition of 23 years’ service.

Hallett Primary School is to get a new headmaster’s residence.

Vandalism.

On the 24 December there was damage at the Memorial Oval. Windows in the toilet block were broken and a toilet pan smashed. All globes and fittings on the basketball court were smashed.

On 1 January filthy words were painted on the front steps of the school, the practice tennis courts, the yard, classroom doors and garbage cans. At the oval they appeared on the toilet block, grandstand, basketball courts and scoreboard and at J.J. & B.C. Richard’s garage and on five school buses. Others were painted on the base of Peacock’s Chimney and on the stobie pole in front of Matthews Emporium. Five young persons were reported and they have since removed the paint.

Accident/Obituary. On 24 December at 6.30 p.m. a Toyota sedan owned by Clifford Howard Herbert of Boulder WA and driven by Felix Garrett Richards (22), a soldier of Mt Yokine, WA, overturned 15 miles east of Burra on the Morgan Road. The driver was killed. Two cars were travelling together to Albury where the deceased was to have been best man at a wedding. Mr Richards was taken to the Burra Hospital in the other vehicle, but was dead on arrival.

Accident. On 25 December a car collided with guide posts at Brown’s Corner while travelling at speed. The driver was not injured.

Accident. On 5 January at 3.30 p.m. a truck laden with bulk wheat and driven by Thomas K. McWaters collided with the ‘Blue Bird’ railcar at the crossing on the by-pass road near the Copperhouse Corner. The train caught the rear of the truck. The driver suffered concussion, fractured ribs and bruised legs. The damage to the truck was estimated at $250, to the bin at $400 and to the train at $1,000. Wheat worth $120 was also lost.

Accident. A vehicle driven by Maurice Quinn of Avondale Heights, Victoria, overturned on 7 January on the Burra-Morgan Road 12 miles from Morgan. The driver’s wife and three children were passengers. A daughter who suffered back and neck injuries was taken to Burra Hospital.

Accident. Terence Bevan was donkeying Anthony Pietsch (12) of Grange on Smelts Road when he hit a stone and Pietsch was thrown to the roadway. He was admitted to the Burra Hospital overnight.

Theft. Truck tyres to the value of $750 were stolen from Burra Livestock Transport of Burra North on the night of 9 January.

94, 1, 18 Jan. 1972, pages 1 & 2

Burra Swimming Pool Learn to Swim Campaign of two weeks. Total enrolment was 235 and a total of 143 Certificates and/or medals resulted. [A list of those who gained certificates and other awards is printed.]

94, 1, 18 Jan. 1972, page 8

Burra Burra DC, 6 December at Burra Town Hall.

It was resolved that plans be drawn up for a new toilet block behind the existing office.

J.B. Topsfield resigned as ticket seller at Burra Pictures and a letter of appreciation is to be sent in acknowledgement of at least 12 years’ service.

94, 2, 25 Jan. 1972, page 1

Adelaide Wool Sales 18-20 January saw prices increase by about 5-71⁄2%. [Local district prices are printed.]

Burra Burra DC has acquired all the land previously controlled by the Burra Sports Syndicate and also, by the use of a subsidy has been able to acquire the ‘land over the road’ and so now the whole of the Burra Golf Course is Council land.

Barker of Baldina Homes. The tender of M.G. Wardle and Co. has been accepted for excavation work on the homes’ site. Some 10,000 yards of material will be removed.

Robertstown Council has asked the Burra Burra DC for support in repairing roads etc. in the Burra Gorge Picnic Area at World’s End. Council will inspect before deciding.

Accident. An interstate semi-trailer loaded with 161⁄2 tons of balled cotton [check: bailed?] overturned on the Mt Bryan Road at 3.45 a.m. on Thursday, while en route to Adelaide. Driver Paul Kalas of Queensland suffered cuts and abrasions to his right arm and leg and a passenger Kenneth Joseph Freeman of NSW suffered minor injuries. Damage to the trailer is estimated at $2,500. Clode’s crane pulled the vehicle back onto its wheels.

Richard Hugh Bell Kearns (57) was born in Adelaide, but lived for a number of years in Burra. He is a step-son of the late Mr Jack Kellaway, a former Burra resident. Mr Kearns later moved to Broken Hill. In the New Year’s Honours List he was awarded an MBE. Mr Kearns is a Fellow of the Australian Society of Accountants and an Associate of the Chartered Institute of Secretaries. He joined the accountancy staff of the North Mine in 1938 and has been Chief Accountant for the past nine years. In World War II he spent 51⁄2 years in the RAAF and saw service in the Solomon Islands, narrowly escaping with a small party when it was over-run by the Japanese in 1942. He has had a long involvement in community affairs in Broken Hill. He is currently deputy chairman of the District Hospital Board and Hon. Secretary of the Broken Hill Legacy Group, Chairman of the Mines Dental Clinic, past Chairman of Broken Hill Branch of the Australian Society of Accountants and President of the local History Society. He has served on the High School Council, in the Parents & Friends’ Association, the ABC Concert Committee, the Mine Employees Pension Fund, Workmen’s Compensation Joint Committee and the War Veterans’ Home. He is married with three children, one of whom has recently graduated s a Bachelor of Economics and another is attending Flinders University.

[He was born in 1914 and his father died in 1918. His mother married John Kellaway in 1925 and he was in Burra from then (and probably earlier) and attended Burra Primary School, gaining his QC there in 1927. After school he worked for Drew & Crewes and in 1937 transferred to the office of M.W. Bednall, solicitor. In December 1938 he joined the office staff of North Broken Hill Mine and enlisted in the RAAF in 1940. Mr & Mrs Kellaway retired to Croydon in 1941. His mother died 1950 and step-father in 1969.]

Obituary. Maurice Ignatius (Naish) Carmody died last week. He was brother to Matt. Carmody. (The deceased was a taxi driver in Adelaide and there was an article about him in last week’s Advertiser.)

[Ignatius Michael Carmody born 26 October 1917 Kooringa: died 20 January 1972 Near Adelaide, residence Somerton Park.]

Obituary. Bruce Morton who was born in Burra died recently in Sydney. He was a son of the late Mr & Mrs Max Morton of Burra. [Born 15 May 1915 Redruth.]

Lindsay Quinn & Alan Kemble visited Burra last week after a considerable time.

Miss Gertrude M. Jordan wrote to us recently from Ashfield, Sydney, where she lives in a house called ‘Kooringa’. Aged 90, she is the last of a family of 10 and she lived in Burra till aged 16. The family moved to Broken Hill in October 1898. In January 1908 she went to Sydney and taught at various schools until retiring as an Infant School Headmistress in 1945. Mr Jordan, her father was a watchmaker and her grandparents lived next door.

[Gertrude May Jordan 1882-1973. She was a sister to the famous Arthur Jordan 1873-1965, who climbed to the top of the Smelts Chimney when aged about 12. See an account at 57, 45, 10 Nov. 1936, page 3.]

Mrs Whitford. [I] recently visited Broken Hill and at the Home of Compassion saw an old lady whose family once lived in a dugout. She was Mrs Whitford aged 100.

Rev. Clarrie Hore was inducted into the Burra Methodist Circuit at a service on Friday night conducted by Rev. A.H.M. Ellison of Nuriootpa, Chairman of the Middle District and Rev. D. Gibson of Clare gave the address. Mrs Jack Oates was the organist. Supper followed in the Church Hall.

Obituary. Robert William Motherall, late 2nd Battalion 1st AIF, died at Clare Hospital 22 January aged 73. He was the son of the late Mr & Mrs H.R. Motherall, husband of Dot. and father of Albert (deceased) and Norma Mrs Barker. Grandfather of Robert and Dianne. [Robert William Motherall born 6 September 1898 Kooringa.]

94, 3, 1 Feb. 1972, page 1

Burra Mine

Heavy machinery used by Roche Bros has disclosed the main access tunnel from the ore body to the outside from the pre-1870 operations. The tunnel would be approximately 600 ft in length from the ‘fall in’ to the top and several hundred feet back to the lower levels of the open cut. About 400 ft along the tunnel there is a turntable of approximately 4 ft 6 inches diameter in perfect working order. Beyond there is a section of rail track and a set of points. The very solid timbering of the tunnel is in good condition with some nails not even rusty. Mine workers had been into the tunnel prior to the visit. The writer was accompanied by Mr Lewis Moore who photographed the turntable. The foul air in the tunnel did not permit a long stay. A series of pulleys along the roof of the tunnel (as seen on either side of the turntable) are still positioned and these were used to draw the rail trucks and loads of ore from the lower workings. The positioning of the pulleys etc. would suggest that while a loaded truck was being hauled up, the weight of an empty truck going down was used to help the upward pull. The access tunnel would have been in use long before the open cut method of mining was adopted and a considerable portion of it would have been destroyed on the lower end. Apparently an unsealed entrance on the top side existed some time ago and persons had been into the tunnel. Several names were written on the underside of the underside of the turntable. One was Rex Walker Bridge St Sunday 17/8/1930.

[There are photographs; one of the turntable suspended from the overhead timbers and showing the solid timbering of the tunnel. Another is a close-up of the turntable with the spliced rope attached, on which the steel worked. Animal fats were used for lubrication and are still evident around the central spindle. There is another on page 7.]

In the modern mine the production of copper oxide has reached its planned level for stage 1. Local and interstate markets have been obtained in the fertilizer field and overseas negotiations continue. Planning for stage two continues and this should be operational within 12-18 months, boosting treatment to 1,000 tons per day.

Methodist Services

With the dividing of the Hallett-Terowie Circuit two churches join the Burra Circuit; Mt Bryan and Willalo. Willalo services will be fortnightly alternating between 3.45 p.m. and 11 a.m.

Mt Bryan services will be fortnightly alternating between 11 a.m. and 2 p.m.

94, 3, 1 Feb. 1972, page 4

Ian Auhl writes to draw people’s attention to the recently published book, The Steel Master. It is the biography of Essington Lewis who was born in Burra in 1881 and became General Manager of BHP and Director General of Munitions and Aircraft Production during WWII. One photo in the book shows the Lewis home in Kangaroo Street after the snowstorm of 1901. The book mentions at some length the years when John Lewis lived in Burra as a partner in the firm Liston, Shakes & Lewis (later Bagot, Shakes & Lewis). Essington attended the Burra Primary School. The author is Geoffrey Blainey.

94, 3, 1 Feb. 1972, page 7

Burra Mine. There is a further photograph showing a close-up view of the turntable in the mine tunnel.

94, 3, 1 Feb. 1972, page 8

Burra Burra DC. Balance sheet at 30 June 1971 is printed.

94, 4, 8 Feb. 1972, page 1

Steelton Post Office finally closed on 29 January 1972 after over 100 years of service. It is thought the office opened in the 1860s or earlier when Steelton was established as a result of the discovery of copper at Burra. Steelton was on the copper route to Kapunda via Black Springs and Marrabel. Steelton then had a blacksmith’s shop, a hotel and other buildings. A school was set up and the first school teacher was Mr Henry Parkins who became the first postmaster. The early mail service came from Saddleworth. Names of early mail contractors are not known, but in the motor car era some have been: Harry Butler, Mr Becker, Norm Tank, Edgar & Harold Milde, Bert Milgate and the present one is Ivan Milde. The first post office was on the main road and existed for nearly 100 years. Henry Parkin passed the office to his sister and soon afterwards she passed it to Harry Parkin, clerk of the Waterloo Council and later overseer of the Saddleworth Council. He carried it on until about 15 years ago, when it was taken over by Mr & Mrs Vern Schmaal, who held it till its closure. About 12 years ago the old building was in a bad state of repair and the site was changed to the present one, some 500 yards north on the property of Mr Ben Schmaal. Locals gathered on Saturday morning to see the arrival of the last mail bag to Steelton. Residents will now be served by a road-side delivery service or private boxes from Saddleworth.

[Opened 1 September 1861 according to Matin Walker The Post, Telegraph & Telephone Offices of SA & NT (2004).]

Theft. 21 gallons of petrol were siphoned from the school buses at Richards’ Garage at Burra North on the last weekend in January.

RSPCA ran a state-wide essay contest. Honourable mentions went to Maryann Shipard, Karen Mengersen, Lorraine Meintjes & Margaret Beare; all in the Junior Section and to Lyn Moreland in the Senior Section. David Nourse gained 3rd place in the state in the Junior Section and appeared on Channel 7 recently to receive his prize.

94, 4, 8 Feb. 1972, page 3

Burra High School

Plans for a replacement High School were referred to the Public Works Standing Committee last Thursday. The plans were to replace the High School buildings completely on a new 20 acre site about half a mile from the present site. The present school is in inadequate buildings on a small site shared with the Primary School, the Minister for Education, Hugh Hudson, said. The new school is planned to be built around a square courtyard with versatile open space, specialist teaching areas and science labs and a library resource centre. There will be provisions for Home science, Needlework, Woodwork, Metalwork and Typing, along with administration, a shelter/activity area and a canteen shell. The new school is designed for up to 200 students. The transfer would allow the whole of the existing school for use by the Primary School, enabling substantial improvements.

Birth. To Jackie & Bill Bampton of the Police House in Queen Street, a son, Shane Patrick.

Marriage. Westbourne Park Methodist Church, 2 February

Christine Riggs, daughter of Mr & Mrs Jim Riggs of Moorook and formerly of Farrell Flat, married Manuel Lopez-Valcashel. The couple will live in Madrid, Spain.

94, 5, 15 Feb. 1972, page 1

Break-in. An attempted break-in on Friday night at the Burra Motor Co. was thwarted when those involved were challenged by Mr Paul Denmead of Burra and they fled.

Accident. A semi-trailer overturned at Hanson on Thursday at 9 p.m. It was loaded with empty bottles. The driver was not seriously injured.

Burra Saleyards

Elders-GM conducted their monthly market in the ‘Bon Accord’ Saleyards today and this was the final sale prior to their demolition. They will be replaced by yards of steel construction. Today’s yarding was of 6,300 sheep. The first market was on Friday 25 November 1887 with a yarding of 25,000 sheep and 300 cattle for Elders Wool & Produce Co.

[The paper of 22 February 1972 says the first Elder’s sale was on 27 July 1888 with 4,350 sheep and 15 cattle. This anomaly may be because of the change of name from Elder’s Wool & Produce Co. to Elder, Smith & Co. Ltd.]

These yards were reconstructed and opened with a sale on 15 October 1891 with a yarding of 25,174 sheep. Messrs Sara & Dunstan were the contractors. With several stock agents in the town, a combined total of 40,000 sheep a month was common. Elders were then yarding over 200,000 sheep a year with Shakes & Lewis handling a similar number and Morris, Sandland & Barritt 170,000 to 200,000, plus some from other agents. Over half a million sheep were handled annually until a series of bad seasons from 1892 saw a drop of more than 50%. As other country markets grew the numbers at Burra fell. The peak sale for SA was on 27 September 1895 when Elders at Burra yarded 44,000 sheep and sold 36,000 of them with 750 head of cattle.

94, 5, 15 Feb. 1972, pages 1 & 8

Adelaide Wool Sales last week saw a dramatic increase in prices. Top price for the district was 119c per kilo on account A.A. & M.N. McInnes of Booborowie. [Other local district prices are printed.]

District Schools Intake 1972

Booborowie has an enrolment of 80, up from 64 for 1971 (aided by the closure of Willalo). [New students are listed.] Miss P. Glencowe has joined the staff as infant teacher. Mrs Blackwell takes Grades III, IV & V. Headmaster Mr Blackwell. This year’s enrolment is the highest since 82 in 1927 and 85 in 1926.

Hallett has 74 students this year, an increase from 64 in 1971. The Headmaster is K. Whittington, with Miss Sue Polmear (Primary) and Miss Margaret Johnson (Infant). [New students are listed.]

Burra Primary School for 1972 has 271 students compared with 248 in 1971. New staff: Mr Grant Good comes from Tennant Creek, Miss Mignon Williams from Alice Springs and Miss Pam Lester from Wattle Park Teachers’ College. [New students are listed.]

Burra High School begins the year with 156 students compered with last year’s 174. [New students are listed.] New staff members are: Mr D. Calder Headmaster), M. Atkinson, I. Coulls, A. Harvey, T. Mends and Mrs K. Lomman.

Burra Kindergarten. Old and new students are listed.

Farrell Flat has no new pupils and no new staff. There was a mid-year intake. The 25 pupils now compares with 29 in February 1971.

Mt Bryan has 28 pupils compared with 29 last year. Mrs Prior has moved to Loxton Primary School and Miss Christine Haskard replaces her. There are three new students.

94, 5, 15 Feb. 1972, page 8

Football. Saddleworth-Marrabel United has rejected a further amalgamation with Auburn Football Club.

94, 6, 22 Feb. 1972, page 1

Football. North Eastern Football League held its AGM 14 February. Booborowie and Hallett announced their amalgamation due to depleted numbers. Mr M. Vandeleur of Clare was elected President of the League with R.N. Collins as Patron; Secretary-Treasurer, A.L. Fillmore. For 1972 the League will comprise Spalding, Burra Clare North, Clare South and Booborowie-Hallett.

Accident. When a semi-trailer was travelling north on the old Belcunda Road on Tuesday the turntable plate broke on a bend. A stock crate fell off and was destroyed and 30 sheep were also destroyed. Damage was estimated at $5,000.

Burra Motel. Applications for shares are due in by 28 February, with tenders for the erection of the building due on the same date.

Weather. The January-February period has been the wettest for 25 years. 225 points fell in January with 191 so far in February. [Other data is printed.]

Burra Library held its AGM. President J.B. Topsfield said the library lacked the support it deserved. The year had been financially successful. In the year Mrs Fennell resigned as Librarian and has now been replaced by Mrs R. Pritchard. Membership is 52 adults and 7 juveniles. Elected: President, J.B. Topsfield; Secretary, B. Kotz; Treasurer, Edith Carpenter and Vice-Presidents, R.J. Steele & Mrs Jean Kotz.

94, 6, 22 Feb. 1972, page 2

94, 7, 29 Feb. 1972, page 1

Advt. Jenny Bannister introduces herself as manageress for St James Salons, who have taken over the Richardson’s Salon in Burra. She will commence on 6 March.

Swimming. Several Burra competitors at Spalding recently have qualified for the Country Championship finals in Adelaide shortly: Terry Bevan (b. 1961), Kerry Spackman (b. 1959) & David Allen (b. 1960).

The Rural Youth Swimming Carnival was held last Sunday at the Burra Pool. The Burra Club won the team effort for the first time. [Results are printed.]

Burra High School Swimming Carnival was held on 21 February. Jennison House won the Shield. [Results are printed.] Cup Winners were:

U-13 Girls J. Bernhardt

U-13 Boys N. Van Buuren

U-14 Girls M. Rooke

U-14 Boys P. Woolley

Open Girls D. Brereton

Open Boys P. Broderick

94, 7, 29 Feb. 1972, pages 1 & 2

Burra Anglican Parish Old Style Country Fair was held at the Burra Showgrounds last Saturday. The crowd of about 700 was well entertained and buying at the stalls was brisk. The gross takings of about $1,150 should see a nett return of about $900. The merry-go-round built by Thamm’s Whitehart Garage was a non-stop success, with children queuing all afternoon. Horse rides were popular and so was the Children’s Fancy Dress Competition, which gave the judges, Rev. & Mrs Hore of Burra Uniting Church, a difficult task. Visitors from Adelaide were offered a three hour town tour with the Mine included and a surprising number of Burra people patronised this option too. The motor cycle skills of the Denton Bros of Farrell Flat delighted the boys and girls.

[Results of the Fancy Dress are printed on page 2.]

94, 7, 29 Feb. 1972, pages 1 & 5

Competition teams this year will be:

Auburn is to confirm its entry after its AGM.

It was resolved that negotiations be entered into for the amalgamation of the Mid North and North Eastern Leagues. Elected: Patron, W.E. Blatchford (Riverton); President, S.H. Noske; Senior Vice-President, B. Stockman (Aberdeen), Secretary, vacant. [A range of other matters is reported.]

94, 7, 29 Feb. 1972, page 3

Marriage. Burra Methodist Church, next Saturday

Lyn Winders, elder daughter of Mr & Mrs Ron Winders of Black Springs, will marry

Lester Launer, son of Mr & Mrs G.J. Launer of Willaston.

Cheryl Finch of Burra has been selected as one of ten members of the Sa Women’s Athletics Team to compete in Perth next month in the National Championships.

Flower Day will be held in Adelaide next Friday. Don’t miss Burra’s entry if you’re there. It is a scaled replica of the chimney, made by Charlie Griffiths and painted very cleverly by Margie Tiver. It features wheat grown by Peter Stockman, wool lent by Ray Lloyd, a dry arrangement by Joyce Lloyd and Betty & Shirley Thamm. Necessary printing was done by Tom Perry and stones were lent by Samin Ltd. It will be located east of the south end of the Victoria Square Fountain.

Anglican Fair. Later figures suggest gross takings of $1,190 for nett proceeds of $1,060.

Ben Kotz is growing some wonderful dahlias. They look so perfect that several people have accused them of being plastic.

Obituary. Joe Pascoe, late of Burra, died in Adelaide on Friday.

[Joseph Thomas Pascoe born 24 August 1895 Kooringa: died 25 February 1972 Mt Gambier.]

Obituary. Mrs Doreen Hempel of Morgan died at the Waikerie Hospital. She was well known in Burra.

[Doreen Veronica Hempel, wife of Norman Leslie Hempel, died 25 February 1972 Waikerie, residence Morgan aged 61.]

[Ronald Ranger Baxter died 26 February, Clare aged 87.]

94, 7, 29 Feb. 1972, page 7

Bowls

1st Division Burra Gold 74 defeated Burrs Green 73

2nd Division Auburn 84 defeated Burra Blue 54

Spalding 95 defeated Burra White 62

94, 7, 29 Feb. 1972, page 8

Burra National Trust Branch held its AGM recently.

President W.L. More gave a résumé of its activities. An Australia-wide appeal was made for funds to rebuild Peacock’s Chimney. The complex of buildings at Peacock’s Shaft was demolished by Samin Ltd. After discussion Samin agreed to bypass the complex to give time to remove the stack. To date $8002.36 has been received. Bad weather slowed the rebuilding, but it is now to the stage of the top brickwork. Much volunteer labour has kept the cost so far to $3,688.47. Thanks are due to all the donors and especially to Ian Auhl for setting up the appeal and to Messrs G. O’Connor, D. Cockington and M. Tiver for so much of their time. On 29 September the Thomas Pickett plaque was unveiled. Mr Bonython as State President of the National Trust gave an address. Mr Ian Auhl recounted the story of Thomas Pickett and Mr Stan Woollacott dedicated the memorial. The stone used is part of one of the counter-balances from the old Mine. The Waterworks officially handed over the Bon Accord engineer’s shop and the manager’s cottage to the National Trust on condition that Mrs Fisher be allowed the use of the cottage as long as she requires it. The roster system at the Museum has worked well. The increasing number of coaches and school visits to the town is placing an increasing demand on volunteer guides. Mr Woollacott estimates 7,000 visitors to the Museum. [Various other people are then thanked.]

Elected: President, W.L. Moore; Vice-Presidents, G.R. O’Connor & L. Warnes; Secretary, M.A. Tiver; Treasurer, D. Cockington; Curator, S. Woollacott and Historical Officer, I.L. Auhl.

94, 8, 7 Mar. 1972, page 1

Adelaide Wool Sales, 29 February-2 March. Prices fell an average 71⁄2%. [Local district prices are printed.]

St Mary’s Harvest Festival will be held next Sunday 12 March.

Football. Blyth Football Club has applied to join the North Eastern League and was accepted 1 March. Blyth will be the sixth club and will field ‘A’ Grade, ‘B’ Grade and Senior Colts teams.

94, 9, 14 Mar. 1972, page 1

Sealed Roads

Work on sealing roads will continue this month with a further 3.7 miles of the Hanson-Clare Road and streets in Mt Bryan Township and in the Housing Trust area of Burra off Smelts Road.

RSL held its AGM on Friday, but it had to be adjourned when numbers failed to make a quorum. It has been postponed to 24 March.

Mr D. Calder, the new Burra High School Headmaster, was introduced to about 80 parents at the AGM of the Parents & Friend’s. He had previously been Headmaster at Craigmore High School at Elizabeth.

Football. Representatives of the Mid North and North Eastern leagues met on Friday last at the Railway Hotel, Saddleworth, to discuss their proposed amalgamation. Mr Stan Noske, President of the Mid North League and Mr M. Vandeleur, President of the North Eastern League, held wide ranging discussions. It was announced that the North Eastern League would have similar discussions with the Broughton League.

Copper Festival

The Tourist Promotion Committee of Burra & District has plans for a Copper Festival on the Holiday Weekend 23 March. [Actually 7-9 October.] On Saturday there will be the Agricultural Show with a Ball at night.

On Monday there will be a gala Day at the oval. Rural Youth will be asked to organise the Ball. Mr Len Bence will be asked to organise an art show in the RSL Hall. Sgt Haynes will be asked about the possibility of the Police Band attending and Samin Ltd will be asked to permit Mine Tours. The break-down of the tourist dollar is estimated as:

Restaurant services and cafés 20%

Accommodation 17.3%

Merchandise 26%

Transport, petrol & motor sundries 36.2%

Notice. The Burra Burra Sports Association Inc. intends to wind up its affairs. Creditors are asked to forward claims to Ken. W. White, Burra North, by 15 April 1972.

94, 9, 14 Mar. 1972, page 7

Burra Primary School Welfare Club held its AGM 7 March. In the past year there had been 58 financial members and an average attendance of 31. Sports Day was successful and $217 was raised. The Club provided a luncheon in the Burra Town Hall in August, which raised $232. Throughout the year the Club spent $1,251 on sports equipment, library books, teaching aids and first aid equipment. The income was $1,295. Elected: President, Mrs B. Stockman; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames I. Allen & Haynes; Secretary, Mrs B.P. Thamm; Assistant Secretary, Mrs M. Tiver and Treasurer, Mrs Ray Alderson.

94, 10, 21 Mar. 1972, page 1

Burra Copper Festival

The Governor Sir Mark Oliphant will visit Burra during the Copper Festival 7-9 October. He will unveil a plaque on the resited Peacock’s Chimney Stack on Sunday 8 October. The Committee is considering many suggestions put forward for the festival. Mr Michael Trinnick of the [British] National Trust’s Committee for Devon and Cornwall has sent £10 sterling for the building fund appeal and says that in Cornwall they have preserved four Cornish engines in their original houses and hope to get one moving by steam. There is a fifth one in Holman’s Museum in Cambourne. The National Trust owns several ruined engine houses as well. These have been repaired and made safe for the foreseeable future and work on another will begin soon at Wheal Coates in the Parish of St Agnes, north of Truro in Cornwall.

Heysen Trail. Mr Allen MP asked a number of questions on the proposed Heysen Trail, but was told the exact route was yet to be determined and questions of fire danger, control of vermin, fencing and the like will be decided later.

The Merino Breeders’ Association arranged for a display of woollen fabrics at Burra Town Hall on Wednesday. Wool was used in a variety of ways with a range of fabrics that could be washed and ironed as easily as synthetics.

Burra Motel Ltd reports that $15,000 more is needed for the project to begin. Tenders ranged from $122,000 to $104,000. Subscriptions will be sought for another week, after which, if sufficient funds are not available, directors will be forced to refund subscriptions. An earlier canvass of the district suggested ample funds were available, but little of the promised money has been subscribed.

Burra Auxiliary Fire Brigade will be inspected 9 April, when Members of the Board and the Chief Officer will visit. Mr K.R. Spackman has qualified for the Fire Brigade’s Long service & Good Conduct Medal for 20 years’ service.

A Methodist Circuit Rally will be held at Mt Bryan next Sunday. The service and rally will be in the Mt Bryan Hall at 11 a.m. and a luncheon will follow.

Mr & Mrs Jeff. Bonython will leave Burra soon to make their home at Balaklava, where Jeff. will manage the Southern Farmers branch there.

Tom & Avis Pratt, who have recently sold the Market Square Café, are moving from Burra this week.

The Burra North Playground Pillars with memorial plaques to Sid and Flo Scroop will be unveiled on 2 April at 2.30 p.m. They honour sterling service to the Aberdeen Tennis Club.

94, 10, 21 Mar. 1972, page 4

The Burra Strike of 1848 [By Ian Auhl?]

News of the strike reached Adelaide 15 September 1848 with a request that twenty policemen be rushed up country because the mines had been occupied by 300 incensed miners, who were refusing to move even one ton of ore. The trouble started when the Sa Mining Association decided to sack Mr Thomas Burr, Superintendent of the Mines. When Burr refused to resign the Directors went to Burra and he was relieved of his duties. He left for Adelaide. The miners then complained of a grievance concerning the analysis of the ore samples. The system used three samples taken from each miner’s ore when it was cleaned and dressed. The first was taken by the miner, the second by the Superintendent and the third was sent to the Directors in Adelaide. The assay made in Burra was agreed to by both parties, but the Adelaide tests were frequently at variance. The miners thought they were being underpaid and the Directors thought the miners were seeking high rates for low grade ores. The Directors refused to talk and threatened to close the mine. There was a large quantity of ore on hand, which had to be assayed before the miners could be paid and the miners took control of the mines to prevent the ore being shifted. Only eight of 300 miners tried to work and two of them were tied back to back and paraded through the streets on a wheelbarrow – the other standouts were compelled to push the barrow. The Directors called on the solitary policeman to arrest the ring-leaders, but he had no chance. The news caused Burra Mine Shared to slump from £220 to £120 for a £5 share. Police Commissioner Dashwood and Inspector Tolmer headed to the Mines and several miners were fined for threatening language.

A conference was then held and it was decided that when the difference between the assays at the mine and those in Adelaide was greater than 30% the results would be averaged. On the way home when Mr Chambers was driving the horses, he lost control. Commissioner Dashwood made a grab for the reins and the horses swerved violently, turning the carriage over. Later Thomas Burra sued for wrongful dismissal and obtained £1,500.

94, 10, 21 Mar. 1972, page 5

94, 10, 21 Mar. 1972, page 6

Notice. A.T. & E.S. Smith have taken over the carrying business of Mr George Allen and will also continue a taxi service.

94, 10, 21 Mar. 1972, page 7

Obituary. A Notice to Creditors reveals the death of Henry Rex Dasborough, farmer and grazier of WA, on 28 June 1971. [He was born 12 July 1905 Findon and on 30 May 1936 married Lurline Nelly Tiver born 8 September 1911 at Redruth to George Samuel Tiver and Ellen Tiver nee Kelly. This connects him to the descendants of James Llewellyn Tiver (1829-1909) in the Burra District.]

Burra High School. The proposed site for the new High School was inspected by Mr E.C. Allen MP and the Public Works Standing Committee [members of which are listed]. It is expected tenders will be called later this year for work commencing in 1973, for occupancy in 1974. The brick building is square in design with about 100 feet square of lawn and shrubs at the centre. There will be tennis courts, a hockey field and oval and two footbridges and one vehicle bridge over the creek. The party also visited the Mine area.

[The site proposed at the time was not spelled out, but subsequent discussion suggests it was on the western side of the bypass road a little south of the railway station – between the bypass road and Copperhouse.]

Eight tables with particle board tops were bought for the Town Hall.

Council advised ETSA that it had no objection to having street lights burning all night, following ETSA’s offer of an all night lighting tariff.

94, 11, 28 Mar. 1972, page 1

Burra Primary School took part in the inter-school swimming carnival at Riverton on 24 March. Results:

Burra 215 points, led Riverton 196 and Hamley Bridge 65.

Vandalism. Three juveniles have been apprehended for breaking windows at the Burra Football Club rooms and the toilet block at the Memorial Oval.

Aberdeen Tennis Club has erected gate pillars at the entrance to the Aberdeen Tennis Courts in appreciation of Mr & Mrs Scroop’s 30 years of service (1940-70) as joint secretary-treasurers of the club and for the many hours spent working in this sports area. Mr A.L. Clode, a Past President of the Club for eight years will unveil the plaque on Easter Sunday at 8 p.m. [Check – surely 2.30 p.m. as advertised!]

M & BHA arranged for a display of period costumes at Mt Bryan Hall. Compere of the show was Mrs Murray Catford of Tarcowie. The clothes had been collected by the late Mrs Innes. [Models are listed and the evening is described in c. 11⁄2 columns of detail.] Nett takings were $111.65.

Cricketer of the Year and winner of the Jennison Trophy for 1972 was T. Cousins of Spalding.

Burra RSL resumed its adjourned AGM on Friday. Mr Ben Kotz was re-elected President, with R. Steele and T.R. Rogers as Vice-Presidents. Secretary, W. Fridd and Treasurer, B. Griffith.

Obituary. P.H. (Bill) Quirke died at the Royal Adelaide Hospital on Saturday aged 73. He was the first Member for Burra and a former SA Liberal Minister. He won the seat of Stanley for Labor in 1941. After disqualification from Party membership for a year in 1948, Mr Quirke resigned. Following the redistribution of seats in 1956 he became the first MP for the new seat of Burra, as an Independent. In 1962 he joined the LCL and was appointed Minister of Lands, Repatriation and Irrigation early in 1963. He retired from Parliament in 1967. He was Managing Director of the Clare Co-Operative Winery. He is survived by a widow, three sons and a daughter. [Photo.] [Percival Hillam Quirke born 30 July 1898 Adelaide: died 25 March 1972 Adelaide, residence Clare.]

94, 11, 28 Mar. 1972, page 2

Advt. Burra Pictures, 1 April

A full-length coloured cartoon, A Boy Named Charlie Brown

Plus The Early Bird

Burra RSL. President B. Kotz, Annual Report for 1971

There has been a lack of support from some of the elected committee members. In nine monthly meetings one committeeman did not attend at all and another only once. The Anzac Day and Armistice Day services were held as usual. The annual dinner was a success and so were the badge days conducted by the Ladies’ Auxiliary, who also ran a successful trading table for Legacy. Mr Ron Wuttke, who had been a solid supporter, was given a public farewell. Three members died during the year: H. Brown, R. Kellock and R. Motherall.

Obituary. Miss Edna Thompson, former postmistress of Burra North died at Burra Hospital on Friday aged 60.

A Sadistic Act on Saturday at Burra North saw a widow come home to find her pet cat had been set alight and had died in agony on a path near the house.

Sealing of Roads in Mt Bryan has been finished and the sealing of 3.7 miles of the Clare Road and of the new housing area in Burra will be finished by tomorrow.

Cheryl Finch, running for SA in the Australian Championships, came 3rd in the Junior 100 m hurdles and reached the final in the 200 m hurdles.

94, 12, 4 Apr. 1972, page 1

Burra Show Society held its AGM on Tuesday night. The balance sheet showed a credit balance of $238.78. Elected: Patron, Rex C. Warnes; President, R. Mason; Vice-Presidents, G. Kellock & M.G. Wardle.

Mrs Val Secomb has resigned as secretary and applications are being sought. The retiring President R. Mason reported on a successful 1971 show, opened by His Excellency Shizuo Saito, Ambassador of Japan. The morning was cold and overcast, but the afternoon remained fine. Overall entries were up on 1970 by 239. Sheep shearing was a highlight, though entries were down. Miss Show Girl was a popular contest. This year jumps and hurdles were improved and 250 new poultry cages were available. Working bees had been well attended. Horses in Action entries were down slightly. Wool entries increased considerably. Sheep numbers were down, but of a high standard. The Agricultural Pavilion was filled to capacity. The Schools’ Display was excellent. Industrial exhibits made a bright display. The Honda Agricultural Motor Cycle Trials were very popular. Many other sections had increased numbers of entries. [Thanks are then extended to many helpers.]

Burra Mine

Poseidon has announced it is going into the copper chemical field using Samin’s product, copper oxide. The Burra venture was acquired late in 1970 when Poseidon successfully bid for Samin Ltd. The copper chemical venture with Vermont Chemical & Seed Pty Ltd of Melbourne (largely owned by protein and fertilizer makers H.C. Pannifex & Co. Ltd) aims to make a range of chemicals for use in primary and secondary industry throughout Australia. The initial product, copper oxychloride, is used for spray cropping [crop spraying?]. The local market is approximately 500 tons p.a. Poseidon is about to begin stage 2 of the Burra project, which should lift production of copper oxide five fold to about 6,500 tons per year, worth $6-$7 million. This expansion of the works at Burra is expected to be completed next year. The market in Australia for cupric oxide has turned out to be larger than expected. [Photo of Burra leach tanks.]

94, 12, 4 Apr. 1972, page 2

Advt. Burra Pictures, 8 April

Peter O’Toole & Sian Phillips in Murphy’s War

Denis Waterman & Tessa Wyatt in Wedding Night

Cricket. Mokota Shield Grand Final

94, 12, 4 Apr. 1972, page 3

Marriage. St Peter’s College Chapel, next Friday

Jude Ashby, daughter of Mr & Mrs E.J. Ashby of ‘Ashrose’ Willalo, will marry

Rick Jones of Cummins. The couple will live at Pt Lincoln.

Obituary. Mrs Baynes, widow of the late Harry Baynes, died in Adelaide last week.

[Born Anna Louisa Niemann 8 December 1887 Walloway: died 28 March 1972 St Peters, residence Booborowie.]

Tom & Josie Battye (nee Jennison) and their three sons have left Adelaide en route for their new home in Lae, Papua New Guinea.

Burra Primary School Committee held its AGM on 20 March. It drew only 25 parents and 9 teachers. Chairman Mr Charles O’Connor welcomed them. Elected: Chairman, Charles O’Connor; Vice-Chairman, Ian Allen and Secretary-Treasurer, Lewis Moore.

[The Chairman reported on sports activities and fundraising for the past year.]

The triangular area directly in front of the school has been unsightly for many years. In 1971 the area was ploughed, levelled and treated with gypsum and sown to lawn. Thanks go especially to Murray Tiver for dealing with the ploughing and working and to others who were involved. The water supply to the school was improved with much increased water pressure and an efficiently functioning fire hydrant after many years. The new classroom was completed in mid-1971 and has been an important addition to the school. The Department has approved the enlargement of the area at the back of the tennis court. The walkway to Burra North is now an easement and work on it should begin soon. We welcome three new teachers for 1972 in Miss Lester, Miss Williams and Mr Good.

94, 12, 4 Apr. 1972, page 6

Accident/Obituary. A head-on collision on the Burra Hanson Road about 2.30 p.m. yesterday resulted in the death instantly of a Broken Hill woman aged c. 52 and a 12-month-old girl died in Burra Hospital last night. Two other people were sent to the Adelaide Hospital, one in a serious condition. The four occupants of the other car were admitted to the Burra Hospital; driver John Reece Watkins of Oaklands suffered concussion and lacerations, his wife suffered belt burns, a six-year-old child had lacerations and a four-year-old sustained concussion.

[Viola May Parker died 3 April 1972 near Burra, residence Broken Hill aged 54 and Jodie Louise Carruthers died 3 April 1972 at Burra, residence Broken Hill aged 7 months.]

94, 12, 4 Apr. 1972, page 7

Bowls. Results of a successful Easter Tournament at Burra are printed.

94, 12, 4 Apr. 1972, page 8

Inter-Primary School Swimming Carnival. Results are printed.

Redruth Ladies’ Guild held its AGM. Secretary Reta Jennison reported an average attendance of 19 for 1971. [The Guild’s activities are summed up in 11⁄4 columns.]

94, 13, 11 Apr. 1972, page 1

Tennis. Kooringa ‘C’ Grade celebrated their win over Aberdeen with a barbecue party on Saturday night. Aberdeen Club had a wind-up dinner at the Burra Hotel.

Farrell Flat Overpass. Mr Allen MP asked in Parliament why the proposed overpass at the railway crossing just north of Farrell Flat had been abandoned. Hon. G.T. Virgo replied that the $150,000 cost was not deemed justified. Only 150 vehicles a day use the crossing, so undue delays are not expected. A new crossing will be constructed with flashing lights just north of the present crossing.

John M. Gordon writes about the Burra Motel proposal from ‘Wahroonga’, 7 April.

I would like to draw the attention of Burra residents to the necessity of completing the Burra Motel project. The project is within striking distance of raising the finance. The town would greatly benefit from the increased tourism. SA is just beginning to see progress in this type of accommodation, which is booming in the eastern states. Tourism has been growing as we know from the caravan park. This venture using local finance will keep the returns in the district.

M & BHA held a lunch at the Burra town Hall on 6 April, but it was not well attended, probably because it clashed with the Burra High School Sports Day. It was disappointing that it was not supported by young mothers. Only four clinic users attended. The address was given by Mrs Dianne Morris, State Secretary of the Association.

94, 14, 18 Apr. 1972, page 1

LCL District Committee met on Friday in Burra Town Hall and was chaired by Mr Cliff Lucas of Hallett. Speakers were Dr Bruce Eastick, recently elected Leader of LCL in SA and Mr E.C. Allen, Member for Frome. At 3 p.m. the Member for Wakefield in the House of Representatives Hon. C.R. Kelly addressed a meeting which was open to the public.

Burra Kindergarten ran an Opportunity Shop last week and raised $240.

Burra Bowls Tournament

With fees and donations this should bring in about $200, which with Government subsidy means about $600 for the Burra Hospital. In the Cosmopolitan Rinks Tournament Section 1 the Burra Rink of Murray & Stella Stockman with Darrell & Pat Field won the final.

Club Handicap Consistency event was won by Bob Gill for the third time in succession.

Burra Burra DC. Members retiring due to the effluxion of time:

Farrell Flat Ward J.W. Burge

Kooringa Ward G.R. Finch

Leighton Ward R.J. White

Mongolata Ward B.A. Riggs

Burra Town Ward C.L .Phillips

Nominations are called by 12 May for an election by ballot on 1 July if required.

Burra Methodist Church

The Sunday School picnic at Christisen Park Clare will be held on Anzac Day.

The Annual RSL Church Parade will be held next Sunday at 7 p.m.

District Guild Rally, Wednesday 24 May.

Church Union Ballot:

Members on the Church Roll on 1 May will be entitled to vote on 25 June on the question of the Union of the Presbyterian, Congregational and Methodist Churches.

94, 14, 18 Apr. 1972, page 2

Tennis. The Burra Tennis Association ended its season with a cabaret in the Burra Town Hall on Friday, which produced a profit of c. $130. Aberdeen White won the ‘A’ Grade Shield, which was accepted by Captain Don Lloyd. Aberdeen Purple won the ‘B’ Grade Shield, which was accepted by R. Taylor. The Junior Shield had been presented to Kooringa at the end of the Grand Final.

94, 14, 18 Apr. 1972, page 3

Advt. Burra Pictures, 22 April

Sophia Loren & Marcello Mastrianni in The Priest’s Wife

Robert Mitchum & George Kennedy in The Good Guys and the Bad Guys

Birth. To Fay & Jack Sullivan of Booborowie at Burra Hospital, 12 April, a son.

Mr & Mrs Tom Pickering visited from Hobart yesterday. Mr Pickering was born her 50 years ago when his father was manager of the ANZ Bank from 1920-1930. His sister Roma, Mrs Hannan of Henley Beach, accompanied him. Mr Pickering is the Librarian in the Hobart Library.

[Tom Mansergh Pickering was born at Kooringa 8 August 1921 and died 26 October 2001. He was also a jazz musician and received the Order of Australia 1982.]

Obituary. Mr Albert Przibilla of Burra North died 13 April aged 81.

[Albert Edward Przibilla born 20 February 1891 Hundred of Mannanarie: died 13 April 1972 Burra North.]

Obituary. Mrs Catherine Hogan, relict of the late Martin Hogan, died on Friday aged 91.

[Born Catherine Dorothea Dempsey 30 May 1880 District of Upper Wakefield (Mintaro): died 14 April 1972 Burra, residence Leighton.]

Mr & Mrs Wayne Clarke have arrived in Burra after six years in Millicent. Mr Clarke is the new manager of the local branch of Southern Farmers.

94, 14, 18 Apr. 1972, page 4

The Heysen Trail. Questions asked by Mr Allen about the trail revealed that it was still in its early stages of development and investigation of the exact route and other details are yet to be determined.

94, 15, 25 Apr. 1972, page 1

Adelaide Wool Sales. Values on 29 February to 2 March were c. 10% higher. Top local price was 1171⁄2c per kilo for C.R. & P.M. Earle of ‘Coralinga’. [Other local district prices are printed.]

The Fathers’ Association of SA has awarded life membership to W.H.D. Carpenter of No. 3 Mitchell Flat aged 82. He is one of the association’s oldest members.

Burra District Sports Grounds

This property was recently handed over to the Burra Burra DC by the Burra Sports Syndicate and with some other land purchased by the Council provided grounds for the Aberdeen Football Club, Aberdeen Netball Club and the Burra Golf Club. The Burra Racing Club has closed at least for the time being and the racing stalls and running rails have been removed. This has made extra space available. The area under the trees along the creek would make an ideal picnic spot if developed with tables, seats and barbecues. Social bodies could hire the oval. The grass courts could be restored to playing condition and could be available for Sunday play. If these ideas appeal to anyone, now is the time to act.

C.L. Phillips.

Obituary. Mr Matthew Francis Carmody died on Sunday morning at his Leighton home when he was crushed between the tip-tray and the chassis of a truck. The raised tray had been propped with heavy timber and he was greasing the rear under section of the vehicle when the timber slipped sideways and there had been a sufficient loss of hydraulic pressure for the tray to descend. Two nephews and his son Patrick discovered the accident at approximately 12.45 p.m. He is survived by his widow and children: Patrick, Mary, Michael and Helen.

[Born 1 July 1919 Leighton: died 23 April 1972 Burra according to SA Deaths CD.]

Bowls

The Burra season closed on Saturday in cold conditions. Trophies were presented:

94, 15, 25 Apr. 1972, page 2

Advt. Burra Pictures, 29 April

Richard Attenborough, Laurence Olivier & Edith Evans in David Copperfield

The Annual Anzac March on Sunday was interrupted by heavy rain and the service was transferred from outside to the RSL Rooms. The wreaths were laid after the service by Ben Kotz for the RSL and R.J. Jeffery of the Burra Burra DC. Rev. C. Hore conducted the service and the Pt Pirie Pipe Band attended. The combined church service in the evening was at the Methodist Church.

Burra Mine

A recent state-wide weekly publication stated ‘Burra seems destined to become nothing more than a big hole in the ground, and a ghastly mess after mining has ended.’

Residents have expressed displeasure at the heading and opening of the article, which was otherwise a well meant attempt at stressing the importance of preserving Burra and its historical buildings. The mine is far from a mess because of the rigid mining regulations and the efficient manner in which Samin Ltd are carrying out operations.

[Six requirements to limit the impact are then listed.]

The District Council were aware of the conditions before mining commenced and the company provides a healthy pay packet each week, which should be spent in the town. Current operations are practically confined to the old mine area, which for the past 100 years has been a ‘big hole in the ground containing water’. The operations will remain inside the boundary fence and will not interfere with the town.

Mr & Mrs (Tom & Win) Canny of Dongara WA and formerly of Gum Creek are celebrating their Golden Wedding on 5 May. Daughter Aileen and husband will attend from Alice Springs, Pat and husband from Adelaide and three sons and their families from WA. Celebrations will be held at the home of daughter Joan, Mrs John Roberts, in Perth.

Frank Spencer (85) visited Burra recently from Adelaide after many years. He was accompanied by his daughter Frances.

Burra Pictures are still plagued by rowdy youngsters.

Oscar Bauer of Hyde Park visited last week. He used to work for Maurice Pritchard.

Burra High School sent a number of students to the studios of ADS7 last Sunday to cheer on three fellow students taking part in the quiz program It’s Academic. The contestants were Necia Mickel (Captain), Grant Maxted and Paul Hogan with Jenny Holmes as reserve.

Burra & District Stockowners’ Association held its AGM in the RSL Hall 17 April. Guest speakers were D.C.W. Edwards Assistant State Secretary and H. McDiamid of Economic Wool Producers. Elected: President, D.G. Radford; Vice-Presidents, R. Rooke & R. Cooke and Secretary, Arthur L. Wright.

94, 16, 2 May 1972, page 1

Wool Day. The Australian Wool Board is organising a Wool Day at the Burra Town Hall foe 20 June. Burra Red Cross is sponsoring this wool promotion day, which will feature illustrated talks, commentaries, question time and competitions. A lavish wardrobe of wool fashion will be on show. A competition will find the speediest knitter.

Burra Women’s Fellowship visited the Burra Telephone Exchange recently. There were three telephonists on duty.

94, 16, 2 May 1972, page 5

Burra Burra DC, 10 April

The Apex Club is to be asked what future is intended for the lawn tennis courts after they have been restored and who is to be responsible for their maintenance costs.

A.L. Clode & Son’s offer to buy a road at Burra North was accepted subject to road closing procedures.

[Part of Mary Crescent see 91, 34, 3 Sep. 1968, page 5 and 94, 13, 11 Apr. 1972, page 6.]

94, 16, 2 May 1972, page 6

Burra Pictures. Residents are advised that the managers are considering closing the show because patrons are unable to enjoy an uninterrupted show on any night. Talking and wandering by young patrons in disregard of the enjoyment of others can no longer be tolerated. Council says the next four shows will dictate the future of the pictures.

Advt. Burra Pictures, 6 May

94, 17, 9 May 1972, page 1

Theft. Six Burra shops were broken into in the early hours of Friday morning. Over 25,000 cigarettes were stolen along with $150 in coins, watches worth $160 and other items. At about 5.40 a.m. Mr Geoff Spackman saw a white Falcon sedan speed away from the lane at the rear of Bence’s. He and Mr L.A. Beinke notified police.

Oppy’s Save-Way 5,700 cigarettes stolen worth $107.

Market Square Café entered, but nothing apparently taken.

Burra Food Traders 8,200 cigarettes stolen valued at $169 and $30 in coins.

Pearce’s Hardware a .22 rifle ($89), watches to value $400 and $21.30 in coins. Some watches and coins were recovered, having apparently been missed when the stolen goods were loaded into the vehicle.

T.W. Wilkinson watches ($160), coins ($30), comics ($5) and cigarettes ($45).

Burra Serv-Wel Safe and $63, 10,800 cigarettes valued at $215 and other items to $7.

The same thieves are believed to be responsible for thefts on the previous night at Angaston and on Friday night at Saddleworth. Several stores in Eudunda were entered on the same night as the Burra break-ins, but that perpetrator was later apprehended at Pt Augusta.

Secondary School Sports were held at Eudunda on 2 May. Burra High School was placed 4th in the Open Shield, which was won by Clare. Kapunda won the Handicap Shield.

[Burra place getters for individual events are listed.]

94, 18, 16 May 1972, page 1

Mr Steele Hall, Liberal Movement Leader, addressed a gathering in Burra on Wednesday evening. He spoke of the urgent need for change within the LCL. The League had failed to attract the metropolitan voters. It has allowed an image to be formed that it is a party of privilege and of the Establishment, with no belief in the common man. The Liberal Movement aims to break this image. He had resigned as leader of the LCL because the party was not willing to embrace the change needed to win city seats.

Adelaide Wool Sales. The recent series saw values for most styles of wool firm. [Local district prices are printed.]

Burra Burra DC Elections

Farrell Flat Ward J.W. Burge re-elected

Leighton Ward R.J. White re-elected

Mongolata Ward B.A. Riggs re-elected

Burra Town Ward C.L. Phillips re-elected

Kooringa Ward W. Brown

N.C. Finch

A ballot will take place for Kooringa Ward on 1 July.

Burra Mine. On Tuesday evening a mining manager from New Zealand visited Burra to look over Samin’s operations on Wednesday. He was Frank Handcock, Manager of Norpac Mining Ltd in Te Aroha. He is descended from Cornish ancestors and his mother was born in Mt Gambier.

Advt. Burra Pictures, 20 May

John Wayne & Forrest Tucker in Chisum

Burra Burra DC, 1 May

Resolved that the Burra Picture patrons be warned that closing will be considered in one month if there is no improvement [in behaviour.]

Resolved that an old dwelling owned by H.C. Davies and M. Bernhardt be demolished by the Council plant when suitable.

Resolved to inform the SA Government that the Council is opposed to daylight saving.

Transfer noted of the transfer from E.A. Schutz deceased to Thomas Johnson Schultz and various parts of section 52 Hundred of Kooringa disposed as Lostwithiel allotments 19, 15, 16, 18, 23, & 17.

94, 19, 23 May 1972, page 1

Copper Festival Plans for 7-9 October.

The Governor Sir Mark Oliphant has accepted an invitation to open the annual show. The Bowling Club Rooms will house an art exhibition and wine tasting. There will be a licensed dance in the Town Hall on Saturday with an event for teenagers in the RSL Hall. Town bus tours will operate. On Sunday there will be the usual church services and in the afternoon the Police Band will play at the unveiling of the relocated Peacock’s Chimney. The Band will then continue its performance in Market Square. At night the Adelaide Glee Club will perform in the Town Hall. On Monday at the Burra North Sports Ground there will be a motor cycle display and Marching Girls and other attractions are being arranged. The Adult Education Department will stage a gem display at the school.

Burra Pictures. Behaviour has improved and become quieter in the past two weeks. The feedback from younger viewers indicates a desire for action films over drama. Council seems prepared to continue if there is sufficient support and a bit of ‘shush’.

The Methodist District Guild Rally at Burra Church tomorrow should have an attendance of over 200. Guest speaker is Deaconess Phyllis Bonython, Superintendent-Chaplain of the Methodist Women’s Welfare Department.

94, 20, 30 May 1972, page 1

The New Elders-GM Stockyards were opened on Tuesday by Chairman of the Burra Burra DC Mr Roy Jeffery. Until 1967 Mr Jeffery had been manager of Southern Farmers at Burra for many years. He said from 1887 for many years the prices of Burra Livestock Markets ruled SA. The Bon Accord yards at Burra North were the scene of Elders first country market. He traced the story of sales by Elders at Kooringa and by Shakes & Lewis; Morris; Morris, Sandland & Barritt; and Goodchild, Duff & Co. in yards at the Burra Hotel and behind Paxton Square. Agents had sold 40,000 sheep a month or 200,000 a year. In 1888 there was a yarding of 39,060 sheep on the site of the present yards. The record yarding was for 44,000 sheep and 750 cattle in 1895. For the new yards Southern Farmers had combined with Elders with an offering of 2,000 sheep and 200 cattle. Elders-GM offered 5,140 sheep and sold 4,810.

District Methodist Ladies’ Guild Rally at Burra Methodist Church on Wednesday drew 220 ladies from Guilds and Fellowships at Balaklava, Blyth, Brinkworth, Clare, Eudunda, Gulnare, Spalding, Gawler, Willaston, Two Wells, Farrell Flat, Ironmine, Willalo and Burra. Deaconess Phillis Bonython, Superintendent Chaplain of the Methodist Women’s Welfare Department & Babies’ Home spoke on the significance of ‘The Widow’s Mite’. There was also an enjoyable musical program to accompany the address. Proceeds from the luncheon and the offering amounted to $223.

94, 21, 6 June 1972, page 1

Adelaide Wool Sales. Local district prices were topped by R.M. Gebhardt & Co. of ‘Mokota’ at 128c per kilo. [Other local district prices are printed.]

Football. At the beginning of the season S. Schrapel, who had been playing for South Clare, was appointed playing coach for North Clare. South Clare did not grant clearance. The North Eastern League did not vote in favour of such a clearance and SANFL ruled a clearance was necessary. At a meeting of the NEFL on Tuesday night North Clare gave notice of its intention to withdraw from the League.

94, 21, 6 June 1972, page 3

Birth. To Ronda & Sid Allen at Burra Hospital last Wednesday, a daughter, Kathryn Michelle.

Birth. To Kevin & Valda Williams nee Mitchell at Burra Hospital 4 June, a son.

Birth. To Sue & Roger Dunn at Burra Hospital 4 June, a daughter.

Marriage. Burra Methodist Church last Saturday

Julie Kerslake, youngest daughter of Mrs & the Late Mr M. Kerslake, married Ted Irlam.

Obituary. Mr W. (Bill) Carpenter died on Thursday night following a short illness. Prior to this he had been a very active person for his 82 years. He had served as a Burra Councillor from 1943 to 1947 and again in 1949, resigning on 2 May 1950 to contest the Mayoral election. He was Mayor from July 1950 for four years. He is survived by a widow and five children: Joyce Mrs Bourman, Perce, Gladys Mrs Pens, Beryl Mrs Woodman and John.

[William Carpenter born 22 March 1890 Aberdeen: died 1 June 1972 Burra.]

Notice. Tenders are called by the Burra Burra DC for the erection of new toilet accommodation and additions to the office block.

94, 22, 13 June 1972, page 1

Burra Burra DC will celebrate its centenary to coincide with the Copper Festival. The District Council was proclaimed 28 November 1872. The Town Council did not appear until June 1876. The first meeting of the DC was in S. Drew & Co.’s office on 9 December 1872. Cr Isaac Killicoat was appointed Chairman. Other Councillors were H. Dawson, S. Drew, J. Dunstan & D. McCulloch. J. Dunstan Jun. was appointed Clerk pro tem. Meetings were held on alternate Thursday s at 10 a.m. with the second meeting in the old Burra Hotel. On 26 December 1872 J.D. Cave was appointed District Clerk and Collector at $150 p.a. Messrs Cave & Goodfellow were appointed assessors at $40 each. On 10 March 1973 Mr Tiver’s offer of two rooms at $48 p.a. was accepted for one month as the DC office. On 6 February 1873 it was decided to call tenders for an office in suitable premises in Aberdeen, Redruth or Kooringa. On 30 September 1873 the Secretary of the Institute advised that the Council could use the Institute for meetings at $40 p.a. provided the agreement was for one year. It was resolved that the offer be accepted provided a new room was built for the clerk’s office by the end of three months. The clerk was instructed to move furniture, safe etc to the office 23 December 1873 and Council evident met there from that date to the present time. [This last statement is not correct.]

[The following clearly reprinted an item written in 1935.]

In 1935 the Councillors were as follows:

N.H. Hearse [sic: error for Pearse], elected July 1914, appointed Chairman 1 July 1921 & served as such to the final meeting* – a period of 21 years.

J. Kellock elected 10 June 1916 – 19 years

R. Warnes elected 12 June 1920 – 15 years

E. Finch elected 29 October 1921 – 14 years

H.W. Tiver elected 4 July 1924 – 11 years

W.H. McWaters elected 4 July 1925 – 10 years

G.G. Hawkes elected 15 July 1927 – 8 years

[* This apparent anomaly in referring to a last meeting in 1935 for an institution having its centenary in 1972 occurs because from 1872 to 1935 there was a District Council of Burra. In 1935 the District Council of Burra Burra was formed by the merger of the DCs of Burra, Hanson, Booborowie & Mt Bryan.]

A.A. Davey was appointed Clerk 9 July 1910 and held the position for 25 years. J.J. Parker was appointed Overseer 10 June 1921 and held it to the present – 14 years.

The final meeting of the Booborowie DC was held 29 April 1935. Offers to buy the Council furniture were refused as too low. The chair of the Council was presented to the Booborowie Hall Committee. The Council recorded a minute that it strongly disapproved of the amalgamation of the district and was not satisfied with the findings of the commission, as the Council was large enough to function on its own. It was resolved that the Clerk be supplied with a reference. The Council would have been 60 years old on 5 May.

The final meeting of the Burra DC was on 26 April 1935. With the merging of Councils the new body comprised: I.J. Warnes as Chairman with Councillors H.C. Atkins, J. Kellock, A.D. McDonald, E. Finch, H.E. Edwards, F.G. Scholz and T.J. Wedding, with G. Powell as Clerk and Overseer.

Aberdeen Oval has recently been improved. More parking space with a good view has been made available, but now some people at the end of the match are driving across the oval instead of using the tracks provided. On a wet day this could spoil the surface for the rest of the season. The cost of erecting fencing would be an unnecessary expense.

Burra Burra DC will borrow $10,000 at 6.2% as a debenture loan over 10 years, to finance the new toilets and office additions, which will include a fire-proof strong room, a storage room and an office machinery room. The public conveniences will open onto Chapel Street.

The Highways Department is acquiring land at Farrell Flat to remove the sharp bend at the end of the Farrell Flat by-pass.

94, 22, 13 June 1972, page 2

Advt. Burra Pictures 17 June

Anthony Quinn & Virna List in Secret of Santa Vittoria.

Golf. On Saturday Peter Dignan beat the course record of 63 established by Stan Longford in 1967. Peter went around in 62 off the stick.

94, 22, 13 June 1972, page 3

Football. Colts Final

Gawler Districts 11.11 defeated North Eastern 8.4

‘A’ Grade Mid North 20.13 defeated Adelaide Plains 16.12.

94, 22, 13 June 1972, page 5

The book Charles Hawker – Soldier, Pastoralist, Statesman by Mrs K.L. Needham has been given to the Institute Library. He was born at Bungaree 16 May 1895 and was an outstanding scholar and sportsman. He received crippling injuries when twice wounded in WWI. After the war he travelled widely, learning much of agriculture and secondary industry. He entered Federal Parliament in 1929 as Member for Wakefield and soon became a Cabinet Minister. In 1932 he was Minister for Commerce. He was killed in the crash of the aircraft Kyeema on Mt Dandenong in Victoria 25 October 1938.

94, 22, 13 June 1972, page 6

94, 23, 20 June 1972, page 1

Burra Mine

There is a photo of the old open cut with Morphett’s Engine & Winding Houses and chimney along with Peacock’s Engine House & chimney, with instructions to see the bottom of page 3 for a photo of the same area with the new open cut in operation. [The 1972 photo actually appears on page 2.]

Burra High School

On Thursday representatives of Burra High and Primary School staff , School Council Members, District Councillors and officers of the Education and Public Buildings Departments met to consider the site for the new High School, which had been proposed for an area of land west of the Railway Station on Copperhouse Road. After the meeting sites in the vicinity of the town itself will be further investigated and it is hoped the planned project will be completed by 1975.

Church Union. A ballot of members of the Congregational, Methodist and Presbyterian Churches will be held on Sunday 25 June to decide on union.

94, 24, 27 June 1972, page 1

Theft. Fifteen porkers 14-16 weeks of age were stolen from ‘Caloola’ Mongolata, property of Mr M. Brady, in the last three weeks.

Adelaide Wool Sales. 30 May to 1 June. Better style wools rose by about 21⁄2%. [Local district prices are printed.]

Wool Day in Burra, organised by the Burra Red Cross and the Australian Wool Board, was attended by about 175 ladies from Burra. A knitting contest was won by Mrs Bowden of Burra. A wardrobe of woollen materials and garments was inspected. Mrs T. Padbury of Mt Bryan was judged the best dressed lady in wool. Proceeds $240.

94, 25, 4 July 1972, page 1

Church Union. The Burra Methodist Circuit voted 157 for union and 8 against.

Burra Burra DC. An election was held following the retirement of Mr Glen Finch. Results:

W. Brown 38

N.C. Finch 23

Accident. A semi-trailer rolled over about four miles east of Burra on Friday while travelling towards Morgan. The vehicle was carrying two industrial tractors when a chain broke and the load shifted. Damage to the vehicle was estimated at $4,000 and to the tractors as $500.

Accident. A sheep was hit by a car driven by R.A. Hurley of Burra near Black Springs on Friday. Damage to the vehicle was estimated at $100.

Deputation on Morgan-Burra Road

Representatives of the Burra, Spalding, Robertstown and Morgan District Councils met with the Minister of Roads, Hon. G. Virgo, introduced by E.C. Allen MP on Wednesday. They were concerned to see the Burra-Morgan Road sealed to encourage tourism, especially in view of the relocation of the Morgan Dock Yard. They received a cordial reception and a sympathetic hearing and an investigation was promised.

Ron Moody, Oliver Reed & Harry Secombe in Oliver

94, 25, 4 July 1972, page 3

Birth. To Judy & Kevin Pope at QVMH 26 June, a daughter, Jayne Judith.

Birth. To Maureen & John Cain, formerly of Burra Primary School staff, 30 June at QVMH, a son, Scott Benjamin.

Birth. To Liz & Roger Bennett of Delamere, recently, a daughter, Melanie Jane. Liz is a daughter of Mr & Mrs Laurie Anderson, now of Sevenhill and formerly of Hallett.

Birth. To Dean & Lenice Pearce of Booborowie, at Burra last week, a son, Nicholas Dean.

Obituary. Trevor Pascoe died 28 June in Adelaide aged 34. He was the son of Mrs Auriel and the late Claude Pascoe and is survived by a widow and two children. [Born 1 June 1938: died Daw Park, residence Pt Noarlunga.]

Obituary. Mrs Eugenie Radford of Glenelg East, relict of the late Maurice Redford died last week aged 89.

[Born Eugene Fuller 4 July 1882 Booleroo: died 28 June 1972 Glenelg, residence Glenelg East.]

Obituary. Mr James Goulter, a great supporter of country shows died last week at Crystal Brook aged 81. For 48 years he was a keen exhibitor of fowls, ducks and geese and it is estimated his birds won 37,000 prizes throughout Australia. [James Eber Goulter born 1 May 1891 Crystal Brook: died 27 June 1972 Crystal Brook.]

The former Dalgety’s Office has been transformed by the Bence Family into Cousin Jack’s Coffee Shop & Gallery. It opened today.

The Burra Kindergarten. The children are going to Hanson tomorrow by car and will return on the train. For many it will be their first train trip.

94, 25, 4 July 1972, page 5

Burra Bowling Club held its AGM last Wednesday 28 June. Elected: Patron, Dudley Jacka; President, Darrell Field; Vice-Presidents, Brian Riggs & Wally Scott; Secretary, Jack Topsfield and Treasurer, K. van der Does. [Details of the operations of the club for the coming year are printed.]

The 1971-72 season was opened by Stan Woollacott, a past President, on 16 October 1971. Two successful tournaments were conducted – a two day event on the Sunday & Monday of the January long weekend and the three-day Easter Tournament. The financial position of the club is satisfactory.

[The rest of the report mainly thanks various people and groups who contributed to the club’s success.]

94, 25, 4 July 1972, page 8

St Mary’s Guild met in the Parish Hall last week when about 45 members and guests heard an address by the managing secretary of the Prisoners’ Aid Association, Mr Ray Kidney. He also spoke to a small group in the Town Hall meeting room on Tuesday evening.

94, 26, 11 July 1972, page 1

Burra Women’s Branch of the LCL held its AGM on Friday afternoon. Hon. C.R. Kelly MHR attended as Member for Wakefield in the Federal Parliament and Mr Goldsworthy, the House of Assembly Member for Kavel attended as guest speaker. Both paid tribute to Mr Claude Allen the local MP for his untiring effort. Also attending were State politicians Messrs Gilfillan & Geddes, Mr & Mrs Allen, Mrs Goldsworthy & Mrs Daniel. Mrs Daniel is the Chairman of the LCL Women’s Council. Elected were: President, Mrs Ron Rollins; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames R. Pearse & W. Klem; Secretary, Mrs N. Finch & Treasurer, Mrs T. Padbury. Mr Goldsworthy spoke on Education, focussing on the Karmel Report.

Mintaro School will celebrate its centenary on Sunday 24 September.

The Copper Festival Committee is conducting a Burra Car Lottery. Tickets are $1 and are now available. The 1st prize is a T.C. Cortina L 1600 cc 4-door sedan valued at $2,595.

Burra Burra DC, July meeting.

Mr R.J. Jeffery was re-elected Chairman.

From 15 July admission for children attending Burra Pictures will extend to all those attending school to the end of secondary school.

Aberdeen Oval: the Council is still unhappy about the behaviour of some attending the football there. They are still driving across the oval. There have also been reports of young drivers doing wheelies on the oval surface.

The tender of G.R. Pearce for alterations to the Council Office has been accepted and work has begun and should be completed before the Copper Festival.

94, 26, 11 July 1972, page 3

Burra Rural Youth held its AGM on 3 July. Retiring President Don Griffen reported on the year. Elected were: President, Andrew Thomas; Vice-President, Michael Bradley; Secretary, Kathy Gebhardt & Treasurer, Heather Keane.

Netball

‘A’ Grade Clare North 52 defeated Burra 28

‘B’ Grade Leighton 56 defeated Burra 20

‘C’ Grade Burra defeated Clare North

‘D’ Grade Clare North 34 defeated Burra 27

‘E’ Grade Burra 28 defeated Leighton 19

Jennison’s in Commercial Street is being remodelled. The motor showroom will have double the space and at the end there will be a covered bay for tyre changing etc. D.T. Jacka & Co. have the contract.

Burra Motor Co. is having a new 3,000 gallon petrol tank installed – presumably to accommodate the new BP supermix, coming soon.

Birth. To Mr & Mrs Muldoon of Frances Police Station, at Naracoorte on 7 July, a son, Anton Nicholas Roger.

Birth. To Kath & Bruce Christie at Naracoorte on Saturday, a daughter, Fiona Evonne.

Obituary. Ashley Cecil Woodgate of Booborowie died 5 July aged 86.

[Born Cecil Ashley Herbert Hooker Woodgate 2 February 1886 Terowie: died Ashley Cecil Herbert Hooker Woodgate at Nuriootpa, residence Booborowie.]

An Earth Tremor was felt at Emu Downs on Wednesday at about 9 a.m.

94, 26, 11 July 1972, page 5

Burra CWA. The Annual Report of the secretary Mrs Wilf Nankivell reports a membership of 54 and average attendance of 24. Details are given in 11⁄3 columns.

94, 26, 11 July 1972, page 6

Accident. At 4.40 p.m. on Tuesday a car driven by Mrs L.J. Verrall and one driven by Mrs E. Carpenter collided at the corner of Stock and Chapel Streets. Damage was estimated at c. $300, but no one was injured.

Accident. On Wednesday at 12.10 a.m. a car driven by Mr T.N. Maxted overturned about six miles north of Burra on the Mt Bryan road. Damage was estimated at c. $500.

Accident. At 1.15 p.m. on Thursday a car driven by P.W. Hirschausen collided with one driven by R.G. Gill at the corner of Helen Terrace and Morehead Street. Damage was estimated at c. $50.

94, 27, 18 July 1972, page 1

Barkers of Baldina Aged Cottage Homes. A grant of $47,600 has been approved on the estimated cost of $86, 450. Work will now start on the one double and eight single self-contained units. The tender of D.T. Jacka & Co. has been accepted.

Burra Methodist Circuit Family Dinner was held at the Redruth Memorial Hall on Saturday night. Families attended from Farrell Flat, Mt Bryan, Willalo, Booborowie, Iron Mine and Booborowie.

Weather. In the last week showers and light rain delivered 70-100 points across the agricultural areas of the district.

Accident. A Torana driven by A. Couzner overturned at about 8 p.m. on Thursday at the Koonoona turn-off just west of Burra. Damage was estimated at $200.

Netball. Mid North

‘B2’ Grade Aberdeen v. Robertstown was abandoned due to rain.

‘C1’ Grade Robertstown 13 defeated Aberdeen 8

Aberdeen Football Club Women’s Auxiliary held its AGM and elected: President, Mrs S. Scroop; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames Wall & D. Robinson; Secretary, Mrs I. Hirschausen & Assistant Secretary, Mrs T. Rule.

Catering in the year gave a profit of $638-18 from a party and weddings, plus $499.24 from ‘at home’ matches. The Auxiliary was thus able to give $650 to the Management Committee and $102 to the Basketball Club. President Florrie Scroop was made a life member of the club at the opening of the new recreation room. [Details in 2⁄3 column.]

Burra North Red Cross held its AGM in the Aberdeen Football Club Rooms on Wednesday 5 July. During the year $400 was sent to the Red Cross March Appeal. Elected: Patroness, Mrs G.C. Heinrich; President, Mrs I. Hirschausen; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames M. Cox & R. Thamm; Secretary, Mrs R.M. Jennison; Assistant Secretary, Mrs E. Heinrich; Treasurer, Mrs S. Scroop.
