94, 29, 1 Aug. 1972, page 1

The rebuilding of Peacock’s Chimney.

[Photo of Burra Mine from the hill above the round chimney looking north past the round crusher chimney to the silos and beyond.]

In the early stages it was plain sailing. The chimney was quickly dismantled and moved to the new site at the Mine entrance. The courses were laid out and re-erection went smoothly as each course had been marked.

Difficulties began when the brick section was reached. The old bricks proved unsuitable, having weathered too much in 100 years and other second-hand bricks had to be found. The wet and windy weather intervened and then new bricklayers had to be found. The original bricklayers found they could not build a tapered chimney and various others tried. Finally two finished the job, but they had almost performed the impossible by squaring the circle. Though it did not look too bad from a distance, it was decided it was unacceptable and unfair both on the subscribers and the memory of the old Cornish masons. It was taken down. After a long search Mr Colin Barron of Barron & Sons offered to complete it, but a week later, due to illness in the family, he had to withdraw.

Mr Bob O’Neill of O’ Neill & Clayton Ltd came to the rescue – recommended by Adelaide architect Mr Steve Gilbert. Mr O’ Neill was President of the Master Builders’ Association for some years and a foundation member of the National Trust. He had specialised in the reconstruction of historic buildings, including the restoration of Charles Sturt’s cottage at the Grange.

Cornish masons were in the habit of building their chimney stacks from the scaffolding inside the chimney and this was the method that had been followed on the first attempt at rebuilding Peacock’s Chimney. Lack of experience resulted in failure, particularly at the top where the brickwork is stepped out (corbelling).

Mr O’Neill decided to use scaffolding on the outside. This is more expensive, but use of volunteers has helped to contain costs. The cost of hiring and erecting the scaffolding without volunteer labour would have been $950. This cost has been halved. Now the work has been re-commenced and the Governor will open the completed chimney at the Copper Festival.

Burra Burra DC has adopted a new assessment. The valuation of 1971 is $5,923,370; a drop from $7,328,700. The previous rate of 0.9c in the dollar will have to rise to 1.1c in the dollar to maintain the income of $65, 958. The new rate will be discussed at Monday’s Council meeting.

Due to a strike of refinery maintenance workers the Local Government Department stopped Council plants from operating.

94, 30, 8 Aug. 1972, page 1

Metric Temperature measurement will be introduced on 1 September when measurement of temperature in degrees Fahrenheit will give way to degrees Celsius.

Apex. A photo is printed of Apexians Grant Goode, Jeff Hirschausen, Gordon Wooton, Gino Santella & Phillip Ogden cutting wood for delivery to needy people in Burra. [Though six men are shown.]Next Wednesday at a dinner at the Burra Hotel President Terry Rule will hand over the presidency to Jeff Hirschausen.

94, 30, 8 Aug. 1972, pages 1 & 4

Football. The voting for the Mail Medal was held at Booborowie last Saturday night. Winner of the Mail Medal for 1972 was Ian Roberts of Blyth. He also won the Mobil Trophy.

As runner-up Paul McCarthy of Clare South won the Burra Record Trophy.

94, 30, 8 Aug. 1972, pages 1 & 8

Local Government in Burra. Researched by Ian Auhl.

From an article in the Register 11 May 1872.

A pleasing sign of improvement in Kooringa is that the Burra Mining Co. is beginning to repair its numerous cottages, and make little additions to roads and footpaths. The town has been in their hands for more than twenty years and signs of the amount spent on it by the landlords, who are supposed to have drawn rent from every house until recently, are few and far between. The tenants have been equally indifferent to appearances and as a result Kooringa has been shabby and many of its houses, if such they can be called, are among the most squalid in the British Empire.

In the main street one sees business places paintless and with stucco off their fronts, a stable roof held on by stones to prevent it blowing away, signboards unreadable owing to the latest coat sweating off and old lettering showing through. A blacksmith’s wooden shop that has not stood upright in the last ten years and the words ‘Letterbox’ visible on a house that was used as a Post Office 22 years ago. With all this, a stranger is surprised to learn the tradesmen are well to do. There are a few exceptions and of late considerable improvement has taken place in a few instances. One large drapery firm has put in new windows and repainted its front. Other houses of business have undergone a little repair and last week the Mining Co. began covering their row of cottages in Market Square with iron and renovating the police cottage walls.

With this and Mr Banks’ new assembly room and his public house undergoing outside improvements the square would present a decent improvement if the ginger beer factory had a new face. But a stroll among houses at the back of the commercial quarter has a depressing effect. Ruins present themselves everywhere. There are cottages without doors and windows and the roofs are often dilapidated. Company houses have daubed and dirty walls and paint is either unknown or ancient. The Wesleyan Mission House and Chapel are surrounded by a substantial stone wall. St Mary’s Church has recently been thoroughly repainted inside and out, as has the Bible Christian Chapel and a few residences of the tradesmen, but in other directions all is in desolation.

The company has begun removing a few old walls and filling in the little creeks on the roadways with old mortar and plaster and is making a kind of road from the paddock towards the cemetery. It is to be hoped more refurbishment will go on and that Kooringa, on entering upon a new career of prosperity, will ‘be relieved from the disgrace of being styled, as it has been, the shabbiest town in the Australias.’

From an article in the Register 2 July 1872.

The District Council movement has died again.

The first agitators, disgusted with the conduct of some others, have stopped their efforts.

This is to be lamented because local government would greatly improve the town. Goats and pigs roam at ease in the streets, much to the annoyance of people who have formed gardens. The roads are miserable.

From an article in the Register 26 August 1872.

A meeting has been held at Banks’ Assembly Rooms in Kooringa to consider the desirability of forming a District Council. Perhaps in no part of South Australia are the roads outside an important town in such a deplorable state as these. Before the land became settled and fenced, traffic could generally be carried on by travellers striking out on fresh tracks when the old ones became too cut up. Now fences preclude such a course and a Council for the repair of highways is imperative.

Captain Killicoat JP presided over a meeting of about 30 people. Mr A. King advocated a District Council extending north to the southern half of the Hundred of Kingston and south to the Hundred of Apoinga; an area of some 80,000 acres. Mr J.R. Stephens proposed a Council be formed of such an area.

Mr Ridgway thought this included too much useless country and wanted the Council confined to the township.

Mr O. Harvey was in favour of the original proposition.

Mr J.R. Stephens thought the area would have to be divided into wards.

Mr Moody was glad to see such energy and action and sought to nominate Councillors and Auditors.

The district was divided into North, South, Redruth and Kooringa Wards with five Councillors; one in each of the first three wards named and two in the last. Chosen as Councillors were:

North Ward Mr J. Dunstan Sen.

South Ward Mr McCullock [sic] JP

Redruth Ward Captain Killicoat JP

Kooringa Ward Mr J. Drew JP

Mr H. Dawson

Auditors Messrs G.V. Goodhart JP and W.H. Rosman

Note by Ian Auhl:

It has been stated that the population of Burra in 1850 was 20,000. This is incorrect. The combined population of Redruth, Aberdeen and Kooringa was a little over 4,500 and 1003 men and boys were employed at the Burra Mine. By 1861 the population of the three towns was 4,347. The SA Mining Association then employed 1,208 men and the population of the County of Burra was 5,483 with 15,856 acres under cultivation. By 1871 the population of the three towns had fallen to 3,401 and the cultivated area had increased to 65, 215 acres.

94, 31, 15 Aug. 1972, page 1

Burra Burra DC declares a new rate.

The assessment dropped from $7,328,700 to $5,923,370.

The anticipated rate income will be $82,928 with the General Rate set at 1.4c in the dollar.

Differential Rates:

Booborowie Township 10c

Farrell Flat 10c

Hanson 5c

Burra 10c

Weather. The last week has seen wind, rain, hail and snow. Wednesday brought light rain of 20-30 points.

Thursday saw morning rain before a cold change. At about 4 p.m. just south of Burra a strip of country had a very heavy fall of hail. Hallett had a fairly heavy snowfall at about 7.30 p.m. and at Burra snow fell accompanied by rain.

94, 31, 15 Aug. 1972, page 2

Football. North Eastern League 2nd Semi-Final

‘A’ Grade Booborowie-Hallett 18.17 defeated Clare South 9.15

94, 31, 15 Aug. 1972, page 3

Burra Football Club Cabaret drew a big crowd with over $700 taken at the door. A final profit of over $300 is expected.

Paxton Square Cottages have received a grant of $5,000 under the Rural Unemployment Scheme. The fronts will be whitewashed, then new guttering and if finance permits the painting of the roof. Four men are working on this project and eight others are employed under the scheme in putting down cement kerbing and water tables elsewhere.

A.L. Clode & Sons’ new funeral parlour is nearing completion.

Jennison’s Showroom Extensions are progressing.

Burra Burra DC. The extensions at the Council Office have begun.

Peacock’s Chimney. The work has been hampered by high winds and rain.

94, 31, 15 Aug. 1972, pages 3 & 6 gutter

Birth. To Jean & Jackie Kleinig of Hanson at Burra on 10 August, a son, Andrew Glenn.

Birth. To Cathy & John Fahey of Hallett 3 August, a daughter, Bernadine Marie.

94, 31, 15 Aug. 1972, page 6

A meeting of delegates 7 August at Saddleworth resolved among many other things to continue discussions with the North Eastern League concerning the amalgamation of the two leagues.

94, 32, 22 Aug. 1972, page 1

Young Liberals held a meeting last Friday at which the guest speaker was Hon. C.R. (Bert) Kelly MHR Member for the Federal Seat of Wakefield. The meeting was at the Taminga Hotel in Clare.

Weather. With a further 85 points for the week, Burra’s rainfall for August is 261 points – 27 points above average – though the annual total is so far 92 below average at 1,101 points.

Bruce Stockman writes:

The new rate struck by the Council will give an income of $82,928 compared with $65,958 previously. The reason for this 25% increase is said to be ‘to maintain the present plant and staff operations.

What increased amount is to be spent on maintaining present plant; and why?

What increase in wages is anticipated?

What increase in salaries is expected?

When will Council publish the proposed budget for the coming year?

Mt Bryan CWA’s 26th birthday is reported in 1⁄2 column.

Burra High School held its Annual Ball in the Burra Town Hall on Friday with door takings of c. $400 and a profit of c. $300 is expected. Kevin Kleinig was MC, the Talisman Band provided the music and Mr Claude Allen MP and Mrs Allen attended.

A Spinning & Weaving Workshop was held at Burra on Saturday 12 August drew 50 students from as far away as Kadina and Olary Station. It was run by P. Munro with three assistants from Adelaide for the Mid North Adult Education Centre. [Photo of Mrs Helen Bruce, Mrs T. Padbury & Mrs M. Perry at the event.]

Burra Hospital. Cabinet has approved a $240,000 contract for improvements to the Burra Hospital. It has gone to Kennett Bros Pty Ltd of Adelaide and involves changes to the Maternity Wing to provide increased accommodation, upgrading the kitchen and general replanning so the hospital operates on the one level instead of the present three levels.

94, 33, 29 Aug. 1972, pages 1 & 4

Johnny Green: research by Ian Auhl

Johnny Green, the silent miner and mascot of the old Burra Burra Miners, has risen again – this time to the top of the resited Peacock’s Chimney. Once again he is holding aloft his pick and gad at the mine entrance. Johnny has been around the mine for more than 120 years. Early paintings and photographs show he has always been the same, holding aloft his emblems on some high point of a mine building. But he has moved around and his bodywork has changed. The first Johnny Green was made of wood, as a hastily constructed mascot erected on the top of the wooden shears on Roach’s Pump House on the day it was completed in 1848 and it was still there in 1855 when he was seen by a reporter from the Observer in March. He was said then to be in his old place, though the engine had been removed.

The second Johnny Green was made of iron and is still in existence, its limbs now riveted together since New Year Vandals tumbled it from its pole at the mine entrance a few years ago. He is having a well-earned rest in the jinker shed. When Schneider’s Engine House was completed in 1852 to house the new engine imported from Cornwall, Johnny was placed on the winding wheel platform over the shaft and an 1857 painting by [William] Bentley shows him there. On approaching the Mine, wrote a visitor, the first object that strikes the eye is Schneider’s Engine House. The engine works at seven strokes a minute, each time raising 136 gallons of water. The completion of an engine house and chimney stack generally called for celebrations. Masons and miners sometimes celebrated completion by drinking a barrel of ale on top. (The author of this article had to settle for a stubby of beer when he went ‘up top’ on Saturday.)

With the starting of the engine came the christening of the building with brass band, speeches and champagne. Johnny Green was there in 1852 to watch over the ‘christening’ of Schneider’s Pump House. The Directors came from Adelaide. Henry Ayers, Secretary of the SA Mining Association, threw a bottle of champagne at the beam and the Directors followed suit.

In 1858 when Morphett’s Engine House was completed the miners shifted their mascot to the poppet-head platform and it stayed there for the next 67 years, presiding over the death of the Mine in 1877.

During the Back to Burra week in 1925 an old miner, John Beale, returned for another look at Johnny Green. He had been the ‘roper’ and for many years had stood by the iron figure of the miner on the high platform of Morphett’s Shaft.

In 1929 Frank Treloar in his 77th year published his reminiscences of the Mine in the Burra Record and wrote of Johnny Green, that he had stood silently on top of the pump house until a fire a few years ago caused his downfall. He was carefully preserved and Mr Treloar was pleased then he learned Councillors intended to have the figure re-erected in a suitable position. Neither Frank Treloar nor anyone else tells us if there was ever a real ‘Johnny Green’ among the miners.

[The report of the fire from the Burra Record in December 1925 is then reprinted. The fire referred to occurred on Saturday morning 5 December 1925.]

At about 11 a.m. smoke was seen coming from the top storey of the small engine house close to Morphett’s Shaft and later grass nearby was also noticed alight. Residents in the area beat out the grass fire, but not realising how serious the fire was, they failed to raise the alarm and tried to put it out themselves. Between 2 and 3 p.m. it has assumed such proportions that fighting it was out of the question and soon the fire spread to the big engine house over Morphett’s Shaft. The woodwork of immense proportions burnt like matches. Towards midnight quite a crowd collected to see the blazing poppets fall, which supported the platform on which the big pulley wheel was fixed, used when the mine was working, for drawing ore up the shaft. On this also stood the life-sized figure of a miner holding a round stone hammer and chisel. This figure had always been revered by the miners and even the present generation felt regrets when it, in company with the wheel, crashed to the ground. The wheel, five feet in diameter and at white heat, broke, but the figure was not badly damaged. Morphett’s Shaft is heavily timbered and is now burning fiercely. On Saturday night the sight was very beautiful with flames leaping to a great height. On Sunday hundreds gathered to see the large columns of smoke ascending from Morphett’s Shaft and the beam timber could be heard falling away and crashing into the water below.

The property belongs to Messrs A.J. & P.A. McBride of Adelaide.

Police are investigating, but it is generally alleged the fire was caused by some lads smoking out pigeons, of which a large number live in these buildings. Many old miners say it could be weeks before the fire burns itself out.

The following week the paper apologised for saying the figure carried a hammer and chisel. It was in fact a pick and miner’s gad. The head had a miner’s hat and place for a candle in front.

At the December meeting of the Town Council it was decided to approach Messrs A.J. & P.A. McBride Ltd and request them to present to the town the effigy of the miner brought to the ground in the recent fire.

Johnny eventually found himself on top of a pole at the mine entrance, where he remained until vandals cut him down in 1967. The second Johnny Green was too broken to be given another lease of life and was pensioned off to the jinker enclosure while his ‘ghost’ still hovers above. It is appropriate that the new Johnny Green was fashioned and presented to the Burra National Trust by the new mine owners Samin Ltd.

[See the report of the fire XXXXVII, 49, 16 Dec. 1925, page 3. The report in the paper seems to indicate that the fire occurred on 12 December, but the boys who started it appeared in court on 10 December, which would seem to make the date of the fire Saturday 5 December rather than Saturday 12 December. In XXXXVII, 49, 16 Dec. 1925, page 3 the court case is also reported. This reveals that the boys were attempting to smoke out rabbits (not pigeons) from under the floor of the engine house near Morphett’s Engine House.]

94, 33, 29 Aug. 1972, page 3

Burra Mine. A trip to the top of Peacock’s Chimney on Saturday made my [Mary Woollacott’s] day. The tradition of drinking a barrel of ale on top of a completed building was honoured in a modified way when a couple of the men who also made the ascent, downed two stubbies instead. There are photos of the above as proof. Abut a dozen folk (including some youngsters) made the ascent before the scaffolding was dismantled.

94, 34, 5 Sep. 1972, page 1

Barkers of Baldina Cottage Homes. The foundations were completed last week.

94, 34, 5 Sep. 1972, pages 1 & 8

Burra Burra Hospital Inc. held its AGM last Thursday night. The Board remains unchanged. Chairman R.K. Pearse’s report: the 95th Annual Report.

Financial. With a surplus of $21,582-90 our credit balance stands at $48,266 plus $25,000 invested. The only major increase in costs has been $8,909 in wages. There are now 15 full-time nursing staff and 4 part-time. The daily average cost per patient rose by $2.26 to $14.08 and the daily average of patients was 19.8. 50 babies were born at the hospital.

Improvements’ It had been hoped that improvements forecast last year would be a reality. Plans and specifications have been approved and tenders called. Estimates were submitted to the Hospitals Department and we await their approval. The estimated cost of the project is $240,000. We will be able to finance this from hospital finances and will not have a public appeal. The only major improvements this year have been the enclosing of the ambulance entrance and replacing twenty-one beds and mattresses for $3,100. Finance permitting we will paint the exterior this year. The remaining rooms of the Nurses Quarters have been re-painted and new curtains hung.

Cropping Program. No Cropping was undertaken this year due to the late season.

Ladies’ Auxiliary. This continues to give valuable assistance with keeping the hospital linen in order and by provision of jams and preserves.

Burra & District Fund Raising Committee. This year a cheque for $1,020 was donated. The new building will require $16,000 worth of new equipment so any money raised will be used in that direction.

Staff. Matron Fyfe and the Secretary-Manager Mr L. Packer have continued their excellent service. Matron has been ably assisted by Sisters Byles, Ward, Wright, Brown, McDonald, Moller, Lucas & Carmody during the year and by Sisters Parker and Broad on staff at present as well as a very willing bans of nurses. Sister Good has ably filled the role of Tutor Sister. The domestic staff and handy-man have carried out their duties diligently.

Meals on Wheels is proving to be one of the most worthwhile operations commenced in the district for some time.

[Various other people and Board members are then thanked.]

I regret the passing of Mr Matt Carmody, a Board Member for eleven years, and welcome Mr Harry Rich to the Board.

94, 34, 5 Sep. 1972, page 6

Aberdeen Tennis Club held its AGM on 23 August. President Dennis O’Reilly welcomed members. For the 1971-72 season the club fielded two ‘A’ teams, three ‘B’ teams and one junior team in the Burra Tennis Association. All three grades played in the grand finals.

‘A’ Grade White won their grand final.

‘B’ Grade Purple won their grand final.

The junior team went down to Kooringa in their grand final.

The year was financially successful although there have been expenses in the resurfacing of No. 5 court and the top dressing of No. 2. Another expense was the erection of the pillars and the plaque honouring 30 years’ service to the club of Mr & Mrs S. Scroop.

94, 35, 12 Sep. 1972, page 1

Accidents. A car rolled over on the Copperhouse Road at 3.10 p.m. Wednesday. A second car rolled over at almost the same place an hour later. The first was owned and driven by Mr Norman Mitchell of Richmond, who sustained some minor lacerations and bruising as did his passenger Alfred Roberts, also from Richmond. Both were treated at Burra Hospital. The car was a write-off.

Spalding Masonic Lodge’s 50th anniversary celebrations are reported.

Obituary. Mrs Mary Josephine Dare died recently in Adelaide. She was born at Mt Bryan East; the eldest in the family of the late Mr & Mrs W.H. Quinn. Her husband, Mr George Dare, died some 5 years ago. They had lived in the Mt Bryan District until moving to Adelaide in the 1950s.

[Born 4 April 1894 Mt Bryan East: died 24 August 1972 St Peters.]

94, 35, 12 Sep. 1972, page 7

‘Irate School Leaver’ writes:

‘There are at least a dozen or more girls who will be leaving school and would like to gain experience in Burra before going to a more challenging job in Adelaide. Why then can’t they find positions in their own home town? I put this question to all employers – Why do you prefer married women to single girls?’

‘The majority of married women working have families and husbands who can ably support their families, why then should the women have to work?’

94, 36, 19 Sep. 1972, page 1

Burra Growth. Apart from the initial program of Samin Ltd there has been other growth in the past two years and at present more is taking place. The second stage of Samin’s mining operations is under way and this will quadruple production. Construction of Barkers of Baldina Cottage Homes has started at a cost of $102,000. Additions and redevelopment at the hospital will give a new maternity section, kitchen and more private and shared rooms at a cost of $240,000. Private and business works underway or just completed are worth c. $30,000.

Hotels in the town, through the addition of new toilets and other improvements have spent in excess of $25,000. New stock saleyards have been erected and building of private homes has amounted to over $40,000. In the 1970-71 period there was the housing project worth over $120,000 and the new Police Station was valued at $30,000. The town is fast becoming known for its unique historic attractions and tourism is growing.

Adelaide Wool Sales, 12-14 September. The highest district prices went to Willogoleche Proprietors of Hallett at 162c. [Other local district prices are printed.]

Mr L. Moore of the Savings Bank of SA has been transferred to Loxton and his replacement as manager will be Mr Bob Buckton, who transfers from Saddleworth where both he and his wife were heavily involved in civic affairs.

[Photo of Mr Moore.]

94, 36, 19 Sep. 1972, page 5

Burra Retail Traders’ Association responds to ‘Irate School Leaver’.

One reason for employing married women is given in Irate’s own letter: she wants experience before going on to Adelaide. It costs money to train employees, who frequently leave before they are of value to an employer. Most local businessmen who employ a percentage of married women do so where a senior is needed to train juniors, or to ensure continuity of employment, or where the married woman joined their staff whilst single. Many local people do not support local business and this does not allow them to grow and employ more staff. The town and district is only as strong as the support it gets. Burra is on the threshold of a great future due to tourism and mining. Unfortunately there are a few in the district who cannot see the advantages of tourism to the whole district, namely that it brings in many people who demand better shops, cafés, hotels, roads, parks and sporting facilities etc. that are also then enjoyed by locals. It creates more jobs for more people and has a snowballing effect. The businessmen of Burra sympathise with school leavers who desire employment here, but hope they will not become ‘knockers’ of the town and district.

D.T. Wedding writes in support of the Booborowie Branch of the United Farmers & Graziers’ Association’s call for the Burra Burra DC to reconsider the rate of 1.4c in the dollar, in favour of a return to an income level similar to the 1971-72 financial year.

94, 36, 19 Sep. 1972, page 6

Notice. A public meeting is to be held in the Booborowie Memorial Hall on Monday 25 September. It is sponsored by the United Farmers & Graziers’ Association, Booborowie Branch, to discuss the proposed increase of rates to 1.4c in the dollar and what action should be taken in response. The Councillors and District Clerk have been invited to attend.

Isolated Children’s Parents’ Association – North Eastern District of SA Branch was formed at Yunta 10 September, at a meeting convened by Mr Athol Tiver and elected: Chairman & Publicity Officer, Athol Tiver (Yunta); Vice-Chairman, Kim Afford (Olary) and Secretary, Keith Treloar (Olary). [Details in 3⁄4 column.]

94, 37, 26 Sep. 1972, page 1

Burra CWA conferred life membership on Mrs Rets Jennison at their meeting on 21 September. The Life Membership Badge and Citation were presented by Divisional President Mrs Aitken of Clare. Mrs Jennison has been a member for over 30 years, has been Branch President for four terms, served as Vice-President for many years and has been secretary several times, as well as being active in a number of other roles.

Accident. A car driven by Lester W. Gare turned over on the eastern road just east of the Deep Creek causeway on Saturday at 3.10 p.m. A passenger, Mr Steven N. Fuller of Burra, suffered internal injuries and a broken arm. The driver suffered bruising.

Theft. Petrol was ‘milked’ from a truck, Land Rover and a tractor at The Gap over last Saturday night and a battery charger and hydraulic jack were also taken. Tools were also stolen from E.S. Brown & Son west of Burra.

Burra Football Club held a wind-up dinner at the Burra Town Hall on Friday night. Presentations were made.

Best and Fairest Awards:

94, 37, 26 Sep. 1972, page 6

Obituary. Stella Alice Humphrys died suddenly 23 September at Medindie Gardens aged 84. She was the wife of Roy W. Humphrys of East St Burra and mother of Gwen, Merv, Margaret, Colin, Ruth & Barbara. There are 11 grandchildren and 2 great grandsons. [Born Stella Alice Blunt 27 July 1888 Riverton.]

94, 38, 3 Oct. 1972, page 1

Barker of Baldina Cottage Homes

Brickwork commenced this week and application forms are available from the secretary-manager Mr L.H. Packer at the Hospital. The units are expected to be available for occupancy early in April. If there are sufficient applications they will be decided on 16 November at the next meeting of the committee. If applications exceed units preference will be given to people with local residence or association with the district. The double and single rooms will be air conditioned with standard built-in furniture, floor coverings, beds, bedspreads, mattresses and pillows and with refrigerator, washing machine, electric range and wall heater. Double units will cost $12 per week and single units $8. The board pays rates, taxes and insurance and keeps the homes in reasonable repair. Occupants are responsible for telephones, TV and electrical costs.

Obituary. Mr ‘Joe’ Lloyd apparently suffered a heart attack at about 8 a.m. Saturday while driving west between the ‘Field’ and ‘Tiver’ properties in the Hundred of Hanson. The car ran off the road, knocked down 72 ft of fencing and came to rest against some rocks after the motor stalled. Mr Lloyd was discovered by a passing motorist. Police and Dr L.G. Miller attended. The car was hardly damaged. [Page 3 adds that he was aged 66.]

[Joseph Lloyd born 23 September 1906 Hundred of Morgan: died 30 September 1972 near Burra, residence Burra.]

Public Meeting at Booborowie Memorial Hall 25 September. The meeting discussed the Burra Burra DC’s decision to declare a rate of 1.4c in the dollar. 63 ratepayers attended. The District Council was represented by its Chairman, six Councillors, the District Clerk and the Overseer.

Mr D. Wedding was elected Chairman of the meeting. After discussion the meeting resolved:

The meeting requests the Council to organise its affairs this year to enable a reduction in rates next year.

This meeting appoints a deputation through our local MP to the Minister of Roads and our local Federal Member in an effort to achieve an increase in grants to the Burra Burra DC.

Legal advice was that nothing could be done about the increase in the rate from 0.9 to 1.4 cents in the dollar.

94, 38, 3 Oct. 1972, pages 1 & 8

A Trip to Kooringa in 1850. Reprinted from the Register in 1850.

An SA colonist who has not visited Burra has neglected to inspect a marvel. It is a triumph of co-operative enterprise, liberality and economy, as credible to its directors as it is profitable to its owners and beneficial to the colony. I enquired as to the most expeditious and cheapest mode of visiting Burra Burra. A seat was suggested in the travelling chariot with the Directors on one of their periodic visits to the Mine. Not knowing the Directors and not wishing to wait for such a grand occasion, I took a seat in the mail cart, a van-shaped vehicle covered with canvas and capable of containing about ten passengers. The proprietor, whose easy manner put everyone in good humour, managed to stow twelve in it. Even an old lady whose bonnet box was cruelly crushed declared that no one could be angry with Mr Chambers. He went at a brisk pace through Hindmarsh, descending gullies and scaling banks with great confidence. When conversation began when we got fairly on the lower road, each assured the rest that the dust was intolerable. One of the passengers said he had just returned from California, of which he gave a graphic account. He had saved a good sum at the Burra Burra and wishing to try his fortune in exchanging copper for gold, set off for San Francisco. His degree of success could be judged from his wasted face and squalid appearance. [His story then continues for several paragraphs.]

We left Adelaide at c. 3.30 p.m. and reached Gawler Town at about 7 p.m. We put up at the Old Spot where Mr Schmidt maintained the reputation of the place established by its founder, Mr Calton. The next morning the group divided. The Kapunda passengers went on in a spring cart. Burra Burra passengers continued in a spring cart without any covering. The horses too were greatly inferior and had but one shoe among the four of them and one with a swollen leg and the others with worn hoofs, so that it was with great difficulty they were induced to move at all. On arrival at She Oak Log there were no fresh horses ready and the mail was handed over to the driver of the spring cart, which could proceed much faster. Progress to Kapunda was slow and one of the passengers had often to alight to flog the crippled horse, but eventually the driver was compelled to set it free – which had he done it at first would have saved much time.

We breakfasted at Ferrant’s just on entering Kapunda where everything was in good order and readiness, despite our very delayed arrival. Newcomers of the roughest class joined the vehicle here and soon made a seat in the mail cart a very unenviable position. One of the men was a fine specimen of the ‘old colonial bore’, who insisted on recounting his hair-raising adventures. He was, however, eclipsed by the arrival of an Irish wench whose gross language and forward behaviour is beyond description. The coarse behaviour and conversation continued till we reached the Burra Hotel.

At the Burra Hotel it was Saturday night and the part set aside for the sale of strong drink was full of people in every condition from sober through exhilarated and joyous to quarrelsome and singing and crying drunk. Germans were singing a chorus in one corner and Welsh smelters were listening to a Celtic solo in another. Cornish miners, English and Scotch mechanics and Irish labourers all combined to swell the mighty discord.

In contrast the hotel rooms were spacious, cool and well-furnished apartments, where the din of voices was softened by distance. The waiter glided noiselessly about and I enjoyed a hearty dinner and went out for a moonlight view of Kooringa. It differed in no respect from any other thriving town. There were a number of large shops and a great concourse of people marketing in a quiet and orderly fashion. I did not see one policeman, nor any occasion for one.

(Note [presumably by Ian Auhl]: the towns of Redruth and Aberdeen had only been laid out in August 1849, which explains why the writer does not refer to them. The population of Kooringa including the dugouts was 4,300 in 1850.)

The next day was Sunday and the Sabbath was strictly observed. Besides the [Anglican] Church there were chapels for the Wesleyans, Independents and Primitive Methodists and the Roman Catholics and divine service in a private house.

There are several streets and the houses are generally well built. In some places are rows of substantial stone cottages built by the company. The chimneys of one of them having as much masonry as would suffice for two of the flimsy building society cottages which disgrace the streets of Adelaide. There seems to be an abundance of good stone in Kooringa, which the inhabitants are putting to good use.

One of Kooringa’s most singular features is the subterranean habitations of ‘The Creek’. For a distance of more than two miles the banks of a ravine are perforated with vaulted chambers in which a populous are living in apparent health and comfort. From above those dwellings (to which some future etymologist, with the accuracy characteristic of his study, will trace the name of Burra (Burrow)), present a squalid, but exceedingly diversified and picturesque appearance. Some are quite cottage-like in their exterior, having stone fronts, well proportioned doors and windows, with verandahs and fences guarding the approach. In those cases the earth is cut away to give a perpendicular front and that secures a sort of terrace before the door. But in many instances there is merely a horizontal cut running far enough into the bank to gain a height for an approach to a door with a similar cut of smaller proportions for a window and the rest of the house is a perforation of the bank continued from these apertures. In most cases the chimney is level with the surface, or raised a foot or two by a pile of a few stones or partially embedding a headless flour or ale cask. Accidents sometimes happen when night walkers fall down the chimneys. Their arms generally arrest their descent, but they remain caught until rescued by an occupant from below, either furious or friendly as the case may be.

On Monday I visited the Mine, which is situated on the side of a hill. A considerable stream of water flows down the acclivity fed by the steam engine, which works incessantly day and night raising nearly 800 gallons of water every minute. Diverted into suitable channels, it carries on the work of washing ore and an immense space is occupied by heaps of rich green and blue ore in every stage of preparation, from the immense masses sent up by the miners to be washed and pulverised and carefully packed into canvas bags for removal by bullock drays to the port, or to the smelting works of the Patent Copper Co. on the other side of the creek. Under extensive sheds men and boys of all sizes carry on the operation of ore crushing etc.

The revolving whims and ceaseless stroke of the immense pump excited at once a dread and uneasy desire to visit the workings underground. Introduced by Captain Roach to the Captain’s Changing Room, I was equipped with a candle in one hand and a piece of tempered clay in the other. I followed the guide to whose care Captain Roach assigned me. We went under a shed near a whim and the top of a ladder protruded from a hole just large enough to allow a man to descend. My guide lit the candle and surrounded it with tempered clay, which he stuck against my hat and told me to follow him. We descended about 16 feet to a landing and then took another ladder and so on until we had reached 30 fathoms. My guide said we were in Peacock’s level and introduced me to several chambers where vast deposits of malachite and other rich ores had been found. In some places the level had been excavated through solid rock and in other parts the earth was soft and damp and there the passage was strongly timbered and boarded. No expense seemed to be spared in securing the comfort and safety of the workers. In places several inches of water, apparently pure and clear, flowed along the level, but above it was a boarded floor, along which the miners walked dry shod. I frequently came to men at work. Some said the ore they were getting was poor, but would be called very rich in England. Others were operating on large fronts of malachite. They said the mineral was richer and more abundant at the 40 fathom level, but as there was some feet of water in the level and the footway was wet, I had no desire to go deeper. In the 30 fathom level I met Captain Matthews, who greeted me courteously and led me to several most remarkable places. On emerging into the light of day I returned to the Captain’s Change Room, where the kindness of Captain Roach allowed me to make a very needful toilet.

After taking leave of Captain Roach I walked towards the works of the Patent Copper Co., but the sight of the flowing furnaces on such a hot day quite evaporated my curiosity and I returned to the Burra Hotel just in time to be present at a public meeting of the inhabitants of Kooringa and the surrounding townships.

The meeting had been called to consider the propriety of demanding municipal institutions for the united townships, but in fact the propositions put did not mention this at all. I afterwards found that the words intimating this cause were inserted into the requisition calling the meeting to please the few who think with the Resident Magistrate that such is desirable, but the majority fear the expense of a corporation would more than outweigh its advantages and so avoided the subject.

Other matters observed:

There is a flourishing Oddfellows’ Lodge there of the Manchester Unity and it meets in a splendid room recently added to the Burra Hotel. It possesses a library of 1,000 volumes from which it lends books at a cheap rate to all who wish to avail themselves of such a service.

The people generally think residence in the creek unhealthy, and it is certain that fever prevails there occasionally. To me, however, the women and children appeared both numerous and healthy and on the Sunday I was in Kooringa it turned out a vast concourse of well-dressed persons who wound their way to different houses of worship. It is thought there is a population in the creek of about 1,000 and there are at least 200 houses there. The approaching census will give the correct numbers. The people complain of the want of a local court of full jurisdiction and are ashamed of the hovel in which their respected Magistrate disposes justice. There are fears that the engine pump of the mine will exhaust all the wells in the town – several having gone dry since it has been at work.

The return to Adelaide presented the same dust and delays for want of horses.

Note [Again presumably by Ian Auhl]: this three day journey to Burra in 1880 cost $2 plus overnight expenses at Gawler and Kapunda. The trip by Mail Cart went via Gawler, Sheoak Log, Kapunda, Tothill’s Creek, Apoinga, Emu Springs and Sod Hut. Hornsby’s hotel still stands at Apoinga. The Burra Hotel was later the Burra Hospital and the last of the old building was demolished in 1967.

94, 39, 10 Oct. 1972, page 1

Burra High School. Mr E.C. Allen MP asked the Minister of education for information concerning the new High School site and development in Burra. A new site was purchased about three years ago, but the Public Works Committee recently visited Burra and was unhappy about the site. Hon. Hugh Hudson said in reply that no decision had yet been made. Following a visit to Burra and consultation there, it had been agreed that acquiring additional land in the immediate proximity to the Primary School would allow both schools to be redeveloped on the existing site and this would offer advantages in the sharing of facilities. The representative bodies of the schools and the town endorsed this alternative plan. Public Building Department has been asked to prepare a sit plan showing future land requirements and the relationship of buildings to recreational grounds etc. This will involve lad acquisition and redesigned plans and inevitably delay the building program. Those involved accepted this because of the long term advantage. The program will proceed as rapidly as possible.

Adelaide Wool Sales. 3-5 October. [District prices were the best for 20 years and are printed.]

94, 39, 10 Oct. 1972, pages 1 & 3

Burra Copper Festival

Burra Show

The gate takings reflect the increased number of visitors. $1,075 compared with $655 last year. Door takings at the Ball in the Town Hall were $875 and for the teenage dance in the RSL Hall $165.

The Show was opened by the Governor of SA Sir Mark Oliphant in fine weather. Show President, Mr R. Mason, introduced the Governor, whose speech is printed.

The display of farm machinery and cars was much larger than usual.

Art attracted a great diversity of entries with a strong junior section.

Budgerigars attracted entries of varying standard.

Cookery was of high standard and the children’s section was very pleasing.

Flowers were a poorer standard than usual, but the children’s entries were good.

Goat entries were larger this year, but of varying quality, though the best were excellent.

Needlework was of a higher standard than usual.

Pigs were revived as a section this year and all the exhibits were good types.

The Sheep Section produced good commercial sheep in both the restricted and poll sections. The Champion Poll Ram was outstanding. Entry numbers should have been better.

In the strong wool section the ewes were much stronger than the rams.

In the medium wool sheep, ram numbers were low, but competition for ewes was good.

Vegetable entries were down in numbers due to the poor season, but of reasonably good quality.

Fleeces on display were commendable.

94, 39, 10 Oct. 1972, page 2

Copper Festival

Unveiling the Peacock Chimney Plaque

Burra people were staggered by the numbers present. Thousands of people gathered for the event. Gusty winds whipped round the small yellow curtain covering the plaque and around the long dresses, capes and bonnets of the ladies and young girls in nineteenth century costume. Men and boys in clothes of the miners added authenticity. A number of veteran cars and horse drawn vehicles added to the scene and the Police Band gave a martial flavour to the procession. After the unveiling the procession was reformed and followed the band back to Market Square where it played for the afternoon. At the chimney Sir Mark & Lady Oliphant were met by National Trust President, Mr G. O’Connor, who welcomed than and the large crowd. Mr O’Connor told the story of the reconstruction. They had not at first realised the size of the task, but that had been compensated for by the degree of satisfaction at its completion. During the resiting some of the massive stones had been broken and new ones had to be cut. The bricks had crumbled to dust and had to be replaced. The new brickwork had not quite the grace and charm of the old, but a century of Burra winters will mellow it. He called on Sir Mark to perform the ceremony.

[Sir Mark’s speech is printed.]

A vote of thanks was moved by Major General G.W. Symes, Vice-President of the National Trust of SA.

Art Display at the Bowling Club

This attracted a continual flow of visitors. The 750 catalogues were exhausted on Sunday. The wine and cheese tasting section catered for 800 on Sunday afternoon and evening until it too was exhausted.

Spinning & Weaving & Gemmology Display

This display at the school also attracted large numbers of visitors.

Burra Methodist Church

The building was packed on Sunday for the Anniversary Service. Mr Reg Harris on behalf of the Westbourne Park Church and other visitors gave a greeting. Mr Harris spent his early days in Burra and is a great grandson of William Woollacott, who brought the large boiler to the Mine on the jinker. Mr Lindsay Thomas, who spent all his life in Burra until recent years, returned and sang King All Glorious.

94, 40, 17 Oct. 1972, page 1

Burra Copper Festival

Gala Day (Monday). Photograph of Humphrey B. Bear.

Annual Collinsville Stud Ewe Sale

Bidding was keen and WA buyers dominated. Of 866 stud ewes on offer 808 were sold.

420 stud ewes averaged $16.10.

388 Ewe Lambs averaged $7.40.

[Other details are printed.]

Weather. Patchy rain in the week has aided crops. Burra received 82 points. District falls were typically 66 to 123 points, but falls to the east were much more variable: Kia Ora 94, Balah 26, Woolgangi 88, Braemar 130, Baldina 40 and The Gums 58.

Burra Bowls. The season opened on Sunday. President Darrell Field called on Jack Stephenson, President of the Mid North Association, to declare the greens open for play. Edgar Pietsch, Club Champion, sent down the first bowl after Pat Field, Associates Champion, had cast the jack.

94, 40, 17 Oct. 1972, page 6

Adelaide Glee Club Concert. Burra Town Hall 8 October. A really first class concert is reviewed in 1 column.

Burra Copper Festival

Gala Day

Pt Pirie Marching Girls gave two exhibitions.

The Constellation Model Flying Club gave demonstrations of radio controlled model aircraft. These planes are values at about $800. In windy conditions the acrobatic stunts were very impressive. They travelled at up to 80 m.p.h. down wind.

A parade of Hot Rod vehicles created interest.

Exhibition games by the SA Netball Association Under 16 Country Touring Team were played.

Eight members of the Adelaide Archery Club gave an amazing display of accuracy under testing wind conditions.

Keith Walker and Levi Hughes gave shearing demonstrations. Tom Rogers provided the sheep.

Boyd Tiver and Graham Day took flights over the town.

The animal nursery featured mothers and babies of various species. Gordon Webster & John Mitchell had constructed the cages. [Exhibits and their owners are listed.]

Humphrey B. Bear was well received by a large crowd surrounding the dais, despite being 15 to 20 minutes late on arrival.

The merry-go-round, donkey & pony rides, mini bikes & mini golf were all well patronised.

Refreshment supplies proved adequate.

94, 40, 17 Oct. 1972, page 7

Birth. To Sue & Philip Ogden of Leighton School House, at Ashford Hospital on Friday, a son, Richard Matthew.

Birth. To Elaine & Rick Price of Pt Pirie last Thursday, a son, Scott Richard.

Obituary. August Heinrich Rudolph (Rudi) Kakoschke died at Whyalla on Sunday aged 69. He was well known in this district. [Born 29 May 1903 Hundred of Linley: died 15 October 1972 Whyalla.]

Obituary. Mr John Dixon, formerly of Hanson, died at the weekend.

[Born John Amys Dixon 25 April 1894 Hanson: died 14 October 1972 Woodside, residence Hanson.]

Mrs Eliza Sampson of Dunbar Presbyterian Home Goodwood is 100. She was born Eliza Slate and lived with her widowed mother, brother and sisters in one of the Mine Cottages in Kooringa and attended the Burra Model School when Mr Caterer [sic: for Cater] was headmaster. Her late husband was Mr A.A. (Archie) Sampson, son of the late John Sampson of Kooringa, a former Mayor and Councillor of Burra. With her husband and family she moved from Burra to Broken Hill where they lived for many years. One of her childhood memories is when in the company of other youngsters she visited Aborigines who were living in the dugouts in the Mine Region after it had closed.

Kooringa Masonic Lodge installed Lynden Beare as Worshipful Master last Thursday and after the ceremony a Masonic Ball was held in the Burra Town Hall.

Other Burra members to hold office of the Grand Lodge are Bro. Brian Riggs who is Assistant Grand Director of Ceremonies and Bro. Dave Thomas who is a Grand Steward.

ZOB

[There is a somewhat enigmatic item under this heading, which says plans have been formulated to form a Youth Club in Burra.]

In the last week volunteers have cleared weeds from the ‘beak’ yard: presumably the back yard. Others have done internal repairs and replaced light globes in the hall. 80 attended on the first night and attacked the place with brooms, buckets and household cleansers, after removing large items of rubbish and the old lino. A formal meeting was followed by supper.

[The location was not stated, but the description suggests the former Salvation Army Citadel.]

94, 41, 24 Oct. 1972, page 8

Burra Burra DC, 2 October

It was resolved to offer Apex $5 per night credit for running the Burra Pictures.

94, 42, 31 Oct. 1972, page 1

Decentralisation of the Post Office Telecommunications Management Authority

Burra is one place being considered as a possible headquarters for this move. Unfortunately its geographical position counts against it. As 150 persons would be employed, it would mean the influx of 400-500 people. Mr R.T. Prior, an old Burra boy has been appointed to the position of Area Manager Telecommunications for the Mid North, Upper North, Far North and Eyre Peninsula of SA. Mr Prior (Ray) called on the Chairman of the District Council, Mr R.J. Jeffery, and the District Clerk, Mr T.G. Perry, on 25 October to discuss the proposal as part of his familiarisation with the vast area concerned.

[The article runs in all for some 31⁄2 columns, but as nothing eventuated and most of it is about changes in general in telecommunications, it is of no great consequence.]

Ray Prior was born on his father’s farm in the Springbank-Hanson area and educated at Copperhouse School and Burra High School, where he was a House Leader and Prefect. He has 36 years experience with the department. For some years he was in charge of the Planning & Development of Telecommunications across SA and later was Superintendent of the Service Branch – a branch he entered some 25 years earlier as a trainee telephonist. His most recent post was Metropolitan Manager of Telecommunications Division. He served at sea in the RANVR in WWII, but was a telegraphist at Darwin in 1942 when the Post Office was bombed. A more enjoyable experience was serving as Communications Officer on the State Royal Visit Committee for a number of Royal Visits to SA and the NT. As a result he and his wife (nee Miss Maisie Peters of Riverton) have been presented to royalty on a number of occasions. He has also for many years been associated with the Postal Institute, of which he is a Life Member.

Burra Copper Festival. The committee met on 23 October to discuss the next Festival. The weekend was a great success and proceeds will total $2,500. This will be placed in the hands of the Burra District Tourist Promotion Committee, which no doubt will seek subsidies to supplement the usefulness of the money.

Samin Ltd’s Stage 2 Program

The commencement of stage 2 is scheduled for September 1973. The copper ore body at Burra was worked over by hand picking as a high grade deposit between 1845 and 1877, contributing valuable wealth to the state at a critical time. It was later worked on a small scale by the Burr [Burra] Copper Co. 1901-07. No further work of importance was undertaken till December 1961 when the SA Department of Mines began investigation. By December 1961 they had discovered interesting reserves of oxidised copper ore. Late in 1969 Samin Ltd acquired the leases and with State Government assistance in providing necessary infrastructure, it commenced to develop the property.

Samin and Australian Mineral Development Laboratories in Adelaide (Amdel) designed a plant utilising an ammonia leaching process capable of treating 250 tons of ore per day. The plant, which commenced operation as the first stage of the development, is producing c. 90 tons of copper concentrate per month. The plant has also been used to provide the metallurgical information needed to design the stage 2 plant. This will considerably increase throughput and recovery. The mining rate will increase to 400,000 tons of ore per year and production to about 6,500 tons of copper concentrate. The new plant involves roasting in a roaster 64 feet high, with 12 hearths, fired by natural gas, before treatment. Santos is supplying the natural gas from the Moomba-Adelaide main via a 14 mile branch line commissioned from the Natural Gas Pipelines Authority. Tenders for this line are expected to be called in January with construction in February-April 1973. The heat from the waste gases and from the hot material leaving the roaster will generate steam for other process work. The waste gases will be filtered to be completely clean before discharge. After roasting the ore will be ground to a fine powder in a 9 ft diameter x 17 ft long ball mill driven by an 11,000 volt motor. The diameter of this 1,100 h.p. motor is over 12 ft and it weighs nearly 20 tons. This is one of the largest motors connected to the ETSA system and special provisions have been made to protect other consumers from interference. ETSA will also be installing two 1,500 KVA transformers to cope with the increased load from other plant motors. After grinding the copper will be extracted from the calcined ore by agitation leaching instead of the present percolation leaching method. The new tanks for this have been installed and are set in the ground to eliminate possible spillage. Stainless steel pressure filters will ensure all ammonia fumes are contained. Most other sections of the existing plant will also be extended. A.L. Clode & Son have already enlarged the maintenance workshop.

Employment will not be greatly increased by this development.

94, 42, 31 Oct. 1972, page 2

94, 42, 31 Oct. 1972, page 8

Adelaide Wool Sales 3-5 October. [Local district prices are printed.]

Santos advises they expect gas to be available at Burra Mine in May 1973.

94, 43, 7 Nov. 1972, page 1

Burra Progress Association was formed on 1 August 1939. The late F.T. Sara was Chairman and Mr John Bowles was Secretary. Its last meeting was on 1 December 1955 when it had a credit balance of £75-4-7. This has grown with interest to be now $232.60. In March 1956, when the building of the swimming pool was under discussion, the Progress Association went into recess because it was the same few people who would be involved with the new project. Now only two local signatories remain in C.H. Cummins and H.J. Topsfield and it has been decided to wind up its financial concerns. Yesterday it was decided to hand the balance to the Tourist Promotion Committee President, Mr W. Scott.

Ian Auhl writes:

It was with mixed feelings that I read in the Sunday Mail of 5 November 1972 the disappointment of an overseas tourist who drove to Burra and expected to see the old open cut and wander freely around the old mine area. None of the brochures he said indicated that people could not get near the old buildings or the old mines. This highlights the need for more up-to-date publicity. A somewhat misleading impression could be given by the current Council brochure, the National Trust-Ampol film and the Burra Sketchbook. These date from 1967, 1967 and 1968 respectively and at that time the re-opening of the mine seemed a very remote possibility. This year the Council is to bring out an up-to-date tourist brochure. Also in 1973 I hope a new Burra book called Burra in Colour will be available. Rigby Ltd has given a young photographer Peter Finch and me the contract to produce the book. This will bring the Burra story up-to-date. The film cannot be up-dated and is now an historic record in colour of the mine area prior to the present mining operations. What is needed is a new film. One can understand the visitor’s disappointment and it is a pity Dr McKinnon was not referred to Mr Rich or Mr O’Connor, as I am sure he would have been shown around the mine area. In any case most of the mine buildings are still accessible. Graves’ Pump House has been spared and the [Peacock’s] chimney resited – a reasonable compromise. I, like Mr Baulderstone, felt a keen disappointment at the loss of the old mine area and some of the mine buildings. I have also been disappointed that other historic buildings in the town have been bulldozed without knowledge or consideration of their tourist value. Samin has shown goodwill and the National Trust and Council have, I believe, come to respect each other’s points of view. Tourism and mining cannot be separate developments; it is no longer practicable. Such statements as those made by Dr A.J. McKinnon are fair comment and must be taken into account.

Lawn Tennis. Six representatives of the SA Lawn Tennis Association visited Burra on Sunday and coached 42 youngsters of the Burra Association. Coaches were Mr Tom Gray and his two sons, Mr Ray Thiele and two ladies.

Kooringa Methodist Ladies’ Guild conducted their fete last Friday. Takings were £218. [Stall holders are listed.]

94, 43, 7 Nov. 1972, page 7

Birth. To Heather & Jeff Hirschausen of Burra North at Burra Hospital 2 November, a son, Gavin Jeffery.

Obituary. Mrs Fanny Butler died at Clare on Sunday aged 89.

[Born Fanny Theresa Nourse 15 May 1883 Hundred of Yongala: died 5 November 1972 Clare.]

The freedom From Hunger Campaign benefited by $110.58 from a door knock collection last Sunday.

Miss Gertrude Jordan writes from Ashfield, Sydney of her memories of the day her brother Arthur climbed the old Smelts Chimney and she enclosed a photo of her class at Burra School in 1897 or early 1898. In a PS she adds: ‘I can remember when Mr Holder (Sir Frederick Holder) had a lot to do with the Record.’

[See Burra Record 57, 45, 10 Nov. 1936, page 3: Memories of Burra by Elizabeth A. Ward. Arthur Jordan was at the time a schoolboy of 12 years of age, son of the late J.D. Jordan, watchmaker, of Kooringa. Arthur Dawson Jordan born 8 March 1873 Kooringa: died 28 October 1965, Gawler. See also 88, 5 (4), 9 Feb. 1965, page 6. Gertrude May Jordan 1882-1973. Note if she was born in 1882 she was unlikely to have been at school as late as 1897 or 1898.]

Harold Foote sent a letter with a couple of old photos. One showed Morphett’s Shaft with the big cable wheel and Johnny Green still in position. He said the roofs were on the Engine Houses and their stair cases in place. He said that when in the boys scouts they used to jump out of the top windows through the ‘shoots’ or were caught in ground sheets by other scouts. The other photo showed the first Kooringa Methodist Church.

Mr Binks-Williams writes a letter citing one he received recently from Harold Foote concerning the late Joe Lloyd and how much Mr Lloyd helped the bowling club. He was always willing to do voluntary work – nailing hundreds of palings on the new fence and carrying ‘tons’ of cement – and of the garden he made and kept bright with flowers – and, of course, about his tournament wins. Binks concludes by saying how much the same could be said of Harold Foote with respect to work around the bowling club.

94, 44, 14 Nov. 1972, page 1

Burra Burra DC. Rural Relief Grant

The $20,000 Rural Relief Grant will be expended by the end of the month. A further $20,000 will be sought. Of the present grant $5,000 has been spent on the exterior renovation of Paxton square. Seven spoon-drains or cement fords have been placed in the Hundred of Ayers. $2,000 has been spent on the old reformatory at Burra North. Repairs are being made to the parapet and some interior stone work. The rest has gone on kerbing and water tables throughout the town, with work in Thames Street, Best Place, Young, Queen, Church and Hill Streets among others. Applications for funds have come from the Farrell Flat Golf Club, Burra Show Society and the Booborowie Recreation Committee to assist with updating buildings under their care.

Hanson-Clare Road. $21,000 has been granted for the sealing of another mile of this road and it is expected to be done before Christmas.

The SA Housing Trust advises it will be erecting a house in the new housing area off Smelts Road for the Education Department.

Plague Locusts are about in the Eastern Pastoral Area.

Burra Creek. Investigations will be made about the possibility of damming the creek when water flow from the mine becomes necessary.

Minister of Local Government, Hon. G.T. Virgo MP will be asked to unveil a plaque fixed to the wall of the Town Hall balcony. [Marking the centenary of the establishment of the Burra District Council.]

Burra Burra District Council Centenary.

The original District of Burra was proclaimed on 27 November 1872. Arrangements are in hand for a Centenary Dinner in the Town Hall on 27 November 1972. The Minister for Local Government, Hon G.T. Virgo will attend, along with Councillors and wives and former Councillors and wives, or widows. Former Councillors will be invited from the merged Councils of Burra, Hanson, Booborowie and Mt Bryan. Information is sought on the names and addresses of any of the above: please contact the District Council Office.

Federal Election. Mr C.R. Kelly, Member for Wakefield, will be outside the post office at Burra on Saturday 18 November at about 10.30 a.m. [Photo]

The Country Party Candidate for Wakefield for the election on 2 December is Mac Shannon. [Photo]

94, 45, 21 Nov. 1972, page 1

The Barker Cottage Homes are progressing and the first two units have been allotted. The first section of three units has been roofed and the walls are being plastered. The walls of the second three units will practically be completed this week.

Burra Hospital. On the eastern side of the Burra Hospital foundation work is progressing on the new maternity wing. When completed this will make a 40-bed hospital all on one floor level. On the western side of the ‘General’ front verandah a sunroom is to be erected for the benefit of patients. Following the resignation of Matron L. Fyfe, who had held the position for 13 years, Sister L.A. Parker has been appointed Matron from 7 December. She comes from Katamatite and has been at Burra Hospital for 12 months.

Deputation to the Minister of Local Government

Following the public meeting at Booborowie over the increase in rates, a deputation has waited on the Minister, the Hon. G.T. Virgo. They pointed out that grants to the Burra Burra Council have decreased by $50,000 over three years. They sought increased funding to enable the budget to balance without the current increase in rates. The increase in rates was a response to the sharp decline in Government grants for road works. As a result of the previous Government policy the Council had built up an efficient plant and staff and incurred debts in the purchase of equipment, which had to be serviced. The deputation had complete confidence in the Council, but could not accept the hardship caused by the rate increase. They provided figures to support their claims:

Money collected in rates 1971-72 $80,370

1972-73 $99,276

Government Road Grants 1969-70 $141,976

1970-71 $131,512 (difference is a carry forward)

1971-72 $107,415

1972-73 $81,990

Comparison of different Council rates within a ten miles radius for similar land:

Burra Burra DC 890 acres rates $259.76

Adjoining Council 868 acres rates $134.40

Another adjoining Council 875 acres rates $265.14

This shows our rates are equal to one and well above the other, showing we are pulling our weight as ratepayers. The town is awakening to tourism and visitor numbers are growing, but a great need exists for a sealed road in an east-west direction. There has been a general increase in the revenue allotted to the Highways Department, but the debit orders to the northern areas have remained constant and to the Burra Burra Council have been reduced. Rate income must be reduced by $20,000.

This can only be done by:

Reducing the rural activities of Council.

Disposal of plant and equipment.

Retention of plant and equipment, but operating on a reduced scale with retrenchment of five or six men.

Highways Department provides grant allocation to enable the Council to meet loan and operational commitments until the rural community recovers from the restricted fiancé that has been and largely still is in place.

The Government supports the Council to provide for tourist activity in Burra as the rural sector has provided the present facilities and services.

94, 45, 21 Nov. 1972, page 8

Burra Golf Club held its AGM 9 November. Elected: President, D.R. Kempster; Vice-Presidents, I. Allen & A. Baulderstone; Treasurer, S. Allen; Secretary, H. Burnett; Captain, P. Dignan and Vice-Captain, A. McFarlane.

Retiring President R.E. Mason reported a successful year with a slight increase in membership. The team was successful in the Mid North Pennant Competition, having moved from bottom of the ladder to the top in three years.

The open day was a great success in perfect weather. We can look forward next year to great changes in the club with proposed reorganising and expanding of the whole course. We will be fortunate to have a top class golf course for 1973.

64, 46 (2), 28 Nov. 1972, page 1

[Note the anomalous change in volume number. This number was previously used December 1944.]

Burra Burra DC. The centenary of the Burra DC was commemorated with a dinner in the Town Hall on 27 November. The District Council of Burra was proclaimed by H.E. Rt Hon. Sir James Fergusson on 27 November 1872. The Hon. G.T. Virgo MP unveiled a commemorative bronze plaque on the northern wall of the Town Hall balcony. The Aberdeen Football and Tennis Clubs’ Auxiliaries catered for the occasion.

[The guest list of Councillors and past Councillors and other official visitors is printed.]

The Melbourne Cup Luncheon at the Town Hall resulted in a gift of $600 to the Hospital, equivalent to $1,800 when subsidised. $20 was given to the Kindergarten, which provided a crèche and four dozen dinner plates will be purchased for the Town Hall.

Federal Elections. Nominated for the Electorate of Wakefield for election on 2 December:

Terence Peter De Lacy, lecturer at Roseworthy College (ALP).

Charles Robert Kelly, MP of Burnside (Liberal).

James MacDonald Shannon of ‘Cambusdoon’ Kapunda, farmer and grazier (Country Party).

John William McMahon of Booborowie, farmer.

94, 47, 5 Dec. 1972, page 1 [Note the resumption of the previous volume number.]

Federal Election. Voting for Wakefield in Frome North Sub Division:

Kelly 800

De Lacy 473

Shannon 242

McMahon 89

Burra Mine

Work at the mine so far has been of a preparatory nature. De-watering of the open cut will start some time in June 1973, or perhaps in the following year. The water level will probably be lowered to 1,540 ft above sea level or 60 ft below the present level and would not then be lowered further for two years. Once started, pumping will continue for the life of the operation. The equipment will be capable of handling 1,000 gallons per minute. Notification of the decision to commence pumping will be given in due course.

Break-in. Burra Motor Co. premises have been broke into for the third time this year. Articles valued at c. $130 were stolen on the night of 28 November.

Commonwealth Secondary Scholarships have been awarded to five Burra High School students this year. They are valued at $400 each, to be used over two years. Winners are: Paul Hogan, Jennifer Holmes, John Lewis, Grant Maxted and Necia Mickel.

94, 47, 5 Dec. 1972, pages 1, 4, 5 & 4-5 gutter

Centenary of the Burra Burra DC

At the Centenary Dinner at the Town Hall last week the Chairman Mr Jeffery welcomed guests and introduced the Minister of Local Government Hon. G.T. Virgo, who presented long service certificates to R.J. Jeffery (17 Years), E.T. Baulderstone (24 years) and R.J. White (10 years). [Three photos are printed.]

[Mr Virgo began his speech with the usual thank yous for the invitation and to the ladies providing the dinner. He moved on to make the usual references to Burra’s past role as a mining centre which had saved SA’s economy in the mid 19th century. He said the re-opened mine is expected to run for 15 to 20 years and to generate some $119-$120 million. He then went on to consider the role of tourism.]

Burra has a very important role to play in tourism. In a quick look around to see the old miners’ cottages I was very pleased to see the standard of preservation. I think these cottages mean something as far as Burra is concerned and as far as tourism is concerned. You may think it worth while pooling your tourist resources with adjoining areas so that the region can provide more than just a one or two day trip. Today the tourist is looking for more than coming to Burra to see mine workings and cottages and the National Trust Museum. They are looking for a package of things to do perhaps over four or five days or a week. A portion of the growing tourist expenditure in Australia can come to Burra provided Burra people are prepared to display the necessary initiative and encourage people in the area to advertise the fact they have tourist potential. With respect to ‘that road’ which must receive serious consideration. While it is acknowledged that it is essential as far as this region is concerned, it is also acknowledged that the Highways Department funds are allocated on the needs of the whole state and so the Department may not give it the same priority as it sifts through the pleas and requests of 157 local governing bodies in SA.

Concerning local government boundaries. If local government by a majority want to have a commission to look into boundaries, I am prepared to have one. If not, then one will not be established.

Mr Brian Riggs responded. As well as thanking Mr Virgo he introduced Mr Ian Auhl’s booklet on the Council’s Centenary and thanked the Floral Art Club for the floral arrangements, the ladies [listed] for the catering and the Clerk, Tom Perry, for making the co-ordinating arrangements for the dinner.

Mr Virgo then presented the long service awards as stated above.

[Photo of the unveiling of the plaque.]

Ian Auhl spoke of the booklet on the Council’s Centenary and pointed out the difficulties Burra had in getting local government – it took twenty years for a District Council and another four for the town to get a Corporation. You, [Mr Virgo] made the remark that Burra once upon a time saved South Australia. I say that it is high time that South Australia saved Burra. My final comment is that if you want to save Burra build that bloody road from Morgan to here!

94, 47, 5 Dec. 1972, page 7

Birth. To Monika & Ray Barnes at Burra 2 December, a son, Dale Raymond.

Frank Blott landed an 80 lb Murray Cod at Morgan on Wednesday.

Mr & Mrs Geoff Saltmarsh are leaving the Bon Accord soon and the new licensee will take over next week.

94, 48, 12 Dec. 1972, page 1

Christmas in Burra

Late night shopping will operate in Burra on Friday 22 December.

Burra Traders have arranged for a free picture show in the Town Hall at 6 p.m. (The Adventures of Huckleberry Finn and a Parade of Cartoons.)

Shops will close 5.30 to 7 p.m.

The merry-go-round will operate near the Burra Hotel with free rides for the day and evening.

A Christmas Dance will be held in the RSL Hall from 8 30 p.m. organised by Rural Youth.

Shopping hours will be normal on 23 December and businesses will close 25 & 28 December and 1 January. [A note on page 7 adds 26 December.]

Willalo Methodist Church was the scene for the presentation of the Christmas Cantata Joy to the World on Sunday night. The Burra Church choir was directed by Mrs Reta Jennison with Mrs Olive Oates at the organ. Soloists were Mrs Ruth Stolte, Mrs Heather Affolter, Mrs Edith Carpenter and Mr Jack Oates. The duet part was taken by Mrs Phil Klem and Mrs Elsie Hore with Norman Maxted as narrator. It will be presented at Burra Church at 11 a.m. next Sunday.

Roche Bros. Social Club organised a Cabaret at the Town Hall on Saturday night and 125 couples attended. Music by the Pfitzner’s five piece ‘Goldtones’ Band.

Burra Hospital Fund Raising Committee has raised $7,396 in the past eight years, which with subsidy allowed modern equipment worth $27,839 to be purchased. The committee and the Auxiliary met jointly last week when a donation of $1,000 was made to the Hospital. Sister L.A. Parker was welcomed as the new Matron from 7 December. Matron Fyfe thanked everyone for their support. The major items purchased in the past eight years were a Heart Machine ($3,000), Air Conditioners ($3,520), Sterilizer ($558), Oil Heaters ($470) and Watson Victor Equipment ($6,000), Bedsteads ($4,500), Over bed Tables ($665)and Furniture ($2,000). The new section of the Hospital will require the expenditure of about $16,000.

Adelaide Wool Sales. 14-16 November. The top local district price was 2301⁄2c per kilo by M.A. Gebhardt of Woollana Mt Bryan. [Other local district prices are printed.]

94, 48, 12 Dec. 1972, page 7

Elizabeth Oates & Julie McBride have completed their final nursing exams. The former gained a gold medal for her results.

Birth. To Lynette & Glen Hammat of Spalding at Jamestown on Friday, a daughter, Debra Julie.

Mr & Mrs ‘Jock’ Paech of the Mt Bryan Post Office are moving to Wirrabara in the New Year. They will be replaced by Mr & Mrs Roger Graetz from Enngonia, NSW.

Carols by the Pool will be held on Sunday next at 8.30 p.m.

The Mid North Tourist Development Association held a competition to design an emblem. It was won by Miss Eunice Mosey of Robertstown from 75 other entries. The emblem on a green background features a large W for wheat, wool and wine. There is a ram’s head, a bunch of grapes and a chimney to symbolise the mining era.

Angela Quinn, who is training and working with the Missionary Sisters of Service in Tasmania, wrote to the paper with congratulations on the Copper festival and on the paper’s souvenir issue of 10 October and with Christmas wishes for all. She then contributes almost half a column on the work of the Order of Missionary Sisters of Service.

94, 48, 12 Dec. 1972, page 8

Burra Primary School held its Swimming Carnival on Wednesday 6 December. [Results are printed.]

94, 49, 19 Dec. 1972, page 1

‘Carols by the Pool’ was held in perfect weather on Sunday. Rev. John Stephenson compered the evening. Mrs Jack Oates provided the piano accompaniment and the Burra Methodist Choir led the singing. The Primary School children presented a Christmas tableau.

Mr Roy Jeffery as chairman of the District Council delivered his Christmas message, in which he paid a special tribute to those various local volunteer bodies who contribute so much to the well being of the community. He also appealed for any ideas the public might have to solve the problem of lerp attacking gum trees along the Burra Creek.

94, 49, 19 Dec. 1972, pages 1 & 8

Burra High School Speech Day

This departure from the traditional speech night received many favourable comments. The Choir began with three popular numbers. Mr Ron Thamm as Chairman of the High School Council thanked parents for their continued support of the school. After the addresses and prize giving afternoon tea was served in the girls’ craft centre.

Headmaster’s Report for 1972

I welcome Inspector Mr Louis Kloeden, to the platform along with Mrs Kloeden, a Senior Mistress and Art Teacher.

The year began with an enrolment of 160 and we expect it to be 200 by 1975.

The students have been co-operative and responsible and the prefects and house captains most conscientious in their duties. Students have done well in helping with the upkeep of the grounds. A Valedictory Service was held last Sunday in the Anglican Church.

We congratulate Commonwealth Scholarship winners Paul Hogan, Jennifer Holmes, John Lewis, Grant Maxted, Necia Mickel, John Bishop, Helen Beare and Kathy Edwards.

[He then went on to thank the staff and the High School Council.]

Next year Miss Baron and Mr Costello are both getting married and will be transferring to Dover Gardens and Findon respectively. Miss Lintern has resigned to take a Social Science course at Flinders University. Mr Allen has been promoted at ASM at Millicent High School. Their replacements are not yet known.

The Parents & Friends have helped the school with a number of purchases including a photo-copying machine ($850) and library books ($400).

[He then spoke briefly of sports and extra-curricular activities.]

In 1973 there will be no ‘2’ track students and only ‘0’ and ‘1’ track. All 1st year students will be offered Art as an alternative to French. 1973 will see the introduction of a Hire Book Scheme.

A new Commonwealth Grant next year will see the school receive some $2,750 worth of equipment including books, films, cassettes etc. over three years.

With respect to the new school. New plans have been drawn up and approved. It is likely the boys’ craft block and the science block areas will be the site for the new school and Wardle’s paddock the recreation area. No commencement date has yet been set.

Mr Kloeden was then introduced.

[The list of prize winners is printed.]
