94, 49, 19 Dec. 1972, page 6

Mid North Football League

This week the Secretary Mr A.E. Bannear tendered his resignation to the President on account of ill health. He had served as Secretary for two periods; 1946-50 and 1965-72. Mrs Bannear, who is Assistant Secretary, will be absent overseas from January 1973 to the end of the 1973 season.

Obituary. William Henry Quinn died 15 December at St Andrew’s Hospital Adelaide aged 68. He was the son of the late William Henry Quinn and Ann Quinn of Mt Bryan and brother to Tom Ellen (Mrs Richards), Ann and John. (And to Mary & Kathleen deceased.) [Born 6 January 1904 Aberdeen: died 15 December 1972 Adelaide, residence Mt Bryan.]

94, 49, 19 Dec. 1972, page 7

Obituary. Mrs Judy Smith, wife of Mr Gus Smith, died 11 December. She was the mother of Mrs Rol Dare of Mt Bryan. [Not apparently in SA.]

Birth. To Mr & Mrs Laurie Sullivan of Hallett about two weeks ago, a daughter, Jessica.

Burra Library has a copy of the biography of one of the town’s most famous sons, Sir Essington Lewis.

Geoffrey Blainey’s The Steel Maker.

Characteristics of the 1972 paper.

There was quite a reasonable coverage of local issues and with a fairly wide interpretation of ‘local’; ranging from Saddleworth to Hallett and Robertstown.

There are quite a few mistakes in setting, however, and not all are subsequently corrected, which leaves some puzzling items. Some of the major news items are general interest, rather than local.

Allocation of material to pages is rather elastic, but the following is typical.

Page 1.

Solidly devoted to news.

Page 2.

Some large local advertisements with sports results,

Sales notices and public notices are sometimes here and sometimes on page 6 or split between the two.

Page 3.

Typically a heavy dose of large advertisements with perhaps one column of news.

Pages 4 & 5.

Generally little news except for sports results and often a large section of 50 and 25 years ago.

Page 6.

Large advertisements for about half the page. The Cash Column (small classified advertisements) for at least one column. Some public notices and other small advertisements.

Page 7.

‘Out and About’ – small snippets of local news.

Further local news and sports. At least half a page of advertising.

Page. 8

Large advertisements for about four columns. Reports from various District Councils and perhaps some other news.

95, 1, 16 Jan. 1973, page 1

Adelaide Wool Sales. Prices rose spectacularly on the opening day. They were up 20-25% on the closing rates from 15 December 1972. An almost total clearance to the trade followed. [Local district prices are printed.]

Mrs Paech, who is leaving the district to live at Wirrabara, was farewelled from Mt Bryan on 2 January by representatives of the CWA and the Anglican Ladies’ Guild.

Robertstown DC decided at its Christmas meeting that the approaches to the swing bridge at the Burra Creek [Gorge] would have to be removed or remodelled due to road construction in the vicinity.

Rainfall for 1972 was 1399 points or 31⁄2 inches below average and of this 4 inches fell in January and February when it did more harm than good. [Further details draw comparisons with other dry years.]

95, 2, 23 Jan. 1973, page 1

Burra Burra DC has received a further $7,000 under Rural Unemployment Relief.

$2,000 will be spent for renovations to the exterior of the Mr Bryan Recreation Hall.

$2,863 goes to the Booborowie Recreation Ground.

$1,000 goes to Farrell Flat Recreation Ground.

The rest will be spent on ongoing renovations at the Redruth Gaol. There repairs to ceilings and some painting have been done. The parapet section of the front wall has been repaired and painted.

District Clerk T.G. Perry is perturbed by acts of vandalism to amenities in the town. Recent targets have been the new toilets at the rear of the Council Offices in Chapel Street and also at the Caravan Park and the Swimming Pool.

Black Springs to Burra Road from Porter’s Lagoon on the main road has been sealed.

Learn to Swim Campaign. Results of the 208 enrolled for the year are printed.

95, 4, 6 Feb. 1973, page 1

New Burra Buildings in 1973 will be worth c. $4 million.

Stage 2 of the treatment Plant at the Burra Mine is estimated to cost over $3 million.

The Burra Hospital will get 40 beds and a new maternity floor, all on one level, at a cost of $220,000.

Barker of Baldina Cottage Homes on the western side of the Hospital are expected to cost c. $90,000. The late Mr J.R. Barker bequeathed $70,000 and there was a Commonwealth subsidy.

Burra Mine. Envirotech Australia Pty Ltd is building the multiple hearth furnace for Samin Ltd for the reduction roasting plant and the first two sections of four are being positioned. [Photograph.] The plant will cost $1.2 million; will be c. 26 ft in diameter and 85 ft high. It will be a 12 hearth, multiple hearth type furnace and will be equipped for recovering heat from the furnace flue, gases and roasted ore, together with cyclonic and bag type dust collection and should be operational this year. It will calcine 1,000 tons of crushed ore per day, using natural gas as fuel. Parts of the roaster came from Adelaide by two low loaders operated by J.W. Bourne Ltd. The width forced a roundabout route via Snowtown, Gladstone, Crystal Brook, Jamestown and Hallett and took two days with lifting of overhead wires taking much of the time. The third and fourth sections arrived on Wednesday after a similar journey.

Barker Cottage Homes are progressing satisfactorily. So far seven applications have been received by the Board of Management and this leaves two vacant units. Construction is by the local firm of D.T. Jacka & Co. and it is expected that the units will be ready for occupation by the end of March or early April. One advantage will be the nearness to the Hospital. [Photograph.]

Burra Hospital extensions will incorporate a new Maternity Wing, kitchen and staff dining room, as well as three additional share wards and a children’s ward for the General Hospital. All will be on the same level. [The old hospital had always been plagued by different levels throughout.] The new wing will include three private wards, a share ward, nursery and a TV room for patients. The existing verandah on the front of the building will be extended on the eastern end to link with the new building and on the western end a new sunroom for patients will be erected. Kennett Bros of Adelaide are expected to complete the work in April or May. The area under the built-up building will house rain water tanks. [Photograph.]

95, 4, 6 Feb. 1973, page 2

Advt. Southern Farmers will sell on 21 February on instructions from Mrs C.T. Carmody, opposite the Leighton School, plant, machinery, furniture etc. [A long and detailed list is printed.]

Advt. Burra Pictures, 10 February

Summer of ‘42

Tennis

‘A’ Grade Kooringa 13-98 defeated Aberdeen Blue 7-71

‘B’ Grade Aberdeen Black forfeited to Hallett White

Spalding White 12-95 defeated Aberdeen Purple 5-68

Hallett White 13-96 defeated Aberdeen Red 7-60

‘C’ Grade Kooringa 9-68 defeated Aberdeen 3-40

Weather. Rain fell over the entire district for four days and nights with falls of 4 to 8 inches. The Eastern Road beyond Woolgangi is impassable. Burra received 372 points. The inside country received about 4 inches, Poonunda 455 points, ‘The Gums’ 417, but to the northeast Pulpara and Mallett both report 800 points, while falls to the east range from 217 points at Braemar to 606 at Glenora.

95, 4, 6 Feb. 1973, page 3

Notice. Burra Burra DC gives notice of intent to close and sell to adjoining landowners the chain Road between sections 894, 211, 212, 217, 893, 214, 215 & 216 Hundred of Ayers.

And chain road between sections 284, 61, 98, 97 & 285, 107, 108 and 109 Hundred of Kingston.

Koonaburra 137 (1st innings) v. Booborowie 125 (1st innings).

Burra Footballers 263 v. Mt Bryan 73

95, 4, 6 Feb. 1973, page 5

Mary Woollacott’s NZ Holiday Part 3.

Burra apex Club decided at its last meeting to hold a charter presentation night on 31 March 1973, beginning with a buffet dinner in the RSL Hall at 6.45 p.m. A cabaret will follow in the Town Hall with the band ‘Lighter Shade of Pale’, from Adelaide. On Sunday 1 April visitors will have a Barbecue Dinner at the Aberdeen Club Rooms. The club is presently small and needs new members. The President is Mr Jeff. Hirschausen. On Sunday members trimmed trees along Burra Creek. An area from opposite the old power house to almost the Caravan Park has been set aside for development as an Apex Park where large trees will provide shelter for barbecues and picnics. Meeting on the second and fourth Thursday s in the month at Burra Hotel. Barry Griffith is the Secretary.

95, 4, 6 Feb. 1973, Supplement

[Assuming this undated supplement is correctly placed in the collection.]

Mid North Adult Education Centre. Program and Timetable for 1973 is printed.

Courses offered in Burra were: Conversational German, Crochet, Dressmaking, General Craft and Gemmology. (All were subject to a minimum enrolment of 10 students.)

95, 5, 13 Feb. 1973, page 1

Meals on Wheels Burra has received a subsidy of $437 for the meals served in twelve months. The service started on 26 July 1971, since when 4,600 meals have been served. Subsidy for the first six months was $100, so it would appear to have been doubled. A doctor’s certificate is required to qualify for the service. Hospital kitchen staff cook the meals and volunteers deliver them. Miss P. Jones and Mrs M. Anderson do additional cooking. Contributions from patients [clients?] reimburse the hospital. Helpers to deliver and drive are needed. Christmas hampers are also needed.

The Crippled Children’s Door Knock Appeal raised $224 at Burra & Farrell Flat.

Burra Primary School held a very successful social at the end of last year.

Burra Tennis Association held its first Junior Tournament 11 February. Winners were:

Girls’ under 14 Singles A. Berryman

Girls’ Open Doubles Gebhardt & Willis

Girls’ Open Singles S. Wright

Girls under 12 Singles K. Webster

Boys’ Open Doubles Webster & Kelly

Boys’ under 13 Doubles Beinke & Drew

Boys’ under 16 Open N. Webster

Boys’ under 14 Singles P. Beinke

Boys’ under 12 Singles J. Lane

Burra Mine - Samin has now had all four sections of the new ‘roaster’ erected.

[Photo of one section arriving on a low loader.]

95, 5, 13 Feb. 1973, page 3

Floods. The Eastern Road is still impassable beyond Woolgangi. Water from the north means watercourses is still flowing and all dams and lagoons are reported full.

The mail contractors deferred the Friday delivery, but have decided to ‘give it a go’ this morning.

The Morgan Road was closed for a few days after the rain.

The Burra Creek reached the Murray, but the flow apparently came from the tributaries flowing from the northeast pastoral country. A flow of the creek from Burra to Morgan occurred about 25 years ago, when the watercourse at Florieton was about three miles wide.

95, 5, 13 Feb. 1973, pages 4 & 5

Marriage. Carlsruhe Lutheran Church 20 January

Rosalie Jean Behn, daughter of Mr B.H. & the late Mrs Behn of Saddleworth, married

95, 6, 20 Feb. 1973, page 1

Burra Mine - Samin Ltd now has the four sections of the new roaster in position, though further equipment is yet to be mounted. There are twelve square holes running vertically up the tower, which are entries to each of the roaster hearths. The hearths will be constructed in special refractory bricks and castable materials and work on this began yesterday. It is expected to take about three months. On the top there will be a safety stack and four ‘cyclones’. The latter will separate grit from the exhaust gases. These will then pass through a large filter to remove any remaining dust, which will then be recycled into the furnace.

[Photographs of the operation are included.]

95, 6, 20 Feb. 1973, page 2

Advt. Burra Pictures, 24 February

Jack Wild, Billy Hayes & Mama Cass in Pufnstuf

Bowls

1st Division Burra 71 defeated Auburn 59

2nd Division Burra 80 defeated Watervale 73

3rd Division Burra White 78 defeated Spalding 65

Clare white 87 defeated Burra Red 75

Tennis

95, 7, 27 Feb. 1973, page 1

Adelaide Wool Sale No. 8 1973. Compare with the sale on 9-11 January values were up to 15% higher, though some faulty and shabby wool barely maintained value.

Burra Burra Show Inc. AGM was held last Thursday and drew a low attendance. Elected were:

Patron Rex C. Warnes

President Graham Kellock

Senior Vice-President Ron Shipard

Junior Vice-President Neil Hurst

Secretary Darrell H. Field

R.E. Mason presented the President’s Report for 1972:

The show was held on 7 October and was opened by the Governor of SA, Sir Mark Oliphant, accompanied by Lady Oliphant. This was the first activity of the Copper festival weekend and attendance almost doubled that of last year. The weather was unsettled, with dust at first, but it improved later. The new sections for pigs and cattle were a success and ring events were popular, as were the dodgem cars at the sideshows. Sheep shearing was popular too and the Agriculture Pavilion was filled to capacity. School exhibits were popular and the industrial displays were well patronised. The wool display was of a high standard, but sheep numbers were very low. The Flower Pavilion was a picture.

School enrolments, staff changes etc. are given for Hallett, Farrell Flat, Booborowie and Leighton schools and for Burra Kindergarten.

Burra Kindergarten has an enrolment of 47.

Burra Primary School enrolment is 257 compared with 268 in 1972.

Mrs Henderson from Littlehampton will take Grades I & II

Teacher Aides are Mrs D. Reed & Miss C. Burnett.

Burra High School

Miss Coralie Plush is Senior Mistress and comes from overseas. (Previously at Kidman Park Girls’ Technical High School.)

Kym Dixon & Robert George come from Adelaide Teachers College.

Jenny Morton comes from Adelaide Teachers College and Birdsville.

Patience Murphy is formerly of Burra and Maureen Sherlock comes from Vermont Girls’ Technical High School.

Mt Bryan Primary has an enrolment of 36.

95, 7, 27 Feb. 1973, pages 4 & 5

Mary Woollacott’s New Zealand Trip, part 6.

95, 7, 27 Feb. 1973, page 6

Advt. Commercial St Burra: for sale 4 Storey shops [sic] with plate glass and ultralite front with office, packaging and storage rooms, garage, etc. Rear portion enclosed with 6 ft cyclone fence. Suitable for departmental store or separate shops. $19,750.

[Presumably ‘4 Storey’ should read ‘4 stone’, in which case the description fits the Drew & Crewes’ site.]

A New Golf Course is taking shape in the racecourse area. The land was offered to the Burra Burra DC by the Burra Sports Syndicate and the Council has acquired the adjoining land known as Elders and the Quarry Paddocks to develop a sports and recreation ground. The Golf Club enlisted the aid of Murray Crafter of Glenelg Golf Club to design a new gold course. His plans were accepted in November 1972. Work began in December on the north face of Quarry Hill. Putting surfaces were laid in the new positions at a working bee on 25 February except for three still under preparation. Thanks go to Lyell Quinn of Roche Bros. for grading Quarry Hill and carting material etc., to the DC for making earth-moving equipment available, to Bill Byles & Gino Santella for driving the machinery and to Ron Moreland for ensuring its availability when required. Thanks also go to Ivan Hirschausen for the use of equipment and to Mike & Ray Wardle for time and equipment as well as to club members generally.

Advt. M & BHA Burra Town Hall Monday 5 March 10 a.m. Morning Tea & Film:

Walter Matthau & Maureen Stapleton in Plaza Suite.

Obituary. Mr Hugo Rost, formerly of Burra, died on Sunday [25 February] aged 47. He is survived by a widow and four young sons: Wolfgang, Werner, Bernhardt and Peter.

Obituary. Jim Miller, formerly of Mt Bryan, died recently aged 82.

[A common name, but a marriage at Mt Bryan suggests that he might have been Christian James Miller, born 25 December 1890 at Wyacca near Gordon.]

Obituary. Mrs Emma Maria Lydia Schmidt nee Launer died at Kapunda 20 February aged 78. She was wife of the late Michael Schmidt and lived at Robertstown for many years. There were seven children, 29 grandchildren and 44 great-grandchildren. [Born Emma Maria Lydia Launer 9 July 1894 Robertstown.]

Andrew Pearce leaves for Melbourne to compete with the SA State Shooting Team from 5 March. He shoots with the Balaklava Big Bore Club.

Weather. Rain has fallen again to the east on 18 & 19 February with Oakvale recording 340 points and Brooks Bore 414.

Mokota Cricket Assoc.

Koonaburra 5 for 198 v. Burra Footballers 87

North Booborowie 149 v. Spalding 120

Mt Bryan 252 v. Hallett 74

Burra National Trust held its 9th AGM and re-elected:

President G.R. O’Connor

Secretary M. Tiver

Treasurer D. Cockington

Curator of Museum S. Woollacott

Research Officer I. Auhl

The address was given by Mr D. Dix, proprietor of the Murray Bridge Museum.

President’s Report

The dominant item for the year was Peacock’s chimney. Last year the stonework had been completed and the brick top begun. After months of frustratingly slow progress the brickwork was topped, but so badly executed as to be totally unacceptable. Eventually the contractor agreed and the brickwork was removed. Before rebuilding commenced the contractor went bankrupt. The services were then obtained of O’Neill & Clayton, who did a first class job. Sir Mark Oliphant unveiled the plaque [at the completed chimney] on 8 October 1972. In the year visits were made to Tanunda and Renmark branches. Jamestown has given us a complete railway signal tower and signal.

95, 8, 6 Mar. 1973, page 1

Burra High School Swimming Carnival was held on Friday 23 February in excellent conditions. [Results are printed.]

Burra Rural Youth Club will host the Upper North Zone Rally for the 3rd time in its nearly 20 years of life. Previous rallies at Burra were in 1955 and 1963. This one will be 13-15 April.

Burra High School. The prefects were inducted last Wednesday. Headmaster D. Calder welcomed parents, staff and students. Mr Shinkfield presented the badges and gave the occasional address.

Prefects are:

(Boys) J. Lewis (Head), N. Webster (Deputy Head), I. Billing, G. Kleinig, K. Farrelly & R. Shattock.

(Girls) Necia Mickel (Head), Anne White (Deputy Head), Carol Haynes, Louise Catt, Sybil Wright & Cheryl Heitbrink.

Burra Apex Club had a good attendance of 20 at its last meeting and two new members in Garry Hirschausen & Brian Ferris. Plans for the Charter Dinner are in hand.

Burra Mine – Samin Ltd.

E.C. Allen MP asked the Premier, Mr Dunstan, about the possible effects on ground water levels of the second stage operations of Samin Ltd at Burra. This is estimated to pump 11⁄2 million gallons of water a day from the mine to keep water levels below operating levels. Landowners would like to see it replaced underground if possible.

Mr Allen asked if the water level at the Bon Accord shaft was falling – it being the present source of water for the mine’s operation.

Mr Bakewell, secretary to the Minister of development and Mines, advises that a survey of bores within 8 km is being undertaken so that drawdown can be determined during a test later in the year. It is believed unlikely bores further away will be affected. Of the 91 bores located, 22 are not in use, 8 provide domestic supplies, 59 are for stock and 2 are for irrigation. The mine is expected to have a relatively short life and the artificial recharge of the aquifers is not considered to be beneficial. No significant fall in the level of water at the Bon Accord shaft has been noted. The level in the open cut has fallen about 12 inches in the summer and this is considered normal.

Burra Burra DC’s centenary book has been selling well since its release last November.

Andrew Pearce (23) has returned from Melbourne, having gained the 6th Queen’s Badge at the Melbourne Queen’s Shoot, from a field of 606. In Canberra he won the 16th badge.

Drew Anderson of Burra took 6 wickets for 15 runs off 5 overs on Saturday in a match against Mt Bryan.

Burra RSL. President Ben Kotz reported on the year’s activities. There were 10 monthly meetings. The annual dinner was very successful and badge days were again held. Patronage at the Annual Anzac Service was poor – it may be our last. Various people hired the club rooms and unfortunately considerable damage was done – by nobody of course!

95, 10, 20 Mar. 1973, page 8

Burra Primary School welfare Club held its AGM. Secretary Shirley Thamm reported on the past year. Average attendance was 28 from 67 financial members. Total income for the year was $1,575.15 and $488 was spent on equipment. At the Copper festival the Club gave tea to 30 members of the Police Band. During the year there was a visit from children from the Nepabunna Aboriginal Community. [Further detail of this is printed.] Elected:

President Mrs B. Stockman

Vice-Presidents Mrs J. Ayliffe & Mrs C. Brereton

Secretary Mrs M. Tiver

Assistant Secretary Mrs R. Pritchard

Treasurer Mrs R. Alderson

95, 11, 27 Mar. 1973, page 1

Burra Apex Club will hold its Charter Dinner on Saturday 31 March. About 250 people will attend of whom 197 will be visitors. The dinner will be in the Town Hall and after the presentation of the charter a cabaret will be held. A Sunday bus tour and barbecue has been arranged.

State Election

Mr E.C .Allen [Photo] has been re-elected for the seat of Frome. Mr Allen was elected for Burra in 1968. This electorate was incorporated in Rocky River and Frome in 1970. He was returned at that election with a majority of 128 and this year had a majority of 1,645.

In the Northern District for the Legislative Council the LCL candidates Dick Geddes and Arthur Whyte [Photos] have defeated their ALP opponents.

95, 11, 27 Mar. 1973, page 8

Burra Football Club AGM

President G.M .Kellock reported on the year. Junior Colts won the premiership without losing a game for the year. Though less successful, the Senior Colts provided their supporters with good football. ‘B’ Grade ended up with the wooden spoon. The ‘A’ Grade team did better, winning through to the Preliminary Final and losing that by just a few points. Kevin Lane is congratulated on his five years as senior coach, in which time the club has taken out two premierships and was twice runner-up. He has asked to be relieved of this task for 1973 and as a consequence D. Kellock has been appointed. Gate takings in 1972 were double those of 1971 and the increased admission from 40 to 50 cents only accounts for a small part of this. Elected for 1973:

President J. Secomb

Vice-Presidents T. Lehmann & R. Nicholls

Secretary A. Day

Treasurer H. Heitbrink

95, 12, 3 Apr. 1973, page 1

Burra Apex Club. On Saturday about 250 people attended a Dinner & Cabaret in the Burra Town Hall to see the Burra Apex Club receive its Charter. Mr Roy Jeffery as Chairman of the District Council congratulated members, especially as they were the first service club in the town. Jeff Hirschausen, as President of the Burra Apex Club, welcomed guests. Regional Director Neil Wilkinson gave an address and the charter was presented by Bob England, Immediate Past President of the Zone, and the induction was performed by the President Tom Chapman. [Members are listed.] On Sunday visiting Apexians and families were given a barbecue at the Aberdeen Club Rooms.

Mr Roy Earle from Queensland is the National Secretary of the ‘Keep the Wool Industry Free’ campaign. He addressed a public meeting in the RSL Hall on Friday. He argued that the industry can prosper without a compulsory acquisition scheme.

Adelaide Wool Sale No. 9 saw an initial price rise followed by a fall, but most Merino types were up to 7.5% dearer.

Weather. Rain has again fallen to the east, varying from 118 points at Woolgangi to 250 at Oakbank. The road to Oakvale is impassable.

Diamond Wedding. Prior-Brown. Jim and Ruby of Hallett announce their 60th wedding anniversary. It was solemnised at Gipsum [sic] Street Baptist Church in Broken Hill.

[Richard James Prior & Ruby Amelia nee Brown.]

Notice. ETSA announces that essential maintenance and increased capacity work at the Burra Substation will mean an interruption to supply at Hanson, Burra, Mt Bryan, Hallett and Leighton from 7 a.m. to 12 noon on Sunday 8 April.

Mid North Bowling Association

Barry Huppatz of Clare is Champion of Champions.

Champion of Champion Rinks went to Auburn

Diamond Wedding. Mr & Mrs Klaebe celebrated their Diamond Wedding at Victor Harbor on Sunday 25 March, having been married at Peterborough Methodist Church 25 March 1913. They later moved to Clare and then Hallett, where Mrs Klaebe was church organist for a number of years. She was a Red Cross worker during the war and also secretary of the Fighting Forces Fund.

[Hugo Bruno Klaebe & Edith nee Day.]

David Hirst of Hobart, Tasmania.

Mokota Cricket Association

Preliminary Final

Booborowie 6 for 121 defeated Burra Footballers 119

95, 13, 10 Apr. 1973, page 1

Booborowie Water. The Department of Mines has been monitoring levels and salinity in 53 bores since May 1971 in the Booborowie Valley. 1972 levels are about one metre lower than 1971 levels, as a consequence of reduced winter rains. No drastic depletion of the aquifer is evident. It is expected further boring this year will determine more precisely the hydrological limits, rate of recharge and the capacity of the valley.

Burra Rural Youth will host members of seven other clubs in the Zone at a rally next weekend.

[The program of events is printed.]

Koonaburra Cricket Club honoured Ron Pearse with life membership at a dinner at the Royal Exchange Hotel on Saturday last. Ron has been President of the club since its inception in 1962 and was captain for many years. He began playing cricket at Burra in 1951. Ron congratulated the team on their grand final win against Booborowie, which was also being celebrated that night.

95, 13, 10 Apr. 1973, pages 1 & 8

Burra Primary School Council AGM

The primary school headmaster Mr S. Allan feels teachers need conferences and observation days because of rapidly changing educational ideas and improved methods. About 35 parents and teachers attended the meeting. The new council members are Mr J. Ayliffe, Mrs M. Alderson, Mr S. Allan, Mrs P. Buckton, Mrs E. Carpenter, Mr G. Nourse, Mr C. O’Connor, Mr R. Shipard, Mrs C. Stockman, Mrs J. Tiver, Mrs Betty Thamm and Mr Brian Thamm.

At their first meeting after the AGM the Council elected Mr I. Allen as Chairman, Mr A. Baulderstone as Vice-Chairman and Mr D. Lloyd as Secretary-Treasurer.

The Chairman’s report covers the Sports Day and Combined Sports Day at Hallett.

Rhe combined sports this year will be held on 13 April.

Swimming meets have been held twice at Riverton; on 24 March 1972 and 16 March 1973. Burra won the first meet by 19 points and the second by 3. The school competition at the Burra Pool was held on 6 December. Fund raising for 1972 saw the men’s group raise and sell an onion crop for $159. Snacks for visitors to the Copper Festival in October were a community service rather than a fund raiser.

Not as much has been spent on the school this year because the High School is to be relocated and the Primary School will be recast about the existing High school and Primary School buildings. Also further clarification is needed about the division of responsibilities between the Department and the parent body for the supply of equipment and teaching aids. Some additional sports equipment was erected.

Three new teachers were welcomed: Miss Dargie, Miss Abbot and Mrs Henderson. Mrs Shattock, Mrs Keller and Mrs Short have helped during periods of staff shortage.

After six years as Secretary-Treasurer Lewis Moore was transferred from Burra and we thank him. Don Lloyd has taken his place. Committees have worked well and merit our thanks. Mr Allan spoke on the planned activities for the coming year. The full staff is now 8 teachers, 1 typist, 1 librarian and 2 teacher-aides. The acquisition of two teacher-aides has been a tremendous help, especially in the Infant Section. This year I intend to set up the old book room as an area for extra help lessons and as a room for group reading to teacher-aides. Changing ideas and methods mean teachers need to go to conferences and observation days. Children should have at least one excursion a year.

95, 13, 10 Apr. 1973, page 3

Mokota Cricket Assoc.

North Booborowie 184 defeated Leighton 139 to win the Mayfield Shield (Second Division) at Willalo on Saturday. Koonaburra won the Mokota Shield when it defeated Booborowie at the Burra Oval on Saturday.

Koonaburra 9 for 198 (including P. Byles 114) defeated Booborowie 125.

‘C’ Grade Kooringa 6-54 defeated Aberdeen 6-46

95, 13, 10 Apr. 1973, pages 4 & 5

Burra High School Sports Day. This was held at the Town Oval on 1 May in cold and unpleasant conditions. [Results are printed.]

95, 13, 10 Apr. 1973, page 6

Obituary. William Henry Wahlert died at Burra 7 April aged 83. He was the husband of Elsie and father of Len, Rubell and Phyllis. There are 7 grandchildren and 12 great-grandchildren.

[Born 9 September 1889 Millerton.]

95, 13, 10 Apr. 1973, page 7

Obituary. Miss Edith Affolter, late of Booborowie, died aged 86.

[Born Agnes Edith Affolter 18 June 1886 Hundred of Morgan.]

Obituary. Mrs Anna Irlam of Burra died aged 83.

[Born Anna Ida Mader 1 November 1890 Bundey; she married Edward James Irlam.]

ZOB. Towards the end of 1972 a youth group named ZOB was formed in Burra under the guidance of Miss Lintern. Mr Gerry O’Connor made the former Salvation Army Citadel available as a meeting place and three meetings and a Zob-a-thon to raise funds were held in 1972. T.C. Mends took over from Miss Lintern when she was transferred to Adelaide in her employment. This year so far there have been three meetings with an average attendance of 60. The support of townspeople is needed and another Zob-a-thon is planned for 29 April [in the form of a sponsored walk]. Membership is open to those aged 12-19.

95, 14, 17 Apr. 1973, page 1

Rural Youth Rally at Burra is reported in c. 31⁄3 columns.

On Friday night there was dancing to The Peter Gunn Band at a ball in Burra Town Hall, which resulted in proceeds of $1,137. It was preceded by a pre-ball party at the home of Mr & Mrs L.A. Beinke at which the winner of the Miss Upper North Zone Competition was judged. Winner was Miss Beverly Pink of Clare.

The competition on Saturday saw events for the boys in Merino judging, wool classing, AIS dairy cattle, welding and ewe culling. And for girls in cooking, dressmaking, craft art and wheel changing.

There were also competitions in metal work, photography, sheaf tossing, shearing, poultry, pigs, cattle, live-weight judging and motor cycle skill trials. One competition involved identification of weeds, seeds, machinery parts, liquids, cloths and glasses.

On Saturday evening there was a debate and public speaking, a mannequin parade and awards presentations.

There was a Sunday lunch at the Showgrounds and fun events

Hallett & Districts Schools Athletics Competition was held on the Hallett Oval last Friday. Six teams competed in 63 events. Competing schools were: Hallett, Burra Green, Burra Purple, Burra Gold, Terowie and Mt Bryan. Hallett won the shield for highest aggregate points, from Mt Bryan. The shield for highest percentage of all events went to Terowie with Hallett second. [Results next issue.]

Burra Apex Club. Photo of the handing over of the charter.

95, 14, 17 Apr. 1973, page 2

Advt. Elders-GM will conduct a sale of land in the Burra RSL Hall 11 May for the proprietors of Mt Glen View Stud Pty Ltd of ‘The Pines’ and ‘Glen Dare’ Merino Stud.

‘The Pines’ 889 acres freehold on the northern edge of Burra Township: Part Sections 7, 8, 9, 30, 2278 & section 316 Hundred of Kooringa with stone bungalow of 8 rooms etc.

‘Glen Dare’ 1,953 acres freehold c. 9 miles northeast of Mt Bryan to be offered in four lots.

[Details occupy most of two columns.]

Advt. Elders-GM will conduct a clearing sale for C.J. & R. Simpson whose property has been sold.

On the property 51⁄2 miles northeast of Mt Bryan on Monday 30 April.

[Details occupy 2 columns by 2⁄3 column deep.]

Burra Swimming Pool has now closed for the season, but will open for cash entry in the coming school holidays if the weather is warm enough.

95, 15, 24 Apr. 1973, page 1

The Barker Homes have been completed and are fully occupied. The Board of Management plans an official opening on 27 May when Miss Priscilla Brown, niece of the late John Barker will perform the ceremony. At Present finishing work being done includes bituminising carports and areas behind homes and a retaining wall. Occupants are:

Mr A. Lucas Mrs L. Watson Mrs G. Blieschke

Mrs F. Kellock Mrs J. Lee Mr H. (Paddy) Cossons

Mrs B. Spackman Mr A.L. Bence Mrs D. Malthouse

[Three photographs of the homes and photographs of the residents are published.]

One photograph shows Dudley Jacka, head of D.T. Jacka & Co, the builders, handing the keys of the cottages over to Mr George Hewlett, works supervisor for the architects.

Football. Games in the North Eastern and Mid North Football and Netball Associations commence on 28 April.

North Eastern football teams are South Clare, North Clare, Burra, Booborowie-Hallett, Spalding and Blyth. (six teams).

Each will field an ‘A’ Grade, ‘B’ Grade, Senior Colts and Junior Colts team.

Netball has the same teams for grades A, B, C & D.

In E grade there is no South Clare team.

‘F’ Grade comprises Booborowie-Hallett, Blyth, Burra, Spalding and Leighton.

‘G’ Grade comprises Booborowie-Hallett, Burra, North Clare and Blyth.

95, 15, 24 Apr. 1973, page 4

Burra Primary School. In March children from Grades III, IV & V with Mrs Pens, Mrs Perry & Mr Allan made a day trip to Berri. Visits included a fruit juice factory, can and carton making factory and glacé fruit packing shed. Lunch was a picnic on the banks of the river at Berri and a tea break was held on the lawns of Lake Bonney.

Marriage. Next Saturday at Nelson, New Zealand

John Phillips, eldest son of Mr & Mrs Les Phillips of Burra, will marry Miss Darrell Forbes [sic] of Nelson.

A Goodridge Family Reunion was held 1 April at Nuriootpa. Descendants of the late Mr & Mrs I.J. Goodridge, formerly of Booborowie, met and families attending are listed.

SAR will begin offering day trips by train to Burra from 7 May.

Anzac Day dawn service tomorrow at 6.30 a.m. at Burra War Memorial.

Burra Burra DC, 2 April 1973.

The Golf Club lease is to be continued at a rental of $50 p.a.

The Golf Club is to be responsible for mowing and the cost of excess water and to be in charge of depasturing use.

Council will attend to weed control.

Aberdeen Football Club rental to be $50 p.a.

The club will pay for power and excess water. (Includes oval and netball area.)

Burra Football Club rental for oval is $200 for the season.

Apex Club is granted the use of the Council Chamber as requested.

Crs H. Quinn & Kellock moved that Town Hall toilets be constructed. Carried.

G. Pearce is to be asked to draw up plans for new toilets to be submitted to a special meeting.

[A somewhat garbled account suggests that the DC Clerk would be asked to make arrangements with the Apex Club for control of the Burra Pictures.

95, 15, 24 Apr. 1973, page 8

Hallett & District School Sports. Results are printed.

Marriage. At Clayton Congregational Church, Norwood, 6 April

Rosemary Field & David Herst. [Hirst in paper of 3 April, page 7.]

95, 16, 1 May 1973, page 1

Burra Golf Course. The new 18-hole course was officially opened on 29 April. An 18-hole Mixed Foursome was played and an 18-hole Par Competition.

Winners of the foursome were Mr & Mrs R. Bratten with a net 691⁄2 from Mr & Mrs E. Jeffery.

The 18-hole par competition was won by P. Boucher with a net 68.

John Gordon holds the record with 79 on the new course.

Mr Roy Jeffery as Chairman of the Burra Burra DC opened the course.

Bulk Super

660 tons of bulk super was off-loaded and distributed between Burra & Hallett over the weekend. It came direct from Wallaroo per 8 rail trucks for Burra and 5 for Hallett. Unloading was by a super lift hydraulic grab. The operation involved close co-operation between Adelaide & Wallaroo Fertilizers, SAR and Hirschausen Bros of Burra.

The Anzac Day Dawn service last Wednesday drew about 40 persons. Rev. John Stephenson conducted the service. Wreaths were laid by Ben Kotz representing the local RSL and Roy Jeffery representing the District Council. Annual services were also held at Spalding War Memorial on Sunday 29 April and at Saddleworth on Sunday.

Burra & District Tourist Promotion Committee held its AGM in the Burra Town Hall on 26 April, but a low attendance caused a decision to re-convene on 28 May at the Town Hall. Provision of improved facilities and information needs to be sorted out as well as arrangements for the 1973 Copper festival.

95, 16, 1 May 1973, page 3

St Mary’s. Bishop Rosier will confirm four adults and six children at a service in St Mary’s, Burra, tonight.

Peter Osterhage, younger son of Mr & Mrs Ernst Osterhage of Mt Bryan, left Perth on Sunday with the Army to spend four months on surveying work in Sumatra.

Mavis Satchell of Colonel Light Gardens writes that her granddaughter, Sarah Baker, is one year old and keeps her parents Meredith and Bob on the go. Mavis’s son Richard has his B. Mus.

Malcolm & Ruby Fairchild left for Holland last week to visit their daughter Jill, her husband and family.

95, 17, 8 May 1973, page 1

Rail Tours to Burra. The first SAR package rail tour to Burra ran yesterday and will be available each Monday. Passengers depart Adelaide 8.45 a.m. and arrive at Burra 11.44 a.m. Bus proprietor Alex Smith then takes passengers on a town tour. Departure for Adelaide is at 3.18 p.m.

10th Adelaide Wool Sales 1973 saw values decline 30 to 35%. [Local prices are printed.]

Anglican Harvest Festivals will be held this month:

20 May at Mt Bryan, Hallett and Burra.

27 May at St Edmund’s, Booborowie.

95, 17, 8 May 1973, page 2

The Zob-a-thon on 24 April for the local youth club raised in excess of $250 and was a financial success. The gruelling 10 mile course was attacked by walkers, bike riders, horse and gig, prams and even a bathtub. 80 people enjoyed the spread in the hall afterwards.

Robert Gill of Burra North has obtained credits in Automotive and General Engineering in his apprenticeship course. He is employed by the local firm of J.J. & B.C. Richards.

95, 17, 8 May 1973, page 8

D. Wedding writes to report on action taken on the decision to request the District Council of Burra Burra to reduce the rate on the assessment to return a rate comparable with the 1971-72 financial year, as requested at a public meeting at Booborowie on 25 September 1972. A further approach was made on 1 May 1973 following a recent meeting of the local branch of the United Farmers and Graziers’. Other members of the delegation were Jim Quinn and Lance Lines. The delegation has received no indication that the request has been acceded to.

95, 18, 15 May 1973, page 1

The Royal Commission into LGA Boundaries is preparing to take evidence.

‘The Pines’ of 884 acres 27 perches was sold at the Burra RSL Hall on 11 May for $119.50 per acre to P. & R. Stockman.

‘Glen Dare’ of 1,953 acres was sold on 11 May in one lot. It was bought by Kiwi Investments of Adelaide for $55 per acre.

95, 18, 15 May 1973, page 7

Judy Oates has come second in the state in her Midwifery Exams.

‘Mick’ Miller of the local police has been promoted to Senior Constable.

Fred Acott will be acting District Clerk during Mr & Mrs Perry’s tour of Europe.

Obituary. Edward Sydney Williams died 10 May 1973 in Adelaide. He was a former Burra identity and for many years a keen member of the Leighton Rifle Club and later of the Burra Rifle Club.

[Born 23 August 1889 Kooringa.]

Di Day is recovering from shock and bruises following a motor car accident near Canberra last week. Her mother who was also a passenger suffered fractured ribs.

Ayers St Bridge. Work appears to be progressing satisfactorily.

The Natural Gas Pipeline has almost been laid as far as Samin’s Mine workings.

95, 19, 22 May 1973, page 1

Tennis Clubs

Separate meetings of the Aberdeen and Kooringa Tennis Clubs to discuss amalgamation have resulted in a recommendation to go ahead and a meeting is consequently scheduled for the Aberdeen Football Club Rooms at 8 p.m. tomorrow. Last season Aberdeen had six teams: Two ‘A’, 3 ‘B’ and a Junior. Kooringa had four teams: 1 ‘A’, 2 ‘B’ and a Junior. Aberdeen has its own five courts, while Kooringa has been renting courts from the school.

It is thought the amalgamated club would be likely to ask Council permission for three more courts adjacent to their present courts at Burra North.

Barkers of Baldina Cottage Homes have been occupied now for a few weeks, but they will officially be opened by Miss Priscilla Brown, step-daughter of the late J.R. Barker, at 2.30 p.m. next Sunday. There is sufficient land available for a further nine units and it is the intention of the Board to proceed immediately with site preparation and erect the additional units as finance permits.

Burra Mine

The new ore roaster being constructed by Envirotech Australia Pty Ltd for Samin Ltd’s Phase 2 extension at the Burra Mine is nearing completion.

[Photo of Roaster Shell, showing ‘portholes’ indicating the spacing of the 12 hearths inside.

Photo of centre column and form work prepared for constructing one of the hearths.]

Some 400 tons of refractory fire bricks have been bought from Kaiser Refractories Plant at Uandarra, NSW.

The work on the hearths is expected to be completed by the end of May. The ore enters at the top of the roaster and is circulated by means of rake arms from hearth to hearth to reach the floor at 1,200°F. It is then carried by means of a heat resistant stainless steel screw conveyor to a 65 ton rotary unit to be cooled to 250°F in preparation for further processing.

[Photo of trees in front of Samin’s Administration Building.]

95, 19, 22 May 1973, page 2

95, 19, 22 May 1973, page 5

Burra Red Cross held seven meetings for the financial year. There is a financial membership of 25 and an average attendance of 12. Wool Day in June 1972 raised $217. $250 was sent to Headquarters in July 1972 and $200 in April 1973.

95, 19, 22 May 1973, page 8

Burra Burra DC, 7 May

A letter is to be sent to Samin Ltd and to the National Trust that items in the Mine are Council property to be held by the Burra Branch of the National Trust of SA and an inventory of items is to be made for record purposes.

A not is to be sent to the owner of lot 64 to remove a dangerous wall and re-erect it.

Mr Ian Auhl was thanked for donating a framed copy of the original Government Gazette proclaiming the District of Burra in 1872.

95, 20, 29 May 1973, page 1

St Mary’s had two interesting visitors on Sunday.

Miss Julia Szuster played the organ in the absence of the regular organist Mrs John Gordon. She is the musical advisor to the Primary Section of the Education Department and a member of the Corinthian Singers.

Brother Geoffrey Calf of the Society of the Sacred Mission assisted the Rector Father John Stephenson. He had been secretary to Fr Nicholas Allenby when the latter was elected Bishop of Kuching and more recently has been in Adelaide University studying Chinese History and language.

Tennis. A meeting last Wednesday decided to combine the Burra and Burra North [Aberdeen & Kooringa] Tennis Clubs. Elected to the new Burra Tennis Club were:

Patron R. Reed

President J. Secomb

Vice-President Don Lloyd

Junior Vice-President R. Nicholls

Secretary D. Calder

Assistant Secretary Margaret Lloyd

Treasurer R. Buckton

Assistant Treasurer Miss C. Nicholls

Football. The program for the Central Zone Carnival on 9 June and 11 June, when Mid North plays the Eastern League, is printed.

95, 20, 29 May 1973, pages 1, 4 & 5

Barkers of Baldina Aged Cottage Homes were opened by Miss Priscilla Brown, step-daughter of the late J.R. Barker. Mr R.B. Jennison, Vice Chairman of the Board of Management, welcomed those present. The Chairman of the District Council Mr Roy Jeffery addressed the meeting. The late John Robert Barker had taken over the running of ‘Baldina’ on the completion of his education [and had bequeathed the bulk of the funds that enabled the construction of the cottages]. Mr Max Gilgen, Assistant Director of Social Security in SA, also spoke, welcoming this addition to the services to the Burra Community. He spoke on the role of the Department and the various types of accommodation it helps to fund. The Commonwealth granted $47,600, which represented the maximum available for the project. Mr Ron Pearse, Chairman of the Board of Management, outlined Mr Barker’s wishes in planning the cottages. There is sufficient money in hand to level a site for a further nine units, which will be built as soon as finance allows. Miss Brown then gave a short address expressing her satisfaction with the building and furnishing of the homes, before declaring them open. [Photograph of J.R. Barker.]

95, 20, 29 May 1973, Supplement

Venture

With this issue came Volume 1 Number 1 of Venture, dated 30 May 1973.

This was a 16-page magazine whose articles were largely directed towards the interests of the rural community, but with some articles of more general interest.

95, 21, 5 June 1973, page 1

Venture a free paper was distributed last week with the Record. Postal regulations will prohibit this in the future. Pick-up points for Venture will be organised through the town and district. In Burra they will be at: the Record Office, Burra Radio & Electrical Book-Shop, Ford’s Roadhouse, Gill’s Store and T.W. Wilkinson & Co.

[Places were also listed for Booborowie, Farrell Flat, Hallett, Mt Bryan, Robertstown and Spalding.]

Accident. A motor vehicle driven by Charles Rutherford collided with a stationary truck owned by the Natural Gas Authority in front of the RSL Building. A passenger, John Nicholson, suffered concussion and abrasions. The driver was charged with driving under the influence and fined $150 and had his licence suspended for six months.

Melbourne Wool Sales this week saw prices rise 2.5%. Prices for Rec C. Warnes & Co. of ‘The Gap’ are cited and vary from 2931⁄2 cents per kilo for 8 bales AAA com. to 168 cents per kilo for 6 bales AA Pcs.

95, 21, 5 June 1973, pages 5 & 4-5 gutter

Tennis. The Final report of the Aberdeen Tennis Club.

The club started about 50 years ago and at the end of the 1972-73 season has amalgamated with the Kooringa club to form the Burra Tennis Club. The season began with a fresh coat of paint on the Clubhouse. We fielded 2 ‘A’ teams, 3 ‘B’ teams and a junior team. The White ‘A’ team were premiers. The ‘B’ Purple team lost their final to Spalding and the Juniors also lost to Kooringa. The Easter Tournament was again a success, as were fund-raising efforts throughout the year. There was also a successful junior tournament. We were sorry to farewell our President, Dennis O’Reilly, his wife Rona and family, at the end of the season, when they relocated to New Zealand. We thank them for their hard work. The season ended with a tea at the Aberdeen Football Club Rooms on 14 April. During the season we paid the balance owing on the No. 5 court and so had five good courts to use.

Hedley Scholz writes a long letter on behalf of the Eudunda Actionist Group of the League of Rights.

[Generally he fears the introduction of a socialist state by the Whitlam Government and a move towards a totalitarian state. Governments which are elected on the basis of promising the most benefits from the public treasury are inevitably followed by a dictatorship.]

Jenny Anderson will marry Gary Hirschausen.

Mark Gilpin married Josephine Sheppard, daughter of Mr & Mrs D. Sheppard of Mt Gambier.

95, 22, 12 June 1973, page 1

Burra Burra DC

Dilapidated Houses Condemned. Under the Health Act six houses in Burra have been entirely condemned and another seven are severely restricted in that they cannot be sold as houses nor let to new tenants.

The dumping if old car bodies within the town is also a concern.

Council will proceed with a deputation to the Mines Department in regard to Royalties.

No objections were voiced re the proposed damming of the Burra Creek and a loan for this has been negotiated.

Council has granted Samin permission to pump water from the Mine into Burra Creek in order to de-water the Mine. Water will be conveyed in an 8 inch pipe under the main road near the old Mine entrance.

SA Housing Trust has allowed the Council to fence off part of the new housing settlement on Smelts Road for tree planting.

Walkerville All Cars Club will conduct a rally through the district on 28 & 29 July.

Bridget O’ Connor has entered the Princess of Industry Quest for girls 10-13, in aid of the Home for Incurables.

Table Tennis Tournament at Booborowie by the North-Eastern Table Tennis Association last Wednesday and Thursday attracted 55 entrants.

Men’s Singles Champion A. Day

Men’s Doubles Champions A. Day & C. van der Does

Men’s Handicap Singles B. Hall

Mixed Handicap Doubles A. Phillips & D. Richardson

Ladies’ Handicap Doubles C. Angel & D. Richardson

Men’s Handicap Doubles N. Kelly & D. Gent

Mixed Doubles Champions C. van der Does & D. Day

Junior Girls’ Singles Champion D. Richardson

Boys’ Singles Champion N. Webster

Junior Girls’ Handicap Singles C. Angel

Junior Boys’ Handicap Singles N. Webster

Men’s No. 1 Plate W. Warner

Ladies’ No. 1 Plate A. Webster

Men’s No. 2 Plate B. Hall

Ladies No. 2 Plate J. Goodridge

95, 22, 12 June 1973, pages 1 & 4

Martin Dunstan writes a letter re his grandfather, John Dunstan and his links with the town.

He enclosed a photo of the Steam Saw Mills in Aberdeen c. 1880 in which John Dunstan was part owner.

John Dunstan was born at Gwenap in Cornwall 4 March 1851 and arrived at Port Adelaide on the Calabar before he was two years old. With his father and mother and baby brother, he made the trip to Burra in a bullock dray in a fortnight. After five years Captain Dunstan took over the Whealsara [sic] Copper Mines north of Bundaleer Station. When a school was established there it was in a dugout in the side of a creek and it was there that John Dunstan learnt spelling and reading in the morning and sewing in the afternoon. At these mines John Dunstan began picking copper ore when nine or ten years old. After three years the family moved back to Burra, where John took night school and later attended F.R. White’s Commercial Academy.

[The above is copied from a story he gave the News in 1923.]

He went dispensing for Dr Nutt and then became clerk of the Redruth Court and later book-keeper for Dr T.H. Mayne. In 1869 he started work with S. Drew & Co. as an accountant and corresponding clerk and stayed for seven years, also acting as clerk for the Burra District Council and auditor later of the Burra Corporation, the Mt Bryan District Council and several mines.

In 1876 he joined forces with G. & W. Sara as timber merchants, builders and contractors. From practically nothing they built a wonderful business with activities all over the colony. Among the notable buildings they erected were the Burra Model School, Gladstone Gaol (£21,640), Corny Point Lighthouse, Roseworthy College, the Adelaide Railway Goods Sheds and most of the railway stations on the northern and hills lines. In a few years the firm was employing 220 men. After W. Sara retired, the firm continued to prosper as Sara & Dunstan. John Dunstan also worked on the Black Hills mining venture and was a part owner of the Burra Record. [Presumably in the period before F.W. Holder gained full control.]

At 30 he was a JP and soon became a Councillor and later Mayor of Burra. Against strong opposition he instituted tree planting. With Cr John Lewis he acquired land for a recreation ground with a 999-year lease from the Burra Burra Mines. He was also a member of the Burra Hospital Board, the Institute Committee and the Burra School Board of Advice. He joined with Mr Lewis in bringing the Burra children down to Adelaide for the Adelaide Exhibition, against strong opposition. In this he was assisted by the late W.B. Rounsevell. The money left over was used to erect the fountain standing near the Anglican Church.

He was also President of the Burra Literary Society. In 1891 he left Burra for Broken Hill, where he carried out similar works and became Mayor in 1899.

On 1 September 1953 the Record referred to Mr Ben Dunstan of Mt Bryan, who was a brother to John Dunstan.

[Martin Dunstan then goes on to say he is something of a fanatic on scrapbooks – in particular on Willunga and he appeals for any information relevant to that. He also says he has his grandfather’s writing books, used at the Academy and two framed farewell messages from the town and the Literary Society, that were presented to his grandfather and he offers to lend his family relics for historic occasions in Burra.]

Willalo Ladies’ Guild met last Tuesday and decided to close, almost exactly 40 years after its first meeting on 7 June 1933. Over recent years the President has been Mrs R. Possingham and the Secretary-Treasurer has been Mrs M. Hausler.

95, 23, 19 June 1973, page 1

Burra Women’s Branch of the LCL held its AGM in the CWA Rooms on Friday. President Mrs R. Collins was in the chair. An address was given by Geoffrey Dare on ‘Politics in America’.

Elected were: President, Mrs Ron Collins; Vice-President, Mrs R. Pearse; Secretary, Mrs N. Finch and Treasurer, Mrs T. Padbury.

Speeches were also given by Mr Allen, MP for Frome and Mr Geddes, the Member for Northern.

95, 23, 19 June 1973, pages 1 & 8

Ian Auhl repeats the report from 15 December 1909 of:

The Grand Balloon Ascent at Burra Oval on 11 December 1909.

Oddly Australia’s first powered flight had been a 51⁄2 second event at Victoria Park, Sydney on 9 December 1909 by Colin de Fris in a Wright bi-plane. The first balloon flight in SA was from North Terrace in 1871 and in 189o the two sisters Gladys & Val van Tassell had ascended and then returned to earth by triple parachute. When the article was being researched Ian Auhl asked Mrs Mary Walker, widow of the late Oswald Walker, who was then 90, if she remembered the 1909 event. She did, clearly, and even recalled that the pilot Rinaldo had landed on a woodheap at Killicoat’s (Abberton Park.)

Viceroy Tea Carnival

A great crowd assembled on Victoria Park on Saturday to witness the balloon ascent arranged by Messrs Wilkinson & Co. of Adelaide as a novel way of advertising their Viceroy Tea. It created a big sensation. The inflation of the balloon was watched with great interest. At the report of a pistol shot, it was released and rose quickly some hundreds of feet, carrying with it Rinaldo, seated comfortably on a trapeze. At the climax he hung by his toes on the fast drifting balloon and then, hanging by his hands, he turned a complete somersault before taking his seat again. The crowd cheered. Another pistol shot was the signal for him to drop from the balloon and his body fell towards the earth rapidly, but suddenly a parachute opened and Rinaldo was seen seated on the trapeze, from which he saluted the crowd with a cheery wave of his hand. Eventually he landed somewhat uncomfortably in P.L. Killicoat’s woodheap at Abberton Park, sustaining a shaking and several cuts, but with his grit and determination undiminished. W.J. Richardson brought Rinaldo back to Victoria Park in his motor car.

SAR Timetable

Burra Hospital was visited on 2 May 1973 and the article reports statistics for 1972-73.

95, 24, 26 June 1973, page 6

Advt. Burra Pictures

Barbara Streisand & Ryan O’Neal in What’s Up Doc

Plus A Big Hand for the Little Lady

Economic Wool Producers held successful meetings recently in Hawker, Jamestown and Burra. More than 200 woolgrowers attended to discuss ways of reducing wool selling costs and maximising competition. Mr Jim Maple-Brown, Chairman of Directors, addressed the meetings. A main aim is to reduce labour costs. Objective measurement was also discussed.

Weather in the week has seen frosts and fogs and some more rain, to bring June’s total so far to 321 points.

Mr Fred Pearce will be 89 on 29 June.

The Meals on Wheels ‘girls’ used the new section of the Hospital kitchen today and they say it is beautiful.

Kutchenmeister) [sic], Iris (Mrs Lomman), Lily (Mrs Lambert), Gladys (Mrs Clayton) and Arnold (deceased).

[Born Selina Jane Kemble 16 April 1882 Naracoorte.]

Obituary. Mrs Ruby Rowe has died aged 64. She was the wife of the late Jack Rowe and mother of Joan (Mrs Machin) and John. [Born Ruby Phillis Voumard 24 August 1908 Kooringa: died 25 June 1973.]

[Born Zelma Ida Achwartz 8 November 1909 Peter’s Hill.]

95, 25, 3 July 1973, page 1

Legislative Council Reform. There have been major changes to the Legislative Council.

All persons qualified to vote for the House of Assembly will now automatically be on the Legislative Council roll and be entitled to vote. (Though voting for the Legislative Council remains voluntary.)

The five electorates will be replaced by a single state-wide electorate returning 22 members – each serving six years with half retiring every three years. They will be elected on the basis of proportional representation using optional preferential voting.

The minimum age for candidates for election has been lowered from 30 to 18.

The Burra Record and other newspapers went metric from 25 June 1973.

11 Hearing Impaired Students from Erindale Speech and Hearing Centre visited Burra for a two day Social Studies Survey Camp and they stayed in Paxton Square.

A similar group from Woodville Speech and Hearing Centre visited earlier in the year. The recent visitors went to Waters’ Bakery, various churches, the Courthouse (to see old records), the Reformatory [Redruth Gaol], the school, the telephone exchange, the Burra Record office and to see shearing at Farrell Flat.

95, 25, 3 July 1973, page 2

Advt. Elders-GM will sell ‘Caroona’ on Friday 10 August at 2.30 p.m. in the RSL Hall, Burra.

The property is 18-20 miles northeast of Mt Bryan and Burra, of 47,0841⁄4 acres, perpetual lease and is offered in four lots.

Lot I ‘Homestead’ of 14,677 acres

Lot II ‘Woolshed’ of 18,419 acres

Lot III ‘Killicoat’s’ of 9,560 acres

Lot IV ‘Jones’ of 4,4281⁄4 acres

[Considerably more details are printed.]

95, 25, 3 July 1973, page 7

Burra Burra DC

The first meeting of the new Council. D.L. Lloyd was the new Councillor. W. Brown was elected Chairman. Cr Roy Jeffery was elected Deputy Chairman.

Birth. To Joan [check this name] & Gordon Goodridge at Clare Hospital, a daughter.

Scouts. Burra 1st Scouts have been renovating their hall at Hanson. Seven Scouts and their leaders filled cracks in preparation for painting on Sunday. This Friday the scouts go to Riverton to see aspects of rescue work demonstrated by the Riverton Civil Defence Unit. Cubs will meet as usual at Hanson.

Accidents

Nick Bence lost skin and fractured a wrist coming off his motor cycle near Hanson on Friday.

Stephen Turner rolled his car at Hanson on Sunday morning.

95, 25, 3 July 1973, page 8

Burra Bowling Club. President’s Report 1972-73

The club again had a successful year. Unfortunate obituaries among members this year were Jack Mitchell, Joe Lloyd, Jack Allen and Bill Carpenter. Max Jacka, Bert Wardle and Bill Byles all went to live in Adelaide.

Burra CWA held its AGM and elected: President, Mrs R. Alderson; Vice-Presidents, Mrs R. Jennison & Mrs E. Baulderstone; Secretary, Mrs W. Nankivell; Assistant Secretary, Mrs E. Hore; Treasurer, Mrs E. Pietsch.

The secretary presented the 46th annual report of the Burra Branch of the CWA. There were 10 meetings for the year with an average attendance of 24 from 48 members.

95, 26, 10 July 1973, page 1

Burra Burra DC. Action will be taken against cyclists on footpaths. Mr & Mrs Andrew Tennant were in Burra last week and advised that a Town Clock had been donated and will be erected in the near future. The Chairman Cr W. Brown expressed the District’s thanks. The exact site for the clock has still to be determined.

Council has asked the Highways & Local Government Department for permission to erect signage concerning historical sites on the approaches to the town.

The previous assessment has been adopted again with the necessary changes.

Council has agreed to accept ownership of the Mt Bryan Recreation Grounds and will lease them to the Mt Bryan Cricket Club on a yearly basis.

Council’s contribution to the Fire Brigade costs will rise by 50%.

Rising wages are also causing concern, with a rise of $7,000 to $8,000 expected in the coming year.

Flinders University has enquired concerning access roads to blocks it owns in the Hundred of Rees, Hallett in connection with an experimental station to be opened by them.

Leighton School children will attend the next Council meeting.

Burra Apex Club officers for 1973-74 take over in August: President, Grant Good; Senior Vice-President, Gordon Wooton; Junior Vice-President, Terry Rule and Secretary, Murray Mitchell.

Underdale Speech & Hearing Centre’s visit to Burra is reported in 13⁄4 columns. Thank are expressed for their reception by the Headmaster, Barry Richardson.

95, 26, 10 July 1973, page 2

‘A’ Grade Auburn 69 defeated Aberdeen 11

‘B2’ Grade Riverton White 58 defeated Aberdeen 28

95, 26, 10 July 1973, page 4

Marriage. Saturday 23 June at Hare St Methodist Church, Kurralta Park

Natalie Rawe, youngest daughter of Mr & Mrs S. Rawe of Clarence Gardens, married

Dennis Short, second son of Mr & Mrs Ken Short of Farrell Flat.

Burra North Red Cross. Annual Report. Membership was 41 with an average attendance 14-18. They met at the Aberdeen Football Club Rooms. Major fund-raising for the year was catering for the Masonic Ball. They also had a stall at the Copper Festival and served refreshments when the Blood Bank visited Burra. In the year our Patroness Mrs Heinrich died and Mrs Cox, another staunch member, left to live at Aldersgate Village. Elected: President, Mrs I. Hirschausen; Secretary, Mrs R.M. Jennison and Treasurer, Mrs S. Scroop.

95, 26, 10 July 1973, page 5

CWA AGMs for Mt Bryan and Hallett branches are reported.

Mt Bryan had 23 members, but was concerned about falling numbers.

Hallett Branch was reporting many younger ladies joining.

John Wayne in Rio Lobo

Notice. It is the intention of the Burra Tennis Club to become incorporated one month from the publication of this notice.

95, 26, 10 July 1973, page 7

Weather. Lately fine, with one or two heavy fogs and a few frosts.

Barry Griffiths, formerly with Elders-GM in Burra, started work with Bennett & Fisher in Adelaide yesterday.

Tony Wall suffered a lacerated nose and a twisted ankle on Saturday morning when his motor cycle collided with a car at the corner of Thames and Commercial Streets.

Obituary. Mrs Annie Jean Bruce, late of Booborowie, died at Gawler last week. She was the wife of the late Clarence Andrew (Billy) Bruce. [Born Annie Jean Mitchell 10 April 1899 Littlehampton.]

Table Tennis. Burra Blue defeated Spalding White.

95, 27, 17 July 1973, page 1

P.D. Ryan of Burra North has had his home broken into and money and other items were stolen during the week before the 13 July. About $500 was taken. After investigation four juveniles and a 31-year-old person were apprehended and charged and remanded to appear at the Burra Court, sitting at Clare on 21 August. All but about $70 has been recovered.

National Bible Society Week will be marked by films screened at Redruth Memorial Hall on 29 July.

95, 27, 17 July 1973, pages 1 & 8

Mid North Tourist Development Association AGM

Chairman D.E. Wilsdon said tourist was Australia’s ninth largest industry and has the fastest growth rate; but if we were complacent the opportunity to benefit would pass us by. He reported on their Emblem Competition, won by Miss Eunice Mosey and on the ANTA Convention in Sydney. Moves to amalgamate with the Southern Flinders Indian Pacific Development Association are reported and reasons given why it was decided not to proceed. Attractions which have been developed in the last 12 months are: Rail Tours to Burra, Swaggie Tours, Burra Mines (old & new), Wolta Wolta, Cumberlandvale, Wineries, Geralka Rural Farm, Motel extensions and the National Trust. He felt Burra was poised to make the most of its attractions with the Copper festival being an encouragement for further developments, but that Clare was ambivalent, with some residents feeling that tourists may upset their already comfortable existence. Some people in Clare are ready to act on the area’s great potential, but many are prepared to let the opportunity slide.

Hanson CWA held its AGM on 21 June. 12 members attended. Three new members were welcomed. Membership is 19, with an average attendance of 12.

Golden Wedding. Albert and Dora Bruce have celebrated the 50th anniversary of their marriage at World’s End Methodist Church. The entire bridal group was able to attend. [Photograph]

95, 27, 17 July 1973, page 6

Advt. Burra Pictures, 21 July

Michael Crawford & Ryan O’Neal in The Games

Trafficator Arms are now illegal as a method of signalling turns, as from 1 July. Flashing turn indicators are now required.

95, 27, 17 July 1973, page 7

Mary Woollacott returns to write the ‘Out and About’ column after her trip to England.

Marriage. Bronwyn Disher of North Booborowie and Raydon Thomas of Gulnare will marry on Friday at Gartrell Memorial Church, Rose Park.

Jack Earle, who left Burra in the 1940s, was back for a visit in the past week.

95, 27, 17 July 1973, page 8

Table Tennis. ‘A’ Grade: Burra Blue defeated Spalding.

W.E.D. Young writes re the parachutist who descended into the woodheap at Burra North. Local boys were so inspired by this that they constructed ‘a parachute’ from canvas, ropes and binder-twine. The top of O’Leary’s slaughterhouse roof was selected for a take-off point with W.E.D. as the parachutist. In a cold withering wind he launched himself from about 45 ft and landed in a heap of junk, badly bruised, with a broken jaw and a lacerated tongue. [William (Bill) Young would have been 11 in December 1909, when the parachutist landed in the woodheap.]

95, 28, 24 July 1973, page 1

Samin Ltd is presently making copper oxide. With the commissioning of the Stage II plant at the Mine in the near future this will become the basic ingredient in the making of a premium grade copper sulphate. This venture links Samin Ltd’s mining resources with the manufacturing and marketing techniques of Adelaide Wallaroo Fertilisers Ltd. The output, it is understood, will satisfy Australian demand as well as provide a product for overseas. Copper has reached a five-year peak in price, rising from $1,240 per tonne at the start of July to $1,400 10 or 12 days ago. At the end of 1972 it was $904 per tonne.

Burra Rural Youth met on 16 July at the Show Hall. It was an evening of interesting demonstrations. Kym Dixon demonstrated how to distil wine and Andrew Thomas showed how to reload your own bullets using a bullet press.

95, 28, 24 July 1973, page 3

95, 28, 24 July 1973, page 4

Winter Inter-School Sports Carnival is reported.

Burra Branch of the Mothers’ & Babies’ Health Association held its AGM recently. Life membership was conferred on Mrs Murray Odgers. Elected were: President, Mrs Peter McDowell; Senior Vice-President, Mrs Alan Day; Junior Vice-President, Mrs Gladys Hall; Secretary, Mrs Loren Reed; Assistant Secretary, Mrs Sue Ogden and Treasurer, Mrs John Secomb. There are 20 financial members with an average attendance of 15.

95, 28, 24 July 1973, page 5

Burra Rural Youth held its AGM on 5 July.

The big event in the year was the successful Rural Youth Rally. In October the club ran a successful Copper Festival Ball. It also ran a cabaret, a tennis tournament, cleared up around two homes as a bushfire project and had a ‘B’ grade debating team. In sport there were football, netball and swimming teams. The annual Christmas dinner was held at the Bon Accord and a Mock Wedding was celebrated at the Royal Exchange. There were interesting and instructive meetings, as well as social gatherings. Heather Keane is being sponsored in the Miss Australia Quest – money raised goes to the Spastic Centre. Elected were: President, Don Griffen; Vice-President, Michael Bradley; Secretary, Judy Beinke, Assistant Secretary, Ros. Parks and Treasurer, Lou Georgiou.

Burra Red Cross held its AGM. For the year there were 25 members with an average attendance of 10 at the 8 meetings. $450 was forwarded to Headquarters this financial year. Elected for 1973-74 were: President, Mrs Baulderstone; Vice-Presidents, Mrs Wright & Mrs Odgers; Secretary, Mrs Rich and Treasurer, Mrs Heitbrink.

[Harold Lawrence Foote born 13 April 1908 Hindmarsh SA.]

Elaine Heneker of Mt Bryan has transferred to Burra Hospital after nursing at Maitland for some time.

95, 28, 24 July 1973, page 8

Underdale Speech & Hearing Centre. Essays by four of the students who visited Burra recently are printed.

95, 29, 31 July 1973, page 1

Burra Primary School Council has convened an Education Symposium at the Burra Town Hall on 10 August. The Director General of Education Mr A.W. Jones will address the meeting, which id directed at parents. Education is a continuing process. Methods and subjects are changing and parents need to know what is going on to stimulate and encourage their children and to play a greater role in the whole process.

[An extended summary of Mr Jones’ career follows.]

Other speakers:

Mrs T. Nolan, immediate past President of the Welfare Clubs of SA.

Mr Ted O’Keefe of Special Education will speak on Developmental Reading.

Peter Jackson, Headmaster of Eudunda Area School will speak on Individual Progression in SA Schools

[Notes on Mr Jackson appear on page 4.]

Mr S.L. McMillan of the Department of Further Education will speak on the role of his department.

[Notes on Mr McMillan appear on page 4.]

Mr Kevin Heath, Director of the Centre of Personal Encounter [COPE], a Division of the Marriage Guidance Council, will speak on Health Education for Schools.

[Notes on Mr Heath appear on page 4.]

Booborowie School played host to five American students under the American Field Services Scholarships International. While in the area the students visited K.S. & E.M. Trengove’s Poll Short Horn Stud, John Sommerville’s piggery, Booborowie School, Booborowie Seed Pty Ltd, J. & F. Sullivan & Co.’s Merino Sheep Stud, shearing at John Drew’s ‘Windy Brae’, Burra Miners’ Dugouts and the Burra Mine.

95, 29, 31 July 1973, page 2

Golf. Burra’s Club Championship Semi-Finals were won by Peter Dignan & Stan Longford in ‘A’ Grade. In ‘B’ Grade the winners were D. Villis and J. Bogisch Jnr. In ‘C’ Grade Allen Baulderstone and E. Zanker were the winners.

Table Tennis. Burra 17 defeated Spalding 4.

At the end of the third round in ‘A’ Grade Burra Blue and Burra Gold top the table.

In the ‘B’ Grade, with two matches to go, Burra Blue is 5th and Burra Gold is 10th (last).

95, 29, 31 July 1973, page 6

Advt. Burra Pictures, 4 August

The Computer Wore Tennis Shoes

The Trouble with Girls

Films at CWA Hall on 20 July.

R. Byles of Samin Ltd, with the aid of slides, traced the development of mining from the fourteenth century to the present, to a capacity crowd.

Mr Ian Auhl showed the film of Burra made in 1915 by Mr Lester featuring Australia Day and Belgian Flag Day and a film made in Clare in 1928 as well as a Charlie Chaplin film of the same era, followed by a film of Burra made for the National Trust for TV.

95, 29, 31 July 1973, page 7

Birth. The first baby born in the new Midwifery Wing of the Burra Hospital arrived on 30 July to Janet & Kevin Whittington of Hallett. She was a daughter, named in the paper of 7 August as Kerry Michelle.

Birth. On 26 July at Ashford Hospital to Noel & Valerie Webb nee Griffiths, a son, Nicholas Nyron.

Birth. On Saturday at Calvary Hospital, North Adelaide, to Eileen & John Quinn of Mt Bryan, a son, John Anthony.

Birth. At Clare on 25 July to Mr & Mrs Bob Simpson, a daughter.

Ned O’Brien is heading to Mt Isa next week to take part in the Rodeo there, accompanied by Matt Reilly.

Accident. A car overturned 11⁄2 miles south of Koonoona on Sunday and four travellers were admitted to Burra Hospital: Richard McDonald of Mansfield Park (driver), Dennis Beverage (13), Christine beverage (11) and Pamela Beverage (10).

95, 30, 7 Aug. 1973, page 1

Burra Burra DC

The general rate has risen to 1.6 cents in the dollar to bring in $11,720 more. Rising wages will add $8,000 a year in costs. New plant is also needed – approval from the Minister will be sought to purchase a new D6 Dozer, 212 Power Grader and Low Loader. (Hiring out of these will offset the costs and negotiations have already begun for hire of the ‘Dozer’ for work at the Mine.)

With a further $6,400 Rural Relief Scheme grant to be spent on uncompleted projects, work at the Town Hall is proceeding. The roof is on the toilets and ceiling and wiring is installed. Floors and plastering is to be done this week.

Aberdeen Football Club

Trevor Wall, on behalf of his family, presented a shield for the best and fairest junior in memory of Robert Wall.

A clock in the club rooms was also unveiled by Bruce Stockman, Vice-President of the Mid North League and a Past President of the club. It is in memory of Robert Wall and Phillip Elliott, both of whom played for the club.

Burra Hospital

The new wing is completed internally, with just a few finishing external details to come. It brings the Hospital into line with some of the best in the state. The sunroom on the western end will be a useful addition. In the wards new beds have replaced old and they can be raised and lowered. Children’s Ward has large observation windows from the corridor. The whole has been designed to be light and cheerful. A sunken area alongside the Children’s bath allows a staff member to wash a child without uncomfortable bending. Several new share rooms have been built. The staff dining room opens into a small courtyard. The kitchen is large and modern with stainless steel equipment. A small room adjacent is provided for Meals on Wheels helpers and communicates with the kitchen through hatches. Large incinerators have been placed in the old kitchen.

The Labour Ward and its satellite rooms are business-like and can deal with any emergency. General patients can be placed in unoccupied midwifery wards if it is necessary. The whole appearance is of hotel-like comfort combined with every consideration of practicality from emergency lighting to the 2,000 gallon rainwater tank beneath the floor and the whole now being on one level makes life much easier for those working there.

95, 30, 7 Aug. 1973, page 2

‘B’ Grade Champion is Don Villis.

‘C’ Grade Champion is E. Zanker.

95, 30, 7 Aug. 1973, page 7

Marriage. At St Mary’s, Burra, next Saturday

Judy Heinrich, younger daughter of Mr & Mrs Eddie Heinrich of Burra North, will marry

Graham Willis, son of Mr & Mrs Frank Willis of Booborowie.

Mr & Mrs Bill Phin of Netley and formerly of Hallett will celebrate their Golden Wedding [on 8 August].

Obituary. Bert Samuels, former postmaster of Mt Bryan for many years, died on 29 July.

The Church of England Dinner Dance on Friday raised c. $500; about $50 more than last year.

‘Young’ Bill Kellaway visited the town yesterday. He left Burra in 1939. The late Bill Kellaway Sen. was a star footballer for Aberdeen about 50 years ago.

SA Art Gallery’s travelling exhibition, Gallery of European Art, will be in Burra next Monday and Tuesday.

95, 30 (2), 14 Aug. 1973, page 1 [Second use of No. 30 in this volume.]

Education Symposium. There was good support from surrounding districts, though local interest was disappointing. Questions from the floor demonstrated the interest in both remedial reading and individual progression. The general lack of local support gives little encouragement to organisers.

‘Caroona’ Station was auctioned by Elders-GM last Friday in two lots.

‘Homestead’ and ‘Woolshed’ were purchased by Guardian Nominee Pty Ltd for $7.25 per acre for the 31,9861⁄2 acres.

‘Killicoat’s and Jones’s’ 13,9881⁄4 acres went to H.J. Broad Pty Ltd of ‘Old Canowie’ for $8.40 per acre.

1,177 acres of ‘Homestead’ was excluded and will be kept by Flinders University for research purposes.

Football

Gary Davis of Riverton Club won the Mid-North goal-kickers award for 1973 with 56 goals in ‘A’ Grade, with Brian Davis of Mintaro-Manoora second with 42 and I. James of Aberdeen third with 39.

95, 30 (2), 14 Aug. 1973, page 2

Notice. From 15 August 1973 Mine Tailings are no longer available to the public. Samin Ltd.

Marriage. Next Saturday at St Mary’s, Burra

Marion Kotz, daughter of Mr & Mrs J.L. Kotz will marry David Thamm, eldest son of Mr & Mrs R.L. Thamm.

The Football Club Cabaret in the Town Hall on Saturday was a good show.

The Thames St Bridge is under repair. New pipes are being placed under it to bring it to the same standard as the bridge on Cemetery Road, recently given the same treatment.

95, 30 (2), 14 Aug. 1973, page 8

Netball

‘A’ Grade Burra forfeited to Blyth

‘B’ Grade Blyth 37 defeated Burra 24

95, 32, 21 Aug. 1973, page 1

Burra Burra DC will destroy weeds on properties from 31 August unless landowners/occupiers have done so. Costs will be recovered.

The estate of the late J.R. Barker leaves the interest on $8,000 investment for the maintenance of Barker family graves and general maintenance of the Burra Cemetery.

The Education Department was granted the use of the swimming pool for learn to swim classes from 7-18 January next year.

A two-year plan was introduced to clean up the old ballast quarry area including the destruction of weeds and the planting of trees.

Council will place signs at the entrance to the town for tourist promotion.

Council will apply for subsidiary grants to maintain roads used by tourists, especially in the Mongolata and Burra Mine areas.

Bins will be placed in parking bays.

Burra Golf Club applies for permission to erect a new clubhouse.

The acting Town Clerk F.T. Acott reports c. $3,000 in outstanding rates. Moves will be made to recover them.
