95, 32, 21 Aug. 1973, page 7

Birth. At Memorial Hospital 14 august, to Gill & Bob Mason, a daughter.

Birth. At Burra hospital 21 August, to Kathy & David Jones, a son.

Dianne Finch, youngest daughter of Mr & Mrs Norman Finch, is now a qualified nursing Sister.

Obituary. Rosslyn Josephine Kakoschke, wife of Gordon Kakoschke, died on 19 August.

[Born Roselyn Josephine Gage 15 August 1941.]

Father Laurie Quinn, well known in the Burra District is presently overseas and last reported to be in Scotland.

C.F. Hore writes expressing concern and opposition to the decision of the SA Government to allow a casino to be established in SA.

95, 33, 28 Aug. 1973, page 1

Burra High School has been placed on the planning and design list for this year. Mr E.C. Allen, Member for Frome, said he was disappointed as it was on the list last year, but the Public Works Committee disapproved of the site and another had to be found, delaying construction by twelve months. The new Peterborough Primary School has been allocated $480.000.

Burra Rural Youth meeting on 20 August took the form of a mixed teams basketball match.

St John’s Ambulance, Burra

Ron Thamm will be presented with a long service award for work with the St John’s Ambulance Brigade at a ceremony and parade in Adelaide in October. People are eligible after twelve years and Mt Thamm has been associated with the Burra Branch since its commencement in 1960.

The Base Radio for the St John’s Ambulance will be housed at Burra Hospital.

Negotiations with the District Council will see the EFS sharing the transmitter equipment to be erected on Nankivell’s Hill.

95, 33, 28 Aug. 1973, pages 1 & 6

Football. North Eastern League

Don Sommerville of North Clare has won the Mail Medal for 1973.

Runner-up Michael Wanganeen of Blyth won the Record Trophy.

In ‘B’ Grade the Best & Fairest (for the G. Pink Medal) went to Jim Jolly of South Clare.

The Senior Colts medal went to Robert Goode of South Clare.

Mid North League

Lyall Ackland of Mintaro-Manoora won the Mail Medal.

Barry Dixon of United won the Jenner Trophy.

The Senior Colts trophy went to Peter Koster.

95, 33, 28 Aug. 1973, pages 4 & 5

Burra Burra DC

[There is a long report of essentially routine business.]

Council accepts ownership of the Farrell Flat Institute.

Council accepts responsibility for the maintenance of graves of the Barker family in the Burra Cemetery in return for interest on an investment of $8,000.

95, 33, 28 Aug. 1973, page 6

Advt. Burra Pictures, 1 September

Donald Pleasance & Gary Bond in Wake in Fright

Clint Eastwood in Hang ’Em High

95, 33, 28 Aug. 1973, page 7

Elizabeth McDonald, daughter of Mr & Mrs Colin McDonald of Leighton, is now a Double Certificated Sister.

Joanna Simpson, daughter of Mr & Mrs E. Simpson of Burra North, left Australia on 20 August for a posting in Singapore with the Australian Army after 8 months at Duntroon Military College.

Len Bence will return from London tomorrow.

Weather. Some very timely rain has fallen. Burra received 201 points and Mt Bryan 139, but to the east Mallett recorded 267, Braemar 220, Woolgangi 169, Balah 120 and Poonunda 267.

Court

Following house-breaking and larceny reports on 17 July a 31-year-old Burra woman was sentenced to three months for receiving money knowing it to have been stolen. (She received it from her children.) A 16-year-old youth and a 15-year-old were charged with breaking into premises. The 16-year-old was sent to McNally Training Centre till 18 and the 15-year-old’s case is being reviewed. A 14-year-old youth is also on remand. A charge against an 11-year-old female for receiving stolen money was found proved, but dismissed under the Juvenile Courts Act. $220 was recovered and will be returned.

95, 33, 28 Aug. 1973, page 8

95, 34, 4 Sep. 1973, page 1

Adelaide Wool Sales saw wool keenly sought and a top price of 313 cents per kilo for some from W.B. Ashby & Sons of ‘Ashrose’, Hallett.

Bridget O’Connor has reached the semi-final of the Princess of Industry Quest, which aids the Home for Incurables.

‘The Unknown City’, a carving of a city landscape some four feet square, of some 50 small buildings, will be on display for one day on 16 September at the Saddleworth Museum. It was carved about 120 years ago by the late Leonard I’Anson (VII) and is kept at the family home at Steelton.

Accidents

Allan James Haydon of the Burra Mine suffered a fractured skull when his car rolled over after a collision with a guide post on the Adelaide Road near ‘Brown’s’ on Thursday. He was admitted to the Burra Hospital.

Cynthia J. Correll and Wendy Martin, nurses of Pt Pirie, escaped injury when their car rolled over eight miles west of Burra on Friday.

Football. The North Eastern League will have a Mini-League team in the carnival at Woodville Oval on Sunday 23 September. (Ages under 13 on 1 January.)

R.D. Waltke has re-opened Gill’s store, recently closed at Burra North.

Apex. Grant Good has taken over as President.

95, 34, 4 Sep. 1973, pages 2 & 7 gutter

Marriage. Saturday 1 September, Immanuel College Chapel

Jeanie Douglas, younger daughter of Mrs B. Douglas of Trinity Gardens and the late Mr T. Douglas, married

Mark Pfitzner, eldest son of Mr & Mrs W.G. Pfitzner of Robertstown.

Table Tennis. ‘A’ Grade: Burra Gold 15 defeated Burra Blue 6

Hallett has won the ‘B’ Grade Premiership.

World’s End Methodist Church will hold its Anniversary Service next Sunday. Rev. Keith Smith will be guest preacher.

95, 36, 18 Sep. 1973, page 1

Burra Hospital. 96th Annual Meeting of the Board of Management

The Chairman said the recent $250,000 improvement made the hospital one of the most up-to-date in country SA. The financial position improved despite salary increases of some $11,000. Patient fee increases have resulted in a surplus of $29,547. The long awaited rebuilding has occurred. In July the new Maternity Wing, Private and Share Wards, Children’s Ward and new kitchen were taken over and a room has been built for Meals-on-Wheels. The laundry has been moved to the old kitchen. Grounds and roadway will be improved and a new retaining wall will be erected around the lawn area. All kitchen crockery and utensils have been renewed and linen and some furniture. Costs have been met from our own funds. The coming year will see painting and renovation to the exterior including the secretary’s residence. Matron’s residence will get a large sitting-dining room and a carport. The Nurses’ Home has a new oil heater. In the past year patients have average 20.1 and 40 babies were born at the hospital. The hospital has land under crop from Tom Rogers and Don Stockman and would welcome further offers of land from ratepayers. The Hospital Auxiliary continues to provide welcome assistance under Mrs S. Scroop. The Burra & District Fund-Raising Committee contributed $1,000 for new furnishings. Last October Matron Fyfe resigned after 13 years to take effect from 7 December 1972. She was much involved in the detailed planning of the new hospital. Matron Phillips was appointed, assisted by Sisters R.Z. Brown, R.M. Lucas, R.B. Seaford, E.A. Oates, J.E. Wall and J. McBride. Sister I.J. Byles left the district after 10 years of valuable service. Sister Good has carried out her duties as tutor. The Secretary-Manager Mr L.H. Packer has kept the administration at a very high level. The Ambulance Service intends to install a radio base at the hospital.

Burra Burra DC

Building permits will be required for all building in the district from January 1974. (Previously required only in town areas.)

The Town Clock will arrive in a week or two. A site for it has not yet been finally settled.

Some preliminary investigation has been made into the structure of the Kingston Street Bridge, allowing water to remain around it. Final plans will now be made.

First royalties from the Mine will be paid in the next two or three months and though not large, they will increase as the Mine increases production.

Mt Bryan Recreation Ground and Farrell Flat Institute have been transferred to the Burra Burra DC.

The new toilets and washrooms at the Town Hall are nearly finished and are usable.

The obscuring of natural light in the Library as a result of this construction will be attended to.

Leighton was chosen as the site for a TV commercial for Radio Rentals.

Ten and twenty foot high white polystyrene foam letters were laid out on a grass strip between areas of forest near Mr & Mrs Colin McDonald’s ‘Rock Hill’. The letters read:

UP TO THREE YEARS SERVICE

AT NO EXTRA CHARGE RADIO RENTALS THE SPECIALISTS

Three aircraft were used and the advertisement features an old Tiger Moth, flown by Bob Burnett-Reid.

[Photograph]

Wool Values fell c. 71⁄2% in the latest wool sales. [District prices are listed.]

Table Tennis. North Eastern Grand Final: Burra Blue defeated Burra Gold.

95, 37, 25 Sep. 1973, page 4

Mackerode Stud Dispersal Sale will be held at the Burra Stockyards on 17 October 1973.

The stud was established in 1882 by G.A. Gebhardt, beginning with ewes and rams from Sir J. Lancelot Stirling’s ‘Napla’, Lake Alexandrina and from William Jervois’s ‘Wellington’ River Murray. Later rams were introduced from ‘Koonoona’ and ‘Cappeedee’ and in the early 1900s from NSW, with rams from ‘Boonoke’ and ‘Bundemar’. The early 1930s saw Collinsville blood introduced and all subsequent breeding has been on Collinsville and Mackerode blood. In the early years the Mackerode rams were small and wrinkly bodied. Early 1900s rams cut 30-35 lb of wool with 12 months’ growth. A difficult task was selecting for wool weight and against body wrinkle. Wrinkles began to disappear by the 1920s and now rams carry an even three-fold front, with no body wrinkle and little tail wrinkle. The aim has been for large format, plain bodied sheep carrying a heavy cutting, soft-handling fleece of 58s-60s quality. Fleece testing has been used in the top 20% of young rams each year to select the best 50% of those tested for potential workers. Testing has shown that rams with 58-60s on count of crimps per inch usually have a fibre diameter of only 21-23 microns (60-64s) which is an advantage and is a result of breeding for soft-handling wool.

Mackerode ewes have a very high fertility rate. The stud has been lambing twice a year for some years – half the ewes lamb in autumn and the other half in spring. Ewes that fail to lamb in spring are culled and the success can be seen in the few that now have to be culled.

The dispersal of such a stud is a rare event and offers breeders a unique opportunity.

95, 37, 25 Sep. 1973, page 5

95, 37, 25 Sep. 1973, page 7

Birth. On 29 September at Burra Hospital to Darryl & Jenny Cockburn (nee Marles), a son, Travis Damien.

Birth. On 21 September at Clare to Peter & Judy Gill of Spalding, twins, Paula Judith & David Peter.

Louis Geyer, who worked at the Burra Railway Station 1924-26, dropped in for a visit yesterday. He now lives at Loxton.

Mr & Mrs Oborn visited last week. Mr Oborn was headmaster at Burra School many years ago.

[This is quite wrong. John Stuart Russell Oborn was headmaster at Burra 1921 until his death at Burra Hospital 7 September 1931. His wife, Ada Kate Oborn nee Cowin died 18 August 1968. The visitor seems likely to have been one of his sons and his wife.]

Tom Kallio of Glenelg received a cheerio call on radio last week from his wife Nell for his 80th birthday.

Football. The North Eastern League Mini-League Team played well at Woodville on Sunday:

Port Adelaide 10 points defeated North Eastern 1 point

Sturt 2.3 defeated North Eastern 1.2

North Eastern drew with Torrens 2.1 each

North Eastern 5.4 defeated Woodville 2.1

On percentage North Eastern was placed 5th out of 17 teams.

Burra Burra DC, 10 September

Correspondence from K. Kleinig re a suggestion for hand-rails on the Town Hall steps.

The rest of the 21⁄2 column report reveals only routine matters.

95, 38, 2 Oct. 1973, page 1

Mothers & Babies’ Health Association was overwhelmed by entrants in their Baby Show on Friday. Sue Bailey as photographer was kept busy. Winners:

1-3 months Kerry Whittington

3-6 months Alan Jacka

6-9 months Stacey Walkley

9-12 months Gavin Hirschausen

12-18 months Jodie O’Brien, Linda Waye, Nicholas Atkinson and Simon Drew

18-24 months Karen Bruce, Amanda Pritchard, Shane Bampton and Adrian Fahey

2-3 years Tasma Wooton, Paquita Queissner, William Duncan and Adrian Nourse

Photographer’s Award for best Baby of the Show: Will Duncan.

Best Behaved Child: Kate Nicholls.

Profits made were a marvellous $350.

The only thing to mar the occasion was the theft of the purse of the President Mrs Peter McDowell. It contained a large sum and has not been recovered. Donations from friends made up over half the amount, for which kindness she is very thankful.

Roadwork. A further 1.6 mile section of the Farrell Flat Road will be sealed – from the Clare side of Farrell Flat towards the railway.

The Quire St Nicholas, based in Adelaide, will sing the Eucharist on 7 October at St Mary’s. Last year they came for the Copper Festival. They are directed by Mr Cliff Boyd. They will also sing some motets during the service. The setting for the service will be by Palestrina. [Note on page 7.]

Vandalism. At the Town Hall cabaret on Friday night two doors on the recently erected and not yet quite completed toilets were wrenched from their hinges, ruining the door closers at a cost of $35 each. One of the glass panels in the door in the foyer was deliberately smashed and cake was trodden into the floor for the full length of the hall and into the foyer. Such mindless destruction is hard to understand.

95, 38, 2 Oct. 1973, page 2

Lot 1. ‘Homestead’ 326 acres, Sections 419, 420, 421 in the Hundred of Ayers, including a substantial stone house of six rooms, etc.

Lot 2. 326 acres, Sections 769, 770, 771 & 996 in the Hundred of Hanson, disposed in six paddocks.

Lot 3. 312 acres, Sections 584 & 585 in the Hundred of Hanson disposed as eight paddocks.

95, 39, 9 Oct. 1973, page 1

The Burra Show was held on Saturday in ideal weather and takings at the gate were $826, only $200 down on last year’s record at the Copper Festival Weekend. The Hon. T.M. Casey, Minister for Agriculture, opened the show and advised the society that special subsidies available previously only for new buildings were now available for upgrading existing buildings. He was welcomed by President Graham Kellock. Thanks were especially extended to Darrell Field for his work as Secretary and Roy Humphrys for maintaining the grounds. Local shearer Keith Walker won the Open Section of the shearing competition and I. Kessell won the Novice Section.

Baby Show photos are published of William Duncan and of Simon Drew with his mother.

[More on page 3 with photos of: Amanda Pritchard, Stacey Walkley, Adrian Nourse & Jodie O’Brien.]

95, 39, 9 Oct. 1973, page 2

Advt. Land Auction by Southern Farmers on instructions from Mrs C.T. Carmody:

Lot 1. Sections 994 & 995 Hd Hanson with seven-roomed stone house etc. (236 acres)

Lot 2. Blocks 3 & 28of Section 70 Hd Ayers. (746 acres)

Advt. Elders-GM Commercial Ewe Sale 19 October. 10,000 sheep to be offered.

95, 39, 9 Oct. 1973, page 3

Burra Show

Miss Show Girl:

Senior Jenny Lawrie

Junior Annette Nankivell

Sub-Junior Theresa Schwier

Industrial stands were well represented, but less machinery was on display due to the improved rural economy, resulting in less being available.

Budgerigars were good this year, despite being in poor feather due to recent heat.

Bantams were good and there were two very good Muscovy Ducks and a good Rouen Ducks.

Large fowls were down both in numbers and quality.

Pigeons were varied in quality.

Horses in action produced keen competition and the standard was good in hunter events and in hack events.

There was a good show of cut flowers.

Grain entries were disappointing – two main competitors dropped out after 25 years of showing.

Cookery was a credit to the society and entrants.

The dog show was successful.

The best of the goats were quite good, but the class tailed off considerably.

Needlework entries were down, but of good quality.

Pigs were of good quality, but with disappointingly few local entries.

Strong wool entires were few in number, but of good quality.

In sheep Polls and Merinos were few in number, but good and the under 1,000 class was quite well represented.

Fleece exhibits were very good and the wool display overall was the second largest on record.

Birth. At 8 October at QVMH to Peter & Helen Stockman, nee Alexander, a son. [Timothy Peter]

95, 39, 9 Oct. 1973, page 7

Burra Show Night. Both the Cabaret and the Teenage Dance fell victims to lack of interest.

Mr & Mrs Peter McDowell and family will soon move to Nuriootpa, where Peter has been transferred by his employer, ETSA.

Obituary. Mrs Eugene Rooke died at the weekend.

[Born Elsie Edith Phillips 6 July 1895, Hundred of Bright: died 6 October 1973. Mr Rooke is hard to trace on the SA Births CD, being cited there as John Augen Rocke. He is cited on the Marriages CD as Johan Eugen Rooke.]

Neb O’Brien won the Open Buckjumping Championship at the Carrieton Rodeo on Saturday. At Marrabel yesterday he rode Son of Curio for about 8 seconds and when the horse rolled he was given a second ride, but that lasted about one second.

A Bikie Gang visited on Saturday and took items from the children’s display at the Show. Local Police recovered the items and gave the bikies until sunset to leave the town. They went.

95, 40, 16 Oct. 1973, page 1

Burra Burra DC

Good road metal has been fund in the overburden at the Mine and will be stockpiled and made available to the Council. The normal cost of raising road metal is 20c/yd3.

Council will now borrow $60,000 to purchase new plant: a D6 bulldozer, a low loader tray to transport it and possibly later in the year a new grader.

Rates have been slow in coming in and this has slowed work. So far $14,000 has come in, mainly from the Town Ward.

The swimming pool was drained some time ago to find the source of a 1,000 gallon a week leak and Councillors are now fairly confident this has been sealed, after a crack across the floor and up one wall was discovered.

Swimming should begin on 1 November as usual.

Smoke Room at the Town Hall. When the cement floor has sufficiently dried the Council intends to lay carpet squares.

The Minister of Local Government has advised of a $1,400 subsidy on Council’s purchase of the old Ballast Quarry.

Burra Scouts & Cubs will have a special meeting at Hanson on 19 October when an Army Display Unit will be present. Families and friends are invited. Army personnel will talk on safety precautions with explosives.

The Methodist Circuit Quarterly Meeting last Wednesday received a report that the Redruth Trust Committee has agreed in principle to develop the Redruth Church and Hall as a Camping and Conference Centre. It will be necessary to provide ablution blocks. The circuit meeting expressed its support.

Obituary. Mr Fred Neindorf of Robertstown died about two weeks before his sister-in-law Mrs E. Rooke. He had a service station at Robertstown, now managed by his son Ray.

[Born Friedrich Wilhelm Neindorf 15 September 1897 Geranium Plains.]

95, 40, 16 Oct. 1973, page 2

Bowls. The new season was opened by the club Patron Dudley Jacka on Sunday.

Kooringa Masonic Lodge. Bro. Keith Robert Phillips was installed as Worshipful Master on Thursday night, after which a ball was held in the Town Hall and over 350 guests attended. Angel’s Band from Balaklava provided the music. Twenty-nine Worshipful Masters signed the visitors’ book.

Obituary. Mr Gus Kakoschke died 15 October aged 80.

[Born Gustav Adolf Ernst Kakoschke 19 August 1893, Hundred of Lindley.]

Burra School children were excited yesterday as they left on their trip to Nepabunna Mission in the Far North of SA.

Rob. George, a teacher at Burra High School, has written a one-act play The Prompt and with Maureen Sherlock and Coralie Plush, assisted by several other teachers, presented it at the local Apex Club. It won first prize in the recent Clare Drama Festival and fourth prize in the Adelaide Advertiser Festival, against stiff opposition.

Miss Gert Williams of Payneham and formerly of Burra celebrated her 89th birthday on 30 September.

Arthur Bence was 81 on 15 October.

95, 41, 23 Oct. 1973, page 1

Burra Sheep Sales last week saw the disposal of about 15,500 sheep for a total of c. $300,000.

Top price for stud Merino Ewes was $191, a record for SA, sold by Barton Hills Proprietors.

The Annual Collinsville Ewe Sale on 16 October saw prices well in advance of last year.

1972, 808 ewes averaged $11.95

388 lambs averaged $7.40

1973, 1,283 ewes averaged $33.84

586 lambs averaged $16.44

Overall sale average was $33.85.

Top price to Barton Hills for 10 selected stud ewes was $191.

W.B. Ashby & Sons offered 37 and sold 37 for an average $37.30.

J. & F. Sullivan & Co. offered 50 and sold 50 for an average $46.25.

Willogoleche Ltd offered 30 and sold 30 for an average $22.50.

J.T. & M.E. Drew offered 24 and sold 24 for an average $32.08

R.W. Lehmann offered 20 and sold 20 for an average $55.00.

Lehmann Bros offered 40 and sold 40 for an average $19.75.

John Collins & Sons offered 1,062and sold 476 for an average $49.57.

At the Mackerode dispersal sale the top price was $117.50 for a line of 22 ewes aged 3 years. [Complete details are printed.]

Oates Pty Ltd sold 4,274 sheep on Thursday in an animated sale. [Details are printed.] Average price $14.20.

Elders-GM sold 8,033 on Friday at firm rates. The top price was to W.S. Murray & Son of Cappeedee: $24.25 for 13 ewes aged 21⁄2 years. [Other details are printed.]

Burra Boy Scouts & Cubs were enthralled by a display by the CMF and a talk on safety with explosives at Hanson on Friday night. Also on display was a collection of rifles valued at over $2,000, the property of Pte Klem of Auburn. Scouts will raffle a Monster Christmas Stocking this year.

Burra District Swimming Pool Committee met on 17 October and a loss of $2,065 was revealed for the past season. The whole committee was re-elected for 1973-74: President, Brian Thamm; Secretary, Miss Heather Keane; Roster Secretary, Mrs J. Carpenter; Treasurer, Mrs D. Kempster and Assistant Treasurer, Mrs N. Hurst. The season had run well. The Treasurer reported a profit of $341.72 on sales less purchases. Major costs were: Repairs $2,574, Chemicals $634, Power $606 and loan repayment $614 of principal and $43 interest.

The pool will be open on days of at least 21°C and evenings if it is 30°C at 6 p.m. (7 p.m. to 9 p.m. and extended at the discretion of the supervisor.) Are any members of the Burra Swimming Club interested in reviving it? Contact the Committee.

[Prices are printed for tickets etc.]

95, 41, 23 Oct. 1973, page 2

Advt. Elders-GM will auction ‘Canopus Station’ of 473 square miles pastoral lease and ‘Morganvale’ of 277 square miles pastoral lease, in the Brookman Buildings, Grenfell Street, Adelaide at 2.30 p.m. 9 November.

Cricket. Mokota Association

North Booborowie 42 & 128 v. Burra Footballers 3 for 105 & 1 for 68.

Koonaburra v. Leighton was continued: Koonaburra 7 for 243 declared (though 6 for 243 declared in paper of 16 October) v. Leighton 178.

95, 41, 23 Oct. 1973, page 3

Saddleworth Show is reported. It was marred by rain, mud and cold temperatures, but attendance was nevertheless good.

Jeff Smith from the Crystal Brook office arrived recently to become manager for Dalgety, Coles & Co. He takes over from Mr John Tate who goes to Naracoorte. Jeff is accompanied by his wife and children, Grant (31⁄2) and Tanya (18 months).

95, 41, 23 Oct. 1973, page 6

Notice. There will be a ZOB meeting in the Citadel on 26 October.

Advt. Burra Pictures, 27 October

Bud Spencer & Jeff Zaccharias in They Call Me Trinity

Obituary. Katherine Ann Halls, wife of the late Brian Halls, died suddenly at her residence on 18 October aged 36. She was the mother of Stephen and Deidre.

95, 41, 23 Oct. 1973, page 7

Escape. Harry rich and policeman Mick Miller caught an echidna in the street last week and placed it in the new cells for its own protection. They jammed the door, but by morning the echidna had effected its escape and has not been seen since.

Burra North Hospital Aid Group moved their Gala Day indoors to the Redruth Memorial Hall due to rain on Saturday. Nearly $100 was raised.

Weather. Rainfall in the last week ranged from 2 to 4 inches across the district. Burra recorded 288 points, Clare 323, Manoora 350 and Mt Bryan 264.

95, 41, 23 Oct. 1973, page 8

Burra Burra DC, Burra Town Hall 9 October

The Department of Public Health is to be asked to expedite common effluent drain scheme plans.

It was resolved that the Grant-in-aid of $1,200 be allotted to work on the Thames Street Bridge.

It was resolved to buy $545 worth of carpet squares for the Town Hall Smoke Room (laying included).

The Minister for Local Government advises of a subsidy of $1,400 to assist in the purchase of 63 acres of Section 4 Hundred of Kooringa [the Ballast Quarry block].

[Other routine matters are reported in 12⁄3 columns.]

Tanunda reunion of descendants of Joachim Christopher Ross (1803-38) and his wife Sophie Dorothea (1803-83) and of her second husband Christian Gastmeyer (1812-98), held on 7 October, is reported.

95, 42, 30 Oct. 1973, page 1

Pastoral Properties to the east have a great potential for fire this season. Rainfall in 1973 has been an all time record with over 16 inches on some properties. There is abundant grass and bush. Rain fell on Thursday-Friday with 90 points at Princess Royal, 102 at Koomooloo and 170 at Thistlebeds.

Mrs C.F. Carmody’s Leighton property realised $102.50 per acre when sold by Southern Farmers. Lot 2 of 746 acres was bought by A.J. & E.J. Broad of Leighton. ‘Kilmorey’, the homestead section, was passed in at auction, but later sold privately to Mr A. Scholz of Leighton, who had been the highest bidder at the auction.

A Barbecue and Gymkhana will be held at the Burra Showgrounds on Sunday. Adults $1, Children 5-14 $0.05. It will be opened by Dr Bruce Eastick, Leader of the SA Opposition. Proceeds will aid Frome LCL Electorate Committee Funds.

Burra Floral Art Group hosted a meeting to aid Red Cross on 26 October. Mrs R. Lloyd demonstrated making a sheaf of flowers. Paintings and needlework by Miss Geake were on show. She was born in Burra and lived here all her life. Her father was a grocer and later worked in Edwin Harris’s shop. The family lived in East Street and later in Ayers Street (the house is now Mr Broad’s). Miss Geake took lessons from Rene Crewes (now Lady McBride) at Kooringa and in 1923 in Adelaide under the late James Ashton. In 1925 she exhibited an oil painting in Adelaide and won a gold medal. Paintings sent to London for examination were awarded meritorial certificates. She taught painting at Kooringa in oil and water colours and also taught the use of pastels and black and white. Students included Mr L. Bence and the Warner twins from Hallett. She has always been interested also in needlework, crochet and knitting. She was a member of the Burra [Cheer-up] Ladies’ Band in WWI, playing the tenor horn. For many years she worked at Wilkinson’s, was connected with the Kooringa Methodist Church and taught at the Sunday school. We are all pleased to learn that Miss Geake has returned to Burra and wish her well. The sheaf made by Mrs Lloyd was later delivered to Miss Geake in the Burra Hospital with a card signed by those who came to view her work.

[Doris Minette Edith Geake born 25 January 1891 Kooringa: died 13 April 1974.]

Post Office finances are critical and it is planned to convert many official post offices in small centres to unofficial agencies. Some 300 are being examined across Australia. Locally under consideration are:

95, 43, 6 Nov. 1973, page 1

4th Adelaide Wool Sale – wool was 12.5% cheaper. [District prices are printed.]

Burra Scouts’ Christmas Stocking is estimated to hold more than $50 worth of groceries. This week’s meeting will be at Burra instead of Hanson, as it is a lesson in First Aid procedures. Cubs meet as usual at Hanson.

Property Sales

‘Ramara’, the 269 acre property of P.J. Thomas at Leighton, was bought by C.W. & M.E. Ramm of Leighton for $169 per acre.

H.L. Phillips’ World’s End Church Paddock of 395 Acres was passed in.

H.L. Phillips’ Mine Paddock of 711⁄4 acres was sold to L.R. Brown of Burra at $80 per acre.

Weather. The rainfall do far this year is 587 points above the whole annual average at 2,351 points. It is the highest rainfall since 1916.

The heavy rains in October have made it impossible for prospective buyers to inspect ‘Canopus Station’ and as a result its auction has been postponed to the New Year.

95, 43, 6 Nov. 1973, page 2

Obituary. Matilda Elizabeth Jane Farley, nee Mosey, wife of the late James Farley, died in Adelaide Hospital on 27 October aged 94. Mrs Farley lived in the Brady Creek area till seven years ago, when she moved to Adelaide. Recently she was an inmate of Carinya CWA Home, Clare.

[Actually she was 96, being born Mathilde Jane Elisabeth Mosey 16 May 1879 in the District of Kapunda.]

Birth. On 27 October to Richard & Dawn Tennant, nee Bogisch at the Lyell McEwin Hospital, a daughter, Kirsty Nicole. (Dawn is the daughter of Mr & Mrs Jack Bogisch of Burra.)

Brian Emerson, son of Mr & Mrs Tom Emerson of Arabiddy Station via Cockelbiddyin, WA, will marry Sue Stocker.

Myrtle Riggs of Prospect and formerly of Burra is 90 today.

Arthur Richards, formerly of Burra, was 90 on 12 September. He lives at Wesley House, Somerton.

Clem Sampson, well known to many in Burra, is 80 today. He lives in Esperance WA. His parents were the late George and Sarah Sampson and his children are Albert, Ronald and Violet.

Carol Napper of Burra began work yesterday for Elders-GM.

Les Field joins the ANZ Bank in Burra from Keith.

Tony Fillmore of the Record leaves town next week to take up a position in Tennant Creek.

A new farmhand at Mr & Mrs Colin Earle’s packed up and left recently, taking $110 of theirs with him.

The Season. Some of the eastern pastoral country has been destocked due to excessive grass seed and fire danger.

The wet year has also resulted in a large fly problem.

95, 43, 6 Nov. 1973, page 8

The Nepabunna Trip by Grade VI & VII children from Burra School began on 15 October. Their accommodation was the shearers’ quarters at Angepena Station. Two teachers went: Mr Allan & Mrs Carpenter and a group of parents: Mr I. Allen, Mr A. Nankivell, Mrs J. O’Connor and Mrs C. Taylor.

[The children then take up the story, which runs for 31⁄3 columns.]

Monday: to Angepena Station, stopping at Melrose, Hawker and Parachilna.

Tuesday: visit to the Nepabunna Mission and the gorge and rock pool.

Wednesday: visit to Nepowie Springs and a camp concert in the shearing shed.

Thursday: to Nepabunna and played sports and in the afternoon to see the Malki cave paintings some 8 miles from Nepabunna, involving a two mile walk. There was heavy rain and then a social at night.

Friday: return to Burra with stops at Copley, Parachilna, Hawker and Peterborough.

95, 43 (2), 13 Nov. 1973, page 1

Property Sales

‘Rockhill’ at Leighton, the property of Mr C.A. McDonald & Mrs F.M. McDonald was sold by auction on 7 November in the Burra RSL Hall. It had been in the family since 1869.

Lot 1. Homestead and 326 acres was passed in at $170 per acre, but later sold to Mrs I.M. Gordon of Wahroonga.

Lot 2. 326 acres sold to W.B. McMahon of Booborowie for $131 per acre.

Lot 3. 312 acres was sold to M.B. & N.C. Miller for $140 per acre.

Melbourne Cup Day saw the ladies of the Cup Committee take over the Burra Town Hall and they and guests numbered nearly 200. Some $800 was taken.

Kooringa Methodist Ladies’ Guild Fete on Friday 2 November at the Burra RSL Hall raised almost $300.

Southern Farmers Burra off-shears sale of sheep and lambs saw 2,500 yarded and demand was good. Prices ranged from $10.45 to $15.45.

The LCL Frome Campaign Fund barbecue and gymkhana raised $500 on 4 November.

Hanson CWA held a mystery tour on 18 October and enjoyed a very successful wander though the Barossa Valley.

95, 43 (2), 13 Nov. 1973, page 2

Advt. Elders-GM Wether Lamb Sale 16 November: 10,000 sheep and lambs.

Advt. Elders-GM will auction ‘Grassville’ 30 miles east of Burra comprising 33,790 acres of perpetual lease, at the Burra RSL Hall 14 December. To be offered as a whole or if not sold in four lots.

Lot 1. ‘Homestead’ 14,575 acres with six-roomed timber and iron homestead etc.

Lot 2. ‘Sixty’ of 12,480 acres.

Lot 3. ‘Tin Hut’ of 6.693 acres.

Lot 4. ‘Red Hut’ of 43 acres freehold.

To be sold on instructions from Devere Pty Ltd.

95, 43 (2), 13 Nov. 1973, page 8

95, 44, 20 Nov. 1973, page 1

Burra Burra DC

The burning off period has been extended to 29 November on account of the green grass around, but the potential fire hazard is quite alarming.

A management committee will be appointed for the Farrell Flat Hall.

Council has decided to exempt from the new building act (1974), new buildings outside the township for permanent occupation.

The delay in opening the swimming pool was due to difficulties with the filtration plant.

Stock Sales

Oates Pty Ltd’s sale of wethers on Thursday 15 November saw good demand for young wethers and prices increased for 11⁄2 year-old wethers to $16.15 and wether lambs to $15.95.

Elders-GM yarded and sold 8,585 at their sale on 16 November.

Booborowie Strawberry Fete raised $620 for the Methodist Ladies’ Guild last Saturday.

Burra Golf Club held its AGM on 8 November, but drew only a small attendance. Elected: President, Don Kempster; Senior Vice-President, Ian Allen; Junior Vice-President, Allan Baulderstone; Captain, Peter Dignan; Vice-Captain, Antony Gebhardt and Secretary, Harold Burnett.

95, 44, 20 Nov. 1973, page 2

Advt. Oates Pty Ltd will auction 298 acres of Willalo farmland on instructions from Mrs K.J. McAskill, at the Booborowie Hall 10 December. The land is section 478 in the Hundred of Ayers with a stone dwelling of six rooms, etc.

Advt. Elders-GM on instructions from K.R. Phillips Pty Ltd (K.R. & I.M. Phillips) will sell ‘The Gums’ comprising 30,000 acres P/L and F/H (12,141 ha). It will be offered first as a whole and if not sold in three lots.

Lot 1. ‘Homestead’ of 11,500 acres P/L with stone homestead of six main rooms etc.

Lot 2. ‘Pooles’ of 12,500 acres P/L and F/H.

Lot 3. ‘Kings’ of 6,000 acres P/L.

Burra CWA held its International Day on Thursday, focused on Holland. Mrs Murphy gave the address.

Mrs Myrtle Riggs, a member of many years, returned to Burra for the meeting. (Aged 90.)

Birth. At Eudunda 13 November to Lorraine & Ian mosey of Robertstown, a daughter.

95, 44, 20 Nov. 1973, page 8

Golf. Report on the past season, which began with the opening of the new course. Over the year it played well. Problems arose in finding a greens keeper and in the breaking down of the mower. Also frost killed many of the young trees, but most of those planted in springtime have survived. Plans for a new clubhouse have been drawn up and finance is being investigated. Open day was successful with 99 competitors.

95, 45, 27 Nov. 1973, page 1

Christmas arrangements in Burra include late shopping on 24 December, a free picture show in the Town Hall at 6 p.m. (Flipper and the Pirates) and the arrival of Father Christmas in Market Square at 8.30 p.m. The merry-go-round will operate near the Burra Hotel.

Redruth Ladies’ Guild Gale Day in the Redruth Memorial Hall on Saturday produced $355. [Details are given in 3⁄4 column.]

Rev. C.F. Williams begins his term as locum tenens next Sunday, when Rev. C. Hore goes on extended leave in December and January.

Adelaide Wool Sales drew firm prices. [Local results are printed.]

The Burra Festival of Carols will be held at the swimming pool on 23 December. Proceeds will aid Ethiopian Famine Relief.

95, 45, 27 Nov. 1973, pages 1 & 5

Puss in Boots by the Jamestown Drama Group in the Burra Town Hall was well attended and appreciated by the children especially. The lack of a nearby shop was felt during the interval.

95, 45, 27 Nov. 1973, page 7

Mrs Esther Clisby of Vale Park was 100 on 11 November. She was born in Burra and went to work when 16 as a maid for Mr C. Drew. She has been a widow for 15 years. She had seven children and has 13 grandchildren, 11 great-grandchildren and 7 great-great-grandchildren.

[Born Esther Davey 11 November 1873 at Paratoo, daughter of Isaac & Eliza Davey nee Horsenell.]

Burra Scouts will hold their annual break-up at Hanson on Friday.

Cricket. Mokota Association

Booborowie 249 v. Koonaburra 0 for 27.

95, 46, 4 Dec. 1973, page 1

Burra Schools were visited on Friday by representatives of the Education Department and Public Buildings Department to discuss with staff and parent bodies the proposals for the development of the two schools on the present site. Proposals would involve replacing the accommodation for the High School and upgrading the original building for the Primary School. Additional facilities would be included, to be used by the school and community groups. The proposal is expected to go soon to the Public Works Standing Committee, and subject to approval and availability of funds to commence as soon as possible.

The Referendums

Voting in the two referendum questions on Saturday will be compulsory and it will be the first time that the 18-20 year age group will be included. [Page 6 gives the polling places, which locally were the Burra RSL Hall and the Burra North Court House.]

St Edmund’s Church of England at Booborowie celebrates its golden jubilee on 9 December. The Bishop of Willochra Rt Rev. S.B. Rosier will preside at Holy Communion and will preach. The celebrant will be the Rector of Burra Parish, Rev. J.H. Stephenson. The foundation stone was laid on 5 December 1923 by Mrs A. Affolter, who with a band of helpers provided a large part of the funds needed for the building. The nave was dedicated on 20 July 1924. It cost $2,680 and the chancel was added at a cost of $540 in 1928. The building was consecrated on 8 November 1929. Before this Anglicans met in Beavan’s homestead at Booborowie for 16 years and from 1921-24 worshiped in the Memorial Hall. Structural repairs to two places in the nave were made some years ago and a thorough external repainting is now being done. A large attendance is expected and a basket luncheon will follow the service. The congregation is now small due to removal after removal of Anglican families from Booborowie.

95, 46, 4 Dec. 1973, pages 1 & 8

EFS Officers and others met in the Burra Town Hall on 28 November from Burra, Farrell Flat, Mt Bryan, Hallett, Whyte Yarcowie and Terowie to plan their co-ordinated reaction to fires this season. They discussed the three divisions of fire fighting:

Field operations

Service to supply the needs of the Fire supervisor

Planning – tactics and operations control

Each Council has at least one EFS station with control rooms and premises suitable for use as a district control centre, bur equally important are trained personnel to staff such centres.

Sgt Haynes cited the problems unique to the Eastern Stations Area. This area covered 6,871 square miles in which there are 15 occupied homesteads and of which only two have a radio link with the Broken Hill Flying Doctor. Of the remaining 13, seven are virtually connected to the outside world only by a party-line telephone; three on one line and four on another. Both lines connect only to the Burra exchange. The greater part of these lines is old private lines and the majority is carried on mallee posts, often white ant eaten, which would burn like kindling. Another problem he discussed was the incompatibility of the various radio systems then in use. Radios capable of DSB, SSB & HF operation were needed. Sgt Haynes thought Burra was the logical co-ordinating centre. In the 1951 fire in the Eastern Stations area some units travelled 300 miles chasing smoke and never saw a fire. There was no co-operation or direction. Maps have now been prepared at 1 inch to 16 miles, showing all homesteads, occupied and unoccupied and all dams and waterholes and major roads and tracks. Supervisors should have lists of names, addresses and phone numbers, with particulars of equipment available.

Mr J.N. McBride, Supervisor of the Eastern Districts Fire Fighting Organisation, also addressed the meeting about the present situation and expectations for the fire season. Negotiation between the two Council areas represented will continue.

95, 46, 4 Dec. 1973, page 2

Advt. Elders-GM will sell 8,000 sheep on 12 December in the ‘Caroona’ dispersal sale.

Accident. Geraldine Peters and fiancé Robert Fisher are in the RAH after a car accident last week. Gerry, of Farrell Flat, has been employed here in Beinke’s Shoe Store.

Obituary. Mr Eugene Rooke died on Thursday 29 November at Nuriootpa. He was formerly of Robertstown and was well known in Burra. His wife died in early October.

[Mr Rooke is hard to trace on the SA Births CD, being cited there as John Augen Rocke, born 25 January 1895, Baldina. He is cited on the Marriages CD as Johan Eugen Rooke.]

95, 47, 11 Dec. 1973, page 1

St Edmund’s Anglican Church, Booborowie

The golden jubilee celebrations were held on Sunday in prefect weather. Extra chairs doubled the capacity to 120 or more and a further 60 people had to remain outside and listen on a public address system. 97 people received Holy Communion. The church has been undergoing restoration for the event. The painters finished the exterior on Friday morning and the ladies of the church gave it a thorough clean and polish on Friday. The Tr Rev. S.B. Rosier, Bishop of Willochra, preached. A luncheon followed in Booborowie Hall. Former parishioners came back from across the state and members of the local Methodist and catholic congregations also attended. The Rector, Rev. John Stephenson, welcomed the congregation.

In its early days the congregation met in the home of Mr B.H. Beaven, until the present church was built. Mrs D.H. Campbell decorated the cake with its 50 candles, which were lit by Mr T. Bailey, a member of the original building committee. Mrs L. Farrelly, who had been present at the laying of the foundation stone, extinguished the candles. The collection of $323.37, when put with donations on hand, will make a total of about $700. Since then the sum has increased to $879. Repairs and painting may cost about $690, so there will be some over for repainting the interior.

Rainfall goes metric from 1 January 1974.

The Referendums

Ian Auhl & Peter Finch’s book Burra in Colour should be on sale at the end of the week or early next week at Burra Stationers at a cost of $2.50.

2nd Division Burra Gold 95 defeated Saddleworth 56

Burra Blue 88 defeated Hallett 66

3rd Division Spalding 99 defeated Burra 57

95, 47, 11 Dec. 1973, page 7

Marriage. Burra Methodist Church next Saturday

Averil Klem, daughter of Mr & Mrs Walter Klem of Farrell Flat, will marry Leith Cooper of Jamestown.

Mothers & Babies’ Health Association held a Christmas Party at Mr & Mrs Roy Jeffery’s garden. Father Christmas came and distributed gifts to small children.

Stephen Lane has won a record player as the fairest and best member of the Port Adelaide Colts Football Team 1973.

Peter Broderick won an electric shaver.

Ashley Nicholls of ‘Blink Bonnie’ has passed his final exams and will receive the degree of Bachelor of Dental Surgery.

Mal & Jan Culbertson have been farewelled as hosts of the Royal Exchange Hotel and will be replaced by Mr & Mrs Reid. The Culbertsons have moved to the city.

Mrs Tom Canny of Dongara WA wrote to the paper. She says in 21 years in WA she has not seen a better season. She says they have sold their farm at Mingenew and are living at Dongara. Tom is unable to travel comfortably far by car after fracturing a hip some three years ago. As a result they had an extensive holiday largely by air early in the year, to SA and the NT and had been home only three weeks when Tom had a stroke, which paralysed his right side. He has been in St John of God Hospital, Geraldton ever since and is making a slow recovery.

Win Canny, formerly of Gum Creek.

95, 48, 20 Dec. 1973, page 1

Burra Burra DC

The lighting of fires has been banned in the Hundreds of Mongolata, Baldina, Rees and King from now till 31 March 1974 and for the rest of the district from 29 November to 15 February 1974.

Council is considering closing down the pictures due to the bad behaviour of some young patrons. Vandalism is also a concern.

A Government grant has been approved through the Highways Department for the sealing of the Station Road.

Council is supporting plans by the Golf Club to erect a new clubhouse.

Council is considering an application by the ‘Melbourne Cup Party’ for better access to the Town Hall Supper Room. The access from Mt Pleasant Road is very steep, slippery and awkward.

The common effluent scheme for Burra is getting closer for those who intends hooking up to the system. Plans are being prepared by an Adelaide firm and are expected to arrive in February or March.

New Plant: Council last week took delivery of a new D6C worth $40,814 and a Cat 12 E Grader at $33,000 (less the trade-in on three second hand units.

95, 48, 20 Dec. 1973, pages 1 & 2

A Christmas Tree Festival was organised by the Burra Tennis Club at the Burra Town Hall last Friday. Twenty trees were erected in competition both by individuals and organisations. [Winners are listed.]

95, 48, 20 Dec. 1973, page 3

‘A’ Grade Burra Blue 11-97 defeated Burra Red 9-91

Spalding 15-111 defeated Burra Gold 5-76

‘B’ Grade Burra Purple 14-98 defeated Leighton 6-54

Hallett White 11-103 defeated Burra Green 9-96

8 December Mt Bryan 13-88 defeated Leighton 7-59

St Joseph’s Convent, Spalding

A large crowd of 250 old scholars and friends attended a function on Sunday 9 December to mark the closing of the convent. Rev. Fr Kineary began with Mass at 10.30 a.m. After the Mass as Angelus was sung by Mr Rod Gill of Victor Harbor, an original scholar in 1921. Luncheon was then served and some sports run for the children.

Visitors included 27 Nuns and Fathers Laws & Matthews. Of great interest was a complete roll of scholars 1921-73.

The Burra Review – Dinner & Theatre Show was held in the RSL Hall on Thursday 13 December. It was a wonderful success. The cast included Mary Abbott, Sid Allen, Edith Carpenter, Teresa Dargie, Rob George, Alan Langham, Coralie Plush, Del Reed, Terry Rule, Maureen Sherlock, John Stephenson, Jan Tiver and Bill Young, who gave two musical items. It is a bit sad to think that half the cast, being teachers, have been transferred for 1974. The event raised $85.70 for Save the Children Fund.

Cricket

Birth. To Bev & David Kellock of Farrell Flat at Burra Hospital on Tuesday, a daughter, Sharon.

Hartley Harris of Reservoir in Victoria and formerly of Burra sends Christmas Greetings to old friends here.

Straying Stock is a nuisance in the town at present, eating gardens and roaming unchecked.

Burra in Colour has arrived after a few delays.

Characteristics of the paper for 1973.

There was a fair coverage of Burra news, but with the service area of the paper extending from Robertstown to Spalding and Saddleworth, quite a bit of space was devoted to news from the other towns in that area. Errors in setting sports results sometimes make interpreting them difficult or even impossible.

Page l

Solid news items with little or no advertising,

Page 2

Larger advertisements dominate, with 2-3 columns of sports results.

Page 3

Similar to page 2.

Page 4

Larger advertisements and a mixture of sports and news for a couple of columns.

Page 5

Typically dominated by the 50 & 24 years ago column and large advertisements.

Page 6

Smaller advertisements, Cash Column, Public Notices and Entertainment.

Page 7

Dominated by larger advertisements and the ‘Out and About’ column featuring snippets of personal news.

Page 8

Typically half news and half larger advertisements. It is often dominated by District Council reports, but the news is quite varied in content.

96, 1, 15 Jan. 1974, page 1

Burra High School Presentation Day (December 1973)

Mr John Halbert, Senior Lecturer in Physical Education at Adelaide Teachers’ College was the guest speaker.

Headmaster D.W. Calder presented the 61st Annual Report.

The year began with 175 students; 100 girls and 75 boys. In Leaving there were 20 girls and 3 boys. The prefects have set a fine example and have been conscientious in their duties. Parent bodies have been co-operative and helpful in enabling the purchase of many sporting and classroom items. The school canteen proved a great success. The High School Council has been concerned at the high rate of staff turnover each year; over 50%, and it ahs sought more stability. It has also been concerned over the standard of school accommodation and the progress of the new school.

St Peter’s Cathedral Choir is coming to Burra again for their annual holiday. They came three years ago. They will camp at the Redruth Methodist Memorial Hall, but need three more beds, 12 mattresses and 29 pillows. If you can help, contact Mr R.R. Reed as soon as possible. The Choir will lead the singing at St Mary’s for a Confirmation and Holy Communion Service on 27 January, when the Bishop of Willochra, Rt Rev. Bruce Rosier will officiate.

Burra Carols Evening at the Burra Swimming Pool the Sunday before Christmas was the best for years. Attendance and proceeds were up. ($67 compared with c. $50 for several years.) Burra Methodist Choir led the singing.

Burra Rainfall totalled 2,434 point for 1973, which is 670 points above the average. From 1 January 1974 measurements will be in millimetres (mm).

96, 1, 15 Jan. 1974, page 2

Weather. It has been wet to the east.

Pine Valley has recorded 25 mm, Woolgangi 12.7, Poonunda 17.5, Balah 10 and Caroona 75, which has placed Newikie Creek in flood. Burra has had 25.8 mm to 9 a.m. this morning.

Accident/Obituary. At about 6 p.m. on Friday Frederick George Seaford aged 64 died as the result of an accidental gun shot wound at his home at Burra North.

[Born 8 November 1909 at Kooringa: died 18 January 1974.]

Rt Rev. S.B. Rosier, Bishop of Willochra will confirm 12 young candidates of Booborowie, Burra and Hallett at St Mary’s on Sunday.

Wheat prices have risen to about $101 per tonne for the 1973-74 pool. This is a rise of $18 per tonne.

(For FAQ wheat on an f.o.b. port basis.)

Adelaide Wool Sales. The prices were 121⁄2 to 151⁄2% lower. [Local District Prices are printed.]

St Mary’s Burra

On Saturday night the children took part in an informal rehearsal for the confirmation ceremony on Sunday. They met the Bishop and had a chat with him in the Hall.

On Sunday after the sermon Leighton Biggs was baptised and then the confirmations were carried out by Bishop Rosier for:

Dion Biggs Leighton Biggs Roy Blight

Jennifer Buckton Merridy Buckton Anne Field

Ann Hurst Jennifer Kempster Maryann Shipard

Antony Stephenson William Wardle Mark Williams

The organist and Master of Chorister at St Peter’s Cathedral, Mr David Swale played magnificent music on the organ. The Cathedral Choristers added to the occasion, while enjoying their camp at the Redruth Hall. The only thing to mar the occasion was the persistent rain.

Weather. There has been unseasonal rain in the last week.

Poonunda (Jack Oates) reports 75 mm to 6 p.m. yesterday. Burra reports 75.1 mm.

Other falls reported are Collinsville 290, ‘The Gums’ 192, Woolgangi 190 and Koomooloo 175.

[Presumably these figures are in points rather than mm.]

Advt. Burra Pictures, 2 February

Tennis

‘A’ Grade Burra Red 12-109 defeated Booborowie 8-89

Juniors [‘C’ Grade] Leighton 10-65 defeated Booborowie 2-34

96, 4, 5 Feb. 1974, page 1

Weather. January was the wettest on record with 179.6 mm or 7 inches of rain in a week. Four days of heavy rain brought floods, but not havoc. It began late on Saturday night or early Sunday morning and continued to Wednesday evening. A dry spell on Thursday morning was followed by more rain Thursday afternoon and night and on Friday. The creeks all flowed strongly. The whole area of the stockyards and beyond turned into a lake of brown water. Part of the Copperhouse Road Bridge gave way and became unsafe. At Gully’s Wharf in Young Street the water came within a foot or so of the top. [Top of what?] The water roared over the Pig and Whistle crossing, creating a foaming whirlpool. Fencing was damaged along watercourses throughout the district. Damage to culverts is extensive, with Springbank Road particularly herd hit. The Burra Creek crossing at World’s End has also been badly damaged. The flow down the creek from Springbank to the Bon accord was perhaps the greatest ever. The total rainfall for January in Burra was 192.4 mm and for the year has reached 224.4 mm or 881 points.

The previous highest rainfall in January was 365 points in 1941.

[Given the nature of the fall described this report is surprisingly limited and brief.]

Burra High School. The 1873 prize list is printed.

Burra Tourist Committee is threatening to be wound up unless greater interest is shown ‘from a generally apathetic bunch of citizens’. A meeting to consider whether there should be a Copper Festival in 1974, the match the 1972 success, is called for Thursday at 8 p.m. in the Burra Town Hall.

96, 4, 5 Feb. 1974, page 2

Cricket. Burra Footballers 1 for 67 defeated North Booborowie 34 & 29.

96, 4, 5 Feb. 1974, page 3

Tennis

‘A’ Grade Burra Red 13-100 defeated Burra Gold 7-84

‘B’ Grade Spalding White 18 sets defeated Booborowie 2 sets

‘C’ Grade Burra Gold 10-68 defeated Burra White 2-34

Bowls. There was no play on Saturday due to waterlogged greens.

Floods

At Robertstown the area received 6-7.5 inches of rain and the lagoon south of the town is filled with water, in places close to the road.

At World’s End the water level rose to a foot beneath the old swing bridge and the cement roadway across the creek was washed away.

96, 5, 12 Feb. 1974, pages 1 & 3

School Enrolments 1974

Burra High School enrolments are a record 190, with 1st Year 60, 2nd Year 60, 3rd Year 40 and Leaving 30.

1st Year enrolments are down 7 on 1973.

Staff & new students are named. Staff:

D. Calder (Headmaster) G. Searle R. Cuttle

Mrs Carina Cuttle Miss Jenny Murphy Miss Caroline Messurier

Hallett Primary School has an enrolment of 63 compared with 59 last year. Newcomers are listed.

Miss Russell is a new staff member.

Booborowie Primary School

The new Headmaster is Anthony Earle. The unofficial enrolment is 68.

New pupils are listed.

Mt Bryan School

There are 36 pupils for 1974 with Headmaster Mr Nick Kingsley. The new teacher is Miss Lorraine Newton.

New enrolments are listed.

Leighton School

Enrolment for 1974 is 28 compared with 25 in 1973. The Headmaster is Mr Ogden. New enrolments are listed.

Farrell Flat School

The new Headmaster is Mr B. Prime. New students are listed.

96, 5, 12 Feb. 1974, page 7

Burra Tourist Committee meeting called for 21 February.

Marriage. St Mary’s Church, Burra next Saturday

Heather Lucas, daughter of Mr & Mrs Cliff Lucas, will marry

Malcolm Crompton of Canberra, son of Dr & Mrs R.W. Crompton of Canberra.

Birth. To Mr & Mrs Ken Graetz (Burra’s new policeman; due this month), a son last week, David Graham.

Rev. John Stephenson has accepted an invitation to become Rector of St Jude’s Anglican Church at Brighton. His ministry here will conclude on 30 April, after six years.

Mrs Vi. Knight & Meralyn Rooke (a school-leaver) have joined the staff at Matthews Emporium.

Old Belcunda recorded 11.89 inches in the recent downpour and 14.76 inches for the month.

Weather. The recent heavy rains have caused numerous landslides on Mt Bryan. It is thought an earth tremor may have helped.

Burra High School. The first site proposed for the new Burra High School was completely submerged during the recent floods.

96, 6, 19 Feb. 1974, page 1

Burra Burra DC

Recent flood damage has forced a re-ordering of priorities on roadwork. Priority will have to be given to repairing school bus routes for instance.

Advice has been received that no subsidy for a Gold Clubhouse can be allocated in this financial year. Plans must first be drawn up and then the matter will receive further consideration.

The Council is aiming to improve the standard of some of the low rental homes in the town and an inspection of some of them was ? made on 19 February by representatives of SA Housing Trust, Department of Health & Welfare, MPs, Curator of Relics, National Trust and the Council.

Details of the town’s planned common effluent system will be released soon.

Council has received the title to the Farrell Flat Institute and a committee of management is being appointed.

Barloo Wildlife Park at the south end of the town of Manoora has been opened to the public. It is a private concern and the animals displayed include Rufus Rat Kangaroos, Wombats, Red and Grey Kangaroos, Wallabies, Emus, Brush Tail Possums from Tasmania, SA and Queensland and Guinea Pigs.

St Mary’s Church, Burra. Parish nominators meet today to consider with diocesan authorities, a new rector. Rev. Stephenson will leave at the end of April. There is a shortage of priests and there may be a short period when the parish is vacant.

96, 6, 19 Feb. 1974, page 2

Advt. Elders-GM will conduct a clearing sale on 14 March for A.C. & F.M. McDonald whose property has been sold. Sale on the property c. 12 miles northwest of Burra, past the Leighton School.

[Details given in an advertisement 2 columns wide by 3⁄4 column deep.]

Advt. Elders-GM will conduct a clearing sale on the property on 13 March for A.E. & D.E. Willis whose property has been sold. Sale on the property on the Petherton Road 7 miles northwest of Mt Bryan.

[Details in an advertisement 2 columns wide by 1⁄2 column deep.]

Bowls

1st Division Saddleworth 91 defeated Burra 53

2nd Division Saddleworth 83 defeated Burra Gold 71

Burra Blue 75 defeated Hallett 62

3rd Division Spalding 74 defeated Burra 62

96, 6, 19 Feb. 1974, page 3

Burra Library Annual Report 1873-74

We unfortunately lost our librarian during the year, but the position has been ably filled by Mrs Bos. The library has had new lighting installed this year and is well stocked and that is supplemented by a continuous rotation of box books from the Institutes’ Association. Adult subscriptions are $3.50 per annum and for juniors just 50 cents.

Tennis

‘A’ Grade Spalding White 19-119 defeated Booborowie 1-49

‘B’ Grade Hallett 11-91 defeated Mt Bryan 9-78

‘C’ Grade Burra Gold 7-59 defeated Leighton 5-43

Cricket

Spalding 3 for 99 declared defeated North Booborowie 58 & 2 for 52

Koonoona 5 for 211 defeated Burra Footballers 73 & 2 for 45

96, 6, 19 Feb. 1974, page 5

Ironmine Methodist Church

The last service was held at the church last Sunday. At a meeting held after the service it was decided to close the church after 103 years.

Mid North Football League held its AGM at Saddleworth on 1 February. Elected were:

President Stan Noske (re-elected)

Vice-President T. Mosey (Robertstown)

Secretary No Nominations: A.E. Bannear agreed to carry on.

Assistant Secretaries Mrs A.E. Bannear & Mrs R.J. Schirmer

[Various reforms were agreed to and details are given in c. 21⁄2 columns.]

96, 6, 19 Feb. 1974, page 6

Advt. Burra Pictures, 23 February

Carry on Henry

Rentadick

96, 6, 19 Feb. 1974, page 7

Birth. To Ros & Mike Jones of Burra North at Burra Hospital on Sunday, a daughter, Megan Kate.

Judith Affolter of Booborowie was presented with her graduation certificate and gold medal at Nurses’ Graduation Day at the QEH on 5 February. She is the only daughter of Mr & Mrs Ray Affolter of Booborowie.

Fr Kevin Matthews is welcomed to St Joseph’s Church at Burra. Fr Kineavy is now at Spalding.

Burra High School. The new Head Prefects are Cheryl Angel and Ron Shattock.

96, 7, 26 Feb. 1974, page 1

Burra Tourist Promotion Committee had a successful meeting on Thursday and decided to conduct another Copper Festival in conjunction with the Burra Show in October. Elected: Ray Jennison, chairman and Wally Scott, retiring Chairman, is now Secretary. Although the Show catalogues have for years suggested the first show was held in 1874, Ian Auhl has now presented research to show the Society was not formed until June 21 1877.

[The story of the foundation is printed.]

Burra High School Parents & Friends’ Association held its AGM least Week. Elected: President, Mrs O. Holmes; Vice-Presidents, Mrs P. Buckton & Mrs L. Kempster; Secretary, Mrs P. Brereton; Assistant Secretary, Mrs E. McMahon & Treasurer, Mrs V. Spackman. In 1973 $879.68 was raised. The organisation was busy catering at sports day and at the inter-school sports hosted here in May. During the year two local cafés closed, one of which had been delivering lunches to the school. A school canteen was started in conjunction with the Primary School. Mrs Webster and her willing helpers produced a profit of $400 by the year’s end. The annual ball was again a success and raised $374.52. [Major purchases for the year are listed.]

96, 7, 26 Feb. 1974, pages 1 & 5

Burra National Trust AGM

President G.R. O’Connor. The year has been one of consolidation. With the aid of three amazing young women from the Salisbury College of Advanced Education the restoration of the dugouts was completed after a long delay. As a fund raising effort a fence building job was undertaken on behalf of Samin Ltd and resulted in a nett profit of $780. The Bon Accord residence bathroom was rebuilt and better facilities installed – much of the rebuilding was necessitated by white ant damage – a problem which has re-appeared elsewhere in the house and must be addressed immediately. The museum continues to be a success and to attract many visitors.

Early in the year an old horse works was purchased and this presents members with the task of making it operative. Three haulage skips in very good repair were also bought and brought to the chimney site.

Due to difficulties associated with mining the area, we have not been able to remove much of the old haulway tunnel, which includes the remarkably preserved wheel. A serious fault in the rock structure has made the area dangerous. Roche’s will do their utmost to retrieve as much as possible. I am concerned that membership remains static. This is common to most branches, but is nevertheless a concern.

96, 7, 26 Feb. 1974, page 2

96, 7, 26 Feb. 1974, page 7

Birth. To Elly & Russell Nicholls of Burra at Burra Hospital last Tuesday, a son, Richard Garfield.

Marriage. St Joseph’s, Burra, next Saturday

Veronica Berryman of Leighton will marry Kym Mitchell.

Mrs Alice Seaford was 91 last Thursday.

Obituary. Mr Threadgold, former postmaster at Booborowie died last month. He is survived by his wife Shirley and two young children, Tracey and Peter.

Obituary. Frank Bates of Naracoorte has died leaving three children. His widow was formerly Marlene Shattock.

96, 8, 5 Mar. 1974, page 1

Rental Housing is required in Burra. At present few houses are available, but in the past five years no applications for housing in Burra have been received by the Housing Trust. The health officers were very concerned with the standard of some housing in Burra and in some cases demolition was the best solution.

Adelaide Wool Sales. Values on most Merino types were about 6% down. [Local district prices are printed.]

96, 8, 5 Mar. 1974, page 2

2nd Division Watervale 69 defeated Burra Gold 66

Spalding 71 defeated Burra Blue 67

3rd Division Hallett 76 defeated Burra 73

96, 8, 5 Mar. 1974, page 3

Tennis.

‘A’ Grade Burra Gold 10-85 defeated Mt Bryan 10-80

Hallett White 14-103 defeated Booborowie 6-74

Inter-Association Match

‘B’ Grade Burra 27-201 defeated Peterborough 9-125

96, 8, 5 Mar. 1974, pages 5 & 6

Burra Primary School Council. Report for 1973 from Ian Allen, Chairman.

Thanks to Mrs Avis Webster and the other women who have made the school canteen such a success. The Education Symposium on 10 August 1973 was a success, but the Council was disappointed that so few local parents attended; instead attendants came from the surrounding districts and from as far away as Clare and Saddleworth. Joint finance meetings with the High School have been useful in sharing costs of purchases. Departmental Heads from Adelaide and representatives of the Primary and High School Councils met on 30 November 1973 concerning the new school and the plans, estimates etc. are now in the hands of the Public Works Standing Committee. We hope tenders will soon be called.

96, 8, 5 Mar. 1974, page 6

Advt. Burra Pictures, 9 March

Steve McQueen, James Garner & Richard Attenborough in The Great Escape

Plus Short Features

96, 8, 5 Mar. 1974, page 7

Cricket

Spalding 4 for 260 declared (including T. Cousins 102) defeated Mt Bryan 58 & 4 for 45.

Leighton 9 for 130 v. Burra Footballers 3 for 147.

Birth. To Michael & Diana Smith nee Lines of Mt Bryan, now of Hart, at QEH last Wednesday, a daughter, Kathryn Margaret.

Birth. To Erica & Jack Kellock of Pine Valley Station at Burra Hospital on 28 February, a son, Andrew James.

Marriage. Burra Methodist Church next Saturday

Jan Richards, younger daughter of Mr & Mrs Jim Richards of Burra North, will marry

Trevor Blatchford, younger son of Mr & Mrs L.G. Blatchford of Saddleworth.

Mr Roy Humphrys was 85 last Sunday.

Peter Broderick has been winning medals in swimming at the State Life Saving Championships as part of the Police Academy Team.

Matron Siegele, formerly of the Burra Hospital, will be guest speaker at the Burra Red Cross meeting next Thursday.

Smelts Road. The Council has that the original name of this street was Landore Street. Residents should let Council know if they want it restored.

[Anyway this was the name of the street as it continued north of the Section 1 boundary.]

Obituary. Fred Williams of Burra North has died aged 82.

96, 9, 12 Mar. 1974, page 1

St Mary’s Anglican Parish. The new Rector will be Fr John Morley who will come from Kadina and take up the position in June.

96, 9, 12 Mar. 1974, pages 1 & 5

Burra Burra Show Inc. held its AGM on Thursday

Improvements of the ground are proposed, in preparation for the show’s centenary event. [1977]

An appeal for $4,000 is being launched. One aim is for new toilet facilities. Elected were: Patron, Rex Warnes; President, Graham Kellock (re-elected); Vice-Presidents, Ron Shipard & Neil Hurst and Secretary, Darrell Field.

The President’s Report showed a successful year with above average attendance on a fine sunny day. The Minister for Agriculture, Hon. T.M. Casey, opened the show.

Art was well supported, but photography was disappointing.

Cookery was well supported.

Needlework was strongly contested.

Produce entries were rather low.

Schoolwork made a good display.

Fresh fruit and vegetables section deserves better support from the home gardener.

Flowers and Floral Arts sections had a good display following a good season.

Birds were strongly supported with good displays.

Wool received many entries.

Sheep entries were again disappointing.

Goats had a good display.

Pigs drew only one exhibit and the cattle section was similar.

The dog display was only average.

The Motor Cycle Trials were a successful innovation.

Horses in Action were popular and entries were of a high standard.

The Shearing Competition was popular with spectators, but entries were down a little.

Miss Show Girl was revitalised this year.

Sideshows were well supplied.

Colin & Madge McDonald whose property ‘Rockhill’ has been sold, will be given a farewell tea in Leighton on Sunday.

[Allan Donald Sellars born 9 June 1908 Redruth.]

Des & Jean Button are leaving the Booborowie Serv-Wel Store, but will remain in the district.

The new proprietors of the shop will be Bill & Gwen Griffiths.

A Leighton Cabaret recently raised $200 for the Hall Committee.

96, 9, 12 Mar. 1974, page 8

Burra Primary School Welfare Club held its AGM and elected: President, Mrs B. Stockman (re-elected); Secretary, Mrs M. Tiver (re-elected); Assistant Secretary, Mrs J. Bowden and Treasurer, Mrs P. Dignan.

The secretary reported on a year devoted to money-raising. Financial members were 45 and average attendance was 22. $1,159 was received and $1443 was spent on classroom equipment. Participation in the new School Council has been most rewarding. On the sports day the Club raised $359 and a Walkathon raised $480 for the Home for Incurables. With little notice at the end of July a band of mothers from the Primary and High Schools organised a canteen at the school and with Mrs Webster as Supervisor a voluntary roster system was worked out and by the end of the year there was a $400 credit. The club has also participated in the Education Symposium and other meetings, which gave a better understanding of modern education.

Kooringa Methodist Guild. The secretary Mrs Y.M. Queissner reported on the past year in a little over 1⁄2 column.

Elected for the coming year: President, Mrs Baulderstone; Secretary, Mrs Queissner & Treasurer, Mrs W. Nankivell.

96, 10, 19 Mar. 1974, page 1

Burra Burra DC

Council is seeking to clean up the town with a campaign aimed at a general removal of rubbish, especially the removal of old car bodies from the area, the elimination of stray dogs and mosquito control. Local Cubs and Scouts have held a Litterthon and collected 248 bags of rubbish. They removed 1,457drink cans and 116 bottles in the town and from one mile of the road west. The greatest source was the Burra Creek.

Burra RSL held its AGM on 8 March and elected: President, R.J. Steele; Vice-Presidents, C.R. Earle and B. Kotz. Secretary, Mr W.J. Fridd and Treasurer, Wayne Clarke. The retiring President, Mr B. Kotz, thanked the Ladies’ Auxiliary for their support. Average attendance at meetings has been 6.

96, 10, 19 Mar. 1974, page 2

Advt. Burra Pictures, 23 March

Bruce Spence & Jackie Weaver in Stork

Bowls

1st Division Saddleworth 70 defeated Burra 61

2nd Division Burra Gold 69 defeated Burra Blue 54

3rd Division Auburn 114 defeated Burra 52

Burra & District Ambulance Association held its AGM. Mr R.L. Thamm was re-elected Chairman. In the year the ambulance travelled 5,300 miles attending 6 car accident cases and 17 sickness cases which had to be transferred to Adelaide hospitals and taking 11 accident and 19 sickness cases to the local hospital as well as attending 24 sporting fixtures.

Ruth Woollacott contributes a 11⁄2-column article on her travels: this time from London and southeast England.

Burra High School induction of Prefects and House Captains is reported in 1⁄2 column.

Burra Kindergarten held its AGM on 4 March. In the year an extension verandah was built and new blinds were installed. $510-83 was raised. Elected: President, Mrs David Jones; Vice-President, Mrs Gerald Wood; Secretary, Mrs Trevor Simpson; Assistant Secretary, Mrs John Secomb; Treasurer, Mrs Kies van der Does and Patroness, Mrs Edith Carpenter.

First Semi-Finals Burra Association

‘B’ Grade Hallett Red 13 sets defeated Spalding White 7 sets

Second Semi-Finals

Hallett White 11-87 defeated Spalding Blue 9-82

Cricket

Koonaburra 0 for 173 defeated Spalding 8 for 127

Leighton defeated Mt Bryan

Booborowie defeated Burra Footballers

Miss Tanya Moiseiwitsch visited Burra on Saturday. She is in the state for the Arts Festival production of Moliere’s The Imaginary Invalid. Her mother was Miss Daisy Fowler Kennedy who was born in a bedroom of the Commercial Hotel in Burra in 1893. Joseph Kennedy, Daisy’s father, was a headmaster and the headmaster’s house was not ready, so the family stayed at the hotel until the house in Kangaroo street was available. Daisy Kennedy became a well known violinist who went to Vienna to study when aged 15. She later married the famous concert pianist from Odessa, Russia, Benno Moiseiwitsch.

Fire. The north bound bus of Mortons of Broken Hill caught fire at Hallett on Sunday about 7.30 due to an engine fault. Some lady passengers suffered shock, but all 45 passengers escaped along with most of the luggage. The bus was completely burned out and damage is estimated at $24,000. The EFS put out the fire.

Mr & Mrs Colin McDonald were farewelled at Leighton Hall on Sunday evening.

Jack Williams of Booborowie has his usual magnificent display of dahlias.

96, 11, 26 Mar. 1974, page 1

Burra Red Cross

The March meeting was attended by 50 ladies to hear an address by Matron G. Siegele. She was Matron at the Burra Hospital 1923-37. During that time she went to Sydney to study the Truby King Baby Nursing Methods and on her return established the first Infant Health Clinic in Burra. After leaving Burra she went to Port Pirie and Broken Hill, before going to Royal Perth Hospital, where she spent 19 years before retiring 12 years ago. At the age of 80 she is an active worker for her church and a member of the Embroidery Guild in Adelaide. While here she visited the Hospital and Barker’s Cottages, where she knew several of the residents. She had lunch with Mrs Roy Jeffery, who also drove her around the town and Mine area before she returned to the city.

96, 11, 26 Mar. 1974, pages 1 & 6

Burra Primary School

Fifty-three Grade IV & V students had a six-day camping excursion to Mt Barker Chalet.

On Sunday 17th They drove to Mt Barker via the Barossa Valley, inspecting a dairy at Mt Torrens on the way.

Monday 18th Visited Piccadilly Valley market gardens and Ashton Cold Stores for grading and packing apples. Went to Mr Trenorden’s apple orchard and to the Police Training School at Echunga in the afternoon.

Tuesday 19th Inspected Jacob’s milk and butter factory. Swam in Mt Barker’s heated pool. Visited Johnson’s Tannery and the Mt Barker School.

Wednesday 20th Morning tour of Port Adelaide, visiting the wharves, Torrens Island Power Station and the Birkenhead Bridge. Moscow Circus matinee in the afternoon and at night visited Mt Lofty Summit to see Adelaide’s lights.

Thursday 21st Went to the Road Safety Centre at Oaklands Park and toured the TAA facilities at Adelaide Airport, where they inspected a plane, returning to Mt Barker by train.

Friday 22nd Retuned to Burra.

[Participants are listed.]

96, 11, 26 Mar. 1974, page 8

Burra High School participated in the Mid-North Swimming Carnival at Riverton.

Burra results are printed.

Burra came third in the Junior Section and fourth in the Senior Section.

96, 12, 2 Apr. 1974, page 1

Redruth Methodist Trust Committee is planning to use their property as a conference centre and they have been successful in their application for a grant from Community Welfare Grants. The Minister of Community Welfare advises that they have a grant of $5,000 for building and $500 for equipment. They will need to erect two ablution blocks and provide additional facilities for cooking, eating and sleeping. The property has already been used by groups for accommodation and further bookings have been made. There is considerable tourist potential for school and church groups. Rev. C. Hore, Chairman of the Committee, says they are much encouraged by the grant. Mr Brian Thamm is the Trust Committee Secretary.

Spalding 202

Koonaburra then batted in fading light and eventually showers of rain, which finally stopped play at 9 for 136.

33 of the required 40 overs were bowled and a meeting on 17 April will decide whether the match is to be decided by bowling the remaining overs or is to be replayed.

Obituary. Mr Jack (Sugar) Kellaway died suddenly 2 April aged 46.

96, 14, 17 Apr. 1974, page 1 CHECK THIS IRREGULAR DATE OF ISSUE

Burra Burra DC

The Local

Government Association is seeking Council feedback on a proposal for quarterly payment of rates. At present inly about 16% of rates are paid on issue of rates notices. The rest are not paid till the end of February. Council has to pay interest on its overdraft and this cost id considerably higher than the accounting cost of quarterly payments.

Spraypave Pty Ltd is sealing the Station Road and the parking area, but has been delayed by bad weather.

Approximately $2,500 has been transferred from the 1st Copper Festival to the Tourist Committee.

Through the generosity of Mrs Andrew Tennant a town clock with two faces has been erected in the lawn area in Commercial St. [Market Square.]

The stray dog problem in the town has not improved.

Vandals have damaged the toilets at the Council Office, allowing water to run freely overnight on 6 April.

At Burra North cisterns were tampered with and water allowed to run to such an extent that a section of wall has sagged.

Burra’s evidence to the Local Government Boundaries Royal Commission will be taken on Friday. The submission by the Council was formulated in July 1973 and the Council opposes the formation of Regional Councils on the basis that:

It will mean added costs to ratepayers.

Such a council would carry out the same duties that the present Council does.

There would be unnecessary duplication of work and administrative costs.

The Council can see some merits in bigger Councils in some cases and in boundary adjustments. This Council was formed five years ago by the amalgamation of the DC and the Corporation of Burra. Its income is about $100,000 p.a. It employs a Clerk, Overseer, Part-Time Health and Building Inspectors and combines with two other Councils for a Full-Time Weeds Inspector. There is a concern over rising costs of maintenance and administration and it feels its boundaries should not be retracted. In the event of a decision that some adjacent Councils should cease to exist, a map is enclosed showing the area that could be incorporated into the Burra Burra DC.

Councillors retiring due to the effluxion of time.

Farrell Flat Ward J.W. Burge

Kooringa Ward W. Brown

Leighton Ward R.J. White

Mongolata Ward B.A. Riggs

Burra Town Ward C.L. Phillips

Nominations are called by 10 May.

96, 14, 17 Apr. 1974, page 2

The final of the Men’s Fours was fought out by two teams from Cadell.

The Mixed Bowls finally went to a Murray Bridge team.
