96, 14, 17 Apr. 1974, page 8

North East Combined School Sports were held recently. [Results are printed.]

96, 15, 23 Apr. 1974, page 1

Water Levels in Booborowie Valley

E.C. Allen MP asked the Minister of Development and Mines to report on test bores in the Booborowie Valley, aimed at determining the rate of recharge and the capacity of the valley. Hon. D.J. Hopgood said 53 observation bores were maintained. Five stratigraphic bores were drilled in a line to determine the hydraulic properties of the aquifer. Other geological investigations are reported and a comprehensive geological report will be available in a few months.

Redruth Methodist Trust Committee has thanked Mr S.J. Woollacott and Mr A.L. Clode for their many years of service. Both were appointed to the Trust in 1937 and now retire under the new Property Trust Act.

Weather. This month has been the wettest April for 85 years with so far 95.8 mm (377 points).

Accident. A two-car collision in heavy fog occurred near Brown’s Corner three miles west of Burra on Sunday morning. Four people were injured: Mrs Claudia Mitchell suffered a fractured leg and hip and lacerations, John Mitchell suffered a ruptured spleen and broken knee cap, Wayne Brereton, the driver of to other car, suffered concussion and lacerations, as did his passenger, Dean Bogisch. Mr & Mrs Mitchell and Dean were later transferred to the RAH.

96, 15, 23 Apr. 1974, pages 1 & 3

Tennis: Junior Tennis Final

(‘C’ Grade) Leighton 8-58 defeated Burra 4-55

This is Leighton’s first shield win since Junior Tennis began in the Association in 1967.

President of the Association, Mr Don Lloyd, presented the Shield to the Captain of Leighton, Barry Gent.

Cricket. Mokota Association Grand Final

Spalding 202 defeated Koonaburra 142. The scores are given without comment, but they suggest the decision was taken to play on and bowl the last few overs: see 96, 13, 9 Apr. 1974, page 2.

96, 15, 23 Apr. 1974, page 8

Stockowners’ Association of SA, Burra Branch held its AGM in the RSL Hall 8 April.

Elected: President, Mr Jock Duncan and Vice-Presidents, Messrs J.T. Drew & R.J. Ashby. The retiring President, D.G. Radford, reported on a year that started well with prices holding up and record rains, but then came the fuel crisis, tumbling wool prices and a blowfly outbreak, with staggering losses. Later beef prices also fell, combined with higher wages, shortages of labour and materials, the withdrawal of the super bounty and unfavourable taxation changes.

96, 16, 30 Apr. 1974, page 1

Burra Floods

Thunderstorms on Tuesday evening brought 24.8 mm in less than one hour. On Saturday came a heavier downpour. Outlets were unable to cope and some minor flooding of streets occurred. At about 1 p.m. the creek past the hospital overflowed at the Commercial Road Bridge. Commercial Street was rapidly covered in muddy water, which flooded parts of Chapel, Queen and Thames Streets. Some Commercial Street premises were flooded and others escaped. The rainfall for the week was 68.8 mm. The rainfall for April so far is 164.6 mm or 650 points and the highest ever was in 1889 when 830 points were recorded.

[This would seem to be a totally inadequate report of the extent of this flood, give the volume of water mentioned. It extends for no more than 1⁄4 column.]

96, 16, 30 Apr. 1974, pages 1 & 5

Burra School

The Public Works Standing Committee has accepted the need for improved school accommodation at Burra and construction has been recommended. The loans allocation will be decided in August and construction will depend on this decision. The decision to redevelop the existing site is based on the fact that it is a pleasant setting for attractive landscaping. It is also near the town centre and will preserve the close relationships of the school with the community and give ready access to the Burra Town Swimming Pool and football oval. The school will be able to offer facilities for the community in terms of the library and art and craft and music facilities and a multi-purpose sports hall. It is envisaged that the school will become a focal point for educational, recreational and cultural interests. There will be a staff block, administration, canteen, sports, music & drama areas and changing rooms as well as a library, recreation areas and car park. Parents will have a continuity of involvement as their children move through the school from primary to secondary years. There is the possibility of a unified administration under a single headmaster.

The size of the planned accommodation has been based on primary enrolments in Burra and district schools. Secondary enrolments should exceed 200 by 1975, which justifies providing for 220-250 students, which would allow for the possibility of a 5th year class in the future. The existing Burra School is a well-known landmark and is among the finest buildings of its type in SA. It has, however, outlived its usefulness for modern educational conditions and needs extensive modifications to meet the requirements of modern educational programs. The large rooms with high ceilings are hard to heat and cool and also present acoustic problems. Little has been done in recent years to modify the original accommodation. Administration facilities are inadequate. The library is far below modern standards and the classrooms do not accommodate modern teaching methods.

The site has made development difficult and the outdoor areas fall far short of requirements. Sports facilities are limited and in need of upgrading and development. The site has also become cluttered by the erection of a multitude of wooden classrooms, a canteen and toilet blocks for both schools. Many of these buildings have outlived their economic usefulness. The plans prepared provide for upgrading of the main building to house a primary school of 350 in modern open-space accommodation. This provision anticipates the eventual closure of Leighton (28 children), Farrell Flat (17 children) and Mt Bryan (36 children). The plan groups buildings around a central courtyard at the rear of the old building and they are functionally linked by the resource centre, while the existing building will be extensively remodelled internally. Planning and design is based on the open space principle. All new buildings are single storey and are stepped up the rising ground so as not to distract from the appearance of the existing building, especially as seen from the town. The relationships of the buildings and their uses allow for the separation or integration of the two schools as required.

96, 16, 30 Apr. 1974, page 2

Birth. To Rosemary & Jim Quinn of Mt Bryan at QVMH 23 April, a daughter, Donnamarie Wendy.

Oddfellows Hall. Some months ago the Hall was advertised for sale by tender. Roche Bros Social Club is now the owner. By agreement the Burra Burra Lodge and the Table Tennis Club have the use of the Hall. After renovations and the building of a new toilet block the Hall will be available for hire.

96, 17, 7 May 1974, page 7

Birth. To Raelene & Murray Tohl of Booborowie at Clare on Friday, a daughter, Trudy Marie.

Obituary. Mrs Martin, the mother of Daphne, Mrs Kevin Jacka of Burra, died last Thursday.

Elizabeth Earle, who has been working at the National Bank in Burra for several years, has been transferred to Adelaide.

Church Union

The Methodist General Conference and the Presbyterian General Assembly agreed last week to join in a new Uniting Church with the Congregational Church. The amalgamation is expected to come into effect on 2 June 1976. The Methodist vote was 160 for and 11 against.

The Presbyterian vote was 230 for and 143 against and this passed the 60% majority needed by only 7 votes.

96, 18, 14 May 1974, page 1

Adelaide Wool Sales. Values were on par or up to 21⁄2% lower. [Local district prices are printed on page 5.]

Roger Nutt of Hallett writes a letter to the editor contending that the Federal Labor Government is heading the country towards a dictatorship and a Communist dictatorship at that, in continuation of the ideas of I.J. Denton in 96, 17, 7 May 1974, page 1.

96, 18, 14 May 1974, pages 1 & 7

Weather. With 23.2 mm to 9 a.m. yesterday and 81.0 mm for the week, the January-May period becomes the wettest on record; 508.6 mm or 20.02 inches. The previous highest was in 1889 with 13.41 inches. The continuously flowing water courses and flooding have made access to many paddocks virtually impossible. Many gutters have become creeks and shallow creeks have been deepened.

The Burra Creek yesterday was a rushing torrent of muddy water for the sixth time this year. Mt Bryan was flooded again on Thursday; the earth is so saturated that it cannot absorb even a slight shower.

Further rain has fallen, with 94 points to 1.30 p.m.

Booborowie received 25 mm in ten minutes at lunch time.

Buildings have been flattened at Eudunda in a cyclonic storm [i.e. a tornado].

96, 18, 14 May 1974, page 2

96, 18, 14 May 1974, pages 4-5 gutter

Obituary. Allan Donald Sellars died 12 March. He has been described as ‘a friend to all who had the pleasure of knowing him’. He was born at Burra North in 1908 and educated at the Burra School. He married Daphne Hirschausen in 1927 and together they commenced and operated a general carrying, grain agency and wood merchant’s business. From the mid 1930s Mr Sellars conducted a mail run for six years, travelling each weekend to the outlying stations east of Burra, covering a distance of 300 miles over unmade roads, with some 180 rates to negotiate. Declared unfit for war service, he opened a service station and garage in conjunction with his other business to release the owner for war service. On medical advice he gave up his business and purchased ‘Emu Flat’ at Keith in 1945. This proved unsuitable for family needs at the time and he then spent six years on dairy farms at Murray Bridge and Jervois before returning to Keith in 1953. In 1958 he founded the General Agency business of A.D. Sellars & Sons – later including all six sons in premises at Keith. Ill health forced him into semi-retirement in 1966. He was always interested in the community and was the founder of the ‘Burdett’ Agricultural Bureau at Murray Bridge. He was a director of the Jervois Co-op Milk Factory and assisted in getting it included in the city milk area, thereby receiving extra bonuses. He was on the committees of the Keith Agricultural Bureau, Keith War Memorial Community Centre and the Keith & District Show Society. He was of a cheerful disposition and ever ready to help his fellowman. He is survived by his daughter, Roma Mrs C.A. Davis and sons, Colin, Brian, Graham, Dean, Ian and Kevin.

96, 18, 14 May 1974, page 6

96, 19, 21 May 1974, page 1

Voting in the Federal Election last Saturday for Burra District:

The marked difference between Burra and Burra North voting patterns was also reflected in early Senate figures.

Weather. Damage to roads is giving the BBDC grave financial concern. The sealing work at Burra North has been delayed due to the ongoing wet weather.

At Eudunda last Tuesday a tornado ripped through the town. A warehouse was flattened, iron was ripped from roofs. Trees and shrubs were uprooted and glass smashed. It came in from the north at about 12.45 p.m.

Ian Auhl is preparing a book of Burra photographs 1877-1977 and he makes an appeal for photos for this intended publication. [The book eventually appeared in 1975 as Burra and District A Pictorial Memoir.]

Gerald Wood & family will be farewelled from Hanson at a barbecue on Sunday. The family is moving to Adelaide.

96, 20, 28 May 1974, page 1

Burra School

The Minister of Education Mr Hugh Hudson has announced the finalised plans for the new school at Burra. Land is now being acquired adjacent to the present school. New accommodation will be built for the High School and the old solid building will receive extensive modification to provide modern primary teaching areas. The proposals have met with a favourable reception from school bodies and the local council. Mr Hudson outlined the advantages of the proposal. [Previously noted.]

96, 21, 4 June 1974, page 6

Notice. Burra Cubs will be closed due to lack of parent interest.

B.P. Thamm, Chairman.

Obituary. Pearl Newland died suddenly 30 May 1974. She was the elder daughter of the late Mr & Mrs W.A. Gebhardt of Burra and only sister of Lil, Mrs H. Byles.

[Born Pearl Gebhardt 22 May 1906 Kooringa. Her first husband was Frederick K.G. Boase who died in 1940.]

Patrick McNee & Connie Stevens in Mr Jericho

96, 21, 4 June 1974, page 7

Marriage. Maylands Methodist Church last Saturday

Mr Wal. Martin married Mrs Joyce Bourman, well known in Burra.

[Her first husband, Leonard Bourman, has died in 1971.]

Pam & Barry Biggs have left Burra after nine years here to open a shop ‘The Gem Cave’ in Alice Springs.

Father John Morley was born in 1924 and lived with his family on a small orchard and vineyard at Williamstown. The family moved to Adelaide in the 1930s and John attended Urrbrae Agricultural HS and Pulteney Grammar School. After school he went jackerooing for Mr Chris Wade on Thistle Island for a year, before working for Sir Philip McBride on Conmurray Station in the South East. He joined the RAAF as air crew in 1942 and was commissioned in 1943, eventually becoming Radar Leader for 102 Squadron, flying in Liberators. After discharge he returned to Conmurray for a time and in 1946 bought a virgin property on the Avenue Range, which he named ‘Dingley’. He developed 1,300 acres before selling it in 1957. He ran 1,500 to 2,000 sheep and Aberdeen Angus cattle. He studied for the ministry at St John’s College, Morpeth, from 1958 for three years. He has been a keen sportsman, playing football and cricket for more than 20 years and now plays golf and a little tennis. He used to show horses in the South East and also played polocrosse. He is married with three children and three grandsons. His son, John, is married and works at G.H. Michell & Sons. Rosemary is married and Susan is still at school at Woodlands, doing matriculation this year.

The Burra Creek is flowing crystal clear water after five weeks, suggesting replenished underground supplies.

96, 21, 4 June 1974, page 8

Adelaide Wool Sales. Prices were up 21⁄2 to 5%. [Local District prices are printed.]

96, 22, 11 June 1974, page 1

St Mary’s. Bishop Rosier and a number of other clergy gathered at St Mary’s last Wednesday when the Bishop commissioned Rev. John Morley as the new Rector of the Burra Parish. The church was well filled for the service. Members of other denominations also attended. [Details in 2 columns.]

96, 23, 19 June 1974, page 1

Accident/Obituary. At about 1.45 p.m. on Sunday about 22 miles east of Burra on the Morgan Road, a vehicle travelling towards Morgan overturned. Two women passengers were admitted to the Burra Hospital with minor injuries, but a 61-year-old man from England and his 38-year-old son from Para Vista died.

96, 24, 25 June 1974, page 1

Burra Bowling Club held its AGM last Tuesday night and elected: Patron, D.T. Jacka; President, Brian Riggs; Vice-Presidents, W.K. Scott & D.J. Broderick; Secretary, T.B. Lynch & Treasurer, N. Hurst.

Burra CWA held its AGM and elected, President, Mrs E. Baulderstone; Vice-President, Mrs E. Baker; Secretary, Mrs V. Fennell; Assistant Secretary, Mrs E. Hore & Treasurer, Mrs R. Jennison.

Fireworks. In future the sale of fireworks will be banned in SA except for organised public displays. A spate of eye and facial injuries over the Queen’s Birthday long weekend had produced letters and petitions of protest against their continued use.

96, 24, 25 June 1974, page 7

Birth. To Marilyn & Peter Fiebig at Burra Hospital last Thursday, a son, Damien Scott.

Elizabeth Oates, daughter of Mr & Mrs J.P. Oates of Burra, will marry

Donald Mosey, son of Mr & Mrs F.M. Mosey of Hampden.

Mr & Mrs Peter Brook of Mt Bryan will soon move to Tarcowie, where Peter is to manage a property.

The Burra Creek is still running after eight weeks.

The Doubles Pool Tournament continues.

Burra Pictures were so disrupted by bad behaviour of young patrons on Saturday night that the film had to be stopped twice.

96, 25, 2 July 1974, page 1

Ian Auhl made a final appeal for photographs for his publication of a collection of them from 1877-1977.

[Donors to this point are listed.]

Booborowie Primary School Gala Day & Gymkhana was held on the oval on Sunday 23 June. $807 was raised. [The results are printed.]

Hanson Post Office was closed on Friday after serving the community for 84 years. Hanson will now be served by private boxes at Burra or Farrell Flat or by the Mail Run. Hanson was a non-official office. The first office was at the Hanson (then called Davieston) Railway Station and was opened in December 1890. Mr I. Rippin was the postmaster with a daily mail service by train. E.S. Blunt was postmaster 1897-1902. A telegraph worked by telephone was installed in 1913. Local residents built the next post office by the schoolteacher’s residence and until 1947 postmasters were the schoolteacher’s wives or immediate relations. E. Dawson was the schoolteacher in 1915, Hester Oakley was schoolteacher 5 January 1916 and Miss Janie H. Fedd from 1 July 1916 was the sister of the schoolmistress. Lilian Mabel Bishop was a temporary appointment 25 March 1920 and Margaret Ellen Marshall was the teacher from 15 April 1920.

Margaret Barbara Trenter 6 October 1923

Margaret Ellen Marshall 7 July 1924

Elizabeth Ellen Craigie 1 April 1926

Gladys Ida Eustis 19 April 1926 (temporary)

Edith Daisy Boehm 26 July 1926

Daphne Hermes 21 January 1933

Mrs Vera Lavina McQueen 22 May 1935

Mrs Alice Lillian Maude Cawthorne 16 May 1941

Mrs Barbara Esme Daw 3 February 1947

A telephone exchange was established c. 1920. When Mr Syd Robinson took over the Hanson store in August 1948 the office moved there and operated until last Friday – the last working day before 30 June. He and Mrs Robinson have given sterling service to the district over the past 26 years. They will continue to live at Hanson in retirement; the store having been closed several years ago.

96, 25, 2 July 1974, pages 1 & 3

Burra Bowling Club. President Darrell H. Field reports on 1973.

The club had a successful year, though it did not win any pennants. In the Mid North Championship Rinks the First Division team of Ian Allen, Wally Scott, Keith Phillips and Bill Corner, came up Champions. The club tournaments were run efficiently. Winners:

Championship Singles Kies van der Does

Handicap singles Edgar Pietsch

Night Singles Bill Corner

Consistency Brice Stockman

Championship Pairs Edgar Pietsch & Les Phillips

Night Pairs Keith Phillips & Kies van der Does

The Open Tournament at the end of January had to be abandoned due to rain.

The Easter Tournament was a great success. Improvements have included:

A cement floor for the top dressing

Repainted score boards

A new 11⁄2 inch main will be connected to increase flow

A new Fernandez watering system will be purchased.

[Other minor improvements are listed.]

[The report concludes with the usual list of thanks.]

96, 25, 2 July 1974, page 7

Birth. To Marie & Peter Murphy of Eudunda on Sunday, a daughter, Amanda Jane.

Peter is the son of Beryl and the late Ken Murphy of Burra.

Obituary. Fred M. Pearce died at Burra Hospital last week aged 89. He was a devoted Mason and member of the Kooringa Masonic Lodge since joining it 62 years ago in 1912. He was worshipful Master in 1919.

[Frederick Moxey Pearce born 29 June 1884 Redruth: died 24 June 1974 Burra.]

July McAllister of Mt Bryan and formerly of Riverton is a new face at Marion’s Hairdressing Salon in Burra.

Weather. More light rain has fallen this week. Burra received 63 points.

96, 25, 2 July 1974, page 8

Burra Women’s Branch of the LCL held its AGM at the Kooringa Hotel on 24 June. The Leader of the Opposition Dr Bruce Eastick was the guest speaker. His theme was Federal Labor’s gallop towards Socialism. He also spoke against the State Government’s expenditure on projects like the Adelaide Railway Station Complex, the Windy Point Restaurant and Monarto. All were unnecessary. The country vote needed to be heard more.

Elected were: President, Mrs Ron. Collins; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames W. Klem & R. Pearse; Secretary, Mrs Finch and Treasurer, Mr C. O’Connor. [The report on the branch activities for the year runs to a little more than one column.]

96, 26, 9 July 1974, page 1

Burra Show Society’s Toilet Fund has been boosted by about $1,200 as the result of a lottery run by the society in conjunction with a cabaret organised by the Rural Youth Club. The lottery was won by Mrs M.T. Kellock who donated $500 of the $750 prize to the Show Society Fund. [Other winners are listed.]

Before Saturday the fund stood at about $400. Now the fund is just over half way to its target of $4,000.

The Pichi Richi Railway will open on 20 July; running from Quorn to Summit.

Kapunda Music Society will present Gilbert & Sullivan’s HMS Pinafore at the Burra Town Hall on 17 august. Proceeds will aid the Burra Swimming Pool Committee.

Community Libraries. A report prepared by a Committee set up by the Minister of Education has recommended that in small communities, the community use of school libraries is the most effective way forward and after this was set up Institute or local libraries would cease. The report is being considered and it is hoped a decision can soon be made.

A teacher surplus in SA

A superphosphate price rise

95, 27 (2), 16 July 1974, page 5

Saddleworth CWA AGM is reported in a little more than 1⁄2 column.

Allison Barckey, an exchange student from Riverton, New Jersey, who is at Burra High School and staying with John & Bev. Dewhirst at Booborowie, makes some observations:

At home we learn to be more independent and here the teachers outline what is important. At home we are given more assorted material and each must judge for himself or herself what is important. At home I go to a private co-ed school drawn from a select group of the community. At BHS there is a wider range and variety of people. At home it is usual to change rooms and class levels for every class. Here there seems to be little academic pressure among fellow students. Living in the country is different too. The atmosphere is relaxed, but with a quiet air of growth and change. It has all been very fascinating and exciting and I cannot discover all I would like in my ten week stay.

95, 27 (2), 16 July 1974, page 6

95, 28 (2), 23 July 1974, page 1

Burra Burra DC, last Tuesday

A meeting of ratepayers has been called to consider the Council’s options in the face of large wage increases and rising overhead costs. The question of lining the Burra Swimming Pool with fibreglass will have to be considered. It removes the need for repainting every year and resists the growth of algae.

At the last meeting of Council on Tuesday Cr W. Brown was re-elected Chairman with Cr R.J. Jeffery as Deputy Chairman.

Commonwealth and State Governments are presently refusing to indicate whether grants are available for unsealed main roads and this is a serious worry. There is a call to generally brighten up the town’s appearance prior to the Copper Festival; removal of weeds and action with the paint brush is recommended.

Methodist Church. The annual Middle District Synod is to be held at Clare on Tuesday and Wednesday next. It will be the last such, with the Uniting Church of Australia to be inaugurated 2 June 1975.

Under the Uniting Church Methodist Circuits will become Parishes, Synods will become Presbyteries and the Annual Conference will become the Synod and the General Conference, the Assembly.

Burra Schools held a Monster Auction on 13 July and successfully raised $457.

Robertstown Lagoon has continued to rise as the wet winter continues. A levee to protect the Point Pass-Robertstown Road failed after rough waves last week and the road was still closed yesterday.

95, 28 (2), 23 July 1974, page 2

Hallett CWA AGM is reported in 1 column.

Football

Mid North League matches were played in shocking wet and muddy conditions. The ‘A’ Grade match at Robertstown was halted at half time when Riverton players refused to continue on the waterlogged and muddy oval. The game was forfeited to Robertstown. Riverton remains safely at the top of the table.

[95, 29 (2), 30 July 1974, page 2. The above statement is corrected; it was not the Riverton players who refused to continue, but the Riverton Committee who decided to forfeit the game.]

Porter’s Lagoon is exceptionally high this year.

The School Concert on Friday night saw a packed Town Hall and the gross takings were $208.

Burra Women’s Golfers Pennant Team has been victorious; defeating Blyth yesterday. Members were: Judy Oates, Jacky Dignan, Estelle Nicholls, Martha Jeffery and Lyn Kempster. The men’s team also won the pennant competition this year.

Burra Library’s Trading Table on Friday saw gross takings of $144.80.

Petition at Burra Record Office for those who wish to see live hare coursing banned in SA.

95, 29 (2), 30 July 1974, page 1

Burra Methodist Church used its new heaters for the first time on Sunday and they proved to be effective. The Burra Branch of the Bible Society will have its annual meeting next Tuesday in Redruth Hall.

95, 29 (2), 30 July 1974, pages 1 & 8

The Royal Commission on Council Boundaries

The first report recommends reducing the number of Councils from 137 to 72 with boundaries based on community of interest. The recommendation does not envisage there being fewer officers employed. In the last 40 years almost all the changes have been the amalgamation of a rural Town Council with surrounding District Council. Very few boundary changes have been made. The mergers of Town Councils and District Councils have all proved to be satisfactory. [Details are given respecting the District Councils of Robertstown and Eudunda, which it is proposed to merge and also the District Council of Saddleworth & Auburn, which it is proposed to merge with the DC of Riverton and of the Clare DC, which it is recommended should be enlarged by absorbing parts of the DCs of Georgetown & Spalding together with all of Blyth.]

The Burra Burrs DC and the Clare DC boundary would remain as it is, but it is recommended that the southern three Hundreds of the Hallett DC (Anne, Hallett & Tomkinson) be merged with the Burra Burra DC. The Burra Burrs DC has not yet had time to consider this recommendation.

95, 29 (2), 30 July 1974, page 7

Obituary. Mrs Florrie Affolter, mother of Marj. & Ray, died at Burra Hospital last Friday aged 83.

Geoff. Pedlar of the Burra branch of the National Bank has been transferred to the City.

Birth. To Dr & Mrs William Chapman of Mosman Park, Perth, last Wednesday, a son, Simon William. Mrs Chapman was formerly Le Snell of Booborowie.

95, 30 (3), 6 Aug. 1974, page 1

Burra Pictures. Council is concerned with the severe fall in income from the pictures. Takings are down to $20 or less. Feedback is sought. Is it price, the weather, the type of film, too much noise or just a sign of the times?

Weather. Further rain amounting to 17.2 mm has brought the annual total to 689.9 mm or 2,715 points. This is approaching the annual record of 2,780 points in 1889.

Premier Don Dunstan will come to Burra during the Copper festival in October.

95, 30 (3), 6 Aug. 1974, pages 1 & 8

Burra & District Ratepayers’ Meeting on Thursday night was well attended. The main concerns expressed covered road deterioration and the lack of grant monies. A petition to the Minister of Roads, followed by a deputation is to be arranged. The Chairman said there have been many changes and proposals for change in local government in the past year and this has created a rather confused outlook. At the start of the year the Council was in a difficult financial position, though this had improved somewhat now. The Council has had to increase staff since January 1973 due to the increased complexity of its work. In the year Rural Unemployment Relief Grant work was completed, resulting in improved recreational facilities at Farrell Flat, Booborowie, mount Bryan and Burra. Some renovation of Paxton Square and the Redruth Gaol was also done. A smoke lounge and toilets were constructed at the Burra Town Hall. Council administration includes Town Hall hire and management, caravan park maintenance, Burra Swimming Pool maintenance and management and two sports grounds at Burra. The projected plan for a dam on Burra Creek has been delayed by weather conditions, but is expected to proceed in early summer. Councillors continue to promote the development of the town and district. Rising costs will be a major factor in the coming year. The EFS has attended several small fires this year. A main theme to appear during the meeting was the deterioration of unsealed roads and some sealed sections within the district. The Booborowie-Spalding Road attracted a lot of comment. The Minister says he is going to look at the matter of road funding, but comes back with a negative result. There seems to be no alternative, but to cut Council costs. Perhaps we must cut staff and rely on outside contractors if and when money becomes available. The petition and deputation will stress the need for road funds, the threat of retrenchment to Council staff and the need for a higher priority to be given to the Booborowie-Spalding Road.

The possible control of water sports on Porter’s Lagoon was also raised and a meeting will be called to discuss this further. At present six fences have been covered by water in the lagoon areas. Weed control was another issue that received some attention.

Burra Primary School Upgrade & New High School have been included in the loan estimates for 1974-75. The new buildings will be in brick and the estimated cost of the project is $1.7 million.

North Eastern League

95, 31, 13 Aug. 1974, page 6

Obituary. Edward John McDonald died at Waikerie Hospital 7 August aged 46. He was the husband of Margaret and father of Russell, Rosemary (Mrs Seaford), Neville, Malcolm, Gil and Scott.

95, 31, 13 Aug. 1974, page 7

Birth. To Sue & Ken Fiebig on Saturday at Burra Hospital, a daughter, Hailey Ellen.

Birth. To Sue & Phil Ogden of Leighton, at Blackwood Community Hospital, 24 July, a son, Nicholas William.

Obituary. Mrs Topsfield, mother of Jack and Harold Topsfield, died in Adelaide last week aged 85.

[Born Ellen Williamson 17 December 1888 Adelaide; wife of George James Topsfield.]

Mothers & Babies’ Health Association street stall on Friday raised $97.80.

95, 32 (2), 20 Aug. 1974, page 1

Burra Burra DC

The rate has been increased by 0.2 cents in the dollar, but the extra $11,700 in revenue will not solve the Council’s financial problems and if Government aid does not increase then retrenchment of the workforce will have to be undertaken. The attitude of the Federal Government is particularly deplorable. Through traffic from the eastern states is considerable and the wet year has also increased the damage to surfaces. Burra has been changed from a zoning of Region 8 to Region 7, to its detriment and is seeking reinstatement. Council has decided to accept the boundary changes as recommended by the Local Government Royal Commission. There has been no real progress on the common effluent drainage system pending a decision whether the Government will provide the necessary subsidy.

Porter’s Lagoon

A Progress Committee was formed at a meeting at Farrell Flat Hall on 12 August. Mr Leo Robinson of Burra chaired the meeting and was later elected President of the new Porter’s Lagoon Progress Committee. The Vice-President is Gordon Webster. The aim is to promote water safety for swimmers, skiers and boat owners. Boat owners will be asked to pay a $2 membership fee to the committee which will control the foreshore.

Locusts and Grasshoppers were around in large numbers last April-May. Locust hatchings are expected in September and indications are that this could be a bad year. A state-wide control program is being organised.

Weather. A further 140 points or 35.4 mm of rain for august has made 1974 the wettest year on record since figures began in 1880. So far the total is 28.27 inches compared with the previous highest of 27.86 in 1889.

Football. The best footballers in each grade were selected at a cabaret at Spalding on Saturday night.

‘A’ Grade winner of the Mail Medal was Brenton Kuska of South Clare.

‘B’ Grade winner was Ken May of North Clare.

Senior Colts winner was Robert Stanway of South Clare.

96, 34, 3 Sep. 1974, page 1

The Grants Commission has recommended grants for local government for the first time since its creation in 1933. The Federal Government has approved the proposal. Burra Burra DC will get $17,000.

Burra Jubilee Benevolent Society held its AGM on 28 August. Rev. Morley was welcomed as a member. Rev. Clarrie Hore was elected Chairman with Mr Atkins as Treasurer and Mrs H. Jennison as Secretary. The society received a substantial amount from the estate of the late Mr John Barker.

A Special Steam Train hauled by an Rx locomotive will arrive in Burra at about 12.40 p.m. on Saturday and will depart about three hours later.

96, 35, 10 Sep. 1974, page 1

Rx 207 hauled a special steam train to Burra on Saturday. About 250 steam enthusiasts came for the journey.

Mr B. Gollin started a humble shop in Burra in 1850 and in 1974 Gollin Holdings Ltd is a business with an annual turnover exceeding $134 million. The Advertiser of 8 December 1874 reported the death of Mr B. Gollin at an early hour on Monday. [Bezaleel Gollin died 7 December 1874 Adelaide.] He had been suffering from a complaint requiring great care for some time, but it had not prevented his continued business dealings. On Sunday he felt unwell and about 11 a.m. he lay down. When he was seized with great pain a doctor was sent for and he died at 2 a.m. on Monday morning. He had been in business in a big way for many years in Burra and Adelaide. He was a successful broker and played a prominent part in the affairs of the Synagogue. He left a widow and a large family of sons and daughters. The Australian International Trading Company that started in Adelaide 125 years ago has commissioned the author Osmar White to write its history.

Gollin Holdings traces its origins to the arrival of Bezaliel Gollin in Adelaide in 1848. He is first recorded as a store owner in Burra in 1850 and when he died in 1874 was said to be a commercial broker in business in a large way. His sons George and Walter expanded the operations and in partnership with two cousins had branches in NZ, Sydney and Melbourne by 1900. They were largely involved in importing foodstuffs, textiles and raw materials and in a902 opened a London purchasing centre. When George Gollin died in 1946 he bequeathed $20,000 to establish the George Gollin Professorship of Economics at Adelaide University. The early days remain very sketchy and Mr White will visit Burra this week on Thursday.

96, 35, 10 Sep. 1974, page 2

96, 36, 17 Sep. 1974, page 1

Burra Burra Hospital Board

Cr R.B. Jennison has retired after 16 years service to the Board and Mr L.A. Beinke was appointed in his place. Chairman R.K. Pearce delivered the 97th Annual Report. This year had been very successful financially. Reserves had been built up sufficiently to enable the alterations to the hospital to be made without a public appeal. They cost $253,926 of which $169,225 was Government subsidy. Expenses have been controlled. Wages have risen $18,787 and a corresponding increase in fees of $50,716. It is likely wages in the coming year will be $150,000. The average bed cost rose $1.11 to $17.40, but we still showed a surplus of $26,617 and there is a credit balance in all accounts of $30,000 on deposit. The building program for now is complete. We have a new Maternity Wing including an Emergency Labour Ward, store rooms, Children’s Ward and kitchen and this brings the hospital to a high standard. The laundry and incinerator rooms have been modernised. Nearly all the rooms and passageways are now air conditioned and the other parts of the hospital and the Matron’s and Secretary’s residences have been renovated and painted. Gardens and Lawns have been re-sown. In the next year we will bituminise the car park and erect a car park for nursing staff. The Secretary’s residence will be renovated inside. This will only leave the painting of the old private rooms and wards to be done. A new X-ray plant has been purchased for $4,600. Daily occupancy is 24 and 33 babies were born. The Hospital Auxiliary continues its important support. The Burra 7 District Fund Raising Committee this year donated $1,000. Matron Phillips has been quietly efficient. Sister Good has been an able Tutor Sister. The Meals On Wheels continues to carry on with great success.

[Mr Pearce concludes with the usual widespread acknowledgements of support and gives special mention and thanks to retiring Board member Mr R.B. Jennison.

Adelaide Wool Sales. South Gum Creek topped local prices with 163 c. per kilo of 10 bales AAA M.

[Other local district prices are printed.]

Burra Burra DC, Thursday

$10,000 grant was received for work on the unsealed part of the Clare Road near Farrell Flat, which involves a realignment of the Clare water main.

$17,000 from the Commonwealth Government will go into general revenue.

The Golf Club has won a grant of $9,000 for work there.

The Swimming Pool planned renovations cannot proceed till after mid October, which may delay the start of the season a little.

Comment from the community is invited concerning the idea of moving the Institute Library to the new school and forming a Community Library.

The Burra-Spalding Road deputation has seen the Minister for Roads.

Trees will be planted near Booborowie Oval.

The Honda Car Club will be permitted a rally through the district in early November.

96, 36, 17 Sep. 1974, page 6

Advt. Burra Pictures, 21 September

George Hamilton & Sue Lyon in Evel Knievel

Robert Blake in Corky

96, 36, 17 Sep. 1974, page 7

Bezaliel Gollin – information from Ian Auhl.

Gollin seems to have arrived in Burra in 1848 and joined the firm of Marks, very early storekeepers in Burra. The firm became Marks & Gollin. Gollin appears as foreman of nearly every court case from 1848 to 1851, including a murder or two. The Register reports Queen Victoria’s 31st birthday when Gollin hoisted the City of London banner from his flagpole and soon flags were flying everywhere in honour of the sovereign. On the 1849 map Mr White noticed Marks and Gollin on a couple of blocks. Mr Marks lived between Kangaroo and Ware Streets where the Walkleys now live. Bezaliel Gollin lived on a block on Ayers Street where Les Broad & family now reside.

Marriage. In Adelaide last Saturday

Peter Riggs, son of Mr & Mrs J.W. Riggs formerly of Farrell Flat, married

Ursula Forster, daughter of Mr & Mrs Ernst Forster of Zurich, Switzerland.

Porter’s Lagoon. The committee will have toilets erected, clean the foreshore and mark the position of fences.

Mr Ray Jennison has been given life membership of Burra Hospital. He is only the fourth so honoured; the others being Mesdames Andrew Tennant and Donald Laidlaw and Mr Glen Finch.

96, 37, 24 Sep. 1974, page 1

Osmar White, the author who visited Burra recently researching the history of Bezaliel Gollin, considers that Burra has by far the best collection of mid-Victorian buildings in the whole of Australia. He cannot understand why they are not being exploited. There should, he says, be hundreds of thousands of tourists annually. A tumbledown stone cottage could produce more wealth for the community than any modern shop or service station that could be erected on its site. People may consider that history is bunt – ‘but these days it’s gilt edged bunt and it brings the money into communities with the common sense to cash in on an historical heritage.’

[Check this use of ‘bunt’. If it is noted correctly, it is probably an incorrect reference to Henry Ford’s famous comment ‘History is more or less bunk.’ This was said in an interview with Charles N. Wheeler and reported in the Chicago Tribune 25 May 1916.]

Weather. The rainfall for the year has now exceeded 30 inches, having reached 762.5 mm at 9 a.m. yesterday or 30 inches.

96, 37, 24 Sep. 1974, pages 1 & 5

The Eastern Fire Fighting Organisation held its annual meeting at Koomooloo Station last Wednesday. With the wettest year on record and the country at its best in living memory, the potential for fire is huge. Forests of spear grass are already drying off. Unless summer rains come it will be a tinderbox.

Luncheon was served in the shearers’ quarters and the meeting was held in the woolshed. John McBride was Chairman & Supervisor of the Organisation. The main visitor was the Director General of the EFS Mr Fred Kerr. The Chairman’s report stressed the tremendous growth of this exceptional season and its potential to make the east the most fire prone district in the state. He suggested the need again for the area to be declared a total fire ban area. He outlined the negotiations which resulted in their having four radio transmitting licences for Single Side Band Receivers on a call sign VL5EM, but at present, while awaiting delivery; they were using the radio on loan from the Traeger Company. He also reported on his visits to other allied organisations at Mannahill and Gladstone. The problem of plague locust hatchings was also referred to. Mr McBride declined to continue in office and Mr Don Lord was elected in his place. Mr Kerr then gave his address. Mr Brian Menadue, a police officer, also spoke and said the pilots who flew to Moomba six days a week would be actively looking for fires.

96, 37, 24 Sep. 1974, page 2

Obituary. Monsignor Patrick Valentine Hughes died on 18 September. After his retirement he lived at Port Pirie for a year with the Bishop, before moving to ‘Villa Beovich’ at Myrtle Bank, a new home for retired priests conducted by the Little Sisters of the Poor. The funeral was at Burra on Friday at 11 a.m. when Bishop Gallagher of Port Pirie was the Principal Celebrant at the Requiem Mass, assisted by Father Kevin Matthews of Burra, Mons. Thomas Horgan, Vicar General of the Archdiocese of Adelaide and twenty-eight priests. Place of honour was given to Archbishop Beovich of Adelaide, who studied in Rome with Monsignor Hughes. Friends came from Renmark and Barmera where he had been Parish Priest as well as from elsewhere in SA. He was a gentle and frugal man with a great zeal for his faith and a love for children. He was born in 1891 and educated at St Augustine’s Geelong, Victoria, Mt Melleray Seminary, Ireland and at the Propaganda Fide College in Rome. After ordination in Rome by Cardinal Pompili in 1926 he went to SA and the then Diocese of Port Augusta. He served as assistant priest in Peterborough, Port Augusta and Port Pirie and was locum tenens at Carrieton before becoming Parish Priest at Renmark and later at Burra, where he was a familiar and respected figure until his retirement several years ago.

96, 37, 24 Sep. 1974, page 5

96, 37, 24 Sep. 1974, page 7

Birth. To Sue & Dale Adams of Princess Royal Station at Burra Hospital last Wednesday, a daughter, Joanne Fay.

Birth. To Julie & Ted Irlam of Burra North on 20 August, a daughter, Janine Elizabeth.

Birth. To Vyvyan & Rhys Horword yesterday in Adelaide, a daughter. A grandchild for Mr & Mrs L.H. Packer of Burra.

Miss Gertrude Williams will be 90 on 30 September. She was born in Burra, the second daughter of Mr & Mrs C.C. Williams. Her mother, then Miss Watson, came to SA in 1876, employed on the voyage as a nurse. Thirteen babies were born en route. She became the Matron of the Burra Hospital during an epidemic of typhoid fever, which saw many patients there in very primitive conditions. Some patients were accommodated in the old bar of the Burra Hotel and others on the floor. Nurse Watson was dismayed to find many patients using tin pannikins to drink from and with her first pay bought them china cups.

Marriage. 13 September

Pauline Miller, daughter of Mr & Mrs Wes. Miller of Hallett married Alaistair Mundy Castle from Rhodesia.

96, 37, 24 Sep. 1974, page 8

‘A’ Grade Burra Gold defeated Mt Bryan 11 to 10.

95, 38 (2), 1 Oct. 1974, page 4

Burra Methodist Church celebrates the 60th anniversary of the present building. A special 11 a.m. service will be held the weekend of the Copper Festival. Guest Preacher will be the incoming President of the Conference, Rev. F.E. Tregilgas, who was a minister in Burra from 1949-51.

95, 38 (2), 1 Oct. 1974, page 6

95, 38 (2), 1 Oct. 1974, page 7

Marriage. Farrell Flat Catholic Church next Saturday

Meredith Short will marry Keith Klingberg.

Birth. To Jean & Des Button of Booborowie at QVMH last week, a daughter.

96, 39, 8 Oct. 1974, page 1 [Note the change in volume number yet again!]

Weather. Good rain has again fallen across the district and Burra’s total is now close to 32 inches. 30.8 mm was added last week to reach 806.3 mm or 31.72 inches.

The 2nd Burra Copper Festival is approaching and the town is preparing for a big influx of visitors. The five hotels have been granted licences to operate from 11 a.m. to 7 p.m. on Sunday for normal bar service as well as for meals. Show entries are strong.

96, 39, 8 Oct. 1974, page 5

The Burra to Adelaide Cycling Classic was held on 28 September. Kevin Phillips of Rostrevor was the winner of the event, which was first run in 1907. Conditions for the race were bitterly cold and wet, but with a strong tail wind for the whole 162 km. [This can’t be literally true, since the race went north to Mt Bryan and then returned to Burra.] Fastest was Victorian scratch man Hilton Clark, in a record 3 hours 29 minutes 15 seconds.

Obituary. Mr Parker died recently at Katamatite, Victoria. He was the father of Lesley, Mrs Andrew Phillips, Matron of the Burra Hospital.

Dave Ledo and his wife are welcomed to Burra. Dave is a butcher with the Modern Meat Store.

96, 40, 16 Oct. 1974, MISSING

96, 40, 16 Oct. 1974, Supplement [A single double-sided sheet slightly smaller than the paper.]

Pictures from the 2nd Burra Copper Festival

Mr Dunstan welcomed at the CWA Rooms.

Miss Show Girl 1974, Miss Sharon Betty

Paul Howell (21⁄2) at the show.

96, 41, 22 Oct. 1974, page 1

Burra Burra DC, 7 October

There has been further damage to local roads due to continuing wet weather.

Burra Swimming Pool is undergoing maintenance for its re-opening; a fibreglass lining will be applied.

R.B. Jennison writes as President of the Burra Copper festival Committee to thank all those who made it a huge success.

96, 41, 22 Oct. 1974, pages 1 & 3

Burra Bowling Club season was opened on Saturday. 66 bowlers enjoyed the opening day’s games. The opening was performed by Mr C. Pearson, the MNBA President. Associates begin their season on Wednesday.

96, 41, 22 Oct. 1974, page 2

Advt. Burra Pictures, 26 October

Peter O’Toole & Sophia Loren in Man of La Mancha

Burt Lancaster & Susan Clark in Valdez is Coming

Back to Burra School Reunion. The names of those attending are printed.

Tennis. ‘A’ Grade: Hallett 11-85 defeated Booborowie 9-80.

96, 41, 22 Oct. 1974, page 3

Cricket. South Booborowie 6 for 159 declared & 0 for 35 declared defeated Leighton 101 & 4 for 64.

96, 41, 22 Oct. 1974, pages 4 & 5

Burra Show: the complete Prize List for 1974 Burra Show is printed.

96, 41, 22 Oct. 1974, page 7

Birth. To Mary & John Tiver of ‘Flagstaff’ on 14 October at Burra Hospital, a son, Benjamin John.

Birth. To Lew & Christine Rayner (nee McBride) of Hallett at Memorial Hospital last Wednesday, a daughter.

Marriage. Kent Town Methodist Church last Saturday

Heather Gillett, daughter of Mr & Mrs R.J. Gillett of Elliston, married

Norman Sommerville, son of Mrs S. Sommerville of Spalding.

Obituary. Charles Rodney Woollacott died last Thursday in Melbourne. He was born in Burra and spent his youth here before taking an MA degree at University and having a respected and successful career as a teacher and principal. He spent most of his life in Victoria. His brother Stan still lives in Burra. He is survived by a son and daughter in Melbourne. [Born 19 September 1895 Redruth.]

The 2nd Copper Festival seems likely to have produced a profit in excess of $3,000.

96, 42, 29 Oct. 1974, page 1

Plague Locusts are hatching near Andrews. Some hatchings have been found around Burra. It takes four to six weeks for them to mature to adult fliers.

Booborowie Methodist Sunday School held its Anniversary Services at the Memorial Hall on Sunday. Sixty scholars formed the choir.

Mt Bryan Methodist Sunday School held its Anniversary Services last Sunday. The preacher was Mr Graham Hancock of Saddleworth.

Booborowie Bowling Club. About 200 visitors attended the opening of the new Bowling Club at Booborowie on Saturday in ideal weather. The greens were opened and the first official jack was rolled by Mr Claude Allen MP, Member for Frome. The first bowl was sent down by Fred Dinham.

Burra Scouts had a trip to Blanchetown at the weekend of 19-20 October. Each had a flight in a Sail Plane at the Armstrong Air Field. A successful meeting of Cubs was held at the Burra Show Hall on 18 October when about 24 boys, mostly first-timers, attended.

The Veteran & Vintage Motor Cycle Club of SA will visit Burra 9 November. [Likely vehicles coming are listed.]

96, 43, 5 Nov. 1974, page 3

Obituary. A Notice to Creditors reveals the death of Christopher John Mitford Collins late of ‘Collinsville’ via Hallett, who had died 21 May 1973. [Not traced in SA Births or Marriages.]

96, 43, 5 Nov. 1974, page 4

Burra Golf Club held its AGM 24 October and elected: President, A. Baulderstone; Senior Vice-President, D. Villis; Captain, A. Gebhardt; Vice-Captain, S. Longford; Treasurer, P. Boucher and Secretary, H. Burnett.

Retiring President, Don Kempster, reported on a year where the main concerns had been the result of high rainfall causing the need for more mowing and soft ground preventing the use of the tractor. Improvements were made to numbers 1, 2 & 11 holes. Later in the season the combined 9th and 11th elevated tee-off was formed. The Group Open Day had to be transferred to Kanimbla because of the constant flooding of the ground.

[The usual thanks and congratulations are included.]

96, 43, 5 Nov. 1974, page 5

Aberdeen Football & Netball Auxiliaries had a very successful year both socially and financially. The Football Auxiliary made a donation to the club of $878 at the start of the football season and since then $1,786 has been raised. 100 new chairs were purchased for the clubroom at $800. Miss Clarice Reed was given life membership of the Football Club in recognition of eleven years as Treasurer of the Auxiliary.

96, 43, 5 Nov. 1974, page 6

Advt. Burra Pictures: No Pictures 9 November.

96, 43, 5 Nov. 1974, page 7

Bowls

1st Division Burra 70 defeated Hallett 69

2nd Division Burra Gold 74 defeated Clare Blue 61

Clare Red 86 defeated Burra Green 74

3rd Division Clare Green 77 defeated Burra 55

St Joseph’s Church

Bishop Gallagher will consecrate the church at its Centenary Celebrations on Friday evening.

Churches are not consecrated till paid for and although St Joseph’s was paid off years ago, the fact that it was not consecrated had been overlooked. The church has a new altar, lectern, seating and carpeting. On Sunday there will be an open air Mass on Aberdeen Oval followed by a Parish Picnic. A booklet outlining the history of the church will be available at the weekend.

Burra Anglicans celebrate the Patronal Festival of St Andrews at Mt Bryan with a Parish Eucharist at 10.30 a.m.

Marriage. Burra Methodist Church, Saturday

Bev. Collins, only daughter of Mr & Mrs Maurice Collins of Booborowie and Mac Goode.

Marriage. Clare Methodist Church, Saturday

Lynette Hausler, daughter of Mrs Margaret Hausler of Willalo and Colin James Shaw.

Elaine, Mrs Robin Eberhard, is finishing work at the ANZ Bank in Burra on Thursday and Cheryl Heitbrink is taking her place.

Burra Swimming Pool renovations are suffering delays and it will not be opened before the first week in December at the earliest.

Obituary. Chris Ryan of Goodwood and formerly of Burra died 31 October after a long illness aged 18.

Obituary. Dr Kenneth Green died recently in Brisbane. His widow was formerly Mavis Riggs of Burra. There are two children; Bill and Annabel.

96, 44, 12 Nov. 1974, page 1

Adelaide Wool Sales. Local district prices are printed.

96, 44, 12 Nov. 1974, pages 1 & 8

St Joseph’s Catholic Church Centenary

Bishop Brian Gallagher of Port Pirie consecrated St Joseph’s Burra exactly 100 years from the day it was officially blessed and opened on 8 November. The celebrations continued over the weekend.

On Friday the church was consecrated.

On Saturday there was a special Mass of thanksgiving and a Parish Picnic at Aberdeen Oval.

Seventeen priests from the Diocese of Port Pirie and the Archdiocese of Adelaide attended the consecration ceremony. One was Monsignor W.H. Nesdale who was parish priest of Burra 52 years ago and is still active as Parish Priest of Georgetown. Monsignor T. Toal of Jamestown is a brother to Dr M.F. Toal, who was a former Burra priest. Fr Laurie Quinn came from Loxton. Fr M. Kineavy, the priest previous to Fr Kevin Matthews, was also present [and the other visiting priests are listed.]

Two aspects of the consecration of interest were the taking possession of the church and the sealing of relics into the altar. In taking possession the Bishop wrote the Greek and Latin alphabets in sand spread in the centre of the church. The idea is that Christ’s possession of the church can be so symbolised, as he is the beginning and end of all things, the alpha and omega or in the Latin alphabet the A and Z. The relics of saints are enclosed in every consecrated altar. The new altar was consecrated and then Mass was celebrated. The Altar, Lectern, President’s Seat and Tabernacle Stand have all recently been constructed from local stones, copper ore, pieces of malachite and azurite, to give a typical local flavour. The design is the work of Fr Kevin Matthews and was done by David Loffler with Fr Matthews as labourer. Ross Drew and Mike Warde laid the new carpet over the extended sanctuary and the candlesticks on the walls were made and donated by Darius Ross of Ross Lighting in Adelaide. Ross and Dianne Drew presented a cushion for the seat to match the new carpet. After the consecration there was a reception in the Town Hall. Mr Jim Quinn, as Master of Ceremonies, gave a brief summary of the early history of the parish. He pointed out the connections with the Austrian Jesuits who founded Sevenhill and the early foundation of a church-school in Commercial Street in 1857. The ruins can be seen on the corner of Kangaroo Street. He mentioned the great work of the Sisters of St Joseph and others over so many years. Bishop Gallagher responded and pointed out that owing to the illness of one of the priests Fr Matthew would now also have responsibility for the Parish of Spalding-Booborowie as well as Burra.

Fr John Morley of St Mary’s [Anglican] Parish spoke on behalf of local clergy.

On Saturday evening St Joseph’s was filled again for a Mass of Thanksgiving.

On Sunday a Parish Picnic was held at Aberdeen Oval and an altar had been erected there for an open air Mass, celebrated by Fr Matthews. Special mention was made of Brother Shutz [sic] SDB, an old identity of Burra and Sister Helen, who had taught at St Joseph’s School for many years. John Fahey of Hallett, with the help of others, conducted a program of sports and competitions for children and parents.

96, 44, 12 Nov. 1974, page 6

Advt. Burra Pictures; no pictures on 16 November.

96, 44, 12 Nov. 1974, page 7

The Melbourne Cup Luncheon last Tuesday was a great financial success. Over $400 was taken at the door and about the same amount from the stall and raffle. The profit is expected to be a tidy sum.

Hallett Ratepayers have met to consider Council amalgamation and have asked the Hallett Council to have further discussions with Spalding DC on their possible amalgamation.

Obituary. Mrs Clem Christopher died last week as the result of a road accident. Her husband Rev. Christopher was at Redruth Methodist Church twenty years ago [1951-55]. They were living at Murray Bridge when she died.

96, 44, 12 Nov. 1974, page 8

Obituary. One of Spalding’s oldest residents Mrs Elizabeth Ann McAvaney died in Clare Hospital on 23 September aged 82. She was a daughter of the late Mr & Mrs Robert Lister and was born in Redhill in 1892 and began her schooling at the Collinsville School. She married Thomas Vincent McAvaney at St Mary’s Cathedral Port Pirie in 1913. They lived at Broken Hill for two years before moving to Spalding. She was a zealous worker for her church and a member of the Red Cross, CWA and Senior Citizens Club. She is survived by two sons; Reg. (Adelaide) and Geoff. (Spalding). There are 8 grandchildren and 2 great-grandchildren.

[Born Elizabeth Ann Lister 12 October 1891 Collinsfield. Since Collinsfield was located 8 km south of Redhill, the reference above to Collinsville is likely a mistake for Collinsfield.]

96, 45, 19 Nov. 1974, page 1

Burra Burra DC

$100,000 in outstanding rates is overdue. Of the district’s 1,600 ratepayers only 400 have paid their rates and of those the majority are from the town of Burra. Carrying the burden of unpaid rates for eight months of the year means that much work does not get done. Main roads get work from Government Grants. Local roads must wait for rate payment.

A total ban on the lighting of fires has been invoked for the Hundreds of Kingston, Ayers, Hanson and Kooringa from 8 December to 28 February.

The relining of the swimming pool is being delayed and the pool is likely to be closed until mid-December on present indications.

Burra Golf Club has approached Council to get a loan on their behalf to be used to build a new clubhouse.

The Porter’s Lagoon Progress Association has been appointed by Council as the Management Organisation for the Reserve.

Booborowie-Burra Road. The Minister of Transport has responded to the deputation to him on this road and has said that funding for further work on it would not be available until 1977-78 at the earliest. Grant assistance will be available for maintenance work.

Vern Riggs has celebrated his 80th birthday.

96, 45, 19 Nov. 1974, pages 1 & 2

Booborowie Methodist Strawberry Fete drew some 200 people and raised $831.

96, 45, 19 Nov. 1974, page 2

Bowls

1st Division Clare 81 defeated Burra 60

2nd Division Burra Gold 79 defeated Hallett 64

Burra Green 73 defeated Saddleworth 53

3rd Division Watervale 59 defeated Burra 53

Burra Community School

A questionnaire will be circulated regarding the new form of Community School proposed for Burra. It is aimed at providing a range of facilities to be used both by students and the community during and after school hours. It will be the first Country Community School in SA.

96, 45, 19 Nov. 1974, page 7

Birth. To Jill & Ron Piggott of Farrell Flat at Riverton Hospital last week, a son, William Lindo.

Birth. To Elizabeth & Roger Bennett at Calvary Hospital on Friday, a daughter, Kate Louise. A grandchild for Mr & Mrs Laurie Anderson of Caroona, Burra.

Marriage. At St Peter’s College Chapel on Saturday

Sherilyn Bowers of Whyte Yarcowie and Peter Mattey of Terowie.

Mr Ernest Archibald Small of Spalding and formerly of Booborowie was 90 on Sunday.

The Melbourne Cup Luncheon has resulted in a donation of $300 to the RFDS and $300 to Barker Homes.

Pony Club. A meeting will be held in the Burra Show Hall on Friday evening with a view to forming a Pony Club.

Obituary. Philip Bampton aged 73 was buried at Holy Cross Church, Goodwood, on 4 November. Mr Bampton and his wife and family – Basil, Isabelle (Mrs Jim Hasse), Anne and Derek – came to Burra from India in the early 1950s. They worked for St Joseph’s Church and Anne and Derek attended the Convent School. His brother, Dr Bampton and his wife and family followed them, but Dr Bampton died soon after arriving. The first of Mrs Bampton’s relatives to come to Burra in the late 1940s were the gentle Mr & Mrs Jim Elder (hairdressers at Burra and Burra North) and their parents, Mr & Mrs McKenna Senior and Eric, who were in business here before moving to their successful antique business on Unley Road. (Jim Elder Jnr is also an antique dealer in North Adelaide.) All these people will be remembered for their refinement and love of life. The change of life style from India to Burra could not have been an easy one, but Philip Bampton was sad when he left Burra to live in Elizabeth North. He cycled around Burra & Burra North daily for many years as the postal delivery man.

96, 46, 26 Nov. 1974, page 1

Burra Apex Club will induct six new members on Thursday 28 November. John Madigan, Zone Representative of the Association of Apex Clubs will come to Burra for the occasion and so will Roger Dixon of the Barossa Valley Apex Club. The six new members will be Carey Noack, Geoff Schwier, Mike & Andrew Scholz, Jeff Thomas and Andrew Anderson. Burra President Trevor Blatchford said Burra now had 22 members.

The Australia-wide project for 1973-74 had been Foundation 41; a project organised by Dr William McBride for research into birth deformities. Burra Apex had raised $300 for this. The 1974-75 project focuses on Multiple Sclerosis. Locally Apex had assisted the Copper festival with the production of ‘Copper Crunch’ Burra’s answer to ‘Mad’ Magazine. Members had also manned the Information Booth. They also staged a Gymkhana on 15 September. Apex will erect new tourist signs when they arrive. A gas barbecue for visitors is a project being considered. Burning excess grass within the town is another project. A restored hay wagon for the kindergarten is also being installed – donated by Ron Pearse of Koonoona. Apex runs the films at the Town Hall. Despite all these activities some people are not satisfied.

[A comment near the start of the article suggests there was some adverse criticism of Apex around the town at this time.]

Burra CWA held its 49th birthday and International Day last Thursday. The country featured this year was Australia and Mrs L. Bence gave her insights as one who came to Australia from Britain. Mrs E. Baulderstone made the cake, which was iced by Mrs M. Cox.

Tennis. Inter-Association Match

The Pressick Sisters visited at the weekend. They stayed at the Kooringa Hotel, near their old home, where Mrs Grace Webster now lived. They are: Pearl Brown, Cousie [Constance] Torr, Dawn Muhlhan, Hazel Cowell and Winifred Armsden.

Obituary. Mrs Arthur Przibilla, nee Winifred Dew, died 16 November. She was born at Burra 80 years ago and was a staunch worker for the Methodist Church before she left here. She is survived by a husband and a daughter; Joyce, Mrs Clements of Bletchley. [Born 7 December 1893 at Springbank, Burra.]

The Bon Accord Crossing now has new flashing lights. About 60 trains pass through Burra each week.

Late shopping will operate in Burra on Tuesday 24 December, along with the usual merry-go-round and arrival of Father Christmas.

96, 48, 10 Dec. 1974, page 1

Community Teaching Comes to Burra. Recently introduced electives have introduced the idea of community teaching on a small scale with parents coming into the school to teach and children going into the community (garages) to learn. Mr Slater introduced the study of the local history of Burra and the children outlined visits and visitors for a five week period. The children made the contacts and arranged tentative bookings by phone and followed up with a confirmation in writing. Visits were followed up with verbal and later written tasks.

Program:

Animals, old people and food. A talk at the school by Mr W. Broad.

Visit to ETSA. Mr Martin gave a talk assisted by Mr C. Broad.

Visit to Cemetery. Talk by Mr T. Perry.

Visit to Dugouts. Mr [S] Woollacott gave a talk.

Visit to Brewery Cellars. Mr Woollacott showed the group through.

Visit to Paxton Square. Talk by Mrs Jennison Sen.

Visit to the Burra Hospital. Talk by Mr Packer.

Visit to St Mary’s, St Joseph’s and the Methodist Church. Talks by Rev. Morley, Fr. Matthews & Rev. Hore.

Visit to Mongolata. Talk by Mr John Carpenter and a walk through an old mine tunnel.

Visit to Market Square Museum. Talk from Mr Woollacott.

Visit to a second hand shop organised by Mrs O’Connor.

Mrs Perry explained the history of water and transport.

Mrs Perry explained the history of the school.

Visit to the Mine and the Refiner; Mr L. Quinn explained the workings and some of the Mine’s history.

Visit to the Courthouse and old Police Station. Sergeant Haynes answered questions.

Visit to the Phosphate Mines.

Visit to Aboriginal Rock Carvings. (Yet to come.)

Mr G. O’Connor will explain the history of labour in Burra.

Mr w. Brown will discuss the Town Hall, the Council and population.

The Women’s Fellowship gave a party for over 100 Senior Citizens at the Redruth Hall on Thursday in the form of a concert, afternoon tea and a visit from Father Christmas.

96, 48, 10 Dec. 1974, page 2

Advt. Announcing the arrival of the Thoroughbred Stallion ‘Comic’ to Mt Bryan. Fee $40. R. & H. Radford, Mt Bryan, Phone Mt Bryan 17.

96, 48, 10 Dec. 1974, page 3

Mid North Field & Game Association reports a shoot held on Sunday in which the most successful shooters were P. Shannon and M. Mickel. The next shoot will be 12 January 1975. The Committee thanks the 15 people who helped when the shooting grounds were burned: this will enable shooting to continue through summer.

96, 48, 10 Dec. 1974, page 7

Marriage. St Peter’s & St Paul’s Church, Gawler

Jenny Morton of Burra High School and Brendan Howard of Gawler.

Rosemary Brak began working in the office at Jennison’s Tyre Service yesterday.

Marriage. Salisbury Methodist Church on Saturday

Anthony Arrowsmith, son of Mr & Mrs Stan Arrowsmith of Burra and Patricia Drewett.

Birth. To Sue & Andrew Gebhardt of ‘Mackerode’ Mt Bryan at Calvary Hospital 2 December, a daughter.

Bob Schuyler of Tambellup WA has been visiting Burra. He is a former resident and attended the RSL dinner on Saturday night.

Bob Crewes was also in town on Saturday night for the RSL dinner.

The RSL Dinner on Saturday night drew 50 members and visitors. Wilf Nankivell was congratulated along with his co-officers for keeping the sub-branch alive. Rev. Morley was present and proposed ‘Fallen Comrades’. Branch President Bob Steele invited Brian Riggs to speak on his recent visit to ‘Watch Hill’ in Devon where a special Memorial Service was held on 28 September. Arthur Wright proposed ‘Visitors and Kindred Associations and Howard Griffen toasted the ladies who provided the spread.

Marriage. Malvern Methodist Church next Saturday

Vivien Williams of Hallett will marry Alan Wiese.

Birth. To Andrea & Denis Miller of Gum Creek on Thursday at QVMH, a daughter, Victoria Margarite.

96, 49, 17 Dec. 1974, page 1 Check date.

Burra Trading Hours have been extended to 9 p.m. on 24 December when the usual Christmas activities will occur in Market Square. Late night shopping in Booborowie will be on Friday 20 December. Burra Traders have organised a free merry-go-round near the Burra Hotel for Tuesday afternoon and evening.

There will be a free picture show in the Town Hall, of cartoons etc. timed to finish about 8 p.m.

Father Christmas arrives at 8.30 p.m.

Rainfall. The official rainfall to date is 879.1 mm or 34.49 inches.

Carols on Sunday. The swimming pool surrounds are not available this year so the School Oval will be used and battery operated torches will provide light, as there is a total fire ban in the district.

Burra Burra DC

Rate payments of an additional $33,000 to the $20,000 already received have been a welcome response to the Council’s concerns expressed recently, but $70,000 is still outstanding. Samin has paid $729.90 in royalties under the Old Mining Act. This covers ore used in the pilot operation in 1971 and to the end of June 1972.

There is now a new Act, but monies due under that have not yet appeared.

It is anticipated that Power Industrial Cleaning Services will have cleaned the pool surface for the application of fibreglass by tomorrow, but Christmas and New Year Holidays mean no further work will be done till 6 January when men from Combo Industries will begin applying fibreglass. They hope to finish on 10 January and water can then be added to the pool. Other renovation work will also be done between now and then. Over 30 panes of glass have been broken in the changing room by vandals. Filtering of the water will take about a week, so the pool should open somewhere about 17 January. Tenders have been called for the purchase of the Council’s 1967 Bedford tip truck.

Site inspections have been made for a new netball court at the War Memorial Oval. It is hoped to have it ready for the 1975 season.

96, 49, 17 Dec. 1974, page 2

Marriage. St Joseph’s Burra on Saturday

Judy Beinke & Don Sommerville.

Bert Cornelius will be 80 on 29 December.

Burra High School

Miss Pat Payne will be the new principal for 1975.

She is the first woman principal of a fully co-ed High School in SA.

Characteristics of the 1974 paper.

There was not a very comprehensive news coverage of Burra. Sports get a reasonable coverage and reports from many societies’ AGMs are frequent, but anything actually written by the paper itself is sparse and often inadequate. The reports on the two floods in Burra for the year are typical of this, being quite brief and lacking in detail. Even the ‘Out & About’ column is less comprehensive than in earlier years. There are many articles that act as ‘fillers’ and many items of general interest (particularly to primary producers), but also fillers giving hints to the handyman (on painting for instance).

After page 1 the layout of the paper varied from week to week, but the following outline is quite typical.

Page 1 Typically full of news, but frequently little of it relating to Burra.

Page 2 Large advertisements and sports.

Page 3 Large advertisements – typically more than half page – plus public notices and sports.

Page 4 Large advertisements and a mixture of sports, news and articles of general interest.

Page 5 Advertisements with some news and general interest items.

Page 6 Large advertisements, the cash column, public notices and entertainment.

Page 7 The ‘Out & About’ column with large advertisements and a small amount of sports or other items of general interest.

Page 8 The 50 Years Ago column and items of general interest.

97, 1, 21 Jan. 1975, page 1

97, 1, 21 Jan. 1975, page 1

Burra Swimming Pool

The pool has now been fibre-glassed, renovated and filled. It will open on Tuesday or earlier depending on the cleaning of the water. The wading pool has also been fibre-glassed and the dressing rooms renovated, following an Australian Government grant towards costs. Season tickets cost $12 for a family, $X single and $3 child. $250 has been transferred from the canteen fund to the Council.

Fire. A fire at the end of December burnt 350 acres at Burra North.

[A thank you notice on page 3 reveals that it entered the properties of Stan Edith & Mary Woollacott, Brian Riggs, and Frank, Dorrie and Robert Reed at Abberton Park.]

Burra Golf Club plans a new Club House and intends to borrow $9,000 from the Savings Bank of SA. The site has been levelled. A meeting of ratepayers to endorse the choice of site has been called for 10 February. The total cost is estimated at $25,000and part payment of $9,000 will be made by the Minister of Local Government under Parks & Reserves grants.

Burra Pictures. Pictures at the Town Hall are likely to close at the end of the year as there is only one licensed operator, Mr Wally Nankivell, and another will then be required to allow the show to carry on.

[Presumably John Harold Torr born 4 June 1898 Farrell Flat.]

[Born 5 May 1901 Adelaide: died 24 December 1974.]

[Hedley Gilbert Pearce born 17 February 1902: died 4 January 1975.]

Obituary. Paddy Williams, late of Burra.

Obituary. Lewis Gare late of ‘Three Trees’ Burra. [Lewis Wesley Pinch Gare born 18 January 1900 Aberdeen. A legal notice in 97, 37, 15 Oct. 1975, page 3 gives the date of his death as 16 January 1975.]

Booborowie Red Cross through the canvassing of Mrs Barbara Harris sent $420-42 and clothing to Darwin Relief.

The New Year’s Teenagers’ Dance at Hanson donated $20 to Darwin Relief.

Burra had a ‘White Christmas’ due to a huge flood of millions of ‘Father Christmas’ seeds from the white thistle.

Ian Lovell and family left Burra last week for Mt Howick Station in WA, where Ian will be senior overseer for 30,000 sheep and 6,500 cattle.

Mr Hank Heitbrink left the ANZ Bank as manager last week and he and his wife will live at Hanson for a while. His replacement as manager is Laurie Higgins, late of Mt Barker.

Kooringa Masonic Lodge will hold a cabaret in the Town Hall on 21 February in aid of the second group of Barker Homes.

Robert (Moo) Cowie (22) of Broken Hill was the late victim of a motor cycle accident to the west of Burra this month.

The National Trust AGM will be held on 10 February in the CWA Rooms at 8 p.m. when Mr Warren Bonython will speak and show pictures of his walk across the Simpson Desert.

Glaucoma Screenings at Burra will be offered free of charge at the Burra Town Hall on 8 February.

The Darwin Appeal. The Cockington and Tiver children raised $9.28 towards the appeal at a concert at the Tiver home. The Council’s Darwin Appeal now stands at $1,233.28.

Mokota Cricket, Saturday 18 January

Koonaburra 8 for 334 defeated Leighton 230.

97, 3, 4 Feb. 1975, page 1

Fire. A large area of grazing and scrub country was burnt in the Hallett-Whyte-Yarcowie area at the weekend. Hundreds of men fought the blaze, which at one time threatened the township of Whyte-Yarcowie. Sight-seers hindered water tankers and other vehicles. The police stopped as many sight-seers as possible, but others got through. So far no stock losses have been reported.

New School Speed Zones. From 1 February the speed at school crossings has been reduced from 30 km to 25 km per hour.

BHS Leaving Exam Results

12 students gained certificates with at least four subjects with grades of 4 or better.

97, 3, 4 Feb. 1975, pages 1 & 4

Ian Auhl continues the story of The Girls of Hampton Court.

Marriage. Farrell Flat Catholic Church on Saturday

Bernadette Short, daughter of Mr & Mrs J.W. Short of Farrell Flat and Ian Kirchner of Narridy.

Dennis Nettleton is welcomed as the new manager of the Savings Bank of SA. He was here as a teller some years ago. He has come from Cowell with his wife Lorraine and two sons.

Mr & Mrs Buckton left today. Bob will manage the Savings Bank at Whyalla Norrie.

97, 3, 4 Feb. 1975, page 8

Obituary. Mr John Harold Torr aged 76, formerly of Farrell Flat, died 22 December 1974 in Adelaide. In the district he farmed ‘Torlnga’; land first taken up by his grandfather. He was born in Farrell Flat and spent most of his life there. He was the son of Sydney and Ann Torr and was educated at Mintaro School. Later the family moved to Gawler and Harold then attended Prince Alfred College. In 1922 he married Clarice Denton of Farrell Flat. The eldest of their five children, Glen, lost his life on Pathfinder operations with the RAAF in WWII. Harold was interested in sports and served on many community committees. He retired to Glenelg six years ago and spent much of his time there fishing. He is survived by his wife and daughter Enid, Mrs Blieschke (Leighton); Brian Adelaide; Peter (Sydney) and Ern (Farrell Flat). [Born at Farrell’s Flat 4 June 1898.]

97, 4, 11 Feb. 1975, page 1

Glaucoma Screening. 560 people were tested on Saturday and eleven suspects will need further treatment and 24 people were referred further for hypertension.

Lent. The Burra Anglican, Catholic and Methodist Churches plan to get together during Lent in an ecumenical venture with services in rotation at the three churches on Wednesday evenings in Lent.

[New enrolments are listed.]

Colin Baker, BA, Dip. Ed.

Enrolment is 172 compared with 190 in 1974.

Other District School Enrolments:

Leighton School enrolment is 24

Farrell Flat enrolment is 21

Booborowie enrolment is 75

Notice. Porter’s Lagoon Progress Association

Power boat owners are advised that on SUNDAY 23 February the Gilbert Valley Lions Club have been given control over Porter’s Lagoon Reserve. All owners of power boats are requested not to use the Lagoon before 6 p.m. on that day. J. Bowden, Hon. Sec.

97, 4, 11 Feb. 1975, page 7

Obituary. Mrs Henson, sister to Colin Campbell, was buried at Burra last week. She had lived at Port Noarlunga.

Obituary. Mr Aub. Young, father of Estelle Nicholls and Margaret Lloyd, both of Burra, died in Adelaide on Saturday. [Aubrey Edwin Thomas Young born 3 April 1899 Long Plain: died 8 February 1975.]

Burra Cubs meetings begin at 7.30 p.m. in the Show Hall on Friday.

Warren Bonython enthralled an excellent attendance at the local National Trust branch AGM last night, when he spoke on his walk across the Simpson Desert.

97, 5, 18 Feb. 1975, page 1

Burra Burra DC

The Council is concerned with the untidy appearance of the town caused by blocks littered with weeds and rubbish and especially with derelict car bodies. Council is to make an effort in the next twelve months to eliminate unsightly areas of weeds and rubbish.

Children riding bikes on footpaths are seen as posing a hazard for pedestrians.

Prosecutions for straying sheep are expected soon.

The swimming pool renovation has now been successfully completed and it has since been well patronised.

The ratepayers’ meeting on 10 February drew a representative gathering. A resolution was passed approving the lease of a site for the planned new club house. The procedure of the club borrowing money through the Council can now go ahead.

Over twelve months ago the Council received a loan of $7,000 for the purpose of constructing a dam across the Burra Creek. The questions of possible flooding and of pollution have been taken into account by the E & WS Department and work has now been started on creating a shallow lake stretching from the Caravan Park to just north of the Burra Hotel. Pumping from the Mine is expected to begin soon at the rate of about 2 million gallons per day. The dam should be an attractive addition to the beauty of the town.

Following a deputation to the Minister of health it seems that the Burra Common Effluent Drainage Scheme will be constructed in 1976-77.

The Grants Commission has invited applications for funding to upgrade sports facilities.

BHS. The year began with 172 students, slightly down on 1974 due to fewer 1st year students. A new staff member Mr Colin Baker was welcomed. Art teacher Mrs Schultz is unfortunately still on sick leave. From now on year levels will be referred to as Grades VIII, IX etc.

The Meaning of STOP SIGNS will change on 1 March.

From that date you must stop and give way to all traffic from the right and the left.

97, 5, 18 Feb. 1975, page 7

Birth. To Cathie & John O’Loughlin of Hallett last Wednesday, a son, Daniel John.

Birth. To Leonie & Pat Ryan of Burra North last Wednesday, a son, Todd Patrick Richard.
