Birth. To Natalie & Dennis Short of Farrell Flat at Burra Hospital yesterday, a daughter, Wendy Nicole.

Obituary. Mrs Beat. Bevan, formerly of Burra, died in Adelaide on Saturday. She was the wife of Alex and mother of Ray. [Born Beatrice Ellen Amanda Byles 3 January 1899 Kooringa: died 15 February 1975.]

Obituary. Hartley Harris, formerly of Burra, died in Melbourne 9 February aged 84. He was a son of the late Frank Harris and left Burra in 1923, keeping up a subscription to the Burra Record ever since. His first job about seventy years ago was with the Burra Record at 5/- a week. After two years he went to Adelaide and entered the grocery trade. In the Great War he saw service at Gallipoli and in France, after which he married and returned to Burra to be employed as a grocer by Drew & Crewes. In 1923 he went to Lilydale in Victoria to an apple orchard and dairy farm. With difficult times and the onset of the Great Depression he returned to grocery, where he remained until he retired. For the last 25 years he lived in the Melbourne suburb of Reservoir. He is survived by his son Bruce and his brother Arthur, now of Adelaide. He spent his last three months at the McLeod Repatriation Hospital. The occupant of an adjacent bed was another man who spent his early years in Burra; Mr Peter Gebhardt. [Hartley Pascoe Harris born 10 August 1890 Kooringa.

Peter Gebhardt would seem likely to have been Adolph Peter Gebhardt born 30 September 1905 at Port Wakefield, though if he was at a Repatriation Hospital it suggests he was a WWII veteran.]

97, 5, 18 Feb. 1975, page 8

Burra & District Floral Art Club held its AGM on 5 February and elected: President, Mrs B. Thamm; Vice-President, Mrs Joyce Lloyd and Secretary-Treasurer, Mrs D. Mengersen. The club had 13 members. Lavender bags were sent to the Adelaide National Flower Day. Several pedestals were bought by the Burra Burra DC to be used for arrangements in the Town Hall.

97, 6, 25 Feb. 1975, page 1

Barkers of Baldina Cottage Homes

$17,000 more is required to erect three more units. The cost of the three units is now $70,000. Government subsidy will bring in $37,000, but only if all the necessary money is in hand before work starts. Cash in hand is $19,000, leaving a shortfall of $17,000 to be raised. The proposed units will be the same standard as the existing ones. The No. 6 Social Club (Masonic) has also handed $657 to the appeal as the result of Friday night’s cabaret. The hotels of the district have all made generous donations, as have Moyles, Coca Cola Bottlers, Snack foods Pty Ltd and Jackie Kleinig’s Dance Band. A gift of $300 has come from ‘Mackerode’ Mt Bryan*. Money must be raised quickly before costs soar even higher.

[* This was corrected in the next issue page 2 to read ‘The Mackerode Gift $300.’]

BHS Council. Two vacancies on the Council have been filled. The parent representatives are R. Thamm, G. Williams, D. O’Connor, G. Webster and B. Stockman.

Tourist Bodies Amalgamate. At Yacka on Thursday 13 February the Mid North Tourist Development Association merged with the Southern Flinders Indian Pacific Tourist Development Association to form the Mid North Tourist Association of SA.

Aberdeen Football Club will continue this year as a member of the Mid North Association, despite rumours to the contrary. The AGM on 14 February elected President, M.C. Broad; Vice-President, P. Reed; Secretary, G. Hirschausen and Treasurer, Arnold Heinrich. They will enter ‘A’ Grade, ‘B’ Grade and Senior Colts teams.

97, 6, 25 Feb. 1975, page 2

Advt. The Circle Theatre Co. presents Four Comedies at Booborowie on Friday 28 February and at Burra Town Hall on Saturday 1 March.

Tennis. Inter-Association Match, 23 February

Burra 21-172 defeated Peterborough 15-155

Cricket

North Booborowie 55 & 5 for 107 declared v. Koonaburra 7 for 130 declared.

97, 6, 25 Feb. 1975, page 3

Mid North Football League on Friday night conferred Life Membership on League Secretary Albert Bannear in recognition of 40 years’ service to the league. He was a club secretary from 1946, has served two long terms as League Secretary (1946-51 and the second from 1965 to the present). He has also served as a delegate, a commissioner and a publicity officer.

1st Division Burra 77 defeated Spalding 61

2nd Division Clare Blue 76 defeated Burra Gold 67

Clare Red 74 defeated Burra Green 69

3rd Division Clare Green 74 defeated Burra 65

Associates

Burra Gold 66 defeated Spalding Red 59

Caltowie 67 defeated Burra Green 50

Porter’s Lagoon Spectacular on Sunday raised $2,000 for community projects in the Gilbert Valley area. The day was sponsored by the Gilbert Valley Lions Club. There were water skiing displays, yacht races, swimming races, sideshows, food stalls and booths.

97, 6, 25 Feb. 1975, page 5

The Penguin Club had a very successful Special Luncheon at the Royal exchange Hotel on 27 November 1974.

Burra Library AGM was held recently and President R.J. Steele reported on the past 12 months. The library had been supported by a successful trading table and raffle and a Council donation as well as subscriptions. During the year about 200 old and damaged books were culled.

97, 6, 25 Feb. 1975, page 6

Marriage. At Burra Methodist Church on Saturday: Suzanne Collins and Peter Wise.

97, 6, 25 Feb. 1975, page 8

Burra Netball Club held its AGM in Burra Town Hall 20 February and elected President, Mrs P. Brereton; Vice-President, Mrs R. Angel; Secretary-Treasurer, Mrs G. Hirschausen and Assistant Secretary, Mrs Fiebig.

97, 6 (2), 4 Mar. 1975, page 1

Burra Division of St John Ambulance Service has decided to buy a new ambulance to be air conditioned and fitted with modern equipment. At the AGM on 19 February Ron Thamm was re-elected Chairman with Mrs Eileen Beinke as Secretary. In the last year the ambulance travelled 7,601 km and involved 304.5 hours of voluntary work. 18 patients were transferred and there were 4 maternity and 23 medical transfers. 11 vehicle accidents were attended. The call-out fee is to be $ X and 50 cents per km for non-members. Membership subscriptions numbered 368 in 1973 and 482 in 1974.

Adelaide Wool Sale: local sellers and prices are listed.

Two New Guinea visitors interested school students this week. Miss Tobu Loi is a trained nurse and Rev. Aya Dabuma is a minister in the United Church of PNG & Solomon Islands.

97, 6 (2), 4 Mar. 1975, pages 1 & 2

The Powder Magazine is being restored. Work started last week. The building dates from 1847. Money has been made available under the National Estate Program.

97, 6 (2), 4 Mar. 1975, pages 1 & 2

97, 6 (2), 4 Mar. 1975, page 5

Mid North Football League held its AGM

(Clubs are Riverton, Mintaro-Manoora, Robertstown, Saddleworth-Marrabel United, Aberdeen & Auburn.)

The league is in credit $1,202.

Elected were: President, Stan Noske (Robertstown); Vice-President, Trevor Mosey (Robertstown); Patron, W.E. Blatchford (Riverton).

This year’s teams:

Aberdeen A, B & Senior Colts

Riverton, Min-Man, Robertstown and S-M United will each field A, B, and Senior and Junior Colts.

Auburn, which was an original member of the league, with an unbroken service of 66 years, will go into recess for 12 months. Arrangements were made for the year’s program.

97, 6 (2), 4 Mar. 1975, page 6

Obituary. Wilfred Essen Rule, son of William and Laura deceased, brother to Cecil and a nephew to Phil, died at Karoonda 22 February. [Born 18 November 1922 Redruth. Note that Wilfred had a sister Cecilia Ita and the reference above might be to her rather than to a Cecil.]

Advt. Burra Pictures, Saturday 8 March

Maggie Smith & Timothy Bottoms in Love & Pain & the Whole Damn Thing

Correction. Miss Janie McGlasson of Booborowie School came from Forbes in Adelaide; not Forbes in NSW.

[I have not noted the original report.]

Obituary. Charlie Griffiths died on Saturday 1 March. He is survived by his wife Dulcie, a daughter Valarie and son-in-law Noel and grandsons Daniel and Nicholas. [Charles Thomas Griffiths born 4 April 1914 Redruth.]

Burra Kindergarten. Peter Fiebig was elected President last night and his wife Marilyn Fiebig was elected Vice-President.

Basketball

Men’s Burra 42 defeated Hallett 42

Women’s Hallett 30 defeated Burra 22

97, 6 (2), 4 Mar. 1975, page 8

Mokota Cricket Association

Spalding 8 for 169 defeated Mt Bryan 83.

Women’s Bowls

Burra Gold 66 defeated Spalding Red 59

97, 7, 11 Mar. 1975, page 1

Burra Show Society held its AGM 11 March. Ron Shipard of Hanson replaced Graham Kellock as President. Other officers: Patron, Rex C. Warnes; Senior Vice-President, Neil Hurst; Junior Vice-President, Peter Stockman and Secretary-Treasurer, Darrell H. Field (re-elected). The society was in credit $122.50 after having new toilet facilities erected. The toilet project was made possible in large part due to the Rural Youth, who ran a Lottery Cabaret to assist. D.T. Jacka & Co. erected the new toilets.

The show was held on the Saturday of the October long weekend and coincided with the Burra Copper Festival. As a result gate takings were a near record. Mr Bert Kelly MHR opened the show. The day began with showers, but cleared as the day progressed. Entries were good in most sections. More entries in shearing would be appreciated. Miss show Girl was a huge success. The Dog Section was not held for lack of a convenor. A pony club has been formed in Burra in the past year and has been given permission to use the grounds. The Boy Scouts have permission to use the halls for their meetings. Thanks to Roy Humphrys for keeping the grounds weed free and to Secretary D.H. Field and his wife and to other members of committees.

Burra High School Swimming Carnival was held on 28 February in perfect weather. [Results are printed.]

Methodist Circuit Family Camp will be held at Melrose at the Diocesan Centre over the coming weekend.

Lobethal Harmony Choir will hold a concert at Redruth Hall on 22 March to aid the Bible Society.

Burra Church Choir will present the cantata Easter Song at the 11 a.m. service on Palm Sunday, 23 March.

St John’s Lutheran Church was well filled for the Annual Women’s World Day of Prayer service on Friday evening. The address was given by Mrs Phyl. Klem of Farrell Flat.

Apex has elected Jeff Hirschausen as President. In 1975 it will boost town tourism with improved signage around Burra and will help beautify the area around the new ‘Burra Billabong’. Murray Mitchell retired as President and Phil. Ogden and Lou Georgeou are losses by transfer.

97, 7, 11 Mar. 1975, page 2

2nd Division Burra Green 88 defeated Saddleworth 49

3rd Division Watervale 75 defeated Burra 48

Burra Associates

Spalding Blue 69 defeated Burra Green 50

97, 7, 11 Mar. 1975, page 3

Notice. Burra RSL AGM will be held 14 March.

Burra High School Swimming Carnival: Results are printed.

97, 7, 11 Mar. 1975, page 5

North Eastern Football League held its AGM 17 February and elected: Patron, R.N. Collins of Booborowie; President, M.J. Vandeleur; Senior Vice-President, W.B. Ashby; Junior Vice-President, A.J. Cousins and Secretary, J.S. Wood of Kybunga.

97, 7, 11 Mar. 1975, page 7

Birth. To Jeannine & Geoff Randall of Burra at QVMH, a son, Joseph Geoffrey.

Birth. To Judy & Bill Macdonald of Lucindale at Ashford Community Hospital 25 February, a son. Judy was born Judy Finch of Burra.

Burra Primary School. Miss Diana Bellman, formerly of Port Wakefield, replaces Barb. Hogan, who takes over the special reading class.

Mr & Mrs Bob. Wakefield have left Mt Bryan for Christies Beach.

Obituary. Mrs Grace Taylor, formerly of Booborowie, died at Clare on Thursday 6 March aged 73.

[Born Dorothy Grace Boxall 27 May 1901 Tablelands (District of Kapunda). She married Harry Taylor.]

Noel Tiver of Toorak Gardens served in WWI and returned in 1919. He married Miss Hazel Nutt in 1921 and they celebrated their Silver Wedding in 1946. Mrs Tiver died in February 1948 and in March 1950 Mr Tiver married Dorothy, widow of the late Ray Thomas of Hallett and the Silver Anniversary of their wedding falls today.

Burra Lutheran Church now has a fence built by members of the congregation.

Mokota Cricket Association

Spalding 4 for 211 defeated Koonaburra 115.

Basketball

Men’s Burra 31 defeated Torreston 7

Women’s Burra 24 defeated Torreston 22

97, 7, 11 Mar. 1975, page 8

Burra High School Parents & Friends Association held its AGM. During the year $864.05 was raised and $646.50 was spent. [Further details as reported by Secretary Pat Brereton are printed.]

97, 8, 18 Mar. 1975, page 1

Burra Burra DC

Some $3,000 is owing to the Council, mainly for services like weed control and legal action will be taken if the amounts are not paid.

The base for the new netball court at Victoria Park has been completed.

The Councils of the Burra Schools are applying for a grant to assist in building a full-sized multi-purpose activity hall. This plan was well supported in a recent survey. District Councils in the area are prepared to contribute. Plans to upgrade facilities for sports and at the Memorial Institute at Booborowie total $43,000.

At Burra there are moves to make five new tennis courts and a netball court on the site of the old lawn tennis courts, with a hocky ground nearby. Commonwealth assistance is likely to be sought.

Burra High School prefects have been elected for 1975.

Girls: Ann Carpenter (Head), Marrie Holmes (Deputy), Jenifer Bernhardt, Kathi Gisi, Jannette Ramm, Jill Rasheed.

Boys: Brenton Ford (Head), Kym Donhardt (Deputy), Paul Beinke, Andrew Spackman, Nick van Buuren, Tom Wardle.

[House Captains and student representatives are also listed.]

38 students visited Salisbury College of Advanced Education to see Shakespeare’s Twelfth Night on 7 March.

The next meeting will be 21 March in the Flower Pavilion at the showgrounds because there will be a Scout Dance in the Show Hall.

Burra Branch of the Liberal Party held a dinner meeting last Friday at the Burra Hotel where the speaker was Trevor Griffin, President of the SA Division.

97, 8, 18 Mar. 1975, page 5

Kooringa Methodist Ladies Guild. The report for 1974 showed a membership of 28 and an average attendance of 17. They met every Wednesday. $345 had been donated to various bodies throughout the year.

Burra Weight Watchers Club reports a successful year, including two graduations when five members received the coveted gold sash and diploma. Burra has the first male graduate in SA.

Kurt Russell & Joe Flynn in The Barefoot Executive

Plus Dumbo

Advt. Lobethal Harmony Choir in Redruth Memorial Hall Saturday 22 March.

97, 8, 18 Mar. 1975, page 7

Birth. To Frank & Millie Nicholls of Booborowie a few weeks ago, a son.

Birth. To Judy & Roger Humphrys, formerly of Hanson last Wednesday at Memorial Hospital, a son, Davis James Ross.

Obituary. Joseph Geoffrey Randall, only child of Jeannine & Geoff Randall of Burra North died last Thursday aged 5 days.

Obituary. George Parker of Burra died last week aged 69. He is survived by a widow and four children.

Obituary. Bill Corner’s mother died last week at Broken Hill.

John Maidment and family have come to Burra and he has taken over Burra’s Modern Meat Store from Fred & Jan McLean.

97, 9, 25 Mar. 1975, page 1

‘Redcliffe’ Station was sold at Burra RSL Hall on 21 March. The vendors were A. & G. Tennant and the buyers were Messrs Murray & Gosse of Hallett for $160,000.

Adelaide Wool Sales of 18 & 19 March are reported with local prices.

‘Venture’ the supplement that has been coming out with the Burra Record is no longer being sent with posted copies, because postal charges have increased to 5 cents. Readers will get it included if they are prepared to pay the extra charge: from $4.50 to $5.25.

Tennis. With so many tennis players in town there is a shortage of courts. There are eight senior and two junior teams and at times local teams with scheduled home matches have to play away; for example at Leighton. Five courts are available at Burra North as well as those at the school. Planned building operations at the school are likely to deprive players of the use of four of these. It is planned therefore to lay down six courts on the area of the former lawn courts. An application has been made to the State Committee of Regional Employment Development for $13,000 to cover the cost and for two netball courts – one at Aberdeen Oval and one at Burra War Memorial Oval. With the building of the new clubhouse for the Burra Golf Club the present clubhouse will meet the needs of tennis players.

Burra Golf Club has decided to sign the contract with D.T. Jacka & Co. for the new clubhouse.

Football. The season starts on 26 April. In the Mid North League it is understood that Auburn has now amalgamated with the Watchman Football Club for 1975 and many players will play in the Adelaide Plains Association.

Athol Tiver writes as Publicity Officer for the Isolated Children’s Parents’ Association concerning the proposal to lower the taxation deduction for students from $400 to $150.

97, 9, 25 Mar. 1975, page 2

Bowls

The Mid North Champion of Champions for 1975 is Keith [Phillips?]

At the end of the season Burra Clubs achieved the following positions:

1st Division Fourth

2nd Division Burra Green came third

Burra Gold came sixth

3rd Division Fifth.

The Lobethal Harmony Choir gave a first class performance in the Redruth Memorial Hall on Saturday and the proceeds of $102 will aid the Bible Society.

Adelaide Children’s Hospital Auxiliary (Burra Branch) raised $70 at a street stall and with the sale of badges? Was able to send away $110 to the Good Friday Appeal.

The Final Lenten Service in the Wednesday evening series will be held at St Joseph’s this week.

Burra RSL AGM was attended by 12 members on 14 March. Elected: President, R.J. Steele; Senior Vice-President, C.R. Earle; Junior Vice President, B. Kotz; Secretary, W. Fridd and Treasurer, E.W. Clarke.

The branch welcomed two ex-Vietnam boys.

Burra Hockey Club held its AGM on 18 March at the school. Captain is J. Wall and Vice-Captain L. Phillips.

Obituary. Lyn Andrew, sister to Ros. Mrs John Lucas of Hallett, died as the result of a road accident on Saturday aged 17.

97, 9, 25 Mar. 1975, page 8

Redruth Ladies Guild held its AGM 13 March. Secretary, Mrs R.M. Jennison reported a membership of 30 with an average attendance of 21 at 11 meetings for the year. The great success for the year was the fete on 30 November with takings a record $585. $455 was donated to various causes throughout the year.

97, 10, 1 Apr. 1975, page 1

The Mid North Lapidary Club meets on the first Monday each month in the Chapel Street Clubrooms at the rear of the baker’s shop. Geoff Randall is President.

Zion Church Hall at Robertstown celebrated its centenary recently.

Bowls

The Easter Bowls Carnival is reported a great success. Men’s Pairs went to Colin Winkler & Fred Miller of Walkerville.

Walkerville players also won the Men’s Fours.

A Spalding team won the Mixed Fours.

The Redruth Camping and Conference Centre amenities block was sufficiently completed to be used over Easter.

97, 10, 1 Apr. 1975, page 5

Burra Primary School Council held its AGM. Chairman I.T. Allen reported on 1974. A number of joint meetings were held with the High School Council for joint approaches to the Government and at present not many projects are under way pending the building program, which should begin soon. Tenders for the new school are expected to be called in April, with work beginning in July.

Jenny Hore and Tony Kotz, formerly of Burra.

Mr & Mrs Glen Finch celebrate their Golden Wedding.

[Glen Roy Finch married Kathleen Winifred Stockman 2 April 1925 at Redruth Methodist Church.]

Gerry Bam gave a free organ recital at the Burra Town Hall on 25 March, which was very enjoyable for the fewer than a dozen who attended.

Jack Williams of Booborowie is producing some fine dahlias.

97, 10, 1 Apr. 1975, page 8

Burra Kindergarten held its AGM and elected: Patroness and Public Officer, Mrs E. Carpenter; President, Mr P. Fiebig; Vice-President, Mrs Marilyn Fiebig; Secretary, Brenda Villis and Assistant Secretary, Marcia Baulderstone. In the year fund raising produced $1,170 gross and $807.44 nett.

97, 11, 8 Apr. 1975, page 1

Burra Primary School Welfare Club last year held nine meetings and the average attendance was 9 from 42 members representing 220 children. This year we began a reading scheme for children with few problems, to encourage them and 15 mothers volunteered. The group held interesting meetings with teachers and visited Balaklava’s flexible unit system of education. The canteen has realised a profit of $869. Elected for 1975 were: President, Mrs R. Thamm; 1st Vice-President, Mrs C. Phillips; 2nd Vice-President, Mrs D. Lloyd; Secretary, Mrs M. Tiver; Assistant Secretary, Mrs J. Secombe; Treasurer, Mrs G. Nourse.

Mokota Cricketer of the Year: F. Cousins of Spalding.

The Mid North Lapidary Club, will commence gemstone cutting classes on Saturday 12 April 2-5 p.m. under the instruction of Ken McLean.

97, 11, 8 Apr. 1975, pages 1 & 3

Saddleworth. There is a long article on the sale of an old home at Saddleworth, formerly Saddleworth Roller Flour Mill, dating from the early 1870s.

97, 11, 8 Apr. 1975, page 2

Burra Tennis Association

Juniors (C Grade) Burra White 8-56 defeated Spalding 4-46

Spalding 186 defeated Booborowie 159.

97, 11, 8 Apr. 1975, page 3

Advt. Elders will conduct a land auction in Booborowie Hall 9 May.

They will offer ‘Lorraine’ and ‘Paradise’ 9 km north of Booborowie and 18 km east of Hallett respectively.

Lorraine (On instructions from S.L., A.W. & G.L. Clapp) comprises 423.5 ha: Section 468 Hundred of Anne (freehold) and also Lucerne Flats of 37.2 ha Sections 523 & 534 Hundred of Anne (freehold).

And ‘Paradise’ of 1,052.79 ha (perpetual lease) comprising Sections 56, 58m, 57, 58, 49, 50, 105, 108, 137 & 144 Hundreds of Hallett & Mongolata.

Advt. Burra CWA Picnic at the Gorge 11 April at 2 p.m.

Basketball

[Men’s] Burra 39 defeated Booborowie 25 to progress to the Grand Final.

97, 11, 8 Apr. 1975, page 7

Marriage. At Burra Methodist Church next Saturday

Vicki McBride will marry Drew Anderson. (Both of Burra)

Bishop Bruce Rosier will attend the Conference of the Rural Deanery of Clare to be held at St Mary’s on Sunday. The Deanery comprises the parishes of Clare, Auburn-Riverton, Crystal Brook-Broughton Valley, Jamestown, Peterborough and Burra.

Obituary. John Burns, a resident of Robertstown area for two years, was accidentally drowned at Waikerie on the Easter Weekend. He originally came from Scotland.

Bowls. In the Lower North Division, in the Champion of Champions Fours competition Burra reached the finals for the first time in twenty odd years. They defeated Nuriootpa, Tanunda, Spalding and Angaston before being beaten by Balaklava.

97, 12, 15 Apr. 1975, MISSING

97, 13, 22 Apr. 1975, page 1

Burra Burra DC

Council calls for nominations for Councillors by 9 May.

Retiring Councillors are:

Burra Town Ward R.B. Jennison

R.J. Jeffery

Hanson Ward D.L. Lloyd

Baldina Ward M.T. Kellock

Booborowie Ward H.B. Quinn

The recent death of Cr T.J. Quinn creates a vacancy in Mt Bryan Ward.

Council has accepted a debenture loan from the Savings Bank of SA of $5,000 to cover the purchase of a back-hoe and part of the cost of a tip truck.

[Obituary. Thomas James Quinn born 20 September 1892 Mt Bryan East: died 9 April 1975 Burra.]

The Football Season starts on Saturday for both the North Eastern and the Mid North Leagues. Aberdeen advises it cannot raise a Senior Colts side, but will enter a Junior Colts team.

Burra School calls for people willing to offer to help with school activities. Areas of interest are: floral arrangement, dressmaking, dancing, Red Cross and First Aid. Messrs Thamm, Jennison and Richards are thanked for allowing boys to study mechanics in their workshops in 1st term.

97, 13, 22 Apr. 1975, page 3

Burra Red Cross celebrated its Golden Jubilee this month. Mrs Roy Jeffrey spoke on its work during two World Wars at the April meeting.

97, 13, 22 Apr. 1975, page 5

97, 13, 22 Apr. 1975, page 7

Birth. To Arnold & Pauline Lomman nee Mosel at Burra Hospital 17 April, a daughter, Jodie Louise.

Birth. To Judy & Donald Irlam at Burra Hospital 17 April, a daughter, Angela Judy.

Rick Pearse of Koonoona has returned home after 12 months overseas.

Obituary. Last Wednesday Arnold Hanlin, formerly of Willalo, died at Clare. He is survived by a widow and one son. [Born Arnold George Hanlin 6 January 1901 Terowie. Married as Arnold George Piercy Hanlin.]

Obituary. Tom Kellaway, formerly of Burra, died on Friday [18 April] aged 63. He is survived by a widow and two sons. He was a former footballer for Burra, Port Adelaide and State teams and played in the 1936 Australian Championship in Perth. [Thomas Kellaway born 29 September 1911 Kooringa.]

97, 13, 22 Apr. 1975, page 8

Stockowners Association of SA. The Burra & District Committee held its annual meeting in the RSL Hall and elected: President, J.G. Duncan; Senior Vice-President, J.T. Drew; Junior Vice-President, R.J. Ashby. The address was given by M.I. McTaggart. The President reported on the year’s activities.

The wool sales in September saw values slide a further 15-171⁄2% with the average bale fetching $176 at the last sale – a slight improvement. There was a year of record rainfall resulting in huge losses in pastoral areas due to blowfly attacks and more recently from grass seeds and worms. Some producers say this combination has been more worry than a drought. The bushfire hazard has been extreme.

Cattle prices have been low, but stable and with an estimated backlog of 2 million cattle to be slaughtered, the outlook is grim.

Pig meat and grain fed lamb prices have been quite good.

Rising costs in the sector in wages, workers’ compensation, fuel, payroll tax, super bounty and depreciation, along with depressed markets are forcing producers to the wall.

97, 14, 29 Apr. 1975, page 1

Aberdeen Football Club held a meeting on Wednesday and decided that owing to a lack of playing members it would be forced to go into recess for the 1975 season. The President Mr M. Broad informed the secretary of the Mid North League, Mr M.A. Bannear, that they would be unable to field any teams for the season. He asked that clearance of players to take positions with other clubs be expedited. The Mid North League will now have five rounds of matches with no byes. Mr Bannear felt that this could well be the last year of the Mid North League, with every possibility of joining with the North Eastern League in 1976.

Father Kevin Matthews, editor of Witness, the monthly paper of the Catholic Diocese of Port Pirie, has been re-appointed National Vice-President of the Catholic Press Association.

Successful Ecumenical Lenten Devotions have led to further ecumenical meetings being planned.

A ‘Starvathon’ involving 50 teenagers is estimated to have raised over $600.

[An item in the paper of 8 April said the sum would go towards Vietnam War Relief.]

Vandalism is concerning the District Council. Targets have included the drain sump at the swimming pool, Redruth Gaol and public toilets.

97, 14, 29 Apr. 1975, page 2

Marriage. Kooringa Methodist Church 12 April

Bicki McBride, daughter of Mrs S. Cullen, married Crew Anderson, son of Mr & Mrs A.M. Anderson.

The reception was held in Roche Bros. Hall.

97, 14, 29 Apr. 1975, pages 4 & 5

Burra Burra DC, 14 April

Permission was granted to Samin Ltd for test holes at the Burra Mine.

A letter is to be sent to the Commonwealth Railways about proposed railway crossing lights at Farrell Flat.

97, 14, 29 Apr. 1975, page 7

Birth. To Marie & Reece Murphy of Hallett at Burra Hospital 25 April, a son, Jamie Reece.

Birth. To Barry Thompson of Cabramatta and formerly of Booborowie (son of Mr & Mrs Ron Thompson) and his wife Rob last Thursday, a son at Fairfield Hospital.

Obituary. Lance Phillips of ‘Studholme’ east of Burra died at Burra Hospital on Thursday aged 62. He is survived by a widow, step-son, daughter-in-law and granddaughter.

[Hazel Lancelot Phillips born 28 January 1913 World’s End.]

Father John Morley conducted the Dawn Service at the Burra War memorial on Anzac Day.

The Catholic Cabaret on Saturday night was a great success.

Football

‘A’ Grade Burra 17.16 defeated Spalding 11.14

Senior Colts Burra 25.10 defeated Spalding 0.0

Junior Colts Spalding 12.1 defeated Burra 2.1

97, 15, 6 May 1975, page 1

Burra Burra DC has obtained $9,000 under the RED Scheme to be spent on six basketball courts, one netball court and beautification of the Burra Creek. The entire project will cost $13,000. The basketball courts will replace six lawn tennis courts at the Burra North Recreation Ground and the netball court will be added at the Burra Oval.

Elders-GM held their annual breeders cattle sale on Thursday at Burra. 545 head were yarded and sold. Koonoona Proprietors provided the largest group of 370Shorthorn and Shorthorn Hereford Cross mixed sex weaners. [Prices are given.]

Adelaide Wool Sale prices are listed for local producers. They were from par to 21⁄2% up.

Rev. E.N. Broomhead of Riverton will conduct an ecumenical service at St Mary’s on Sunday evening.

Football. The umpiring section of the SANFL has advised that ‘A’ Grade umpires will no longer officiate at ‘Double-Headers’. Umpires for Senior and Junior Colts will not be supplied except for inter-association matches and finals. This is due to the very low availability of umpires for country appointments. This poses a major problem for the Mid North Football League.

97, 15, 6 May 1975, page 2

Advt. Burra Pictures, 10 May

Brian Keith & Helmut Grien in The McKenzie Break

Burt Reynolds & Anne Francis in Impasse

97, 15, 6 May 1975, page 3

Advt. Elders-GM give details of a clearing sale for Mr Stan Mudge, whose property at Willalo has been sold.

Advt. Oates Ltd advise the sale of Ayers Park for R.J. & J.M. Steele comprising 208.2 ha freehold and 395 ha perpetual lease, 7 miles northwest of Burra. [Details are printed.]

97, 15, 6 May 1975, page 5

Hallett & District Schools Athletic Association held its sports day at Burra Oval on 18 April. All school trophies were won by Hallett School. Individual trophies went to Carol Reed, Wendy Hughes & Philip Clode. [Results are printed, but students are not identified by school.]

CWA. The Warnes Group of 16 branches held its annual conference at Booborowie on 17 April. [The report runs for 3⁄4 column.]

Bowls. The Upper North & Silver City Divisional Bowls Championships were played in Burra on 21 & 22 April.

[Results are printed, but there were no Burra winners.]

97, 15, 6 May 1975, page 7

97, 16, 13 May 1975, page 1

Burra Burra DC

All the following men nominated for councillor were elected unopposed for a term beginning 5 July.

Hanson Walsh D.L. Lloyd

Baldina Ward A.A. Barker

Booborowie Ward J.S. Hawker

Mt Bryan Ward A.J. Gebhardt

Burra Town Ward R.B. Jennison

Another councillor is required for Burra Town Ward and nominations are called by 23 May in a supplementary election.

Burra Cubs continue to meet in the Show Hall.

The Ecumenical Service at St Mary’s on Sunday was attended by 60-70 people. The address was given by Rev. Ted Broomhead (Methodist) of Riverton. He was assisted in the service by Fathers John Morley and Kevin Matthews and Rev. Clarrie Hore.

Football. The Mid North League Commissioners remind coaches and players that bad or offensive language is a reportable offence.

CWA Warnes Group Table Day was held at Burra Town Hall on 5 May. Door money was $52. The Auburn Branch gained the overall aggregate of points.

97, 16, 13 May 1975, page 2

Football

‘A’ Grade Burra 18.18 defeated Booborowie-Hallett 5.9

‘B’ Grade Burra 8.9 defeated Booborowie-Hallett 5.4

Senior Colts Burra 13.13 defeated Booborowie-Hallett 2.1

Netball

97, 16, 13 May 1975, page 5

Burra Bowling Associates held their AGM 6 May and elected: President, Mrs Jean Jamieson; Secretary, Mrs Daphne Martin and Treasurer, Mrs Minnie Heitbrink. Mrs Myrtle Phillips of Booborowie won the pennant. Retiring President Pat Field reported a successful year and details of the year’s activities are printed.

97, 16, 13 May 1975, page 6

Advt. Burra Pictures

Steve McQueen in Le Mans

Plus Carry on Henry

Hanson Tennis Club. Tenders are called for the purchase, dismantling and removal of the club’s shed and contents and of the backstops of the now disused Hanson Tennis Courts.

97, 16, 13 May 1975, page 7

Hanson Tennis Club was formed in 1927 and various members played regularly till 1970. At a recent meeting it was decided to wind up the club and dispose of any monies. 50% will go to the Hall and 25% each to the CWA and the Table Tennis Club.

Bill Gebhardt, Jeffrey Burgess & Robert McLeod held a successful dance at the Mt Cone Woolshed at Mr Bryan on Saturday.

The Willalo Dance on Saturday was also a success. The raffle raised $76.50 and the door and donations totalled $93 to aid the Motor Mission Sisters.

Notice. Burra Burra DC District Clerk advises the sale by tender of the block of land in Kingston Street known as the Corporation Depot.

97, 17, 20 May 1975, page 1

E.C. Allen MP Member for Frome objects to plans to close all polling booths with under 50 voters average in the last three elections. Places affected around Burra would be Black Springs av. 46. [Though how 54, 48 & 51 averages 46 is not explained!] Also Bright (41), Hanson (40) and Willalo (50). His complaint is not so much about closures in the settled areas as the effect in more remote locations. The result would be only one booth in the whole area north-east of Peterborough; at Yunta. In the far north, if Oodnadatta closed (50) the nearest booth would be Marree 274 miles away. With mail deliveries once a fortnight postal votes are also not an option in such remote areas. The system would have to be changed.

The old bridge over the Light at Kapunda will not be demolished. Dating from 1890, it is presently in sound condition and will be incorporated into a roadside stopping area.

97, 17, 20 May 1975, page 2

Advt. Burra Pictures, 24 May

Five Fingers of Death

Jane Fonda & Donald Sutherland in Steely and Blues

97, 18, 27 May 1975, page 1

Aberdeen Football Club

A special general meeting was held on 2 May, called by President M. Broad. The President reported on the committee’s decision to go into recess. Jumpers will be held for 12 months, all accounts will be paid and $1,500 will be placed on fixed deposit. A meeting with delegates from other sporting clubs will be held on 30 May to decide what use can be made of the club rooms.

Mid North Lapidary Club members have visited Cowell, Iron Knob, Whyalla, Victoria and New Zealand and have returned with material for cutting and polishing. A field trip to the Utica Copper Mine resulted in the collection of a small specimen of malachite and atacamite crystal. Members have visited the local Aboriginal rock carving site and the Redbanks area for jasper. The next meeting will be in the Town Hall supper room on Monday 2 June.

Farrell Flat railway crossing lights have been delayed by design questions for the crossing.

Adelaide Wool Sales are reported with local prices printed. Values were generally firm.

97, 18, 27 May 1975, page 2

Junior Colts South Clare 10.16 defeated Burra 0.0

Vandals have entered the home of Mr Norman ‘Sixty’ Wilson, Mayor of Payneham, several times recently. Mr Wilson is a former Burra identity. [Perhaps Norman James Wilson born 5 January 1930.]

Mrs Holden, former Matron of Redruth Reformatory, was the grandmother of former Senator, now Dame Nancy Buttfield.

Pool. The grand final of the pool tournament will be played at Burra Hotel on 4 June between John Nankivell and Ray Mann.

Obituary. Lance Phelan, formerly a publican of the Burra Hotel, died recently. Though he left Burra some time ago, he only recently sold the freehold of the hotel. [Richard Lancelot Phelan born 15 November 1907 Wayville. He held the licence for the Burra Hotel 1942-46.]

Obituary. Mrs Dot Kemp of Elizabeth and formerly of Gum Creek died on Friday at the Lyell McEwin Hospital aged 70.

Obituary. Mrs Edith Jettner died at Murray Bridge on Saturday aged 97. She was a foundation member of Burra CWA in 1926. [Born Edith May McCallum 30 April 1878 Caltowie: died 24 May 1975 Murray Bridge. She married Ebenezer Jettner in 1901.]

97, 20, 10 June 1975, page 1

Oates Ltd sold ‘Ayers Park’ in the RDL Hall at Burra on Friday on account of Mr & Mrs R.J. Steele.

Lot 1. ‘Heinrich’s’ of 429 acres went to Wandillah Pty Ltd of Burra at $114 per acre.

Lots 2 & 3. ‘Homestead’ and ‘Brown’s’ went to Coolangatta Pty Ltd of Two Wells for $110 & $111 per acre respectively.

The Pool Tournament was decided last Wednesday when Ray Mann defeated John Nankivell.

Methodist Women gathered at Kapunda on 4 June for the annual rally of Methodist Guilds in the District of Light. Over 200 attended from as far afield as Nuriootpa, Balaklava, Burra, Mt Bryan, Gawler, Hamley Bridge and Tarlee. This will be the last such gathering as districts will be redistributed into presbyteries with church union in 1976.

Helen & Wally Scott were farewelled from the Kooringa Hotel on Saturday evening. Helen had been the licensee for nearly 25 years and having sold the licence they are retiring in Burra.

97, 21, 18 June 1975, page 1

Burra Burra DC intends to introduce fines of from $10-$200 for littering offences.

T.G. Perry the Council Clerk is now Curator of the Cemetery, replacing Mr D.B .O’Brien, who was appointed by the previous Town Council.

Hanson Hall Committee has been given the right to crop and graze the surrounding parklands for three years.

An extra Government grant of $3,450 towards the Golf Club project brings the subsidy to $12,450 of a total expenditure of $25,000.

Burra High School

In a reply to a question from Mr Allen the Deputy Premier said that delays to the plans for the new Burra Community School have occurred due to the need to redesign certain aspects of the Primary School. New plans have now been prepared and work will commence immediately on preparing to call a tender. No firm date is available at present.

Mrs Margaret Goyder Kerr of Somerton Park writes seeking information on the life of James and John Chambers who came to SA in 1837 and who pioneered postal and coaching services in SA. They also took up vast areas of land for cattle and sheep and went in for breeding horses. With William Finke they discovered copper on their Oratunga station. They employed John McDouall Stuart to move further into then unknown territory. They were among the founders of Adelaide’s early hunt and racing clubs. Their sister Priscilla married the adventurous Alfred Barker, who came to SA with Colonel Light before the colony was founded.

97, 21, 18 June 1975, page 2

Mid North Football Carnival was held on Saturday at Spalding and Monday at Crystal Brook and Saddleworth.

97, 21, 18 June 1975, page 5

Obituary. Mary Williams was the fourth daughter of the late Charles and Elizabeth Evans of Riverton. The family of five daughters was cared for by their kindly father after Mary’s mother died when she was nine. Mary was educated at Tothill’s Creek, Tothill’s Belt and Riverton High School and then went to Adelaide Teachers’ College. She was gifted at needlework. She taught at small schools in the vicinity of Pinaroo, Frances, Hawker, Warooka and Kadina until her marriage in 1936 to Maurice Williams of Carrieton at St Agnes Church, Marrabel. The couple lived at Baldina Downs and later in Burra. There were three daughters and four sons, but only the eldest lived beyond very early infancy. Mary was a relief teacher at Burra Primary School in the 1950s and assisted when health and family commitments allowed in Burra Rural Youth and at St Joseph’s Church and School. Her husband died in 1866 and two of her sister, Essie Evans and Olive Hansbery, also predeceased her. She became incapacitated in august 1974 and was cared for at Burra Hospital until her death on 31 May 1975.

97, 21, 18 June 1975, page 6

A panel and paint shop at Jennison’s Tyre Service

A house for W. Scott.

97, 22, 25 June 1975, page 1

Burra Community School

The Minister of Education Mr Hugh Hudson has released plans for SA’s first Community Complex School to be built at Burra. This involves rebuilding the present Burra Primary and High Schools and integrating them into a community facility. The original school building, which is a structure of historic interest classified by the national Trust, will be preserved. The interior will be converted into modern open space, leaving areas for primary students. There will be five additional buildings and a library will be built at the rear of the old building. The separate building for secondary classes will include science and commercial studies facilities and a third will provide for art and craft activities. A fourth building will house a drama workshop, activity hall and canteen, while an administrative block will house offices, staff accommodation and a sick room. The area between the buildings will be developed into an amphitheatre. The landscaping of the site will provide a new hockey field, an additional oval for primary students and an adventure playground. The tennis courts in front of the building will remain, while those at the rear will be replaced. The present impressive façade of the school will be preserved.

97, 22, 25 June 1975, page 3

Burra Bowling Club held its AGM on 18 June and elected: Patron, Dudley Jacka; President, Brian Riggs; Senior Vice-President, W. Scott; Junior Vice-President, M. Broderick; Secretary, Tom Lynch and Treasurer, Hank Heitbrink.

97, 22, 25 June 1975, page 5

Hockey. Roseworthy 5 defeated Burra 0.

Burra Rainfall figures by the month 1880-1975 are printed.

Ruth Trevivian nee Glenister1 contributes an article: ‘Memories of Burra’.

She was born in Darton Cottage – formerly Dr Sangster’s [Sen.] residence and her sister was born in ‘Bleak House’, the former Mine Hospital. She recalls Granny Howell2 living in a cottage a few yards from Darton Cottage, who said she had originally come from England as a lady-in-waiting to someone of high rank.

She remembers getting fitted for shoes at Pederson’s. Her father was the Choir-master at St Mary’s; he had sung in St Paul’s Cathedral in London before leaving England. Mr Graham Dow was then organist at St Mary’s and the ministers were Revs Hopton3 and Hewitson4. A small boy pumped the organ. She recalls being taken over the Black Bridge to the Chinaman’s Garden5 for vegetables [in Kingston Street] and also being taken for an afternoon walk by a girl from the Reformatory (when Miss Bubb was Matron) and how the girl dumped her on a windowsill of a stock firm for a moment’s rest and the window breaking. The girl flew along the wide street with her and she can’t recall the outcome. She remembers the Misses Ethel and Lily James behind the haberdashery counter at Drew & Crewes and Miss Tiver in the dresses and hats department. Miss Gert Pearce was a reporter and Mr Marston the editor at the Burra Record. Mr Parks the baker looked like a ghost, standing in his doorway with a big white apron and hair and eyebrows white with flour. The boys rocking the swing bridge made the journey home uncomfortable and swaggies asleep on the creek banks frightened her when she was on her own. The creek ran and they caught frogs to release in shop doorways – unbeknown to her mother. She recalls Mr Wicklein the jeweller, Mr Walker the shot outfitter [sic-?] and Mr Stan Lane the saddler. Mr Streicher’s waxed moustache fascinated her. She recalls Mr Pearce’s furniture shop with its smell of sawdust and a cat snoozing in the sun and old Mrs Pearce sitting inside the doorway. She recalls also Pompey Pederson6 and his speedy entrance into Burra after racing from Adelaide. And the earthquake. And the tragic death of Mrs Lafsky, who did their washing and was killed at a railway crossing on her way home from one of the stations7. Other names she mentions include Killicoat, Hann, Dane, Winnall, Jarrett, Pickering, Maundrell, Murphy and Mr Hogg, whose wife was a Belgian.

[1Ruth Grace Glenister born 31 August 1915 the daughter of Herman John Glenister (formerly Schneider) and Doris nee Dollman.

2Mrs Annie Howell nee Lewis; see Burra Record XV, 460, 27 Mar. 1901, page 2-3; XV, 464, 24 Apr. 1901, page 2; XV, 632, 1904, 29 June 1904, page 3; XXII, 1940, 14 Apr. 1915, page 2; XXXXV, 25, 13 June 1923, page 3 and XXXXVII, 46, 25 Nov. 1925, page 3.

3Henry Hopton was Rector of St Mary’s 1918-21.

4Frank Hewitson was Rector of St Mary’s 1921-27.

5The Chinaman was Luke Day c. 1867-1962. He came to Burra c. 1893 and lived there till his death. For many years he had a shop on the corner of Kingston and Thames Streets and later in the former Bible Christian Chapel in Paxton Square, living in the adjacent house in Kingston Street. See Colin T. Branford Luke and Hester Day 1966, and E.R. Fuss Burra Chinese 2004, both in the Burra Library.

6Percival Morton Pederson 1867-1945. See Noel & Geoff Pederson The Boy from Burra they called “Pompy”2012 in the Burra Library.

7 Bridget Joraslafsky nee Nugent c. 1967-1923. See Burra Record XXXXV, 27, 4 July 1923, page 4 for a report of the inquest.]

97, 22, 25 June 1975, page 8

Burra Bowling Club AGM

The report by retiring President Brian Riggs.

Two members died during the year: Lance Phillips and Hedley Pearce. Financially the year was a success, due in considerable measure to the bar manager Neil Hurst. The new watering system is now working well after a few initial hitches. Membership numbers leave a little to be desired. Facilities are being constantly improved. Keith Phillips was the Club Champion and also won the Mid North Champion of Champions at Auburn. The open tournaments in January and at Easter were a great success despite mediocre weather.

The Associates are an essential part of the club and their catering has been especially capably handled. The greens were reasonably good throughout and were good for Easter and the inter-divisional championships of the women’s Bowling Clubs. The purchase of a new mower will make the job of the Greens’ Manager Edgar Pietsch easier. Andrew Phillips had done good work preparing them for play and Wally Fridd is thanked for attending to the watering.

97, 23, 1 July 1975, page 1

The Citizenship Ceremony at the Town Hall on Thursday drew about fifty people. Mr & Mrs Derek Bos became Australian citizens. The Chairman of the District Council Mr Bill Brown welcomed visitors and handed the new citizens their certificates after they had repeated the Affirmation of Allegiance. The school Welfare Club provided supper. Mr & Mrs Bos live in Lewis Street.

The Country Party has decided not to contest the Seat of Frome at the next election, as it was felt that the sitting member Mr E.C. Allen ‘had been giving his best attention to the needs of the electorate’.

Rain is urgently needed. Frosts have prevailed and hand feeding of stock is widespread.

97, 23, 1 July 1975, pages 1 & 5

The Northern Fire Fighting Association will hold a special public meeting at the Soldiers’ Memorial Hall in Gladstone on 3 July. This is to discuss moves by the Fire Fighter’s Association to interfere with the present powers of Councils and with the present arrangements of the EFS and in the light of this all interested were urged to attend.

97, 24, 8 July 1975, page 1

Burra Scouts continue to prosper. Twelve passed tests to qualify them to ‘Meet the Chief’ and a Venture Group was formed at the beginning of the year led by Mr H. Groome.

Twenty-two Cubs attended their last meeting at the Show Hall.

Burra Burra DC. The supplementary election produced a turn-out of only 28%. Francis Robert Ford received 113 votes and Jeff Hirschausen 57.

97, 24, 8 July 1975, pages 1 & 4

Liberal Party. The Burra Women’s Branch AGM had Mrs Judy Roberts as guest speaker. Retiring President Mrs Ron Collins took the chair. Other guests included Hon. R. Geddes MLC, E.C. Allen MP and Hon. Ren de Garis MLC. The report concentrated on the dire peril of Australia’s slide into socialism under the Federal Labor Government and the activities of the local branch in the past year. Mrs Roberts’ speech was concerned with the role of SA in ‘becoming the pilot state for Socialism’ under Mr Dunstan. Elected were: President, Mrs Ron Pearse; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames Ron Collins and Tony Barker; Secretary, Mrs John Gordon and Treasurer, Mrs Charles O’Connor.

97, 24, 8 July 1975, page 2

Football

‘A’ Grade South Clare 17.13 defeated Burra 11.16

‘B’ Grade South Clare 14.10 defeated Burra 5.2

Senior Colts Burra 9.12 defeated South Clare 7.9

Junior Colts South Clare 11.12 defeated Burra 0.1

A letter to the editor expresses the writers’ extreme concerns about the disastrous course being pursued by the Federal Labor Government under Whitlam and the SA Labor Government under Dunstan and specifically against the escalation in pornography, easy divorce, increasing social service benefits and the general undermining of moral standards. Signatories were:

Sylvia Pearce M. Tiver Maureen Furst

Glenda Bailey Betty Cousins Jo. Quinn

Olive Holmes Melva McInnes Eileen McMahon

97, 24, 8 July 1975, page 6

97, 24, 8 July 1975, page 7

Tourists. There were 4,000 vans at the Burra Caravan Park for the past financial year. The $5,000 revenue compares with $2,000 for the previous year.

97, 25, 15 July 1975, page 1

Mr Chatterton Minister of Agriculture and Forests has denied that there are plans to turn the EFS into a single fire-fighting authority. The party State Conference called for a committee of enquiry into the most efficient way to provide fire safety standards throughout the state. While the EFS will be reorganised and a headquarters will be erected at Keswick, the present system of subsidising expenditure by EFS organisations and local governing authorities, on fire fighting equipment, will be continued. [The recent public meeting at Gladstone is reported at length.]

The Adult Secondary Education Assistance Scheme will encourage students to return to full-time matriculation level studies, with a maximum grant valued at $1,600 p.a. In 1976 matriculation classes in English, Maths, Physics, Chemistry, Biology, Geography and History will be offered at BHS.

Ambulance costs will rise from 1 September. Call-out from $20 to $24. Costs per km will stay the same for the next five months, but from 1 January 1976 will rise from 50c to $1 per km.

Rainfall has come in useful quantities this week: 32.8 mm.

A Ratepayers’ Meeting at the Burra Town Hall tomorrow night will be attended by Judge Gerald Ward of the Royal Commission into Local Government Areas and three other Commission members.

Medibank Community Liaison Officer Jack Ewins is visiting the Mid North to explain Medibank benefits and claiming procedures. He will be at T.W. Wilkinson’s at Burra on Thursday from 11 a.m. to 12.30 p.m.

SA Elections.

House of Assembly

Allen (Liberal) 1018

Reece (Labor) 395

Sara (Liberal Movement) 235

Legislative Council

Liberal 873

ALP 459

Liberal Movement 230

[Totals given in the paper are incorrect.]

97, 25, 15 July 1975, page 8

Obituary. Arthur L. Bence was born at Hampstead, London in 1892, the eldest of three children. Both parents died when he was about eight. His brother and sister went to live in Acton and he lived for the next three years with his maternal grandparents at Chiswick. When his grandfather died he applied in 1903 to become a Bernado’s Boy and was taken to a home near Whitechapel. He was trained as a bell-ringer and mandolin player and went on tour with fellow boy musicians to Southern England, Wales and the Channel Islands. On one tour when he was fourteen he met Olive Stringer and eleven years later they were married in Singapore Cathedral. In June 1908 a small party of Barnardo’s Boys led by Rev. W.J. & Mrs Mayers, with Mr Aarons as Musical Director, toured Australia to raise money for the Barnardo’s Homes. They arrived at Fremantle on 8 August 1908. They visited each state and New Zealand. A few weeks before the end of the tour Arthur, with the consent of Rev. Mayers, accepted the offer of a home and job in Melbourne. A few weeks later his employer lost the agency he had been running and Arthur had to fend for himself. He worked in Sydney for two years and then answered an advertisement to become a trader in the Solomon Islands in 1912. At that time he did not see another white face for months. Eventually a passing schooner picked him up from Guadalcanal when he was seriously ill from malaria, having been deserted by his native helpers, who said he had ‘devil-devil’. He was returned to Australia, where he recovered. Over the year he had kept in touch with the Stringer family and on his recommendation they had migrated to Victoria, where they had a grand reunion. He was still in no position to become engaged to Olive and he returned to the Solomon Islands in 1913 and continued to trade and recruit labour there till 1916. He then received news that his brother had been severely wounded in the war and he joined the Australian Forces. He arrived in Egypt early in 1916 and later went on to fight in France. In 1917 he was badly wounded and convalesced in England before being returned to Australia. On returning he became engaged to Olive Stringer. His wound had left him with only one usable arm. Being used to handling native labour, he decided to become a rubber planter in Malaya and sailed to Singapore in 1918. He got a plantation manager’s job with control of 250 coolies. He soon sent for Olive and they were married on Easter Saturday 1918. About eighteen months later, soon after the birth of their daughter Lotus, the rubber price plummeted from 5/- per pound to 6d per pound. Mrs Bence and Lotus returned to Australia and three months later Arthur followed. They settled in Burra where he became an auctioneer. He also travelled the eastern country selling goods and was soon able to start the business Bence’s Ltd, which still flourishes. The first sale at the Burra Auction Mart was on 7 September 1921. The Record reported that this innovation would be a boon to many people, as Mr Bence would be ‘prepared to submit to auction on any Friday, anything brought in from a sucking pig to an elephant’. They expected it to be an unqualified success.

By 1924 Bence’s – Burra’s Cash Drapery Store was established and they had a second child, Len, the store’s present manager. During WWII Len was stationed in England where he flew Wellington Bombers, returning safely with an English wife. Lotus married an Australian flying officer, who was killed by the Japanese in the Solomon Islands after his Catalina crashed. She remarried and now lives in Norway.

Through good and harsh times the store survived and both Arthur and Olive put much time and effort into its continuing success. Stories of personal generosity in the supply of clothing etc. to struggling families come from the depression days. They were both workers for charity. Despite the disability with his arm, Arthur was an accomplished tennis player and golfer. Many people will remember the beautiful Pearly King and Queen costumes Mr & Mrs Bence wore to fancy dress functions at times. Arthur also appeared as Father Christmas and made one novel entry to the RSL Hall when he descended to the floor hand over hand on a rope suspended from a skylight.

[This was a neat trick for a one-armed man!]

They retired in the early 1960s to Glenelg and remained there till Olive’s death a few years ago. [1971] Mr Stringer, her father, lived to be over 100 and only died in the last couple of years. Arthur returned to Burra to live in one of the Barker Cottage Homes before going to an Adelaide Nursing Home for a short time and dying there on 3 July. [2 July according to a previous report.] Father John Morley conducted the funeral in St Mary’s on 5 July. He is survived by a son, a daughter, four grandsons and one great-grandson.

[Arthur Leonard Bence born 15 October 1892 Hampstead, London: died 2 or 3 July 1975 Adelaide.]

97, 26, 22 July 1975, page 1

The Ratepayers’ Meeting last week drew a disappointing 34 people.

The Chairman gave his report and said despite State and Federal Government discussion, there had been no change in local government’s reliance on the unpopular land rating system of finance. A major expense in 1974-75 was the renovation of the Burra Swimming Pool. Revenue from the Caravan Park was pleasing. A project on hand was the tidying up of the Burra Creek, which will shortly fill with water. At Burra North a REDS funded project will see six new tennis courts available for 1975-76. Six other projects have been put to the REDS authorities. The Burra Golf Course will be improved by the development of the new clubhouse. State Government provided a grant of $12,450 towards this.

New Councillors for 1975-76 are:

Baldina Ward A.A. Barker

Booborowie Ward J.S .Hawker

Mt Bryan Ward A.J. Gebhardt

Burra Town Ward F.R. Ford

Re-elected Councillors are:

Burra Town Ward R.B. Jennison

Hanson Ward D.L .Lloyd

In the last fire season Council units attended more fires outside the district than in it. The Farrell Flat fire truck has been replaced with a cab chassis from Council plant.

Service certificates were presented to Mal. Kellock and Harry Quinn. Roy Jeffery was unable to be present.

Judge Ward then gave an address.

He agreed with the importance of recognising the service of Councillors, but said many Councils were grossly understaffed and at time job satisfaction was low. Changing communities also required some changes to Council boundaries. The main difficulty experienced by all Councils is funding.

One matter given some airing was a call by some ratepayers (supported by a petition) for part of the present Burra Burra Council to secede to Hallett.

Other topics raised centred upon weed control, the rubbish dump and fire bans for the next fire season.

Table Tennis. Annual Inter-Association Matches

‘A’ Grade North Eastern 36 games defeated Stanley 33 games (15 sets each)

‘B’ Grade Stanley 16 sets defeated North Eastern 14 sets

Rail Timetable

To Adelaide

To Burra

There will be consequent changes to mail times.

Obituary. Mary Jane Turnbull nee Morrison died 10 July in Adelaide, late of Daw Park and Burra. She was the wife of Daniel late of Mt Gambier aged 87. She was the mother of Jean, essie [sic], Laurel and Gordon and of the late Colin and Della. [‘essie’ is a misprint for Jessie. The deceased was born Mary Jane Morrison 18 May 1889 Kooringa and married Daniel Turnbull at Kooringa in 1912.]

The Lewis Family store at Hallett will close on 31 July after many years of business.

97, 27, 29 July 1975, page 1

Government Supplementary Grants for 1975-76 for District Councils have been announced. Allocations in the area are:

Meals on Wheels held its AGM at Burra Hospital 7 July

In the last year the organisation successfully supplied 3,408 meals. Mrs L. Jennison is the new staff officer and elected were: Chair, Mrs L.A. Phillips; Vice-Chair, Mrs A.M. Odgers and Treasurer, Mrs E.L. Clode.

The Art Gallery of SA Travelling Exhibition will visit Burra from 4-6 August at the Burra Town Hall.

The Arts Train is also coming. This is a four van travelling crafts workshop, which is visiting the South-East and Mid North, moved from siding to siding by passing goods trains. Crafts include pottery, jewellery making, photography and video work. The train will be in Burra 13-16 September.

A One-Day EFS Seminar will be held at Spalding 20 August. Topics for sessions include:

Hazardous Loads

Electrical Hazards

Fire Extinguishers

The Bush Fires Act

Forest Fires

House Fires

Burns and Eyes Injuries

97, 27, 29 July 1975, page 3

Advt. Burra Pictures, 2 August

Jim Brown & Christopher George in I Escaped from Devil’s Island

Advt. Burra Cold stores are buying rabbits.

Yorke Peninsula Field Days

New cradle and race crutching equipment to reduce the time, cost and effort of sheep crutching will be demonstrated at Kadina 19-21 August. The new system can increase output from 400-500 a day to 800-1,000 a day.

97, 27, 29 July 1975, page 7

Ian Auhl & Denis Marfleet’s new book Australia’s Earliest Mining Era: SA 1841-51 will be launched by Mr Warren Bonython on Monday at the Historical Museum of the SA Art Gallery. In conjunction with it there will be an exhibition of paintings by S.T. Gill, which are featured in the book.

Father Matthews is on long service leave and departs on Thursday for Johannesburg where he will attend the consecration of a friend to the office of Bishop. Father Phillips serves in Burra in his absence.

The Savings Bank of SA in Burra has had its interior altered and renovated.

Birth. To Carolyn & Syd Kuchel at Blyth last Sunday, a daughter, Sharyn Renee. Syd is the Lutheran Pastor at Blyth.

Marriage. St Peter’s College chapel last Saturday

Dr Geoffrey Pitcher, son of Dr & Mrs Russell Picher of Stonyfell & late of Burra, married Victoria Dean.

Geoffrey spent much of his childhood in Burra.

Marriage. In Surrey, England, Glenda Bidgood, former teacher at Mt Bryan, has married Rob Cook.

Obituary. Jack Fahey of Willalo died in Jamestown Hospital on Friday.

[A Return Thanks notice in 97, 32, 9 Sep. 1975, page 6 suggests this was Thomas John Fahey, which in turn suggests he was born 22 August 1893 near Spalding.]

97, 27, 29 July 1975, page 8

Burra Senior Rural Youth held its AGM 21 July and elected: President, Gary Earle; Secretary, John Brak and Treasurer, Hugh Greenhill.

97, 28, 5 Aug. 1975, page 1

The United Farmers & Graziers’ State Conference in Adelaide is reported at length.

The Anglican Diocese of Willochra is celebrating its Jubilee Year and visits to other parishes in the diocese have been arranged. Locals went to St Peter’s Winulta, near Maitland, on 29 June. On Friday at Burra there was a dinner dance and it is anticipated it will have raised c. $800. Visitors from Maitland attended a 10.30 Eucharist at St Mary’s at which Fr Neihus of Maitland preached. Dennis Nettleton played the organ. Lunch was held in the Parish Hall.

Ian Auhl & Denis Marfleet’s book Australia’s Earliest Mining Era is reviewed at length after its launch on 4 August by Warren Bonython at the SA Art Gallery. Reproduced in it are 31 paintings by S.T. Gill, of which 24 are in colour and 15 concern the Burra Mine and Township. The original paintings will be on display in the historical section of the SA Art Gallery in Adelaide for the next two months. There is a specially commissioned review by Hans Mincham, which is more an outline of the contents and the life of S.T. Gill than a critical appraisal of the volume – though what there is in that vein is full of praise.

The three are studying in Adelaide for a year as part of their training.

97, 28, 5 Aug. 1975, page 5

The Centenary of Parnaroo Hall will be celebrates by a ball there on 16 August, sponsored by the Hall Committee and the Parents & Friends’ Association of Peterborough’s St Joseph’s Convent School. The hall is a section of the previous Parnaroo Wool Shed, erected in 1875 of stone from the surrounding hills. It is on a section of Paratoo Station and Pandappa Station, leased by Thomas Elder – 719 square miles with 40,000 sheep. A portion of the homestead still stands about 400 yards northwest of the Hall. Local residents bought the Hall from the SA Government in 1904 for £400, since when it has been used for wedding receptions and dances. It was originally the wool room of the Parnaroo Station Shearing Shed, where 60 stands once operated. Shearers then started at 6 a.m. with breakfast at 8.30 a.m. by which time 1,000 sheep were shorn. The pay in 1875 was 20/- or £1 for 100 sheep. In 1880 the land was subdivided and sold for £1 per acre, but the land proved difficult for farming and finally the Government auctioned off 23 farms in 1893 and the 15,000 acres brought up to 2/41⁄2 per acre. Descendants of early settlers who remained in the area are the late William Just, August Hennig, William Neil, John O’Toole, Sam Saunders, Albert Gericke, Gustav Gruel, Martin O’Dea and Roland Betty. Two large families of old were Albert Gericke’s 13 children and John O’Toole’s 12 children. Early farmers reaped up to 40 bushels per acre and carted it to Ucolta to the train. In the early 1900s it is said up to 30,000 bags of wheat could be stacked there. Now there are just two remaining families; Mr & Mrs Roland Betty of Blue Hills Station and Mr & Mrs Flank Polomka of Parnaroo Pastoral Company. Government grants have enabled the installation of toilets in the hall and an annex on the front. The Centenary Ball will also feature entertainers from Peterborough and District, and will include the well known country singer Allen Graham of Terowie.

97, 28, 5 Aug. 1975, page 7

Birth. To Judy & John Morley Jnr on Saturday, a son, Christopher William, at Memorial Hospital, Adelaide. A fourth grandson for Rev. & Mrs Morley of Burra.

Police Changes in Burra. Ken and Lorraine Graetz go to Pt Pirie and Noel and Jan Saxby come from Pt Augusta.

Notice. The Kapunda Musical Society will stage Die Fledermaus at the Burra Town Hall 23 August.

97, 29, 12 Aug. 1975, page 1

C.M. Lewis & Sons’ shop at Hallett closed on 31 July, ending a life which had begun in 1912, when Fred Lewis, the father of the last owner, Mr Alf Lewis, began the Lewis Bakery. Mr Lewis Sen. was an Englishman who migrated from Malmsbury in Wiltshire in 1910 and after working in Farrell’s Flat, Broken Hill and elsewhere, arrived in Hallett in 1912. After his marriage in 1913 he and his English wife spent the rest of their lives in the business. At first the break etc. was sold from the bakehouse, but in the 1920s the old coaching stables, where the northern coaches changed horses in the early days, were demolished and the present substantial shop and attached house was constructed. Lewis’s delivered bread to the four shops that were then in Mt Bryan and also two or three times a week to Petherton, Canowie, Willalo and North Booborowie. In the 1920s there were several grocery stores in Hallett, including Harris’s General Store (later W. Phin’s and now part of the Hall’s family residence). On the site of the present road-house was a saddler’s shop owned by Alex Davy of Terowie and the grocery shop of John Doyle. Drew & Crewe’s were in the property now held by Seigert Bros. Mrs McCrae kept a greengrocer’s shop and refreshment rooms on the property of Mr & Mrs Bill Reed. There was a butcher shop owned by George Trussler, recently deceased, on the site of the present fire station. South of the crossroads was Statton’s Blacksmith, Welding & Wheelwright’s business, employing seven men. It closed in the late 1950s. Near the railway station was another butcher’s owned by the Carpenter family, adjacent to the first Hallett Hotel, demolished in the early 1970s. In the 1930s Depression Lewis’s delivered ration bread to the gold miners at Ulooloo. After the death of Mr Fred Lewis his widow and sons Alf and Arthur took over. As the Hallett township declined and it became increasingly difficult to get relief bakers, the family ceased baking in the mid 1960s and obtained its bread from Burra. Alf continued to make pasties and cakes until ill health forced him to close his business. In recent years he has been assisted by his sister Gladys Mrs Bob Slatter and his brother Arthur and his family.

Dr L.G. Miller writes in reply to Mr Banfield’s recent statements about ‘wicked doctors who are denying patients their “fundamental rights.”’ He opposed the dictatorship from petty bureaucrats that he clearly believed had come with Medibank.

The [Methodist] Ladies’ Guilds of the Middle District converged on Burra on 7 August for a rally that combined the Home and Overseas Missions. About 200 attended at Burra Methodist Church. Mrs E. Hore managed proceedings and Rev. G. O’Neil, Middle District Chairman, conducted morning devotions. Speakers included Mrs Gore (President of WHMA), Rev. Dean Brookes (on Inland Mission work), Rev. Ponciale’o of Samoa and Deaconess E. Simmons on Ba Hospital in Fiji.

97, 29, 12 Aug. 1975, page 7

Birth. To Monica & Andrew Scholz at Burra Hospital 5 August, a daughter, Tanya Maree.

Obituary. Mr Jack Webster died at the hospital yesterday aged 88.

[John Michael Stewart Webster born 17 January 1888 Pt Germein. A legal notice in 97, 37, 15 Oct. 1975, page 3 says he was a retired farm labourer of 25 Smelts Road.]

Len & Muriel Bence have returned to their London base after a two week holiday on the Amalfi Coast of Italy.

The Rt Rev. Bruce Rosier Bishop of Willochra visited Burra on Sunday. While here he did the Dare’s Hill trip.

Father Burke of Sevenhill writes to say that the centenary of their church occurs on 12 October 1975. He recently received a letter about Fr Pallhuber, who came from Austria in 1856 and journeyed extensively in the north from 1860-1880. Despite a rather severe look in a photograph, he is described as being kindly, witty, interesting and entertaining and was well regarded by those of other faiths. He spent a lot of time visiting remote shepherds, prospectors, miners etc. and often had to sleep out in winter in wet clothes. His horse sometimes headed for home without him – once leaving him to return 15 miles and on another occasion 100 miles.

Golf. Burra Club

‘A’ Grade Championship was won by Stan Longford.

‘B’ Grade Championship went to Paul Boucher.

‘C’ Grade Championship was won by Dean Bogisch.

97, 30, 19 Aug. 1975, page 1

Burra Burra DC

The rate was declared at 2c in the dollar compared with 1.8c for 1974-75. This was largely to accommodate inflation. The minimum rate payable for a property in the Townships of Burra, Mt Bryan, Booborowie and Farrell Flat is $40. Outside those the minimum rate payable is $15. The differential rate has been declared at 10c in the dollar for all towns including Hanson, bringing town rates to the maximum possible 12c. This has followed a further reduction in State grants for road works. A grant from the Grants Commission in Canberra of $20,000 is one bright spot in the gloom.

Rev. John Morley writes in support of Dr Miller and in opposition to the increasing power of the State.

Mr Allen MP speaking in Parliament, said that in areas controlled by the Commonwealth Railways people wished they were under the SAR for its better service, but in SAR areas people thought the Commonwealth did it better. He was concerned about railway workers’ housing. He was afraid Peterborough’s railway workshops would be relocated to Pt Augusta to the detriment of the town and the Premier can offer no assurance that with the transfer of SAR to Commonwealth this will not happen. The Town Clerk of Peterborough has, however, received an assurance from the Premier that there is a provision ‘that there should be no reduction in the level of employment of railway workshops, without prior agreement with the State Government.

97, 30, 19 Aug. 1975, page 2

97, 30, 19 Aug. 1975, page 5

Burra Branch of MBHA AGM. President Helen Stockman reported on the year’s activities. Life membership was awarded to Mrs E.T. Baulderstone. There has been a successful year, but average attendance is declining and attendance has varied from 6 to 16.

Burra North Red Cross AGM. Mrs R. Steele was appointed Secretary for 1975-76. The branch was registered on 17 July 1941 and the late Mrs Frank Sara was the first President for two years.

From 1943-1965 [Mrs Reta Jennison] was President and she also served as Secretary from 1971-75.

Mrs I. Hirschausen was President 1965-75.

Mrs S. Scroop has been Treasurer for 32 years and was re-elected for another 12 months.

Secretaries have come and gone, including Mesdames M. Miels, V. Knight, T. Reed, R. Reed, J .Henderson, R. Thamm and E. Heinrich. Auditors have been the late A.B. Riggs, T. Brazil and for the last 32 years Mr A.L. Clode.

97, 30, 19 Aug. 1975, page 7

A first grandchild for Mr & Mrs Joe Phillips of Booborowie.

Birth. To Eileen & John Quinn of Mt Bryan at Calvary Hospital on Friday, a son, Matthew Joseph.

Obituary. Charles Henry Hawke (Charlie), formerly of Burra, died at Elliston Hospital 8 August aged 63. He is survived by his widow Jean, stepson Robert, sons Evan and Leon and daughter Raelene Mrs Graham Waters of Burra. [Born Charles Henry Symonds Hawke 19 May 1913 Adelaide.]

Obituary. Margaret Meers of Hallett died last Monday. She is survived by her husband Jim and young son Andrew.

Frank Marston

The Mount Barker Courier has an article saying that its Chairman of Directors Mr Frank Marston published his first newspaper fifty years ago on 12 August 1925 when with one employee, Mr Eric Angel, now of the Burra Record, he published the Eudunda Courier & Murray Flats Advertiser. Later he came to Burra and in 1952 went to Mt Barker, where he still takes an active interest in the business.

Netball

A1 South Clare 40 defeated Burra 30

A2 Burra forfeited to South Clare

B1 Burra 42 defeated South Clare 37

B2 South Clare 49 defeated Burra 41

C1 South Clare 40 defeated Burra 28

Junior 2 Burra 18 defeated South Clare 9

Burra Gold Club’s Open Day is reported.

97, 30 (2), 26 Aug. 1975, page 1

Geoff Searle takes issue with Rev. Morley over the latter’s definition of Man’s fundamental rights.

Football. As runner-up to the Mail Medal winner, J. Wallace of South Clare, M. Wanganeen [of Blyth] wins the Record trophy for the second time, having won it first in 1973.

In the ‘B’ Grade the winner was Colin Hall of Booborowie-Hallett and Andrew Spackman of Burra won the trophy for Senior Colts.

Obituary. Rudolph Launer died at his home near Robertstown suddenly on 19 August aged 71. He was the son of the late Mr & Mrs Gustav Launer of Emu Downs. His father died 69 years ago on 1 August, leaving his mother to raise a large family. All his siblings except Mr Fred Launer of Robertstown had predeceased Rudolph.

[Despite the above age being sited, he was Fredrich Rudolph Bernhard Launer, born 23 October 1898 Emu Downs.]

97, 30 (2), 26 Aug. 1975, page 2

Burra Burra DC, 11 August

Crs Jennison & Phillips moved that the Council advise adjoining owners it intends to declare Mary Crescent a public road. Carried.

Hanson Soldiers’ Memorial Hall Committee accepts the lease on the parklands at Hanson for the next three years.

The Fire Brigades Board offers the old Diamond T to the Council.

Road Closures:

The road dividing Block 13A & pt Block 13 of GRO Plan 20 of 1905 from Pt Section 1 Hd Kooringa is to be closed and the land vested in the Minister of Education. [This road ran along the front of the school.]

Birth. To Margaret & Bob Williams at Ashford Community Hospital 19 August, a son, Mark.

Bob is with the National Bank in Burra.

Birth. To Barry & Christine Hodges nee Finch at Glenelg Community Hospital 19 August, a daughter, Arleta Renee. She is a first grandchild for Ann & Aub Finch of Burra.

Obituary. Mr Linley M. (Len) Gordon of Glenelg and formerly of Burra died suddenly 18 August aged 84.

[Linley Matheson Gordon born 1 January 1891 Glenelg – the ‘Linly’ on the SA Births CD is probably a mistake.]

Obituary. Mrs Vera Collins died at Burra Hospital on Friday aged 80. She was the mother of Mrs Rex Opperman.

[Headstone says Vera May Collins died 22 August 1975.]

Fr John Morley leaves Burra early next week to become Rector of the Anglican Parish of Mt Barker.

Die Fledermaus attracted a smaller audience than it deserved. Those who attended thoroughly enjoyed it.

97, 31, 2 Sep. 1975, page 6

Notice. ETSA offers $300 reward for information leading to a conviction of vandals who damaged a 19,000 volt SWER insulator by rifle fire on 30-31 August on the Mongolata Road east of Baldina Station.

Notice. Porter’s Lagoon Progress Association AGM in Farrell Flat Hall 8 September.

Notice. Savings Bank of SA calls tenders for repainting and repairs to its Burra Branch and Manager’s Residence.

Obituary. Alfred (Mick) Jones, husband of Dorothy Eileen of Mt Bryan, died 1 September in hospital aged 70. He was the father of Dawn, David, Pauline, Harold, Winston, Michael and Robert.

[Born 13 March 1905 Millerton (Burra).]

97, 31, 2 Sep. 1975, page 7

Birth. To Chris & Clive Ball of Farrell Flat last week, a son, Andrew Phillip.

Obituary. Miss Nell Thomas of Adelaide and formerly of Willalo died 27 August aged 66.

Ian McGrath who spent part of his youth in Burra and is a son of Sergeant and Mrs Fred McGrath, now of Stirling Police Station, has written a play Sonny, premiering in Sydney’s Ensemble Theatre 11 September.

The film matinee on Friday last for the Burra Kindergarten raised $163.

Vandalism to the insulators on the power line on the Mongolata Road cut power to eastern consumers for six hours last Sunday.

97, 32, 9 Sep. 1975, page 1

Burra Mine. Poseidon Directors say that due to low copper prices and falling demand, operations in Burra have had to be curtailed. They have been reduced from seven to five days a week and twenty employees have been retrenched. The effect on the town will be widespread.

Burra Burra DC. The Council is concerned about the Burra Mine retrenchments and will seek Government aid in providing employment.

It is also concerned about the changing ratio of Government grant money to rates as the former falls. Rates have risen 10% and Council feels any greater rise would bring considerable difficulties to the rural sector. Roadwork grants have fallen by $11,000. A more equitable funding formula is needed.

Kooringa Methodist Ladies’ Guild celebrates its 50th birthday next Wednesday.

The State Government has increased the Emergency Fire Services maintenance grants to Local Government Councils from $2,000 to a maximum of $4,000. The EFS is angry at the delay in EFS reorganisation and in building a new headquarters.

97, 32, 9 Sep. 1975, page 2
