97, 32, 9 Sep. 1975, page 3

Advt. Burra Pictures, 13 September

William Smith & Tony Young in Chrome and Hot Leather

Richard Thomas & Mary Lane in Cactus in the Snow

97, 32, 9 Sep. 1975, page 7

Obituary. Mrs Hilda A. Earle of Burra died on Saturday aged 86.

[Born Hilda Acacia Brook. Died 6 September 1975.]

The Burra Creek Lake is a reality at last.

97, 33, 16 Sep. 1975, page 1

Burra Burra Hospital Inc. AGM

Frank Ford and Allan Baulderstone were welcomed as Members of the Board of Management.

Chairman R.K. Parse read the 98th report of the hospital.

Financially the hospital is very sound. A credit of $60,000 is invested. Expenses rose 71% and receipts by 63%. Bed cost rose by $5 to $22.46. We were able to show a surplus of $59,298.

Improvements included air conditioning the Nurses Home and a carport there and a new piano. TV sets were placed in private rooms and handrails in toilets and bathrooms. The Secretary’s residence was renovated. The hospital’s interior was renovated and repainted. Average daily patient numbers rose to a record 27.8 and 24 babies were born. The auxiliary has maintained linen etc. and restocked the storeroom with jams and preserves. In the year we lost the services of Sister Goode as tutor, to be replaced by Sister Wall. After ten years the Secretary-Manager Mr L.H. Packer resigned on 30 June and his place has been taken by Mr Hank Heitbrink.

Meals on Wheels has continued to operate efficiently.

Porter’s Lagoon Progress Association held its 1st AGM, bur attendance was disappointing. Chairman Leo Robinson was re-elected, with G. Webster as Vice-Chairman and J. Bowden as Secretary-Treasurer. Weed control in the Lagoon is a problem that will be monitored. A film on the 1975 Porter’s Lagoon Spectacular was shown.

Burra Burra DC

The Council has no present intentions of cutting its workforce.

The Golf clubhouse is almost finished and has now to be paid for – though half comes from grants and much from the club itself.

REDS work has taken funds that will later be repaid.

An appeal for funds from the National Estate has been forwarded to the Government to enable completion of the restoration of the Powder Magazine and work on the Bon Accord Mine Engineer’s Shop, along with further work on the dugouts, Brewery Cellars and Redruth Gaol.

Local Ladies on the Melbourne Cup Fund Raising Committee have offered to help contribute towards a new piano for the Town Hall.

Burra Golf Club

The new clubhouse will be opened on 28 September at 4 p.m. Four years ago Council acquired the Racecourse and Elder’s Paddock to develop into a recreation area. Following an offer and request from Council the Golf Club undertook an ambitious plan to redesign the golf course and erect a new clubhouse. The services of the SA Golf Association’s architect Mr Murray Crafter were employed. The new course was opened for the 1973 season. A tree planting program then initiated is continuing; 100 trees are now growing and another 400 are planned. A grant to partly fund the clubhouse was obtained from the State Government’s Parks and Reserves Committee. Foundations were laid last May and completion will be in the next two weeks. The Savings Bank of SA has granted a $9,000 loan to complete the project.

97, 33, 16 Sep. 1975, page 3

Advt. Burra Pictures, 20 September

For Pete’s Sake

Brother John

Methodist Rendezvous between members of Burra Methodist Circuit and the Hope Valley & Tea Tree Gully Churches took place last weekend. Redruth Hall was filled for the rally on Saturday night, led by Graham Hore, with Rev. Horrie Dunkin as speaker. Visitors were billeted in district homes and took part in services at Farrell Flat and Mt Bryan and in a study group at Booborowie as well as in a service at Burra.

World’s End Methodist Church services have had to be cancelled for the time being.

97, 33, 16 Sep. 1975, page 6

Notice of a Pet-a-thon on 18 September by the Burra Junior RSPCA Branch. (A walk and street parade.)

97, 33, 16 Sep. 1975, page 7

Rains have fallen in Burra to bring the month’s total to 47 mm. To the east falls have ranged from 60 points at Thistlebeds to 204 points at Pulpara.

Russell Campbell, formerly of Burra, was runner-up in this year’s Brunei Open Golf Championship; coming second by one stroke. He also won the Tun Mustapha Cup at his ‘home’ club at Kota Kinabalu in Sabah.

Ian Tiver was installed as Worshipful Master of Hallett Masonic Lodge on 10 September.

Birth. To Lyn & Noel Cousins of Booborowie at Burra Hospital 10 September, a son, Matthew Joseph.

Obituary. Mr Horace B. James of Burra died last week aged 67.

[Horace Burton James born 24 February 1908 Kooringa.]

Alf & Barbara Sanders are retiring from Mt Bryan Hotel soon to their property at Riverton.

Redruth Gaol. A great-great granddaughter of Thomas Perry, the first gaoler at Redruth Gaol, visited Burra recently. Her great grandfather was the first person born at the gaol.

97, 33, 16 Sep. 1975, page 8

Burra Tennis Association held its AGM and reported a successful year. There were 8 ‘A’ teams, 12 ‘B’ teams and 7 junior teams for 1975-76. Elected: President, Alistair Murray (Hallett); Vice-Presidents, G. Matters (Spalding) & John Lucas (Hallett) and Secretary, Margaret Hillman (Mt Bryan).

Junior Colts, the President’s Trophy for Best & Fairest to Konrad Bettison (United)

Albert Bannear was given Life Membership of the League and also received a Merit Award from SANFL for 40 years’ Service to Country Football.

97, 34, 23 Sep. 1975, page 1

Barker of Baldina Aged Cottage Homes. The difficult economic circumstances have caused a deferral of Government funding and so additional units have been deferred until at least July 1976.

Adelaide Wool Sale No. 2 is reported with local prices cited.

The Copper Industry. The Industries Assistance Commission has been asked for advice on whether the Government should provide assistance to the industry in view of rising production costs and low copper prices.

97, 34, 23 Sep. 1975, pages 1 & 6

Eastern District Fire Fighting Organisation held its annual meeting at Koomooloo on Wednesday. Chairman Don Lord welcomed visitors, especially Fred L. Kerr Director of the EFS and his Assistant Tony Kaye and National Parks & Wildlife Officer John Fitzgerald. He said the fire risk is high this year. The meeting supported the recommendations of the working party on country fire service re-organisation. From 1 November 1974 to 25 February 1975 thirteen fires were attended to though only five were in the immediate area. Radios had proved effective. Don Lord was re-elected Chairman. Two Traeger SSB 50 radio transceivers will be bought to give greater coverage. At present the district covers 30 properties and 25 members. It was recommended that the organisation becomes incorporated. Ironically it was raining during the meeting, but the accompanying lightning reminded all that most of last season’s fired had been caused by lightning and in SA such fires had burnt out nearly 31,000 km2.

Advt. Elders-GM will offer for sale a portion of Koonoona Station in 14 convenient sized blocks at Burra Institute 22 October. The lots vary from 13.7 ha to 293 ha. Koonoona was originally taken up in 1856. Annual average rainfall for over 100 years is 466 mm or 18.63 inches. [Details occupy 3⁄4 column.]

Advt. Burra Pictures, 27 September

Sidney Poitier & Barbara McNour in The Organisation

97, 34, 23 Sep. 1975, page 8

The Tiver Reunion

A reunion of descendants of James Tiver, who was born 11 June 1929, will be held at Burra 12 October.

James was the son of a baker, Hugh Tiver and his wife Rebecca of Bristol, England. Hugh died young and James received little education, going to work aged 8 as an apprentice mason. He married Elizabeth South of Newport and with a young son, James Hugh (then under 2) sailed from Plymouth in the David Malcolm. A daughter, Margaret Malcolm Tiver, was born on the voyage. They arrived at Port Adelaide in April 1855 and were met by an uncle, James Rosser. They came to Burra by bullock dray and James erected a wattle and daub hut near the ford1 where Mr & Mrs Roy Jeffery now live. Elizabeth died in 1856 and in 1858 James married Emma Price, who had come to SA in 1856 in the Alloquis. From this marriage there were ten children. James did contracting work and also did carting to and from Port Adelaide. He built the middle house in Tiver’s Row in Redruth and it was there that most of the children were born. Later with Emma’s help he added the houses either side to create Tiver’s Row. In 1870 he built the house and store at Aberdeen2 and the family then lived there. Emma and step-son James Hugh Tiver kept the store and James continued with contract work, employing as many as 100 men. He participated in the construction of the Wallaroo Smelting Works. James said it was cheaper to cart beer from Port Adelaide than water for the men at Wallaroo. With Mr Thomas Burgoyne MP and Mr Aaron Cole he built the first macadamised roads in the district, the Aberdeen Ford, the Redruth Bridge3, the original Burra Institute, Burra Railway Station and Yards, the Stationmaster’s residences, from Tarlee to Farrell Flat and many private homes. When the railway was extended to Hallett in 1876 he opened a branch store there and James Hugh then ran the Hallett Store and became a Councillor and Chairman of the Hallett DC at various times. James Hugh Tiver died aged 434.

Later James had a large plant at Terowie for building the new railway yard there for the line to continue to Petersburg. James also bought land; first Mt Cone at Mt Bryan for £1 per acre. He sold this and bought country at McVitties Flat near Hallett, which he later sold and bought Harry’s, Opie’s and Gare’s farms at ‘Banbury’ Hallett.

In 1888 and later James and his sons purchased and were allotted pastoral leases when the Government cut up the old Paratoo Run and so they founded ‘Pats Well’, later to become ‘Tiverton’. James was a member of the Kooringa5 Corporation, a Superintendent of the Sunday School and office bearer in the Methodist Church for many years. He was also a JP and member of both the Masonic and Oddfellows Lodges for many years. Despite a long hard struggle against drought, James eventually became a prosperous pastoralist. He died 12 March 1909. Emma lived until 1926 and died aged almost 90. She was always a very active support for James and once when he urgently needed supplies at Wallaroo, she packed quickly and made the journey there in a bullock dray with some of the young family. With no accommodation on arrival they erected an ‘instant cottage’ in one day. The children of Emma and James were:

Mary Ann (Mrs [Edward Francis] Opie) Albert Joseph (who died as a child) [aged 3]

Charles Godwin George Samuel

Emma Price [Mrs John Sara] Charlotte Dunn [Mrs Arthur Stock]

Edgar Henry (Harry)

Emily Price6 [Mrs Arthur Sara] Harold Walter

[Notes:

1In Young Street.

2Tiver’s Railway Store, later known as Sara’s Store on the corner of Young and Morehead Streets.

3This was the 1861 timber bridge. Tiver & Cole contracted for the masonry abutments. By 1878 the timbers had rotted and it was replaced by a steel bridge in 1879. It is possible that the original abutments were retained, but further research would be needed to verify that.

4James Hugh Tiver 3 June 1853-10 April 1896; making him 42 at death.

5This was actually the Burra Corporation or Town Council of Burra. James Tiver was the Councillor for North Ward December 1883 to November 1887.

6The ‘Price’ is probably an error; it is not added in any of the birth, marriage or death registrations.]

97, 35, 30 Sep. 1975, page 1

Burra Tourist Promotion Committee Annual Meeting

The meeting failed either to elect a new Chairman or to find a new Secretary. Messrs Jennison and Scott have retired after fine service. A further effort to replace them will be made on 18 November.

R. Jennison reported on the year.

The Copper festival in 1974 contributed about $2,500 to the committee’s finances. We contributed $500 to the Welcome to Burra sign at the southern entrance to Burra and I hope you are gratified with the result. Areas needing future attention are to increase the caravan accommodation and facilities and the development of the area around the Burra Creek Lake. The finances of the committee are a healthy $4,988.85. Other projects considered were the floodlighting of Johnny Green and additional facilities at the War Memorial Oval.

[The report included the usual thanks to those who had contributed.]

North Eastern International Rules Basketball Association

Elected: President, C. Reed; Vice-President, R. Bailey and Secretary-Treasurer, R. Schwartz.

Burra Golf Club

The new clubhouse was opened on Sunday when about 300 people attended in fine weather. A large field of 116 players took part in Foursomes prior to the ceremony. Mr Baulderstone welcomed visitors and said the services of the SA Gold Association Architect Mr Murray Crafter were obtained for the design of the new course opened at the start of the 1873 season. Attention then turned to tree planting and the building of the new clubhouse. The club is indebted to the District Council for the site levelling and road work. Congratulations were extended to D.T. Jacka & Co. for producing such a fine building. Thanks also went to Associate members for their helpfulness throughout the year. Mr Claude Allen MP said a few congratulatory words and Mr W. Brown as Chairman of the District Council opened the clubhouse. The State Government had made a grant of $12,300 and the Savings Bank of SA had given a loan of $9,000 repayable by the club and the club had contributed $4,000 and a great deal of time in planning and much voluntary labour. A lavish afternoon tea followed.

97, 35, 30 Sep. 1975, page 2

Advt. Burra Pictures, 4 October

Dean Jones & Nancy Olsen in Snowball Express

Plus Yellowstone Cubs

97, 35, 30 Sep. 1975, page 3

Football

The four Mid North Clubs have received a letter from the Secretary of the North Eastern Football League Mr John Ward, inviting them to join the North Eastern League in 1976. During 1975 the long established Mid North League was reduced to four active clubs when Auburn and Aberdeen withdrew. The move to amalgamate the two leagues started some years ago. The Secretary of the Mid North League will shortly advise member clubs to hold meetings so that a firm decision can be made by the end of October to enable adequate time for planning the 1976 season.

97, 35, 30 Sep. 1975, page 5

The World’s End Methodist Church service planned for next Sunday has been cancelled.

Burra Primary School held a Petathon, which is reported in c. 11⁄4 columns.

97, 35, 30 Sep. 1975, page 6

Peter & Gladys Hall will be tendered a farewell tea at Leighton Hall on Sunday 5 October.

Advt. Mt Bryan Hotel is under new management by Connie & Lindsay Davidson. Come and try the $1.00 counter meals and the Saturday Smorgasbord Dinner.

97, 35, 30 Sep. 1975, page 7

Wayne Clarke, manager of Southern Farmers’ will leave soon with his wife and family to live in Adelaide. He was farewelled on Friday night by his RSL friends.

Coral & Jim Murphy are retiring from Hallett to live in Jamestown.

Cycle Race. Last Saturday the annual Burra to Adelaide Cycle Race was held, but with so little fanfare that we didn’t notice it and are unaware of the winner.

97, 35, 30 Sep. 1975, page 8

Kooringa Methodist Ladies’ Guild celebrated its Golden Jubilee in the Church Hall on 17 September, amidst thunder, lightning and squally showers. A large number of past members returned for the occasion. Mrs E. Baulderstone made the cake, which was iced by Mrs Zanker and was cut by long-time members Mrs R. Jennison, Mrs Nell Pearce and Mrs Dick Smith. Eighty-seven-year-old Mrs Kellock, who attended, was a foundation member. There was a program of entertainment and a delicious afternoon tea. Among returning members were Essie Morrison, Betty Palmer and Joyce Martin. Proceeds were $107.61.

97, 36, 7 Oct. 1975, page 3

Advt. Elders-GH have instructions from Koonoona Proprietors to auction 2075 ha or 5,127 acres, being portions of the historic Koonoona Station, in 14 conveniently sized lots at Burra Institute 22 October.

1,511 ha south of Koonoona Homestead in 9 lots with frontages to the old Burra-Adelaide Road and to Robertstown Road. Also 555.3 ha at the northern end of Koonoona and 8.5 km south of Burra, in four lots with frontages to the old Burra-Adelaide Road and Springbank Road. And 8.9 ha of perpetual lease in one paddock on the Main Adelaide-Burra Road adjacent to Hanson Siding.

Obituary. David Lambert aged 18 died as a result of XXX at home last week. He appeared in the Auburn Players production of Up the Wakefield.

Gladys & Peter Hall were farewelled at Leighton on Sunday. They and their children are going to live and share farm near Cummins.

Kooringa Masonic Lodge. Tony Thomas of Mt Bryan will be one of the youngest Worshipful Masters ever when he is installed at the Kooringa lodge tonight.

97, 37, 15 Oct. 1975, page 1

Burra Schools Conference will be held next week to address policies and trends in education. Topics:

Policies and Trends (Dr J. Mayfield)

Continuous Intake (Miss A. Farrow)

Open Education (Mr J. Giles)

Organisation within an Area and Flexible Plan School (Mr H. Harris)

Religious Education (Mr D. Beck)

Plus discussion groups.

Burra Bowls season 1975-76 is about to commence with a social mixed bowls on Sunday 19 October at 2 p.m. President Brian Riggs extends an invitation to all.

Freedom From Hunger Campaign doorknocks will be held on 19 October and volunteer collectors are asked to assemble at RSL Hall by 1 p.m.

97, 37, 15 Oct. 1975, pages 1 & 5

Burra’s 98th Show was a Success. [If was in fact far short of the 98th Show; The first show was in 1877, but the society had gone into recess from 1886-93 and during WWII 1940-45 and was also cancelled in 1897 and 1914 due to seasonal conditions.]

The 1975 show was a success with gate takings of $856, which compared well with 1974’s $1,046, when it coincided with the Copper festival. President Ron Shipard introduced Hon. Dr Hopgood to open the event. Much of the success is due to the Secretary Mr Darrell Field. Entries were good, especially in Horses in Action, Wool, Fruit & Vegetables, Flowers and Birds. The Sheep Pavilion was full. Dogs were re-introduced and attracted good entries. The food and drink stalls have been updated. The display of modern farming equipment was bigger and better than ever. In the Miss Show Girl Contest the Open Winner was Miss Susan Kotz of Burra, the Junior Winner was Susan Towle and the Sub-Junior Winner was Janet Durling.

Page 5 reviews the following sections with judges’ comments: School Work, Sheep Shearing, Sideshows, Horses in Action, Art, Bantams & Budgerigars, Cattle, Cooking, Dogs, Flowers, Floral Arts, Goats, Grain & Fodder, Handicrafts, Needlework, Fruit & Vegetables, Produce Preserves, Pets, Sheep, Pol Rams, Medium Wool, Wool and Lapidary.

The licensed dance at night was arranged by the Rural Youth Club in the Town Hall with music by the ‘Tremulos’. The Motor Cycle trials were cancelled due to insufficient entries.

97, 37, 15 Oct. 1975, page 2

Advt. Elders-GM will hold its annual Commercial Ewe Sale on Friday 17 October when it will offer 10,000 sheep.

97, 37, 15 Oct. 1975, page 3

Burra Tennis Club. The new tennis courts will be opened on 19 October by the Patron Mr Robert Reed. They have been erected by the efforts of the Burra Burra DC, RED Scheme and the Burra Tennis Club. Top players from Adelaide will give demonstration matches.

Burra Cubs met at the Gorge 5 October. Their next meeting 17 October at the Show Hall.

97, 37, 15 Oct. 1975, page 5

The Lapidary Field Club will visit the Cowell jade deposit and the Iron Knob-Whyalla area 8-9 November.

97, 37, 15 Oct. 1975, page 6

Advt. Southern Farmers will auction 4000 sheep on 22 October.

Road Work. Two kilometres of road between Point Pass and Robertstown is being closed for reconstruction and is expected to re-open 19 December.

97, 37, 15 Oct. 1975, page 7

Sharon Betty, last year’s Burra Show Girl, has won this year’s Miss SA Quest.

Tiver Family Reunion. About 300 attended the reunion on Sunday in the Burra Town Hall. The oldest member present was Mrs Netley Sumner of Hallett (79) and the youngest Justin Tiver of Adelaide (8 weeks).

Wayne Clarke of Southern Farmers has been transferred to the city and is replaced by Kevin Kleinig.

Mr & Mrs Cec. Edwards and girls have moved to Burra after many years at Baldina.

The local Kindergarten Committee organised a Saturday barbecue and barn dance at Dutton’s Trough.

Andrew, Wendy & Scott Bence are going to live at Windarra, WA, this week.

97, 37, 15 Oct. 1975, page 8

Burra Golf Associates held their AGM 6 October and elected: President, Mrs N. Finch; Senior Vice-President, Mrs J. Gordon; Junior Vice-President, Mrs C. Neill; Secretary, Mrs M. Nicholls; Treasurer, Mrs D. Martin; Captain, Mrs J. Oates and Vice-Captain, Mrs E. Jeffery. There are 36 members and the Secretary reported a successful year with the opening of the new clubhouse as the outstanding event.

97, 38, 21 Oct. 1975, page 1

Elders-GM Annual Commercial Ewe Sale cleared 8,271 of the 8,816 yarded and prices were up on recent Northern Areas sales. [Prices are printed.]

Burra Bowling Season was opened last Sunday by Arthur Kench, President of the Mid North Bowls Association. He was introduced by Burra President Brian Riggs. Mr Kench favours changing the arrangements so that there would be eight sides in Division 1; one from each club now playing and a second from each of the two larger clubs, Clare and Burra. Then an 8 side 2nd Division and all others in 3rd Division, with relegation of the bottom sides in divisions and the promotion of top sides.

Burra Burra DC

Work is being delayed by slow payment of rates.

Brian Thamm continues as President of the Burra Swimming Pool Committee following their AGM on 2 October. John Brak is Treasurer and Mrs E. Carpenter is Secretary. The pool will open on 1 November subject to favourable weather. [Details of prices and times are printed.]

The Porter’s Lagoon Progress Association has asked that By-law XV limiting vehicle speeds in the reserve be enforced.

Application has been made to borrow $3,000 to re-seal a number of the town’s streets.

The Council has approved the printing of the tourist booklet Burra Historic Tour. At present only the cover is printed and the rest done on the Council’s duplicator.

Chairman Cr Brown will place a wreath on the War Memorial on 11 November.

Councillors are invited to the opening of the new tennis courts in Burra on Sunday.

Burra Apex Club will place barbecues in the Burra North Playground and renew seating there. The old seats have been filched for firewood over the years. They intend eventually to renovate other equipment there.

Stray sheep and cattle remain a problem and it has been decided to employ a pound-keeper.

Ian Auhl’s new book Burra & District a Pictorial Memoir will be launched at Baldina Homestead on 9 November by Dame Nancy Buttfield. Matron Mary Holden of the Girls’ Reformatory was Dame Nancy’s great grandmother. The grounds of the historic homestead will be open to the public from 1.30 p.m. to 5 p.m. Admission $1. Arrangements have been made by the National Trust.

97, 38, 21 Oct. 1975, page 3

Advt. Open Day at Baldina Station 9 November 1.30-5 p.m. for the launching of Ian Auhl’s new book Burra & District – A Pictorial Memoir.

Obituary. Mrs M. Symons, widow of the late Owen Symons, died recently at Westbourne Park and was buried at Robertstown. [Born Mary Ann Garnett 15 November 1885 Willowie. Married Owen Henry Symons 1909.]

97, 38, 21 Oct. 1975, page 5

Burra Show Prize List is printed.

97, 38, 21 Oct. 1975, page 6

Kindergarten Union of SA’s Mobile Unit will tour the Mid North from 27 October to 7 November for the first time to promote interest and provide information on its services. It will visit Auburn, Mintaro, Farrell Flat, Blyth, Clare, Spalding and Booborowie.

97, 38, 21 Oct. 1975, page 7

Advt. Burra Pictures, 25 October

Burt Reynolds & Jennifer Billingsley in White Lightning

Roger Moore & Martha Hyer in Cross Plot

Mrs Raelene Jamieson And children will leave Burra to live in Millicent.

Rev. Don Haydon, formerly of the Redruth Circuit about 20 years ago, has been elected as the last President of the Methodist Conference before church Union. He takes office in October 1976.

A piece of malachite from the first load carted to Adelaide from the Burra Mine has been returned here to the museum. It comes as a result of a letter sent by Len Roberts of Kybybolite and Ian Auhl to Mary Broughton of the now defunct Chronicle. The malachite came from the Misses Roberts; 86-year-old twins of Clapham, whose grandfather was Thomas Roberts, the first Captain of Burra Burra Mine.

The Mt Bryan School display at the Burra Show was stolen, comprising four leather belts made by the children, two leather key-rings and six plaster models.

97, 39, 28 Oct. 1975, page 1

Ian Auhl’s Burra & District – A Pictorial Memoir is reviewed as a must buy for local residents or anyone with even a drop of Burra blood in their veins. It comprises 200 pages and 320 photographs. There are three sections in the foreword: The Burra Mine, The Burra Record and The Survival of a Mining Town, and then photographs under a series of headings covering the life of the town and district. Dame Nancy Buttfield will launch the book on Sunday 9 November at 2 p.m.

Elders-GM sold a portion of Koonoona Station by auction on 22 October. 2,075 ha was sold in 14 lots. [Details are printed.]

97, 39, 28 Oct. 1975, pages 1 & 5

The 1975 Hallett Red Cross Flower & Indoors Show is reported at length. The printed prize list continues on page 5.

97, 39, 28 Oct. 1975, page 3

Football. At a special meeting of the Mid North Football League two of the four active clubs reported their members had voted to seek affiliation with the North Eastern League and two reported their members wanted to carry on with a four team Mid North League. A further meeting is scheduled for 10 November to resolve the impasse.

Notice. Burra Burra DC advertises for a pound-keeper.

97, 39, 28 Oct. 1975, page 5

Burra Burra DC

Council will apply for a loan of $30,000 to upgrade town streets on a 10-year debenture.

[As usual much of the minutes as reported is too cryptic to be useful.]

97, 39, 28 Oct. 1975, page 7

Advt. Burra Pictures, 1 November

The Way of the Dragon

Loot

Birth. To Kath & Maurie Fitzgerald of Burra North at Burra Hospital on Sunday, a daughter, Teresa Maree.

Birth. To Ian & Gail Peaty nee Brandt of Burra and now of Menindie, NSW, at Broken Hill 24 October, a daughter, Kerrilie Jane.

Mr & Mrs Bill Broad of Burra celebrate their Golden Wedding next Saturday.

Vandals again smashed two cisterns at the Burra North Playground on Friday night and one opposite the Town Hall and left taps turned on.

Dr Geoff Pitcher of north Adelaide will check Kindergarten children’s teeth on Thursday morning.

The Anglican Diocese will celebrate its jubilee at a service on the Port Augusta Oval on Sunday. Among those present will be the Primate of Australia and the Archbishop of Adelaide.

The Jamestown Drama Group will present Is Your Honeymoon Really Necessary? At the Burra Town Hall 15 November.

97, 40, 4 Nov. 1975, page 1

Adelaide Wool Sales are reported with local prices. Values were generally in the sellers’ favour.

97, 40, 4 Nov. 1975, pages 1 & 8

Deputy Premier Des Corcoran spoke in Parliament to allay the fears of turning the EFS into a single fire fighting body. The present Government had full confidence in the present voluntary system. The present committee may well lead to changes that will make the fire service the responsibility of one Minister rather than three as at present.

97, 40, 4 Nov. 1975, page 2

Advt. Elders-GM will sell on 28 November, in the estate of B.H. Rodgers deceased, Allotment 396 in the Hundred of Kooringa with an old stone building of eight rooms etc. located at 18 Paxton Terrace. The dwelling is subject to a Local Board of Health notice.

Advt. Burra Pictures, 8 November

Paul Newman & Jacqueline Bisset in Life and Times of Judge Roy Bean

Cher in Chastity

Mrs F.L. Kellock has celebrated her 88th birthday.

Freedom From Hunger raised only $315.97 in the whole district.

Sharon Betty is now Miss Australia.

Prime Minister Whitlam attended the Anglican Diocesan Family Day at Pt Augusta on Sunday.

97, 41, 11 Nov. 1975, page 1

Article on the Bushfire Research Committee by its Chairman Dr J. Melville and the launching of the 1975-76 Bushfire Prevention Campaign by the Minister of Agriculture Mr Brian Chatterton.

Launching of Burra & District – A Pictorial Memoir compiled by Ian Auhl. It was launched at Baldina Homestead by Dame Nancy Buttfield. Mr Gerry O’Connor as President of the Burra Burra Branch of the National Trust welcomed guests and introduced Dame Nancy and her husband. Dame Nancy’s great grandmother was Mrs Holden, 1st Matron of the Redruth Girls’ Reformatory. She had taken to the workforce on being widowed and suffering the effects of the depression of the 1880s and had worked at Magill and Edwardstown before coming to Burra. Ian Auhl thanked Dame Nancy for her generosity in launching the book. At the launch Burra Pottery had an interesting stall and so did the Eastern Dorcas Society. The Golf Club served tea and soft drinks.

97, 41, 11 Nov. 1975, page 2

Kooringa Methodist Guild held its fete last Friday in the RSL Hall. Takings were $560.97.

Tennis

‘A’ Grade Burra Blue 14 defeated Spalding 6

Burra Red 11 defeated Burra White 9

Burra Gold 16 defeated Hallett 4

‘B’ Grade Andrews 10-89 defeated Burra Gold 10-88

Burra Red 10-99 defeated Booborowie White 10-86

Burra White 10-97 defeated Mt Bryan 10-86

Burra Blue 18 defeated Hallett 2

Juniors Burra Gold 10 defeated Burra Blue 2

Spalding 6-51 defeated Burra white 6-42

Premier Don Dunstan announced greatly reduced succession duties, in particular for the rural community. A special rebate of one half the value of the property will apply.

Fourteen Cubs attended their last meeting.

97, 41, 11 Nov. 1975, page 3

Bowls

Pennant Bowls finally commenced last Saturday after two wet Saturday s.

1st Division Burra 71 defeated Clare [?]

2nd Division Burra Green80 defeated Watervale 55

Clare green 74 defeated Burra Gold 61

3rd Division Clare 80 defeated Burra 56

97, 41, 11 Nov. 1975, page 5

Burra Golf Club held its AGM and elected: President, A.G. Baulderstone; Senior Vice-President, Don Villis; Secretary, H. Burnett; Treasurer, P. Boucher; Captain, S. Longford and Vice-Captain, R. Hillman.

A very successful season was reported with a new clubhouse, which climaxed a year of hard work and many headaches. The club funds benefited by $550 from a cabaret on 17 October.

The Schools Conference over two days recently was reported. Dr John Mayfield reviewed recent policies and trends. Miss Ailsa Farrow spoke on continuous fifth birthday admission. Small group discussions on Thursday afternoon covered Maths, Science and Social Studies. Mrs Margaret Haynes argued for the benefits of more traditional practices. Fr Kevin Matthews outlined several educational models. Don White spoke on community educational needs. Tom Perry spoke on community, local government and school links. Jim Giles addressed the varying educational methods in use today and a film on open space schooling followed with a talk on it by Harry Harris. Finally David beck gave an account of how the Year 10 Religious Studies course was being taught at his school.

About 25 members of the local community attended along with teachers.

Burra EFS at its AGM elected R. Stockman as Chairman and R. Shipard as Secretary.

97, 41, 11 Nov. 1975, page 6

Advt. Jamestown Drama Group presents Is Your Honeymoon Really Necessary? At Burra Town Hall Saturday 15 November.

97, 41, 11 Nov. 1975, page 7

Birth. To Marilyn & Brian Ide of Burra at Burra Hospital last Thursday 6 November, a son, Andrew Stuart.

Birth. To Ray & Kathryn Busch nee Simpson of Saddleworth at QEH 4 November, a daughter, Sophia Kathryn. (Kathryn was formerly of Mt Bryan.)

Birth. To Jackie & Peter Dignan, formerly of Burra, at Orroroo on Friday, a son, Matthew Peter.

Obituary. Les. Pearce of Booborowie died at Burra Hospital on Sunday aged 72.

[Born Thomas Leslie Pearce 1 June 1903 Mt Bryan: died 9 November 1975 Burra.]

Mrs Stella Sandland (93) and her daughter Mrs Gwen Esselbach visited her former home ‘Heathmont’ on Sunday. ‘Heathmont’ has been restored by its present owners the Pollard family.

The Tourist Committee will try again to elect a Chairman on 25 November at the Town Hall.

The Petathon on 18 September raised $260. $34 of this will go on native trees and shrubs to beautify the creek and provide homes for native birds.

Het & Bill Broad of 8 Ayers Street celebrated their Golden Wedding on 1 November.

Bowls. Burra Associates

Caltowie 60 defeated Burra Green 46

Burra Gold 55 defeated Jamestown Red 44

97, 41, 11 Nov. 1975, page 8

Tennis. 1 November

‘A’ Grade Burra Red 11-104 defeated Burra White 9-94

‘B’ Grade Burra Gold 10-89 defeated Andrews 10-88

97, 42, 18 Nov. 1975, page 1

Burra Burra DC

The Council and the Eastern Districts Fire Fighting Organisation are both concerned about increasing fire danger and have been discussing the problems. Council reminds landowners that using farm-type slashers has been known to start fires in the district and so care is urged with their use. They must not be used on a fire ban day. Incinerators must be four metres clear of flammable material and should be constructed not to emit sparks.

A new pound for straying livestock has been built opposite the sale yards at Burra North. The District Clerk is the pound-keeper.

Football

At the last meeting of the Mid North Football League the President Mr Stan Noske was granted Life Membership. The clubs reported on their individual consideration of the future.

Riverton said it had decided to seek affiliation with Barossa & Light and if not accepted there it would seek to join the North Eastern League.

Robertstown wished to stay with the Mid North League.

Mintaro-Manoora had not changed its decision to seek affiliation with the North Eastern League.

Saddleworth-Marrabel United wished to remain with the Mid North League.

Auburn would not field any teams in the Mid North League for 1976.

The President then read out conditions governing the disbandment of the League in its constitution. An application for withdrawal must be in the hands of the Secretary by 24 December 1975. The AGM will be called for 30 January 1976. If the League is dissolved a wind-up dinner will be held.

97, 42, 18 Nov. 1975, page 2

The Mt Bryan Reunion was held in perfect weather on 2 November. At the school roll call the two oldest living scholars present were Mr Lyle Bell of Glenelg [85] and Mr John R. Simpson [87] of Rose Park. In the evening a ball was held and CWA members served supper. On Sunday there was a church service in the school grounds conducted by Fr Matthews and Rev. Hore. A pooled lunch followed.

Booborowie Annual ‘Rainbow’ Fete was held on 16 November. Mrs Hore the wife of the Minister in the Burra Circuit opened the fete. She and her husband would be moving to Maitland in the New Year (not Moonta as earlier announced). Stalls and takings are listed. Gross takings were $912.87.

Obituary. Mrs Rosewarne died at Port Lincoln last week. She was the mother of Mesdames Lorna Finch and Lu Riggs of Burra. [Born Myrtle Margaret Puckridge 11 April 1898 Lake Wangary SA. Married Russell John Rosewarne 1920.]

The Annual Melbourne Cup Luncheon drew over 200 ladies to the Town Hall. The $700 profit will be equally split between the RFDS and the Town Hall Piano Fund.

97, 43, 25 Nov. 1975, page 1

Adelaide Wool Sale No. 5 is reported with local prices. Prices were generally firm.

Ken White, local Shell distributor, was given a presentation dinner last Wednesday night to mark his 25 years with Shell. Among those present was Hugh Clutterbuck, now District Sales Manager who was succeeded at Burra by Barry Taylor. Barry Taylor left Burra ten years ago and now lives at Broken Hill. He will soon go to Port Pirie as Area Manager.

A Liberal Party Rally at Clare on 14 November in the form of a dinner was well supported.

Elders-GM yarded 9,438 sheep on 21 November and sold 8,320.

Oates Ltd in its Off Shears Sale on 14 November had 4,700 yarded and 4,530 sold.

Burra Primary School will run a family sports day on the Town Oval on Thursday, to be followed by a barbecue.

Scouts. 19 Scouts went to Farrell Flat on 14 November and all were given a flight in an aeroplane and a talk on how an aeroplane works, courtesy of Mr Trevor Denton, pilot.

97, 44, 2 Dec. 1975, page 1

Burra Burra DC

The rates are only slowly coming in, with at least half yet to be paid.

The Tourist Committee meeting drew about a dozen people to the Town Hall on Tuesday. Ray Jennison has agreed to continue as President till March 1976 when the AGM is due. Mrs Ivan Hirschausen takes over as Secretary.

The Apex Club will be asked to do further research on beautifying the Burra Creek before an approach is made to the Department of Tourism, Recreation and Sport for a subsidy.

The signs for the Burra Historic Tour are on order and should be in place before Christmas.

Booborowie School. Attendance was boosted to 90 with the preparatory children who will begin properly in 1976. Eleven will graduate to BHS.

Twenty Burra Cubs attended the last meeting and the next will be on 5 December at Porter’s Lagoon, travelling there by bus from the Burra Post Office at 6.30 p.m. and arriving back at about 9 p.m. Lads are to bring bathers and a plate of food.

97, 45, 9 Dec. 1975, page 1

Hallett & District Schools Athletics Association

An article outlines the Association’s history at some length. The inaugural meeting was of teachers only on 14 April 1928. A later meeting resolved that each school committee appoint two persons to assist the teachers. The first meeting at the Hallett Oval on 3 October 1928 arranged sports for those from under 7 to under 15 and included novelty events as well as conventional athletics. A special train came from Terowie and the schools represented were: Whyte-Yarcowie, Terowie, Mt Bryan, Booborowie, Willalo, Ulooloo, Hallett, Booborowie North, Petherton, Narrowie and World’s End.

In the early years a dance was held in the evenings. This became a concert and dance and continued till 1950.

The exhibition component of the gathering began in 1929. Meetings continued till 1941 when petrol rationing caused the only postponement of the event. Over the years team events became increasingly important. Over time other schools participated including, Mt Bryan East, Ucolta, Sunny Brae, Yongala Vale, Hundred of Whyte and in later years, Burra. For some years there were special events for Correspondence School children. The last Executive Meeting of the Association was held on 19 August 1975 when it was resolved to present the balance of money in the account to the St John Ambulance Centre in Burra. Trophies were distributed to schools and written records were donated to the Burra National Trust. Of the seventeen school at some time involved, only three were affiliated at the time of the last sports day on 18 April 1975; Hallett, Mt Bryan and Burra.

[Note that this article is lengthy and includes many names of people and families involved in the long history of the Association.]

97, 45, 9 Dec. 1975, page 7

Advt. Burra Pictures, 13 December

Santee

Glen Ford & Michael Burns in The Dawn of Victory

Changes at Burra Schools

High School Principal Pat Payne and Primary School Principal Howard Groome are both leaving Burra this year. Ann Perry retires after many years of teaching.

Clarrie and Elsie Hore are moving from Burra to the Methodist Manse at Maitland.

Peter Osterhage, younger son of Mr & Mrs Ernst Osterhage of Mt Bryan will graduate as an Army Lieutenant from Portsea Officer Training School next Friday. His wife Del will live in Perth while he studies for a Bachelor of Applied Science.

Obituary. Mrs Neindorf of Caltowie and mother of Mrs Hugh Kelly of Hallett died at Jamestown on Saturday aged 72. [Probably born Ada Annie Woolcock 4 July 1903 near Kapunda, who married Adolph Neindorf at Caltowie in 1927.]

Lightning caused a spate of small fires in the area last week.

Debra Brereton, daughter of Pat 7 Colin Brereton of Hanson, topped the state in second year Hairdressing recently.

Dennis Nettleton will give a half-hour pipe organ recital at St Mary’s before the 7 p.m. Christmas Eve Service.

The Senior Citizens’ Christmas Party was held last Friday in Redruth Hall.

The Annual RSL Dinner was held last Saturday.

Darrell Field writes concerning the regrettable losses of material from Show Exhibits despite care being taken, specifically the items from the Mt Bryan School, but he says it does not help that the display was not collected until the Tuesday after the show.

97, 45, 9 Dec. 1975, page 8

Tiver Family Reunion. 272 signed the family book at the Burra Town Hall and at least 300 were present. James Tiver helped to construct the main Hall 100 years ago. Bad weather prevented the planned gathering at the racecourse. People brought their own lunches and there was a thanksgiving service. Hedley Thomas of Mundulla took family group photographs and there was a display of old photographs and family documents. 12 December was the 109th anniversary of Edgar Tiver’s birth. The oldest descendant present was Netley Sumner of Hallett aged 79 and the youngest was the baby Luke Tiver a great grandson of Charles Godwin Tiver. A few days later a letter was received from Raymond George Tiver in the UK where he has lived for many years. He is a grandson of James Hugh Tiver and nostalgically recalled memories of Burra and Hallett districts from 50 or 60 years ago and of relatives. [The report names many of those present.]

97, 46, 16 Dec. 1975, MISSING

97, 48, 22 Dec. 1975, page 1 [Note anomalous numbering.]

Fire Ban. Seasonal conditions have resulted in a complete fire ban over the Northeast and Northwest Fire Ban Districts and most of the Flinders Ranges until 31 March 1976. Winter rain has produced a lot of growth this year. Most fires so far have been started by lightning.

Federal Election. A statement by Mr Anthony, Leader of the National Country Party, on the outcome of the 13 December election is printed.

Late Shopping will apply in Burra on Wednesday 24 December to 9 p.m.

In Booborowie Father Christmas will visit Griffiths’ Serv-Wel Store at 8.30 on 23 December.

At Burra there will be a free picture show for the children at 6.30 p.m. Christmas Eve.

What Happened at Campo Grande

Wildlife Paradise

Father Christmas will arrive in Market Square at 8.30 p.m.

Mr Dennis Nettleton organist will give a half-hour recital at 6.30 p.m. before the Christmas service by Canon Keith Sorby-Adams at 7.00 p.m. [Page 7 corrects this to a service by Rev. Ian Barlow.]

Burra Associates, 17 December

Burra Green 52 drew with Jamestown

Peterborough Blue 57 defeated Burra 55

Burra Methodist Church will hold an Induction Service for Rev. Alan Beames on Thursday 22 January 1976.

The Ironmine Methodist Church Trust Committee held its final meeting on Monday last week. The sale and transfer of the property have been completed. Committee members, formerly Trustees were thanked by the Chairman Rev. Clarrie Hore and special thanks were paid to Ray Lloyd who was Secretary and Treasurer since 1948. The committee was then dissolved.

97, 48, 22 Dec. 1975, page 7

Michelle Beinke has passed her final nursing examinations and is now Sister Beinke.

Anne White & Jenny Holmes of Burra Hospital leave soon to continue their training at the RAH.

Marriage. Burra Methodist Church 3 January 1976

Roslyn Maxted, daughter of Mr & Mrs Norm Maxted of Burra, will marry David Keane.

Obituary. Jean Bogisch died in Adelaide last Thursday aged 53.

Obituary. Mavis Jean Hirschausen, wife of Ron Hirschausen of Mt Gambier, has died suddenly.

Christmas Carols last night were compered by Dennis Nettleton and it was a most enjoyable evening. Music was supplied by Olive Oates, Jack Kleinig’s Band and the Methodist Choir. About $50 was raised for Timor Relief.

98, 1, 28 Jan. 1976, page 1

Burra Community School

Mr Christopher J. McCabe has been appointed Principal of Burra Community School. He was previously Deputy Principal of Penola High School. He is the first principal of a Country Community School in SA. The comprehensive rebuilding of the existing Primary and Secondary Schools provided an integrated educational facility. The original building, which is of historic interest, and has a National Trust classification, has been preserved. Mr McCabe will be responsible for the successful introduction of the concept of community education in Burra. In 1973 Mr McCabe took up a Rotary Foundation award to the USA and studied for his MA at Ball State University, Indiana. A significant part of his study was community education. He has taught at Findon and Port Pirie and Mt Gambier High Schools and was appointed Deputy Principal at Penola High School in January 1975. In the rebuilding process the shell of the original building will be retained, while the interior is converted into modern open space learning areas for the Primary School students.

Adelaide Wool Sales. Prices were generally 21⁄2% firmer. [Local district prices are printed.]

Porter’s Lagoon will be the site for an Aquatic Spectacular on 22 February, sponsored by the Gilbert Valley Lions Club. The Club’s money-raising this year is principally aimed at making a significant contribution to the provision of an Orthopaedic Workshop at the new Crippled Children’s Centre at Regency Park. This will design and make all manner of clothing and aids to make affected persons more mobile. The club is supporting Mrs Denise Benger of Saddleworth in the Miss Personality Quest.

Football

The Mid North Football League has been dissolved. Mr A.E. Bannear, Secretary of the League, has advised of the steps in the dissolution of the League. Notice of the intention of member clubs for the 1976 season was required by 24 December 1975. It was:

Auburn FC: withdrawal from the League and to remain in recess for 1976.

Aberdeen FC: no response, but remaining in recess for 1976.

Mintaro-Manoora: withdrawal from the League and joining the North Eastern Football League.

Riverton FC: withdrawal from the League and joining the Barossa & Light League.

Robertstown FC: withdrawal from the League and joining the Barossa & Light League.

Saddleworth-Marrabel United FC will amalgamate with the Riverton FC with the new team to enter the Barossa & Light League.

As a consequence the AGM of the Mid North Football League will be held on 2 February 1976 at Saddleworth, when it will discuss and act on clause 6 of the constitution, to dissolve the League. In the next two months all players will be transferred either to the Barossa & Light League or to the North Eastern Football League and in the case of the Riverton and United players, transferred to the new club and then to the Barossa & Light League. A wind-up dinner will be held at a date to be fixed. A history of the League from its foundation, possibly in 1911, to its dissolution is in hand. Clubs are asked to give consideration to setting aside certain funds for this purpose.

98, 1, 28 Jan. 1976, page 2

98, 2, 3 Feb. 1976, page 1

Burra Community School

Mr G. Searle SM opened the first assembly for the year and introduced the new staff: Principal, C. McCabe; SM, Brian Baker; Mr G. Bayly (Biology), Miss M. Beck (English), Mr R. Bednall (Physical Education), Miss M. Nahhay (Years I & II), Mr J. Hearse (Year VI), Mr E. Lane (Technical Studies), Mr Rick Pellew (Agricultural Science), Mr Wally Spehr (Science) and Ms Heather Thick (Commerce).

There are 13 students taking Matriculation and 42 students taking Agricultural Science. Matriculation and Agricultural Science are being offered for the first time.

Notice. The sale of ‘Eversdale’ Mt Bryan has been changed from 27 to 20 February.

Advt. Burra Pictures, 7 February

Summer Wishes

Stand Up & Be Counted

Dr Margaret Loutit has been appointed Associate Professor of Microbiology at the Medical School, University of Otago in Dunedin NZ. She is the daughter of Mr & Mrs Roy Jeffery of Burra North. She attended Burra Primary School, MLC and the University of Adelaide.

Maurice Perry and his wife Mai of Kota Kinabalu, Sabah, Malaysia, are visiting SA at present. He is the son of Mr & Mrs Tom Perry of Burra and is an architect.

Burra Kindergarten has abolished fees for attending.

Tony Snook has come to Burra as Finance Officer at Southern Farmers.

98, 3, 10 Feb. 1976, page 1

Football. At a meeting recently at Riverton the Riverton-Saddleworth-Marrabel United FC was formed. It will be known as the United FC and will play in the Barossa & Light League.

98, 4, 17 Feb. 1976, page 1

BCS Parents and Friends met at the school last Thursday. Edith Carpenter as Co-ordinator for the Community School addressed the meeting. The Principal Mr Chris McCabe introduced the new staff and addressed the meeting. Ron Thamm chaired the meeting and steered the discussion smoothly through questions of open space teaching, fund-raising priorities etc. Ian Allen outlined the achievements of 1975. Tenders have been called for the painting of the exterior of the main building. Nine parent representatives were elected to the School Council. Mr McCabe stressed the need for community involvement if the concept of a Community School is to work. An Open Week will be held 15-19 March when many different subjects will be offered to people interested in taking part. Year 12 student Anne Carpenter also addressed the meeting, urging community support for the new school concept.

Burra Library AGM. President, R.J. Steele reported on a successful trading table and raffle, which helped the library keep going. The holds c. 6,000 volumes. Elected were President, Mr Steele; Vice-Presidents, Mr Nankivell & Mrs Fennell; Treasurer, Mrs Carpenter and Secretary, Mr Ben Kotz.

District School Enrolments 1876

Hallett: 9 new enrolments are listed. Total enrolment is 74, which is up from 68 in 1975.

Booborowie School opened with 78 children, including 11 in Year I and those are listed.

Robertstown had 66 on the roll in 1975 and 65 in 1976, to become 70 by the end of March. New students are listed.

Farrell Flat total enrolment is up from 22 in 1975 to 28 this year. New Year I students are listed.

Advt. Burra Pictures, 21 February

Shark’s Treasure

Lee Marvin, Gary Grimes & Ron Howard in The Spikes Gang

Accident. The inboard motor on a boat exploded at Porter’s Lagoon on Thursday afternoon and Margy Stockman and two young Hanson boys suffered burns. The Shipards who were nearby rescued Don, Margy and the two lads, but the boat sank.

[George Philip Beinke born 5 October 1897 Walloway: died 15 February 1976.]

[Edward John Hogan born 9 November 1895Aberdeen: died 17 February 1976.]

[Born Alice Maud Eig at Coonabarrabran NSW.]

Mr ‘Tod’ Mosey of Robertstown is 90 today.

[Arthur Levie Mosey born 16 February 1886.]

98, 4, 17 Feb. 1976, page 8

Football

The Mid North Football League held its AGM 2 February. President Mr S. Noske read the report for 1975. There was a credit balance of $1,354.14. G. Hirschausen & P. Reed moved that the Aberdeen FC be allowed to withdraw from the League and the Club to remain in recess. It was then unanimously resolved to dissolve the League. It was resolved to have a Mid North Football League Dinner. And to have the History of the Mid North Football League recorded by the League secretary and published. $150 was retained to cover the basic publishing costs with one copy to go to each club and a further decision to be made on other copies.

Funds are to be divided $170 each to Riverton, United, Mintaro-Manoora and Robertstown, with $130 each to go to Aberdeen and Auburn. Money from the disposal of assets is to be divided equally between the six clubs. Shield are to be returned to the Secretary at the end of the 1976 season and then to be given to the club with most names thereon. Other final arrangements were made and the records will go to SA Archives.

Polo

After an absence of 37 years the Clare Polo Club returned to their old ground, with Stanley Hawker officially opening it before a large crowd on 25 January. Since being reformed in 1971 practices and tournaments had been held at Anama Park and then at Anama. Now the field within the racecourse has been levelled and drained and sown and should be an ideal playing surface. Practices are held every Saturday afternoon with a season from January to Easter.

98, 5, 24 Feb. 1975, page 1 [Note wrong year used throughout this issue; should be 1976.]

Burra National Trust held its AGM on 9 February.

Retiring President G.E. O’Connor reported.

The Federal Government’s National Estate program provided $12,000 in a grant, but it had to be spent in two months, which meant it could not be used to best advantage. Work done was:

The Bon Accord Engine Shop was half re-roofed and the building repainted satisfactorily after Mr Cockington had condemned the contractor’s first efforts. Drainage was improved on the southern side.

Restoration of the second dugout was commenced as a voluntary project, but when $2,500 became available it was contracted to G. Nourse and D. Cockington. Some work remains to be done.

$3,800 was allocated for the restoration of the old Powder Magazine. The first contractor withdrew over a dispute concerning the quality of work and it was completed by Don Villis. The western wall (previously dismantled) was rebuilt and the eastern wall of the magazine itself was removed. The building is secure, but much more needs to be done. After we had spent the money it was discovered that the Powder Magazine was not National Trust Property, which upset National Estate authorities because the funds were only to be spent on Trust owned properties. It was finally resolved by the Council giving the Trust control of the property by means of a covenant.

We have found that local contractors give greater satisfaction than outsiders.

Ian Auhl published two beautiful books during the year.

Late in the year the Diamond T fire engine that served the town from 1937-75 was offered for sale by the Fire Brigade Board and was snapped up by the District Council who sold it to the National Trust.

Our first ever organised dinner in December 1974 at the Kooringa Hotel was well attended and very satisfactory.

[The retiring President G.R. O’Connor also acknowledged the support of all volunteers, Mr Woollacott, the District Council and the Federal Government for their respective support.]

Burra Methodist Circuit cancelled the family camp at Melrose due for 12-14 March.

‘Glen View’ Mr Bryan was auctioned at the RSL Hall in Burra on 19 October. The 2,733.8 ha property was offered in nine lots of which five were sold at auction:

‘Back Paddock’ of 97.2 ha for $15,000 to Dudley Cockington Nominees Pty Ltd of Burra.

‘Weber’s Front Paddock’ of 54.27 ha for $7,900 to H.D. & C.L. Jones of Hallett.

‘Weber’s Homestead’ of 167.67 ha for $11,000 to Alden Stud, Box 37, Hallett.

‘Scrub Paddock’ of 454.8 ha for $11,000 to A.W. & G.A. Thomas of Mt Bryan.

‘Ned Weber’s Paddock’ of 217.08 ha for $13,000 to D.B. Brooks.

Negotiations are proceeding for the other lots.

Red Mosey of Robertstown turned 90 on 16 February and his brother Perce Mosey of Robertstown turned 80 on the same day.

Burra Community School

A new Parents and Friends Association was formed on Thursday to support the school and keep abreast of current educational trends. President is Mrs L. Kemp; Vice-President, Mr B. Stockman; Secretary, Mrs H. Reed and Treasurer, Mrs S. Nourse.

Burra Burra DC, 9 February

Council resolved that a request be made to purchase the Booborowie Recreation Ground and that the reply contain the price.

98, 6, 2 Mar. 1976, page 1

BCS will launch the first Community School Week 15-19 March. For that week the normal program will be suspended. Special student courses related to the curriculum will be held from 9-11 a.m. and for the rest of the day mini-courses on a wide variety of subjects will be held for both students and adults. Courses are free except for any materials used. Courses are being supported by Sturt CAE and the Clare Further Education Centre as well as by the school staff and community volunteers. For the students work experience has also been arranged. Added to the student program are the Year 8 camp at Barmera and a Year 12 visit to Adelaide tertiary education centres and some Festival of Arts productions. Unfortunately this week clashes with Field Day Week and in future this will be avoided.

New Electoral Boundaries

Mr Claude Allen MP has decided not to contest the seat of Frome at the next election. Following the redistribution based on the one vote one value principle the electorate will become much larger and he says it could not be represented by one person and have the sort of representation the electors are entitled to. The redistribution has been passed with Liberal Movement support. Mr Allen was elected first as successor to the late P.H. Quirke in 1968. In 1970 the Electorate of Burra was abolished. The western half went to the electorate of Rocky River and the eastern half went into Frome. Mr Allen won Frome and has contested and won four elections in just over seven years. The present Electorate of Frome covers 38% of the state and could become larger with the redistribution. Mr Allen will retire to Spalding on the completion of his parliamentary term. Before becoming a politician he was a farmer for forty years.

98, 6, 2 Mar. 1976, page 2

98, 6, 2 Mar. 1976, page 5

Burra Primary School Welfare Club

President Mrs J.S. Tiver presented the 1975 and final report to end 38 years of service under the present title.

This year there were 42 members and an average attendance of 22. The short period of tenure of Mr Howard Groome was productive and he was a sincere and capable leader. Sports Day in April allowed the Club to raise $268. A Tabloid Sports Day was held in November and was generally acclaimed as a preferable format. Other fund raising for the year brought in $319. $826 has been provided for the purchase of equipment and the present bank balance is $245. [The various guest speakers are reported.]

Burra H.S. Parents & Friends’ Association. Report by Shirley Thamm.

The seven meetings had an average attendance of 14. Principal Miss Pat Payne proved to be friendly and maintained good communications with the parent body. Profits from the School Sports Day were $240 and the High School Ball made a profit of $252. Other income of $489 allowed a donation of $600 to be made for matriculation books. $200 was donated for outdoor seating, $50 for indoor games and $50 for the mower fund. The bank balance is presently $283 with a further $800 in deposit stock.

Jude Oates has been appointed Matron of the 25-bed hospital at Kimba. She finishes at Burra Hospital tomorrow and will then have a holiday before taking the new post early in May.

98, 7, 9 Mar. 1976, page 7

Advt. Burra Pictures, 13 March

Peter Pan

World’s Greatest Athlete

Birth. To Pauline & Alistair Mundy-Castle on 28 February, a son, Joshua.

The National Trust has received extra funds for further work on the Powder Magazine and the dugouts. High School students will help to create a Wool Museum at the Bon Accord Buildings soon.

The Siebum Family will leave Burra to live at Salisbury at the weekend.

98, 8, 16 Mar. 1976, page 1

The Circle Theatre Company will be performing at Burra Town Hall on Tuesday 30 March as part of their country tour program.

Burra Community School

The land is being developed for the Agricultural Science course. The vegetable area has been ploughed and will soon be fenced and surveyed into individual plots. The car for Student Driver Education should be available within three weeks. The response to Burra School’s first Community Week has been particularly good and most gratifying to the organisers and teachers. 121 adults have enrolled for the range of courses offered.

Year 12 students are in Adelaide for visits to Festival of Arts productions and Tertiary Education Centres. Year 8 students are at camp at Barmera and Year 5 & 6 students are at Halbury Camp near Balaklava. The absence of these groups makes it possible to accommodate adult students this week.

98, 8, 16 Mar. 1976, pages 1 & 5

Burra Burra DC

A number of people in town are keeping horses in closer proximity to houses than is allowed; at least 100 feet from a house is required. They are not always in hygienic conditions.

The Apex Club has mown the grass at the Burra North Playground and cleaned up rubbish. They will soon install barbecues and repair the swings and seating.

Fees at the caravan park will rise from 1 April to $2.75 a night for a caravan and $2 for tents (including power).

Tenders have been accepted for the sealing on another 1-5 km [sic: 1.5?] of the Burra-Farrell Flat-Clare Road; from Farrell Flat to near the railway crossing.

98, 8, 16 Mar. 1976, page 2

Advt. Elder-GM on instructions from J.P. & J.R. Paterson will conduct an auction of Lot 329 situated in Ayers Street, with a stone house of three bedrooms etc.

98, 8, 16 Mar. 1976, page 3

Bowls

1st Division Saddleworth 76 defeated Burra 59

2nd Division Burra Gold 74 defeated Clare Red 73

Watervale 83 defeated Burra Green 61

3rd Division Auburn 95 defeated Burra 57

98, 8, 16 Mar. 1976, page 5

Burra Kindergarten held its AGM on 1 March.

Elected were: President, Mrs E. Nicholls; Vice-President, Mrs V. Secomb; Secretary, Mrs M. Schwarz; Assistant Secretary, Mrs B. Villis and Treasurer, Mrs B. Armstrong.

The annual opportunity shop will be held on 8 & 9 April in the RSL Hall.

B.E. Villis reported on 1975:

The project for the year was heating and insulation. The ceiling was insulated at a cost of $220 and an oil heater was installed for $356. The windows facing Queen Street got new blinds. A heatcrete incinerator was purchased. In the 12 months $984.42 was raised. Toys and teaching aids worth $408-94 were purchased.

[Activities at the various meetings are outlined.]

98, 8, 16 Mar. 1976, page 6

Advt. Burra Pictures, 20 March

John Wayne & Eddie Albert in McQ

Joel McRae & Barbara Hale in The Oklahoman

98, 8, 16 Mar. 1976, page 7

Birth. To Heather & Geoff Short of Evanston Gardens on Sunday, a daughter. An addition to the Angel family of Burra and the Short family of Farrell Flat.

Birth. To Vicki & John Scott on 6 March, a daughter, Rebecca Louise. A granddaughter for Barbara & Roy Harris of Booborowie.

Birth. To Barry & Trenna Ryan (nee Eberhard) on 11 March at Ballarat, a daughter, Jene Danielle.

Birth. To Jack & Janet Dempsey (nee Harris) formerly of the Burra District, at QVMH, a daughter, Rebecca.

Mrs Nell Fahey visited Booborowie last week. She and her late husband, Charlie, first settled there after their marriage 63 years ago. They were at Booborowie’s first shop. Mrs Fahey is now a lively 83. Her sister is Mrs [W.J.] Lee of Burra. [Born Ellen Barrow.]

Venture Scouts Geoff Kempster & Alan Mengersen of Burra are the first of their group to have flown solo in gliders at Blanchetown. On the weekend of 6 & 7 March.

Ross Lenthal, former Rector of the Burra Parish, was clothed as a novice in the Anglican Society of St Francis on 23 November. He is presently Guest Master at Brookfield Priory in Queensland, where he is known as Brother Gregory Ross.

St Mary’s. Rev. Barry May will be commissioned as Rector of the parish next Tuesday 23 March. The living has been vacant for almost seven months. Mr & Mrs May have four children.

Obituary. Mr Ernest (Ernie) Satchell of Burra died 7 March aged 90. He was buried at Gawler.

[Ernest William Satchell born 7 February 1886 North Clare.]

Obituary. Mr Ivon E. Gare of Bordertown and formerly of ‘Three Trees’ Burra died at home on 10 March aged 73. The funeral was held at Burra. [Ivon Edward Gare born 24 December 1902, Malvern, SA.]

Marriage. Burra Methodist Church on Saturday

Debbie Rawnsley & Roger Przibilla, both of Farrell Flat.

Burra Pistol Club. A meeting last week showed there was sufficient interest to form a Pistol Club in the town. Sergeant Haynes spoke of the requirements, rules and regulations for such a club.

Mrs Reta Jennison was given a posy at the annual meeting of the Redruth Guild last week in recognition of fifty years’ service.

Burra Burra Show Inc. held its AGM on 8 March.

Elected: President, R.J. Shipard; Vice-Presidents, N. Hurst & P. Stockman and Secretary-Treasurer, D.H. Field.

The previous year had been very successful socially and financially. The floor of the confectionary and pet sections had been cemented. Weed control is being worked upon. The 1975 show was well attended despite poor weather. Insurance covered the loss in attendance money. In the coming year in conjunction with the Pony Club it is intended to enlarge and top dress the show ring. Rural Youth will work on general repairs to the Main Hall. The Scouts have asked permission to erect a storage shed.

98, 8, 16 Mar. 1976, page 8

BCS Swimming Carnival results are printed.

Burra RSL held its AGM on 12 March when only eight members attended. Elected: President, Mr R. Steele; Vice-Presidents, Mr Duance and Mr R. Opperman; Secretary, W. Fridd and Treasurer, Mr Ben Kotz.

In the year maintenance work was required on the premises. Renewal of guttering and white and treatment cost considerable money. Attendance at the annual dinner was down, but the event proved most enjoyable and thanks are due to the Ladies’ Auxiliary for again preparing a sumptuous meal.

98, 9, 23 Mar. 1976, page 1

Cricket. Philip Byles of Booborowie is Mokota Association Cricketer of the Year for 1975-76.

Burra Pre-School Kindergarten wishes to appoint a full-time director, but has almost no hope of doing do before 1 July and perhaps not this year unless there are enough children to fill the kindergarten for nine sessions per week. At present the number cannot increase and the times of attendance cannot be extended until there is a full-time director. Further information is required regarding the age of children and the number of days they would attend.

BCS has concluded a very successful Community Week program. At the Parents & Friends’ Assoc. meeting on 25 March there will be a demonstration of the new colour television and video-tape recorder. A Student Representative Council has been elected in place of the traditional prefect system. [Names listed.]

98, 9, 23 Mar. 1976, page 2

Burra Methodist Circuit has cancelled its family camp at Melrose, but having paid the deposit, a group of families decided to retain the booking and a successful family camp took place. Twenty-four people had a successful weekend under the leadership of Rev. Beames.

98, 9, 23 Mar. 1976, page 3

Bowls

1st Division Burra 89 defeated Auburn 58

2nd Division Burra Gold 87 defeated Clare Blue 65

Booborowie 69 defeated Burra Green 66

3rd Division Burra 88 defeated Clare 61

Burra Gold has won the pennant in the 2nd Division.

Cricket. 1st Semi-Final of Mokota Cricket.

Spalding 231 defeated Burra Footballers 55.

Redruth Ladies’ Guild. Secretary Reta Jennison reported on an interesting year at the recent AGM. Attendance averaged 23. Activities for the year are reported in one column of detail.

98, 9, 23 Mar. 1976, page 5

St Mary’s Ladies’ Guild held its AGM recently. Margaret Hurst reported on the year’s activities. Average attendance had been 12. [Details are given in a little more than one column.]

Kooringa Methodist Ladies’ Guild held its AGM 3 March. Mrs E.T. Baulderstone was re-elected President. Mrs F. Fennell was elected Secretary, with Mrs W. Nankivell as Treasurer. Mrs M. Williams as retiring Secretary reported on the year. [Details occupy about 1⁄2 column.]

Booborowie Methodist Ladies’ Guild held its AGM, which is reported in 3⁄4 column.

98, 9, 23 Mar. 1976, page 7

Birth. To Suzie & Peter Cousins at Booleroo Centre, a daughter, Melissa Jane.

Rev. Barry & Kath May have moved into the Rectory with their children, Leanne, Craig, Michael and Timothy.

Mrs Coverdale of Sydney, a former Burra resident, has sent a very clear photograph of the unveiling of the Soldiers’ Memorial in Market Square in 1922 for the Museum. It was delivered by another former resident; Alex Bevan.

The old dry-cleaning premises in Burra has been demolished. [Kingston Street.]

Zita Brown won the Champion of Champions title for the North-Eastern Women’s Bowling Association at Caltowie yesterday.

Les & Robyn Field of the ANZ Bank have been transferred to Maitland from early in May.

Obituary. Noel Tudor aged 20 was killed in a road accident. He was a grandson of Mr & Mrs Bob Honan of Hallett.

Burra Burra DC, 8 March

Details are given of the transfer of some land at the corner of West Street from Ian Trevor Allen, carrier, and his wife Margaret Leslie Allen, to the Burra Burra DC from 23 August 1974 and now declared to be a public road.

Chairman and Overseer are to liaise with the Apex Club over the restoration work at the Burra North Playground.

98, 10, 30 Mar. 1976, page 1

St Mary’s. Last Wednesday evening the Bishop of Willochra Rt Rev. Bruce Rosier commissioned Rev. Barry May as Rector of the Burra Parish. The procession was announced by a fanfare composed and played by organist Denis Nettleton. The parish comprises St Mary’s Burra, St Edmund’s Booborowie, St Andrew’s Mt Bryan and St Catherine’s Hallett. After the service the parishioners and visitors gathered for supper in the parish hall. Fr Kevin Matthews and Rev. Alan Beames were welcomed to the occasion. Mr Stanley Hawker welcomed the May family as Senior Trustee.

Football. North-Eastern Football League AGM elected President, A.J. Cousins; Vice-Presidents, M.H. Kennett & M. Beinke; Patron, R.N. Collins and Secretary-Treasurer, J.S. Ward. The Mintaro-Manoora Football Club has joined the league. [Arrangements for the coming season are printed.]

BCS

Years 5 & 6 Camp at Halbury was very successful. Students undertook map-making, sketching, weaving, rent-making and hiking. The evening saw dancing and music-making. On Wednesday softball and cricket matches were staged with Balaklava School. Thursday saw a visit to Balaklava swimming Pool.

The Year 12 students visited Adelaide and Flinders Universities and the Career Reference Centre. They saw two films relevant to their studies: Barry Lyndon and Great Expectations. They went to the SA Theatre Company’s performance of Coriolanus and also saw the Lhama Theatre of Tibet and the Negro Ensemble’s production of The Story of the Blind Pig as well as a performance of Basically Black; concerning racial discrimination. Community Week also saw Year 10 & 11 students giving assistance with restoration work at the Bon Accord manager’s residence. Year 9 students helped with some restoration work at Paxton’s Square.

98, 10, 30 Mar. 1976, page 2

Burra Hockey Club held its AGM on 22 March and elected President, Kath Millard, Secretary-Treasurer, Jenny Wall and Coach, Richard Bednall.

98, 10, 30 Mar. 1976, page 3

Bowls. Mid-North Champion of Champions is Colin Hancock of Spalding, for the third time.

1st Division Rink Champion of Champions went to Saddleworth.

2nd Division Rink Champion of Champions went to Burra Green.

3rd Division Rink Champion of Champions went to Watervale.

98, 10, 30 Mar. 1976, page 4

Burra Weight Watchers held their AGM at the CWA rooms on 25 February. They elected President, Irene Hirschausen; Vice-Presidents, Mary Simpson & Mavis Wall; Secretary, Margaret Alderson*; Assistant Secretary, Margaret Hoskins and Treasurer, Mavis Wall.

[* This was corrected in the paper of 6 April page 7 to Margaret Anderson.]

98, 10, 30 Mar. 1976, page 6

Obituary. Aileen Hope Lomman died at Clare Hospital 29 March aged 75. She was the wife of Alfred Lomman and mother of Fay and Dorothy. [Born Aileen Hope Cornfoot 14 February 1901, Mintaro.]

98, 10, 30 Mar. 1976, page 7

Advt. Burra Pictures, 3 April

Barbara Streisand, James Cann & Omar Sharif in Funny Lady

Birth. To Joy & David Baynes of Katherine, NT, 23 March, a daughter, Kylie Michelle, a grandchild for Mr & Mrs Norrie Baynes of Burra.

Bob Lawes of Elders-GM, with his wife and two daughters are transferring to Cleve next week.

Burra Tennis Club held its championships recently and the results are:

‘A’ Grade Don Lloyd and Margaret Lloyd

‘C’ Grade Greg Thamm and Judy Higgins

Burra Swimming Pool season closes this Friday.

98, 11, 6 Apr. 1976, page 1

Burra Burra DC

Stray dogs are a problem again in the town. Their presence around the Kindergarten is causing concern.

Litter at the edge of the Burra Creek is detracting from its appearance.

BCS

The Year 8 camp at Camp Kedron on the shores of Lake Bonney during Community Week was conducted in perfect weather. Visits were made to a number of business establishments and to historic sites including Overland Corner Hotel and the Loxton Historic Village, Renmark Museum and the paddle steamer Industry. Mr Joe Bredl’s Snake Farm was a highlight. There was also time for swimming, canoeing and various sports.

Basketball

The North-Eastern International Rules Basketball Association was formed on 28 October 1970.

There were then five men’s teams: Clare, Torreston, Hallett, Burra Blue and Burra White.

And three women’s teams: Hallett, Torreston and Burra.

For 1971-72 Burra added a further men’s team and another women’s team.

In 1972-73 the men’s teams were Hallett, Torreston and three Burra teams.

The women’s teams numbered five.

On 20 June 1973 the North-Eastern and the Spalding Associations merged.

For the 1973-74 season Burra supplied one men’s team and one women’s team and in all the Association comprised 6 men’s teams and 4 women’s teams.

The line-up for 1974-75 was unchanged and in 1975-76 season Burra High School added a men’s team.

This season Burra entered three men’s teams and one women’s team. Letters have been sent out to see if a Burra Association could be formed.

98, 11, 6 Apr. 1976, page 3

Notice. Mt Bryan General Store, previously conducted by Mrs I. Stelman, has been taken over by George & Eva Reavley.

98, 12, 13 Apr. 1976, pages 1 & 6

BCS. The agricultural area is developing rapidly. Firebreaks have been graded around Wardle’s paddock and two burning off operations have cleared the vegetable area and the paddock. A water pipe has been laid on to the area. A shed from Whyte Yarcowie has been obtained for agriculture.

Mr Richard Bednall has organised a program for senior students of the school each Friday evening at the former Salvation Army Citadel.

Year 7 had an excursion on 2 April to Mount Razorback. The mountain was climbed before lunch. Some kangaroos were spotted on the way up. A sketching exercise followed the descent. A science scavenger hunt followed and a hide and seek game ended the day. (This report was by student Emma O’Connor.)

98, 12, 13 Apr. 1976, page 2

Mr Graeme Stafford is the new manager of the Burra Branch of the National Bank. He has come from Darwin with his wife and family. [Photo.] [Correction in paper of 21 April, page 7; Graeme Spafford not Stafford.]

Advt. Copper Town Coffee Shop, 12 Commercial Street. Opening Wednesday 14 April, 10 a.m. to 7 p.m.

Light Meals, Drinks, Sweets, Ice Cream. Proprietors John & Dorothy Maidment, Lionel & Barbara Loughhead.

Manager Barbara Loughhead.
