98, 12, 13 Apr. 1976, page 7

Advt. Burra Pictures, 17 April

Huckleberry Finn

Sammy Davis Jnr & Peter Lawford in One More Time

Stockowners’ Association of SA, Burra District Branch held its AGM 6 April at the Burra RSL Hall.

Elected: President, J.T. Drew of Windy Brae, Booborowie; Vice-Presidents, R.J. Ashby & L.M.R. Gosse.

Guest speakers from the SA Executive were H.G. Brooks & W.E. Seager.

Burra Methodist Choir will present the cantata Easter Day on Sunday.

Birth. To Elizabeth & Geoff Mosey of Robertstown on Sunday, a daughter, Natalie.

Tennis. Grand Finals

‘B’ Grade Spalding White narrowly defeated Burra White by 10 games

‘C’ Grade Booborowie 8 sets defeated Hallett 4 sets

Bill & Bet Corner have returned after some months at Nuriootpa since Bill became ill.

Don Kempster finishes as Manager at the National Bank at Burra on Thursday and will move into insurance in the district.

98, 12, 13 Apr. 1976, page 8

The Mid North Football League ceased to exist when President Stan Noske signed the minutes of the annual meeting at a dinner at the Riverton Hotel on Friday night 2 April. [Details of those present and the toasts proposed are reported in 23⁄4 columns.]

98, 13, 21 Apr. 1976, page 1

The Burra Burra Pistol Club was formed at a meeting held on Wednesday 14 April. Elected: President, Sergeant Bruce Haynes of Burra; Secretary, Nick Kingsley of Mt Bryan and Treasurer, Phil Edwards of Burra. A further meeting is scheduled for 28 April. Over 40 people indicated their interest. Four members of the SA Target Pistol League were present, including the President. Initially air pistol shoots can be held in any building with 10 m of space. Progress will later be made to the use of live ammunition.

Burra Burra DC

Final measurements are being collected for the Common Effluent Drainage Scheme. The plans should be received before the end of June for presentation to the Government. It is hoped the cost will be included in the list of estimates for 1976-77.

A volunteer has been accepted for the job of dog catcher.

Burning off has tidied up a number of town blocks.

New street signs have been erected for unmarked streets and to better mark others.

The map of the historic tour has been redone and upgraded.

It seems that sporting bodies will have to contribute more to the upkeep of recreation facilities.

Twelve model by-laws have been prepared by the Clerk for Council and for submission to the Local Government Office and the Crown Solicitor’s Office. They cover:

Hoardings Petrol Pumps Proceedings of Council

Slaughter Houses Traffic Bees

Garbage Bins Control of Horses Meetings of Ratepayers

Nuisances Water Reserves Tents

98, 13, 21 Apr. 1976, page 2

Advt. Burra Pictures, 24 April

Frogs

Wedding Night

98, 13, 21 Apr. 1976, page 3

Burra Easter Bowls Tournament

Men’s Pairs was won by B. Riggs & J. Topsfield of Burra

In Men’s Rinks on Saturday Morgan defeated Burra in the top section and Hallett won the bottom section.

On Monday two Hallett teams competed in the final of the Mixed Fours.

98, 13, 21 Apr. 1976, page 5

Burra Burra DC

It was resolved the Council make a firm offer up to $10,000 to convert the BCS Hall to a full-sized hall.

A letter was received from the Burra Small Bore Rifle Club concerning its closure.

98, 13, 21 Apr. 1976, page 7

St Mary’s has been desecrated by vandals.

Altar vessels, the cross and candlesticks were removed and shoved under the altar in the Lady Chapel. Pieces of candle were strewn around and the wires of the public address system were broken. Water was poured on the carpet; glass in historic photographs was broken. Sunburn cream was applied to a glass case and a door. Books and magazines were thrown around and some were torn. The Reserve Sacrament was removed from the Aumbry. The adjacent hall was also entered and coffee and tea were mixed with the children’s sand tray.

St Joseph’s was visited by vandals about a week ago. The vandals have since been apprehended. The church will now be locked when not in use.

Adam Thomas Simpson is the adopted infant son of Brian & Judy Simpson of Melbourne and a grandchild for Nancy & Len Simpson of Burra.

Obituary. Mrs Irene Gebhardt, widow of the late Ludie Gebhardt and mother of Don and Bob of Mt Bryan, died in the Burra Hospital on Saturday.

[Born Irene Gladys Gooley 5 April 1892 Adelaide: died 17 April 1976. Other sources give death date as 14 April.]

Burra National Trust Branch has formed a junior group within BCS.

98, 13 (2), 28 Apr. 1976, page 1

National Trust

A Junior Branch of the National Trust has been formed within the Community School. The inaugural meeting was on 15 April. President, Brenton Henriks; Vice-President, Anthony Lloyd; Secretary, Daryl McGuire; Treasurer, Anthony Quinn and works foreman, Mark Hopkins.

The group’s present major objective is the completion of the restoration work at the Bon Accord building. The Senior Branch is removing the Queen Victoria letter receiver from its position in Commercial Street to allocation opposite the Barker Homes near the Hospital, where it will once more be on active service.

The town’s original fire engine will be kept in running order and will be seen at special events.

[In the paper of 4 May, page 7, this was corrected to say that the comparatively recently retired 1930s Diamond T fire brigade will be kept in running order.]

The restoration of the Powder Magazine is nearing completion.

The new waterproof surface replaces the original roof platting. The stonework will soon be re-pointed and an iron gate placed at the entrance.

Borers have attacked the roofing timbers at the restored dugouts.

BCS will conduct a recreation program for young people during the May school vacation. Mr Richard Bednall, the Physical Education teacher, will organise the program. Community involvement now includes card evenings and a yoga group.

Mr Bob Steel, President of Burra RSL, addressed an assembly of students from Year 4 to Year 12 on the significance of Anzac Day at an assembly on Friday.

98, 13 (2), 28 Apr. 1976, page 2

98, 13 (2), 28 Apr. 1976, page 3

The ABC Program Blue Hills will end in September. The program began on 28 February 1949 and the final episode will be number 5,795 to be broadcast on Thursday 30 September 1976.

98, 13 (2), 28 Apr. 1976, page 7

Anzac Day. The Dawn Service was attended by about 50 people at the Market Square Memorial. Rev. Alan Beames conducted the service.

Marriage. Salisbury Methodist Church

Andrew McInnes of Booborowie, son of Mr & Mrs Angus McInnes and

Patrice Griffiths, formerly of Booborowie, daughter of Mr & Mrs Bill Griffiths.

Obituary. Mr Malcolm Villis, who spent his childhood in Burra, died on Sunday aged 47.

[Malcolm James Villis born 5 November 1928 Kooringa.]

Burra Red Cross held a door knock appeal and raised $213.10. With other earnings they were able to send $300 to headquarters.

The Queen Victoria letter receiver was moved this morning from outside the Record office.

98, 14, 4 May 1976, page 1

BCS Year 1, 2 & 3 students went to Cumberlandvale Farm near Saddleworth on 26 April. The students saw hen feeding, egg sorting and packing as well as sheep shearing. They went on a bumpy trailer ride and on donkey rides.

98, 14, 4 May 1976, page 8

Burra Bowling Associates held their AGM 28 April and elected: President, J. Jamieson; Vice-Presidents, Hilda Wise and Zeta Brown; Treasurer, Minny Heitbrink and Secretary, Laurel Neill.

[The past year’s activities are reported in 3⁄4 column.]

98, 15, 11 May 1976, page 1

Burra Burra DC

Councillors retiring 3 July through the effluxion of time:

Burra Town Ward C.L. Phillips

Kooringa Ward W. Brown

Farrell Flat Ward J.W. Burge

Leighton Ward R.J. White

Mongolata Ward B.A. Riggs

Nominations are called by 14 May.

Burra Tennis Club has completed the first season on the new courts. Over $9,000 was received by the club and over $8,000 paid out in expenses, leaving a balance of $623. Balls cost $1,125. The Club’s share of new court costs was $2,000. New nets, posts and winders cost $540 and club house expenses were $200.

BCS. Interschool sports between Eudunda, Kapunda and Burra schools were held at Eudunda. The BCS sports day was held on 28 April. The lack of enthusiastic involvement by many students indicated the need for activities to involve the many not taking part in championship athletic events. Steele House was the clear winner.

Cup Winners:

U13 Boys P. Clode

U13 Girls H. Shattock

U14 Boys G. Phillips

U14 Girls S. Hughes

Open Boys N. van Buuren

Open Girls A. Berryman

[Individual results are not printed.]

Burra Burra Pistol Club

The second meeting of the Pistol Club was held 29 April in the Burra North Court House. Former members of the Burra Small Bore Rifle Club informed the meeting that a club shed, other equipment and over $300 would be transferred to the new club in the near future. A constitution was adopted and elected were: Patron, J. Oates; Vice-Patrons, T. Perry & G.R. Pearce; President, Sergeant B. Haynes; Vice-President, J. Newton; Captain, A. Pearce; Vice-Captain, L. Broad and secretary, N. Kingsley. [There were a number of lady members.]

Burra Pre-School Kindergarten has applied for a full time director to enable more children to attend and to make available two afternoons for play groups.

Burra Inter-Church Council

This group has recently been formed to discuss the sharing of ideas within the context of Christian unity. Fr Kevin Matthews presided and was assisted by Rev. Alan Beames and Rev. Barry May.

The Powder Magazine needs some smaller bricks than the standard size to complete the gateway. The originals were imported from England. Can anyone help?

98, 16, 19 May 1976, page 1

ARHS will run a special steam train to Burra on Saturday. Locals will be able to join the train for a run leaving at 1.15 p.m. to Hallett, arriving at 1.45 p.m. Departing Hallett 2.14 p.m. and arriving at Burra at 2.58 p.m. Tickets are $3 for adults and $1.50 for children. The train will be hauled by Rx 207 built in 1913.

Adelaide Wool Sales. Prices were somewhat lower generally. [Local district prices are listed.]

Burra Burra DC

It is expected that changes to the rate payments will be in force from 1 July. Payment of rates will become due sixty days after the serving of the notice. Provisions allow for payment by quarterly instalments and application for this must be made within thirty days.

Council is investigating the cost of new railings at the Town Hall.

Election nominations received:

Mongolata Ward J.P. Oates (replacing B.A. Riggs)

Leighton Ward J.W. McMahon (replacing R.J. White)

Farrell Flat Ward J.W. Burge (re-elected unopposed)

Kooringa Ward W. Brown (re-elected unopposed)

Burra Town Ward No nominations

A supplementary election is called for Burra Town Ward with nominations closing on 28 May.

Apex Club members have painted the shelter sheds at the Burra North Playground.

Rx 207 should arrive at Burra at 12.14 p.m. and proceed to the golf clubhouse, arriving there at 12.16 p.m. Passengers will disembark for lunch. The train will then return to the station, ready for the 1.15 p.m. departure for Hallett. After returning from Hallett the engine will be turned in readiness for its departure for Adelaide.

98, 17?, 25 May 1976, MISSING?

98, 17 (2)?, 1 June 1976, page 1

BCS

The main school building has been painted and so has the Home Economics room.

The Minister of Education, Dr Don Hopgood has announced that the building program will begin in July.

$20,000 contributed in two parts; $10,000 from the Burra Burra DC and $10,000 from the School Council will enable a full sized hall to be included in the program. Plans for the building (as revised) are on display in the foyer of the school.

A Men’s Fitness Course will begin soon and the typing class begins on Thursday 3 June at 7.30 p.m.

Community Programs are being organised and input is requested so that they end up providing what is really wanted. Two groups will receive suggestions and contribute to the organisation; The Community Advisory Agents and the Management Committee. [Members are listed.]

The Burra Inter-Church Council has arranged a special Ecumenical Service for Friday night in St Mary’s to mark the Week of Christian Unity. For the first time the Lutherans will be represented along with members of the Methodist, Anglican and catholic congregations. The first meeting of the Inter-Church Council was at St Joseph’s Hall last Wednesday. Elected: President, Roger Schwarz; Joint Secretaries, Rosemary Quinn & Jan Cockingham and Publicity Officer, Mary Woollacott.

The Council aims to promote shared worship, prayer, action and discussion among the churches and Christians of Burra.

98, 17 (2)?, 1 June 1976, page 7

Birth. To Lester & Lyn Launer (nee Winders of Black Springs) and now of Clare, on 25 May, a son, Trent Nicholas.

Obituary. Mr John Simpson of Rose Park and late of Mt Bryan has died aged 88.

[John Richard Simpson born 1 February 1888 Redruth.]

The Austcare Collection for Burra and District has reached $550 and is still open for donations.

98, 18, 8 June 1976, page 1

Monsignor T.F. Toal, Parish Priest of Jamestown and his brother Dr M.F. Toal celebrated their Golden Jubilee of Ordination at Jamestown this week. They were ordained in Genoa, Italy, 29 May 1926. There was Mass at St James’ Church at 11 a.m. followed by luncheon at the Jamestown Town Hall. Monsignor Toal studied at Mungret College, Limerick, and then at Collegio Brognole Sale, Genoa. After ordination he came to Australia and served in the Perth Diocese before coming to SA. He then served at Jamestown, Streaky Bay, Pt Pirie and at Whyalla for 31 years and in 1967 returned to Jamestown.

Dr Toal served at Jamestown and then at Burra and Pt Pirie. While at Burra in the 1930s and 1940s he was an interpreter at Loveday Prison Camp in WWII because of his multi-lingual abilities. He was a Professor at St Patrick’s College, Manly, and at St Francis Xavier’s Seminary, Adelaide. He went to Rome 23 years ago. He has been engaged in translating and publishing the homilies of the Fathers of the Catholic Church. Four volumes have already been published.

BCS. Community Week this term will offer assessment drives for licensed motorists. Computing courses will also be offered. One course will cater for students with some tertiary education and one for people with no Maths background or tertiary education. The student driver education course has commenced at the school, using a loaned new HJ Holden.

19, 16 June 1976, page 1 [The volume number is discretely omitted; probably due to the announcement of the paper’s centenary in this issue, when the inclusion of volume 98 would raise questions.]

The Paper celebrates its centenary on 30 June 1976, although it was first called the Northern Mail and Messrs Pether & Jarman undertook its editing and printing. A facsimile of the first edition is available for 60 cents.

[Ian Auhl produced a history of the paper on pages 1 & 4.]

BCS. Community School Week aims to produce a booklet about Burra and a record and booklet of some of the songs associated with Burra’s history. The school needs some interesting old photos and information about the songs sung here in the past. There is a committee compiling information for a centenary history of the school and they would like any photos or other relevant information.

19, 16 June 1976, pages 1 & 4

A History of the Burra Record by Ian Auhl

The paper began on 30 June 1876 as the Northern Mail

Six months later it changed its name to the Burra News and Northern Mail.

In July 1878 its new editor, Frederick William Holder announced its new title would be the Record.

On 4 October 1878 the name changed again to the Burra Record.

It had taken a long time for Burra to get a local paper. Compare its starting date with the Kapunda Herald (1864), the Kadina & Wallaroo Times (1865) and the Northern Argus (Clare, 1869).

Burra had to make do with printed handbills for advertising and a town crier. Other local news was occasionally to be found in the Adelaide papers the Advertiser or the Register or the weekly Observer.

The first editor, Henry Pether, ascribed this lack to opposition to a paper from the SA Mining Association, which had also been against local government.

The first editor of the Burra Record was Frederick William Holder. He had come to the town in 1875 as a bachelor to take charge of the Burra Public School. He became an active member of the Burra Parliamentary Club and discussion in this club led to the proposal for a local paper. A committee was formed to establish one. The cost originally of 3d made it too expensive for many and kept its circulation low; 600 by the end of 1876. Pether left in June 1878, soon after Jarman’s departure. The Government school opened in January 1878, leaving Holder without a job. When the editorship became available the committee of eight co-proprietors appointed Holder in his place.

In October 1878 Holder became the sole proprietor.

Under Holder the paper flourished. He became Mayor of Burra in 1886 and again in 1888, having been elected to Parliament in 1887. He was later Premier of SA on two occasions.

The paper has had three homes. The first seems to have been on what is now the eastern corner of Bence’s store.

In September 1880 Holder announced they would move next door because the original office was about to be demolished to make room for two new shops to be built for Messrs Drew & Co.

Three years later on 6 January 1883 four shops on Market Square were destroyed by fire: Lane’s Saddlery, Geake’s store, Packard’s Solicitor’s Office, Doe’s Hairdressing Salon and the Burra Record Office.

Despite the complete destruction the Burra Record appeared later that week, having been printed in Adelaide. The shops were rapidly rebuilt.

Late in 1883 the paper was issued twice a week and the price fell to 2d.

In 1890 Holder sold the paper to Mr P. Murrie Jnr.

In January 1891 the paper reverted to being a weekly.

In September 1891 W.J. Davey took over as editor. [And later became the proprietor.]

Davey reduced the size of the paper and in 1904 increased the pages to 8.

Davey sold out to Ernest Frederick Marston in March 1913.

In 1945 E.F. Marston sold the paper to his son Frank Teare Marston.

In 1942 the paper was reduced to four pages, but increased again to 8 from 1945.

E.E. & R.E. Angel acquired the paper in June 1954. The Marstons had printed the paper for 41 years.

Eric Angel must be the person with the longest association with the paper. He came to Burra from Eudunda in 1929 and was employed by Mr Marston Sen. and then by his son before taking it over in 1954 with his son, Bob, the present editor.

[Auhl fails to mention the move from Market Square to Commercial Street and its date. I have not ascertained when it moved to Commercial Street, but the Market Square premises were destroyed by fire again in April 1910, but were rebuilt on the same site. In January 1935 they were in Commercial Street when a fire that began in an adjoining shop again burnt out the office, but this time the press was saved. See also 98, 21, 29 June 1976, page 7 for corrections to this history.]

98, 20, 22 June 1976, page 1

BCS. Community School Week offers 52 short courses. [Listed on page 3.]

The model of the new school is on display in Matthews’ window.

Burra Pistol Club will officially open the club’s range on 23 June at the Burra Show Hall. This will be the club’s first official shoot and members of the SA Pistol Club and delegates of the SA Pistol League are expected to attend. [Details in about 3⁄4 column.]

Frank McMahon has won this year’s C.J. Dennis prize for narrative poetry at the Adelaide Festival. He had written no poetry until ten months ago and had begun writing while convalescing from a series of illnesses. He had been introduced to C.J. Dennis as a boy – both his father and an uncle had been WWI veterans and C.J. Dennis devotees. His winning poem is titled Chapel Street Burra SA.

98, 21, 29 June 1976, page 1

Basketball. A call is made for teams to be formed for the coming season.

Stock Brands. All brands will be cancelled from 31 December. The existing register has been used for over 40 years and is difficult to interpret because of the number of cancellations and transfers and there is a problem with many brands not being officially transferred. Persons wishing to keep their existing brand need to write to the Registrar of Brands or complete a form and lodge it before the end of the year.

BCS. Enrolments for Community School Week are now flowing in. [Details of offerings are printed.]

98, 21, 29 June 1976, pages 1 & 4

Birth. To Christine & Jeffery Wedding of Booborowie on 22 June, at Burra Hospital, a son, Damien Craig.

Paul Beinke has joined the SA Police and starts tomorrow.

Obituary. Mr Arnold Lucas of Burra and formerly of Hallett died last Thursday aged 88.

[George Arnold Lucas, but birth not on SA Births CD.]

Arthur Wright of Burra scored a hole in one on Saturday.

Dogs have been worrying sheep lately with several being mauled. The most recent attack was at ‘The Pines’ just north of the town, where several three-month-old lambs have had to be destroyed.

The Burra Floral Art Club is to be wound up.

Corrections to last week’s History of the Burra Record.

E.F. Marston who took over the paper in 1913 did not run a photographic studio. His predecessor Mr W.J. Davey did.

Mr Davey’s sons Harold and Billy continued to work for the Record until they went elsewhere.

The Record was then printed in premises occupied by Matthews in a section nearest Bence’s.

It was later burnt out.

We have a photo of the premises in 1913 with E.F. Marston, W.J. Davey Jnr and H.J. Davey standing outside with Arnold Gravestocks, another employee. This has come from Ian Auhl on loan from Mrs Miriam Davey, widow of the late W.J. Davey Jnr. We hope to publish it next week. [They didn’t.]

Adelaide Wool Sales. Local district prices are printed.

98, 21, 29 June 1976, page 8

Chapel Street, Burra SA, the C.J. Dennis Prize-Winning poem by Frank McMahon is printed along with a letter from the author to Rev. Alan Beames, Minister of the Burra Methodist Church.

98, 22, 6 July 1976, page 1

Hallett Centenary

In 1977 Hallett will celebrate 100 years of local government. Oddly, due to an oversight, Hallett has never been proclaimed a town. A meeting was held on 23 June to formulate a program for the Centenary Celebrations. [The suggestions are printed.] A further meeting is scheduled for 14 October when sub-committees will report to the public.

Hockey. Burra drew with Balaklava nil each.

Dogs have killed and wounded many sheep on properties adjoining the town. Dog owners are reminded of their responsibilities under the relevant section of the Dog Registration Act. [Section 21 is printed.]

BCS. School Community Week 5-9 July will involve many of the community, school staff and instructors from the local community and from further away and is shaping up to be a great success.

98, 22, 6 July 1976, page 4

Burra Pistol Club. Fifty-two people attended the opening night. President Sergeant B. Haynes welcomed visitors. Vice-President of the Pistol League Mr I. Macfarlane attended. Vice-Patron Tom Perry made a short speech and Patron Jack Oates fired the first official shot. Forty shooters then went through five-shot rounds. N. Doube and I. Macfarlane demonstrated the correct way to stand and breathe and handle the pistol. Thirty-three of thirty-eight members attended.

Clem & Olive Sampson of Esperance WA write congratulating the paper on its centenary. They have been receiving the paper ever since moving to WA in 1936. W.J. Davey’s sons Bill and Harold were friends, says Clem, who says he was born at Hampton in 1893 and the family lived in Redruth and Aberdeen till 1900 when they moved to the old manse of the Primitive Methodist Church in Kooringa, next to what is now the Masonic Lodge building.

Athol Tiver writes concerning the Federal Conference of the Isolated Children’s Parents’ Association (ICPA) to be held in Broken Hill 21 July – at which observers would be welcome.

98, 22, 6 July 1976, page 6

Advt. Burra Pictures, 10 July

James Cann in Rollerball

John Houseman & Maud Adams in Sleeper

Lyle Quinn, Roche Bros’ manager, is leaving Burra. He came to the town in 1970 when Roche Bros. won the contract for earth moving at the Burra Mine for Samin Ltd. He has been involved in other jobs outside the Mine, including site preparation for the new Golf Club. He was responsible for starting Roche Bros. Social Club, which bought the Oddfellows’ Hall for its use and was also involved in the annual Miners’ Cabaret. Now after 24 years of earthmoving and 20 years with Roche Bros. he is leaving Burra and the company. He will go to manage a caravan park at Rushworth in Victoria; his hometown. He has worked on a huge range of job types in earthmoving in NSW, ACT, SA and Tasmania (including King Island). Dave Ball will take over his position in Burra as temporary manager. The social club will continue with David Thamm as the new President.

98, 22, 6 July 1976, page 7

Burra Women’s Branch of the Liberal Party

Mrs Ron Pearce’s report of the branch’s activities for the year is printed in 1 column.

Birth. To Kerry & Robert Phillips of Burra North at QVMH on Friday, a daughter, Anita Michelle.

Obituary. Don Tomkins died recently at Koonamore Station aged 53. He was well known in Burra.

98, 22, 6 July 1976, page 8

Burra Bowling Club. The President’s Report for the 1975-76 season is printed in 11⁄3 columns.

Neil Hurst was the Club Champion.

Johnny Hill and Kies van der Does won the Championship Pairs.

The January and Easter Open Tournaments were financially successful. The Associates have again supplied catering arrangements for these tournaments.

The sound financial position of the club has been considerably aided by the success of the bar and thanks go to Clive Neill as bar manager. The good condition of the greens is a tribute to the work of Edgar Pietsch.

98, 23, 13 July 1976, page 1

RSL Snooker Tournament will be held over the next few weeks.

B.A. Santamaria contributes a 21⁄4 column article on The Rural Crisis – reprinted from his column Point of View in News Weekly.

Thefts. Early on Sunday morning goods and cash to a value of $5,600 from four premises. [Though the paper actually has $56000 with an awkward line split after the 5.]

Jennison’s Tyre Service – six colour television sets

Garage Workshops opposite – entered apparently in a search for a utility to use as transport

T.W. Wilkinson & Co. – Chemist – entered and sun glasses and petty cash taken.

Burra Hotel – a quantity of cash was taken and a getaway vehicle was taken from J.J. & B.C. Richards’ Garage.

Community School Week has run smoothly and the weather for outdoor activities was perfect. Almost 100 adults took advantage of the courses on offer.

98, 23, 13 July 1976, page 3

Advt. Elders-GM will auction the farming property ‘Windarra’ 19 km southwest of Burra comprising 508.06 ha on instructions from R.T. & A.J. Bailey. The property will be offered in one lot and if not sold then in eight lots.

[Details including section numbers are printed in an advertisement 2 columns wide by 2⁄3 column deep.]

98, 23, 13 July 1976, page 8

Hanson CWA held its AGM, which is reported in 12⁄3 columns. Membership was 20 with an average attendance of 11.

Mr Ivan Milde of Saddleworth has been a mail contractor for 22 years and on 30 June carried the Royal Mail for the last time from Saddleworth to Black Springs, calling at Marrabel, Waterloo, Black Springs and Tarnma. An article on his experiences runs for a little less than 2 columns.

98, 26, 20 July 1976, page 1 Check this leap in numbering from 23 to 26.

Burra Burra DC, last Monday

Cr R.B. Jennison was elected Chairman and former Chairman Cr W. Brown is now his deputy.

A petition is being organised for road works on the Spalding to Morgan Road via Burra. Four Councils will give it support.

Advt. The Circle Theatre Company will present Young Mo by Steve J. Spears. It is a new musical play based on the life of Roy Rene. In Burra Wednesday 28 July.

Birth. To Mr & Mrs Randall of Burra North on 17 July, a daughter, Gabrielle Ruth.

Obituary. Mrs Mary Sullivan of Booborowie died in the RAH on Sunday. She was the widow of the late Frank Sullivan and is survived by her children, Peter, Frank, Jack and Maureen.

[Probably born Mary Clare Neylon 30 April 1912 Conway Town (Port Augusta).]

Obituary. Mr Gustav A. Mickel of Farrell Flat died in Riverton Hospital 20 July aged 83. He is survived by his wife and three children. [Gustav Alfred Mickel born 7 August 1892 Hundred of English.]

Tony Ryan, the well-known shearer, was on TV last night demonstrating the cradle method for shearing sheep, crutching and mulesing.

The Queen Victoria letter receiver near the Barker Homes has been renovated and after marking with clearance times will be returned to use.

Val Martin, Burra manager for ETSA, with his wife Daphne and daughter Penny will move to Bordertown in about two weeks.

A Spinning & Weaving Group might be formed in Burra if there is sufficient interest. A meeting is planned for Coral Billington’s home 7 Mt Pleasant Road on Thursday evening.

Northern Region Red Cross will hold its Annual Service in St Joseph’s, Burra on Thursday 10 August.

[Correct in the paper of 3 August, page 7 to Tuesday 10 August.]

98, 27 (2), 3 Aug. 1976, page 1

Burra Burra DC

The wall on the downstream side of the Burra Creek dam was not constructed as a walkway. It was not planned as such and is not envisaged as such in the future.

The trees in the area were not planted to provide an anchorage for ropes swinging over the lake.

The wood supplied for barbecues is not to be removed for other purposes.

Littering is a problem in the creek area.

The Art Gallery’s Travelling Exhibition will be at the Town Hall in Burra on 18 & 19 August.

Mr Simon Newell of Newell’s Travel Agency in Falmouth, Cornwall, contacted Mr Ian Auhl recently on behalf of a client, Mr John Gill aged 72. Mr Gill had read the Burra Sketchbook and it prompted the contact.

Mr Gill came to Australia in 1921 as a sponsored emigrant and returned to the UK in 1928. While in Australia he drove a 1904 Sunbeam Talbot for Mr Jim Gallagher of Quondong Station and later a f-ton International truck and trailer for the Burra firm of Drew & Crewes. On the delivery run for the firm Mr Gill took three days for the round trip and was paid £4 for a seven day week. There were 90 gates to open and close on the route, still served by a Burra contractor. Mr Gill claims that he and a companion brought in the first load of wool from the ‘outback’ by mechanised transport. Soon after arriving back in the UK he set out on a round the world tour on a motor bike with sidecar. (A Vincent HRD) This took over a year. He married and has two daughters. For many years he was chief engineer for the Admiralty and moved to Falmouth about 33 years ago.

98, 27 (2), 3 Aug. 1976, page 3

Burra Pistol Club. Best at the last shoot were: A. Pearce, L. Broad, W. Barker & L. Whitrod.

Carey Noack of the Burra Post Office will soon move to the GPO in Adelaide.

Neil Hurst, Burra Post Master, will move to the Pulteney Street Post Office in Adelaide next month.

Mr & Mrs Tom Hams of Leighton recently celebrated their Golden Wedding.

Burra Branch of M&BHA held its AGM recently. President Eleanor Nicholls reported a year of fellowship and fundraising. Early in the year attendance was averaging only eight, but the post-Christmas average has been fourteen. [Details are reported in 1 column.]

98, 27 (2), 3 Aug. 1976, page 8

Burra Red Cross Branch held its AGM and elected: President, Mrs E. Baulderstone; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames A. Wright & G. Gallagher; Secretary, Mr H. Rich & Treasurer, Mr H. Heitbrink. Membership was 27 with an average attendance of 8. Despite low attendance, members give outstanding support both financially and with their time. [The report on activities extends for just over 1 column.]

98, 28, 10 Aug. 1976, page 1

Hockey. The second semi-final was a protracted affair. At the end of normal time the match between Burra and Roseworthy was drawn at 3 goals each. Two extra five minute halves left the scores unchanged. Five penalty strokes followed and brought the scores to 4 goals each. After a further five penalty strokes Burra 6 eventually defeated Roseworthy 4 and so moves into the grand-final.

BCS will hold its first Annual Ball on Friday 20 August in the Burra Town Hall. The ball will be attended by Mr Claude Allen MP, who will launch the ‘Buy a Brick’ campaign. This is to raise funds for the School Community Hall. Years VI & VII students are planning an end-of-year social.

Lutheran Sunday School Rooms at Burra North will be dedicated on Sunday 15 August with a special service at which Pastor Kuchel and previous Pastors A.H. Schmidt and P.A. Scherer will officiate. Luncheon will follow in the Redruth Memorial Hall. The first Lutheran Church was built opposite the Court House at Burra North. This later was burnt down and the deeds were lost. Services were then held in a variety of places, served by the Pastor from Kunden Parish, Waterloo. Among places used were the Copperhouse Methodist Church [actually Westbury Methodist Church, adjacent to Copperhouse] the Oddfellows’ Hall Burra North and the Church of England Hall at Burra. There is little evidence of Sunday school activity during this period.

In 1967 parishes were re-aligned and Burra joined with the Clare-Blyth parish. Colin Heinrich is then noted as the first Sunday school teacher. On 21 August 1967 the existing Burra Lutheran Church arrived on a low loader from Mansfield Park. The building was placed on newly acquired land at Burra North and dedicated on 5 November 1967. In 1968 David Munzberg was elected Sunday school superintendent and Mr Kleinig as a teacher. At times lessons were held in the back seat of a car until the late Mr P. Beinke kindly lent his house. This became unsatisfactory when numbers increased to make three classes. Classes were then held in the vestry, porch and hall of the church. Eventually it was possible to obtain a four-roomed building at Milang for $650. It arrived in Burra in January 1976 and was sited north of the church. The building required considerable repairs and repainting. This work has now been completed. There are presently 27 children on the roll with three helpers, three relief teachers, four teachers and a Sunday school superintendent.

98, 28, 10 Aug. 1976, page 2

Burra Pistol Club. Best scorers at the last shoot were: N. Kingsley, L. Whitrod, M. Hoskins & M. Stolte.

98, 28, 10 Aug. 1976, page 3

Advt. Elders-GM will auction ‘Windarra’ 19 km southwest of Burra on 27 August in Burra RSL Hall on instructions from Mr R.T. & Mrs A.L. Bailey. The property in the Gum Creek district has been in the Bailey Family since 1857. It will be offered as a whole first and if not sold then in eight lots.

[The eight lots are described and other details are given in an advertisement two columns wide by 3⁄4 column.]

98, 29, 17 Aug. 1976, page 1

Burra Burra DC

The Council adopted last year’s assessment with necessary adjustments and increased the rates by 5%.

A general rate of 1.2 cents in the dollar was adopted with 12 cents in the dollar in the townships of Farrell Flat, Booborowie, Mt Bryan and Burra. Payment by instalments can be applied for. Work needed to enable the public toilets in Chapel Street to be re-opened will be done in the next couple of weeks.

BCS. Site work for the new school is expected to begin in September. Twenty to thirty men will work on the site until the beginning of the 1978 school year.

The 25th International Geological Congress in Sydney was preceded by a series of associated tours. One of them in SA saw up to 80 leading geologists from overseas visit the Middleback Ranges iron ore deposits, Beltana willemite [a zinc silicate] and Burra copper deposits.

Seat of Eyre. The Shadow Minister for Agriculture, Mr Graham Gunn, will seek Liberal Party endorsement for the newly created seat of Eyre in the House of Assembly.

BCS will act as a Recreation Centre in the school vacation 23 August to 27 August. [Program details are given.]

98, 29, 17 Aug. 1976, page 3

Notice. The National Bank of Australasia gives notice that the weekly agency conducted at Hallett since 1909 will close on 29 September 1976. This change has been brought about by declining use of the service as many clients now prefer to travel to Burra once or twice a week to shop and attend to banking business.

G.R. Spafford

Branch Manager, Burra.

North Clare 7.3 defeated South Clare 4.4

98, 29, 17 Aug. 1976, page 4

Uniting Church

The High Court of Australia has dismissed an action challenging the proposed entry of the Presbyterian Church into the Uniting Church. An appeal to the Privy Council has not been rules out and this could delay the inauguration of the Uniting Church beyond the scheduled date of 22 June 1977. In the meantime a comprehensive educational program is preparing the local church for union. Burra Circuit will become a Parish and be part of Frome Presbytery.

98, 29, 17 Aug. 1976, page 5

Burra Scouts & Cubs continue to be active, with 18 Cubs at the last meeting. The Scouts visited Samin’s Laboratory at their last meeting.

Obituary. Mr McMahon Sen. died in Adelaide last Tuesday aged 92. Mons McMahon & Sons Optometrists have been advertising in this paper for decades.

Redruth Methodist Ladies’ Guild celebrates its jubilee on Thursday 26 August with a musical luncheon in Redruth Memorial Hall. It was formed by the late Rev. Harry Alvey in 1926.

98, 30, 24 Aug. 1976, page 1

BCS. The School Ball was successfully held in the Burra Town Hall on Friday night. The proceeds were $503. (Door takings were $598 and donations $40.) The Buy-a-Brick Campaign to fund the multi-purpose hall was launched and presently stands at $434.

Years 5 & 6 students recently spent a morning cleaning up debris from the Burra Creek as their part in ‘Clean Up Week’.

The Spinners & Weavers Group is meeting monthly with the next meeting on 9 September.

Burra Town Hall 3 September 2 p.m.

98, 31, 31 Aug. 1976, page 1

Adelaide Wool Sales 25-26 August. Top district price was 204c for W. Brown & Co. of ‘The Grove’.

[Other local district prices are printed.]

Date Stamps. New regulations requiring date stamping of short-life perishable foodstuffs [or as the paper says ‘footstuffs’] will come into force in 12 months time and will apply to all pre-packaged perishable foods with a life up to 90 days or less. They will have to carry a date as to when they should be used. Break and milk bottles will be exempt because of labelling problems.

98, 31, 31 Aug. 1976, pages 1 & 7

Redruth Methodist Ladies’ Guild celebrated its 50th Anniversary last Thursday. Mrs Reta Jennison has been the secretary for those 50 years and Mrs A.B. Riggs and Miss C.A. Reed were two of eight foundation members present. Luncheon was held in the Redruth Memorial Hall where beautiful flower arrangements were done by Mrs Les White. Olive Oates and Jan Cockington played light music. Several former ministers attended with representatives from the town’s other guilds and the Catholic Women’s League. Miss Clarice Reed gave the gold-iced birthday cake. Mrs A.B. Riggs, who was the first treasurer, came from Adelaide with her daughter Lois and cut the cake. Mrs Venning, formerly Mrs Dyer, the wife of the late Rev. Dyer, came to Burra in 1937 and she lit the candles. After lunch there was time for reminiscences and performances from many with long associations with the church at Burra North.

Lindsay Thomas sang I shall not pass this way again and Lucky ‘ole Sun accompanied by his wife Joyce at the piano, who also played two pieces by Greig.

Dorothy White, nee Woollacott sang Early in the morning and Faith can move mountains, accompanied by Jan Cockington.

Netta McIntosh, nee Thomas sang If I can help somebody and May the good Lord bless and keep you.

Her husband, Howie McIntosh gave two stories: The three little pigs and Cinderella in the manner of Dr Spooner.

Mavis Satchell, nee Fairchild, sang Her name is Mary and Little Jack Horner in the style of Handel.

The Guild had been founded in 1926 by the late Rev. Harry Alvey with the strong support of his wife. The minutes of the first meeting were read again with the names of the ladies who had joined in the first year. Other speakers were Rev. Don Haydon (President elect of the Methodist Conference), Rev. George O’Neill (Chairman of the Middle District), Rev. Pitman, Rev. Clem Christopher, Mrs M. Odgers, Mrs Boyce and Mr Colin Fuller.

Other visitors included: Joyce Pearce, May Cox, Nellie Benger & her husband Alan, Sheila & Joyce Fairchild, Jean Humphrys, Barb Thompson nee Jennison and her daughter Marian, Norma Reed, Mrs F. Przibilla, Joyce Greig nee Jefferies and Shirley Fuller.

98, 31, 31 Aug. 1976, page 2

Notice. The ANZ Bank regrets to advise that its Hallett Agency, operated each Wednesday by its Burra branch, will be discontinued from 29 September. Steeply rising costs have forced this decision.

L.H. Higgins

Burra Branch Manager.

Obituary. Ellie Byrnes, wife of Percy Byrnes, died in Adelaide on 21 August. She and her husband had conducted a shoe shop in Burra for many years before retiring to Adelaide. She is survived by her husband and children, John, Des and Moira. [Born Ellen Mabel Fitzgerald 17 May 1904 Solomontown. The surname should be Byrne.]

Fire. A derelict house just off Kangaroo Street was gutted by fire on Friday night at about 11 p.m.

98, 32, 7 Sep. 1976, page 7

BCS. Several prefabricated buildings have been positioned in the former car park area. The road to the school via Bridge Street [sic: for Bridge Terrace] is now closed at the school end.

Birth. To Peter & Sue Wise, nee Collins, on 2 September at Brisbane hospital, a daughter, Belinda Lee. A granddaughter for Mr & Mrs J. Collins of Booborowie and for Mr & Mrs Bert Wise of Burra.

Marriage. Clare Sunday 29 August

Bev. Kleinig, younger daughter of Mr & Mrs Kevin Kleinig of Burra, married Mike Scanlan.

Film Matinee. Fans of the Three Stooges were not pleased when the matinee screening on Friday showed Alice in Wonderland instead of the advertised feature – through no fault of the local organisers.

Marriage. At ‘The Barn’ McLaren Vale next Saturday

Jane Bailey, daughter of Mr & Mrs Don Bailey of Hallett, will marry

Robin McLeay, son of Mr John McLeay MHR and Mrs McLeay.

Peacock’s Chimney will soon be floodlit as a result of a joint project of the National Trust and the Tourist Promotion Committee.

98, 33, 14 Sep. 1976, page 1

BCS. October is mini-course month. One night a week will be devoted to a series of courses. The School Council has funded the latest Nashua photocopier for the school. The A.B. Riggs Award this year has been used to purchase a set of agricultural reference books.

Burra Burra Hospital Inc. Annual Report

The Board of Management will have to rely on public support for the next 12 months even more than it has in the past year if standards are to be maintained. Thanks are extended again to the sewing ladies and other donors for their continued support. The Government has indicated a strict budget for the coming year. Average bed costs have risen by $7.76 to $30.22. During the year there were 386 patients admitted and 355 were discharged. There were 703 out-patients and 101 operations were performed. During the year a new boiler was installed and air-conditioning placed in the Nurses’ Home and in the remaining private rooms. New beds and a new deep freeze unit have been purchased. We regret losing the services of Sister Oates, who took a position as Matron at Kimba Hospital. Matron and the other nursing and domestic staff have done excellent work. Meals on Wheels has continued to operate efficiently from the hospital.

98, 33, 14 Sep. 1976, page 2

Netball. Preliminary Finals

B1 Min-Man 40 defeated Burra 27

C2 Burra 34 defeated Blyth 30

Advt. Burra Community Entertainment Group will present Salad Days, a lively musical at the Burra Town Hall on Friday 1 October.

Football. North-Eastern League. Voting figures for the Mail Medal Count are printed.

98, 33, 14 Sep. 1976, page 6

Advt. Burra Pictures, 18 September

Naturally Free

Blue Water, White Death

98, 33, 14 Sep. 1976, page 7

Football. North-Eastern League Preliminary Finals

‘A’ Grade North Clare 22.14 defeated South Clare 18.7

‘B’ Grade Burra 10.9 defeated South Clare 5.8

Senior Colts North Clare 10.5 defeated Burra 5.7

Junior Colts Blyth 6.3 defeated Burra 3.7

Weather. Burra experienced a light fall of snow on Thursday. It didn’t linger, but at Mt Bryan and Hallett the ranges were blanketed all day. In the last week rainfall was significant at 27.2 mm or 107.09 points.

Marriage. Saturday 25 September

Nannette Simpson of Mt Bryan will marry Gordon Burns.

Obituary. Mr Frank Reed died suddenly at home yesterday aged 77. He is survived by his widow Dorrie and children Robert and Rosemary. [Frank Henwood Reed born 12 July 1899 Semaphore.]

The Mail Medal for the North-Eastern Football League this year has gone to Don Sommerville of North Clare.

Ian Tiver will be installed as Worshipful Master of the Hallett Masonic Lodge tomorrow evening. This will be the second year he has held the position.

98, 34, 21 Sep. 1976, page 1

BCS

The Burra Community Entertainment Group is made up of students, staff and community members and after much work and great enthusiasm they will produce a lively and fun-filled production of Salad Days on Thursday 30 September and Friday 1 October.

The Youth Club ZOB, which existed in Burra a few years ago still held over $300 in funds when it ceased activities. Now that there is a youth group active in the town again, those funds have been handed over to them.

School has continued with little interruption despite the fact that all the prefab. Classrooms have been lifted and transported from the rear of the main building to the front, where they have been re-sited on what was the car park. Burra Burra DC will carry out the site works. The Public Buildings Department will begin laying out the new Resource Centre, which is to be attached to the rear of the present stone building – and the erection of the secondary teaching block.

A meeting is called for 23 September to arrange for the opening of the swimming season and to form a swimming club for the benefit of the enthusiastic young people who could gain so much from its existence.

The Great Gatsby will be screened on Thursday 23 September in the Town Hall at 9.30 a.m. Adults as well as students are invited. Cost $0.50.

98, 34, 21 Sep. 1976, page 2

Football. North-Eastern League Grand Finals

‘A’ Grade Burra 19.13 defeated North Clare 14.9

‘B’ Grade Burra 11.10 defeated North Clare 7.13

Senior Colts Blyth 7.4 defeated Min-Man 6.7

Junior Colts Min-Man 15.14 defeated North Clare 7.7

Presentations:

Mr P. McInerney who won the Mail Medal in 1933 presented this year’s Mail Medal to Don Sommerville of North Clare.

Patrick Hill of Min-Man was presented with the Senior Colts’ ‘Bull Dog’ Medal.

‘B’ Grade leading goal kicker award went to Clive Clark of North Clare.

‘B’ Grade Best and Fairest, the Pink Medal, went to Colin Hall of Booborowie.

Barry Pontt of South Clare won the award for ‘A’ Grade leading goal kicker.

The Burra Record Trophy for the runner-up in the Mail Medal count went to Ian Roberts of Blyth.

Burra Pistol Club. Graham Williams won the Karmia Trophy for marksman. Norma Barker was most improved lady and Phillip Edwards was most improved gentleman. Best scorers were A. Pearce, L. Whitrod, L. Broad and K. Burley.

98, 34, 21 Sep. 1976, page 5

Burra Burra DC, 13 September

A legalistic paragraph declares Mary Crescent at Burra North closed and part of it is sold to E.A. & E.L. Clode and part to A.L. & E.G. Heinrich.

It was resolved to purchase a Ford petrol motor truck with air operated tailgate and high tensile steel tray for a changeover price of $18,700.

98, 34, 21 Sep. 1976, page 6

Obituary. A Return Thanks Notice reveals the death of Roy Voumard, husband of Mary Voumard – probably at Jamestown Hospital.

Notice. Tenders are invited by the Methodist Church Property Trust for allotments 89-90 Town of Hanson on which are erected a former Sunday school hall approximately 57 ft x 27 ft in solid stone and a former church in stone approximately 36 ft x 24 ft.

98, 34, 21 Sep. 1976, page 7

Advt. Oates Pty Ltd will conduct an auction for Mrs E.J. Villis on the premises, 12 Thames St at 9.30 a.m. Saturday 16 October, on which is erected a five-roomed stone dwelling with bathroom and laundry under the same roof.

Advt. Burra Pictures, 25 September

Ryan O’Neal, Madeline Kahn & Tatum O’Neal in Paper Moon

Rock Hudson & Dean Martin in Showdown

The Lapidary Club voted to be disbanded at a committee meeting held on Sunday. In its heyday it had nearly 40 members, but removals and declining interest has necessitated this move.

Mr & Mrs Jeff Maehr have come to Burra from Windarra, WA, with their four children. Jeff is the new local manager for Roche Bros. who have the earthworks contract for the Burra Mine.

Peach’s Australia on the topic of SA’s Cornish heritage has been shown and gone to the film libraries. Burra features only briefly considering the time spent here filming.

The Adams family from Spalding will arrive in Burra this week to take up residence in the postmaster’s house.

Birth. To Graham & Jeanette Milde, (nee Zanker, of Burra) now of Adelaide, recently, a son, Todd.

98, 35, 28 Sep. 1976, page 1

BCS. At the recent Parents & Friends’ Association meeting the President Mrs Lyn Kempster resigned as she is leaving the district.

The Tourist Promotion Committee met on 24 September and elected Chairman, Ian Allen and Secretary, Mrs Irene Hirschausen. It was decided to hold a Copper festival in October 1977. This would coincide with the centenaries of the Burra Show Society and the Burra Model School.

Burra Football Club held its end of season dinner in the Town Hall on Friday night.

Awards:

‘A’ Grade Best & Fairest was C. Baker.

Most votes in the Mail Medal count for Burra Club were obtained by Bert Seaford.

‘B’ Grade Best & Fairest was R. Williams.

Bankcard will start operating in the Burra area in November 1976.

The Burra Anglican Parish held a special Blessing of the Fleece service in the spacious Caroona Station Woolshed last Sunday. About 150 people attended. Thanks to James & Ryves Hawker for allowing the use of their property and to manager Mr Lawrie Anderson and his wife Daph. For their work in preparation. Father Robert Niehus of Maitland gave the sermon and assisted Fr Barry May of Burra in the celebration of Holy Communion. A barbecue followed the service.

Accident/Obituary. A Piper Cherokee 180 aircraft crashed east of Mt Bryan Township soon after 8 a.m. on Friday in thick fog. The crash was about two miles northeast of Belcunda Homestead. The four people on board died instantly. The pilot was Quentin Thorpe of Victor Harbor and his wife, Helen and the other passengers were his parents, Mr & Mrs V. Thorpe of Peake.

98, 35, 28 Sep. 1976, page 2

Electorate of Eyre

The proposed new Electorate of Eyre would cover more than 75% of SA. The technical description of the boundary is printed.

98, 35, 28 Sep. 1976, page 3

North-Eastern Combined Schools Sports were held on Spalding Oval on 17 September.

[Results next issue.]

Burra Junior Footballers had a wind-up barbecue at Burra Oval on Sunday. The Netball and Senior Colts teams also attended. Awards:

Best & Fairest Philip Clode

Most Improved Stefan Thomas

Most Consistent Peter Thomas

Most Constructive Philip Jones

Best Team Man Patrick O’ Connor

Best Position Andrew Allen

Best Utility Player Garry Southall

Best at Training Craig May

98, 35, 28 Sep. 1976, page 4

Apex Club Annual Report by President David Thamm.

The number of members has been fairly stable, with six losses and four new members and three Prospexians waiting for induction. The first stage of upgrading the Burra North Playground has been completed. We have run the local pictures and it is pleasing that we are now also being consulted on the choice of films and this has probably reduced some of the behaviour problems encountered in the past. We sent one boy to a YMCA camp in September.

The incoming President is Dick Cuttle.

Burra Rural Youth has been busy renovating the Burra Show Hall.

98, 35, 28 Sep. 1976, page 7

Charles Bronson & James Coburn in The Streetfighter

Connie Stevens & Shelley Winters in The Sex Symbol

Spalding Township celebrates its centenary this weekend.

Birth. To Bev & ‘Mac’ Goode at Snowtown on Tuesday, a son, Colin Andrew. A grandson for Maurice & Elvyn Collins of Booborowie.

Birth. To Marlene & Gordon Wooton of Burra North, at Burra Hospital on Tuesday, a son, Clay Justin.

Marriage. Prince Alfred College Chapel next Saturday

Lester Gare, elder son of Mrs L.G. Gare of Burra & the late Keith Gare, will marry

Jacqualin Whicker, daughter of Mrs D.G. Whicker of West Richmond and the late Mr Whicker.

Simon O’Connor has won the state section for children aged 9 and under in the Australia Post National Stamp Week Poster Competition. He is the younger son of Mr & Mrs Gerry O’Connor and is in Year 4 at BCS.

Junior Netball. Top goal throwers for the season:

C1 Ann-Marie Stockman, 360

C2 Lorraine Meintjes, 185

‘Blue Hills’ the long-running ABC radio serial finishes on Thursday with a half-hour episode.

98, 36, 5 Oct. 1976, page 1

Salad Days was a delightful production by the Burra Community Entertainment Group last Thursday and Friday nights, as their first effort. Edith Carpenter excelled herself in producing the show. The production had excellent lighting effects, costumes, scenery and props and Kath Millard and Dick Cuttle as the principal singers were extremely well chosen. The whole cast performed very well. Special mention is made of Liz Fahey, Ian Knowles, Bev. Farrelly, Ruth & Wally Spehr, Patricia McGuire, Stephen Angel, Cathy Button and Coral Billington.

Burra Tennis Association will start matches on 16 October. A new A2 Grade has been created from the bottom of last year’s ‘A’ Grade and the top of last year’s ‘B’ Grade, to even up competition and reduce the number of teams in ‘A’ Grade. There will now be 8 in ‘A’ Grade, 6 in ‘A2’ Grade, 6 in ‘B’ Grade and 8 in Junior Grade. There will be a total of 224 players each Saturday. Regrettably Leighton Tennis Club has gone into recess.

Burra Methodist Circuit. Nominations are called for the election of Elders for the Uniting Church in Australia, Burra Parish. Details of the criteria and of the process involved are printed.

BCS. The Grounds and Surrounds Sub-Committee has recommended the planting of a large number of trees and $200 has so far been allocated for their purchase. The first stage will see 116 trees planted along the northern boundary. Further plantings will then be made along Smelts Road, the Agricultural Area overlooking the Creek and then a grove to the west of the new secondary building.

Saturday 3-5 p.m., Sunday 1.30-5 p.m. and Monday 10 a.m. to noon.

Cricket. Burra Footballers 124 v. South Booborowie 0 for 35.

98, 36, 5 Oct. 1976, page 7

Advt. Burra Pictures will not be shown 10 October due to the Rural Youth Cabaret.

Weather. There were heavy falls of rain through the week and some minor flooding of houses and shops in Burra. Some of this was due to overflowing tanks. Thunder rumbled for more than 24 hours. Some gaugings:

Woolgangi 210 points Koomooloo 218 points Quondong 184 points

The Gums 190 points Kia-Ora 190 points Pine Valley 160 points

Balah 190 points Braemar 164 points Hallett 185 points or 47 mm

Burra 263 points or 67 mm Farrell Flat 161 points or 41 mm Clare 188 points or 48 mm

Birth. To Mary & Don Griffen of Mt Bryan, at Burra Hospital 29 September, a son, Benjamin Joel.

Obituary. The father of Mrs Spafford, the wife of the manager of the National Bank branch in Burra, died at Burra Hospital on Saturday after falling ill while on a visit from WA with his wife.

Coral Winders of Black Springs has been transferred to the ANZ in Burra from the Woodville North branch.

Kooringa Masonic Lodge will install Sgt Bruce Haynes as Worshipful Master this evening. The ceremony will be followed by a Ball at the Burra Town Hall.

Peterborough celebrates its centenary next weekend and a special steam train will travel through Burra at about 11 a.m. en route to the celebration.

Netball. Trophies for Burra players were awarded at Friday night’s dinner:

A1 Bev Scanlan (nee Kleinig)

Top goal-thrower Elaine Eberhard, 240

A2 Di Day

Top goal-thrower Sandra Spackman, 124

B1 Lyn Taylor

Top goal-thrower Sharyon Brereton, 231

B2 Bronwyn Ford

Top goal-thrower Jane Fennell, 188

Dennis Clifton is the new policeman in town, having arrived with his wife following the Saxby family’s removal to the city.

98, 37, 13 Oct. 1976, page 1

BCS. The October mini courses have got away to an enthusiastic start. Examples are: Blacksmithing, Rug Making & Leather Embossing, Estate Planning & Taxation, Insurance and Land Transactions, Evaluations for the man on the land.

A china painting group has been established.

Three canoes are available for use through the school, which bought one, one was provided by the Youth Club and one belongs to Mr Bednall.

Basketball. The season of the Burra Basketball Association starts on 13 October. Sixteen teams will play on Burra courts on Wednesday nights with games at 7 p.m., 7.50 p.m., 8.40 p.m. and 9.30 p.m.

Burra Burra DC

Federal Grants to local Councils have been announced. The Burra Burra DC gets $45,000. This is the third year of Federal Funding and the first in which all Councils in the state will get a share of the grants.

98, 37, 13 Oct. 1976, pages 1 & 3

The Burra Show [Incorrectly cited as the 99th.]

The day dawned frosty and remained fine, but became intensely cold as the day progressed. A fair crowd attended. The gate amounted to $615. There were record entries for horse in action. Michelle Burton was Miss Show Girl and A. Talent won the open shearing contest. Show President Mr Ron Shipard welcomed guests and thanked exhibitors and all those who worked so hard to put the show on.

Mr Ray McCallum, President of the Northern Show Societies, from Orroroo opened the show.

Junior Miss Show Girl was Mary-Anne Shipard.

Sub-Junior Miss Show Girl was Carolyn Armstrong of Burra.

In the open shearing contest L. Hughes and A. Talent both scored 187 points and there was a shear-off to decide the winner, with Arthur Talent coming out on top. The judges were Tony Ryan and Graham Heine.

Greg Germein won the Novice Section.

Art entries were of a very high standard.

Budgerigars were of a good standard with some excellent young birds.

Pigeons were a big improvement on last year’s display.

Poultry were well staged, but the number of shows held on the same day made it hard to get a large show of top birds.

Children’s pets were well displayed and covered a wide range from a goat to a white mouse.

Cattle had some good heifers, but generally carried less condition than in 1975.

Cooking was of a good standard with notably good cheesecake, boiled fruit cake and chocolate cake entries.

Junior entries were impressive.

Flowers were down a bit due to the season, but there was a fair display and some very good blooms.

Floral Art was good, with outstanding entries under ‘Á Song Title’. The children’s section was a pleasure to judge.

Grain entries were down, but of good quality.

Fodder entries reflected a dry season.

Goat entries showed good potential in the young stock.

Needlework entries were down, but work on the whole was good, especially in the Crochet Cloth.

Produce entries were few. The winning sauce entry was excellent.

Vegetable entries were down due to the severely cold winter. Quality was, however, a little better.

Poll sheep were of excellent quality and the Champion Ram was excellent.

The Champion Ewe was an excellent breeder with a thick covering of strong wool.

In the medium wool section the entries were of a high standard and numbers were high.

The Champion Strong Wool Ram carried a good bulky 58’s fleece.

The ewe section was particularly strong in both numbers and quality.

Wool:

The fleeces shown were particularly well grown and many fleeces weighed in excess of 10 kg.

98, 37, 13 Oct. 1976, page 2

Adelaide Wool Sales. Prices were about 5% up across the range, with some finer lines up to 10% dearer.

[Local district prices are printed.]

98, 37, 13 Oct. 1976, page 4

Hallett Red Cross Flower & Indoor Show was held on Friday 1 October at the Hallett Hall. Though smaller than the 1975 record show, it was a great social and financial success and netted in excess of $250.

[The prize list is printed.]

98, 37, 13 Oct. 1976, page 5

Saddleworth Show is reported in c. 3 columns.

Leighton Basketball Club has been disbanded. It had been formed on 4 May 1946 and with the Spalding, Hallett and Booborowie Clubs formed the North-Eastern Basketball Association. They played on a ground at the Leighton Recreation Ground, which had been already graded for a tennis court. The Leighton team was premier in its first year. Nelda Bruce (Kleinig) was Club President 1946-55. Elvyn Collins took over for 1956-58 and 1966-68.

In 1956 permission was given to play on asphalt courts at the Recreation Ground. Jacie Bruce was President 1959-61 when Mr F. Goodridge became President. Due to lack of players the club went into recess until 1963, when it entered a team in ‘C’ Grade in the North-Eastern Association. In 1965 & 1966 ‘B’ and ‘C’ Grade teams were entered. In 1967 ‘A’, ‘B’ and ‘C’ Grade teams played. In 1968 ‘B’, ‘C’ and ‘D’ Grade teams were fielded and three teams continued to play until 1973.

Amalgamation with Booborowie and Hallett was discussed in 1972, but it was decided to continue.

Circumstances prevented it entering teams in the North-Eastern Association in 1974 and it then joined the Stanley Netball Association and in 1974 entered two teams. The senior of these was premier in ‘C’ Grade in 1975. The Stanley and Mid-North Associations amalgamated in 1976 and distances became too great. The players joined the United Club. [Details of the Club occupy about 3⁄4 column.]

98, 37, 13 Oct. 1976, page 6

Mr & Mrs Don Kempster will be given a [farewell] social evening at the Burra Golf Clubhouse on Saturday 16 October.

Advt. Roche Bros. Social – Miners’ Spree in Burra Town Hall on Saturday 27 November.

Burra Bowling Club held its opening day on Sunday 10 October. President D. Broderick welcomed guests. Zita Brown put down the 1st jack and Neil Hurst, Club Champion put down the 1st bowl.

Advt. Burra Pictures, 16 October

Alice in Wonderland

Sleeping Beauty

Hang Gliding Championships were conducted near Burra over the long weekend.

The Special Steam Train hauled by 520 class locomotive Sir Malcolm Barclay-Harvey was over an hour late in reaching Burra due to mechanical problems and was delayed at least as long in Burra before setting off for Peterborough.

Obituary. Miss Vera Wilkinson died last week. She was a daughter of the late Mr & Mrs T.W. Wilkinson.

[Vera Euphrasia Wilkinson born 1 April 1885, Kooringa.]

Trevor Gordon, the Hallett District Clerk, will move to Strathalbyn DC to take up the District Clerk position there in January.

The Snooker Finals at the RSL Hall on Thursday will see Alf Puckridge, Drew Anderson, John Nankivell and Laurie Higgins as the contenders.

Phyl & Walter Klem of Farrell Flat have sold their property and moved to Jamestown.

Burra National Trust has a part in a display about early SA Towns in the John Martin’s Elizabeth Store in conjunction with the firm’s 110th birthday.

The M&BHA will hold a Miniature Debutante Ball on Friday night in the Burra Town Hall. Debs will be presented to TV personality Pam Tamblyn and Sammy Seagull. Debs and partners will be:

98, 37 (2), 19 Oct. 1976, page 1

Burra Burra DC

The Hon. T.M. Casey Minister of Tourism, Recreation and Sport advises that $5,000 has been granted as a dollar for dollar subsidy on the beautification of the Burra Creek area of the town. It is anticipated that stone barrier walls will be erected on the bank across from the Town Hall. Banks generally will be cleaned up and trees and ground cover planted.

There is some problem with parents parking cars while picking up students from school, so that access to the caravan park is blocked.

BCS. Site preparation for the new building is continuing.

Mt Bryan Netball Club has disbanded following a decision at a meeting on 4 October. Funds will be divided between the Hall Committee and the Tennis Club.

Burra Kindergarten will conduct a Barn Dance at Dutton’s Trough on Friday 29 October.

98, 37 (2), 19 Oct. 1976, page 3

Burra Golf Associates held an AGM on 4 October and elected: President, Mrs N. Finch; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames J. Gordon & D. Field; Secretary, Mrs M. Nicholls; Treasurer, Mrs R. Drew; Captain, Mrs J. Oates & Vice-Captain, Mrs L. Higgins.

The year 1976 had a record number of 42 associates. The new clubhouse has been greatly appreciated and its big windows are a joy to sit by and the hot water system makes a big difference to cold and dirty hands.

[The secretary’s report of c. 1 column is printed.]

Burra Pistol Club. Andrew Pearce again won the Karmia Trophy for marksman. Most improved were N. Barker and D. Jones. Best scorers were A. Pearce, M. Stolte, L. Whitrod and P. Cornwall.

Advt. Burra Pictures, 23 October

West World

Speedway

Birth. To Mr & Mrs Peter Brown of Aubiddy Station, WA, at Calvary Hospital 14 October, a son, Simon Leigh. A grandson for Mr & Mrs Bill Brown of ‘The Grove’ Burra.

Lindsay Walter has come from Bennet & Fisher Ltd at Clare to Oates Ltd at Burra. (Oates is now a fully owned subsidiary of Bennet & Fisher.)

Marriage. Clare United Church Saturday 23 October

Barbara Gent, only daughter of Mr & Mrs Ron Gent of Leighton will marry Wesley Hooper of Clare.

Marilyn, Mrs Trevor Gent has taken over from Lyn Kempster as Relief Assistant Postal Officer at the Burra Post Office.

The Kempster Family leaves soon for Orroroo, where they will run a hotel.

Obituary. Frank Holmes Sellars, who lived at Ironmine for many years before moving to Adelaide, has died there aged 76. [Birth registered as Frank Holmes Washington Sellers 9 April 1900 Iron Mine.]

Burra’s Lutheran Congregation held a picnic at the Reed property ‘Kookaburra’ last Sunday.

The Burra Anglican Parish will hold a picnic at Black Point following a service at St James Church, Ardrossan, on Sunday.

Burra Scouts will hold a dance in the Town Hall on Friday night to raise funds.

M&BHA hopes to nett about $280 from their Miniature Deb. Ball.

Burra Jubilee Benevolent Society has changed its name to the Burra Community Aid Society. Its President is David Bednall.

RSL Snooker Tournament was won by local School teacher Alf Puckridge from Johnny Nankivell.

98, 38, 26 Oct. 1976, page 1

BCS. Contracts have been let for the new school building. Adelaide contractor L.A.L. Hellebaut has the contract for bricklaying – worth more than $190,000, with some 250,000 bricks to be laid. The successful tenderer for structural steel for the site was Manuele Engineers Pty Ltd of Adelaide – worth $130,000. Local labour will be employed where possible. Site preparations costing about $80,000 by the Burra Burra DC are under way. The project is scheduled for completion for the start of the 1978 school year at a total cost of c. $3 million.

A voluntary Church Seminar Day will be held for Years 7-11 on 27 October.

Progress on the new building is said to be on schedule despite the wet weather. The large secondary teaching complex is due for completion by 19 June 1977 when staff and students are due to transfer from the old building to the new areas so that work can then begin on transforming the interior of the old building. The District Council is now working on levelling the area near Paxton Terrace so it can be seeded early next year to be ready for use as a playing area late in 1977.

Notice. Course to be available during Community School Week 8-12 November are listed.

Census Returns comparing 1971 & 1976 for Burra Burra DC

Mary Wilton, daughter of Mr & Mrs J. Wilton of Clapham.

Spalding-Burra Catholic Parish is having a Mission this week, conducted by Passionist Fathers Austin Kenny from Glen Osmond and Ambrose Glynn from Geelong, Victoria. On Sunday there will be a Folk Mass at Booborowie and then a picnic and sports.

98, 39, 2 Nov. 1976, page 1

Adelaide Wool Sales. Prices were slightly higher; generally up about 2%. [Local district prices are printed.]

Freedom From Hunger Appeal had trouble getting volunteers this year, but nevertheless did well:

Burra $306.04

Spalding $151.84

Mt Bryan $104.10

Hallett $78.48

Burra Swimming Pool will remain closed until more parents volunteer to help with supervision and the canteen roster. Poor attendance at a meeting last Wednesday led to this decision. Another meeting is scheduled for 5 November.

A Film Night at BCS on Monday 8 November will feature the 1924 Buster Keaton classic The Navigator and a modern film.

Burra Golf Club Inc. AGM 22 October elected: President, A.M. Gebhardt; Vice-Presidents, A. Day & D. Villis; Captain, Stan Longford; Vice-Captain, R. Hillman; Secretary, H.C. Burnett & Treasurer, J. Duance.

The retiring President Allen Baulderstone reported on a successful season. Renewed interest saw an increase in membership for both men and associates. Most Saturdays saw over 40 players hitting off. Stan Longford won the Club Championship and Kies van der Does won the ‘B’ Grade, with Don Lloyd winning in the ‘C’ Grade and Roger Buckley in the ‘D’ Grade. The open day was successfully held on 15 August when Dean Harris won the Open Championship and equalled the course record. Financially the club has almost overcome the trials of building the clubhouse and is almost back to the credit balance of 1975. Two payments have been made off the clubhouse loan and $1,000 spent on a tractor and equipment. The annual cabaret on 17 September was a financial success and should nett in excess of $300. A cheque from the Burra Sports Syndicate has not yet been used and is in a fixed deposit. The associates have again been a great support and the catering for open day was notable. The tree planting program under Ern Zanker has continued.

[A list of thanks to individuals for their work follows.]

98, 39, 2 Nov. 1976, page 5

It was resolved to accept applications made by pensioners for payment of rates by instalments, but to reject all other applications.

98, 39, 2 Nov. 1976, page 7

Burra Mine

The Chairman of the Burra Burra DC sent telegrams yesterday to the Premier Mr Dunstan, the Leader of the Opposition Dr Tonkin and the Minister of Mines Mr Hudson. They expressed the hope that some action could be taken to save 62 jobs directly involved at the Burra Mine following the concern of people in the town and district towards Samin Ltd being in receivership. He believed the mine was viable even at the present depressed copper prices and that future operations were straight forward and efficient.

Birth. To Lynette & Glenn Hammat of Spalding at Jamestown Hospital recently, a son, Timothy Scott.

Kooringa Methodist Guild Fete will be held in the RSL Hall on Friday.

98, 40, 9 Nov. 1976, page 1

Burra Mine

The Burra community became worried when the Poseidon receiver and manager Mr Buckley and Professor Rudd visited the town and inspected the Mine. The business people and the town generally grew concerned and telegrams were sent to the Premier, the Minister of Mines and the Leader of the Opposition. Professor Rudd says the Mine is presently operating with a small profit and it is not intended to close it. But we all know that if the price of copper drops much more it could cause the Mine’s closure. At present the Mine employs 62 people and when in full production, 100. Samin owns several houses in the town. In Parliament the Hon. Hugh Hudson said that discussions with Samin had been going on for some time and would be continued with the receiver. Poseidon, Samin’s parent company is in difficulty and if Samin needed cash to sustain a period of insufficiency there would be a problem. The difficulty is greater for Burra because it produces a specialty product for which appropriate markets had to be developed. The Government certainly wishes to keep the Burra Mine going if it can reasonably be achieved, but it cannot support an operation if it is likely to continue to be unprofitable. There are hopes the copper price will recover by the end of June and hopefully the Government will be able to reach an agreement with the receiver to ensure the Mine can continue so that the market can be tested. We cannot, however, say with any certainty that this will be achieved.

Bankcard began to operate in Burra yesterday.

The Mid North Schools Welfare Clubs Association has changed its name to the Mid North Schools Parent Clubs Association.

98, 40, 9 Nov. 1976, page 2

98, 40, 9 Nov. 1976, page 7

Burra Apex Club will screen Picnic at Hanging Rock on Saturday 4 December with proceeds to aid the RFDS.

Allen & Myrtle Phillips (nee Pearce) celebrate their 50th wedding anniversary, solemnised at Booborowie Hall 11 November 1926.

Burra Swimming Pool opened yesterday following a more successful meeting of parents and others.

Obituary. Mr Cliff Brooks, formerly of Booborowie, died recently at Burra Hospital aged 75.

[Clifford Samuel Brooks born 11 April 1901 Nuriootpa.]

98, 41, 16 Nov. 1976, page 1

Burra Burra DC

Burra Town Hall upgrading continues. Some new seats will be bought. The stage curtains will be altered to provide wings at the sides. New welded steel handrails have been placed at the side of the external steps at the entrance and these have been painted white.

Work on the beautification of Burra Creek is proceeding, with the new car park opposite the Town Hall being levelled and a low stone barrier wall will now be erected. Seats, tables and barbecues will be placed on the opposite sides of the creek and extensive tree planting will be undertaken. The Tourist Promotion Committee is co-operating with the Apex Club and the Community School in this. The National Trust is planning to embark on tree planting as well.

About 20 properties on which rates have not been paid for at least three years will soon be sold by the Council.

Peacock’s Chimney has been floodlit and looks very impressive. Young vandals on bikes were seen throwing stones at the lights on the second night of illumination.

Late night shopping will operate in Burra on Christmas Eve, Friday 24 December. The usual merry-go-round will operate in the afternoon and evening.

Matriculation Exams are in progress in the Catholic Parish Hall this week and next.

A Burra Caravan Park Occupant writes objecting to the noise throughout the night created by a group of youths 12-14 years old who appear to be at a shed near the lawns beyond the Caravan Park. District Clerk T.G. Perry would appreciate any relevant information.

BCS. The Management Committee has been looking at the possibility of the BCS Library becoming a Community-School Library. The present library is set up to serve the needs of the school students. If it became a Community-School Library it would be funded in three ways; through the Education Department, through the State Government vis the State Library and through the local District Council. As well as books there would be periodicals and cassettes available. Access would be given to all State Library resources. It would normally have 14 books per head of population and the annual replacement would be about one seventh of the stock. Institute libraries in the district would have to be dissolved and in return the Community-School Library would set up branches, which would provide books and periodicals and change the stock regularly by means of the school bus service. Books of historical or local significance would be retained by the local branch. The whole arrangement was discussed by representatives of those involved at a meeting on 11 November.

Each Council and Institute must now make its own decision. So far the Burra District Council has come out enthusiastically in favour and the Booborowie Institute has also agreed. Other decisions are eagerly awaited.

98, 41, 16 Nov. 1976, page 4

BCS Year 7 students recently went for a camp at Christie Downs from Monday to Friday.

Students reported on the experience in an article of a little more than 2 columns.

Monday

The group travelled by train to Adelaide and then by train to Christie Downs before walking for 20 minutes to the camp site. The rest of the day was spent in the local area.

Tuesday was spent at the beach.

Wednesday

They went by train to Adelaide, visiting the Public Library, the War Memorial and Parliament House. After lunch in the Botanic Gardens they returned to Parliament House to witness Question Time and then went to Elder Park.

Thursday

There was a scavenger hunt and sports at the camp.

Friday

There were games and packing up as well as tidying the camp in the morning. In the afternoon they went to a skating rink before catching the evening train to Burra.

Steps are to be taken to sell the Market Square Café for non-payment of rates.

Other properties in the same position are to be placed in the hands of the solicitor within two months.

It was resolved to approach the Department of Lands with a view to closing the Towns of Douglas and Tracy.

Council accepted plans for the car park opposite the Town Hall, subject to cost estimates being approved.

The Lutheran Church sought assistance with flood control.

98, 42, 24 Nov. 1976, pages 1 & 5

Burra CWA has guests from nearly 30 branches for its 50th birthday celebrations on Friday at a special luncheon at the Burra Town Hall. The guests included the State President, Mrs Cooper; Group President, Mrs Lambert and Divisional President, Mrs Klem. Burra Branch President Mrs David Baker was a gracious hostess and a small brochure summarising the history of the branch was compiled by Mrs Baker. International Day was also celebrated and this year the study was Kenya. Floral decorations were by Mrs Les White and Miss Gwen Humphrys. The only foundation member able to attend was 93-year-old Mrs Marks. After a short business meeting Mrs Cooper gave an address. [This is reported at some length.]

Mrs Baulderstone made the birthday cake, which was iced and decorated by Mrs Merv. Cox.
