Obituary. Mrs Winifred B. Warnes of Glenelg and formerly of this district died on Friday aged 79. She is survived by five sons, including Mr Les Warnes of Woolgangi Station.

[Born Winifred Brockis Cater 25 April 1897 Redfern, SA.]

Mr Perth Collins passes on a little information compiled by the late Miss Alice Collins, concerning the late Henry Collins of ‘Lucerndale’ Mt Bryan.

Henry Collins came to SA with his parents in 1839 from Devonshire. He was then aged 6. His first job was to mind a mob of sheep. When the family came to Burra they had to construct dug outs in the bank of the Burra Creek. At an early age he went to work in the Burra Mine and when his father went to the Victorian gold rush he was the sole support of his mother. Later they were able to buy a couple of bullock teams and began carting between Burra and Port Adelaide. Henry was so small that he had to use a stool to enable him to place the yokes on the bullocks.

The Burra Methodist Women’s Fellowship voted at its recent annual meeting to go into recess.

The Melbourne Cup Luncheon was the best attended ever, with 250 ladies present. The profit was about $1,000, which will be divided between Red Cross, RFDS and the Town Hall Piano Fund. John Ovenden was the guest speaker.

98, 42, 24 Nov. 1976, page 8

Burra Rural Youth members enjoyed a weekend at Cowell on 5 November as part of an exchange program.

Kooringa Methodist Ladies’ Guild held its annual fete recently. [Stall holders and their takings are listed.]

The sum raised was $508.

96, 43, 30 Nov. 1976, page 1

The Season. Although the season has improved in the last few weeks the state’s wheat crop is likely to be less than half the ten year average, but barley will be almost 80% of the ten-year average. Up to 50% of sheep and cattle have been moved from the lower rainfall areas to the cereal belt, either for agistment or slaughter.

Notice. Burra Library will hold a special subscribers’ meeting on 13 December to make a final decision on transfer to a Community-School Library or to remain as the Burra Library.

Ben Kotz, Secretary.

Richard Pickburn of Morialta High School writes thanking BCS for its hospitality when 28 Morialta students from Year 10 visited recently and were billeted locally. The students were overwhelmed by the kindness and effort made and the school staff also put themselves out to make the visit a success.

BCS

Enrolment day for 1977 is Friday 3 December 1976. The school has asked for a dental clinic to be established in Burra. This has become more urgent since the local dentist, Dr C. Leslie Phillips, has decided to limit his practice to denture work and emergencies. A Vacation Recreation Centre will operate at the school from 17 to 21 January.

Burra Pistol Club. Winner of the Kamere Marksman’s Trophy was Andrew Pearce. Most improved lady was V. Oakley and most improved gentleman was G. Williams.

Best scorers were: A. Pearce, L. Whitrod, M. Stolte and W. Barker.

Obituary. Mr Percival Gordon Mosey died at the Eudunda Hospital on 18 November aged 80. He was a WWI soldier and one of 13 children of whom only Mr Todd Mosey now survives. He lived on a farm at Bradey Creek before retiring into Robertstown. He is survived by a wife and five children: Eric, Heather, Don, Morris and Peter. There are 13 grandchildren.

[Although the SA Births CD has him registered as Percevil Gorden Mosey born 16 February 1896 at Burra, he was married as Percival Gordon Mosey.]

The Anglican Bishop Rosier will confirm 15 children and three adults at a service at St Mary’s next Sunday. The choir of St Jude’s Brighton will lead the singing. They are staying at the Redruth Camping and Conference Centre for the weekend.

Redruth Methodist Ladies’ Guild held a Gala on Saturday and raised $600.

The Hallett Catholic Dance recently raised c. $250 for the work of the Motor Mission Sisters.

96, 46, 7 Dec. 1976, page 1 [Note the irregular numbering of this issue.]

Ratepayers’ Meeting

About 30 people attended the meeting called by the Burra Burra DC Chairman Cr R.B. Jennison last Wednesday night. The Council had felt the impact of a slowing inflation rate. While Government grants for road works are decreasing, the no-strings Federal Grants increased to $45,000 from $20,000 in 1975-76. Council has budgeted for a planned program of district road works. Nominated streets in Burra will be reformed and sealed. Council assisted with the site works at the new Burra Community School and the go-ahead for this $3 million project will stabilise Burra as an important district centre. The improvements to the Burra Creek in the town in conjunction with the Tourist Promotion Committee, Apex and BCS and the National Trust is another significant project. We hope drainage problems in the business area will be addressed with funding for the Effluent Drainage Scheme in 1977-78. Plans are under way to give the district a superior library service. Council will join in the Pest Plants Control and Vertebrate Pests Act projects.

[The report then lists a number of subjects about which questions were asked, but does not report any answer given.]

The Local Dentist [C. Leslie Phillips], who has been practising in Burra for 45 years, has decided to discontinue conservative dentistry and has for some time been referring patients to other dentists for fillings. He is continuing to make and repair dentures and to undertake dental extractions.

Burra Methodist Church. Next Sunday at 7.30 p.m. Mrs E. Wilks will present a stained glass memorial window and a bronze plaque commemorating the Ironmine Church (now closed). After the dedication of these memorials the choir will sing the Christmas Cantata Born a King by John Peterson. It will be an ecumenical occasion with Rev. Fr K. Matthews and Rev. Fr B. May assisting in the service.

BCS. The first speech day for BCS will be held in the Memorial Gardens at 11 a.m. next Friday. Guest speaker is Mr Kevin Duggan, SA Crown Prosecutor. The Primary students held their sports day on Friday 26 November. Champions were:

Junior Girl A. Stockman

Junior Boy P. Clarke & A. Allen (tie)

Senior Girl L. Mason

Senior Boy K. Lynch

The RSL Annual Dinner was held on Saturday night. Fifty people attended the meal provided by the Ladies Auxiliary. The toast to ‘Fallen Comrades’ was made by Rev. Barry May. [His speech is printed.]

Frank Pollard of Jamestown Sub-branch was made a life-member. He has been an office-bearer and committeeman for over 20 years and has been coming to the Burra Annual Dinners for 30 years.

Four WWI veterans attended: Albert Bruce, Wilf Nankivell, Charlie Bennett and Jack Williams.

96, 47, 14 Dec. 1976, page 1

The First BCS Speech Day was well attended by parents. Principal Mr McCabe felt that the major challenge for the school was for a changed assessment by the students of their own ability. At present it is too modest and they are capable of a standard equal to any in the state.

Staff changes:

Mr Brian Baker is transferring to The Parks

Miss Demidowicz is returning to Adelaide

Miss Haska will travel overseas

Miss Hogan has a year’s study leave

Miss Harrison is transferring to Clare

Miss Lydeamore is moving to Morphett Vale East

Miss Reed, Mrs Hill and Mr Dower are leaving the ancillary staff.

Incoming staff:

Mr A. Kraft (Deputy Secondary)

Miss C. Bourke (Home Economics)

Mrs Bednall (Physical Education)

Mr Geoff Hood (Geography Senior)

Mr Steven Moloney (Regional Reading Consultant)

Miss Elizabeth Lynch (English/History)

Mrs Hardy (Year 1)

Miss P. Stecker (Art)

Mr Queissner has been appointed the new groundsman.

The Principal thanked Mr I. Allen & Mr R. Thamm especially for their help in the past year. Mr Thamm as chairman of the High School Council reported on the busy year in the lead-up to the building project.

Mr K. Duggan, Crown Prosecutor was the guest speaker.

[Photos of Mr R. Thamm, Chairman of the School Council; Mrs Edith Carpenter, Co-ordinator at the School and Mr I. Allen, Management Committee Chairman.]

96, 47, 14 Dec. 1976, page 3

BCS

Ian Allen reports as Chairman of the Management Committee.

The Committee had a role in:

Controlling community use of school facilities

Liaising with sporting and service clubs on the use of school and community facilities

Informing the public on the resources of the school

Assisting in organising Community Week

Promoting the Community Education concept

Implementing programs to meet identified needs

As a consequence the following had been done:

Community service groups and clubs had been identified

Community use of the School Library has been arranged and the move to a Community Library awaits further replies from affected parties.

A toy library will be ready for the start of 1977.

In the future the group will repaint the rotunda in Market Square.

Adelaide Wool Sales. Prices were generally up 21⁄2%. [Local district prices are printed.]

The Annual Learn to Swim Campaign will be held 10-21 January with instruction from beginners through to some Royal Life Saving Society Awards – at least as far as Bronze Medal.

96, 48, 21 Dec. 1976, page 2

1st Division Clare Red 66 defeated Burra Green 64

Spalding 82 defeated Burra Gold 66

2nd Division Saddleworth 91 defeated Burra 57

3rd Division [Results are garbled.]

96, 48, 21 Dec. 1976, pages 3-6 gutter

D.E. Woolley writes highly dissatisfied with the local council, but also dissatisfied that the voices most loudly expressing their unhappiness in the pubs around the town were conspicuous by their absence from the Ratepayers’ Meeting.

96, 48, 21 Dec. 1976, page 5

Burra Pistol Club. The President’s Trophy Shoot was held on 18 December. Nick Kinglsey was the winner with Marlene Broad as runner-up.

Burra Burra DC

Julie Brandt has been appointed junior assistant at the office.

100 new chairs will arrive at the Town Hall early in 1977.

A new fence will be placed around the playing area and the parking areas are being levelled [at the town oval].

The two cricket clubs and the football club will contribute towards the cost.

Kerbing work has been done in Queen Street.

Mr Vic. Elliott of Burra North will build a stone barrier at the car park opposite the Town Hall. The foundations have been laid and the wall will be built in January.

Council has accepted the Burra Rural Youth Club’s offer to repaint the Market Square Rotunda.

Burra Rural Youth have done a fine job in cleaning up around Redruth Gaol.

The plans for the Common Effluent Drainage Scheme have been completed and will be available for inspection on or after 4 January at the Council Office.

96, 48, 21 Dec. 1976, page 7

A Nativity Play was staged at St Mary’s on Sunday night last. [Participants are listed.]

Women’s Fellowship will sing carols at the hospital tomorrow night.

The Burra Pensioners’ League held their Christmas Party in the RSL Hall on 9 December.

Birth. To ‘Darky’ & Ann Matthews (nee Simpson) of Burra at Port Pirie Hospital on 16 December, a son, Jeremy Todd.

Marriage. At St Matthew’s Lutheran Church, Riverton 15 January

Julie McAllister (of Marianne’s Salon, Burra) will marry Ken Heinrich of Black Springs.

The Duance Family is leaving Burra this week to live at Tennant Creek.

The Gordon Family is moving from Hallett to Strathalbyn.

Hallett’s new District Clerk is Mr D.H. Gollan.

John & Cynthia Clark are leaving Burra in mid-January to live at Snowtown where John will still be with Elders.

Gail & Phil Newton are moving to the city on 12 January 1977, where Phil will be working in the wool department at Elders-GM.

Brian Carpenter, formerly of Burra and now with the RAAF at South Windsor, NSW, now has his wings. He belongs to No. 7 Squadron, which flies Hercules transports.

Characteristics of the paper in 1976

It was a rather disappointing paper for local coverage. Some events that are foreshadowed are not reported when they occurred. There are many general interest items, which, while relevant to local farming or grazing, were not local news.

The District Council reports are mostly useless and frequently indicate that a question was raised, but not what it was or what resulted. An example would be:

‘Mines Royalty – Dept. of Mines re royalties Burra Mines.’

As in 1975 AGM material is printed, but there is no evidence that the paper itself was doing much in the way of collecting material.

Page 1

News

Page 2

Largely advertising in some months with perhaps an article from the Department of Agriculture and Fisheries or a Bowls Club report.

Page 3

Large advertisements and sport.

Pages 4 & 5

Large advertisements, sports results and items from other centres like Saddleworth.

Page 6

Cash column, large advertisements, public notices and entertainment.

Page 7

Out and About column – a major source of local news, but in very brief snippets. Some general interest items.

Page 8

Large advertisements and the 50 & 24 years ago column. Occasionally a small sports result or small news item.

99, 1, 18 Jan. 1977, page 1

Advertisements

99, 1, 18 Jan. 1977, page 1

Local Government Voting

Recently the State Parliament has enacted the Local Government Act (Amendment Act) No. 73 – The Adult Franchise Bill, which affectively gives the vote at local government elections to all enrolled as an elector in the SA House of Assembly for the area.

Burra Burra DC

Up to six streets in Burra and Burra North will be sealed during March.

A $1,600 grant has been made to assist in repair of damage done to the Burra-Andrews Road in last October’s floods.

Council has agreed to relocate the old gun from the Mine Entrance to a point near their new complex at Burra North.

Vandalism at the swimming pool in the past month or so has caused great inconvenience and expense.

There is a move for parts of the Hundreds of Kingston and Ayers to secede from Burra and join the Hallett Council. Council is most concerned about this and has asked in a circular that ratepayers think carefully about this subject.

Burra Community School Library

Booborowie and Burra Libraries have decided to join in the move to create a new Community Library. A Hallett meeting on Monday last week voted against participating.

3rd Division Burra 74 defeated Saddleworth 59

Apex has again run the Burra Pictures.

Stage 1 of upgrading the Burra North Playground has been completed.

We have the signs for the Burra Town Tour and these will be erected in the coming year.

99, 1, 18 Jan. 1977, page 7

Locusts have been active, particularly on the lucerne flats at Booborowie and have attacked vines in the Clare-Hoyleton area.

Marriage. St Matthew’s Lutheran Church at Riverton last Saturday

Julie McAllister married Ken Heinrich.

Chris Pedersen from Elder’s Adelaide office has taken over the duties of Phil Newton, Chief Clerk, who has transferred to the Wool Department at Port Adelaide.

Elders-GM. Darrel Sims from Keith will take over from John Clark, who has been transferred to Snowtown.

BCS. Matriculation Exams

Six of the twelve candidates were successful: Dianne Bowden, Anne Carpenter, Heather Jones, Greg Thamm, Jeffery Kempster & Roy Blight. Bernadene Mackie received a Certificate of Registration, which allows her to attend the Institute of Technology.

Obituary. Jack Bown died recently at Coburg in Victoria aged 75. He was formerly of World’s End and a brother to Mrs Perc Thomas. [The only brother to Daphne Thomas nee Bown who would seem to fit this scenario was born General Milton Bown 22 January 1902 at Baldina. ‘General’ could, I suppose, be known as Jack.]

Nick van Buuren will start an apprenticeship on Monday at the British Tube Mills, Kilburn.

99, 2, 25 Jan. 1977, page 1

Locusts are hatching in large numbers following recent rains. Free insecticides are available through District Councils for landowners seeking to control locusts.

Burra Swimming Pool. The Learn to Swim Campaign saw 165 children taking part. Instructors were Mrs Jan Tiver, Mrs S. Williams, Miss J. Gebhardt and Miss H. Bell.

[Participants are listed along with the certificates gained.]

Rural Landowners have been asked to submit examples of interference to their private property tights by Government Departments and others. The enquiry was initiated by the Burra District Committee of the SA Stockowners’ Association and supported by the United Farmers and Graziers of SA. Examples are the Heysen Trail, acquisition by the Coastal Protection Board and interference in the sale and transfer of leases.

99, 2, 25 Jan. 1977, pages 1 & 3

Adelaide Wool Sales. Prices have been essentially unchanged. [Local district prices are printed.]

Council endorsed the transfer of Parklands at Booborowie for school purposes as outlined in a plan from the Department of Lands.

99, 2, 25 Jan. 1977, page 7

Notice. A public meeting will be held at the Royal Exchange Hotel at 8 p.m. on 1 February to form a Burra Sub-Branch of the Australian Labor Party. Contact Ben Kotz or Dick Cuttle for details.

Marriage. St Joseph’s, Burra 15 January

Carol Williams, daughter of Mr & Mrs Peter Williams of Burra married

Michael Hoskins, son of Mr & Mrs Tom Hoskins of Burra.

Marriage. At Farrell Flat on Saturday

Lorraine Blieschke, daughter of Mr & Mrs Rex Blieschke, and David Mills of Brinkworth.

Marriage. At Bute next Saturday

Patrick Brown, second son of Mr & Mrs Bill Brown of ‘The Grove’ Burra will marry Pauline Betties.

99, 3, 2 Feb. 1977, page 1

Bence’s Ltd Drapery & Clothing Store has changed hands after operating for 56 years. Proprietor-Manager Mr Len Bence has conducted the business since the early 1960s following the retirement of the late Arthur and Olive Bence. Arthur started life in Burra as an auctioneer, holding sales of furniture and sundry items. This followed a period of trading in the Solomon Islands around 1913. He saw active service in Egypt and France in 1916. He also travelled around the eastern country selling goods and was soon able to start Bence’s Ltd, which has flourished ever since.* The first sale at the Burra Auction Mart was advertised on 7 September 1927.* The editor commented that it should be a boon to many people. By 1924 the columns of the Record were advertising Bence’s Cash Drapery Store. The store has kept its doors open through hard times and times of plenty.

Now Mr Len Bence intends to devote more of his time to a life-long interest in painting. Many of his fine works already adorn the walls of homes in the area. Len and Muriel intend to stay on in Burra. The new proprietor is Mr Arnold Earnshaw who intends to carry on business with the same staff and will trade under the name of Bence’s. He previously had a similar business at Leigh Creek and has been associated with the trade for many years, including the management of several of C.J. Coles’ Variety Stores.

[*Some of these dates and statements are not quite true. The following references from the Burra Record may clarify the history of the enterprise:

XXXXIII, 35, 31 Aug. 1921, page 2: Advt. A.L. Bence (late AIF) Auctioneer & Commission Agent sets up the Burra Auction Mart opposite Eyes & Crowle’s in Commercial St. Furniture, Poultry and all classes of goods every Friday from 9 September.

XXXXIV, 38, 20 Sep. 1922, page 3: Advt. ‘Bon March’ Burra’s new shop will be opened by A.L. Bence in that portion of the Auction Mart previously occupied by Mr Woollacott on 21 September.

XXXXV, 4, 24 Jan. 1923, page 3: A.L. Bence will be moving into the premises formerly occupied by Miss Snell and will open the shop as a general cash drapery store with occasional auction sales.

XXXXVI, 1, 9 January 1924, page 2: Advertisement for Bence’s Burra Cash Drapery Stores & Agent for Alston’s Windmills

52, 5, 4 Feb. 1931, page 2: Advt. This issue carried the last advertisement for Bence’s. It announced the last week of their Summer Sale. [For the continuation of the business as Bence’s Ltd see 52, 11, 18 Mar. 1931 page 2.]

52, 11, 18 Mar. 1931, page 2: Advt. The formation of Bence’s Ltd is announced. It was financed by certain local people and managed by A.L. Bence. Bence’s Ltd has purchased the entire assets in the assigned estate of A.L. Bence at a huge discount. [There location is not stated, but probably the west side of Market Square. In any case by August the former SAFU store that had been the location of Bence’s Cash & Carry Department was vacant and available for a dance.]

52, 33, 19 Aug. 1931, page 3: Shell Co. Dance. The Shell Co. is to hold a dance in every town in Australia on 29 August and Mr T.H. Woollacott has been tireless in making arrangements. The Institute Hall is engaged and so the SAFU store, now vacant, (but late [Bence’s] Cash & Carry Store) will be used.]

99, 3, 2 Feb. 1977, page 2

99, 3, 2 Feb. 1977, page 3

99, 3, 2 Feb. 1977, page 7

Vandals attacked the public toilets at the Council office over the weekend.

Burra Branch of the ALP was re-formed last night at a meeting at the Royal Exchange Hotel. About 40 people attended and arrangements are made for the Premier to visit Burra on 15 February. Elected: President, Ben Kotz; Secretary, Geoff Hirschausen and Treasurer, Dick Cuttle.

Birth. To Lorraine & Terry Dixon of Farrell Flat at Clare Hospital on Friday, twin daughters, Paula Reenee and Helen Louise.

Birth. To Dianne & Phillip Byles at Ashford Community Hospital on 29 January, a daughter, Emma Jane.

Birth. To Andrew & Debbie Bolt [Boult] (nee Brereton) at Clare Hospital on Monday, a daughter, Samantha Maree.

Mr & Mrs Roger Crompton have left the Bon Accord Hotel and John & Kath McLean have taken over.

Obituary. Mrs Dafney Kakoschke of Burra North died on 25 January. She was the widow of the late Gus Kakoschke and mother of Sheila, Brudy, Isabel, Harold, Iris and Gordon.

[Born as Dafferty Wall 4 November 1897 at Hampton (Burra), but married as Dafney Wall.]

99, 4, 8 Feb. 1977, MISSING

99, 5, 15 Feb. 1977, MISSING

99, 6, 22 Feb. 1977, page 1

Premier Don Dunstan visited Burra last Tuesday. In a busy day he met the Burra Burra DC, the School Council, inspected Samin Ltd Mine, toured the town’s hotels and attended an evening barbecue.

At the school he said the SA Government was proud of the pioneering work being done at the Burra Community School. The co-operation and sense of community of the people of Burra ensure that in every sense it will be a Community School. He inspected the work on the new site.

He also had a meeting with the District Council where he was welcomed by Mr Jennison, who stressed the need for a sealed east-west road from Morgan to Spalding.

[A list of other subjects is provided, but with no indication of what was said on either side.]

Adelaide Wool Sales. Prices were 2-3% lower. [Local district prices are printed.]

99, 6, 22 Feb. 1977, page 7

Mr Stanley J. Humphrys, an artist, has bought the Hanson Church and Hall as a gallery and residence. His great uncle Mr Jesse Humphrys laid the foundation stone in 1904.

[This date is incorrect: Burra Record XV, 596, 21 Oct. 1903, page 3

Wesley Bicentenary Church Hanson, Wednesday 14 October.

Bad weather kept some away, but there was still a good crowd at 3 p.m. when Rev. H.J. Pope, President of Conference preached a sermon in the State Schoolroom. The memorial stone service was preached by Rev. W.F. James. Mr Jesse Humphrys laid the first stone. The President then laid the Wesley bicentenary stone.]

Mr & Mrs Murray Tiver are celebrating their Golden Wedding tomorrow, 23 February.

Daws Road Repatriation Hospital recently had three patients well known in Burra: Ray Alderson, Lance Fiebig and Bert Groth.

Obituary. Albert Hempel died at Semaphore over the weekend aged 81.

[Albert Stanley Hempel born 16 October 1896 World’s End Creek.]

Obituary. Deborah Pens aged 18 of Terowie was fatally injured in a car accident over the weekend. She was the daughter of Mr & Mrs Cliff Pens.

99, 7, 1 Mar. 1977, page 1

BCS

A meeting of parents was attended by more than 100 people. The election of the new School Council was held.

New members: Mr R. Shipard, Mr R. Thamm, Mr R. Stockman, Mr B. Stockman and Mr G. Kellock.

Continuing members: Mrs O. Holmes, Mrs J. Tiver, Mr D. Nettleton, Mr G. Searle.

Mr D. Lloyd represents the District Council and Mr R. Mason is the Parliamentary representative.

For the Parents & Friends’ Association elected were: President, Mrs C. Stockman; Vice-President, Mrs M. Lloyd; Secretary, Mrs H. Reed and Treasurer, Mrs G. O’Connor.

The Parents & Friends’ Assoc. in 1976 had nine meetings with an average attendance of 48. Mr R. Thamm reported that the Centenary Booklet is in the hands of Mr I. Auhl and is progressing well. The application for a dental clinic was refused as there are insufficient students for a full-time clinic, but discussion with Mr Don Dunstan indicated the possibility of a mobile clinic. Mr I. Allen has resigned as Chairman of the Primary School Council, a member of the Community School Council and as Chairman of the Community School Management Committee after years of dedicated work. A minute of appreciation was recorded.

A Council Levy of $500 per family, which in comparison to many schools was very modest, was added to the booklist this year. It will be used for administration costs, insurance fees, maintenance of Council property and for school amenities. [This must surely be a misprint?]

Mrs E. Carpenter, Community School Co-ordinator reported on programs and services offered.

In 1975 there were four DFE Classes and in 1976 there were 9. There were 7 voluntary classes in three centres; Burra, Hallett and Booborowie and 4 voluntary evening classes.

In October Community School Week saw 292 adult enrolments.

There was a Vacation Recreation Centre run each holiday.

Youth Club attendance varied from 40 to 80.

The Burra Community Entertainment Group put on Salad Days.

Support was given to Arts Council Productions and to the Art Gallery Travelling Exhibition.

A Junior National Trust Branch had been established.

Horse riding was organised in vacations.

A Dog Obedience Club was run.

There were ballet classes and a DFE class in Leather Embossing.

A Toy Library had been set up.

The Management Committee has taken on the establishment of the Community School Library as a major operation and has instituted a comprehensive list of all organisations and clubs within the district.

Burra Traders’ Association has decided to be more active in trying to bring trade back to Burra.

E.C. Allen MP, Member for Frome writes:

When Mr Jennison greeted the Premier recently he suggested that the Burra District had little or nothing to show by way of benefits from many years of Liberal Party Government. I cannot speak for the period of the Playford era, but this assertion is not true for the time of the Hall LCL Government 1968-70. The efforts of the Minister of Mines Hon. R.C. De Garis MLC in that Government had much to do with the re-opening of the Burra Mine by Samin Ltd. A program of sealing portions of main roads each year was commenced and the sealing of the Hanson-Clare Road was commenced – it has still not been completed after seven years of a Labor Government. The Hall Government also investigated a site for a new Burra High School and had plans drawn up. There was then a desire to move to another site and the Hall Government was defeated at that point, but it had much to do with the progress towards a new school for Burra. Construction work which was begun on the Morgan-Spalding Road by the Hall Government has been discontinued under Labor.

[Check to see if the ‘he’ in the first sentence applies to Jennison or Dunstan.]

99, 7, 1 Mar. 1977, page 2

Bowls

Associates Burra Green 73 defeated Hallett 45

Spalding 61 defeated Burra Gold 54

1st Division Clare Blue 74 defeated Burra Gold 73

Saddleworth 83 defeated Burra Green 63

2nd Division Clare Red 74 defeated Burra 53

3rd Division Mintaro 81 defeated Burra 55

99, 7, 1 Mar. 1977, page 3

Burra Pistol Club. On 16 February the best shots were: A. Pearce, L. Broad, P. Edwards & J .Ford.

Burra Tennis Club held a social evening in the Golf Clubhouse on Saturday night to present ten life-members with badges and certificates. Those recognised were the late Mr Frank Reed, Mr S. Scroop, Mrs F. Scroop, Mr Dick Reed, Mr B. Hirschausen, Mr I. Hirschausen, Mr R. Reed, Mrs A. Kelly and Mr & Mrs Don Lloyd. A large Honour Board was also presented.

Booborowie Methodist Ladies’ Guild held its AGM and elected: President, Mrs A. McGuire; Vice-Presidents, Mesdames M. White and Sutton; Secretary, Mrs Janet Price & Treasurer, Mrs G. Dewhirst. Mrs M. White retired as President after 13 years and Mrs M. Pearce retired as Treasurer after 16 years.

In future the group will be known as the Booborowie Uniting Church Fellowship.

99, 7, 1 Mar. 1977, page 4

Hallett Institute. President Mr B.H. Richards spoke at the AGM on 17 February of problems associated with a lack of interest and support and of financial woes. The closure of the National and ANZ Bank branches has reduced income for the Institute and the M&BHA has also closed its fortnightly clinic. Only essential maintenance could be carried out. The committee recommended joining the Burra Community Library, but a public meeting pressed for the retention of the Institute Library.

Burra Library AGM elected President, Mr R.J. Steele, Vice-Presidents, Mrs Ben Kotz and Mrs I. Hirschausen; Secretary, Mr Ben Kotz & Treasurer, Mrs E. Carpenter. Support this year was appreciated from the Burra Burra DC and from a raffle. A special meeting in December resolved to join the Burra Community Library, but the present arrangements will continue until the new library is established.

99, 7, 1 Mar. 1977, page 6

Michael & James Honan came to Burra from Fermanagh in Northern Ireland in the Glentanner in 1855 and the Utopia in 1858 respectively, with their wives Margaret and Elizabeth. There will be a reunion of their descendants in the Hallett Hall on Sunday 10 April.

Advt. Burra Pictures, 5 March

Sean Connery & Audrey Hepburn in Robin & Marian

George Segal in The Black Bird

99, 7, 1 Mar. 1977, page 7

Birth. To Vicki & David Brinkley at QVMH on 23 February, a son, Brad David.

Roy Humphrys will be 88 on 3 March.

Mrs Alice Seaford of the Burra Hospital was 94 last Wednesday.

Ted Kotz of Burra has found an old diary kept by Robert (Bob) Voumard, who spent most of his life as a drover. It covers the period 1901-06. He was born 22 June 1869 and came to Burra 27 October 1976. He died about 1950.

[Almost 1 column of details is printed.]

[Born 22 June 1869 in Switzerland and died 16 October 1950 in his Roach St cottage, Burra.]

99, 8, 8 Mar. 1977, page 1

The final issue as the Burra Record.

The Burra Record will amalgamate with the Peterborough and Orroroo based paper, the Review Times, which in future will be the Review Times Record and which will be printed in Port Pirie by the latest offset process by Independent Newspapers Ltd. This will be the final issue as the Burra Record.

The price of the enlarged paper will rise from 8c to 10c a copy. R.E. & A.J. Angel will continue with their job printing and act as agents for the new paper, accepting advertsing, copy and photographs for it. Representatives of the publishers will make periodical visits to Burra to assist advertisers with copy and layouts, in which photos and drawings will be more readily incorporated. Advertisers should benefit from the larger circulation and more modern printing facilities. The cost of production at Burra has been rising and it is increasingly hard to get replacement parts for the old machines. Another reason for amalgamation is the retirement of the linotype operator Eric angel, who came to the office in 1929 and has been setting the type here for 45 years. The office is not closing as a job printing service.

Booborowie will celebrate the centenary of its proclamation as a township on 29 March 1977. A committee has been formed to make arrangements for celebrations on 30 April and 1 May 1977. There will be a Back to School and a tea at the Hall followed by an Old Style Dance. Sunday will begin with a combined church service in the Hall and the unveiling of a commemorative plaque and there will be a barbecue lunch.

99, 8, 8 Mar. 1977, pages 1 & 4

BCS. The School Council’s tender for $25,156 for the development of the school grounds has been accepted. This includes developing the hockey field, oval and numerous other areas with trees and shrubs around the buildings. About eight acres has to be grasses.

Principal Mr McCabe has invited interested parents to join a school curriculum committee.

A successful swimming carnival was held on 25 February, when Riggs won the House Shield.

Individual winners were:

Under 11 Girls Elizabeth Robinson Under 11 Boys Mark Nettleton

Over 11 Girls Elizabeth Thamm Over 11 Boys Mark Lloyd

Under 13 Girls Dianne Robinson Under 13 Boys Patrick O’Connor

Under 14 Girls Karen Gent Under 14 Boys David Nourse

Under 15 Girls Lorraine Meintjes Under 15 Boys Andrew Moore

Over 15 Girls Cathy Tobinson Over 15 Boys Dennis Thamm

99, 8, 8 Mar. 1977, page 2

Bowls

1st Division Burra Gold 72 defeated Burra Green 68

2nd Division Booborowie 82 defeated Burra 45

3rd Division Bye

99, 8, 8 Mar. 1977, page 5

Burra Burra DC, 14 February

The tender of I. Hirschausen was accepted for sealing the car park opposite the Town Hall.

Taylor Street, Sancreed Street and The Crescent are to be sealed.

Ten park seats and six table assemblies are to be bought from Monier Pre-Stressed Concrete Pty Ltd for Burra Creek sites.

99, 8, 8 Mar. 1977, page 7

Birth. To Natalie & Dennis Short at Burra Hospital on Saturday, a daughter, Amanda Jane.

Birth. To Del & Peter Reed this morning, a daughter.

Cheryl Boswell nee Finch was SA’s team captain at the Australian Track and Field Championships, where she won a silver medal in the Senior 100 m hurdles.

Marriage. Last Saturday at Hallett

Ann Hughes, daughter of Mr & Mrs Colin Hughes of Hallett married Kevin Robinson of Jamestown.

Obituary. Mr Kym Tiver of ‘Banbury’ died recently.

Obituary. John Lobban died on Tuesday of last week aged 38 as a result of a tractor accident on his property at Hynam in the South East. His widow was Miss Margaret Kellock and he is also survived by two sons.

Obituary. Dorothy Jones, widow of the late Mick Jones died on 2 March.

[Born Dorothy Eileen Allen 13 January 1915 Aberdeen.]

‘King’ Broad was guest of honour at the Commercial Hotel on Friday night and he received a 35-year service medal on his retirement from the SAR.

Frank Slatter of Spalding says today is the 25th anniversary of his arrival in SA. He and a mate, Bert Poole, came to Adelaide on the Omar having been sent from Balliol College Boys Club in Oxford to learn Farming. They commenced at the Booborowie Experimental Farm. Frank put in six years there, ending up as head stockman. Bert Poole returned to England in the depression, but Frank thinks there are a number of the lads who worked on the Booborowie Farm still in Australia. He would be glad to hear from any.

The Cabaret at the Gaol on Saturday had a somewhat disappointing turnout. The place was well prepared with the Stimulus Band and a portable dance floor and the supper was superb. Profits have yet to be finalised.
